{"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "When the Atlanta Braves hired Alex Anthopoulos as general manager in November, action seemed likely to follow. The team needed help, having just endured a third consecutive season with at least 90 losses, and Anthopoulos had a knack for high-impact trades.\n\nBut there were no deals for stars like Josh Donaldson, David Price or Troy Tulowitzki, who carried Toronto to a deep playoff run in 2015 after Anthopoulos acquired them as the Blue Jays\u2019 general manager. In Atlanta, essentially, Anthopoulos simply waited for the season to start. He moved around some contracts in a deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers, for whom he had worked as an assistant the last two seasons, but that was about it.\n\n\u201cI talked to some people that had gone through the same thing and they all, to a man, said, \u2018In hindsight, I should have waited and given it a little bit of time,\u2019\u201d Anthopoulos said. \u201cSo the big thing was we weren\u2019t going to trade any prospects at all, unless it was just an absolute no-brainer. And the challenging part about it was we may miss a window to sell high on a player. But the flip side was that there may be a player that wasn\u2019t highly regarded that we may have traded who would have come back to bite us. So I do think it\u2019ll balance out.\u201d\n\nAs an example, Anthopoulos cited outfielder Ronald Acu\u00f1a Jr., who soared to the No. 1 overall spot in this year\u2019s Baseball America prospect rankings, from 67th the year before. Acu\u00f1a hit .325 with 21 homers and 44 runs batted in at three levels last season, and made his major league debut on Wednesday. He went 3 for 4 with a homer the next afternoon.", "title": "A Big Dealer Holds His Cards in Atlanta", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Her study, which will appear in the New York University Law Review\u2019s online supplement, gave Justice Gorsuch high marks.\n\n\u201cGorsuch does exceedingly well according to the standards that legal writing authorities espouse,\u201d Ms. Varsava wrote. \u201cHis writing has become progressively stronger by these standards over the past decade.\u201d\n\nShe started work on the report before Justice Gorsuch\u2019s literary stock plummeted. The reversal puzzled her, she said in an interview.\n\n\u201cI was quite surprised,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen I started doing this research, I couldn\u2019t find anything negative on his writing. People on the left and the right were celebrating his writing. And then people started sending me headlines saying Gorsuch is a terrible writer.\u201d\n\nMs. Varsava did not analyze Justice Gorsuch\u2019s writing on the Supreme Court. But she has read his opinions, and she had some tentative explanations for the recent critiques.\n\n\u201cHis Supreme Court opinions feel a bit more heavy-handed,\u201d she said. \u201cHe\u2019s a little contrived, a little too much.\u201d\n\nShe gave an example, citing the opening line from Justice Gorsuch\u2019s first majority opinion: \u201cDisruptive dinnertime calls, downright deceit and more besides drew Congress\u2019s eye to the debt collection industry.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Varsava said the alliteration was showy and jarring. \u201cIt just seemed like not something a justice should be spending so much time on,\u201d she said. \u201cEven though alliteration is pleasing, it should be a bit more subtle than that.\u201d\n\nMore recently, she said, Justice Gorsuch seemed to hit his stride in a majority opinion in a water dispute that started with this observation: \u201cWill Rogers reportedly called the Rio Grande \u2018the only river I ever saw that needed irrigation.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s quite nice,\u201d Ms. Varsava said of the opinion. \u201cIt opens nicely, and it\u2019s a very nice read.\u201d\n\nRoss Guberman, an authority on legal writing and the author of \u201cPoint Taken: How to Write Like the World\u2019s Best Judges,\u201d said he, too, was puzzled by the vehemence of the recent critiques. Justice Gorsuch has real gifts as a writer, he said, and assessments of his writing have had a partisan tinge.\n\n\u201cWhy is Gorsuch so divisive even when it comes to something as nerdy as writing style?\u201d Mr. Guberman asked. \u201cOne explanation could be that his writing seems highly personal \u2014 not personal in the sense of conversational but personal in the sense that he\u2019s trying to call attention to himself.\u201d\n\nIt is true that most Supreme Court opinions are impersonal, but that is because they are generally written in a colorless bureaucratic style.\n\nJustice Gorsuch\u2019s writing, by contrast, is informal, full of lively idioms and nicely paced. He uses contractions, short sentences, a varied vocabulary, the active voice and the second person. He has a talent for narrative storytelling, sometimes presenting the factual background of a case as an engaging yarn.\n\nMs. Varsava\u2019s study looked at Justice Gorsuch\u2019s roughly 175 published majority opinions when he sat on the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit. She compared them to the majority opinions of his colleagues on the appeals court in some 3,000 opinions.\n\nJustice Gorsuch used 3.9 contractions per 1,000 words, while other judges averaged 0.8. He started sentences with short conjunctions like \u201cand,\u201d \u201cbut\u201d and \u201cso\u201d 4.9 times out of every 1,000 words, compared to an average of 1.5. He used foreign words, including legal Latin, about half as often as his colleagues.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn all, Ms. Varsava found, \u201cGorsuch\u2019s style is considerably less formal and conventional than average, which likely makes his opinions seem more down-to-earth and less legalistic than other opinions \u2014 qualities that might increase his appeal and enable him to reach a wider audience.\u201d\n\nMs. Varsava also tested the swagger of Justice Gorsuch\u2019s appeals court opinions in light of what she called \u201chis reputation for self-assuredness and overconfidence\u201d by counting \u201cterms of certainty\u201d like \u201cclearly,\u201d \u201csurely\u201d and \u201cdecidedly.\u201d It turned out that he did use those kinds of terms more than twice as often as the average judge.\n\nBut Justice Gorsuch was also about twice as likely to use \u201cterms of hesitancy\u201d like \u201cpossibly\u201d and \u201cmaybe.\u201d Ms. Varsava concluded, with a bit of hesitancy of her own, that \u201che might have a proclivity for qualifiers in general.\u201d\n\nJustice Gorsuch is 50, and he just celebrated his first anniversary on the Supreme Court. He will most likely have decades to hone his style.\n\nMr. Guberman said the shortcomings in Justice Gorsuch\u2019s writing could settle into something more satisfying over time.\n\n\u201cDespite all his talents and brilliance,\u201d Mr. Guberman said, \u201che makes writing look hard, not easy, as if he\u2019s fiddling with a sentence and then looking up to see if anyone is applauding the latest line. But he\u2019s definitely getting better, and more natural.\u201d", "title": "#GorsuchStyle Garners a Gusher of Groans. But Is His Writing Really That Bad?", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Most jurisdictions abolished these formal rules in the 1970s. Even so, skepticism of the accuser remains an informal barrier to justice today. Victims of sexual assault \u2014 a population overwhelmingly, though not exclusively, comprising women \u2014 confront a system that is generally unresponsive to their claims. The sexual assault enforcement gap is particularly wide in cases involving women of color, immigrants, L.G.B.T. individuals, women in poverty and sex workers. Across the board, sexual assault allegations generally are treated with incredulity at every stage of the criminal process, resulting in an extraordinary rate of case attrition. Most accusations are dropped well before ever reaching a jury.\n\nMany survivors forgo the criminal justice system altogether for fear of how their cases might be mistreated. Apart from the personal and professional risks involved in reporting an assault, would-be accusers rightly fear that their allegations will be met with unwarranted skepticism \u2014 a pervasive problem I call \u201ccredibility discounting.\u201d\n\nNot every sexual assault allegation is true, of course. But what is troubling is the large gap between commonplace perceptions of falsity and actual falsity. This is a particular worry in the criminal justice setting, where law enforcement officers often disregard reports of sexual violence before they are fully investigated, having assumed at the outset that the complainant is probably lying. In one 2008 study, more than half of the police detectives interviewed said they believed that 40 percent to 80 percent of sexual assault complaints are false.\n\nThis default to doubt the accuser is unjustifiable. The quality of research on false rape allegations varies widely, but studies that have independently evaluated whether an allegation was false found false report rates ranging from 2 percent to 8 percent. Among them, a study on policing and prosecuting sexual assault in Los Angeles concluded that 4.5 percent of all sexual assaults made to the Los Angeles Police Department in 2008 were false. Another study that analyzed sexual assault allegations reported to one university in the Northeast over 10 years found that 5.9 percent were false. Moreover, research suggests that the types of reports most likely to be considered false \u2014 namely, those involving people who know each other or were intoxicated \u2014 are the least likely to be false.\n\nOf late, to overcome this discounting, sexual assault survivors have joined forces, telling their stories in numbers that greatly enhance the likelihood they will be believed in the court of public opinion. Outside of the courtroom, Bill Cosby, whose retrial began last Monday in suburban Philadelphia, has about 60 accusers. Harvey Weinstein, who has not yet been charged with a crime, has over 80. Larry Nassar, the doctor for U.S.A. Gymnastics who pleaded guilty before trial, has twice that number of accusers.\n\nTo be sure, numbers like those don\u2019t necessarily translate into success in the courtroom. But we may be on the cusp of a cultural shift in our orientation to sexual assault and its survivors.", "title": "Opinion | #MeToo Comes to the Cosby Courtroom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Needless to say, it also relieves the pressure on partners to meet annual billing targets.\n\nMs. Saeed conceded that the lockstep-compensation system removes a powerful lever of management control. It puts a high premium on partner selection and development, and requires attention to ensure that partners uphold all aspects of the social compact, not just in terms of their contribution but also in how they reflect the values of the partnership. A desire to change the Cravath system and the resulting internal friction was a factor in some of the recent departures.\n\n\u201cKirkland is the antithesis of Cravath when it comes to compensation,\u201d said Bruce MacEwen, president of Adam Smith, Esq., a consultant to law firms, who writes widely about their economics. \u201cIt\u2019s very individualistic and competitive, with a very big spread between the highest- and lowest-paid partners. But Kirkland has a reputation for excellence that rivals Cravath\u2019s.\u201d\n\nThere is no doubt that Kirkland, which has expanded rapidly from its Chicago headquarters, has been on a roll. The American Lawyer\u2019s annual survey of the largest law firms measured by revenue shows that it took in $3.165 billion last year, displacing Latham & Watkins from the top spot \u2014 an achievement Kirkland partners will celebrate next week at their annual retreat in Southern California\n\nKirkland\u2019s 19.4 percent growth rate in revenue last year compared with the previous year was the largest of any firm on The American Lawyer\u2019s list. Although its traditional strength has been in private equity transactions \u2014 a field it dominates \u2014 it was also ranked first last year by the website Mergermarket in mergers and acquisitions, with 447 deals.\n\nCravath has never aimed to be the biggest firm, in terms of revenue or number of lawyers. But it does put a premium on profitability. This year, Kirkland edged out Cravath on that count, too, with average profits per equity partner of $4.7 million, according to The American Lawyer. (The figures don\u2019t account for Cravath\u2019s gold-plated pension plan, which is among the most generous in the profession.)\n\nKirkland has shaken up the profession and expanded its practice by poaching top partners not just from Cravath, but from other prominent, old-line firms, including Latham and Skadden Arps Meagher Slate & Flom. It has raided the venerable Simpson Thacher & Bartlett in New York for so many partners that one Kirkland partner, in a widely circulated email, referred to Simpson as \u201cKirkland\u2019s AAA farm club.\u201d\n\nIn contrast to the lockstep system, which is still used by a dwindling number of law firms, albeit some of the most prestigious, Kirkland\u2019s approach is a star system known somewhat pejoratively as \u201ceat what you kill.\u201d", "title": "$11 Million a Year for a Law Partner? The project was backed by two high-ranking African National Congress politicians close to the Guptas: Mosebenzi Joseph Zwane, who later became Mr. Zuma\u2019s minister of mineral resources, and Ace Magashule, the party\u2019s current secretary general. The Gupta brothers are now believed to be in Dubai.\n\nEighty to 100 black farmers who were supposed to become beneficiaries of the project ended up receiving nothing \u2014 an outcome that, to many, symbolized the corruption that has flourished under the A.N.C., the party that has ruled South Africa since apartheid ended in 1994.\n\nFor years, the problems surrounding the dairy project had drawn the attention of the South African news media as well as investigators from the National Treasury. But the authorities made arrests in the case only in February, after Mr. Zuma was ousted as president.\n\nThe case is regarded as a test of how far his successor, Cyril Ramaphosa, will be able to carry out his pledge to root out corruption in government.\n\nSo far, no A.N.C. officials have been arrested or had their assets seized.", "title": "$21 Million in Assets Seized in South African Corruption Inquiry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The California case was one of the first lawsuits filed by the Cyber Civil Rights Legal Project, an initiative started in 2014 by K&L Gates, a Pittsburgh law firm, to litigate against online harassment and the nonconsensual posting of explicit material, often involving a former girlfriend or a spouse. Ms. D\u2019Amico, in the firm\u2019s Miami office, is a leader of the initiative.\n\nMost states have laws that can be used to address revenge porn, but they vary widely. They include laws against criminal invasion of privacy, voyeurism, impersonation or fraud, harassment and stalking.\n\nOn the federal level, courses of action include copyright infringement and computer fraud and abuse claims, according to Without My Consent, a nonprofit organization that combats online invasions of privacy and breaks down the legal remedies that are possible in all 50 states.\n\nIn the California case, Ms. Doe already held the copyright to the sexually explicit images that she had shared privately with Mr. Elam because she took them herself. But when he started to publish them without her permission, she registered her ownership, which is a prerequisite for her to seek relief under federal copyright laws, Ms. D\u2019Amico said.\n\n\u201cIn many instances it is easier for a victim of revenge porn to have photos of herself and himself removed from a website if they own a copyright registration,\u201d said Seth A. Gold, the lead lawyer on the Doe case.\n\nThe judgment included $450,000 for copyright infringement, $3 million for severe emotional distress and $3 million for other damages, including stalking and online impersonation with intent to cause harm.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Elam, who also allegedly sent some of the explicit material to Ms. Doe\u2019s acquaintances, could not be reached for comment.\n\nThe lawyers representing Mr. Elam withdrew in 2015, the judgment says. They did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt least 36 states have some laws that penalize the nonconsensual distribution of intimate images, representing a national patchwork of different standards and punishments for an activity that transcends borders.\n\n\u201cFrom a victim perspective, it can be exceedingly difficult to figure out,\u201d Christine M. Gagnier, a lawyer and board member of Without My Consent, said. \u201cThe photograph is on the internet, so the harm is happening in a variety of places.\u201d\n\nCalifornia, for example, has a nonconsensual pornography law with misdemeanor penalties, she said. The law was used in a case in which a former Playboy model was sentenced to community service in 2017 for secretly photographing a naked older woman in a Los Angeles gym and then posting the picture online.\n\nLegislators have tried to fill the gaps in federal law. In 2016, Representative Jackie Speier, Democrat of California, introduced the Intimate Privacy Protection Act. A bipartisan second version, called the Enough Act, was introduced in both the House and Senate last November.\n\n\u201cWe are continuing to gain support and are talking with the relevant committees about next steps,\u201d said Josh Connolly, Ms. Speier\u2019s chief of staff. \u201cWe treat this as a privacy violation, which we think it is. That is the heart of the violation, rather than what the intent is of the individual.\u201d\n\nThe K&L initiative has counseled thousands of victims of sexual cyber harassment since it started, Ms. D\u2019Amico said. In 2017, a couple in the Seattle area was awarded $8.9 million in a judgment against an Arizona man who posted sexual images they had shared with him online, and sent them to people they knew, court documents said.\n\n\u201cA lot of times individuals will engage in victim blaming,\u201d Ms. D\u2019Amico said. \u201cBut when images are shared within the confines of a private relationship, it is recognized that there is a right to privacy there.\u201d", "title": "$6.4 Million Judgment in Revenge Porn Case Is Among Largest Ever", "authors": ["Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Seattle\n\nWHAT A 1935 home with two bedrooms and one and three-quarter bathrooms\n\nHOW MUCH $700,000\n\nSIZE 1,820 square feet\n\nPRICE PER SQUARE FOOT $385\n\nSETTING The house is in West Seattle, half a mile from a large park on Puget Sound with running trails and a swimming pool, and about two miles from the trendy shops and restaurants of the Junction neighborhood.\n\nINDOORS An arched door with a stained-glass window opens to a bright foyer. Next to it is a living room with a recently installed gas fireplace. The current owners put their dining table in this room and turned the adjacent dining room into a family room. In the kitchen, they kept the original cabinets but updated the rest with oversize subway tile, Restoration Hardware light fixtures, quartz countertops and luxury vinyl flooring.\n\nTwo bedrooms are on the upper level, one with a small en-suite study. The bedrooms share a full bathroom. The basement level has a second bathroom with a shower. There is also a laundry area.", "title": "$700,000 Homes in Washington, Pennsylvania and Michigan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nBALLET HISP\u00c1NICO at the Joyce Theater (April 10-11, 7:30 p.m., through April 15). This season sees two premieres inspired by the writings of Federico Garc\u00eda Lorca: \u201cEsp\u00edritus Gemelos\u201d by Gustavo Ram\u00edrez Sansano and \u201cWaiting for Pepe\u201d by Carlos Pons Guerra. The program also features a reprise of \u201cL\u00ednea Recta,\u201d Annabelle Lopez Ochoa\u2019s 2016 exploration of flamenco. The works were created through the company\u2019s Instituto Coreogr\u00e1fico, a lab for Latino choreographers that Ballet Hisp\u00e1nico\u2019s artistic director and chief executive officer, Eduardo Vilaro, began in 2010 as a way, in part, for dance makers to explore their heritage.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nEIFMAN BALLET OF ST. PETERSBURG at the David H. Koch Theater (April 6, 6:30 p.m.; April 7, 2 and 7:30 p.m.; April 8, 2 p.m.). In honor of the 20th anniversary of his company\u2019s New York debut, Boris Eifman returns with his evening-length production of \u201cAnna Karenina.\u201d The choreographer\u2019s take on the Tolstoy novel raises the tragic affair of Anna and Count Vronsky to melodramatic heights with his melding of ballet and contemporary dance. Accompanying the dancers will be the New York City Ballet Orchestra performing a mix of Tchaikovsky. Nikolay Alexeev conducts.\n\n212-496-0600, davidhkochtheater.com\n\nGATHERING PLACE: BLACK QUEER LAND(ING) at Gibney (April 10, 6-9 p.m.; April 12, 8 p.m., through April 28). In this new nearly three-week performance series, programmed by Mar\u00fda Wethers, the focus is the intersections among blackness, queerness and indigeneity. The first weekend presents Mayfield Brooks\u2019s three-part \u201cIWB: Dancing in the Hold.\u201d Part I, \u201cP(a)rLAY,\u201d is an invitation to black-identified artists to participate in an improvisational dance workshop and performance (April 10). Part II, \u201cDancing in the Hold,\u201d features a production inspired by underwater finds, like a shipwreck (April 12 and 13). And Part III, \u201cProcess(Ion),\u201d is a performance installation that includes a procession from the theater to the African Burial Ground in Lower Manhattan (April 14). The series continues later this month with performances by Jumatatu M. Poe and the I Moving Lab collective.\n\n646-837-6809, gibneydance.org", "title": "10 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nABRAHAM.IN.MOTION at the Joyce Theater (May 1-2, 7:30 p.m.; May 3-4, 8 p.m.; through May 6). Before Kyle Abraham was known for creating rich, evocative ensemble dances for his company, he was hailed for his own mellifluous dancing. As part of A.I.M.\u2019s weeklong season at the Joyce, Mr. Abraham returns to form, presenting \u201cINDY,\u201d his first solo in almost a decade, as well as a new group work called \u201cMeditation.\u201d Mr. Abraham has also invited other choreographers for his two programs, including a premiere from Andrea Miller; Doug Varone\u2019s 1994 \u201cStrict Love,\u201d set to Diana Ross, the Jackson 5 and others; and Bebe Miller\u2019s 1987 \u201cThe Habit of Attraction.\u201d\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nCHARLES ATLAS at the Kitchen (May 3-5, 8 p.m., through May 12). Collaboration is an intrinsic ingredient for this filmmaker, who worked frequently with Merce Cunningham. In connection with an installation at the Kitchen, Mr. Atlas presents \u201cThe Kitchen Follies,\u201d performances that showcase his current collaborations. Some are with artists he has known for a long time, like the choreographers Jodi Melnick and Stanley Love and the duo DanceNoise. Others are with first-time partners, including Laurie Berg and the Illustrious Blacks, a performance-art pair. During performances, Mr. Atlas will film, alter and project footage as part of the show.\n\n212-255-5793, thekitchen.org\n\nE-MOVES at Harlem Stage (May 2-5, 7:30 p.m.). What does it mean to be African in today\u2019s America? Three choreographers grapple with that question in Harlem Stage\u2019s signature contemporary dance series. Lacina Coulibaly, from Burkina Faso, presents an ode to African culture, \u201cThe Rite of Initiates.\u201d Ousmane Wiles, from Senegal, combines West African, Afrobeat, house and vogue dance styles in \u201cSila Djiguba,\u201d and Zimbabwe-born artist Nora Chipaumire contributes \u201cDark Swan,\u201d a solo performed by Shamar Watt that is a nod to the 1905 dance classic \u201cThe Dying Swan.\u201d\n\n212-281-9240, harlemstage.org\n\nGIBNEY DANCE COMPANY at Gibney Dance (May 3-4, 8 p.m., through May 5). Choreographer Bryan Arias\u2019s new work for the Gibney Dance Company, called \u201cOne Thousand Million Seconds,\u201d is an abstract meditation on life and happiness. Mr. Arias\u2019s work is paired with \u201cValence,\u201d by Amy Miller, Gibney\u2019s senior company director. The piece borrows its title from chemistry and refers to the bonding properties of atoms, which Ms. Miller uses here as a metaphor for human relationships.\n\n646-837-6809, gibneydance.org\n\nMARIANGELA LOPEZ at Abrons Arts Center (May 2-5, 8 p.m.). Tarantella, the name of an Italian folk dance, derives from tarantism, a form of hysteria marked by compulsive movement that swept the country\u2019s southern region starting in the 15th century. In her new work, \u201cRaphael,\u201d Ms. Lopez uses this remarkable historical episode as a source of inspiration, along with the exaggerated machismo of the male Spanish singers of her youth. The Venezuelan choreographer will be accompanied by four other dancers.\n\n866-811-4111, abronsartscenter.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSARAH MICHELSON at Performance Space New York (April 27-28 and May 3-5, 6:30 p.m.). In the early 1990s, Ms. Michelson performed as a dancer at the performance space then known as PS 122. As she developed into a highly regarded choreographer, she returned there with a number of her own works, most recently in 2005. PS 122 has recently been renamed Performance Space New York, and Ms. Michelson has created a new work called \u201cMay 2018/\\\u201d that reflects on her long relationship with the space and is likely to feature her unique blend of dry wit and physical rigor. All performances have sold out, but you can get on a waiting list by appearing in person at the box office (no phone calls) 90 minutes before showtime. If a ticket does become available, you must pay for it in cash.\n\n212-352-3101, performancespacenewyork.org", "title": "10 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Brian Schaefer"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "RONALD FELDMAN GALLERY through May 12; 31 Mercer Street, feldmangallery.com. Another SoHo holdout, this gallery arrived on Mercer Street in 1982; it often mounts shows of politically engaged work, and takes a particular interest in Jewish and Israeli artists. The group exhibition \u201cViolated! Women in Holocaust and Genocide\u201d features 30 artists whose art portrays the legacy of the Shoah for Jewish women, as well as female suffering in the former Yugoslavia, Rwanda and Darfur. If much of the art here has greater moral clarity than aesthetic ambition, one searing work on paper makes the show worth a visit on its own: a vision of Auschwitz, picturing emaciated female prisoners and sadistic female kapos, drawn by the survivor Ella Liebermann-Shiber one month after the liberation.\n\nBORTOLAMI through May 5; 39 Walker Street, bortolamigallery.com. When the shrewd Italian gallerist Stefania Bortolami relocated from Chelsea to Walker Street last spring, she ratified the emergence of this dowdy north TriBeCa street as an art world thoroughfare. Nicol\u00e1s Guagnini, an artist on her roster, has curated a cerebral group show, \u201cHuman Applause,\u201d whose artists imbue repeated forms with humanistic qualities. Sitting on a gridded bench by Superstudio, the radical Italian architecture firm, is an iPad looping a video by the Venezuelan painter Eugenio Espinosa, performing with a gridded fabric; a painting of repeated amoeboid forms by Claude Viallat, the grand man of the French movement Supports/Surfaces, continues the play between repetition and creation. (Opening this weekend here is a second show of chopped-and-screwed landscapes by the Brazilian painter Marina Rheingantz.)\n\nTriBeCa\n\nARTISTS SPACE through May 6; 55 Walker Street, artistsspace.org. It hasn\u2019t yet moved into its new permanent home on White Street, but this enduring nonprofit, led now by Jay Sanders, the Whitney\u2019s performance alumnus, is doing what it does best from its Walker Street rental: essential shows by emerging artists and by historical figures too little celebrated. The Chicago painter Miyoko Ito (1918-1983), who was born in Berkeley and interned during World War II, is one of the latter: her strange abstract paintings, informed as much by Giorgio Morandi\u2019s sallow still lifes as by the legacy of Surrealism, come as a revelation. In a palette of chartreuse, ocher, cinnamon and gamboge, Ito overlaid uncommon shapes, such as a rectangle rounded and pinched at the top like a loaf of Wonder Bread, into compositions of preternatural calm.", "title": "10 Galleries to Visit Now Around SoHo and TriBeCa", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGalleries, small and midsize, are having a rough ride. Rents keep climbing. So do art-fair fees. And certain people who might help pay the gallery bills \u2014 collectors, big-museum curators \u2014 keep not showing up except at a handful of spaces with social cachet and publicity machines. Plus, a sizable portion of the art audience has taken to doing its looking online, raising the question: Why have physical galleries at all?\n\nBecause they\u2019re the only places where you truly see new work, experience it. Scale, texture, light, air, mood; all that changes when you\u2019re physically present, shifting positions, moving in close, backing away, hearing noise from the street. Most of the galleries on the Lower East Side are still storefront-size, scaled for shopping, and open on Sundays. They put you in intimate contact with objects, sensations and ideas so you can examine them, stay with them, make them your own.\n\n17ESSEX through May 26; 17 Essex Street, 17essex.info. This is one of the neighborhood\u2019s smaller spaces, but it holds a big conceptual world in a project by Ala Younis. Born in Kuwait, she contributed an outstanding installation to the Guggenheim\u2019s 2016 show of new art from the Middle East, a piece called \u201cPlan for Greater Baghdad,\u201d which featured the contributions of Western starchitects \u2014 Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier and Frank Lloyd Wright \u2014 to the creation of the city. In an update at 17Essex, Ms. Younis focuses on the work of women in the realization of that plan. The cast of players is formidable, from major architects like Ellen Jawdat, Wijdan Maher and Zaha Hadid to Balkis Shararah, who smuggled research material into Abu Ghraib prison when her architect-husband, Rifat Chadirji, who rebuilt Baghdad after Iraq\u2019s 1958 revolution, was jailed there, to help him complete a book. Ms. Younis\u2019s show is formally spare and compressed. The story it tells is huge.\n\nLMAK GALLERY through April 29; 298 Grand Street, LMAKgallery.com. While Ms. Younis charts the hidden history of a city, Nayda Collazo-Llorens surveys a wide-open cosmos in \u201cUnmappings.\u201d Like many artists who claim dual homes, Ms. Collazo-Llorens \u2014 born in Puerto Rico, educated in the Northeast \u2014 is global-minded, viewing the world both at ground level and from above, which are the perspectives we find in a wall installation made up of more than 300 framed fragments of oceanic maps that take us from the Caribbean to the Sea of Tranquillity on the moon. The back-and-forth between the terrestrial and the celestial suggests that cultural identity is all about transition, and nomadism is universal citizenship.\n\nPhoto\n\n47 CANAL through May 27; 291 Grand Street, second floor, 47canal.us. The American artist and writer Theresa Hak Kyung Cha (1951-1982), one of the most intriguing figures of the 1970s, seems to have dropped from view for a younger generation. So it\u2019s great that Cici Wu, who was born in 1989 and came to the United States from China in 2012, pays tribute to her in a show, \u201cUpon Leaving the White Dust,\u201d that sculpturally evokes a film, \u201cWhite Dust From Mongolia,\u201d that Cha shot on a trip to her native South Korea and that was left unfinished when she died in New York City at the age of 31. Against a flickering projection of white light, Ms. Wu sets an assemblage of small objects that refer to images in the film: trains, an airplane, a mop, the silhouette of an urban skyline. \u201cMemory, time, silence, words, and whiteness\u201d were the essence of Cha\u2019s art, wrote the art historian Moira Roth, as they are of Ms. Wu\u2019s homage.", "title": "10 Galleries to Visit Now on the Lower East Side", "authors": ["Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "CRAIG F. STARR GALLERY through May 25; 5 East 73rd Street, craigstarr.com. Although Eva Hesse (1936-70) is best known for her sculptures and installations using latex, fiberglass and other unorthodox material, she was also an inventive painter and draftswoman. \u201cEva Hesse: Arrows and Boxes, Repeated\u201d at Craig F. Starr includes early grids and abstract gouaches and a 1968 version of her \u201cAccession\u201d series of boxes. In each of these open steel-mesh containers, she would weave rubber tubes through the grid, creating a minimalist form that looked as if it were growing hair or coming alive.\n\nMICHAEL WERNER through May 5; 4 East 77th Street, michaelwerner.com. If the Upper East Side is filling up with all kinds of newcomers, the German art dealer Michael Werner represents the new old guard: He opened his first gallery here in 1990. His current show, \u201cPer Kirkeby: Paintings and Bronzes From the 1980s,\u201d reflects Mr. Werner\u2019s stable of (mostly male, mostly European) artists. The dark, murky canvases and expressive abstract bronzes are drawn partly from Mr. Kirkeby\u2019s studies in the 1960s, when he traveled in Greenland and the Arctic while working on a master\u2019s degree in geology.\n\nHALF GALLERY through May 9; 43 East 78th Street, halfgallery.com. A pocket-size gallery that lives up to its name, Half Gallery shows a solid lineup of young painters who approach the canvas with conviction and a twisted vision. In Ginny Casey\u2019s \u201cSkeleton Key,\u201d the murky-hued paintings are populated with curvy, vaguely surrealistic objects, like a chair with arms, a metronome the size of an armoire or a key too large for any human\u2019s door.\n\nGAGOSIAN through May 25; 976 Madison Avenue, gagosian.com. In the portfolio of galleries that make up the Gagosian empire, the bookstore might be the most fun. This is at least the case with the display of Jonas Wood\u2019s prints that is thereright now. The works spill into the book-selling space, which Mr. Wood has covered with wallpaper in a tennis-ball motif. Other prints play around with images of vases, remaking historical Greek versions or those painted by Matisse into goofy creations, like a vessel that has the words \u201cDiet 7Up\u201d on it. Sports, often ignored in \u201cfine\u201d art, is also a favored theme; Mr. Wood conjures the image of the slacker artist sitting on his couch, watching basketball, tennis or gymnastics, if he must.\n\nPhoto\n\nACQUAVELLA GALLERIES through May 25; 18 East 79th Street, acquavellagalleries.com. The most traditional European gallery experience can be had at Acquavella Galleries, housed in a French neo-Classical-style townhouse. \u201cThe Worlds of Joaqu\u00edn Torres-Garc\u00eda\u201d offers a survey of the work of this Uruguayan-born artist (1874-1949), who lived in Paris and New York during vital creative periods. A collage with a label for bullion \u201cen cubitos\u201d playfully shows off his Cubist knowledge, while a pair of painted overalls titled \u201cNew York Suit\u201d (1920s) feels very New York Dada. The rest of the gallery has paintings made of grids filled with images of architectural fragments and symbols from history, various religions or perhaps dreams.", "title": "10 Galleries to Visit Now on the Upper East Side", "authors": ["Martha Schwendener"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere are a few days left to celebrate National Poetry Month (of course it\u2019s worth celebrating verse year-round), and our recommendations this week start with books by two of America\u2019s leading young poets: Kevin Young and Tracy K. Smith. A slightly older poet (and playwright), William Shakespeare, has his \u201cMacbeth\u201d updated by the Norwegian thriller writer Jo Nesbo. Also this week, Lawrence Wright takes us on a tour of his complicated home state, Texas; David Reich takes us on a tour of the even more complicated science of population genetics; Aliette de Bodard reimagines Sherlock Holmes and Doctor Watson in a science-fiction universe; and much more.\n\nJohn Williams\n\nDaily Books Editor and Staff Writer\n\nBROWN: Poems, by Kevin Young. Photographs by Melanie Dunea. (Knopf, $27.) \u201cBrown\u201d is the latest book by the prolific Kevin Young, who in addition to his steady output as an author is the poetry editor of The New Yorker and the director of Harlem\u2019s Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. \u201cYoung is a maximalist, a putter-inner, an evoker of roiling appetites,\u201d our critic Dwight Garner writes. \u201cAs a poet of music and food, his only rival is Charles Simic. His love poems are beautiful and sexy and ecstatic. He mostly wears his politics lightly but regularly sinks hooks into you that cannot easily be removed.\u201d\n\nWADE IN THE WATER: Poems, by Tracy K. Smith. (Graywolf, $24.) Tracy K. Smith, America\u2019s poet laureate, returns with her first collection since \u201cLife on Mars\u201d won a Pulitzer Prize in 2012. The book includes a suite of found poems that employ, nearly verbatim, the letters and statements of African-American Civil War veterans and their families. Our critic Dwight Garner writes: \u201cSmith\u2019s new book is scorching in both its steady cognizance of America\u2019s original racial sins \u2014 open wounds that have had insectlike eggs repeatedly laid in them \u2014 and apprehension about history\u2019s direction.\u201d\n\nGOD SAVE TEXAS: A Journey Into the Soul of the Lone Star State, by Lawrence Wright. (Knopf, $27.95.) Lawrence Wright, whose books include investigations of Scientology (\u201cGoing Clear\u201d) and Al Qaeda (the Pulitzer Prize-winning \u201cThe Looming Tower\u201d), turns his attention to the state he has long called home. \u201cGod Save Texas\u201d \u201cis both an apologia and an indictment: an illuminating primer for outsiders who may not live there but have a surfeit of opinions about those who do,\u201d our critic Jennifer Szalai writes. \u201cThe book rambles far and wide, and it\u2019s a testament to Wright\u2019s formidable storytelling skills that a reader will encounter plenty of information without ever feeling lost.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMACBETH, by Jo Nesbo. Translated by Don Bartlett. (Hogarth, $27.) Jo Nesbo, the celebrated Norwegian writer of thrillers, is the latest contributor to Hogarth Shakespeare, a series in which best-selling novelists turn Shakespeare\u2019s works into contemporary fiction. Nesbo sets his \u201cMacbeth\u201d in the early 1970s, in an unnamed city that strongly resembles Glasgow. \u201cBy making addiction so central to his plot,\u201d our reviewer, James Shapiro, writes, \u201cNesbo also makes Macbeth\u2019s paranoia and hallucinatory visions, so crucial to Shakespeare\u2019s play, not just believable but meaningful in a contemporary way.\u201d", "title": "10 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018ALOHA, ALOHA, OR WHEN I WAS QUEEN\u2019 at the Abrons Arts Center (in previews; opens on April 6). It\u2019s leis and hula skirts for all as the delightfully off-kilter writer and performer Eliza Bent (\u201cThe Hotel Colors\u201d) recreates an impolitic school project in which she impersonated the last monarch of Hawaii even though she\u2019s not Hawaiian. Knud Adams directs the screening of home movies and the dawning of self-recrimination.\n\n866-811-4111, abronsartscenter.org\n\n\u2018CAROUSEL\u2019 at the Imperial Theater (in previews; opens on April 12). The roundelay of Broadway revivals comes around again to this Rodgers and Hammerstein\u2019s classic musical, directed by Jack O\u2019Brien and choreographed by Justin Peck. Jessie Mueller, Joshua Henry, Lindsay Mendez and John Douglas Thompson star in a metaphysical musical of fraught love and real nice clambakes.\n\n212-239-6200, carouselbroadway.com\n\n\u2018CHILDREN OF A LESSER GOD\u2019 at Studio 54 (in previews; opens on April 11). Broadway becomes a place that\u2019s not in silence and not in sound when the director Kenny Leon revives Mark Medoff\u2019s 1979 play about the relationship between a deaf custodian and a hearing teacher. Lauren Ridloff, a longtime educator now making her Broadway debut, plays Sarah, with Joshua Jackson as her lover, James.\n\n212-239-6200, childrenofalessergodbroadway.com\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018KING LEAR\u2019 at BAM Harvey Theater (previews start on April 7; opens on April 14). Antony Sher plays the man more sinned against than sinning when the Royal Shakespeare Company brings this tragedy to Brooklyn. In Gregory Doran\u2019s production of this drama of truth, betrayal and inheritance, Mr. Sher caps a long career of playing fools, princes and kings.\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org\n\n\u2018MEAN GIRLS: THE MUSICAL\u2019 at the August Wilson Theater (in previews; opens on April 8). So fetch. The musical version of the 2004 comedy arrives on Broadway, with a book by Tina Fey, music by Jeff Richmond and lyrics by Nell Benjamin. Under Casey Nicholaw\u2019s direction, Taylor Louderman, Ashley Park and Kate Rockwell star as the Plastics, with Erika Henningsen as the new girl Cady. Queen bees and wannabes are all welcome.\n\n800-745-3000, meangirlsonbroadway.com", "title": "10 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Plus, two Times Talks events. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018DANCE NATION\u2019 at Playwrights Horizons (previews start on April 13; opens on May 8). A playwright with an abiding and sometimes grotesque interest in the female body, Clare Barron comes to Playwrights Horizons with a drama about a preteen dance competition. The director and choreographer Lee Sunday Evans oversees the spangled, cutthroat fun. Eboni Booth, Ellen Maddow and Thomas Jay Ryan star.\n\n212-279-4200, playwrightshorizons.org\n\n\u2018LIGHT SHINING IN BUCKINGHAMSHIRE\u2019 at New York Theater Workshop (previews start on April 18; opens on May 7). The director Rachel Chavkin says she wants a revolution, and in this revival of Caryl Churchill\u2019s 1976 drama, she\u2019s exploring insurrection in 17th-century England. Vinie Burrows, Rob Campbell and Mik\u00e9ah Ernest Jennings star in a play about Levellers, Ranters and a time when a nation almost remade itself.\n\n212-460-5475, nytw.org\n\n\u2018MY FAIR LADY\u2019 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater (in previews; opens on April 19). Lerner and Loewe\u2019s musical comedy confection returns to Broadway with the loverly Lauren Ambrose as the spirited flower seller Eliza Doolittle and Harry Hadden-Paton as her eccentric phonetician, Henry Higgins. Bartlett Sher\u2019s lush production for Lincoln Center Theater includes Diana Rigg as Mrs. Higgins and Norbert Leo Butz as Eliza\u2019s church-bound father.\n\n212-239-6200, lct.org", "title": "10 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "NAIROBI, Kenya \u2014 Ten relief workers traveling in South Sudan have been abducted by an armed group, the United Nations said on Thursday. The kidnapping underscores the risks to humanitarian aid providers in the war-afflicted African country.\n\nA statement from the United Nations said the aid workers, all from South Sudan, disappeared on Wednesday during a trip through the southern part of the country. The statement gave no details on the armed group that seized them or its demands.\n\nThis is the third time in six months that aid workers have been held by militants in South Sudan, the world\u2019s youngest country. At least 98 aid workers have been killed in South Sudan since it devolved into civil war in 2013, two years after it was founded. The majority of the aid workers killed since the conflict began are South Sudanese.\n\nThe United Nations statement called for the release of the workers \u201cwithout condition so that their work can continue.\u201d", "title": "10 South Sudan Aid Workers Are Abducted, U.N. Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine what you could find if you rummaged through the attic of America\u2019s oldest orchestra, the New York Philharmonic, founded in 1842. A Beethoven score, annotated decades apart by Mahler and Toscanini, two Philharmonic music directors who didn\u2019t always see eye to eye. A flute part from the 1893 premiere of Dvorak\u2019s \u201cNew World\u201d Symphony. A \u201cMahler Grooves\u201d bumper sticker that Leonard Bernstein put in his score of Mahler\u2019s Sixth.\n\nFor more than three decades, the Philharmonic\u2019s rummager-in-chief has been Barbara Haws, its first archivist and historian. She has been a visionary, photographing its collection and making much of it available online as part of a digital archive that now has 1,789 marked scores, more than 13,880 programs and reams of historical board minutes and correspondence. She recently announced that she is retiring to pursue a doctorate at Oxford University, studying Ureli Corelli Hill, the Philharmonic\u2019s founder \u2014 whose diary she acquired for the archive.\n\nAs she prepared to leave, she chose 10 favorite treasures from the archive. Below are her explanations of their significance.\n\nUreli Corelli Hill\u2019s Diary From Abroad, 1835-37", "title": "10 Treasures, Unearthed From the New York Philharmonic\u2019s Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nEvery month, as various licenses expire, streaming services lose movies and TV series from their catalogs. Here are 11 noteworthy titles leaving Netflix in May.\n\nGeorge Clooney, left, and Brad Pitt in \u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven.\u201d Bob Marshak/Warner Bros.\n\n\u2018Ocean\u2019s Eleven\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 1\n\nMay 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe Oscar-winning director Steven Soderbergh brings together a jaw-dropping ensemble \u2014 including George Clooney, Matt Damon, Brad Pitt, Andy Garcia, Don Cheadle, Bernie Mac and Julia Roberts \u2014 for this sly, funny remake of the 1960 \u201cRat Pack\u201d caper. Soderbergh keeps the basic story (a gang of con artists robs several Las Vegas casinos simultaneously) and the \u201call-star cast\u201d hook. But he also updates the story to acknowledge Sin City\u2019s current, family-friendly aesthetic and invests the heist with enough unexpected twists and turns to keep audiences guessing. There\u2019s not a weak link in the cast, but Clooney and Pitt are especially good together, trading jabs and finishing each other\u2019s sentences with the punchy panache of an old-school comedy team.\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cGoodfellas.\u201d Warner Bros., via Everett Collection\n\n\u2018Goodfellas\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 1\n\nMay 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis electrifying crime epic from Martin Scorsese tells the story of the real-life Henry Hill, a neighborhood kid who idolizes the local mobsters and goes on to work his way from being a low-level grinder to a big-time operator to, finally, a coked-up, burned-out witness for the feds. Scorsese\u2019s visceral direction and propulsive pacing seduce the viewer right alongside Mr. Hill \u2014 his bravura set pieces go beyond showing off, adroitly dramatizing both the appeal of criminal and the dread of its walls closing in. Ray Liotta masterfully conveys Hill\u2019s affability and how it degenerates into sweaty desperation; Robert De Niro, Lorraine Bracco, Paul Sorvino and (especially) Joe Pesci shine in their memorable supporting roles.\n\n\u2014\n\nRay Liotta, left, and Kevin Costner in \u201cField of Dreams.\u201d Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Field of Dreams\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nKevin Costner crafts one of his finest performances in this clever but tender drama from director Phil Alden Robinson, which was nominated for the best picture Oscar for the class of 1989. Costner plays Ray Kinsella, a child of the \u201960s who settles down on an Iowa corn farm but finds himself hearing voices and seeing visions \u2014 all of which give him the unorthodox advice of plowing under some of his corn and building a baseball diamond. What happens next is an unlikely mix of magical realism and genuine emotion, bolstered by splashes of real sports history and thinly-veiled roman \u00e0 clef. It sounds like a mess, but Robinson and his peerless cast never step wrong \u2014 and its closing scenes are guaranteed to turn on the waterworks.\n\n\u2014\n\nJeremy Renner in \u201cThe Hurt Locker.\u201d Summit Entertainment\n\n\u2018The Hurt Locker\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 1\n\nMay 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWinner of the Oscar for best picture of 2009, this tense fusion of war movie and psychological drama from Kathryn Bigelow, stars Jeremy Renner as Sgt. William James, the team leader of a special Army unit dedicated to diffusing and disposing of on-the-ground bombs and improvised explosives in Iraq, circa 2004. It sounds like a suicide mission, and James\u2019s reckless tendencies alarm even that team. Bigelow, who for her work on this film became the first woman to win a best director Oscar, grippingly conveys James\u2019s inner turmoil using action rather than verbose monologues, and the results are terse, efficient and frequently terrifying.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nRen\u00e9e Zellweger in \u201cBridget Jones\u2019s Diary.\u201d Miramax Films\n\n\u2018Bridget Jones\u2019s Diary\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nRen\u00e9e Zellweger was nominated for a best actress Oscar for her charming and uproariously funny work as the heroine of the best-seller by Helen Fielding, here adapted with style and grace by director Sharon Maguire. As a perpetually self-doubting and accident-prone publicist, Zellweger\u2019s Jones takes to her diary as she attempts to navigate the treacherous waters of single life, finding herself caught between two diametrically opposite suitors (Hugh Grant and Colin Firth). \u201cDiary\u201d never skimps on the embarrassing details, but Zellweger is such a sympathetic heroine, and the events are crafted with such warmth and good cheer, you\u2019re with her every step of the way.\n\n\u2014\n\nDakota Fanning in \u201cCharlotte\u2019s Web.\u201d Lisa Tomasetti/Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018Charlotte\u2019s Web\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nE.B. White\u2019s classic children\u2019s book \u201cCharlotte\u2019s Web\u201d \u2014 in which an especially talented spider uses her web-spinning skills to save the life of a friendly pig \u2014 was adapted into an animated feature back in 1973, but that effort was so sloppily constructed it was all but forgotten. Thankfully, advances in visual effects allowed the director Gary Winick to take another crack at the book in 2006, giving \u201cBabe\u201d-style voice to live-action animals (and casting such stars as Julia Roberts, Oprah Winfrey, Steve Buscemi and John Cleese for those voices). Dakota Fanning is marvelous as Fern, the little farm girl who treats Wilbur the pig as her house pet, while the child actor Dominic Scott Kay is delightful as the voice of Wilbur. Winick\u2019s sweet and sensitive approach to material does right by White\u2019s text, at long last.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Wesley Snipes, John Leguizamo and Patrick Swayze in \u201cTo Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything! Julie Newmar.\u201d Universal Pictures/Getty Images\n\n\u2018To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything! Julie Newmar\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 1995 road comedy, something of an American riff on \u201cThe Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,\u201d was a revelation at the time of its release: a mainstream studio comedy concerning three drag queens, all played by marquee movie stars, free of the condescension and gay-panic so typical of the era\u2019s popular culture. Patrick Swayze is utterly disarming as the den mother of the trio, whose cross-country trip to the Miss Drag Queen of America Pageant is diverted by car trouble into a back-road small town, and Wesley Snipes delivers his one-liners with screwball snap. But John Leguizamo, then a newcomer, steals the show as \u201cChi-Chi Rodriguez,\u201d the \u201cdrag princess\u201d in training. His performance is energetic, upbeat and enjoyable, and the movie offers much of the same.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cHigh School Musical.\u201d Fred Hayes/Disney\n\n\u2018High School Musical\u2019 / \u2018High School Musical 2\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 2\n\nIn what is presumably one more step in Disney\u2019s much-discussed exodus from Netflix to a streaming service of its own, more than two dozen Disney Channel original movies and series \u2014 including \u201cPhineas and Ferb,\u201d the \u201cCheetah Girls\u201d trilogy and the \u201cCamp Rock\u201d films \u2014 are exiting Netflix on May 2. The biggest of the bunch are the first two films in the \u201cHigh School Musical\u201d series, which made the likes of Zac Efron, Vanessa Hudgens and Ashley Tisdale into household names. They\u2019re light as a souffl\u00e9 and about as substantial, but the stars are charismatic and the dancing is dazzling (director Kenny Ortega was best known before this as the choreographer for films like \u201cDirty Dancing\u201d and \u201cOne From the Heart\u201d). And fans of the franchise don\u2019t have to be entirely heartbroken \u2014 Netflix is adding the (theatrically released) third installment on May 1.\n\n\u2014\n\nWill Ferrell in \u201cTalladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby.\u201d Suzanne Hanover/Columbia Pictures\n\n\u2018Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 12\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWill Ferrell re-teamed with his \u201cAnchorman\u201d co-writer and director, Adam McKay, for this 2006 sports comedy, which features Ferrell playing another self-assured blowhard, surrounded by sycophants. This time, that character is Ricky Bobby, a Nascar superstar whose life of high speeds and lucrative endorsements comes to a crashing halt. It\u2019s as broad and silly as his and McKay\u2019s previous collaboration, but it also hints at McKay\u2019s later pivot to social commentary (he was a multiple Oscar nominee for \u201cThe Big Short\u201d). McKay sets this story in the so-called Red States, and subtly subverts both the conventional wisdom about that world and about those it sees as outsiders. To do all of that, while landing so many solid laughs, is no small accomplishment.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Jungle Book.\u201d Disney\n\n\u2018The Jungle Book\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: May 30\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 2016 family adventure from Jon Favreau uses astonishing advances in computer-generated animation to update the 1967 Disney animated classic (itself based on the stories of Rudyard Kipling). Unlike with \u201cCharlotte\u2019s Web,\u201d there wasn\u2019t much improvement to be made \u2014 but Favreau, who directed the first two \u201cIron Man\u201d movies, honors the original by keeping his remake faithful and honest, all the while coaxing out an emotional weight less easily conveyed by hand-drawn figures. Little Neel Sethi is both appealing and heartbreaking as young Mowgli, the \u201cman cub\u201d raised by the creatures of the jungle; Bill Murray\u2019s Baloo and Idris Elba\u2019s Shere Khan are the standouts of a stellar voice cast.\n\n\u2014", "title": "11 Great Titles Expiring From Netflix in May", "authors": ["Jason Bailey"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith this week\u2019s selection of titles, we put ourselves into the hands of experts: expert storytellers, expert thinkers, expert biographers of expert subjects. For instance? As the founding curator of the New York Public Library\u2019s photography collection, Julia Van Haaften is a leading authority on the city\u2019s rich photographic heritage \u2014 surely the right person to have produced the first major biography of Berenice Abbott, the larger-than-life artist who captured and defined New York City in some of the 20th century\u2019s most arresting images. Read that, and spend some time lingering over the photos. Also for instance: We recommend fiction by the celebrated masters Thomas McGuane and Richard Powers \u2014 whose new novel, \u201cThe Overstory,\u201d is reviewed by Barbara Kingsolver, speaking of experts \u2014 and nonfiction by Hannah Arendt (about politics), Barbara Ehrenreich (about mortality) and Ross Douthat (about the Catholic Church under Pope Francis). Other choices include a family memoir, a debut novel about a single gay mother, a ghost story and a Nordic thriller with shades of \u201cThe Silence of the Lambs.\u201d And if the Abbott biography gets you thinking about the character and destiny of cities, you might want to settle in with Ben Austen\u2019s \u201cHigh-Risers,\u201d about the ill-fated Cabrini-Green projects in Chicago. It\u2019s not a happy story, but it\u2019s an important one, and Austen, a journalist who frequently writes about urban planning and housing issues, tells it expertly and well.\n\nGregory Cowles\n\nSenior Editor, Books\n\nBERENICE ABBOTT: A Life in Photography, by Julia Van Haaften. (Norton, $45.) The photographer Berenice Abbott (1898-1991) was born in Ohio and fled to Greenwich Village after dropping out after one year at Ohio State University. In 1920s Paris, she took sensitive and indelible portraits of Jean Cocteau, James Joyce and others. After returning to New York, she became a revolutionary chronicler of the modern metropolis. Julia Van Haaften, the founding curator of the New York Public Library\u2019s photography collection, has written the first full-dress biography of her. \u201cThis is a vital work of American cultural history, and it wedges in so many personalities and vistas that it\u2019s hard to know where to begin,\u201d our critic Dwight Garner writes.\n\nNATURAL CAUSES: An Epidemic of Wellness, the Certainty of Dying, and Killing Ourselves to Live Longer, by Barbara Ehrenreich. (Twelve, $27.) At 76 years old, Barbara Ehrenreich has decided that she is old enough to die, and she has sworn off annual exams, cancer screenings and other measures those with health insurance are expected to take. \u201cNatural Causes\u201d takes aim at the wellness movement as a whole, at our tendency to treat aging as an outrage or, worse, as a sin. The book is \u201cpeevish, tender and deeply, distinctively odd,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes. \u201cThe pleasures of her prose are often local, in the animated language, especially where scientific descriptions are concerned. Her description of cells rushing to staunch a wound is so full of wonder and delight that it recalls Italo Calvino.\u201d\n\nFUTUREFACE: A Family Mystery, an Epic Quest, and the Secret to Belonging, by Alex Wagner. (One World, $28.) Alex Wagner was born in 1977, in Washington, D.C. The only child of a Burmese mother and a white American father, she grew up listening to histories of \u201cmigrations, escapes, settlement, assimilation.\u201d In \u201cFutureface,\u201d she embarks on a quest to find out as much as she can about both sides of her family, beyond the gauzy stories that have been handed down. The book \u201craises urgent questions having to do with history and complicity,\u201d our critic Jennifer Szalai writes. \u201cWagner is determined to look at her family with the coldest eye, making excuses for no one.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTHE OVERSTORY, by Richard Powers. (Norton, $27.95.) The science of botany and the art of storytelling merge to ingenious effect in Powers\u2019s magisterial new novel \u2014 a story in which people are merely the underbrush and the real protagonists are the trees that the human characters encounter. In her review, Barbara Kingsolver calls it a \u201cmonumental\u201d book, and notes that by following various characters as they interact with the forest, Powers \u201caccomplishes what few living writers from either camp, art or science, could attempt. Using the tools of story, he pulls readers heart-first into a perspective so much longer-lived and more subtly developed than the human purview that we gain glimpses of a vast, primordial sensibility, while watching our own kind get whittled down to size.\u201d", "title": "11 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "THE CHANDELIER, by Clarice Lispector. Translated from the Portuguese by Benjamin Moser and Magdalena Edwards. Edited by Benjamin Moser. (New Directions, $25.95.) Lispector\u2019s characteristically hypnotic second novel, originally published in 1946 in her native Brazil, has just been translated into English for the first time. \u201cNo one sounds like Lispector \u2014 in English or Portuguese. No one thinks like her,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes. The book, about the interior life of a young, unhappy woman named Virginia, is \u201cuniquely demanding \u2014 it\u2019s baggy, claggy and contentedly glacial,\u201d Sehgal writes, but it\u2019s also \u201ca vulnerable and moving performance \u2014 with a heart-stopping payoff.\u201d\n\nTHE STREET PHILOSOPHY OF GARRY WINOGRAND, by Geoff Dyer. (University of Texas Press, $60.) Dyer\u2019s latest book, physically imposing and visually sumptuous, pairs 100 brief essays by the author with 100 photographs by Garry Winogrand, including 18 color photographs previously unpublished. Winogrand, born in 1928, \u201ccaptured the fallout from the midcentury American moment \u2014 those few decades, from the 1950s on, when placid middle-class prosperity started to give way to something less affluent, more fragmented and harder to define,\u201d our critic Jennifer Szalai writes. \u201cDyer\u2019s accompanying texts wear their erudition lightly. He makes ample and appreciative use of Very Serious Ideas from the likes of Erich Fromm, Marshall Berman and Richard Sennett, but it\u2019s the specifics in the pictures themselves that most excite his imagination.\u201d\n\nTHE HOUSE OF BROKEN ANGELS, by Luis Alberto Urrea. (Little, Brown, $27.) In Urrea\u2019s sprawling, tender, funny and bighearted family saga, the de La Cruz clan gathers in San Diego to celebrate the 70th birthday of its patriarch, who is dying of cancer. \u201cUrrea is intent on both celebrating the particularities of Mexican-American life and attacking the anti-Mexican racism that has been a part of American culture ever since the United States conquered quite a bit of Mexico,\u201d Viet Thanh Nguyen writes in his review. \u201c\u201cWhat is Urrea\u2019s novel but a Mexican-American novel that is also an American novel? American in the broadest possible sense, from the United States of America, north of the border, to Mexico and by implication all of the other countries south of the border that are also American. The novel disrespects borders.\u201d\n\nTHE CADAVER KING AND THE COUNTRY DENTIST: A True Story of Injustice in the American South, by Radley Balko and Tucker Carrington. (PublicAffairs, $28.) Tracing the wrongful convictions of two men in Mississippi in the early 1990s, the authors ask whether problems in our justice system stem from basic incompetence, bald racism or both. \u201cJunk science convicted these men; real science set them free,\u201d our reviewer, Elie Mystal, writes. \u201cThe inability of judges and jurors to tell the difference is why innocent men languish in jail while the prosecutors who put them there run for higher office.\u201d\n\nFAREWELL TO THE HORSE: A Cultural History, by Ulrich Raulff. (Liveright, $35.) Raulff ranges far and wide to tell the story of the complicated relationship between humans and horses \u2014 an elegy that is labyrinthine in the varied places it goes, but never frustrating. \u201cHe layers fact over myth over military anecdote over personal memory over Darwin over Napoleon over Tolstoy over Gehlen until the book resembles an oil painting of outrageous complexity, so thickly laden with paint that it would take years to scrape down to its blank canvas,\u201d C. E. Morgan writes in her review. \u201cIt\u2019s a bold play, a kind of intellectual onslaught. \u2026 Raulff mostly succeeds and succeeds remarkably.\u201d", "title": "11 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nAre \u201csophomore slumps\u201d real? That\u2019s the question faced by this April\u2019s television lineup, as three highly acclaimed shows \u2014 HBO\u2019s \u201cWestworld,\u201d FX\u2019s \u201cLegion\u201d and Hulu\u2019s \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d \u2014 all try to follow stellar first seasons with equally strong second ones.\n\nOther questions to ask this month: Can \u201cBosch\u201d and \u201cBrockmire\u201d continue their under-the-radar excellence? Will work by the authors Ian McEwan and E.M. Forster translate well to the small screen? And can Netflix finally make a \u201cLost in Space\u201d that becomes must-see TV?\n\nThere\u2019s a lot to ponder this spring. Here\u2019s some of what\u2019s in store:\n\nBBC\n\n\u2018The Child in Time\u2019\n\nAired: April 1, on PBS\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBenedict Cumberbatch is both the star and a producer in this Masterpiece movie, based on an early Ian McEwan novel about a successful children\u2019s author whose child is abducted. Kelly Macdonald plays his estranged wife, who years after the kidnapping is having trouble coming to grips with what happened. \u201cThe Child in Time\u201d promises to touch on themes typical of McEwan\u2019s writing: contextualizing the extremes of human experience and showing how even the most mundane moments shape how we react to tragedy.\n\n\u2014\n\nABC Television Network\n\n\u2018The Crossing\u2019\n\nStarted: April 2, on ABC\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLike many sci-fi sagas, ABC\u2019s new time-travel drama \u201cThe Crossing\u201d uses a fantastical premise to comment on the real world of its time. Steve Zahn stars as a small-town Oregon sheriff who finds himself at the center of an unexpected crisis when dozens of strangers spontaneously appear on a nearby shore, claiming to be American refugees from a war they say will happen 180 years from now. As the visitors from the future share news of a divided world to come, the country of today grapples with how these newcomers \u2014 some of whom have special abilities \u2014 fit into an already fractious society.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nTBS\n\n\u2018The Last O.G.\u2019\n\nStarted: April 3, TBS\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nTracy Morgan returns to television in this broad but quietly ambitious sitcom, playing an ex-con who comes back to Brooklyn after 15 years in prison \u2014 only to find that both his old neighborhood and the culture at large are very different. \u201cThe Last O.G.\u201d was created in part by the newly minted Oscar-winner Jordan Peele; it also features Tiffany Haddish as the hero\u2019s ex-girlfriend, who tries to help him adjust \u2014 even though she has changed a lot, herself. This is ultimately Morgan\u2019s show, however, and it rises and falls on his character\u2019s alternately outraged and wistful reactions to a world where \u201cBrooklyn\u201d has become an adjective.\n\n\u2014\n\nMarvel Entertainment\n\n\u2018Legion\u2019 (Season 2)\n\nStarted: April 3, FX\n\nApril 3, FX Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe first season of this mind-bending Marvel Comics superhero show from FX introduced David Haller (played by Dan Stevens), a telekinetic mutant so powerful that he can\u2019t always tell whether he\u2019s mentally ill or he can actually warp reality with his mind. By the end of the first eight episodes, the hero and his allies had at least temporarily fended off the shadowy government agents and the supernatural villain hounding them. For Season 2, the writer-producer Noah Hawley plans to expand this quasi-psychedelic, prog-rock-inspired universe while taking further advantage of his appealingly eccentric supporting cast \u2014 which includes the magnificent Aubrey Plaza as a slippery chaos agent.\n\n\u2014\n\nSTARZ\n\n\u2018Howards End\u2019\n\nStarts: April 8, Starz\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe multi-Oscar-winning 1992 movie version of E.M. Forster\u2019s novel \u201cHowards End\u201d was one of the most popular films from the producing-directing-screenwriting team of Ismail Merchant, James Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, and it helped initiate a wave of high-class literary adaptations and period dramas. This new four-part TV mini-series \u2014 already acclaimed during its BBC run last year \u2014 was written by Kenneth Lonergan and stars Hayley Atwell as a freethinking aristocrat who attempts to bridge the gap between her old-money and working-class friends. As with the film and the book, the TV adaptation concerns the inequitable distribution of privilege, between classes and genders.\n\n\u2014\n\nBBC America\n\n\u2018Killing Eve\u2019\n\nStarts: April 8, BBC America\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe British writer and actor Phoebe Waller-Bridge is best-known for creating and starring in the slice-of-life comedy series \u201cFleabag,\u201d but her new show \u201cKilling Eve\u201d is a real change of pace. Based on the work of the novelist Luke Jennings, this cat-and-mouse thriller stars Sandra Oh as a meticulous secret agent whose latest assignment involves chasing down a skilled but psychopathic assassin (Jodie Comer) whom she secretly admires. Although \u201cKilling Eve\u201d is about two women trying to murder each other, expect Waller-Bridge to spend at least some time each episode exploring how people become trapped by their own senses of self.\n\n\u2014\n\nPrime Video\n\n\u2018Bosch\u2019 (Season 4)\n\nStarts: April 13, Amazon\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn its first season, this Amazon adaptation of the novelist Michael Connelly\u2019s Harry Bosch police procedurals came across more like a heavy prestige drama than the sophisticated genre show it was always meant to be. Seasons 2 and 3 corrected its course, leaning more on Connelly\u2019s clever plotting and his eclectic cast of characters, many of whom represent conflicting aspects of the Los Angeles criminal justice system. The sense that law and order in Los Angeles is a delicate structure held in place by bitter rivalries should be a prominent element of Season 4, which is based on the book \u201cAngels Flight,\u201d wherein Detective Bosch investigates the murder of a crusading, anti-cop attorney.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix\n\n\u2018Lost in Space\u2019\n\nStarts: April 13, Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe original 1960s version of \u201cLost in Space\u201d was cheap-looking and hopelessly square, but still found a devoted fan base, thanks in large part to its depiction of a loving family \u2014 and their helpful robot \u2014 surviving the universe\u2019s dangerous unknowns by sticking together. Judging from the early trailers, Netflix\u2019s remake is going to be much more special effects-driven, and hipper to boot, with Molly Parker taking the lead as the Robinson clan\u2019s matriarch and Parker Posey playing the morally ambiguous opportunist Dr. Smith.\n\n\u2014\n\nHBO\n\n\u2018Westworld\u2019 (Season 2)\n\nStarts: April 22, HBO\n\nApril 22, HBO Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nHBO has had a tough time producing another series as talked-about and internationally successful as \u201cGame of Thrones.\u201d But given how much chatter the first season of \u201cWestworld\u201d generated, it is likely that Season 2 \u2014 arriving nearly a year and a half later \u2014 could become a sensation. After a finale in December of 2016 that spilled some big secrets and shook up the power structure at the show\u2019s futuristic, robot-populated theme park, the story seems poised to move into another phase, expanding the action to incorporate new locations, new characters and new mysteries for fans to argue about online.\n\n\u2014\n\nIFC\n\n\u2018Brockmire\u2019 (Season 2)\n\nStarts: April 25, IFC\n\nApril 25, IFC Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne of the 2017 TV season\u2019s most pleasant surprises, the raunchy comedy \u201cBrockmire\u201d took what seemed like a thin concept \u2014 an alcoholic former major league baseball announcer tries to resuscitate his career in the minor leagues \u2014 and gave it unexpected depth and soul. Last year ended on a mini-cliffhanger, as that comeback threatened the budding romance between Jim Brockmire (Hank Azaria) with the woman who helped save him: a sports-loving small-town entrepreneur played by the excellent Amanda Peet. Fans of Season 1 are no doubt looking forward to more of Jim\u2019s rich-toned, colorfully phrased vulgarity, along with more of the show\u2019s nuanced understanding of what \u201csuccess\u201d means in 21st-century America.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nHulu\n\n\u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019 (Season 2)\n\nStarts: April 25, Hulu\n\nApril 25, Hulu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nSeason 2 of this Hulu adaptation of the dystopian novel by Margaret Atwood will have a hard time topping Season 1, which scored an Emmy for best drama series (unprecedented for a streaming series) and also became a relevant conversation piece in a year when sexist privilege made international headlines. But on the assumption that Elisabeth Moss will continue to give a superb performance as a sex slave in a theocratic society \u2014 and with Marisa Tomei, Cherry Jones and Clea DuVall joining the cast \u2014 there\u2019s plenty of reason to believe this show will keep going strong, even as it moves further beyond the source material.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cKing in the Wilderness\u201d (HBO, April 2), \u201cFamous in Love\u201d (Freeform, April 4), \u201cNational Treasure: Kiri\u201d (Hulu, April 4), \u201cJersey Shore Family Vacation\u201d (MTV, April 5), \u201cThe Boss Baby: Back in Business\u201d (Netflix, April 6), \u201cPaterno\u201d (HBO, April 7), \u201cAn American Murder Mystery: The Staircase\u201d (ID, April 8), \u201cUnforgotten\u201d (PBS, April 8), \u201cNew Girl\u201d (Fox, April 10), \u201cRellik\u201d (Cinemax, April 13), \u201cWyatt Cenac\u2019s Problem Areas\u201d (HBO, April 13), \u201cThe Circus\u201d (Showtime, April 15), \u201cFear the Walking Dead\u201d (AMC, April 15), \u201cCivilizations\u201d (PBS, April 17), \u201cInto the Badlands\u201d (AMC, April 22), \u201cThe 100\u201d (The CW, April 24), \u201cGenius\u201d (Nat Geo, April 24), \u201cArcher\u201d (FXX, April 25) and \u201cDancing With the Stars\u201d (ABC, April 30).", "title": "11 Shows We\u2019ll Be Talking About in April", "authors": ["Noel Murray"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "In April 2014, more than 200 girls were kidnapped from a school in Nigeria.
