International", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": ["Kaly Soto"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to the weekend. Is it spring yet? Doesn\u2019t look like it from where I\u2019m sitting. If it\u2019s still too cold (wet, dark, snowy) for a morning stroll, no worries. We\u2019ve got stories for you. Some are serious (about ISIS and private prisons) some are less so (imagining travel in Wakanda and sitting down with Grace Jones). Pick one or all 11. Who knows, by the time you\u2019re finished reading, the sun might be out.", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "INTERSTATE PROJECTS through May 6; 66 Knickerbocker Avenue, Bushwick, interstateprojects.org. At this gallery, the only spot of color in Cindy Ji Hye Kim\u2019s punchy mixed-media show \u201cCelibate Machine\u201d \u2014 aside from a glowing red \u201cExit\u201d sign in the bunkerlike basement space \u2014 is a small pink silicone brick cast inside a can of Spam. Otherwise, everything, from a wall-size graphite reproduction of Pieter Bruegel\u2019s \u201cThe Parable of the Blind,\u201d minus the people, to a short video loop of a kissing couple who have been rotoscoped into pulsing clouds, is in black and white. But by complicating an otherwise chilly investigation of cultural identity and depersonalized violence, that bit of pink makes all the difference.\n\nSIGNAL through May 6; 260 Johnson Avenue, Bushwick, ssiiggnnaall.com. Performing together under the name FlucT, Sigrid Lauren and Monica Mirabile choreograph movements and expressions that reside in the intense, confusing and all-too-relevant space where sex and violence overlap. In the best of the mind-bending videos in this show \u2014 it plays on a screen mounted inside a doghouse \u2014 they also recite fragments of text that ricochet between existential inquiry and self-help-style command. (My favorite example was \u201cDrop your shoulder and sacrifice your behavior out the mousehole!\u201d) If you survive the passage through these disorienting amplifications of the American psyche, you\u2019ll find in the gallery\u2019s back room a serene concurrent show of extraordinary red ballpoint-pen drawings by Fin Simonetti. \u201cHearth (7),\u201d in particular, which depicts a sheet of loose-leaf paper \u201cwatermarked\u201d with a highly detailed cow, is a technical tour de force.\n\nMOTEL through May 6; 1078 DeKalb Avenue, Bedford-Stuyvesant, bkmotel.org. This space is featuring Harry Gould Harvey IV\u2019s intricate and peculiar driftwood dioramas \u2014 tramp art \u00e0 la Brancusi. Using foraged clay, medium-density fiberboard and driftwood collected on the islands of Narragansett Bay, off Rhode Island, Mr. Harvey builds square towers, miniature biers and complicated arrangements of less identifiable shapes that are studded with thimble-size clay heads. One square tower, its base surrounded by red and green moss, is topped with a cross, a head and a tiny cloud of words, lettered in charcoal, about our present political confusion.", "title": "12 Galleries to Visit Now in Brooklyn and Queens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Chelsea may be the New York art neighborhood that many people love to disdain. It also may be approaching a tipping point, where new apartment towers outnumber galleries. But the place is not monolithic. Its scores of galleries come in all shapes, sizes and annual budgets, and as usual they offer a ton of art to be seen. Here is but a small sample.\n\nTHE KITCHEN through May 12; 512 West 19th Street, thekitchen.org. Chelsea\u2019s busiest, most multimedia alternative space is presenting the outstanding \u201cCharles Atlas: the past is here, the futures are coming.\u201d It reviews the long, often brilliant career of Mr. Atlas, who has few equals when it comes to blurring the lines among art, documentary, dance and film. Eight video collaborations made from 1982 to 2016 with different choreographers dazzle with their different camerawork and editing \u2014 especially those created with Michael Clark and Yvonne Rainer. The centerpiece is \u201c2003,\u201d an enormous five-channel-video montage of Mr. Atlas\u2019s dance films and various interviews and current events, like the Iraq war. The totality equals a crash course in New York choreographic history that reveals an ingenious symbiosis of dance and film.\n\nMICHAEL ROSENFELD GALLERY through June 2; 100 11th Avenue, michaelrosenfeldart.com. Claire Falkenstein (1908-1997), who, outside her native California, has never had a full-scale retrospective in this country, is generally known for her exquisitely excessive sculptures dating from the mid-1950s \u2014 welded metal tangles embedded with bright pieces of Venetian glass. \u201cClaire Falkenstein: Matter in Motion\u201d explodes this narrow view with nearly 50 works, introducing a relentless exploration of abstraction in early paintings on canvas and also curved perforated aluminum; sculptures of wood and glazed ceramics; and one fantastic mixed-media relief. Her dialogue with artists like David Smith and Jackson Pollock is but one fascination. More rewriting of art history, please.", "title": "12 Galleries to Visit Now in Chelsea", "authors": ["Roberta Smith"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s more, they don\u2019t all look like, say, someone akin to the Comic Book Guy on \u201cThe Simpsons.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou will see everybody here,\u201d Ms. McCoy predicted. \u201cThe last one, we had kids in theater, senior citizens in the theater, and they stayed up the entire time.\u201d And she was right \u2014 there wasn\u2019t a dominant sex, race, or age in the theater. The only thing everyone had in common was that they love these movies.\n\nAs day turned into night, some slept, as I did, slumped in their upright chair, airplane-style. Taking advantage of neighbors who had slipped out, some curled up on a series of empty seats. Others simply hit the floor, with backpacks and jackets as makeshift pillows and blankets. The overnight movies were complemented by the soft buzz of snoring, and the silence between lines was occasionally punctured by the pop of a particularly loud snort, which drew a chuckle from the bleary-eyed souls who were still awake.", "title": "12 Marvel Movies in 31 Hours. It Didn\u2019t Feel Like Infinity.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Tom Bianchi, Photographer\n\nMy building, a brown brick on East Ninth Street between University Place and Broadway, was like all the others built at that time. It wasn\u2019t extravagant by any means, so I set about making adjustments to it. I plate-mirrored one wall of the living room and turned it into an art gallery. Egon von Furstenberg came for a party one night and said, \u201cOne would never imagine an apartment like this in a building like this!\u201d I said, \u201cWell, I\u2019ll take the left-handed compliment.\u201d Then Donald Sterzin [the art director of GQ] picked up on it and organized a story on the space for GQ. I knew when that happened that I was going to have to come out publicly. As one friend said to me, \u201cTom, who\u2019s going to look at those pictures and see the bowl of tulips on the pedestal under a perfect down spot and not know?\u201d\n\nImage A bill for production work completed by Eric Goode in 1979. Inset: Goode in his 49 Walker Street loft, circa 1979. Credit Courtesy of Eric Goode\n\nThe Day Jobs They Worked\n\nRosie Perez, Actress\n\nI started working when I was about 10 years old. I was back and forth from the group home in upstate New York, and I would do people\u2019s lawns, clean out their garages, babysit, really anything. I used to do well. I would make $10 for babysitting, $5 for raking leaves. My first major job was at Wyckoff Hospital, and I didn\u2019t like it. I was hired to transcribe medical records via Dictaphone. I could type really fast in high school \u2014 90 words per minute. I wish I still had my first paycheck, because I was so proud. Going to the bank to cash it, I felt like such a grown-up. I was a hustler even back then.\n\nThurston Moore, Musician\n\nAt this point in my life I knew I wanted to make records, but I didn\u2019t know how to make them. I found a job in the back of the New York Post asking for a shipping clerk. I went up there and it was Masterdisk, a place that cut records \u2014 people like Frank Zappa or Bryan Ferry would come in. So I got to see how it worked. I\u2019d take the acetates of the records and deliver them to different places in midtown, like RCA Studios. The more I got involved with my band, the Coachmen, and then Sonic Youth, though \u2014 well it prohibited me from having a very cogent day job. I kept not going to work. And there was no way to contact me, because I couldn\u2019t afford a telephone. Eventually I would go in and sheepishly say, \u201cI\u2019m sorry.\u201d They kind of liked me and would let it go, but at some point they let me go. Then, by maybe the third or fourth Sonic Youth album, we had a good enough profile where we could actually use a really good mastering studio: Masterdisk. It was kind of like, welcome back.\n\nEric Goode, Entrepreneur\n\nMy roommate, Shawn Hausman, and I worked for Steve Mass, designing different spaces in the Mudd Club. We\u2019d have these absurd hours: painting a Renaissance ceiling in the basement at 4 in the morning. We also worked on movies, because Shawn\u2019s father was in the industry. We\u2019d stay out all night and then go and do location scouting or production work on different films. When there wasn\u2019t film work we would do what you would call art directing work for other nightclubs, including Studio 54 and Danceteria, before starting our own. The motivation in those days was definitely not money. We were just barely surviving.\n\nAndre Walker, Fashion Designer\n\nI made quite a few friends selling T-shirts outside of my mom\u2019s store in Brooklyn, pulling kids off the street to participate in my fashion shows. I was selling T-shirts from 11 years old. I would hand-paint them, cut them, fringe them \u2014 what I would see people in the Village doing when I was much younger. Then I started cutting fabric and gluing it together with Magic Stitch and, eventually, sewing. We had a big house, so it was very, \u201cLet\u2019s go to my house and get dressed up, wear clothes and take photos.\u201d That would be an after-school activity, listening to everything from Polyrock to Gang of Four to LiLiPUT to Siouxsie and the Banshees, Echo & the Bunnymen, you name it. I was making $100 on a slow day, because usually I\u2019d sell at least 10 or 15 T-shirts, so I always had money on me. My mom used to hide money everywhere. I was definitely doing research at the homestead, looking for the places she was putting extra cash.", "title": "13 Celebrated New Yorkers on Their Early \u201980s Apartments and Jobs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "While there was no shortage of memorable projects on view during last week\u2019s Salone Internazionale del Mobile fair in Milan, possibly the biggest thing that stood out this year was the turnout. A crush of visitors and locals alike descended to experience exhibitions and product launches occupying storefronts and palazzos throughout the city, creating lines that stretched along hallways, into courtyards and, in one case, all the way down three very long flights of stairs. Perhaps it was the picture-perfect spring weather that drove the crowd \u2014 but more likely it\u2019s the current popularity of contemporary design. And, judging by these highlights from the fair, is it any wonder?", "title": "13 Great Things We Saw at Milan\u2019s Design Fair", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the group that monitors compliance with an international chemical weapons treaty, said on Tuesday that it intended to send a team to Douma to investigate, which would depend on the cooperation of the Syrian government. The allegation of chemical weapons use this week in Douma has been based on the symptoms exhibited by victims; in past incidents, confirmation has depended on outside groups like the organization conducting laboratory tests on samples taken from the scene.\n\nThe wave of refugees from eastern Ghouta, an area with hundreds of thousands of civilians, is the latest in a war that has displaced millions of people, and the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on Tuesday voiced alarm at the surging numbers of casualties and people driven from their homes.\n\nTens of thousands of civilians remain trapped in eastern Ghouta, and relief agencies are just beginning to grasp the full extent of humanitarian needs in an area where years of siege have created desperate levels of malnutrition among children and shortages of medicines.\n\n\u201cOnly a monster targets civilians and then ensures that there are no ambulances to transfer the wounded, no hospitals to save their lives, no doctors or medicine to ease their pain,\u201d Nikki R. Haley, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said on Monday.\n\nIn a statement released on Tuesday, Mohammad Javad Zarif, Iran\u2019s foreign minister, called the American position hypocritical, noting that the United States supported Iraq in the 1980s, when it used chemical weapons against its own population and against Iran. Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cthreats to repeat impulsive acts of aggression is symptomatic of U.S. policy helping extremists,\u201d Mr. Zarif said.", "title": "133,000 Flee Besieged Syrian Towns in Eastern Ghouta, U.N. Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "DJANGO FESTIVAL ALL-STARS at Carnegie Hall (May 1, 8 p.m.). The Django Festival All-Stars go a little bit beyond celebrating their namesake, Django Reinhardt, the Romani French guitarist known as gypsy jazz\u2019s main hero. Their songbook includes many items from Reinhardt\u2019s repertoire, as well as originals by the group\u2019s own band members inspired by the broader field of early 20th-century jazz. At this concert, the founding bandleader Dorado Schmitt will pass the All-Stars\u2019 mantle to his sons Samson and Amati, who are both guitarists. The show features appearances from a few special guests, including the vocalist Melody Gardot and the clarinetist Ken Peplowski.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nINTERNATIONAL WOMEN IN JAZZ FESTIVAL at St. Peter\u2019s Church (April 28, 1 p.m.). Charenee Wade\u2019s warm voice can swing easily from the earthy to the seraphic. She\u2019s the headlining performer at this daylong festival, which begins with an early-afternoon jam session and also includes appearances by the vocalist Debbie Goodridge and the pianist Dotti Anita Taylor. The young vocalist Kameelah Harper, the winner of the International Women in Jazz Youth in Action prize, will also perform.\n\n212-560-7553, internationalwomeninjazz.org\n\nJUNEBUG FESTIVAL at Happylucky No. 1 (May 2-4, 8 p.m.). Situated in the heart of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, this art gallery and performance space has recently become a reliable presenter of experimental improvised music, often engaging some of New York\u2019s top talent. The Junebug Festival is a prime example: Over three days, the gallery will welcome two ensembles each night, including Amirtha Kidambi\u2019s explosive quartet, Elder Ones, on Wednesday; the hyperarticulate guitarist Liberty Ellman\u2019s trio on Thursday; and the renowned bassist Reggie Workman in an intriguing trio with the electronic musician Ikue Mori and the flutist Redi Fern\u00e1ndez on May 4.\n\n646-623-0414, happyluckyno1.com\n\nARTURO O\u2019FARRILL AND FRIENDS at New York City Center (April 28, 8 p.m.). The five-day \u00a1Adelante, Cuba! Festival ends with a gathering of major talents from across the spectrum of Cuban performance. At the helm is the pianist Mr. O\u2019Farrill, whose Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra will serve as the house band. Also taking the stage are the poet and rapper Telmary Diaz, the vocalist Omara Portuondo, the pianist Roberto Fonseca, the all-female string orchestra Camerata Romeu, the trumpet player Yasek Manzano and the tap artist Ayodele Casel.\n\n212-581-1212, nycitycenter.org\n\nCHUCHO VALD\u00c9S at the Blue Note (through April 29 and May 1-6, 8 and 10:30 p.m.). Earlier this week, Mr. Vald\u00e9s, a Latin jazz patriarch, began an extended run at the Blue Note that will find him flexing his powers in a variety of contexts. Through Sunday, he performs with a midsize ensemble, celebrating the 45th anniversary of the founding of Irakere, his watershed Cuban fusion band. On Tuesday and Wednesday, he\u2019s joined by the trumpeter Roy Hargrove and the vocalist Roberta Gambarini; on Thursday, he performs alone; and from May 4 to 6, he\u2019ll be accompanied by Ron Carter. (The drummer Lenny White joins Mr. Vald\u00e9s and Mr. Carter for the last two dates, with the violinist Regina Carter coming aboard for the final evening.)\n\n212-475-8592, bluenote.net\n\nDARRYL YOKLEY at Smoke (May 3, 7, 9 and 10:30 p.m.). Mr. Yokley, an enterprising young tenor saxophonist, composed each of the 13 tunes for his new album, \u201cPictures at an African Exhibition,\u201d in collaboration with the artist David Emmanuel Noel, who painted a different canvas for each tune. Recorded with a large ensemble, the music has a hustling, declaratory spirit and a broadly Pan-African take on acoustic jazz, with touchstones spanning from the Antilles to the Eastern Cape of South Africa. He celebrates the release with a quartet featuring the brothers Zaccai and Luques Curtis \u2014 whose Truth Revolution Records released the album \u2014 on piano and bass, and Mark Whitfield II on drums.\n\n212-864-6662, smokejazz.com\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "CAROLINE DAVIS at the Jazz Gallery (April 13, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Davis, an alto saxophonist, arrived in New York a few years ago by way of Chicago, and last month she released her third album, \u201cHeart Tonic,\u201d an impressive collection of twisty, chattering originals performed by a spry quintet. Ms. Davis will play music from that disc here with the rhythm section from that band \u2014 Julian Shore on piano, Tamir Shmerling on bass and Jay Sawyer on drums \u2014 as well as Noah Preminger on tenor saxophone.\n\n646-494-3625, jazzgallery.nyc\n\nFESTIVAL OF MALI at Brooklyn Bowl (April 14-16, 8 p.m.). The offerings at this three-night festival provide a cross sample of the country\u2019s music \u2014 from the kinetic churn of the Songha\u00ef vocalist and guitarist Sidi Tour\u00e9 on Saturday to the gentler admonishments of the griot supergroup Trio Da Kali on Sunday. The series closes on Monday with Fatoumata Diawara, a beguiling talent on vocals and guitar whose music splits the difference between the other two headliners while admitting folk influences from around the world.\n\nbrooklynbowl.com\n\nTERRACE MARTIN AND FRIENDS at National Sawdust (April 13, 8 p.m.). Mr. Martin has no problem weaving a contemporary Angeleno sound out of the common thread that already runs through 1970s jazz-funk and 1990s G-funk. An enterprising multi-instrumentalist, he primarily plays the saxophone; his signature sound is a high, zigzagging squeal. But Mr. Martin has also become one of Los Angeles\u2019s most sought-after producers, working with Herbie Hancock, Kendrick Lamar and a growing list of other pop and hip-hop stars. It\u2019s less common for him to lead his own band, let alone in New York. Catch him here at the helm of a talented group featuring James Francies on keyboards, James Genus on bass and Marcus Gilmore on drums.\n\n646-779-8455, nationalsawdust.org\n\nCHRISTIAN MCBRIDE\u2019S NEW JAWN at Dizzy\u2019s Club Coca-Cola (through April 15, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Mr. McBride has more clean, fastidious power than almost any other bassist around \u2014 it makes him a kind of dream sideman. But most of his creative energy these days gets spent on his own ensembles, and the most recent of them is a big winner. The New Jawn quartet has a roguish, brawny sound, sprung from the earthy drumming of Nasheet Waits and the sharp-elbowed horn playing of Josh Evans on trumpet and J. D. Allen on tenor saxophone (on previous engagements, the saxophonist has been Marcus Strickland).\n\n212-258-9595, jazz.org/dizzys\n\nPHAROAH SANDERS at Le Poisson Rouge (April 19, 8 p.m.). A doyen of spiritual jazz, Mr. Sanders is known for his mantralike compositions, often featuring no more than two chords and a repetitious theme. They tend to open onto acres of space where the tenor saxophonist can improvise and conjure. At 77, Mr. Sanders \u2014 an N.E.A. Jazz Master \u2014 still performs with ardor, often singing as well as blowing the horn. And on jazz standards he can still channel the beaming, late-1950s sound of his mentor, John Coltrane.\n\n212-505-3474, lpr.com\n\nSFJAZZ COLLECTIVE at Jazz Standard (through April 15, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Since its founding in 2004, this rotating all-star band has focused on the catalog of a different modern composer every year, interrogating and rearranging their tunes. But the current season is about taking stock of the collective\u2019s own book \u2014 by now quite an overstuffed volume. On Friday, the group will release a double-disc collection featuring originals by its members, as well as new takes on arrangements from past seasons. At Jazz Standard, the group will play some of those originals, as well as its versions of pieces by Miles Davis, the collective\u2019s 2016 honoree. The group\u2019s current lineup features the tenor saxophonist David S\u00e1nchez, the trumpeter Sean Jones, the vibraphonist Warren Wolf, the alto saxophonist Miguel Zen\u00f3n, the trombonist Robin Eubanks, the pianist Edward Simon, the bassist Matt Penman and the drummer Obed Calvaire.\n\n212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "THE MESSTHETICS at the Bell House (April 20, 8 p.m.). There are two story lines for the Messthetics: It\u2019s a reunion band, bringing together the bassist Joe Lally and the drummer Brendan Canty from Fugazi, an iconic Washington, D.C., post-punk ensemble; and it\u2019s a place of ascent for Anthony Pirog, an extravagantly creative young guitarist hailing from Fugazi\u2019s hometown. And the music that this trio creates has a double identity, too: sometimes a tangle of electric laceration, elsewhere an ethereal sprawl.\n\nthebellhouseny.com\n\nNICHOLAS PAYTON QUARTET at Smoke (April 20-22, 7, 9 and 10:30 p.m.). Mr. Payton has gone from being a straight-ahead jazz prodigy from New Orleans to an advocate for a pan-African musical approach, and a restless experimenter in his own right (case in point: his most recent album, \u201cAfro-Caribbean Mixtape\u201d). He performs here with Taylor Eigsti on piano, Barry Stephenson on bass and Jonathan Barber on drums \u2014 a band suggesting that Mr. Payton will be leaning toward the acoustic-jazz side of his sound.\n\n212-864-6662, smokejazz.com\n\nSOF\u00cdA REI at the Stone (April 24-28, 8:30 p.m.). Ms. Rei, a vocalist hailing from Argentina, sings in a windblown, mountains-high voice, but she often sounds like she might be withholding something, too. It\u2019s as if maybe the full delivery might be too overpowering \u2014 an engrossing suggestion. On Tuesday, Ms. Rei will perform a portion of John Zorn\u2019s newly released, 11-volume collection, \u201cThe Book Beriah,\u201d the closing installment of his epic \u201cMasada\u201d series. On Wednesday, she performs material from her own most recent album, a dedication to the Chilean folk icon Violeta Parra. On Thursday, she presents a gathering of eight vocalists titled \u201cSlides, Stills & Snapshots.\u201d\n\nthestonenyc.com\n\nTOMEKA REID QUARTET at the Jewish Museum (April 26, 7:30 p.m.). When playing in a swing rhythm, Ms. Reid creates a flow with her cello that\u2019s tensile and quick \u2014 like so much free jazz of the 1970s and \u201980s \u2014 but also earthy and more sturdily organized. Her playing has a sandpapery warmth and a stately power, and often a thick backbone of funk. Here she performs with Mary Halvorson on guitar, Jason Roebke on bass and Tomas Fujiwara on drums, the quartet behind a strong self-titled album from 2015. The concert is presented through a partnership between the Jewish Museum and Bang on a Can.\n\n212-423-3337, thejewishmuseum.org\n\nMATANA ROBERTS at the Park Avenue Armory (April 24, 7 and 9 p.m.). Ms. Roberts is an alto saxophonist with a big, blooming tone. She\u2019s also a historically minded conceptualist, digging deeply into the workings of memory and taking up arms against the present-day traumas that will haunt us in the years ahead. Her primary musical form is the long suite, but recently she\u2019s also solidified a visual art practice. Ms. Roberts is represented by the Fridman Gallery in Lower Manhattan, where her second solo exhibition, \u201cJump at the Sun,\u201d is on view through Wednesday. In the mixed-media works presented there, she uses combinations of sound, musical scores, old photographs and other collaged items. This concert, uptown at the Park Avenue Armory, coincides with the closing of that show and features Ms. Roberts joined by a poet known as Geng and a sextet of snare drummers.\n\n212-616-3930, armoryonpark.org\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO\n\nEditor\u2019s Pick\n\nBC35 RECORD RELEASE SHOW at St. Vitus (April 20, 7 p.m.). Thirty-five years ago, in an old factory space in Gowanus, Brooklyn, the producer and musician Martin Bisi established BC Studio, where he\u2019s has been at the controls for underground classics such as Sonic Youth\u2019s \u201cBad Moon Rising\u201d and the Dresden Dolls\u2019 self-titled debut. Fittingly, Mr. Bisi is honoring this anniversary with a righteous racket: first by releasing a compilation with bands he has produced, as well as some he put together and one that was resurrected for the occasion, and then by celebrating that album with those groups at clubs in Brooklyn, Boston and Philadelphia. This Greenpoint stop will feature New Old Skull, a reunion of members of Live Skull; Excop, an improvisational instrumental collusion between the bassist Algis Kizys (Swans, Foetus, Of Cabbages and Kings) and three members of Cop Shoot Cop (Jack Nantz on bass, Phil Puleo on percussion and Jim Coleman on electronics); Nowhere Near, with Mr. Bisi on guitar, Bob Bert (Sonic Youth, Lydia Lunch) on drums, Ryan SkeletonBoy (the Art Gray Noizz Quintet) on bass, and Ivan Lip (Pop. 1280) and Alyse Lamb (Parlor Walls) on guitar; as well as the psychedelic churn of White Hills and the sonic abrasiveness of Tidal Channel. The evening promises to be ear-splittingly glorious, so you might want to bring protection \u2014 or just savor the tinnitus later.\n\n877-987-6487, saintvitusbar.com\n\nDANIELLE DOWLING", "title": "14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nArchaeologists in northern Peru say they have found evidence of what could be one of the world\u2019s largest single cases of child sacrifice.\n\nThe pre-Columbian burial site, known as Las Llamas, contains the skeletons of 140 children who were between the ages of 5 and 14 when they were ritually sacrificed during a ceremony about 550 years ago, experts who led the excavation told The Associated Press on Friday.\n\nThe site, located near the modern day city of Trujillo, also contained the remains of 200 young llamas apparently sacrificed on the same day.\n\nThe burial site was apparently built by the ancient Chimu empire. It is thought the children were sacrificed as floods caused by the El Ni\u00f1o weather pattern ravaged the Peruvian coastline.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey were possibly offering the gods the most important thing they had as a society, and the most important thing is children because they represent the future,\u201d said Gabriel Prieto, an archaeology professor at the National University of Trujillo, who has led the excavation, along with John Verano of Tulane University.", "title": "140 Skeletons Discovered at Site of Mass Child Sacrifice in Peru", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "HUMBOLDT, Saskatchewan \u2014 Update: An earlier version of this article, relying on incorrect information from the Office of the Chief Coroner of Saskatchewan, misidentified one of the victims killed in the crash. They went out to lunch on occasion and became friends before romance struck in August 1986, at a restaurant in White Plains.\n\n\u201cShe was smart, kind, sweet, vivacious and loved life in the way that I loved life,\u201d said Mr. Veras, who was 35 at the time and working in Manhattan as the coordinating producer of \u201cThe N.F.L. Today\u201d show and \u201cCBS Sports Saturday/Sunday.\u201d\n\n\u201cI went over to the side of the table and kissed her,\u201d he said, \u201cand the magic began.\u201d\n\nMs. Gallas, a graduate of Ohio State University, said that Mr. Veras, who graduated from New York University, where he also received a master\u2019s degree in public administration and an M.B.A., was \u201cincredibly magnetic and focused.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe was also very intelligent, very dynamic and assertive,\u201d she said. \u201cI really enjoyed being with him, it put me in a certain comfort zone.\u201d\n\nThey began dating steadily and married at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, N.Y.\n\nIn the ensuing years, they expanded their family by having two more sons of their own.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFaith and family are the biggest parts of our lives,\u201d Ms. Gallas said. \u201cThat\u2019s what has kept us anchored for so long.\u201d\n\nThey traveled around the globe, visiting, among other countries, Greece (their ancestral home), Australia and China.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTo me, those are just places,\u201d Mr. Veras said. \u201cThe real journey that we have been on is our life journey, which over the years has always seemed to turn a new adventurous corner that deepens our love.\u201d\n\nMr. Veras, who eventually left CBS to start his own television production company, landed a job in 2005 as the vice president of marketing and production for the Cleveland Browns, which took the couple back to the city where each had family roots. (At that time, Ms. Gallas\u2019s parents lived in Brecksville, Ohio, and her father was a Federal U.S. Magistrate Judge in Cleveland.)\n\nFour years later, Mr. Veras took another job, becoming the chief operating officer and executive producer at the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio.\n\nLast month, Ms. Gallas and Mr. Veras\u2019 journey turned yet another adventurous corner: They became grandparents.\n\n\u201cIn order to get as far as we have in life you have to be open with your partner, you have to address any disagreement in openness but you need to do it with an attitude of \u2018how do we get to a better place?\u2019\u201d Mr. Veras said. \u201cWhen you marry, two become one, but to make that happen you have to give up some of yourself.\u201d\n\nThough that may sound straightforward, translating it into a 30-year marriage is another thing entirely. How About 30 Years of Happiness?", "authors": ["Vincent M. Mallozzi"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018TRANSFERS\u2019 at the Lucille Lortel Theater (in previews; opens on April 23). Getting out of the South Bronx and into a great college isn\u2019t just a matter of geography. In Lucy Thurber\u2019s play, directed by Jackson Gay, two young men are vying for a place in spite of present circumstances and past actions. The production stars Juan Castano and Ato Blankson-Wood, a standout in last summer\u2019s \u201cAs You Like It.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, mcctheater.org\n\n\u2018TRAVESTIES\u2019 at the American Airlines Theater (in previews; opens on April 24). If you stopped into a Zurich cafe for r\u00f6sti in 1917, you might have run into James Joyce. Or Vladmir Lenin. Or Tristan Tzara. In Tom Stoppard\u2019s wildly erudite historical comedy, great men dash in and out of a Wildean romp loosely based on coincidence. When Patrick Marber\u2019s production, starring Tom Hollander, ran in London, Matt Wolf praised its \u201cmind-bending splendor.\u201d\n\n212-719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018FLIGHT\u2019 at the McKittrick Hotel (closes on April 20). The young boys at the heart of this theater piece in miniature from Vox Motus reach the end of their hazardous journey. Laura Collins-Hughes wrote, \u201cThough enchanting sounds like the wrong word for a work of art as intrinsically painful and political as \u2018Flight,\u2019 enchanting it is.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, mckittrickhotel.com\n\n\u2018OLD STOCK\u2019 at 59E59 (closes on April 22). Created by Hannah Moscovitch, Ben Caplan and Christian Barry, and based on the lives of Ms. Moscovitch\u2019s great-grandparents, the play is \u201ca reminder \u2014 salutary, obvious \u2014 that there\u2019s a face behind each immigration form.\u201d\n\n212-279-4200, 59e59.org\n\n\u2018PAY NO ATTENTION TO THE GIRL\u2019 at the Doxsee (closes on April 21). Consider a disco nap \u2014 or, more appropriately, a techno nap \u2014 before heading out to this D.J. set from the British electronic producer Daniel Avery. He\u2019s scheduled to keep spinning records through last call until 5 a.m. the next morning. With a new album, \u201cSong for Alpha,\u201d arriving the day of the show, Mr. Avery should have no shortage of material.\n\n718-349-2373, goodroombk.com\n\nBRANDI CARLILE at the Beacon Theater (April 6-7, 8 p.m.). This singer-songwriter has carved out an enviable niche over the past decade-plus on the higher levels of contemporary folk-rock and country music. Her most recent album, \u201cBy the Way, I Forgive You,\u201d features grand orchestral arrangements by the late Paul Buckmaster and songs that exemplify the frank, deeply felt storytelling that has won Ms. Carlile many devoted fans (including, but not limited to, at least one former president).\n\n800-745-3000, beacontheatre.com\n\nHELADO NEGRO AND SNEAKS at Elsewhere (April 9, 8 p.m.). Roberto Carlos Lange, the Floridian musician who performs as Helado Negro, makes invitingly smudged synth-pop. The best songs from his 2016 album, \u201cPrivate Energy\u201d \u2014 \u201cLengua Larga,\u201d \u201cYoung, Latin and Proud\u201d \u2014 sound like they might contain vast worlds, even when Mr. Lange is the only musician present. His opening act at this show uses similar instrumentation but couldn\u2019t be more different in tone: Eva Moolchan, a.k.a. Sneaks, practices a rigorously minimal form of post-punk that borders on ascetic.\n\nelsewherebrooklyn.com", "title": "15 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "The good news for anyone who finds the Tribeca Film Festival daunting is that the event, which starts Wednesday, is about the same size as last year\u2019s slimmed-down edition \u2014 not that that\u2019s terribly slim. At 101 new features, the program is smaller than Sundance\u2019s was in January but larger than the typical official selection at Cannes, which takes place in May.\n\nWithout the auteurs or marquee titles of those festivals, Tribeca can leave the average moviegoer lost for guidance. Plot summaries aren\u2019t much use, given that the festival often appears to have two films for every premise. (Interested in a satire about buffoons who try to market an absurd product in China? You have options.)\n\nThe only way to find good movies at Tribeca is to watch them. That task requires long hours, an unflagging optimism that the next film might be a masterpiece and, mostly, a colossal stubborn streak. I\u2019ve seen 40 new fiction features and documentaries and sampled about two dozen more. Here, in honor of the festival\u2019s 17th year, are 17 titles I enjoyed.", "title": "17 Movies to Enjoy for the Tribeca Film Festival\u2019s 17th Edition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Most of them were not yet born when students shot a dozen people to death inside Columbine High School in Colorado, an atrocity that sparked a national debate over guns exactly 19 years ago.\n\nBut on Friday, on the anniversary of the April 20, 1999, shooting, the several thousand high school students who walked out of schools across the city and beyond to rally against guns in Manhattan said they felt they lived in a world of near-constant Columbines.\n\nThe teenagers spoke angrily of active shooter drills since kindergarten, of backpack and locker searches, of mock lockdowns sitting in silence in classrooms with the lights turned out, as they gathered in protest in Washington Square Park. And they spoke of the numbing barrage of school shootings in America \u2014 by some counts more than 200 in the past two decades.\n\n[See photos of Friday\u2019s student walkouts in cities across the United States.]\n\nCaroline Castellano, 16, a sophomore at Hunter College High School in Manhattan, had only just recently heard the name Columbine. \u201cSo I did the classic internet search,\u201d she said. \u201cIt really freaked me out really quickly.\u201d Near her, with a pink Post-it note with the word \u201cvictim\u201d written on it on her forehead, stood Kathya Rodriguez, 16, a sophomore at the High School of Fashion Industries, a public school in Chelsea.", "title": "19 Years After Columbine, Students Again Say \u2018Enough\u2019 on Gun Violence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "AMERICAN FRONT, FRANCE, April 18 \u2014 Presentation of the Croix de Guerre to Lieutenants Alan F. Winslow and Douglas Campbell was made to-day by the French. The formality took place in the presence of several French and American officers and caused embarrassment to the Americans who, on Sunday last, brought down two German aeroplanes in the nick of time.\n\nThe French officers complimented the youthful aviators and said that it was noted by the French that the distinguishing medal went to a man from each of the two American universities known to everyone in Europe \u2014 Yale and Harvard. Winslow is from Yale and Campbell from Harvard.\n\nWhen the correspondent asked the aviators if they had a message which they would like to send to the home folk through the HERALD, they said: \u201cNothing in particular. We suppose our own folk will hear of it, won\u2019t they? That\u2019s all that\u2019s necessary.\u201d\n\nThe correspondent assured them that without doubt all the American folk had heard of it already.\n\nLieutenant Winslow, when asked if he had been excited by the experience, said: \u201cNo. But I am a little afraid to wake up in the morning, for fear that it\u2019s all a dream.\u201d", "title": "1918: American Heroes Honored in France", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "ASTRAL WEEKS\n\nA Secret History of 1968\n\nBy Ryan H. Walsh\n\nIllustrated. 357 pp. Penguin Press. $27.\n\nIn 2015, the musician and journalist Ryan H. Walsh published an article in Boston magazine about \u201cthe untold story of how Van Morrison fled record-industry thugs, hid out in Boston and wrote one of rock\u2019s greatest albums.\u201d The album was the sylvan, ineffably spiritual \u201cAstral Weeks,\u201d released in 1968, when Morrison was 23. Walsh\u2019s article included less-than-sylvan details about cash handoffs to gangsters, someone smashing an acoustic guitar over Morrison\u2019s head and insights from the singer\u2019s first wife, Janet Rigsbee (\u201cBeing a muse is a thankless job, and the pay is lousy\u201d).\n\n\u201cAstral Weeks\u201d was recorded in New York City, but it was \u201cplanned, shaped and rehearsed in Boston and Cambridge,\u201d Walsh writes in his new book, which shares its title with the album. \u201cThis fact has been a secret kept in plain view.\u201d What exactly this secret yields is a question that the book never quite answers. Morrison\u2019s work had to be conceived somewhere, after all, and the album\u2019s otherworldly pastoral vibe means that almost any earthly answer \u2014 any place other than an unknown planet covered only in ferns and flutes \u2014 would be a surprise.\n\nVan the Man, who\u2019s front and center in the montage of characters on the book\u2019s cover, didn\u2019t talk to Walsh, but that\u2019s no matter; the singer\u2019s oppositional crankiness tends not to produce much. More troubling for the project is the width of its lens.\n\n\u201cWhile researching the album\u2019s half-buried local connections, my curiosity about Boston in the late \u201960s grew into obsession,\u201d Walsh writes. And that\u2019s how the book reads, as the record of an obsession, with the surfeit of granular detail, the loose anecdotal structure and the numerous cul-de-sacs that implies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis is not to say that Walsh\u2019s book lacks charm. It opens with a fresh angle on one of the stalest scenes in music history, when Bob Dylan went electric at the Newport Folk Festival in 1965. A harmonica player named Mel Lyman, one of many musicians upset by Dylan\u2019s plugging in, took the unlit stage at the event\u2019s end, Walsh tells us, and blew a mournful version of \u201cRock of Ages.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLess than two years later, Lyman founded the Fort Hill Community, a group of musicians and activists and dropouts who lived in a series of connected homes in the Roxbury section of Boston. Much of the book is concerned with the commune\u2019s activities, including its publication of Avatar, a controversial underground newspaper that took firm stances on the Vietnam War (anti-) and astrology charts (pro-).", "title": "1968 Revisited: A Boston Commune and a Van Morrison Classic", "authors": ["John Williams", "Ryan H. Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Hundreds of playbills mostly from 19th-century New York theater performances will be restored and digitized, thanks to a grant by the National Endowment for the Humanities to the Museum of the City of New York.\n\nThe museum\u2019s collection consists of about 700 of these broadsides, many of which are extremely fragile; all of them will be digitized, while half of them will go through a conservation process. The N.E.H. has given $143,804 for this project.\n\n\u201cA lot of the pieces have bits barely hanging on by a thread,\u201d Morgen Stevens-Garmon, the project\u2019s director and an associate curator of the museum\u2019s theater collection, said in an interview.\n\nThese one-sheet playbills trace the history of theater in New York. They were originally posted around Manhattan to advertise Shakespeare plays, minstrel shows, new American plays and early musicals. One showcases a performance of \u201cThe Black Crook,\u201d which opened in 1866 and is often credited as the first musical. The earliest broadside in the collection advertises the Old American Company\u2019s performance of \u201cThe Merchant of Venice\u201d in 1785; tickets were four shillings for a gallery seat.", "title": "19th-Century Playbills to Be Restored and Digitized", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s founder, endured a rite of passage this week that other powerful executives have gone through before: a public grilling before Congress.\n\nOver two days, nearly 100 lawmakers in the House and Senate interrogated Mr. Zuckerberg about the company\u2019s handling of user information. He faced almost 600 questions, including whether the company should be more heavily regulated, whether it intentionally censors conservative content and how much Russians may have meddled with America\u2019s democratic process through the social network.\n\nThe hearings came in the wake of revelations that the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica improperly harvested data of up to 87 million Facebook users.\n\nMark Zuckerberg has been on an apology tour.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg spent most of Monday visiting with top lawmakers he would later face in the hearings, mounting an apology tour of sorts. He tried to impress upon them that he understood where his company had failed, and outlined the work that Facebook was doing to avoid similar issues in the future.", "title": "2 Days, 10 Hours, 600 Questions: What Happened When Mark Zuckerberg Went to Washington", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBERLIN \u2014 Two people were killed and about 20 injured on Saturday in M\u00fcnster, in western Germany, after the driver of a small truck crashed into a group of people in the heart of the old city, the police said.\n\nThe driver killed himself in the cab of the truck immediately after the crash, Andreas Bode, a spokesman for the M\u00fcnster police said. \u201cWhat led to the act is still fully unclear and we are investigating in all directions,\u201d he said.\n\nPolice also said they were investigating what they identified as a \u201csuspicious item\u201d found in the cab of the truck, but declined to give any further details. They ordered all residents of the inner city and reporters at the scene to clear out while they were investigating the item.\n\nHerbert Reul, the interior minister of the state of North Rhine-Westphalia, where M\u00fcnster is, said the driver was a German citizen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeveral German media outlets, citing unnamed security sources, reported that the driver had a history of psychological problems. According to the S\u00fcddeutsche Zeitung, a national newspaper, the man was born in 1969 and had come to the attention of authorities for psychological issues in 2014 and 2016.", "title": "2 Dead in M\u00fcnster, Germany, After Truck Driver Crashes Into Crowd", "authors": ["Melissa Eddy"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "A co-director of the S.E.C.\u2019s enforcement division, Stephanie Avakian, said in a statement that the Centra co-founders had \u201csold investors on the promise of new digital technologies by using a sophisticated marketing campaign to spin a web of lies about their supposed partnerships with legitimate businesses.\u201d\n\nLawyers for Mr. Sharma and Mr. Farkas did not respond to emails seeking comment Monday evening. The authorities did not charge a third man who had been listed as a Centra co-founder, Raymond Trapani.\n\nInitial coin offerings, or I.C.O.s, emerged suddenly last year to become one of the most popular ways for start-ups to raise money, with investors pouring more than $6 billion into such offerings. But I.C.O.s operate in a regulatory gray area, and that has drawn a swift blowback from authorities around the world.\n\nThe New York Times Explains...\n\nThe S.E.C. is said to have sent subpoenas to dozens of I.C.O. projects, and has already sought to halt a handful of such projects.\n\nThe Centra founders appear to have been the first people arrested because of a coin offering. In addition to the S.E.C. complaint, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York brought criminal charges against Mr. Sharma and Mr. Farkas \u2014 including conspiracy to commit securities fraud, securities fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud and wire fraud.\n\nMr. Farkas had a flight reservation to leave the country on Sunday but was arrested before he could board the plane, according to the S.E.C. complaint.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe complaint alleges that the men \u201cengaged in an illegal unregistered securities offering and, in connection with the offering, engaged in fraudulent conduct and made material misstatements and omissions designed to deceive investors in connection with the offer and sale of securities in the Centra I.C.O.\u201d\n\nThe chairman of the S.E.C., Jay Clayton, has said that most tokens offered through coin offerings should be categorized as securities and registered with regulators, which few have done.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Sharma announced that he was leaving Centra after the Times article was published last fall, but the company has continued its operations and said this week that it would release the \u201cCentra Roadmap 3.0\u201d at a conference in South Korea.\n\nAfter the arrests were announced on Monday, the price of Centra\u2019s token on virtual currency exchanges crashed and the administrators of a Centra chat room on the Telegram messaging app expressed confusion.\n\n\u201cThe admins have no more info then you,\u201d an administrator named Tomo wrote to the other users.", "title": "2 Founders of $32 Million Centra Virtual Currency Project Are Arrested", "authors": ["Nathaniel Popper"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI made contact with the families, and as you\u2019d expect, you can never be prepared for something like this,\u201d Sheriff Schultz said. \u201cBut make no mistake, they\u2019re proud of their families. They understood when their loved ones pinned on the badge and they strapped on the gun that this was a possibility.\u201d\n\nTrenton, the seat of rural Gilchrist County, is a small town of around 2,000 residents, but the killing of the deputies drew the attention and condolences of national officials. Sheriff Schultz said his department\u2019s small size, with just 27 deputies, made their deaths especially painful.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe senseless act committed by this coward has shaken each of us, but we will endure,\u201d the sheriff wrote on Facebook on Friday morning.\n\nA candlelight vigil is planned for Saturday night in Trenton.\n\nThe authorities released few details about Mr. Highnote, but property records show he lived on several acres of land off a dirt road in Bell, a town of about 450 people. His home is about 10 miles from the Ace China restaurant in Trenton.\n\nBefore moving to Bell, Mr. Highnote lived in the Tampa-St. Petersburgh area. He was convicted in 1978 for a carrying a concealed weapon near Tampa but the charge was dismissed in 1980, according to court records.\n\nThe authorities said on Thursday that Mr. Highnote shot the deputies through a window of the restaurant. But a spokesman for the Alachua County Sheriff\u2019s Office, which is assisting in the investigation, said on Friday that Mr. Highnote walked inside Ace China and shot them while they were sitting down.\n\n\u201cWe have no information right now that our officers were able to return fire,\u201d the Alachua County spokesman said at a news conference on Friday afternoon.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMy thoughts, prayers and condolences are with the families, friends and colleagues of the two @GCSOFlorida deputies (HEROES) who lost their lives in the line of duty today,\u201d President Trump tweeted Thursday evening.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Florida attorney general, Pam Bondi, expressed her \u201cdeepest condolences and prayers\u201d and said in a statement, \u201cThe daily risk that law enforcement officers take to protect our communities is overwhelming.\u201d\n\nIn his news conference, Sheriff Schultz said his department would \u201chonor these men by doing our jobs.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe haven\u2019t been through anything quite like this before, but what makes our county unique is that we\u2019re a family,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to grieve. We\u2019re going to get upset. We\u2019re probably going to cuss a little bit. But at the end of the day, we\u2019re going to remember those two men for who they are. They\u2019re heroes.\u201d", "title": "2 Sheriff\u2019s Deputies Are Killed While Eating at North Florida Restaurant", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "On newsstands, the headline \u201cSuspect flees after Mountainview stabbing\u201d was splashed across the front page of Pipe Dream, the student newspaper. Students have sought counseling or gathered to pray and share their feelings. Events like Salamander Days, a traditional competition between dorms named for the amphibians that wander from the campus\u2019s nature preserve this time of year, have been postponed. The university\u2019s president, Harvey G. Stenger, described the events of the past few weeks as \u201cdefinitely the hardest thing that I\u2019ve been through since I\u2019ve been here.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe distress may not be overt, but it is palpable.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re an outsider and you come to Binghamton, you may not be able to see a difference,\u201d Jermel McClure Jr., president of the university\u2019s Student Association, said in an interview. \u201cBut if you really are in that residential community, if you really know what things are like in terms of people\u2019s spirits being uplifted, you could tell something different is going on here.\u201d\n\nOn March 9, Haley Anderson, a 22-year-old nursing student, was found strangled in an off-campus residence. The suspect, a fellow student who had once briefly dated her, fled to Nicaragua before her body was discovered, the authorities said.\n\nThen, on April 15, Joao Souza, a 19-year-old engineering student from Brazil, was attacked with a knife in his dormitory suite, the police said. Soon after, the authorities released a photograph of a suspect, with the hood of his sweatshirt shielding his face from the camera. Investigators did not disclose a motive for the attack.\n\nSasha Hupka was the first reporter to arrive at the dormitory that night, having dashed up the steep slope between Pipe Dream\u2019s newsroom and the scene. She saw blood in the hallway and heard students trying to convey what had happened. She finished an article in time for the deadline for the next day\u2019s issue, which the newspaper\u2019s editor in chief, Noah Bressner, had to deliver himself because the students hired to distribute it were frightened by the manhunt.\n\nReporters for Pipe Dream typically cover stories like funding for buses and a campus food co-op closing over sanitary violations \u2014 the other articles on the front page. Before this semester, Ms. Hupka, the newspaper\u2019s news editor and a sophomore, had never reported on a murder.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not going to lie and say it\u2019s an easy thing to cover,\u201d she said. But, she added, \u201cIt has shown me how important my job is.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nStudents described feeling starved for information as rumors spread and officials in the middle of an investigation offered few details. On social media, parents have complained about the roughly 45-minute span between the time when the stabbing was reported and the first alert issued by the university. An editorial in Pipe Dream on Thursday assailed the university for failing to \u201csend out information in a timely manner after the attack.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSchool officials said that it was essential to strike a balance between sharing confirmed information and doing so expediently. But Mr. Stenger, the president, said the university would review the episode and its handling of it.\n\n\u201cYou kind of learn on the fly on these things,\u201d he told reporters after the suspect had been arrested. \u201cWe want to make sure that if anything could have been done better, especially in the communication with our community, that we learn from that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBinghamton University\u2019s sprawling campus of red brick buildings cascades down a wooded hillside above the Susquehanna River. It is about three and a half hours from New York City, just outside of Binghamton, N.Y.\n\nOn a recent evening, deer grazed near a roadway as students hurried to class and played basketball outside a dormitory. Binghamton, a State University of New York campus considered one of the Northeast\u2019s top public schools, has more than 13,000 undergraduate students. Some of them pointed out the university\u2019s regular place at the top of \u201cbest value\u201d college rankings as part of its appeal. Others described being drawn by its inclusive nature.\n\n\u201cThis is not going to break our community,\u201d said Ms. Lin, who is the student president of the school\u2019s collection of dormitories, including Mr. Souza\u2019s, called Mountainview College.\n\nPhoto\n\nHundreds of people attended the funeral for Ms. Anderson last month in Westbury, on Long Island, where she was from. The suspect, Orlando Tercero, 22, has been apprehended by the authorities in Nicaragua, where he remains as officials in the United States seek to extradite him. Senator Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, has sent a letter to the State Department urging that \u201call available levers of influence and persuasion should be employed to secure Mr. Tercero\u2019s prompt extradition.\u201d\n\nIn the second killing, Michael M. Roque, 20, was charged with second-degree murder last Monday evening in the death of Mr. Souza. He pleaded not guilty at an initial court appearance. His lawyer declined to comment.\n\nMr. Souza, a first-year student, had joined the Zeta Psi fraternity and lived in Windham Hall, a dormitory that houses many international students and athletes who might need to stay on campus during breaks. He graduated last year from Blind Brook High School in Westchester County.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDanielle Goz met Mr. Souza in eighth grade. She said she remembered him struggling with English when he first arrived from Brazil. \u201cHe learned so fast,\u201d she said, \u201cand right away everyone just loved him.\u201d\n\nShe recalled his \u201cpromposal,\u201d when he asked her to the dance by surprising her while she was eating with friends. He used sushi to spell out \u201cprom?\u201d (She said yes.) She called him a \u201cposter child\u201d with good grades and athletic ability that helped him become the captain of the varsity soccer team.\n\n\u201cEvery single person who has encountered him knows how sweet and loving he always was,\u201d said Ms. Goz, 18. \u201cMy life will not be the same without him, but I will have to find a way to move on. He was my best friend and the best person I knew.\u201d\n\nBeyond mourning Mr. Souza\u2019s death, students also expressed disquiet over how the attack had violated a \u201csafe haven \u2014 not only for you as an individual but for ideas, discussion, thoughts,\u201d as Mr. McClure, the student body president, described it.\n\n\u201cIt makes you think about your interactions with the space in a much different way,\u201d Mr. McClure said. \u201cYou feel sort of invincible,\u201d he said of the sense of safety that had existed on campus, adding, \u201cIt is a reality check.\u201d", "title": "2 Student Murders Have Binghamton University on Edge", "authors": ["Rick Rojas"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Berthinia Rutledge-Brown remembers the first time she sat in a room full of parents whose children had gone to elite colleges.\n\n\u201cI cried because I realized that there was a chance that my child would get the education he deserves \u2014 the one I could not afford to pay for,\u201d she said.\n\nHer son, it turns out, has several options \u2014 and they will all be free.\n\nLast week Ms. Rutledge-Brown\u2019s son, Micheal Brown, opened the last of his big envelopes, and put an exclamation point at the end of an impressive streak: Mr. Brown, 17, got into all 20 highly selective colleges he applied to, all of which offered him a full ride through a combination of merit- and financial-based scholarships and grants.\n\n\u201cHe actually earned it,\u201d said Ms. Rutledge-Brown, a drug counselor. \u201cI always knew Mike would get into a good school. I always knew he\u2019d get good scholarship support. But I never imagined this.\u201d", "title": "20 Full Rides to Top Colleges: A Texas Student\u2019s Perfect Sweep", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nS\u00c3O PAULO, Brazil \u2014 Gunmen attacked a prison in northern Brazil while trying to enable a mass escape of inmates on Tuesday, setting off a gun battle with the police that killed 20 people and injured at least four, authorities said.\n\nPublic security officials in Para State identified 19 of the dead as prisoners or their supporters. A guard at the prison, the Santa Izabel Penitentiary, also died.\n\nOfficials were doing a head count inside the prison Tuesday night to determine whether any inmates escaped.\n\nIn a statement, police investigator Rodrigo Leao said two assault weapons, three pistols and two other guns were seized from a group that tried to get into the prison to enable a breakout by inmates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe attempted breakout began when explosives were used against a prison wall, according to a statement from the state\u2019s public security secretariat. The police and guards then exchanged gunfire with the armed men trying to help inmates escape and with the inmates themselves who were armed, it said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t immediately clear how many of the dead were inmates and how many were gunmen trying to help them escape.\n\nBrazil, Latin America\u2019s largest nation, has more than 726,000 prisoners, one of the largest inmate populations in the world. Many of its prisons have terrible conditions, and gang leaders often run drug businesses from behind bars.", "title": "20 Killed in Attempted Prison Escape in Brazil", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The Jazz and Blues Art Box comprises 230 concerts and 96 interviews, all filmed at the International Jazz Festival Bern in Switzerland from 1983 to 2002. It contains performances by most of jazz\u2019s biggest stars from the era, including Sonny Rollins, Sarah Vaughan, Wynton Marsalis and Dizzy Gillespie. Each of the concerts was originally broadcast on Swiss television, and is rendered here in full.\n\nThe DVD collection, which comes in a nearly-four-foot-tall black cabinet, was donated by the jazz impresario George Wein, who served as an adviser on the art box project.\n\nAt the Schomburg Center, a branch of the New York Public Library, the collection enters a newly renovated Moving Image and Recorded Sound Division, where visitors can watch the videos on either a desktop screen or a wall-mounted projector.", "title": "20 Years of Jazz Concerts, Heading to Harlem", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Original headline: \u201cUntucked Shirttails, the New Pennants of Rebellion,\u201d from July 2004.\n\nA new normal: Strange how some fashion fads that seem destined to last for months somehow endure for decades. The backward baseball cap, for example, blew up as a rebellious teenage fashion flourish in the 1980s, but instead of going the way of acid-washed jeans and Members Only jackets, the look evolved into a bedrock element of the bruh uniform for 30 years running. Every bit as rule-flouting, but even more ubiquitous, is the untucked dress shirt. This seemingly fleeting fashion trend attracted arched-eyebrow skepticism in this Styles article by Guy Trebay, which appeared on the front page of this newspaper at the peak of mid-aughts metrosexuality. \u201cThis may be remembered as the summer when new sartorial frontiers in the workplace were definitively breached \u2014 and in a manner destined to agitate bosses and parents everywhere,\u201d Mr. Trebay wrote. \u201cMen are letting their shirttails wave, a fact true not just of polo shirts or square-cut tropical styles designed to be worn outside of trousers but of broadcloth dress shirts with tapered tails never meant to see light of day.\u201d\n\nWinds of change: When it comes to launching a style trend into the mainstream, it takes an army of influencers, and the untucked shirt managed full mobilization. By 2004, fashion-forward editors like Jim Nelson of GQ and Nick Sullivan of Esquire, along with seemingly every male celebrity under 50, were doing their best to make respectable this once-slovenly look, which also happened to dominate the front rows of the Milan men\u2019s wear shows that year. \u201cIt\u2019s a kind of nonfashion fashion look,\u201d Joe Zee, the well-traveled style editor, told Mr. Trebay in 2004. \u201cAll the young Hollywood types, the young heroes who are cool, like Jake Gyllenhaal, Orlando Bloom and Spike Jonze, wear their shirts untucked. It\u2019s one of those looks that\u2019s meant to seem like there\u2019s no effort, although we know that it\u2019s really thought out.\u201d\n\nThe deeper context: Men under 30 might find it strange that anyone other than cops, accountants and Capitol Hill types ever tucked in a button-down shirt. But for decades, the untucked look was relatively rare on the fashion landscape, outside of slumming college students and madras short-clad preppies summering in Nantucket. O.K., the look had some precedent in American culture: the more rebellious of the bobby soxers, those rebellious teenage girls of the early Sinatra years, shocked grown-ups nationwide by rocking untucked shirts along with rolled dungarees, saddle shoes and, obviously, bobby socks. Among men, however, flapping shirttails were relatively rare. Even rock \u2018n\u2019 roll iconoclasts like the Rolling Stones of the 1960s and CBGB-era Blondie of the 1970s tended to politely tuck in their button-downs. That all began to change, however, in the casual-everything, dot-com era of the late \u201990s. Suddenly, sneakers and hoodies transformed into office wear among proto-Mark Zuckerbergs. Even Wall Street banks and law firms dallied, fairly risibly, with \u201ccasual Fridays.\u201d By the middle of the next decade, the untucked shirt became the \u201cdefault for a generation still searching for a middle ground between the traditional coat-and-tie uniform for the workplace and the Internet-era alternative of outfits best suited for mowing the lawn,\u201d Mr. Trebay wrote.\n\nA new generation gap: This is not to say there was no pushback. \u201cFor decades, the sartorial establishment took the part of Mom and Dad,\u201d Mr. Trebay wrote. \u201cTucked shirttails looked neater. They were more efficient, suaver and also, it should be noted, kept one from being taken for the pizza guy.\u201d The squares, however, were destined to lose this battle. As much as employers initially pushed back against casual clothing in the workplace, \u201cconcerned that sloppy dress correlated with shoddy output,\u201d the \u201cmarch of casualization is not so easily stopped,\u201d Mr. Trebay concluded. \u201cInfluenced, perhaps, by the crisp Latin American guayabera or by the adolescent ease of urban hip-hop clothes, the untucked dress shirt may not yet have made inroads at law offices or financial institutions. But the style is well-entrenched in Hollywood executive cadres \u2014 at the lineup on stage at a screening of the Harry Potter movie in New York last month nearly all sported the look \u2014 and among influential fashion types.\u201d", "title": "2004: How Untucked Shirts Became a Male Uniform", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "How he fits: Cleveland has needed a quarterback since it came back into the N.F.L. in 1999. They must believe that the similarities between Mayfield and Manziel are only superficial, and they were willing to bet big on that fact. He has a little time to develop with Tyrod Taylor in town and Browns fans will have to hope that they\u2019ve finally found the quarterback to solve what has seemed like an endless deficiency.\n\n\u2014-\n\nWant exclusive sports news, highlights and analysis from a rotating cast of New York Times journalists, delivered to your inbox once a week? Click here to receive our weekly Sports newsletter.\n\n\u2014-\n\nPhoto\n\n2. New York Giants: Saquon Barkley \u2014 RB, Penn State\n\nIf Leonard Fournette owed Ezekiel Elliott a thank you card for going with the No. 4 pick last year, then Saquon Barkley should send both of them a gift basket. Drafting running backs at the top of the first round is cool again, and that is great timing for Barkley, who has the potential to be a special player at the pro level. Barkley runs a 4.4 40-yard dash, has a 41-inch vertical leap and did 29 reps on the bench press at the combine. Elliott didn\u2019t participate in the bench press but was worse in the 40 (4.47 seconds) and in the leap (32.5 inches). The physical gifts were turned into production in college, with Barkley rushing for 3,843 yards and 43 touchdowns in his three years at Penn State, and developing into a solid pass-catching option out of the backfield as a junior. He does not break many tackles, and may take some time to learn pass-protection, but there is little doubt that he can be a star.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n[Read more about the Giants\u2019 pick here.]\n\nHow he fits: Even with quarterback Eli Manning\u2019s future in doubt, the Giants made the wise decision to take the best player in the draft. The three top quarterbacks available are all talented but also have some question marks about how good they will be. Almost no one doubts that Barkley will be an immediate superstar.\n\nPhoto\n\n3. New York Jets: Sam Darnold \u2014 QB, Southern California\n\nDarnold is the happy medium of the first-round quarterback options. At 6-foot-3 and 221 pounds he is not quite as big as Josh Allen but he has a more typical pro build than Baker Mayfield. He has the arm to make any throw and has shown decent accuracy as well, while being far more mobile than you might guess. His 40-yard dash time of 4.85 seconds was just one-hundredth of a second slower than Mayfield and wasn\u2019t enough slower than Allen\u2019s 4.75 for that to tip the scales in Allen\u2019s favor. The biggest drawback with Darnold, beyond a troubling propensity for turnovers, is a slow and deliberate release that could be a major issue in the N.F.L.\n\n[Read more about the Jets\u2019 pick here.]\n\nHow he fits: The Jets\u2019 biggest needs were at quarterback, cornerback and edge rusher. Josh McCown can hold down the fort at quarterback for the time being and Teddy Bridgewater has a ton of potential (and a ton of risk) as a backup, but Darnold is too talented to pass up. He could easily take over the starting job this season but he has the luxury of not having to if his development goes slowly.\n\n4. Cleveland Browns: Denzel Ward \u2014 CB, Ohio State\n\nWard is fast. Really fast. His 4.32-second 40 tied for the fastest mark among defensive backs at the combine and he used that speed, along with strong instincts in man coverage, to find consistent success at the college level. He did not generate many turnovers, with just two interceptions over three seasons, but he broke up 15 passes as a junior thanks to his ability to read plays. On intelligence and speed he should step in as a starter-level player immediately, with the main concern for him being his size. At 5-foot-11 and 183 pounds, he is far smaller than the receivers he will be asked to cover, and even with a 39-inch vertical leap he could be prone to losing battles for passes thrown above the shoulder level. He could also potentially be a liability in terms of tackling, though plenty of poor-tackling cornerbacks have proven their worth in the past.\n\nHow he fits: With the quarterback situation settled (the Browns hope), Cleveland took a risk by skipping over Bradley Chubb and going with Ward, the best defensive back in the draft. The Browns have Myles Garrett on the defensive line already, so they may have just wanted to get an elite talent on another level of their defense, but Ward presents at least slightly more risk than Chubb.\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Denver Broncos: Bradley Chubb \u2014 DE, North Carolina State\n\nChubb won both the Hendricks and Bronko Nagurski awards as the nation\u2019s top defensive end and top overall defender thanks to his 10 sacks and 23 tackles for a loss. The numbers were impressive, but even more so because they were nearly carbon copies to what he\u2019d done as a junior in 2016, when he had 10 sacks and 21 tackles for a loss. With a 4.65-second 40-yard dash he is among the fastest defensive linemen in the draft, but he matches that with a rangy (for his position) build of 6-foot-4 and 270 pounds. He has found success both outrunning offensive linemen and also running through them. His game could still use some pro refinement, but he has relatively few question marks for his ability to be an immediate impact player.\n\nHow he fits: Everyone expected the Broncos to take a quarterback but the team decided to reload its strength on defense by taking the best defensive player in this draft. Chubb doesn\u2019t necessarily fill a need, but the prospect of he and Von Miller terrorizing quarterbacks makes the team\u2019s struggles on offense at least somewhat less of an issue. They still badly need a quarterback, however.\n\n6. Indianapolis Colts: Quenton Nelson \u2014 OG, Notre Dame\n\nOffensive tackles have finally begun to be appreciated by a widespread audience, but guards still tend to be overlooked, which is why Nelson\u2019s status near the top of most draft boards makes him stand out so much. At 6-foot-5 and 325 pounds he is built like a tackle, and he uses his off-the-charts power to move through a defense in a way that has inspired comparisons to Larry Allen. Only 11 guards have ever been selected in the first five picks of the draft (none since 1985), and the only one since 1988 to crack the top-nine was Jonathan Cooper who went to Arizona at No. 7 in 2013. But Nelson\u2019s size, strength and technique make him perhaps this draft\u2019s most can\u2019t-miss talent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow he fits: Colts running backs are popping bottles of champagne. Nelson is a wrecking ball and he is the type of offensive line prospect who can single-handedly make the team dangerous. It\u2019s unusual for a guard to go this high in the draft but Nelson will instantly make their team better. He was the top offensive line prospect in the draft by a mile and the Colts, a team that theoretically doesn\u2019t need a quarterback, recognized that he was too good to pass up.\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Buffalo Bills: Josh Allen \u2014 QB, Wyoming\n\nThe first trade of the draft. The Bills gave up the No. 12 pick and two second rounders for a chance at Allen, who is easily the most divisive of the elite quarterback prospects (and no, it\u2019s not because of a few dumb tweets he sent while he was in high school). He\u2019s big (6-foot-5, 237 pounds), he\u2019s fast enough to be considered mobile (4.75-second 40) and he\u2019s got arm strength to spare. But he developed late, which led to very little recruitment coming out of high school, and he has yet to show an ability to have the accuracy necessary to succeed in the N.F.L. The combination of a lack of ability to throw on the run, a tendency to make poor decisions, and a sense that he does not necessarily have much control of where the ball ends up leaves him as a quarterback who can look elite on one play and inept on the next. If it is simply a matter of him still learning the game, then he could develop into something special, but there is a tremendous bust risk in picking him high in the draft.\n\nIn an interview broadcast on ESPN, Allen addressed the Bills trading up for him despite the controversy over offensive tweets that he\u2019d sent in high school. \u201cI\u2019m going to make them look like they\u2019re the smartest people out there,\u201d he said.\n\nHow he fits: With Tyrod Taylor gone and Nathan Peterman being terrible, the Bills needed a quarterback and they got one that some people thought was the top overall player in this draft. There are certainly question marks about Allen but he\u2019s played in cold weather and he has slightly more upside than Josh Rosen, so the team is hoping they bet big and will win big.\n\n8. Chicago Bears: Roquan Smith \u2014 LB, Georgia\n\nSmith is sort of the antithesis of Tremaine Edmunds. He\u2019s not nearly as large (6-foot-1, 236 pounds) and while he has elite speed there are questions about if he is strong enough to play in the middle of the field. Where he makes up for that is in natural linebacker instincts. He is a smart player, a strong leader, and is the type of guy coaches will trust to make decisions on the field.\n\nHow he fits: The Bears\u2019 biggest need was at linebacker and Smith fits the bill. The team is hoping he\u2019s a new version of Brian Urlacher, and the concept is not entirely out of the realm of possibility. He could be a true anchor for their defense.\n\n9. San Francisco 49ers: Mike McGlinchey \u2014 OT, Notre Dame\n\nHe is the top-rated tackle in the draft, but McGlinchey is far overshadowed by his linemate Quenton Nelson. That being said, McGlinchey brings a huge frame (6-foot-8, 309 pounds with 34-inch arms) and he is pro-ready in terms of technique and instinct. The limitations to his game all revolve around his strength and his ability to deal with power rushers. If he can add some bulk without losing his mobility, that could help alleviate the concern.\n\nHow he fits: McGlinchey is the second Notre Dame offensive lineman to go in the first 10 picks, and while he\u2019s not nearly the prospect that Nelson is, he\u2019s a solid tackle who can be an anchor on either side of the line for San Francisco. He now has the job of protecting Jimmy Garoppolo who went from backup in New England to face of the franchise in San Francisco in the span of five games.\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Arizona Cardinals: Josh Rosen \u2014 QB, U.C.L.A.\n\nThe second trade of the draft sent the tenth pick from Oakland to Arizona so the Cardinals could get their new franchise quarterback.
