But Cornell was deeply moved by Gris, the overlooked, tag-along third wheel in the Cubist movement that also included Picasso and Braque, and the show succeeds in tracking the fluttery ways of artistic inspiration. (Deborah Solomon)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018MARKUS BRUNETTI: FACADES \u2014 GRAND TOUR\u2019 at Yossi Milo Gallery (through April 21). Micro and macro collide to visceral, even wondrous effect in these large, astoundingly detailed photographs of European cathedrals and churches, most dating from the 11th to the 14th centuries. Stitched together from hundreds of small digital images, the photographs ignore the laws of perspectival recession. The structures are implacably frontal, powerful expressions of fervent religious belief that also convey how they once sat, and sometimes still do, above their town and cities like large, protective beasts. (Smith)\n\n212-414-0370, yossimilo.com\n\n\u2018THE VIETNAM WAR: 1945-1975\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through April 22). In contrast to the PBS series \u201cThe Vietnam War,\u201d this exhibition delivers historical data, a lot of it, quick and dirty, through labels, film and audio clips and objects, some of which fall under a broad definition of art. Along with paintings by contemporary Vietnamese artists, there\u2019s graffiti-style drawings on combat helmets and Zippo lighters, and period design in album covers and protest posters. Words and images work together in murals labeled \u201cHome Front\u201d and \u201cWar Front\u201d that put you in the middle of the war\u2019s primary issues and events. (Cotter)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\n\u2018ZURBAR\u00c1N\u2019S JACOB AND HIS TWELVE SONS: PAINTINGS FROM AUCKLAND CASTLE\u2019 at the Frick Collection (through April 22). More devout than Vel\u00e1zquez, more shadowy than Murillo, Francisco de Zurbar\u00e1n was little known outside Spain until the mid-19th century, when Manet and his friends found the seeds of modernism in his frisky, open brushwork and streamlined form. The Frick is now showing a baker\u2019s dozen of the Spaniard\u2019s biblical portraits, of an aged, hunched Jacob and the sons who would become the founders of the Twelve Tribes of Israel, with most of the paintings on loan from a castle that until recently belonged to the Church of England. The gents pose in a startling variety of crisp, supple fabrics, whose glamour or grittiness echoes Jacob\u2019s foretelling of their destinies in Genesis. Two are especially compelling: Judah, child No. 4, decked out in a fur-trimmed coat and vamping alongside a kindly lion, and Joseph, who forgoes the Technicolor dreamcoat for a blue sash and a belt stitched with gold. (Farago)\n\n212-288-0700, frick.org", "title": "25 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "As I near retirement age, I realize I will retire at the poverty level. The antiquated myth of the noble, yet poor, teacher must go. I am passionate about my subject and my students. I am not passionate about living paycheck to paycheck.\n\nImage Jose Coca uses these textbooks daily in his Tempe, Ariz., middle school. Credit Jose Coca\n\nTempe, Ariz.\n\nJose Coca, teacher at Kyrene Middle School\n\nSalary: $46,000 with 12 years of experience\n\nAnnual out-of-pocket expenses: $1,000\n\nThe building smells old and dank. There are holes in the ceiling, skylights don\u2019t work, the walls need to be painted , I still use a chalk board, but \u2014 more important \u2014 my students need new desks and computers.\n\nI can\u2019t speak for other school districts, but mine \u2014 in Tempe \u2014 can\u2019t get new social studies books for students. Young teachers spend more out of their own pockets because they don\u2019t have supplies stockpiled.\n\nMy pay is not keeping up with inflation. I have co-workers leaving midyear, or not renewing their contracts, and I work with a lot of older teachers that have maybe five more years in them. I also work with some who retire and return as workers for a private staffing company.", "title": "25-Year-Old Textbooks and Holes in the Ceiling: Inside America\u2019s Public Schools", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "After 17 years in the United States, these public displays still make no sense to me. But I\u2019m trying.\n\nPhoto\n\nHugs Galore\n\nHugging wasn\u2019t a thing in my childhood in Hong Kong. When I saw my grandmother, I just shook her hand. In fact, I never hugged anyone until I was 13, when I came to America. The concept of hugging was so foreign to me that I had to study how other people hugged to understand the mechanics of wrapping your arms around someone. Was I supposed to put both arms over the shoulder? Both arms around the belt? One up and one down? It was a confusing time in my life.\n\nWhen I finally mustered the courage to hug this girl in school, I\u2019m pretty sure I forearmed her in the face. Yet these days, I\u2019m recklessly hugging everyone, with complete disregard, and hopefully fewer injuries. I hug my friends, I hug people I\u2019ve just met, I hug the UPS man if he delivered a cool package. (Even if he delivers toilet paper, I still give a quick hug.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018Bae\u2019?\n\nMost of my friends have at least two dating apps on their phones. One friend is having lots of success on Plenty of Fish, another had her heart broken twice by different guys from Bumble, and I have gathered a database of nightmare stories from my own Tinder dates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI once matched with a woman whose job description was \u201csocial influencer.\u201d Deep down I knew this probably meant she was unemployed with 50,000 Instagram followers \u2014 some of them real \u2014 but I gave it a shot. I took her out to Dave & Busters so if the date went south, I could still enjoy myself playing Mario Kart.\n\nThroughout the date, she kept having me take videos of her for her Instagram story. \u201cO.K., do one like that, but turn the phone the other way.\u201d \u201cLet\u2019s do one with the puppy face filter!\u201d \u201cO.K., get one of me playing Mario Kart.\u201d I\u2019m not your cameraman! I want to play Mario Kart, too! I would have walked out if I hadn\u2019t just invested $30 in my Dave & Buster\u2019s game card. Priorities.", "title": "3 American Intimacies I Don\u2019t Get", "authors": ["Jimmy O. Yang"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBetrayed by their former boss \u2014 a South African crime lord who testified against them \u2014 three American men who worked as soldiers of fortune were convicted on Wednesday of a murder conspiracy plot to assassinate a real estate agent in the Philippines six years ago.\n\nAfter only two hours of deliberations, a jury in Federal District Court in Manhattan returned a guilty verdict against the men, Joseph Hunter, Adam Samia and Carl D. Stillwell.\n\nThe government\u2019s case against the defendants \u2014 presented at a spellbinding three-week federal trial \u2014 was built on the testimony of Paul Le Roux, a murderous kingpin who trafficked in guns, drugs and gold, and employed a private army of mercenaries on four continents to protect his assets and kill on his behalf. After Mr. Le Roux, 45, was arrested by the Drug Enforcement Administration in Liberia in late 2012, he began to cooperate with the government as they rounded up and prosecuted the members of his sprawling organization, in an effort to reduce a possible life sentence.\n\nMr. Hunter, a former United States Army sergeant with Special Forces training, was among the first to be caught. In 2013, Mr. Le Roux helped the D.E.A. set up a sting operation in Phuket, Thailand, during which they arrested Mr. Hunter, 52, for conspiring to kill one of their agents and a federal informant. Because the charges in that case included a plot to bring cocaine to New York, it was handled by prosecutors in Manhattan, who are also handling the murder in the Philippines, on the grounds it evolved from the same investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the case that ended on Wednesday, Mr. Le Roux recounted that in early 2012, just before he was captured, he asked Mr. Hunter \u2014 his chief of security \u2014 to arrange the murder of Catherine Lee, a real estate agent who Mr. Le Roux suspected had been stealing from him. Mr. Hunter, he recalled, then reached out to Mr. Samia, a onetime Army sniper, and Mr. Stillwell, a firearms instructor, both of whom lived in the small town of Roxboro, N.C. Flight records showed that Mr. Samia, 43, and Mr. Stillwell, 50, traveled to Manila weeks later. There, Mr. Le Roux recalled, they took Ms. Lee into the countryside pretending to be property buyers, shot her in the face then dumped her body on a pile of garbage on the road.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith its frequent references to car bombs, arsons and paid assassinations, the trial exposed the covert world of Mr. Le Roux\u2019s band of guns-for-hire, who, he testified, were kept on retainer for as much as $10,000 a month \u2014 plus expenses for food, fuel and travel. Mr. Le Roux admitted that he paid his men an extra $25,000 for \u201cbonus work,\u201d which he described as \u201cacts of killing and any other acts of violence.\u201d\n\nBefore his arrest, Mr. Le Roux had also killed people, he said, including his former security chief, a man named David Smith. On the witness stand, Mr. Le Roux described how in 2010 he lured Mr. Smith into a rural area near Manila and shot him in the head with the assistance of a hit man.", "title": "3 American Mercenaries Are Convicted in Murder of Filipino Woman", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "At a news conference on Wednesday, Mr. Trump acknowledged the \u201charsh treatment\u201d of what he called the \u201cthree prisoners\u201d and pledged action.\n\n\u201cWe have been talking about them,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re negotiating now. We are doing our very best.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cWe fought very hard to get Otto Warmbier back. And when we came back, he was in very, very bad condition. It was a very sad event. We are likewise fighting very diligently to get the three American citizens back. I think there\u2019s a good chance of doing it.\u201d\n\nA White House adviser, Matthew Pottinger, told reporters this week that the three Americans were a priority.\n\nHere is what is known about the three detainees.\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Hak-song\n\nKim Hak-song, also known as Jin Xue Song, was arrested on May 6, 2017. He worked at Pyongyang University of Science and Technology, and it was not clear whether his arrest was connected with that of his colleague Tony Kim two weeks earlier.\n\nThe university said in a statement that he had been doing agricultural development work at its research farm and was arrested after a trip there.\n\nAccording to CNN, Mr. Kim, an ethnic Korean, was born in Jilin, China, near the North Korean border, and emigrated to the United States in the 1990s. After becoming an American citizen, the network said, Mr. Kim returned to China and studied agriculture at Yanbian before moving to Pyongyang, the capital.\n\nPhoto\n\nTony Kim\n\nTony Kim, also known as Kim Sang-duk, was arrested on April 23, 2017. He had spent a month teaching accounting at Pyongyang University of Science and Technology and was trying to board a plane to leave the country when he was arrested, according to the chancellor of the university, Chan-Mo Park.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe cause of his arrest is not known, but some officials at P.U.S.T. told me his arrest was not related to his work at P.U.S.T.,\u201d Mr. Park told Reuters. \u201cHe had been involved with some other activities outside P.U.S.T., such as helping an orphanage.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim, who is in his 50s, had previously taught at Yanbian University of Science and Technology, an affiliated institute in the Chinese province of Jilin, near the North Korean border. He had most recently been living in North Korea with his wife, who is believed to still be in the country.\n\nMr. Kim studied accounting at the University of California, Riverside, and at Aurora University, and he worked as an accountant in the United States for more than a decade, according to his Facebook page.\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Dong-chul\n\nKim Dong-chul, a businessman, was sentenced to 10 years of hard labor in April 2016 on charges of spying and other offenses.\n\nA month before his trial, Mr. Kim appeared at a government-arranged news conference in Pyongyang and apologized for what he described as his attempted theft of military secrets in collusion with South Koreans. The South Korean spy agency has denied any involvement.\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s predicament was not known until January 2016, when the North Korean government let CNN interview him in Pyongyang. At that time, Mr. Kim identified himself as a 62-year-old naturalized American citizen who lived in Fairfax, Va. He said he had once run a trading and hotel services company in Rason, a special economic zone near North Korea\u2019s borders with China and Russia.\n\nHe said he was arrested in October 2015 while meeting with a former North Korean soldier to receive classified data.", "title": "3 Americans Held in North Korea: Who They Are and How They Got There", "authors": ["Russell Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "KAZUO MIYAGAWA: JAPAN\u2019S GREATEST CINEMATOGRAPHER at Japan Society and the Museum of Modern Art (through April 29). Was the same person really responsible for the ghostly compositions in Kenji Mizoguchi\u2019s \u201cUgetsu\u201d (on Monday at MoMA), the delicate balance of color and geometry in Yasujiro Ozu\u2019s \u201cFloating Weeds\u201d (on Friday at Japan Society) and the Tohoscope symmetries of Akira Kurosawa\u2019s \u201cYojimbo\u201d (on Wednesday at MoMA)? Yes, and add to Mr. Miyagawa\u2019s accomplishments a virtuosity with high-speed athletics in Kon Ichikawa\u2019s \u201cTokyo Olympiad\u201d (on April 21 at Japan Society and April 29 at MoMA), a pioneering use of the bleach bypass process \u2014 a source of the dystopian look in films like \u201c1984\u201d and \u201cSeven\u201d \u2014 on Mr. Ichikawa\u2019s \u201cHer Brother\u201d (on April 20 and 21 at MoMA) and the 17th-century imagery in Masahiro Shinoda\u2019s \u201cSilence\u201d (on April 26 and 29 at MoMA), adapted from the Shushaku Endo novel later filmed by Martin Scorsese. This retrospective of Mr. Miyagawa\u2019s career is so extensive and filled with rarities that it seems to have required three theaters to host it. (Film Forum previewed the series with two Mizoguchi features last week.)\n\n212-715-1258, japansociety.org\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\nQUADROPHILIA: FIRST ANNIVERSARY 21-FILM SALUTE! at the Quad Cinema (April 13-23). They include \u201cParis, Texas\u201d (showing on Sunday and Thursday), featured in last fall\u2019s Harry Dean Stanton retrospective, which opened shortly after the actor\u2019s death in September, and \u201cSwept Away\u201d (on Thursday), which screened during the Lina Wertm\u00fcller series that reinaugurated the venue last April.\n\n212-255-2243, quadcinema.com\n\n\u2018QUAI DES ORF\u00c8VRES\u2019 (April 13-19) and \u2018LE CORBEAU\u2019 (April 20-May 1) at Film Forum. Before \u201cThe Wages of Fear\u201d and \u201cDiabolique,\u201d Henri-Georges Clouzot had at least two strikingly modern classics of French cinema to his name. \u201cQuai des Orf\u00e8vres,\u201d first shown in 1947, is one of his most elegant films, an ensemble mystery in which a music hall performer, her jealous husband and a photographer become variously implicated in the murder of a lecherous businessman. Darker, both in content and in the circumstances under which it was made, \u201cLe Corbeau\u201d opened in 1943 in occupied France. While working for the German-controlled production company Continental Films, Mr. Clouzot bit the hand that fed him and made a movie that \u2014 today, at least \u2014 clearly registers as a condemnation of Nazi collaborators and informants. Pierre Fresnay plays a doctor and relative newcomer to a small town that is inundated with anonymous, suspicion-sowing poison-pen letters. Branded a collaborator himself after the war, Mr. Clouzot was, until \u201cQuai,\u201d briefly barred from making movies in France.\n\n212-727-8110, filmforum.org", "title": "3 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "But with Cynthia Nixon\u2019s energetic primary challenge of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, and the emergence of anti-Trump activists targeting state and local politicians in New York, the pressure had mounted on the I.D.C. to return to the mainstream Democrats. In early April, Mr. Cuomo helped broker a reconciliation between the two factions.\n\nOn Tuesday, Democrats in New York won special elections for two vacated Senate seats, giving them, in theory, a one-vote majority in the 63-seat body. But hours before polls closed that day, Mr. Felder declared that he was going to continue to sit with the Republicans \u2014 keeping that party in power.\n\nThat was immediately followed by renewed pledges from state Democratic officials to liberal activists to flip Republican seats in the Senate in November to create a less tenuous majority there.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the state Republicans have voiced their own determination to hold onto their control. Foderaro"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The skeleton key to streaming music, movies and TV shows\n\nPrepare to feel either really old or really young: Roku players have existed for 10 years. The first Roku player streamed Netflix (and only Netflix) to your TV. Now, you have your pick of streaming devices, from Chromecast to Apple TV to a variety of Roku players. If you don\u2019t have one, it\u2019s about time you invested in one. Several devices are budget-friendly and portable. I f you\u2019re all about video quality and immersive audio, there are options that deliver.\n\nWhen many of these devices were first introduced, they could stream only certain services. When Google first offered the Chromecast in 2013, it could support only Netflix and YouTube. Now, it works with Hulu, HBO Go, the CW, Sling, VUDU and hundreds more.\n\nWirecutter, a New York Times company, recommends the Roku Streaming Stick+, which retails for about $65. It comes with an external Wi-Fi antenna, lots of supported streaming content (including 4K video), and a customizable home screen so you can go straight to the services you use. Best of all, you can take it with you on vacation or a business trip.\n\nOf course, there are cheaper options, like the Roku Streaming Stick for $45 or Google\u2019s Chromecast, for $35. The point, of course, is to finally embrace lying on the couch, binge-watching your next new favorite show.", "title": "3 Gadgets You Didn\u2019t Know You Needed, but Are Worth Buying", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Appropriate criteria helps you avoid personality judgments, which reflect your personal preferences rather than the job requirements. We naturally gravitate toward certain personalities at work, but it\u2019s nearly impossible to tie subjective traits like \u201capproachability\u201d or \u201chumor\u201d to job performance. If you can\u2019t give specific examples of how the trait affected her work, leave it out. Similarly, give examples for how she can act on your feedback; otherwise, you likely won\u2019t help her improve.\n\nTake the time to vet your criticisms. Katie Stricker, a career coach, recommends asking these questions before sharing feedback:\n\n1. How does this apply to the work she\u2019s meant to do or the product she\u2019s supposed to deliver?\n\n2. How would I apply this feedback to anyone in the company?\n\nYou can also talk through your critique with another colleague to get her perspective, as long as you frame the conversation about professional development and not gossip.\n\nYou don\u2019t need to just criticize. \u201cWe tend to associate \u2018feedback\u2019 with \u2018negative feedback.\u2019 But feedback should really be continuous and include both positives and negatives,\u201d Ms. Stricker said. \u201cIf we make feedback more organic, frequent and well rounded, it becomes a bit less loaded for everyone.\u201d\n\nWhile criticism should be thoughtful and measured, don\u2019t let anxiety about biases prevent you from giving regular feedback. In the wake of #MeToo, men have expressed to me that fear of saying something sexist leads them to say nothing. Silence won\u2019t help anyone grow. But by making good-faith efforts to reduce bias from your feedback and to have open and honest conversations with your co-workers, your feedback is much more likely to be well received.\n\nBest of Smarter Living\n\nHow to Do Laundry Laundry can be frustrating and time consuming and there is so very much that can go wrong. This guide will help you understand your machines, how fabric types behave and methods for treating common problems like stains, dinginess and odor \u2014 all with the important caveat that laundry is a very personal endeavor.\n\nStudies Show Little Benefit in Supplements Americans continue to buy vitamins, herbs and other dietary supplements that are often of questionable value.", "title": "3 Steps to Avoid Giving Biased Feedback", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Friday\n\n1) 3 p.m. BRIDGE THE CITY\n\nYour introduction to the evolving nature of the city is Inderhavnsbroen (Inner Harbor Bridge), a cycling-and-pedestrian bridge that connects the Nyhavn and Christianshavn districts. Completed in 2016, the structure is the final link of the Harbor Circle, an eight-mile route for cyclists and pedestrians traversing this maritime city\u2019s myriad waterways. Although the bridge itself is unremarkable, the impressive panorama spans both the past and future: historic Nyhavn with its colorful rowhouses and 17th-century canal; influx Papiroen island; the gray stone building that formerly housed Noma (the acclaimed New Nordic restaurant reopened nearby in February); and modern architectural landmarks, including the neo-futuristic Opera House and the Royal Library with its angular black facade.\n\n2) 4 p.m. STYLE UPGRADE\n\nDanes are known for their design savvy, but the innate sense of style also extends to their wardrobes. To appropriate an understated Scandinavian look, visit Project 4, a small Latin Quarter shop packed with functional canvas Sandqvist backpacks, woolen Klitmoller Collective sweaters, and leather jackets from the Copenhagen-based label Ventil Studios. The spinoff store downstairs, Concept 4, is stocked with durable Rains raincoats and interior items ranging from Kinfolk tomes to cork-bound Nomess notebooks. Then browse the showroom of Hofmann Copenhagen, a niche brand for women, known for high-neck blouses and wide-leg trousers.", "title": "36 Hours in Copenhagen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Friday\n\n1) 2 p.m. HILLTOP HIGHS\n\nTo gain some perspective on Lisbon\u2019s undulating terrain, ascend the city\u2019s highest hill into the Gra\u00e7a district. Start at the Gra\u00e7a Convent, whose tiled chapel and Baroque cloister opened to the public for the first time after recent restorations (free). Then head outside to admire one of the city\u2019s finest miradouros (viewpoints) that sweeps across the terracotta-tiled rooftops. Afterward, on the steep descent, peek inside Surrealejos, a closet-size atelier producing surrealist tiles \u2014 one series depicts an anthropomorphic panda \u2014 that are a cheeky twist on Portuguese azulejos (traditional painted tiles).\n\n2) 5 p.m. PORTRAITS OF AN ARTIST\n\nGetting to know Fernando Pessoa, the shape-shifting writer who is considered one of Portugal\u2019s greatest poets, is no easy task. But that\u2019s the goal of Casa Fernando Pessoa, a museum and cultural center in the residential Campo de Ourique neighborhood. Situated in the final home of the bespectacled author, the site is a treasure trove of Pessoa\u2019s early 20th-century works \u2014 most published posthumously \u2014 including poems written under three well-developed heteronyms. Through interactive exhibits, engage with the poet\u2019s language: \u201cI\u2019m beginning to know myself. I don\u2019t exist.\u201d There\u2019s also a collection of portraits of Pessoa \u2014 fittingly, in diverse styles \u2014 including paintings by J\u00falio Pomar. Admission, 3 euros, or about $3.70.", "title": "36 Hours in Lisbon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "This compact, eminently walkable city, set amid the breathtaking beauty and bounty of Vancouver Island, is lauded as one of the world\u2019s top small urban destinations. Beyond the picture-perfect downtown waterfront, British Columbia\u2019s capital is an exhilarating blend of cultures, from Canadian and First Nations to Chinese and European (especially British). There are three universities, thriving arts and cultural institutions, significant historic preservation, a celebrated local food scene and Canada\u2019s mildest climate: That means year-round forest visits, biking and golf; gardens galore (daffodils in February); even beehives downtown (at the Fairmont Empress hotel; atop the Harbour Air floating terminal). There is wildness too: \u201cbear jams\u201d disrupting traffic, cougar sightings and soaring eagles, towering ancient trees, log-strewn beaches and distant snowy peaks.\n\nFriday\n\n1) 3 p.m. EARLY DAYS\n\nThe blocks north of the Empress and west of Douglas Street, including Chinatown, comprise the Old Town. Start at Bastion Square and Wharf Street, overlooking the harbor, where James Douglas founded Fort Victoria in 1843 as an outpost of the Hudson\u2019s Bay Company. This area became the heart of commerce, industry and government, swelling in size after the 1858 Fraser Gold Rush drew thousands of immigrants. Next to the Old Victoria Customs House is a grassy overlook with a display telling the history of British settlement and the indigenous Lekwungen people. Check out the lively Bastion Square pedestrian area of shops, restaurants and cafes, music and markets; then, on Government Street, browse through Munro\u2019s Books, situated in a century-old bank, and founded in 1963 by the Nobel Prize-winning Canadian writer Alice Munro and her then-husband. Detour through Trounce Alley (note the 125-year-old gaslights), then walk east on Fort Street to La Taqueria to snack on Mexican tacos amid festive music and colorful tiles. A juicy carnitas taco with pickled red onions and salsa is 3 Canadian dollars, or about $2.35, and a Baja fish taco with cabbage, salsa and chipotle mayonnaise is 6 dollars; wash it down with Mexican fruit soda or local beer.", "title": "36 Hours in Victoria, British Columbia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "She was friendly with Mr. Pantaleo, and many Sunday nights after his leg healed they danced together at the local teen club to the Jackson Five\u2019s \u201cI\u2019ll Be There,\u201d a song they both loved. But when she graduated and enrolled in a local community college, she didn\u2019t stay in touch.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Pantaleo, with two more years of high school ahead of him, was heartsick but not the moping type. Instead of pining for Ms. Jewell or settling into a relationship with another girl, he immersed himself in sports. In 1985, the year he graduated, he won a wrestling scholarship to the University of Michigan. By 1987, he had won titles including a world freestyle championship. In 1992, two years after he graduated college and the same year he was ranked No. 1 in the world in his weight class, he earned a spot as an alternate on the United States Olympic wrestling team. And so his love life was stalled.\n\nMs. Jewell\u2019s love life, on the other hand, was taking flight. After plunging into a career in the health industry in the mid-1980s and landing a job as a regional supervisor for Jenny Craig in Michigan in the \u201990s, she was ready to settle down. In 1998, she got engaged to the man she would marry the next year.\n\nMr. Pantaleo, by then a Grosse Pointe, Mich., high school teacher with a stint as a Michigan State University wrestling coach behind him, was not spared Ms. Jewell\u2019s happy news.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is the funny part,\u201d Mr. Pantaleo said. \u201cI left East Lansing, where I was a coach, and moved back to the Detroit area where Diana was in 1997 to teach. In the spring of 1998, I finally reconnected with her.\u201d By chance, the gym he joined, in Clinton Township, Mich., was in the same strip mall as Ms. Jewell\u2019s Jenny Craig office. Mr. Pantaleo was working out when he bumped into Ms. Jewell, also a gym member.\n\n\u201cHer personality, her smile, the twinkle in her eye, the way she says my name \u2014 all of that God-given stuff was still there, she hadn\u2019t changed a bit,\u201d he said. \u201cI was still captivated. I had butterflies when I saw her. I was thinking, maybe I finally have a shot with Diana.\u201d The next day, he sent her flowers.\n\nMs. Jewell, still as friendly as in high school, agreed to go rollerblading with Mr. Pantaleo a few weeks after the chance gym meeting. In her helmet and kneepads, she told him about her new boyfriend, who would become her fianc\u00e9 later that year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI was shattered,\u201d Mr. Pantaleo said. \u201cBut at the same time I knew I had to continue on with my life. You just kind of go, Oh, I guess I missed my shot, and try to regroup.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Jewell moved to Charlotte, near Mr. Pantaleo\u2019s former job in East Lansing, with her husband the next year. Mr. Pantaleo continued teaching until 2009, when an assistant wrestling coaching job at Liberty University, in Lynchburg, Va., opened. His nephew was on the team.\n\nLiberty, founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell, is a Christian university. Mr. Pantaleo was not the religious type when he started out there. \u201cI had a friend who was always trying to get me to go to church. I would say, I\u2019m not going into any church. My feet will burn up!\u201d he said. But the job at Liberty, he said, connected him with his spiritual side. In 2011, when the college dropped its N.C.A.A. Division I wrestling program, he returned to Michigan a devout Christian.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Jewell, struggling in her marriage by then, was also finding comfort in her faith. At the 2011 get-together with high school friends that reunited them for the second time since high school, they bonded over talk about God. Still, Mr. Pantaleo\u2019s romantic timing was off. Ms. Jewell\u2019s divorce was not final until 2016. Both were morally opposed to dating until she was legally single.\n\n\u201cI think the divorce had already happened psychologically when Joe came back into her life,\u201d said Robin Crouch, Ms. Jewell\u2019s pastor at First Baptist Church in Charlotte. \u201cBut she knew she had to set boundaries if she wanted to look back and say, \u2018What I did was right for Lacy and for my faith.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Pantaleo wouldn\u2019t have his first kiss with Ms. Jewell until Jan. 27, 2017. When it finally came, during a dance around the living room he now shares with Ms. Jewell in Charlotte, he had a song cued: the Jackson Five\u2019s \u201cI\u2019ll Be There.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Crouch, who had encouraged that first kiss, anticipated Mr. Pantaleo\u2019s herculean patience. \u201cHe\u2019s the type of person who sets goals and goes after them,\u201d Mr. Crouch said. \u201cHe brought the same intensity he showed in his athletic career, when he was a champion, to his relationship with Diana. He knew he couldn\u2019t get there overnight.\u201d\n\nA little less than a year after that long-awaited kiss, on Jan. 5, 2018, Mr. Pantaleo, now the director of marketing at the human resources firm America\u2019s Back Office in Sterling Heights, Mich., asked Ms. Jewell and Lacy to take a day trip with him to Roseville.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018We should take Lacy by the school and show her where we met,\u2019\u201d he said. Ms. Jewell needed convincing; she wasn\u2019t sure her daughter would be interested. Lacy, though, was on board.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Pantaleo planned to propose and had armed himself with a 1.8 carat diamond solitaire bought at a Lansing jewelry shop. He enlisted Lacy to keep his secret days earlier.\n\nIn Roseville, Mr. Pantaleo arranged for a friend who works for the school district to let them in since school was closed for holiday break. Ms. Jewell and Lacy followed Mr. Pantaleo to the spot where he dropped his books all those years ago.\n\n\u201cHe got down on one knee and said, Will you be my wife?\u201d Ms. Jewell said. \u201cI said yes, forever.\u201d\n\nOn March 31, on Vedado Way Beach in Naples, Fla., Mr. Pantaleo, wearing a white button-down shirt and khakis, finally married Ms. Jewell, barefoot and in an ivory French lace dress by Grace Loves Lace, before a circle of only six guests. Lacy was maid of honor; Mr. Pantaleo\u2019s brother Dan Pantaleo was best man. Mr. Crouch, now retired and living in West Virginia, officiated.\n\nAs Mr. Pantaleo watched Ms. Jewell walk toward him over a path in the sand laid with rose petals, he was in tears. \u201cMy heart is so happy today,\u201d he said.\n\nDuring a short ceremony, Mr. Crouch reflected on the 36-year odyssey that delivered Ms. Jewell to Mr. Pantaleo. \u201cThey just wanted to do it right. And they have,\u201d he said.\n\nPost-wedding, Lacy expressed her happiness. \u201cI couldn\u2019t ask for a better person in my life,\u201d she said.\n\nMonths earlier, she had summed up the couple\u2019s long but triumphant journey in a picture posted on Instagram: \u201cThirty-six years later, it IS possible to get out of the friend zone, y\u2019all,\u201d she wrote.", "title": "36 Years Later, He\u2019s Out of the Friend Zone", "authors": ["Tammy La Gorce"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nMAHAMAT-SALEH HAROUN: MODERN GRIOT at BAM Rose Cinemas (April 20-25). This series celebrates Mr. Haroun, the France-based, Chad-born filmmaker who won a prize at Cannes in 2010 for \u201cA Screaming Man\u201d (showing on Saturday and Sunday) and, more recently, grappled with the legacy of a murderous government in Chad in \u201cHissein Habr\u00e9, a Chadian Tragedy\u201d (on Sunday). The understated drama \u201cA Screaming Man\u201d is a more characteristic place to start: It tells the story of a pool attendant (Youssouf Djaoro) who loses his job to his son. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called it \u201ca quiet, tender, finally wrenching story of an individual at the intersection of the personal and the political.\u201d\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org\n\nRADICAL PRESENCE: ANNE WIAZEMSKY at the Quad Cinema (April 20-26). The relationship between Ms. Wiazemsky (1947-2017) and her onetime husband and seven-time director Jean-Luc Godard is dramatized in \u201cGodard Mon Amour,\u201d the new film from Michel Hazanavicius, the director of \u201cThe Artist.\u201d Mr. Godard is said to have called the biopic \u201ca stupid, stupid idea.\u201d So instead of seeing impersonations, check out the real collaboration. Beyond canonical Godard titles like \u201cLa Chinoise\u201d (showing on Friday and Tuesday) and \u201cWeekend\u201d (on Saturday and Tuesday), the Quad is showing \u201cSympathy for the Devil\u201d (on Saturday and Thursday), which, in addition to Ms. Wiazemsky, features the Rolling Stones, shown working methodically and repetitively in a recording studio.\n\n212-255-2243, quadcinema.com\n\nTRIBECA FILM FESTIVAL at various locations (through April 29). Neither totally in TriBeCa nor exclusively a film festival (it also includes TV episodes, web series and virtual reality experiences), this annual, mainly downtown event offers more than 100 features this year. For a full accounting, see our roundup.\n\ntribecafilm.com\n\n\u2018YEAR OF THE WOMAN\u2019 at Film Forum (April 21, 4:30 p.m.). In 1972, the year of Shirley Chisholm\u2019s presidential campaign, the writer Sandra Hochman and an all-female film crew crisscrossed the Democratic National Convention asking attendees for their thoughts on feminism and consequently exposing the hypocrisy and pigheadedness of male politicians and correspondents. The result was this rarely seen documentary essay. Ms. Hochman will appear for a Q. and A. after the screening.\n\n212-727-8110, filmforum.org", "title": "4 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nFASHION IN FILM FESTIVAL \u2014 WEARING TIME: PAST, PRESENT, FUTURE, DREAM at the Museum of the Moving Image (April 6-22). Retrospectives centered on fashion and cinema proliferated with the release of \u201cPhantom Thread,\u201d but this one, which debuted in London and was curated by the academics Marketa Uhlirova and Tom Gunning, explores clothing not to celebrate stylishness but to examine how cinema has used costuming to represent the passage of time and dream states. Take note of when the red dress appears in Nicolas Roeg\u2019s \u201cDon\u2019t Look Now\u201d (on April 15) and of what Gena Rowlands\u2019s aging-actress protagonist wears in John Cassavetes\u2019s \u201cOpening Night\u201d (on Sunday). The festival begins with \u201cThe Inferno Unseen\u201d (on Friday), a new arrangement of footage shot for Henri-Georges Clouzot\u2019s unfinished movie \u201cInferno,\u201d the subject of a documentary that was released in the United States in 2010. The screening will feature live musical accompaniment.\n\n718-784-0077, movingimage.us", "title": "4 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 An organization that uses architectural rendering software to uncover human rights abuses and three artists depicting social, racial and political issues in film have been nominated for the Turner Prize, Britain\u2019s prestigious contemporary art award, Tate Britain announced on Thursday.\n\nThe research organization Forensic Architecture, and the artists Naeem Mohaiemen, Charlotte Prodger and Luke Willis Thompson have been shortlisted for the prize, awarded annually to an artist born or living in Britain for an outstanding exhibition in the previous year. The winner will receive 25,000 pounds, or almost $35,000, and the other nominees will each receive \u00a35,000.\n\nThe Turner Prize, founded in 1984, could be likened to the Oscar of the art world, and it can give a major boost to an artist\u2019s career. Former recipients include Damien Hirst, Chris Ofili, Rachel Whiteread, Gillian Wearing, Steve McQueen and Grayson Perry. The British news media, which eagerly covers the award, has often turned the prize into an opportunity to examine, or denounce, the state of contemporary art.\n\nLast year, the prize was opened to artists 50 and older, but the change was moot this year: All of the artists on the shortlist are younger.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nForensic Architecture \u2014 nominated for exhibitions in London; Barcelona, Spain; and Mexico City \u2014 is a collaboration of architects, artists, filmmakers, software developers, archaeologists, scientists and others, based at Goldsmiths, University of London.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe group, Michael Kimmelman wrote in The New York Times recently, \u201cscours for evidence of lies, crimes and human rights violations \u2014 combining the spatial and engineering skills of architects, the data-gathering prowess of librarians, the doggedness of investigative journalists and the storytelling finesse of screenwriters.\u201d", "title": "4 Turner Prize Nominees Are Announced", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Nick Burchill has been called \u201cthe worst hotel guest ever.\u201d\n\nIt isn\u2019t because he left a suitcase filled with pepperoni in a hotel room in Canada in 2001.\n\nIt\u2019s because, as Mr. Burchill tells it, he left it next to an open window and about 40 sea gulls invaded the room, drawn by the smell of the cured meat.\n\nThe ensuing chaos \u2014 and most likely the cleanup bill \u2014 got Mr. Burchill barred for life from the Fairmont Empress in Victoria, British Columbia, according to him and the hotel.\n\nHis Facebook post about the strange saga and his plea for a \u201cpardon\u201d from the hotel last month unleashed an outpouring of appreciation online, and ruminations on forgiveness.", "title": "40 Sea Gulls Wrecked His Hotel Room. 17 Years Later, a Pepperoni Pardon.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "No charges were filed, Chief Bentzel added.\n\nEveryone disbanded, and the women left the golf course.\n\n\n\n\u201cThe police were respectful, so it is not about the police,\u201d Ms. Thompson said in her Facebook post.\n\nThat contrasted with other episodes involving black customers that have fueled fury online this month. At the Starbucks in Philadelphia and the Waffle House in Alabama, the police made arrests.\n\nThe former county commissioner, Steve Chronister, and the club\u2019s co-owner, his son, Jordan Chronister, could not be reached for comment. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nTell me if this part of my bedtime routine sounds anything like yours.\n\nJust as I notice myself drifting off to sleep, I nudge myself awake to set anywhere from five to 10 alarms on my phone in five-minute intervals; I make sure the volume on my phone is turned all the way up; I double-check that I just changed the ringer volume and not the regular volume; I double-check that my alarms are set even though I set them 90 seconds ago; and some nights, I\u2019ll wake up just after falling asleep in a panic thinking I didn\u2019t set any alarms, then go through the whole process again. (Not to mention the horror of thinking, What if my phone dies overnight and the alarms don\u2019t go off?)\n\nSound familiar? (No really, tweet at me if this is you so I know I\u2019m not just insane.)\n\nThat\u2019s no way to live! This series, which regularly takes place on both the East and West Coasts, is a consistently reliable bet for those comedy aficionados who want to catch up-and-comers before they\u2019ve signed their big-time sitcom or movie deals. Improv may already seem like a no-holds-barred kind of comedy outlet, but this popular recurring show takes it to a whole other level, throwing seasoned improvisers and trained actors into a mishmash of performative fun. The deal is that the actors are given a script with lines to memorize beforehand, while, true to form, the improvisers aren\u2019t. \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d stalwarts like Amy Poehler and Vanessa Bayer are frequently invited to partake at these performances, created and directed by Stephen Ruddy. The show is sold out, but a standby line will start forming about a half-hour before showtime.\n\n212-366-9176, hellskitchen.ucbtheatre.com\n\n\u2018RAPE JOKES: BY SURVIVORS\u2019 at Caveat (April 28, 7 p.m.). Almost no topic is too taboo in the world of comedy. Case in point: Men have been making rape jokes for years. This event flips that script. At this night of \u201cstorytelling, catharsis and laughter,\u201d female comedians who have been victims of sexual assault and harassment will share their experiences to \u201cchange the narrative of how we joke about rape.\u201d Caveat creates a safe space for the spotlight to shine on the 13 survivors who\u2019ll be taking the stage.\n\n212-228-2100, caveat.nyc", "title": "5 Comedy Shows to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Kasia Pilat"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\n#ADULTING at the Bell House (April 23, 8 p.m.). This biweekly show invites New York\u2019s LGBTQ improv performers from all experience levels for a comedy jam with the M.C. Peter Valenti and his all-queer troupe, Just a Phase. They host other all-queer improv teams at this event, but solo improvisers can also partake by joining the group on its Facebook page. Those teamless participants are then added to a mash-up team that Mr. Valenti assembles ahead of time. That way, anyone \u2014 from greenhorn newbies to seasoned veterans \u2014 can join in on the unscripted fun.\n\n212-244-1722, thepit-nyc.com\n\nMOVIES R DUMB PRESENTS \u2018REEFER MADNESS\u2019 at Q.E.D. Perhaps best known for playing the role of Silent Bob in many of the films he wrote and directed, Mr. Smith has been a familiar face since the release of his debut comedy, \u201cClerks,\u201d in 1994, a movie he famously sold his beloved comic book collection to make. Mr. Smith has since directed, written and acted in a number of other films and also added podcaster, comic book store owner and reality TV star to his r\u00e9sum\u00e9 \u2014 the series \u201cComic Book Men,\u201d on AMC, is shot at his Red Bank, N.J., shop. Before they hit the big leagues, catch the next generation of ballet stars in intimate environs as Ballet Theater\u2019s junior ensemble presents a mixed bill of classical and contemporary work. The program includes August Bournonville\u2019s \u201cWilliam Tell\u201d pas de deux and an excerpt from the Romantic staple \u201cGiselle\u201d as interpreted by Ethan Stiefel and Johan Kobborg. \u201cUntitled\u201d by the young British choreographer Liam Scarlett and new works by Marco Pelle and Lauren Lovette, a principal ballerina at New York City Ballet, will also be featured.\n\nabt.org\n\nBROOKLYN BALLET at the Actors Fund Arts Center (April 19-20, 8 p.m., through April 22). The lineup for Brooklyn Ballet\u2019s spring performances is practically a tour of 20th-century dance history. It begins with a juxtaposition of modern dance pioneer Isadora Duncan\u2019s \u201cChopin Dances\u201d with Michel Fokine\u2019s important 1909 ballet \u201cLes Sylphides.\u201d Two more giants follow: George Balanchine, represented by \u201cThe Four Temperaments\u201d (three of which will be shown), and modern master Merce Cunningham, represented by a duet from \u201cLandrover\u201d (1972). Lynn Parkerson, Brooklyn Ballet\u2019s founding artistic director, also includes two new works of her own.\n\nbrooklynballet.org\n\nLAR LUBOVITCH DANCE COMPANY at the Joyce Theater (April 17-18, 7:30 p.m., through April 22). One of the most enduring names in American modern dance, Lar Lubovitch has been choreographing for half a century. He will honor that remarkable milestone this week with three programs spanning more than 30 years, from \u201cA Brahms Symphony\u201d (1985), performed by students, to the premiere of a new work. Members of the Martha Graham Dance Company will join the anniversary celebration with performances of Mr. Lubovitch\u2019s \u201cThe Legend of Ten,\u201d as will dancers from the Joffrey Ballet with a selection from Mr. Lubovitch\u2019s full-length \u201cOthello.\u201d His acclaimed, tender exploration of masculinity in dance, \u201cMen\u2019s Stories: A Concerto in Ruin,\u201d anchors each program.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nLIL BUCK AND JON BOOGZ at N.Y.U. Skirball (April 14, 3 and 7:30 p.m.). The mesmerizing performers Lil Buck and Jon Boogz believe dance can make a substantive social impact, and they founded Movement Art Is to spread that message. On Saturday, they bring to New York \u201cLove Heals All Wounds,\u201d a vaguely narrative work that touches on police brutality and champions empathy and inclusion. Issues are evoked and emotions conveyed, with the help of a talented ensemble, through the duo\u2019s unique physicality, which mimics stop-motion animation and uses uncanny slow-motion techniques to imbue their work with a cinematic sense of tension, urgency, vitality and grace.\n\n212-998-4941, nyuskirball.org\n\nTHE V.4 DANCE FESTIVAL at N.Y.U. Skirball (April 19-20, 7:30 p.m.). The Visegrad group is the political alliance of the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia. This week they form a dance alliance as well with a two-day festival showcasing one artist from each country. On April 19, Vera Ondrasikova from the Czech Republic presents \u201cGuide,\u201d an audiovisual experience featuring lasers, and Pawe\u0142 Sakowicz from Poland performs \u201cTotal,\u201d a satirical look at virtuosity in dance. On April 20, the Debris Company from Slovakia offers \u201cWow!,\u201d a surreal portrait of humans and the environment, while Laszlo Fulop and Emese Cuhorka of Hungary tackle the concept of boredom in \u201cYour Mother at My Door.\u201d\n\n212-998-4941, nyuskirball.org", "title": "5 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Brian Schaefer"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nALAN RUDOLPH\u2019S EVERYDAY LOVERS at the Quad Cinema (April 27-May 10). A prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Robert Altman with a highly stylized approach to visuals and dialogue, Mr. Rudolph has \u2014 according to the Quad \u2014 never before received a retrospective of his own. To celebrate the director\u2019s return with \u201cRay Meets Helen\u201d (which opens on May 4), his first feature since \u201cThe Secret Lives of Dentists\u201d (showing on May 7 and 9) in 2003, the Quad is giving his movies a full airing. His Los Angeles romantic roundelay from 1984, \u201cChoose Me\u201d (on Friday and Wednesday), might be a strong dose of undiluted Rudolph. But the uninitiated could try \u201cThe Moderns\u201d (on Saturday and Thursday), from 1988, whose Lost Generation milieu gives shape and even some verisimilitude to Mr. Rudolph\u2019s verbal flights of fancy. (He wrote the script with Jon Bradshaw.) It centers on an American painter and forger (Keith Carradine) in Paris in the 1920s.\n\n212-255-2243, quadcinema.com", "title": "5 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cStage: \u2018Fool for Love,\u2019 Sam Shepard Western,\u201d by Frank Rich, published May 27, 1983.\n\nImage Credit Weichia Huang\n\nWhat No One Could Have Predicted\n\nLawrence K. Altman, M.D. joined The New York Times science news staff in 1969, and is believed to be the first licensed physician to work as a daily newspaper reporter.\n\nNew York and the rest of the world, including The New York Times, were ill-prepared for the arrival and spread of a new disease (later named AIDS) when the first cases were recognized among gay men in 1981. For three years, while fear tore through the gay community, the world\u2019s most sophisticated laboratories could not identify the cause. Experts debated various candidates (among them: toxins, drugs, sperm in the bowel) until the discovery of the retrovirus H.I.V. Even after epidemiologists documented that the virus spread only through sexual contact, childbirth or injections of contaminated drugs and blood, disbelievers shunned public restrooms and restaurants for fear that it could be passed through food and flatware. Many hospital workers avoided AIDS patients and left trays by the door where occupants were too weak to pick them up. Some doctors refused to treat AIDS patients.\n\nAt the time, medicine was celebrating the eradication of a naturally occurring disease (smallpox) from the world for the first time and installing the first artificial hearts in humans. Earlier, I had written about the discoveries of the Ebola and Lassa fever viruses and the Legionnaire\u2019s disease bacterium, as well as the ways in which health workers stopped outbreaks of these infections. Few thought \u2014 and certainly no one I know went on record to predict \u2014 that AIDS would become one of the worst pandemics in history, infecting an estimated 76 million people and killing 35 million of them.\n\nAt Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan, where, in the late 1970s, I was an attending physician in addition to working as a reporter at The Times, I saw a small number of young patients with unusual infections. Others had enlarged lymph nodes throughout their body. Many had been injection drug users. These cases baffled the medical staff.\n\nMy plans to write about the mysterious ailment before my first article about AIDS appeared on July 3, 1981 were thwarted by assigned coverage of the attempted assassinations of President Reagan and Pope John Paul II and by two broken elbows, souvenirs of an accident in Italy. My initial article focused on 41 cases of a rare cancer, Kaposi\u2019s sarcoma, in homosexual men (The Times did not allow people to be described as \u201cgay\u201d at that time) who also had seriously abnormal immune systems. But whether these immune issues were the cause of, or resulted from, their ailment was unknown. Many in the gay community ridiculed the article as a needless scare. Scientists who went on to become international leaders in battling AIDS considered this collection of cases to be an oddity, until a broader picture emerged in the advancing months and years. In 1985, I traveled through Africa to report that in many sub-Saharan countries, AIDS infected nearly as many women as men through heterosexual intercourse. I went on to write several hundred articles about scientific discoveries of the virus, its uncanny ability to trick the immune system and the development of drugs that now make AIDS a chronic disease. Despite these and other advances, it is still transmitted in this country and the world.\n\n\u201cRare Cancer Seen in 41 Homosexuals,\u201d by Lawrence K. Altman, published July 3, 1981.", "title": "5 New York Times Writers on What They Got Right and Wrong in the Early \u201980s", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "In Finland, for example, the Northern lapwing and Eurasian curlew have usually built their ground nests on barley fields after farmers have sown their crops in the spring. But as temperatures have risen, the birds are now increasingly laying their eggs before the farmers get to the fields, which means their well-concealed nests are more likely to get destroyed by tractors and other machinery.\n\nLooking at 38 years of data, researchers found that farmers in Finland are now sowing their fields a week earlier in response to warmer temperatures, but the birds are laying their eggs two to three weeks earlier. \u201cThis has created a phenological mismatch,\u201d said Mr. Santangeli, the lead author of the study. \u201cThe response we\u2019ll see is declines of these birds.\u201d\n\nCaribou show up late for lunch\n\nCaribou in western Greenland follow a strict seasonal diet. In the winter, they eat lichen along the coast. In the spring and summer, they venture inland to give birth to their calves and eat the Arctic plants that grow there.\n\nAs Greenland has warmed up and sea ice has declined, however, those inland Arctic plants have been emerging earlier \u2014 with some plant species now greening 26 days earlier than they did a decade ago. But the caribou have not shifted their migration as quickly. And scientists have documented a troubling trend in the region: More caribou calves appear to be dying early in years when the spring plant growth preceded the caribou\u2019s calving season.\n\nWhile that study only found a correlation between warmer temperatures and caribou calf deaths, \u201c it\u2019s consistent with the idea that mismatch is disadvantageous,\u201d said Eric Post, an ecology professor at the University of California, Davis. When Arctic plants green up earlier, they may become tougher and less nutritious by the time the caribou get there and start eating them.\n\nWhy don\u2019t the caribou speed up their migration? One possibility is that their reproductive cycles respond most strongly to seasonal signals like the length of the day, whereas plants respond more strongly to local temperatures, which are rising.\n\nIn theory, if given enough time, the caribou might eventually adjust as natural selection takes its course and favors individuals that calve earlier. But with the Arctic warming faster than the rest of the globe, Dr. Post said, \u201cthe question is whether things are changing too fast for evolution to matter.\u201d", "title": "5 Plants and Animals Utterly Confused by Climate Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s common for hotels along the Italian coast to be closed during the winter months and full to capacity during the summer. But between these extremes, the spring months offer an attractive combination of mild temperatures and lack of crowds. Hotels from the Lake District to the Amalfi Coast, all the way to Sardinia offer discounts for the season\u2019s first visitors in April, May and sometimes well into June.\n\nSun on the Shores of Lake Como\n\nAt the Grand Hotel Tremezzo on the shores of Lake Como, preseason rates start at $495 per night, compared to $750 per night for high season. This hotel is unique for its swimming experience; a floating pool is set right in the waters of Lake Como. In addition to beautiful water views, this family-owned property dating back to 1910 looks out at the Grigne Mountains and the village of Bellagio.\n\nBoutique Savings On the Sea\n\nCasa Angelina, a 39-room boutique hotel on the Amalfi Coast, reopened for the season on March 24. Located in the town of Praiano, with views of the Tyrrhenian Sea, this hotel also offers four rooms in old fishermen\u2019s houses. Rooms during the summer months start at $961 per night, but during the spring start at $604 per night. A special offer available through May 15 includes extra savings: a further 10 percent room discount and a $99 credit for food and beverages or for the on-site the spa.\n\nFine Dining and Views in Sorrento\n\nSet on top of a cliff in Sorrento, the Grand Hotel Excelsior Vittoria overlooks the Gulf of Naples and Mount Vesuvius. Spring rates start at $506 per night compared with $782 per night in the high season. Sea views are especially striking from the terrace, home to Terrazza Bosquet, a candlelit Michelin-starred restaurant.", "title": "5 Springtime Italian Coast Getaways for Less", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "But the majority report said that the intelligence case for attributing the email theft to Russians was \u201csignificant\u201d and that it had found \u201cno credible evidence,\u201d including in still-classified intelligence reports, supporting the alternative theory of \u201can insider.\u201d\n\nPro-Trump Statements Are Portrayed as Credible and His Opponents With Skepticism\n\nThe Republican report was often skeptical in tone about statements and testimony by people who put forward information that could be damaging to Mr. Trump, and more credulous about statements in his favor. For example, when discussing Mr. Steele, the Republican report uses suspicious terms, like saying he \u201cclaimed\u201d to have obtained his allegations from \u201cpurported\u201d high-level Russian sources. But when discussing testimony by witnesses who explained away various meetings with Russians, the report instead presents what they said with neutral terms, like \u201cstated,\u201d or uses words connoting the idea that they were acknowledging a truth.\n\nOne example of that concerns testimony by Rob Goldstone, who helped set up the June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower between Trump campaign officials and Russians. He wrote in an email to Donald Trump Jr. that the visitors wanted to provide damaging information about Mrs. Clinton that was \u201cpart of Russia and its government\u2019s support for Mr. Trump.\u201d But Mr. Goldstone later told Congress that he had no evidence supporting that statement, saying he had embellished his email with inaccurate information to get a response. The report says Mr. Goldstone \u201cadmitted\u201d this exonerating account.\n\nAn Attack on Leaks, and James Clapper\n\nThe Republican report is scathing about leaks to the news media that have brought to light various information about Trump-Russia contacts. Against that backdrop, it declares that James R. Clapper Jr., the former director of national intelligence, gave \u201cinconsistent testimony\u201d about his discussions of the so-called Steele dossier with Jake Tapper, the CNN anchor. (Many news outlets had copies of the dossier but did not report on its existence because they were unable to verify its contents. But in January 2017, CNN reported that intelligence officials had briefed Mr. Trump, then the president-elect, about the dossier, and BuzzFeed published it shortly after.)\n\nThe Republican report said that Mr. Clapper initially denied discussing the dossier with journalists but subsequently \u201cacknowledged\u201d having discussed it with Mr. Tapper and \u201cadmitted\u201d possibly talking about it with other reporters, too. The Democratic report portrays this passage as written to \u201csmear\u201d Mr. Clapper with a \u201cdark insinuation,\u201d saying it promotes a \u201cnarrative that former Obama administration officials, such as Clapper, leaked classified or sensitive information to the media.\u201d The Democratic report notes that the dossier was not classified.\n\nIt also provides an excerpt from a transcript of Mr. Clapper\u2019s testimony. It shows that he was asked whether he had discussed the dossier or intelligence related to Russia with journalists and replied \u201cno.\u201d But then, asked whether he confirmed or corroborated the dossier\u2019s contents to Mr. Tapper, Mr. Clapper acknowledged discussing the dossier with Mr. Tapper but said that was \u201cwhen it was out all over the place.\u201d The transcript is ambiguous about whether that meant they discussed it before or after CNN reported the briefing.", "title": "5 Takeaways From the House Report on Russian Election Meddling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Before you take a long bus trip, ask about the route, and whether it\u2019s a standard route that the driver has taken before. Well-maintained and well-lit roads are preferable to smaller ones, and have better access for emergency medical services should they be necessary. Ask if the driver has been behind the wheel for more than eight hours and if there is backup for long journeys. Most bus and tour companies that operate aboveboard should be willing to have this conversation with you, and those that aren\u2019t should arouse your suspicion. If you have doubts, consider taking a train or hiring a private car service with a local driver who is familiar with the region.\n\nAvoid Night Travel\n\nOvernight buses are a perennial favorite of budget-minded travelers who want to save on hotel stays. In some cases that may be true, but in many countries, particularly in rural areas, taking a bus at night or in early dawn hours is strongly discouraged because drivers often turn off their headlights; they falsely believe it saves the vehicle\u2019s batteries. The danger is exacerbated when roads are in bad condition, where visibility is poor, and in mountain areas with narrow, winding roads.\n\nIn countries with higher road safety standards and bus companies that operate more transparently, overnight bus trips may be an affordable and comfortable option, but it\u2019s critical to do your homework before booking one.\n\nSpot Red Flags Before You Depart\n\nBottom line, if something seems amiss, speak up. If a driver is being reckless or speeding, politely ask that he or she slow down. Be assertive. If the situation does not improve or if the driver seems impaired or overly fatigued, get off the bus as soon as possible. If you don\u2019t speak the language, ask a local to assist.\n\nAvoid buses in poor condition or that are crowded and top-heavy, which can offset the center of gravity. Check if the bus\u2019s tires are bald or low on air, or if the name of the company on the bus is unclear. You don\u2019t have to be a mechanic, but look the bus over as if it were your own vehicle, and decide if you feel safe enough to ride in it.\n\nAfter a crash, bus companies often close down, repaint their vehicles, and reopen under new names. \u201cLook at the vehicle and ask yourself,\u201d Ms. Sobel said \u201c\u2018is this the wisest choice?\u2019\u201d", "title": "5 Ways to Stay Safe on Bus Trips Abroad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "For the generation who learned more about math, grammar, history and civics from the interstitial cartoons on the ABC Saturday morning program \u201cSchoolhouse Rock!\u201d than they would care to admit, Bob Dorough was one of the most integral influences of their formative years \u2014 even if they didn\u2019t know his name.\n\nMr. Dorough, who died this week at 94, was a jazz musician, composer and singer, and the mastermind behind dozens of educational earwigs primarily in the \u201970s and \u201980s \u2014 a man who understood that the best way to trick children into learning was to wrap lessons inside irresistible, frequently funky ditties.\n\nHere are five of Mr. Dorough\u2019s most memorable \u201cSchoolhouse Rock!\u201d contributions, weighted for cleverness, pedagogical utility and the degree to which they\u2019ve taken up permanent residence our brains for over 40 years.\n\n[ Never miss a pop music story: Sign up for our weekly newsletter, Louder. ]\n\n\u2018Three Is a Magic Number\u2019", "title": "5 \u2018Schoolhouse Rock!\u2019 Songs From Bob Dorough We\u2019ll Never Forget", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "For decades, it seems, Diane Nash has been asked about women\u2019s role in the civil rights movement: what it was, why it hasn\u2019t been more widely acknowledged, if she can describe her fellow organizers\u2019 contributions.\n\nMs. Nash, now 79, led students in sit-ins and helped coordinate the historic 54-mile march from Selma to Montgomery. She has been portrayed in the film \u201cSelma.\u201d\n\nBut when asked again recently by The New York Times about women\u2019s contributions, she joked that the list was \u201cbrief.\u201d", "title": "50 Years After Dr. King\u2019s Death, Remembering the Women Who Steered the Movement", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nROBIN BLAZE AND ELIZABETH KENNY at Weill Recital Hall (April 11, 7:30 p.m.). The idea behind this recital from a noted countertenor and a lutenist is simple: Shakespeare\u2019s words, set to music, interspersed with readings from the playwright, given by the actor Simon Jones. Expect music by Purcell, Dowland and others.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nBOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA at Carnegie Hall (April 11-13, 8 p.m.). The big night is Thursday, which gives New York audiences a chance to hear the tenor Jonas Kaufmann sing Tristan for the first time, in a concert performance of Act II of Wagner\u2019s \u201cTristan und Isolde.\u201d He appears alongside Camilla Nylund as Isolde, Mihoko Fujimura as Brang\u00e4ne and Georg Zeppenfeld as Marke. Is yours? Here\u2019s an opportunity to find out: Audience members sign up as they would at an open mike to offer riffs of their own as they watch clips from bad movies. Mr. Conniff and his guest judges will chose the best riffer, who will try to hold his or her own against Mr. Conniff at the end of the night.\n\n347-451-3873, qedastoria.com\n\nDESUS AND MERO at Williamson Theater, Center for the Arts at the College of Staten Island (April 10, 8 p.m.). Now they\u2019re bringing their usually televised act to the stage in a five-stop tour across New York\u2019s boroughs. That\u2019s the good news. Since July 2017, the comedian Emma Vernon has hosted her brainchild of a show at the Peoples Improv Theater. In it, she lives out her dreams of being a matchmaker, \u00e0 la Patti Stanger (and persistent, impatient moms everywhere), and sets up dates between people who fill out a Google form with details like what they\u2019re looking for and descriptions of themselves. The potential couple meets onstage for the first time and picks a location out of a hat, after which improvisers jump in on the action and bring the scene to life. Ms. Vernon has yet to succeed in forging a lasting union, but perhaps her luck is about to change.\n\n212-563-7488, thepit-nyc.com/the-pit-striker\n\n\u2018LATE NIGHT WHENEVER\u2019 at the Jerome L. The course, which hosts the annual Phoenix Open tournament, is a few hundred feet from the airport\u2019s northern tip.\n\nA spokesman for the Scottsdale Police Department said that none of the six people on the plane survived. The plane crashed next to a green patch on the Champions Course, one of two courses at TPC Scottsdale, the police said. No one on the ground was injured.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration identified the plane as a Piper PA-24, a single-engine aircraft that can hold up to six people. It was not immediately clear what caused the crash or where the plane was headed, the authorities said.\n\nAn agency spokesman said that the F.A.A. and the National Transportation Safety Board were investigating. Members of the N.T.S.B. blocked off part of the golf course on Tuesday morning as they inspected the crash site.\n\nTPC Scottsdale is about 15 miles northeast of downtown Phoenix.", "title": "6 Killed in Plane Crash at Arizona Golf Course", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "BERLIN \u2014 Six men suspected of plotting a possible attack on the Berlin half-marathon on Sunday were detained by the police amid heightened security in Germany a day after a truck attack in the western city of M\u00fcnster killed two people.\n\nThe authorities said on Sunday that the M\u00fcnster attacker, a 48-year-old German citizen who turned a gun on himself after plowing into people at sidewalk tables, did not appear to be linked to Islamist terrorism or to hold any other political convictions.\n\nBut on a continent that has seen Islamic State supporters repeatedly turn vehicles into weapons to target civilians, the authorities remained on raised alert. In Berlin, roughly 630 officers were deployed along the marathon route.\n\nThe authorities said the six detained men had shown a suspicious level of interest in the race. \u201cAhead of the Berlin half-marathon there were scattered indications that the six detainees, aged 18 to 21, could have been involved in the plotting of a crime linked to this event,\u201d the Berlin police and prosecutors said in a joint statement.", "title": "6 Men Were Plotting Attack on Berlin Half-Marathon, Police Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Memos written by the former F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, that were released on Thursday revealed several new details about his relationship with President Trump and the president\u2019s first chief of staff, Reince Priebus.\n\nThough much of what the memos describe was already public, the documents themselves provided an intimate portrait of the early months of the Trump White House and how the president and Mr. Priebus confronted leaks, the prospect that the national security adviser was under investigation and allegations about Mr. Trump\u2019s ties to Russia.\n\nMr. Comey depicts Mr. Trump as a man engrossed to the point of distraction with political rivalries and fears that bureaucrats and government officials, including in the F.B.I., were trying to undermine his legitimacy.\n\n[Read the memos here.]\n\nThe president responded late Thursday by insisting that the memos showed no collusion with Moscow\u2019s election interference and that Mr. Comey had erred by leaking classified information. The memos were reviewed by Justice Department officials before being released.", "title": "6 Takeaways From the James Comey Memos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "A Beloved Cookbook Revised \u2014 With Art by Ed Ruscha and Ellsworth Kelly\n\nToo often I\u2019ve been guilty of buying cookbooks, then leaving them unopened on countertops. (Despite my culinary aspirations, I\u2019m not one for following directions.) And then there are the cookbooks I succumb to entirely for aesthetic reasons. But the new one by River Caf\u00e9 London distinguishes itself as something worthy of both display and dinner-making.\n\nCoinciding with the beloved London restaurant\u2019s 30th anniversary, the new tome features updated recipes from co-founders Ruth Rogers and Rose Gray\u2019s original 1995 cookbook \u2014 their famous Chocolate Nemesis Cake, for example \u2014 alongside 30 new favorites like crab and raw artichoke salad; white asparagus with bottarga butter; and mezze paccheri pasta with black pepper and langoustines.\n\nBut River Caf\u00e9 is about much more than what\u2019s on the menu (which changes twice daily). The restaurant\u2019s special synthesis of riverside garden terrace, open kitchen and local Thames Wharf community is reflected in the book\u2019s pages, which feature photography by Jean Pigozzi and design by the London firm Michael Nash Associates. Adding to the brightly hued chapter openers, fluorescent pink page edges, and Josef Albers font, the book boasts one-of-a-kind works from artist friends including Ellsworth Kelly, Peter Doig, Susan Elias, Damien Hirst and Ed Ruscha, who each used a page from the restaurant\u2019s menu as their canvas. Indeed, it might be worth getting a copy for the kitchen and the coffee table. On sale April 10, $40, penguinrandomhouse.com \u2014 LAURA NEILSON", "title": "6 Things T Editors Like Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA young sperm whale that washed ashore on the southeast coast of Spain in February most likely died after being unable to digest more than 60 pounds of plastic trash, fish netting and garbage bags in its stomach and intestines, scientists said this month.\n\nThe 33-foot-long whale was swept onto a rocky beach in Cape Palos, a port city on the Mediterranean Sea, on Feb. 27. It was not yet fully grown but weighed just 13,000 pounds, an unusually scrawny size for a whale that can reach 120,000 pounds as an adult.\n\nWhen scientists performed a necropsy, the reason became clear: The whale had 64 pounds of trash \u2014 plastic bags, ropes, netting and even a plastic drum \u2014 clogging its intestines and stomach. It could not process the garbage or pass it through its digestive system, causing severe inflammation as it withered away, officials in the region of Murcia said.\n\n\u201cThe presence of plastics in the seas and oceans is one of the greatest threats to the conservation of wildlife throughout the world,\u201d Consuelo Rosauro Meseguer, the region\u2019s environmental director, said in a statement.\n\nSperm whales, which are among the largest of their species, can dive thousands of feet deep into the darkest regions of the ocean to hunt for squid. But in between those deep dives, they often hang around the surface, making them susceptible to ingesting floating debris that might be mistaken for food.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPollution in the ocean has disastrous effects, particularly for wildlife. Because of the ocean\u2019s currents, some buoyant debris eventually settles in islands of trash that float above or just below the surface. One such area between California and Hawaii, known as the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, is now estimated to contain at least 87,000 tons of plastic.", "title": "64 Pounds of Trash Killed a Sperm Whale in Spain, Scientists Say", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nLAWRENCE BROWNLEE at Zankel Hall (April 24, 7:30 p.m.). What to pair with Schumann\u2019s \u201cDichterliebe,\u201d the classic first half of this recital from a fine tenor? \u201cWhy don\u2019t I think about doing some type of song cycle, detailing our own perspective of what it is to be a black man in America?\u201d Mr. Brownlee asked himself, according to a recent interview with The New York Times. Here, then, is the local premiere of \u201cCycles of My Being,\u201d with lyrics by the poet Terrance Hayes and music by Tyshawn Sorey, an outstanding young composer who will conduct a small accompanying ensemble.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nJULIA BULLOCK at Weill Recital Hall (April 20, 7:30 p.m.). Scratch your head to try to understand why Ms. Bullock, already a consummate artist, will be presented on the least of Carnegie\u2019s stages \u2014 and while you\u2019re at it, start dialing for returns. With the pianist John Arida, she performs Schubert, Barber and Faur\u00e9, as well as jazz and blues numbers.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nCHELSEA SYMPHONY at the American Museum of Natural History (April 22, 2 p.m.). Young.\n\nensemble-echappe.com\n\nNEW YORK PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (April 26, 7:30 p.m.; April 28, 8 p.m.).
