Edward Gardner, an increasingly solid conductor, is on the podium.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\n\u2018TOSCA\u2019 at the Metropolitan Opera (April 21, 8 p.m., through May 12). Anna Netrebko is singing Tosca. If you need to know more, note that her husband, Yusif Eyvazov, sings Cavaradossi, Michael Volle is Scarpia and Bertrand de Billy conducts in David McVicar\u2019s avowedly conservative production.\n\n212-362-6000, metopera.org\n\nDANIIL TRIFONOV at Carnegie Hall (April 25-26, 8 p.m.). More from Mr. Trifonov\u2019s Perspectives series this week, but the view is singular: Nothing but Chopin is on the agenda, all with the help of the Kremerata Baltica, a chamber orchestra. On Wednesday, works include the Piano Trio (with Gidon Kremer and Giedre Dirvanauskaite) and the Piano Concerto No. 1; on Thursday, there\u2019s the Piano Concerto No. 2, the Cello Sonata (with Gautier Capu\u00e7on) and more.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org", "title": "7 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (April 27, 8 p.m.; April 29, 3 p.m.). My colleague Zachary Woolfe has declared that while the Cleveland Orchestra is the best in America, the Los Angeles Philharmonic is the most important, not least for the daring of its programming and the capaciousness of its vision for what an orchestra can and should be. Only parts of that vision make it to New York for this stop on the ensemble\u2019s tour, but there\u2019s still much to look forward to. On Friday, Shostakovich\u2019s Symphony No. 5 is prefaced by Var\u00e8se\u2019s \u201cAm\u00e9riques\u201d and a new piece by Esa-Pekka Salonen, \u201cPollux\u201d; for Sunday\u2019s matinee, Bernstein\u2019s \u201cChichester Psalms\u201d introduces Beethoven\u2019s Symphony No. 9. Gustavo Dudamel conducts.\n\n212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org\n\nNEW YORK PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (May 3, 7:30 p.m., through May 8). He may have been beaten to the music directorship by Jaap van Zweden, or so rumor has it, but Manfred Honeck remains the finest musician mounting the Philharmonic\u2019s podium on a regular basis. His concerts have been some of the orchestra\u2019s finest in the past few years. He conducts selections from Tchaikovsky\u2019s \u201cSleeping Beauty,\u201d his own \u201cRusalka Fantasy\u201d \u2014 a suite arranged from Dvorak\u2019s opera with the aid of Thomas Ille \u2014 and Sibelius\u2019s Violin Concerto. Nikolaj Znaider, who plays the Sibelius with cold fire, is the soloist.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\nNOVUS NY at Trinity Wall Street (May 3, 1 p.m.). Trust Julian Wachner, who has turned Trinity Wall Street into a musical powerhouse, to take an unusually interesting approach to an anniversary that has dominated so much of the classical music season, that of Leonard Bernstein\u2019s 100th birthday. Throughout this series, \u201cTotal Embrace,\u201d the free concerts have included music by Bernstein himself, music he was associated with as a conductor, music by other composer-conductors and new music by composers working today. This Thursday, see the premiere of Mr. Wachner\u2019s \u201cEpistle Mass,\u201d as well as Mahler\u2019s \u201cKindertotenlieder,\u201d sung by Stephen Salters.\n\n212-602-0800, trinitywallstreet.org/music-arts\n\nMAURIZIO POLLINI at Carnegie Hall (April 29, 2 p.m.). Detractors lament Mr. Pollini\u2019s loss of dexterity and technical accomplishment in his eighth decade, but they tend to think that precision is all he ever had. Those who think that view wrong, as I do, would be wise to hear this pianist at every opportunity. Chopin and Debussy make up the bill.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org", "title": "7 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Inspectors from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons arrived in Damascus, Syria, on Saturday to investigate the attack in Douma, the group said in a post on Twitter.\n\nMr. Mattis was working to slow the move toward a military response, concerned that a missile strike could spark a wider conflict between Russia, Iran and the West.\n\nAnd Mr. Trump sent mixed signals about timing. On Wednesday, he warned Russia on Twitter that missiles \u201cwill be coming, nice and new and \u2018smart!\u2019 \u201d But the next day, he added: \u201cNever said when an attack on Syria would take place. Could be very soon or not so soon at all!\u201d\n\nAt a news conference on Saturday morning, Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain said that the strikes had been \u201cthe right thing to do,\u201d in part for the \u201coperational security\u201d of those carrying them out.\n\nAssad absorbed another blow.\n\nThe airstrikes sent an unambiguous message to Mr. Assad, and it was not clear that it would change his thinking. He remained firmly in power thanks to the support of Russia and Iran.\n\nMr. Assad has essentially been under siege since the Syrian civil war began more than seven years ago. In that time, he has dealt with the war, airstrikes, sanctions, Islamic State militants, a variety of rebel groups and a crumbling economy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs Syrian state news media reported that many of the missiles had been intercepted, the Syrian presidency\u2019s Twitter account posted a video that appeared to show Mr. Assad showing up for just another day at the office.\n\nThe events depicted could not be independently verified.\n\nCapitol Hill remained divided.\n\nThe reaction in Washington was divided along party lines, with the strikes bringing praise from Republicans and criticism from Democrats like Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader.\n\n\u201cThe Butcher of Damascus learned two lessons tonight the hard way,\u201d Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, said in a statement. \u201cWeapons of mass destruction won\u2019t create a military advantage once the United States is done with you and Russia cannot protect its clients from the United States.\u201d\n\nSenator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, complained that Mr. Trump had not sought permission from Congress. Proceeding with the strikes, he said, was \u201cillegal and \u2014 absent a broader strategy \u2014 it\u2019s reckless.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRussia deploys angry rhetoric.\n\nRussia called for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council and offered some harsh warnings before the attack. (At the meeting, the Security Council later rejected a Russian resolution condemning the missile strikes.) But the speed and the tone of the Russian reaction on Saturday, stressing that the attack had not resulted in a direct confrontation and was rather limited, suggested almost relief on the part of the Kremlin.\n\nAccording to Russian state news media, President Vladimir V. Putin condemned the missile strikes as an \u201cact of aggression against a sovereign state\u201d and against the United Nations Charter.\n\nGen. Valery V. Gerasimov, the chief of staff for the armed forces, had warned that Russia would \u201ctake retaliatory measures,\u201d but he included an important caveat: Russia would attack missiles and the platforms from which they were launched only in the event that Russian military personnel were placed in danger.\n\nThe Federation Council, the upper house of the Russian Parliament, stated that it would discuss the airstrikes \u201cnext week.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMay avoided a conflict at home.\n\nMrs. May has said she believed there was a need to send a strong message about the use of chemical weapons, but she also had compelling diplomatic and political reasons to support the United States \u2014 and to carry out the strikes as soon as possible.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne imperative was the desire to reciprocate the support London has received from the United States in the dispute with Russia over the poisoning of a former spy, Sergei V. Skripal, and his daughter, Yulia S. Skripal, on British soil.\n\nMrs. May, who made an explicit connection between the airstrikes in Syria and the poisoning of the Skripals, benefited from the timing of the airstrikes, two days before lawmakers were to return from vacation. While not obligated to consult Parliament, she may have felt constrained to do so and could easily have lost a vote on a strike, as her predecessor David Cameron did in 2013.\n\nBritain also wants to prove its use as an ally to Mr. Trump at a time when its international influence is under question because of its withdrawal from the European Union, and when it hopes to strengthen trade ties with the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor France, a red line was crossed.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron had prepared his nation for this moment: He had discussed the possibility of airstrikes and made clear early in his presidency that the use of chemical weapons was a red line.\n\nWhile pressing for a military response to the use of chemical weapons, Mr. Macron has also said he wants to work on a peace deal for the region, creating a dual-pronged strategy that has support in France. Mr. Macron has cultivated a closer relationship with Mr. Trump than other Western leaders, but he has also reached out to Mr. Putin.\n\nHe will visit both presidents in the coming weeks: Mr. Trump at the end of April and Mr. Putin in May.", "title": "7 Takeaways From the Airstrikes on Syria", "authors": ["Michael Wolgelenter"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018GENIUSES\u2019 at Tada! Youth Theater (April 28-May 20). There\u2019s a reason that the words \u201cevil\u201d and \u201cgenius\u201d are sometimes paired. In this new musical, with a book and lyrics by Jon Agee and a score by Dan Feigelson, two students from a school for children whose learning styles are outside the mainstream sneak into an exclusive institution for those with extraordinarily high I.Q.s. In addition to creating some welcome disruption, the infiltrators discover that one of the elite school\u2019s pupils is bent on world domination. The show is performed by a cast that knows all about student life: the members of the Tada! Resident Youth Ensemble, ages 8 through 18.\n\n212-252-1619, ext. 5; tadatheater.com\n\n\u2018LEGO BRICKS: A CELEBRATION!\u2019 OPENING PARTY at Scandinavia House (April 28, 3-5 p.m.). Where in New York City can you find more than 30,000 loose Lego bricks just waiting to be played with? (Yes, that means other than under your own sofa cushions, bed covers and carpets.) The answer is Scandinavia House, the center for Nordic culture, which is honoring the 60th anniversary of this signature Danish invention with the exhibition \u201cLego Bricks: A Celebration!\u201d Opening on Saturday with snacks, live music and other free festivities, it features thousands of the building pieces within an interactive play zone. It also details the Lego Group\u2019s history: The name comes from the first two letters of each of the words in the Danish phrase \u201clege godt,\u201d which means \u201cplay well.\u201d On view through Aug. 4 and accompanied by a series of children\u2019s workshops, the exhibition demonstrates what a talented grown-up can do with Lego, too: The artist Sean Kenney has created mosaics, busts, models of plants, reproductions of architectural landmarks and even larger-than-life sculptures.\n\n212-779-3587, scandinaviahouse.org\n\nOPEN STUDIO FOR \u2018NICK MAUSS: TRANSMISSIONS\u2019 at the Whitney Museum of American Art (April 28, 10:30 a.m.-3 p.m.). Ballet is often much more than movement: It can also incorporate costume design, visual art, acting and storytelling, disciplines that the artist Nick Mauss explores in \u201cTransmissions,\u201d his installation at the Whitney. In this program, young visitors can investigate them, too. (A parental advisory: The exhibition, on a different floor from the open studio, includes some nude photographs.) Alexandra Albrecht, a member of Mr. Mauss\u2019s rotating cast of performers \u2014 the exhibition features live dances daily \u2014 will appear at the open studio from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., showing participants how to shape their bodies to reflect personas. Family members will work together to create their own costumes and characters, posing for take-home collaborative portraits that Whitney staff members will photograph.\n\n212-570-3600, whitney.org/events\n\n\u2018THE POLAR BEARS GO UP\u2019 at Flushing Town Hall (April 28, 2:15 p.m.). To many people, polar bears, which inhabit the Arctic Circle, are already pretty far up. But in this production, they go way, way up \u2014 into the atmosphere. Created and performed by Eilidh MacAskill and Fiona Manson and presented by the London-based Unicorn Theater, this Queens show focuses on the title characters\u2019 comic efforts to retrieve a balloon, which include energetic leaps, tree climbing and ultimately a rocket launch. Although a preshow movement-and-music workshop with the cast, at 12:30 p.m., has very few available spaces, plenty of seats remain for the performance, a wordless 50-minute journey that is geared to preschool travelers.\n\n718-463-7700, ext. 222; flushingtownhall.org\n\n", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nBALLET WORKSHOP AND STORYTIME: CELEBRATING JEROME ROBBINS at the Children\u2019s Center at 42nd Street, New York Public Library (April 6, 3 p.m.). Imagine getting professional instruction in dancing the first movement of a Jerome Robbins ballet \u2014 no tuition, audition or previous experience required. That\u2019s the opportunity the library will present to children on Friday as part of a yearlong series of events commemorating Robbins\u2019s 100th birthday. Recommended for dance fans 5 and older, the program will center on \u201cGlass Pieces,\u201d a ballet that was choreographed to music by Philip Glass and captures the breakneck pace and fierce purpose of pedestrians on New York streets. (Robbins was a city native.) An evocative picture book \u2014 Salvatore Rubbino\u2019s \u201cA Walk in New York\u201d \u2014 will be read to the young participants, who will then learn the dance from Deborah Lohse, a choreographer and performance artist. Each child will leave with not only the memory of the steps, but also a free copy of the book. (Space is limited, and registration is required.)\n\n212-621-0208, nypl.org/events\n\nCATSBURY PARK CAT CONVENTION at Convention Hall and the Paramount Theater, Asbury Park, N.J. (April 7-8, 11 a.m.-7 p.m.). This isn\u2019t the Asbury Park that Bruce Springsteen immortalized \u2014 he didn\u2019t add meows to any of his tracks \u2014 but this temporary addition to the boardwalk still promises to be worth a road trip. With proceeds benefiting Catsbury Park, a local cat cafe and rescue organization, this festival will host appearances by celebrity animals like Lil Bub and Nala, as well as seminars on cat care and a D.J. providing feline-themed tunes. Children may especially enjoy attractions like cat trivia, cat bingo, a cat costume competition and a yoga session with cats.\n\ncatsburyconvention.com\n\nDISCOVER OPERA! \u2018OPERAPUNZEL\u2019 AND \u2018THE MAGIC FLUTE\u2019 at the Manhattan School of Music (April 8, 2:30 p.m.; April 9, 6:30 p.m.). Rapunzel won\u2019t be alone in letting down her hair: Nothing is staid or formulaic during these free concert performances from the Manhattan School of Music\u2019s outreach program. Intended to introduce children to opera, the double bill leads off with \u201cOperapunzel.\u201d The hourlong work by Mark Janas (and the cast) sets \u201cRapunzel\u201d in a 1960s hair salon and explains the art form\u2019s terms and elements. It will be followed by a 45-minute adaptation of Mozart\u2019s fanciful \u201cThe Magic Flute.\u201d (If your family isn\u2019t ready for an opera doubleheader, the school will also offer a relaxed, lower-volume \u201cOperapunzel,\u201d geared toward children on the autism spectrum or with special needs, on Sunday at 11:30 a.m.)\n\n917-493-4428, msmnyc.edu/performances\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018THE LITTLE BLACK FISH\u2019 at Triskelion Arts (through April 8). This children\u2019s tale from the 1960s by the Iranian writer Samad Behrangi doesn\u2019t sound particularly subversive: Its title character longs to explore the world beyond his small pond and see what influence he can have on others. Nevertheless, the story\u2019s nonconformist theme was strong enough to cause Iran\u2019s prerevolutionary government to ban the work. But while Mr. Behrangi\u2019s career was brief, his fiction has lived on, and now Maaa Theater Company has adapted \u201cThe Little Black Fish\u201d for the stage. Combining music, narration, physical theater and video, this Brooklyn production illuminates an adventure in which a tiny hero has a huge impact.\n\n571-212-7796, blackfish.bpt.me", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "KAZOOM FEST at Harlem School of the Arts (April 20, 7 p.m.; April 21, 3 p.m.). The interactive digital stories published by KaZoom Kids Books have heroes and heroines unlike those in most children\u2019s works: They\u2019re black and Latino. Now the Harlem School of the Arts is bringing three of these tales to the stage in a theater festival starring its students and some of their parents. The productions are adaptations of \u201cTaking the E Train\u201d and \u201cEverybody Loves Cake,\u201d stories about a Latino family by Lapacazo Sandoval, and \u201cAlyssa Marissa and Her Magical Hair,\u201d by Angela Williams, which follows an African-American second grader as she learns to love her unruly curls. Both authors will discuss their fiction before the shows.\n\n212-926-4100, hsanyc.org\n\nNEXT GENERATION NOW at the PEN World Voices Festival in Manhattan and the Bronx (April 21 at various times). For centuries, young people have been agents of change, and PEN America, the literary organization promoting freedom of expression, is actively encouraging them. This year, its PEN World Voices Festival, whose theme is \u201cResist and Reimagine,\u201d is featuring Next Generation Now, a new series of more than a dozen programs aimed at aspiring writers and political advocates from preschool through high school. Little Activists: A Workshop and a Mini-March, at 3:30 p.m. at Town Stages, invites children in the second and third grades and younger to meet Leila Sales, author of \u201cThe Little Book of Little Activists,\u201d and some of the children she has written about. Family Affair: Color Me Abstract, from 1 to 4:30 p.m. at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, offers art-making and writing workshops for ages 4 through 12 led by the authors Tony Medina and Liza Jessie Peterson. These events are free with R.S.V.P.; some of the others require tickets. A full schedule is on the website.\n\n646-981-0689, worldvoices.pen.org\n\n\u2018THE NUMBER ON GREAT-GRANDPA\u2019S ARM\u2019 at the Museum of Jewish Heritage \u2014 A Living Memorial to the Holocaust (through April 29). How do you explain the Holocaust to children? The short film \u201cThe Number on Great-Grandpa\u2019s Arm\u201d offers a simple answer: Let a child do it. Presented by HBO and the museum, the documentary captures the tender relationship between Elliott Saiontz, 10, and his 90-year-old great-grandfather, Jack Feldman, a survivor of Auschwitz. Elliott provides much of the narration in the 19-minute movie, which juxtaposes archival photographs and film clips with Mr. Feldman\u2019s soft-spoken recollections and the hand-painted animation of Jeff Scher, which, though haunting, is less grim than historical footage. Produced and directed by Amy Schatz, the film is at the heart of this museum installation. Visitors can see the documentary on a continuous loop alongside hundreds of its images, including 24 of Mr. Scher\u2019s original watercolors. Although Mr. Feldman suffered greatly \u2014 first sent to a labor camp at 14, he never saw his parents again \u2014 he seems happy to be alive, surrounded by the love of the generations that the Nazis tried so hard to erase.\n\n646-437-4202, mjhnyc.org\n\nTHE PUPPET MASTER: THE COMPLETE JIRI TRNKA at the Walter Reade Theater (April 20-25 at various times). \u201cPuppet\u201d is a word that can conjure pure silliness and slapstick, but the work of the Czech filmmaker Jiri Trnka (pronounced YIR-zhee TURN-kah), a pioneer in puppet animation, is sophisticated, elegant, intricately beautiful and occasionally dark. This touring series from the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which has billed it as the first complete United States retrospective of the career of Trnka (1912-69), has fairy-tale films that children in elementary school may enjoy, as well as political allegories that teenagers can appreciate. Some of the family-friendly titles are \u201cThe Emperor\u2019s Nightingale\u201d (1948), a dialogue-free version of a Hans Christian Andersen story; \u201cBayaya\u201d (1950), a medieval adventure with English subtitles; and \u201cTales and Collaborations,\u201d a program of shorts whose subjects include circuses and toys. And don\u2019t miss \u201cA Midsummer Night\u2019s Dream\u201d (1959), a 72-minute Shakespeare adaptation narrated by the actor Richard Burton.\n\n212-875-5601, filmlinc.org\n\n", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Nine years later, while Mr. Guzm\u00e1n was fighting another competitor, the Beltr\u00e1n Leyva organization, he received word that one of its top lieutenants, Israel Rinc\u00f3n Mart\u00ednez, had been kidnapped by his henchmen, the government said. According to the memo, Mr. Rinc\u00f3n was shuttled between a series of Mr. Guzm\u00e1n\u2019s properties, where he was tortured and questioned by Mr. Guzm\u00e1n\u2019s cousin, Juan Guzm\u00e1n Rocha. Even though Mr. Guzm\u00e1n ordered the interrogators not to kill Mr. Rinc\u00f3n until he got there, the memo claimed that by the time he arrived, Mr. Rinc\u00f3n was dead.\n\nThe memo clearly sought to portray Mr. Guzm\u00e1n, 58, as a calculating and violent man. In 2006, for instance, after relaxing over lunch, he had two members of the Zetas beaten, the government said, then shot them both in the head \u201cwith a long gun.\u201d According to the memo, Mr. Guzm\u00e1n then \u201cordered his workers to dig a hole in the ground, throw the bodies in the hole and light the bodies on fire.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Guzm\u00e1n\u2019s lawyer, A. Eduardo Balarezo, said on Tuesday that he was reviewing the memo and would \u201crespond in due course.\u201d\n\nFor several months, Mr. Balarezo has been arguing \u2014 mostly to no avail \u2014 that Mr. Guzm\u00e1n cannot get a fair trial with the severe restrictions placed on him in custody and the sensational publicity surrounding the prosecution. On Monday, he filed his own court papers asking the government to provide him with the criminal histories of the various drug lords, couriers, enforcers and accountants that prosecutors may put on the stand \u2014 as many as 40 witnesses, some of whom may be allowed to testify under aliases.\n\nThose witnesses will likely be the ones who describe the brutalities the government included in its memo, but their accounts will not be the only evidence presented. Prosecutors wrote that they also had satellite photos of Mr. Guzm\u00e1n and his operation, seized drug ledgers, dozens of videos, thousands of intercepted phone calls and emails, and more than 300,000 pages of documents. They said they might even offer evidence about payments Mr. Guzm\u00e1n made to his lawyers as \u201cproof of the defendant\u2019s unexplained wealth and substantial income.\u201d\n\nAnd yet there remain certain things that the government does not want the jury to hear. The memo said that included any suggestion of the charitable works that Mr. Guzm\u00e1n performed in Mexico or his recent announcement through a lawyer that he was planning to run \u2014 from his jail cell in New York \u2014 for the Mexican Senate.\n\nThe government has also asked the presiding judge, Brian M. Cogan, to exclude any mention of the interview that the actor Sean Penn conducted with Mr. Guzm\u00e1n for Rolling Stone magazine in 2015 while Mr. Guzm\u00e1n was hiding at a safe house in the hills of Mexico. The government took issue with the interview because in it, Mr. Penn referred to Mr. Guzm\u00e1n as \u201ca Robin Hood-like figure\u201d and alleged that the American drug-buying public was complicit in his crimes.", "title": "7 Tons of Cocaine in Jalape\u00f1o Cans: The Evidence Against El Chapo", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Philadelphia 76ers, winners of 10 games just two seasons ago, advanced to the second round of the Eastern Conference playoffs for the first time since 2012 with a 104-91 win over the Miami Heat in Game 5 on Tuesday.\n\nJoel Embiid had 19 points and 12 rebounds, Ben Simmons had 14 points and 10 boards, and the victorious hosts had celebrities, politicians and kids dancing in the aisles, spurred by the presence of the rapper Meek Mill, who was ordered free from prison while he appeals decade-old gun and drug convictions.\n\nHe was taken from prison by helicopter to Philadelphia, where he rang the ceremonial bell at the start of Game 5.\n\n\u201cWelcome home Meek Mill,\u201d the public address announcer declared as wild cheers drowned out the rest. Mill sat courtside next to the actor and comedian Kevin Hart and the 76ers\u2019 co-owner Michael Rubin.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJust having someone that looks out for us, all of us here, it would just mean a lot for him to be back in Philly, in the city of Philadelphia with the fans, especially with a game like that tonight,\u201d Simmons said.", "title": "76ers Advance as Celtics Have Bucks on Brink of Elimination", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Despite it all, the 76ers were unfazed.\n\nPhiladelphia turned a 10-point deficit into a 7-point lead with a 19-2 run that ended midway through the fourth quarter, then absorbed the best shot Dwyane Wade could throw at the 76ers in the final minutes before heading home with a chance to close out the Heat in Game 5 on Tuesday.\n\nWade led all scorers with 25 points off the Heat bench, 12 of them in the fourth. But it wasn\u2019t enough.\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t let you off the hook,\u201d Wade said, tipping his cap to the 76ers. \u201cYou make one mistake, or you take your foot off the gas for one second, they make you pay.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWade doesn\u2019t have a contract for next season. He has said if he plays, he\u2019ll be back with Miami \u2014 though there are no guarantees.\n\nAnd that means Saturday might have been his last home game in a Heat uniform. If he knows what the future holds, he didn\u2019t offer any hints.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m focused on the next game, trying to win that one,\u201d Wade said.\n\nSimmons\u2019s triple-double consisted of 17 points, 13 rebounds and 10 assists. The distinguished pianist performs a mix of the expected and the surprising on this program, with Bach\u2019s English Suite No. 6 and Beethoven\u2019s Op. 101 Piano Sonata on the one hand, and music by Byrd and Debussy on the other.\n\n212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org/great-performers\n\nJUILLIARD ORCHESTRA at David Geffen Hall (April 16, 7:30 p.m.). My colleague Zachary Woolfe recently wrote that in a time when we ought to rethink our very idea of what a conductor could and should be, Alan Gilbert\u2019s tenure at the New York Philharmonic was \u201cmore of a model than I recognized.\u201d Perhaps so, though I still have more doubts about the caliber of the performances he put in. Either way, here\u2019s a chance to listen again, hard, as Mr. Gilbert conducts the young players of the Juilliard Orchestra in Barber\u2019s Essay No. 1, Rouse\u2019s Flute Concerto (with the soloist Giorgio Consolati) and Brahms\u2019s Symphony No. 1.\n\n212-799-5000, juilliard.edu\n\nMATA FESTIVAL at the Kitchen (April 13, 8 p.m.). A greatest hits parade of some of the most important music to come out of this crucial festival in its first 20 years, including Randy Hostetler\u2019s \u201cP(l)aces,\u201d Carlos Gutierrez Quiroga\u2019s \u201cJintili,\u201d Kate Moore\u2019s \u201cSensitive Spot\u201d and Eric Wubbels\u2019s \u201cViola Quartet (IJVER).\u201d\n\nmatafestival.org\n\nNEW YORK PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (April 19, 7:30 p.m., through April 24). Mozart and Bruckner are on the bill this week, with Till Fellner playing the Piano Concerto No. 22 and Christoph Eschenbach conducting it, and Bruckner\u2019s frightening, unfinished Symphony No. 9.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\nMARK PADMORE AND PAUL LEWIS at Alice Tully Hall (April 19, 7:30 p.m.). At least among partnerships in which the pianist is a recognized soloist in his own right, I can think of no finer duo in lieder than this. Unusually, here there is not a bar of Schubert in sight. There is plenty of Schumann, however, with the \u201cLiederkreis\u201d and the \u201cDichterliebe,\u201d as well as songs by Brahms.\n\n212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org/great-performers", "title": "8 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\n\u00a1ADELANTE, CUBA! FESTIVAL at New York City Center and the Jerome L. Greene Performance Space (April 22-28). The highlight of this celebration of Cuban music and dance is the appearance of the Havana-based Acosta Danza, led by the ballet star Carlos Acosta (April 25-27). The City Center program offers dances by Goyo Montero, Marianela Bo\u00e1n, Ra\u00fal Reinoso and Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui; in Mr. Cherkaoui\u2019s \u201cMermaid,\u201d Mr. Acosta graces the stage in a duet depicting a chance encounter between two tipsy partners. The program wraps up with Jorge Crecis\u2019s brisk, athletic \u201cTwelve.\u201d The festival also includes master classes and talks at City Center\u2019s studios, as well as an opening program featuring the jazz artist Arturo O\u2019Farrill, the tap dancer Ayodele Casel and the trumpet player Yasek Manzano at the Greene Space at WNYC and WQXR.\n\n212-581-1212, nycitycenter.org\n\nBALLET DU GRAND TH\u00c9\u00c2TRE DE GEN\u00c8VE at the Joyce Theater (April 24-25, 7:30 p.m.; April 26-27, 8 p.m.; through April 29). This Swiss company, led by Philippe Cohen, returns to the Joyce with the United States premiere of Pontus Lidberg\u2019s evening-length \u201cUne Autre Passion.\u201d In it, Mr. Lidberg, a choreographer and filmmaker, reimagines Bach\u2019s \u201cSt. Matthew Passion\u201d with a mix of dance and video that explores the music through the themes of suffering and desire.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nCOLUMBIA BALLET COLLABORATIVE at Miller Theater (April 21, 8 p.m.; April 22, 3 p.m.). This student-run dance company attracts talent, both in its dancers, who study at Columbia University, and in its established and up-and-coming choreographers. (Justin Peck, the resident choreographer of New York City Ballet, got his start here.) For the group\u2019s spring season, the lineup includes Jerome Robbins\u2019s \u201cAntique Epigraphs,\u201d a 1984 work set to Debussy that brings Greek friezes to life. There will also be dances by Miro Magloire, Caili Quan, Michele Wiles, Allegra Herman and Connor Yockus.\n\n212-854-7799, columbiaballetcollaborative.com", "title": "8 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Susan was given to Elizabeth later that year, as an 18th birthday present. According to an article in Vanity Fair, Elizabeth, then a princess, became so inseparable with her dog that she sneaked Susan with her and Prince Philip on their honeymoon in 1947.\n\nOver the nearly 80 years since the queen acquired Susan, she and her family have continued to breed dogs from Susan\u2019s lineage. The queen has owned at least 30 Pembroke Welsh corgis, all of whom have descended from Susan. Willow was believed to be part of the 14th generation in the line.\n\nBut Willow\u2019s death would signal the end of an era for the queen, who reportedly stopped breeding corgis sometime after the death of her mother in 2002.\n\nIn 2015, Monty Roberts, a horse trainer who has advised Queen Elizabeth, told Vanity Fair that the queen said to him in 2012 that \u201cshe didn\u2019t want to leave any young dog behind.\u201d\n\nThe Palace Still Has \u2018Dorgis\u2019\n\nStill, while Buckingham Palace may have lost its corgis, the so-called \u201cdorgis\u201d remain.\n\nThe queen has two such dogs, Vulcan and Candy, who are part of a crossbreed created when a dachshund belonging to the queen\u2019s sister, Princess Margaret, mated with one of the queen\u2019s corgis.\n\nQueen Elizabeth has also had other dogs over the years, including hunting dogs like the ones bred at Sandringham, her royal estate in Norfolk, England, just over 100 miles north of Buckingham Palace. At one point, she also adopted a Sealyham terrier from her sister.\n\nBeware of the Dogs\n\nDespite the constant presence of animals, the corgis\u2019 time with the royal family has not been without incident.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1954, one of the queen\u2019s corgis \u2014 there were three at the time \u2014 bit a member of the Queen\u2019s Guard. Some time earlier, The International Herald Tribune reported, one of them, believed to be Susan, had also bitten the royal clockwinder.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFourteen years later, a member of Parliament called upon the royal family to post \u201cBeware of the Dog\u201d signs outside the queen\u2019s residences after one of the corgis bit a postal worker delivering mail to Balmoral Castle in Scotland.\n\nThe queen herself hasn\u2019t been spared, either. In 1991, she was bitten by one of the dogs after she tried to break up a fight between some of them, Reuters reported.\n\nShe wasn\u2019t the only victim; her mother\u2019s chauffeur at the time was also bitten and had to receive a tetanus shot.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t the only time relationships between the dogs and the royal staff have sometimes been strained. In 1999, a royal footman was demoted after he allegedly spiked the dogs\u2019 food and water with gin and whiskey. He was reportedly caught when an exam on one of the dogs found traces of alcohol in its blood.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018Barking All the Time\u2019\n\nIt also appears that not everyone in the royal family has shared the queen\u2019s enthusiasm for her fleet of corgis. In a television interview in 2012, Prince William, the queen\u2019s grandson and the second in line to the British throne, expressed some issues with the dogs.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re barking all the time,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t know how she copes with it.\u201d\n\nPrince Harry, his brother, has also registered a noise complaint. \u201cI\u2019ve spent the last 33 years being barked at,\u201d he told the BBC in 2017.\n\nOne person who did receive the dogs\u2019 approval? Prince Harry\u2019s fianc\u00e9e, Meghan Markle.\n\nIn the BBC interview, the prince commented that the dogs \u201ctook to [Markle] straight away.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s true,\u201d Ms. Markle replied.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t the dogs\u2019 only moment in the spotlight.\n\nIn 2012, Willow co-starred in a sketch that opened the London Olympics. In the taped skit, James Bond (played by Daniel Craig) travels to Buckingham Palace to escort the queen to the Olympic opening ceremony. Joining Willow were Holly, who reportedly died in 2016, and Monty, who died in 2012.\n\nThe corgis are featured in close-ups as they greet Bond, follow him and the queen down the stairs of the palace and stay still as a helicopter takes off for London Stadium.\n\nWillow and Holly, along with their dorgi cousins, were also featured prominently in a Vanity Fair cover that celebrated the queen\u2019s 90th birthday. In a photograph taken by Annie Leibovitz, Holly sits next to queen in Windsor Castle while Willow, Vulcan and Candy roam at her feet.\n\nThe Corgis in Pop Culture\n\nOver the nearly 80 years that the queen has owned the corgis, they have become so closely associated with her that the dogs have even made their way into pop culture depictions of the monarchy.\n\nThe dogs are featured in \u201cThe King\u2019s Speech,\u201d the 2010 movie depicting King George VI\u2019s ascension to the throne. The corgis are prominent enough throughout \u201cThe Queen,\u201d in which Helen Mirren portrayed Queen Elizabeth during the aftermath of the death of Princess Diana in 1997, that the dogs portraying them received awards for their onscreen performances.\n\nMs. Mirren later played opposite corgis again on stage as the queen in the play \u201cThe Audience\u201d in 2013.\n\nMore recently, the corgis\u2019 appearance in the Netflix series \u201cThe Crown\u201d has been credited for renewing interest in the breed in Britain.\n\n\u201cPeople used to have the impression that while corgis were in the spotlight, because of the queen, they could be seen by young people as an older person\u2019s dog,\u201d David Robson of the Kennel Club told The Telegraph in February. \u201cNow that\u2019s changed, partly because we are seeing the character of the younger queen surrounded by them.\u201d", "title": "8 Decades of British Royal Corgis Reportedly at an End", "authors": ["Michael Gold"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBecause we work in newspapers, and are as susceptible to buzzy jargon as the next person, we sometimes refer to \u201cthe mix\u201d when we try to explain how we make our assignments or schedule our reviews each week. It\u2019s an amorphous term, redolent of Chex cereal or disco floors or cocktail bars, and not easy to define in the context of books journalism. But this week\u2019s recommended titles offer a perfect illustration of the concept: On the surface, these eight books have little in common, but taken together they add up to a broad snapshot of life today. One novel looks at gun culture; another explores how feminism has changed over the years. There\u2019s the memoir of a woman raised among survivalists, and a look at the Syrian civil war, and a deep investigative dive into the 2016 presidential election and possible Russian interference. Less topical, but still fascinating, is Yunte Huang\u2019s thorough history of the 19th-century conjoined twins Chang and Eng. Finally, because sometimes all you want is an original mind or a great escapist plot, we\u2019ve also found a surreal story collection and a retro thriller and introduced them into the \u2014 well, you know.\n\nGregory Cowles\n\nSenior Editor, Books\n\nINSEPARABLE: The Original Siamese Twins and Their Rendezvous With American History, by Yunte Huang. (Liveright, $28.95.) Yunte Huang\u2019s new book recounts the extraordinary 19th-century lives of Chang and Eng Bunker, the original \u201cSiamese twins.\u201d The brothers went from the humiliations of showcased servitude all across America to a life of Southern comfort in small-town North Carolina, fathering at least 21 children between them and at one point owning as many as 32 slaves. Our critic Jennifer Szalai calls \u201cInseparable\u201d a \u201ccontemplative yet engrossing\u201d history.\n\nTHE FEMALE PERSUASION, by Meg Wolitzer. (Riverhead, $28.) Of all the political threads that permeate Wolitzer\u2019s 12th novel, the most interesting is the challenge of intergenerational feminism. The book \u201cis speaking to the larger issue of ambition: who has it, what curtails it and what it means to reframe it,\u201d Lena Dunham writes in the Book Review. \u201cBut when all is said and done, Wolitzer is an infinitely capable creator of human identities that are as real as the type on this page, and her love of her characters shines more brightly than any agenda.\u201d\n\nAETHERIAL WORLDS: Stories, by Tatyana Tolstaya. Translated by Anya Migdal. (Knopf, $25.95.) Tolstaya\u2019s remarkable short stories are all about people haunted by their flashing glimpses of shadow worlds \u2014 moments of pure transcendence when the dull plastic coating of reality peels back to reveal something vastly more precious underneath. \u201cTolstaya is doubly haunted by the past, both by its lostness and by its stubborn refusal to go away,\u201d Lev Grossman writes in his review. \u201cShe is blessed, and cursed, with the mystic\u2019s gift of seeing the shades of the departed.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRUSSIAN ROULETTE: The Inside Story of Putin\u2019s War on America and the Election of Donald Trump, by Michael Isikoff and David Corn. (Twelve, $30.) Two veterans of Washington political journalism provide a thorough and riveting account of the 2016 election that casts an unfavorable light on both the Democratic and Republican campaigns. This is a book without heroes. Reviewing it, Steven Lee Myers of The Times calls the book \u201ca granular, source-on-the-wall election diary\u201d that is \u201csure to infuriate readers on both sides of what should be the most urgent question facing the nation today: the vulnerability of our democratic institutions to Russian manipulation.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGUN LOVE, by Jennifer Clement. (Hogarth, $25.) Clement\u2019s novel, her second about the gun trade, unfolds at a Florida trailer park where firearms and people intimately coexist. The imagery is dreamlike, as if to suggest the self-delusion of the novel\u2019s real-life counterparts, Terese Svoboda writes in her review. \u201cBut the writing is crisp and the images sharp: a field of 63 Barbies buried up to their knees around a trailer; the hatching of conjoined twin alligators \u2018still with white pieces of eggshell on the green, scaly back they shared.\u2019\u201d", "title": "8 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018JEWS IN SPACE: MEMBERS OF THE TRIBE IN ORBIT\u2019 FAMILY PROGRAM at the Center for Jewish History (April 15, 10 a.m.-noon). Throughout history, persecution and the diaspora have led Jews to travel to many regions, but this free event will honor one that they\u2019ve visited purely voluntarily: outer space. Held in conjunction with a new exhibition of the same title, \u201cJews in Space\u201d will send young participants on a gallerywide scavenger hunt to discover contributions from astronomers and astronauts. They can also make a rocket ship that actually launches; hear the musician Rob Schwimmer play the theremin, an instrument whose eerie sound is ideal for science-fiction soundtracks, and then try it themselves; and have a discussion via Skype with Vickie Kloeris, a NASA food scientist, who will explain how and what astronauts eat. (Reservations are required.)\n\n212-294-8301, cjh.org\n\n\u2018THE LITTLE RED FISH\u2019 at the Lion Theater at Theater Row (through April 29). There\u2019s more than one way to dive into a story. JeJe, a little boy, does so literally in this 30-minute production, an adaptation of a picture book of the same title by Taeeun Yoo. Presented by New York City Children\u2019s Theater, the play showcases the creative talents of the Puppet Kitchen, the inventive team that devised the fantastical puppetry in the original production of \u201cThe Very Hungry Caterpillar Show.\u201d \u201cThe Little Red Fish,\u201d which plays on weekends at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m., finds JeJe at the library, where he has gone with his grandfather. The child has also taken his pet, the title character. Yet when the fish escapes its bowl and disappears into the pages of a book, JeJe has no choice but to follow his finned friend on a literary adventure turned real.\n\n212-239-6200, nycchildrenstheater.org\n\n\n\n109TH SALUTE TO MAGIC at the Haft Theater, Fashion Institute of Technology (April 14, 7:30 p.m.). Very little entertainment is truly for all ages, but magic and circus arts \u2014 at least the sophisticated kind \u2014 fit the bill. This annual event, presented by the Society of American Magicians, will showcase more than a half-dozen acts with impressive pedigrees. Children may especially enjoy the work of Elliot Zimet, who performs with birds; Keith Nelson, a founder of the Bindlestiff Family Cirkus, who swallows swords, eats fire and juggles plates; and David Kaye, a.k.a. Silly Billy, who will call four young audience members onstage for assistance.\n\n800-838-3006, salutetomagic.com\n\nSPRING FAMILY FAIR at the Morgan Library & Museum (April 15, 2-4:30 p.m.). The Morgan is inviting young people to slip into the past, where they\u2019ll meet interesting characters like powerful dragons and a librarian who was powerful, too: Belle da Costa Greene (1879-1950), whose name alone is enough to belie the dowdy stereotypes associated with her profession. The fair\u2019s activities will include making colorful dragon puppets based on the museum\u2019s medieval illuminated manuscripts; decorating picture frames, inspired by the work of Peter Hujar; dreaming up verse to add to the library\u2019s Poetry Wall; and encountering Ms. Greene, the Morgan\u2019s first director, who will be portrayed by the actress Starr Kirkland in two interactive performances.\n\n212-685-0008, themorgan.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSUPER PET EXPO at the New Jersey Convention and Exposition Center, Edison, N.J. (April 13, 3-8 p.m.; April 14, 10 a.m.-7 p.m.; April 15, 10 a.m.-5 p.m.). Not many events at convention centers allow you to take along your dog, but this one welcomes canine companions \u2014 on leashes, of course. In addition to providing information on pet adoption, rescue and training, it offers attractions like a puppy playground; a petting zoo; a luring course for dog exercise and play; an educational presentation on wolves (they may be big, but they\u2019re not bad) by Wolf Visions; and a Walk the Rain Forest experience with Lonely Grey Rescue, an avian nonprofit. It also features a best-dressed pet competition; cat, dog and even pig agility demonstrations; and a Repticon section for those who prefer their pets furless.\n\n888-718-4253, superpetexpo.com", "title": "8 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "For more than a month, the police in Toronto have been trying to solve a mystery. They had a photograph of an unidentified dead man, and they had discovered human remains in planters where a man suspected of multiple killings had worked as a landscaper.\n\nOn Monday, the police announced that they had charged the suspect, Bruce McArthur, with first-degree murder in the death of an eighth alleged victim \u2014 Kirushna Kumar Kanagaratnam, the man in the photograph.\n\nThe development was weeks in the making. Investigators released Mr. Kanagaratnam\u2019s photograph to the public on March 5, declining to say where it had come from and appealing for help identifying him. They enlisted the assistance of an officer who spoke Tamil, and coordinated with Mr. Kanagaratnam\u2019s family, who was still in Sri Lanka.\n\n\u201cThe stress and anxiety over dealing with hundreds of tips, hundreds of missing-persons occurrences and dozens of potential identifications for the eighth victim has been enormous,\u201d Sgt. Hank Idsinga said at a news conference.", "title": "8th Murder Charge in Case That Rattled Toronto Gay Community", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Director Milos Forman died Friday at age 86. As one of the leading lights of the Czech New Wave in the 1960s, Forman joined a generation of young filmmakers that built a creative bulwark against communist oppression. That rebellious spirit carried over to his decades in Hollywood, from the counterculture sentiments of \u201cOne Flew Over the Cuckoo\u2019s Nest\u201d and \u201cHair\u201d to his embrace of rabble-rousing iconoclasts like Larry Flynt and Andy Kaufman in \u201cThe People vs. Larry Flynt\u201d and \u201cMan on the Moon.\u201d\n\nNot all of his great films are available to stream, but here are nine, including two best-picture winners, that showcase Forman\u2019s engagement with history and politics, and with the characters willing to fight the current. If you want to check out any of the movies at a later time, save them to your Watchlist, where you can keep a personal list of TV shows and films you\u2019d like to try out.\n\n\u2018The Firemen\u2019s Ball\u2019 (1967)\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA strong anti-authoritarian streak runs through much of Forman\u2019s work, but the controversies that greeted \u201cThe Firemen\u2019s Ball\u201d abruptly ended his time in communist Czechoslovakia and brought him to Hollywood. Forman denied the allegorical implications of the premise, which details the calamitous efforts of a volunteer fire department to give a party for its former leader, but the film nonetheless belongs on the satirical continuum between \u201cDr. Strangelove\u201d and Armando Iannucci (\u201cVeep,\u201d \u201cThe Thick of It\u201d). Over a brisk 73 minutes, the outbreak of disasters include a beauty contest with homely and stage-shy contestants, a rash of disappearing raffle prizes and an actual fire that breaks out across town.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Visions of Eight\u2019 (1973)\n\nWhere to watch: FilmStruck, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFor \u201cVisions of Eight,\u201d Forman and seven other internationally renowned directors were commissioned to participate in an anthology film about the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich. Forman\u2019s \u201cThe Decathlon\u201d is the sixth and longest, a peculiar juxtaposition of individual sporting events and musical performances, mostly from a Bavarian folk band. Each event is presented without context \u2014 his interest in documenting the winners and losers is nil \u2014 and Forman shoots extensively in slow-motion, emphasizing the pregnant moments before the athletes start to compete.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nOnly three films in Oscar history have swept all five major categories (picture, actor, actress, director and screenplay): \u201cIt Happened One Night,\u201d \u201cThe Silence of the Lambs,\u201d and Forman\u2019s adaptation of the novel by Ken Kesey, which frames the conflict at a mental hospital as an allegory for a polarized culture. At the center of that conflict is a battle of wills between Randal P. McMurphy (Jack Nicholson), a convict who bluffs his way into the psyche ward, and Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher), who runs the place like a sinister warden. \u201cOne Flew Over the Cuckoo\u2019s Nest\u201d has a big, generous sense of humor, but there\u2019s humanity, too, in McMurphy\u2019s championing of patients who are more vulnerable to Ratched\u2019s abuses than he is.\n\n\u2014\n\nMovieclips Classic Trailers\n\n\u2018Hair\u2019 (1979)\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAfter establishing his counterculture bona fides with \u201cOne Flew Over the Cuckoo\u2019s Nest,\u201d Forman took on the challenge of adapting Gerome Ragni and James Rado\u2019s Broadway smash about a New York hippie enclave rebelling against the Vietnam War. There\u2019s an urgency and danger missing from Forman\u2019s musical, which was a decade removed from the tempest around the original production. But he brings a shaggy naturalism to \u201cHair\u201d by shooting in real locations and allowing the choreography to get a little unkempt. And the songs remain terrific.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Ragtime\u2019 (1981)\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWhen Forman left Czechoslovakia for America, he immediately (and permanently) keyed into the dramatic crosscurrents that animated the culture, and in E.L. Doctorow\u2019s historical novel about the early 1900s, he worked on his largest canvas to date. But rather than give \u201cRagtime\u201d the \u201cNashville\u201d treatment, Forman and his screenwriter, Michael Weller, focused mainly on revealing this world through the story of an African-American jazz pianist (Howard E. Rollins Jr.) who gets entangled in class and racial conflicts. A beautiful production, it also has a willingness to engage in the uncomfortable issues that continue to plague the nation.\n\n\u2014\n\nMovieclips Classic Trailers\n\n\u2018Amadeus\u2019 (1984)\n\nWhere to watch: Google Play, YouTube\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nForman collected another Oscar for best director, along with awards for best picture and six others, for this rousing adaptation of Peter Shaffer\u2019s stage play about the rivalry between the composers Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (Tom Hulce) and Antonio Salieri (F. Murray Abraham). In telling the story through Salieri\u2019s perspective, \u201cAmadeus\u201d becomes a drama about deranged jealousy and betrayal as Salieri fumes over his prodigious counterpart, who is seen as immature and unworthy of his superior talent. Yet through the heat of Salieri\u2019s contempt, Mozart\u2019s compositions come alive with fresh urgency: \u201cAmadeus\u201d isn\u2019t a stodgy costume piece for classical music fans only, it\u2019s a gripping drama about a divine gift and its costs.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Valmont\u2019 (1989)\n\nWhere to buy: iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nArriving just a year after the superb \u201cDangerous Liaisons,\u201d this adaptation of Pierre Choderlos de Laclos\u2019s epistolary novel \u201cLes Liaisons Dangereuses\u201d was doomed to fail. And did just that, sinking under a bloated production budget and lackluster reviews. The side-to-side comparison did no favors to Forman\u2019s version, which didn\u2019t have the same snap, especially in the role of Valmont, which Colin Firth couldn\u2019t play with anything close to John Malkovich\u2019s malevolent panache. But now, from a greater distance, the virtues of \u201cValmont\u201d are better appreciated, particularly Annette Bening\u2019s deliciously nasty turn as the Marquise de Merteuil, who inspires the cruel erotic gamesmanship that eventually curdles into tragedy.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The People vs. Larry Flynt\u2019 (1996)\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cIf the First Amendment will protect a scum bag like me, it will protect all of you.\u201d With that quote as its prevailing sentiment, Forman\u2019s fleet biopic about the \u201cHustler\u201d pornographer turned free speech crusader Larry Flynt doesn\u2019t underplay Flynt\u2019s seamier side \u2014 well, maybe a little \u2014 but it does use it as a stress test for a cherished Constitutional principle. Woody Harrelson plays Flynt as an irreverent wild card whose life lurches from porn trailblazer to Christian convert, until finally landing him in a protracted legal battle with Jerry Falwell. Courtney Love is equally good as his wife Althea, whose fortunes are troubled first by addiction and later by contracting H.I.V.\n\n\u2014\n\nMovieclips Classic Trailers\n\n\u2018Man on the Moon\u2019 (1999)\n\nWhere to watch: HBO, Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWorking again with the \u201cLarry Flynt\u201d screenwriters Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, Forman sank his teeth into this lively biopic about another cultural provocateur, Andy Kaufman. Jim Carrey famously immersed himself in the role of Kaufman, the anti-comedy legend who played Latka on \u201cTaxi\u201d but shaped his persona in late-night and stage performances that were rife with inside jokes, offensive behavior and weird sideshows. For better or worse, Carrey sucks up much of the oxygen, but Forman\u2019s characteristic attention to period detail helps put Kaufman\u2019s antics in their proper cultural context.\n\n\u2014", "title": "9 Great Milos Forman Movies to Stream", "authors": ["Scott Tobias"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018THE BIRDS\u2019 at St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse (previews start on May 2; opens on May 6). Dreamed of flying away from the current iteration of democracy? Feel free to join a few Athenians with the same goal. Aristophanes\u2019s comedy, adapted by Nikos Karathanos and Giannis Asteris and produced by the Onassis Cultural Center, follows two guys looking to create a new society in the clouds.\n\n718-254-8779, stannswarehouse.org\n\n\u2018A BRIEF HISTORY OF WOMEN\u2019 at 59E59 Theaters (in previews; opens on May 2). In Alan Ayckbourn\u2019s latest play, the showpiece of Brits Off Broadway, a manor house becomes a girls\u2019 school and then an arts center and then a hotel. As walls don\u2019t tend to talk, Mr. Ayckbourn explores these permutations by tracing the adventures of a 17-year-old footman (Antony Eden) through the decades.\n\n212-279-4200, 59e59.org\n\n\u2018THE BOYS IN THE BAND\u2019 at the Booth Theater (previews start on April 30; opens on May 31). The year before Stonewall, Mart Crowley wrote this funny and anguished play about a get-together for a group of gay men, which The Times, in between unthinking slurs, called \u201ca gripping, if painful, experience.\u201d It\u2019s back, directed by Joe Mantello, with an all-star cast, including Jim Parsons, Matt Bomer, Zachary Quinto and Andrew Rannells.\n\n212-239-6200, boysintheband.com\n\n\u2018HENRY V\u2019 at the Public Theater (in previews; opens on April 27). The Public Theater\u2019s Mobile Shakespeare Unit goes once more unto the breach, bringing a brisk distillation of this Shakespeare drama to prisons, shelters and rec centers, then returning home to Astor Place. The playwright and director Robert O\u2019Hara leads the charge for the historical play, with a cast that includes Carolyn Kettig and Zenzi Williams.\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018OUR LADY OF 121ST STREET\u2019 at the Pershing Square Signature Center (previews start on May 1; opens on May 20). A much-loved nun has died and her former students have gathered to mourn her. Too bad someone has stolen the body. The Signature revives Stephen Adly Guirgis\u2019s steamed-up 2002 comedy of dust-ups, punch-ups, missing pants and uneasy reunions. Phylicia Rashad directs.\n\n212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org", "title": "9 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019ve heard from dozens of people like this since I wrote about the fix-it fund last week. Here are a few of their stories.\n\nPaying Too Much\n\nRobin White\u2019s overpayments were purposeful. An assistant professor at Nicholls State University in Thibodaux, La., she had already worked through a different issue that disqualified earlier payments. So she eventually began doubling down on what her servicer, FedLoan, was telling her to pay via the income-based repayment program that participants in the public service loan forgiveness program must use.\n\n\u201cI thought that if I paid more that they were going to see that I was trying to do this as thoroughly and deliberately as I can,\u201d Dr. White said. \u201cI wanted to make it clear that I was not trying to take taxpayers\u2019 money.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the system cares not for intent. If you don\u2019t pay the right amount you owe, your payment that month does not count toward the forgiveness that occurs after 120 payments.\n\nDr. White said she would never forget when the FedLoan phone representative discovered she was in what\u2019s called \u201cpaid ahead\u201d status. \u201cShe said, \u2018Oh, it\u2019s this nasty little thing,\u2019\u201d she recalled. What followed was a Kafkaesque stretch of confusing statements and, ultimately, a double-digit number of months that did not count toward her forgiveness total.\n\nAccording to Keith New, a spokesman for FedLoan, which is a part of the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency and is the servicer for the forgiveness program, the initial confusion resulted from the fact that \u201cinformation was not provided surrounding the difference in paying the installment amount versus the bill due amount and how the paid ahead status can affect qualifying payments.\u201d\n\nGiven that FedLoan could have been clearer here, will it arrange for the payments that Dr. White made during this period of confusion to count toward forgiveness? I asked, but Mr. New did not reply.\n\nThe Wrong Employer\n\nOnly certain jobs \u2014 perhaps a quarter of all forms of employment \u2014 qualify for public service loan forgiveness. Just to be sure, everyone in the program ought to submit what\u2019s known as an \u201cemployer certification form\u201d each year to make sure that his or her employer qualifies or still qualifies.\n\nEdge cases have already been the subject of litigation, as I outlined in a 2016 column. But Chris Golding, who works for the North Carolina Nurses Association in Raleigh, N.C., did not know that. Others at the association thought that it qualified, but you can\u2019t get an instant reading on the matter in the time it takes to consider a job offer.\n\nAlas, when Mr. Golding submitted his form, he received a reply last November saying that he was not eligible. There was no detailed explanation, and Mr. Golding said he was unable to get one when he called FedLoan.\n\nThe rules state that an employer must provide a \u201cqualifying public service.\u201d In Mr. Golding\u2019s case, the governing language would appear to be a requirement that an organization\u2019s \u201cprimary\u201d purpose is to provide \u201cpublic health\u201d services. Mr. Golding is a registered nurse. He does not treat patients, but he does support other nurses through education.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. New, the FedLoan spokesman, added a bit more detail. \u201cWhile his employer is a nonprofit 501(c)(6) organization, its primary purpose is not one that would be considered as a public service,\u201d he said. He added that FedLoan\u2019s customer service department had consulted with its own compliance services division in making that determination.\n\nMr. New also said FedLoan\u2019s phone representative had told Mr. Golding in November that he could provide documentation supporting the \u201cpurported public service his employer provides for further consideration.\u201d\n\nMr. Golding said he intended to do just that, with the help of his boss and perhaps the organization\u2019s attorney. Meanwhile, he asked me a question that has no good answer: \u201cHow is anyone supposed to make a decision about where to work if they can\u2019t get a reading ahead of time about whether an organization is eligible?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Wrong Loan\n\nWhen the public service loan forgiveness program began, people who had already taken out student loans in the Federal Family Education Loan, or F.F.E.L., program were supposed to switch to something called \u201cdirect\u201d loans to be eligible.\n\nMany people never got the message, however, and spent years making payments only to discover that they had been in the wrong loan program. Other borrowers did not always understand what kind of federal loan they had, since statements could be unclear.\n\nJennifer Johnson, a Brooklyn social worker, said she had contacted Citibank, her loan servicer at the time, in 2010 in an effort to get enrolled in public service loan forgiveness. She recalled being told that she needed to be in a federal loan program to be eligible and get on some kind of an income-driven repayment plan, which she did.\n\nDuring the years that followed, Ms. Johnson said, she regularly searched the web for information on the public service loan forgiveness program to make sure she hadn\u2019t missed any other requirements. In 2015, she became aware of the existence of the employer certification forms, which did not exist when the forgiveness program began. She filed one just to have her employment on record.\n\nThen came the reply, which indicated that none of her payments had counted toward the magic 120 number because she was in an F.F.E.L. loan. Citibank had not made her aware of this, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMy first hope was that maybe it was a mistake,\u201d Ms. Johnson said, describing an ensuing phone call to her loan servicer for clarification, which ended in her sobbing. No one had much consolation. \u201cThey told me that it was a new program and that there wasn\u2019t really a system for it yet,\u201d she said.\n\nSo did Citigroup fail her, given that she is certain that she made it perfectly clear that she wanted to be in public service loan forgiveness? \u201cWhile we have fully exited the student loan servicing business, we looked into this matter from seven years ago and have found no confirmation that the conversation transpired as Ms. Johnson suggests,\u201d said Mark Costiglio, a Citigroup spokesman.\n\nTo be clear, Citigroup is not accusing her of making it up. It could not verify that its communication with her had happened as she described it. Nor could it verify that it hadn\u2019t. But logic would suggest that if it had told her that she was in the wrong loan, she would have switched it right quick.\n\nAnd if it didn\u2019t, shouldn\u2019t the Department of Education\u2019s ombudsman or her congresswoman and senators take up her cause?\n\nConfusion With the Servicer\n\nLawyers were early adopters of the public service loan forgiveness program, given that many of them run up six-figure law school debts and have ample opportunities to perform public service as a prosecutor, as a public defender or through other legal work.\n\nSo it was with Myles Braccio, a Phoenix prosecutor who elected to go into and stay in that line of work because it would allow him to wipe away his debt. He loved his contracts classes in law school, so he would seem to be well equipped to slay any bureaucracy.\n\nBut this week, he told me a hair-raising story of FedLoan\u2019s giving him bad advice about loan consolidation, wiping away close to two years of qualifying payments, restoring them after he complained to the federal Department of Education\u2019s ombudsman\u2019s office and then taking them away again after he made another inquiry because he was so paranoid that it would mess up his payment count again.\n\nSince then, he said, he has not been able to get straight answers from FedLoan. I asked Mr. New for a few, and he said Mr. Braccio\u2019s account was \u201cin review as we are working to confirm employment time-frame eligibility requirements.\u201d He added that Mr. Braccio\u2019s employer had provided \u201cconflicting\u201d information. Nonsense, Mr. Braccio replied; there is no conflicting information related to the years when he was eligible for loan forgiveness.\n\nAnd why did it take my intervention to extract this explanation? \u201cWe base our life decisions off of what they are telling us,\u201d Mr. Braccio said. \u201cBut you get one person after the other who has absolutely no idea what they are doing.\u201d", "title": "A $350 Million Fund Helps Many Public Servants. Meet the Ones Left Out.", "authors": ["Ron Lieber", "Your Money"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The couple bought their penthouse, which is on the 17th and 18th floors of the limestone-clad 740 Park, for $27.5 million in 2006. They purchased it from the estate of Enid A. Haupt, a noted philanthropist and passionate supporter of the New York Botanical Garden, several months after her death. Ms. Haupt, who was a daughter of the publishing magnate Moses L. Annenberg, had moved into the apartment in 1967.\n\nLong regarded as one of New York City\u2019s most prestigious addresses, 740 Park has housed many other wealthy and powerful residents, from John D. Rockefeller Jr., to more recently, the Blackstone Group founder Stephen A. Schwarzman and the billionaire businessman David H. Koch. (Not surprisingly, financing is not permitted for purchases there.) The building was designed in the late 1920s by the architect Rosario Candela and developed by James T. Lee, a grandfather of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, who also lived there.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Thains said they spent two years making numerous improvements and upgrades to their penthouse, in collaboration with the architect Oscar Shamamian and the interior designer Michael S. Smith. Their work included refurbishing the elaborate architectural finishes (and adding a few of their own), renovating the kitchen and bathrooms, and reinstalling stairs to the roof. They also added a Crestron home automation system.\n\n\u201cIt appeared to have been abandoned for a number of years,\u201d Mr. Thain said, describing the apartment\u2019s previous condition. \u201cFireplaces were closed up and even the roof-level terrace space was completely shut off.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think the previous owner had been wary of intruders,\u201d Ms. Thain added.\n\nThe unit\u2019s early-20th century charm has since been restored. Throughout the home \u2014 filled with an eclectic mix of antiques, traditional furnishings and striking artwork \u2014 are ornate plaster and wood moldings, Parquet de Versailles hardwood floors, functioning wood-burning fireplaces, French doors and oversize windows. Ceilings on the main level reach 12 feet.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a very elegant apartment,\u201d Mr. Burger said. \u201cYou just don\u2019t see these kinds of opulent details anymore.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe apartment has three bedrooms and three and a half baths, plus an office that could be converted into a fourth bedroom. There is ample outdoor space \u2014 with two terraces on the lower level, a wraparound terrace on the top floor and the recreated roof deck \u2014 that provide stunning cityscape and Central Park vistas.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the best part of this side of 740 Park: You have park views,\u201d Mr. Burger said of the building\u2019s west wing, where the penthouse is situated. \u201cThe light here is just fantastic.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the home\u2019s main level, a private elevator landing opens to a stately windowed gallery 27 feet long, with a grand elliptical staircase and entry to a 15-by-14-foot west-facing terrace. The gallery leads to an enormous living room that also connects to the terrace. It is anchored by a richly carved marble fireplace, one of three in the apartment, and flows into the formal dining room.\n\nOff the dining room is a butler\u2019s pantry with two dishwashers, and beyond that, a large eat-in kitchen with custom marble flooring and a spacious pantry and laundry area. The kitchen is equipped with stainless-steel appliances like a Wolf stove and Sub-Zero refrigerator and wine cooler and also features a stainless-steel center island.\n\nThe most eye-catching features in the kitchen are the geometric plaster medallions along the ceiling perimeter \u2014 a design idea of Ms. Thain, who wanted to replicate the ornamental details found at the top of the building\u2019s facade.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond.
