The 16-by-19-foot library, lined with sumptuous wood paneling by F\u00e9au & Cie of Paris, has a fireplace and French doors that open to a small south-facing terrace.\n\nOn the second floor is another spacious gallery, along with a sizable master bedroom with walk-in closets and a fireplace, and a guest bedroom currently being used as a study. Each bedroom has an en-suite marble bath. The master bath features heated floors and a separate soaking tub. Both bedrooms open to the wraparound terrace, with eating and lounging areas.\n\nThis floor is reachable via the main staircase and service stairs off the kitchen, as well as a private elevator bank off the gallery. A third set of stairs from this floor connects to the teak roof deck, with trellis walls and various plantings like climbing hydrangea.\n\nMr. Thain said the roof deck was one of his favorite spots in the penthouse, and one that he will miss the most. \u201cIt\u2019s a beautiful space, and it has amazing views.\u201d", "title": "A $39.5 Million Penthouse at 740 Park Avenue", "authors": ["Vivian Marino"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "A public university president in Oregon gives new meaning to the idea of a pensioner.\n\nJoseph Robertson, an eye surgeon who retired as head of the Oregon Health & Science University last fall, receives the state\u2019s largest government pension.\n\nIt is $76,111.\n\nPer month.\n\nThat is considerably more than the average Oregon family earns in a year.\n\nOregon \u2014 like many other states and cities, including New Jersey, Kentucky and Connecticut \u2014 is caught in a fiscal squeeze of its own making. Its economy is growing, but the cost of its state-run pension system is growing faster. More government workers are retiring, including more than 2,000, like Dr. Robertson, who get pensions exceeding $100,000 a year.\n\nThe state is not the most profligate pension payer in America, but its spiraling costs are notable in part because Oregon enjoys a reputation for fiscal discipline. Its experience shows how faulty financial decisions by states can eventually swamp local communities.\n\nOregon\u2019s costs are inflated by the way in which it calculates pension benefits for public employees. Some of the pensions include income that employees earned on the side. Other retirees benefit from long-ago stock market rallies that inflated the current value of their payouts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor example, the pension for Mike Bellotti, the University of Oregon\u2019s head football coach from 1995 to 2008, includes not just his salary but also money from licensing deals and endorsements that the Ducks\u2019 athletic program generated. Mr. Bellotti\u2019s pension is more than $46,000 a month.", "title": "A $76,000 Monthly Pension: Why States and Cities Are Short on Cash", "authors": ["Mary Williams Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Iraqi intelligence officials say that high-value detainees, people accused of involvement in specific terrorist attacks, are held separately from the majority of prisoners, who are suspected of having been low-level cogs in the Islamic State bureaucracy.\n\nSince the summer of 2017, more than 10,000 cases have been referred to the courts, the people familiar with the court said. To date, they said, approximately 2,900 trials have been completed, with a conviction rate of about 98 percent.\n\nThey did not say how many had received the death penalty, or how many executions had been carried out.\n\nThe government said 11 people were executed on Monday for \u201cterrorism crimes,\u201d fulfilling \u201cthe government\u2019s promise to kill those responsible for shedding Iraqi blood,\u201d the Justice Ministry said in a statement.\n\nAmong those held apart from the general prison population are approximately 1,350 foreign women and 580 children, the majority of whom surrendered to Iraqi security forces last August during military operations to liberate the town of Tal Afar. The vast majority of these detainees are Turkish, Russian and Central Asian.\n\nIraq says it is determined to try them if evidence links them to the Islamic State, but some of their home countries, including Saudi Arabia, have requested extradition for some of their citizens. Other countries, like Britain and France, have been reluctant to take their citizens back, officials from both countries said.\n\nIn rare cases, individuals have been returned to their home countries, such as a group of four Russian women and 27 children in February, after Iraqi authorities concluded they had been tricked into coming to Islamic State territory. Turkey has been working to repatriate minors whose parents took them to the caliphate, as well as those found innocent of wrongdoing.", "title": "A 10-Minute Trial, a Death Sentence: Iraqi Justice for ISIS Suspects", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "As Nick Kristof wrote in his first column from our trip, resolving conflict should top humanitarian efforts because there\u2019s little that can be accomplished in times of conflict. But in stable areas \u2014 such as the southwestern part of CAR where we traveled \u2014 investments in infrastructure, particularly paved roads, should take precedence. Without working roads to transport people and goods, economic opportunity is difficult to find.\n\nThe empty road laid bare this reality in CAR, where people throughout the country are deprived of essential resources. The Global Hunger Index ranks the country as the hungriest in the world, and in a place that\u2019s arguably the world\u2019s most neglected political and humanitarian crisis, government doesn\u2019t exist in most places to fill in the gaps. Compounding the political instability, the United Nations says its humanitarian plan for the country is only 2 percent funded. So although we didn\u2019t see any road improvement projects in our travels, it\u2019s encouraging that the World Bank has invested in some construction projects to improve trade with neighboring countries. However, more robust foreign investment, which is required for large-scale infrastructure projects, is unlikely to precede peace.\n\nAnd when people can\u2019t move from one place to the next, it causes all sorts of problems. As we stopped in villages along the road, we found many children didn\u2019t attend school and medical services were out of reach. Others lamented the lack of access to markets to sell their goods. The distance to these critical places \u2014 and the inability to get there \u2014 was almost always the prohibiting factor. A paved road would probably make those trips more feasible.\n\nThroughout our time driving in CAR, we passed through numerous villages that, as locals explained, have sprouted up on the road\u2019s edge as communities have moved out of the forest. We watched as two boys kicked a soccer ball back and forth, each with only one cleat and one long sock. Young children raced handmade toy cars, assembled out of sticks, leaves and empty food containers. Dozens of people bathed and swam in the roadside streams.", "title": "Opinion | A 15-Hour Road Trip Through Broken Bridges and Makeshift Checkpoints", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "A six-month grant from the Uganda Press Photo Award spurred Esther Mbabazi to document what it is like to be a teenager in Uganda, where half the country\u2019s citizens are under 16. The topic was fresh in her memory: She herself was only 23.\n\nMs. Mbabazi said she hadn\u2019t previously noticed Uganda\u2019s youthful demographics. \u201cBut once I thought about it, I realized that almost everyone I knew was young,\u201d she said. \u201cI settled on teenagers because they are just starting to get a sense of independence in their lives.\u201d\n\nWith the help of a mentor, the German photographer Anne Ackermann, she settled on three main characters to follow.", "title": "A 23-Year-Old Ugandan Photographer Documents Youth in Her Country", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The head of a City Council watchdog committee has accused City Hall\u2019s top lawyer of carrying out a political vendetta against the city\u2019s investigations commissioner on behalf of Mayor Bill de Blasio.\n\nThe accusation, in a strongly worded letter sent Monday by Councilman Ritchie Torres to Zachary Carter, the city\u2019s corporation counsel, marked a sharp escalation in a three-sided power struggle among different arms of city government.\n\nThe confrontation had taken on an added dimension on Tuesday when the investigations commissioner, Mark G. Peters, announced that he had appointed an outside lawyer to conduct an independent probe of whistle-blower claims lodged against him.\n\nIt was a dizzying round robin of investigations, counterinvestigations and finger-pointing, and at its center was Mr. Peters: a onetime de Blasio campaign treasurer who has since become a frequent irritant to the mayor.", "title": "A 3-Way Fight Over How to Police the Conduct of City Investigators", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "When I suggested to my Beatles-obsessed husband that we should go to Liverpool, I won points for the rest of our marriage. What I didn\u2019t realize until later, when I was standing on a certain lane behind the shelter in the middle of the roundabout, was that I would actually enjoy myself. Very strange .\n\nI had wondered if, in making such a pilgrimage, there would be a place for the nonreligious. But when slanted sunbeams fell on Eleanor Rigby\u2019s headstone as if on cue, I shivered a little and smiled.\n\nMy husband, Ricky, knows all the answers (at least when it comes to the Beatles), so I let him engage in trivia contests with our tour guide in Liverpool. Freed from the tug of minutiae, I was able to marvel in the phenomenon of the Fab Four: how one band united the world, and continues to do so, 50 years after the release of \u201cSgt. Pepper\u2019s Lonely Hearts Club Band.\u201d", "title": "A Beatles Tour in England? You Know That Can\u2019t be Bad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "How to improve your video quality\n\nShooting video on a phone isn\u2019t the most intuitive experience. That\u2019s because phones were designed as multipurpose devices, which also means they lack some important features, like a handgrip or optical zoom, which gets you closer to your subject without degrading image quality. (Instead, phones mostly use digital zoom, which often degrades image quality. So, avoid zooming in digitally. Instead, \u201czoom with your feet\u201d or simply walk closer to your subject, if you can.) Here are several tips for getting better results.\n\n1. Orientation: Be sure to orient your phone horizontally. \u201cWhen I\u2019m watching the news and there\u2019s footage from a bystander that\u2019s in portrait mode,\u201d says Mr. Nachtrieb, \u201cthat\u2019s an immediate signal that it\u2019s an amateur video.\u201d He says that while Instagram and Snapchat seem to be \u201caiding and abetting\u201d users to create more portrait- or vertically-oriented footage, it\u2019s best to avoid it.\n\n2 Avoid Back Lighting: \u201cAvoid having a window or light source behind your subject, since he or she will look silhouetted,\u201d says Mr. Nachtrieb. Instead, have the light source more to the side of you or behind you.\n\n3. Use both hands: \u201cAlways have two hands on the phone,\u201d says Mr. Nachtrieb. \u201cIt may seem rudimentary, but it makes a big difference. Phone lenses generally have optical image stabilization built in, so they\u2019re pretty stable already. But using two hands produces even steadier footage.\u201d It also avoids what he calls the Jell-O effect. \u201cIf you\u2019re moving the camera around too quickly, it can have a wavy quality to it.\u201d Using two hands lessens the chance of creating this effect.\n\n4. Lock Focus and Exposure: Mr. Nachtrieb suggests tapping on your phone\u2019s LCD (on the point you want to focus on), which will lock focus on Google Android devices, or holding your finger in place, which locks focus on the Apple iPhone.\u201cIn low light, your phone\u2019s camera will hunt for focus.\u201d That makes it look less professional. Most phones let you also lock or manually adjust the exposure, too.\n\n5. Improve Your Audio, Too: Most video pros say good quality audio is essential for powerful video. The good news is that the microphones on smartphones have improved in recent years. What\u2019s more is that audio accessories, such as Bluetooth microphones, can make the audio in your video projects sound outstanding (which we\u2019ll get to in a moment).\n\nHere are two audio tricks: Borrow a second phone, start recording audio, and place the phone in your subject\u2019s pocket. \u201cThen, shoot video on your phone from far away,\u201d says Mr. Nachtrieb. \u201cYou can always sync up the audio tracks later in video editing.\u201d And when interviewing subjects, don\u2019t interrupt their replies, says Mr. Nachtrieb.", "title": "A Beginner\u2019s Guide to Taking Great Video on Your Phone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The long-term consequences of using SARMs are largely unknown, and people who purchase products marketed as them cannot be entirely sure what they are putting in their bodies, said Dr. Shalender Bhasin, the director of research programs in men\u2019s health, aging and metabolism at Brigham and Women\u2019s Hospital and an author of the JAMA report.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know whether these compounds are safe,\u201d he said, \u201cbut we do know that some of them have side effects.\u201d\n\nThat has not stopped many people from experimenting with them.\n\nThaddeus Owen, 42, a self-described biohackerwho lives in Saint Paul, Minn., began using SARMs in 2016 in combination with a diet and exercise program. He said that the pills helped him pack on five pounds of muscle in four weeks, which he documented on his website, \u201cPrimalHacker.\u201d He argued that informed adults should be allowed \u201cto experiment on ourselves and improve our biology,\u201d but added, \u201cthis is definitely a use-at-your-own-risk type of supplement.\u201d\n\nAnti-doping officials have known about SARMs for some time and have seen an increasing number of elite athletes using them. Since 2015, the United States Anti-Doping Agency has imposed sanctions on more than two dozen track and field stars, weight lifters, cyclists, mixed martial artists and others for testing positive for a variety of SARMs, most frequently one called ostarine.\n\nLast year, Joakim Noah, a center for the New York Knicks, was suspended for 20 games for testing positive for a SARM. The college basketball star Allonzo Trier of the Arizona Wildcats was also suspended for using SARMs. And in October, a top CrossFit Games competitor, Ricky Garard, was stripped of his third-place title after testing positive for two SARMs: ostarine and testolone.\n\nWhile the underground use of SARMs has made them controversial, the drugs could one day serve a crucial purpose for many patients.\n\nScientists developed SARMs decades ago to counter the age-related decline in muscle and strength that tends to begin around middle age and that can contribute to falls and broken bones. Many chronic diseases, such as cancer, heart failure and kidney disease, are also punctuated by a loss of muscle and physical mobility.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnabolic and androgenic steroids such as testosterone can help people regain muscle and physical function. But they act on many tissues throughout the body and have been tied to a litany of potential side effects, including prostate problems and cardiovascular events.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSARMs were designed to selectively target skeletal muscle and spare other tissues, in an attempt to reduce some of these unwanted side effects. A number of trials are looking at their usefulness in cancer patients, people recovering from hip surgery, and postmenopausal women with urinary incontinence linked to weak pelvic muscles.\n\nA three-week trial at Boston University demonstrated that LGD-4033, a SARM developed by Ligand Pharmaceuticals, was safe and tolerable in healthy men, producing \u201csignificant gains in muscle mass and strength\u201d without raising levels of a protein linked to prostate cancer. But it had other effects as well, for instance causing a drop in HDL cholesterol, the protective kind, which raised questions about its effects on heart health.\n\n\u201cLong-term studies are needed to clarify the effects of long-term SARM administration on cardiovascular risk,\u201d the authors concluded.\n\nThomas O\u2019Connor, a doctor who founded a men\u2019s health clinic and wrote a book called \u201cAmerica on Steroids,\u201d said that many of his patients are anabolic steroid users who turned to SARMs because they were told that they were safe and nontoxic. He said that since 2010 has seen \u201chundreds, maybe over 1,000 men on SARMs\u201d from all walks of life: police officers, defense workers, amateur athletes, accountants and others.\n\nIt\u2019s hard to determine the precise impact of SARMs because many people who use them combine them with other drugs, supplements and substances, Dr. O\u2019Connor said. But one thing he often sees among people using SARMs is that their cholesterol profiles worsen and their liver enzymes rise, a sign of increased strain on their livers. Some also experience diminished sex drive, hair loss, acne and irritability, though it\u2019s often difficult to know whether it\u2019s the SARMs causing these symptoms or some other unlisted ingredients in the products.\n\nAs a longtime power lifter, Dr. O\u2019Connor said he relates to a lot of his patients and understands their desire to be bigger, stronger and fitter. But he counsels them to give up the drugs they are using because they are jeopardizing their health.\n\n\u201cI always tell them the same thing,\u201d he said. \u201cThese are illicit agents. They\u2019re not supported by expert guidelines and they\u2019re dangerous. So don\u2019t take them.\u201d\n\nThe Council for Responsible Nutrition, a supplement industry trade group, launched a campaign on social media, #SARMSCanHarm, and is working with sports clubs, fitness groups and coaches around the country. The military and federal government also have an awareness campaign about risky products called Operation Supplement Safety.\n\nPatricia Deuster, a professor of military and emergency medicine at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, said SARMs are popular among some soldiers because they are easier to access than anabolic steroids, but she warns them there are hazards, citing one soldier who suffered liver damage and could not deploy with his unit because he was hospitalized after using a product containing SARMs and other ingredients.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe try to tell them that there are other ways that they can achieve their goals without risking their health or their ability to maintain their deployment status,\u201d Dr. Deuster said. \u201cWe are trying to educate them.\u201d", "title": "A Better Body in a Pill? Experts Urge Caution on SARMs", "authors": ["Anahad O Connor"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Spotify\u2019s main cost is what it pays record companies for the music it streams to its customers. As Spotify has grown, that expense has fallen as a share of its total revenue, which shows that Spotify is negotiating increasingly advantageous deals with record companies.\n\nThat has bolstered Spotify\u2019s gross profit margin, which measures how much money a company keeps after paying out the costs directly related to generating its revenue. Last year, that margin was 21 percent of revenue at Spotify, well up from 14 percent in 2016.\n\nCrucially, though, Spotify has said it expects its gross margin to expand to as much as 35 percent over the longer term. In other words, as Spotify\u2019s spending on music grows, so will its leverage over record companies. And it may well achieve its gross margin target. After all, Netflix, which occupies a similar position in the market for streaming video, has a gross margin of 35 percent.\n\nBut Spotify\u2019s main rivals could complicate things. What if Amazon offered record companies better terms than Spotify? That would reduce Spotify\u2019s bargaining power, making it harder to deliver wider gross margins investors are expecting. And Amazon, along with Apple and Google, has far deeper pockets to slog it out over the long term.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nHow does Spotify\u2019s first day stack up?\n\nSpotify\u2019s unusual path to the public markets was a success.\n\nOn its first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the music streaming service finished with a valuation of $26.5 billion.\n\nSpotify\u2019s shares opened at $165.90 before closing at $149.01.\n\nThat\u2019s well above the high of $132.50 that its shares changed hands at in private transactions this year. It\u2019s also well above the $137.50 the WSJ reported its private shares were trading at during the past week.\n\nSpotify had eschewed a typical initial public offering in favor of a direct listing. That meant there was no \u201cdeal price\u201d for investors to reference on the first day of trading and no underwriters acting as stabilizing agents if the stock began to plunge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite all that, Spotify\u2019s valuation at the close on Tuesday ranks among the highest for a tech company debuting on an American exchange.\n\nHere\u2019s a look at the tech companies with the 10 biggest market capitalizations after their first day of trading, courtesy of Dealogic:\n\nAlibaba \u2014 $233.9 billion\n\nFacebook \u2014 $81.7 billion\n\nPalm \u2014 $53.3 billion\n\nInfineon Technologies \u2014 $47.9 billion\n\nJD.com \u2014 $28.9 billion\n\nSnap \u2014 $28.9 billion\n\nGoogle \u2014 $27.2 billion\n\nSpotify \u2014 $26.5 billion\n\nTwitter \u2014 $24.9 billion\n\nAgilent \u2014 $20.1 billion\n\nPhoto\n\nTesla\u2019s shares rise on production numbers\n\nShares of the electric carmaker are up 3.3 percent Tuesday after the company released production data Tuesday that showed progress in producing its mass-market Model 3.\n\nTesla said:\n\n\u2022 It built 2,020 Model 3s in the past seven days. That fell short of its goal of 2,500 by the end of the quarter.\n\n\u2022 Tesla produced 9,766 Model 3s during the quarter.\n\n\u2022 In total, Tesla produced 35,000 cars in the first quarter.\n\n\u2022 It has delivered 8,800 Model 3s during the first quarter, below the 8,800 analysts expected according to Bloomberg.\n\n\u2022 In all, Tesla delivered a record 29,980 vehicles during the quarter.\n\n\u2022 The company said it expects Model 3 weekly production to reach 5,000 by the end of the second quarter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The combined deliveries of the Model X and Model S came to 21,800 cars, the lowest total in several quarters.\n\nContext\n\nTesla\u2019s stock and bond prices have plunged amid concerns about how much cash the company is using as it struggles to speed up assembly and sales of the Model 3. With a starting price of $35,000, the car is supposed to be more affordable than Tesla\u2019s other cars. The company has been counting on a quick expansion of its Model 3 business to increase revenue.\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump\u2019s attacks on Amazon continue\n\nThe president reiterated his claim that Amazon is \u201ccosting the United States Postal Service massive amounts of money\u201d in a post to Twitter on Tuesday morning.\n\nShares are essentially flat on the day.\n\nThe accusation is the latest in a string of critical tweets that began Thursday about the e-commerce giant. As The Associated Press pointed out over the weekend, Mr. Trump is misrepresenting Amazon\u2019s record with the United States Postal Service.\n\n\u201cPackage delivery has been a bright spot for a service that\u2019s lost money for 11 straight years. The losses are mostly due to pension and health care costs \u2014 not the business deal for the Postal Service to deliver packages for Amazon. Boosted by e-commerce, the Postal Service has enjoyed double-digit increases in revenue from delivering packages, but that hasn\u2019t been enough to offset declines in first-class letters and marketing mail, which together make up more than two-thirds of postal revenue. \u201cWhile the Postal Service\u2019s losses can\u2019t be attributed to its package business, Trump\u2019s claim that it could get more bang for its buck may not be entirely far-fetched. A 2017 analysis by Citigroup concluded that the Postal Service was charging below-market rates as a whole for parcels. The post office does not use taxpayer money for its operations.\u201d\n\nCould Mr. Tump\u2019s criticism lead to action against Amazon?\n\nGabriel Sherman over at Vanity Fair reports on a few of the ideas being tossed around, including pushing for the Postal Service to renegotiate its contract with Amazon and encouraging \u201cattorneys general in red states to open investigations into Amazon\u2019s business practices.\u201d\n\nWall Street analysts are largely advising investors to ignore the noise. But even if changes were made to sales tax collection, that may end up benefiting Amazon. Michael Olson, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, writes:\n\n\u201cNothing can be certain, except death and taxes \u2026 and more Trump tweets on Amazon. We believe sales tax collection changes would have limited impact on consumer use of Amazon and could actually help Amazon\u2019s relative competitive positioning in domestic e-commerce.\u201d\n\nElliott takes on Korea Inc. again\n\nElliott Management has acquired a $1 billion stake in Hyundai Motors, Kia Motors and Hyundai Mobis.\n\nLast month, Hyundai simplified its ownership structure. The aim was to resolve the group\u2019s circular shareholdings, which critics have long said give too much power to Hyundai\u2019s controlling Chung family at the expense of shareholders, Reuters reported.\n\n\u201cWhile this step is encouraging, more needs to be done to benefit the companies and stakeholders. Elliott calls on management to share a more detailed roadmap as to how it will improve corporate governance, optimize balance sheets, and enhance capital returns at each of the companies. Elliott looks forward to engaging with management and other stakeholders directly on these issues, and to offering recommendations regarding the proposed plan.\u201d\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s behind the market slump?\n\nS.&P. 500 futures are up this morning, suggesting yesterday\u2019s market rout may not continue. And European and Asian markets didn\u2019t fall as sharply as did the U.S.\u2019s. But what\u2019s behind the markets dropping 4 percent so far this year? A couple of ideas:\n\n\u2022 Washington (and Beijing), again: China\u2019s tougher-than-expected retaliatory tariffs gave investors more reason to fear a trade war. American pork and fruit producers are among those sweating. \u201cThe Trump administration\u2019s unorthodox and unpredictable decision-making is likely to keep markets on edge,\u201d Mike Ryan of UBS Wealth Management told the FT.\n\n\u2022 Tech, again: The FAANG stocks are still weighing down the S.&P. 500 and the Nasdaq, as the likes of Facebook and Google face the prospect of greater regulation and President Trump repeats his attacks on Amazon. (Tesla was down, too, but that\u2019s more understandable.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Technical issues: Traders could be trimming bull market bets.\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: Before investors began fretting about tech and trade, the underpinnings of the stock market\u2019s ascent were perhaps not as robust as they looked. Analysts expect S.&P. 500 companies\u2019 earnings to grow 25 percent this year. But rising interest rates worldwide could affect revenue growth. And if wages and other costs come in higher than expected, profit margins could get squeezed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bottom line: Uncertainty has descended upon the markets, and it will be hard to shake off.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow a \u2018Why Me?\u2019 button could help fix Facebook\n\nIn his latest column, Andrew suggests a way the company could make its practices more transparent \u2014 one that Google and Amazon could consider, while we\u2019re at it: a button next to every ad and piece of content that would explain why a user is seeing it.\n\nMore from Andrew:\n\nThe \u201cWhy Me?\u201d button might create all sorts of problems for Facebook, and its advertisers, too. It would allow users \u2014 and rivals \u2014 to reverse engineer much of the way the system works. And advertisers would probably object to the idea of making their targeting plans public. But that would be the cost of using such large public platforms with such exact targeting.\n\nAlso: Mark Zuckerberg just mused about greater transparency to Vox, and suggested an independent appeals process to review content on Facebook. Scott Stringer, the New York City comptroller, wants him out as Facebook\u2019s chairman. And why Southeast Asia, Facebook\u2019s fastest-growing market, poses it unique problems.\n\nElsewhere in data privacy: Beijing and other governments are figuring out what data regulation means for A.I. And Grindr, the gay dating app, has stopped sharing users\u2019 HIV statuses after a BuzzFeed expos\u00e9.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Amazon has visited more than half the cities shortlisted for its second headquarters, unnamed sources said, and the rest are scrambling for tips on their itineraries. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "A Big Reason Wall Street Is Flocking to Spotify: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "All told, the national park, which was created in 1926, partly from farmland bequeathed by Cecil John Rhodes, the founder of the British South African Company, which colonized Rhodesia, has more than 400 varieties of birds, ranging from southern ground hornbills to black storks to mocking cliff chats. In recent decades, thanks to the efforts of Zimbabwe Parks and Wildlife Management Authority \u2014 one of the few functioning institutions in this country \u2014 the park has also become a sanctuary for leopards, antelopes and a robust population of white and black rhinos.\n\nBut it was the birds of prey that I had mainly come to see. Over the past six months I have been researching a book that deals in part with Jeffrey Lendrum, described by British police as one of the world\u2019s most prolific wildlife thieves and smugglers.\n\nRaised in Bulawayo in the 1970s, at the height of the Rhodesian bush war that brought the guerrilla leader Robert Mugabe to power, Mr. Lendrum began climbing into Matobo\u2019s hard-to-reach nests as a boy. He would later turn his agility and ornithological expertise to controversial ends, roaming from Tierra del Fuego to northern Quebec, and snatching the live eggs of wild falcons \u2014 reportedly on behalf of wealthy Arab falconry enthusiasts. (Mr. Lendrum was convicted of stealing eggs in Britain in 2010 and in Chile in 2015, and served time in prison, but insists he did it to save falcons that would otherwise have perished in the wild.)\n\nIn the course of my reporting I have begun tracing Mr. Lendrum\u2019s footsteps around the world, viewing the aeries of peregrines in the Rhondda Valley in Wales, and flying with a falcon in a hot-air balloon in Dubai. Now I had come to southern Africa see where his journey had begun.\n\nMr. Brebner and his wife, Jen, another bird enthusiast, picked me up at my guest cottage in Bulawayo in their four-wheel-drive vehicle, and we headed down a two-lane tarmac road toward Matobo. It was just two weeks after the military coup that had unseated Mr. Mugabe after 37 years in power. \u201cThe roadblocks are gone now,\u201d Mr. Brebner said, referring to the ubiquitous checkpoints that had appeared in the last two years of Mr. Mugabe \u2019s rule. Desperate police officers, he explained, had extorted cash from drivers to replace their unpaid salaries.", "title": "A Birder\u2019s Paradise in Zimbabwe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Professor Martin, of Washington University in St. Louis, discovered the collaboration between Elder Michaux and the F.B.I. when he was working on a book on religious broadcasters.\n\nHe obtained 230 pages of F.B.I. files on Elder Michaux and discovered that Hoover would send the elder memos full of praise. Professor Martin learned that there was more to the relationship.\n\nWhy did you file Freedom of Information Act requests on Elder Michaux?\n\nFerguson happened here in St. Louis, where I live and, of course, the F.B.I. was involved with that, and I knew the F.B.I. was sort of interested in the role of faith communities, that were playing in Ferguson. So I thought, \u201cWell, I\u2019m sure the F.B.I. probably had this concern in the \u201920s, \u201930s and \u201940s as it relates to preachers as well.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat did you discover?\n\nHe was what the F.B.I. at the time called a special correspondent, which meant that he was someone the F.B.I. reached out to and had very cordial relationships with, and very cooperative relationships with for the majority of his broadcasting career. That included, of course, his cooperation with the F.B.I. to discredit Martin Luther King.\n\nWhat specific things did he do to discredit Dr. King?\n\nIn collaboration with the F.B.I., he laundered some of their counterintelligence for them. So for example, the F.B.I. would pass along some information to him on King about, perhaps, King being a communist, and then Michaux would, of course, scrub that intelligence and present it in some of his broadcasts or sermons. In all, what he does is he colludes with the F.B.I. to preach sermons that discredit Martin Luther King and also even engage in a protest of Martin Luther King that was cleared by the F.B.I.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat were some lines of attack that Elder Michaux took against Dr. King?\n\nOn the same day that the F.B.I. writes a memo that says that King is the most dangerous Negro in the world, on that same day they reach out to Michaux and he preaches a sermon against the March on Washington. So the March on Washington has already occurred and, about a month later, Michaux preaches a sermon criticizing the March on Washington and questioning King\u2019s religious commitments. The sermon basically says that King, his religious commitments are questionable, and this whole entire dream that Martin Luther King has will never ever happen and will never come about by marching and protesting. But it will only come about by sort of seeking the Christian conversion of individuals in America.\n\nAnd it questioned his motivations, right?\n\nThe sermon says that King is being motivated not by the Bible, not by religion, but by something else. And of course the F.B.I. is distributing throughout Washington that King is a communist. And so the sermon is sort of used to sort of provide air cover for the kind of counterintelligence the F.B.I. is engaging in as it relates to Martin Luther King.\n\nWere there other times when Elder Michaux was used to further criticize or delegitimize Dr. King?\n\nA second moment is when Martin Luther King and J. Edgar Hoover have a public spat. King tells a New York Times reporter that the F.B.I. cannot sort of investigate segregation if the F.B.I. has segregationists in it. He questions the F.B.I. and their commitments to racial justice and equality. Eventually, Hoover responds by saying that Martin Luther King is the most notorious liar in the country and that King should not be trusted. So when they have this public spat, the F.B.I. reaches out to Michaux and, again, he obliges and helps them. He writes an open letter, releases it to the media, to the newswires at the time, saying that it was Martin Luther King\u2019s fault, and that Hoover is a good Christian servant who is working to ensure the morality of the nation.\n\nHe has help from the F.B.I. in constructing this letter. He\u2019s given information illegally by the F.B.I., inserts it into the letter, sort of vouching for the F.B.I.\u2019s efforts in racial justice.\n\nAnd finally in 1965 he engages in a protest. Martin Luther King is fresh from the march at Selma. He is then in Baltimore with the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, planning their summer plans, and Michaux reaches out to the F.B.I., let\u2019s them know that he\u2019s going to be protesting outside the hotel. So about 100 members of his congregation \u2014 between 100, 125, according to The New York Times \u2014 are outside marching, protesting King with signs such as \u201cCommunist termites are inside\u201d and \u201cGod save America.\u201d\n\nWhat do you think is the big takeaway now?\n\nWe have these African-Americans who are part of this evangelical advisory board in the executive branch. At the same time, we know from documents that have recently been released by the F.B.I. that the executive branch is overseeing the Department of Justice and the F.B.I., who are following Black Lives Matter protesters. I think it allows us to see how these televangelists, who make connections with the executive branch, can be used as religious cover for what the F.B.I. and the executive branch more broadly wants to do.\n\nAs April 4th rolls around, we\u2019ll see Trump and, I\u2019m sure, ministers across the country who will be praising Martin Luther King, praising his ministry, mourning his untimely death. But yet their policies and their commitments will be really far from Martin Luther King. In actuality, I think we\u2019ll see they\u2019re in a tradition with Elder Lightfoot Solomon Michaux.", "title": "A Black Evangelist Who Opposed Dr. King", "authors": ["John Eligon"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Brennan ran. The man followed briefly, walking out of his house and stepping off his porch, according to home security camera footage reviewed by the authorities. He fired a single shot with a 12-gauge shotgun, but Brennan was not hit. The teenager kept running. A few minutes later he encountered deputies \u2014 the woman at the home had called the authorities \u2014 and told his story.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s disgusting, it\u2019s disturbing and it\u2019s unacceptable on every level,\u201d Sheriff Michael Bouchard of Oakland County said. On Friday, the man, Jeffery Zeigler, 53, was charged with assault with intent to murder and possession of a firearm in the commission of a felony, the authorities said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe security footage suggested that Mr. Zeigler was \u201cnot terribly weapons-competent,\u201d Sheriff Bouchard added. \u201cHe was slower to discharge the weapon and as a result, allowed this young man, thankfully, to get farther away.\u201d\n\nThe episode involving Brennan, who is black, called to mind instances in which black people have been killed by armed civilians or the police in recent years, like Stephon Clark, 22, who was fatally shot last month by Sacramento police officers, setting off widespread protests. Brennan\u2019s story is similar to that of Renisha McBride, 19, who approached a stranger\u2019s home in a Detroit suburb and was shot and killed in 2013.\n\nBrennan\u2019s mother, Lisa Wright, said she considered Rochester Hills, a Detroit suburb, a safe community but was only half-surprised that her son was threatened. \u201cAs a black person, I know it\u2019s a possibility,\u201d she said.\n\nMrs. Wright was mindful of what has happened to other black teenagers, like Trayvon Martin, the unarmed 17-year-old in Florida who was killed while wearing a hooded sweatshirt by a neighborhood watch volunteer. She said she had already had the talk with her son about all of the extra things he might have to do to keep himself safe: Don\u2019t wear hoodies. Be open and approachable. Take your hands out of your pockets. She added that in the security footage she had seen, her son appeared to be doing everything right on Thursday morning.\n\n\u201cI just remember a huge shotgun being pointed and aimed at my son,\u201d she said. \u201cMy son was running away.\u201d\n\nMr. Zeigler, a retired firefighter, told a District Court judge on Friday that he was in bed on Thursday morning when his wife began \u201cscreaming and crying,\u201d The Associated Press reported. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot more to the story than what\u2019s being told,\u201d he added, \u201cand I believe that will come out in court.\u201d", "title": "A Black Teenager Asked for Directions. A Man Responded With Gunfire.", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The two women soon established a pattern to their column, and comic guidelines for the quintessential \u201chey ladies\u201d email: It must have \u201ca million exclamation points to show how excited you are,\u201d said Ms. Markowitz. And \u201cthrow in a sentence about how excited you are just in case the exclamation points don\u2019t do it,\u201d said Ms. Moss.\n\nIt should include \u201csome \u2018friendly reminders,\u201d written in a passive-aggressive tone, Ms. Moss said, plus a pointless inquiry, like \u201casking 26 people what dates in June are good for them.\u201d\n\nThrough some kind of wedding-industrial-complex magic, she said, someone always owes money by the end of the email.\n\nThe authors \u201calways thought a book would be fun,\u201d Ms. Markowitz said, but didn\u2019t formally begin planning one until 2016, around the same time that The Toast was shutting down. (Their final column for the site, \u201cTake It to Slack,\u201d was published June 30, 2016.) \u201cWriting a book was a good way to keep the ladies around,\u201d she said.\n\nThe book \u2014 which tells the story of one year in a female friend group entirely through their emails, off-thread text conversations about emails, and social media posts \u2014 was also a good way to \u201ccreate a world where these women really are friends, and actually really do care about each other, and want to be near each other, and want to talk to each other,\u201d said Ms. Moss. The characters vent, date and debrief, in addition to booking a destination bachelorette to South Portugal, which they inexplicably abbreviate as \u201cSoPu.\u201d\n\nFor Ms. Moss and Ms. Markowitz, friendship is the whole point. \u201cThere\u2019s a little bit of an inner struggle\u201d when one receives a \u201chey ladies\u201d email, Ms. Markowitz said. You\u2019re stuck between feeling \u201cthis is going to be a lot of work, and how much is this going to end up costing me\u201d and gratitude for the relationship that landed you on the email chain in the first place. \u201cYou want to be a part of something and make your friend feel special,\u201d she said.", "title": "A Book of Emails Women Love to Hate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 When President Trump began railing against the current state of American immigration measures over the weekend, it was hard to tell where his thoughts ended and Brandon Judd\u2019s began.\n\nMr. Judd is the president of the National Border Patrol Council, a frequent guest on Fox News and a reliably vocal supporter of the Trump administration\u2019s hard-line immigration agenda. On Sunday, he was interviewed on \u201cFox & Friends,\u201d one of the president\u2019s favorite programs.\n\nWhat followed was a public mind meld with the president, one that has frequently occurred since Mr. Trump took office.\n\n\u201cOur legislators actually have to stand up, and the Republicans control the House and the Senate; they do not need the Democrat support to pass any laws they want,\u201d Mr. Judd said during the segment. \u201cThey can go the nuclear option, just like what they did on the confirmation. They need to pass laws to end the catch-and-release program that\u2019ll allow us to hold them for a long time.\u201d", "title": "A Border Patrol Agent (and Frequent Fox News Guest) Has Trump\u2019s Ear on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "A clue is that 7 percent of ancient DNA samples from Europe and the steppes contain DNA of the plague microbe that caused medieval Europe\u2019s Black Death. Perhaps steppe peoples acquired plague, developed some immunity with exposure, and transmitted it to unexposed European farmers, thereby decimating them. It would be ironic if Europe\u2019s first farmers succumbed to an introduced disease, because other diseases introduced by European colonists of the New World after 1492 equally decimated Native American populations.\n\nMy last example: What was the origin of Polynesian people, who colonized every habitable Pacific island from Tonga to Hawaii within the last few thousand years? Archaeological and linguistic evidence had already shown that Polynesians can be traced back to the island of Taiwan. But what happened to them between their leaving Taiwan and their reaching Tonga?\n\nThe astonishing answer is: genetically, nothing! The first proto-Polynesian culture located archaeologically on islands east of the Solomons is called the Lapita. DNA of early Lapita skeletons from Vanuatu and Tonga is mostly Taiwanese DNA, with little or no contribution from the Papuan peoples inhabiting the New Guinea region through which Taiwanese farmers passed en route to Vanuatu and Tonga. That sexual abstemiousness is unexpected. But Papuans subsequently reached those Pacific islands and mixed with the Lapita first arrivals, because the islands\u2019 modern inhabitants do carry Papuan genes.\n\nAs with any new scientific methodology, new genetic methods tend to alter previously held beliefs about the course of human history. And some readers will certainly find Reich\u2019s conclusions unpalatable. Japanese may not like hearing that they share 80 percent of their DNA with Koreans. Reich\u2019s collaborators from India didn\u2019t like hearing that their own DNA samples attested to massive past migrations into the Indian subcontinent. Native Americans may not like hearing that 10,000-year-old Native American skeletons whose repatriation and reburial they seek have no demonstrable connection to tribes living in the same geographic area today. Those reactions are inevitable, but Reich bends over backward to present both the evidence and the uncertainties.\n\nWhat should you expect when you read this book? Don\u2019t expect an oversimplified story. Population genetics is a complicated, fast-moving field with many uncertainties of interpretation. To tell that story to the broad public, and not just to scientists reading specialty journals, is a big challenge. Reich explains these complications as well as any geneticist could; others rarely even try. Some of Reich\u2019s conclusions will surely be superseded within a few years. But few subjects fascinate us as much as human origins. Humans have been on the move not just since Columbus\u2019s voyage of 1492, but throughout our long history. The ancestors of modern Japanese, Indians and Native Americans didn\u2019t become fixed in their modern locations in ancient times and simply stop moving. If you want to understand our origins over the course of the last 100,000 years, this book will be the best up-to-date account for you.", "title": "A Brand-New Version of Our Origin Story", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Holt and Austin exchanged words and the benches and bullpens emptied, but the situation quickly cooled and the game resumed.\n\n\u201cI probably said something I shouldn\u2019t have to start the whole thing, so I\u2019m sorry for that,\u201d said Holt, whose calf was cut by Austin\u2019s spikes. \u201cI just wanted him to know that it was a bad slide and I think everyone on the field knows that it was.\u201d\n\nNaturally, the Yankees disagreed.\n\nManager Aaron Boone said that while the slide may have violated the letter of the law, \u201cto construe that as a dirty play or that you\u2019d be offended by that, I don\u2019t buy that at all.\u201d\n\nAustin, who was the Yankees\u2019 designated hitter on Wednesday night, struck out in his next at-bat against Heath Hembree in the fifth. At the time it looked like the Yankees, with an 8-1 lead, were on their way to a laugher.\n\nBut by the time Austin came to bat with one out in the seventh, the Red Sox were back in it. J.D. Martinez had belted a grand slam off Masahiro Tanaka to get the Red Sox within 8-6 in the fifth before the Yankees pushed another two runs across in the sixth to lead, 10-6.\n\nKelly retired Neil Walker to begin the seventh, then hit Austin with a 2-1 fastball.\n\nAs he charged the mound, Kelly waved, signaling for Austin to come get him. As they approached each other, Austin, who was being grabbed from behind by catcher Christian Vazquez, slipped and fell while trying to tackle Kelly, who landed a couple of punches on Austin.\n\nQuickly, though, they were engulfed. After a brief pause, she added: \u201cBut really, they help me not die.\u201d\n\nIn order to explain her craft and how she wanted the brothers to edge her sword, Ms. Knapp gave an impromptu demonstration in the store, which Joey recorded on his phone.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThey knew right away what they needed to do,\u201d Ms. Knapp said. \u201cJoey and Vinnie can do everything in like 15 minutes but I always end up staying for over an hour and a half, chatting.\u201d\n\nSeveral large grinding wheels are spread throughout the workspace. One wall displays scissors in all shapes and sizes; prices range from $50 to $500 per pair. Next to the scissors are hair sprays and dyes, brushes and beard oils. The counter space has a dizzying display of nail cutters, splitters and nippers, most of which are made by the Biancos.\n\nPerhaps the store\u2019s most charming fixture \u2014 although he is not officially on the payroll \u2014 is Joseph Solitario, 83, who lives down the block. Every day, he stands behind the counter to help people. He\u2019ll get the brothers\u2019 attention if a customer hasn\u2019t been greeted. He\u2019ll wash the windows. He\u2019ll have a cup of coffee and talk about his 21 grandchildren.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHis wife\u2019s baked ziti is the best,\u201d Vinnie said, who often eats lunch with Mr. Solitario.\n\nOn the back of the entrance door, customers have made an ad hoc bulletin board. On a recent weekday morning, there were two ads looking for a barber, and a for-sale listing of a barbershop on Avenue U.\n\nPhoto\n\nHenry Ficke, a podiatrist with an office in Gravesend, said he\u2019s been a customer since the mid-90s, ever since he met Vinnie at a trade show.\n\n\u201cAny person who works with precision tools knows the importance of good maintenance,\u201d he said.\n\nBut Dr. Ficke said he also relies on Vinnie for all kinds of things, including an introduction to a new part-time podiatry job in Staten Island, because of Vinnie\u2019s \u201cvast connections.\u201d\n\n\u201cI call him before I call anyone else,\u201d Dr. Ficke said. \u201cI once called him about a broken chair!\u201d", "title": "A Brooklyn Go-To for Beauticians and Butchers", "authors": ["Kaya Laterman", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Hung like artwork, 26 white doors decorate the dining room of Las Puertas, Victor Parra Gonzalez\u2019s tiny nouveau-Mexican restaurant in a gray gabled house on Buffalo\u2019s West Side.\n\n\u201cEvery one represents a person of major importance who told me I would not open this restaurant,\u201d the chef said. \u201cSeeing those doors every day tells me we accomplished something.\u201d\n\nThe doubters had a point. Mr. Gonzalez\u2019s first restaurant, the ambitious Jaguar at the Bistro near Niagara Falls, closed in 2015. As a follow-up, a deeply personal food venture in Buffalo\u2019s emerging Five Points neighborhood seemed audacious.\n\nA year after Las Puertas\u2019 debut, though, the Acapulco-born chef is having the last laugh. Marrying the earthy cuisine of his birthplace with rigorous French technique, the 29-year-old earned a 2018 James Beard Awards semifinalist as Best Chef/Northeast. His highly photogenic plates \u2014 luscious duck breast in subtle pipian verde, translucent scallop aguachile, rich chicken confit in mole rojo \u2014 make fond allusions to his homeland while showcasing his precision and wit.", "title": "A Buffalo, N.Y., Restaurant With Bona Fides From Acapulco, Quebec and Beyond", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "A question that I suspect that you\u2019re often asked: is your assignment dangerous?\n\nI don\u2019t like to talk about this because the purpose of our work is to shed light on the issues facing our world and not to draw attention to ourselves. But yes, the document hunting is especially difficult because ISIS mined many of the buildings they occupied. It\u2019s why I never enter these buildings alone. My team was always embedded with Iraqi troops, who took the greatest risk by entering the buildings first and who then watched over us as we searched for documents. There were numerous buildings that they deemed were too risky to enter. In one, we searched the front part of the house and then suddenly the troops started shouting and all of us ran outside. It was in the courtyard that they explained that they had discovered an unexploded I.E.D. in one of the side rooms, which they believed had been rigged to blow when we opened the door to the room.\n\nThe podcast means that you now have a colleague from The Times along when you\u2019re reporting. Has that brought any changes, either good or bad?\n\nMy work is often very solitary. It\u2019s usually just me flying to the country where I am reporting, staying by myself in a hotel and then meeting up with our translators and fixers during the day. When I\u2019m writing, it\u2019s even lonelier. It was so much fun to have my audio colleague Andy Mills for one of my trips to Iraq. He was at my side for almost four weeks. We slept on the roofs of abandoned buildings together. We embedded with troops and searched buildings side by side. And then back in New York, it was such a rush to be able to work with a team \u2014 including producers Larissa Anderson and Asthaa Chaturvedi and our editors Wendy Dorr and Sam Dolnick. In addition to a 1,875-square-foot finished basement, it also has roughly 1,550 square feet of outdoor space, including an unfinished rooftop terrace off the penthouse and a rear garden with a limestone fountain, which, according to Mrs. Geller, \u201cwas inspired by the Bethesda Fountain\u201d in Central Park.\n\nThroughout the high-ceilinged home are numerous architectural flourishes and period antiques, painstakingly added by the Gellers over the years. The couple managed to locate sales materials put out by Mr. Noble, the builder, and sought to match some of the interior styles and materials used by his architect, Edward L. Angell. (Mr. Noble had built nine single-family houses, Nos. 241-249, along that Central Park West block; Col. Richard Lathers, a successful cotton merchant who was also involved in banking and insurance, bought No. 248 for $35,000, according to Mr. Sieger.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond.
