View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nVarious kinds of marble were brought in during the renovation, and the couple made lavish use of decorative ceiling patterns. The parlor-floor powder room, for instance, has a domed silver leaf ceiling. Quartersawed white oak is also prominent and can be found in the paneling, moldings and Parquet de Versailles patterned floors.\n\nThe couple also refurbished the exterior, hiring Building Conservation Associates to restore the bas-relief carvings and balcony grills, recreate a wrought-iron entrance gate and add curved windows, among other things.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s what\u2019s so special about this house: the architectural details,\u201d said Mrs. Geller, a retired office manager. \u201cI put my heart and soul into it for the last 14 to 15 years.\u201d\n\nThe home\u2019s main entry is on the parlor floor at the second level. A marble foyer, with an antique mirrored coat rack, opens to a formal parlor that is anchored by a fireplace with a white oak mantel and marble surround, one of four in the house. The space flows into an oak-paneled library with built-in shelves and a Putnam rolling ladder. A pocket door separates the library from the music room, which contains a late 1800s Steinway grand piano crafted from rosewood.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe third level is dedicated to dining. It features a formal dining room with a wood fireplace mantel obtained from Westland London, an architectural antiques dealer. A spacious eat-in kitchen is equipped with high-end appliances like a La Cornue Ch\u00e2teau gas and electric stove, and a long center island of Calacatta gold marble. Connected to the kitchen is a butler\u2019s pantry with Caesarstone countertops.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe master bedroom suite, which has another Westland London fireplace mantel, takes up the entire fourth level and features dual dressing rooms and bathrooms. There is also a large sitting room/study with views of the park, one of Mrs. Geller\u2019s favorite rooms. \u201cI spend a lot of time here,\u201d she said.\n\nThere are four more en-suite bedrooms on the top two levels, including a second master suite with a mechanical closet in the penthouse. Another en-suite bedroom is on the garden level, along with a second kitchen and dining area, and a screening room, outfitted with eight black velvet theater seats, that opens to the backyard.\n\nIn the basement is a lap pool, around 50 feet long and 6 feet wide, a gym, a laundry room and storage space.\n\n\u201cI come here every morning to work out,\u201d Mr. Geller said. He also runs in the park, which has served almost as an extension to the couple\u2019s home. \u201cWhen there are concerts,\u201d Mrs. Geller said, \u201cwe come up to the roof and listen.\u201d", "title": "A Central Park West Townhouse, Rooted in History, on the Market for $29 Million", "authors": ["Vivian Marino"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The class in Anderson taught by Ms. Hamlin \u2014 or Ms. Elysse as she is known by her students \u2014 is at a Goodwill Excel Center tuition-free adult high school. There are 15 such schools in Indiana and one each in Austin, Tex.; Memphis; Washington; and Little Rock, Ark. They are all under the umbrella of the nonprofit Goodwill Industries International and are for anyone over 16 or 18 years old, depending on the state, who dropped out of high school before receiving a diploma.\n\n[READ MORE: Goodwill Working to Help Dropouts]\n\nFive more, four in Missouri and one in Muncie, Ind., are scheduled to open by 2019.\n\nAlthough there are many other programs around the country to help adults get their high school diplomas, the Goodwill Excel school model stands out because it accepts students of any age \u2014 most other schools cap their enrollment at age 25 or younger \u2014 is growing nationally and offers intensive support to overcome the obstacles facing most people trying to go back to school.\n\nPhoto\n\nEach school provides life coaches, who serve as a combination guidance counselor and social worker, drop-in child care, transportation assistance and other benefits. Students work toward a regular diploma and dual college credit or industry-recognized vocational certification in any number of fields, such as pharmacy technician, information technology or welding. And any Excel Center in any state is required to incorporate all those elements.\n\nRigorous research has shown that that kind of wraparound support \u201chas the potential to have the most impact,\u201d said Elizabeth Zachry Rutschow, a senior research associate with MDRC, a nonprofit research organization. \u201cThis comprehensive support model is very unusual. Adult education programs are often really strapped for funding.\u201d\n\nAlthough most of the students dropped out in high school, the average student has a fourth-grade reading and math level.\n\n\u201cI had an epiphany the first time I saw the Excel Center in Indiana,\u201d said Tony Martini, president and chief executive of Memphis Goodwill. \u201cI thought, how can we not do this?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was a struggle. In 2015, his Goodwill opened an Excel school in Memphis, with Goodwill funding the bulk of the program and private philanthropists helping out. Goodwill lobbied hard for a change in state law, which was approved late last year; now adult learners receive the same financing as traditional students, and the state will pick up most of the funding for the Memphis center.\n\nAbout 400 students have graduated or are expected to graduate from the Memphis school by June, and Mr. Martini hopes to open six to 12 centers in Memphis over the next six years\n\nOne reason politicians like these schools is that employers like them.\n\n\u201cA lot of employers are looking for the more mature adult who has demonstrated literacy and numeracy skills, training in basic technology and the soft skills,\u201d such as knowing how to operate in a business environment and self-regulation, said Terry Salinger, institute fellow and chief scientist for reading for the American Institutes for Research, a social science research company.\n\nLuke Kenley, a recently retired Indiana state senator, a Republican and appropriations chairman, was a strong supporter of the Excel Center.\n\n\u201cThis is a looming problem in Indiana like everywhere else in the country. Where do you get people educated for today\u2019s work force?\u201d he said. When Goodwill, which already ran a free traditional charter school in Indianapolis, came forward seeking funding for the Excel Center, \u201cI knew they were an exceptionally capable nonprofit in terms of social issues, and the problem has become so large \u2014 getting people prepared for good jobs \u2014 that government funding appeared to be necessary.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nI was bouncing around through foster homes; I was 17 when I dropped out. I made it through to senior year and didn\u2019t have any of my credits because I was going from school to school because of foster care. I called Goodwill for the G.E.D. program, but they had done away with it, and they invited me to Excel. I was one of the first students who walked through the door. It wasn\u2019t easy \u2014 I worked all day, every day. A couple of times I wanted to give up. (Some staff members) took me on college tours. They got me amped up, and I took the ACT. I\u2019ve been working full time at night as a maintenance mechanic for about seven years, and I also went to Marian (University in Indianapolis) and graduated with a bachelor\u2019s degree in business administration. I\u2019ll be going back to get an engineering degree. I want to move from fixing machines to more the engineering and design.\n\nJamieson Brewer, 26, was one of the Excel Center\u2019s first graduates, in 2011.\n\nLearning: A Special Section Welcome to the new Learning section \u2014 a deep dive into the joys, excitement, challenges and opportunities in the world of education and learning. This is the first of four refreshed and redesigned sections we will publish this year. Drawing on the commitment to the subject and the expertise across The New York Times, we want Learning to be a place where educators, students and parents can join a vigorous conversation around the best ways to educate people, whether children or adults. (You can reach us at learningsection@nytimes.com with comments and ideas.) - Jane Bornemeier, Editor\n\nThe first Excel Center opened in 2010 in Indianapolis, and it was something of a failure. About 300 students attended the school, but the curriculum was online, and it just didn\u2019t work. Only four students graduated.\n\nThe staff rethought its approach and moved from online to almost entirely in-class instruction. Each school offers five eight-week terms annually, and students can enter at the beginning of any term. They are tested before entering to determine their level of English and math. Students who fail a subject can retake it in the next eight-week term \u2014 and the next.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe core classes are also offered morning, evening and sometimes at night, so a student can work and attend classes.\n\nThe teachers, many of whom taught in public schools before joining the Excel Centers, and the life coaches know all too well the obstacles facing their students\u2019 quest for a diploma. Children or parents get sick or in trouble, the car breaks down or the bus doesn\u2019t come, the family\u2019s breadwinner loses a job or goes to prison. The teachers and life coaches cajole, praise, encourage, and if a student who has been on track suddenly disappears, they call, text, reach out on Facebook and even show up at their door. Teachers have taken homework to hospitals when a student gets sick.\n\nBut there\u2019s a fine line between helping the students, many of whom are struggling with multiple financial and family problems, and doing too much.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re loving them, but also challenging and pushing them,\u201d said Dionne Leard, the director at the Excel Center University Heights in Indianapolis.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile the average student graduates within 18 months, some, like Karen Johnson, a recent graduate, take much longer. Arriving barely able to read, she took English 2 six times.\n\n\u201cAs long as they are making progress they can stay,\u201d Ms. Leard said.\n\nTera Price, 21, fusses over her month-old daughter in a car seat next to her \u2014 the infant is too young to go to the child care center. Nicole Gosha, 42, and her son Rickey, 29, sit next to each other joking with some other students.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just glad I came,\u201d Ms. Gosha said, \u201cand I gave a speech, which isn\u2019t something I normally do.\u201d\n\nHer son leaned in. \u201cI gave the best speech. I did research on bed bugs.\u201d\n\nThe graduation rate at Excel Centers in Indiana is about 20 to 25 percent; while that appears low, the model of eight-week terms makes traditional measurements difficult.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn terms of bang for your buck, that graduation rate still looks good,\u201d said Kate Hovde, a senior adviser in education at the Center for High Impact Philanthropy at the University of Pennsylvania. \u201cThe benefits of earned income over their lifetime is still significant.\u201d The organization included the Goodwill Excel Center in Indiana as part of a report released last month to help inform donors about programs and strategies to help young adults who have dropped out of school and are not working.\n\nAt the start of a term, most of the students are full of hope and enthusiasm, proud they showed up the first day.\n\nBut it\u2019s hard to know who will end up with a diploma and who won\u2019t. Who will power straight through, who will disappear forever and who will reappear after months away. Two weeks after the first class, Tera Price stop showing up. A month in, the Goshas, mother and son, had near-perfect attendance.\n\nI had to start paying bills for our household. My mom has a lot of health issues, and my dad has a lot of problems with his back, so they weren\u2019t making the money to make ends meet to pay the bills.\n\nI dropped out in eighth grade; my sister dropped out in high school. We were skidding. We drove around and picked up wooden pallets and cashed them in for the money\n\nI always felt bad about dropping out. I got pregnant with my daughter when I was 19, and one of the things mainly pushing me toward getting my diploma was my daughter kept asking me why I didn\u2019t graduate. She was having a problem. She didn\u2019t want to go to school. She asked me, \u201cWhy do I have to go? You never finished.\u201d Right there it hit me. She\u2019s looking at me, and I don\u2019t want her to follow in my footsteps.\n\nAmber Parrish, 27, expects to graduate in June from the Excel Center.", "title": "A Chance for Dropouts, Young and Old, to Go Back to School", "authors": ["Alina Tugend"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Some chefs meditate. Some do yoga. Others do shots. But when it comes to finding calm amid the hectic whirl of the professional kitchen, Ruth Rogers, the chef and owner of the River Caf\u00e9 in London, likes to stir risotto.\n\n\u201cRisotto is such a relaxing thing to make because of the slowness of it,\u201d she said in a recent phone call. \u201cIt\u2019s got a soothing rhythm that\u2019s good when you\u2019re anxious about something.\u201d\n\nAnd I was anxious about something, which is why I called. I was anxious about the nettle and taleggio risotto in the recently released \u201cRiver Caf\u00e9 London\u201d cookbook (Knopf, 2018).\n\nThe book, a vibrantly designed celebration of the restaurant\u2019s 30th anniversary, includes updated versions of recipes from the classic 1995 \u201cRiver Caf\u00e9 Cookbook,\u201d along with new ones.", "title": "A Chef\u2019s Advice for Relaxation: Stir Some Risotto", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "So \u201cThe Lucky Ones\u201d is wounded autobiography veiled in fiction. Set in crunchy small-town New England (\u201ca part of Vermont that happens to be in Maine\u201d), it\u2019s a follow-up to \u201cHundred Days,\u201d a musical memoir of the Bengsons\u2019 beginnings as a couple that was a hit last fall at New York Theater Workshop. Like \u201cHundred Days,\u201d \u201cThe Lucky Ones\u201d is directed by Anne Kauffman and has a book co-written by the playwright Sarah Gancher, who is the Bengsons\u2019 neighbor across the hall in Ridgewood, Queens.\n\nIn the new show, an extended family runs a school together, raising their children \u2014 Abigail, her sisters and their cousins \u2014 in a kind of hippie idyll. Then, in one cataclysmic season, it all falls apart, beginning with a killing that might have been prevented if only the parents hadn\u2019t been so committed to a you-choose-your-feelings worldview that they dismissed the signs of mental illness in one of the kids.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s possible that we have all been raised in a way that hurt us,\u201d Abigail says in the show. \u201cAnd maybe hurt us so badly that we will hurt other people.\u201d\n\nLike Abigail, the character she plays in \u201cThe Lucky Ones,\u201d Ms. Bengson grew up in an extended hippie family that revolved around a school. In reality, though, the person in her clan who killed someone was not a blood relative but rather a person she had been raised to consider an older sibling \u2014 someone she loved and admired, who \u201cwrote strange and beautiful music,\u201d who claimed to hear voices and did as they instructed.\n\nThis is the person, no longer institutionalized, whose life Ms. Bengson is most fearful of harming with \u201cThe Lucky Ones,\u201d an ensemble piece in which a cascade of events results in the dissolution of her family, including her parents\u2019 marriage.", "title": "A Childhood Eden Seared by Violence. Set to Music?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was waiting for a friend at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A handsome young man entered wearing a long, single-button, camel coat that I recognized in an instant.\n\n\u201cVintage Perry Ellis,\u201d I said, by way of paying a compliment.\n\n\u201cHow do you know?\u201d he asked.\n\n\u201cI had that coat and I wish I still did!\u201d\n\nI thought back to buying the coat, wearing it and feeling wrapped in its luxury.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a designer for Perry Ellis now,\u201d the young man said, \u201cand a friend told me he had this old coat.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt was iconic,\u201d I said, recalling the pride of its swing with my hands embedded in those deep patch pockets.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s from 1983, a year before I was born!\u201d\n\nMy carefree memories began to recede.", "title": "A Coat to Remember", "authors": ["Charles Kopelman", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "A selection of 380 pieces from the Perlstein collection will fill all three floors of the Hauser & Wirth Chelsea gallery in New York from April 26 through July 27. (Nothing is for sale.) Unlike the leading collectors of our day, who hire professionals to track the market as assiduously as hedge fund managers, Mr. Perlstein follows his nose through the bewildering maze of modern art. He says that he pounces when he sees \u201csomething not normal.\u201d His collection includes Dada and Surrealism (Max Ernst, Man Ray, Dora Maar, Ren\u00e9 Magritte, Jean Tinguely, Niki de Saint Phalle); American minimalism and post-minimalism (Donald Judd, Ad Reinhardt, Brice Marden, Fred Sandback); and land art (Richard Long, Robert Smithson, Michael Heizer, Gordon Matta-Clark).\n\nHere are some of the best-known artists and themes, and how he came to collect them.\n\nMan Ray\n\nLike many collectors of contemporary art, Mr. Perlstein prizes his relationships with artists. He met the man whose work arguably forms the core of his collection at a gallery in Vence, in the south of France, in 1969, when he and a friend decided to salvage a rainy day by driving to an exhibition that bore the intriguing title \u201cLes Invendables\u201d (\u201cThe Unsellables\u201d).\n\nWhen they arrived, they saw a man leaning against the door. \u201cWhat are you doing here?\u201d he asked them. \u201cWhat do you want?\u201d He had such a strong American accent that Mr. Perlstein offered to switch to English, but the mysterious stranger insisted on French.", "title": "A Collector Follows His Nose Through the Maze of Modern Art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The Marine Corps likes to present itself with dutiful seriousness. \u201cTerminal Lance\u201d is a counterpoint to that. It is a tribute to the service\u2019s permanent underclass, the young grunts who are too weary to feign enthusiasm anymore. (The strip\u2019s title is derived from slang for the holder of a junior rank \u2014 lance corporal \u2014 who will never be promoted and thus will depart the corps as a terminal lance.)\n\nThe Pentagon speaks of duty, commitment and national defense. Mr. Uriarte\u2019s troops seem to have boarded the wrong bus. They are anxious, lonely and bored. Sick of slogans and tired of being casually hazed and verbally abused, they take refuge in drawing penises inside the porta-potties that dot their bases and outposts. They find chaplains creepy and lifers tiresome. Their corps is a bizarre professional ecosystem where the working caste masturbates, binge-drinks, watches porn and plays video games in the barracks and then reports to work hung over.\n\nIn art as in life, it is not that these lance corporals are unwilling to train or to fight. It\u2019s that America\u2019s wars give them little opportunity to train and fight smart. Much of their deployed time is spent on duties that accomplish little, or worse, cause harm to others and themselves. In this dispiriting system the only privilege many of them can claim is the power to look down on even newer Marines \u2014 the \u201cboots,\u201d a clueless population subject to harassment and ridicule.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf this sounds like a hard sell to a proud service, \u201cTerminal Lance\u201d fans have rewarded Mr. Uriarte\u2019s unflinching take and reportage with a full embrace. The nearly 691,000 followers of the \u201cTerminal Lance\u201d Facebook page are almost four times the number of active-duty Marines. In just three years, its newer Instagram account has swelled to 287,000 fans, the largest proportion of whom are 18- to-24-year-olds. The strip\u2019s own website averages about one million unique visitors a month, and its reach is further boosted by the publication of a less offensive version in the Marine Corps Times, an independent biweekly newspaper.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Uriarte, formerly a terminal lance himself, attributes the success to an unusual trait for a comic strip: accuracy. \u201cI think \u2018Terminal Lance\u2019 has done very well because while it has been critical, it\u2019s been honest,\u201d he said.\n\nThat\u2019s not to say the strip has not generated complaints. Senior Marines often contact Mr. Uriarte to grouse about unflattering portrayals, including his characters\u2019 excessive drinking. Some try to root out his sources. But the corps and its illustrator have found a measure of peace.\n\n\u201cIf you are a grunt and can\u2019t laugh at this stuff, you\u2019d go crazy,\u201d Gen. Robert Neller, the Marine commandant, said in a telephone interview last week. \u201cEvery time I see his comic I read it. If nothing else it makes you ponder his point, or just laugh out loud.\u201d\n\nIn hindsight Mr. Uriarte\u2019s success looks like a plan. He enlisted in the Marines in 2006, when he was 19, hoping to become a professional artist with time. He had been drawing and sketching since he was kid and was seeking a challenge and the rich story lines he expected to find in grunt life.\n\n\u201cI consider myself an artist before anything else,\u201d he said. \u201cThis whole thing was really to inform my artwork, from a weird 19-year-old perspective.\u201d\n\nHe spent his first combat tour, in 2007, as a machine-gunner in the turret of an armored truck, escorting his company commander around. By his second tour, in 2009, he had talked himself into a job as an official photographer.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe next year, with only a few months left on active duty and no promotion in sight, Mr. Uriarte started \u201cTerminal Lance,\u201d publishing under his own name. He had a smartphone, a website and a subject: his fellow disgruntled Marines, who had almost no voice of their own. He channeled it.\n\n\u201cThey essentially created a monster,\u201d he said, of the corps. \u201cI wonder if they regret not promoting me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTerminal Lance\u201d immediately attracted attention, including from a sergeant major who summoned Lance Corporal Uriarte to his office and sent him to see a Marine lawyer. The lawyer told him not to use real names \u2014 a warning he did not always heed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen Mr. Uriarte left the corps, he enrolled at the California College of the Arts on the G.I. Bill. He became part of a growing network of Marines attuned to problems plaguing their cohort: cycles of deployments leading to despair, post-traumatic stress disorder and difficulties readjusting to civilian life. Two members of his former infantry company committed suicide.\n\nAll of this informed \u201cTerminal Lance.\u201d Staff Sgt. Kevin T. Hoffman, a Marine based at Camp Lejeune, N.C., was drawn to Mr. Uriarte\u2019s strip as it launched, when he was a lance corporal recovering in a hospital from wounds suffered in a bomb attack in Afghanistan.\n\nHe recognized it as real. The strip resonated with him, he said, because it \u201cmade me reflect and miss the barracks and my friends.\u201d He reads it still, even as a supervisor himself. Mr. Uriarte has \u201cbeen able to remain a figurehead because his experiences are timeless,\u201d Staff Sergeant Hoffman said.\n\nOver the years the strip has come to focus on the experiences of two main characters, Abe and Garcia, who in many ways are foul-mouthed millennial updates on Willie and Joe, Bill Mauldin\u2019s comic-strip characters of World War II.\n\nGarcia is likable and reasonable, a Marine who accepts the corps\u2019 absurdities, indignities and tedium in stride. Abe is often selfish, unimpressed and eager for the weekend. He seems born not to fight, but to complain, and is not even sure why he volunteered.\n\nBut Mr. Uriarte\u2019s work has evolved past Abe\u2019s brief and often one-sided episodes of venting. In \u201cThe White Donkey,\u201d his graphic novel, he used the characters to venture into more serious themes, confronting the violence at the center of the infantry\u2019s purpose and presenting a grim view of Marines eager for war.\n\nSet in 2007 during the occupation of Iraq, it includes a scene where an Iraqi police officer stands silently beside Abe and Garcia as they talk and smoke cigarettes. Abe is disgusted. Violence has declined. He has seen little action \u2014 except for an unarmed civilian he mistook for a suicide bomber and shot. He finds Iraq ugly. He admits he hates the place.\n\nThe Iraqi officer startles the Americans by revealing he speaks English and understood everything Abe said. \u201cWould it make you feel better to kill someone?\u201d he asks. \u201cYou came here to kill brown people like me, yes? Why not kill me now?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe spares no disgust for the occupier\u2019s journey. \u201cI have met many of your type over the last few years, coming here to fulfill some personal conquest, but you never stop to think about how arrogant you are,\u201d he says. \u201cYou seek some enlightenment at the expense of my people.\u201d\n\nFor Mr. Uriarte, who modeled Abe in part on his younger self, the scene is both self-lacerating and a hint of perspective gained. It is also a challenge to his core readership, as are his occasional statements on personal social media standing up for gays in the military, women in the corps and gun control.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Mr. Uriarte works on a second graphic novel, he acknowledges that he is growing older than his subjects. He said he expects his work will eventually leave the corps behind.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to keep doing this forever,\u201d he said. \u201cAt some point I\u2019ll stop.\u201d\n\nThat day does not seem soon. For now, Mr. Uriarte remains fully engaged with the corps and his illustrated version.\n\nWhen an annoyed Marine wrote to Mr. Uriarte demanding that he reveal a source behind a recent video, Mr. Uriarte did not drift into a discussion about the First Amendment or the role of anonymous sources in keeping the public informed.\n\nLike a proper terminal lance, his reply was dismissive and defiant, in keeping with what his fans might expect. \u201cYour mother,\u201d he shot back.", "title": "A Comic Strip About the Marines: The Few, the Proud, the Bored Out of Their Minds", "authors": ["C. J. Chivers"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Six years later, Douthat, a columnist for this newspaper, has become the successor to the conservative Catholic doyen William F. Buckley Jr. (who once took him sailing \u2014 and skinny-dipping \u2014 on Long Island Sound). His ascendance has come at an odd moment: The right wing dominates politics, but so-called conservatives have traduced the ideals that drew him to the movement. Small-government congressmen have dropped commitments to rein in federal spending; evangelicals (those champions of traditional marriage) are supine in their support of the sexual predator in the White House. And after a third of a century in which John Paul II made the papacy \u201ca rallying point for resistance to the redefinition of Christianity,\u201d the church is led by a pope who has no use for the culture-war schema of resistance and accommodation \u2014 who sees the church called to \u201cgo to the peripheries\u201d rather than strive to restore Christianity as the vital center.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo Douthat Francis is an accommodationist, and decline has reached the apex of the church. \u201cThis is a hinge moment in the history of Catholicism,\u201d he declares, \u201ca period of theological crisis that\u2019s larger than just the Francis pontificate but whose particular peak under this pope will be remembered, studied and argued about for as long as the Catholic Church endures.\u201d\n\nWhat immediately follows is an adroit, perceptive, gripping account of Catholic controversializing. Douthat sets out the liberal and conservative \u201cmaster narratives\u201d about the Second Vatican Council and then offers a third narrative that deftly blends the two. He sketches the life and times of the future pope, Jorge Mario Bergoglio, the Argentine Jesuit archbishop of Buenos Aires. There\u2019s commentary on past controversies and a brief history of Catholic teaching on marriage, from Matthew 19 (\u201cWhat God has joined, let not man put asunder\u201d) to Humanae Vitae, the 1968 encyclical in which Pope Paul VI upheld the ban on artificial birth control.\n\nIt\u2019s strong stuff, conversationally lively and expressive. Apt on-the-spot paraphrase abounds: \u201cIn his famous in-flight news conference coming back from Rio\u201d Francis \u201cseemed to indicate an interest in the remarriage issue, offering a positive-seeming mention of Eastern Orthodoxy\u2019s practice on divorce. \u2026 But the furor over gay priests and `Who am I to judge?\u2019 overshadowed these remarks.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd then, as Douthat reaches what he sees as the heart of the matter \u2014 the Vatican synods on marriage and the family in 2014 and 2015 \u2014 his culture-warrior tendencies stir fully to life. He casts the synods as a battle: warring factions, attacks and frontal assaults, purges and collaborators. Francis\u2019 openness to the German cardinal Walter Kasper\u2019s proposal to relax the ban on divorced-and-remarried people in Germany receiving Communion at Mass is framed as a liberal pope\u2019s \u201ccrusade to change the church.\u201d Although Francis has invited free discussion more than any previous pope, his efforts to shape the synod\u2019s outcome (he is the pope, after all) are seen as \u201cstage-managing\u201d and \u201cdeck-stacking.\u201d The synod fathers\u2019 disputes are rolled down the slippery slope and deemed a \u201cfull-scale theological crisis\u201d in which the hope that Francis would foster unity and renewal is undone by the supposed liberals\u2019 supposed desire to accommodate \u201cthe sexual revolution and all its works.\u201d\n\nDouthat\u2019s own position is traditionalist-cum-literalist: Any relaxing of the Catholic teaching on marriage \u2014 one man, one woman, one time \u2014 means that core teachings can be changed; if core teachings can be changed, the Catholic Church is no longer the Catholic Church; and if the church is not the church, all hope is lost. From this fixed position, he slyly derides other positions, especially the liberal outlook.\n\nAs a first draft of history, \u201cTo Change the Church\u201d is a high-wire act, an effort to maintain a balance between theology and polemics for a wide public. And yet the air is thin up there, the wire narrow and tight. From above, Douthat, seeing every act as a tactical move in the culture wars, pushing every hypothesis to its limit, ignores human experience. Left out is the prospect that Francis called a synod about marriage and family not because he wanted to fly the flag of the sexual revolution but because marriage and family are where so many people in our time encounter the paradoxes of body and soul, self-fulfillment and self-sacrifice. Left out is the fact that Catholics don\u2019t skirt the church\u2019s teaching on marriage just to make things easier for themselves; they say, \u201cBy what right do those child-abuse-indulging clerics tell me that my marriage is adulterous while twice-divorced, thrice-married Newt Gingrich is now a Catholic in good standing, living in Rome as the spouse of his ex-aide/girlfriend who is the United States ambassador to the Vatican?\u201d Left out are the signs that the traditionalists don\u2019t want to tamp down divorce so much as bar the door to same-sex marriage. Left out is the truth that sexual behavior is more fluid than the culture-war schema allows: that there are conservative libertines as well as liberals who live marriage faithfully (even chastely). Left out are people like Gabby, who live off the grid of the culture wars \u2014 as does Douthat himself, a conservative whom liberal institutions have educated, sponsored and let thrive.\n\nLeft out, especially, is the home truth that the Catholic Church has changed already. Vatican II was at once the church\u2019s response to a crisis and the perpetuation of it. In less than five years the council fathers made changes whose number and scale dwarf the modest proposals floated in Francis\u2019 pontificate \u2014 made them over the objections of Bill Buckley and other pundits who styled themselves as more Catholic than the pope. The biggest change had to do with the church\u2019s relationship to Judaism, other churches and other religions. In a few strokes, Jesus\u2019 hard saying \u201cNo one comes to the Father except through me\u201d and its Catholic expression (\u201cOutside the church there is no salvation\u201d) were softened and qualified. The change was profound and tradition-defying. Ever since, the church has affirmed the integrity of other faiths; ever since, Catholics have had to ask themselves, \u201cWhy be Catholic, when other ways are O.K., too?\u201d Ever since, there has been no one clear answer.\n\nThis is not to say that people entering into Catholic marriage shouldn\u2019t fully grasp the church\u2019s understanding of the sacrament and its obligations. It is to say that the view of marriage as a marker in a culture war \u2014 a doctrinal asymptote, a line that may be approached but not crossed \u2014 is itself a greatly diminished view of marriage. Fidelity is going into new forms; like it or not, Catholics, right up to the pope, have to work out the implications as we go. The slope is slippery now and forevermore. Truly, it has been all along.", "title": "A Conservative Catholic Begs the Pope: Lead Us Not Into Temptation", "authors": ["Paul Elie", "Ross Douthat"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump has sometimes seemed to view military action as a game and foreign policy as something set by online taunts. He seemed to think that as commander in chief he could simply follow his whims.\n\nSo it was reassuring that his military response to a suspected chemical attack that killed dozens of people in the rebel-held Damascus suburb of Douma on April 7 was coordinated with Britain and France. In his address to the nation Friday night, he said that preventing the use of chemical weapons was in the \u201cvital national security interest of the United States.\u201d\n\nEarlier this week we got his usual bluster. \u201cGet ready Russia, because they will be coming, nice and new and \u2018smart,\u2019\u201d the president said on Twitter on Wednesday, in his best movie tough-guy impersonation, after a Russian diplomat warned that his nation\u2019s forces would shoot down any missile fired at their ally Syria. On Friday night his message to the Syrian regime\u2019s two main defenders, Russia and Iran, was more measured. \u201cWhat kind of a nation wants to be associated with the mass murder of innocent men, women and children?\u201d he asked. \u201cThe nations of the world can be judged by the friends they keep.\u201d\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis said that while this was a \u201cone-off\u201d attack, like the airstrike against Syria a year ago, the targets were involved in the production and storage of chemical agents, not just an airfield. He warned of further attacks if Syria used chemical weapons again.", "title": "Opinion | A Coordinated Attack on Syria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Sometimes you want a martini. And sometimes you want something like a martini, but are not sure exactly what.\n\nThat second, uncertain feeling appears to be benefiting an old cocktail. The Alaska is a gin drink, like the martini, but instead of dry vermouth, it calls for yellow Chartreuse, the intensely herbal French liqueur, and sometimes orange bitters. Over the last year or so, it has shown up on bar menus in San Francisco, Chicago, Minneapolis, Houston, Boston and New York.\n\nEach bar has found its own path to the drink. Thomas Waugh knew he wanted a martini-oriented cocktail list at the Bar inside the Grill, in the Seagram Building in Manhattan.\n\n\u201cI feel like, when you\u2019re putting a menu together, there\u2019s not a lot in the way of martini variations,\u201d said Mr. Waugh, the director of bar operations. \u201cA lot of people look to the Alaska as one of the more approachable variations. It\u2019s just obscure enough, but not too obscure.\u201d", "title": "A Cousin of the Martini, the Alaska, Strikes Gold", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was cleaning a crystal Tiffany vase one evening and cut my hand on the inside rim.\n\nAfter 30 minutes of trying to stop the bleeding, I managed to wrap enough gauze around the wound to staunch the flow. I was late for an event, so I decided to wait until morning to deal with the suturing that I was sure was going to be necessary.\n\nLater on, I was having a drink with some friends when one of them pointed out that my hand was covered in blood. I grabbed a dozen napkins and ran to the bathroom to clean up as best I could.\n\nWhen I returned, I saw an emergency medical technician. He had stopped at the bar for a late-night burger, and my friends had persuaded him to come to my aid. He gestured for me to go outside to his truck.\n\nHe and his partner asked me what had happened. As they began to clean the wound, I recounted the day\u2019s events.\n\nOne of the two commented on how perfectly neat the cut was.\n\n\u201cWell,\u201d the other said, not missing a beat, \u201che did say the vase was from Tiffany.\u201d", "title": "A Cut With Some Class", "authors": ["David N. Mcilvaney", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "AWAYLAND\n\nStories\n\nBy Ramona Ausubel\n\n240 pp. Riverhead Books. $26.\n\nWhat is a parent anyway? A thick, ever-vanishing fog surrounding a growing child? Old Poseidon out at sea, secretly throwing gifts to his son abandoned onshore? A \u201cprecise oil painting\u201d changing before her daughter\u2019s eyes into a watercolor? These are some of the possibilities presented in Ramona Ausubel\u2019s excellent and peculiar story collection \u201cAwayland.\u201d\n\nHer new book \u2014 her fourth after two novels, including \u201cNo One Is Here Except All of Us,\u201d and a previous collection of stories \u2014 charts ever more steadily her interest in relationships, particularly within a family. These are not normal families, not happy or sad families, but families so cracked and mythologically weird that they are more like interesting old ruins. They are families as written by Hans Christian Andersen with the poetry of Auden, both of whom used fairy-tale imagery to explain our suffering. (\u201cYou shall love your crooked neighbor with your crooked heart,\u201d Auden wrote in 1937, in what could be a mantra for \u201cAwayland.\u201d) In Ausubel\u2019s stories, family life is depicted as treacherous and life-giving, and growing up in one is like passing through beautiful, dangerous woods \u2014 which also abound in this book.\n\nAusubel seems to trust metaphor as much as reality. Whenever the book stumbles upon regular old life it\u2019s a surprise that it\u2019s still there, plugging away. In \u201cFresh Water From the Sea,\u201d a daughter looks out over the Mediterranean and thinks of \u201cthe mythic voyages, the wars. It seemed strange that it was just a place \u2014 dirt and water and wind.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nReading this, you\u2019d be tempted to think the imagination\u2019s work is to make life more beautiful. And isn\u2019t that plenty? But by the time you come to the sixth story, the wonderful \u201cRemedy,\u201d a near novella-length meditation on mortality, it\u2019s clear that Ausubel\u2019s imagination wants to do much rougher, harder work: It wants to offer consolation for how ghastly things can get, a type of healing that only reading can provide.", "title": "A Cyclops With a Dating Profile and Other Fanciful Characters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Let\u2019s talk about the differences between a frittata and an omelet, but not dwell on them. And let\u2019s praise burrata, that cream-filled Italian cheese, but not get hung up on it.\n\nMany people consider the savory Italian frittata to be a flat omelet. But who\u2019s to say omelets can\u2019t be flat, as they often are in the South of France? And why should the classic filled and folded French omelet have a reason to claim or disclaim any relationship to the frittata, other than the fact that both are made from beaten eggs?\n\nFor our purposes, let\u2019s say a frittata is a mixture of whisked eggs cooked in a frying pan. It can be thick or thin, flipped and cooked entirely in the pan, finished in the oven or under the broiler, or prepared in a baking dish. (It can also be depressingly dry and overcooked, but that\u2019s not our goal here.) A frittata is a perfect light lunch or supper accompanied by a rather large mixed-green salad \u2014 an easy standby when you don\u2019t feel like cooking.", "title": "A Deluxe Asparagus Frittata, Topped With Burrata", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "You either love it, or you don\u2019t. But honestly, it\u2019s pretty easy to love bagna cauda.\n\nTraditionally served warm and used as a dip for raw vegetables, bagna cauda is a classic Italian sauce that features, unabashedly, a fair amount of anchovy and garlic.\n\nMaking bagna cauda couldn\u2019t be simpler. Mash some anchovy fillets (the better the anchovy, the better the sauce) with a few cloves of garlic, and simmer the result in olive oil for a few minutes. This tames the garlic somewhat and dissolves the anchovy. You can stop right there, but it tastes better with a little lemon juice or vinegar. Some cooks add butter; some add cream. There are versions with walnut oil. If you happen to be in northern Italy in the winter, you may come across bagna cauda laced with truffles. My version calls for cr\u00e8me fra\u00eeche.", "title": "A Dressing (or Dip) That\u2019s Easy to Love", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Scrambling for ways to contain America\u2019s out-of-control opioid crisis, some experts in the field are convinced that one bit of good advice is to just say no to the enduring \u201cjust say no\u201d antidrug message. Addiction, they say, is not a question of free will or a correctable character flaw, as a lot of people would like to believe. Rather, it is an affliction of the brain that needs to be treated as one would any chronic illness.\n\nOne possible approach, an experimental vaccine, draws attention in this offering from Retro Report, a series of short video documentaries exploring major news stories of the past and their lasting impact. This vaccine would be intended principally for men and women already hooked on heroin or related opioids like Oxycodone and fentanyl \u2014 people who would be at risk of death should they detoxify and then relapse, as all too many do.\n\nIf it works, the vaccine would stop opioids by effectively blocking them from reaching the brain by way of the circulatory system. At the same time, it would not interfere with other treatments for addicts, like methadone and buprenorphine, or with a compound like naloxone that reverses overdoses.\n\nThe vaccine is designed to create high levels of antibodies, said Dr. Gary Matyas, an immunologist who has been developing it at the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research, in Silver Springs, Md. \u201cYou inject heroin, the antibodies basically grab all the heroin, bind it all up, and the heroin can\u2019t cross the blood-brain barrier,\u201d he told Retro Report. \u201cAnd so there\u2019s no high.\u201d Presumably, in time, the heroin would be expelled from the body like any waste product.", "title": "A Drug to End Addiction? Scientists Are Working on It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCENSUS\n\nBy Jesse Ball\n\n272 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $25.99.\n\nJesse Ball is one of our most prolific experimentalists. His last few novels, starting with the excellent \u201cSilence Once Begun,\u201d demonstrate a mature style that feels less like an experiment than a means to communicate deep emotional truths without the clutter of too many narrative conventions.\n\n\u201cCensus,\u201d Ball\u2019s eighth and latest novel, may be his most emotionally affecting book to date. It is also his most transparent. In a candid preface, Ball explains that he wrote \u201cCensus\u201d in memory of his brother, Abram Ball, who had Down syndrome. Ball sets out to write a book that captures \u201cwhat it is like to know and love a Down syndrome boy or girl.\u201d\n\nIn \u201cCensus,\u201d a father and son journey across a nameless, dystopian land. The father, a recent widower and retired doctor, has just received news that he is dying. Both he and his wife had always meant to travel, but because their son was born with Down syndrome, they talked themselves out of it. The cruelty of others kept them from the road: \u201cEver since he was born, our lives, my wife\u2019s, mine, bent around him like a shield.\u201d Now, with his wife passed on, his son grown and his own end very near, he devises a plan to become a census taker, which will take him and his adult son on a cross-country road trip.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe census itself is part of the novel\u2019s central mystery. It is both a survey of the population and an existential measurement. The father explains, \u201cI must, in speaking to a person, know what is special about that individual, and that data must pass through me \u2026 in such a way that what is \u2026 most special about the nation \u2026 could be known and felt.\u201d He asks participants to tell their own unique stories, after which they are marked \u2014 tattooed \u2014 on a rib, proof that they have been tallied. While the census may sound like an Orwellian device, Ball is more concerned with his characters\u2019 emotional lives than with authoritarian foreboding. The father and son move from region to region, entering strangers\u2019 homes, administering the census. With each new encounter a story from the narrator\u2019s life is revealed. The best of these recall him falling in love with his wife, a renowned clown and performance artist who is also one of the novel\u2019s most dynamic characters. In one lovely scene, prompted by his encounter with two eccentric sisters who conjure the Beales of \u201cGrey Gardens,\u201d the narrator remembers a performance in which giant pieces of silverware, a knife and fork, hovered overhead as his wife and other clowns evaded them. In a novel that ruminates so heavily on death, such memories provide a celebratory sense of joy.\n\nWhile Ball accomplishes the stated goal of his preface, bringing the son with Down syndrome to life, the census itself leaves a little to be desired. If the narrator aims to hear each citizen\u2019s story, that which is \u201cmost particular, most special,\u201d he never shares enough details to make a lasting impression. This creates a kind of flatline with regard to the central conceit. Without more of the particulars, \u201cthe small, the overlooked,\u201d it\u2019s hard to understand what the census is meant to measure.\n\nYet the spare and episodic encounters do take us to some tender places. In one scene, a mother who raised a girl with Down syndrome recognizes the narrator as someone who sees what she sees in their children: \u201cThey experience the world just as we do, maybe even in a clearer light.\u201d More than a dystopian tale, \u201cCensus\u201d is a profound and stirring meditation on love, loss and paternity.", "title": "A Dying Father, His Son and One Last Road Trip", "authors": ["Alex Gilvarry", "Jesse Ball"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhat Trump Is Learning From Singapore \u2014 and Vice Versa (Opinion, March 29):\n\nKirsten Han\u2019s article paints Singapore as an authoritarian paradise, where critics of the government are squelched and drug traffickers are hanged.\n\nHowever, more than 60 international media organizations are accredited in Singapore, and we debate issues vigorously, online and off.\n\nThe New York Times, including Ms. Han\u2019s article, is available in print and online, as are all other online sites, except a few pornographic, jihadist and gambling ones.\n\nSingapore, like many other countries, is trying to deal with the spread of falsehoods online, which can undermine democracy and social cohesion. As a multiethnic, multireligious society, we cannot give bigotry free rein.", "title": "Opinion | A False Portrait of Singapore", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "As our open-sided Land Cruiser rolled through the reserve, I was impressed by how varied the landscape was. Because of all the rivers and lakes, wide swaths of the Selous are impenetrable \u2014 picture green, overgrown, scratchy and thorny bush. I can only imagine how grueling and tortuous it was for the first batch of explorers, like Frederick Selous, the Victorian hunter and collector whom the reserve was named after, to hack their way through this place. But the Selous also contains wide-open areas, with wavy yellow grass and, in the distance, jagged brown hills; in between are cool forests.\n\nThat afternoon we found ourselves in a cool forest. A light rain fell, more like a mist. It softly brushed our skin, tiny droplets sticking to the hairs on our arms. Our falcon-eyed guide, Zacharia, had found some lion spoor near the road and he was tracking it deeper and deeper into the forest. \u201cThere!\u201d he finally said, and we all followed where his finger was pointing. Just up ahead a lioness and her three cubs wrestled on a log. We drove even closer and Zacharia cut the engine. We rolled to a stop just a few feet away. Oblivious to us, the lions pawed each other\u2019s heads, pushed each other off the slippery log, tumbled down and hit the muddy ground and sprang back up, training for the rigors of hunts to come. It was as if they were playing king of the mountain but there was clearly a point to it.\n\nWhat made our experience even sweeter was that we were by ourselves. So many times when you\u2019re on safari and spot lions in action, the drivers get on the radio and next thing you know, several other trucks come chugging in, tourists popping out the sunroofs of their trucks, snapping photos like crazy. Here, we were the only car for miles.\n\nThat\u2019s the magic of this place. It\u2019s all yours. My friend Rob Ross spent four years photographing it for a lavish photo book, \u201cThe Selous in Africa: A Long Way From Anywhere.\u201d (Some of Ross\u2019s shots illustrate this story.) He slogged through mucky water, got chewed up by tsetse flies, waited in the intense heat for sleepy wild dogs to wake up and go on a hunt (and sometimes they didn\u2019t feel like it), and he still considers those four years the most rewarding of his life.\n\nWhere else, he asks, can you \u201cactually feel like you might have been the first person to stand where you\u2019re standing for 10 or a hundred or a thousand years?\u201d\n\nI guess the dominant feeling I had in the Selous was being free. Lake Manze Camp made that feeling even deeper. We didn\u2019t have to keep anyone else\u2019s schedule. Shaun gave us a four-wheel drive truck and assigned us a driver and a guide. We could get up when we wanted and drive (or boat) around when we wanted and have our meals in the bush, if we wanted.\n\nEvery part of the reserve we visited brought the same joys: few cars, zero garbage, trees and plants and wildflowers that couldn\u2019t have looked much healthier, and lots of animals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs Shaun put it on our last evening when we gathered for a final beer by the fire: \u201cThere are now traffic cops in the Kruger.\u201d (He was referring to South Africa\u2019s best known wildlife park, which has paved roads cutting across it and the occasional traffic jam.) \u201cThis,\u201d Shaun said, spreading his arms as wide as possible, \u201cis the real Africa.\u201d\n\nOver the years, in my travels across Africa, I\u2019ve heard that claim many times, in many different places. Who knows what the \u201creal\u201d Africa is. So many of us outsiders seem to be on a search for the Africa we imagined. And for the Africans who live in this part of the world, what we romanticize is simply their home.\n\nBut that said, there is something undeniably special, and moving, about these last undisturbed places. And standing outside in the dying twilight, surrounded by miles of bush, in the middle of one of the last great untouched spaces left on the continent, I knew exactly what Shaun meant.", "title": "A Family Adventure in the Wild Heart of Tanzania", "authors": ["Jeffrey Gettleman"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMinna Kao\u2019s work as a fashion designer has led her to the kitchen. She designs and sells aprons and uniforms to restaurants, and makes some of her aprons to be used at home. Her products are made with sustainable fabrics and without toxic dyes. The simple, adjustable, unisex designs have handy pockets. Aprons, $78 to $114, boworkwear.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Fashion Designer Looks to the Kitchen", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cOne Good Meal,\u201d we ask cooking-inclined creative people, who aren't professional chefs, to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis \u2014 and not just when they\u2019re trying to impress.\n\nIt all started with a trip to Puglia. This was maybe a decade ago, and Rosie Assoulin didn\u2019t go herself. But her in-laws did, and they came back raving about a meal they\u2019d eaten: a whole white fish, baked and served over crispy vegetables. So simple, so Italian. Assoulin, 32, and her husband Max decided they\u2019d try to replicate the dish through a process of experimentation \u2014 and they quickly found it to be \u201cone of those home-cooked recipes where you just kind of wing it and it\u2019s always different every time.\u201d Branzino makes an ideal fish, they discovered, though snapper and bass work too. Cauliflower is nice as one of the vegetables. Eggplant, if they have it. The constant: They always put herbs (thyme, rosemary) and lemon into the fish\u2019s cavity \u2014 \u201csometimes we\u2019ll put lavender in if we\u2019re feeling a little fancy\u201d \u2014 before baking it in a cast-iron tray, the kind you might use to cook paella. They bring that pan to the table and eat straight out of it.", "title": "A Fashion Designer\u2019s Simple Mediterranean Fish Dish", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "But here at the crossroads of Highway 335 and Highway 35, where there was a constant churn of visitors, the conversation often turned to speculation about what happened.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany people said they assumed that the truck driver passed through Highway 35\u2019s stop sign before being hit by the bus. Others suggest that the truck driver, who had only recently completed his training, may have encountered a problem when turning his vehicle left onto Highway 35 and was struck because of a moment\u2019s inattention by the bus driver.\n\nBut no one knows, and there is no obvious explanation. On Wednesday it claimed another victim: Dayna Brons, the team\u2019s athletic therapist.\n\nThe crash, which also injured 13 people, occurred at about 5 p.m. The skies were clear, and the highway free of snow and ice. For the truck driver, the sun was directly ahead as he headed west on Highway 335. But at that time of day, it is still relatively high in the sky.\n\n\u201cPeople are asking: \u2018Is this a really dangerous intersection?\u2019\u201d said Art Lalonde, a farmer who is the top elected official of this small rural municipality. \u201cWell, it\u2019s not. You can see for miles and it\u2019s absolutely straight.\u201d\n\nAt the spot where Highway 335 crosses over Highway 35, the remains of the truck and bus have been taken away. But the air was pungent with the odor of diesel fuel and churned-up earth covered with peat moss, the truck\u2019s cargo.\n\nA shrine, started with a flower cross left by the police, was slowly growing. Stuffed animals, flowers, cards and crosses made from hockey sticks had accumulated. A truck driver stopped, ran out to leave a solar-powered lamp and burst into tears before running back to his cab.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe intersection, known as Armley Corner, has a notorious past. Six white crosses mark a collision in 1997 that killed six family members. They were in a pickup truck that went through the Highway 335 stop sign and was then hit by a tractor-trailer truck traveling on Highway 35.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe oversize stop signs, warning lights and streetlights on Highway 335 appeared the next year.\n\nLike many rural highways in Saskatchewan, which has a population of 1.1 million, traffic volume is comparatively light. According to the Ministry of Highways and Infrastructure, between 1,100 and 1,320 vehicles travel daily on Highway 35, the road the hockey team took; Highway 335, the truck\u2019s route, has about half that amount of traffic.\n\nWhile fatalities from bus crashes are rare in Canada, collisions involving them are relatively common. According to Transport Canada, a federal department, between 2010 and 2015, the most recently available dates, buses were involved in 4,026 collisions, with 574 passengers injured. But during that period, only one passenger died.\n\nThe players traveling on the bus ranged in age from 16 to 21. Most had left their families elsewhere in Western Canada and come to live with families in Humboldt to advance their hockey careers.\n\nFor them and other members of junior hockey teams across the country, buses become almost as much a part of their lives as ice rinks. While team bus travel is not unique to hockey, as a winter sport it often means taking to the road in potentially dangerous weather.\n\nThe routes plied by junior teams like the Broncos often follow secondary highways linking remote communities. The Broncos were going northeast from Humboldt, population 4,800, to a playoff match against their archrivals in Nipawin, population 4,000.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFor me, it was 21 years on a bus.\u201d said Dean Brockman, a former head coach of the Broncos \u201cWhen you live on a bus, 85 percent of the time you feel like it\u2019s safe. Fifteen percent of the time, it\u2019s either bad weather, late at night or whatever and you talk to the driver all the way home.\u201d\n\nThe Broncos\u2019 bus was owned by Charlie\u2019s Charters. The company, which did not respond to requests for comment, works with six other teams, including the Nipawin Hawks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the wheel was Glen Doerksen, a 59-year-old from Carrot River, a town just off Highway 335. It would be his last trip. He died in the collision, which obliterated the front of the bus.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address.
