Ms. Fermino said the museum is asking the Council for $2.25 million.\n\nMr. Johnson called \u201cDay\u2019s End\u201d an \u201cexciting, great project for a great New York artist\u201d and said there was no connection between the loan of the artwork and the request for financing. \u201cI didn\u2019t make any connection between the two things.\u201d\n\nMr. Soba said the museum often lends artwork for display in elected leaders\u2019 offices and that the installation in Mr. Johnson\u2019s office was \u201ccompletely unrelated\u201d to the financing request. The museum requested a total of $5 million in capital financing for the project \u2014 $2.25 million each from the Council and the Department of Cultural Affairs and $500,000 from the Manhattan borough president\u2019s office, Mr. Soba said. \u201cThe overwhelming majority of the funding is being privately raised by the Whitney,\u201d he said.", "title": "A Modern Touch at City Hall With Help From a Museum Seeking Money", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was on an uptown No. 1 train on a frigid night. I was reading a collection of poems by Philip Levine.\n\nA middle-age man in a purple wool sweater plopped down next to me and opened a book. A young man wearing a camouflage-print jacket and bluejeans who was sitting across the car took notice. He leaned forward toward the man in the purple sweater.\n\n\u201cExcuse me,\u201d the young man said. \u201cCan I ask you about your book?\u201d\n\n\u201cHere,\u201d the man in the purple sweater said, handing it over. \u201cYou can actually read it. I don\u2019t know what stop you\u2019re getting off at, but I can read something else.\u201d\n\nThe man in the purple sweater pulled another book out of his briefcase. This one was appeared to be in Hebrew.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe younger man quickly became absorbed in his borrowed pages. I looked at the book\u2019s title: \u201cOn Becoming a Person.\u201d\n\nI returned to my own reading.\n\nThe train was silent otherwise. The quiet was only interrupted by a voice coming over the speaker to tell us about yet another delay.", "title": "A Mostly Quiet Car", "authors": ["Helen Ouyang", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Wood-roasted rabbit sliders. Chesapeake Bay oysters. Osetra caviar. This is not your typical bar food.\n\nBlack Rabbit, which opened in November in downtown Nashville, is the latest brainchild of the local chef Trey Cioccia. He and his business partner Robert Compton fell in love with an 1890s brick building near Printers Alley, the hub that buzzed with night life many decades ago. They wanted to recreate that early-20th-century ambience by featuring handcrafted cocktails, small plates to share and live music. While a visit may feel like stepping back in time, the food and drinks are some of the most innovative in Music City today.\n\n\u201cBack then, Printer\u2019s Alley was the place,\u201d said Mr. Cioccia of the one-block-long street. He wanted the bar \u201cto be a cool little social place for adults where you can have a conversation, do business, maybe play a game in front of the fire.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s notable \u2014 other than the fantastic cocktails, original brick walls and wood floors \u2014 is the quality of the food. Mr. Cioccia made a name for himself nearby at the Farm House restaurant, where he specializes in Southern fare, working closely with local farmers and ranchers to procure the best ingredients.", "title": "A Nashville Spot Serving Bar Food That Is Anything but Standard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Anton is also a prolific essayist who flavors his writing with references to Gibbon and Montesquieu. He is most famous for a polemical article he published in September 2016 in the Claremont Review of Books, \u201cThe Flight 93 Election,\u201d which became an unlikely, highbrow manifesto for Mr. Trump\u2019s election.\n\n\u201cCharge the cockpit or you die,\u201d he wrote, this time under the pseudonym Publius Decius Mus. \u201cA Hillary Clinton presidency is Russian roulette with a semi-auto. With Trump, at least you can spin the cylinders and take your chances.\u201d\n\nHis argument for a Trumpian assault on the nation\u2019s elites, conservative and liberal alike, was a sensation on the right. When Mr. Trump\u2019s aides recruited him to be director of strategic communications for the National Security Council, Vanity Fair and The Weekly Standard portrayed him as an enigmatic figure \u2014 a thinking man\u2019s Beau Brummell among the philistines of Trump world. \u201cThe most interesting man in the White House,\u201d Yahoo News said.\n\nAnd that was without the cooking.\n\nMr. Anton dates his interest in French cuisine to graduate school at St. John\u2019s College in Annapolis, Md., where, he says, he cooked the recipes in Julia Child\u2019s \u201cMastering the Art of French Cooking,\u201d years before Julie in the Nora Ephron film \u201cJulie & Julia.\u201d He worked as a vegetable cutter at a local restaurant, Treaty of Paris, and told his parents he wanted to drop out and go to culinary school (they vetoed that plan).\n\nHe honed his cooking while working in the Bush White House, once losing a half-finished demi-glace sauce \u2014 a three-day project \u2014 when the national security adviser called him from the Situation Room and told him to get to the office immediately. \u201cDown the drain it all had to go,\u201d he wrote in a 2014 essay, \u201cthe wages of divided loyalty.\u201d\n\nLiving in New York during the Obama years, Mr. Anton decided to get serious about cooking. He took classes at the French Culinary Institute (now known as the International Culinary Center) in Lower Manhattan, and worked, unpaid, as a line cook at L\u2019Ecole, a French restaurant that was affiliated with the institute.\n\n\u201cYou got yelled at for screwing up,\u201d he recalled. \u201cBut I liked the fact that they didn\u2019t let you get away with things.\u201d", "title": "A National Security Aide\u2019s Departing Wish: Cooking for the State Dinner", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAn OddFellows Ice Cream outlet with a very particular focus \u2014 coffee and cream \u2014 is opening Wednesday. An assortment of drinks and confections featuring the combination of ice cream and coffee will be dispensed at the counter in the bright corner shop with swimming pool turquoise banquettes, where they will also serve the two elements independently. \u201cI thought it was time to bring them together,\u201d said Sam Mason, who owns OddFellows with Mohan Kumar. Andy Mullins is the coffee geek who figures out which coffees to serve and with what. Espresso with whipped cream (con panna) in flavors like saffron, riffs on affogato, cold-brew milkshakes, artfully layered caf\u00e9 li\u00e9geois, and coffee soft serve are on the menu. Du\u2019s Donuts provide something to nibble: Coffee & Cream by OddFellows Ice Cream Co., 55 East Houston Street (Mott Street), oddfellowsnyc.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Natural Combo: Ice Cream and Coffee", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "The explanation was obvious: racism, and the continuous price African-Americans pay for it, from generation to generation.\n\nFor this black parent, those stories are the stuff of nightmares. From the moment I saw the double lines on my pregnancy test, I dreamed of a world in which my children win \u2014 where they slay their A.P. courses, go to great colleges like Yale or Spelman and enjoy lucrative careers.\n\nI assumed that by the time my two daughters and stepson were of age, society would have moved on from the institutional barriers that lurk in the shadows like some boogeyman, ready to jump out and thwart the forward movement of black folk.\n\nI was hopeful that by then black students would be accepted into A.P. classes without a fight; employers would no longer be tossing out r\u00e9sum\u00e9s with \u201cblack sounding\u201d names; black women would get the same pay for the same work as white men; and black families could live in the neighborhoods of their choosing and get mortgage rates based on their credit and not on the color of their skin. Surely my children would be better off than me.\n\nBut here we are, in 2018, the same old shotgun threatening to buck down my children\u2019s chances at a better life, despite my efforts to play by America\u2019s rules. I have been a hands-on parent. I have pushed my kids academically. I have pushed myself, just like Daddy, to make sure that they have what they need and even some of the things they want so they could focus on being great.\n\nStill, statistics say they have a high chance of failing. And I am scared for them.\n\nAfrican-American parents can\u2019t stop demanding equality, but perhaps we need to start dreaming of a different kind of success: a hybrid of the life my father led as a child (while appallingly unjust, segregation made the black community self-reliant, assuring that African-Americans traded in goods and services among themselves) mixed with the expectations he had for me (success in corporate America). Maybe the challenge we should pass along to black children now is to never be afraid of avoiding the shackles of corporate America and creating their own businesses \u2014 businesses that also serve our community.\n\nAnd maybe it\u2019s time for us to redefine success altogether. Doing \u201cbetter than me\u201d could be about our babies growing up to be healthier, happier and more passionate about the things that matter to them \u2014 hard workers, yes, with the cash they need, sure, but also pioneers of a new paradigm that lets go of the all-too-elusive American dream.\n\nIn all things, let there be joy. This, for my children, young, black and gifted, I wish with no fear.", "title": "Opinion | A New Black American Dream", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA start-up is taking on Equifax\u2019s employee verification service, and it now has a bit of a war chest too.\n\nThe new company, Truework, will try to compete with an Equifax service known as The Work Number, which helps employers handle all of the irritating notices they receive from banks and other entities that want to verify a person\u2019s employment history and salary. The gears of consumer credit can\u2019t function well without this process, but it\u2019s a pain for employers and, as a result, a lucrative business for Equifax.\n\nMost employees do not know that their employer hands over sensitive information to Equifax and similar services each pay period, even though workers have agreed to some kind of employment check somewhere along the way. And Equifax does not notify those workers each time it gives information to a bank or a potential landlord.\n\nTruework aims to change that, promising that employees will receive a message at their work email address each time an entity seeks information about them. The recipients would click to see what information their employers plan to share and can approve the handoff.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese things were built for lenders, which is fine,\u201d said Ryan Sandler, a Truework co-founder who previously worked at LinkedIn. \u201cBut they left employers and employees as the second and third priority. We wanted to flip the model on its head.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEmployers pay to use these services, as do banks and others that grant credit. Mr. Sandler said that his company intends to charge banks at least one-third less than Equifax does. This week, it announced that it had raised $2.9 million from several investors to help the effort.", "title": "A New Challenger to Equifax\u2019s Employee Verification Service", "authors": ["Ron Lieber"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s been 60 years since anyone other than a Castro was at the head of the Cuban state, so the installation of Miguel D\u00edaz-Canel Berm\u00fadez as president in Havana this week does rank as a symbolic moment. But not much more, at least for the moment.\n\nR\u00e1ul Castro, who handpicked this loyal apparatchik as his successor, remains at the helm of the Communist Party and the armed forces; his son runs the intelligence services; his ex-son-in-law runs the military\u2019s vast business interests. In his first speech, Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel vowed there would be no \u201ccapitalist restoration\u201d and concluded with a slogan that has not roused the masses for some time now: \u201cSocialism or death! We will triumph!\u201d\n\nYet the history of Communist regimes suggests that once the revolutionary old guard passes on, change is possible. R\u00e1ul Castro, the late Fidel Castro\u2019s younger brother, is 86, and there is no certainty that his kith and kin can carry the torch once he\u2019s gone, especially since the flame is flickering.\n\nIn his 10 years as president, R\u00e1ul Castro opened the economy a crack to private investment and private enterprise, but without lifting the state\u2019s firm and onerous centralized control. The Soviet Union was no longer around to prop up the economy, and Venezuela, which for a time filled the void, descended into its own economic hell. And President Barack Obama\u2019s opening to Cuba has been partly reversed by President Trump. The result, according to a study by Richard Feinberg of the Brookings Institution, is a \u201cpersistent stagnation\u201d that has left Cuba further and further behind the world on most fronts.", "title": "Opinion | A New Cuba After the Castros? Not Quite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "With public housing racially isolated, other policies \u2014 some misguided but well intentioned, others indefensible \u2014 exacerbated the dysfunction. Austen notes that long waiting lists for relatively few units left poor applicants without other options for safe lodging. Compassionate officials addressed the predicament by lowering the income cutoff to qualify for public housing. The Chicago Housing Authority then made space for the poor by evicting working-class families for whom the projects were initially designed. The authority\u2019s executive director told them, \u201cBe proud to move out, so that a lower-income family can have the advantage that you have had.\u201d Public housing\u2019s opponents also demanded the evictions, insisting that those able to afford private accommodations should be barred from public support.\n\nAs Austen observes, the policy created a disincentive to marry, because a husband\u2019s wages might render a family ineligible to remain in its home. The result was the segregation of projects by race and by income, concentrating fatherless young men who not only had little access to legitimate employment but lacked working-class role models who knew how to search for it. In the early 1950s, the median income of Chicago\u2019s public housing residents was nearly two-thirds of the citywide average. By 1970, it was barely one-third.\n\nInitially, Cabrini-Green hired residents as maintenance workers. But perversely, when income cutoffs were lowered, holding such jobs made tenants ineligible to remain. With residents themselves no longer responsible for maintenance, projects deteriorated. And with projects now filled with the politically powerless, and with revenue from rent payments falling, government slashed maintenance budgets and turned high rises into slums. In 1977, Cabrini-Green had 19 maintenance workers; two years later, there were six. Nearly half its units were unoccupied because of insufficient staff. Yet for most who remained in the projects, conditions were still superior to those in the overcrowded dwellings from which they had come.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMeanwhile, industry departed the Cabrini-Green neighborhood, leaving young men with few lawful ways to earn a living. The efforts of public officials to provide job training and transportation that might have mitigated their plights were minimal and episodic.\n\nAusten supplements his account of these policy failures with interviews with former Cabrini-Green residents. They are mostly community leaders, but their stories can\u2019t skirt the drug dealing, gang wars and homicides that dominated Cabrini-Green\u2019s public image. The police response ranged from rare attempts at community monitoring (difficult, at best, when officers had to roam 19 stories) to unprovoked brutality and even torture \u2014 a reflection of law enforcement\u2019s general contempt for the civil rights of law-abiding residents, as well as a fundamental lack of concern for their safety. Chicago\u2019s police superintendent acknowledged that his officers walked a \u201cvery fine line between maintaining order and becoming oppressive.\u201d\n\n\u201cHigh-Risers\u201d concludes by recounting the resolve of Chicago elites, in the last decade or so, to reclaim the Cabrini-Green property, so close to downtown, for condo owners and their upscale services. Gentrification was only slightly hindered by the residents\u2019 reluctance to vacate their apartments, out of the well-founded fear that the alternatives might be no better. The project\u2019s reputation as a violent wasteland made this resistance easy for civic leaders to overcome.\n\nThe last of Cabrini-Green\u2019s 15 towers was demolished in 2011. In their place, Chicago subsidized middle-class residences, with a promise that 40 percent of units would be reserved as public housing for the project\u2019s former occupants. But that pledge was abandoned, as was one to relocate tenants to decent housing elsewhere. Most of the African-Americans who called Cabrini-Green home are now in less adequate (and frequently just as dangerous) homes in new, still segregated neighborhoods.\n\nThe alternatives Paul Douglas faced \u2014 either segregated housing or none at all \u2014 were not the only possibilities. We as a society could have dispersed low-income families across less dense public projects throughout metropolitan areas. We could have preserved diversity of income and race; many working-class white families, especially returning war veterans, needed apartments in the 1950s and would have preferred heterogenous housing developments to living with their in-laws. Many employed white veterans did initially live in public housing, only to abandon it for single-family homes in racially restricted suburbs, thanks to attractive federal mortgage terms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an otherwise nuanced book, Austen labels the social workers and officials who vowed to clear slums and house the poor as \u201cdo-gooders.\u201d Implicit in his scorn is a hindsight appreciation that, for the poor to thrive, their communities must include working- and even middle-class families. The urbanist Jane Jacobs knew as much, but her \u201cThe Death and Life of Great American Cities\u201d was published in 1961, after evictions of working-class public housing residents were already well underway. Until the sociologist William Julius Wilson published \u201cThe Truly Disadvantaged,\u201d in 1987, few comprehended the terrible consequences of cleansing urban neighborhoods of the stably employed. In 2018, Ben Austen has illustrated these repercussions; we can now better consider remedies by contemplating the lessons \u201cHigh-Risers\u201d offers.", "title": "A New Look at the New Deal\u2019s Legacy of Public Housing", "authors": ["Richard Rothstein", "Ben Austen"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Then \u2014 whoops! \u2014 Romney, who\u2019s spent more than $500,000 so far on his campaign, lost the vote at last weekend\u2019s Republican convention to a state representative who\u2019d spent around $30,000.\n\nMaybe they still regard Mitt as an outsider. (The winner, a physician named Mike Kennedy, declined in a phone interview to say exactly how he and Romney differed on policy: \u201cI\u2019ve not spent a lot of time studying his record as Massachusetts governor.\u201d)\n\nA more likely answer is that the delegates resented Romney for collecting signatures to qualify for a primary in case the convention thing didn\u2019t work out. The good news here, people, is that you don\u2019t need to educate yourself about this matter. You have a lot of things on your mind, and the inside politics of Utah ballot access does not have to be one of them.\n\nVirtually everybody expects Romney to win the primary in June. And the actual election shouldn\u2019t be a problem in a deeply red state. But what then? Will we get a new principled Republican opposition, or just another guy waiting for his chance to be interviewed on CNN about the glories of tax cuts?\n\nOne hint: When he announced his candidacy, Romney praised Utah, which he said \u201cwelcomes legal immigrants from around the world,\u201d while the Trump administration \u201csends immigrants a message of exclusion.\u201d But when it was time to woo those conservative convention delegates the pitch, um, changed. \u201cI\u2019m also more of a hawk on immigration than even the president,\u201d Romney announced. \u201cMy view was these DACA kids shouldn\u2019t all be allowed to stay in the country legally.\u201d\n\nHe was speaking, of course, about the Obama-era program protecting people who were brought into the country illegally as children. On this issue our current president has held about every position known to mankind. Romney, meanwhile, is moving up on seven-eighths.\n\nAfter his remarks, the campaign explained that Romney believes the DACA immigrants should be allowed to stay. The difference between him and Trump was that Romney doesn\u2019t want to give them a special path to citizenship. While Trump did \u2014 that one day a couple of months ago.\n\nWe need that principled national voice, not just a guy who bounces around on issues like a well-coiffed rubber ball. Romney has to do better. Otherwise, we\u2019ll go back to discussing the time he drove to Canada with the family dog strapped to the car roof.", "title": "Opinion | A New Mitt or the Same Old Weenie?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "There are many iterations of paprika. Some of the finest are from Spain, where it\u2019s called piment\u00f3n and comes in degrees of heat and smokiness. Spanish paprika labeled Piment\u00f3n de la Vera, a name that has government protection, is from the La Vera Valley in rural Extremadura in Western Spain, where paprika-making is a centuries-old tradition. Now, that notably vibrant piment\u00f3n from the Gualtaminos Cooperative, a collection of small farmers, is available in the United States for the first time. The ruddy spice to speckle your deviled eggs, enliven potatoes and add pungent intrigue to chicken dishes comes in sweet, semisweet and hot varieties, all with a whiff of smoke: Gualtaminos Piment\u00f3n de la Vera, $3.95 for 2.65 ounces, Lucy\u2019s Whey, 1417 Lexington Avenue (93rd Street), 212-289-8900, lucyswhey.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A New Paprika Import From Spain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "When my chin is down, my eyes are closed and my hands are cupped over my ears, it\u2019s a sure sign that I\u2019m tasting. I know how odd I look, but the momentary calm helps me concentrate on flavors when there\u2019s a new recipe at hand or a complex ingredient. I always taste chocolate this way, and every once in a while I lock myself in my sensory cocoon because I\u2019ve come upon something unusual that I want to get to know better. A couple of months ago in Paris, it was a pastry from a new, strikingly designed patisserie in the Marais, Maison Aleph.\n\nThe morsel was called 1001 Feuilles (feuilles is French for leaves or layers), one layer more than the classic mille-feuille; its name carries a hint of the tales of the Arabian Nights. It was square, about the size of a marker for a board game, and it was, all at once, chewy, buttery, sweet, creamy, a tad chunky, nuttish and precisely balanced. It straddled the territory between baklava and mille-feuille, and it spoke of place, although I couldn\u2019t be certain where. From the patisserie\u2019s name, I expected something Middle Eastern \u2014 aleph is the first letter of both the Hebrew and Arabic alphabets \u2014 and knowing that the pastry was built on phyllo dough should have confirmed its origins. But the filling seemed French, as did the deep flavor of butter. The sweet was neither fully French nor Middle Eastern, neither familiar nor completely new, and it captured my imagination.\n\nWhen I met Myriam Sabet, Maison Aleph\u2019s founder and owner, I learned how closely the traditions of East and West that shape her desserts mirror her own history. Now 41, she was born in Aleppo, Syria, went to college and graduate school in Canada and moved to France almost two decades ago, when, she says, she decided, \u201cI was mature enough for Paris.\u201d In 2014, Sabet, who worked in finance, turned her life upside down to learn about pastry. She studied with an elderly Syrian baker in Montreal, was certified in French pastry at a Paris school and, last July, opened Maison Aleph, a small shop that attracts dessert lovers from around the world. The day I was there with her, I heard French and English and Arabic, Hebrew, Japanese, Spanish and snippets of tongues I couldn\u2019t place at all. Once having hoped for a career in foreign affairs, Sabet looked around the room, laughed and exclaimed, \u201cMaybe that\u2019s exactly what I\u2019m doing now.\u201d\n\nSabet makes about a half-dozen variations of the 1001 Feuilles, each with layers of phyllo sandwiching a nut mixture in the style of baklava. One has hazelnuts from the Piedmont, one almonds from Valencia, another pistachios from Iran. The feuilles that called to me was made with sesame and halvah. As it was for Sabet, halvah was a sweet from my childhood. In Brooklyn, where I grew up, we would get it sliced to order from rounds about the size of snare drums. I knew the rich, pressed sesame-seed confection solely as a candy, but the Maison Aleph recipe for the squares\u2019 filling used it as an ingredient to be smoothed, baked and transformed by heat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was only when I returned home and made the dessert myself that I grasped how complex it truly was, if not in preparation, then in conception: It seamlessly fused two disparate heritages. The filling blends the halvah with tahini, toasted sesame seeds, butter, eggs, sugar and cornstarch, and traces the contours of a classic cr\u00e8me d\u2019amande, the mixture a French p\u00e2tissier would use to fill a traditional fruit tart or a galette des rois.", "title": "A New Pastry Layers Tastes of France and Syria", "authors": ["Dorie Greenspan", "On Dessert"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Activists say the number of closed schools is even higher. Mattiullah Wesa, who leads the organization the Pen Path, said they have counted 1,600 shuttered schools.\n\nOf Afghanistan\u2019s approximately 400 school districts, there are 48 districts where not a single male student has graduated from high school in the past 17 years, Mr. Wesa said. There are around 130 districts from where not a single girl has graduated from high school in the same period, he added.\n\nNearly half of schools lack buildings.\n\nA survey of 32 of the country\u2019s 34 provinces by The New York Times shows close to half the schools lack buildings. Provincial officials in these areas reported that more than 7,000 schools either teach in open air or have worked out temporary arrangements for classes in rental homes.\n\nThe provinces of Ghor and Herat in the west, Badakhshan in the northeast, and Nangarhar in the east had the highest number of schools without buildings, each with at least 400.\n\n\u201cEven inside the city, and the centers of the districts, we have schools that lack buildings,\u201d said Rohullah Mohaqeq, the provincial director of education in Badakhshan.\n\nCorruption hits every level.\n\nDespite huge donor investment in Afghan education, corruption remains one of the major causes for its abysmal infrastructure.\n\nThe country\u2019s education system is marred by corruption \u2014 from the smallest procedures of modifying school certificates, to the appointment of teachers and the handling of school construction contracts \u2014 a damning report by the country\u2019s independent corruption monitor said last year. People seeking a teaching job could pay as much as a $1,000 in bribes, nearly five months\u2019 salary, to secure a position.", "title": "A New Push Is On for Afghan Schools, but the Numbers Are Grim", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Instead, Frenchette has gone off the rails, charting a completely different course. The wine director, Jorge Riera, has put together a list that is entirely, uncompromisingly, focused on natural wines, a controversial genre in which the grapes are farmed organically at the least, and the wine produced with minimal artifice or manipulation.\n\nMany of the 300 bottles or so on the list may indeed be distinctive and excellent, but they are also relentlessly obscure, with characteristics that some people may find surprising, and occasionally even appalling.\n\nRather than lard the list with expensive wines, as so many high-end restaurants do, Frenchette has devoted much of its lineup to the extremely reasonable $50- to $85-a-bottle range. That is still a lot to pay for wine, perhaps, but well below the Manhattan destination-restaurant norm, in which the wine list is often used as a cash cow to subsidize other parts of the operation.\n\nIn short, it\u2019s a challenging list that may annoy some people who want recognizable names, yet is also brilliant. Mr. Riera, the wine director who came to Frenchette from Contra and Wildair, has built a list full of wonderful discoveries, great values and the sort of direct, unmediated experiences that characterize natural wines at their best. Almost all the wines are low in alcohol as well, 13 percent or less, and they go very well with the cuisine.\n\nBut Mr. Riera will have a lot of explaining to do, introducing producers and regions that will largely be unknown to people, no matter how well versed they may be in Burgundy, Barolo or Napa Valley.", "title": "A New Restaurant, Frenchette, Stands Up for Natural Wines", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "DNA has complicated that picture, however. In the last few years, Dr. Hormiga\u2019s lab and others have built detailed family trees by sequencing small sections of spiders\u2019 DNA. In these trees, spiders that have similar genetic markers are deemed more closely related to one another than to spiders whose markers are different. In order to have more points of comparison, the team behind the new paper used a more recently developed approach to compare approximately 2,500 genes.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe resulting spider tree shows a massive network of species whose ancestors began to branch away from each other hundreds of millions of years ago. Over here are the wolf spiders; over there the builders of underground funnel webs, as well as the orb weavers and black widows. Because the researchers could draw on so many more genes and species than in previous studies, they are able to state the relationships among spiders with greater confidence than in the past, Dr. Hormiga said.\n\nTo use the tree to study the evolution of webs built to catch prey, the researchers assigned each species a status: This one made an orb web to hunt, that one made a horizontal web, this one didn\u2019t build a web at all, and so on. Then they asked what the most logical way for those traits to have arisen, looking for the most likely route from ancestors with various different webs to those that spiders build today.\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Hormiga and colleagues say based on this analysis that the ability to make orb webs must have arisen multiple times. On the tree, spiders that make sticky orb webs are all closely related, but the makers of non-sticky orb webs have an ancestor that didn\u2019t use a web for hunting at all. Dr. Hormiga and colleagues write that the hypothesis that the orb web evolved once and was simply passed down \u201ccrumbles\u201d under this evidence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt puts it on very solid ground that the orb web evolved more than once,\u201d Dr. Hormiga said.\n\nNot everyone agrees. Jason Bond, a professor at Auburn University who, with collaborators, has also published genealogies for spiders in recent years, says the tree itself is an admirable, solid piece of work, and rises above earlier efforts.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut he expressed doubts about the researchers\u2019 conclusions. Dr. Bond said that because of the way the researchers categorized the data on web architecture, their analysis creates, among other things, the impression that the use of webs for hunting evolved independently more than 10 times among spiders. He said that seemed implausible, given the complexity of this particular way of spinning a web.\n\n\u201cI would say these authors have climbed pretty far out on to a limb,\u201d he said. \u201cIt will be interesting to see if it holds.\u201d", "title": "A New Spider Family Tree Tries to Untangle the Evolution of Webs", "authors": ["Veronique Greenwood"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Sean Manaea, an Oakland Athletics left-hander, pitched the first no-hitter against the Boston Red Sox in almost exactly 25 years, with an overturned call preserving the gem as the A\u2019s beat the sizzling Red Sox, 3-0, at the Oakland Coliseum on Saturday night.\n\nManaea struck out 10, walked two and threw 108 pitches to finish off Oakland\u2019s first no-hitter since Dallas Braden tossed a perfect game against Tampa Bay in 2010.\n\nManaea got Hanley Ramirez to ground out to complete the first no-hitter versus the Red Sox since Seattle\u2019s Chris Bosio did it April 22, 1993.\n\n\u201cI just telling myself, keep everything the same, and not let anything get too big for me,\u201d Manaea said.", "title": "A No-Hitter by Oakland\u2019s Sean Manaea Tames the Red Sox", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Years ago I was rehearsing a piece for flute, viola and piano by the composer Seymour Barab. Mr. Barab was attending the rehearsal, and the pianist asked him at one point if it was important to \u201cbring out,\u201d or highlight, a certain clever rhythmic pattern. Mr. Barab\u2019s instant reaction was to shout: \u201cNo! It\u2019s none of your business!\u201d\n\nMr. Barab\u2019s position, expressed in his inimitable fashion, was that it was not the performer\u2019s job to try to teach the audience, nor was it the audience\u2019s responsibility to try to pass some sort of test in rhythm recognition. If he, the composer, had done his job well, and had organized and manipulated his musical materials in a compelling fashion, the music would \u201cwork,\u201d and the audience would enjoy it.\n\nIt\u2019s sad but true that many people denigrate and distrust their own reactions to classical music out of fear that they don\u2019t \u201cknow enough,\u201d and that other, more sophisticated folks know more. When people leave the movie theater they rarely hesitate to give their opinion of the movie, and it never occurs to them that they don\u2019t have a right to that opinion. And yet after most classical music concerts you can swing your program around from any spot in the lobby and hit a dozen perfectly capable and intelligent people issuing apologetic disclaimers: \u201cBoy, I really loved that \u2014 but I\u2019m no expert\u201d or \u201cIt sounded pretty awful to me, but I don\u2019t really know anything, so I guess I just didn\u2019t get it.\u201d\n\nAt least those people showed up. Many others are too intimidated to attend classical concerts at all.\n\nIt\u2019s human nature to want to know more, and to try to understand and explain our experiences and reactions. And there\u2019s no denying that the more we know about music, as with cooking or gardening or football, the more levels of enjoyment are available to us, and the better we\u2019re able to recognize great achievement. Do we have to know the Latin names of flowers \u2014 or the English names, for that matter \u2014 to be moved by the beauty of a garden? No. Do we have to know about blocking schemes and \u201cdefensive packages\u201d to be excited when our team scores a touchdown? No. But we find these things \u2026 interesting. They add to our appreciation.", "title": "Opinion | A Note to the Classically Insecure", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mejdal assisted in any way he could, throwing batting practice or feeding a pitching machine, shagging balls in the outfield, doing the grunt work to allow Manager Morgan Ensberg and his staff more instruction time for a raw 35-man roster.\n\nEnsberg, an All-Star third baseman for the Astros in their run to the 2005 World Series, was grateful for the help. The Astros have development coaches at every level, but Mejdal\u2019s research background set him apart.\n\n\u201cThere was one team last year that got to live in the future, and that was the Tri-City ValleyCats,\u201d Ensberg said. \u201cWe got to experience what a major league bench is going to be like in a few years. There\u2019s a bunch of information that I couldn\u2019t possibly know.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo take advantage of it, Ensberg said, he would consult Mejdal at least five times a game, asking what the numbers suggested in a given situation. He would also ask his hitting and pitching coaches for their input, then weigh his options and make a decision.\n\nPlayers, likewise, sought out Mejdal to dig deeper on their performance.\n\n\u201cThey ate this stuff up,\u201d Mejdal said. \u201cThere was no surprise or skepticism. It was like: \u2018Wow, really? You guys can measure that? I didn\u2019t know that.\u2019 \u201d\n\nMcKee said he benefited from the sophisticated reports on pitch usage and hitters\u2019 tendencies. After a rough pro debut the year before, McKee had a strong season, allowing only 19 hits in 41 innings. He was promoted this season to the Class A Quad Cities River Bandits, like Meyers, who said the Astros\u2019 emphasis on video \u2014 especially in spring training, where cameras ring the practice fields \u2014 also helps.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe can pretty much see anything we would want to see throughout the whole day, whatever it is,\u201d Meyers said. \u201cThere\u2019s always eyes watching with cameras. There\u2019s always a way to get better.\u201d\n\nThe ValleyCats finished 34-39, but that was largely irrelevant to Luhnow\u2019s goals. By learning from Mejdal\u2019s experience in Troy, he hoped to give the Astros a better chance to turn their concepts into reality. Front offices everywhere now teem with well-educated executives who have backgrounds outside baseball. Luhnow, who has an M.B.A. from the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern, wondered how the Astros could get more from theirs.\n\n\u201cThere is an ivory tower effect, if you will, where great ideas are being thought about and discussed at headquarters, but until you roll them out into the field, you don\u2019t realize all the challenges involved,\u201d he said. \u201cAmazing ideas find all kinds of issues when you try to roll them out with human beings because that\u2019s all we are, a collection of human beings trying to do things to help players perform on the field.\u201d\n\nIn past years, Luhnow found, it was easy for executives to visit a minor league affiliate for a week but difficult to form more than a surface-level bond with players and staff members. In Mejdal, whom he had first hired with the St. Louis Cardinals in 2005, he had a trusted confidant with intimate knowledge of the Astros\u2019 culture.", "title": "A Numbers Guy Left the Front Office to Coach Prospects. Here\u2019s What He Learned.", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nANATOMY OF A MIRACLE\n\nThe True Story of a Paralyzed Veteran, a Mississippi Convenience Store, a Vatican Investigation, and the Spectacular Perils of Grace\n\nBy Jonathan Miles\n\n355 pp. Hogarth. $27.\n\nFor as long as novels have existed, they have disguised themselves as something other than novels. \u201cDon Quixote\u201d \u2014 the book most often credited with inventing the genre \u2014 purported to be a work of history translated from Arabic into Spanish by a Moor named Cide Hamete Benengeli. The early English realists presented their books not as fictional prose narratives but as journals, collections of letters and other found documents. Some authors have used this pretense ironically, to emphasize the fictional nature of the proceedings (see \u201cLolita,\u201d a prison cell confession complete with diagnostic foreword and names changed to protect the innocent), while others have borrowed nonfiction forms to give otherwise improbable events the urgency of fact (see \u201cThe Plot Against America,\u201d an earnest memoir of childhood during the Lindbergh administration).\n\n\n\nJonathan Miles\u2019s much-celebrated first novel, \u201cDear American Airlines,\u201d took the shape of a 200-page letter to the titular carrier, composed during an extended delay at O\u2019Hare. After a more formally conventional second novel, Miles has returned to the imitation game with \u201cAnatomy of a Miracle.\u201d A tagline on the cover allows that the book is, indeed, a novel, but everything that follows is designed to mimic a work of New Journalism\u2019s narrative reportage, beginning with a pitch-perfect evocation of the wordy expository subtitle such books carry, continuing through a \u201cnote on methodology\u201d assuring readers that \u201cthe scenes and dialogue contained herein were reconstructed from the recollections of participants,\u201d and concluding with the obligatory acknowledgments page, where the author thanks the novel\u2019s characters. Miles\u2019s commitment to this conceit is admirable, but his ultimate intentions are somewhat unclear. Where \u201cDear American Airlines\u201d fell squarely in the winking, Nabokovian mode, \u201cAnatomy of a Miracle\u201d more or less asks to be read straight \u2014 a striking demand given that the story it recounts is quite literally incredible.\n\nThe miracle of the title occurs in the book\u2019s opening pages, when Cameron Harris, an Army veteran paralyzed from the waist down, stands up from his wheelchair outside the Biz-E-Bee convenience store in Biloxi, Miss. Miles traces the ramifications of this act for Cameron and a host of other characters in a documentary style that goes well beyond the occasional parenthetical admission that one fact or another \u201cremains a contested point.\u201d The conceits of creative nonfiction seep into nearly every sentence. We are dutifully told that the word \u201cmiracle\u201d has its origins in the Latin noun miraculum, an object of wonder, and that C. S. Lewis defined one as \u201can interference with Nature by supernatural power.\u201d Cameron\u2019s hometown is introduced with a potted history that includes a quote from the very real memoir of a local reporter, and we learn that Gallup has judged Mississippi to be \u201cthe most religious state\u201d in the Union. The skepticism of a rationalist Veterans Affairs doctor is contextualized with a poll, \u201ccommissioned by the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York City,\u201d indicating that \u201croughly three quarters of doctors believe in miracles.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBecause the genre that Miles is aping applies fiction\u2019s methods to real-life stories, \u201cAnatomy of a Miracle\u201d offers the Victor-Victoria frisson of watching a novel impersonate a work of journalism impersonating a novel. It\u2019s a difficult balancing act that Miles for the most part pulls off, and his book is best appreciated as a highly entertaining literary performance. Of course, such faithful reproduction has inherent risks, which he doesn\u2019t entirely escape. \u201cSaturated with unrelentingly grim headlines,\u201d goes one typical sentence, \u201cthe summer of 2014 was proving \u2018an anxious and depressing muddle,\u2019 as The New Yorker\u2019s George Packer characterized it.\u201d A reader can admire the realism here \u2014 this is, indeed, just the sort of shoddy scaffolding that too often fills out such books \u2014 without wanting much more of it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLuckily, Miles\u2019s writing has many compensatory virtues. One of them is broad humor. (After the Biz-E-Bee attempts to cash in on Cameron\u2019s recovery, a Yelp reviewer describes it as \u201ca Cracker Barrel at Lourdes.\u201d) Another is compassion. Miles specializes in giving fully rounded humanity to characters who might elsewhere be treated as stock figures \u2014 the pious nonagenarian who lives across the street, the sports-car-driving Vatican operator charged with verifying the miracle, the cynical reality television producer looking to get rich off it. Far and away the most compelling of these characters is Cameron Harris himself. As a young boy, he is drawn to acting and making camcorder movies, but he winds up on the high school football team after one of his mother\u2019s boyfriends worries about his \u201cmanliness.\u201d He excels at the sport and is on his way to a college scholarship when his mother dies and he abruptly quits the team. He enlists and heads to Afghanistan, where he is on foot patrol with his superior officer when the two men drift inexplicably from their assigned station and the officer steps on an old Soviet mine, blowing off his own legs and sending shrapnel into Cameron\u2019s spine.", "title": "A Paralyzed Army Vet Walks Again. Is He Healed \u2014 or Is It a Hoax?", "authors": ["Christopher R. Beha", "Jonathan Miles"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Their goal was to raise money for the Mus\u00e9e en Herbe (Budding Museum). Tucked in the First Arrondissement, a stone\u2019s throw from the Louvre, the Mus\u00e9e en Herbe\u2019s mission is to bring art and culture to children and those typically excluded from the art world.\n\nFounded more than 40 years ago, the 6,400-square-foot space provides exhibit-related activities for those \u201cbetween the ages of 3 and 103.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re a little alien in the world of art,\u201d said Sylvie Girardet, the museum\u2019s director. She was a wide-eyed graduate in art history and archaeology when she created the museum with two friends. At the time, she had been shocked to learn that the majority of the French population did not visit museums (In 2014, 61 percent had not been to a museum once in that year, according to one report).\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cChildhood is when a lot of core values are formed,\u201d said Ms. Girardet, 67. \u201cWe thought that if we initiated children into the world of art, then as future adults they wouldn\u2019t have this mental block.\u201d\n\nThe current exhibition (through Sept. 9), \u201cThe Secrets of the Studio: From Monet to Ai Weiwei,\u201d showcases the work of Damian Elwes, who paints the studios of famous artists. Visitors, equipped with a mini magnifying glass and a Sherlock Holmes-style hat, set out on a mission to find Mr. Elwes\u2019s \u201cmissing palette.\u201d\n\nChildren are encouraged to study the paintings to see if they can uncover which artist \u201cstole\u201d the palette. At the end of the exhibition, once they have found the culprit, they are given a tube of paint.\n\n\u201cYoung parents who came to visit the museum when they were little now come back with their children,\u201d Ms. Girardet said as she watched schoolchildren crowd around the tables in the museum\u2019s atelier. \u201cIt\u2019s touching; it means they remember and they keep fond memories of their time here.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEvery year, she said, the nonprofit museum \u201cstruggles to find a budget for the year ahead.\u201d The annual budget is around \u20ac1 million. About half comes from admissions; grants from City Hall make up a fifth of the budget, and the rest is acquired through sponsors.\n\nPhoto\n\nNicolas Laugero-Lasserre, 42, the director of the Icart School of Arts and a fan of the philosophy behind the Mus\u00e9e en Herbe, suggested having his students organize an auction for the museum.\n\n\u201cThree years ago, I decided I wanted the students to really experience how the art market works,\u201d Mr. Laugero-Lasserre said at the exhibition before the auction. \u201cThen I thought, why not raise money for a good cause? The Mus\u00e9e en Herbe is like a paradise for children, open to everyone and breaking social barriers.\u201d\n\nIn 2017, the first edition of Street for Kids raised just over \u20ac74,000. With this extra funding, the museum was not only able to continue to educate children and families but also to fund its program R\u00e9cr\u00e9s du Mus\u00e9e (Break Time in the Museum). This included working with nongovernmental organizations accompanying families from disadvantaged backgrounds on free tours of the museum.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The museum will use part of the funds for its next exhibition on the monsters of Japanese manga comic books and their influence on contemporary artists in Japan.\n\nCharley Uzzell Edwards, a street artist known as Pure Evil who is based in London, donated two original pieces. One sold for \u20ac4,000, and the other, painted live at the auction, sold for \u20ac3,000.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s awesome that they have [the Mus\u00e9e en Herbe] set up to cater to children and get them inspired,\u201d he said. \u201cI think for a lot of kids, street art is their art.\u201d", "title": "A Paris Auction Helps Bring Art to Children", "authors": ["B\u00e9reng\u00e8re Sim"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe big news is that it\u2019s not a couple of thousand people who are affected \u2014 it\u2019s a couple million people,\u201d said Dr. Joseph Habboushe, an assistant professor of emergency medicine at N.Y.U. Langone/Bellevue Medical Center and lead author of the new paper, published in Basic & Clinical Pharmacology & Toxicology.\n\nOthers questioned the one-in-three figure, however. Paul Armentano, the deputy director for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML), said that even with more widespread use of marijuana, \u201cthis phenomenon is comparatively rare and seldom is reported\u201d and strikes only \u201ca small percentage of people.\u201d\n\nAnd several physicians who routinely prescribe medicinal marijuana for conditions ranging from chronic pain to epilepsy said they have not seen the cyclic vomiting syndrome in their patients, but noted that they typically prescribe compounds that are not designed to produce a high and contain very low amounts of the psychoactive ingredient THC.\n\nDr. Habboushe said doctors in other parts of the country may be unfamiliar with C.H.S. or mistake it for a psychiatric or anxiety related syndrome. And even if they are aware of it, many regard it as a \u201crare, kind of funny disease,\u201d replete with anecdotes of patients who spend hours in the shower.\n\nBut the condition can be quite serious. One 33-year-old military veteran who asked not to be identified by name described bouts lasting up to 12 hours in which he felt \u201clike a puffer fish with sharp spikes was inflating and driving spikes into my spine from both sides. I\u2019ve broken bones, and this blew it out of the water.\u201d\n\n\u201cI know patients who have lost their jobs, gone bankrupt from repeatedly seeking medical care, and have been misdiagnosed for years,\u201d Dr. Habboushe said.\n\n\u201cMarijuana is probably safer than a lot of other things out there, but the discussion about it has been so politicized and the focus has been on the potential benefits, without looking rigorously at what the potential downside might be,\u201d he said. \u201cNo medication is free from side effects.\u201d", "title": "A Perplexing Marijuana Side Effect Relieved by Hot Showers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Those examples are mine, but they are the sorts of things the book discusses throughout, always ending the discussion with some variation of the question when it comes to material goods: \u201cIs more really better?\u201d\n\nTo help readers answer that question, the authors ask them to calculate to the penny how many hours they would have to work to pay for anything they are thinking of buying, whether it is a night on the town or a new couch.\n\nThey\u2019re betting that doing that kind of sobering arithmetic will reduce the amount of money you spend. \u201cLooking around at your accumulation of stuff, you can ask, \u2018How many hours of my life did I invest to have this chair, car, mismatched set of cookware.\u2019\u201d\n\nIf you consistently do the math, you may decide you have \u201cenough,\u201d the financial state that the book says you should be aiming for.\n\nWhat is enough? \u201cWe have everything we need; there\u2019s nothing to weigh us down, distract or distress us, nothing we\u2019ve bought on credit, have never used and are slaving to pay off,\u201d the book says. Enough is \u201can honest and self-observant place. It\u2019s appreciating and fully enjoying what money brings into your life, and yet never purchasing anything that isn\u2019t needed or wanted.\u201d\n\nWhen you understand what enough is for you \u2014 and obviously it will vary by person \u2014 you can, in the words of her subtitle, transform your relationship with money and achieve financial independence.\n\nEverything is not binary\n\nI have always had problems with the book. For one thing, there really isn\u2019t much investment advice \u2014 it gets about 10 percent of the space, and what is there tends to be general. Yes, telling people to use index funds and diversify their holdings are good ideas, but details are lacking. The first round is now happening in Berlin, and it will move to Singapore on Sunday, and then to the DiMenna Center in New York on Wednesday.\n\nThe competition \u2014 whose prizewinners include Radu Lupu, Mitsuko Uchida, Andras Schiff and Murray Perahia \u2014 is going global in an effort to confront the growing power of its rivals on the international circuit: heavy-hitting operations like the Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, the Van Cliburn in Fort Worth, or the Honens in Calgary, Alberta. But there\u2019s another reason.\n\nMusic competitions are widely thought to be in need of change, to modify their death-or-glory qualities and find a new kind of humanity. Harry Eelman didn\u2019t seem like the one when he first showed up.\n\nIn person, Mr. Eelman is calm and reserved. And, his images feature sometimes detached subjects, not apathetic so much as quietly comfortable in their own skin.\n\nTheir styles, behind the camera and away from it, contrast in such a way that for the first time in a decade, Ms. Levitt was noticing someone who could finally tip the scales in her work-life balance. (Even as they remembered their romance, Ms. Levitt was scattershot, getting details wrong, laughing at everything, while Mr. Eelman remembered every detail, rarely raising the volume of his voice in the telling of their adventures.)\n\n\u201cI had focused so heavily on my work,\u201d she said, \u201cand because I love it, and because it brings me joy, and I like telling stories, and I like to hopefully do my part and give back to the world, and influence the world and change the world in any way through representation or through storytelling. I had been single for a very long time.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom their first meeting and onward, it was just a matter of keeping an East Coast-West Coast relationship developing. Generally, it was done through photo assignments \u2014 the more exotic, the better. Ms. Levitt got plenty of work in Los Angeles to make frequent visits and stays with Mr. Eelman at his home in Echo Park. Traveling together as a couple didn\u2019t happen often, though.\n\nThat\u2019s when the actor Neil Patrick Harris helped give the couple the nudge they needed. Mr. Harris had met and bonded with Ms. Levitt on a 2008 photo shoot in Alaska. He asked her if she wouldn\u2019t mind \u201cdropping down four pegs\u201d to photograph his 2014 wedding to his longtime partner, David Burtka, at a rented castle in Perugia, Italy. Ms. Levitt quickly agreed.\n\nMr. Burtka and Mr. Harris couldn\u2019t help but chuckle about a weekend that was meant to seal their own bond and wound up sealing another in the process. As they remember it, at first Ms. Levitt had said she was bringing a particular assistant, but not Mr. Eelman.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAnd then she said, \u2018I think I\u2019m bringing a different assistant, and I\u2019m not sure cause it\u2019s a guy that I kind of like, and I don\u2019t know \u2026 We\u2019re gonna be in the same room,\u2019\u201d Mr. Harris recalled.\n\n\u201cAnd we were wondering,\u201d Mr. Burtka said, \u201c\u2018Should we get another room?\u2019 She goes, \u2018Nah, it\u2019s all right. It\u2019s fine, it\u2019s fine. I\u2019m a grown-up. You know, we\u2019ll make it happen.\u2019 And when I checked her into the room, I came into the room, I said, \u2018Is this O.K.? There\u2019s only one bed,\u2019 and she goes, \u2018Don\u2019t worry about it, I got it covered.\u201d\n\nAs Ms. Levitt said, looking back, \u201cI took a risk.\u201d\n\nShe marvels about how incredible the weekend was. \u201cThis sort of high level of romance. Like pasta, wine and Champagne and vistas and views. Harry thinks that I don\u2019t like vistas, but it was amazing, stereotypical-like, textbook.\u201d\n\nShe paused, \u201cWhat does it mean to be on a romantic holiday?\u201d She had found her answer. And for Mr. Burtka and Mr. Harris, it meant the obvious.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI really think that our wedding was the time that they fell in love,\u201d Mr. Burtka said.\n\nRomance blossomed into love. Trips to Los Angeles became increasingly longer stays, and, after a steady stream of photo assignments and more exotic trips, he decided it was time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn a trip to Provence, France, in summer 2017, outside their villa and taking in another lovely vista, Mr. Eelman knelt down and proposed. She said yes, and they both cried.\n\n\u201cI was so elated,\u201d Mr. Eelman said.\n\nFor Ms. Levitt, New Orleans was an ideal location between their two home bases for a wedding. She had fallen hard for the city over the years, sparked in part from friendships she had forged during a 2008 assignment on the bounce music scene in New Orleans.\n\nVery quickly, she turned Mr. Eelman into a fan of the city.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s kind of a little lawless, a little fun,\u201d he said. \u201cYou can just have a good time and the people are great, and the food\u2019s amazing, and it doesn\u2019t feel like anywhere else in America.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe couple turned their days leading up to the March 17 ceremony as a kind of mini-vacation for their wedding party: traditional jazz at Preservation Hall, drinks at Vaughan\u2019s Lounge, fried chicken at Willie Mae\u2019s, Israeli food at Shaya, sandwiches at Turkey and the Wolf, Creole food at Neyow\u2019s Creole Caf\u00e9, wine at Bacchanal, lunch at Commander\u2019s Palace, a swamp tour, a cemetery tour \u2014 as with all things Danielle Levitt, it became a blur. (The day after the wedding, there was a drag brunch at the Country Club.)\n\nAndy Harman, a New York artist and set designer, who became a Universal Life minister, showed up in a specially designed robe for the ceremony.\n\nMs. Levitt, who wore a silver lam\u00e9 jersey gown designed by Rick Owens, sashayed down the aisle escorted by her mother, Marie-France Salaun, and her brother, Alain Levitt; her two nieces, Ludivine and Rima, tagged along as flower girls. As a gospel choir sang \u201cSea of Love,\u201d Ms. Levitt did stutter steps to and fro, as the guests hooted their approval.\n\nAs they exchanged their vows, the couple fought back their tears.\n\n\u201cYou broke down every wall I put up,\u201d she said. \u201cYou\u2019re my champion. I always feel I\u2019m my best self with you. You inspire me to be the person I dream of becoming.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI feel like I\u2019ve lived more in the past three and a half years than the whole of my life,\u201d he told her. \u201cI promise you, Danielle, to always help carry your expanding collection of luggage, I promise to support and love you, be by your side through the good and bad, to be your champion and best friend.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd with that, the couple marched out into the spring afternoon for drinks and chatter as the opera house was reconfigured into a reception hall.\n\nIn a sea of seersuckers, satin and plaid shorts with matching jackets, and crocheted dresses, one stylish guest in particular stood out: the casting director Shay Nielsen, with her long, flowing, black-and-white Art Deco-style dress.\n\n\u201cWhat a colorful group!\u201d Mr. Burtka said as he and Mr. Harris managed their 7-year-old twins, Gideon and Harper. \u201cI\u2019ve never seen so many hipsters out of Brooklyn!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOnce the reception started, Ms. Levitt returned wearing a gown made of silk habotai fabrics that she codesigned with the Los Angeles-based Everybody.World. Guests feasted on a menu that included cochon de lait po\u2019 boys, red beans and rice, and \u00e9touff\u00e9e-spiced shrimp skewers.\n\nAfter guests danced to the classic soul tunes played by the Essentials, and toasted for hours, the Hot 8 Brass Band showed up to lead the party out of the opera house and over to Mimi\u2019s in the Marigny, a nearby bar, for more dancing.\n\nAs the procession made its turn from Dauphine Street onto Franklin Avenue, one bystander asked another, \u201cIs that Neil Patrick Harris?\u201d\n\n\u201cYes.\u201d\n\n\u201cI feel like such an idiot. I went up to him and said, \u2018Has anyone told you you look like Neil Patrick Harris?\u2019 And he just nodded. The woman looked back toward the procession, called the second-line in New Orleans parlance.\n\n\u201cSo, this is a wedding and not a funeral?\u201d\n\n\u201cYup.\u201d\n\n\u201cCool.\u201d", "title": "A Picture-Perfect Wedding in the Big Easy", "authors": ["David Lee Simmons"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Sarah Charlop-Powers was comparing New York City\u2019s forests to its subways.\n\nThe city has more than 840 miles of tracks for one. It has 10,542 acres of the other, about half as much as the Congaree Swamp in South Carolina, a small national park with an old-growth forest and, according to the website I Love National Parks, \u201cmore bugs than you can imagine.\u201d\n\nNo doubt there are many bugs in New York\u2019s forests, even cockroaches that have yet to find their way to somebody\u2019s basement or bathtub. But Ms. Charlop-Powers, the executive director of a Manhattan-based nonprofit group called the Natural Areas Conservancy, is not focused on them. She sees the trees \u2014 and the forest. Most of the city\u2019s forest is deep in parks, and on the worry spectrum, she is \u201cconcerned\u201d about them.\n\n\u201cThe situation is not dissimilar to the subways, in that we\u2019re at a crucial moment,\u201d she said.\n\nFortunately, urban forests appear to be at the point the subways reached decades ago, before transit policymakers decided that maintenance could be deferred.\n\nBut there is another concern for urban forests: climate change.\n\nMs. Charlop-Powers wants to prepare the city\u2019s forests for a changing climate. If nothing else, forests can slow rising temperatures by reducing what foresters call urban \u201cheat-island effects.\u201d Trees lower the nearby temperature by up to nine degrees. There is also the worry that forests could be overrun by invasive species that can change soil conditions \u2014 another contributing factor on the climate change checklist.", "title": "A Plan for New York City\u2019s Forests. Yes, Forests.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Well, actually, no. We had it right. But perhaps we should have anticipated the confusion.\n\nMany people are familiar with the use of this expression in the sense of getting \u201cwhat you had coming to you,\u201d usually meaning punishment. But often people have only heard it spoken. And because the word is pronounced with the stress on the second syllable, they assume it\u2019s spelled \u201cdessert,\u201d like the sweet course at the end of a meal.\n\nBut \u201cdesert\u201d in this sense is related to \u201cdeserve,\u201d and that\u2019s what it means: He got his just deserts means He got what he deserved. It has nothing to do with whether he got ice cream or cake. (\u201cDessert\u201d comes from the same Latin root, but via an Old French word meaning \u201cto clear the table.\u201d)\n\nThe confusion is compounded, of course, by the other word spelled \u201cdesert,\u201d pronounced with the stress on the first syllable \u2014 the one that means a dry, barren region.\n\nBy midday Friday we had received emails from nearly 100 readers pointing out what they assumed was an error. Others voiced their concern on social media. My colleague Zach Montague replied to each reader who contacted us, explaining the distinction. We even included a famous quotation from Hamlet using \u201cdesert\u201d in the sense we intended:\n\nUse every man after his desert, and who should \u2019scape whipping?\n\n(Of course, Shakespeare\u2019s spelling was famously erratic, so a good dictionary is probably a better way to settle a spelling question like this. But we thought that if readers didn\u2019t believe us, they might believe Shakespeare.)\n\nAs the overseer of The Times\u2019s style manual and the de facto newsroom language arbiter, I know that many Times readers care passionately about grammar, usage and good writing. I hear often from readers pointing out our all-too-frequent lapses (in fact, we\u2019ve gotten \u201cjust deserts\u201d wrong ourselves). Many of their observations end up in copy-editing quizzes I publish occasionally.", "title": "A Playful Headline. Confusion Ensues. An Editor Explains.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "A: Since leaving Western Mass. and seeing more of the world, I now understand that part of my own desperation to get admitted to college came from not understanding that there is more than one path to success. Part of the scarcity model I grew up with taught me to believe I only got one shot. There are many ways to educate yourself.\n\nQ. You grew up with a single mother, sometimes struggling with homelessness, and you ultimately received scholarships to boarding school and Sarah Lawrence. What were the most difficult aspects of crossing over, from one world into another?\n\nA. It was shocking to me, in a wonderful way, when I got to Sarah Lawrence, to be in a place where people did not need to lock their doors. And not just because they weren\u2019t afraid of people stealing, but because they weren\u2019t afraid of who might come into their room at night. Suddenly I found myself in this foreign land of unfathomable safety, and plentiful resources. I had no bearings or examples of how to operate within it. Suddenly my day was supposed to be about getting to class, deciding what to wear, and doing homework, as opposed to worrying about how to get warm, where to find food later, or how to avoid someone threatening me or my mother with violence. And my language, my mode of being, was very foreign to the other students I met, who could not believe my utter fascination with the salad bar at lunch. Ultimately I made incredible friends and that institution changed my life, but it was a jagged beginning. I experienced panic attacks and PTSD. I felt ugly and isolated, because I did not know the culture of this place of luxury, or how to blend in within it. It wasn\u2019t until fairly recently that I\u2019ve accepted that this other life I\u2019ve built was not borrowed or temporary.\n\nQ. \u201cTransfers\u201d takes issue with the idea that poor students should be forced to produce reductive narratives of their challenging lives as a kind of poverty porn, for college admissions offices. How have you seen this play out?\n\nA. Privilege is often blind to the more subtle aggressions students face when they are asked to talk about their lives to the elite. I have seen and experienced the tokenism and exploitation of minorities in the admissions process in many parts of our country. When you come from an underserved community, for some reason people think your \u201chard luck story\u201d is something they are owed for considering your application. It is just another aspect of our identities that these institutions seek to own, label and misuse, albeit unintentionally. I understand though, that it often comes from a genuine desire to help.", "title": "A Playwright of Poverty Rejects \u2018Hard Luck Porn\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Did I say this was a political screed? A radical\u2019s blurt of invective? Forget it. The Rev. Kevin Young has opened the Book of Jubilees and the Book of Lamentations, and he is here to pray. No fool he \u2014 Young is currently poetry editor at The New Yorker and director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. He is the author of 10 books of poetry and two books of nonfiction, and the editor of several anthologies. Harvard graduate. Finalist for the National Book Award. Winner of a Guggenheim. Professor. I believe I saw him beat Colson Whitehead in a poker game a few years ago. Record geek. I suspect he could add a further title to his r\u00e9sum\u00e9: trickster.\n\nPhoto\n\nI can tell he knows that in barrios like my old one, the kids boasted, \u201cI\u2019m down and brown.\u201d Though they did not feel empowered in any way, their words made them taller and braver. Made them bold on mean streets and in barren dirt ball fields. \u201cAin\u2019t no shame in my game,\u201d their ghosts still shout. I don\u2019t know how he knows this. It\u2019s somewhere in his blood. He can hear them. He knows we used a long-dead cat for home base. Made believe we were Hank Aaron and hit a deflated soccer ball with a dinged wooden bat on the edge of a tidewater slough between a church and a slaughterhouse.\n\nIn a fleet-footed baseball poem called \u201cStealing,\u201d he says:\n\nIn that game\n\ncalled pickle, or hotbox, I rarely\n\ngot caught. I ran\n\nlike only the sly, four-eyed can \u2014 to get there\n\n& to get away\u2014\n\nto reach somewhere safe, where I\n\nnever thought\n\nto stay.\n\nThe sly four-eyed poet knows there are precious few safe places. Knows that stealing sanctuary is what one gets in brown places. That one will not stay safe, because that is not possible. And the reader of course knows we\u2019re not talking just about baseball.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat being said, I always thought B. H. Fairchild wrote the best baseball poems. But Young is opening a book that has no time for batting heroics or fulsome electrically lit baseball diamonds in approaching night. It\u2019s not just baseball either. The field grows crowded with Muhammad Ali, and an unlikely poetic hero in the swirl, Arthur Ashe. Joyous in its particulars, the collection knows a harrowing is coming. Trayvon Martin watches in the deep shadows, and Young is calling us to see him in \u201cTriptych for Trayvon Martin\u201d:\n\nBecause maybe\n\nBecause we must say your names\n\n& the list grows\n\nlonger & more endless\n\nI am writing this.\n\nThe above is dedicated to Sandra Bland. Lest we forget: She was a 28-year-old African-American woman found hanged in her cell in Texas after being arrested during a traffic stop. Soon, the almost unbearable beauty and sorrow of \u201cWhistle,\u201d which among other things reads as a prayerful lament for Emmett Till, arrives.\n\nDon\u2019t be afraid. Listen to the records. Even Robert Plant and Jim Carroll have come to play. Sinead O\u2019Connor is shyly in a corner. Oh Lord, Jethro Tull has been invited. It\u2019s a parade for all of us. Kevin Young loves you. That\u2019s why he sometimes gives you a kick. It\u2019s a rage that protects the most delicate observer\u2019s heart.\n\nWitness these last lines of the book. I actually held my breath for a moment and just let the stillness of these words do what had to be done after this immense journey. The poem is called \u201cHive.\u201d In it, a boy tries to rescue bees in his bare hands. Believing he can do it. Not unlike the poet himself, I suspect. A blessing. A forgiveness. These lines, then:", "title": "A Poetry Collection That Squints Hard at the Culture, in Pain and in Joy", "authors": ["Luis Alberto Urrea", "Kevin Young"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "ALT-RIGHT\n\nFrom 4chan to the White House\n\nBy Mike Wendling\n\n294 pp. Pluto Press. Paper, $18.\n\nAs Donald Trump went from reality television star to United States president, an obscure, fervently Trump-backing right-wing movement calling itself the \u201calt-right\u201d gained wide attention. That raised a question: How should journalists, politicians or even ordinary citizens think about this group?\n\nIn his book \u201cAlt Right: From 4chan to the White House,\u201d the BBC journalist Mike Wendling demonstrates that good old reporting is the answer. By paying close, critical attention to the alt-right \u2014 most important, doing so long enough to see through its fog of lies, misdirection and trolling \u2014 he has developed a well-rounded understanding of the movement, and created an important guide to one of the most disturbing political developments of our time.\n\nPhoto\n\nEach chapter in his short book takes on one aspect of the alt-right. Wendling writes about the \u201cIntellectuals\u201d (like the democracy-hating Curtis Yarvin), the \u201cRacialists\u201d (peddlers of racist pseudoscience), the \u201cChanners\u201d (4chan forum posters) and the \u201cMeninists\u201d (male anti-feminist activists). He discusses the movement\u2019s abuses of language and its obsession with the media. Finally, he describes the neo-Nazis and other violent white supremacists who have come more to the front since the election of Trump. What united all these groups was a (sometimes irony-cloaked) attachment to hard-right politics, especially on race and gender, together with a seething hatred of liberals, leftists and above all \u201csocial justice warriors,\u201d those campus leftists supposedly obsessed with political correctness, safe spaces and trigger warnings. The fact that the basic agenda of the alt-right is making America a safe space for white men and that its major political activity is whining on the internet when someone disrespects its cultural totems are only two signs of many of how this crowd projects its own insecurities onto others.\n\nAlthough Trump\u2019s victory was a tremendous boost for the alt-right, Wendling argues convincingly that it is already cracking up under the weight of its own contradictions. Winning the presidency sapped much of the strength of a movement that defines itself almost exclusively through what it hates. Wendling shrewdly notes that despite its edgy, countercultural pretensions, the alt-right is almost entirely \u201cculturally sterile.\u201d Endless piles of ephemeral internet memes aside, it has produced little or no music, literature, film or poetry.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDuring the campaign, more \u201cmoderate\u201d members like Milo Yiannopoulos presented themselves as merely trolling when making bigoted or hateful comments. But after the election the extreme elements of the movement stepped up their abuse and terrorism, as seen in Charlottesville, Va., and elsewhere. Later Buzzfeed uncovered documents showing Yiannopoulos himself had been working hand in glove with outright white supremacists to promote their views under his moderate facade.\n\nBut the dishonest void at the heart of the alt-right meant it could not unite around any realistic policies, which has severely hampered it politically. The most significant representative of the movement within the Trump administration, the former Breitbart publisher Steve Bannon, was easily outmaneuvered by traditional Republicans and pushed out of the administration. Now Trump\u2019s cabinet is heavily skewed toward wealthy financiers, and the only major legislation the Republican government has managed to pass is a huge tax cut tilted toward the rich. \u201cThe entire right has been duped,\u201d Wendling finds one 4chan poster concluding.\n\nHowever, Wendling is perhaps a little too sanguine about the alt-right\u2019s future prospects. The fact that a shameless huckster like Donald Trump managed to turn such a disparate movement into a somewhat effective political force does not bode well. The alt-right would be easy pickings for a more competent demagogue.", "title": "A Political Movement, Defining Itself by What It Hates", "authors": ["Ryan Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "For referees, who have broad discretion in calling certain offenses, navigating such diverse terrain can be tricky.
