While swearing is discouraged, it usually generates only a technical foul if it crosses the line into abusive behavior. Now, with players blowing off steam in more than a dozen languages, how can referees reasonably determine whether to penalize them?\n\nJoe Forte, a former N.B.A. referee who also officiated at international tournaments, recalled his occasional struggles.\n\n\u201cYou could kind of sense that they were using some kind of profanity,\u201d Forte said. \u201cBut you didn\u2019t know for sure, so there was nothing you could do about it.\u201d\n\nIt should be noted that many players who come to the N.B.A. from abroad are fluent in multiple languages, including English. Serge Ibaka, a Congolese-born power forward who plays for the Toronto Raptors, recently had a news conference where he answered consecutive questions in English, French and Spanish.\n\nMarcin Gortat, a forward from Poland who plays for the Washington Wizards, said that if he were to curse at an official \u2014 and he does not condone the practice \u2014 he would do it in English, almost as a matter of courtesy.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s how tough you are, that you\u2019ve got to curse the referee in a different language? Just tell him in English,\u201d said Gortat, who once argued that the league should allow hockey-style fistfights among players. \u201cBe a man about it. Get mad, tell him what you think and pay for it. That\u2019s it.\u201d\n\nSaric, a second-year forward, joined the 76ers after several seasons in Europe, where many of the referees are multilingual. Saric had a hard time getting away with anything. He recalled how he once screamed at himself in Croatian \u2014 \u201cI said something about how I\u2019m stupid,\u201d he said \u2014 and got called for a technical foul by a referee who was from Turkey.\n\n\u201cI was like, \u2018I didn\u2019t say it to you!\u2019\u201d Saric said. \u201cBut it didn\u2019t matter.\u201d\n\nWith the 76ers this season, Saric was called for five technical fouls \u2014 a sign, perhaps, of N.B.A. referees\u2019 increased familiarity with naughty words in languages other than English. Saric could not say for certain whether that was the case. When he gets mad, he usually expresses himself in a mix of Croatian and English. But he did acknowledge that his technicals during the regular season were largely warranted.", "title": "A Polyglot N.B.A. Swears by One Thing: That Call Was #@!&", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Thousands died in the schools, and many were victims of physical and sexual abuse. Some priests and nuns at the Catholic schools were involved in the most depraved abuses, including at an Ontario school where students were shocked on a homemade electric chair.\n\nSince the release of the letter from the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops saying the pope would not apologize now, Canada\u2019s bishops have offered little clarity about why. Several Catholic lay people in Canada, including some who have worked within the church, say they believe the pontiff is following the advice of the Canadian bishops, who generally oppose the idea.\n\nSome bishops in western Canada and the north \u2014 where most of the schools were \u2014 do support an apology. When the letter was released, Bishop Mark Hagemoen in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, noted the disappointment of the Indigenous community in a statement, adding, \u201cI too regret that Pope Francis is not coming at this time.\u201d The presumption is that an apology would be made during a visit.\n\nOther bishops, in east Canada, say they believe that the church has already apologized and that in any event the pope\u2019s actions shouldn\u2019t be dictated by a government commission. They also are concerned about the cost of any papal visit because local dioceses would bear the expenses.\n\nIn recent years, papal infallibility, a concept officially codified by Pius IX nearly 150 years ago, seems to have been supplanted by papal apology.\n\nSeven years before the death of John Paul II, in 2005, an Italian journalist, Luigi Accattoli, counted the pope as making at least 94 apologies. And that was before some of his big ones, like his \u201cDay of Pardon\u201d apology for the church\u2019s sins against Jews, heretics, Gypsies, native peoples and women.\n\nPope Benedict XVI continued the trend, though the theologian argued that apologies were for the actions of individual Christians. His milestone apology went to clerical sexual abuse victims in Ireland.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrancis also has said sorry time and again \u2014 but never more forcefully and poignantly than he did this month in a letter to Chilean bishops that came after his own missteps on the sexual abuse issue that threatened to stain his papacy.\n\nHe first dismissed as \u201cslander\u201d accusations that a Chilean bishop had covered up abuse. The resulting outrage, the harshest he had faced in his papacy, led him to send his top investigator to Chile. The result was a remarkable apology.\n\n\u201cI recognize and I want you to communicate this accurately, that I have made serious errors of judgment and perception of the situation, especially due to lack of truthful and balanced information,\u201d Francis wrote.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo now would seem a particularly good time to ask for an apology. And if Canada\u2019s bishops supported it, it is hard to see that the pope would refuse because a hallmark of the Francis papacy is to decentralize authority to the bishops conferences around the world.\n\nJoe Gunn, who spent a decade at the bishops\u2019 conference in Canada helping to develop policies related to Indigenous people, said bishops in Ontario and Quebec whose diocese had little or no direct involvement in the notorious schools, likely blocked efforts to recommend a visit and an apology.\n\nFinancial concerns most likely factored in, if a papal visit were part of the apology, Mr. Gunn and others suggested. A 2002 visit to Canada by Pope John Paul II left the Canadian bishops\u2019 conference 36 million Canadian dollars in debt. The shortfall was covered by the country\u2019s dioceses, financially straining some.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Mr. Gunn, who is now the executive director of Citizens for Public Justice, a faith-based public policy group, said the bishops\u2019 stance more likely reflected a fractured church in Canada, as well as a general lack of a national strategy on reconciliation.\n\n\u201cEach diocese and institute is corporately and legally responsible for its own actions,\u201d the bishops wrote in a recent statement. \u201cThe Catholic Church as a whole in Canada was not associated with the residential schools, nor was the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops.\u201d\n\nThat assertion, though, has been widely rejected.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s convenient when you have an issue like this to not have the responsibility shared nationally,\u201d Mr. Gunn said. \u201cContrast that with when the bishops speak about other issues like abortion. They don\u2019t use the same kind of language.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the public backlash in Canada has grown over the lack of an apology, the bishops have also adopted the position that there have, in fact, already been papal apologies for residential schools.\n\nIn particular, they cite a private meeting in 2009 between Pope Benedict and Indigenous leaders, including Phil Fontaine, then the leader of the Assembly of First Nations, the country\u2019s largest aboriginal group. At that time, the pope expressed his \u201csorrow\u201d about the schools.\n\nFew people other than the bishops, however, equate the pope\u2019s words at that meeting with an apology \u2014 including Mr. Fontaine.\n\n\u201cIt was right for the moment,\u201d Mr. Fontaine said this past week about Pope Benedict\u2019s expression of sorrow. \u201cBut there\u2019s a lot we didn\u2019t know about in 2009: We didn\u2019t know the number of deaths, the numbers of those abused. So much has been exposed through the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, it\u2019s really so different now.\u201d\n\nFather Tom Rosica, the chief executive of Salt and Light Media, a Catholic television service based in Toronto, is among those in the church bristling at the idea of Canada\u2019s Parliament, or any government, issuing demands of the pope.\n\n\u201cGovernments never dictate to the pope what the pope should say and when he should say it,\u201d said Father Rosica, who has worked in the Vatican\u2019s media office.\n\nBut Mr. Angus, the lawmaker who introduced the motion, which is likely to be debated late this week, said that because the church ran the schools on behalf of the government using government money, the measure does not inappropriately cross any lines between politics and religion.\n\nWhile Canada has no constitutional separation between church and state, it is unusual for Parliament in modern times to make a request of any church.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring a recent news conference, Archbishop Richard Gagnon of Winnipeg, Manitoba, endorsed the pope\u2019s decision not to offer an apology now.\n\nBut Archbishop Gagnon and Bishop Lionel Gendron, the president of the bishops\u2019 conference, repeatedly avoided answering direct questions about advice they had given the pope, and they did not offer much guidance about when they thought a visit and apology might be appropriate.\n\n\u201cIf you place Pope Francis among Indigenous people and he hears these horrible stories, what do you think he\u2019s going to say?\u201d Archbishop Gagnon told reporters.", "title": "A Pope Given to Apologies Has Nothing for Indigenous Canada", "authors": ["Ian Austen", "Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Jeff Gore, a biophysicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and his colleagues Christoph Ratzke and Jonas Denk, report that when a sample of Paenibacillus sp., a soil bacteria, is fed a diet of glucose and nutrients in the laboratory and allowed to grow at will, the microbes end up polluting their local environment so quickly and completely that the entire population soon kills itself off.\n\nIn essence, the researchers said, the microbes commit \u201cecological suicide.\u201d The study was published in April in Nature Ecology and Evolution.\n\n\u201cThe effect is so dramatic,\u201d Dr. Gore said. \u201cYou have an exponential growth of the population followed by exponential death.\u201d Within 24 hours of the onset of the death spiral, he said, \u201cno viable cells were left in the entire culture.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s not that the microbes had exhausted their resources: Food remained to feed on. But in gorging heedlessly on the glucose bounty, each bacterium had secreted a steady flow of acidic waste into the culture medium, until the ambient pH level had plunged lethally low.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a strong pH change,\u201d Dr. Gore said. \u201cThe cells don\u2019t realize what they\u2019re doing in time to stop doing it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNor was Paenibacillus the only microbe found capable of committing eco-suicide. Testing a series of bacterial strains isolated from soil, the researchers found that about a quarter of them, if given the chance, would alter the acidity of their surroundings to the point of mass extinction.\n\nIn each case, the researchers showed they could block the die-offs by either adding a buffer to the medium to sop up the acid or by slowing the reckless pace of microbial growth through modest applications of antibiotics.\n\n\u201cThis is a very important discovery,\u201d said Jo Handelsman, who studies microbial diversity at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where she directs the Wisconsin Institute of Discovery. \u201cI didn\u2019t think bacteria were so self-destructive, but this is a very simple phenomenon. The pH changes, and the bugs all die. How did we miss it all these years?\u201d\n\nBy the standard dogma, she said, inhibitory processes would intervene before an entire bacterial population is wiped out, with at least a scattering of microbes going quiescent, forming spores or otherwise waiting out the catastrophe until prevailing conditions improved.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe new research suggests that extinction is more easily set in motion than previously thought, and that once it gets started, the responsible parties may be helpless to make it stop.\n\nDr. Gore emphasized that the study was not a recapitulation of how microbes behave in the wild. They looked at individual isolates of bacteria, monocultures pampered with an assured source of glucose and freed of the need to contend with other microbes.\n\nIn the real world of, say, a forest floor, \u201csoil is a tremendously complex environment, with high bacterial densities and diversity and competing interests at play,\u201d he said. Some bacteria are acidifying their neighborhood, while others turn it alkaline and still others expel politely neutral waste. That diversity, Dr. Gore suggested, likely keeps microbial populations from annihilating themselves under ordinary circumstances.\n\nThe paper nonetheless illustrates the perpetual struggle found at every stratum of the natural world and its human hyperprojection: between cooperation and selfishness, the tribe and the individual \u2014 between the creation of a public good, like a siderophore agent for scavenging iron, and a public hazard, like acid waste.\n\nNature is at best a fickle conservationist, and many animals can prove quite destructive to their surroundings. Flocks of parrots can strip stands of fruiting trees of all their seeds, risking the long-term viability of the very food source on which the birds depend. Elephants are endangered in much of Africa, but in some South African reserves like Makilali they are merry marauders, yanking down trees and denuding all visible vegetation at a dizzying rate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s no surprise,\u201d said Simon Levin, a theoretical ecologist at Princeton University. \u201cOrganisms engage in actions that provide short-term benefits that ultimately can be damaging to the societies of which they are part.\u201d\n\nAnd humans, well, where do we start? Digging up lead, forging it into water pipelines and adding it to cosmetics, paint, gasoline and other everyday goods before realizing that lead is toxic in tiny doses, especially to the brain.\n\nDumping sewage into lakes and rivers and shoveling plastic waste into the ocean, where it swirls and accretes into a ghastly new continent.\n\nBurning ancient sources of carbon at a fever pitch and hoping somebody figures out what to do about our battered climate before Osaka and Miami disappear.\n\nDr. Gore calls himself \u201can optimist\u201d and points to positive trends in earth management: cheaper solar power, cleaner air and water in some places, tigers rebounding in others. \u201cThere are some bright spots,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, humans are a monoculture, a single macrobial strain, with none but ourselves to keep the petri dish clean.", "title": "A Population That Pollutes Itself Into Extinction (and It\u2019s Not Us)", "authors": ["Natalie Angier"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "What to do with my hands? Would it be more dangerous to leave them in my pocket, letting the officers wonder if I had a gun? Or to take them out and risk appearing to pull out a weapon? I could imagine the officer\u2019s statement after shooting or assaulting me: \u201cI feared for my life.\u201d I opted to very slowly pull out my hands and let them swing by my sides. Gloveless, they hurt from the cold.When I finally turned the next corner, the cops slowed and glanced my way but kept walking. I sighed in relief.\n\nMy fear was not irrational. Although a federal court ruled the New York Police Department\u2019s stop-and-frisk practice unconstitutional in 2013, over 80 percent of people stopped by the police are black or Latino, while members of these groups make up less than 60 percent of the city\u2019s population. The department has received more than 1,500 complaints of racial profiling since 2015.\n\nMy fear was also related to a problem much bigger than what happened at Starbucks \u2014 a problem the anti-racial bias training the company has scheduled for its employees can\u2019t even begin to address. The police in this country have long been empowered to respond to white anxiety about the very presence of black people. The 1863 \u201cOrdinance to establish patrols for the police of slaves in the Parish of St. Landry\u201d is an early example. \u201cEvery free white male person, having attained the age of 16 years and not above the age of 60 years, who shall reside in the State of Louisiana and Parish of St. Landry, shall be bound to do patrol duty within the limits of the patrol district in which he resides,\u201d it read. This piece of legislation allowed white men to directly police black people.\n\nWhen emancipation finally came, so did the Black Codes and Jim Crow. As Carol Anderson wrote in \u201cWhite Rage: The Unspoken Truth of Our Racial Divide,\u201d the Black Codes created a world in which, for African-Americans, \u201cself-sufficiency itself was illegal, as blacks couldn\u2019t hold any employment besides laborer or domestic,\u201d and they were \u201cbanned from hunting and fishing and thus denied the means even to stave off hunger.\u201d At the same time, \u201cIf African-Americans refused or could show no proof of gainful employment, they would be charged with vagrancy and put on the auction block, with their labor sold to the highest bidder.\u201d If the police didn\u2019t see the \u201ccrime\u201d \u2014 working, not working, fishing, hunting \u2014 firsthand, all it took to derail a black person\u2019s day (and in some cases, life) was a white person making a report, and this happened often.\n\nMy great-great-grandfather Thomas was policed for helping a friend in the early 20th century. As family lore goes, when he was a sharecropper in Georgia, black farmers needed a pass to leave their plot of land. Thomas lent his pass to a friend to go visit a woman, but when a white person demanded to see it and the name didn\u2019t match, all hell broke loose. The patrol came to beat Thomas, but he shot back at them. While the patrol retreated to get more ammunition, Thomas and kin left the land they had worked for generations and fled north.", "title": "Opinion | A Problem Starbucks Can\u2019t Train Away", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "As its title implies, this is not just a memoir but a call to action. Richards wants you to know that you too can make social change. She also wants you to know that a life of social activism is fun. She offers career advice (\u201cnever turn down a new opportunity\u201d) and even travel tips (\u201ctry to know where the best ice cream is in any given airport terminal\u201d). Considering how often progressives are portrayed as joyless scolds, this is a message that needs to get out more. There\u2019s a lot of satisfaction in activism, even if you don\u2019t win every battle.\n\nThose battles are something I wish Richards had gone into more deeply. Although she opens with her appearance before the congressional committee investigating Planned Parenthood for profiting from fetal remains \u2014 the same committee that investigated Hillary Clinton over Benghazi, with as little to show for it \u2014 her take is basically upbeat. She and her daughter may curl up in bed and weep together on election night 2016, but a few pages later she\u2019s knitting a pussy hat for the women\u2019s march held the day after Donald Trump\u2019s inauguration. She doesn\u2019t spend much time analyzing the current state of reproductive rights in this country, the number of abortion clinics closing or the continuing threat to defund Planned Parenthood and cancel Obamacare\u2019s expansive birth control benefit (which has no co-pay requirement), to say nothing of the hundreds of state restrictions on abortion passed in the last few years.\n\nRichards is absolutely right that Planned Parenthood is popular \u2014 one in five American women has visited one of its clinics. Almost all women have used birth control at some point, and one in four will have had at least one abortion by age 45. Given those facts, I would have liked to read why she thinks the enemies of reproductive rights have been so successful. The once pro-choice Trump \u2014 who said Hillary was willing to \u201crip the baby out of the womb\u201d right before birth \u2014 is in the White House. As a congressman, Mike Pence wanted to shut down the federal government in order to defund Planned Parenthood; today he\u2019s the vice president. She describes as a big win the storm of outrage that resulted when the breast-cancer charity Komen Foundation decided to drop Planned Parenthood from its list of recipients (it had to backtrack within days). But she doesn\u2019t say that the woman behind Komen\u2019s ill-fated plan, Karen Handler, defeated Jon Ossoff in a much-publicized Georgia congressional race. Nor does she mention the 2015 murder of three people at a Colorado Springs Planned Parenthood clinic by a deranged abortion opponent.\n\n\u201cFor the first time in my life, I\u2019m wondering whether my own daughters will have fewer rights than I\u2019ve had,\u201d Richards writes. She\u2019s hardly the only one to have that fear: After the election, Planned Parenthood experienced a 900 percent increase in requests for IUDs from women looking for birth control that would outlast the Trump administration. It is not going to be easy to undo the damage that every day seems to bring to women\u2019s rights, status, opportunities and well-being, but if you\u2019re looking for books to fill you with energy for the long haul that lies before us, this one is a great place to start. After all, with a man in the White House accused of sexual harassment by over a dozen women and Health and Human Services staffed from top to bottom with opponents of reproductive rights, what better time to make trouble?", "title": "A Professional Troublemaker\u2019s Guide for Young Activists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Stunned by the public outcry, which included an online petition that has now garnered nearly 1,500 signatures, the district amended its decision to rename the school the Abington Schwarzman High School. Instead, Mr. Schwarzman\u2019s name would merely grace the new science and technology center.\n\nThe school board president, Raymond McGarry, accepted responsibility. \u201cI was so focused on the positive aspects of this that, frankly, I was blinded,\u201d he said.\n\nChristine Anderson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Schwarzman\u2019s private equity firm, the Blackstone Group, who attended the meeting, insisted that Mr. Schwarzman was all right with his name not being on the school. \u201cThe naming was inconsequential,\u201d she said.\n\nUnder the amended agreement, the Stephen A. Schwarzman Center for Science and Technology will feature plaques or photos of him. It is unclear if his portrait also will hang in the building.\n\nA decade has passed since the global financial crisis. The economy is growing; unemployment is low. But emotions are still running hot about the role that big banks and other Wall Street firms \u2014 and their millionaire and billionaire leaders \u2014 play in America. Yawning inequality has cemented the feeling that just about everything is available for purchase by the very, very rich.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Schwarzman, with an estimated $12 billion fortune, is the embodiment of that caste. He has become a public supporter of President Trump. That helped him land a major international investment last year, but it also made him a polarizing figure in Abington, which voted more than 2-to-1 for Hillary Clinton in 2016.\n\nNaming-rights deals are common, but they increasingly risk provoking fierce reactions \u2014 sometimes leading to embarrassing retreats by the wealthy patrons and the recipients of their largess.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2015, former Citigroup chief executive Sanford I. Weill and his wife, Joan Weill, abandoned a $20 million donation to a small college in Paul Smiths, N.Y., after alumni fought their demand that the school modify its name to include Mrs. Weill\u2019s. That same year, on a far smaller financial scale, a quarrel erupted in Beverly Hills, Calif., over an elementary school courtyard that was named after a local real estate agent who had donated tens of thousands of dollars.\n\nMr. Schwarzman has used his wealth to get his name attached to stuff near and far.\n\nIn 2007, he gave $100 million to the New York Public Library, which renamed its grand Fifth Avenue flagship the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building. The Schwarzman Scholars, a $550 million international scholarship program in Beijing, was started in 2013. And in New Haven, Conn., a $150 million gift established the Schwarzman Center at Yale University, a futuristic student building to feature new dining halls, meeting rooms, and performance space.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Schwarzman\u2019s cash-for-naming-rights frenzy was underway as early as 2004, right here in Abington, when he donated $400,000 to the high school to build a new football stadium. It was named in his honor.\n\nDuring his youth, his family moved to Abington from downtown Philadelphia. Abington was known for its good schools, and his mother wanted a better education for her children.\n\nAt Abington, Mr. Schwarzman ran track and cross-country, once logging a record time despite breaking his wrist partway through a race, and was elected student body president. After graduating in 1965, he attended Yale and then Harvard Business School. In 1985, he helped start Blackstone, which became the world\u2019s largest private equity firm. He has credited Abington Senior High School with kick-starting his future.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy this decade, the high school needed an upgrade. Its main building dated back to the 1950s. It lacked anything resembling cutting-edge computer or science facilities.\n\nAmy Sichel, the longtime Abington School Superintendent, started searching for a benefactor to help bankroll a renovation project that the school board estimated would cost roughly $100 million. Mr. Schwarzman, one of the school\u2019s most famous alumni, was an obvious target.\n\nDr. Sichel approached him about a new contribution in January 2017. Two months later, the Abington school board incorporated the Foundation for Abington School District, a tax-exempt nonprofit organization that could manage the potential gift, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.\n\nDuring the ensuing months, Dr. Sichel, a former school psychologist who is one of the highest-paid superintendents in Pennsylvania, discussed her high school\u2019s needs with Mr. Schwarzman and his philanthropic team. He was especially interested in having the school embrace technology.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTalks were so cordial that Dr. Sichel was invited to Mr. Schwarzman\u2019s 70th birthday celebration last February. The party, in Palm Beach, Fla., featured camels and a performance by the rock star Gwen Stefani.\n\nBy the following January, Mr. Schwarzman had committed $25 million to the renovation, which would feature improved science labs, a new laptop for each student and coding classes available to all.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Schwarzman announced his donation at a gathering of 3,000 school superintendents in Nashville on Feb. 15. There was no mention that Mr. Schwarzman\u2019s name would be plastered all over the school.\n\nThat was because that detail was still being discussed, said Dr. Sichel. So were other requirements contained in the original agreement, which was finalized on March 22 but never signed. The deal also stipulated that the renovated building should feature a portrait of Mr. Schwarzman that he commissioned and that his twin brothers, Mark and Warren Schwarzman, should have spaces named for them.\n\n\u201cControversy over the naming and process aside, the need and desire for the funds still exists, and Mr. Schwarzman is unwavering in his desire to help,\u201d said Ms. Anderson, the Blackstone spokeswoman.\n\nIn a phone interview on Friday, Dr. Sichel said that given the size of the gift, she and the board \u201cwere sure that it would come with some kind of naming opportunity.\u201d\n\nShe said she was shocked by the visceral objections the name change inspired.\n\nThe outcry, raised by the school board\u2019s ratification of the deal on March 27, started with social media posts. It culminated in angry emails to school officials and a petition to oppose the renaming.\n\nSchool board meetings in Abington are normally dull affairs that sometimes last less than 15 minutes. But the gathering on Tuesday immediately took on a circuslike atmosphere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficials first gave an exhaustive presentation about the planned renovations. \u201cThis is a punishment!\u201d shouted a woman in the audience, filled with locals in pressed khakis or Eagles jerseys. One woman clicked away on knitting needles.\n\nWhen the floor was finally opened to the audience, it was nearly 9 p.m. Dozens of people queued for their three minutes at the microphone. Some read from prepared notes. Others cross-examined Dr. Sichel and the school board\u2019s nine members.\n\nThe anger was not just about the school being renamed for Mr. Schwarzman. It was that the school board forged the deal in secret.\n\nDavid Brooks, who graduated from the high school in 2000, said the board was one of three things: \u201cbrazen,\u201d \u201csneaky\u201d or \u201cstupid.\u201d If the school\u2019s name could be auctioned for $25 million, he added, \u201cwhat else is for sale?\u201d", "title": "A Public Outcry Against a Wall Street Titan\u2019s Name on a High School", "authors": ["Kate Kelly"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ballen\u2019s own artistic germination began after his mother\u2019s death in 1973. After briefly studying painting at the Art Students League of New York, he decided to leave the United States behind and travel the world. Over the next five years, Mr. Ballen photographed everywhere from Cairo to Cape Town in the tradition of the street photographers he grew up admiring. His photographs of boys he encountered along the way became the subject of his first book, \u201cBoyhood,\u201d published in 1979.\n\nThose photos are recognizably Ballen photographs, but the hallmarks of his aesthetic \u2014 the windowless rooms, the absurdist juxtapositions, the recurring cast of otherworldly characters \u2014 didn\u2019t truly emerge in his work until the early 1980s, when he moved to South Africa to pursue a career in mineral exploration. As he traveled the countryside for his geological work, he became drawn to the country\u2019s remote dorps, or small towns, and the marginalized white people who lived there.\n\nOne day, he finally gathered the courage to knock on the door of a home in Hopetown and ask to photograph inside. Stepping through that threshold, he said, was a \u201ctipping point\u201d in his career, the beginning not only of his documentation of outsiders, but of his attempts at probing his own psyche through his photography.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s what my photography has been about all these years: defining Roger, and Roger\u2019s relationship to the world, and the world\u2019s relationship to Roger, and Roger\u2019s relationship to deeper philosophical issues of the human condition,\u201d he said.", "title": "A Puzzle With No Solution: Roger Ballen\u2019s Quest for Meaning Through Photography", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "At this point, I should probably point out that as a hip person who is totally in the know, I was going to boast that I knew that DABS means something totally different now, so I went looking for a video that would demonstrate the act of dabbing with one\u2019s arms. Eventually I found it, because it turns out that even Betty White dabs (probably for money, but I digress), but before I found that, I found out that DABS now means something even more different \u2014 and possibly illegal in some states \u2014 which just goes to show you that there is no point at all in even trying to keep up.\n\n6D: Wordplay alert! \u201cForm letters?\u201d are those annoying things you get in the mail, but in today\u2019s puzzle, the clue refers to the tax forms you fill out, so the letters we are looking for are IRS.\n\n18D: Not a tricky clue, although she doesn\u2019t come up as much these days, but shout out to the ERMA Bombeck Writers\u2019 Workshop, which holds terrific conferences for humor writers every other year at the University of Dayton.\n\n32D: Trivia question! In 1954, President Dwight D. Eisenhower added two words to the United States\u2019 Pledge of Allegiance. One of these words was GOD. Bonus point if you know the other one.\n\n50D: Nice to see ISAAC Mizrahi in the puzzle after his turn as a celebrity constructor last July.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Gordon takes the John Donne quote and 15-letter entry, \u201cNO MAN IS AN ISLAND,\u201d and proves it wrong, which is quite a feat this early in the week. I\u2019m barely caffeinated at this point.\n\nHe does so by offering us a theme list of three well-known men whose names are \u2014 wait for it \u2014 islands. The author BRET EASTON ELLIS represents Ellis Island, the actor CUBA GOODING JR. represents the island of Cuba, and the actor IDRIS ELBA represents ELBA (best known in crosswords for being the island where Napoleon was exiled).\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThe idea for this puzzle came while solving Andrew Ries\u2019s \u201cStagger Sessions,\u201d a 20-crossword EP. In one puzzle, ELBA is clued like so: \u201cIdris who\u2019s a counterargument to John Donne\u2019s \u2018No man is an island\u2019 bit\u201d I immediately noticed that NO MAN IS AN ISLAND is 15 letters, and thought if I could come up with some other men whose names were islands, I might have a theme. All I found were CUBA GOODING JR., BRET EASTON ELLIS, DOCK ELLIS (an All-Star pitcher who supposedly threw a no-hitter while on LSD), and the fashion designer PERRY ELLIS. The ELLIS names didn\u2019t work with the other theme lengths of 9, 13, and 15, so I thought this theme wouldn\u2019t work. But then I realized I could make it a left-right symmetric puzzle, and the grid worked nicely with just 72 words. I contacted Andrew Ries to make sure he was O.K. with me adapting his clue into an entire puzzle. He said that he had the same idea seven years ago, and had CECIL RHODES and JOHN IRELAND on his list, but not CUBA GOODING JR. He said JOHN IRELAND had the problem of repeating LAND with NO MAN IS AN ISLAND, and back then IDRIS ELBA was not nearly as famous as he is now, so he scrapped the idea and ended up incorporating it into the ELBA clue. He gave me the go-ahead for my theme, and here we are.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "A Quote Disproved", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nFirst, Democrats had another strong night at the polls last night. Yes, their candidate in an Arizona special House election lost, by five percentage points. But don\u2019t be distracted by that. The district is overwhelmingly Republican.\n\nThe Arizona result \u2014 along with several state-legislature races in New York \u2014 is consistent with that of dozens of other special elections so far this year and last year: Democrats are running far, far ahead of their 2014 and 2016 showings. Their performance suggests they are more likely to retake the House than not.\n\nOf course, there is still a lot that could happen between now and November.\n\nReader project. A couple of weeks ago, I asked readers of this newsletter: Which political views that you disagree with do you nonetheless want to read? And on social media, I asked a related question: Which views are underrepresented in the national media? In both cases, I also asked which views readers considered beyond the pale of productive debate.", "title": "Opinion | A Reader Project on Opinion Journalism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMy father is very stuck in his ways,\u201d said the blunt-edged Mr. Soloviev. \u201cHe has his area, and that\u2019s it. But I would like to build in other cities, like out West, which I know very well because I\u2019ve spent a lot of my life there.\u201d\n\nThe often press-shy father and son made themselves available last month after they launched condo sales at 685 First, which is supposed to open by the end of the year. They were joined at the interview by the architect Richard Meier, whose firm designed the building and portions of a long-delayed mixed-use project planned for a three-block parcel across the street.\n\nThe interview took place a few days before Mr. Meier, 84, announced he would temporarily step down from his firm after reports that he had sexually harassed female employees over a 30-year period. Since then, the architect\u2019s name has been completely erased from 685 First\u2019s website, though Mr. Meier\u2019s own firm still features the project.\n\n\u201cDisappointment and anger were my reactions,\u201d upon learning of the harassment accusations against Mr. Meier, Mr. Soloviev said. \u201cI didn\u2019t see it coming. But his firm did their job and gave us a beautiful building.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt first glance, the tower at 685 First Avenue, which has 148 condos and 408 rentals, is a classic Solow project. On a site that spans the entire block from East 39th to East 40th Streets, it has a reflective black-glass facade, like most of his apartment towers, including 265 East 66th Street, a rental at Second Avenue, and One East River Place, on East 72nd by the F.D.R. Drive.\n\nIt even resembles Solow\u2019s 9 West 57th Street, the sloping office tower that once commanded some of the highest office rents in the city, though much of it is currently vacant.\n\nMr. Meier, who is known for almost always designing white buildings, rolled his eyes when asked why he hadn\u2019t deployed his signature look. \u201cI have to be honest with you,\u201d he said, before looking in the direction of his client.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI just feel from the outside it is very strong, almost like marble, but from the inside you can\u2019t tell it\u2019s black, because it\u2019s perfectly translucent,\u201d Mr. Solow said of his favorite building color.\n\nIf Mr. Solow, who lives nearby at 860/870 United Nations Plaza, is remembered for any buildings, he said he hopes they will be 9 West 57th and 685 First. And the deep-pocketed developer, who in 2017 was ranked 140 on the \u201cForbes 400\u201d list of the richest Americans, with $4.7 billion, seems intent on shaping his legacy carefully.\n\nIn February, he traveled to a quarry in Italy, accompanied by Mr. Soloviev, to personally choose travertine panels for the walls of 685 First\u2019s soaring 30-feet-tall lobby. Workers at the site said Mr. Solow calls every day to check on his tower\u2019s progress.\n\nThe tower, whose one-bedroom condos start at $1.5 million, will also showcase art from Mr. Solow\u2019s extensive collection. A large three-painting creation from Joan Mir\u00f3, made up of green, orange, and red panels, will likely be relocated to the lobby of 685 from its current home at 9 West 57th, Mr. Solow said.\n\nHe had also planned to bring an outpost of Brasserie 8\u00bd, the restaurant that sits at the base of a circular staircase at 9 West 57th, to the new building. But Mr. Soloviev has rejected that idea, saying the neighborhood around 685 First, a mix of United Nations missions, older apartment buildings and tunnel ramps, is not quite ready for a business-lunch spot just yet. \u201cI would have to strongly advise against it,\u201d Mr. Soloviev said. \u201cI say no to everybody. I do things my way, and sometimes it\u2019s not that popular.\u201d\n\nMr. Soloviev has asserted himself in other ways. Despite his father\u2019s long-held belief that balconies clutter facades, Mr. Soloviev pressed for them and about a fifth of the units will have them. \u201cHe won,\u201d Mr. Solow said.\n\nThe presence of condos at 685 First also differentiates the building. Mr. Solow, who has almost exclusively built rentals, beginning in Far Rockaway, Queens in the 1950s, said the expiration of the state\u2019s lucrative 421a property-tax abatement in 2016 has made rental development all but impossible. So, 685 First, which broke ground in 2017, had to incorporate condos, which typically allow developers to recoup their investment more quickly.\n\nPhoto\n\nSeveral projects going forward will be condos, including a skinny 16-unit condo that\u2019s under construction at 7 West 57th Street, as well as a hotel-condo across the street from it, though that project has been delayed by ongoing litigation involving a retail tenant in a building marked for demolition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Soloviev said that the three residential buildings planned for the vacant site across from 685 First would also be condos, not rentals as originally conceived. The site\u2019s master plan, created in part by Mr. Meier and approved a decade ago, also calls for a fourth building, an office tower, that will house biotech companies.\n\nThe last recession is one reason the mixed-use project has taken so long. In 2010, the firm decided to sell a nearby parcel at East 35th Street to the city for about $33 million for a new public school. Another parcel at East 35th was sold to JDS Development Group in 2013 for $127 million, and the two rental towers known as American Copper Buildings stand there today.\n\n\u201cI hate the price we got\u201d for the Copper site, Mr. Soloviev said. \u201cBut those were some trying times.\u201d Around that time, he added, his father took a six-month leave of absence from the firm for medical reasons, leaving Mr. Soloviev at the helm.\n\nThat six-month run was not the son\u2019s first taste of the family business. When he was a teenager, he parked cars at 9 West 57th. Much later, he worked on layouts and finishes at Two Sutton Place, a 209-unit rental high-rise by the Ed Koch-Queensboro Bridge that opened in 2014. He also takes credit for helping boost the occupancy rate at 9 West 57th from \u201cbelow 50 percent\u201d several years ago to 70 percent today.\n\nFor years, though, Mr. Soloviev was largely based out west, where his family owns close to a half million acres of land. About 145,000 acres planted with wheat, sorghum, corn and sunflowers are in Colorado, Kansas and New Mexico. Another 300,000 acres are grassland in New Mexico used for cattle.\n\nA decade ago, Mr. Soloviev spent about half the year, on and off, in those rural locations. Now, he heads west only a few days a month, he said, instead living mostly in East Hampton, in a house he shares with five of his children. Having dinner with them every night, he added, often requires a helicopter trip home.\n\nAll told, Mr. Soloviev has 15 children, 11 of whom were from his marriage to his ex-wife, who lives in upstate New York with their other children. Mr. Soloviev\u2019s other four children \u2014 from relationships with two women \u2014 live with their mothers in Sacramento, he said.\n\nMr. Soloviev, who drives a Dodge Ram truck in contrast with his father, who used to own a collection of Rolls-Royces and now typically rides in a chauffeured car, said he is in no rush to be the only one in charge of the family real estate company.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m taking over the business. I get that,\u201d he said. \u201cBut right now I work with my father. And I don\u2019t think we\u2019ve ever worked as well together as we are right now.\u201d", "title": "A Real Estate Dynasty Passes the Torch", "authors": ["C. J. Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Then there\u2019s the question of what the E.R.A. would do. Even the most die-hard proponents of the amendment acknowledge that it\u2019s unlikely to radically advance women\u2019s rights, at least in the short term. That\u2019s because, for decades, many courts have applied the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment to sex discrimination, creating a body of case law that\u2019s functioned as a sort of de facto E.R.A. As to whether the amendment could actually undo some programs that are beneficial to women, like sex-based affirmative action efforts, legal experts point to the fact that though the Constitution already protects the rights of people regardless of race, race-based affirmative action continues to exist. They also point to parts of the country that have state-level E.R.A.s and have not had such outcomes.\n\nThe fight against the E.R.A. is being led by groups on the religious right like the Illinois Family Institute, using arguments that are the ideological heirs of those so vociferously expressed by Phyllis Schlafly, whose group Stop E.R.A. \u2014 the first word standing for \u201cStop Taking Our Privileges\u201d \u2014 which became the Eagle Forum, prevented the E.R.A.\u2019s ratification at the time.\n\nThose arguments include fearmongering about how coed locker rooms could become standard and alimony for women outlawed \u2014 arguments that are hard to take seriously but that nonetheless helped Mrs. Schlafly to very effectively convince Americans, including many women, that the E.R.A. was bad news. (Mrs. Schlafly, who died in 2016, would no doubt be appalled that her home state, Illinois, could now play such a pivotal role in ratification.)\n\nAnother conservative talking point is that the E.R.A. would lead to abortion restrictions being struck down. That outcome is not at all certain, but it would help many women. (For obvious reasons, the anti-E.R.A. crowd already had to slink away from an argument that the amendment would lead to legalizing same-sex marriage.)\n\nLooking at everything the E.R.A. would not do raises the question of why it\u2019s still needed. Here\u2019s why it is: The court decisions that make up the \u201cde facto E.R.A.\u201d can be undone in a way a constitutional amendment cannot. The E.R.A. would add an extra layer of legal protection for women \u2014 and men \u2014 against discrimination. This could become especially important if Mr. Trump gets to pick additional conservative Supreme Court justices.\n\nThere\u2019s also a symbolic and emotional element to this fight that\u2019s not to be discounted. Ruth Bader Ginsburg \u2014 who, before becoming a Supreme Court justice, fought many legal battles over gender discrimination and is a longtime supporter of the E.R.A. \u2014 summed up this argument in 2014.\n\n\u201cI would like my granddaughters, when they pick up the Constitution, to see that notion \u2014 that women and men are persons of equal stature,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019d like them to see that is a basic principle of our society.\u201d\n\nEnshrining women\u2019s rights in the Constitution matters. Doing so now, during this presidency, would be particularly fitting.", "title": "Opinion | A Rebuke to Trump, a Century in the Making", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "The story of Slater\u2019s attempts to get and stay well weaves throughout \u201cBlue Dreams: The Science and the Story of the Drugs That Changed Our Minds\u201d and provides some of the book\u2019s most poignant and lyrical writing. Just as important, her experience makes her a convincing travel guide into the history, creation and future of psychotropics. She is, understandably, not an uncritical cheerleader. But she resists the facile role of hard-charging prosecutor. And no wonder, really, given that the drugs have allowed her to have two children, write nine books, marry (and divorce) and hold dear friendships.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo, when she takes us back to the 1950s and the story of Thorazine, she doesn\u2019t just give us a \u201cOne Flew Over the Cuckoo\u2019s Nest\u201d bag of horrors, but also a glimpse into doctors\u2019 excitement when the drug quelled patients\u2019 delusions and hallucinations and the once-comatose resumed living. A former barber, who had been in a haze for years and for whom all previous treatments failed, returned to shaving (his first customer: the doctor who gave him Thorazine). A juggler asked for billiard balls and began juggling again. And people on one psychiatric ward picked up musical instruments, used drills and saws, held conversations that had been unthinkable shortly before.\n\nIn what becomes a through-line in the book, no one fully understood how the drug worked (nor do we know what happened to the juggler or barber once they left the asylum). It was simply enough that it seemed to be working. And yet, in high doses and over the long term, patients often experienced tardive dyskinesia, which includes tongue thrusting, lip smacking, restlessness, involuntary movements of arms and legs, which become twisted like pretzels. When Slater wonders aloud to a psychiatrist why the new class of antipsychotics is really so much better than the old ones, he says: \u201cYou have to pick your poisons. Which would you rather be in two years \u2014 a circus freak or a diabetic?\u201d\n\nShe takes us on similar journeys into lithium and MAO inhibitors, each bringing hope and problems. And then, in the late 1980s there\u2019s the arrival of serotonin reuptake inhibitors, known as SSRIs, and their promise to be different from the antidepressants of the past. The standard explanation is that Prozac, Celexa, Zoloft and other SSRIs boost serotonin levels. But studies have never proved that depressed people suffer from low serotonin (some do, some have normal levels and others have high levels). And SSRIs often fare no better than placebos for mild to moderate depression. Still, doctors tend to talk about depression as if the science is settled, often telling patients: If you\u2019re diabetic you take insulin; if you\u2019re depressed you take a pill. The analogy, of course, doesn\u2019t hold. There is no blood test, no X-ray, no urinalysis that pinpoints depression. It is a field, Slater writes, \u201cstill stuttering, with at best a slippery grasp on the science behind its pills and potions, a legion of medical men and women who can help you in one way but hurt you in another.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHope does arrive in the second half of \u201cBlue Dreams,\u201d when Slater walks us through emerging interventions. Unfortunately, by this point she\u2019s taken us through so much material and still has so far to go \u2014 including brain stimulation and memory drugs \u2014 that the journey begins to feel too wide-ranging and, occasionally, too thin on details about what we\u2019re passing along the way.\n\nStill, several of the up-and-coming treatments \u2014 many of them not new at all \u2014 shift our focus from unmediated pill popping. Among them are placebos, which don\u2019t work for all patients and have no effect on those with Alzheimer\u2019s. But, as Slater rightly notes, numerous studies show their amazing potency, which remains too untapped by a psychiatry field still enthralled with drugs.\n\nLike placebos, hallucinogens also aren\u2019t new, of course, but researchers are repurposing them in promising ways. Studies show that psilocybin, the active ingredient in so-called magic mushrooms, curbs smoking addiction, as well as relieves anxiety and depression for people with end-stage cancer. And in clinical trials, psychotherapy combined with MDMA (the chemical more commonly known as ecstasy) offers significant relief for PTSD sufferers. The drug, which creates feelings of empathy and euphoria, allows traumatized victims to recall their terrors in a calm state of mind and establish deep trust with their therapists \u2014 ingredients that pave the way for psychological change.\n\nOne of the keys for MDMA, psilocybin and some placebo therapies is the connection between patient and provider. And connection is exactly what vanishes during Slater\u2019s own depressive states. Her primary feeling, she writes, is \u201cthe loss of love \u2014 my people falling away \u2014 and the loss of language, my words dwindling so low that my thought seems to move without rhythm or reason.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s no surprise that Slater goes searching for relief among these new treatments. She tracks down a therapist who uses MDMA in her practice. And in the cozy office painted in calming colors, Slater tells the therapist her history and lists her prescriptions. MDMA won\u2019t work for Slater, the therapist tells her; her current medications would block the drug\u2019s effects. Slater knows from past experiences that she can\u2019t risk weaning herself from the prescriptions that keep her stable. Her dependency on our terribly imperfect drugs has ruled out her candidacy for more promising ones.", "title": "A Reckoning With an Imperfect Science in \u2018Blue Dreams\u2019", "authors": ["Maggie Jones", "Lauren Slater"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "No doubt such an outcome would please the many fans of Apu, some Indian-Americans among them, and those who love to rail against \u201cpolitical correctness\u201d \u2014 Apu is just a funny fictional character, and critics are being overly sensitive, these people often argue.\n\nBut for many of us, it is not so easy to dismiss Apu and his accent as a mere joke. It is too often clear that the joke is on us \u2014 and even more so on our older relatives. Apu was the only major South Asian character on prime-time TV for many years, helping to define how millions of Americans think Indians, Pakistanis and other people from the subcontinent talk and live.\n\nAs with all caricatures, there is some truth to Apu. Many South Asian immigrants, especially those who came in earlier decades, do work behind the counters of 7-Elevens and other such stores, often because it is the only work they can get. Many of them are parsimonious because they are sending money home or saving up to send their kids to college. They don\u2019t always understand American slang and norms, and so can come across as bumbling. They cling to customs and religions that they brought with them from the old country because those are their connection to home.\n\nBut many aspects of the character reveal Apu to be the brown equivalent of blackface minstrel performances. He comes across as a caricature designed to mock a minority for the entertainment of the majority. \u201cOften, racism is dismissed under the guise of humor,\u201d says Shilpa Dav\u00e9, a professor at the University of Virginia and author of \u201cIndian Accents: Brown Voice and Racial Performance in American Television and Film.\u201d \u201cThere is always an undercurrent of truth to it and there is also an undercurrent of censure and satire.\u201d\n\nBrownface \u2014 or brown-voice, in the case of Mr. Azaria and Apu \u2014 does not have as long a history as blackface, but there are plenty of examples of it. Mr. Azaria has said he was inspired by a performance Peter Sellers gave in a 1968 comedic movie, \u201cThe Party.\u201d His face darkened with makeup, Mr. Sellers plays an Indian actor who is invited to a Hollywood bash, which he proceeds to wreck. Earlier, Mr. Sellers had a cameo as a clueless Indian doctor in the 1962 movie \u201cThe Road to Hong Kong.\u201d In the 1988 movie \u201cShort Circuit 2,\u201d Fisher Stevens, who is white, plays an Indian scientist with brown makeup and a fake accent. More recently, in 2012, Ashton Kutcher put on brownface for an ad for PopChips. Even blackface has not disappeared \u2014 it crops up especially around Halloween.", "title": "Opinion | A Reckoning for Apu, \u2018The Simpsons\u2019 and Brownface", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Over the past six months or so, in what has come to be called the #MeToo movement, women \u2014 and some men \u2014 have come forward with long-repressed and long-ignored accusations that powerful men abused and harassed them with impunity. Some of the most famous men in entertainment, journalism and other fields have been defenestrated, often after years of predatory behavior.\n\nSome people might see cause for hope in the Cosby verdict, since he was the first celebrity convicted in the #MeToo era.\n\nBut since it happened only after scores of women suffered in silence for decades, and only in the midst of a global reckoning with sexual violence, even a \u201cvictory\u201d like this verdict suggests that the abused still face a desperately uphill battle.\n\nSome men may yet be punished \u2014 in New York, prosecutors are seriously looking at accusations that the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein raped one of the many women whose accusations against him set off the #MeToo reckoning. And the punishment Mr. Cosby is facing \u2014 up to 30 years in prison \u2014 would be too severe for much of the misconduct that some other men have been accused of recently.\n\nBut a majority of the men accused of improper, even criminal, actions in recent months are unlikely to be brought to justice and instead seem to be waiting things out, often in their mansions, already plotting career comebacks.\n\nMs. Constand fought for years to get to this day. While she won a $3.38 million settlement from Mr. Cosby in 2006, that came only after prosecutors in Pennsylvania declined to charge him earlier. His first trial ended with a hung jury last year. The conviction was won this time after those five women were allowed to bolster Ms. Constand\u2019s testimony, demonstrating his signature pattern of abuse.", "title": "Opinion | A Reckoning for Cosby \u2014 Now for Others?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The goal is to provide a safe haven for those who can prove they are fleeing persecution in their homeland.\n\nWhat\u2019s the difference between a refugee and an asylum-seeker?\n\nThere are two ways people can win protection and the right to live permanently in the United States. In both cases they must prove the same well-founded fear of persecution on account of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership in a particular social group.\n\nPeople who apply and are selected overseas eventually enter the United States as refugees.\n\nMany of them, hundreds of thousands, remain parked in camps as the refugee application process unfolds, typically over several years. That process involves several interviews with United Nations and American officials. The United States also conducts several layers of security screening.\n\nPeople already on United States soil apply for asylum.\n\nAlexander Godunov, a principal dancer with the renowned Bolshoi Ballet, was granted asylum in the United States in 1979. He was the first of several dancers to defect from the Bolshoi during that year\u2019s tour in the United States. He requested asylum in New York City and received it immediately. Ms. Navratilova received asylum in October 1975, a month after filing for it.\n\nDuring the 1980s, civil war in El Salvador displaced several hundred thousand people. Tens of thousands flocked to the United States and applied for political asylum.\n\nNowadays, the process of applying for asylum often takes years to complete, from start to finish. It involves interviews with United States immigration officials and often with immigration judges.\n\nWhether people entered the country legally or not, they are eligible to apply for asylum.\n\nThe surge\n\nThe world is suffering the worst refugee crisis since World War II. There are now a staggering number of refugees, asylum-seekers and displaced people \u2014 about 50 million.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nViolence around the globe is pushing desperate people to seek safety across international borders. People from the Middle East and Africa are taking rickety boats and making treacherous treks to reach Europe. They are less likely to show up at the southwest border of the United States than people from Latin America who are, relatively speaking, nearby and can come over land.\n\nIn recent years, violence in Central America \u2014 it has some of the highest murder rates in the world \u2014 has prompted tens of thousands of people since 2014 to make the perilous journey to the United States.\n\nThe migrants either turn themselves in at the border to American authorities or sneak into the country illegally. Regardless, they then declare that they are seeking asylum.\n\nBefore 2011, only 1 percent of all arriving foreigners requested asylum. Today, one out of 10 apply, according to government officials.\n\nThe caravan\n\nJeff Sessions, the United States Attorney General, called the caravan now awaiting processing at the San Ysidro port of entry a \u201cdeliberate attempt to undermine our laws and overwhelm our system.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere is no right to demand entry without justification,\u201d he said, adding that he would deploy prosecutors to handle cases.\n\nIndeed, there are signs that the administration is seeking to disqualify certain applicants, such as victims of domestic violence, who have sometimes won asylum. Recently, Mr. Sessions suggested they should not be eligible.\n\nYet the law does require authorities to accept and consider their petitions.\n\nOnce they are processed at the port of entry, they are likely to be transferred to a detention facility where they must pass the first step in the asylum process, a \u201ccredible-fear\u201d interview with an officer of the United States Immigration and Citizenship Services.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe number of credible-fear interviews conducted by the federal agency has soared from 5,000 in 2007 to 80,000 last year.\n\nMore than three quarters of those interviewed pass that screening and are referred to an immigration judge for hearings that may span months or longer. (Those who fail the interview can be deported immediately.)\n\nAsylum applicants awaiting a hearing before a judge either remain in detention or are released wearing a tracking device, such as an ankle monitor, with a date to appear in court.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMany Central Americans stay with friends and relatives who already live in the United States. Once 180 days have passed after filing of their application, they are eligible to work in the United States. Their children attend public schools.\n\nBecause some migrants in the past have skipped their court hearings, Mr. Trump has criticized the practice of releasing migrants, describing it as \u201ccatch and release.\u201d In recent months, his administration has ordered border officers to, when possible, keep these migrants in detention, rather than release them.\n\n\u201cWhile these asylum seekers are, on paper, eligible for consideration for release on parole, in reality ICE holds them in detention for long periods of time,\u201d said Eleanor Acer, director of refugee protection for Human Rights First.\n\nUnited States officials say the administration is trying to figure out how to deal with the surge in asylum applications in a manner that is consistent with its international obligations.\n\nPart of the problem is that immigration courts are clogged, and not just with asylum cases.\n\nAt of the end of March, there were 692,298 cases in the backlog, according to Syracuse University\u2019s Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse, which tracks the trends. The average wait time for current pending cases was 718 days, or nearly two years.\n\nAre their claims legitimate?\n\nCentral Americans who apply for asylum often have been threatened with death or suffered attacks at the hands of gangs. Often mothers flee to protect their children from recruitment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have seen firsthand the extraordinarily violent conditions in the Northern Triangle of Central America that forces families and children to flee their homes in search of urgently needed safety in the U.S.,\u201d said Jennifer Sime, senior vice president of United States programs at the International Rescue Committee.\n\n\u201cThose who qualify and are fleeing violence, who have no other route to protection, should be granted safety and asylum,\u201d she said.\n\nImmigrant advocates say their circumstances are akin to those faced by people escaping war in Syria or Somalia. However, it is more difficult for Central Americans to win their cases.\n\n\u201cA huge percentage of these people get deported,\u201d said Marty Rosenbluth, an immigration attorney. \u201cIt\u2019s a really difficult struggle to win asylum.\u201d\n\nMr. Rosenbluth said that all of his asylum cases based on gang violence have failed because his clients could not establish that they fit into a social group suffering particular persecution to qualify.\n\nIn some cases, judges have found that applicants fabricated or exaggerated their claims, though that is not usually the case.\n\nImmigration court records show that more asylum cases were denied over the previous five years than have been granted. In fiscal year 2016, 62 percent of asylum cases were denied, compared with 44.5 percent five years earlier. Among Mexicans and Central Americans, the approval rate is substantially lower.\n\nAre some people just looking for a better life?\n\nSimply wanting a better life does not meet the international criteria to qualify for asylum. But there are people who apply anyway because it gives them some benefits, albeit temporarily, even if they ultimately lose their case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince the election of Mr. Trump, undocumented immigrants who have lived in the country for many years and fear deportation have been applying for asylum, knowing that they are unlikely to win, but hoping to remain in the country legally for a time.\n\nWhile their application crawls through the courts, they can obtain work permits and driver\u2019s licenses.\n\nThe administration, which has taken a hard-line on immigration, has said that it is seeking to expedite asylum cases and crack down on abuse.\n\n\u201cThere is a significant increase in terms of individuals seeking asylum,\u201d said Jennifer Higgins, an associate director at United States Immigration and Citizenship Services who handles refugee and asylum issues. \u201cOur goal is to make sure we have a fair and efficient asylum system. Right now we have individuals exploiting it. That means legitimate applicants will suffer.\u201d\n\nThe government has also said that it will prosecute those who break immigration law.\n\nIn the case of the caravan, critics say that it would be a violation of international law to conduct speedy hearings for the caravan members at the expense of a full hearing of their claims.\n\n\u201cThe Trump administration has made clear that asylum seekers associated with the caravan will be subjected to detention, criminal prosecutions, and rushed proceedings, in essence punishing them for seeking refugee protection,\u201d said Ms. Acer.\n\nBut Ms. Higgins said officials are assigning staff and officers to help house and process all those admitted for hearings, wherever they end up.", "title": "A Refugee Caravan is Hoping for Asylum in the U.S. How Are These Cases Decided?", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Identity politics gained traction on the left, but now the Trumpian right has decided to fight fire with fire. Populism is a form of identity politics because it\u2019s based on in-group/out-group distinctions. It says anybody who doesn\u2019t think or look like us is not a true American.\n\nThis tribal mentality is tearing the civic fabric and creates a war of what Goldberg thinks of as \u201cecstatic schadenfreude\u201d \u2014 the exaltation people feel when tribal foes are brought down.\n\nI love the way Goldberg provocatively tells his story, but I partially disagree with it. The central tension in his book is between Locke, who emerges as a rational, calm, pipe-smoking economist, and Jean-Jacques Rousseau, who emerges as a wild-haired, passionately resentful rock star. The liberal order emerges from the individualism of Locke and is threatened by group consciousness and romantic resentments of Rousseau.\n\nBut America is both rational and romantic, both Locke and Rousseau. We have a rationalist constitution, but we have a shared national faith and are an emotional community, rooted in our land, inspired by our history, warmed by the hope of our common future.\n\nThe core problem today is not tribalism. It\u2019s excessive individualism, which has eaten away at our uniting faith and damaged our relationships with one another. Excessive individualism has left us distrustful and alone \u2014 naked Lockeans. When people are naked and alone they revert to tribe. Tribalism is the end product of excessive individualism.\n\nGoldberg is suspicious of nationalism and has a tendency to think that any effort to build a national community puts you on the express lanes on the road to serfdom.\n\nHis conservatism is missing the bonding sentiments of Edmund Burke, and the idea that the little platoon of the family is nestled in the emotional platoon of the neighborhood and the emotional platoon of the nation. Tribalism is not the only way to form a group; there\u2019s also the redeeming and forgiving love of community, and a shared national faith. Goldberg misses the way Hamilton, Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt built a national community that didn\u2019t crush local communities but rather reinforced them.\n\nGoldberg is right to fight tribalism on the left and the right. But you can\u2019t reweave a fragmented nation by appealing just to Lockean individualism. Gratitude is too weak a glue to hold a diverse nation together. Renewal will come through the communitarians on the right and the left, who seek ways to improve relationships on a household, local and national level.", "title": "Opinion | A Renaissance on the Right", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "I saw, for example, a hint of the money being spent. Officials have been vague on the precise cost of the deployment, but the resources before me were stunning: pricey Bushnell binoculars, hotel rooms, rental vehicles. Texas has had troops on the border since 2014 as part of a state mobilization, and the cost was roughly $1 million a month. This new, federally financed deployment will run far higher.\n\nIt all started last Saturday, when Marc Lacey, The Times\u2019s National editor, asked me to request an embed with the troops on the border in Texas. On Monday, the Guard sent me an email back stating that I had been selected, along with the Times photographer Lynsey Addario. We would have five hours, starting at noon Tuesday, the first of several media embeds of Texas ground forces planned during Mr. Trump\u2019s deployment.\n\nBut first, I had to sign my life away. The Guard gave us a five-page form. By signing it, I acknowledged that I had been advised by the Guard that, \u201cin pursuing the successful accomplishment of its mission,\u201d the state\u2019s military forces could not \u201cguarantee my personal safety or the safety of my equipment.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday at noon, Weslaco was hit with a lightning storm. Part of the armory where we and a few other media outlets gathered had no power. Soldiers were walking around dark halls using the lights from their phones. Our departure at noon was pushed to 1:45 p.m.\n\nBefore we got on the highway, we were told we could not reveal our locations, other than to say we were in Starr County. And we could not photograph the full faces of the troops \u2014 to protect their identity and safety. Military leaders worried that smugglers would target them for speaking out.\n\nOn the one hand, there was an element of organizational paranoia at play. But the border \u2014 not the towns and cities where people live, but the physical line on the Rio Grande \u2014 can be a dangerous place. In 2011, drug smugglers trying to protect a raft loaded with marijuana threw rocks and fired up to six gunshots at officers on the border near the places where we traveled (the agents answered those six gunshots with a barrage of about 300).\n\nI thought about that incident as I stood next to a soldier overlooking the river.\n\nHe said nothing to me as he stared through binoculars. He was in his 20s. He wore a wedding ring. He was Latino. I would guess he lived not too far away from where he stood at that moment. This young man was a visual representative of America and vulnerable to those six gunshots in a way that I was not. So much of this debate has been filled with generalities that I appreciated the chance to put a specific human face on the issue. When I think about it now, I picture that silent, focused young man, his M-4 rifle and his silver wedding band.\n\nThere was a moment at the first observation post when Ms. Addario \u2014 who has risked her life covering war zones around the world and was captured and held in Libya for six days in 2011 \u2014 wanted to stand on a Humvee to get a better shot. She was told not to. It was too risky. At the second observation post, Ms. Addario persisted, and ended up climbing a Humvee. A soldier who served as the media coordinator assured a captain that she had, indeed, signed a waiver, and they let her do it. She came down safely, without a scratch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMission \u2014 that little one at least \u2014 accomplished.", "title": "A Reporter\u2019s Mission to the Border Takes Him Backstage With the Troops", "authors": ["Manny Fernandez"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201c \u2018They Were Never Going to Let Me Be President,\u2019 \u201d by Amy Chozick (Sunday Review, April 22):\n\nHillary Clinton\u2019s statement on election night that \u201cthey were never going to let me be president\u201d is not only incorrect but unfortunately finds the former first lady wallowing in self-pity. Who is \u201cthey\u201d?\n\nMrs. Clinton won the popular vote. So even with vicious Republican attacks and James Comey\u2019s whopping errors of judgment, she still received more votes than her opponent in the 2016 election. There\u2019s was no \u201cconspiracy\u201d to keep her from being president.\n\nSimply put, Mrs. Clinton lost because she ran an awful campaign, not even bothering late in the campaign to visit key states needed for an Electoral College victory. Calling some people \u201cdeplorables\u201d is not the mark of an astute politician.\n\nHillary Clinton lost not because she was a woman or the victim of right-wing smears or because of James Comey. The G.O.P. has not won a statewide race here since 2002, and Astorino lost by a decisive margin. Adding to the challenge is a groundswell of enthusiasm among Democratic voters angry over President Trump\u2019s tenure, as well as Mr. Cuomo\u2019s considerable financial edge: He has about $30 million in the bank and more fund-raisers in the offing.\n\nMr. Molinaro\u2019s main challenger for the nomination \u2014 which will be decided at the state Republican convention in May \u2014 is State Senator John A. DeFrancisco, who represents the Syracuse area and has been running a low-key campaign since announcing his candidacy in late January. On Monday, Mr. DeFrancisco \u2014 an outspoken and off-the-cuff critic of Mr. Cuomo in Albany \u2014 said he welcomed Mr. Molinaro\u2019s entrance into the race and the opportunity for \u201ca spirited debate.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnyone who knows me, knows I\u2019m anything but quiet,\u201d Mr. DeFrancisco said in a statement, adding, \u201cNow is the time to fight for the future of our state.
