(Mr. Molinaro\u2019s daughter is autistic.)\n\nMr. Molinaro also signaled his intention to target Mr. Cuomo over the issue of corruption, including the recent conviction of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s former aide and friend, Joseph Percoco, on federal bribery charges. Standing next to Mr. Griffith \u2014 who has also been elected mayor of Tivoli, population 1,100, winning as an independent \u2014 and in front of an adoring crowd, Mr. Molinaro recalled that he had once worked mucking horse stalls in the village, which is surrounded by rich farmland.\n\n\u201cAlbany,\u201d he said, \u201ccould use a little mucking.\u201d", "title": "A Republican With Small-Town Roots Launches Bid for Governor", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Andres said he was struck by the strangeness of the work, which came from a time when American artists weren\u2019t quite free from the traditions of European painting.\n\n\u201cThe painting itself is not what I find moving about it,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s almost the qualities that the viewer brings to it that are most interesting to me. It\u2019s so much about the viewer\u2019s perspective and creating an experience for them. That has a real musical analog.\u201d\n\nAndrew Cyr, the Metropolis Ensemble\u2019s conductor, described Mr. Andres\u2019s concerto as full of \u201ca sense of space and spaciousness that relates to place,\u201d and Ms. Segev praised the way it conjured light and movement \u00e0 la Mussorgsky\u2019s Promenade in \u201cPictures.\u201d\n\n\u201cUpstate Obscura\u201d features Mr. Andres\u2019s deceptively chaotic rhythmic hallmarks, but it also nods to Versailles\u2019 heyday and Baroque ornamentation. Mr. Andres took a book of tunes by Couperin and stretched out mordents, trills and turns until they became their own melodies.\n\nSpeaking in front of Vanderlyn\u2019s panorama, Mr. Andres pointed to three scenes in the painting and explained how they appear in his concerto. Below are edited excerpts from what he said, as well as demo recordings of him at the piano accompanying Ms. Segev in her apartment earlier this week.", "title": "A Room-Size Painting Becomes a Cello Concerto About Versailles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 After months of speculation about whether the Obamas or the Trumps would be invited to the royal wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle next month the answer is finally in: neither.\n\nNeatly sidestepping the issue, Kensington Palace released an opaque statement Tuesday saying that no politicians would be invited to the May 19 wedding at Windsor Castle, not even Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain.\n\n\u201cIt has been decided that an official list of political leaders \u2014 both U.K. and international \u2014 is not required for Prince Harry and Ms. Markle\u2019s wedding,\u201d Kensington Palace said in a statement. \u201cHer Majesty\u2019s Government was consulted on this decision, which was taken by The Royal Household.\u201d\n\nThe lack of \u201can official list\u201d was interpreted by royals watchers to mean that no invitations would be issued to political leaders.", "title": "A Royal Wedding Riddle Is Solved: No Trumps, No Obamas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey are looking for what he calls \u2018loopholes,\u2019 and what we call protections, and trying to close them,\u201d said Wendy Young, the executive director of Kids In Need of Defense, a nonprofit organization that represents young immigrants who come to the country unaccompanied. \u201cUnder this administration, everybody is presenting a fraudulent claim, rather than, \u2018Why is this child here and do they need protection?\u2019\u201d\n\nSo far, at least 81 applicants from the New York City area have been denied or were told they would soon be denied by the immigration agency, according to The Legal Aid Society of New York. In total, more than 1,000 young people across the state, not all of them from Central America, could be affected.\n\nAlthough there are other states that follow a process similar to New York\u2019s, including California, Massachusetts, Maryland and Washington, lawyers believe that New York has seen the most denials.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the last week, the Legal Aid Society said, the immigration agency has also sent a handful of notices to New York-area clients saying they were going to revoke applications that had previously been approved.\n\n\u201cWhen do immigrants get to rely on decisions from U.S.C.I.S.?\u201d asked Eve Stotland, the legal director for The Door, an organization that works with disadvantaged youth in New York. \u201cWhat if the client is naturalized? You spin into a place of arbitrariness and absurdity, and a failure to follow the rule of law.\u201d\n\nJonathan Withington, a spokesman for the agency, said: \u201cU.S.C.I.S. has not issued any new guidance or policy directives regarding the adjudication of S.I.J. petitions. We remain committed to adjudicating each petition individually based on the merits of the case and safeguarding the integrity of our lawful immigration system.\u201d\n\nThe federal law establishing Special Immigrant Juvenile status was first enacted as part of the Immigration Act of 1990 and then expanded in 2008. To obtain it, applicants must first have a ruling from their state\u2019s juvenile court, finding that they have been abused, abandoned or neglected. A judge must also declare the young person dependent on the court, or appoint a caretaker. In the second part of the process, the applicant submits the judge\u2019s order to the immigration agency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Trump administration seems to be narrowly reinterpreting the law, saying that in cases where applicants are over 18, they no longer qualify, because the state court\u2019s authority ends at that age. According to its reasoning in one denial letter provided to The Times, \u201conce a person attains the age of 18, the family courts lack jurisdiction over the person\u2019s custody.\u201d\n\nThose over 18 can be appointed guardians, however, which the immigration agency now does not consider the same as custody. Lawyers say that\u2019s semantics, since in state law, guardianship and custody have equal rights and responsibilities.\n\n\u201cNothing in the federal statutes has changed; only the interpretation has changed,\u201d Beth Krause, the supervising attorney for the Immigrant Youth Project at The Legal Aid Society of New York, said. \u201cAnd now, U.S.C.I.S. is interpreting this in a way to cut out a very large portion of kids who, until the past couple of weeks, had gotten these grants under the same facts.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a bad faith argument,\u201d said Rebecca McBride, a lawyer at Atlas: DIY, a nonprofit organization helping immigrant youth in Brooklyn, who represents several people with special immigrant status.\n\nThe immigration agency declined to explain the change, saying in an email response, \u201cA petitioner must submit a court order issued by a juvenile court that contains specific determinations made under relevant state law.\u201d It referred to a policy manual rewritten in October 2016. The agency pointed to the dramatic increase in SIJ applications in recent years, with 11,335 approved applications in 2017 compared with 1,590 in 2010, with the greatest increase coming after the surge of Central American minors coming to the U.S. in 2014.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nConsider the case of J., a shy young man, now 22, from Burkina Faso. He went to family court in New York in late 2016 when he was 20, and the court granted him an order that enabled him to apply to the immigration agency. He received two requests for more information before being denied because of his age several weeks ago.\u201cAt the moment of application, if they had this issue about 18 years old, why would they allow me to continue this if that\u2019s what they thought?\u201d J. said, in French, with his lawyer at The Door. \u201cWhy would they let this whole family court thing happen? Why would they allow this to advance to this point and now decide?\u201dHe and other young immigrants interviewed asked to be identified only by their first initial or first name because of fear of repercussions from the government.\n\nJ.\u2019s lawyer at The Door is appealing the denial.\n\nY., another client of The Door, came to the United States in August 2016, and at the end of that year, when she was 20, obtained a special findings order from the New York family court. She said she had also been threatened with rape by a gang in Honduras because she was a lesbian. That would seem, her lawyer said, to make it \u201cin the best interests of the child\u201d not to send her back \u2014 another part of the law.\n\nY. was denied, but her younger brother, A., who had come to the United States in 2015 and also applied when he was over 18, was approved in February 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe government wants to pick and choose who is and isn\u2019t a child, but in fact it\u2019s a matter of law,\u201d Ms. Stotland said.\n\nLegal organizations say they first started seeing signs that the government was holding up the special immigrant applications in the later years of the Obama administration, but the trend became more pronounced in the spring of 2017, when the agency started asking for more information about applications.\n\nRomain, 23, was 4 years old when his parents were murdered in Congo, in the house where he was sleeping. His uncle took him to Burkina Faso, and 14 years later sent him to the United States to study. Then the uncle cut all ties with him, Romain says, leaving him in New York, alone, broke and homeless.\n\nRomain came on a student visa, but without money to pay for college, it lapsed. He landed in a homeless shelter for boys.\n\nIn 2015, when Romain was 20, he applied for special immigrant status with the help of Ms. McBride at Atlas: DIY. A family court in Brooklyn found that he fit the criteria that year, but upon further review, the federal immigration agency caught a discrepancy they believed was fraud. Romain\u2019s uncle had filled out his student visa application incorrectly, saying the young man\u2019s parents were alive, so the application was initially denied.\n\nThat complicated the appeal process, but Ms. McBride and Romain persisted, finding sufficient evidence of his parents\u2019 death, which the government eventually believed. But in Spring 2017, Ms. McBride said, the agency said that death was not akin to abandonment. And, finally, this winter, the agency added the over-18 stipulation to its notice of intent to deny Romain\u2019s application. She submitted an appeal, and they are waiting.\n\n\u201cI am extremely frustrated, I\u2019m confused,\u201d Romain said, \u201cbut I am always thinking that if the interpretation of those rules can be changed today, the same interpretation can be changed tomorrow \u2014 for the better.\u201d", "title": "A Rule Is Changed for Young Immigrants, and Green Card Hopes Fade", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "He came to visit in late spring. Without the thousand miles of telephone static between us, I couldn\u2019t hide my condition. At a baseball game, my head began to rock back and forth. The field dissolved into color. My dad, who had never seen me during an episode, looked at me as though I were a wounded animal he had no way of saving.\n\nFrom the time I started running competitively in middle school, my dad had been the one to forecast race day weather, calculate my workout splits, and map out courses so he could cheer for me as many times as possible. Long-distance running was our love language. What would we talk about if not about mileage and routes and new success? Would he still love me the same?\n\nFor the remainder of spring, when my coach ordered me to practice, I slogged through laps on the track until the rust-orange lanes dissipated into a blurry haze. To run again would mean the neurological episodes had been a fluke, some kind of spell I could break. Again and again, I collapsed onto the interior of the field. Eventually, my symptoms pervasive, I made a difficult decision to quit the team, leaving behind a dream and an identity that I had cultivated since I was a young girl.\n\nOn the walk to my apartment from the track, I called home. \u201cI quit, Dad,\u201d I said. I held my breath. I hadn\u2019t ever quit a race, not for sickness, not for shin splints, and not for an overgrowth of bone that burst through my big toe during my junior year of high school, for which I held off surgery until after the State Meet.\n\nHe was silent on the other side of the line for a moment. \u201cI\u2019m glad, bug. We\u2019ve got to get you healthy.\u201d\n\nIllness is a run with no known distance, an unseen finish line. In the seven years since quitting the team, my dad and I have traded workout splits for vitals and race strategies for medication plans. Instead of analyzing course maps, my dad studies the results of my EEG recordings. He sits with me in waiting rooms before big appointments, and once composed math problems for me during a hospital stay as if prescribing a set of intervals.\n\nDespite staying twice in the testing ward of the hospital for three days of continuous monitoring, and despite visiting neurologists and other specialists for years, I still remain without a clear diagnosis. My charts, when I leave my neurologist\u2019s office, describe my condition as \u201cSeizure Disorder, Migraine Variant, and Transient Alteration of Awareness.\u201d", "title": "A Runner\u2019s Mysterious Illness, With Her Dad at Her Side", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Step out onto the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and you are confronted by a towering figure, somewhat humanoid but with a ferocious face that looks like a primate mask. She-He-It-They visually dwarfs the jagged Manhattan skyline and the treetops in Central Park. Kneeling before this behemoth is a second figure, bowing in supplication or prayer, with long cartoonish human hands and a scraggly tail emerging from its shiny black drapery.\n\nWelcome to Huma Bhabha\u2019s \u201cWe Come in Peace,\u201d a spare and unsettling sculptural installation for the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Roof Garden Commission, which opens on Tuesday and runs through Oct. 28. While the figures aren\u2019t meant to be scary, in at least one way they can be interpreted as a warning sign. The title harks back to science fiction, the line an alien uttered to a human in the 1951 movie \u201cThe Day the Earth Stood Still\u201d \u2014 but it ripples with other associations: colonization, invasion, imperialism or missionaries and other foreigners whose intentions were not always innocent.\n\nMs. Bhabha, 56, who was born in Karachi, Pakistan, and educated at the Rhode Island School of Design and Columbia University (she lives in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.), is a smart choice for the rooftop commission. Working in figurative sculpture \u2014 or some version of it \u2014 she provides a cross-cultural approach that is needed particularly at this moment, making connections among histories, languages and civilizations, and our shared present and future. Her work has been included in large international exhibitions, including \u201cAll the World\u2019s Futures\u201d at the Venice Biennale in 2015.\n\nUnlike recent years and other commissions, where the Met roof felt like a playground or an obstacle course, Ms. Bhabha\u2019s project is shockingly, refreshingly, simple. There are only two sculptures, arranged in a kind of dialogue with the open-air roof serving, as Ms. Bhabha describes it in the accompanying catalog, as a kind of stage \u2014 an elegant play on the traditional pedestals on which sculptures were customarily displayed.", "title": "A Sci-Fi Showdown at the Met Museum\u2019s Rooftop Garden", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhat Sleeping With Married Men Taught Me,\u201d by Karin Jones (Modern Love column, Sunday Styles, April 8): It is challenging for couples of all ages and stages in life (married or not) to keep the sizzle in their sex lives.\n\nAs for hormones and menopause, I have treated many women in their 70s and 80s whose sex lives were more active and satisfying than those of women in their 30s and 40s. If problems arise, topics including sexual desire, frequency, pornography, a lack of desire and open marriage need to be discussed openly and honestly.\n\nEfforts to get to the root of the problem, including seeing a qualified therapist, should be a priority before making the decision to have a secret life.\n\nBEATTY COHAN, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer, a psychotherapist and sex therapist, is the author of \u201cFor Better, for Worse, Forever: Discover the Path to Lasting Love.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A Secret Sex Life?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Questions about whether the American military, under the Trump administration, is seeking to obscure the expanding scope of operations in Africa surfaced last month when it was revealed that the United States had carried out four airstrikes in Libya between September and January that the military\u2019s Africa Command had failed to disclose at the time.\n\nSoon after, the military acknowledged for the first time that Green Berets working with Nigerien forces had killed 11 Islamic State militants in a multiday firefight in December. No American or Nigerien forces were harmed in the December gun battle.\n\nBut the combat \u2014 along with at least 10 other previously unreported attacks on American troops in West Africa between 2015 and 2017 \u2014 underscored the fact that the deadly ambush in Niger was not an isolated episode. Nigerien forces and their American advisers are preparing other major operations to clear out militants, military officials say.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s essential that the American public is aware of, engaged in, and decides whether or not to support American military operations in countries around the world, including Niger,\u201d said Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, who visited Niger with four other senators this month.\n\nSix months after the fatal attack, which took place outside the village of Tongo Tongo near the Mali border, the Trump administration stands at a critical crossroad in the military\u2019s global counterterrorism campaign.\n\nOne path would push ahead with President Trump\u2019s campaign vow to defeat the Islamic State and other violent extremist organizations, not just in Iraq and Syria, but worldwide. The other would be to pull out and leave more of the fighting to allies, as Mr. Trump said he wants to do in Syria, possibly ceding hard-fought ground to militants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring a counterterrorism exercise this past week in north-central Niger that drew nearly 2,000 military personnel from 20 African and Western countries, many officers voiced concerns that America\u2019s commitment in West Africa could fall victim to the latter impulse.", "title": "A Shadowy War\u2019s Newest Front: A Drone Base Rising From Saharan Dust", "authors": ["Eric Schmitt"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Galaxy have won a record five M.L.S. Cups, including three in four years from 2011 to 2014, when they were led by high-profile, and highly paid, signings like David Beckham, Robbie Keane and Landon Donovan. That star-centered system has been the Galaxy\u2019s calling card and winning business model, and after missing the postseason in 2017, the team has doubled down on it, signing Zlatan Ibrahimovic, a swaggering Swedish striker with the crowd-pleasing habits of scoring stunning goals and talking about himself in the third person.\n\nTo Major League Soccer\u2019s delight, Ibrahimovic\u2019s debut \u2014 in Los Angeles against L.A.F.C. last month \u2014 ended with his scoring two goals in a 4-3 thriller, delivering some welcome buzz for the league in a rivalry that had been preemptively called El Tr\u00e1fico.\n\nYet if the Galaxy\u2019s model is the exemplar of M.L.S. 2.0 \u2014 imported headliners, a suburban soccer-specific stadium and success \u2014 then L.A.F.C. is already showing what its next generation of fan engagement, stadiums and media relationships might look like.\n\nBecause beneath the gleam and glimmer of L.A.F.C.\u2019s new home \u2014 the pristine field, the silver roof that shades row after row of gray seats and the theatrical nature of seemingly everything the club does online \u2014 is something more fundamental: a well-run team and a well-executed plan.\n\nL.A.F.C., after all, was born from the ashes of Chivas USA, an earlier Los Angeles M.L.S. club with a manufactured Mexican identity that folded in 2014 after years of lackluster play, dwindling attendance and lost opportunity.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cChivas was effectively a failed expansion in L.A.,\u201d said Larry Berg, L.A.F.C.\u2019s lead managing owner. More than anything else, Berg said, that experiment provided a blueprint for what not to do.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead, from the awarding of the expansion team in 2014 until its on-field league debut in March, L.A.F.C. undertook an expansive branding effort to try to position itself as belonging to the city of Los Angeles specifically, and to Angelenos generally. Street by street, block by block, one by one is a mantra repeated endlessly by those around the team and on its social media accounts, and the methodical approach has proved even more successful than the founders had hoped.\n\nBefore the team ever kicked a ball, L.A.F.C. had sold 17,500 season tickets, and club officials project that Banc of California Stadium \u2014 in the heart of south Los Angeles, adjacent to the famed Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, home to Southern California football and two Summer Olympics \u2014 will be sold out for every match this season.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe implicit, and sometimes explicit, message is that the Galaxy aren\u2019t of Los Angeles, and play in the faraway land of Carson. L.A.F.C fans even have a hashtag (#carsongalaxy) they use on social media to mock the Galaxy, much as N.Y.C.F.C. and its fans needle the Red Bulls for claiming to represent New York while playing their home games in New Jersey.\n\nSo far, the team\u2019s play on the field has been both exciting and, at times, infuriating. Opening the season on the road as finishing touches were put on its new home, L.A.F.C. has won four of its first six games, scoring goals by the bucketful but conceding almost as many, as the humbling 4-3 loss to the Galaxy and a 5-0 thrashing in Atlanta a week later illustrated.\n\nStill, eschewing the outdated stereotype of M.L.S. as a retirement league for well-known Europeans, Coach Bob Bradley and General Manager John Thorrington have built a fan-friendly and surprisingly formidable (at least up front) team. Carlos Vela, a 29-year-old Mexican forward, arrived with extensive experience in the Premier League and Spain\u2019s La Liga, and Diego Rossi, a 20-year-old from Uruguay, quickly opened eyes inside the league and out.\n\nFans who want to watch them but can\u2019t get into the stadium will not find English-language L.A.F.C. matches on a free over-the-air channel or a regional sports network, but somewhere more novel: YouTube\u2019s streaming cable replacement, YouTube TV. The decision to seek out the unusual arrangement, which also includes a jersey sponsorship, was a purposeful effort to explore a nontraditional solution.\n\n\u201cI think in a world where the M.L.S. local rights aren\u2019t quite where they are in other leagues, it allows you to experiment a little bit more,\u201d Berg said.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nBut while Major League Soccer hopes L.A.F.C. and the Galaxy grow into formidable rivals, their biggest competition remains international: the cross-border appeal of Mexico\u2019s top soccer league, Liga MX, in the heavily Latino Los Angeles market. That was the original conceit behind the failed Chivas USA experiment \u2014 to create a team with a Mexican identity to attract Mexican fans \u2014 but the target audience dismissed it, and Galaxy fans already had a team.\n\nBanc of California Stadium is the latest attempt to draw those fans in for another look, to try to win them over with a Mexican striker, an attack that has produced a few memorable goals and some stardust in the owners\u2019 box. The timing of the team\u2019s debut hasn\u2019t hurt, either: The Galaxy finished last in the league standings last season, missing the playoffs for the first time since 2008.\n\nAt a ribbon cutting for the stadium last week, the team\u2019s sky-high expectations were on display when Johnson got his turn at the microphone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJust like we were able to turn the Lakers around into a championship team,\u201d he said, \u201cwe\u2019re going to do the same thing with this great soccer team, L.A.F.C. We will be champions one day.\u201d\n\n", "title": "A Shiny New Front in the Battle for L.A.\u2019s Soccer Soul", "authors": ["Kevin Draper"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Set among the questionable new-builds and Victorian rowhouses of East London\u2019s once gritty, now desirable Shoreditch neighborhood, the facade of the recently opened Blue Mountain School is impossible to miss. The six-level brick townhouse, on the corner of Redchurch and Chance Streets, has been painted in a sleek and surprising silver. Inside, the multipurpose space defies easy categorization.\n\nAn impeccably curated showcase of exquisite garments, furniture and objects \u2014 of which only a small selection is for sale \u2014 this interdisciplinary project also includes an exhibition space, a kitchen with a nightly dinner menu and a listening room that will feature a handpicked music library and monthly music-inspired events. The building\u2019s interior is also an experience unto itself, capturing the ambitious creative vision of Blue Mountain School\u2019s founder, James Brown, and his partner, Christie Fels.\n\nThe duo became known as the team behind the upmarket, craft-focused fashion boutique Hostem, which originally occupied the Redchurch Street site before closing, in 2016, to make way for this new endeavor. Having grown weary of the traditional retail model, Brown and Fels wanted to offer their clients something more interesting: an experiential space that prioritizes culture over commerce. Over the course of two years, the building was reimagined from the ground up in collaboration with the architecture firm 6a.\n\nNow, the only real traces of the original retail space live on in the Hostem Archive, a rotating display of clothing, ceramics and artwork presented across the double-height basement and the ground floor of Blue Mountain School. Though most of the items here are for sale, the Archive feels less like a store and more like a secret library of rare goods meant to be examined and admired. \u201cThis is not about shopping,\u201d explains Fels, \u201cBut providing a platform for artists with integrity, who take their craft to its purist form and create meaningful, enduring work.\u201d Among the handful of designers with work on display are the Mallorca-based ceramist Dora Alzamora Good, who makes richly textured stoneware vessels, and the Texan-born artist Amy Revier, known for her sculptural, hand-woven clothing.", "title": "A Shrine to Craftsmanship Inside a Silver London Townhouse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "That lack of public information about the cyber-preparedness of businesses is all the more striking given the relative severity of the threat. More than half the adult population of the United States was affected by the breach of Equifax last year.\n\nUnfortunately, we have become inured to these hacks. Our response to breaches has become routine: more calls for regulation, followed by congressional hearings and failed regulatory proposals. Consumers go about their lives, numbed by the frequency and the lack of consequences. Meanwhile, the hacks get worse.\n\nThis cycle stems in part from a lack of information about the security practices of businesses. But forcing companies to explain how they are keeping the bad guys out would only help the bad guys.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe simple grading system used by restaurant regulators can and should be a model to inform the public about the digital security of businesses that store sensitive consumer data. A letter grade is a crude measure to assess a complex issue like cybersecurity to be sure, but what the metric lacks in nuance it makes up for with brute force.\n\nCurrent measures to assess cyber-preparedness are either not compulsory or too complex. The federal government\u2019s National Institute of Standards and Technology framework is widely respected, but it\u2019s voluntary, underused and not easily digestible for the average consumer. Only seven Fortune 500 companies mentioned it in their annual filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission last year, and only one said it had adopted it.\n\nMSCI \u2014 an index provider and independent research firm for institutional investors \u2014 ranks companies on cybersecurity. More than a year before Equifax\u2019s breach was revealed, MSCI scored Equifax a 0 out of 10 on privacy and data security. As prescient as it was, consumers would have had difficulty absorbing such a rating, which is just one of several components that MSCI uses to arrive at an environmental, social and governance, or E.S.G., rating of overall corporate citizenship.\n\nA new grading system should start with the basics: Are companies on top of data security, and if hacked, do they know how to reduce the impact?\n\nEach year, the Ponemon Institute, an independent research group, and IBM look at the cost of the average data security breach, as well as the average cost of each piece of data compromised. In 2017, the average cost of a data breach in the United States was $7.35 million, or $141 per record compromised. But if a company has an incident response team, uses encryption, trains its employees, has a business continuity program and monitors cyber-threat intelligence, that reduces the cost of the average data breach by nearly 47 percent. Using these five factors \u2014 weighed for their impact of cost reduction \u2014 is a simple starting point.\n\nThere are plenty of details to be worked out about a cybersecurity grading system. But the one nonnegotiable aspect would be that, once assigned, letter grades must be made highly accessible to the public. Companies should be required to display their grades prominently at their physical locations, on their websites, on certain documents (mortgage applications, for example) and on credit card readers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA grading system would not solve every cybersecurity problem, nor prevent every breach. But our sad state of affairs \u2014 in which we are equal parts fearful, apathetic and ignorant about digital security \u2014 must change. Providing clearer information to the public is the most productive next step we can take.", "title": "A Simple Proposal to Help Fix Corporate America\u2019s Cybersecurity Problem", "authors": ["Craig A. Newman", "Another View"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Sexton was New York University\u2019s president for 14 years, until he retired in 2015; Mr. Lupo has been cutting his hair since shortly after he joined the law school faculty in 1981. \u201cOne out of every three times I run into a faculty member there,\u201d Mr. Sexton said. \u201cI\u2019ve also reunited with former students through the accident of running into them.\u201d\n\nThe staff has a long history of cutting hair in the neighborhood, though not all of it at Salon G: Ms. Bermudez, 67, began working at a salon on Washington Place in 1992, before joining Mr. Ianniciello 13 years ago. \u201cIt was a different place back then,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor one thing, the school didn\u2019t always play such a big role in the neighborhood. Mr. Lupo, 65, started working at Frank\u2019s Barber Shop one street over, on Thompson, in 1972 as a 19-year-old. That was before N.Y.U.\u2019s aggressive expansion in the Village. \u201cSeventy percent of my customers were Italian,\u201d he said. \u201cNow 60 percent are N.Y.U.\u201d\n\nEven so, as Mr. Sexton pointed out, \u201cJoe\u2019s still the newcomer.\u201d Mr. Lupo started here in 2015, after Frank\u2019s was sold, and he brought many clients with him. \u201cI\u2019m a Village person,\u201d Mr. Sexton said, explaining why he switched to Salon G. \u201cI care about the neighborhood people, like Giovanni and Joe. I offered to buy his barber chair from Frank\u2019s and install it here. But he said no.\u201d\n\nMr. Ianniciello, who opened the salon in 1999, came to New York from Italy, and so did Mr. Lupo; the rest of the staff are native New Yorkers. It\u2019s an amiable, boisterous crew. For many, coming to Salon G is like visiting family.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
