Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nElizabeth DeLeon, 56, works at NYU Langone Medical Center and has been getting her hair styled by Ms. Bermudez for more than two decades. \u201cMaria is family to me \u2014 she\u2019s the only one who touches my hair,\u201d she said. \u201cMy daughter who\u2019s at N.Y.U. goes to her too.\u201d\n\nMr. Sexton also feels a connection that goes beyond the usual commercial acquaintanceship. \u201cJoe and I are so beyond small talk,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ve gone through our families changing, kids growing up, even the sudden death of my wife. I tell him that when I can\u2019t move around anymore, he\u2019s going to have to come to my apartment to cut my hair.\u201d\n\nMr. Sexton isn\u2019t the first N.Y.U. president that Mr. Lupo has known professionally. His predecessors, John Brademas and Jay Oliva, both patronized Frank\u2019s. So when Mr. Sexton stepped down at the end of 2015, Mr. Lupo had a thought.\n\n\u201cHe asked me,\u201d Mr. Sexton recalled, \u201c \u2018Is there any chance of getting your replacement to come in for a cut so we can keep the tradition going?\u2019 I told him, \u2018You obviously haven\u2019t seen a picture of Andrew Hamilton.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe then pulled up a photo of the nearly bald Hamilton on his iPad to show Mr. Lupo. \u201cYou aren\u2019t gonna get rich cutting his hair.\u201d", "title": "A Smart Haircut", "authors": ["Bill Vourvoulias", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "D.B.: How did the process help you to think differently about global warming?\n\nP.H.: We constantly hear that global warming is an energy problem, that the solutions are solar, wind and electric vehicles. For the individual, that message sounds like I hope \u201cthey\u201d do it. There\u2019s a belief that there\u2019re only a few things individuals can do beyond recycling, riding a bike and eating less meat. In fact, there\u2019s an extraordinary diversity of solutions to global warming that are at hand, being implemented and scaling. I don\u2019t think people, politicians and businesspeople know that. Clean energy is the crucial solution to be sure, but there\u2019s much more we can do.\n\nD.B.: Like what?\n\nP.H.: Two of the top four solutions individuals can practice every day. No. 3 is reduced food waste, which particularly applies to America, where we waste 133 billion pounds of food a year \u2014 close to a third of the food supply. That is a conservative estimate. In our model we didn\u2019t include the methane emissions caused by landfilling our food because we couldn\u2019t get the data \u2014 and methane is 28 to 36 times more powerful in global warming potential than carbon dioxide.\n\nThe No. 4 solution is a plant-rich diet. This means reducing overconsumption of protein to a healthy level \u2014 about 50 to 55 grams a day instead of 90 to 100 or more, and shifting a proportion of that reduced intake to plant proteins. It doesn\u2019t mean being a vegan or vegetarian; it means more plants. You choose which diet you want. Levels of protein that are medically healthier for you are healthier for the planet and atmosphere, too.\n\nD.B.: Can you talk about the No. 1 solution? I was surprised to see that it was \u201c\u2018refrigerant management.\u201d\n\nP.H.: We were, too. The hydrochlorofluorocarbon gases (HFCs) used in refrigerants that replaced chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), which were destroying the ozone layer, are anywhere from 146 to 12,500 times more powerful than carbon dioxide in their global warming potential. Poorly maintained air-conditioners and refrigerators leak HFCs. When air-conditioners and refrigerators are disposed of or recycled, the refrigerants can escape into the air. We do a pretty good job preventing this in the United States, and the European Union does even better, but in Asia and Africa, HFCs are allowed to escape and have a huge impact.\n\nD.B.: What else caught you by surprise?\n\nP.H.: Over all, we were surprised that the largest sector was food. Agriculture, food waste and diet, food production and distribution of food, holistic grazing. We didn\u2019t see that coming. It\u2019s larger than the electrical generation sector.\n\nAnd the overall ranking of the solutions shocked us. If you had asked every person at COP21 in Paris (us included) to name the top 10 solutions in any order, I don\u2019t believe anyone would have gotten it even close. That is still true. After 50 years of global warming being in the public sphere, we didn\u2019t know the top solutions to reversing it. And there\u2019s a reason: We never measured and modeled the top solutions. Instead, sincere, well-meaning people profess their beliefs. You have a prominent scientist asserting that if we don\u2019t go all in with nuclear power, we\u2019re toast. Vastly untrue. You have journalists assuring us that if we go 100 percent solar, we\u2019ll stabilize emissions. That\u2019s a scientific howler, too. People who are earnestly guiding us to climatic stability have not done the math. That\u2019s all we do at Project Drawdown: math.", "title": "Opinion | A Smorgasbord of Solutions for Global Warming", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "In the months before Ms. Park was impeached, millions of South Koreans demonstrated in Seoul calling for her ouster, in the biggest popular uprising since protests in 1987 officially ended military dictatorship. Three decades later, government-business collusion had become the nemesis big enough to bring the populace into the streets.\n\n\u201cChaebol are accomplices!\u201d protesters chanted.\n\nMany South Koreans still speak proudly of Samsung, Hyundai and other chaebol, whose export-driven growth helped lift the country out of the poverty that followed the Korean War. But over the years, frustration has grown with the chaebol, which are widely accused of stifling smaller businesses as well as doing corrupt deals with government officials.\n\nMs. Park was convicted on Friday of collecting or demanding $22 million from three chaebol businesses, including Samsung. She was also found guilty of pressuring 18 chaebol companies into donating $72 million to two foundations controlled by Choi Soon-sil, a longtime friend and confidant of the president.\n\nAhn Jin-geol, a leader of People\u2019s Solidarity for Participatory Democracy, an anticorruption watchdog, said Ms. Park\u2019s downfall spoke well for South Korea\u2019s still-young democracy.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe were ashamed that this kind of corruption still happened,\u201d Mr. Ahn said. \u201cBut we South Koreans peacefully unseated a sitting president for corruption and had her convicted in a court of law. How many countries in the world can do that?\u201d\n\nBut if Ms. Park\u2019s dramatic ouster reflected a vibrant democracy at work, the scandal also unveiled a deeply flawed political system.\n\nFor decades, the government has nurtured the chaebol with favors like tax benefits and a buy-Korea policy. In return, past presidents often treated them like personal ATMs, critics say. If they did not oblige, they say, the businesses feared that the government would retaliate through the tax authorities, government regulators and prosecutors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe donations to Ms. Choi\u2019s foundations, nominally set up to promote sports and culture, seemed yet another example of this phenomenon. The Seoul district court that convicted Ms. Park ruled that she had coerced chaebol into donating to the foundations. The sums were determined according to the companies\u2019 size, according to the ruling, with Samsung contributing the most: $19 million.\n\nMs. Park also solicited $6.5 million in bribes from the hotel chain and shopping mall giant Lotte, the court found. In return, Lotte\u2019s chairman, Shin Dong-bin, wanted government help in regaining a license to run lucrative duty-free shops, the court said. In February, Mr. Shin was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on bribery charges.\n\n\u201cThe ruling on Park Geun-hye confirms a pattern we have seen repeatedly: The politician seeks financial gains through blackmailing chaebol, and chaebol oblige so they can win government favors to solve their own problems,\u201d said Chung Sun-sup, editor of a website that monitors the conglomerates.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnother pattern also held true: As in past corruption scandals, few corporate chiefs implicated in Ms. Park\u2019s and Ms. Choi\u2019s dealings seem likely to spend much time behind bars.\n\nSamsung\u2019s de facto leader, Lee Jae-yong, the third-generation scion of the conglomerate\u2019s founding family, is the latest case in point, critics say.\n\nIn August, Mr. Lee was sentenced to five years in prison for giving $6.7 million in bribes to Ms. Choi and Ms. Park, with a court finding that he had embezzled the sum from Samsung\u2019s coffers. Under South Korean law, a businessman convicted of embezzling more than $4.7 million must be sentenced to at least five years in prison. What is more, that term \u2014 like any prison term of more than three years \u2014 cannot be suspended by a judge.\n\nNevertheless, Mr. Lee went free in February. An appeals court ruled that the amount of bribes he had offered to Ms. Park totaled $3.3 million \u2014 less than half the sum originally alleged, and below the $4.7 million threshold requiring a five-year sentence. The court reduced Mr. Lee\u2019s sentence to two and a half years in prison, and suspended it.\n\nPhoto\n\n(The district court that sentenced Ms. Park disagreed with the appeals court, ruling that Mr. Lee had, indeed, offered $6.7 million in bribes \u2014 a finding that could put him in new jeopardy as the Supreme Court considers his case. Mr. Lee denies having committed bribery, maintaining that he never sought favors from Ms. Park in return for the money he said Samsung was forced to donate.)\n\nKim Jin-baek, a professor at Chung-Ang University, a business school in Seoul, said the power of Samsung and other chaebol is so pervasive that some government officials will do them favors without a direct quid pro quo arrangement, believing that \u201cSamsung won\u2019t forget and one day will reward them.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProfessor Kim said the corruption between chaebol and the government would not end as long as chaebol\u2019s founding families continued to exert far more influence over their empires than their shares warrant.\n\nA typical chaebol family owns just a small percentage of the conglomerate\u2019s shares but rules it like a fief through a maze of cross-share holdings, installing executives who Professor Kim said work for the family, \u201cnot for the interest of shareholders in general.\u201d\n\nMost chaebol scandals have originated in the families\u2019 dubious attempts to ensure that the next generation inherits control, such as arranging for scions to buy shares of unlisted subsidiaries at reduced prices.\n\nSuch shady practices make the chaebol easy prey for officials seeking bribes, analysts said.\n\nTime and again, judges overseeing corruption trials have treated chaebol more as victims than as willing accomplices.\n\nOn Friday, the Seoul court did not accept prosecutors\u2019 argument that Mr. Lee had provided or promised as much as $40 million in bribes to Ms. Park in exchange for government support for a merger of two Samsung subsidiaries. That merger strengthened Mr. Lee\u2019s grip on Samsung Electronics, the world\u2019s largest maker of smartphones and the conglomerate\u2019s crown jewel.\n\nWith the economy heavily dependent on chaebol \u2014 Samsung alone generates revenues equivalent to one-fifth of South Korea\u2019s gross national product \u2014 some South Koreans are wary of disrupting them too much. They credit the controlling families with making daring investment decisions that were possible only because of their unchallenged management control. That strategy has helped Samsung edge out rivals, analysts say.\n\nPresident Moon Jae-in, who succeeded Ms. Park in May, is pushing for bills that would strengthen the rights of minority shareholders at chaebol and make it harder for their chairmen to enrich their children through dubious business deals. But his party lacks a majority in Parliament, where a pro-business lobby is strong, and the diplomacy surrounding North Korea has been a higher priority for the president.\n\n\u201cThe real, hidden power in our country remains chaebol,\u201d said Mr. Ahn.", "title": "A South Korean President Is Jailed for Graft, but Few Expect Major Change", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "It is easy to miss whitlow grass in bloom; the mature plant can hide under a quarter with room to spare. But what whitlow grass lacks in size, it makes up for in sheer abundance. There are often hundreds if not thousands of blooming plants in just a few square feet of turf, but most people never notice them. In fact, it is easy to miss this tiny plant\u2019s entire blooming season; by the time most people even consider looking for local spring wildflowers, whitlow grass has come and gone.\n\nWhitlow grass blooms in the poorest of soils \u2014 look for it where cultivated plants have had trouble establishing. In fact, failed lawns are often an excellent place to start searching. The plant (it\u2019s not actually a true grass) seems to prefer soils which have been amended in the past, but which remain moderately moist. Whitlow grass is also almost always found in full sun, which is a little surprising considering its minute size. Locations such as the islands in shopping mall parking lots, the shoulders of highway entrance ramps and the worn areas of schoolyards provide near perfect conditions. Though these areas are frequently mowed, the plants thrive below the blades. Whitlow grass often matures at under two inches tall, and lawn mowers simply eliminate the competition.\n\nLike all of its mustard-family relatives, the flowers of Draba verna (also Erophila verna) have four petals. In Whitlow grass, a notch in the center of each one is often so deep, a quick look gives the impression of a flower with 8 petals. With flowers that measure a fraction of an inch wide this mistake is understandable, but leads to misidentification.\n\nEven during a spring as cold as this one, whitlow grass wastes no time flowering. The process culminates just days after soil temperatures consistently rise above freezing. Whitlow grass\u2019s mass flowering gives the impression of frost over a swath of low growing plants, or sometimes as a peculiar thin layer of fog at ground level. The flowers and minute leaves of this species are best appreciated while lying on your belly. For those who appreciate their first whiff of damp spring soil up close, or who can\u2019t wait to wash the first grass stains from their pants\u2019 knees, whitlow grass provides ample opportunity.", "title": "A Spring Frost? Or Are Those Flowers?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Today, Mr. Moore and K2 Intelligence are the ones under scrutiny. After activists learned of his ties, they filed a lawsuit in London against him and the firm\u2019s British affiliate, charging that their personal information had been illegally taken during the operation. Mr. Moore has been pilloried in press accounts of the episode as a duplicitous spy for hire. Public health advocates who embraced him as an ally feel betrayed.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe said I had given him a purpose in his life,\u201d said one of the activists, Laurie Kazan-Allen. \u201cI bought it all. I bought the store.\u201d\n\nThe corporate intelligence business has boomed into a billion-dollar industry that provides companies, lawyers and Wall Street firms with due diligence inquiries, \u201cstrategic\u201d information and investigations into potential business partners as well as adversaries. K2 Intelligence, started in 2009 by Jules Kroll, a man regarded as the father of corporate intelligence, and one of his sons, Jeremy, is one of the industry\u2019s best-known companies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut of late, attention has focused on the unsavory tactics some firms use to gather information. Last year, it emerged that the producer Harvey Weinstein had hired four investigative firms, including K2 Intelligence, to dig up information about women who accused him of sexual misconduct. One of those companies, Black Cube, had an operative pose as a women\u2019s rights advocate to try to win the confidence of one of his accusers.\n\nMr. Moore, who has denied any wrongdoing, insisted in recent interviews and in court papers that he had become a double agent not long after getting his assignment from K2 Intelligence and had secretly worked to help anti-asbestos advocates. His self-appointed mission: to expose the person he believed was behind the firm\u2019s operation, a Kazakh oligarch with interests in asbestos mines in Kazakhstan and Russia.\n\n\u201cI took huge personal risks and put my security and my family\u2019s security on the line,\u201d said Mr. Moore, who has cropped hair and a long, narrow face. \u201cI was utterly motivated by what I saw.\u201d\n\nThe asbestos case poses a potential minefield for K2 Intelligence. Several private investigators said they would not have an operative assume a fake identity or work for an industry selling a product as dangerous as asbestos. Such ethical issues aside, having an operative publicly go rogue is not the best advertisement for an investigative firm.\n\nIn its filings in the London lawsuit, K2 Intelligence has also denied any wrongdoing and maintains that its asbestos-related investigation was legitimate and used reasonable measures.\n\n\u201cThe matters and methods of investigative work undertaken by K2 Intelligence employees are assessed and evaluated regionally as appropriate,\u201d the company said in a statement. \u201cIt is our practice to maintain the highest ethical standards at all times and to comply with the laws of the jurisdictions in which we operate.\u201d\n\nCiting the active litigation, K2 Intelligence declined to make executives available for interviews, and the company did not respond to written questions from The New York Times. A lawyer for the firm urged Mr. Moore not to speak with a Times reporter, an email shows.\n\n\u201cIt would be in all our interests for you not to engage,\u201d the lawyer, Dan Morrison, wrote in an email. \u201cThat is the approach that K2 will take and I hope you will agree that this is the correct approach.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMaking \u2018Mischief\u2019\n\nMr. Moore\u2019s curious life as a corporate operative started unexpectedly on a British beach in 2007 when he bumped into an old television acquaintance. The friend had since gone to work for Kroll Inc., a major corporate intelligence firm, and offered to make an introduction for him.\n\nTwo years earlier, Mr. Moore had lost his job as head of television comedy at a production company. After a career of orchestrating pranks, he had hit a creative wall. \u201cI thought I had lost my way,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Moore eventually decided that being a private investigator would pay more than gardening. And over the next few years, he got sporadic assignments on due diligence and fraud investigations from Kroll, started in 1972 by the senior Mr. Kroll, who later sold it.\n\nOn some cases, Mr. Moore, who had dabbled in journalism before his comedy career, posed as a reporter. He also once disguised himself as a deliveryman with a large floral bouquet to get into a mansion owned by a Russian oligarch. Mr. Moore, who was eager to get back into television, saw cases as possible fodder for documentaries.\n\n\u201cI found the work fun,\u201d he said. \u201cI enjoyed the mischief.\u201d\n\nIn late 2011, he also started working as a contractor for K2 Intelligence. And after a few small jobs, the firm\u2019s top executive here, Matteo Bigazzi, offered him the biggest and best-paying assignment of his career as an operative.\n\nAccording to Mr. Moore, Mr. Bigazzi told him that a new client, described to him as a \u201cU.S. investor,\u201d wanted to know if American plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers handling asbestos cases were financing efforts by activists to ban the material. One of those lawyers was Ms. Kazan-Allen\u2019s brother, Steven Kazan.\n\nThe firm\u2019s client, Mr. Bigazzi said, suspected that American lawyers like Mr. Kazan were trying to drum up lawsuits by foreign workers. And he added that producers of the material believed that the type of asbestos still widely used in some developing countries \u2014 chrysotile, or so-called white asbestos \u2014 did not cause mesothelioma, a fatal lung cancer tied to the material, if properly handled.\n\n\u201cHe told me chrysotile was safe,\u201d Mr. Moore said. \u201cSo if the law firms were doing this, I felt that it was a legitimate investigation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe initial targets of the inquiry, which was code-named Project Spring, were Ms. Kazan-Allen and an international coalition of activists she founded, the International Ban Asbestos Secretariat. And court papers show that Mr. Moore seized on the assignment with unbridled enthusiasm.\n\nIn one memo, he told Mr. Bigazzi that the best way to infiltrate the group without arousing suspicions would be to present himself as a documentary filmmaker eager to develop a series of films about dangerous industries, not just asbestos.\n\n\u201cThe advantage of going into this world with a bigger agenda than simply asbestos is that it might make my entry seem less deliberate,\u201d he wrote. He added that he planned to win Ms. Kazan-Allen\u2019s confidence by engaging her in \u201cthe most genuine and heartfelt way possible.\u201d\n\n\u2018Completely Believable\u2019\n\nWhen Ms. Kazan-Allen met Mr. Moore, she found him, as most people do, bright, charming and energetic. She also glimpsed in him a future leader of efforts to expand national bans on asbestos use, particularly in developing areas such as Southeast Asia.\n\n\u201cHe was very polite, incredibly engaging and completely believable,\u201d Ms. Kazan-Allen, 70, said.\n\nMr. Moore had planned their encounter to mask his motives, according to court papers. He first befriended one of her associates, who introduced him to Ms. Kazan-Allen. Soon, he was sending her fawning notes thanking her for recommending books about the asbestos industry, the court papers show. He also mentioned that his sister was a top executive at the British Broadcasting Corporation.\n\n\u201cOnce I\u2019m completely up to speed I would very much like to start meeting other experts and campaigners,\u201d he wrote Ms. Kazan-Allen in mid-2012.\n\nMr. Moore also asked her to arrange for him to attend an asbestos conference in Brussels. She agreed to do it, unaware that his real reason for going was to see if American lawyers like her brother were funding it, filings indicate.\n\nWhen Mr. Moore reported back to Mr. Bigazzi, his supervisor at K2 Intelligence, that he had not seen financial involvement by American lawyers, he said, he was told that the client next wanted him to go to Thailand, where activists were pushing for an asbestos ban. It was around then, Mr. Moore said, that he began to question what he was doing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moore said he learned that independent groups viewed chrysotile as being as deadly as other varieties of asbestos. He also believed that activists were right to want it banned and started to wonder whether K2 Intelligence\u2019s client was someone other than the \u201cU.S. investor\u201d that had been mentioned to him.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t see the work of an arch mastermind who is unreasonably using disingenuous statistics,\u201d he wrote to Mr. Bigazzi in late 2012, court papers show. \u201cI see the work of campaigners who have a good argument on their side.\u201d\n\nMr. Moore acknowledges that he could have simply walked away. Instead, he decided to discuss his situation with fellow Buddhists. He said he had told them that if he quit, K2 Intelligence would simply replace him. But if he stayed he might be able to do something positive by exposing the asbestos industry.\n\n\u201cI was told that I could absolutely do this from a Buddhist perspective providing I didn\u2019t cause harm to anyone,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nActivists suing Mr. Moore say they believe he had a more prosaic motive \u2014 money. Court papers indicate that K2 Intelligence paid him about $100,000 annually, far more than he had made since losing his television job. Whatever the case, Mr. Moore said he soon began to deceive K2 Intelligence and its client.\n\nAlthough he continued to secretly record activists, Mr. Moore insists that the reports he sent back to K2 Intelligence were filled with worthless information. And when Mr. Bigazzi assigned him to monitor the World Health Organization, he persuaded officials there to underwrite a short film he produced, \u201cVictims of Chrysotile Asbestos.\u201d It showed a worker in India stricken with lung cancer.\n\nAnti-asbestos advocates believe Mr. Moore made the film to enhance his cover story as a journalist. But its director, Greg Atkins, said that was not the case. \u201cHe used to laugh about the concept of the industry paying him to screw the industry,\u201d Mr. Atkins said.\n\nIn court filings, K2 Intelligence said its executive, Mr. Bigazzi, had become aware of the film only after Mr. Moore billed the firm for time he had spent working on it. And Mr. Bigazzi apparently was not amused by how asbestos was depicted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moore said that when he showed the K2 Intelligence official the film, he was told halfway through to turn it off. \u201cHe said he had seen enough,\u201d Mr. Moore recalled.\n\nA Dangerous Ride\n\nInvestigative firms usually keep client names secret. But Mr. Moore said he was told during a chance conversation in late 2013 that the client in the asbestos case was a little-known investment firm in Singapore, the Kusto Group.\n\nUnsure whether it was true, Mr. Moore tried to ferret out more information. He said he had found nothing at first on Kusto\u2019s website to connect the firm or its founder and chairman, a Kazakh businessman named Yerkin Tatishev, to asbestos. Rather, Mr. Moore said, he stumbled over a link in 2014 when K2 Intelligence assigned him to go back to Thailand.\n\nHe kept striking out initially when he asked officials of roofing tile companies there if they had heard of Kusto. Then he showed one local official photographs of executives from Kusto\u2019s affiliate in Vietnam.\n\nMr. Moore said the official had recognized two of the executives from their work with a previous company and told him that \u201cthose are the guys who sold us asbestos from the oligarch.\u201d The same official added that Mr. Tatishev had once visited a roofing tile company in Thailand to urge it to keep using asbestos, according to Mr. Moore.\n\nThose leads weren\u2019t conclusive. But Mr. Moore says he began to focus his efforts on understanding what part, if any, Kusto or Mr. Tatishev was playing in the asbestos industry. In one 2015 email, for instance, he suggested to an anti-asbestos activist that they start looking into Kusto and the role of Russian asbestos producers in blocking bans in Southeast Asia. And he contacted journalists and filmmakers about making a documentary with him about the asbestos trade.\n\nHe also met at a London restaurant with a director, Dan Reed, to discuss a film project based on his experience as a corporate operative. Mr. Moore envisioned the film as having a climactic scene in which he would out himself as a whistle-blower at an asbestos conference.\n\n\u201cHe said, \u2018I don\u2019t want to be a part of this,\u2019 and thought there was an opportunity to expose it,\u201d Mr. Reed said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moore said he started secretly recording his meetings with Mr. Bigazzi of K2 Intelligence. While in Vietnam for the firm, he also gave a speech to reporters titled \u201cThe Duty of Journalists to Protect the Public Health,\u201d in which he urged them to investigate the role of Kazakhstan and Russia in asbestos use. One slide he showed had a photograph of Mr. Tatishev and bags of asbestos.\n\nMr. Moore said he had received an irate phone call afterward from Mr. Bigazzi, who had somehow learned about the talk. But Mr. Moore said he had defused the situation by telling Mr. Bigazzi that he had repeated the contentions of anti-asbestos advocates only to maintain his cover as a journalist.\n\nThe strain of his life appeared to be taking a toll on Mr. Moore, friends of his said. Bill Lawrence, an occupational safety expert who was helping him analyze asbestos export data, said that he called Mr. Moore at home. During the conversation, Mr. Lawrence overheard Mr. Moore\u2019s companion express fear about their safety.\n\n\u201cThis is getting too dangerous, Rob,\u201d Mr. Lawrence said he had heard the woman say.\n\nLegal Repercussions\n\nMr. Moore\u2019s life as an operative soon unraveled. In late 2015, Mr. Moore said, K2 Intelligence offered him another assignment, this time to get close to leaders of a major anticorruption group, Global Witness.\n\nGlobal Witness was then working with the authorities in several countries investigating two major oil producers for suspected bribery. Mr. Moore said K2 Intelligence had wanted to find out on behalf of one of the companies what the group knew about those inquiries. But he took another approach.\n\nIn June 2016, he met with a co-founder of Global Witness, Simon Taylor, in a setting worthy of an espionage novel \u2014 a restaurant inside London\u2019s bustling St. Pancras train station. Soon, Mr. Moore placed a book, \u201cAgent Zigzag,\u201d on the table between them. The book chronicles the real-life adventures of a famous British double agent against the Nazis.\n\nMr. Taylor recalled Mr. Moore saying words to the effect of: \u201cIf you know this story, this is what I want to do for you.\u201d Mr. Moore proposed playing the part of a double agent, sharing that K2 Intelligence had also paid him to spy on anti-asbestos advocates, Mr. Taylor said.\n\nGlobal Witness considered Mr. Moore\u2019s proposal but decided it could not trust him, Mr. Taylor said. The group also urged him to alert activists such Ms. Kazan-Allen about his work. When Mr. Moore balked, Global Witness contacted a law firm. That firm then sued K2 Intelligence, Mr. Moore and Mr. Bigazzi in 2016 on behalf of several activists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moore said he felt that Global Witness had betrayed him and insists that he was close to telling activists the truth. But Mr. Taylor said it was not Mr. Moore\u2019s role to set the timetable, adding that his reports to the intelligence firm\u2019s client might have jeopardized the safety of activists.\n\n\u201cHe is not in a position to play God,\u201d Mr. Taylor said.\n\nMr. Moore has struggled since the lawsuit. He said he had spent his life savings, over $375,000, on legal fees and was now represented by pro bono attorneys.\n\nMr. Moore said he understood why advocates like Ms. Kazan-Allen felt betrayed. He believes that they will come to see him differently if he has a chance to tell his story in court.\n\nIn its filings in London, K2 Intelligence said it had undertaken the asbestos inquiry on behalf of a trade group called the Chrysotile Cement Industry of Kazakhstan.\n\nA spokesman for the Kusto Group, Michael Farrant, said the firm had never had any asbestos-related holdings. However, Kusto\u2019s website notes that Mr. Tatishev, before starting Kusto, was a major player in the asbestos industry who revived the fortunes of two large asbestos mines, one in Kazakhstan and the other in Russia.\n\nThe Kazakh mine, Kostanai Minerals, is a member of the Chrysotile Cement Industry of Kazakhstan. \u201cThe town and its operations were on the brink of bankruptcy,\u201d Kusto\u2019s website states. \u201cSomething profound had to change.\u201d\n\nMr. Tatishev declined through Mr. Farrant to be interviewed for this article and did not respond to written questions about his current interests in any entities involved with asbestos.\n\nEfforts to settle the lawsuit are underway, though Mr. Moore said he had resisted doing so. Some activists have rejected his tale of intrigue as a product of his imagination. \u201cHow can you believe that anything he says is true?\u201d Ms. Kazan-Allen said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOthers, while finding Mr. Moore\u2019s tactics unacceptable, believe his intentions were genuine. \u201cEvery part of my bones tells me there is truth in what he is saying,\u201d said Mr. Lawrence, the occupational safety expert.\n\nMeanwhile, Mr. Moore said, he has gone back to developing prank comedy shows, though he is not sure what the future holds.\n\n\u201cDo I strike you as someone who knows how to plan?\u201d he asked.", "title": "A Spy\u2019s Tale: The TV Prankster Who Says He Became a Double Agent", "authors": ["Barry Meier"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nName a Middle Eastern country and chances are a Hollywood film has reduced it to a featureless dusty landscape, inhabited by faceless hairy men and modestly dressed women, most of them interchangeable. The latest such movie to irritate Arabs around the world (myself included) is the hostage drama \u201cBeirut.\u201d Set in 1982, the film stars John Hamm as an American diplomat on a rescue mission during Lebanon\u2019s devastating civil war. In her review, Manohla Dargis writes that \u201cthe absence of Arab voices beyond those of the terrorists further flattens a movie that never fully takes satisfying shape.\u201d\n\nBut fear not! There are plenty of films made by Lebanese filmmakers that counter such reductive visions. Many local favorites \u2014 like \u201cWest Beirut,\u201d \u201cZozo\u201d and \u201cLittle Wars\u201d \u2014 haven\u2019t reached the streaming world yet, but the streaming platform M Media has been building a library of Arab films old and new. (The platform offers a free one-month trial, and a subscription is $5 per month after that.) Here are some of the best you can stream right now.\n\nIf You Like Romantic Comedies\n\nNadine Labaki in \"Caramel.\" Roadside Attractions\n\n\u2018Caramel\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu, YouTube, M Media\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIf you\u2019re remotely familiar with Lebanese entertainment, you have probably heard of this uplifting debut feature by Nadine Labaki. Named after a wax-like concoction widely used across the Middle East for hair removal, the film stars Labaki as one of five women who work at and frequent a beauty salon in Beirut. Each woman\u2019s woes touch on issues that aren\u2019t often talked about in the more traditional parts of the Arab world \u2014 like infidelity, homosexuality and mental health.\n\nThe film takes place in a world devoid of war and its tensions, instead taking an emotion-driven look at everyday lives. This seemed to be a welcome change for audiences. In 2007, \u201cCaramel\u201d topped the box office charts in Lebanon and became the first Lebanese film to open theatrically in the United States.\n\n0\n\nIf You Like Tales of Morality\n\nEmmanuel Khairallah in \u201cGhadi.\u201d Fortissimo Films\n\n\u2018Ghadi\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon Prime, iTunes, M Media\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLike \u201cCaramel,\u201d this heart-warming dramedy from 2013 makes no mention of Lebanon\u2019s contemporary politics. Instead, the film is a social satire told through the eyes of Leba, a music instructor from a provincial Christian village where gossip thrives and privacy is a foreign concept. Leba\u2019s young son, Ghadi, has Down syndrome and spends much of his time trying to mimic his father\u2019s singing, provoking the ire of the intolerant townsfolk.\n\nWhile open public discussions around disabilities and mental health are finally cropping up in Lebanon, the subject has long been taboo. This lighthearted feature gently denounces bigotry with humor and its spot-on portrayal of Lebanese village life.\n\nIf You Like Quirky Dramedies\n\nA scene from \"Where Do We Go Now? Rudy Bou Chebel/Sony Pictures Classics\n\n\u2018Where Do We Go Now?\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu, Youtube\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLabaki\u2019s second feature, this charming satire also revolves around a group of provocative women, but it is goofier than \u201cCaramel\u201d and not as surefooted in its plot. Its shortcomings end there, however. Led by Labaki, who also plays the young widow Amale, a group of Muslim and Christian women in an isolated Lebanese village scheme to keep their belligerent men from starting a sectarian war.\n\nUnlike the women in the ancient Greek play \u201cLysistrata,\u201d who end war by withholding sex, the women in this film exploit carnal desire. The film made waves in Lebanon for its unorthodox approach to a grave concept. And despite its star-studded Hollywood competitors, it took home the audience award at the 2011 Toronto Film Festival.\n\nIf You Like War Dramas\n\nNada Abou Farhat and Georges Khabbaz in \u201cUnder the Bombs.\u201d Film Movement\n\n\u2018Under the Bombs\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon Prime, Kanopy\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWar films produced years after the conflicts in question have subsided can sometimes lack a sense of immediacy. Not so with this heart-wrenching road movie. Shot during the 2006 conflict between Israel and the Lebanese militant group and political party Hezbollah, \u201cUnder the Bombs\u201d is a docu-fiction drama with some very real elements. The bombs exploding in the distance are not fabricated, and the cast consists mostly of nonprofessional actors who are merely reenacting their experiences. This is by no means a polished production, but it stands out because of its visceral tragedy and moving performances, which capture the realities of war the way few films have.\n\nIf You\u2019re a Theater Buff\n\nA scene from \u201cWhat About Tomorrow?\u201d M Media\n\n\u2018What About Tomorrow?\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: M Media\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe play \u201cWhat About Tomorrow?\u201d had an 8-month run in Beirut in 1978. Directed by the composer and playwright Ziad Rahbani, who also stars, it has been an important cultural reference point in Lebanon ever since. At once a searing and sardonic look at the demands of city living, the production follows Zakaria and his wife Thuraya, who run a bar in the trendy Hamra neighborhood of Beirut. In an effort to keep themselves afloat, Zakaria reluctantly allows Thuraya to work as a prostitute.\n\nFor nearly 40 years, the play was accessible only in audio format for most people. But over the course of three years, M Media cleaned and pieced together the 8-millimeter footage used for this restoration, which was was originally recorded to help the actors improve their performances (and thus never intended for a theatrical release). Fans rejoiced at the result: The film shattered box-office records in Lebanon when it opened in 2016.\n\nIf You Like Dark Comedies\n\nAlain Saadeh in \u201cVery Big Shot.\u201d Kabreet Productions\n\n\u2018Very Big Shot\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Netflix, Google Play, YouTube\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cVery Big Shot\u201d starts out as an action thriller about three brothers who are trying to close up shop on their drug-dealing operation and go straight. But when a mishap during their last deal leaves them with a truck full of amphetamines, the film takes a sharp, comedic turn into social commentary.\n\n0\n\nIn a plan to smuggle the drugs to Iraq, the three brothers take control of a film project by one of their indebted cocaine buyers, and the production eventually draws intense media coverage. The absurdity of the plot is a nod to the widespread corruption in Lebanon (a recent study found that Lebanon was the most corrupt country in the Arab world), and a tendency for public opinion to be easily swayed by theatrics. Some moments of \u201cVery Big Shot\u201d are stronger than others, but this bold comedy is a refreshing change from the depictions of love and war you\u2019ll typically find in Lebanese cinema.\n\nIf You Like Forbidden Love Stories\n\nFlavia Bechara in \u201cThe Kite.\u201d Ognon Pictures, via Everett Collection\n\n\u2018The Kite\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon Prime, Fandor\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDirector Randa Chahal Sabbag has described this family drama as a fairy tale and a fable. Call it what you will, but one thing is for sure: It\u2019s a conversation starter. In it, a teenager named Lamia lives in a Lebanese village near the Israeli border that was split when Israel annexed the Golan Heights in 1981. Her conservative family arranges for her to marry her cousin on the Israeli side, a plan Lamia could not be less enthusiastic about. On her wedding day, she crosses the border and catches the eye of a young Israeli-Arab soldier, Youssef. Intrigued by his watchful gaze, Lamia rejects her marriage and pursues the forbidden fruit.\n\nThe complexities of Israeli-Arab affairs give \u201cThe Kite\u201d a specific political context, but its basic premise of teenage rebellion is universal. And the comical scenes of covered women on both sides of the border discussing private matters (such as Lamia\u2019s puberty) over a megaphone relieve the drama of its sorrow.\n\nIf You Like Thrillers With a Romantic Edge\n\nDarine Hamze in \u201cBeirut Hotel.\u201d M Media\n\n\u2018Beirut Hotel\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: M Media\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn a security-obsessed country like Lebanon, plagued by conspiracies and proxy wars, you never know what kind of sticky situation you might fall into. In \u201cBeirut Hotel,\u201d this daily uncertainty forms the backdrop for a passionate affair between Zoha, a voluptuous \u2014 and married \u2014 singer, and Mathieu, a Frenchman who says he works for a telecom company. But Mathieu might actually be a spy, and he is being trailed by two competing security services.\n\nThe couple have doubts about each other, and they also have Zoha\u2019s domineering husband to contend with. Tensions build throughout the movie\u2019s meandering plot as news of kidnappings dominate the headlines and people are threatened on the street.\u201cBeirut Hotel\u201d attracted international attention after it was initially banned in Lebanon because of its subplot about the 2005 assassination of the former prime minister Rafic Hariri.", "title": "A Starter Guide to Streaming Lebanese Cinema", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cChoosing a Road Fit for Dr. King\u201d (news article, April 16):\n\nTo satisfy both sides of the argument regarding the renaming of a street to honor Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the black community, Kansas City, Mo., might consider renaming Prospect Avenue but making it very attractive to outside companies and people willing to make long-term investments along the street.\n\nBoth could be accomplished through special tax incentives for businesses and flexible real estate policies to encourage families to renovate and occupy the well-built but now-deteriorated houses.\n\nWith the prosperity these policies might invite, Prospect Avenue could become what Dr. King envisioned, a street where \u201clittle black boys and little black girls will be able to join hands with little white boys and girls.\u201d\n\nIf business opportunities could bring billions of dollars into this country from Germany and Japan (our World War II enemies), why not outside investment in a renamed Prospect Avenue?", "title": "Opinion | A Street Named for Dr. King", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "With Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron visiting Donald Trump this week, much of the commentary has focused on how wildly different the staid German chancellor and the globally minded French president are from the mercurial American president. But the three do share one trait: They are all unpopular at home despite the good economic times.\n\nThis is new. For most of the postwar era, voters in the big democracies rewarded leaders for strong economies and punished them for policies that hurt growth. Now the link between good politics and good economics seems to have broken.\n\nLast year, the global economy was finally accelerating out of the long torpor that followed the financial crisis of 2008. Unemployment hit lows not seen in decades, and inflation all but disappeared. Yet by January, my index of approval ratings for leaders in 20 major democracies showed their average rating hitting a new low of just 35 percent, down from a peak of more than 50 percent a decade ago.\n\nPresident Trump is Exhibit A of this fraying connection between politics and economics. Surveys of consumer confidence show that Americans haven\u2019t felt this good about the economy since at least the height of the dot-com boom in 2000. Yet Mr. Trump\u2019s approval ratings have hovered around record lows for this point in any president\u2019s first term. Many commentators assume this is because Mr. Trump\u2019s divisive personality has overshadowed the strong economy.", "title": "Opinion | A Strong Economy Won\u2019t Make You Popular These Days", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNovak Djokovic is done working with Andre Agassi and Radek Stepanek, the latest in a series of coaching changes for the 12-time major champion, who has gone nearly two full years without winning a Grand Slam title.\n\nDjokovic announced Wednesday on his website that he has split from Agassi after less than a year and from Stepanek after less than six months.\n\nHe has lost his past three matches.\n\n\u201cThe private relationship with Stepanek was and will remain great, and Novak has enjoyed working with him and learning from him,\u201d the statement on the website said. \u201cHe remains grateful and appreciative of all the support he has received from Radek during the last period.\u201d\n\nThe only mention of Agassi comes in the final sentence, which reads simply: \u201cThe cooperation between Novak and Andre Agassi has also ended.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDjokovic, 30, has struggled on the court this season as he deals with a right elbow problem. He took the second half of last year off and then had a medical procedure in February. His latest setback was a straight-set loss in his opening match last month at the Miami Open, a tournament he has won six times.", "title": "A Struggling Novak Djokovic Shakes Up His Coaching Staff Again", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s as simple as cook the heck out of root vegetables,\u201d Mr. Barber said. \u201cI like the idea of root vegetables simply roasted for a long time. You\u2019re getting out all the water you can and caramelizing all the sugars. Add a scoop of ice cream, and it\u2019s a great experience.\u201d\n\nFor Blue Hill\u2019s squash dessert, the honeynut squash \u2014 a smaller, sweeter relative of butternut squash \u2014 was roasted for several hours, scooped out and dried further on the stove top. \u201cEvery bite you are taking is squash times 800 percent,\u201d Mr. Barber said. \u201cIf it was picked at the right moment, it bombs with sweetness. That\u2019s true of parsnips, celery roots and beets as well.\u201d\n\nAlthough we tend to think of vegetables as a savory food, every vegetable has a natural range of sugar that can vary based on the soil and growing conditions, how recently it was picked and whether it was in the ground during a freeze.\n\nA food\u2019s sugar content is measured on a Brix scale (named after Adolf Brix, the German chemist who first measured sugar in plant juice) \u2014 the higher the number, the sweeter the food.\n\nFor instance, sweet corn can average about 10 on the Brix scale, but can go as high as 24, putting it in the same range as grapes, oranges, papayas and pineapples. Carrots can range from 4 to 18 \u2014 similar to kumquats, mangoes and raspberries. Bananas and melons can measure around 12 to 14 on the Brix scale, along with tomatoes, sweet potatoes, English peas, beets, broccoli, celery and cucumbers.\n\nBrix scores are affected by soil conditions, weather, harvesting and storage conditions. Most experts agree that fresh vegetables sold at farmers\u2019 markets are likely to have higher Brix scores than those bought at grocery stores. The website High Brix Gardens found that green beans picked from a home garden scored a sweet 6.2 on the Brix scale, compared to 4.2 for beans bought at a grocery store. In a 2011 Ohio State study, cucumbers collected from four Ohio farms had vastly different Brix readings, ranging from 2.2 to 5.4, showing how different growing methods and soil conditions can affect sugar content even in the same region.\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring cold weather, root vegetables like carrots and parsnips convert starch to sugar to prevent freezing, resulting in a sweeter taste. As a result, a carrot or parsnip picked after a freeze will have a higher sugar content than those harvested before the freeze.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an experiment at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., the farm harvested different sections of a carrot plot each week. Some of the carrots went through three freezes. The sugar content jumped from 3 or 4 Brix in the early batches to 7 in the later-harvested carrots. The restaurant created a \u201chigh-Brix\u201d carrot sorbet served with parsnip cake or purple sweet potato sorbet.\n\nSome home gardeners have taken to measuring Brix levels \u2014 in addition to sweetness, a high Brix reading is also believed to be associated with higher mineral density and pest resistance. A device called a refractometer, sold on Amazon for $20 to $30, can measure Brix levels from a drop of juice.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nChefs note that not every vegetable works alone as dessert. Recently during a master cooking class, Mr. Uskokovic tasted a dessert made with radicchio, simple syrup, macadamia nut cream and wild rose flavors. \u201cIt was beautiful and delicious, but I think it needed more sugar,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was too borderline salad.\u201d\n\nAlex Stupak, founder of Empell\u00f3n in New York, said that culture plays a role in our feelings about vegetables. Rhubarb, for instance, is a vegetable traditionally used in desserts, even though it can be bitter. By comparison, tomatoes (technically a fruit) and celery aren\u2019t \u201cdessert\u201d foods, but they can actually be sweeter.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never been a huge fan of rhubarb, but I\u2019ve reached for celery over and over again,\u201d Mr. Stupak said. \u201cI think it has brilliant effects in the dessert world.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAt Empell\u00f3n in Midtown Manhattan, diners have been served corn ice cream tacos (a more sophisticated version of the ice cream truck Choco Taco) and banana ice cream topped with a tuile ribbon of roasted parsnip. One of the signature dishes at Empell\u00f3n is made with avocado, a savory fruit rarely used in dessert. Mr. Stupak\u2019s creation is essentially a parfait glac\u00e9, a French iced dessert typically made with egg yolks, sugar, heavy cream and flavoring, but in the Empell\u00f3n version, avocado pur\u00e9e replaces the cream, and the final dessert is shaped to look like exactly a real avocado, including the dark skin.\n\n\u201cI love tasting avocado in the sweet context,\u201d Mr. Stupak said. \u201cIf you really eat an avocado and close your eyes and taste it, the flavors are subtly nutty and almost anise-like or fennel-like.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Stupak noted that carrot cake, while popular, doesn\u2019t really taste like carrots. \u201cSomething like a carrot sorbet or carrot ice cream gets much closer to transmitting the flavor,\u201d he said. He said he once served a carrot ice cream made with carrot pur\u00e9e and many people thought it had the orange and vanilla flavors of a creamsicle. \u201cI love that because they are tasting facets of a carrot they haven\u2019t tasted before,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Stupak said he happily mashes and pur\u00e9es vegetables at home that he turns into cakes and cookies for his two young children. \u201cIt\u2019s a very clever way to get someone to eat their vegetables,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd if you try cooking a vegetable for dessert and it\u2019s not quite sweet enough for your palate, Mr. Barber has an easy fix. \u201cFor the home cook, I don\u2019t have a problem putting sugar on vegetables for dessert,\u201d he said. \u201cThe sweetness will still be a lot less than a conventional dessert.\u201d", "title": "A Surprising Way to Eat Vegetables: For Dessert", "authors": ["Tara Parker-Pope"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "With easy-to-peel satsumas, seedless clementines and scarlet blood oranges all available to satisfy citrus yearnings, it can be hard to remember to give grapefruits their due.\n\nEven when I do think to buy them, they often languish. Their vast size requires you either to commit or to share, and they\u2019re not the kind of thing you\u2019d casually toss into your bag on the way out the door. Grapefruits can also be somewhat bitter, which may turn off people accustomed to honey-sweet tangerines.", "title": "A Tart Solution for Sweet Crumb Cake", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Ready for a new renovation project by 2015, they needed only to find the right space. At a children\u2019s birthday party early that year, Mr. Livingston learned from a father who lived across from the American Museum of Natural History that his rental building, The Orleans, was on the verge of converting to condominium.\n\nThe Livingstons contacted the building\u2019s sales team before the units were officially on the market and eventually snapped up a 2,500-square-foot sunny corner unit with a view of the museum\u2019s grounds for $5.6 million.\n\nAfter being reconfigured many times over the years, the apartment was a hodgepodge of awkward spaces, mismatched flooring and multiple electrical panels \u2014 which was exactly what they wanted.\n\n\u201cIt was a positive for us to come into a space that needed to be fixed,\u201d Ms. Livingston said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t want a place that somebody had already renovated.\u201d\n\nMr. Livingston sharpened his pencils and engaged StudioLAB to lead the project once again, but with plenty of collaborative effort. \u201cI was looking to be part of designing every square foot,\u201d he said.\n\nTogether, Mr. Miller and the Livingstons pulled together a plan for a complete gut renovation that would create a four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bathroom apartment with an open living, dining and kitchen area, and extensive custom millwork, including folding and sliding doors that would conceal a television and bar in the living room. One of the bedrooms would also serve as a combination playroom and guest room, with a wall of built-in storage to conceal toys and a Murphy bed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Miller suggested buying a small portion of the shared hallway from the building to create a more gracious foyer. Mr. Livingston suggested taking some space from a large bathroom to create a \u201cgarage\u201d for sports equipment with its own door from the shared hallway.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Livingstons also spent days researching materials. \u201cIt was such an education, which I didn\u2019t realize would be so fun,\u201d Ms. Livingston said. \u201cMatt explained wood flooring to us, and the difference between rift-sawn versus quarter-sawn, and character versus no character. We learned about veneer. We went to look at stone and pick out slabs.\u201d\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t all smiles and smooth sailing. One of the biggest points of contention between the Livingstons was the custom floor-to-ceiling, steel-and-glass wine storage wall that Mr. Miller proposed building between the foyer and the kitchen.\n\n\u201cThat wasn\u2019t on the list of things we had asked for,\u201d said Mr. Livingston, who nevertheless thought it would be a novel way to allow sunlight from the exterior windows to reach the foyer.\n\n\u201cI had strong feelings about that,\u201d said Ms. Livingston, who lobbied for a larger kitchen pantry instead.\n\nThe wine wall stuck (though an aquarium might have been a better idea, a helpful doorman suggested to this reporter on a recent visit).\n\nWhen construction began in November 2015, \u201cKevin came here once in the morning and once in the evening\u201d \u2014 nearly every day \u2014 \u201cto see what was going on,\u201d Mr. Miller said.\n\nAnd by the time the project was wrapping up in the summer of 2016, at a total cost of about $1.6 million, the homeowners had grown so fond of their architect that he was the first person they called with important family news: Ms. Livingston was pregnant with their fourth child, Keaton, who is now 1.\n\n\u201cMatt knew before any of our family,\u201d Mr. Livingston said. \u201cWe wanted to make sure there wasn\u2019t anything he would do to change the design.\u201d", "title": "A Taste for Renovation", "authors": ["Tim Mckeough", "On Location"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Shed, the new cross-disciplinary arts center planned for the Far West Side of Manhattan, is still a hard-hat construction site, with an opening date of next spring. But starting on Tuesday, its creators will serve up two free weeks of arts events as an amuse-bouche, hoping to entice New Yorkers with an early look at the type of ambitious programming the Shed will eventually offer.\n\nAll of the works included in the festival, which is called \u201cA Prelude to the Shed,\u201d will merge seamlessly into one another throughout each day \u2014 a fusion of dance, visual art and music, with a hint of theater. Performed in an outdoor pavilion, they are meant to break down the barriers between disciplines, underscoring the importance of collaboration.\n\n\u201cThe Shed is interested in the advancement of art forms, whereas other institutions are about preserving the treasures of the past,\u201d said Alex Poots, its artistic director and founding chief executive.", "title": "A Teaser for the Shed, Hoping to Entice New Yorkers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "This is a time for big ideas. One of the Trump presidency\u2019s only silver linings is its proof that our political discourse had been too narrow. Frustrated Americans don\u2019t feel bound by old rules. Almost 63 million of them voted for a man who had no political experience and made a mockery of politics as usual.\n\n\u201cDonald Trump\u2019s victory implies that people need to be more bold,\u201d as Ro Khanna, a Democratic congressman, has said. \u201cPeople yawned at the smallness of American politics, at the stagnation of American politics, at the same faces, the same ideas, the same talking points.\u201d Or as Neera Tanden, who runs the Center for American Progress, a progressive think tank, says, \u201cDonald Trump has widened the aperture for policy discussions in the United States.\u201d\n\nSome observers remain confused about all of this. They imagine American politics as a simple two-dimensional spectrum on which Democrats must move to the center. But every issue isn\u2019t the same. Yes, there are cultural issues, like abortion and guns, on which the country is classically divided. On these, moving to the center, or at least respectfully acknowledging our differences, can help Democrats. Representative Conor Lamb recently showed how to do it in Pennsylvania.\n\nEconomic policy is different. Most voters don\u2019t share the centrist preferences of Washington\u2019s comfortable pundit class. Most voters want to raise taxes on the rich and corporations. They favor generous Medicare and Social Security, expanded Medicaid, more financial aid for college, a higher minimum wage and a bigger government role in job creation. Remember, Trump won the Republican nomination as a populist. A clear majority of Americans wants the government to respond aggressively to our economic problems.\n\nI think they\u2019re right about that, too. Lawrence Summers, the former Treasury secretary, has a nice framing. He says that the late 1960s and the 1970s should have moved a reasonable person to the right on economic policy, in response to rampant inflation, rising crime, sky-high top tax rates and breakdowns in Europe. The last 15 years \u2014 with \u201cwidening inequality, financial crisis, zero interest rates, rising gaps in life expectancy and opportunity,\u201d as Summers notes \u2014 should move that same person to the left. Different eras require different solutions.", "title": "Opinion | A Time for Big Economic Ideas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "I wanted to fly to South Florida as soon as possible. But I was helping to report in New York, and it took me 10 days to get back. Once here, with no assignment or story in mind, I drove to Parkland. I needed to see the school for myself. Standing alone next to the vast, improvised memorial outside its gates, I felt overcome with sadness. I rushed to my car and cried.\n\nIn late February, the photographer Sam Hodgson pitched spending some time with Sarah Lerner, the yearbook adviser, and her staff. I thought the idea was brilliant, and I was grateful that Ms. Lerner, her students and school administrators would let us in to report. I worried about how the students would react to us. But I had forgotten, in my years since covering education, how easily young people get used to having a reporter around. How often they speak truths that older people might hesitate to say out loud. How incisive their reflections and observations can be.\n\nSam and I tried to be unobtrusive, letting the students work while we hung back and watched and listened. But the computer lab was small, and we were unavoidable.\n\nStill, the students said they appreciated that we tried to blend in. They did not mince words when they shared their grievances about other journalists since the shooting. Throngs of reporters crowded the sidewalk on the day the school reopened, clamoring for a sound bite. Kyra Parrow, an 18-year-old senior, chided that reporters \u201calways ask the same questions.\u201d\n\nAt one point, I started talking with Isabel Chequer, a 16-year-old junior who was painstakingly reviewing group photos for student clubs and identifying each person pictured. To my surprise, she called the task \u201ckind of relaxing.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just such a good distraction for everything going on,\u201d she said.\n\nIsabel explained a few minutes later that she had been injured in the shooting. I didn\u2019t know this; the names of the wounded had not yet been made public, and she had not shared her story with any reporter.\n\nBut there, side by side in the yearbook lab, she recounted her horrifying experience, with the remarkable poise that has characterized so many of the Parkland students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s kind of been overwhelming. I\u2019m kind of closed off in talking about my emotions,\u201d Isabel said. \u201cI\u2019ll never be over the grief.\u201d\n\nBut she expressed hope about the future: that a story of loss might turn into one of recovery and action.\n\n\u201cI really think we\u2019re going to do something,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to change the world forever.\u201d", "title": "A Times Reporter Returns Home to Cover a Tragedy", "authors": ["Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Every day, the tiny elevator in Building 11 of the Boulevard Houses in Brooklyn does what it was built to do.\n\nIt ferries tenants to the lobby as they start their morning commutes. It carries retirees down to run midday errands. And it brings residents back to their apartments after a twilight chat or an evening cigarette.\n\nTo enter the elevator, residents swing open the leaden door and as they board, perhaps they glance up at the convex mirror that reflects anyone behind them. Inside, it is easy to feel encased in the dim confines of the metal box.\n\nThe ride is quiet, even serene. It is a stark contrast from the cacophony of police sirens tenants have heard for years outside their home, the oldest housing project in East New York, long one of the city\u2019s more violent neighborhoods.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the ride up or down the six-story building is slow and it gives some passengers enough time to remember why the elevator will forever be tainted by what happened inside nearly four years ago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn June 1, 2014, the elevator was the scene of a killing that defied explanation. After following two children into the elevator, an assailant stabbed a 6-year-old boy, Prince Joshua Avitto, to death and slashed a 7-year-old girl, Mikayla Capers, to within an inch of her life. It was a gruesome crime that pained many in the city, and focused public attention, however briefly, on the security problems that plague many of the developments operated by the New York City Housing Authority.", "title": "A Tiny Elevator, a Haunting Reminder in Brooklyn", "authors": ["Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "When companies want to use individuals\u2019 data for a new purpose, they must explain that new purpose and obtain users\u2019 permission. And companies must get special permission from users to collect and use sensitive details like health information, unless that data is clearly related to the purpose of the service, such as a diabetes management app.\n\nThat means Facebook will probably need to rework its data policy and terms of service, said Finn L\u00fctzow-Holm Myrstad, director of digital policy at the Norwegian Consumer Council, a nonprofit group in Oslo. He added that he thought the law would also require Facebook to give users more \u201creal choices, not take it or leave.\u201d The current data policy requires people who sign up for the social network to allow Facebook to, among other things, track them on many other apps and websites.\n\nMr. Sherman, Facebook\u2019s deputy chief privacy officer, said that Facebook was updating its terms of service and data policy to ensure that it complied with the new European law. Those updates cover users worldwide, with legal variations in some places.\n\nAlgorithmic Decision-Making\n\nThe European law gives individuals the right not to be subject to completely automated decisions which significantly affect them. These decisions could include credit algorithms that use an individual\u2019s data to decide whether a bank should grant him or her a loan.\n\nPrivacy International said the clause on automated decisions could allow consumers to challenge Facebook practices like political advertising , which can be sent to users based on algorithms, because the ads are meant to sway users\u2019 votes.\n\nFacebook currently has a section called \u201cYour Ad Preferences\u201d that allows users to opt out of seeing ads based on their relationship status, employer, education, interests, and use of websites and apps. Users can also hide ads related to three topics \u2014 alcohol, pets and parenting \u2014 or suggest a topic they would rather not see ads about.\n\nAccessing Data About You\n\nThe European law gives people the right obtain a copy of the records that companies hold about them.", "title": "A Tough Task for Facebook: European-Type Privacy for All", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Pierre Yovanovitch\n\nAge 51\n\nOccupation Interior designer; furniture designer\n\nLocation Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur region of France\n\nPhoto\n\nHis Favorite Room In 2009, Mr. Yovanovitch, whose primary residence is in Paris, bought a chateau surrounded by 90 acres of woodland that was in the same family for centuries. He turned a separate barnlike structure where hay was once stored into a warm, wood-filled salon decorated with art, vintage furniture and a zigzag sofa he designed.\n\nWas it daunting to renovate and furnish what amounts to a castle?\n\nI think it was the most crazy thing I have ever done. If you think too much about possessing this kind of property, you don\u2019t, because there is too much work, too much everything. But for me, life is short, and you need to do some crazy things.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe salon is fairly spare, with carefully chosen objects. What\u2019s your criteria?\n\nIn every client project, and for myself, I try to make a story around the room. Here, I don\u2019t want to use any shiny fabric, bronze and so on, because it was a farm. You feel that in the architecture. I try to respect the style of the house, but in a modern way, a nicer way. I used simple objects, lots of wood.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe zigzag sofa made of pine is really cool, but is it actually comfortable?\n\nThe inspiration is very brutalist, because it\u2019s sharp. But it\u2019s also cozy. Because of the shape, you\u2019re sitting close to each other. Very warm and very comfortable.\n\nPhoto\n\nI\u2019m intrigued by the small owl sculpture.\n\nI love this object because it was given to me by a client. He knew that I love owls. One day, we were at a fair in Paris. I saw it and fell in love. I couldn\u2019t afford it; it was quite expensive. The next day, I received the owl in my office as a gift. It\u2019s a very good memory for me.\n\nYou\u2019re planning to open a New York office. Will that mean less time at the chateau?\n\nMaybe, yes. If I decide to open an office in New York and I want to grow in the U.S., it\u2019s a part of the success. But I will try to go as often as possible. To buy this chateau gives me a lot of energy to do other projects. I have to work more to afford this.", "title": "A Tour of Designer Pierre Yovanovitch\u2019s French Chateau", "authors": ["Steven Kurutz", "My Space"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOur life was lived around hockey when we were hosts,\u201d said Ms. Kienlen, whose three children were young when the family hosted players in their homes. \u201cWe had a player who was just 15 years old. Imagine that: just 15 years old. But he needed parents. We didn\u2019t know how to parent teenagers then, but it worked.\u201d\n\nThe custom of players\u2019 living with local families means the deaths double the number of parents affected. In a new subdivision behind Humboldt\u2019s hospital, Devin and Rene Cannon were hosts to two players killed in the crash: Logan Hunter, 18, and Adam Herold, whose 17th birthday would have been on Thursday.\n\n\u201cWe aren\u2019t built to not get attached,\u201d Ms. Cannon told the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. \u201cWe take every single boy that\u2019s ever come into our house right into our hearts and into our family.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cThey\u2019re children of our heart from the moment they walk in our door. We don\u2019t just feed them and house them, we care about them.\u201d\n\nNow, Ms. Cannon said, \u201cWe feel like our hearts have been splintered. There are three people in our lives we will never get to hold and hug and tell them to go kick some butt on the ice ever again.\u201d\n\nThe outsize role the team plays in Humboldt was obvious even on the outskirts of town, where a large sign on the highway at the Humboldt exit called for prayers for the team. On the main street \u2014 named Glenn Hall Drive, after the hometown hero, a goalie who went on to the National Hockey League, winning two Stanley Cups \u2014 gold, green and white Broncos jerseys hung behind counters in shops, restaurants and hotels. It seemed almost everyone in town was wearing green lapel ribbons to honor the team.\n\nThe Humboldt arena has a capacity of 1,854 \u2014 a seat for every 2.6 residents, given the town\u2019s official population. Yet during playoff games, like the two held against the Nipawin Hawks this past week, the arena is so full of spectators that it\u2019s standing room only.", "title": "A Town That Lives for Hockey Is Devastated by Humboldt Broncos\u2019 Deaths", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 An organ-failure-inducing, military-grade nerve agent may seem an unlikely source of inspiration for a product that is advertised as promoting \u201clongevity.\u201d\n\nNot so for Alexei Yakushev, a farmer from a village in central Russia. This week, he launched \u201cNovichok,\u201d a sunflower oil named after the chemical agent the Kremlin is accused of using last month to poison the Russian former spy Sergei V. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, in Salisbury, England.\n\nThe oil comes in a tall brown bottle with a black label decorated with the emblem of the Soviet-era secret police and the words, \u201cRecommended by the K.G.B.\u201d On Thursday, a beaming Mr. Yakushev posed for photos and a video promoting his new product at a trade fair in Ulyanovsk, a city 520 miles east of Moscow.\n\nThe 43-year-old farmer, who runs a family business called Yakushev, said in a telephone interview that he was seeking to inject an element of humor into an international spy scandal that has prompted Western nations to eject more than 150 Russian diplomats and the United States to impose a new round of economic sanctions, sending relations with the West to their lowest point since Russia\u2019s military interventions in Crimea and eastern Ukraine.", "title": "A Trace of Novichok on Your Salad?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Around the same time, President Trump began to impose tariffs intended to protect American industries from foreign competition. Solar panels and washing machines were his first targets. Then came steel and aluminum.\n\nTariffs may or may not help the targeted industries, which in these cases are not significant segments of the economy, anyway, and the taxes are almost universally viewed as harmful to consumers, who have to pay more for the affected goods. And then there\u2019s the impact of tariffs imposed by foreign governments in retaliation, which came swiftly from China, the main target of the trade war that Mr. Trump has threatened to wage.\n\nThe potential impact of the back-and-forth trade moves, and the ones that yet may come, helped send stocks on one of the swiftest plunges on record starting in late January \u2014 11.8 percent in less than 10 trading days for the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index.\n\nThat was followed by a rally that recouped most of the loss, and then another decline that took the index close to a fresh low, leaving it down 1.2 percent in the first three months of the year, the first quarterly decline since 2015. The early days of April have been rocky as well.\n\nIf a trade war really has begun, some household names in corporate America could become casualties, Andy Rothman, an investment strategist at Matthews Asia, warned.\n\n\u201cThere are already a lot of U.S. companies doing really well in China,\u201d he said. \u201cG.M. sells more cars in China than in the U.S., Boeing sells more planes in China than in any other market, and Apple derives 20 percent of its revenues in China. Those are big listed names.\u201d\n\nThe impact would go beyond sales in China, he added. American companies that obtain parts and supplies there could see that conduit disrupted.\n\nMutual Funds Highlights of mutual fund performance in the first quarter.
