Index Chou Opportunity\n\nAs for the Chinese economy and stock market, Mr. Rothman said, they are mostly immune.\n\n\u201cVery few listed Chinese companies export stuff to the United States,\u201d he said. \u201cEven if Trump disrupts U.S.-China trade, the impact should be negligible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA trade war, therefore, \u201cwill hurt us more than them,\u201d he said. That\u2019s why he expects the president\u2019s protectionist tendencies to be reined in.\n\n\u201cThe odds of a full-blown trade war are extremely low,\u201d Mr. Rothman said. Not only is the Chinese leadership eager to avoid one, but \u201cTrump must be coming under a lot of pressure not to do this for the damage it will do to the U.S. equity market.\u201d\n\nTobias Levkovich, chief United States equity strategist at Citi Research, also foresees limited damage to the economy and stocks from an unraveling in trade relations. He pointed to the exemptions on steel and aluminum tariffs offered to big trading partners like Canada and Mexico, and he expressed hope that Mr. Trump\u2019s words and actions merely reflected his penchant for eccentric deal making.\n\n\u201cTrump has a unique negotiating style,\u201d Mr. Levkovich said. But \u201cif he takes it further, it could be a problem and hurt growth in a more meaningful way.\u201d As for the impact of the president\u2019s tactics on investments, he added, \u201cit doesn\u2019t help.\u201d\n\nMr. Yardeni said he thought a trade war could be forestalled, although the mere prospect of one could depress the stock market. He agreed that \u201cthis could be Trump\u2019s art of the deal \u2014 take an extreme negotiating position and wait for people on the other side to say, \u2018Let\u2019s talk about this.\u2019\u201d\n\nTighter monetary policy is a more run-of-the-mill concern. But investors should not underestimate the potential it has to harm their portfolios with valuations elevated across the board and inflation threatening to return.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cPrices across just about every asset class look high historically,\u201d said Ben Inker, head of asset allocation for the asset management firm GMO. \u201cWhat they all have in common is that when you squint, they make sense if you assume cash rates are going to stay low for some time. If inflation is up, then you need significantly tight monetary policy. That\u2019s bad for bonds and also stocks.\u201d\n\nMr. Inker is concerned about a trade war, like many other investors, but he emphasizes the risk of higher prices on goods \u2014 inflation \u2014 that it might cause.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe nightmare scenario is a general rise of economic nationalism and the mercantilist view that trade has winners and losers,\u201d he said. \u201cThen you get a retreat from globalization, which has helped the economy grow without experiencing significant inflation.\u201d\n\nWhen stocks fall, so usually do yields on high-quality bonds, sending prices higher in a so-called flight to safety. But one ominous development during the first leg of the decline in stocks, from Jan. 26 to Feb. 8, was that the yield on 10-year Treasury securities rose to 2.85 percent from 2.66 percent. Yields were steady during the second wave of selling in stocks, but they rose overall during the first quarter, to 2.74 percent from 2.4 percent.\n\nThat means that bond prices, as well as stock prices, fell.\n\nTerri Spath, chief investment officer of Sierra Investment Management, warned in a note to clients that the traditional balanced portfolio, split 60/40 between stocks and bonds, might not provide the protection through diversification that it used to if the bond bull market that began in the early 1980s is over, as she believes.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cTightening Fed policy, inflation, rapidly growing deficits and their impact on rates can sometimes move bond prices violently,\u201d Ms. Spath wrote. \u201cJuly 2016 marked the lowest level in rates I will likely see in my lifetime,\u201d with the 10-year Treasury yield reaching 1.33 percent. \u201cIf interest rates continue the climb up from that level, traditional bonds and the 60/40 will continue to die, as foreshadowed during the first correction of 2018.\u201d\n\nMs. Spath is not alone in disdaining bonds. The latest Bank of America Merrill Lynch survey of global fund managers, released in late March, showed bonds to be the second-least-favorite of 22 asset classes \u2014 behind only British stocks \u2014 relative to how managers have rated them throughout the survey\u2019s 17-year history.\n\nBond funds and domestic and international stock funds all fell in the first quarter, though not by that much. The average taxable bond fund declined 0.5 percent, according to Morningstar, led lower by portfolios specializing in longer-term issues.\n\nThe average domestic stock fund fell 0.4 percent, with consumer defensive and natural resources groups faring worse than most and technology being one of the few clear winners, up 6 percent. International funds declined 0.3 percent, although specialists in China and Latin America recorded gains.\n\nWith interest rates rising, stock market valuations still high and protectionist impulses threatening to ignite a full-blown trade war, advisers encourage investors to indulge protectionist impulses of a different sort when it comes to their portfolios. They recommend keeping less money in stocks or being more selective about the ones investors own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re better off investing pretty much anywhere other than the U.S.,\u201d Mr. Inker said about stocks, although he prefers Treasury bonds to foreign bonds.\n\nThe only type of investment he recommends outright, rather than in comparison to others that he deems even worse, is \u201cthe cheap half of emerging\u201d markets, in particular technology stocks in places like Taiwan and elsewhere in Asia.\n\n\u201cOther than emerging market value, we don\u2019t see assets that deserve to go up a lot,\u201d he said.\n\nCiti\u2019s analysts prefer emerging markets and Europe, where stocks are cheaper and central banks are doing more to prop up the markets. Mr. Levkovich counters that stocks are cheaper abroad for good reasons: American businesses have higher returns on equity, and American benchmark stock indexes are heavier in technology and lighter in the financial industry.\n\nMr. Levkovich recommended that investors prune their portfolios to enhance return prospects. In particular, he would be cautious on tech and usually defensive areas like utilities, consumer staples and telecoms, and emphasize traditional industrial companies and the materials industry, including chemical producers.\n\nMr. Yardeni remains optimistic about stocks, but he\u2019s in no hurry to buy.\n\n\u201cYou have to recognize that if you\u2019re thinking of buying stocks, you\u2019re not exactly getting in early,\u201d he said. \u201cWe could have a shakeout here until we get clarity on protectionism.\u201d\n\nHis advice is to be patient in the likelihood that stocks can be bought at lower prices. When the time feels right, he said, he would look at exporters and other companies that would be on the front lines in a trade war, which he expects to be averted.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re probably going to find some good opportunities in blue-chip stocks with exposure to tariff issues,\u201d Mr. Yardeni said. But for now, he cautioned, risks in the market have risen.\n\n\u201cThis probably will turn out to be a panic attack, like before,\u201d he said, \u201cbut it has the potential to be a more serious correction than we\u2019ve had in some time.\u201d", "title": "A Trade War Could Leave Investors With Few Places to Hide", "authors": ["Conrad De Aenlle"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Executives will no doubt have good arguments for why their businesses won\u2019t be hurt much. China\u2019s airlines will remain reliant on a steady supply of Boeing\u2019s aircraft for a long time. The facilities in China that make G.M. and Apple products are big employers. And since the proposed tariffs most likely won\u2019t be in effect by the time first-quarter earnings are announced, companies will probably be able to get away with some generalities.\n\nStill, the prospect of a trade war raises questions about the adequacy of corporate disclosure. Those of G.M., contained in its latest annual report, seem quite detailed. They offer quite specific warnings about the risks of doing business in China, and the company even mentions the possibility of trade agreements falling apart. But financial reports from Boeing and Apple arguably have less on potential problems in China and trade disputes.\n\nBoeing\u2019s annual report did mention tariffs and embargoes as threats. But the report, released in February, also sounded a bullish note on the global economy that now almost sounds like it was from a different era:\n\n\u201cThe long-term outlook for the industry continues to remain positive due to the fundamental drivers of air travel growth: economic growth and the increasing propensity to travel due to increased trade, globalization, and improved airline services driven by liberalization of air traffic rights between countries.\u201d\n\nWill such language remain in Boeing\u2019s reports?\n\n- Peter Eavis\n\nFed and trade shake markets.\n\nFor years, investors had a singular focus on the Federal Reserve and its plans to raise rates.\n\nAny indication that the Fed could move more aggressively than expected to tighten monetary policies and stocks would pull back.\n\nNow the Fed has company in sending jitters through the market: Trade.\n\nA one-two punch from the White House and the Fed pushed stocks on Wall Street down Friday. The S.&P. 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average both finished off more than 2 percent.\n\nMarkets began to slide at the start of trading after President Trump\u2019s threat on Thursday to heap fresh tariffs on China. Investors took little comfort in statements from the administration\u2019s top economic policymakers, Larry Kudlow, the director of the National Economic Council, and Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary. Both men sought to tamp down the contentious back-and-forth between the two economic giants.\n\nComments from Mr. Powell in the early Friday afternoon added to the unease. In a speech in Chicago, Mr. Powell highlighted the strength of the United States economic recovery and gave little indication that the Fed planned to deviate from its gradual path of lifting interest rates.\n\nPhoto\n\nInvestors should get ready to feel \u2018a little pain.\u2019\n\nPresident Trump, in a radio interview that was taped on Thursday and aired on Friday, acknowledged his approach to China could cause \u201ca little pain\u201d to financial markets but that it would be worth it in the long run.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn WABC Radio\u2019s \u201cBernie & Sid in the Morning\u201d show, Mr. Trump said:\n\n\u201cNow we could\u2014the easiest thing for me to do would be just to close my eyes and forget it.\u201d \u201cIf I did that, I\u2019m not doing my job. So, I\u2019m not saying there won\u2019t be a little pain but the market\u2019s gone up 40 percent, 42 percent \u2014 so we might lose a little bit of it\u2014 but we\u2019re going to have a much stronger country when we\u2019re finished. And that\u2019s what I\u2019m all about. We have to do things that other people wouldn\u2019t do.\u201d\n\nThe president also took to Twitter to defend his approach to trade policy. Mr. Trump, in a tweet, criticized both China and the World Trade Organization, saying that the Chinese \u201cget tremendous perks and advantages, especially over the U.S. Does anybody think this is fair. We were badly represented. The WTO is unfair to U.S.\u201d\n\nThat followed another early morning tweet, in which Mr. Trump boasted that the new metals tariffs he has put into effect on China and other nations had not hurt American consumers as his critics predicted.\n\nSome context here: The price of aluminum per pound has been falling since February, a decline that started before the tariffs were imposed. Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to exempt Canada, which supplied more than half of America\u2019s aluminum imports in 2016, has also helped to soften the blow from tariffs, companies say.\n\n\u2018China is prepared\u2019 to duel on tariffs\n\nIn response to a potential new set of U.S. tariffs on $100 billion worth of Chinese goods, Beijing said in a briefing on Friday that it would \u201cimmediately fight back with a major response.\u201d\n\nMore from what a representative for China\u2019s Ministry of Commerce said:\n\n\u201cWe feel America is very arrogant. They have taken a wrong action. The result is that they will hurt themselves.\u201d\n\nThe briefing \u2014 amid a Chinese holiday \u2014 signals the latest instance of saber-rattling between the U.S. and China on trade. But was Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement on Thursday just a bluff? Even his advisers aren\u2019t sure.\n\nThe Chinese official said that the two sides can\u2019t negotiate under the current conditions. And in an interview with Bloomberg on Friday, Larry Kudlow \u2014 who has been national economic adviser for just under a week \u2014 said he could not predict when talks would begin. He added:\n\nBut China has reasons to think it could win a trade war. (Worth noting: U.S. tariffs wouldn\u2019t bite until after a two-month comment period.)\n\nMore companies, like Cargill, are getting jumpy. Some fear the tensions could kill Qualcomm\u2019s bid for NXP Semiconductor. Jacob Frenkel, the chairman of JPMorgan Chase\u2019s international business, is worried, too: He said the hostilities could be \u201cthe greatest danger to the world economy,\u201d but aren\u2019t at a war level yet. The Economist says that the president\u2019s comments \u201cdo not suggest he is ready to sue for peace.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, the White House hopes to announce a preliminary Nafta deal this month after revising some of its more aggressive demands.\n\nReaction of the day, from Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska:\n\nIs the inflation scare over?\n\nEarlier this year, stocks sold off after the jobs report for January showed a 2.9 percent annual increase in wages, a relatively strong rise. Investors feared that a sustained increase in earnings could prompt consumers to buy more goods and services, pushing up prices in the process. Concerns receded after February\u2019s report showed a 2.6 percent jump in wages, and March\u2019s rise of 2.7 percent is not likely to stir up more worries.\n\nBut as they gauge wage pressures, analysts also pay close attention to the forces that indirectly affect wages. One of those is, of course, the number of additional jobs the economy is creating. March\u2019s gain of 103,000 jobs was below economists\u2019 forecasts and about half the monthly average this year. That weakness will no doubt reduce inflation fears still further.\n\nThe March report contained data that could do even more to quell investors\u2019 nerves over inflation. While the report revised February\u2019s gain higher to 326,000 jobs from 313,000, it sharply reduced the January figure to 176,000 from 239,000. The January revision prompted Jim Vogel, of FTN Financial, to write:\n\n\u201cThat collapsed what had been an upward slope to the last two years of payroll growth and implicitly reduced the upward pressure on wages that so many are still certain will arrive this year.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nHiring slowed in March\n\nThe United States added jobs for its 90th straight month in March, an unprecedented run of growth for the economy, but at a much slower pace than in March.\n\nThe headline numbers\n\n2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 thousand +300 200 100 0 Monthly change in jobs +103,000\n\nMarch 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 thousand +300 200 100 0 +103,000\n\nMarch Monthly change in jobs\n\n\u2022 103,000 jobs were added last month. Wall Street economists had expected an increase of about 185,000, according to Bloomberg.\n\n\u2022 The unemployment rate was 4.1 percent for the sixth straight month.\n\n% +4 2 0 +2.7% \u201908 \u201910 \u201912 \u201914 \u201916 \u201918 Year-over-year wage growth % +4 2 0 +2.7% \u201908 \u201909 \u201910 \u201911 \u201912 \u201913 \u201914 \u201915 \u201916 \u201917 \u201918 Year-over-year wage growth\n\n\u2022 Average earnings rose by 8 cents an hour and are up 2.7 percent over the past year.\n\n% 10 5 0 4.1% \u201908 \u201910 \u201912 \u201914 \u201916 \u201918 Unemployment rate % 10 5 0 4.1% \u201907 \u201908 \u201909 \u201910 \u201911 \u201912 \u201913 \u201914 \u201915 \u201916 \u201917 \u201918 Unemployment Rate\n\n\u2022 Estimates of February\u2019s job growth were revised upward, but January\u2019s figure was revised sharply downward. The net result was a loss of 50,000 jobs relative to prior estimates.\n\nThe takeaways\n\n\u2022 Wage growth remains weaker than most economists would expect when unemployment is so low.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The manufacturing sector has posted solid job gains over the past year, and that growth continued in March, when American factories added 22,000 jobs. But mounting trade tensions with China could threaten the sector\u2019s rebound in the months ahead.\n\n\u2022 Perhaps the biggest surprise in the blockbuster February report was the surge of workers into the labor force. That flood of new workers partly reversed in March, when the labor force shrank by 158,000 people.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhere to begin with the FT\u2019s lunch with the Mooch?\n\nThere\u2019s a lot to quote from Anthony Scaramucci\u2019s meal with Edward Luce of the FT \u2014 held at the Hunt and Fish Club, the Midtown Manhattan restaurant that the onetime investor owns, naturally. So we\u2019ll have to limit ourselves to just a few selections:\n\n\u2022 \u201cThat\u2019s something I get no credit for, by the way,\u201d he says. \u201cI have been for equal opportunity in gay marriage for the last 12 or 13 years.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cSee this?\u201d he says. \u201cThese are front-stabbing knives. You only use these in New York. In Washington you use a shiv, or mechanisms in the press, back-stabbing, subterfuge, opposition research . . . Not in New York. We come at you right from the front.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cMy parents thought it was Hartford law school, Connecticut \u2014 not Harvard,\u201d he says. \u201cTrue story. They\u2019re still alive \u2014 you can ask them. When I told them I was going to Goldman Sachs they didn\u2019t know what that was, either. \u2022 \u201cWall Street is a circulatory system for American capitalism. If its arterial flow is blocked, it blunts and slows down the economic engine for everyone else.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nThe U.S. sanctions Oleg Deripaska\n\nProminent among the Russian oligarchs and businesses sanctioned by the Treasury Department on Friday is Oleg Deripaska, the billionaire known for his jet-setting, his consistent presence at the World Economic Forum in Davos \u2014 and his ties to Vladimir Putin (and, before a falling out, Paul Manafort).\n\nMr. Deripaska is associated with aluminum producers like EN+ Group, which went public in London late year, and Rusal, as well as the commercial vehicle maker GAZ Group and energy producer EuroSibEnergo. All those companies were also sanctioned for being controlled or owned directly or indirectly by Mr. Deripaska.\n\nHere\u2019s what the Treasury Department said about the move against the businessman:\n\nOleg Deripaska is being designated pursuant to E.O. 13661 for having acted or purported to act for or on behalf of, directly or indirectly, a senior official of the Government of the Russian Federation, as well as pursuant to E.O. 13662 for operating in the energy sector of the Russian Federation economy. Deripaska has said that he does not separate himself from the Russian state. He has also acknowledged possessing a Russian diplomatic passport, and claims to have represented the Russian government in other countries. Deripaska has been investigated for money laundering, and has been accused of threatening the lives of business rivals, illegally wiretapping a government official, and taking part in extortion and racketeering. There are also allegations that Deripaska bribed a government official, ordered the murder of a businessman, and had links to a Russian organized crime group.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat does Jamie Dimon\u2019s annual letter say about his politics?\n\nAndrew\u2019s take: A favorite Wall Street parlor game is whether the JPMorgan Chase C.E.O. would run for president in 2020. Mr. Dimon\u2019s latest annual letter increased that chatter, touching on immigration and political polarization. He praised some of President Trump\u2019s policies (on tougher trade negotiations, on taxes). But his stances on deregulation and on social issues likely mean that he would have to run as an independent \u2014 and history hasn\u2019t been kind to third-party candidates.\n\nPeter Eavis adds: The JPMorgan chief also homed in on regulations of bank liquidity, or access to cash and equivalents. He contended that liquidity requirements are higher now \u2014 which he favors \u2014 but are also more rigid and could impinge on lending. But the argument is flawed, in part because banks that have less liquidity aren\u2019t in a position to lend.\n\nPhoto\n\nBlackRock acts on guns\n\nThe investment behemoth\u2019s plan to offer new funds that exclude gun makers or sellers is the latest prominent step by a financial firm to offer some support to gun control. (And with $6.3 trillion under management, the firm\u2019s actions carry enormous weight.) The products include:\n\n\u2022 A new exchange-traded fund that focuses on favorable environmental, social and governance (E.S.G.) standards and excludes firearms-related companies. BlackRock will update other E.S.G. funds to exclude them, too.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "A Trade War Will Test Corporate America\u2019s Openness: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Once established as a global reserve currency, the dollar has been kept strong by sustained demand for it, and a strong dollar makes American exports expensive to the rest of the world. American exports decline, imports increase, and a result is the trade deficit. Testifying before Congress in 1960, the economist Robert Triffin observed that the dollar\u2019s global reserve status depends on the willingness of the United States to run trade deficits. This relationship, known as Triffin\u2019s Dilemma, doesn\u2019t always hold true (other countries have had reserve currencies and a trade surplus), but the American trade deficit with China, $375.2 billion last year, offers perhaps the best example of how a strong currency and trade deficits are connected.\n\nStill, there are enormous benefits to being able to print paper money and have the world treat it as if it were gold. Other countries need American dollars, and they are willing to pay a premium to hold them. Valery Giscard d\u2019Estaing, finance minister of France from 1962 to 1966, called this an \u201cexorbitant privilege.\u201d Once they have amassed those all-important dollars, countries use them to buy United States Treasury bonds. (China alone held $1.2 trillion dollars of United States government debt at the end of 2017.) This enormous global demand for American debt means that the United States can borrow at relatively low interest rates, financing its budget deficits away.\n\nThe \u201cexorbitant privilege\u201d extends to ordinary Americans, who have access to a vast supply of credit and can borrow to buy homes and cars at lower interest rates.\n\nAs the trade war rhetoric escalates, some raise the fear that China could sell off its dollar-denominated assets, which could trigger a rise in interest rates, inflation and possibly devaluation of the dollar. Even the threat of a sudden sell-off can stir up trouble in global currency markets. China could also diversify its cash reserves away from the dollar and acquire yen, euro or sterling instruments, or commodities such as gold. Indeed, China has already been accumulating gold, ranking as one of the world\u2019s largest importers of it.\n\nChina and the United States are too closely economically intertwined via the dollar to make that a credible fear. United States treasuries are still the world\u2019s safe haven of choice. And selling off American debt would cause the yuan to appreciate, which would put China\u2019s exports at a disadvantage.\n\nStill, China is clearly taking steps to ensure a larger role for its currency. In 2015, the yuan was designated by the International Monetary Fund as one of five elite currencies in the world, along with the dollar, the euro, the pound and the yen. China is putting in place a pilot program with Russia and Angola, in which it can buy oil with yuan instead of with dollars. As the biggest importer of crude oil in the world, China believes it has the purchasing power to push for settlement in yuan. Even Saudi Arabia, a stalwart American ally, is under increasing pressure to accept yuan for its oil trade. If the yuan does become a global reserve currency, China, too, could see its influence and economic power expand even further.", "title": "Opinion | A Trade War the U.S. Is Actually Winning, for Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJacqueline Winspear was mired in London gridlock back in 2001 when her fictional detective, Maisie Dobbs, popped into her head. \u201cStoplights were at red as far as I could see,\u201d the novelist remembers. \u201cIn my mind\u2019s eye I saw a woman walk up the old wooden escalator at the Warren Street underground station, dressed in the garb of the mid-1920s. She spoke to the newspaper vendor, then made her way along the street to a building, where she took an envelope with two keys from her bag ... I was shaken out of my daydream by honking from cars stuck behind me. I could not wait to get home to start writing.\u201d Maisie Dobbs \u2014 nurse turned private eye \u2014 now has a devoted following (Hillary Clinton is a fan), and the 14th book in the series, \u201cTo Die but Once,\u201d debuts at No. 5 on the fiction list.\n\nWinspear, who sets the books largely in the period between the two world wars, was drawn to that era from a young age. \u201cAs a small child, I was aware my grandfather had difficulty breathing, that he would often be in pain \u2014 and we had to be quiet around him,\u201d she recalls. \u201cMy questions were always met with the same answer: \u2018Granddad was wounded in the Great War.\u2019 Not injured. Not hurt. He was wounded, and there was something in the word that seemed to suggest something deeper, a wounding that went to the very soul of a person.\u201d\n\nAs she grew older, Winspear says, \u201cI became more and more interested in the \u2018war to end all wars\u2019 and its impact on ordinary people, especially the women of that generation.\u201d Her research led back to her grandparents. \u201cI have always wondered how it might have felt for my grandfather, wounded at the Battle of the Somme in 1916, to see his sons joining the army in World War II, and my grandmother, partially blinded in a munitions factory explosion, when her children were called up for military service. I wanted to move my characters through time to explore that experience, all underpinned by a mystery, that archetypal journey through chaos to resolution.\u201d\n\nWinspear doesn\u2019t outline before she writes. When she began the first Maisie Dobbs book, she stuck three huge Post-its on the wall. \u201cOn one I marked the major landing points in the story. On another I kept track of characters and on the third I noted anything I didn\u2019t know but needed to know to develop the story,\u201d she says. \u201cI have kept to that system ever since. My landing points give me direction, yet leave room to dance with the moment \u2014 permission to go down an unplanned byway if I am inspired to do so.\u201d", "title": "A Traffic Jam Changed Her Life", "authors": ["Tina Jordan", "Inside The List"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "MARIA RESPONDO, Philippines \u2014 Angel Cabaluna dusted makeup onto her thighs, styled her hair in loose curls and applied smoky eye shadow that glittered on her lids.\n\nAs this hamlet of cornfields and concrete houses prepared for festivities honoring its patron saint, and as some people gathered in prayer, Ms. Cabaluna, 20, was primping to compete in an annual transgender beauty pageant.\n\n\u201cThis is our passion,\u201d she later said.\n\nDominated by conservative morals taught by the Roman Catholic Church, the Philippines is also one of Southeast Asia\u2019s most tolerant countries toward gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people. And lawmakers are taking steps to ensure national legal protections that would penalize discrimination against them.\n\nAt the pageant, children sat cross-legged in the dirt, crowded close to the spindly stage where the contestants spun and danced in red feather headdresses, gold brocade and clouds of tulle. The crowd laughed and cheered as they delivered flowery speeches, weaving jokes with witty rhymes, beauty-queen platitudes and proclamations on gender equality.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a nearby chapel, the pageant\u2019s blaring pop songs mixed with the steady rhythm of churchgoers reciting the rosary.", "title": "A Transgender Paradox, and Platform, in the Philippines", "authors": ["Aurora Almendral"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "But what Uwe showed was that while America spent much more on health than anyone else, we weren\u2019t getting better care or even more care than other countries; we were just paying higher prices. That was a hugely important insight, one that Uwe delved into in a series of path-breaking papers. To give you a sense of the kinds of things he explored, another of his major papers was titled \u201cThe pricing of US hospital services: chaos behind a veil of secrecy.\u201d\n\nYou might think that everyone would be eager to get health care facts right; that is, you might think that if you\u2019ve been living in a cave for, I don\u2019t know, the past 35 years or so. The reality is that policy debates over health care are, if anything, even uglier than average for U.S. economic debate, which is really saying something; the reason, I think, is because the facts \u2013 the kind of facts Uwe dedicated his working life to discovering \u2013 are so inconsistent with many forms of political orthodoxy.\n\nSo it would have been understandable and forgivable if Uwe had become a pugnacious, somewhat angry warrior. The miraculous thing is that he didn\u2019t. In the battlefield of ideas and ideology that is health economics, Uwe was always a calm voice of reason, telling people things they didn\u2019t want to hear but without a trace of personal rancor. I\u2019ve run into people who vigorously disagreed with Uwe \u2013 vigorously and, invariably, wrongly. But I\u2019ve never run into anyone who disliked him.\n\nAnd while keeping an even keel amid intellectual storms, he managed at the same time to be something you might guess from his paper titles: consistently, uproariously funny. Every talk I ever heard him give was simultaneously serious in purpose and a barrel of laughs; everyone I know who ever heard him talk says the same thing.\n\nThat was Uwe Reinhardt the economist. Let me just finish up with a few words about Uwe Reinhardt the man. I\u2019ve known a few people who were as charming, gracious, and fun to be around as Uwe; I\u2019ve known a few couples who seemed to complement each other as well, to make the world a better place, as Uwe and May. But I\u2019ve never known either an individual or a pair to surpass them. Uwe was a great man but also a good man, a joy to know, and his life partner was and is every bit his match. We lost him far too soon, but were blessed to have had him at all.", "title": "Opinion | A Tribute to Uwe Reinhardt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, made a big announcement this week: The E.P.A. will reconsider, and most likely roll back, Obama-era automobile standards for greenhouse gas emissions and fuel efficiency. The decision goes beyond what even the automakers had asked for, and sets up a showdown with California over air pollution rules.\n\nBut headlines in recent days have focused on Mr. Pruitt himself as he faces a growing list of potential ethics scandals. It can be hard to follow every development, so let us catch you up on some of the biggest ones dogging Mr. Pruitt this week.\n\nTravel: Mr. Pruitt is still under fire for extensive first-class and business-class travel. Records obtained by the Environmental Integrity Project and reviewed by The New York Times showed that two weeks of travel in June for the administrator and his aides cost taxpayers more than $120,000. The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is reviewing Mr. Pruitt\u2019s travel, as is the E.P.A.\u2019s inspector general. On Tuesday Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, Democrat of Rhode Island, wrote to Mr. Pruitt asking him to explain a $40,000 five-day trip to Morocco with staff in December. Mr. Whitehouse cited the administrator\u2019s calendar for the trip, which showed one full workday and two other days with one hourlong meeting each. The E.P.A. did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nRaises: Amid all the scrutiny of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s travel and personal finances, other issues are brewing inside the agency. The Atlantic broke a story Tuesday showing that the administrator bypassed the usual White House procedures to give political appointees substantial raises. The aides, Sarah Greenwalt and Millan Hupp, had both worked for Mr. Pruitt in Oklahoma, where he served as attorney general before coming to the E.P.A. Ms. Greenwalt\u2019s salary was raised to $164,200 from $107,435, while Ms. Hupp\u2019s was raised to $114,590 from $86,460. Citing anonymous sources, the article outlines how Mr. Pruitt reappointed the aides with higher salaries under a provision of the Safe Drinking Water Act after the White House did not approve the raises. The E.P.A. did not dispute the story.\n\nOn Wednesday, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, was asked whether Mr. Trump was \u201cO.K.\u201d with Mr. Pruitt\u2019s apartment arrangement. \u201cThe president\u2019s not,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re reviewing the situation. When we have had a chance to have a deeper dive on it, we\u2019ll let you know the outcomes of that, but we\u2019re currently reviewing that here at the White House.\u201d", "title": "A Trip to Morocco. A Condo Rental. Here\u2019s Why Scott Pruitt Is Under Fire.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "A week and a half later, McCall and the state attorney, Gordon Oldham, announced they had found the rapist and were holding him in custody. The alleged culprit? Jesse Delbert Daniels, an impoverished, mentally impaired 19-year-old with a fifth-grade education. Daniels was also white. Oldham explained that the house was so dark at the time of the rape that Knowles had misidentified her assailant\u2019s skin color.\n\nPhoto\n\nWas this a case in which justice was actually served? Or was something more confounding \u2014 and insidious \u2014 at work? McCall had held two black men in custody for several days; Knowles stated that a black man attacked her, and now McCall, who once declared that black men had a \u201cbarbarous animal instinct\u201d that \u201ca white man don\u2019t have,\u201d was suddenly saying a white man did it.\n\nAs a local journalist named Mabel Norris Reese put it at the time, this was a puzzling turn from an office \u201cthat gloats over the \u2018crime record\u2019 of Negroes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf McCall is the villain of King\u2019s book, Reese is clearly the hero, doggedly trying to find out what happened to Blanche Knowles while teaming up with Daniels\u2019s mother, Pearl, to advocate on his behalf. At a hearing that lasted barely five minutes, Truman G. Futch \u2014 the same judge from the Groveland case \u2014 deemed Daniels \u201cinsane and incompetent,\u201d and had him committed to the Florida State Hospital at Chattahoochee without a trial. Daniels, who still slept with a teddy bear, would spend the next 14 years there, confined to the criminal ward.\n\nReese got ensnared in a tangled web of promising leads and dead ends \u2014 as does King\u2019s book, which can get bogged down in the morass of Lake County\u2019s unrelenting racism and squalid corruption.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA chapter on Chattahoochee meanders away from the Daniels case and into varieties of shock therapy, ice pick lobotomies, Rosemary Kennedy and unwritten \u201cparamour rights.\u201d Another chapter is devoted to the plight of the Platt family, whose five children were expelled from a Lake County public school in 1954 on suspicion of being black (even though the Platts identified as Irish-Indian and had government documentation stating they were white). McCall insisted on inspecting the children himself, pointing to the 13-year-old daughter and saying, \u201cI don\u2019t like the shape of that one\u2019s nose.\u201d\n\nThis isn\u2019t to say that King\u2019s digressions are uninteresting, or even irrelevant. It\u2019s just that combined with the baroque twists of the Daniels case, the book begins to get unwieldy. King, an amateur historian, has an appreciation for the startling detail and the circuitous connection. He\u2019s clearly done his research, unearthing transcripts and talking to survivors.\n\nBut where \u201cDevil in the Grove\u201d pitted McCall\u2019s viciousness against the rich and complicated character of Thurgood Marshall, the future Supreme Court justice who defended the Groveland Four, \u201cBeneath a Ruthless Sun\u201d tracks the noble efforts of Reese, who is mainly presented here through her earnest editorials. No doubt Reese was not as one-dimensional as the upstanding figure in this book (in the Groveland case, King mentions, she had initially called for the execution of the defendants). But without a more riveting linchpin to anchor the narrative, \u201cBeneath a Ruthless Sun\u201d grows as sprawling as the conspiracy it depicts.\n\nWhich ultimately might illustrate King\u2019s point. The plot against Daniels seems baffling, verging on nonsensical \u2014 until you begin to see the community the way King does: so deformed by racial animus and misogyny that the white establishment of Lake County deemed it less of an \u201cindignity\u201d for Knowles to have been raped by a white man than a black man.\n\nTo disclose too many details would be to spoil the book, since much of its momentum relies on the true crime at the center of it, and the mystery of how the many bewildering bits of information might all fit together. The racism and corruption King depicts were so embedded in Lake County that they perverted even perversions of justice; the argument is timely and important, even if one sometimes wishes it were more clearly made.", "title": "A True-Crime Mystery From the 1950s, Fueled by Racism and Corruption", "authors": ["Jennifer Szalai", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "If they were genuinely grateful to Mr. Trump, they were also seen as stoking the ego of the impulsive American leader so that he would continue to support South Korea\u2019s efforts to resolve the North Korean crisis through dialogue.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Trump mentioned in a tweet the possibility of meeting Mr. Kim at the border between North and South Korea, where Friday\u2019s meeting between Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon was held.\n\nMr. Trump has also been eager to take credit for Mr. Kim\u2019s shift in behavior as the inter-Korean summit has fanned speculation that he could receive the Nobel Peace Prize.\n\nWhen Mr. Trump held a rally in Michigan on Saturday, his fans chanted \u201cNobel, Nobel, Nobel!\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s very nice, thank you. That\u2019s very nice,\u201d a visibly flattered Mr. Trump said in response. \u201cI just want to get the job done.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSenator Lindsey Graham, a Trump ally who is sometimes critical of the president, said that if Mr. Trump \u201ccan lead us to ending the Korean War\u201d while \u201cgetting North Korea to give up their nuclear program\u201d in a verifiable way, then he \u201cdeserves the Nobel Peace Prize and then some.\u201d\n\nBut some were skeptical about Mr. Trump\u2019s chances \u2014 including his own son. \u201cThe globalist elite would never give him that win,\u201d Donald Trump Jr. tweeted on Friday.\n\nNo matter what the likelihood is for Mr. Trump\u2019s getting a Nobel, his public image among South Koreans has been improving markedly as the mood on the Korean Peninsula shifts from fears of war to hopes of peace.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring their summit meeting, Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon agreed to push for talks with Washington to negotiate a peace treaty to formally end the 1950-53 Korean War, an agreement that, to the pleasant surprise of many South Koreans, a usually tempestuous Mr. Trump has eagerly endorsed.\n\nLast year, as tensions escalated on the Korean Peninsula, with Mr. Trump\u2019s administration openly threatening military action against North Korea, Mr. Moon publicly denounced such talk, swearing that no such military action would take place without South Korea\u2019s consent. When Mr. Trump visited Seoul in November, weeks after he threatened to \u201ctotally destroy\u201d North Korea, protesters took to the streets in Seoul, calling him \u201ca war maniac.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThese days, it is easy to find citizens and political analysts in South Korea who mouth something few would have imagined a few months ago: support for giving Mr. Trump, Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon the Nobel Prize together should they achieve lasting peace.\n\nSuch talk reflects rising hopes for coming discussions between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim, the first summit meeting between the leaders of the United States and North Korea, which could happen by early June.\n\nSkeptics, however, say that Mr. Kim might be duping Mr. Moon and Mr. Trump into a false peace.\n\nTo whet Mr. Kim\u2019s appetite for a deal, Mr. Moon on Friday handed Mr. Kim a computer thumb drive that contained detailed plans to rebuild the North\u2019s decrepit economy if Mr. Kim denuclearizes his country, aides to Mr. Moon said.\n\nAnd when Mr. Kim talked alone with Mr. Moon, without aides, he sought Mr. Moon\u2019s advice for his coming talks with Mr. Trump, they said. Mr. Moon found Mr. Kim forthright and courteous, they said.\n\nStill, the prospect that Mr. Kim could even be considered for a Nobel is likely to alarm human rights activists. Mr. Kim has also been accused of masterminding the fatal poisoning of his half brother.", "title": "A Trump Nobel Peace Prize? South Korea\u2019s Leader Likes the Idea", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "In several tweets, Mr. Trump referred to \u201ccaravans\u201d of immigrants headed toward the United States\u2019 southern border. Buzzfeed has reported that hundreds of Central Americans are walking en masse through Mexico, staying together for protection from cartels and immigration authorities. Organizers estimated that up to 10 to 15 percent of the migrants would seek asylum at the United States border.\n\nBut to qualify for DACA, or Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, the immigrants would have had to have been living in the United States since 2007. Furthermore, in September Mr. Trump rescinded the program, which shielded immigrants who arrived in the United States illegally as children from deportation.\n\nThough the program\u2019s fate is tied up in court, American immigration officials are not accepting new applications.", "title": "A Twitter Rant That Rails and Misleads on Immigration Policy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Most of those bills have stalled, though, sparing for now a substantial revenue stream for the video game industry, which is eager to counter rising production costs.\n\nActivision Blizzard, whose portfolio includes popular games like Candy Crush, Call of Duty and Hearthstone, generated $4 billion in 2017 from in-game transactions, more than half of its total revenue. That amount includes both loot boxes, whose specific contents aren\u2019t revealed until after they\u2019re bought, and traditional purchases.\n\nDan Hewitt, vice president of media relations for the Entertainment Software Association, an industry trade group, said loot boxes are not gambling because they each provide something to use in the game. They offer an alternate experience and players are not required to buy them, he said.\n\n\u201cOur industry constantly tests new business models because those innovations can drive creativity and fan engagement,\u201d Mr. Hewitt said. He added that legislation is unnecessary because the industry responds to players\u2019 concerns. The Entertainment Software Rating Board recently has introduced an \u201cin-game purchases\u201d label, and consoles have parental controls that can block children from buying in-game content.\n\nPhoto\n\nCritics say that those steps are inadequate and that loot boxes are predatory, seducing people with murky odds and dazzling presentations. Even if they are not legally deemed gambling, they share core principles with casino games, said Keith Whyte, executive director of the National Council on Problem Gambling.\n\n\u201cIntermittent variable reinforcement is the means of delivering rewards that is the most exciting to the human brain,\u201d Mr. Whyte said. \u201cIt is the fundamental basis to slot machines. It is the fundamental basis to loot boxes. There is no distinction.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMost loot boxes can be accumulated free by playing the game, but they are also for sale: In Overwatch, a vibrant team-based shooter by Blizzard, they are sold in packages from two for $2 to 50 for $40. The items in the loot boxes vary in rarity: common, rare, epic and legendary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe software association has compared loot boxes to packs of sports cards or games like Pok\u00e9mon and Magic: The Gathering. In the 1990s, unsuccessful lawsuits made similar gambling claims against the companies of those products.\n\nBut there is a difference, said State Senator Kevin Ranker, who sponsored the bill in Washington: \u201cThe entire setup of digital gaming, the entire visual of it, the entire sensory load of it, is rapid and is immediate.\u201d\n\nThose audiovisual cues are important, Mr. Whyte said, noting that casinos have preserved the sound of crashing coins even though slot machine winnings now come on slips of paper. When an elite soccer player is opened in the game FIFA 18, fireworks explode and confetti falls. Overwatch\u2019s items soar into view to a triumphant tune.\n\nGaming commissions in the United Kingdom and New Zealand have said loot boxes are not gambling. The Belgian Gaming Commission, however, announced this week that it was, and the Netherlands has said that at least four popular games violate its gambling laws because loot box items can be transferred in a marketplace, assigning them value.\n\nPlayer opinions are not monolithic.\n\nJames Tuttle, 38, of Wilmington, Mass., considered the $300 he has spent on Overwatch loot boxes worthwhile because he has played for more than 800 hours. \u201cI don\u2019t see it as a gamble, I see it as an investment for future fun,\u201d he said.\n\nDenis Kharlamov, 27, of Toronto, has spent about $900, primarily when items are available for a limited time. \u201cIt is addicting,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen you are opening those loot boxes, there is definitely a feeling of euphoria when you get something you perceive as valuable.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA public outcry came in November, during an early access period for Star Wars Battlefront 2. Frustrated players complained that unlocking popular characters like Luke Skywalker and Darth Vader for use in multiplayer modes would require playing for dozens of hours \u2014 or wielding a credit card instead of a light saber.\n\nFaced with the perception it was greedy, Electronic Arts, the game\u2019s publisher, removed the option to pay for loot boxes hours before the game was released.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA company spokesman declined to comment, and it was unclear how it will incorporate loot boxes in future games. Blizzard did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nLoot boxes have been prevalent for at least a decade, mostly in free games, but the Battlefront controversy was \u201cthe first real big punch in the gut,\u201d said Christopher Hansford, the political engagement director for Consumers for Digital Fairness, which wants randomized in-game transactions regulated as gambling.\n\nIt was also the catalyst for Mr. Lee\u2019s legislative proposals in Hawaii. The bill that has survived would force publishers to publicly disclose the odds of loot boxes \u2014 a requirement that already exists in China.\n\nOther loot box legislation has faltered, including a California bill seeking warning labels; a Hawaii bill proposing a minimum age of 21; an Indiana bill asking the attorney general whether they \u201cprey on children\u201d; a Minnesota bill requiring the disclosure of odds; and a Washington bill turning to its gambling commission.", "title": "A Video Game \u2018Loot Box\u2019 Offers Coveted Rewards, but Is It Gambling?", "authors": ["Jason M. Bailey"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Two weeks after the 2016 election, President-elect Donald J. Trump was in the middle of making the press rounds and had scheduled a meeting with The New York Times. But on the morning of Nov. 22, The Times learned via Twitter that Mr. Trump was canceling. He claimed that the \u201cfailing\u201d New York Times had changed the conditions \u2014 \u201cnot nice.\u201d The paper held its ground, saying it was the Trump team who had tried to change the rules when he asked that the meeting be off the record, which it had refused. Hours later, the president-elect changed course, tweeting the meeting was back on: \u201cLook forward to it!\u201d\n\nThat day, I was sitting at my desk, trying to figure out, as a filmmaker, how to make sense of the seismic political shift that had occurred. Everyone I knew was doing the same thing. Calls with ideas for films had been flying in since Mr. Trump\u2019s win \u2014 people trying to get a handle on a future that they had not prepared for, that they desperately wanted to engage with. Nothing felt quite right \u2014 nothing felt big enough \u2014 until that morning. Scanning Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter feed, I thought, \u201cI want to be a fly on the wall for that meeting.\u201d Now all I had to do was convince The Times!\n\nRespect for the First Amendment is in my DNA. My father was a civil liberties lawyer; he fought for Lenny Bruce\u2019s right to offend when his comedy routine violated New York\u2019s obscenity statutes in 1964, and for American neo-Nazis\u2019 right to march in 1978 in the Chicago suburb of Skokie, Ill., where many Holocaust survivors lived. Now we have a sitting president who called the free press \u201cthe enemy of the people,\u201d frequently singling out The Times for derision his bully pulpit.\n\nIt seemed to me that story was extraordinary from The Times\u2019s point of view as well. How would the organization take stock of this new era, one that it \u2014 and its peers \u2014 hadn\u2019t fully understood during the 2016 election, and rethink coverage amid a chaotic administration with little transparency?", "title": "A View Inside \u2018The Fourth Estate\u2019 During Trump\u2019s First Year", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "There are violinists who talk about Strads, which are old, and Zygs, which are less old. The violinist Chad Hoopes, who used to play a Strad, now plays the other.\n\nThe word \u201cnewer\u201d would have been tidier in that first sentence. But \u201cless old\u201d seemed appropriate after Mr. Hoopes, who went from playing a Strad made in 1713 to playing a Zyg made in 1991, said that the Zyg is \u201cnot a new violin.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s older than I am,\u201d he added, quickly.\n\nIt is, by almost four years. Mr. Hoopes is 23. In 2016, The Washington Post said he had been \u201crising \u2014 or maybe hurtling \u2014 toward international stardom\u201d since he was a teenager. Last year he won an Avery Fisher Career Grant through a program established by the electronics executive and philanthropist.\n\nNow, about those violin names.\n\nStrads were made in Italy more than 300 years ago by Antonio Stradivari. Almost ever since, aficionados have tried to figure out what made them so special, what gave them their almost magical properties. Was it the wood? Was it the varnish, which changes the way the wood vibrates? Was it the F-shaped holes on the front, as suggested by scientists who studied the matter? (The F-holes serve as escape hatches for air from inside \u2014 air that resonates with the strings, contributing to the tone.)", "title": "A Violinist Goes From a Strad to a Zyg and Finds Happiness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "In Part 2, Kit and Ahmed move to Beirut, she converts to Islam so they can marry and Ahmed becomes more and more secretive. As Kit discovers the truth about him, his manipulative manner has a ring of authenticity, particularly when it emerges that his first wife was still alive when he and Kit married, and he has a son he has never told her about. After his first wife dies in Baghdad, he asks Kit to help raise the boy. \u201cIf you are the woman I love,\u201d he tells her, \u201cyou will forgive me.\u201d We are never sure whether Ahmed is simply a liar and adulterer or a man whose political leanings are taking him \u2014 and, by extension, Kit \u2014 down a very dangerous path.\n\nImage\n\nThe political mysteries in Steavenson\u2019s novel could be gripping, but the form-versus-content battle rages throughout. Given the circumstances, it\u2019s easy to accept, for example, that we can never fully understand what Ahmed is up to or why. But our emotional engagement is diminished when potentially dramatic events lead nowhere. In Part 1, Kit negotiates a dangerous journey out of Baghdad to investigate attacks on American soldiers in a town called Samarra. At one point, she and her photographer, Zorro, are locked in a room by the fighter they\u2019ve been interviewing. Have they been abducted? Is an attack in progress? The possibilities are terrifying. But there\u2019s no time for much tension to develop: Within just a few lines, they\u2019re released unharmed. Further on, there is a visit to a remote Syrian monastery and a taut, evocative scene in which mysterious, threatening men come in search of Ahmed. Instead of shooting or kidnapping him, however, it turns out that they, like all the main characters, want to have an intense discussion about the Middle East and its problems.\n\nSo many scenes involve the characters talking about politics or art that I wondered if Steavenson, who now lives in Paris, reads a lot of French fiction, where it\u2019s considered perfectly acceptable to halt the action for page after page so the characters can drink, eat and philosophize. It\u2019s a device that\u2019s likely to make your average English-language reader impatient.\n\nIn Part 3, the novel moves to Paris. Kit and Ahmed separate, and when he returns to Baghdad she takes sole custody of her stepson, Little Ahmed, becoming the blond stepmother of an Iraqi Muslim in a country increasingly suspicious of young men who fit that description. She befriends a woman called Rousse, who works at Charlie Hebdo and is among the victims of the killings there in January 2015 \u2014 although in real life the only woman murdered at the magazine\u2019s office was the columnist Elsa Cayat. The insertion of one of the fictional characters in \u201cParis Metro\u201d into a very real massacre is a tricky balancing act that Steavenson pulls off with sensitivity, but it raises yet again the question of why she has chosen to relate these events in the form of a novel.\n\nIn these middle sections, the stop-start nature of the narrative becomes particularly frustrating. Steavenson has such an abundance of material that it\u2019s never clear what story she\u2019s telling. Is this the tale of a cross-cultural marriage and adoption gone wrong or a political thriller? Is it about the loss of a friend in a terrorist attack or a search for cultural identity? In many ways, \u201cParis Metro\u201d seems to be about the psychological cost of being a perpetual bystander.", "title": "A War Correspondent Comes Home, Bringing War With Her", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Of all the figures due for cinematic canonization on the centennial of World War I\u2019s conclusion, a dog named Stubby might not seem like the obvious choice. But Stubby was famous \u2014 the first dog given rank in the United States Armed Forces, according to the Smithsonian.\n\nAlso, \u201cSgt. Stubby: An American Hero\u201d is a computer-animated film. Stubby\u2019s feats of derring-do would upstage the human interest even if those humans didn\u2019t look eerily round and smooth.\n\nBefore his heroism, Stubby was a stray from New Haven, Conn., who joined in training exercises with the man who adopted him, J. Stubby: An American Hero\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "After Ms. Brown graduated in spring 2016 from Colby College in Maine, she packed her things and drove to Cleveland to volunteer for the Clinton campaign. She was quickly hired as a field organizer and walked precincts, talked to voters and worked on turnout. After the campaign, she assumed she would get a job in strategic communications or maybe journalism, but Mrs. Clinton\u2019s loss made her believe she had to stay in politics and work to elect women.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI really revisited my values and thought to myself, I could move to a firm or go in another direction,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cBut if this is about to be as bad as we think it is going to be, I want to be able to look back and say I did everything I could when our country was threatened.\u201d\n\nShe connected with the Virginia chapter of Emerge America, a group that trains Democratic women to run for office. That led her to Wendy Gooditis, then a candidate for the Virginia House of Delegates who had $700 in campaign money and very little chance to win. Ms. Brown helped her create a compelling message, then relentlessly worked on raising money and contacting voters. Within six months, the campaign had raised $500,000, and Ms. Gooditis won her race in November.\n\nMs. Brown\u2019s success made an impression on Ms. Davis Stover, a former chief of staff to a Democratic congressman, who is running against Representative Barbara Comstock, one of the most vulnerable House Republicans.\n\n\u201cI wanted a woman to run our race,\u201d Ms. Davis Stover said. \u201cI wanted Emma because she\u2019s intelligent, she\u2019s compassionate, she\u2019s driven. I wanted someone with grit to walk through the fire.\u201d", "title": "A Wave of Young Women Running Campaigns (and Changing Politics)", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Together with Sorensen and Brandrup, he told the team that there would be no hard feelings for anyone who decided to go immediately. The rest, he said, would wait until Friday at 3 p.m. If no money arrived then, if no new owner had been found, they would have no choice but to leave.\n\nThe mood was anxious. In private, the players would ask each other their intentions, but it was hard, Hebo said, to be sure everyone was being honest. \u201cMaybe one person told you one thing and said something different to others,\u201d he said. Surreptitious phone calls prompted suspicion: Was he talking to his agent, arranging a move?\n\nTauber did what he could to canvass opinion. \u201cI talked to almost everybody,\u201d he said, about contracts, but also about wives, and children, and mortgages. Looking back, now, he knows that not everyone told him the truth.\n\nIn the end, five players decided they could not take the risk, and left. One, Casper Nielsen, a fullback who had already agreed to sign for Aarhus at the end of the season, simply brought his move forward. Even then, Tauber said, \u201che refused to be the first: He would not be the one who took everyone with him.\u201d\n\nBy Thursday night, though, Tauber feared it was over. He had heard there might be a chance of salvation, but time was running out. The artificial deadline \u2014 3 p.m. the next day \u2014 was fast approaching. \u201cI knew it was close, but I also knew they were missing a few million kroner,\u201d he said of the new investors. And so he spent that night on the phone to his teammates one more time, to \u201chear their situations, hear their thoughts.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt 6 a.m. on Friday, Byder\u2019s phone beeped. \u201cThanks for last night,\u201d read the first email on the thread. Seven of the potential investors that had gathered the previous night had agreed to try to save the club. A local lawyer, Lars Borring, registered a company: The Friends of Lyngby had been born. That morning, the members started transferring money \u2014 some $50,000, some closer to $1 million \u2014 to replenish the club\u2019s accounts.\n\nAfter training, the squad gathered in the canteen at Lyngby\u2019s stadium. The last of the money had landed in the new company\u2019s accounts with 15 minutes to spare. Petersen and Jorgensen told the players the money was in place. They would be paid.\n\n\u201cBoom, like that, everyone stays,\u201d Hebo said. In his car on the way home, Tauber cried with relief. Byder, though, had another problem. The bank account was empty again.\n\nThe Friends Multiply\n\nThere were, at the start, seven Friends of Lyngby. There are now more than 20: lawyers and chief executives and restaurateurs, as well as several players who started their careers at the club\u2019s academy. Andreas Bjelland, a Danish international now with Brentford in England, was the first; three others have followed.\n\nThey are, as Byder said, a \u201cteam behind the team,\u201d their experience in a whole swath of industries, all of which he believes can help develop the club in some way. \u201cWe reflect different resources,\u201d he said. Sponsors are returning, too, eager to be involved.\n\nThe club\u2019s accounts, quickly emptied to pay the players\u2019 overdue wages and the team\u2019s outstanding bills, have been filled again. The new owners remain open to further investment; the only requirement is that any further Friends should not have \u201cterms and conditions\u201d to their input. This is with the heart, as Byder told the first few to sign up; it is investing in fun.", "title": "A Week Inside a Soccer Club When the Money Runs Out", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "HOUSTON \u2014 It\u2019s going to be strange, living in Houston without Barbara Bush. She was so much a part of this place, even if many of us just imagined that we had anything to do with her. All those literacy galas starring best-selling authors, the loyal appearances at Astros games (thank God she lived to see them win the World Series!), the endless questions about who she would and would not support, and the bracingly frank answers that often seemed a little jolting in a country-club Republican wife. (See most recently: \u201cI don\u2019t know how women\u201d could vote for Donald Trump.)\n\nUnlike so many flash-in-the-pan socialites here, Mrs. Bush reigned like a semi-benevolent monarch for decades, particularly after she and 41 moved back to Houston permanently in the 1990s, following that painful loss to Bill Clinton. And once 43 took over the White House in 2000, the Bush stock, which never hit a low here, began to rise precipitously again. It will be very hard to forget all those dinner parties where to say an unkind word about any member of the Bush family was to assure that you were never, ever invited back.\n\nIn the beginning, they didn\u2019t cause much of a fuss. The Bushes came to Houston from West Texas in 1962, when George H.W. had already set the family on the path to wealth as president of a small oil company. Back then, there were lots of families who were linked to the oil business, and many of them were, well, more colorful. The Bushes were just another pair of Yankee immigrants without much flash, which in those days was the behavior of choice.\n\nThen George got into politics, running for president of the Harris County Republican Party in \u201962. Most Texans were Democrats back then \u2014 even if they were right-wing Democrats \u2014 and Barbara\u2019s introduction to local politics sounds about right. She got a flier in the mail calling her father, a publisher of women\u2019s magazines, \u201ca tool of the Commies,\u201d as she wrote in her autobiography, and when she canvassed a neighborhood for her husband a woman kept spitting in her flowerpot while Mrs. Bush asked for her support. Another not-so-potential supporter answered the door in his underwear \u201cand didn\u2019t seem to mind a bit.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A Well-Bred Yankee Embraced by Houston", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA woman and her daughter were killed in a fire that tore through their two-story Queens house before dawn on Monday, the authorities said.\n\nNeighbors woke to thick smoke that shrouded the wood-frame house on Wheatley Street in Far Rockaway.\n\n\u201cI could see the flames igniting inside,\u201d said Elease Oakley, who lives next door. She added that firefighters had knocked at her door shortly after 4 a.m. to tell her and her family to evacuate.\n\n\u201cI could feel the heat,\u201d Ms. Oakley said.\n\nAs firefighters battled the blaze, others searched inside and discovered the victims in separate locations, said James Long, a Fire Department spokesman.\n\nBoth women were taken to St. John\u2019s Episcopal Hospital.
