Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Flint said his transport association, which has a liaison stationed at the Federal Aviation Administration\u2019s command center in Virginia, had agreed to help facilitate communication between international airlines and the Port Authority and terminal operators.\n\n\u201cWe look forward to working with the Port Authority and all stakeholders to collaboratively develop procedures based on industry best practices and expertise that will enhance the customer experience going forward,\u201d Mr. Flint said in a statement.\n\nInside two of the terminals at Kennedy in January, baggage-handling procedures broke down, leaving hundreds of pieces of luggage piled up in waiting areas. Some travelers did not get their bags back for days.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo prevent a recurrence, Port Authority officials said they would require terminal operators to have a common baggage-service office for airlines that do not have their own. Mr. Cotton said the agency would impose this obligation \u201cso a passenger who is looking for their bag has a clear place to go.\u201d\n\nHuntley A. Lawrence, who oversees the airports for the Port Authority, said the agency also would take inventory of all of the equipment at the airport in case it needs to ask an airline to lend a spare piece, \u201cso when you have a winter storm emergency, you\u2019re not scrambling around.\u201d The Port Authority\u2019s primary responsibility in a winter storm is to clear snow and ice from the runways and taxiways. After the January storm, the Federal Aviation Administration said it would investigate how the Port Authority handled snow removal.\n\nMr. Lawrence said he has not learned of the conclusion of that investigation, but the Port Authority has already decided to add snow-moving equipment.\n\n\u201cWe did see this winter a lot of heavy wet snow,\u201d Mr. Lawrence said. \u201cThe heavy, wet snow is more difficult to move.\u201d\n\nHe said the agency would spend $3.5 million on four snow blowers and $1.4 million on four plows.", "title": "After Chaos, Port Authority Sets Storm Rules for Planes to Kennedy", "authors": ["Patrick Mcgeehan"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The United States has potential military options against the Iranian-backed forces that are operating in Syria, either through direct strikes or by seeking to interdict supply flights that cross Iraqi airspace. But American officials made clear that they had no desire to use force against Russian troops in the country. Instead, the president could consider a range of other options to hold Moscow responsible, including further economic sanctions or diplomatic isolation.\n\nSome lawmakers urged Mr. Trump to use sanctions authorized by Congress last year with bipartisan support. \u201cThe Syrian regime cannot exist without the support of Russia and Iran,\u201d Senator Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, a senior Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said on CNN. \u201cAnd we need to take action against both Russia and Iran, making it clear that they need to act to control what President Assad is doing.\u201d\n\nBut some national security veterans doubted Mr. Trump\u2019s tough words would amount to anything more than that. \u201cWhere we may come out with the Iranians and Russians is it\u2019s mostly talk, and he doesn\u2019t have a plan or they don\u2019t have a plan because I just can\u2019t imagine they want to escalate into a military situation,\u201d said Robert S. Ford, a former ambassador to Syria.\n\nMr. Trump left little doubt that he intended to order a military response against Syria for what he called a \u201cbarbaric act\u201d and said a decision could be made as early as Monday night or soon thereafter. \u201cWe\u2019re making a decision as to what we do with respect to the horrible attack that was made near Damascus, and it will be met and it will be met forcefully,\u201d he said Monday evening as he hosted the military leadership for dinner at the White House.\n\nThe White House was feeling pressure from France to act, lest President Emmanuel Macron do so first, according to a Trump administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe delicate international interactions. Mr. Macron, who spoke with Mr. Trump by telephone on Sunday and again on Monday, has repeatedly declared that the use of chemical weapons by Syria\u2019s government would be a red line and pledged to strike weapons sites connected to such attacks.\n\nTwo Arleigh Burke-class guided-missile destroyers are in the Sixth Fleet\u2019s area of operations in the Mediterranean Sea and would be able to get within striking range within hours to days. When Mr. Trump ordered the retaliatory strike against Syria at almost the exact same time last year, it was carried out by two destroyers firing 59 Tomahawk cruise missiles at Al Shayrat airfield, the suspected source of the chemical attack, hitting fighter jets, hardened aircraft shelters, radar equipment, ammunition bunkers and sites for storing fuel and defense systems.\n\nThe already tense situation in the Middle East was further inflamed early Monday morning by an attack reportedly conducted by Israel on a Syrian air base used by Iranian-backed militias. The strike killed about 14 people, according to a conflict monitoring group, and Russia and Syria said it was carried out by Israel, whose government declined to confirm its involvement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe chemical attack in the suburb of Douma over the weekend killed at least 49 people and raised the temperature of an already simmering relationship between the United States and Russia, which rejected the conclusion that Syria\u2019s military was behind the chemical attack. It asserted that the attack was staged by militants to falsely blame the government and justify an American strike against Mr. Assad\u2019s government.\n\nRussia\u2019s foreign minister, Sergei V. Lavrov, told reporters in Moscow that despite Mr. Trump\u2019s comments last week that he wanted to withdraw American troops from Syria, the United States was actually seeking to entrench itself in the country. \u201cThe U.S. is taking steps not to leave as President Trump said, and leave Syria for others, but to establish a foothold there for a very long time,\u201d Mr. Lavrov said.\n\nMr. Trump dismissed the Russian and Syrian denials. \u201cThey\u2019re saying they\u2019re not\u201d responsible, \u201cbut to me, there\u2019s not much of a doubt,\u201d he told reporters. Mr. Trump said that Syria was not allowing any independent inspection of the attack site. \u201cIf they\u2019re innocent, why aren\u2019t they allowing people to go in and prove\u201d it, he asked.\n\nFrance was not the only European ally to express outrage over the attack. \u201cIf they are found to be responsible, the regime and its backers \u2014 including Russia \u2014 must be held to account,\u201d Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain said during a visit to Denmark.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the United Nations, the United States called for an investigation into the site of the attack. Ambassador Nikki R. Haley used an emergency meeting of the Security Council to blame Russia and Iran for \u201cenabling the Assad regime\u2019s murderous destruction.\u201d\n\n\u201cHistory will record this as the moment when the Security Council either discharged its duty or demonstrated its utter and complete failure to protect the people of Syria,\u201d she said. \u201cEither way, the United States will respond.\u201d\n\nThe United States floated a draft resolution on Monday to establish an independent international panel to look into who used chemicals weapons, which are prohibited by international law, but there is little chance that Russia would agree to it. Late last year, Russia effectively disbanded a previous panel that had been set up to identify perpetrators of chemical weapons strikes inside Syria.\n\nThe panel, known as the Joint Investigative Mechanism, looked at eight cases of alleged chemical weapons use in 2015 and 2016, concluding that the Syrian government had used chemical weapons in three attacks and that the Islamic State had used them once. The panel\u2019s mandate expired, and Russia blocked an effort to extend it, calling it a tool of Western powers.\n\nVassily A. Nebenzia, the Russian ambassador to the United Nations, insisted on Monday that no chemical weapons attack took place at all in Douma, arguing that it had been fabricated to build an \u201canti-Russian alliance.\u201d He said the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons could visit Damascus, with Russian help, and carry out its investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Nebenzia went on to boast of Russia\u2019s popularity. \u201cYou\u2019re misguided if you think you have friends,\u201d he told Ms. Haley, adding, \u201cRussia has friends. Unlike yourselves, we do not have adversaries.\u201d\n\nIn Geneva, Zeid Ra\u2019ad al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, issued a scathing denunciation of the feeble response to past attacks by the international community in general.\n\nWarring parties in Syria had used chemical weapons at least 35 times since 2013, Mr. al-Hussein said, summing up the response of the international community as \u201cempty words, feeble condemnations and a Security Council paralyzed by the use of the veto.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe world \u2014 and in particular the veto-wielding states on the Security Council \u2014 need to wake up, and wake up fast, to the irreparable damage that is being done to one of the most important planks of global arms control and prevention of human suffering,\u201d he warned.\n\nThe crisis came on a day when Mr. Trump\u2019s foreign policy team was in the midst of transition as his new national security adviser, John R. Bolton, arrived for his first day on the job. Still adjusting to the assignment, Mr. Bolton sat back as Vice President Mike Pence led a national security meeting, but he sat next to Mr. Trump for his dinner with the generals. Mr. Trump was expected to huddle with Mr. Bolton, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, after dinner.\n\nKnown as a national security hawk, Mr. Bolton in the past urged military action against governments in Iran and North Korea to counter their nuclear programs, and he remains a staunch defender of the 2003 invasion of Iraq to topple Saddam Hussein.\n\nBut like Mr. Trump, he resisted a strike against Syria when President Barack Obama was in office and facing a similar choice after a chemical weapons attack against civilians in 2013. In that instance, Mr. Obama sought support from Congress, but ultimately backed off a strike after reaching an agreement with Russia to remove Syria\u2019s chemical weapons arsenal.\n\n\u201cIf I were a member of Congress, I would vote against an authorization to use force here,\u201d Mr. Bolton said at the time. \u201cI don\u2019t think it\u2019s in America\u2019s interest. I don\u2019t think we should in effect take sides in the Syrian conflict.\u201d\n\nMr. Bolton took a different position when Mr. Trump ordered action last year. \u201cI think the Trump decision to strike as they did was the correct decision,\u201d he said then. He added, \u201cI think there is an American national interest in preventing people from violating treaties that try to restrict the use or the spread of weapons of mass destruction.\u201d", "title": "After Chemical Weapons Attack in Syria, Trump Weighs Retaliation", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Her new novel, \u201cThe Emissary,\u201d translated by Margaret Mitsutani, is a contentedly minor work. It has a recessive, lunar beauty compared to the sunny ambition and inventiveness of its predecessors, including her masterpiece (with the self-explanatory title), \u201cThe Bridegroom Was a Dog\u201d (2012), and \u201cMemoirs of a Polar Bear\u201d (2016), which followed three generations of a distinguished literary family of polar bears.\n\nThe new book is set in Japan after an unnamed disaster (nuclear fallout is suggested). The country has quarantined itself from the rest of the world. The only wild living things left are spiders and crows. Language has started to vanish, too. The shelf life of words seems to have shortened; they pass out of fashion quickly and aren\u2019t replaced. Men go through menopause. Children are so enfeebled that heartsick pediatricians begin to kill themselves.\n\nOnly the elderly remain robust \u2014 none more guiltily than Yoshiro, who is raising his great-grandson, the impossibly, almost unbearably sweet Mumei, who grows kinder and more tolerant as his body wastes away. When Mumei\u2019s teeth begin to fall out, he reassures the horrified Yoshiro, \u201cDon\u2019t worry, Great-grandpa, sparrows get along fine without teeth.\u201d\n\nTawada is a great disciple of Kafka\u2019s; he \u201cpredicted reality,\u201d she is fond of saying. And while she shares certain of his preoccupations \u2014 with otherness and evoking animal life \u2014 hers is a more prosaic mission: She mirrors reality. Although her work is frequently described as strange \u2014 which it is, determinedly \u2014 there is always a stark social critique at its core. \u201cMemoirs of a Polar Bear\u201d is, after all, an immigrant novel and a stirring defense of the human right to migration. \u201cFor polar bears, national identity has always been a foreign concept,\u201d she writes in that novel. \u201cIt\u2019s common for them to get pregnant in Greenland, give birth in Canada, then raise the children in the Soviet Union. They possess no nationality, no passport. They never go into exile and cross national borders without a visa.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Emissary\u201d is as bleak a portrait of contemporary Japan as you could imagine. Tawada takes on the graying of the population and the trauma of the 2011 tsunami and the ensuing radiation leakage at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant. Hovering above all this, as always, is Tawada\u2019s interest in the issue of translation, but this time the gulf is between what Susan Sontag called the kingdom of the well and the kingdom of the sick.", "title": "After Disaster, Japan Seals Itself Off From the World in \u2018The Emissary\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "But many Afghan and American officials say there is often an overlap between the facilitating networks used in urban attacks claimed by the Islamic State in recent years and those used by the extreme elements of the Taliban, particularly the Haqqani Network, which had a long history of deadly urban attacks even before the rise of the Islamic State.\n\nIn the small foothold the Islamic State maintains in eastern Afghanistan, it carries out particularly barbaric acts of violence. In the Chaparhar district of Nangarhar Province, officials said three brothers were beheaded by the group late on Sunday. Their father, a medical doctor, was killed by the Islamic State last year.\n\nAs mass-casualty attacks have increased in Kabul, the country\u2019s capital, Kabul Province has become the deadliest one for civilians, surpassing Taliban-dominated southern areas where local residents have long borne the brunt of the war, now in its 17th year. Last year, nearly 500 civilians were killed in attacks in the city and 1,350 were wounded, according to the United Nations.\n\nWhile the violence has turned life in Kabul into a game of chance, more recently the odds have been worse for Shiites like Mr. Allahdad.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis home is on a busy road in a western Kabul neighborhood. Almost every street pole is adorned with a photograph of an attack victim.\n\n\u201cHe was just a poor man\u2019s son trying to earn bread for his children,\u201d said his elderly father, Hussain Ali Allahdad, wiping his tears with a white kerchief.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs visitors arrived on Monday morning to pay their respects, someone would recite another verse of the Quran before hands were raised in prayer. The father would lean back against the wall and close his eyes.\n\nMany visitors apologized for having shown up so late, busy with other funerals and burials. One had a cousin killed in the bombing, another had a brother-in-law, a third had a neighbor.\n\nThe visitors tried to console the father by emphasizing that in the eyes of the Shiite community, his son was a martyr who had sacrificed his life for a noble cause.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cNot everyone gets the rank of martyr,\u201d said one visitor who walked with a limp.\n\n\u201cYes, he was lucky to become a martyr,\u201d said another. \u201cThat he has left us burning here \u2014 that\u2019s a separate issue.\u201d\n\nIn western Kabul where many Shiites live, Mr. Allahdad had quite a presence \u2014 not only for his reputation as a wrestler, but also as the defender of an increasingly vulnerable community. Some Shiite youths have started carrying weapons at religious gatherings, no longer trusting the authorities to protect them. They looked to Mr. Allahdad as a mobilizer and a leader.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe was my student for 20 years \u2014 he started wrestling when he was 13,\u201d said Sher Jan Ahmadi, deputy head of the country\u2019s wrestling federation.\n\nMr. Allahdad had amassed many accolades in his wrestling career, the medals hanging at his home and office. He won domestic tournaments as a teenager, and in his youth he dominated his weight class of 214 pounds. In one of the last international tournaments he took part in, held in Pakistan, he won a silver medal.\n\nWhen he retired from competing after having torn a leg muscle four years ago, he could not break with the sport entirely. He started coaching a local wrestling club, with about 150 students arriving for daily training at 6 a.m. On his Facebook page, he shared a Russian meme: a video of a babushka rushing to a wrestling mat to smack an opponent who was pinning her son down.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Allahdad also had an entrepreneurial ambition. He began with a small crockery business, then expanded to a travel agency that specialized in pilgrimages to Mecca, in Saudi Arabia, and the Shiite holy city of Karbala in southern Iraq. He awarded free trips to his best wrestling students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs attacks escalated against Shiite places of worship in Afghanistan, the former wrestler found a more urgent use for his strength. He became a volunteer emergency responder, often among the first at the scene.\n\nWhen suicide bombers armed with rifles and grenades stormed the largest Shiite shrine in Kabul two years ago, a photographer captured an image of Mr. Allahdad carrying a wounded girl. His embroidered clothes were soaked with blood, his eyes red from tears and smoke.\n\nWhen another mosque was attacked last June, cellphone video showed Mr. Allahdad rushing a bloodied middle-aged man on his shoulder to the back of a police truck. Covered in blood again, he sat on the floor and said he might have dislocated his hip. Someone bent down to help him out.\n\n\u201cGood?\u201d the person asked.\n\n\u201cYes, good,\u201d said Mr. Allahdad as he got back on his feet and rushed back into the smoke coming from the mosque.\n\nLate on Sunday evening, hundreds of mourners gathered at the walled family cemetery, where just two weeks earlier Mr. Allahdad and two dozen relatives had planted trees to welcome spring. His body was removed from an ambulance, and after a brief prayer, lowered into his grave.\n\nJust days before he was killed, Mr. Allahdad had expressed to an older brother, Ghulam Sakhi, how tired he had been: \u201cFor three months, or six months, I just want to go somewhere where I don\u2019t hear anything.\u201d", "title": "After Each Attack He Carried the Wounded. Then He Became a Victim.", "authors": ["Mujib Mashal"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Israel\u2019s defense minister, Avigdor Lieberman, ruled out participation in any commission of inquiry, telling Army Radio on Sunday that the Israeli military \u201cdid what had to be done.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cI think that all of our troops deserve a medal.\u201d\n\nPresident Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey described the harsh Israeli response as \u201can inhumane attack.\u201d After Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel wrote on Twitter that \u201cthe most moral army in the world will not be preached to on morality by someone who for years has indiscriminately bombed a civilian population,\u201d apparently referring to Ankara\u2019s battle against the Kurds, Mr. Erdogan called the Israeli leader a \u201cterrorist.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFriday\u2019s protest was the start of a six-week campaign called the Great Return March. The organizers said it was intended to raise international awareness of the longstanding blockade of the isolated and impoverished coastal enclave, imposed by Israel and Egypt, and to support the Palestinian demand to return to homes lost in 1948, in what is now Israel.\n\nThe organizers had been purposely vague about plans to breach the border, to keep Israel guessing.\n\nThe Israeli mainstream has largely backed the army, though there has been criticism.\n\n\u201cI categorize what happened as a failure,\u201d said Shlomo Brom, a retired brigadier general now at Israel\u2019s Institute for National Security Studies. \u201cThe Palestinian aim was to raise international consciousness, and to put the Palestinian issue back on the international and Israeli agenda. It succeeded.\u201d\n\nWhile the military probably also decided to use lethal force as a deterrent, Mr. Brom said, \u201cIn my opinion they should have planned from the beginning to use minimal force and to prevent casualties.\u201d\n\nMkhaimar Abusada, a professor of political science at Al-Azhar University in Gaza, said that from what he had heard there was no plan to cross the border. \u201cIt was a mass Palestinian nonviolent protest against Israel, and to approach the border area,\u201d he said. \u201cBut when you have large crowds you cannot control \u2014 so yes, some tried to infiltrate the borders between Gaza and Israel.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAhmed Abu Artema, a Gazan social-media activist who initiated the protest, said by telephone on Sunday that the idea of returning to the lands lost in 1948 was a \u201cstrategic goal\u201d that would \u201cnot necessarily be achieved within a month or a year,\u201d but that the protesters along the borders would determine the timing.\n\nHamas, which quickly adopted the return campaign, played a large role in orchestrating it. The Islamic group, which is classified by much of the Western world as a terrorist organization, said five of those killed belonged to its military wing, but said they were participating in the protest \u201cside by side\u201d with their people.\n\n\u201cLast Friday we stopped at the border,\u201d Ismail Haniya, the group\u2019s leader, said on Sunday. \u201cNext time we don\u2019t know where the limit will be.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Israeli authorities named eight of those killed as Hamas fighters or activists and said two more belonged to other militant factions.\n\nThe Israeli military produced a video showing what it said was one of the Hamas fighters and an accomplice shooting at Israeli forces across the fence in northern Gaza before being killed by Israeli tank and gunfire.\n\nAnother army video montage showed protesters hurling stones and firebombs and rolling burning tires at the fence, apparently in an effort to set it on fire.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn the other side of the divide, videos circulated widely on social media appearing to show unarmed protesters being shot by the Israelis.\n\nIn one, a youth identified as Abdel Fattah Abd al-Nabi, 19, is shot in the back as he runs away from the fence carrying a tire; in a second, a woman is shot as she approaches the fence waving a Palestinian flag; in a third, a man is shot in the leg when he stands up after praying by the fence.\n\nIsrael identified Mr. Nabi, who was killed, as a Hamas fighter, but Hamas\u2019s military wing did not claim him as one of its members.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGaza health officials said an additional 800 protesters were injured by live fire.\n\nBrig. Gen. Ronen Manelis, the chief army spokesman, described that as \u201cnonsense\u201d in an interview on Sunday, saying the number of live fire injuries was more likely in the dozens, with the rest hit by rubber bullets or tear gas.\n\nGeneral Manelis said that his troops had fired precisely, and that there was information that Hamas was planning attacks under the cover of the protests, like the cross-border shooting. He would not detail the rules of engagement but said the principle was \u201cnot to allow the sabotage of military infrastructure and not to allow any mass crossing of the fence.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe said his forces in the field had described Mr. Nabi as one of the most active participants in rolling burning tires toward the fence, but said the military would examine each episode.\n\nIf the fence had burned and collapsed, General Manelis said, the \u201cnightmare scenario\u201d of a mass influx may have been realized. \u201cHow many would have been killed then?\u201d he asked. \u201cWe prevented a blood bath.\u201d\n\nJihad Abu Jamous, 30, from Bani Suheila, a village near Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip, set off for the border in a taxi with his wife, Ghadir, and their four children. He didn\u2019t come back.\n\nHis widow said he had moved toward the fence and was shot in the head. It was not clear whether he was throwing stones at the time. His widow said he had been holding an onion she had given him to counteract the effects of tear gas. Like most of the protesters, she stayed back.\n\nThe mourning tent outside the house flew the yellow flags of Fatah, Hamas\u2019s main rival. Ms. Abu Jamous said her husband had been jailed in the past by Hamas and was financially desperate.\n\n\u201cHe became tired of life,\u201d she said. Berating Hamas leaders for caring only about their own positions, she said, \u201cThe leaders are sending the young men toward the borders. The people are the victims.\u201d\n\nRelatives said he had worked from dawn till dusk collecting scraps of plastic, iron and soda cans from garbage dumps, and was thin as a skeleton.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe went to be a martyr,\u201d said his aunt, Mona al-Najjar, 51. \u201cIt\u2019s better than robbery or being a beggar.\u201d", "title": "After Gaza Clash, Israel and Palestinians Fight With Videos and Words", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "This has certainly not happened yet. Both before and after the march, high school students have shown themselves eager to hatch longer-term plans, with some plotting together last week through their spring breaks.\n\nIn this stretch of Northern Virginia, students are trying to organize a town hall with Representative Barbara Comstock, one of the most vulnerable Republicans in Congress, recognizing that her support from the National Rifle Association could be a drag in a district that preferred Hillary Clinton in 2016.\n\nPhoto\n\nNew voter registration pushes, steered by teenagers, are well underway. Students are consulting with established (and adult-run) groups like Everytown for Gun Safety, founded and financed by Michael R. Bloomberg, and the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence \u2014 with plans to discuss how to host their own candidate events before November or start clubs at their schools.\n\nEven less politically active students in Virginia\u2019s 10th Congressional District have learned Ms. Comstock\u2019s name. \u201cThey know who she is,\u201d said Paige Thimmesch, 16, Ms. Banks\u2019s classmate in Sterling, Va., who is hoping to arrange the forum with the congresswoman. \u201cThey don\u2019t know every single policy. They do know that she is pro-gun.\u201d\n\nLooking to history, fledgling activists are researching Vietnam-era student protests for context and inspiration. They are using words like \u201cintersectional.\u201d They are quoting favored lyrics from \u201cHamilton\u201d: \u201cThis is not a moment, it\u2019s the movement.\u201d\n\nThat movement, though, will hinge on reversing years of below-average voter turnout among young Americans \u2014 translating sound and fury into the long, slow work of lasting change.\n\nIn the 2014 midterm elections, less than 20 percent of voters between the ages of 18 and 29 turned out to cast ballots, compared to more than 40 percent of voters between 45 and 59, according to an analysis of survey data by the United States Elections Project, which is run by Michael P. McDonald, an associate professor of political science at the University of Florida. Recent polling suggests the gap could close, at least somewhat, this fall. A Quinnipiac University survey released in late February found that 54 percent of those 18 to 34 said they were more motivated than usual to vote, outpacing every other age group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile youth-driven movements in recent years, like Black Lives Matter and Occupy Wall Street, have installed themselves as forces in Democratic politics and the national discourse, their effects at the ballot box have been uncertain.\n\nGun owners, mindful that flurries of mass activism have often dissipated on their own after past shootings, are still taking no chances. Some efforts have been unsavory: Survivors of the Parkland, Fla., massacre in February have been the subject of internet conspiracy theories and bizarre fictions. More civic-minded supporters of gun rights are discussing counter-rallies this month to demonstrate their collective might.\n\n\u201cAll these calls for gun control are only making gun owners snap to attention,\u201d said Philip Van Cleave, the leader of the Virginia Citizens Defense League, a gun rights group. \u201cThis is not a one-way movement by any means.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen there is the N.R.A., whose track record includes few political losses in recent memory \u2014 its power derived less from direct donations than a fine-tuned electioneering machine primed to mobilize voters with a letter-grade system for assessing candidates and tens of millions of dollars in campaign ads and voter-guide mailings. Shortly after the Parkland shooting, President Trump expressed support for gun restrictions opposed by the N.R.A., scolding fellow Republicans for kowtowing to the group. It did not take long, after an Oval Office meeting with N.R.A. officials, for the president to reverse himself.\n\nYet even in corners of the country unaccustomed to dissent on gun issues, supporters of restrictions sense an opening. In Maine\u2019s Second Congressional District, a region that includes both small cities and parcels of land so rural they are officially called \u201cunorganized territory,\u201d school walkouts and satellite March for Our Lives protests have specked the map, powered by students and Democratic activists.\n\nThough gun owners have betrayed little immediate concern \u2014 \u201cIf they hang around, we\u2019ll still be here, and if they don\u2019t, we\u2019ll still be here,\u201d said Todd Tolhurst, the president of Gun Owners of Maine \u2014 students seem comfortable with their odds in any war of attrition.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll outlive them,\u201d said Sean Monteith, 17, a junior at Lewiston High School, adding that he hoped his peers would be able to outvote them, too. His cellphone includes a list of action items and reminders: \u201cconnect with city council,\u201d \u201cdraft legislation,\u201d \u201cdo not go on assumptions.\u201d\n\nBack in Washington, a handful of Republicans seem attuned to at least two of those directives, hedging their positions in recent weeks to accommodate the post-Parkland moment. Several vulnerable members signed on to a Democratic bill authorizing federal research into gun violence. Two of them, Brian Mast and Carlos Curbelo, both Republicans from Florida, have endorsed an assault weapons ban.\n\nActivists appear determined to make others pay a professional price for declining to engage. In Colorado\u2019s Sixth District, where Representative Mike Coffman is widely considered one of the most endangered Republican incumbents, organizers with Never Again Colorado, a new group advocating gun control, are planning a forum to discuss guns \u201cwith or without\u201d Mr. Coffman. The district includes Aurora, where a gunman killed 12 people in a movie theater in 2012.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe have a lot of momentum right now,\u201d said Ian Gaskins, 17, a high school junior who is helping to plan the event. \u201cI don\u2019t want people to stop caring about this until the next mass shooting.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Democrats, the zeal for gun control has at once presented an uncommon opportunity and an occasion to revisit plans for midterm messaging. After Mr. Trump\u2019s election, his opponents did not necessarily expect a gun reckoning to be central to their 2018 strategy.\n\nLast summer, as the party strained to communicate its own agenda in the Trumpian haze, Democrats chose Berryville as the backdrop to introduce a broad-strokes platform of economic populism. Their top leaders in Congress, Senator Chuck Schumer and Representative Nancy Pelosi, and progressive stars like Senator Elizabeth Warren schlepped 65 miles outside Washington to deliver their message in the same park where Mr. Ashby, the gun owner, flicked away his cigarette on a recent afternoon.\n\nEight months later, it is gun violence, more than any fiscal issue, that has galvanized a new generation of prospective Democrats, some not yet old enough to vote.\n\nIn Virginia, the party had already long targeted Ms. Comstock, casting her as a poor fit for a district that includes some rural pockets, like Berryville, but also left-leaning Washington suburbs and vast reserves of more moderate voters repelled by Mr. Trump. \u201cBarbara Bump-Stock,\u201d said Candy Baracat-Donovan, 34, from Leesburg, Va., whose morning routine now includes a round of phone calls to the offices of representatives like Ms. Comstock.\n\nPhoto\n\nA spokesman for Ms. Comstock, Jeff Marschner, said the congresswoman was \u201ccommitted to a multipronged effort to prevent gun violence,\u201d citing her support for additional mental health funding and narrow, N.R.A.-backed legislation improving reporting to the national background check database, among other measures.\n\nIt is not clear if she will agree to a town hall with students. They seem to understand the calculation.\n\n\u201cHigh school students are scary,\u201d said Jay Falk, 18, a senior in Virginia who co-founded Students Demand Action DMV, a gun control group with over 100 members. \u201cWe are not cynical yet.\u201d", "title": "After Gun Control Marches, \u2018It\u2019ll Go Away\u2019 vs. \u2018We Are Not Cynical Yet\u2019", "authors": ["Matt Flegenheimer", "Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "With two moderate Democrats signaling their support for Mr. Pompeo earlier on Monday, the confirmation of the United States\u2019 top diplomat by the full Senate this week was all but secured anyway.\n\nSenator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, intends to move the full chamber to begin debate on Mr. Pompeo\u2019s nomination as soon as Wednesday, with a final vote expected before senators leave Friday for a weeklong recess.\n\nBut supporters of Mr. Pompeo feared that he would become the country\u2019s 70th secretary of state with a bruised standing on the world stage after a Foreign Relations Committee rebuke.\n\n\u201cI understand the climate we are in. I understand the polarization we have as a nation,\u201d Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee, the committee\u2019s chairman, said Monday. But Mr. Corker touted Mr. Pompeo as one of the most qualified secretaries of state in history, ticking through his r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\nEven Monday, it took a \u201cpresent\u201d vote by Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, to allow the nomination to move forward after Senator Johnny Isakson, Republican of Georgia and a Pompeo supporter, did not show because he was delivering a eulogy out of town.\n\nBut the partisan environment that Mr. Corker lamented, in the end, provided Mr. Pompeo a lift. Democrats up for re-election in states that Mr. Trump carried in 2016 broke the nominee\u2019s way: Senators Joe Manchin III of West Virginia and Joe Donnelly of Indiana pledged their support on Monday, joining Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, who declared her \u201cyes\u201d vote last week. Other endangered Democrats from Trump states are under pressure to also fall in line.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Monday, White House officials trained their fire on Senate Democrats, who they said are stonewalling the president\u2019s nominees without good cause.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump, writing on Twitter, labeled those voting against Mr. Pompeo \u201cObstructionists\u201d and said he needed more Republicans in office in their place.\n\nMr. Trump did not include Mr. Paul in his criticism. The president said last week that Mr. Paul was a \u201cvery special guy\u201d who had \u201cnever let me down.\u201d\n\nCommittee Democrats stood by their opposition.\n\n\u201cThis is not about policy difference,\u201d said Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, before casting a vote against Mr. Pompeo. \u201cI don\u2019t want to vote for people who are antidiplomatic to be the nation\u2019s chief diplomat.\u201d\n\nThe Senate has historically given deference to presidents to choose their top diplomat. President Barack Obama twice reached into the chamber\u2019s ranks to choose a secretary of state, elevating first Hillary Clinton then John F. Kerry for the role. Both received 94 votes to confirm their nominations, with opposition from only a handful of their Senate colleagues.\n\nMr. Pompeo\u2019s predecessor Rex W. Tillerson was confirmed 56 to 43 by the Senate in February 2017. He was approved by the Foreign Relations Committee by an 11-to-10 vote along party lines. Mr. Trump fired Mr. Tillerson, a former oil executive who never really meshed with the president, in March in favor of Mr. Pompeo, a former Tea Party congressman with whom he has developed a close relationship.\n\nIn a briefing Monday afternoon at the White House, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, dismissed Democratic opposition as \u201cpointless obstruction to score cheap political points with their base as a willful attempt to undermine American diplomacy.\u201d\n\nDemocrats, many of whom voted for Mr. Pompeo\u2019s confirmation as C.I.A. director, dispute that claim, saying that their problems with Mr. Pompeo derive from more than just distaste for the president\u2019s foreign policy.\n\nAs a four-term House member from Kansas, Mr. Pompeo earned a reputation as a sharp-tongued conservative partisan. He first appeared on Mr. Trump\u2019s radar in 2015 when, while still a member of the House, he peppered Mrs. Clinton with searing questions in a hearing about the deadly attacks in 2012 in Benghazi, Libya. Mr. Pompeo called Mrs. Clinton, then on her way to becoming the Democratic presidential nominee, \u201cmorally reprehensible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDemocrats also point to comments by Mr. Pompeo that they say betray prejudice against lesbians, gay men, bisexuals and transgender people and against Muslims.\n\nAs he has tried to win over senators to support him for the State Department job, Mr. Pompeo has tried to play down those stances. At his confirmation hearing this month, Mr. Pompeo presented himself in moderate terms. He promised to defend gay rights around the world, to work to rescue the Iran nuclear deal and to reverse the administration\u2019s marginalization of American diplomats under Mr. Tillerson.\n\nThe Senate Intelligence Committee will formally consider Mr. Trump\u2019s nominee to replace Mr. Pompeo at the C.I.A., Gina Haspel, at a hearing on May 9. Ms. Haspel\u2019s nomination is similarly dividing Republicans and Democrats in the chamber.", "title": "After Late Vote Switch, Senate Panel Approves Pompeo for Secretary of State", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "He agreed to meet her, but \u201clike most guys,\u201d he said, he \u201cdawdled and never got around to doing anything about it.\u201d\n\nBut Ms. Sullivan kept after him, he said. \u201cWhen she found out I go down to Hilton Head every year at the end of September on a golf trip with a bunch of guys, she asked me if I\u2019d see Jenny while I was there,\u201d Mr. McKay said.\n\nIn September 2016, he abandoned his golf buddies on a Saturday and drove north. \u201cI said, \u2018Guys, I\u2019m leaving. I\u2019ve got a better option than you two hours away in Charleston,\u2019\u201d near Sullivan\u2019s Island, where Ms. Sanford lived at the time. Mr. McKay and Ms. Sanford met for the first time at Leon\u2019s, a local restaurant. \u201cWe had a nice dinner and that\u2019s how the whole thing started,\u201d he said.\n\nWell, not exactly, according to Ms. Sullivan, an artist who now lives in Vienna, Va. In her version of events, she had been plotting to set the wheels in motion for years, from the first time she met Mr. McKay.\n\n\u201cWith Andy, it\u2019s what you see is what you get,\u201d she said. His honesty and straightforwardness seemed well suited to her sister. But Ms. Sanford\u2019s social calendar didn\u2019t allow for a long-distance setup, at least not at first. \u201cJenny had been dating and I wasn\u2019t crazy about the people she was dating,\u201d Ms. Sullivan said. \u201cI knew it was going to take a special kind of person to make her happy.\n\n\u201cWe all know the story of Jenny and Mark,\u201d she continued, adding that she is still close with her former brother-in-law. \u201cI wanted her to experience what it was like to have someone love you unconditionally. I don\u2019t think she had ever experienced that.\u201d", "title": "After Scandal and Divorce, Jenny Sanford Learns She Can Love Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Three years later, a jury convicted Mr. Johnson of transporting his white girlfriend across state lines. He served a year in prison and died in 1946.\n\nThe Justice Department does not typically consider posthumous pardons because, according to department guidelines, the time \u201cis better spent on the pardon and commutation requests of living persons.\u201d\n\nBut for decades, lawmakers and filmmakers \u2014 and, now, a movie star \u2014 have tried to persuade presidents to pardon Mr. Johnson. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Representative Peter T. King, Republican of New York, have been the most recent legislators to ask.\n\nDuring nearly every term of Congress since 2004, they have introduced a resolution recommending a pardon. It passed both the House and Senate in 2009 and 2011, but just as Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton before him, President Barack Obama did not grant a pardon.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t you think this issue says something about the character of America?\u201d Mr. McCain asked The Times in 2015.\n\nAccording to the Justice Department, Mr. Trump has so far issued three presidential pardons. In August, he pardoned Joe Arpaio, the former Arizona sheriff whose hard-line approach to tamping down on illegal immigration earned him a criminal contempt conviction. In March, he pardoned Kristian Mark Saucier, a Navy submariner jailed after taking unauthorized photographs in a classified area of a submarine.\n\nThis month, Mr. Trump pardoned I. Lewis Libby Jr., known as Scooter, who was convicted in 2007 of perjury and obstruction of justice for his involvement in unmasking the identity of Valerie Plame, a C.I.A. officer.\n\nIn the time it took to write this article, Mr. Trump, who spent the week mostly ensconced at his Florida properties, had angrily returned to a pet topic: the news media. The committee began an investigation last week into Dr. Jackson\u2019s White House work record, and its Republican and Democratic leaders jointly announced Tuesday that his confirmation hearing, planned for Wednesday, would be postponed indefinitely \u201cin light of new information presented to the committee.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe take very seriously our constitutional duty to thoroughly and carefully vet each nominee sent to the Senate for confirmation,\u201d said Senators Johnny Isakson of Georgia, the committee chairman, and Jon Tester of Montana, its top Democrat, in a joint statement. \u201cWe will continue looking into these serious allegations.\u201d\n\nDr. Jackson, speaking with reporters on Capitol Hill before meeting with a Republican senator Tuesday afternoon, gave no indication that he would withdraw his nomination. He also did not answer questions about the accusations.\n\nBut he added, \u201cI\u2019m looking forward to getting it rescheduled and answering everybody\u2019s questions.\u201d\n\nMembers of Mr. Tester\u2019s staff said that they had been given several credible accounts of Dr. Jackson being intoxicated during official White House travel. In several cases, they said, he had apparently grabbed his medical bag and was \u201cattempting to assert himself,\u201d to show he was in charge.\n\nOn one trip during Barack Obama\u2019s presidency, White House staff needed to reach Dr. Jackson for medical reasons and found him passed out in his hotel room after a night of drinking, Tester aides said. The staff members took the medical supplies they were looking for without waking Dr. Jackson.", "title": "After Trump Hints V.A. Nominee Might Drop Out, an Aggressive Show of Support", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "If the primary message of the strikes was that Mr. Assad could not use chemical weapons, a secondary message was that the West was going to leave him in power, no matter what else he did.\n\n\u201cEven if this is a chemical weapons deterrent, that leaves a whole arsenal of conventional means with which people can be killed in Syria with few real repercussions,\u201d said Sam Heller, a senior analyst who studies Syria at the International Crisis Group. \u201cThere is every reason to expect that that will continue.\u201d\n\nSeven years of conflict have seen Syria sliced up by world powers, with the Turks administering towns in the north, the United States working with Kurdish-led militias in the east, and Russia and Iran helping Mr. Assad rout the remaining pockets of rebels elsewhere.\n\nAt this point, no one seems to have a realistic plan to broker a lasting peace between those forces that would bring Syria together again in a stable enough way to allow millions of refugees to return home and for rebuilding to begin. Many discount the idea that Mr. Assad can play a meaningful role in that process.\n\n\u201cIt is very shortsighted and erroneous in my mind,\u201d said Maha Yahya, the director of the Carnegie Middle East Center in Beirut. \u201cFacilitating a win for Assad is making sure that Syria remains the epicenter of instability in the region.\u201d\n\nResearch by the center has found that if Mr. Assad remains in power, it would discourage the return of Syrian refugees from neighboring countries and Europe. \u201cThey are not going back as long as Assad is in power because they don\u2019t believe that there will be safety and stability while Assad is there,\u201d Ms. Yahya said.\n\nThe only solution, she said, is a settlement between Russia and the United States that other powers, like Turkey and Iran, could eventually be brought into. But reaching such an agreement would involve an intensity of diplomatic efforts that Mr. Trump\u2019s administration is not interested in.", "title": "After U.S. Strikes, Syria Returns to War as Usual", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Imperfect as it is, many students said they were proud of the school\u2019s diversity, and some families move to New Rochelle explicitly for it. But this asset also makes the school fragile in a particular way. If people perceive New Rochelle High to be dangerous, will parents with the means to do so send their children to private school? Will families who are thinking of living there move someplace else instead? The school district and the city have been trying hard to prevent this from happening.\n\nAfter the violence in January, the campus was sealed off during the school day, and students were no longer permitted to come and go. Two police officers are now stationed at the school, and there is an increased police presence along North Avenue, a thoroughfare behind the school. For a couple of days, student bags were searched at random by school security, and a security firm has been hired to audit safety measures at the high school.\n\nBut Brian Osborne, the district superintendent, said that members of the New Rochelle community did not want to \u201cpolice themselves out of this problem,\u201d and were trying to be thoughtful in their response. The district has created a task force on reducing violence in the lives of young people, which will look beyond school to supporting children in other parts of their lives. It might look, for example, at whether mental health counselors are available 24 hours a day for those in crisis.\n\n\u201cAll the kids who were involved, they were reflections of where we as a society are deficient in terms of supporting kids and families, where they get to the point where they feel that this is the only way to either resolve an issue or express themselves,\u201d Mr. Richardson, the principal, said.\n\nThree students were indicted last week in connection with Ms. Schwab\u2019s murder. Prosecutors say she was assaulted on North Avenue by three teenagers who then took her house keys. Ms. Schwab followed them to Dunkin\u2019 Donuts to get her keys back, and she was stabbed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe next incident took place a week later, when a 15-year-old student appears to have been attacked by a group of young people at a pizzeria. The following day, that victim came to school and stabbed a classmate during first period. He ran out of the school, and the authorities are still looking for him. Police say they don\u2019t believe the student who was stabbed in class was involved in the incident at the pizzeria.\n\nIn the face of intense local media coverage, some of New Rochelle\u2019s neighbors do not seem comforted by the steps the city has taken.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn February, George W. Hewlett High School, in Hewlett, on Long Island, said its students would not participate in a model congress at New Rochelle High School. \u201cThe safety of our students and staff is our highest priority, and there is too much uncertainty there at this time,\u201d Jack Lenson, the interim principal of Hewlett High School, said in a letter. Schools from at least four other districts also declined to participate, so the event was canceled. Hewlett officials did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nNew Rochelle students made the best of it, Mr. Richardson said. They took a bus down to Washington, D.C., and participated in the March for Our Lives against gun violence that weekend instead.\n\nIndeed, many students, teachers and parents say that adults have been more nervous than the children who attend the school.\n\n\u201cI think the feeling of fear is mostly coming from people who aren\u2019t here every day,\u201d said Ajani Thomas, 16, a junior at New Rochelle High School. \u201cThe feeling in the hallways is not fear.\u201d\n\nMaggie Bangser\u2019s son Amar Rajani-Bangser was sitting in Spanish class with the student who was stabbed \u2014 in fact, right next to him. But she considers the event such an outlier that she said she never thought about pulling her son out of school.\n\n\u201cAs horrible as those events were, they do not in any way represent fully what New Rochelle is, they just don\u2019t,\u201d Ms. Bangser said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe came home for a couple of hours right after the incident, but he had a math midterm that afternoon, and at a certain point he said, \u2018Well, I\u2019m ready to go back,\u2019\u201d Ms. Bangser said.", "title": "After Violence, a High School Tries to Regain Its Balance", "authors": ["Elizabeth A. Harris"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Today, on some of those same corners, bulldozers and construction cranes work almost nonstop to transform Long Beach\u2019s 1.38-square-mile downtown and outlying areas into a more vibrant urban center. Roughly three dozen projects, valued at around $3.5 billion, are underway or in the pipeline in one of the country\u2019s largest continuing downtown redevelopments.\n\n\u201cThe downtown is being reborn and recreated,\u201d Robert Garcia, the mayor of Long Beach since 2014, said. \u201cA lot of people view Long Beach as the kid sister to Los Angeles. It\u2019s finally stepping into the national stage, and I\u2019m really excited about the transformation.\u201d\n\nThe whole world will get to see Long Beach\u2019s shiny new self soon enough as Southern California prepares for the 2028 Summer Olympics and Paralympic Games. Los Angeles has been chosen as the host city, and several events are expected to take place in Long Beach.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe changes to Long Beach \u2014 about 25 miles south of Los Angeles \u2014 began in earnest more than 15 years ago. The city began buying up nearly four dozen properties, including vacant lots and derelict buildings, through its redevelopment agency. The total purchases, over an area of about 25 square miles, were part of a more than $100 million spending plan that included improving infrastructure and beefing up the police force, said Patrick H. West, the city manager.\n\n\u201cWe purchased liquor stores, parking lots, motels and apartments that were gang hangouts \u2014 911 hot spots, according to the police \u2014 and relocated the displaced tenants,\u201d Mr. West said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe properties were later resold to developers, and new zoning regulations were put in place about five years ago to help speed up construction and building conversions.\n\n\u201cWe became a land banker,\u201d Mr. West said. \u201cThe objective was to change the neighborhood and blight, not to regenerate dollars.\u201d\n\nAs a result of these efforts by the local government, many developers have been eager to do business in Long Beach, and companies like Virgin Orbit and Mercedes-Benz have found new homes there.", "title": "After Years of Decline, a California Port City Sheds Its Past", "authors": ["Vivian Marino", "Square Feet"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The 7,600-nautical-mile leg, which started March 18, covered the most dangerous stretch of the race, where rapidly changing depressions spin unimpeded in the Southern Ocean between Antarctica and Cape Horn. Winds this year rarely dropped below 30 knots and often exceeded 40, considered gale force.\n\nTwo of the seven teams retired during the punishing leg. Vestas 11th Hour Racing arrived in Itaja\u00ed on Monday under a makeshift rig after being dismasted past Cape Horn. The Mapfre team, the overall race leader entering the leg, finished fifth after having to anchor off the coast of Chile to repair a mainsail that had ripped in two, and is now second over all, behind Dongfeng.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nScallywag sailed into Puerto Montt, Chile, on April 3, and most of the crew flew home to be with their families. But the team plans to start the next leg, to Newport, R.I., on Sunday.\n\nThe loss of the sailor was the second in recent Volvo Ocean Race history. The Dutch sailor Hans Horrevoets went overboard in a North Atlantic gale during the 2005-06 edition. He was about to put on his harness when a wave swept him away at night.\n\n\u201cNothing\u2019s guaranteed when you are on the water,\u201d Richard Falk, the Royal Yachting Association\u2019s director of training and qualifications, said during an interview last winter regarding the Clipper fatality. \u201cOur take on training is giving as much knowledge and trialing to make better decisions. What can never be done is completely eliminate the risk.\u201d\n\nIn the Volvo Ocean Race, crews are given R.Y.A. safety training and inflatable harnesses with single or double tethers. According to the Scallywag team, Fisher had unclipped his tether to move forward from the cockpit when the boat, moving at 20 to 30 knots, surfed down a wave and accidentally jibed. Fisher was thrown overboard, and crew members believe he was knocked unconscious.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor the first time, every Volvo crew member received a Yachtmaster certification from the R.Y.A. And Greenhalgh said that training allowed her team to gain control of the boat and return to the area where Fisher went overboard.\n\nProfessional ocean sailors have been criticized for being cavalier and not clipping into the boat or not wearing a harness, as can be seen in onboard images and videos.\n\nIn January, Witt and the Scallywag crew were targets of this criticism when the youngest crew member, Alex Gough, 24, fell off the boat during Leg 4 in benign conditions during daylight. He was clearing a sheet while hanging over the side without wearing a harness.\n\nAn upset Witt, in a video from onboard after the recovery, said: \u201cYou should, one, either be tethered on, or, two, at a minimum, tell the driver what you\u2019re doing so he knows. He didn\u2019t do either of those.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a phone interview from Race Control in Alicante, the race director, Phil Lawrence, said: \u201cIt\u2019s always the responsibility of the skipper and crew to wear the equipment. We have recommendations, but we can\u2019t enforce it when they are a thousand miles away.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGreenhalgh, who helped propel Scallywag to a victory in Leg 4, said clipping in all the time was not realistic on almost any offshore boat.\n\n\u201cWhen you go to move about the boat, you can\u2019t tell me there isn\u2019t a fraction of a second where you\u2019re not clipped in,\u201d she said in a phone interview from her home in England last week.\n\nThe conditions the night Fisher was lost were some of the worst she had seen, she said.\n\n\u201cThe sea state was the size of mountains,\u201d Greenhalgh said. \u201cYou\u2019d ask yourself, \u2018Is that an island or a wave?\u2019\u201d\n\nZooming in on digital charts and satellite phone communications with rescue services was a challenge, she said. But communication failures did not hinder the search for Fisher. Scallywag\u2019s Automatic Identification System, or A.I.S., was broken.\n\nThis edition of the race is the first to provide personal A.I.S. beacons for the crews. The system is used on commercial and recreational ships to observe boats on navigation screens to avoid collisions. Personal A.I.S. instantaneously puts a person overboard target on the screens of the ships within several miles of the victim.\n\nFor Scallywag, this lifesaving new technology went away when, two days out of Auckland, the boat\u2019s lone A.I.S. antenna at the top of the 100-foot mast was damaged in the strong winds.\n\n\u201cIf we had our A.I.S., we would have found him,\u201d Witt said. \u201cI\u2019ve learned that redundancies in this system is an example of change, like a second antenna.\u201d\n\nHe added that he believed the race\u2019s safety procedures worked well but that \u201cwe waste an awful lot of time and money\u201d on safety equipment that is not as useful as a second antenna would be.\n\nLawrence, the race director, said the skippers meet at each stopover to review safety procedures and equipment, and investigate accidents. Such a meeting is scheduled for Friday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRace procedures can change after each race, even each leg,\u201d he said. \u201cWe will take into account new techniques, new technologies.\u201d", "title": "After a Man Was Lost at Sea, the Volvo Ocean Race Scrutinizes Safety Measures", "authors": ["Chris Museler"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "How did I feel when he came out? It was a bit like finding there was an unopened birthday gift that had been hidden under a couch for years. Learning something new about your child means there is something else to love. It is truly a gift.\n\nFinding out that Oliver is gay was no different than finding out my other son is obsessed with \u201cThe Lord of the Rings.\u201d To me it was both big and no big deal.\n\nLater I had a fleeting thought about not having grandchildren, and then reminded myself that there was always adoption or assisted reproduction technologies. And how no one knows if her heterosexual child will grow up to want children or struggle one day with infertility.\n\nI also reminded myself that this wasn\u2019t about me.\n\nOliver\u2019s love for the L.G.B.T.Q. community is something to behold. (For any reader wondering, the Q can stand for either \u201cqueer\u201d or \u201cquestioning.\u201d) He is so proud of being gay that I struggle to think of a personal trait that makes me similarly proud. Na\u00efvely, I didn\u2019t worry much about the impact of his coming out because we live in the San Francisco Bay Area. But even if we didn\u2019t, there would be no point in trying to keep Oliver quiet.\n\nOliver and I speak a lot about coming out and what it means for him to be gay, thanks in large part to everyone who has come out before him. Seeing versions of himself on screen \u2014 as in the show \u201cGlee\u201d and, more recently, the movie \u201cLove, Simon\u201d \u2014 has done more to strengthen his sense of self than any conversation with me could have. The power of representation is something to behold.", "title": "After a Son Comes Out, Seeing the World Through His Eyes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI always feel like that\u2019s possible,\u201d Manager Aaron Boone said. \u201cIf we can get traffic on the bases, we\u2019re always one swing away with our guys.\u201d\n\nFor five and two-thirds innings, the Yankees could get no traffic against Gibson, who struck out 10 batters, a career high, and stifled them with a sinking fastball that ran in on the hands of right-handed hitters.\n\nBut after Gardner singled and Aaron Judge followed with a walk, Twins Manager Paul Molitor removed his starter before the seventh and replaced him with Reed.
