He was busy rehearsing the title role in \u201cHamlet\u201d while also preparing for \u201cKing Lear,\u201d in which he is playing Edmund alongside Antony Sher.\n\nBoth productions were about to travel to the United States: \u201cKing Lear\u201d runs through April 29 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and \u201cHamlet\u201d arrives at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., on May 2. But eventually Mr. Essiedu was able to find a time to talk, between the cool-down from one play and the warm-up for the other. He wasn\u2019t being difficult; this was just how it was.\n\nFor a man with so much on his plate, Mr. Essiedu seemed to be operating on another, more relaxed plane entirely. Ambling into his dressing room at the Hackney Empire theater here \u2014 it was filled with a boyish clutter of discarded drink cartons and unwashed T-shirts \u2014 he admitted that, yes, the last few weeks had been a bit extreme.\n\n\u201cBut that\u2019s exciting, right?\u201d he said with a slow grin. \u201cBusy is good.\u201d\n\nA little more than a decade ago, Mr. Essiedu, 27, was in high school and had a grand total of one production to his name: a Christmas pageant when he was 8. These days, he is regarded as one of the brightest young stars in British theater. A 2015 production of \u201cRomeo and Juliet\u201d at Tobacco Factory Theaters in Bristol, not long after he left drama school, offered a taste of his remarkable talents. Instead of the moonstruck lover usually on display, this Romeo was a mixture of wide-eyed charm and hot-blooded passion.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut his Hamlet, which originally opened in Stratford-upon-Avon two years ago and has since been on a British tour, has cemented his reputation. The Guardian called the production \u201cspiritually refreshing.\u201d A critic for The Telegraph declared, \u201cI\u2019d say it\u2019s 99.9 percent certain that within five years Essiedu will be a major star.\u201d In London, there has been excitement on social media and long lines outside the theater\u2019s box office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Essiedu was politely reluctant to dwell on this, preferring to deliberate on the differences between Edmund and Hamlet and speculate on the boundlessness of Shakespeare\u2019s imaginative geography. This \u201cHamlet\u201d is set not in Denmark, but somewhere that looks like contemporary West Africa, filled with colorful Batik prints, razor-sharp tailoring and Yoruba drumming.\n\nHamlet has just graduated as an overseas student at the University of Wittenberg, Ohio, when he\u2019s abruptly called home by his father\u2019s death. We sense that he is struggling with culture shock as much as raw grief. (Though there is certainly plenty of the latter.)", "title": "After \u2018Hamlet\u2019 and \u2018King Lear,\u2019 Where Else Can Paapa Essiedu Go?", "authors": ["Andrew Dickson"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Sketchbook | The Literati\n\nAgatha Christie Solves the Mystery of Happiness in Marriage\n\nWhen the author of \u201cMurder on the Orient Express\u201d rode that very train on a journey toward true love.", "title": "Agatha Christie Solves the Mystery of Happiness in Marriage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Warsh described \u201cHumanity\u201d as a continuation of the 6-inch-tall 2012 book \u201cWeiwei-isms\u201d \u2014 which he also edited \u2014 with Mr. Ai\u2019s ruminations on individual rights and freedom of expression.\n\nMr. Ai will be interviewed onstage at the New York Times Art Leaders Network conference, a gathering in Berlin of established and emerging figures in the art world on Wednesday and Thursday. Mr. Ai sat down to discuss his new book and some of the issues he will address there. Following are edited excerpts.\n\nWhy put these thoughts in a book?\n\nYou have the internet, you have this information flow, but you can still use the structure of museums or galleries or newspapers or books to generate a public discussion. I cannot create it, I can\u2019t even measure it, I\u2019ll just be part of it.\n\nWhat initially got you interested in the refugee crisis?\n\nOne lady from Iraq came to see me. She said, \u201cI want you to help me to select drawings made in an Iraqi [refugee] camp. With your reputation, the wind is behind you, so we want to draw some attention.\u201d I looked through their drawings \u2014 kind of na\u00efve drawings, memories about how their houses had been bombed. They were like children\u2019s drawings. I got very attracted to it. I said, \u201cI can do that only with one condition: if I can send some of my team to that camp. I just want to interview those people.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYou ultimately were able to regain your passport and go to a refugee camp on the Greek island Lesbos yourself, for the documentary \u201cHuman Flow.\u201d What was that like?\n\nIt\u2019s so different when you see a real snake. I was quite surprised to see this very, very unprepared primitive response in dealing with this human crisis. It\u2019s total neglect or wanting to avoid the issue. If you\u2019re a doctor and you see sickness, you deal with it. This is a very scientific society \u2014 we have all kind of resources. Yet we were totally paralyzed. In the beginning, we didn\u2019t know how to respond, just let it be rotten.\n\nWith your installation, \u201cLaundromat\u201d \u2014 featuring the cleaned castoff clothes of refugees \u2014 and your recent public art project, \u201cGood Fences Make Good Neighbors,\u201d a series of fences and barriers, you\u2019ve lately been a larger presence in New York. Why is that?\n\nI have a strange relationship with the city \u2014 I really struggled here, but I love it here. Lately, I started thinking about New York\u2019s history with immigration \u2014 everybody in New York comes from somewhere. Here are the strongest characters, the imagination, the passion. Something about New York is about losing control and having control at the same time. It generates so much energy. If you\u2019re walking down Broadway, and you just see the people passing, you never know where they come from. They often look tired but they\u2019re quite determined to survive here. I wanted to do something about this.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou have said that your early blogs were often funny. Yet most of your more recent artistic expression seems fairly serious. How do you explain that?\n\nI probably used up all my humor. I have no humor anymore.\n\nGiven the immensity of the refugee crisis, why even try to make an impact? Do you ever get frustrated by a sense of futility?\n\nHow do you prove you\u2019re living at this time? We are given one time to live. You\u2019re a passenger passing through, you leave some traces. In China we say, \u2018When birds pass over the sky\u2026\u2019 I\u2019m just one of the birds who made some sounds. Wind will blow them away.\u201d", "title": "Ai Weiwei\u2019s Little Blue Book on the Refugee Crisis", "authors": ["Robin Pogrebin"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 When the Chinese artist and activist Ai Weiwei moved from Beijing to Berlin in 2015, he vowed to steer away from what had been the primary focus of his creative practice until then: China.\n\n\u201cI want to forget about China and do something which surprises me,\u201d he said in a September 2015 interview. \u201cWhy do I have to be labeled? I\u2019m not a car seller. Nothing can replace freedom, and that\u2019s a challenge, and I\u2019m ready for that.\u201d\n\nIn the two and a half years since, Mr. Ai has found an acutely challenging topic to take on: the global refugee crisis \u2014 sparked by the civil war in Syria and the migration of more than 5.4 million of its people. Recently, he has installed 17 fences and bus shelters around New York, \u201cGood Fences Make Good Neighbors,\u201d and released a documentary, \u201cHuman Flow.\u201d", "title": "Ai Weiwei\u2019s Refugee Project Moves to Qatar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 A former American intelligence official who came under intense scrutiny during a stint at the White House last year is returning to government as the national security adviser to Attorney General Jeff Sessions, according to a person familiar with the decision.\n\nThe official, Ezra Cohen-Watnick, will play an important role at the Justice Department, advising Mr. Sessions on counterintelligence and counterterrorism.\n\nMr. Cohen-Watnick is known to be hawkish on Russia and China, believing the intelligence community needs to take a more aggressive approach in countering their activities. Both countries conduct wide-ranging espionage in the United States that targets commercial and government secrets. Mr. Sessions is broadly viewed in the Justice Department as lacking expertise in the area.\n\nThe Justice Department declined to comment.\n\nMr. Cohen-Watnick, 31, served briefly at the start of the Trump administration as the senior director for intelligence for the National Security Council, overseeing covert action and other intelligence programs. He was brought on by Michael T. Flynn, President Trump\u2019s first national security adviser. But some former officials criticized Mr. Cohen-Watnick, a former clandestine officer in the Defense Intelligence Agency, as too young for the job, which is usually filled by C.I.A. veterans.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Cohen-Watnick was ousted in August 2017 as part of changes in the White House, one of several appointees of Mr. Flynn who were removed by his replacement, Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNational Security Council aides usually draw little public scrutiny, but Mr. Cohen-Watnick was swept up in the tumult of early 2017 when Mr. Trump accused the previous administration, without evidence, of wiretapping his phones at Trump Tower.", "title": "Aide Ousted From White House Re-emerges at Justice Dept.", "authors": ["Adam Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAir pollution, even of short duration, increases the number of lower respiratory infections, a new study reports, and the effects may be particularly serious in young children.\n\nAcute respiratory infection of the lungs and airways, usually caused by viruses, are a leading cause of illness and death in young children.\n\nThe study, in the American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, tracked 146,397 people, 77 percent of them children younger than 2, who had infections treated in hospitals and clinics in Utah. Researchers gathered data on levels of small particulate matter, or PM2.5, from sensors at three monitoring stations in the state\u2019s Wasatch Front region. The area has substantial variations in PM2.5.\n\nBeginning in the second week after an increase in pollution levels, the researchers found a corresponding increase in respiratory infections, peaking in the third week after the PM2.5 increase.\n\nThe scientists calculate that each short-term increase of 10 micrograms per cubic meter in PM2.5 is associated with a 15 to 23 percent increase in serious respiratory infections.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no reason to panic here,\u201d said the lead author, Benjamin D. Horne, of Intermountain Medical Center Heart Institute. \u201cWhen air pollution is high, avoid idling cars, stay distant from highways, stay indoors or go out in the early morning when pollution is usually lower. We don\u2019t have to feel like we\u2019re victims.\u201d", "title": "Air Pollution May Pose Serious Risks to Young Children", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Airlines are avoiding Syrian airspace as the United States and other Western powers consider their response to a suspected chemical attack near Damascus last weekend.\n\nThe European Aviation Safety Agency, a European Union organization, issued an alert on Tuesday, prompting a number of airlines to steer away from the country\u2019s airspace.\n\n\u201cDue to the possible launch of airstrikes into Syria,\u201d the agency said, \u201cdue consideration needs to be taken when planning flight operations.\u201d The alert cited the possible use of air-to-ground and cruise missiles and the likely disruption of radio navigation equipment.", "title": "Airlines Clear Skies Over Syria, Noting Threat of Missile Strikes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "But of course, politics has intervened. State leaders have tweaked the plan so that it will raise revenue but limit political risk \u2014 by excluding personal cars from paying, at least for now \u2014 and therefore have negligible impact on congestion.\n\nCongestion is caused by all vehicles, not just a fraction of them. The plan arbitrarily divides the vehicles that ply our streets into for-hire vehicles and applies a surcharge \u2014 $2.50 per trip for taxis, $2.75 for for-hire, $0.75 shared for-hire \u2014 and lets all other vehicles go free. Analysis from Charles Komanoff, a transportation expert who contributed to the Fix NYC report, finds that without congestion pricing on all vehicles, \u201cthe time savings from reduced traffic congestion drops by at least 60 percent. The revenues available to improve transit drop by 60 percent or more as well.\u201d\n\nThe real challenge for city streets is to move people, not cars, efficiently. Not only does Albany\u2019s plan treat a significant fraction of vehicles as if they were invisible and took up no space; it also underplays an incredibly salient distinction \u2014 how many people are in a vehicle \u2014 by lumping all for-hire vehicles together. If one person alone in a car is bad (and it is), then two people in a car is better. Three is better still. Getting lots of people into a bus or subway is the holy grail of congestion reduction. While the Albany plan will charge pooled passengers a smaller surcharge ($0.75), it doesn\u2019t go far enough to recognize the enormous benefits of ride-sharing and microtransit.\n\nIn fact, on a percentage basis, riders in shared-trip vehicles will be paying a higher tax than those who choose to ride alone, and in some cases the total tax per vehicle will be higher too. During morning and evening commutes, Via transports six people per vehicle; the collective surcharge on those vehicles will be $4.50, larger than for lone riders in other for-hire vehicles and infinitely more than for the person driving his or her own car without charge.\n\nIndependent research conducted in San Francisco finds that the regular Uber and Lyft services average 2.1 passengers per vehicle, yet neither of them will get a tax break because the services aren\u2019t registered as \u201cshared for hire.\u201d Seventy-three percent of people who commute in their personal cars travel alone and won\u2019t be paying a fee at all.", "title": "Opinion | Albany Punts on Clearing Manhattan\u2019s Clogged Streets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Shortly after a gunman entered Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida in February and killed 17 people, the conspiracy theory website Infowars claimed it had a photo of the attacker wearing \u201ccommunist garb.\u201d It showed a young man with a clenched fist in a red shirt emblazoned with a hammer and sickle and images of Joseph Stalin, Vladimir Lenin and Karl Marx.\n\nBut that man was not Nikolas Cruz, who was arrested two miles from the Parkland, Fla., school on Feb. 14 and later confessed to the shooting, the police said. The man in the red shirt was Marcel Fontaine, who lives 1,200 miles away in Massachusetts and has never visited Florida.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Fontaine filed a defamation lawsuit against Infowars, one of its reporters and its right-wing founder, Alex Jones, asserting that their story misidentified him as the gunman and caused his photo to spread across social media, message boards and other websites. In the lawsuit, a lawyer for Mr. Fontaine said it appeared that Infowars published his photo simply because of his shirt.\n\n\u201cMr. Jones and Infowars have long been consumed with paranoia over the prospect of communist infiltration and indoctrination,\u201d the lawsuit, filed in Travis County District Court in Austin, Tex., said. \u201cOver the past year alone, Infowars has featured hundreds of sensationalist articles and videos focusing on the threat of communist agitation and conspiracies.\u201d", "title": "Alex Jones and Infowars Are Sued for Defamation After Misidentifying Parkland Gunman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "The good news for the Tampa Bay Lightning is they\u2019re up, two games to none, on the Devils in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs, and they still haven\u2019t played their best hockey.\n\nAlex Killorn scored twice during a four-goal second period, helping the top-seeded team in the Eastern Conference beat the Devils, 5-3, on Saturday afternoon in Tampa, Fla., in Game 2 of the best-of-seven series.\n\nThe Lightning, the Atlantic Division champions, scored three times in a span of 2 minutes 47 seconds in the second period, and the reeling Devils pulled goalie Keith Kinkaid after Killorn\u2019s third goal in two games made it 5-1 with 6:48 remaining in the period.\n\nKinkaid, whose stellar play since January helped the Devils finish strong and claim their first playoff berth since 2012, yielded five goals on 15 shots.", "title": "Alex Killorn Scores Twice as Lightning Beat Devils in Game 2", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Alex Ovechkin scored twice and Braden Holtby made 35 saves as the Washington Capitals advanced to the Eastern Conference semifinals with a 6-3 victory on Monday over the host Columbus Blue Jackets.\n\nThe Capitals, who won the series, four games to two, will face Pittsburgh in the second round of the playoffs for the third straight season. The Penguins won each of the last two years on the way to winning consecutive Stanley Cup championships.\n\nChandler Stephenson had a goal and an assist, and Dimitry Orlov, Devante Smith-Pelly and Lars Eller also scored for Washington, which never trailed in the game after prevailing in overtime in Game 5 on Saturday.\n\nNick Foligno had two goals, Pierre-Luc Dubois also scored and Sergei Bobrovsky finished with 22 saves for the Blue Jackets, who lost in the first round for the second consecutive season and fourth time over all. They remain the only active N.H.L. franchise never to win a playoff series.", "title": "Alex Ovechkin Carries Capitals Past Blue Jackets and Into Second Round", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "For Wagner, a teenager at the time, here was an identity that was intelligible \u2014 enviable, even \u2014 instead of leaving her at the mercy of confused line cooks: \u201cI was a precursor, sent from the future to show the people of America what they would all look like a few generations hence.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSuch post-racial triumphalism now sounds bogus, and Wagner knows it. \u201cThe generic mantle of \u2018mixed\u2019 felt empowering but also weightless,\u201d she writes. \u201cThis sense of existential unrootedness, of transience, followed me into adulthood.\u201d Looking at the current political moment, she sees her growing disillusionment refracted in something more aggressive and poisonous.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a creeping sense that multiculturalism might not be the answer to, but the seed of, our discontent,\u201d she writes. \u201cThat we\u2019ve forsaken specific ancestry for something fashionably exotic, and this has made us disconnected and isolated, or angry and confused.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo she embarks on a quest to find out as much as she can about both sides of her family, beyond the gauzy stories that have been handed down. What begins as a reflective memoir of loneliness and longing turns into a methodical investigation, as Wagner digs into the archives, calls up experts and tests her DNA.\n\nShe\u2019s primed to discover the worst. Her mother and her maternal grandmother, who became a democracy activist in American exile, spoke of their lives in Burma with such reverence that it made Wagner suspicious: \u201cIt always rang alarm bells when anyone got misty-eyed about the good times, because, in reality, those were often the actually pretty bad times for quite a few other people.\u201d\n\nWagner unearths Burma\u2019s long history of ethnic cleansing and failed social experiments \u2014 though whether her family was involved in the truly nasty stuff is never entirely clear. Her great-grandfather worked in a credit union, the pivot point in a cooperative lending system that eventually collapsed because of lax standards.\n\n\u201cIt pained me to think of my great-grandfather as an actor who\u2019d brought so many Burmese to their knees, courtesy of a failed banking system,\u201d she writes. But did he? She doesn\u2019t find evidence that her great-grandfather actually made bad loans; only that some people in similar positions did.\n\n\u201cFutureface\u201d raises urgent questions having to do with history and complicity. Wagner is determined to look at her family with the coldest eye, making excuses for no one. Considering how tempting it is to let loved ones off the hook, her ruthlessness can feel refreshing and often admirable. I\u2019ve rarely encountered a family history this unsparing. Hers, however, can come off as unsparing to a fault.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWagner\u2019s parents are committed liberals \u2014 they met on the job, working for the Teamsters \u2014 but they\u2019re presented here as inveterate hypocrites. After recounting one of her mother\u2019s giggling jokes, Wagner writes: \u201cMy mother had a lot of opinions about a lot of ethnic groups, which she would probably attribute to her broad reading habits and extensive travels, and which I chalked up to a proclivity toward ethnic tribalism and an innate haughtiness.\u201d\n\nShe\u2019s a little more forgiving of her father, though not by much. He \u201chad an annoying habit of adopting (his version of) the local accent, in a pathetic and ill-advised bid to \u2018fit in.\u2019\u201d She portrays her Burmese grandmother\u2019s friendships with gay men and black men in the 1960s and \u201970s as hardly more than a calculated bid for assimilation: \u201cIn her seeming tolerance, ironically, she moved closer to a certain white, liberal American ideal.\u201d\n\nSuch ungenerous assessments aren\u2019t necessarily inaccurate; Wagner knows her family better than I do. But in her push to dismantle some cherished myths, her book starts to feel bloodless, so shorn of sentiment that Wagner\u2019s project loses the profoundly personal feelings that animated it in the first place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt would be one thing if she uncovered definitive evidence of a real whopper, an astounding family secret; what she discovers instead are the kinds of skeletons \u2014 illegitimacy, hypocrisy, selective memory, callous prejudice \u2014 that are distressing, but also distressingly common.\n\nThese ordinary cruelties might not make for riveting journalism, but they make for a rich and revealing memoir. As Wagner points out, so much of the American dream revolves around those who built their selves \u201con deceit and half-truths.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s missing in \u201cFutureface\u201d is a palpable sense of who Wagner became after her teenage years. She self-deprecatingly alludes to being a \u201cbad friend\u201d who lives with her husband in \u201can overpriced converted yuppie loft complex\u201d that she despises. For the most part, though, Wagner turns her gaze outward, away from her life as it is right now. The result is a book that seems mercilessly honest from one angle and carefully guarded from another.\n\nWagner\u2019s skepticism and irreverence are so polished that you want to get a better sense of what motivates them. But the harsh light she shines on those around her can be so blinding that we lose sight of who she is.", "title": "Alex Wagner Digs Into Her Family\u2019s Past in \u2018Futureface\u2019", "authors": ["Jennifer Szalai", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAlexa Kaeten Mehraban and Daniel Peter Matthews were married April 21 at the Metropolitan Club in New York. The bride\u2019s mother is an antiques dealer and interior decorator in New York.\n\nMr. Matthews, 27, is the founder and chief executive of Postcard, a mobile software service allowing users to place food orders at restaurants of their choosing.\n\nHe is the son of Rita Matthews and Robert S. Matthews of New York. The groom's father is the founding partner of Matthews & Company, a tax consultancy with offices in New York, Westchester and Florida.\n\nThe couple first met through mutual friends while growing up in New York.", "title": "Alexa Mehraban, Daniel Matthews", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSarabande is unique as a hub of creativity and an incubator of young talent,\u201d Andrew Bolton, curator in charge of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a patron of the foundation, said in an email. \u201cIn only a few years, it has established itself as one of the most important and exciting community of artists in Britain.\u201d\n\nResidents say the studios are affordable sanctuaries, allowing them to develop their creative practices while benefiting from the organization\u2019s business education programs, networking opportunities and mentoring support. \u201cIt brings some much-needed freedom to what I can do,\u201d said Katie Roberts Wood, a women\u2019s wear designer who has been using a studio since October. \u201cI have to run a business but I also have to be able to function fully from a creative side, or it doesn\u2019t work. I feel like Sarabande pays equal attention to both these aspects, which is so rare.\u201d\n\nThat dual emphasis is thanks to Trino Verkade, a founding trustee and driving force behind Sarabande\u2019s development. In 1994, she became Mr. McQueen\u2019s first employee and stayed for 18 years, providing the business acumen to support his creative talent. She also brought to the foundation years of experience as an executive vice president at Thom Browne and, most recently, chief executive at Mary Katrantzou.\n\nDuring a recent interview at the foundation, Ms. Verkade said that providing financial support and expert advice to artists was important for their development but also for Britain\u2019s, referring to government research that found that creative industries add almost \u00a39.6 million per hour to the national economy. And, despite a decade of austerity, cuts in education funding and the uncertainty over Britain\u2019s departure from the European Union, the research also showed that the art, fashion and film industries have grown at almost twice the rate of the overall economy, and that they are worth \u00a384 billion a year.\n\nMs. Verkade said Sarabande\u2019s goal was to plug the gaps left by reduced government support, rising college fees and a dearth of practical business advice for fledgling operations. \u201cBritain has done a good job exporting talent,\u201d she said, but \u201cthere\u2019s all this untapped potential here. That\u2019s a real business opportunity.\u201d", "title": "Alexander McQueen\u2019s Legacy: The Sarabande Foundation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "How did you get into computers?\n\nI managed to convince my parents to get me a PC in eighth or ninth grade \u2014 that it would help me with my career. In reality I just wanted to play video games. Then I got a 33.6 dial-up connection, and I was building websites for strangers on the internet for free. I just wanted a chance to flex as a web developer. They had no idea I was this dorky kid at my parents\u2019 house.\n\nWhat was your first job?\n\nMy first job was at a CompUSA demo-ing software, and it was the worst public speaking experience a teenager going through puberty could have. Every 30 minutes I\u2019d have to get on a mic and demo to the whole store some lame piece of hardware or software and literally get ignored by people. People would walk up to me, look at me and then walk away.\n\nBut I got paid well for it, and basically got my 10,000 hours of public speaking out of the way at an early age. From there I worked as a cook and dishwasher at Pizza Hut. Then I worked my way up to a waiter, where I learned basically everything I\u2019ve ever needed to know about customer service.\n\nDid you think you were going to be an entrepreneur?\n\nI\u2019d been studying for the LSAT. I was going to be an immigration lawyer. I had this romantic idea of helping people get citizenship. But then I realized how much I hated what I was doing, so I went and got a waffle instead. It was at a Waffle House I realized I wanted to start something.\n\nSo in 2005, how\u2019d you start Reddit?\n\nI convinced my college roommate to start a business that would help people skip lines. That didn\u2019t work out. But then [the Silicon Valley incubator] Y Combinator said, \u201cO.K., take our money and do something else.\u201d And that was Reddit.", "title": "Alexis Ohanian Talks Reddit, Serena Williams and Metallica", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Since then Jahi has survived for years despite confident medical predictions to the contrary, and she now gives pretty decent evidence of retaining some form of consciousness, some ability to listen and respond. In California her status as a dead person is under litigation; in a small apartment in New Jersey, in the care of her mother, she is very much alive.\n\nHer fate is thus a case study in why a decent society allows families leeway to defy medical consensus: not only for the sake of parental rights and religious beliefs, not only because biases around race and class and faith creep into medical decision-making, but also because in hard cases the official medical consensus often doesn\u2019t come close to grasping all the possibilities, and letting people go their own way is often the only way to discover where it\u2019s wrong.\n\nBut this tendency to arrogate power away from the family is not just an issue for extreme medical cases. In Aviv\u2019s story on guardianship among the elderly, it plays out in a more prosaic and yet similarly shocking form \u2014 with old people who are hardly incompetent handed over to professional guardians who sell their assets and consign them to assisted living facilities from which they can\u2019t escape.\n\nThe basic dynamic is like the Gard and Evans and McMath cases but with the generational roles reversed: Instead of parents trying to pry their children away from the medical establishment, you have adult children unable to bring their parents home because their state-appointed guardians say no.\n\nAviv focuses on the Kafkaesque odyssey of Julie Belshe, a mother of three who spent years extracting her parents from the talons of a woman, April Parks, who was later indicted on charges of perjury and theft. But Parks flourished in a larger system designed around the assumption that old people are basically better off without their kids, because offspring are probably motivated either by raw emotionalism or by gimme-gimme avarice, as opposed to the cool wisdom of expert doctors, professional guardians, and wise judges.", "title": "Opinion | Alfie Evans and the Experts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "On Saturday, Pope Francis posted on Twitter: \u201cI am deeply moved by the death of little Alfie. Today I pray especially for his parents, as God the Father receives him in his tender embrace.\u201d\n\nThe foreign minister of Italy, Angelino Alfano, also tweeted in Italian: \u201cGoodbye, little Alfie. We loved you.\u201d\n\nAlfie, who was born on May 9, 2016, was admitted to the hospital when he was 7 months old, after suffering seizures.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Monday, the hospital withdrew life support against his parents\u2019 wishes. But the boy continued to breathe on his own.\n\n\u201cFor the third day now, there\u2019s been not one single problem with him,\u201d his father said outside the hospital on Thursday. \u201cIt\u2019s not a miracle; it\u2019s a misdiagnosis.\u201d\n\nHis parents lost or were turned away in the High Court, the Supreme Court and European Court of Human Rights. On Wednesday, the British Court of Appeal upheld a ruling that approved the withdrawal of care and sustenance. It also prohibited Alfie\u2019s parents from seeking treatment elsewhere.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe parents\u2019 lawyers, from the Christian Legal Center, had vowed to continue their appeals.\n\nThe rulings echoed another high-profile case, that of Charlie Gard, the British infant who had a rare genetic abnormality known as mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome. The boy could not see, hear, swallow or cry.\n\nHis plight drew attention from Francis and President Trump.\n\nCharlie\u2019s parents fought a long and public battle to prolong his life, but bowed to the consensus of medical experts who said there was no realistic chance of saving him: The child had irreversible brain damage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe British High Court ruled that he could be moved to a hospice and that his life support could be withdrawn. Charlie died in July 2017 with his parents by his side a day after.\n\nThe news of Alfie\u2019s death drew an outpouring on social media.\n\n\u201cAwful news,\u201d Tara Vernal wrote on Facebook. \u201cCan\u2019t help feel angry for you.\u201d\n\nAnother person, Mary Fiander, wrote: \u201cGod bless you, beautiful Alfie. Fly high and free darling. Tom and Kate, my heart goes out to you both. Your little soldier was loved and adored by you. Nobody could have fought a tougher battle for Alfie. You are amazing.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, the hospital expressed \u201cheartfelt sympathies and condolences to Alfie\u2019s family.\u201d", "title": "Alfie Evans, Terminally Ill British Toddler at Center of Court Fight, Dies", "authors": ["Yonette Joseph"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cThe Columbian Exchange: Biological and Cultural Consequences of 1492,\u201d a wide-ranging book published in 1972, Professor Crosby examined in pithy, sometimes wry prose how disease had devastated indigenous populations after Columbus landed.\n\nHe also described a parallel development that transformed global ecology forever: the transoceanic movement of plants and animals, in which Europeans shipped staple crops like wheat, oats and fruit stock along with horses, goats and pigs to the Americas, where they were not known, and transported back to Europe New World cultivars like maize, potatoes and beans.\n\nOn Oct. 12, 1492, the \u201ctwo worlds\u201d on opposite sides of the Atlantic, \u201cwhich were so different, began on that day to become alike,\u201d Professor Crosby wrote.\n\n\u201cThat trend toward homogeneity,\u201d he concluded, \u201cis one of the most important aspects of the history of life on this planet since the retreat of the glaciers.\u201d\n\nWhen asked in an interview in 2011 with Smithsonian magazine why his scholarly approach had not been pursued before, he said, \u201cWe were thinking politically and ideologically, but very rarely were historians thinking ecologically, biologically.\u201d\n\nHe had expanded on that idea in 1994 in \u201cGerms, Seeds and Animals: Studies in Ecological History,\u201d a collection of essays. He wrote that a venture into epidemiology had led him to \u201ca more general subject: ecological history, the history of all organisms pertinent to human history and their (our) environment.\u201d\n\n\u201cYes, germs were important,\u201d he continued, \u201cand so, it turned out, were insects, fungi, weeds, crops and domesticated and wild animals. Humanity turned out to be the purposeful but often drunken ringmaster of a three-ring circus of organisms.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1986, with \u201cEcological Imperialism: The Biological Expansion of Europe, 900-1900,\u201d Professor Crosby, in his words, \u201ctook \u2018The Columbian Exchange\u2019 up another notch in scope and abstraction.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn this book he posited the existence of \u201cneo-Europes,\u201d areas and countries where Europeans settled, especially between 1820 and 1930, after they had \u201cleapfrogged across the globe.\u201d These settlers became so successful at food production and food export that they easily dominated indigenous cultures and then nearly decimated them.\n\nHe traced the rise of these \u201cneo-Europes\u201d to a kind of environmental competition that the invading Europeans won. Flora and fauna native to the Americas were so different from the plants and animals that Europeans brought with them, and so acclimated to specific growing conditions, that they couldn\u2019t compete biologically. What Professor Crosby called \u201cthe companions of the conquistadors\u201d conquered as well.\n\nAt the same time, catastrophically, native peoples increasingly died of diseases, usually smallpox, that had moved from domestic animals to humans. Descendants of the European settlers, by contrast, had acquired immunity.\n\nThe books had wide impact. The author Charles Mann\u2019s well-regarded 2011 best-seller, \u201c1493: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created,\u201d was an effort, encouraged by Professor Crosby, to update \u201cEcological Imperialism.\u201d\n\n\u201cAl was an exceptionally independent thinker whose work pioneered half a dozen new genres,\u201d Mr. Mann wrote in an email. \u201cScores, if not hundreds of writers \u2014 me among them \u2014 have scribbled their works in the margins of \u2018The Columbian Exchange\u2019 and \u2018Ecological Imperialism.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAlfred Worcester Crosby Jr. was born in Boston on Jan. 15, 1931, and grew up in Wellesley, Mass., to Alfred Sr. and the former Ruth Coleman. He graduated from Wellesley High School.\n\nHe told an interviewer in the journal \u201cThe Americas\u201d in 2015 that comic strip superheroes and historical events like \u201crockets vaulting the English Channel\u201d during World War II, and \u201cthen rockets on their way to the Moon and Mars,\u201d had seized his imagination when he was young. But he nevertheless concluded, he said, that \u201cColumbus stumbling on an unexpected continent seemed more suitable an object for my focus than even the all-powerful Clark Kent.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe graduated from Harvard in 1952 with a degree in history and then served in the Panama Canal Zone as a sergeant in the Army, becoming exposed to a Latin American culture that he had known little about, he said. After the service, he obtained a doctorate in history from Boston University.\n\nProfessor Crosby taught at the University of Texas in Austin for 22 years and retired in 1999 as professor emeritus of geography, history and American studies.\n\nBefore that, while teaching at Washington State University, he was involved in a student strike that led to his becoming a co-founder, with the anthropologist Johnetta Cole, of the school\u2019s first black studies department. He taught there for 11 years.\n\nHe also came to know the labor and civil rights leaders Cesar Chavez and Dolores Huerta when Professor Crosby pitched in to help build a medical center for the United Farm Workers in California.\n\nIn addition to his wife, Ms. Karttunen, his survivors include his son, Kevin; his daughter, Carolyn Crosby; his stepdaughters, Jaana Karttunen and Suvi Aika; and two grandchildren. His previous marriages, to Anna Bienemann and Barbara Stevens, ended in divorce.\n\nProfessor Crosby\u2019s other books include \u201cThe Measure of Reality: Quantification and Western Society, 1250-1600\u201d (1997), which he called \u201can essay on the essential characteristic of civilization: mathematics,\u201d and \u201cChildren of the Sun: A History of Humanity\u2019s Unappeasable Appetite for Energy\u201d (2006).\n\n\u201cThe Columbian Exchange\u201d might not have been published at all if Greenwood Press, a small publisher of academic books in Westport, Conn., had not agreed to take it on. Dr. Crosby had found no takers among mainstream publishers\n\nIn the preface to \u201cThe Columbian Exchange,\u201d Professor Crosby addressed his interdisciplinary method and what may be considered his scholarly legacy. He expressed hope that the book was \u201can unpretentious one, but I am the first to recognize that historians, geologists, anthropologists, zoologists, botanists and demographers will see me as an amateur in their particular fields.\u201d\n\nHe said he would partly agree with them if they thought so, but he also concluded that \u201calthough the Renaissance is long past, there is a great need for Renaissance-style attempts at pulling together the discoveries of the specialists to learn what we know, in general, about life on this planet.\u201d", "title": "Alfred Crosby, \u2018Father of Environmental History,\u2019 Is Dead at 87", "authors": ["John Motyka"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAlicia Hunt Ciccone and William Benjamin Thomas were married April 14 at the Liberty Warehouse, an events space in Brooklyn. She graduated from Cornell and received a master\u2019s degree in applied biostatistics and epidemiology from the University of Southern California.\n\nShe is a daughter of Christine M. Ortega and Chris A. Ortega of Santa Fe, N.M. The bride\u2019s father retired as a civil engineer for the City of Santa Fe. He is a commercial pilot for Armstrong Consultants in Albuquerque. The bride\u2019s mother is a financial analyst in Santa Fe for the State of New Mexico at the Public Employees Retirement Association.\n\nDr. Mukherjee, 35, is a neurosurgeon at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. He graduated from Dartmouth and received a medical degree from Johns Hopkins.\n\nHe is a son of Kalpana Mukherjee and Mahitosh Mukherjee of Los Angeles. The groom\u2019s mother is an associate nurse at Sakura Intermediate Care Facility in Los Angeles. The groom\u2019s father retired as a structural engineer and owner of Diversified Engineering in Hammond, Ind.\n\nThe couple met in 2012 at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where the bride was a research analyst and the groom a neurosurgical resident.", "title": "Alicia Ortega, Debraj Mukherjee", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Around this same time, I had my first kiss. The average temperature inside the human mouth is 98.2 degrees. Our skin is cooler, though, especially the curved, protruding parts of our bodies (think nose, fingers, toes). So what I recall most from that romantic encounter is the delight I felt when my boyfriend blew into my curved, protruding ear, the surface of which may have been anywhere from 92 to 87 degrees.\n\nI also remember a black and white checkered ice bag that was about the size and shape of a tam. I could fill it with ice cubes to use on a sprained ankle or nasty bruise, but mostly I filled it with warm water when I was cramping. The sloshing water was kept inside by a metal cap that looked just like the one on my thermos.\n\nIn my 20s and living on my own, I bought my first heating pad, a plastic white square over which slipped a pink machine-washable cotton cover. It stayed with me through many moves. Maybe because I used it only once or twice a month, this rudimentary heating pad didn\u2019t conk out until after I\u2019d reached menopause.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor occasions when my mid and lower back hurt, I put on an extra long Ontel Relief Wrap. This burgundy heating pad also clasps with magnets at the neck, but looks more like a cape than a stole and provides heat all the way down to my rear end. For targeting a small muscle group, I have my trusty infrared Light Relief, which supposedly uses NASA technology to promote healing.\n\nI ordered it one sleepless night, mesmerized by a late-night TV commercial in which Robert Wagner says, \u201cSounds like science fiction? Well, today, it\u2019s science fact!\u201d Maybe I was impressed by his turn of phrase. But more likely I was desperate, so I called the 800 number. The gadget has a small jellylike blue pad that contoured to my aching shoulder. I don\u2019t think the infrared light did one darn thing, but the heat was amazing.\n\nFor times when I\u2019m sore but must be on the go without an electrical outlet, I use my Bed Buddy. This amazing device does not require a teakettle. I just pop it in the microwave for a minute or so and wear it, like an open scarf, driving through stressful Miami traffic. The Bed Buddy is shaped like a sausage but is filled with grains so it drapes and contours well.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe blasting AC in my Honda in combination with the heat on my neck is akin to the delight I felt when I beheld my first flaming baked alaska: the pleasures of extremes. The Bed Buddy has rope handles at each end, so I can tug for more pressure as the contraption starts to cool. More than once I have seen another woman, stuck at a light, wearing her own Bed Buddy.\n\nIf all this sounds a bit like a fetish, maybe it is. Why else would a pain relief thingumajig be called a Bed Buddy anyway? As a child visiting my relatives in Canada, I learned that my widowed aunt would take a hot water bottle wrapped in a towel and put it between the top sheet and bedspread to keep her warm, as my uncle once had. At a residency at the Elizabeth Bishop House in Nova Scotia, I found potholder-size pillows filled with herbs that could be heated up and put near socked feet for a toasty slumber. And long before the invention of hot water bottles and microwaves, brass bed warmers were filled with warm coals for the same purpose.\n\nAfter my friend lost her husband, she bought herself a Bodymate pillow at Bed Bath & Beyond. She put it on his side of the bed to fill the place he once slept and marveled at how the pillow also kept her warm. Another friend, after a breakup, bought a Pillow With Benefits, out of which jutted a human-size arm into which she could cuddle. When I tried to make her feel better, congratulating her on her recent promotion, she quoted Marilyn: \u201cA career is wonderful, but you can\u2019t curl up with it on a cold night.\u201d\n\nI suppose an electric blanket is the biggest heating pad of all. I remember the one on the double bed my sister and I shared during those fierce Rhode Island winters when my parents were trying to save money on heating oil. My sister and I snuggled in. That blanket may have given us static cling, but how we loved turning the switch on high.\n\nEveryone who has ever shared a bed knows it is much warmer to sleep with someone else. Everyone who has ever held a sleeping baby knows how much heat that little furnace can radiate. When we love, we feel warmth. When we warm up to someone, we feel endearment. Sometimes I find myself singing, \u201cI Wanna Be Loved by You\u201d to my Sunbeam, grateful that, at least for now, nothing hurts.", "title": "All Heated Up", "authors": ["Denise Duhamel"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Some agricultural experts are skeptical. \u201cThis paper does not settle the matter,\u201d said Logan J. Kistler, the curator of archaeogenomics and archaeobotany at the Smithsonian Institution.\n\nAlternative explanations remain on the table, because the new study didn\u2019t provide enough evidence for exactly where sweet potatoes were first domesticated and when they arrived in the Pacific. \u201cWe still don\u2019t have a smoking gun,\u201d Dr. Kistler said.\n\nThe sweet potato, Ipomoea batatas, is one of the most valuable crops in the world, providing more nutrients per farmed acre than any other staple. It has sustained human communities for centuries. (In North America, it often is referred to as a yam; in fact, yams are a different species originating in Africa and Asia.)\n\nPhoto\n\nScientists have offered a number of theories to explain the wide distribution of I. batatas. Some scholars proposed that all sweet potatoes originated in the Americas, and that after Columbus\u2019s voyage, they were spread by Europeans to colonies such as the Philippines. Pacific Islanders acquired the crops from there.\n\nAs it turned out, though, Pacific Islanders had been growing the crop for generations by the time Europeans showed up. On one Polynesian island, archaeologists have found sweet potato remains dating back over 700 years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA radically different hypothesis emerged: Pacific Islanders, masters of open-ocean navigation, picked up sweet potatoes by voyaging to the Americas, long before Columbus\u2019s arrival there. The evidence included a suggestive coincidence: In Peru, some indigenous people call the sweet potato cumara. In New Zealand, it\u2019s kumara.\n\nA potential link between South America and the Pacific was the inspiration for Thor Heyerdahl\u2019s famous 1947 voyage aboard the Kon-Tiki. He built a raft, which he then successfully sailed from Peru to the Easter Islands.\n\nGenetic evidence only complicated the picture. Examining the plant\u2019s DNA, some researchers concluded that sweet potatoes arose only once from a wild ancestor, while other studies indicated that it happened at two different points in history.\n\nAccording to the latter studies, South Americans domesticated sweet potatoes, which were then acquired by Polynesians. Central Americans domesticated a second variety that later was picked up by Europeans.\n\nHoping to shed light on the mystery, a team of researchers recently undertook a new study \u2014 the biggest survey of sweet potato DNA yet. And they came to a very different conclusion.\n\n\u201cWe find very clear evidence that sweet potatoes could arrive in the Pacific by natural means,\u201d said Pablo Mu\u00f1oz-Rodr\u00edguez, a botanist at the University of Oxford. He believes the wild plants traveled thousands of miles across the Pacific without any help from humans.\n\nMr. Mu\u00f1oz-Rodr\u00edguez and his colleagues visited museums and herbariums around the world to take samples of sweet potato varieties and wild relatives. The researchers used powerful DNA-sequencing technology to gather more genetic material from the plants than possible in earlier studies.\n\nPhoto\n\nTheir research pointed to only one wild plant as the ancestor of all sweet potatoes. The closest wild relative is a weedy flower called Ipomoea trifida that grows around the Caribbean. Its pale purple flowers look a lot like those of the sweet potato.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead of a massive, tasty tuber, I. trifida grows only a pencil-thick root. \u201cIt\u2019s nothing we could eat,\u201d Mr. Mu\u00f1oz-Rodr\u00edguez said.\n\nThe ancestors of sweet potatoes split from I. trifida at least 800,000 years ago, the scientists calculated. To investigate how they arrived in the Pacific, the team headed to the Natural History Museum in London.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe leaves of sweet potatoes that Captain Cook\u2019s crew collected in Polynesia are stored in the museum\u2019s cabinets. The researchers cut bits of the leaves and extracted DNA from them.\n\nThe Polynesian sweet potatoes turned out to be genetically unusual \u2014 \u201cvery different from anything else,\u201d Mr. Mu\u00f1oz-Rodr\u00edguez said.\n\nThe sweet potatoes found in Polynesia split off over 111,000 years ago from all other sweet potatoes the researchers studied. Yet humans arrived in New Guinea about 50,000 years ago, and only reached remote Pacific islands in the past few thousand years.\n\nThe age of Pacific sweet potatoes made it unlikely that any humans, Spanish or Pacific Islander, carried the species from the Americas, Mr. Mu\u00f1oz-Rodr\u00edguez said.\n\nTraditionally, researchers have been skeptical that a plant like a sweet potato could travel across thousands of miles of ocean. But in recent years, scientists have turned up signs that many plants have made the voyage, floating on the water or carried in bits by birds.\n\nEven before the sweet potato made the journey, its wild relatives traveled the Pacific, the scientists found. One species, the Hawaiian moonflower, lives only in the dry forests of Hawaii \u2014 but its closest relatives all live in Mexico.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe scientists estimate that the Hawaiian moonflower separated from its relatives \u2014 and made its journey across the Pacific \u2014 over a million years ago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Tim P. Denham, an archaeologist at the Australian National University who was not involved in the study, found this scenario hard to swallow.\n\nIt would suggest that the wild ancestors of sweet potatoes spread across the Pacific and were then domesticated many times over \u2014 yet wound up looking the same every time. \u201cThis would seem unlikely,\u201d he said.\n\nDr. Kistler argued that it was still possible that Pacific Islanders voyaged to South America and returned with the sweet potato.\n\nA thousand years ago, they might have encountered many sweet potato varieties on the continent. When Europeans arrived in the 1500s, they likely wiped out much of the crop\u2019s genetic diversity.\n\nAs a result, Dr. Kistler said, the surviving sweet potatoes of the Pacific only seem distantly related to the ones in the Americas. If the scientists had done the same study in 1500, Pacific sweet potatoes would have fit right in with other South American varieties.\n\nDr. Kistler was optimistic that the sweet potato debate would someday be settled. The world\u2019s herbariums contain a vast number of varieties that have yet to be genetically tested.\n\n\u201cThere are more than we could look at in a lifetime,\u201d Dr. Kistler said.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Mu\u00f1oz-Rodr\u00edguez plans on searching for more wild sweet potato relatives in Central America, hoping to get more clues to how exactly a thin-rooted weed gave rise to an invaluable crop.\n\nWorking out the history of crops like this could do more than satisfy our curiosity about the past. Wild plants hold a lot of genetic variants lost when people domesticated crops.\n\nResearchers may find plants they can hybridize with domesticated sweet potatoes and other crops, endowing them with genes for resistance to diseases, or for withstanding climate change.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEssentially, it\u2019s preserving the gene pool that feeds the world,\u201d Dr. Kistler said.", "title": "All by Itself, the Humble Sweet Potato Colonized the World", "authors": ["Carl Zimmer"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Wellness isn\u2019t a concept that seems synonymous with the ever-growing hassles of flying, but that could finally be changing. Some airlines are embracing the idea of healthier flying, offering calorie-conscious menus and new exercise videos.\n\nAccording to Beth McGroarty, research director for The Global Wellness Institute, a nonprofit organization for the wellness industry, even as seats shrink and flights get more crowded, many carriers want air travel to be more bearable (and even enjoyable). They believe wellness is the way to do that. \u201cIt\u2019s part of the larger wellness movement happening in the travel industry,\u201d she said.\n\nAnd, unlike the usual trend of amping up onboard amenities for only their first and business class customers and stripping them away for passengers in economy, Ms. McGroarty said that no passengers are left out in this recent wellness push. \u201cWellness in the air, in many instances, is more democratic,\u201d she said.\n\nMeditation Apps, Stretching Exercises and Yoga Videos\n\nAll United Airlines and JetBlue customers have access to the popular digital meditation service Headspace as part of their in-flight entertainment. JetBlue\u2019s Headspace content includes videos that address travel topics, such as fear of flying and difficulty sleeping upright.", "title": "All the Amenities Airlines are Offering for Healthier Flights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "An actress from the television series \u201cSmallville\u201d was charged on Friday with sex trafficking for her involvement in an organization promoting itself as a self-help group for women that forced its members to have sex with its leader, federal prosecutors said.\n\nThe actress, Allison Mack, 35, helped gain recruits for what was purported to be a mentorship group but instead exploited its followers, who were branded with a symbol containing the initials of the organization\u2019s leader, said Richard P. Donoghue, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, in a statement.\n\nMs. Mack participated in a group known as Nxivm (pronounced Nex-e-um), the authorities said. The organization, near Albany, was led by Keith Raniere, 57, who was arrested in March by federal officials in Mexico on sex-trafficking charges. Its followers were forced to have sex with him because they feared that if they did not do so, compromising material that they had provided about themselves would be released publicly, according to a complaint.\n\n[Inside a secretive group where women are branded: Read our article on Nxivm.]\n\nThe group has denied it was a cult, but former members have said that Mr. Raniere demanded obedience from his followers, who referred to him as \u201cVanguard.\u201d", "title": "Allison Mack of \u2018Smallville\u2019 Is Charged With Sex Trafficking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Slow but solid growth in the United States since the Great Recession has finally altered the balance between borrowers and lenders. Higher rates mean those with cash to spare now have the upper hand and can demand a higher price to part with it.\n\nThat\u2019s how it\u2019s supposed to work. But as any saver can tell you, some short-term rates have barely budged. Those are the ones banks offer to savers on plain-vanilla accounts for checking, savings and CDs.\n\nBanks are almost always slow to lift deposit rates when interest rates start to rise. They make a lot of their money on the spread between the interest they pay to borrow \u2014 for banks, deposits are a form of borrowing \u2014 and the interest they charge to lend. So keeping those rates as far apart as possible, for as long as possible, helps their bottom line. But during this current rate-raising cycle, banks are being even slower than usual.", "title": "Almost Zero: Why You\u2019re Still Not Making Much on Your Bank Account", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAmanda Leigh Zeiger and Jesse Michael Reich were married April 21 at the Pierre hotel in New York. In June she is to begin a pediatric residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York.\n\nShe is the daughter of Helene I. Zeiger and Alan L. Zeiger of Villanova, Pa. He\u2019ll find another target.\u201d\n\nAssociates say the president is often riled up by Amazon\u2019s connection to The Washington Post, whose owner, Jeff Bezos, founded the retail giant. People close to the president have said his attacks on one of the country\u2019s largest businesses have usually been prompted by articles in The Post that Mr. Trump perceives as negative.\n\nLikewise, the president\u2019s interest in the AT&T merger with Time Warner largely stems from his repeated clashes with CNN, a subsidiary of Time Warner, which he regards as biased against him.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s lashing out at the N.F.L. \u2014 he has repeatedly criticized football players for kneeling at games and once said he hoped a player \u201csues the hell out of the @nfl for incompetence & defamation\u201d \u2014 comes in part from his decades-long legal fight with the N.F.L. after he bought a team in the competing United States Football League.\n\nAs a private citizen, Mr. Trump has attacked companies, including calling several times for boycotts. The remarks served to raise his profile and fed the image of a no-holds-barred businessman who was unafraid to rebuke his rivals or his critics. But in those days, such comments had little ability to move stock prices or affect sales.\n\nAs a candidate and as the president, Mr. Trump also uses his verbal assaults on companies to bolster his populist message that he is on the side of workers, not big business. (Still, Mr. Trump secured a large tax cut last year for corporate America.)\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s most ardent supporters say they appreciate his willingness to criticize the corporate establishment.\n\n\u201cHe continues to go directly after the companies and not care about political correctness,\u201d said Terry Bowman, a former Trump campaign organizer who works at a Ford Motor parts factory in Ypsilanti, Mich. \u201cHe says things that a polished politician would never say. He says things that come directly from the American worker.\u201d", "title": "Amazon Has Lots of Company as Trump Slams \u2018Stupid\u2019 Businesses", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The new in-car delivery service, which will be available in 37 cities and surrounding areas, is a variation of Amazon Key.\n\nFor in-car delivery to work, customers must have a 2015 or later Chevrolet, Buick, GMC or Cadillac vehicle with an active account with OnStar, the roadside assistance and navigation service from General Motors. Car owners with 2015 or newer Volvos with a similar service, On Call, can also receive in-car deliveries from Amazon.\n\nPhoto\n\nCouriers can use those assistance services to find the cars through satellite location-tracking and unlock the trunk.\n\nAmazon said the service will be expanded to other carmakers over time. The company conducted a small pilot test of in-car delivery in Germany in partnership with Audi and DHL several years ago.\n\nThe company says its systems will allow couriers to unlock vehicles only once for each scheduled delivery, to prevent unauthorized access. Still, the service will require a hefty amount of trust that a courier won\u2019t swipe any valuables. The in-car service requires fewer protections than Amazon\u2019s in-home delivery service, which requires customers to have an internet-connected front door lock and security camera to deter any shenanigans by couriers once they\u2019re inside.\n\n\u201cWe believe in offering customers choices,\u201d said Rohit Shrivastava, general manager of Amazon Key. \u201cThis product may not be for everyone.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech?
