View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough statistics on the prevalence of package theft are elusive, police departments across the country say it has become commonplace, especially as internet shopping has become mainstream behavior. Package thieves have even earned a snappy moniker, \u201cporch pirates.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJames McQuivey, an analyst at Forrester Research, said Amazon has for years been ferociously tackling every obstacle it can identify to customers buying more goods online. \u201cThis goes back to one-click ordering,\u201d he said. \u201cThe company knows that the less friction you have, the better.\u201d\n\nCustomers won\u2019t be able to get in-car deliveries if they park inside gated and underground parking garages where satellite signals often can\u2019t penetrate. The service seems aimed especially at people who leave their vehicles in the lots of large, easily accessible suburban office parks.\n\nCar owners, who are frequently discouraged from leaving valuables in their vehicles, may rightly be concerned receiving an Amazon package to their cars when they\u2019re not present could make them a target. Amazon said customers shouldn\u2019t worry \u2014 it will take care of a broken window or lock that happens as a result of a delivery to a car.\n\n\u201cIf the damage is caused by a delivery and a customer calls, we will make sure it\u2019s right,\u201d Mr. Shrivastava said.", "title": "Amazon Tries a New Delivery Spot: Your Car", "authors": ["Nick Wingfield"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Some are concerned about the president\u2019s motivations for his attacks, which people close to Mr. Trump have said are often triggered by negative coverage of his administration in The Washington Post, a newspaper owned personally by Mr. Bezos. Mr. Trump has mingled his attacks on Amazon and the newspaper in some tweets, including one in early April slamming \u201cthe Fake News Washington Post, Amazon\u2019s \u2018chief lobbyist.\u2019\u201d\n\nMatt Stoller, a fellow at the Open Markets Institute, a think tank that has become a vocal critic of the power of tech companies, said he believed Amazon was worthy of action by regulators in part because of its power in the book market. But he also said he found Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts to \u201cpersonalize law enforcement\u201d troubling.\n\n\u201cWhat he\u2019s doing is a threat to democracy, but so is Amazon,\u201d Mr. Stoller said. \u201cThat\u2019s the dilemma.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, early this month, after Mr. Trump launched another Twitter tirade against Amazon\u2019s deal with the Postal Service, Mr. Stoller jumped on board on Twitter.\n\n\u201cOn the post office shipping charges Trump is correct and oddly aligned with postal employees while Bezos isn\u2019t, so I\u2019m going to stick with the postal employees,\u201d he wrote.\n\nThe most direct effort to tap Mr. Trump\u2019s hostility toward Amazon was an advertisement last month about the contract to provide cloud computing services to the Defense Department \u2014 worth up to $10 billion, by some estimates. The ad, with a picture of Mr. Bezos looking chummy next to Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis, appeared in the president\u2019s favorite hometown tabloid.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump: Your Defense Department is set to award a no-bid, ten-year contract for all its IT infrastructure to Administration-enemy Jeff Bezos\u2019 Amazon,\u201d read the ad in The New York Post.\n\n\u201cI had never seen that before,\u201d Katell Thielemann, an analyst who follows the government technology contracting market for the research firm Gartner, said of the attack ad.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ad was placed by Less Government, which calls itself a nonprofit based in Washington, D.C. Seton Motley, who runs the group, did not respond to requests for comment. He has said in interviews that he funded the ad himself. It\u2019s unclear who backs the group, but there are large tech companies, some with connections to Mr. Trump, that have expressed their unhappiness with how the contract is structured.\n\nThe contract came up in a dinner this month with Mr. Trump and Safra Catz, co-chief executive of Oracle, according to a person briefed on the matter, who asked not to be identified because the details are confidential. Ms. Catz told the president that the way the Defense Department had written the contract, awarding it to just one vendor, was an advantage to Amazon, the person said.\n\nSo far, Mr. Trump hasn\u2019t publicly expressed concern about Amazon\u2019s bid for the contract. The White House didn\u2019t immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nMr. Trump recently escalated his attacks on Amazon with a presidential order to review the Postal Service\u2019s financial model, which he has denounced on Twitter as money-losing because of favorable deals worked out with Amazon. (The Postal Service denies that deals like its one with Amazon are unprofitable.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe playing field has to be leveled,\u201d he told reporters this month, promising to take a serious look at policies that might affect Amazon.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s Amazon attacks have amplified criticisms that have been building for years among research groups and trade organizations that represent Amazon\u2019s rivals.\n\nThey have produced studies that say Amazon\u2019s warehouses \u2014 which employ more than 125,000 full-time workers in the United States \u2014 don\u2019t increase total local employment because of losses in other sectors. They also question the wisdom of subsidies to attract them. The American Booksellers Association, which represents independent bookstores, recently published a similar report on Amazon\u2019s economic impact.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, one of the largest private-sector unions in the country, representing 1.3 million workers in grocery stores and related industries, said Amazon\u2019s investments in automation would hurt workers. Since it bought Whole Foods last year, Amazon has become one of the union\u2019s top concerns.\n\nAsked about Mr. Trump\u2019s attacks on Amazon, Marc Perrone, president of the union, said: \u201cAllowing Amazon\u2019s unchecked growth to continue will lead to the destruction of millions of American jobs. Which begs the question: Why aren\u2019t all Democrats and Republicans speaking out?\u201d\n\nA spokesman for Amazon declined to comment.\n\nWhen Mr. Trump bashes Amazon for not collecting taxes, he is echoing long-running criticism of the company by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, a nonpartisan research organization. Amazon collects sales tax in states that have one for items it sells directly to shoppers, but in most states it does not when shoppers buy merchandise from independent merchants on Amazon.\n\nOther critics \u2014 from technology pundits to a former chief executive of Walmart U.S. \u2014 have called for antitrust action against Amazon by the government, including a breakup of the company.\n\nAmazon\u2019s defense is that \u2014 even as it has swelled into a giant, with over $177 billion in revenue last year \u2014 its share of overall retail sales is still small, estimated to be in the mid-single digits in the United States. This, along with Amazon\u2019s emphasis on keeping prices low, has made it challenging for opponents to spark action under current antitrust law, which is primarily focused on consumer harm.\n\nIt\u2019s unclear if Mr. Trump can do much to get antitrust enforcers at the Federal Trade Commission or Justice Department, which are supposed to keep politics out of competition cases, to act against Amazon. But his executive order asking for a review of the Postal Service, including its relationship with customers like Amazon, could lead to changes unfavorable to the company.", "title": "Amazon\u2019s Critics Get New Life With Trump\u2019s Attacks on the Company", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang", "Nick Wingfield", "Danielle Ivory"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "SEATTLE \u2014 Jeff Bezos, Amazon\u2019s founder and chief executive, long ago figured out how to keep Amazon\u2019s sales figures shooting skyward. Now he is doing the same with profit.\n\nThe company, which once seemed to have only a passing interest in turning a profit, said its net income for the first quarter more than doubled. Although Amazon is best known as an internet shopping destination, its cloud computing and advertising businesses were big contributors to the jump in profit.\n\nMr. Bezos singled out the performance of the company\u2019s cloud computing business \u2014 known as Amazon Web Services, or A.W.S. \u2014 referring in a statement to a \u201cremarkable acceleration\u201d in growth in the segment for a second consecutive quarter.\n\nAmazon often boasts of its commitment to lowering prices \u2014 part of the reason its profits have been so limited until now \u2014 but on Thursday it announced a price hike for one of its most important offerings. The company said it was raising the price of its Prime membership service 20 percent, to $119 from $99. Prime memberships include two-day shipping at no extra cost, a video streaming service and other benefits.", "title": "Amazon\u2019s Profit Swells to $1.6 Billion, Lifted by Its Cloud Business", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "The Civil War had just concluded and Reconstruction had already begun.\n\nBut Johnson, the racist that he was, opposed many aspects of Reconstruction. As the Senate website points out: \u201cJohnson vetoed legislation that Congress passed to protect the rights of those who had been freed from slavery. This clash culminated in the House of Representatives voting, on Feb. 24, 1868, to impeach the president.\u201d Both the House and Senate were controlled by Republicans.\n\nBut here is the hurdle that the founders built into the process to make it nearly impossible to remove a president: While it only takes a majority of the House to impeach a president, two-thirds of the Senate must vote to convict in order to remove the president.\n\nIn the Senate, the three articles of impeachment that were voted on all fell short by one vote, and that is because seven Republicans switched sides and voted with the Democrats for acquittal.\n\nOne of those Republicans, Senator James Grimes of Iowa, explained his actions this way: \u201cI cannot agree to destroy the harmonious working of the Constitution for the sake of getting rid of an Unacceptable President.\u201d\n\nEven a Supreme Court associate justice, David Davis, a Republican who had served as Lincoln\u2019s campaign manager, reportedly opposed Johnson\u2019s impeachment, even though he believed him to have \u201cqualities totally unfitting him to be the ruler of a people in the fix we are in\u201d and calling him \u201cobstinate, self-willed, combative, slow to act\u201d and in possession of \u201cno executive ability.\u201d\n\nJohnson was impeached before the advent of modern polling, but that polling did exist when Nixon resigned and Clinton was impeached.\n\nIt is important to note in Nixon\u2019s case that the televised Senate Watergate hearings had started and the Saturday Night Massacre occurred in 1973 and yet the percentage of people saying he should be removed from office never rose above the 30s that year, according to Gallup. It wasn\u2019t until after the House Judiciary Committee recommended impeachment that a majority of Americans thought he should be removed.\n\nIn the case of Clinton, who was also acquitted, Gallup reported:\n\n\u201cBill Clinton received the highest job approval ratings of his administration during the Lewinsky/impeachment controversy. As the Lewinsky situation unfolded, Clinton\u2019s job approval went up, not down, and his ratings remained high for the duration of the impeachment proceedings.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | America Abhors Impeachment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "A huge oil spill. A river catching fire. Lakes so polluted they were too dangerous for fishing or swimming. Air so thick with smog it was impossible to see the horizon.\n\nThat was the environmental state of the nation 50 years ago. But pollution and disasters prompted action. On April 22, 1970, millions of people throughout the country demonstrated on the inaugural Earth Day, calling for air, water and land in the country to be cleaned up and protected. And that year, in a bipartisan effort, the Environmental Protection Agency was created and key legislation \u2014 the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act and the Endangered Species Act \u2014 came into force.\n\nNow, the Trump administration has made eliminating federal regulations a priority, and an increasing number of environmental rules are under threat.\n\nHere\u2019s a look at five environmental disasters that shifted the public conversation and prompted, directly or indirectly, lawmakers to act.", "title": "America Before Earth Day: Smog and Disasters Spurred the Laws Trump Wants to Undo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The United States-led air campaign to hunt down the last pockets of Islamic State militants in eastern Syria effectively ground to a halt in the past two months after the allies lost their most effective battleground partner, stalling a critical phase of the offensive.\n\nWith Islamic State fighters now starting to claw back some of their lost territory in Syria, and with President Trump previously threatening to withdraw American troops there before finishing off the last militants holding ground, commanders have rushed to adopt new tactics to regain some momentum. (The president subsequently dropped his demand for an immediate withdrawal when commanders told him they needed time to successfully finish the mission.)\n\nThe new approach includes stacking several surveillance planes over two big remaining pockets of fighters, patiently watching the suspected enemy\u2019s every move for days \u2014 and then striking only when sure the foes are really foes, and the risk to civilians is low. The new tactics have helped increase strikes in eastern Syria to 23 last week compared with only three in the week ending April 5, military officials said.", "title": "American Warplanes Shift Tactics to Target Last ISIS Pockets in Eastern Syria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nThere\u2019s a roiling debate about whether Democrats should move to the political center to win back Trump voters or focus on energizing the party\u2019s progressive base. On some issues \u2014 like abortion, guns and immigration \u2014 Democrats really do face this difficult choice. The policies that excite progressives alienate many of the white working-class voters who swung the 2016 election to Donald Trump, and vice versa.\n\nBut there is also one huge area where no such tradeoff exists: economic policy.\n\nOn economic issues, the politics are really quite simple. The Democratic base and swing voters have remarkably similar preferences. And those preferences are quite progressive.\n\nOn one issue after another, a majority of Americans want aggressive action to respond to the problems facing the middle class and poor: generous Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security; a higher minimum wage; more financial aid for college; and more federal action to create good-paying jobs.", "title": "Opinion | Americans Aren\u2019t Centrist on Economics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Heat waves claim more lives than any other natural hazard, and in 11 of the country\u2019s largest school districts, in addition to countless smaller ones, many schools do not have air-conditioning.\n\nIn the Santa Maria-Bonita School District in California, teachers report that classroom temperatures sometimes reach 90 degrees. Thirty percent of the classrooms in the district lack air-conditioning, primarily because they are in old buildings that do not have the electrical capacity to support portable units. It would cost upward of $45 million to install central air in all classrooms. In 2015 the teachers\u2019 union asked the school board for that funding, but the request was denied. Some teachers have resorted to offering sweaty and distracted students small cooling towels purchased with donated funds.\n\nAt the other end of the temperature spectrum, cold snaps have left children shivering in schools with malfunctioning boilers and drafty windows that do little to protect them when temperatures dip below zero. Low-income and black and Hispanic students are more likely to attend such poorly maintained schools.\n\nThis winter, Marietta English, president of the Baltimore Teachers Union, wrote in a letter to the school system\u2019s chief executive, Sonja Santelises, that \u201ctrying to provide a stable learning environment in these extreme conditions is unfair and inhumane.\u201d Dr. Santelises acknowledged that \u201ctoo many of our buildings have outdated heating systems, poor insulation and aging pipes as a result of years of inadequate funding for maintenance and facilities improvements.\u201d\n\nWhen it comes to earthquakes, we have seen some progress in terms of seismic upgrades for schools in states such as California and Oregon. But many other places lag woefully behind.\n\nIn Utah, hundreds of old school buildings with unreinforced masonry lie along or near the Wasatch Fault and could suffer serious damage, including complete collapse, in an earthquake. And in Washington, one in three children attend schools built before seismic construction standards were adopted statewide. The most unsafe schools are largely in poorer districts.\n\nThis is another reminder that these issues are not just environmental. They are social justice issues, too.\n\nIf we legally require children to attend school, then we should be held accountable for keeping them safe there. We need to see a real investment in our nation\u2019s school infrastructure and emergency planning efforts.", "title": "Opinion | America\u2019s Deathtrap Schools", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Government at all levels embraced racial covenants that forbade even well-to-do African-Americans from purchasing homes outside of black communities. Cut off from homeownership \u2014 the principal avenue of wealth creation \u2014 African-Americans lost the opportunity to build the intergenerational wealth that white suburban families took for granted. The vast wealth gap that exists today between whites and African-Americans has its roots in this era.\n\nThe argument for what became the Fair Housing Act emerged forcefully in the 1968 Kerner Commission report, which blamed segregation in large measure for the riots that ravaged the country in the 60s and called for national fair housing legislation. The housing law might well have died in committee had the country not erupted in fresh violence after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April 4, 1968. It was signed into law a week later.\n\nThe housing act put the federal government on record as supporting open housing and prohibiting the pervasive discrimination that had locked most African-Americans out of decent accommodations and homeownership. But the version that passed in 1968 had been declawed \u2014 stripped of enforcement provisions that would have given HUD strong authority to root out discrimination. Nearly a quarter-century would pass before Congress strengthened the law. So during that time, African-Americans were left subject to the harsh discrimination the original act was supposed to preclude.\n\nThis progressive sounding law \u2014 which requires entities that receive federal money to \u201caffirmatively further\u201d fair housing goals \u2014 was consistently undermined by officials of both parties who had little appetite for confronting entrenched segregation.\n\nThat realization came home with particular force to George Romney, Richard Nixon\u2019s HUD secretary, who initially took the law at its word and tried to enforce it by turning down grant applications from communities that continued to segregate themselves racially.\n\nWhen white communities complained directly to the Oval Office, Nixon shut down Romney\u2019s effort and eventually forced him out of government. Subsequent administrations shied away from enforcing the law in ways great and small \u2014 but the Reagan administration sold it out in an egregious fashion that angered even Republicans in Congress. The administration conspired with the real estate industry to undermine HUD\u2019s already limited powers, brought cases that attacked integration programs and showed scant vigor in enforcing civil rights laws.\n\nTHE NEXT FAIR HOUSING FIGHT\n\nThe Fair Housing Act received new life three years ago when the Supreme Court endorsed the doctrine known as disparate impact, ruling that housing discrimination did not have to be intentional to be illegal. The court reminded the country that the statute does indeed bar governments from spending federal money in a way that perpetuates segregation.\n\nSoon after, the Obama administration issued a long-awaited rule that required state and local governments to affirmatively further fair housing goals by making efforts to address the cumulative results of the discrimination that historically shut African-Americans out of many communities.", "title": "Opinion | America\u2019s Federally Financed Ghettos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Leadon\u2019s tale is a whirl of characters: architects and landlords, capitalists and unionists, reformers and traditionalists, visionaries and charlatans. It is a whirl, too, of events like ticker-tape parades, civic battles, financial booms and inevitable busts. Enlivening the stories are cameo appearances by the rich and famous, like the showmen David Belasco and George M. Cohan, the ever-burdened Edgar Allan Poe, the radical Emma Goldman and the rivalrous cousins of enormous wealth William Waldorf Astor and John Jacob Astor 4th. And in this age when we\u2019ve all been (Lin Manuel) Mirandized, how can one leave out Alexander Hamilton? Leadon makes sure to include him. Hamilton\u2019s farmhouse, the Grange, figures prominently in the Mile 10 section, exploring a part of town that modern real-estate developers have christened Hamilton Heights.\n\nThere is plenty here that rings familiar to 21st-century ears. \u201cAs the city expanded, and as the divide between rich and poor grew ever wider, alarming numbers of indigent men and women gathered each day on Broadway,\u201d Leadon writes. He\u2019s talking about the 1840s. Ten years later, New York had become \u201ca city of strangers.\u201d By the 1890s, \u201cit was noisy.\u201d The homeless, referred to as \u201cthe tramp class\u201d in a blunter era, vexed the middle class just as they do now. After economic collapse in the Panic of 1893, The New York Tribune \u201ccomplained that it had become impossible to relax on a park bench without a \u2018greasy, rum soaked tramp leaning against your shoulder.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA robust act of civil disobedience in 1901 was the sort that easily could take place today. Chairs had been placed in Madison Square Park, ruled by a concessionaire who charged 5 cents to sit, equivalent to about $1.30 now. Attendants overturned the chair of anyone who dared take a seat without forking over a nickel. Many New Yorkers deemed the fee unfair, and in the collar-wilting summer of 1901, they had had enough. They ignited the \u201cMerry Chair War,\u201d refusing to pay and tossing chairs into the street. Soon enough, the concessionaire caved, and the nickel chair became history. Thousands flocked to the park in celebration. Today, they might well go by #OccupyMadisonSquare.\n\nThis is a book best read in several sittings; there is a lot of detail to absorb. At times, it can be nearly numbing. Is it really necessary to recite practically the entire inventory of the vast Arnold Constable department store, located in 1869 at Broadway and 19th Street? But Leadon is graced with a wry wit. Flashes of it are sprinkled throughout, as when he describes Union Square\u2019s ascendance as a gathering spot for all manner of causes. At the onset of the Civil War, an immense crowd formed there. New York Sun journalists reported not seeing a single drunk or hearing a profane word. \u201cNo doubt,\u201d Leadon says dryly, \u201cthey weren\u2019t looking very hard.\u201d\n\nFor all the diversity of its 13 miles, from financial citadels far downtown to bodegas way uptown, Broadway will always mean the theater to many people \u2014 the Great White Way. By the dawn of the 20th century \u201cBroadway had become New York\u2019s chief cultural export,\u201d Leadon writes. To an extent, it still is. Nothing, though, can compare with the creative flow in the years before the Great Depression. In 1927 alone, 264 new Broadway shows opened.\n\nSustaining that kind of energy would have been nigh impossible. As Leadon says, \u201cIt is the nature of things in New York that very little lasts.\u201d True enough, and \u201cBroadway\u201d the book shows that Broadway the street is no exception.", "title": "America\u2019s Most Famous Street", "authors": ["Clyde Haberman", "Fran Leadon"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe utter irrelevance of Trump\u2019s one-off bombing of a Syrian airfield hasn\u2019t made the slightest dent in the myth that Obama bombing Syria in 2013 would have changed everything, has it,\u201d Marc Lynch, a George Washington University professor of Middle East studies, wrote on Twitter.\n\nIndeed, pressure is mounting for another set of such strikes, and it looks as if Mr. Trump may again carry them out.\n\nWhat Americans may be confronting \u2014 whether they want to or not \u2014 is the reality that some problems can\u2019t be fixed by the sort of low-cost, low-risk solutions to which they grew accustomed in the brief moment of American global hegemony after the Cold War. It feels impossible that something could be beyond easy American resolution, so the problem must be that the president lacks proper will or resolve to see that resolution through.\n\n\u201cFor those who want a military response, the question is simple: can you tell me any practical response short of full-fledged invasion that could prevent this?\u201d Emma Ashford, a Cato Institute analyst, asked on Twitter, referring to further chemical attacks.\n\nTo understand this, it helps to divide possible American responses into three categories, each of which comes up against hard problems that are structural to the Syrian war.\n\nPhoto\n\nOption category #1 could be termed the sort of limited, punitive strikes that Mr. Obama was pressured to execute and that Mr. Trump saw through last year.\n\nSuch action is meant to impose a modest cost on Mr. Assad or to send a message that future chemical weapons use will not be tolerated. At the same time, it is meant to avoid any risk of changing the course of the war, which could lead in unanticipated directions \u2014 like embroiling the United States in a larger conflict, or collapsing the Syrian government, which could, in turn, spread chaos that would risk millions of lives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut past efforts at these kind of strikes have failed for two reasons. First, they do not change Mr. Assad\u2019s calculus because, to Mr. Assad, this war is a matter of personal and national survival. If he believes chemical weapons are necessary to his survival, he will abandon them only in the face of some threat to his survival greater than the benefit he thinks they offer him. That requires an existential threat, which the United States is unwilling to impose because of the risks.\n\nSecond, Mr. Assad\u2019s Russian and Iranian allies can easily help him absorb the costs imposed by such strikes. If the United States bombs another Syrian runway, Russian contractors can simply pave Mr. Assad a new one. It\u2019s not exactly a game-changer for him.\n\nFuzzier arguments for limited strikes \u2014 that they will communicate American resolve and toughness \u2014 play well in domestic politics, but there is little concrete evidence that such messages make much difference to adversaries.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOption category #2 might describe the policies that Mr. Obama favored: actions that make the war costlier for Mr. Assad \u2014 arming anti-government rebels, for instance \u2014 so as to pressure the Syrian leader into complying with American demands.\n\nMr. Obama supplied rebels with anti-tank TOW missiles, which they used to great effect, pushing back government forces with the weapons they called \u201cAssad tamers.\u201d\n\nThe problem with this strategy is that Mr. Assad\u2019s Russian and Iranian allies are able to escalate in turn, matching and exceeding any American bid. The Americans send guns; the Iranians send a combat brigade. The Americans send missiles; the Russians install an artillery unit. Russia and Iran can simply do more, giving them control over what military planners call \u201cthe escalation ladder.\u201d\n\nSome analysts argue that the \u201cAssad tamers\u201d were so successful that they prompted Russia\u2019s 2015 intervention in Syria. In that sense, Mr. Obama\u2019s approach not only failed, it backfired terribly. The result was a bloodier war with more Syrian suffering but little change in Mr. Assad\u2019s calculus. Further such escalations would risk the same.\n\nOption category #3 would be attacks that go beyond what the Russians and Iranians can match, which is likely to mean either a full intervention or strikes that existentially threaten the Syrian government.\n\nThese strikes would only be enough to work if they deliberately create one of two risks that the United States has strained to avoid. The first risk is that of collapsing the Syrian government, which would exacerbate Syrian suffering by throwing millions more lives into chaos and most likely prolong the war. The second risk is of a direct military confrontation with Russia, a nuclear-armed power with the ability to escalate hostilities rapidly in the Middle East and Eastern Europe, putting millions of non-Syrians at risk.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBottom line: Assad\u2019s actions are abhorrent, but there is no practical military option here unless you are willing to effectively collapse the Syrian state and re-escalate the civil war,\u201d Ms. Ashford wrote.\n\nMr. Trump, she predicted, would launch another set of punitive strikes that would \u201cchange nothing\u201d but win domestic approval.\n\nBut why does such support still exist for a policy that has already demonstrably failed?\n\nResearch by Sarah Kreps and Sarah Maxey, political scientists at Cornell University and the University of Pennsylvania, found that Americans feel a moral obligation to help humanitarian victims \u2014 and to provide that help in the form of military action. This can lead Americans to support seemingly incongruous policies like saving war refugees by dropping bombs.\n\nBut it\u2019s not just voters. Within Washington, an odd revisionism has arisen around Mr. Trump\u2019s previous set of strikes, meant to explain why they produced little tangible benefit. They only appeared to fail because the United States, it is said, did not properly capitalize on the \u201cleverage\u201d the strikes had provided.\n\nThere is an alternate hypothesis: The reason that limited strikes rarely seem to translate into \u201cleverage\u201d is because they do not produce \u201cleverage,\u201d a fuzzy term with no fixed meaning.\n\nThis is where this debate arguably starts to reveal more about the United States, and particularly Washington\u2019s foreign policy community, than about the Syrian war.\n\nThe cult of \u201climited strikes\u201d is so powerful in Washington that, even when they do occur, it\u2019s said they were never properly capitalized on. There is always the shimmering hope, just over the next hill, that bombing a runway will make all of Washington\u2019s dreams come true.\n\nIt sometimes seems as if the United States will be bombing empty runways until the end of time, dead certain that it\u2019s a way to get everything Americans want at no real cost or risk, and that all the past failures only prove that the next time it\u2019ll work for sure.", "title": "America\u2019s Three Bad Options in Syria", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Amid fears of an escalating trade war between the United States and China, President Trump tweeted Sunday morning that he and President Xi Jinping of China will \u201calways be friends, no matter what happens with our dispute on trade.\u201d\n\n\u201cChina will take down its Trade Barriers because it is the right thing to do,\u201d he added. \u201cTaxes will become Reciprocal & a deal will be made on Intellectual Property. Great future for both countries!\u201d\n\nA White House spokeswoman on Sunday said the reciprocal \u201ctaxes\u201d mentioned in the tweet referred to \u201ctariff levels and also to reciprocal trade more generally.\u201d\n\nIt was unclear whether the president was suggesting that progress had been made in solving the trade dispute between the world\u2019s two biggest economies.
