But Bradley Jr. slid early and directly into the bag, and though Gregorius managed to get off a throw to first from the seat of his pants, it was late.\n\n\u201cA lot of people get caught up in their emotions, whether it\u2019s the fans, the media, the players and I think they lose a sense of the game itself,\u201d Bradley Jr. said Thursday after batting practice.\n\nHe continued: \u201cEverybody is out here trying to play the game and make a living for themselves and their families. There\u2019s no need for the extra stuff. At the end of the day you don\u2019t want anybody hurt. I was just trying to play the game the right way and that was that.\u201d\n\nWhether that is indeed that is not certain.\n\nOn Thursday night, Hanley Ramirez of the Red Sox was hit on the wrist by a pitch from Sonny Gray, and Giancarlo Stanton of the Yankees was nicked on the arm by Rick Porcello. Though both benches were warned after Ramirez was hit in the first inning \u2014 he left the game \u2014 neither incident caused a renewal of tensions, and the Red Sox went on to a 6-3 victory.\n\nJust before the game, Major League Baseball suspended Kelly for six games and Austin for five on Thursday, but both players were in uniform after filing appeals. Undisclosed fines were handed down to Red Sox Manager Alex Cora, Yankees third-base coach Phil Nevin and a handful of players on the disabled list who entered the field: C.C. Sabathia of the Yankees, and Dustin Pedroia, Marco Hernandez and Xander Bogaerts of the Red Sox.", "title": "Amid Yankees-Red Sox Chaos, a Moment of Base-Running Chivalry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "From my own anti-abortion perspective, this opinion makes Williamson an extremist as well. When American laws restricted abortion they generally did not impose such penalties, and today\u2019s pro-life movement likewise generally rejects the idea of prosecuting women. This position often gets cast as inconsistent by pro-choicers, but I think it represents the incorporation by pro-lifers of the points that my pro-choice friends actually get right \u2014 that pregnancy is unique in ways that mitigate culpability and make it unwise to treat abortion like a normal homicide, that the government can only go so far in restriction without becoming a reproductive police state \u2014 without making the literally fatal mistake of believing these things also require a civil right to kill your unborn child.\n\nNow: The fact that Williamson is an extremist doesn\u2019t change the fact that to hire him for his pen and then fire him for having expressed an extreme opinion was stupid and gutless \u2014 akin to hiring Christopher Hitchens and then firing him for antireligious bigotry (and yes, Hitch was a bigot, but worth publishing anyway), or adding Hunter S. Thompson to your masthead and then dropping him because it\u2019s pointed out that he writes under the influence of drugs. But still there is a part of me, as someone whose goal is to persuade liberal readers to reconsider their pro-abortion views, that\u2019s glad Williamson won\u2019t be carrying the pro-life flag at The Atlantic, out of fear that his extremities could make the work of persuasion harder.\n\nAnother part of me, though \u2014 the more important one \u2014 thinks that this is a case study in exactly the problem establishment editors are trying to address by widening their pool of writers: the inability of contemporary liberalism to see itself from the outside, as it looks to the many people who for some reason, class or religion or historical experience, are not fully indoctrinated into its increasingly incoherent mix of orthodoxies.\n\nBy this I mean that my pro-choice friends endorsing Williamson\u2019s sacking can\u2019t see that his extremism is mirrored in their own, in a system of supposedly \u201cmoderate\u201d thought that is often blind to the public\u2019s actual opinions on these issues, that lionizes advocates for abortion at any stage of pregnancy, that hands philosophers who favor forms of euthanasia and infanticide prestigious chairs at major universities, that is at best mildly troubled by the quietus of the depressed and disabled in Belgium or the near-eradication of Down syndrome in Iceland or the gendercide that abortion brought to Asia, that increasingly accepts unblinking a world where human beings can be commodified and vivisected so long as they\u2019re in embryonic form.\n\nAll this extremism has its reasons, as those tenured philosophers will be happy to explain. But everyday liberalism is sufficiently muddled between semi-Christian ideas and a utilitarian materialism that mostly the system is defended by euphemism and evasion, and by a failure to imagine oneself as all of us once were: tiny and dependent and hidden, and yet still essentially ourselves.", "title": "Opinion | Among the Abortion Extremists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Starting out in her Manhattan garment district loft, Ms. Aberra went on to create a thriving business under the company name Amsale, opening her first store on Madison Avenue and acquiring and expanding into new lines.\n\nShe dressed celebrities like Halle Berry, Julia Roberts, Katy Perry and Ariana Grande, and her dresses appeared in the television series \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d and the films \u201cRunaway Bride,\u201d \u201c27 Dresses\u201d and \u201cThe Hangover.\u201d\n\nThe bridal gown retailer Mark Ingram, who worked with Ms. Aberra, was quoted in Women\u2019s Wear Daily as calling her \u201cthe inventor of the modern wedding dress.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHer fashion enterprise began with one wedding gown: her own.\n\nAfter arriving in the United States to attend college in Vermont, she had moved to New York and was attending the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan in 1985 and planning her wedding when she found she could not find a dress she liked among the confectionary-like options available.\n\nShe realized, she said, that she must not be the only woman in New York who wanted something simple to wear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEverything was overdone!\u201d Ms. Aberra said in a 2004 interview for the website Ladies Who Launch. \u201cYou really have to look back at magazines from the \u201880s to understand.\u201d\n\nSo she made her own dress \u2014 just as she had done as a child in Ethiopia.\n\nThe following year, she and her husband maxed out their credit cards, bought a sewing machine and turned their loft apartment into a design studio. Then they put an ad in Modern Bride magazine announcing their made-to-order business and waited for the calls to come in.\n\nThey did, many from professional women, and Ms. Aberra began fitting and making each dress at her home.\n\nMs. Aberra introduced her first wholesale collection in the early 1990s and showed it to the owners of Kleinfeld Bridal, an emporium then located in Brooklyn that drew customers from around the world. Hedda Kleinfeld Schachter purchased it on the spot.\n\nDuring Fashion Week in New York, Ms. Aberra would turn her apartment into a runway, laying down a long carpet and inviting fashion buyers from around the country. Models changed in her bedroom.\n\nShe opened her Madison Avenue store in 1997 and expanded it to include more dramatic and glamorous designs under the Kenneth Pool label in 2003.\n\nIn 2005, she acquired the ethereal Christos collection, and in 2015 she started a lower-priced line, Nouvelle Amsale. Amsale dresses typically range between $4,000 and $12,000. One dress she made for a head of state cost $45,000.\n\n\u201cThe most important thing to focus on in the beginning is the silhouette,\u201d Ms. Aberra wrote in 2012 on \u201cAsk Amsale,\u201d her advice column for brides on what is now the HuffPost website. \u201cIf you tackle the shape first and detail later, you\u2019ll find it easier to focus, and you won\u2019t waste time getting hung up on a bow or a brooch.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Aberra was born on March 1, 1954, in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to Aberra Moltot, a government minister, and Tsadale Assamnew, a homemaker. As a child, she made her own clothes and would get in trouble for cutting them up to make dresses for her dolls, too.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe was 19 when she traveled to Poultney, Vt., to attend Green Mountain College, where she studied commercial art.\n\n\u201cShe shows up to a college on the side of a mountain in Vermont that\u2019s covered in snow, and she didn\u2019t even bring a coat,\u201d Mr. Brown said.\n\nIn 1974, after she had moved to the United States, her father was imprisoned amid political turmoil in Ethiopia, and her parents could no longer pay Ms. Aberra\u2019s tuition. Soon she dropped out of college and moved to Boston, where there was a large Ethiopian community and where her half sister lived. She found a series of service jobs, including taking orders at a fast-food restaurant.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThroughout, she made clothing for herself and her friends.\n\n\u201cWhether it was a jumpsuit, whether it was a skirt, it had a level of drama and level of coolness without anything garish,\u201d said Mr. Brown, who became Amsale\u2019s chief executive.\n\nMs. Aberra eventually paid her way through Boston State College, graduating with a degree in political science. She was working in a campus coffee shop at Harvard University when she met Mr. Brown, who was a law student there at the time.\n\nMoving with him to New York, she enrolled at the Fashion Institute of Technology and majored in sportswear.\n\nAfter founding her business Ms. Aberra became a leader in New York\u2019s black business community. She was twice included on Ebony Magazine\u2019s \u201cPower 150\u201d list of influential African-Americans and received a legacy award at the 2012 Black Enterprise Women of Power Summit.\n\n\u201cShe always felt that the African-American community had adopted her and supported her,\u201d Mr. Brown said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Aberra served on the board of the Ethiopian Children\u2019s Fund and was a member of the Council of Fashion Designers of America and a trustee of the Fashion Institute of Technology.\n\n\u201cAmsale was a designer whose work exuded an elegance that emanated from her deep reservoir of grace and humility,\u201d Dr. Joyce F. Brown, the institute\u2019s president, said in a statement.\n\nIn addition to her husband, Ms. Aberra is survived by her father; her daughter, Rachel Amsale Brown; and a half sister, Aster Yilma.\n\nThe company\u2019s launch of its spring 2019 bridal collection is scheduled for April 13 and will go on as planned, Mr. Brown said. Ms. Aberra had requested that.", "title": "Amsale Aberra, Trendsetting Bridal Gown Designer, Is Dead at 64", "authors": ["Nellie Bowles"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "The disruptions to train service in New York City that Amtrak has planned for this summer will not be hellish, but they will be historic, railroad officials said Tuesday.\n\nAmtrak announced that it plans to take a track at Pennsylvania Station out of use for an overhaul similar to the work last year that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo predicted would cause a \u201csummer of hell\u201d for commuters. Amtrak also plans to reroute its trains that run along the Hudson River to Grand Central Terminal from Penn Station, from late May until early September.\n\nDuring that diversion, there will be no direct service between New York City and Chicago for the first time since Amtrak was created in 1971 \u2014 with the exception of unplanned disruptions, said Gary Williams, Amtrak\u2019s chief engineer.\n\nTo get to Chicago from Grand Central, Amtrak passengers would have to catch a train to Albany and transfer there to the Lake Shore Limited, which usually runs between Union Station in Chicago and Penn Station.", "title": "Amtrak Plans More Track Work (and Less Pain) at Penn Station", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "It seemed another isolated, horrific episode of sexual violence in India, perpetrated against a powerless girl by brutal men. But in the months since Asifa\u2019s murder, the case has become another battleground in India\u2019s religious wars.\n\nHindu nationalists have turned it into a rallying cry \u2014 not calling for justice for Asifa, but rushing to the defense of the accused. All of the men arrested are Hindu, and Asifa\u2019s nomadic people, the Bakarwals, are Muslim.\n\nSome of the police officers who investigated the case are also Muslim, and for that reason, the Hindu activists say, they cannot be trusted.\n\nThis week, a mob of Hindu lawyers physically blocked police officers from entering a courthouse to file charges against the men. The officers retreated to a judge\u2019s house later in the evening to complete the paperwork.\n\nPhoto\n\nProtests and counterprotests are now spreading. On Wednesday, much of Kathua, a small town in northern India near where Asifa was killed, was shut down by demonstrators, including dozens of Hindu women who helped block a highway and organize a hunger strike.\n\n\u201cThey are against our religion,\u2019\u2019 said Bimla Devi, one of the protesters. If the accused men aren\u2019t released, she said, \u201cwe will burn ourselves.\u2019\u2019\n\nPolice officials say they have physical evidence and DNA tests linking the defendants to Asifa\u2019s death. They also say they have interviewed more than 130 witnesses, who \u201cunequivocally corroborated the facts that emerged.\u2019\u2019\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeveral prominent members of India\u2019s dominant political force, the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, are pushing to have the case taken out of the hands of the state police, arguing that the Central Bureau of Investigation would be a better, more neutral agency to handle it. Many suspect this is an attempt to win leniency for the accused, noting that the bureau is an arm of the central government, which the Bharatiya Janata Party controls.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat a Hindu temple is at the center of the crime makes this case even more combustible. The police say that Sanji Ram, the temple\u2019s custodian, devised the plan as a way to terrorize the Bakarwals, and that he enlisted a nephew and some friends to kidnap and kill Asifa. The police say the culprits selected Asifa simply because she was by herself and \u201ca soft target.\u201d\n\nFor generations, Bakarwal nomads, who drift with their herds across the plains and hills of northern India, have leased pastures from Hindu farmers for their animals to graze in winter. But in recent years, some Hindus in the Kathua area have begun a campaign of abuse against the nomads. Villagers said Mr. Ram was their ringleader.\n\n\n\n\u201cHis poison has been spreading,\u2019\u2019 said Talib Hussain, a Bakarwal leader. \u201cWhen I was young, I remember the fear Sanji Ram\u2019s name invoked in Muslim women. If they wanted to scare each other, they would take Sanji Ram\u2019s name, since he was known to misbehave with Bakarwal women.\u2019\u2019\n\nFeelings between the two communities are so bitter that when Asifa didn\u2019t return from the meadow, her parents immediately suspected that something terrible had been done to her.\n\n\n\nThey enlisted the police and went to the small temple run by Mr. Ram. He insisted that he had not seen the girl. The temple was locked. According to the police, at that moment Asifa was being starved inside, hidden under a table and some plastic mats.\n\nMohammad Yusuf Pujwala, Asifa\u2019s father, said his daughter was killed for one reason: to drive the Bakarwals away.\n\n\u201cBut we have land here and life here,\u2019\u2019 he said. \u201cThis is home for us.\u2019\u2019 He sounded almost too tired to grieve.\n\nHe said Asifa had never been to school, even though her brothers had. Her favorite thing to do was play in the meadow.", "title": "An 8-Year-Old\u2019s Rape and Killing Fuels Religious Tensions in India", "authors": ["Jeffrey Gettleman"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "I had hoped that by now most adults in this country would have completed an advance directive for medical care and assigned someone they trusted to represent their wishes if and when they are unable to speak for themselves. Alas, at last count, barely more than one-third have done so, with the rest of Americans leaving it up to the medical profession and ill-prepared family members to decide when and how to provide life-prolonging treatments.\n\nBut even the many who, like me, have done due diligence \u2014 completed the appropriate forms, selected a health care agent and expressed their wishes to whoever may have to make medical decisions for them \u2014 may not realize that the documents typically do not cover a likely scenario for one of the leading causes of death in this country: dementia. Missing in standard documents, for example, are specific instructions about providing food and drink by hand as opposed to through a tube.\n\nAdvanced dementia, including Alzheimer\u2019s disease, is the sixth leading cause of death overall in the United States. It is the fifth leading cause for people over 65, and the third for those over 85. Yet once the disease approaches its terminal stages, patients are unable to communicate their desires for or against life-prolonging therapies, some of which can actually make their last days more painful and hasten their demise.\n\nEnd of Life Choices New York is trying to change that and has created an advance directive that it hopes will become a prototype for the rest of the country. (Washington State has already developed its own, though somewhat different, document.)", "title": "Alzheimer\u2019s? Your Paperwork May Not Be in Order", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "NASHVILLE \u2014 There is something fundamentally democratic about a Waffle House restaurant in the wee hours of the morning. It\u2019s a place where people working the late shift can stop for a hot meal on the way home, where high school kids can extend prom night just an hour longer, where 20-somethings jazzed on live music can wind down after a night on the town. The coffee is always fresh, and the counter staff has heard it all before but will usually listen again if you need an ear. It\u2019s a uniquely American place.\n\nThere\u2019s something tragically, fundamentally American, too, about an angry young white man with a firearm killing a bunch of strangers who have done him no harm. That\u2019s what happened early Sunday morning, when a man who was naked except for a green jacket loaded with ammunition opened fire with an AR-15 rifle at a Waffle House in the Antioch section of Nashville. Four people were fatally shot and four others were wounded before James Shaw Jr., an unarmed customer, wrestled the gun from him, saving untold lives.\n\nThe attacker ran away, shedding the jacket as he fled. Also left in his wake: Akilah Dasilva, DeEbony Groves, Joe Perez, and Taurean C. Sanderlin, all dead. All were in their 20s. All were people of color.\n\nA search of the truck the gunman left behind led investigators to Travis Reinking, an Illinois man who had moved to Nashville only last fall. Considered armed and dangerous, Mr. Reinking immediately went to the top of the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation\u2019s most-wanted list. After some 34 hours at large in a cold rain, he was apprehended Monday afternoon clothed and wearing a backpack containing a loaded semiautomatic handgun.", "title": "Opinion | An American Tragedy in Nashville", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Smiling may be a universal sign of positivity, but there are cultural differences. American smiles are more assertive, reflecting Americans\u2019 rating of themselves as more dominant. A University of California at Berkeley professor of psychology claims that American smiles emphasize the upper teeth while British smiles also show the lower teeth, which Americans often mistake as \u201cdeferential\u201d or a \u201csuppressed grimace.\u201d\n\nA German friend told me she felt sorry for the actors on American television because they had to smile so much. It seemed exhausting to her, and a strain. (When Walmart opened stores in Germany, it had to scrap its requirement that employees smile because some customers had misread it as flirting.)\n\nDoes America\u2019s emphasis on smiling say something about a desire for happy endings, for appeasement and artifice? Or do we smile more as a way to cope with our troubles, as a source of comfort? A 2015 study concluded that people in Canada and the United States, countries with a long history of immigration, do smile more than those in other countries, as smiling is a form of nonverbal communication between those who don\u2019t share a language. In The Journal of Nonverbal Behavior, a 2016 study found that cultures with a \u201clow uncertainty avoidance,\u201d in which the future is judged to be relatively unpredictable and social conditions are regarded as uncertain, view smiling too much as unintelligent. The more corrupt a society is, the more its citizens see smiling as suspicious.\n\nSmiling when you don\u2019t feel like it has been proven to make you feel good by producing actual feelings of happiness. I\u2019ve tried it, and it does work, but I don\u2019t want to be ordered to smile. If a smile is the appearance of happiness, then to be commanded to smile takes away our right to our own feelings. We must appear happy, even if we\u2019re not. A man told my friend to smile, for instance, on the day that she found out her father had died.\n\nOr maybe there\u2019s just something about my neutral expression that comes across as seeming worried or displeased. People have asked if there was something wrong when I was feeling just fine. To compensate, I\u2019ve found myself smiling forcefully when socializing with strangers, wanting to assure them that they don\u2019t have to worry. That I\u2019m O.K.", "title": "Opinion | An American Woman Quits Smiling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "It was a cold, sunny day last spring when retired U.S. Army Specialist Michael McCoy visited the war memorial in Cumberland, Md., to look for the name of Pfc. Albert M. Nelson.\n\nMr. McCoy, who grew up in West Baltimore, and Mr. Nelson, who was from West Philadelphia, became close friends in 2006 just before Mr. McCoy\u2019s second of two yearlong deployments to Iraq. Mr. Nelson was a bit of a joker and, at 31, a few years older than the other soldiers. He was a big brother figure, well liked, especially by Mr. McCoy.\n\n\u201cWe used to talk about hanging out in Philly when we got home,\u201d he said. \u201cWe never got that chance.\u201d", "title": "An Army Veteran Confronts His Own Trauma With a Camera", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Eating breakfast alone at his hotel in Kochi \u2014 \u201cwhen it\u2019s off-season, no one comes to Kochi except the curator of the biennale,\u201d he says \u2014 he studied the fruit plate he ate each morning, and started to think that \u201cthe sliced apples lovingly placed by the chef would suddenly look like star fields.\u201d When he returned to his studio in 2015 he began a series called \u201cSightings,\u201d extraordinarily detailed photographs of fruit that are printed using lenticular lenses, so they seem to distort and change color as a viewer moves around them. The images are befuddling to begin with \u2014 the top of a blueberry looks like aerial photography of some harsh and unfamiliar landscape \u2014 but the lenticular lens makes for a kind of hallucinogenic experience, as if breakfast has been reimagined via Stanley Kubrick\u2019s experiments with light and color at the end of \u201c2001: A Space Odyssey.\u201d\n\nImage A \u201cWind Study\u201d by Kallat, made predominantly by using fire and wind. Credit Jitish Kallat, courtesy of the artist and Sperone Westwater, New York. Photo: Anil Rane.\n\nMost intriguing of all are Kallat\u2019s so-called \u201cWind Studies,\u201d which begin as line drawings based on a pattern by the German mathematician David Hilbert. Kallat then places them outside and intermittently lights parts of the drawing on fire. What results is a burned section of the line and a dramatic shadow from where the wind directed the flame. Kallat will continue on like this, setting a portion of his drawing on fire and waiting to see what the wind will do. The works are a kind of transcript of the wind\u2019s movement, and the culmination of his games of chance with nature.\n\n\u201cAll I\u2019m doing in the work,\u201d Kallat says, \u201cis letting the paper intervene into what is otherwise a minor turbulence on the minor surface of a minor planet in a sort of minor constellation of stars in a minor galaxy. And to me, that little shift that happens on the paper is almost an alchemy that happens beyond me.\u201d", "title": "An Artist Who Leaves His Work Up to Nature \u2014 and Chance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "As a teenager on the streets in the early 1970s, artist David Wojnarowicz frequented the then-seedy blocks around Times Square, hustling among junkies, drug dealers and pimps. The harsh reality of his New York City childhood would later become paramount to his work \u2014 black-and-white photography, Super 8 films, paintings \u2014 stripping away the layers of civil society to reveal modern culture in all its raw brutality: the hypocrisy of government and religion, the marginalization gay people faced during the Reagan era. But his personal artifacts, many of which are now archived at N.Y.U.\u2019s Fales Library & Special Collections along with his work, reveal Wojnarowicz\u2019s humorous side, including an assembly of Halloween ornaments and decorations cataloged after his death in 1992. \u201cHe had over 400 objects in the collection,\u201d says Marvin J. Taylor, the director of Fales. \u201cHe managed to hold on to everything despite moving around a lot throughout his life.\u201d A retrospective of Wojnarowicz\u2019s work opens July 13 at the Whitney Museum of American Art.", "title": "An Artist\u2019s Halloween Paraphernalia, Illustrated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "What does a plant feel when strapped to a human being and sailing down a lengthy slide? With his new installation, \u201cThe Florence Experiment,\u201d the Belgian-born artist Carston H\u00f6ller aims to find out. He began by constructing a coiling pair of 60-foot slides, along with a neurobiology laboratory stocked with pea seedlings, inside the museum at Florence\u2019s 15th-century Palazzo Strozzi.\n\nIt will be his first investigation into the vegetable kingdom. Opening to the public this week, the exhibition brings scientifically inspired contemporary art to the Renaissance city, where the union of art and science first flourished. But H\u00f6ller, a former entomologist, sees this installation as an artistic retort to the dominance of science. \u201cWhere science is limited, art can open new doors of understanding,\u201d he says.\n\nSet in the interior courtyard of the Strozzi, the curves of the steel chutes provide a striking contrast to the symmetrical Renaissance arches of the centuries-old palazzo. The museum allows visitors to descend the slides, but with their intimidating height and pitch, a touch of courage is required. Brave visitors careen down 160 feet of pirouetting tubes, a few chosen ones with a plant strapped to their torso.", "title": "An Artist\u2019s Modern Slides, Inside a 15th-Century Palazzo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "It was a perfect day to jump mountains. The sky was clear, the temperature mild and the jagged peaks in Canada\u2019s backcountry were dusted with snow.\n\nOn that day, April 22, a team of expert snowboarders stood on a ridge. The plan was to pop off the top of the mountain, drop onto its powdery face and shred its untouched slope, racing against gravity for the sheer love of it.\n\nBut each of the four riders on the ridge in the Whistler region of Canada that day was also weighing the sobering reality that the terrain at their feet might be engraved with features that would make it susceptible to their worst fear: an avalanche.\n\nAnd that is what happened.\n\nOne of the four riders, Brock Crouch, 18, went on the first run down the mountain, then returned to try a second route nearby. But somehow, he ended up on a cornice \u2014 a bulge of snow sculpted by wind that bends over a ridge to form a ledge.", "title": "An Avalanche Sweeps Away a Snowboarder, but His Friends Rescue Him", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Paying more for better, faster care may not be fair, but the concept has been around for decades.\n\nConcierge physicians often charge patients directly, bypassing insurance companies that discount their rates. They do this through annual membership fees but also with charges for each visit. In return, patients get direct access and more time with a doctor.\n\nTop hospitals have also started to provide concierge services, offering programs with stately names that are meant to coddle dignitaries, celebrities and international patients paying their own way. In New York, Mount Sinai Hospital has its Executive Services Department, the Hospital for Special Surgery offers its Ambassador Services, and Weill Cornell Medicine provides its International Patient Services.\n\nBut emergency rooms by law treat the sickest patients first. If you\u2019ve been shot, you\u2019ll be seen right away. If you\u2019re stable, you\u2019re going to wait \u2014 and you could keep waiting depending on who else comes in.\n\nPhoto\n\nAccording to research by ProPublica, the average time a patient spends in an emergency room in New York State before being sent home is three hours. In certain hospitals in New York City, the wait can stretch to closer to five hours.\n\nWaiting in emergency rooms is the norm. In Maryland, it\u2019s about three and a half hours on average; in North Dakota, the wait is comparatively speedy: You\u2019re in and out in about an hour and a half.\n\nA lot of people are fed up with the process, but few can do anything about it. That\u2019s where Priority Private Care, with its care center on the Upper East Side, saw an opening for a clientele familiar with the costs and benefits of concierge medicine.\n\nDr. Bernard Kruger, a board-certified physician in oncology and internal medicine, started the company 18 months ago with two partners. He had a concierge medical practice for 15 years but saw its limitations, particularly on weekends if a patient was hurt and needed an X-ray or blood work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe got the idea for a concierge emergency room after helping a patient, an actress, who had fallen off a horse. \u201cI brought her to Mount Sinai,\u201d Dr. Kruger said. \u201cThe head of the department came down. We still waited five hours for a CAT scan. I said something is wrong here.\u201d\n\nThe Priority Private Care facility is sleek and modern, with a Chuck Close painting hanging on the wall. In addition to being well staffed, the center has the imaging machines and laboratory equipment for blood work to get results quickly and help doctors make a diagnosis.\n\nDr. Kruger summed up the experience: \u201cYou get seen right away. You get treated right away. You have a consistent doctor with you.\u201d\n\nIt has its limits. It is not equipped to handle a gunshot wound, for instance, and it is not a surgery center. But according to a 2013 study by Truven Health Analytics, about three-fourths of emergency room visits by people with insurance did not require emergency room-level care.\n\nThat\u2019s a lot of waiting (and unnecessary visits), given that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that there are 141 million emergency room visits each year. The same C.D.C. study said that 11.2 million emergency room visits resulted in people being admitted to the hospital and 1.8 million, or about 1 percent, of those visits ended with people being admitted to critical care units.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe founders of Priority Private Care envisioned a service focused on three areas. The first is emergency care. They believe they can handle about 80 percent of the cases that require emergency care.\n\nThe second is access to a network of specialists and the ability to get patients in to see someone quickly. This was one thing that attracted Russ Coniglio, a businessman who lives in Boca Raton, Fla., but keeps an apartment in Manhattan.\n\n\u201cYou call a specialist on Park Avenue, and they say six months,\u201d said Mr. Coniglio, who works in the beauty care business. But when Dr. Kruger calls a specialist, he said, \u201cthey say come right over.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how you put a price tag on it,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you have a problem and wait three weeks for the appointment, that\u2019s hard to do.\u201d\n\nMr. Coniglio also put his children on the plan, and both of his college-age sons have used it for emergency services for sports-related injuries.\n\nThose medical connections also extend to getting a patient admitted into a hospital through its V.I.P. services, if additional care is needed.\n\nThe third is convenience for any ailment, like a sore throat or a cough, that crops up after hours or on the weekend. \u201cAs long as we have to staff a full facility to effectively run empty, people can use us for convenience services,\u201d said Andrew Olanow, a co-founder of Priority Private Care.\n\nThe center differs, though, from hospital emergency rooms, which have to take anyone who walks in off the street. Priority Private Care is not obligated to do that, though Mr. Olanow said it would.\n\n\u201cIf they\u2019re gushing blood, we\u2019d stabilize them and walk them the one and a half blocks to Lenox Hill,\u201d he said of a nearby hospital.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd the center, which is regulated as an urgent care facility by New York State, offers free care to the schoolchildren and teachers in its neighborhood as community outreach.\n\nTexas has addressed concierge emergency rooms in a different way. The state allows free-standing emergency rooms, many of which act as concierge providers. The advantage is the greater attention and the quicker passage through the emergency room. Like Priority, though, if you\u2019ve been shot or need surgery, the staff members will get you to a hospital emergency room.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI get to spoil my patients and go over every lab and sit with them,\u201d said Dr. Harvey Castro, a former emergency room doctor who is now medical director of Coppell ER in the Dallas area. \u201cWe have extra staff who can go and walk a person\u2019s dog. We\u2019ve picked up children at school.\u201d\n\nIn lieu of a membership fee, Coppell ER bills insurance companies and collects the hefty emergency room payments. That can be lucrative for the emergency room, if expensive for the insurance company.\n\nPriority Private Care\u2019s membership fee decreases as more family members are included. Mr. Wilson said it was $5,000 for him, $3,000 for his wife and $2,000 for their daughter.\n\nThe center has 1,100 members, from about 350 families. Mr. Olanow said it planned to cap membership at 2,000 to 2,500, depending on how crowded the facility got.\n\nOn a given day, the center, which has two doctors and a physician assistant ready to go, sees four or five patients. A typical emergency room doctor sees three patients every hour.\n\nBut like a hospital emergency room, it also gets patients who come in with nonemergencies. Mr. Wilson, who lives just a few blocks away, said he had awakened one morning with a pimple and wondered whether Priority Private Care could take care of it.\n\n\u201cIt was really bothering me,\u201d he said. \u201cThey said come on over.\u201d\n\nWhen the concierge E.R. is empty, a visit for any ailment is welcome.", "title": "An E.R. That Treats You Like a V.I.P.", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Orban has relentlessly transformed Hungary\u2019s political system and remade the country's institutions and society \u2014 efforts that have been roundly condemned by democracy advocates. But the prime minister\u2019s allies say that Hungarians really care about his successful stewardship of the economy and that \u201cOrbanomics\u201d will most likely decide the election on Sunday.\n\n\u201cPeople feel that they have a much better life in terms of the economy,\u201d said Istvan Lovas, a radio host and one of Mr. Orban\u2019s most prominent supporters. \u201cWhatever figures you look at, they are clearly improving.\u201d\n\nIn many cases, that is true. Government debt, as a proportion of Hungary\u2019s gross domestic product, has fallen more than 6 percentage points since 2010. The country\u2019s credit ratings have improved. The budget deficit has roughly halved. Growth has almost quadrupled. Wages have risen by more than 10 percent. Though still high, deprivation has fallen by nearly half \u2014 not least in places like Siklosnagyfalu, where villagers benefit from their workfare wages. Officially, unemployment has dropped by nearly two-thirds.\n\n\u201cHungary has been on the right track,\u201d Mihaly Varga, the economy minister, said in an email that cited most of these positive developments. \u201cNow everyone who is capable of work and wants to work can find a job.\u201d\n\nBut critics argue that things are not as rosy as the traditional macroeconomic measures suggest.\n\nSince Mr. Orban came to power, Hungary has slipped to 29th place from 20th on the Euro Health Consumer Index, a comparison of European health systems. Student performance in reading, math and science has worsened, according to the Program for International Student Assessment, which compares global education systems.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd as other Central European countries have become less corrupt, Hungary has become significantly more so, according to the World Bank\u2019s Worldwide Governance Indicators. During Mr. Orban\u2019s first six years in power, five of his closest friends were awarded roughly 5 percent of public procurement contracts, a total of $2.5 billion, according to an analysis by the Corruption Research Center Budapest.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Orban\u2019s successes have also partly been the result of factors beyond his control.\n\nUnder Mr. Orban, gross domestic product has been unusually dependent on money from the European Union. Between 2009 and 2016, such funding constituted nearly 4 percent of Hungarian G.D.P. per year, one of the highest ratios in the bloc, European officials have calculated.\n\nEurope also functions as a pressure valve for the Hungarian labor market. The government says 730,000 new jobs have been created since 2010 \u2014 but that includes as many as 350,000 Hungarians who have found work elsewhere in the European Union, said Janos Kollo, research director of the Institute of Economics at the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.\n\nMr. Orban has also benefited from the global economic revival.\n\n\u201cThe Hungarian government was like any other government,\u201d said Istvan Madar, a senior analyst at Portfolio, a Hungarian financial journal. \u201cThey had some special methods, some unorthodox measures, but the overall Hungarian government economic performance was no better than any other regional government.\u201d\n\nSome of those measures raised eyebrows. Until Mr. Orban and his far-right party, Fidesz, came to power, Hungarians could hold 25 percent of their retirement savings in a private fund; the rest went into a public pot. To cut state debt, the government announced that Hungarians who did not transfer private pension assets into the public system would not receive a state pension. By the time the order was ruled unconstitutional, most people had already complied.\n\n\u201cIt was a completely unlawful blackmailing of the population,\u201d said Balazs Romhanyi, an economic analyst who at the time was chief of staff at the Hungarian Budget Council, a state body that monitors state expenditure.\n\nPhoto\n\n(Mr. Varga, the economy minister, justified the decision by arguing that the private pensions were \u201ctoo costly,\u201d and that the new system had been more \u201cstable and predictable.\u201d)\n\nThe highlight of Mr. Orban\u2019s apparent economic success \u2014 the fall in unemployment \u2014 also fades under scrutiny.\n\nIn 2017, more than 200,000 Hungarians \u2014 nearly 4 percent of the country\u2019s work force \u2014 participated in the government\u2019s workfare program, and were therefore counted as employed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut labor economists questioned their inclusion, since many were doing work that did not really need to be done. In Siklosnagyfalu, for example, 25 workfare participants are allocated to work all year on five hectares, or about 12 acres, of public farmland \u2014 work that requires neither that many people, nor such a permanent assignment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn really small settlements, there are no real jobs,\u201d said Gyorgy Molnar, a specialist in workfare at the Institute for Economics at the Hungarian Academy of Science. \u201cThe majority of people are working for one or two hours and then going home.\u201d\n\nHe estimated that the real unemployment rate in 2017 was 7.3 percent \u2014 lower than when Mr. Orban entered office, but far higher than the official rate of 4.2 percent.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe program also makes participants more dependent on both on their local mayor, who decides work assignments, and on Fidesz, the party that expanded workfare.\n\nIn the last general election in 2014, Fidesz received 116 votes in Siklosnagyfalu and the runner-up nine. That result is likely to be repeated on Sunday, said the village\u2019s independent mayor, Jozsef Kosztics, who said he had talked with villagers about how they planned to vote.\n\nThough the workfare program may skew national employment figures and exacerbate feudal dynamics in the countryside, it has nevertheless improved lives in Siklosnagyfalu.\n\nParticipants are paid approximately $175 a month \u2014 less than half the minimum wage, but roughly double what was paid out in unemployment benefits. Four Siklosnagyfalu residents said they could now afford to pay for heating in the winter and to buy meat more regularly.\n\n\u201cThis little bit of money goes a long way in this village,\u201d said Eva Petrovics, 60, who helps to clean the village nursery school. \u201cThe fridge is full now.\u201d\n\nThe program has also helped to spruce up the village. Since 2012, workfare participants have built a small bridge, added a drainage system, and renovated the town hall and sports fields. The terms of the program have also allowed Mr. Kosztics to buy farming machinery for the village, including a new tractor and plow.\n\n\u201cYou can say a lot of things about the workfare program, but one thing is certain,\u201d Mr. Kosztics said. \u201cFor municipalities like this one, it means survival.\u201d", "title": "An Economic Miracle in Hungary, or Just a Mirage?", "authors": ["Patrick Kingsley", "Benjamin Novak"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "It played to the room like an \u201cIn Memoriam\u201d segment from the Oscars.\n\nThe video \u2014 which featured footage from more than three dozen Fox films, including \u201cAll About Eve,\u201d \u201cTitanic,\u201d \u201cThe Sound of Music,\u201d \u201cAvatar,\u201d \u201cThe Grapes of Wrath,\u201d \u201cAlien\u201d and \u201cThe Devil Wears Prada\u201d \u2014 concluded by showing various versions of the towering 20th Century Fox logo over the years, accompanied by the studio\u2019s signature trumpet fanfare.\n\nContinuing the end-of-an-era vibe, Chris Aronson, Fox\u2019s president of domestic distribution, then took the stage and rattled through the names of employees in some of the departments at Fox that are expected to be downsized after Disney completes its takeover. Antitrust regulators are currently scrutinizing the deal; Fox executives have said they expect approval by the middle of next year.\n\nDisney has not yet given many details about how it plans to operate 20th Century Fox, which was founded in 1935. It is assumed in Hollywood that Fox will sit beside Marvel, Lucasfilm and Pixar as a label inside Walt Disney Studios. Fox Searchlight, which specializes in art films and has been an Academy Awards powerhouse, will remain a separate brand.\n\nMs. Snider, who is not expected to make the move to Disney, cited the recent success of Fox\u2019s \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d when briefly referring to the acquisition in her speech on Thursday.\n\n\u201cWe face a new transition \u2014 a potential merger that will have lasting implications for the movie business,\u201d she said. \u201cI have no more insight into this transaction than you do. But I am holding onto the very basics \u2014 what helped make \u2018Showman\u2019 a hit. Let\u2019s stay dedicated to the future of cinema and passionate about the films to come. For our first installment, we\u2019ve chosen Sir Ken Robinson, a best-selling author and longtime advocate of transforming education. His latest book, \u201cYou, Your Child, and School,\u201d was published in March by Viking. The following interview was edited and condensed.\n\nYour new book offers wide-ranging advice for parents as they try to manage their children\u2019s education. If you had to choose one takeaway, what would it be?\n\nParents have more power and more choices than they may realize in educating their children. Many parents are worried about how the world is changing and the uncertain futures their children face. Parents are especially anxious about education. They worry that there\u2019s too much testing and competition, that the curriculum is too narrow, that their children are not treated as individuals and that schools are not cultivating their curiosity, confidence and creative talents.\n\nThey worry about how many young people are being medicated for \u201clearning problems.\u201d They worry about the rising costs of college and whether their children will eventually find a job, whether or not they go to college. Often parents feel powerless to do anything about all of this. The good news is that a great many educators share these concerns and are also campaigning for change.", "title": "An Expert\u2019s View: Sir Ken Robinson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "MethaneSAT, by comparison, is designed to detect emissions across the planet with sufficiently high resolution to identify sources. The organization plans to make the data publicly available so that companies, policymakers and regulators can take action.\n\nIdentifying major sources of leaks could help governments and industry coalitions work together to address the problem, said Daniel J. Jacob, a professor of atmospheric chemistry and environmental engineering at Harvard. \u201cHow can you do climate policy for methane if you don\u2019t know where the sources are?\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Krupp, the Environmental Defense Fund president, is announcing the initiative at the TED2018 conference in Vancouver, British Columbia. His organization has already obtained most of the \u201ctens of millions of dollars\u201d that building the satellite and launching it should cost, Mr. Krupp said in an interview. Much of the early money came from the Robertson Foundation, which has environmental work as part of its focus. The launch is planned for late 2020 or early 2021.\n\nSpace is a tough neighborhood; timetables slip and challenges proliferate. But the \u201cnew space\u201d movement has helped move orbital launches out of the realm of superpowers and put it within the reach of businesses and nonprofits.\n\n\u201cI think this is entirely feasible,\u201d said Peter Platzer, the chief executive of Spire Global, a satellite company, who was not involved with the MethaneSAT project but has talked with members of the team extensively.\n\nThe environmental group is also working with Steven C. Wofsy, a professor of atmospheric and environmental science at Harvard, and his colleagues to address the daunting technology challenge of creating an infrared spectrometer that can detect methane plumes on the Earth\u2019s surface.\n\nThe lead scientist for a major methane-detecting satellite program applauded the idea. Ilse Aben, a senior scientist at the Netherlands Institute for Space Research , presented the first data this week from a European satellite launched in October with an instrument that can detect methane, but at lower spatial resolution. In Match.com\u2019s annual Singles in America Survey, which polls more than 5,000 people who are not Match users, the company found that the No. 1 place where singles meet is online. In 2016, Pew reported that 27 percent of people aged 18 to 24 had used a dating app or site. In 2013, it was 10 percent. The proportion of 55- to 64-year-olds in the same category doubled.\n\n\u201cAn average person spends about three hours a day on their mobile phone,\u201d said Lexi Sydow, a market insights manager at AppAnnie. \u201cDating apps are really tapping into that.\u201d Ms. Sydow noted that global consumer spending for dating apps, or the amount of money users pay for add-ons, subscriptions, memberships and other features, has nearly doubled from a year ago.\n\nEven traditional matchmaking services are wading in. \u201cI used to be a matchmaker before this,\u201d said Meredith Davis, the head of communications for the League, a dating app that has a screening process for where you went to school, where you work (and have worked), how many degrees you have and other social-status categories. \u201cMatchmakers are now overseeing their clients\u2019 dating app accounts.\u201d\n\nWith so many people using the internet to find the One (for life, for tonight or for next week), more niche options have popped up, too. Greenberg\u2019s score would be 100.\n\nIn the same way he entered a number of fields and excelled \u2014 co-founding the influential digital advertising agency R/GA, designing titles and visual effects for hundreds of feature films including \u201cAlien\u201d and establishing himself as a communications guru \u2014 Mr. Greenberg goes all-in and doesn\u2019t second-guess.\n\nScooping up collections by the dozens or hundreds of items is easier when you live in a massive, two-story penthouse loft, as Mr. Greenberg does with his wife, Corvova Lee (an artist whose work is also on view). It\u2019s one of five homes they own, including two in the Hudson Valley.\n\nAbout 90 percent of the art he has bought is outsider or self-taught, and he was an early adopter of the field in the early 1980s. \u201cThe scale of it has gotten to be very large,\u201d Mr. Greenberg, 69, said on a tour of the loft, in the West 30s, which includes a display of 300 colorful fish decoys installed all together.\n\nMr. Greenberg is perhaps best known for collecting dolls, some of them made in the 1950s by Calvin and Ruby Black as part of the California roadside attraction Possum Trot Shop and Fantasy Doll Show. Can America learn anything from other nations? We gathered experts with a range of perspectives, from America and abroad, and asked them to compare the systems in Australia, Britain, Sweden and the United States.\n\nWe chose this grouping of nations because they highlight important differences both in loan repayment systems and in related policies such as tuition and loan limits, not necessarily because they all belong among the best systems in the world. In the spirit of March Madness, we devised a bracket-style tournament, seeding the countries so that those with more similar systems would meet in the semifinals.\n\nSweden vs. United States\n\nSweden and the United States differ in whether the monthly loan payment remains the same over time and in the number of years borrowers can repay their loans.", "title": "An International Final Four: Which Country Handles Student Debt Best?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Life in a midtown high-rise\n\nIn August, we moved several blocks to 1180 Peachtree, which we refer to as the midtown market area, between downtown Atlanta and Buckhead. There are a number of law firms and professional services firms around us. I\u2019m on the 31st floor. From my desk I can see One Atlantic Center, also known as the IBM Tower. I\u2019m fond of it because a team of us placed a large tenant in that building 30 years ago.\n\nWe\u2019ve moved about four times in the 40 years I\u2019ve been with this commercial real estate company. My last office was around 300 square feet; my current one is about 100.\n\nArt appreciation\n\nOne of my favorite photos is \u201cOutskirts of Morton, Mississippi, Halloween 1971,\u201d by William Eggleston. It was a gift from a friend who doesn\u2019t collect photography.\n\nWhen I had it appraised, I learned it was worth a couple thousand dollars and sent my friend a nice case of Bordeaux as a thank you. I\u2019ve never bought anything with the thought that it would appreciate, but this photo, like almost all Eggleston photos, has significantly increased in value.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother friend sent me Ernie Mickler\u2019s \u201cWhite Trash Cooking\u201d cookbook. I was particularly drawn to the photographs illustrating it.", "title": "An Office Decorated in Homage to Southern Art", "authors": ["Patricia R. Olsen", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "John Gibbons grew up in San Antonio, so his accent sounds as if the Texas winds are blowing straight from his mouth, and his bowlegged gait conjures images of horse-weary cowboys. Texas is embedded in his background and persona, but not in his blood.\n\nGibbons, the long-serving manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, is actually the scion of a family of Massachusetts optometrists, not Texas ranchers. While his formative years were spent in Texas, some of his earliest recollections are from the years when his family lived in Middleton, Mass., in a house with the Ipswich River running through the backyard.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m really a New Englander,\u201d Gibbons said in his signature Texas accent. \u201cThat\u2019s where the jerk in me comes from.\u201d\n\nGibbons, who rarely misses an opportunity for a self-deprecating joke, said the last line with a wink, knowing he was speaking to a fellow New Englander. After all, few consider Gibbons the jerky type, even if he has unloaded on a few players and more than a few umpires over the years, sometimes in spectacular fashion.", "title": "An Old-School Manager Thrives in a New Baseball Age", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Opera is a pretty placid universe these days. So it\u2019s hard to imagine a premiere that could single-handedly divide the music-loving public in two, separating it into factions with positions as hotly held as those of today\u2019s Democrats and Republicans.\n\nRameau\u2019s \u201cHippolyte et Aricie\u201d had just such an impact on France when it opened at the Paris Opera in 1733. It will be presented in a new, eagerly anticipated production on April 17, 19 and 21 at the Juilliard School, which has become an early music powerhouse over the past decade.\n\n\u201cHippolyte\u201d was Rameau\u2019s first opera, but it is not at all the product of a novice. Nearly 50 when he wrote it, already a master of the harpsichord and the author of a groundbreaking treatise on harmony, he had thought long and hard about the task, and probably knew the controversy he would be stirring.", "title": "An Opera Worth Fighting Over", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Federal regulators, doctors and others were swayed by pharmaceutical companies that argued for greater use of opioids; there was increasing awareness that doctors had become too unresponsive to patients who were in pain. Patient advocates and pain specialists demanded that the medical establishment recognize pain as the \u201cfifth vital sign.\u201d\n\nMr. Courtwright says that this was not a simple case of historical amnesia. In the earlier epidemic, doctors \u201cmade mistakes, but it was a bad situation to begin with,\u201d he said. \u201cThere was no equivalent of Purdue Pharma flying you off to the Bahamas for the weekend to tell you about the wonders of these new drugs.\u201d\n\nWHAT SHOULD WE DO NOW?\n\nThe AIDS crisis might provide public officials some lessons for how to move forward. Like with opioids, the federal government responded to that epidemic by doing next to nothing for many years. But an organized movement led in part by people with H.I.V. and gay activists eventually forced Congress to create and fund new programs. For example, in 1990 Congress approved the Ryan White Care Act, a bipartisan bill that poured billions of dollars into providing treatment and support to people with H.I.V. By 1995, the federal government was spending $3.3 billion a year (about $5.4 billion today after adjusting for inflation) on AIDS efforts, not including billions spent through mandatory programs like Medicaid and Medicare, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. That was up from just $116 million in 1985.\n\nThough slow to act, Congress eventually treated AIDS as a complex, multidimensional problem and tackled it by funding prevention, treatment, support services and research. Lawmakers provided money to make expensive antiretroviral drugs accessible to more people and allocated money to help house people infected with H.I.V., recognizing that they needed more than just access to drugs.\n\nImage AIDs activists demonstrating in New York in 1988. Credit Allan Tannenbaum/Getty Images\n\nLawmakers so far have fallen far short of such a vigorous effort when it comes to opioid addiction. Congress has taken what can be considered only baby steps by appropriating a total of a few billion dollars of discretionary opioid funding in recent years. This funding amounts to a pittance relative to what is needed: substantial long-term funding for prevention, addiction treatment, social services and research. Andrew Kolodny, co-director of opioid policy research at Brandeis University, says at least $6 billion a year is needed for 10 years to set up a nationwide network of clinics and doctors to provide treatment with medicines like buprenorphine and methadone. Those drugs have a proven track record at reducing overdoses and giving people struggling with addiction a shot at a stable life. Today, large parts of the country have few or no clinics that offer medication-assisted treatment, according to an analysis by amfAR, a foundation that funds AIDS research.\n\nNext, lawmakers need to remove regulations restricting access to buprenorphine, an opioid that can be used to get people off stronger drugs like heroin; its use is unlikely to end in an overdose. Doctors who want to prescribe the drug have to go through eight hours of training, and the government limits the number of patients they can treat. These limits have made the drug harder to obtain and created a situation in which it is easier to get the kinds of opioids that caused this crisis than to get medicine that can help addicts. France reduced heroin overdoses by nearly 80 percent by making buprenorphine easily available starting in 1995. Yet many American lawmakers and government officials have resisted removing restrictions on buprenorphine, arguing it replaces one addiction with another. Some of the same people have also stood in the way of wider availability of naloxone, which can help reverse overdoses, and opposed harm-reduction approaches like supervised drug consumption sites, where users can get clean needles and use drugs under the watch of staff who are trained to reverse overdoses.", "title": "Opinion | An Opioid Crisis Foretold", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Rise of God\u2019s Spokeswomen\u201d (column, April 1):\n\nI appreciate Nicholas Kristof\u2019s excellent column about the changes in women\u2019s roles in our religions and his awareness that the issue is not merely equality of women, but also radical transformations of our religious practices and theological understandings, as the pioneering feminist theologian Mary Daly argued in 1973.\n\nI\u2019m delighted that so many people are now placing an orange on the Seder plate. But as the person who originated the custom out of solidarity with gay and lesbian Jews, I am concerned that Mr. Kristof cites an oral legend that the orange represents support for women in the pulpit.\n\nThe legend transfers credit for my idea to a man, erases the point of the custom (rejecting homophobia) and affirms what already exists (women are on the bimah) rather than demanding needed change.\n\nOrdination of female clergy is a first step; there is much more we still need to accomplish.\n\nSUSANNAH HESCHEL\n\nHANOVER, N.H.", "title": "Opinion | An Orange on the Seder Plate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The shimmer at the end of the second \u201cChant d\u2019amour\u201d was dazzling in its restraint, rather than being Technicolor-bright. The start of the \u201cTurangal\u00eela I\u201d section placed clarinet, ondes, double bass and bells pristinely atop one another, as if with silver tweezers.\n\nIndeed, I was struck the following evening by how sheerly louder \u201cTristan\u201d got from the very beginning, which builds to a ferocious evocation of sexual union. But the end of the Prelude was remarkable: a vision of the loneliness that follows togetherness, as forlorn and clouded as a fog-filled sea.\n\nPolished and conscientious, the performance was a little cool to the touch. (It was closer to the guy you bring home to Mom than the other kind, the Tristan kind.) There was a feeling more of momentarily vivid colors than of larger ebbs and flows of intensity.\n\nThe soprano Nina Stemme\u2019s Isolde is a known quantity; she sounded wonderful, as ever \u2014 the voice healthy and mellow, the high notes rich and penetrating. Yet there\u2019s little sense of risk with her, and when there was, Mr. Welser-M\u00f6st certainly wasn\u2019t abetting it. The revelation of the cast was the mezzo-soprano Okka von der Damerau, a Brang\u00e4ne of bright, unforced power.\n\nThe long, crucial central love duet strained the tenor Gerhard Siegel, as Tristan, almost to breaking; the scene\u2019s listlessness left an empty space at the opera\u2019s center. Mr. Siegel was more effective at the agonies of the third act than the ecstasies of the second. And, in general, this was a \u201cTristan\u201d in which solitude was more persuasive than communion.\n\nMany ensembles would have done the Prelude and \u201cLiebestod\u201d from Wagner\u2019s opera \u2014 or maybe, like the Boston Symphony Orchestra recently, an excerpted act. A few would have done a complete \u201cTristan\u201d alone. Maybe one or two would have added a bonus performance of a suite from Prokofiev\u2019s \u201cRomeo and Juliet,\u201d or something, on a program about great lovers. (That would have sold a lot better than \u201cTurangal\u00eela.\u201d)", "title": "An Orchestra\u2019s Ecstatic, Once-in-a-Lifetime Birthday Party", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI do not have a \u201cbucket list.\u201d I have no desire to jump out of an airplane, run with the bulls or climb Mt. Everest.\n\nI do, however, have a list of things from my past that I would like to correct. An apology not given, a thank you not expressed, an \u201cI love you\u201d withheld.\n\nMy daughter was born in our apartment on East 78th Street in April 1999. My wife and I had every intention of making it to the hospital, but it all happened much too quickly.\n\nI called 911. Two emergency medical technicians from the Fire Department arrived and effortlessly delivered our baby while keeping me, her two older brothers, and a friend who had the boys on his lap while watching \u201cSeinfeld\u201d in our kitchen, calm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough I\u2019m sure I thanked the EMTs at the time, I always meant to thank them in a more formal way, perhaps in a letter to the Fire Department telling the higher-ups about them and how great they had been.\n\nAs with many things, though, I never got around to it. To be totally honest, I don\u2019t even remember their names.", "title": "An Overdue Thanks", "authors": ["Tim Lyons", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Without a permanent gallery, Assi commissions experimental, conceptual works to be shown under the Seeds banner at pop-up spaces and design fairs including Collect at London\u2019s Saatchi Gallery, and Nomad in Monaco.
