Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe five-story house in Kensington, with its white walls and Dinesen oak flooring, acts as a restrained backdrop for whatever wild constructions Assi\u2019s commissions might bring in. It is also the site of regular Seeds \u201cget-togethers and dinners, formal and informal\u201d \u2014 occasions to show works and share the narratives behind them. Assi is an avid storyteller who gleefully relates the histories of her pieces. As she sips rose-petal-flavored water, she explains how Jochen Holz and Silo Studio formed the Jell-O-colored vessels by blowing glass into fabric bags. The misshapen carafe was the fruit of chance: \u201cin this instance the bag ripped,\u201d she says. Before bringing a new piece home, she says, \u201cI need to like the story and feel a connection with it: Once the connection exists, I try to share it with as many people as I can.\u201d\n\nWorking with designers who pursue a conceptual rather than mass-market approach, Assi considers herself a bridge between London\u2019s creative bohemia and the moneyed, collecting classes of West London. She sees Seeds as bringing the East London \u201cvibe\u201d to a neighborhood that is perhaps \u201cdisconnected from the creativity\u201d happening on the other side of town.\n\nAssi draws a core body of collectors from her social circle. \u201cMums from school in Kensington are collectors or could be collectors,\u201d she says, \u201cMy husband\u2019s connections, people we go out with, people we travel with are all collectors.\u201d Social relationships are Seeds\u2019s driving force. In seeking out designers, Assi is attentive to personal and emotional qualities, considering them influential on the works produced. She praises the \u201cpositive energy\u201d of the East London-based designer Martino Gamper, with whom she has worked on a number of projects. Inspired by the creative circle around him, Assi encouraged a new working relationship for Seeds Season Three, the platform\u2019s third show. Gamper and a dozen friends \u2014 among them the designers Max Lamb and Bethan Laura Wood \u2014 made a series of clay and brass objects as a new collective under the name No Ordinary Love. \u201cWhen someone has an ecosystem of such positive and happy people, that means he\u2019s a person who is able to inspire,\u201d Assi says. \u201cIt tells a lot about the quality of the person, and that\u2019s what I\u2019m interested in.\u201d\n\nAs No Ordinary Love, too, Gamper and his collaborators made the dining table around which Assi, her family and her friends gather. With revelry, family life and commerce all taking place among such precious objects, how does she guard against damage? Assi is philosophical, suggesting that rather than venerate furnishings, we need to accept that they\u2019re here to live with us. \u201cSometimes we\u2019re not careful with people, with each other,\u201d she says. \u201cWhy would we care more about objects than we care with humans?\u201d", "title": "An Unorthodox Design Gallery in a London Townhouse", "authors": ["Hettie Judah"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wellerstein is worried over the Trump administration\u2019s fixation on hints that North Korea would consider \"denuclearization,\u201d which North Koreans tend to mean as gradual and mutual easing of tensions but which Americans read as complete North Korean disarmament \u2014 an expectation that Mr. Wellerstein called \u201cbizarro\u201d in his Twitter feed.\n\nThe countries are already treating the meeting less as the start of a long and difficult process, in which both would need to make painful compromises for narrow gains, but as the culmination of what each seems to see as its glorious triumph over the other.\n\nBut those two imagined victories are mutually exclusive and, barring a drastic strategic shift by either country, categorically unacceptable to the other side.\n\nIf both leaders are setting themselves up to fall short of the lofty expectations on which each has staked his reputation and ego, Mr. Wellerstein tweeted, \u201cwhat happens when this (inevitably) becomes clear?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nClashing Realities\n\nStatements by both governments suggest they are not only driving at conflicting goals but also operating within parallel realities.\n\nOn Friday, North Korea announced that it would pause certain nuclear tests and development programs, which its statement portrayed as a result of the country having achieved its technological ambitions. Vipin Narang, a scholar at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, translated the meaning of the statement as: \u201cThis is what we will look like as a nuclear weapons power. Get used to it.\u201d\n\nBut American officials greeted the testing pause as the first of many expected North Korean concessions. Two days later, Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter that North Korea had already \u201cagreed to denuclearization (so great for World), site closure, & no more testing!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis confusion appears to extend beyond differing interpretations of terminology, setting up both sides for nasty surprises when they meet.\n\nThe North Koreans seem to believe that their nuclear breakthroughs forced Mr. Trump to accede to a leaders\u2019 summit meeting, something they have long desired as a way to prove themselves a peer of the major powers.\n\nBut American officials have said Mr. Kim was the one forced to the table, compelled there by American sanctions and military threats.\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s statements suggests that the country sees itself as on the verge of forcing the world to accept it as it is, finally securing its long-term survival.\n\nAmerican statements, which appear written to fend off critics who say Mr. Trump is getting ahead of himself, imply that Mr. Kim will surrender his nuclear arsenal, which virtually no expert believes the country would do.\n\nEach country is hoping for a dramatic \u2014 and unlikely \u2014 win over the other. When their realities collide, it is difficult to predict how either leader will respond.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne part of the table will be occupied by Mr. Kim, a young despot atop an insular and impoverished country whose degree of political stability remains a mystery. In the early years of his rule, Mr. Kim cemented power by making risky purges at home and provocative attacks abroad, which he may feel compelled to repeat if he suffers a loss of face at the meeting.\n\nAt the table\u2019s other end will be Mr. Trump, who tends to see negotiations as zero-sum \u2014 that is, the other side must lose for him to win. He has proved capricious and temperamental, at times lashing out when negotiations falter, as he has done in Congressional talks over tax or health care bills. And he can be maximalist and impulsive, for instance blowing up trade talks with China and Canada.\n\nPhoto\n\nClashing Strategies\n\nThese contradictory realities have long filtered through the two countries\u2019 approach to their relations. Each has, for decades, been laser-focused on a narrow \u2014 and increasingly far-fetched \u2014 vision of success and plan for how to get there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince the fall of the Soviet Union, the United States has expected that North Korea will collapse as well. The theory was, the country would save itself by surrendering to American demands, including nuclear disarmament, for relief from economic sanctions and diplomatic isolation.\n\nIn the meantime, few believed the hermit kingdom could develop advanced missiles to carry nuclear weapons to the American mainland.\n\nThis led to severe American demands, which only fed North Korea\u2019s conviction that it required a nuclear deterrent to survive. And it allowed the United States, confident full victory was inevitable, to miss earlier opportunities for partial victory through an agreement to freeze North Korea\u2019s nuclear program when it was smaller and less advanced.\n\nIn the American view, the coming meeting is the result of sanctions and pressure, so surely Mr. Kim is prepared to discuss the degree of his nuclear surrender.\n\nThe North Koreans, though, have long patterned their strategy on what they see as China\u2019s path: international pariah in the 1950s, rogue nuclear state in the 1960s, and, finally, accepted global power in the 1970s.\n\nThat was when the United States embraced the Beijing government and withdrew troops and security guarantees from its longtime ally in Taiwan \u2014 a possible precedent, in North Korean eyes, for partial American withdrawal of support for South Korea. For China, economic prosperity followed, securing the future of a communist government once seen as unlikely to survive the modern world.\n\nIn reality, China won acceptance by playing the United States against the Soviet Union. Its size and power, which North Korea lacks, made it impossible for other nations to ignore.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that history is why, for Mr. Kim, his meeting with Mr. Trump could seem like an echo of President Richard M. Nixon\u2019s 1972 summit with Mao Zedong, where the former accepted the latter as the leader of a fellow great power. It is also why he seems to expect, like the Americans, a kind of victory that might not be realistic.\n\nPhoto\n\nClashing Expectations\n\nWith Mr. Trump unconstrained by the international norms he disdains or the diplomatic institutions he has largely circumvented, and with Mr. Kim\u2019s domestic political considerations almost entirely unknown, it is difficult to articulate even the range of possible outcomes.\n\n\u201cWe have misunderstood North Korea\u2019s promises before (and they have broken them),\u201d Melissa Hanham, an analyst at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, warned on Twitter.\n\nMr. Kim \u201ccan go back on his promises really easily,\u201d she wrote of his pledges to stop testing. He might secure a high-level meeting, a major achievement in its own right, while offering little concrete in return.\n\nMira Rapp-Hooper, who works on Asian security issues at the Center for New American Security, has argued that Mr. Trump will feel pressured to return with a deal.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s skepticism of alliances, she has written, could lead him to offer partial American withdrawal from the region and acceptance of a North Korean nuclear program in exchange for Pyongyang\u2019s halting development on the long-range missiles that can reach the continental United States.\n\nThere are perhaps a dozen such scenarios, some more drastic than others. They have little in common other than at least potentially reconciling the contradictions in what each country expects to achieve.\n\nPerhaps even more important and even less certain is what happens if these clashing expectations cannot be reconciled, leading the talks to collapse in angry disagreement.\n\nMr. Narang, the M.I.T. professor, warned that the mile-wide gaps in the countries\u2019 goals and even their understandings of basic terminology leaves \u201ceither lots of room for a bargain, or lot of room for a war.\u201d", "title": "An Unpredictable Trump and a Risk-Prone Kim Mean High Stakes and Mismatched Expectations", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEach explosive investigation is going to be different,\u201d said Matt Farr, section chief of the DNA analysis division at the laboratory here. \u201cIt\u2019s very scene- and device-specific.\u201d\n\nFew domestic bombings are the same. Deconstructing them requires a combination of logistical skill \u2014 physically analyzing explosives and their components \u2014 and creative psychology, involving analysis of the motivation and patterns of the bombers. And the digital age has made it increasingly easy to experiment with amateur devices.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of information available on the internet now,\u201d said Doug Klapec, the chief of the arson and explosive division in Beltsville. \u201cPeople used to have to go to the library and check out \u2018Anarchist Cookbook.\u2019\u201d\n\nIn the post-9/11 era, the notion of bombings has become almost inextricably linked to Islamic extremist terrorism, which the F.B.I. investigates. But the majority of bombings in the United States bear no nexus to Islamic terrorism. The evidence in those cases is sent to Beltsville, or one of its two sister labs, in Atlanta and Walnut Creek, Calif.\n\nSince 1886, the A.T.F.\u2019s laboratory division has been spread across those three places. Its modest staff includes chemists, forensic biologists and scientists who analyze evidence each year from thousands of fires, explosions and other crimes. In 2017, A.T.F. labs helped close 314 explosives cases.", "title": "Anatomy of a Bomb Investigation: Inside an A.T.F. Lab", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Jatahy has found a home for her multimedia experiments in Paris in recent years. In addition to her company\u2019s tours, she was commissioned last year by the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise to adapt Jean Renoir\u2019s classic 1939 film \u201cThe Rules of the Game,\u201d albeit with mixed results. \u201cIthaque (Notre Odyss\u00e9e 1)\u201d reflects her growing ties to the country: Alongside three women from her Brazil-based ensemble, who moved fluidly between French and Portuguese, she cast three French actors.\n\nAs often with Ms. Jatahy, there is no \u201cfourth wall\u201d to speak of in \u201cIthaque (Notre Odyss\u00e9e 1).\u201d The cast established a warm rapport with the audience, passing chips and peanuts around, even singling out one onlooker to chat. Characters proved fluid, too: The women all took turns playing Calypso and Penelope, opposite different Ulysses.\n\nThe action \u2014 Ulysses\u2019 struggle to break free of Calypso\u2019s hold, his return to Ithaca \u2014 comes in fits and starts, with unfortunate lulls throughout. What Ms. Jatahy succeeds in conveying, however, is a sense of lawlessness and despair, compounded by the misogynist violence that emerges as Penelope tries to distract her boisterous guests. In the playbill, the director cited corruption in Brazil as one inspiration, as well as the plight of refugees in Europe \u2014 at one point, a performer reads from real-life migrant stories.\n\nOver the course of the performance, the space between the two parts of the stage slowly fills with a shallow pool of water. The curtains parting the auditorium are ultimately raised for Ulysses\u2019 massacre of Penelope\u2019s suitors, which both halves of the audience see at the same time. In this \u201cOdyssey,\u201d however, the violence brings no catharsis: The damage is done, and the water remains.\n\nInstead of a contemporary makeover, Ms. Vignaud went the opposite route with the myth of Phaedra, wife of Theseus, who sexually pursues her stepson Hippolytus after the disappearance of her husband. For her debut at the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise, the young director \u2014 Ms. Vignaud is only 29 \u2014 opted to turn back the clock and stage a rarely seen Latin play, Seneca the Younger\u2019s telling of the tale of Phaedra.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt turns out to be more urgent, in many ways, than French literature\u2019s go-to \u201cPh\u00e8dre,\u201d Jean Racine\u2019s 1677 tragedy. This supremely classical work is one of Racine\u2019s finest creations, but its characters often have a remote quality in performance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn the contrary, Seneca\u2019s play (in Florence Dupont\u2019s translation) has a warmer, more human tone. Cuts were made for this spare, 80-minute production, performed on the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise\u2019s smaller Studio stage, but Phaedra emerges as a defiant woman in a man\u2019s world. She pulls no punches: After declaring her husband, Theseus, \u201ca sodomite and an adulterer,\u201d she proceeds to explain why the bull her mother, Pasiphae, mated with was a better lover than him.\n\nIt\u2019s a startling moment, as is her cunning manipulation of her nurse (played by the excellent Claude Mathieu), usually recognized as one of Racine\u2019s great Machiavellian confidantes. As Phaedra, Jennifer Decker was languor itself, with a callous side: She is very much in charge as she seduces Hippolytus, then lies to Theseus upon his surprise return. Only N\u00e2zim Boudjenah seemed miscast as the young Hippolytus. His lack of chemistry with Ms. Decker robbed Ms. Vignaud\u2019s production of some of the simmering tension that was clearly intended. Still, she has the instincts of an original director: She is one to follow.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nElsewhere, the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise troupe took to one of its other two stages, the Th\u00e9\u00e2tre du Vieux-Colombier, with another play inspired by a legend, albeit a German one: Goethe\u2019s \u201cFaust.\u201d Its duo of directors, Valentine Losseau and Rapha\u00ebl Navarro, are both magicians; in the early 2000s, they were co-founders of the \u201cnew magic\u201d movement, which aimed to strip illusion-based theater of its outdated conventions.\n\nThey trained the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise cast in their craft for the occasion, and the result is visually astonishing. The opening scene, in which Mephistopheles the devil visits God and bets on the fate of the erudite Dr. Faust, sees both these supernatural beings hovering in the air on invisible chairs, as if freed from gravity. The role of Mephistopheles is a true gift to Christian Hecq, one of the most distinctive character actors at the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise. Weightless and buoyant, he turned his tricks into sly, superlative comedy.\n\nMs. Losseau and Mr. Navarro\u2019s direction is less compelling when no special effects are required. While Laurent Natrella made a fine, restless Faust, his seduction of Marguerite and her subsequent downfall lacked potency. An appearance by the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise director \u00c9ric Ruf, who harangued the audience as himself in an introduction to the performance, proved a memorable addition, but Goethe\u2019s 19th-century play is often more heavy-handed, in moral terms, than Seneca\u2019s Roman-era take on a Greek myth. On stage, historical distance often means nothing: Dramatic relevance can emerge when you least expect it.", "title": "Ancient Tales for Modern Times", "authors": ["Laura Cappelle"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 I\u2019m not sure what this says about me, but one of the things that I appreciate most in crossword puzzles is a secretly subversive theme.\n\nIt\u2019s not clear if that was Bruce Haight\u2019s intention, but it solved that way for me and made me laugh. You\u2019ll see why when we talk about the theme.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nThe vast majority of the clues were very straightforward, this being Monday, but I thought I\u2019d help some of our younger solvers with 44D.\n\nHi, kids! \u201cThe Dick Van Dyke Show\u201d was a hit network (ask your folks) television show that ran from 1961 to 1966 on CBS. Dick Van Dyke (please tell me your parents sat you down and made you watch \u201cMary Poppins\u201d; he was Bert, the chimney sweep) starred as Rob Petrie, a fictional television writer on the fictional \u201cAlan Brady Show.\u201d As an aside, Alan Brady was played by the comedian Carl Reiner, who created the show, and has also been a guest blogger here. Mary Tyler Moore (please tell me you know who she is) co-starred as Petrie\u2019s TV WIFE, Laura, and was in charge of dangerous ottoman placement:\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nListen, it\u2019s no secret that there are a lot of men making and editing our puzzles. As members of the estrogen-festooned half of our species, I and others of my ilk sometimes get tired of seeing the entries BRA and A, B or C CUPs in our puzzles, with no balance in terms of men\u2019s undergarment entries. We have never seen the entry JOCK, for example, clued as an undergarment, although JOCKSTRAP was used once \u2014 and only once \u2014 back in 2010.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo I had to suppress an evil giggle when I solved Mr. Haight\u2019s puzzle, because it is basically a goofy foray into the world of men\u2019s underwear. Of course, both men and women can wear these items, but given that the constructor is a man, I read it as men\u2019s garments. And while it\u2019s only one puzzle, it felt good to see that. So to speak.", "title": "And Underwear for All", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cJust lettin\u2019 it fly and not thinking too much.\u201d\n\nThose were the words Andre Ingram said at center court after he easily beat Jimmer Fredette in the finals of the N.B.A. development league\u2019s 3-point contest in 2016.\n\nBefore this week, that contest, in which Ingram sank 39 of his 50 shots in a half-empty arena in Toronto, represented one of the high points of a long and consistent career for one of the mainstays of a league that rarely gets romanticized in the way that baseball\u2019s minor leagues often are.\n\nBut after years of hard work, and a development-league record 713 career 3-pointers, \u201clettin\u2019 it fly and not thinking too much\u201d paid off when Ingram, at the grizzled-by-N.B.A.-standards age of 32, was told on Monday that he had been promoted from the South Bay Lakers to the Los Angeles Lakers for the final two games of the regular season. (\u201cI won\u2019t go away, there is a lot more I will say,\u201d she wrote in one.) But as the #MeToo movement against sexual abuse has gained influence, women who have agreed to settlements with powerful men \u2014 including Harvey Weinstein, Bill O\u2019Reilly and Donald J. Trump \u2014 have broken their nondisclosure agreements, arguing that speaking out was more important.\n\nMs. Constand\u2019s lawyer, Dolores Troiani, said by phone on Friday that she and her client were evaluating their options and the enforceability of the contract with Mr. Cosby.\n\n\u201cObviously everyone in the world has sent me an email or text, but we\u2019re just stepping back and seeing where we\u2019re going to go,\u201d Ms. Troiani said, referring to the extensive media requests for interviews with Ms. Constand. \u201cI think we\u2019re taking a breather, for one.\u201d\n\nAt a news conference after the verdict on Thursday, Ms. Constand stood by, letting the Montgomery County district attorney, Kevin Steele, and Kristen Gibbons Feden, the special prosecutor on the case, speak about its importance.\n\nMr. Steele commended Ms. Constand for fighting through two trials. \u201cShe has been a major factor in a movement that has gone in the right direction, finally,\u201d he said.", "title": "Andrea Constand Makes First Statement Since Bill Cosby\u2019s Conviction: \u2018Truth Prevails\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany arrives at the White House on Friday in the broad wake of a visit this week by the French president, Emmanuel Macron. But don\u2019t expect a sequel to the buddy movie. Already, the contrasts could not be starker.\n\nMr. Macron was treated by President Trump to a 21-gun salute, a state dinner, a night of opera and a private visit to the home of George Washington. The public displays of affection between the two men were so gushy that they became the butt of jokes \u2014 even by Mr. Macron when, by the way, he addressed a joint session of Congress.\n\nOn the schedule for Ms. Merkel? A working lunch.\n\nThe last time Ms. Merkel met Mr. Trump at the White House, in March 2017, the two did not even manage to shake hands before assembled photographers. Few expect their rapport to be much different this time.\n\nBut the lack of chemistry between Ms. Merkel, a scientist who grew up in communist East Germany, and Mr. Trump, a billionaire with a weakness for beauty pageants, is not new. What is new is the apparent indifference in the White House to the German chancellor, as well as the weakening of Ms. Merkel\u2019s once towering position.", "title": "Angela Merkel Is Next to Visit Trump, Skipping the Bonhomie", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "The Los Angeles Angels arrived in Kansas City this weekend leading the major leagues in runs scored, hits, home runs and total bases. They were the first team in the American League to reach 10 victories.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s too early to draw conclusions,\u201d said their general manager, Billy Eppler, though he had to concede the obvious. \u201cIt beats some of the other outcomes. But we\u2019re just trying to stay beholden to our process, that\u2019s it.\u201d\n\nThe Angels\u2019 process has been the most scrutinized in baseball this season, at least in how it relates to Shohei Ohtani, the rookie from Japan who has starred at the plate and on the mound. The Angels have pitched Ohtani only on Sundays, with his third start scheduled against the Royals at Kauffman Stadium. He has made several starts as the designated hitter, but hasn\u2019t been a hitter in the games before, when, or after he pitches.\n\nAs a two-way force, Ohtani is trying to do something no player has done in almost a century. That gives the Angels no clear template for how to use him, and they are choosing a cautious approach. Ohtani\u2019s early success \u2014 three home runs in his first three games as a hitter, victories in his first two games as a pitcher \u2014 has not tempted them to use him more often.", "title": "Angels Are Reborn, and Not Just Because of Shohei Ohtani", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mrs. Chennault was one of the most visible private citizens in Washington: a vice president of the Flying Tiger Line, a cargo line founded by Robert Prescott, a pilot who had flown with her husband during the war; a writer of novels, poetry and nonfiction books; a Voice of America broadcaster; and the center of a social whirl at her Watergate penthouse that drew in cabinet members, congressmen, diplomats, foreign dignitaries and journalists.\n\nBut there was a hidden side to Mrs. Chennault\u2019s affairs, historians say. She was known to have been a conduit for Nationalist Chinese funds for the Republican Party, and to have been a secret go-between for American officials and Asian leaders like Chiang Kai-shek, the Nationalist Chinese generalissimo, and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam.\n\nAnd in a contretemps of international intrigue and presidential politics that generated heated debate for years, Mrs. Chennault was recorded on an F.B.I. wiretap helping to sabotage a peace initiative during the Vietnam War in order to promote Nixon\u2019s victory over Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey in the 1968 presidential election.\n\nSoon after President Lyndon B. Johnson announced a halt to the bombing of North Vietnam to ease the way for Paris peace talks that fall, Mrs. Chennault, a behind-the-scenes liaison for Nixon\u2019s campaign and the Saigon government, was overheard urging South Vietnamese officials to boycott the Paris peace talks, saying they would get a better deal from a Nixon administration if they waited until after the election.", "title": "Anna Chennault, Behind-the-Scenes Force in Washington, Dies at 94", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDr. Anna Marie Ward and Dr. Daniel Mark Frendl were married April 7 at the Paradise Valley Country Club in Paradise Valley, Ariz. Winthrop, a judge on the Arizona Court of Appeals, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 32, is an instructor in anesthesia at Harvard Medical School and a practicing anesthesiologist at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She graduated from the University of California, Berkeley and received a medical degree from the University of Arizona College of Medicine, Phoenix.\n\nShe is the daughter of Pamela Thomas Ward and Dr. John Alfred Dudley Ward of Paradise Valley. The bride\u2019s father retired as a plastic surgeon in private practice in Scottsdale, Ariz. Her mother is a retired business manager, also in Scottsdale.\n\nThe groom, 31, is a resident in the Harvard Urologic Surgery Residency Program at the Massachusetts General Hospital. He graduated from Duke and received a medical degree and a doctor of philosophy from the University of Massachusetts.\n\nHe is a son of Dr. Gyongyi Szabo and Dr. Gyorgy Frendl of Southborough, Mass. The playwright Tony Kushner, a Universal Life minister, officiated. Until 2014, the groom worked as Mr. Kushner\u2019s assistant in New York.\n\nMs. Blackstock-Bernstein, 31, is pursuing a doctorate in human development and psychology in the department of education at the University of California, Los Angeles, from which she received a master\u2019s degree in the same subject. Until 2012, she worked as a research assistant at Weill Cornell Medical College in New York. She graduated magna cum laude from Brandeis with a degree in psychology, sociology and education studies.\n\nShe is the daughter of Ann Blackstock and Joel Bernstein of New York. The bride\u2019s father is an actor now appearing as Warren Boyd, the concertmaster in \u201cMozart in the Jungle,\u201d a comedy-drama Amazon web series filmed in the New York area. Her mother is a freelance photographer based in New York.\n\nMr. Warren, also 31, is a television writer/producer currently for \u201cLethal Weapon,\u201d a Fox comedy-drama series based on the movie by the same name. He graduated summa cum laude from Northwestern with a degree in theater and a certificate in creative writing for the media.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe is a son of Sandi R. Michaelson and Jeffrey C Warren, both of Fairfield, Conn. The groom\u2019s mother is the vice president for foundation partnerships at Save the Children, a global humanitarian organization for children, in Fairfield. His father is an actuarial consultant based in Fairfield.\n\nA mutual friend introduced the couple at a party in New York in 2010. Neither Ms. Blackstock-Bernstein nor Mr. Warren, however, recalled meeting the summer of 1999 at the Center for Talented Youth at Mount Holyoke College, where they were part of a 12-person class Model U.N. and Advanced Geography.", "title": "Anne Blackstock-Bernstein, Kyle Warren", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "23andMe has partnerships with lots of third parties. Has the Facebook/Cambridge Analytica scandal given you any second thoughts about how you share data with other companies? I have to say, because we\u2019re regulated, it\u2019s a very different world for us than it is for Facebook. I think that one of the benefits is that it made us go a little bit slower. It\u2019s an extra step of checkpoints about how you\u2019re doing things.\n\nAnne Wojcicki is a co-founder and the chief executive of 23andMe, a genomics company. Age: 44 Occupation: Chief executive Hometown: Los Altos, Calif. Her Top 5 science-fiction films: 1. \u201cWonder Woman\u201d (2017) 2. \u201cE.T.\u201d 3. \u201cBack to the Future\u201d 4. \u201cJurassic Park\u201d 5. \u201cThe Matrix\u201d\n\nThe site uses your DNA to match you with other relatives in the 23andMe database. How often do you hear about people who discover they\u2019re actually adopted or have a secret sibling? Every day. Every day. The nonpaternity average in this country is much higher than people think it is. There\u2019s a good chance there\u2019s an \u201cUncle Joe\u201d in your family who\u2019s actually just \u201cJoe.\u201d So everyone has a story like that; they just don\u2019t necessarily know it. In the early days, we wondered: How are we going to handle this? And in some ways, I think we\u2019ve helped normalize it.\n\nThe most popular things that people search for alongside your name are \u201cnet worth,\u201d \u201cA-Rod\u201d and \u201cAlex Rodriguez.\u201d Why do you think people find your former relationship with A-Rod so fascinating? In some ways it\u2019s a lot like genetics: On the outside we seem very different. On the inside, there were a lot of similarities. I have a lot of respect for him. There\u2019s people in the world who talk a lot about what they want to do, and there\u2019s people who do it. And that boy, he goes after the world with a voracious appetite.\n\nCan I ask you about whether gene stuff that happened in movies will ever happen in real life? Sure.\n\nWith gene engineering available to only the wealthy, society will break down into two social classes, the modified and the unmodified. That\u2019s \u201cGattaca.\u201d No. By the time there\u2019s really gene-editing ability, it\u2019s going to be accessible to the majority of the population. Also, I think we\u2019re a ways off from actually knowing how to modify. The human body is spectacularly complex beyond anything you could imagine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWill we ever bring a dinosaur back to life? I don\u2019t think that\u2019s feasible. But those are the things I dream about. Maybe I\u2019ll think about that tonight instead of monetizing prevention.", "title": "Anne Wojcicki Wants to Be Healthy at 100", "authors": ["Dan Amira"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "About half of the city\u2019s 1,800 schools will share in the new money, and while the $125 million is significant, it is not a game changer. If every school received the same amount, each would see a boost of about $146,000, but that\u2019s not how the money will be allocated. Funding varies based on enrollment as well as factors like how many students in a given school have special education needs or are still learning to speak English. Schools in the city\u2019s Renewal program, for its lowest performing institutions, are already funded at 100 percent of the formula.\n\n\u201cAs a longtime principal, let me tell you this: Every dollar counts,\u201d said Philip Santos, the principal of Leadership and Public Service High School in Manhattan. \u201cWe\u2019re already making plans. Leadership and Public Service needs a full-time college counselor, and these additional funds can pay for it.\u201d\n\nThe total education department budget for this year is about $30 billion.\n\nAfter a parade of local lawmakers took their turns praising the new funds and gleefully swiping at Albany, Mr. de Blasio answered questions from reporters, during which he wandered into his statement on sexual harassment. While politically it was undoubtedly a misstep as the country grapples with the #MeToo movement, the mayor, perhaps inadvertently, gave voice to concerns about the way investigations are used as weapons within the city\u2019s schools.\n\nHe said, \u201cI\u2019m also trying to be honest about something that is different at D.O.E. than a lot of other places, and it\u2019s a pretty well-known thing in the educational world. Some people inappropriately make complaints for other reasons. I\u2019m not even sure it\u2019s ever about sexual harassment. But it is unfortunately a part of the culture and it has to be addressed separately.\u201d\n\nHe went on to talk about \u201culterior motives\u201d that might drive complaints in the schools.\n\nIn 2017, there were 1,932 complaints of all kinds made against principals or assistant principals to the city\u2019s Special Commissioner of Investigations, the office that investigates corruption and criminal activity in city schools, compared with 870 complaints in 2007. Principals brought in to improve struggling schools can be confronted with a cascade of allegations.\n\nThe Special Commissioner\u2019s office has been embroiled in its own turmoil in recent months. The office has long had a degree of independence, but earlier this year, Mark G. Peters, the city\u2019s investigations commissioner, tried to seize control of the unit. Mr. Peters, who was once Mr. de Blasio\u2019s campaign treasurer but is now feuding with the mayor, installed a new special commissioner only to fire her a few weeks later when she pushed back against efforts to limit the office\u2019s independence.", "title": "Announcing $125 Million for Schools, de Blasio Stumbles Over #MeToo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "That makes it impossible for city officials to aim scarce resources at the most problematic owners. And it makes it hard for researchers to know, for example, if property has become concentrated among fewer owners.\n\nBecause the stakes are so high and the spillovers significant, there has always been a public element to private property, said Susan Pace Hamill, a law professor at the University of Alabama who has written about L.L.C.s since the late 1980s.\n\n\u201cShould tenants have a right to know who they\u2019re renting from?\u201d she said. \u201cShould cities have a right to know who owns the property? The answer is a resounding yes.\u201d\n\nL.L.C.s today hide what should be public information, she argues.\n\n\u201cI am quite disturbed by that,\u201d she said. \u201cHaving participated in the evolution of L.L.C.s from their early days, I feel like they\u2019re being abused.\u201d\n\nWyoming passed the first L.L.C. statute in 1977 at the prodding of oil and gas interests, creating an entity with the liability protections of a corporation without the tax responsibilities of one. Hardly anyone took advantage of the tool, and few states followed until the I.R.S. blessed L.L.C.s a decade later. They then quickly became the entity of choice for all kinds of businesses, and by the mid-1990s, all 50 states had L.L.C. laws.\n\nIn Milwaukee, according to research by a Harvard doctoral student, Adam Travis, L.L.C.s have grown to about a quarter of the rental market in the two decades since they became legal in the state.\n\nThe original idea was never specifically about real estate, and anonymity wasn\u2019t particularly the appeal. But over time, Ms. Hamill said, state laws have made it easier to conceal who\u2019s behind L.L.C.s. So they have simultaneously grown more common and less transparent.", "title": "Anonymous Owner, L.L.C.: Why It Has Become So Easy to Hide in the Housing Market", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. Some players kneel in prayer after a big play, and often pray together at the center of the field with opposing players after the game.\n\nWare is demanding arbitration from the Florida commission, and she also requested a hearing with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell.", "title": "Another Former N.F.L. Cheerleader Files a Complaint", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "The record-setting $35.5 million capitalization \u2014 the amount raised from producers and investors to pay an unusually large cast and crew, rehearse an unusually long show and build an unusually elaborate production \u2014 was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. By comparison, most nonmusical plays on Broadway are between $3 million and $5 million, and even the splashiest musicals rarely top more than $25 million.\n\nBut the capitalization is only a portion of what it took to pave the way for \u201cCursed Child\u201d to get to Broadway.\n\nThe Ambassador Theater Group, the British theater giant that operates the Lyric, spent about $23 million to persuade its previous occupant, Cirque du Soleil, to shutter its \u201cParamour\u201d musical and make way for \u201cCursed Child,\u201d according to two people with knowledge of the transaction.\n\nPhoto\n\nAmbassador, which competed with other Broadway landlords to woo \u201cCursed Child,\u201d overhauled the Lyric at the behest of the play\u2019s producers. A charmless barn of a theater (previously home to a series of flops, including the $75 million musical \u201cSpider-Man: Turn Off the Dark\u201d), it was reconfigured to feel more like an old-fashioned opera house, with a vaulted ceiling, a necklace of boxes, and 1,622 seats (down from 1,896). Even the entrance was relocated, from crowded 42nd Street to the less dense 43rd Street.\n\nThe work on the building was expected to cost about $10 million, according to documents filed with the New York City Department of Buildings.\n\nThe play, a two-part experience with a running time of more than five hours, is a sequel to the series of young adult fantasy novels written by J.K. Rowling about a boy wizard. \u201cCursed Child\u201d takes place 19 years after the final book, at a time when Harry and his friends have become parents.\n\n\u201cCursed Child\u201d was written by Jack Thorne, based on a story by Mr. Thorne, Ms. Rowling and the director John Tiffany. It was developed in Britain and has been sold out in London\u2019s West End for 22 months, and last year it won a record nine Olivier awards \u2014 the British equivalent of the Tonys \u2014 including one for best play. A third production, in Melbourne, Australia, is scheduled to open next year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn response to questions about the show\u2019s finances, two of the lead producers, Sonia Friedman and Colin Callender, offered a tour of the renovated theater. Strolling through the theater, they showed off phoenix sconces and dragon lanterns and a lobby wall featuring prints of patronuses (silvery animal guardians).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe color scheme is rich and dark \u2014 most of the walls are painted a color called raven plume \u2014 and a custom carpet features H monograms (for Hogwarts, Harry\u2019s alma mater). The newly adorned exterior features giant wings and large sculptures of a child (symbol alert!) trapped in a nest.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to create a mood, without crossing a line into theme park,\u201d Mr. Callender said. Ms. Friedman added, \u201cIt was really important to us that the lobbies and the front-of-house had the atmosphere of the Harry Potter world, because this is the beginning of the audience\u2019s experience.\u201d\n\nMs. Friedman, who has been vocal about the high cost of working on Broadway, said that the play has cost significantly more to mount in New York than in London. Labor, marketing and theater rentals all tend to cost more in New York.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI find the costs here difficult to comprehend,\u201d Ms. Friedman said. \u201cIt\u2019s a number I do not like.\u201d\n\nBut she also said that particular aspects of \u201cCursed Child\u201d make it expensive. A play in two parts required twice as much time to rehearse; the show\u2019s elaborate illusions required significant substage mechanics and extra training. It took 16 weeks just to load the show\u2019s set elements into the theater.\n\nInvestment documents filed with the New York attorney general\u2019s office offer a rough breakdown of the capitalization, including $11.7 million for the physical production, $7.8 million for \u201cgeneral and administrative\u201d costs, including the design and signage of the facade, $3.4 million for advertising and publicity and $3.2 million for salaries.\n\nThat money goes to pay a cast and crew that is much bigger than for most plays. According to Ms. Friedman and Mr. Callender, a shop crew of 220 people was assembled to build and install the scenery and lighting and costumes. The show has 40 actors, a stage crew of 26, some 16 people assigned to wardrobe and hair and 5 stage managers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very obvious where the money went \u2014 the whole theater has been transformed to fit the show, and the level of technical expertise is like nothing I\u2019ve ever seen on Broadway,\u201d said Jonathon Rosenthal, a 38-year-old I.T. consultant from the Bronx who runs a Harry Potter meet-up group and who saw the play on Broadway earlier this month. \u201cIt looks like there is magic going on on the stage.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Broadway production is already largely sold out through next March, although there are periodic releases of more tickets, including some low-priced ones every Friday. Each part of the show had a recent average ticket price of $164.83 and a top price of $286.50; 300 seats per performance cost $40 or less. The two parts can be seen on the same day or consecutive days.\n\nAmong the biggest beneficiaries will be Ms. Rowling. The investment papers do not detail her compensation, but say that the \u201cunderlying rights owner, licensor and their affiliates\u201d \u2014 a group that includes Ms. Rowling \u2014 will initially receive 31 percent of the play\u2019s net profits, and that cut will eventually rise to 41 percent as the show moves deeper into profitability. Ms. Rowling can profit from the play in other ways as well; she is the third lead producer, through her company Harry Potter Theatrical Productions.\n\nHer deal appears to be more lucrative than the ones negotiated by other prose writers whose work was the basis of a Broadway show. Harper Lee, before her death, signed an agreement giving her 2.5 percent of the net profits, plus an author royalty, for a coming stage adaptation of \u201cTo Kill a Mockingbird\u201d (that money will now go to her estate), while Ron Chernow, the author of a biography of Alexander Hamilton, gets 1 percent of the adjusted grosses from \u201cHamilton.\u201d\n\nThe comparisons, however, are imperfect. Fiction writers generally get a bigger share of profits than do writers of nonfiction, since the novelists actually dream up their characters. And, unlike \u201cMockingbird,\u201d \u201cCursed Child\u201d is not adapted from a novel \u2014 it is a new story, created for the stage.", "title": "Another Harry Potter Landmark: At $68 Million, the Most Expensive Broadway Nonmusical Play Ever", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Yankees Manager Aaron Boone employed a novel line of reasoning to explain why Sonny Gray, the No. 3 starter in his pitching rotation, had struggled so much in his first four starts of this season.\n\n\u201cI think a lot of it has to do with his talent,\u201d Boone said before Gray faced the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday night at Yankee Stadium. \u201cHe gets great movement on his pitches, he\u2019s got really good stuff, he\u2019s able to do things not a lot of guys are able to do. I sometimes feel it\u2019s a case of, he feels like he can always make the perfect pitch.\u201d\n\nIt was a euphemistic way of saying Gray\u2019s pitching had been less than aggressive. Or, in baseball parlance, he was nibbling.\n\n\u201cHe needs to go out and attack hitters,\u201d Boone said. \u201cAnd I think success will follow.\u201d\n\nIn an effort to help Gray find that success, Boone on Wednesday matched him with Austin Romine, the Yankees\u2019 backup catcher with whom Gray has performed markedly better than with Gary Sanchez, the starting catcher. It also helped that Gray was throwing to the Twins, who over the past 16 seasons have been a reliable punching bag for the Yankees.", "title": "Another Middling Outing by Sonny Gray Is Enough for the Yankees", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA Shooting at YouTube\u2019s Offices Rattles Silicon Valley\u201d (news article, April 4):\n\nThe shooting on Tuesday at YouTube\u2019s headquarters in California is among the latest to draw the attention of the national news media since the Parkland, Fla., school shooting, and was accompanied by the usual \u201cthoughts and prayers.\u201d\n\nCountless deaths continue to be routine in inner cities and receive much less attention.\n\nThe terms \u201cactive shooter,\u201d \u201cshooting survivor,\u201d \u201clone shooter,\u201d \u201cmass shooting,\u201d \u201clockdown,\u201d \u201cmagazine\u201d and \u201cbump stock\u201d have sadly become part of our lexicon.\n\nThe numbing of Americans to gun violence is unique to our country, and the inaction by Congress to protect us is a national tragedy.\n\nFELICE BUSTO\n\nOCEAN GROVE, N.J.", "title": "Opinion | Another Shooting Tragedy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAn enormous, globally diverse food festival called World\u2019s Fare, which is meant to recall the world\u2019s fairs that were held in Flushing, Queens, decades ago, will move into the parking lot of Citi Field this month. Some culinary heavy-hitters like Claus Meyer, Jessica B. Harris and the street food expert K.F. Seetoh of Singapore are helping to set the lineup of 100 or so chefs, food vendors and restaurants that will participate. Craft breweries, art and music are part of it. Tickets, from $19 to $199 are now available: World\u2019s Fare, April 28 and 29, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m., Citi Field, 123-01 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens; theworldsfare.nyc.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Another World\u2019s Fair Heads to Queens, This One for Foodies", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The result is a confusion that turned the past week into a theater of the absurd after Mr. Corbyn was slammed in the British press for attending a Seder hosted by a far-left, but unmistakably Jewish, group called Jewdas. Jewdas calls itself non-Zionist, and it revels in the history of the radical Jewish diaspora; during the Seder, participants sang Yiddish songs cursing the police (in addition to observing more traditional Passover rituals).\n\nThis group was then denounced by the president of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, Jonathan Arkush, as \u201ca source of virulent anti-Semitism.\u201d The board, which has claimed to speak for British Jewry since the 18th century, usually keeps its head down and avoids the headlines. In the 1930s, it held back as other Jewish groups, mostly on the left, led the struggle against a nascent fascist movement on the streets of London. An inglorious role, perhaps, but one that has allowed the Board of Deputies to appear nonpartisan and impartial.\n\nNot this time. Interviewed on TV, Mr. Arkush opined that Jewdas\u2019s members \u201care not all Jewish,\u201d as if he were in a position to make authoritative pronouncements on the subject.\n\nWe are back in the usual arena of communal politics in which notables bandy writs of excommunication as a means of confirming their own authority. What happened to keeping shtum? Is fighting Jewdas really a priority in the struggle against anti-Semitism?\n\nIn this business no one comes out well \u2014 neither Mr. Corbyn nor his critics. But the lack of perspective and insight that both sides have demonstrated ultimately have less to tell us about anti-Semitism than they do about the diminished state of British politics. Is anti-Semitism a real issue in Britain? Yes. Is it worse for the Labour Party than for others? The evidence suggests not. Is it the most serious manifestation of racial prejudice facing the country? By no means. Muslims have it much worse than Jews, and Eastern European and other immigrants have also been the targets of far-right violence, especially since the referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nIn Brexit, Britain faces the most consequential foreign policy decision of the past half-century, one that will transform the country\u2019s position in the world. So far, the government has handled the negotiations like amateurs. Faced with a hostile use of deadly nerve agents on its own territory, the foreign secretary, Boris Johnson, has responded with his characteristic lack of professionalism. If this is how the country\u2019s political elite tackles issues of such gravity, can we be surprised at how Mr. Corbyn, no less parochial in his way than his Conservative opponents, has fumbled his own internal crisis \u2014 and how the news media have fanned the flames?\n\nI am not sure that my grandfather would have seen much change in the Labour Party. The ongoing clash within its ranks between moderates and radicals would have been familiar to him. Nor would he have been very surprised to find prejudice extending left as well as right: This would not have affected his preference for the party of social justice. And since, as a Bundist, he had grown up in opposition to Zionism (Bundists and Zionists were locked in ideological combat from their birth onward), he would have regarded pretty searching criticism of Israel as a far more normal part of the political landscape than most people do today.\n\nBut he could only have been disappointed at the immense change in the country that took him in, in Britain itself, losing its way in a hall of mirrors, distracted by secondary issues while the country\u2019s fate hangs in the balance.", "title": "Opinion | Anti-Semitism and Britain\u2019s Hall of Mirrors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cBritish Labour and the \u2018Jewish Question\u2019 \u201d (Op-Ed, April 9):\n\nAs Jews across the globe prepare to commemorate the Holocaust on Yom Hashoah, I must take issue with Mark Mazower\u2019s characterization of anti-Semitism in Britain.\n\nThat Britain\u2019s left may be more or less anti-Semitic than Britain\u2019s right is entirely beside the point. To quibble about whose brand of anti-Semitism is slightly less virulent is to minimize the odiousness of \u201cthe world\u2019s oldest hatred.\u201d\n\nOur time would be better spent unequivocally repudiating anti-Semitism from all precincts.\n\n(RABBI) YOSIE LEVINE, NEW YORK", "title": "Opinion | Anti-Semitism in Britain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "BARCELONA, Spain \u2014 A long hail of whistles and jeers from a crowd numbering in the tens of thousands might not be the most articulate way to express a political opinion, Arnau Pans acknowledged with a shrug. But, in his eyes, it can serve a purpose.\n\nPans, 24, is a die-hard fan of the soccer club F.C. Barcelona and, like many such fans, an active supporter of the Catalan independence movement. On Saturday, for the fifth consecutive year, Barcelona \u2014 the most high-profile of Catalan institutions \u2014 will appear in the final of the Copa del Rey, the oldest soccer tournament in Spain. And for the fifth straight year, that means questions about free expression and the boundaries of political etiquette are being debated as vehemently this week as questions about team tactics and lineups.\n\nThe final of the Copa del Rey \u2014 the King\u2019s Cup \u2014 is the only occasion in Spanish club soccer that features the playing of the national anthem. So for the past several years, that brief ritual has given fans of Barcelona who sympathize with the independence cause the chance to whistle and jeer the song \u2014 and the royalty in attendance \u2014 with impunity, subverting the stately ritual and exasperating their critics.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a way to show the world that something\u2019s happening in Spain, in Catalonia,\u201d Pans, a graduate student, said last Saturday outside Camp Nou, Barcelona\u2019s home stadium. \u201cWe know whistling the anthem is not a solution. But it\u2019s a way to open the situation to the world.\u201d", "title": "Anticipating Anthem Protests, Spain Braces for \u2018Verbal Violence\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "In a widely read article on antidepressant withdrawal published on April 8, The New York Times invited readers to describe their experiences coming off the drugs. More than 8,800 people responded \u2014 teenagers, college students, new mothers, empty-nesters, retirees.\n\nDozens did write in to say the drugs had been lifesaving, literally so. \u201cYou fail to acknowledge that mood disorders can be lifelong, debilitating diseases requiring lifelong medical treatment,\u201d wrote Rachel S., of New York.\n\nA different kind of reader query would most likely have attracted thousands of responses of gratitude for drugs that offered relief to tens of millions of people with chronic mood problems. Some doctors chimed in, too, more than one calling our focus on withdrawal irresponsible and unduly alarming to those who might benefit from antidepressants.\n\nThe volume and diversity of the other responses painted a different picture, showing how modern antidepressants, beginning with Prozac in 1987, have percolated through our culture and have shaped public understanding of mental health. These stories traced sharp demographic fault lines: Readers of different generations came to antidepressants, and tried to quit them, for different reasons.", "title": "Antidepressants and Withdrawal: Readers Tell Their Stories", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "On the days it doesn\u2019t come so easily, you can fill the white space with you. Who is to say where Picasso ends and Mr. Banderas begins? Who can give that information now that he\u2019s prepared for this role three separate times?\n\nKenneth Biller, a creator of the show, and Ron Howard, an executive producer, immediately thought of Mr. Banderas for the role. They worried that they\u2019d have to convince him to play the part, but he jumped up (pop!) and agreed to do it. He had recently happened upon the first season of \u201cGenius,\u201d with Geoffrey Rush as Albert Einstein, while cruising on his Apple TV. He watched the whole thing in two days.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cGenius: Picasso,\u201d which takes place over 10 episodes, is shot during two eras: Picasso\u2019s youth, and his old age. In his younger days, he is played by Alex Rich, who does a Picasso impression that is actually an Antonio Banderas impression. The camera follows Mr. Rich to show the freneticism of youth. But during the old age scenes, the camera stays still, like a portrait with Mr. Banderas entering and leaving it. In those scenes, it\u2019s Mr. Banderas who supplies the energy.\n\nHow wonderful. How wonderful to find in your late 50s a character that\u2019s been so meaningful. You can maybe understand that after all the years of masks and tangos and needing to drip with Andalusian lust, it\u2019s nice to play someone who is considered a genius. Oh yes, it is nice to finally play someone who has touched greatness.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nHAD MR. BANDERAS stayed in Spain, this would have been an entirely different story. He would have continued on the path Mr. Almod\u00f3var had set for him, playing men with depth and inner lives. But he didn\u2019t \u2014 he couldn\u2019t.\n\nHe grew up going to the theater with his parents: plays by Lope de Vega, Pedro Calder\u00f3n de la Barca. He marveled at theater as an act of civilization. \u201cIt was so beautiful,\u201d he said. \u201cWe are all here and we have an agreement. We\u2019re going to sit down here and you\u2019re going to tell me a story and you have to make me believe it. And I thought, \u2018This is [expletive] magical.\u2019\u201d He wanted to be on the other side of the theater. He wanted to be onstage.\n\nBut his parents had seen how artists were treated under the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco. Many were exiled. His mother was distraught. \u201cDon\u2019t be an actor,\u201d she pleaded. \u201cBe something dignified.\u201d He thought maybe he\u2019d be a soccer player instead.\n\nThen in 1976, the year after Franco died, an American theater company came through M\u00e1laga with \u201cHair\u201d and it was just over for Mr. Banderas. \u201cOh, my God. What is this? What is this beard and this long hair and this freedom?,\u201d he remembered thinking. He told his parents, \u201cI have to do this. I have to do this type of theater. This is theater that is revolutionary.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1981, while sitting at Caf\u00e9 Gij\u00f3n in Madrid, a man with a red briefcase held court telling funny stories. Mr. Banderas had long hair and a mustache for a role in a play. The man looked at him and said: \u201cYou should do film cinema. You are very romantic and you have a romantic face.\u201d Mr. Banderas said, \u201cO.K. Cool.\u201d Afterward, he asked other patrons if anyone knew who the man was. \u201cThey said to me: \u2018He\u2019s called Pedro Almod\u00f3var. He made one movie\u2019\u201d \u2014 he had, in fact, already made two feature films and several shorts \u2014 \u201c\u2018but he\u2019s not going to make any more.\u2019\u201d\n\nTwo days later, Mr. Almod\u00f3var came to see Mr. Banderas in the play. In the dressing room afterward, he asked Mr. Banderas if he wanted to do a movie with him. \u201cSure,\u201d Mr. Banderas said. Their first movie was the 1982 comedy \u201cLabyrinth of Passion,\u201d in which he plays a terrorist.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey made six more movies together. He played complex, brooding men \u2014 people with souls. In Spain, for Mr. Almod\u00f3var, the soul was inherent in the character. Later, in the United States, working for American directors, Mr. Banderas had to create his characters\u2019 souls.\n\nHe had a choice. He could go back to Spain and work with great directors \u2014 the star system there revolves around auteurs, not actors \u2014 and there was no shortage of deep, complex roles for him.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis fellow Hispanic actors asked him, \u201cSo, are you going to stay in America?\u201d He told them, \u201cWell, I don\u2019t know. Maybe. Yeah.\u201d They told him, \u201cWell, if you stay here you\u2019re going to be the bad guy, number one.\u201d They told him he would only ever get cast as a member of a cartel or a gang.\n\nBut it was too late. By 1996, he was married to Melanie Griffith. They had a daughter, Stella. He had grown attached to his stepchildren. The question became one not of artistic fulfillment but of practicality. \u201cHow can I keep my career here? I\u2019m married here. I live here. I have to play here.\u201d\n\nAnd he loved America. \u201cThe culture here.\u201d He shimmered with delight. \u201cThere is something very beautiful about America, very innocent. Oh, yes. It\u2019s still new. It\u2019s innocent.\u201d\n\nI expressed some surprise. Over the course of my time in Hungary with him, we\u2019d gotten word of the mass school shooting in Parkland, Fla. America had become horrifying to me. \u201cYes,\u201d he said. \u201cBut you guys believe. You believe everything \u2014 even in this moment you believe.\u201d In Europe, he said, people are skeptical. There\u2019s the weight of history. But America, man. \u201cI love NASA. I love those institutions. And I remember visiting Houston and going there and me doing my eyes like this.\u201d He made his eyes big and full of disbelief.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd the innovation! \u201cThese people that invent Googles and Apples and all these companies, they put heart in the skies. Elon Musk doing this thing is unbelievable to me.\u201d\n\nSo he played what he called the \u201cexotic guy.\u201d His agent told him he\u2019d become more powerful the more he said no. \u201cBut,\u201d he would say. \u201cI have a problem here because I have to build a career almost handicapped.\u201d He knew he was offered jobs that weren\u2019t quite the best, jobs that had been offered to five or 10 actors before him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI cannot play in the same league as certain American actors because my accent didn\u2019t allow me just to play a banker from New York or an astronaut,\u201d he said. \u201cSo I have to be balancing. And it\u2019s almost like the guy in the circus that tried to keep all the plates going. And if he stops they fall. And so I did have to do in my career things that I wouldn\u2019t have done, yes.\u201d What could he do? \u201cIt was a desert for Spanish actors.\u201d\n\nBut lately, a strange thing started happening. He\u2019s not being asked to wear matador outfits anymore. At the ripe (but still extremely handsome) age of 57, the roles got better. \u201cThey have more weight, they are more complex, they are more profound and I enjoy more to play them because you can just actually find many different ways to play,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s almost like a pot and you can\u2019t stop putting things in. Before it was a uniform almost. They wanted the heroic, the epic, the guy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMaybe it\u2019s the Hispanic population coming of age, he wondered. Great numbers with advanced degrees and a real presence in cinema. \u201cNow it\u2019s normal to see at the Academy Awards Mexican directors taking Oscars, Spanish actors, actors from Puerto Rico.\u201d\n\nBut it could also be him. It could also be that there\u2019s something about transforming small caricatures into great, big, memorable characters. All that time working to stay in business \u2014 as opposed to working to keep up an image \u2014 paid off. He subverted America\u2019s attempts to objectify him. He took artistic risks. He became adept at infusing soul into one-note characters (I\u2019m talking what could have been a throwaway role in \u201cMiami Rhapsody;\u201d I\u2019m talking the Nasonex bee.)\n\nThat\u2019s the thing about Picasso: He was considered one of the greatest artists of the 20th century and he was also prolific. He wasn\u2019t cheap with his talents. He didn\u2019t think that to practice his art would be to drain the supply of his artistry. He knew that was not how greatness works.\n\n\n\nAT THE END of the day, Mr. Banderas sat in the makeup trailer as a woman applied glue remover to his head with a paintbrush, then pulled at the netting that hosted the white hair he\u2019d been wearing. She did the same for his eyebrows, where there was a shadow of stubble. They began to work their fingers at the silicone that covered his face. He liked to help free himself from it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Watching Get the most out of your screen time with movie and TV recommendations, news and commentary from New York Times experts. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Banderas lives in England now, in Surrey, about an hour southwest of London. He lives there with his girlfriend, Nicole Kimpel, an investment adviser he met at Cannes a few years ago.\n\nThe truth is, he doesn\u2019t need to be in America anymore. So many movie shoots are done in Europe now for tax reasons. And Ms. Kimpel has an identical twin sister who lives in Switzerland whom she can\u2019t bear to be too far away from.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat did he need to stay in the United States for anyway? His days of co-parenting are over. Stella is off at the University of Southern California, studying cinema. Of his divorce from Ms. Griffith in 2015 he says: \u201cMelanie is a very generous woman and an excellent mother and a great lover for many years. But there is a moment that things were not working and before we started damaging each other we just decided to take that option.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s the truth about why Antonio Banderas stayed in the States for so long. Yes, he got married. Yes, he loved NASA and the Googles. Yes, he loved our innocence. But you know what else? He won\u2019t say it, almost out of fealty to the country he was born in, but Ms. Hayek and Mr. Rodriguez will. In Spain, Ms. Hayek said, \u201cHe could not do some of the action movies. He\u2019d never been on Broadway.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Spain he could do a lot of interesting work. But in the U.S., he can be an action star, a comedy hero, a Nasonex bee, a spy dad. In Spain he could be in the theater, yes, but in America, he can be on Broadway. That year he was in \u201cNine?\u201d Mr. Banderas said it was his happiest time in America.\n\nThat\u2019s who Antonio Banderas is. \u201cHe\u2019s someone who wants to eat the world,\u201d Mr. Rodriguez told me.\n\nYou can\u2019t just eat the world from Europe, though. That\u2019s the thing about being an actor in America. When you\u2019re famous here, you\u2019re famous everywhere. Mr. Banderas stayed here because Spain simply wasn\u2019t big enough for him.\n\nIn Hungary, sitting in his makeup chair in the set of \u201cPicasso,\u201d Mr. Banderas said, \u201cIt\u2019s hard to look into the mirror and see a doddering old man.\u201d He didn\u2019t take his eyes off himself when he spoke. \u201cPicasso is 67 here. I\u2019m two-and-a-half years away from 60. It\u2019s not so far away.\u201d He tilted his head, evaluating his cheek. \u201cIt\u2019s scary to visit an age before you get there. But it\u2019s somehow even scarier when it\u2019s not that far away.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAbout a year ago, Mr. Banderas was preparing breakfast in his home when his arm began to hurt. He\u2019d had an arrhythmia issue for years, and one of his doctors in Los Angeles had told him he had a blockage in one of his arteries. He\u2019d been under a lot of stress recently \u2014 the divorce, the move. He filmed seven movies that year. He was smoking. The pain in his arm was faint, but suddenly he felt it in his jaw. That\u2019s when he knew: He was having a heart attack.\n\nHe was in the hospital for just a day. As the nurse, who was a fan, said goodbye to him, she said: \u201cAntonio, you\u2019re going to be very sad. For like a month or two months you\u2019ll be very sad because the hearts hold feelings. And you\u2019re going to feel like the world is crumbling around you. Don\u2019t worry because you can put it back where it was and be the happy person that you are and continue doing your work.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe didn\u2019t think much of it, but as he recuperated, he found that he couldn\u2019t shake his sadness. It engulfed him. It was like nothing he\u2019d ever felt before. \u201cSuddenly, you discover at your root level that it can be like in a second you can say goodbye.\u201d\n\nBut he\u2019s Antonio Banderas, so eventually the sadness made way for a different feeling: inspiration. He was still here. He was still here and he had so much left to do.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first script he read after his heart attack was \u201cLife Itself,\u201d written and directed by Dan Fogelman (\u201cThis Is Us\u201d). Mr. Banderas read to the last page and he knew he\u2019d found his next project, a drama about intersecting lives in Spain and America. He was offered the role of a \u201cnormal\u201d character \u2014 not a historical figure, not a masked avenger, not a slutty cat. Just a real man.\n\nDuring filming, he was different than usual. \u201cI was not so anxious about what is going to be the result of this, what is going to be their opinions. No, it was about me. It was \u2014 well, it\u2019s very genuine because actually I love this profession. What about that? I love this profession.\u201d\n\nAfter that, \u201cthings magically start happening. Picasso came walking into my life.\u201d\n\nThe silicone was now gone from his face. The hair was, too. He looked like a beautiful egg. Every day when the makeup came off, he was relieved to see that he was still there underneath. It\u2019s scary to get old. Maybe it\u2019s even scarier because you still have all the energy in the world, I suggested, and you feel like you haven\u2019t done the thing you\u2019ll be remembered for yet.\n\nHe smiled. I took him too literally, he said. It\u2019s not that he doesn\u2019t think he\u2019ll be remembered for what he\u2019s already done. It\u2019s just that \u2026 Did he tell me the story yet about what Dal\u00ed supposedly used to say? \u201cHe used to say, \u2018I am a very mediocre painter for the reason that I don\u2019t want to die. In fact, I am the best painter in the world but I don\u2019t paint a good painting because if I paint a good painting I will die the next day. So I prefer to be mediocre.\u2019\u201d\n\nHe gave me a combination [laughing with mouth open emoji] and [eyerolling emoji]. Ay, was Dal\u00ed crazy. Didn\u2019t he know? Dignity comes when it\u2019s required. Didn\u2019t he know? Greatness only gets greater the more it\u2019s practiced. Oh yes. That\u2019s how greatness works.", "title": "Antonio Banderas Doesn\u2019t Think You\u2019ll Remember Him. Not Yet.", "authors": ["Taffy Brodesser-Akner"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "With few encouraging gestures or initiatives from the White House, it is no surprise that Gallup reports only 16 percent of Latin Americans approve of Trump, a fraction of Mr. Obama\u2019s 62 percent first-year approval.\n\nFurther muddying the waters are the alarms raised by senior United States officials about China\u2019s expanding role in the region, which have stirred unpleasant memories of a long-past era when Washington considered Latin America its \u201cbackyard.\u201d Many in the region wonder whether the administration\u2019s new, more hawkish foreign policy team might resurrect the Monroe Doctrine, again giving the United States self-appointed authority to intrude on the region\u2019s sovereignty.\n\nWashington is already insisting that Latin America make the United States its \u201cpartner of choice,\u201d while simply ignoring that the region\u2019s economic and diplomatic ties are already globally diversified and China, not the United States, is South America\u2019s largest trading partner. Pursuing this path will be offensive even to such leaders as Argentina\u2019s Mauricio Macri and Chile\u2019s Sebastian Pi\u00f1era, successful entrepreneurs and now presidents.\n\nStill, despite the shared confusion and distrust about United States policies and intentions, nearly all Latin American governments have chosen a pragmatic approach to dealing with Washington, seeking to accommodate Trump\u2019s idiosyncrasies without caving in to his often exaggerated demands. They are not ready to risk an open breach and potentially lose the United States\u2019 huge, profitable market and access to its trade, investment and technology. But Mr. Trump\u2019s failure to show up in Lima will leave the region less secure about the future of United States-Latin American relations. Yes, it is good news that Vice President Mike Pence will be there, but he is not the same as having Mr. Trump. The Latin American presidents want the opportunity to engage the president of the United States, as their predecessors have had at every summit meeting of the past quarter-century.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s absence has reduced expectations that the United States and Latin America can find a way to effectively address the one issue where some signs of common ground can be discerned: the disaster engulfing Venezuela. This crisis of unprecedented proportions has, albeit belatedly, become the concern of almost every nation in the Americas. It poses the most crucial test of the hemisphere\u2019s capacity for join action, but so far it has produced only limited agreement. Mr. Trump\u2019s off-handed suggestion last August of a \u201cmilitary option\u201d was immediately rejected across the region.\n\nThe Lima gathering gives the hemisphere\u2019s heads of state a rare opportunity to discuss face-to-face what it will take to develop a sustained regional effort, which no government could mount by itself, to press hard on the Venezuelan regime to alter its destructive economic and social policies and allow for a meaningful political opening. Urgent action is also required by the region\u2019s nations to respond to the needs of an accelerating migration from Venezuela. In just the past two years, a million Venezuelans have fled their country. This is clearly no easy task, given the divisions among nations, the lack of United States-Latin American cooperation and Venezuela\u2019s fractured opposition.", "title": "Opinion | Anxiety at the Summit of the Americas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "As they grew up, with Simmons playing shortstop and Gregorius playing second base, they shared ambitions of reaching the big leagues.\n\n\u201cWhen you\u2019re a little kid and you\u2019re one of the two best players on your team, you think it\u2019s easy, you think it\u2019s possible,\u201d Simmons said. \u201cYou think, \u2018Yeah, I can be that guy.\u2019\n\n\u201cAs you get older, you see more talent and you start playing against them, you start being more realistic and you know how hard it is. Once you actually make it and you look back, it\u2019s pretty special.\u201d\n\nIf their big hits on Friday night were poignant on a personal level, they were also emblematic of their emergence among the game\u2019s best shortstops in what might be considered a golden era for the position, with young stars like Carlos Correa of the Houston Astros, Francisco Lindor of the Cleveland Indians, Corey Seager of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Manny Machado of the Baltimore Orioles.\n\nIt was their gloves that got Gregorius and Simmons, both 28, to the big leagues at early ages \u2014 they each debuted in 2012 \u2014 but they both improved greatly at the plate last season, a jump that has continued this season.\n\nPhoto\n\nGregorius has had a torrid April and has firmly established himself in the heart of what may be baseball\u2019s most fearsome lineup, surrounded by Aaron Judge, Giancarlo Stanton and Gary Sanchez, whose two-run homer gave the Yankees a 2-1 win over the Angels on Sunday. Gregorius is hitting .340, tied for sixth-best in baseball; his 10 home runs are tied for first with Mike Trout of the Angels and Mitch Haniger of the Seattle Mariners; and he leads the majors with 30 R.B.I. and a .766 slugging percentage.\n\nSimmons, who won his third Gold Glove last season, is considered in this era of advanced defensive metrics to be one of the best defensive shortstops ever.
