He\u2019s hitting .312 with a slugging percentage of .473 \u2014 nearly 100 points above his career average \u2014 and he has done even more damage in crucial spots, batting .417 with runners in scoring position entering Sunday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA midcareer blossoming is not unexpected from players who grew up in Cura\u00e7ao, where facilities \u2014 and access to them \u2014 are not what they are in the United States. The sport is also not as ubiquitous in Cura\u00e7ao as it is in places like the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico or Venezuela.\n\n\u201cGenerally when guys haven\u2019t played a lot of baseball, regardless of where they\u2019re from, it gives you some level of belief \u2014 cautious optimism let\u2019s call it \u2014 that there\u2019s a high amount of upside there,\u201d Angels General Manager Billy Eppler said.\n\nThat belief helped drive the Yankees\u2019 pursuit of both players when \u2014 unable to develop a shortstop to replace Derek Jeter \u2014 they went scouring the market for one when Jeter retired after the 2014 season. Unable to reach an agreement with the Atlanta Braves for Simmons, the Yankees swung a three-way deal to land Gregorius from the Arizona Diamondbacks.\n\nEppler, who was an assistant to Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman, was hired by the Angels a year later. His first trade was to acquire Simmons.\n\n\u201cWe saw a young, elite defender who had some process characteristics on the offensive side that were attractive to us,\u201d said Eppler, who might have been describing Gregorius as well. \u201cI have always been a big believer in the up-the-middle defense, kind of a throwback to traditional scouting.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBesides their backgrounds, stellar defense and bowlegged gait, Simmons and Gregorius share a trait that some believe has contributed to their late-blooming bats.\n\n\u201cThese guys \u2014 they have a special drive in them,\u201d said Hensley Meulens, the bench coach for the San Francisco Giants who paved the way for Cura\u00e7aoans when he reached the major leagues for the Yankees in 1989.\n\nThat purpose has been particularly tested for Gregorius, who was blocked at shortstop by Zack Cozart \u2014 now Simmons\u2019s teammate \u2014 in Cincinnati, and considered superfluous with the Diamondbacks, who had Nick Ahmed and Chris Owings at shortstop. When Gregorius got off to a poor start with the Yankees, fans at Yankee Stadium jeered his mistakes, sometimes chanting Jeter\u2019s name.\n\n\u201cYou learn from struggles,\u201d Gregorius said. \u201cWhen you have your struggles, you\u2019d better find a quick way out of it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the plate, that has meant tightening up his swing \u2014 keeping his front shoulder closed against left-handed pitching \u2014 and, specifically this season, being more selective. Gregorius has taken 18 walks this year \u2014 he took 25 all of last season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe used to be like a chicken wing against left-handers with fastballs,\u201d said Meulens, pointing his left elbow up in the air. \u201cThe front arm goes up, the barrel drops and you filet balls. Now you keep that down and all of a sudden the bat head is out front and you\u2019re back-spinning balls into the seats and keeping them fair, which is not easy to do.\u201d\n\nMeulens gets to see the work Gregorius puts in each winter at the workouts he helps organize for the growing number of professional and collegiate players from Cura\u00e7ao, where Gregorius lives during the off-season. There is also the occasional barbecue and a weeklong clinic that serves 1,300 Little Leaguers around the island.\n\nSimmons, who returns home for a week or two each winter, joins the workouts and tries to time his visits with the clinic. Angels Manager Mike Scioscia traces Simmons\u2019s improvement at the plate to when he returned from missing five weeks with a thumb injury in 2016. He came back with a shortened swing.\n\n\u201cI had a little time to really look at what I was doing and be more critical of my technical stuff when I finally came back,\u201d said Simmons, who batted .315 with a .774 on-base-plus-slugging percentage the final three and a half months of the season.\n\nIn the fourth inning on Friday night, Simmons and Gregorius had a chance to catch up at second base after Gregorius hit a blooper just over the head of first baseman Albert Pujols.\n\nSimmons, standing near the bag, told Gregorius he had a bad feeling he was going to get a hit.\n\n\u201cHe was like, \u2018Oh, I haven\u2019t gotten a hit in so long,\u2019\u201d Simmons said, rolling his eyes at the comment from Gregorius, who had been hitless in his previous five at-bats. \u201cI\u2019m like, \u2018You\u2019re hitting, like, four hundred and seventy thousand.\u2019 He was saying he wasn\u2019t getting any hits. I think that\u2019s why he laughed.\u201d\n\nIf others are surprised that Gregorius and Simmons have made such a transformation into potent hitters, the two boyhood friends are not \u2014 well, mostly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSimmons said he knew Gregorius was a better hitter than he showed with the Diamondbacks because he had seen how hard he could hit the ball growing up.\n\n\u201cBut hitting third and fourth in a lineup with Stanton, Sanchez and Judge?\u201d Simmons said with a chuckle. \u201cI didn\u2019t see that.\u201d\n\nThere was no argument in the other clubhouse.\n\n\u201cMe neither,\u201d said Gregorius, once again enjoying the last laugh.", "title": "Anything Andrelton Can Do, Didi Will Try to Do Better", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Mulvaney defended his actions as lawful, painting himself as a humble bureaucrat and reformer.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not seeking to undermine the mission of the bureau,\u201d Mr. Mulvaney insisted, adding that he no longer wanted it to be a regulatory \u201cblack hole.\u201d\n\nJust hours after testifying, Mr. Mulvaney unleashed a blistering memo to bureau staff members that accused some inside the agency of leaking the outlines of a proposed $1 billion fine against Wells Fargo. The potential fine was reported by Reuters on Monday.\n\n\u201cI am extraordinarily concerned that some of these leaks might have come from bureau employees,\u201d he wrote, according to a copy of the memo forwarded by a person on the distribution list.\n\nMr. Mulvaney\u2019s memo seemed to offer at least partial confirmation that the Reuters report was grounded, describing the leaked material as \u201cconfidential\u201d information.\n\n\u201cI recognize that there may well be some (a few? a lot?) of people who work here who aren\u2019t happy that I\u2019m working here. That\u2019s fine,\u201d Mr. Mulvaney wrote. \u201cI also recognize that these folks might be interested in undermining my leadership here, or in quite simply looking to make me look bad.\u201d\n\nHe has instructed the bureau\u2019s inspector general to investigate leaks, he said.\n\nMr. Mulvaney said he was not seeking to stifle legitimate whistle-blowers, but added that he would \u201csupport any disciplinary and other actions taken against any bureau employees\u201d found to have divulged information about investigations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe bureau does not play games,\u201d he concluded.\n\nThe question of Mr. Mulvaney\u2019s legal ability to run the consumer bureau stems from the provision in the 2010 Dodd-Frank law that created it. The statute mandated that the bureau, which draws its funding from the Federal Reserve, retain complete independence from other federal agencies \u2014 particularly the Office of Management and Budget, which oversees rule-making for the executive branch.\n\nThe appeals court, which fast-tracked the case, is expected to release a final ruling \u2014 which could order Mr. Mulvaney\u2019s ouster \u2014 within the next few weeks, according to a person with knowledge of the case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf that happens, Justice Department lawyers, who maintain that Mr. Trump has the right to appoint Mr. Mulvaney under the 1998 federal Vacancies Reform Act, are likely to appeal the case directly to the Supreme Court.\n\nAt that point, Mr. Trump would face a tough choice: Keep Mr. Mulvaney in the post under a legal cloud, pending an appeal, or replace him with another appointee who would most likely face a ferocious confirmation fight.\n\n\u201cOf all the people in the federal government, Donald Trump chose the one person, Mick Mulvaney, who isn\u2019t supposed to run the bureau under the law,\u201d said Deepak Gupta, Ms. English\u2019s lawyer and a former lawyer at the watchdog agency.\n\nA spokesman for Mr. Mulvaney did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nMr. Mulvaney, who has frozen new enforcement cases since taking over the bureau, is required to step down by June 22, under the vacancies law. But he could stay in the job if Mr. Trump nominates his successor, remaining in place until a new director is confirmed by the Senate.\n\nWhile Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee largely praised his work, Democrats were unimpressed.\n\nSenator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat who helped create the bureau, confronted Mr. Mulvaney with examples in which he called for the abolishment of the bureau and argued that it was clear from his leadership that he was trying to tear it apart.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve taken obvious joy in talking about how the agency will help banks a lot more than it will help consumers, and how upset this must make me,\u201d Ms. Warren said. \u201cYou\u2019re hurting real people to score cheap political points.\u201d", "title": "Appeals Court Questions Dual Roles of Consumer Bureau\u2019s Director", "authors": ["Glenn Thrush", "Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Apple has hired Google\u2019s chief of search and artificial intelligence, John Giannandrea, a major coup in its bid to catch up to the artificial intelligence technology of its rivals.\n\nApple said on Tuesday that Mr. Giannandrea will run Apple\u2019s \u201cmachine learning and A.I. strategy,\u201d and become one of 16 executives who report directly to Apple\u2019s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook.\n\nThe hire is a victory for Apple, which many Silicon Valley executives and analysts view as lagging its peers in artificial intelligence, an increasingly crucial technology for companies that enable computers to handle more complex tasks, like understanding voice commands or identifying people in images.\n\n\u201cOur technology must be infused with the values we all hold dear,\u201d Mr. Cook said Tuesday morning in an email to staff members obtained by The New York Times. \u201cJohn shares our commitment to privacy and our thoughtful approach as we make computers even smarter and more personal.\u201d", "title": "Apple Hires Google\u2019s A.I. Chief", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 If data is the most valuable currency of the digital economy, at what point does a company have so much that it becomes unfair?\n\nThat\u2019s a question antitrust experts are increasingly asking themselves as the world\u2019s biggest technology companies harvest more and more information about people and businesses. On Monday, European regulators pushed the idea forward, announcing an investigation into Apple\u2019s proposed acquisition of the song-identification app Shazam over concerns the iPhone maker would get access to data on competitors like Spotify.\n\nAntitrust cases, particularly in the United States, are typically argued over the impact a deal will have on consumers, such as the price of a product or service. Margrethe Vestager, the European Union\u2019s top antitrust official, has argued data should become more of a factor.\n\nMs. Vestager has said that with free services, customers pay with their data, and are not always getting a fair deal. This broader interpretation of antitrust law would have important consequences for future acquisitions made by companies such as Amazon, Facebook and Google.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nApple said in December that it would buy Shazam, the song-recognition service that has been a mainstay on people\u2019s smartphones for years with its ability to name a track after listening for a few seconds. The app has also become a valuable source of data, giving music industry executives insight into what songs and artists are performing well and in what regions.", "title": "Apple\u2019s Deal for Shazam Is Delayed in Europe Over Data Concerns", "authors": ["Adam Satariano"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "With the announcement on Tuesday that Max Hollein, a 48-year-old born in Vienna, would be its new director, the Met has opted to maintain its status quo. The point is not that Mr. Hollein isn\u2019t qualified for the post; it\u2019s that so are many others, and his hiring sheds light on the implicit biases of museum culture that continue to inform what being \u201cqualified\u201d means at the Met. In response to criticism of his appointment, Candace Beinecke, a trustee who was a co-leader of the search committee, said, \u201cThe museum\u2019s commitment to diversity is evident in everything we do, and the search was no exception to that.\u201d\n\nThis professed commitment to diversity does not appear to have been put in practice. Mr. Hollein\u2019s appointment brings the total number of white men hired to lead the institution to 10. What\u2019s more, in March, the Met ended its pay-as-you-wish policy for out-of-state visitors, and now requires that New York state residents show some form of identification for free admission. Such a requirement will likely discriminate against minorities or residents who either don\u2019t have legal identification or are reluctant to show it.\n\nMr. Hollein stood out as a candidate because of his prowess as a developer and \u201caggressive fund-raiser,\u201d attractive qualities for a museum in financial turmoil. But the Met\u2019s choice of a director based on those attributes is puzzling because, in the aftermath of Mr. Campbell\u2019s resignation the museum decided to separate artistic and fiscal responsibilities, appointing Daniel Weiss as chief executive and president. Now, instead of taking the opportunity to hire a woman or a person of color \u2014 or both \u2014 the Met has put two white men at top, instead of just one.\n\nAnd Mr. Weiss, it appears, couldn\u2019t be happier to have his mirror image as director. \u201cThe Met\u2019s a big, complicated place, and Max\u2019s area of expertise overlaps with mine quite considerably,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m an art historian with an M.B.A., and he\u2019s an art historian with an M.B.A.\u201d\n\nWhile women hold the majority of directorships in smaller museums, only 30 percent of museums with budgets of $15 million or more have female directors. Women are once again seeing the glass ceiling they have been bumping their heads against for decades being reinforced by the Met. They can sleep well tonight knowing that not just one white man, but two, are here to steer aright the big and complicated ship that is the Met.", "title": "Opinion | Appointing Yet Another White, Male Director Is a Missed Opportunity for the Met", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWelcome to Zucktown\u201d (Sunday Business, March 25):\n\nThere are so many anxiety-producing consequences of what the article describes \u2014 the hyper-production identity of the Facebook and Google worker; the disregard for a community that should accommodate the service workers supporting the well-paid elite; the disdain for existing communities \u2014 but I was shocked as well by the fact that, except for naming Frank Gehry as the designer of the Facebook campus, the word \u201carchitect\u201d was nowhere to be found.\n\nThe designing of communities and the knowledge to avoid those stated pitfalls are our purview!\n\nI believe that the lack of architectural presence in the article is not an oversight by the reporter, but rather an oversight by the tech community and our own profession for a willingness to perpetuate the myth that all we care about is formal, egocentric virtuosity.\n\nHow sad that the social vision that is at the heart of our discipline is so unrecognized.\n\nPEGGY DEAMER, NEW HAVEN\n\nThe writer is a professor at the Yale School of Architecture.", "title": "Opinion | Architects Gone Missing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s human nature, it seems, to resist change and fear the unknown. So it is no surprise that genetic engineering of food and feed crops resulted in their resounding condemnation as \u201cFrankenfoods\u201d by many consumers, who seem as terrified of eating an apple with an added anti-browning gene or a pink pineapple genetically enriched with the antioxidant lycopene as I am of self-driving cars.\n\nTrek down the grocery aisles of any large market and you\u2019ll find many products prominently labeled \u201cNo G.M.O.s.\u201d It\u2019s much harder to spot the small print on many other foods stating \u201cPartially produced with genetic engineering,\u201d a result of a 2016 federal law that mandated uniform labeling of all food products containing genetically engineered ingredients.\n\nThe labeling requirement arose in response to public pressure and a confusing array of state rules. But while I endorse the public\u2019s right to know and honest labeling of all products, in an important way it is very misleading. Farmers and agricultural scientists have been genetically engineering the foods we eat for centuries through breeding programs that result in large and largely uncontrolled exchanges of genetic material. What many consumers may not realize: For many decades, in addition to traditional crossbreeding, agricultural scientists have used radiation and chemicals to induce gene mutations in edible crops in attempts to achieve desired characteristics.\n\nModern genetic engineering differs in two ways: Only one or a few new genes with a known function are introduced into a crop, and sometimes the new genes come from an unrelated species. Thus, a gene meant to instill frost tolerance into, say, spinach, might come from a fish that lives in icy waters.", "title": "Are G.M.O. Foods Safe?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAETHERIAL WORLDS\n\nStories\n\nBy Tatyana Tolstaya\n\nTranslated by Anya Migdal\n\n256 pp. Knopf. $25.95.\n\nThe first story in \u201cAetherial Worlds,\u201d a new collection from the Russian writer Tatyana Tolstaya, describes an excruciating three-month convalescence from corrective eye surgery. This is Russia, 1983, so we\u2019re talking razors, not lasers. The patient has to stay in near-total darkness. As preludes to adventure go, it\u2019s sufficiently unpromising.\n\nBut over time the narrator \u2014 who may or may not be Tolstaya, I can\u2019t tell \u2014 develops a different kind of vision. She starts seeing episodes from her past, not just images but whole narratives, so precisely and clearly that she has to write them down, even though she\u2019s never written a story in her life. She eventually regains her earthly eyesight, but this new shadow world stays with her: \u201cIt turned out to be a multifaceted underside of so-called reality, a dungeon full of treasure, an aetherial world through the looking glass, a mysterious box with passcodes to all enigmas, an address book with the exact coordinates of those who never existed.\u201d Title drop! The main theme has been sounded.\n\nBut if the stories that follow are more of these aetherial worlds, they\u2019re also about people who are haunted by aetherial worlds \u2014 visions, glimpses of the transcendent, moments when the dull plastic coating of reality peels back to reveal something vastly more precious underneath. These glimpses can come at any moment, in any form: the premonitory ecstasy before an epileptic seizure; a pane of blue glass through which the shades of the dead seem to be visible; a still snowy dawn before the rest of the family is up; a beautiful patio, dreamed of but never built; the ancient mosaic ceiling of a Roman mausoleum, lost in shadow until it is briefly and gloriously illuminated when a tourist drops a coin in a box. There\u2019s no shortage of aether in \u201cAetherial Worlds.\u201d\n\nTolstaya\u2019s stories come both plotted and plotless. There\u2019s a perfectly turned Borgesian tale about a magical window from which one can collect random consumer goods for free (except that they\u2019re not) and a marvelously vivid recollection of Tolstaya\u2019s rambling old family dacha. Tolstaya is well known in Russia as a brilliant and caustic political critic, but her memories of her Soviet childhood have a tender, personal quality, devoid of any ideological ax-grinding. One could reassemble an entire midcentury Russian apartment block out of \u201cAetherial Worlds,\u201d from a characteristic doorbell \u2014 \u201ca flat brass knob the size and shape of half a butterfly\u201d \u2014 to the slow descent of an old-fashioned elevator: \u201cFirst the intestines appear in the elevator\u2019s wrought-iron cage, then the cabin itself.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTolstaya is doubly haunted by the past, both by its lostness and by its stubborn refusal to go away. She is blessed, and cursed, with the mystic\u2019s gift of seeing the shades of the departed; she\u2019s visited by, among many others, the memory of an old neighbor whom she used to meet walking his dogs:\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t know, do you, the names of his dachshunds. But I do! Another fifty years from now \u2014 even a hundred, or two hundred \u2014 and I\u2019ll still be able to hear his noble clarion voice:\n\n\u201c\u2018Myshka, Manishka, Murashka, Manzhet!\u2019\n\n\u201cThose were their names, and always in that order.\u201d\n\n(It\u2019s an echo of the triumphant moment in \u201cSpeak, Memory\u201d when Nabokov finally recalls the long-lost name of his first love\u2019s dog: Floss!)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere\u2019s a valedictory sadness to these memories, but Tolstaya isn\u2019t the type to pine. She\u2019s much given to sudden rhetorical gearshifts \u2014 she\u2019ll swerve from a flight of melancholy lyricism straight into a thicket of profanity, shaking off her own eloquence like a bad mood. This sonorous lower register gives voice to her bracing impatience with sentimentality and disingenuousness. As she says (or fantasizes about saying) to a student who\u2019s trying to snow her: \u201cDon\u2019t piss on my leg and tell me it\u2019s raining. I\u2019ll corner you and eat your brains for breakfast.\u201d\n\nAlthough this is Tolstaya\u2019s first book to be translated into English in 10 years, it could not be said of \u201cAetherial Worlds\u201d that it is all killer, no filler. There\u2019s a Seinfeldian outing on the subject of what-is-the-deal-with-all-those-missing-socks, and another that tackles the pressing question, \u201cWhat if there were no Italy?\u201d There\u2019s an interesting but surely misplaced academic rant about Kazimir Malevich\u2019s painting \u201cThe Black Square.\u201d (It features a cameo by the great Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, who, I should mention somewhere in this review, was Tolstaya\u2019s great granduncle; also, irrelevantly enough, my namesake.) But it\u2019s more than worth sifting through a little dross for the pleasure of seeing the world through the corrective lens of Tolstaya\u2019s vision, which reveals the world as not just a dull accretion of matter but a complex and shifting system of real and unreal realms, populated by beings both visible and invisible, floodlit by flashes of transcendence.", "title": "Are Her Characters Seeing Things? Maybe. Maybe Not.", "authors": ["Lev Grossman", "Tatyana Tolstaya"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "SYRIA-ISRAEL BORDER, Golan Heights \u2014 Ever since the Iranian Islamic Revolution in 1979, Iran and Israel have been fighting each other in the shadows \u2014 through proxies, assassination squads and cyber-virus attacks, but never as rival armies meeting on the field of battle. That may be about to change, and if it does, it will have vast implications for Syria, Lebanon and the whole Middle East.\n\nI\u2019m sure neither side really wants a war. It could be devastating for Israel\u2019s flourishing high-tech economy and for Iran\u2019s already collapsing currency. But Iran\u2019s Revolutionary Guards\u2019 Quds Force seems determined to try to turn Syria into a base from which to pressure Israel, and Israel seems determined to prevent that. And in the past few weeks \u2014 for the first time ever \u2014 Israel and Iran have begun quietly trading blows directly, not through proxies, in Syria.\n\nThey have already gone through two rounds, and Round 3, now pending, could blow Syria sky-high.\n\nRound 1 occurred on Feb. 10, when an Iranian drone launched by a Quds Force unit operating out of Syria\u2019s T4 air base, in central Syria, was shot down with a missile from an Israeli Apache helicopter that was following it after it penetrated northern Israel airspace.\n\nInitial reports were that the drone was purely on a reconnaissance mission. But the Israeli Army\u2019s spokesman, Brig. Gen. Ronen Manelis, said Friday that the flight path and Israel\u2019s analysis of the drone indicated that \u201cthe aircraft was carrying explosives\u201d and that its mission was \u201can act of sabotage in Israeli territory.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Are Iran and Israel Headed for Their First Direct War?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "This strategy has produced a string of box office hits, an intensely loyal fan base, and even a surprising number of critical successes. It has also become the envy of Hollywood, with rival studios racing to create their own expanded universes, but often with mixed results (like last year\u2019s abysmal \u201cJustice League\u201d). Other studios have cloned Marvel\u2019s structural attributes \u2014 the pop-culture nostalgia, the serial storytelling, the knowing fan service \u2014 but none have managed to replicate the consistency of its product.\n\nConsider Fox, which, somewhat confusingly, owns the rights to the X-Men and related Marvel superheroes. The X-Men films, which predate the Marvel universe, have varied far more in both quality and originality than their Marvel Studios counterparts: No Marvel movie has been as bad as the 2015 reboot of \u201cFantastic Four.\u201d But no Marvel film has even attempted the elegiac despair of \u201cLogan\u201d or the manic, profane irreverence of \u201cDeadpool,\u201d and it\u2019s hard to imagine that one ever will.\n\nMore than anything else, then, Marvel has succeeded because it has become a kind of quality guarantee, a brand that represents a workshopped and audience-friendly competence. Even the lesser entries among the Marvel-universe films are sturdy and watchable. No Marvel movie has a Rotten Tomatoes score of less than 66 percent; the top nine films have all scored 89 or better.\n\nIn an era where films routinely cost $200 million to produce and just as much to market, this is no small feat for a studio or its viewers. Marvel\u2019s implicit promise is that you can buy a ticket for any of its films and know, with reasonable confidence, that even if the movie isn\u2019t great, it is, at the very least, likely to be pretty good.\n\nThis quality guarantee has given Marvel the latitude to take big-budget risks that more conventional studios might balk at \u2014 and delivered equally large box office payoffs in return: It\u2019s hard to imagine that a $230 million production of something as obscure as \u201cGuardians of the Galaxy,\u201d with a talking raccoon and living tree in its main cast, could have received a green light without Marvel\u2019s presumption of an audience. And while various producers have attempted to develop a Black Panther film since at least the 1990s, it was Marvel that finally managed to transform it into a mega-budget cinematic reality \u2014 and Marvel\u2019s best-reviewed movie.\n\nYet \u201cBlack Panther\u201d also suggests the inherent limitations of Marvel\u2019s model. The movie was directed by Ryan Coogler, a talented young filmmaker whose two previous films, \u201cCreed\u201d and \u201cFruitvale Station,\u201d demonstrated a remarkable gift for emotional nuance and cinematic lyricism. That gift is still on display in \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d but in a way that sometimes feels muted and constrained, hemmed in by the broad formulas and expectations of a $200 million superhero movie. Mr. Coogler stitched together a characteristically impressive single-take action scene in the middle of the film, but the climactic battle in Wakanda plays out with the same sort of pixelated weightlessness that is typical of Marvel movies.\n\nTo be clear, \u201cBlack Panther\u201d is a better-than-average Marvel film. But it\u2019s less a Ryan Coogler movie made under Marvel than a Marvel movie made by Ryan Coogler.\n\nGiven the current state of Hollywood blockbusters, one might be forgiven for assuming that a certain amount of poll-tested blandness is necessary in order to achieve mass appeal. But it\u2019s not, even in the big-budget superhero genre, which in many ways was built on the idiosyncratic personal visions of pop-culture auteurs.", "title": "Opinion | Are Pretty Good Marvel Superhero Movies the Best Hollywood Can Do?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "What are your parents\u2019 hopes and dreams for you? Are they the same as or different from those you have for yourself?\n\nIn \u201cHow to Disobey Your Tiger Parents, in 14 Easy Steps,\u201d Michelle Kuo writes:\n\nI know a lot about disobeying immigrant tiger parents. I didn\u2019t take the conventional route of becoming a doctor or going into tech, as many Asian parents want. Instead, I nurtured lofty ideas about living radically: My heroes were Malcolm X, James Baldwin and Dorothy Day. The choices I made confused my parents and caused them despair. I majored in social theory and gender studies: despair. Worked on women\u2019s rights in Kenya: despair. Became a teacher in rural Arkansas: despair. Declined an offer from a corporate law firm to do legal aid work in Oakland, Calif.: more despair. Every fight was intense, terrible. None of us could believe what was said (or thrown). We grew up in two different worlds. Taiwan, a developing country when my parents were children, didn\u2019t have many options. Science and engineering could get you a job. Other professions, in social work and the arts and activism, were dangerous or unstable, or didn\u2019t exist. My book, \u201cReading with Patrick,\u201d tells the story of how I came to reject my parents\u2019 wishes for me. I have been moved by young readers asking me how they should talk to their parents about career choices. Their families come from Nigeria, China, Ghana, India, South Korea. These teenagers and college students are at a crossroads in their lives. They want to change the world but fear losing their parents\u2019 love.\n\nHere are some of Ms. Kuo\u2019s suggestions:\n\n2. Invite your parents into the conversation. Let them believe they are helping to guide you. Offer information that might persuade them. Mention older people whom you have consulted, spelling out their paths. 3. If you find that you can\u2019t persuade them, stop trying. Buy the plane ticket, find housing, accept the offer. 4. When they challenge you, do not back down. Do not even look as though you are backing down. Defy their expectation with a powerful display of your inflexibility. (Note: You may privately be open to their viewpoint, but don\u2019t show it.)\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Are you conforming to or rebelling against your parents\u2019 wishes for you? Why?\n\n\u2014 Do the choices you make for your life confuse and upset your parents? Or satisfy and delight them? How do these decisions affect your relationship?\n\n\u2014 What do you think might explain the differences or similarities in what you and your parents want for your life?\n\n\u2014 How do you talk to your parents about your future? Which of Ms. Kuo\u2019s suggestions would you use? Which of these would not work in your family? What advice for others might you add?", "title": "Are You Conforming to or Rebelling Against Your Parents\u2019 Wishes for You?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "What is your opinion on classical music, modern art, theater or opera? Why do you feel the way you do?\n\nIn \u201cA Note to the Classically Insecure,\u201d Miles Hoffman writes:\n\nI was talking about music recently with a friend who makes his living cloning genes, manipulating molecules and investigating the pathways of the human immune system. This is a person whose intellectual molecules are clearly very well arranged. But he proceeded to tell me that although he loved classical music, when he listened to it he wasn\u2019t able to perceive anything other than his own emotional reactions. Could it be true? Well, he thought it was. But he was wrong. What my friend was expressing was merely a symptom of a common affliction, one that crosses all intellectual, social and economic classes: the Classical Music Insecurity Complex. Immediate therapy was indicated. There\u2019s no question, I pointed out, that he perceives more than just his own reactions. Lots more. In every piece he listens to he perceives changes, both great and small, in tempo, volume, pitch and instrumentation. He perceives melodies, harmonies and rhythms, and their patterns. He perceives, in short, virtually all the musical ingredients that composers manipulate to stimulate emotional effects, which is precisely why he\u2019s emotionally affected. His \u201cproblem\u201d isn\u2019t perception \u2014 it\u2019s description. And what he doesn\u2019t know is the jargon, the technical terms for the ingredients and manipulations. And why should he? He\u2019s a scientist, not a musician. And frankly, it\u2019s not even essential that he be aware of the specific musical and technical means by which his reactions are being stimulated.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do you suffer from what Mr. Hoffman calls \u201cClassical Music Insecurity Complex\u201d? In other words, are you intimidated by highbrow art forms like classical music, art and theater? Why do you think this is?\n\n\u2014 Did reading this article change your mind about classical music at all? Would you be any more willing to attend a performance or listen to a piece than you were before? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Mr. Hoffman writes that \u201cthere\u2019s no denying that the more we know about music, as with cooking or gardening or football, the more levels of enjoyment are available to us.\u201d Do you agree with this statement? Are there times when knowing too much about something might actually hinder your appreciation and emotional experience of it? Can you give an example?", "title": "Are You Intimidated by Classical Music and Art?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\n\u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d is back \u2014 and it\u2019s grimmer than ever. In the first two episodes of Season 2, which arrived on Hulu on Wednesday, the series moves beyond the scope of the Margaret Atwood novel on which it\u2019s based, following Elisabeth Moss\u2019s Offred after authorities haul her away from the home of Commander Waterford (Joseph Fiennes). A harrowing visit to Fenway Park, a desperate act of self-mutilation and a first glimpse of the notorious Colonies are just some of the horrors that open the new season.\n\n\u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIs all that misery worth enduring? Most critics agree that it is. \u201cAfter a first season that started strong, then wobbled as it found its own material,\u201d writes the New York Times TV critic James Poniewozik, the series has \u201cbecome a confident, emotionally rich series \u2014 but one that, by nature and obligation, is wrenching to watch.\u201d\n\nWhile we can\u2019t make the show\u2019s patriarchal dystopia any easier to stomach, we have put together a list of essential essays, interviews and recaps to help guide you through it. (Brackets in quotations come from their source publications.)\n\nEssays\n\n\u2018\u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d and the Suffering of Women\u2019 [The Atlantic]\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a unique kind of tension when a show whose message is so explicitly feminist (even if no one involved wants to actually use that word) depicts so much violence and brutality against women,\u201d Sophie Gilbert observes. \u201cFor one thing, the series is doing it to prove a point: This is what happens, it says, when women are deprived of reproductive freedom, autonomy, votes, choices.\u201d\n\n0\n\nBut Gilbert wonders whether all that horrific imagery is necessary, pointing out that, \u201cas the first season showed, it\u2019s possible to do all of this without such explicit, repetitive violence.\u201d\n\n\u2018The Diminishing Returns of \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d\u2019 [The Ringer]\n\nShould \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d have ended where Atwood\u2019s book did \u2014 with Offred\u2019s capture? Alison Herman makes the case against Season 2, writing: \u201cRather than hitting notes of triumph or inspiration that inevitably ring false, these latest chapters lean into the all-consuming anguish. In doing so, \u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019 follows through on the logical implications of its premise \u2014 but also raises a critical question about its overall direction. There\u2019s little hope in Gilead, or for it. How long does it take to drive that home before the show goes inert?\u201d\n\n\u2018In \u201cHandmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d and \u201cHomeland,\u201d Two Heroines Judged by Their Devotion to Motherhood\u2019 [The Washington Post]\n\nHank Stuever asks why \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d and \u201cHomeland,\u201d two dramas about formidable women, place so much emphasis on maternal guilt. \u201cShows with strong female protagonists routinely fall back on motherhood as the character\u2019s prime motivator as well as her most vulnerable flaw,\u201d he writes. \u201cStarting with the usual guilt trip (Mommy works too much) and escalating to something as horrific as June having Hannah ripped from her arms by Gilead\u2019s enforcers, the message is remarkably the same, and, when you think about it, depressingly trite.\u201d\n\nInterviews\n\n\u2018The Story Behind \u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201ds Haunting Season 2 Opening Sequence\u2019 [LA Times]\n\nMoss emailed the Los Angeles Times her account of shooting the season\u2019s bleak first scene, set at a decrepit Fenway Park. \u201cPicture our cast and crew in the midst of an abandoned baseball field in these horrific conditions, and now picture a few dozen handmaids on top of rickety wooden platforms,\u201d she wrote to the reporter Yvonne Villareal. \u201cThis was grueling and, honestly, one of the toughest two days I\u2019ve ever had on set. My bones felt brittle, my blood ran cold. This was a reality, in that moment, gasping for air was real, shivering was real.\u201d\n\n\u2018How Margaret Atwood and Bruce Miller Tackled Race on Hulu\u2019s Biggest Hit\u2019 [Newsweek]\n\nIn a conversation on the book\u2019s and the show\u2019s approaches to race in Gilead, Atwood, who is 78, told Newsweek\u2019s Anna Menta that her critics \u201cshould read some history.\u201d\n\nEvangelicals \u201cwere segregationists,\u201d she continued. \u201cRemember how old I am. I existed for quite a while before the civil rights movement. I saw [racism] in action.\u201d\n\n\u2018How Ann Dowd Found Aunt Lydia\u2019s Twisted Soul\u2019 [Vanity Fair]\n\nAs Aunt Lydia, the handmaids\u2019 sadistic den mother, Ann Dowd was one of the darkest characters in the show\u2019s first ten episodes \u2014 and she\u2019s even more terrifying in Season 2. In an interview with Vanity Fair\u2019s Laura Bradley, she recalls the questions she asked herself in an attempt to understand Lydia\u2019s behavior. \u201cDid she have a baby at 13?\u201d Dowd wonders. \u201cDid she have an abortion at 13, or just plain old have sex and then, because she was raised in a religious environment, just fell apart and said to God, \u2018If you save me from this, I promise for the rest of my life without exception I will honor you?\u2019\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d Executive Producer Warren Littlefield Tells Us How Trump Influenced Season 2\u2019 [Uproxx]\n\nAsked how life in Donald Trump\u2019s America has influenced \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale,\u201d one of the show\u2019s executive producers, Warren Littlefield, tells Uproxx\u2019s Jessica Toomer, \u201cI think it\u2019s important for us to not be MSNBC. We\u2019re a dramatic thriller about stripping away human rights and feminist rights in this world, but we are formed by the world around us. We\u2019re formed by torture and fascist regimes, knowing what happens in our world, it forms how we end up with certain scenes, like [this season\u2019s] opening scene. But, as we often say to ourselves, we just wish we were not as relevant. It would be a better world.\u201d\n\nRecaps\n\n\u2018\u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d Season 2, Episodes 1 and 2: The Limits of Mercy\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nIn her recap of the two-part premiere, Genevieve Valentine notes that, this season, the writers \u201cseem less content simply to shock us with Gilead\u2019s draining \u2014 and ultimately fictional \u2014 cruelty.\u201d She continues: \u201cWe\u2019re familiar with that by now. With these two episodes, it feels as if their writer, Bruce Miller, wants to make us just as afraid of the world as it was before Gilead, which feels awfully close to home.\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d Season-Premiere Recap: Godspeed, June\u2019 [Vulture]\n\nHillary Kelly offers a close reading of the season\u2019s opening sequence. \u201cIn a scene that could be ripe for melodrama,\u201d she writes, \u201cMoss\u2019s expression, in which terror and confusion are constantly interchanging, take us to a vulnerability seldom seen on TV, even in this golden age. Audiences in a post-\u2018Game of Thrones\u2019 world have been trained to love and expect a death for shock\u2019s sake, but that\u2019s not put first here. Instead, the camera begs us to consider the human condition: not death itself, but the isolation of death.\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d Returns With Grim Fury \u2014 And Strange Song Choices\u2019 [Vox]\n\nVox is recapping Season 2 in a series of conversations that bring together a few of the site\u2019s writers to dissect each episode. The first installment includes a chat about the show\u2019s music supervision, which really isn\u2019t working for one participant, Constance Grady. When Kate Bush\u2019s \u201cThis Woman\u2019s Work\u201d plays during the opening sequences, she recalls, \u201cI remembered once again how incredibly bad \u2018Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019 is at music.\u201d\n\nShe continues: \u201cThe world it\u2019s created is so viscerally discomfiting to watch that whenever the show tries to use music to punch up the tension or to undercut it ironically, instead it has the opposite effect: Things start to feel mawkish and silly, and my emotional attachment to what\u2019s happening onscreen is broken a little.\u201d", "title": "Are You Watching Season 2 of \u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019? Here\u2019s What to Read", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Ariana Elexa Angrisani and Michael Edward Wilson were married March 30 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. On April 21, Matthew Angrisani, a cousin of the bride, is to lead a second ceremony at the Steam Whistle Brewery in Toronto, where he will be commenting on the couple\u2019s relationship.\n\nThe couple, both 31, met at the University of Michigan, from which they graduated.\n\nMrs. Wilson is a senior marketing manager for lifestyle brands at the Authentic Brands Group, a New York-based licensing and branding company.\n\nShe is a daughter of Susan J. V. Angrisani and Angelo F. Angrisani of New York. The bride\u2019s father is a sales representative at Eli\u2019s Breads in New York. Her mother is a business development manager at Colavita USA, an importer of olive oil and other foods, in Edison, N.J.\n\nMr. Wilson is a corporate vice president at New York Life Insurance in New York.\n\nHe is the son of Gene E. Wilson and Donald D. Wilson of Pickering, Ontario. The groom\u2019s mother is a digital marketing specialist for Yellow Pages in Toronto. His father, who also works in Toronto, is a nuclear engineer for Candu, a Canadian pressurized heavy water reactor designed to generate electric power.", "title": "Ariana Angrisani, Michael Wilson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Federal health officials said on Friday that they had identified one of the sources of tainted romaine lettuce that has so far left 98 people sick, in what is the largest multistate food-borne E. coli outbreak since 2006.\n\nThe whole-head romaine lettuce that sickened eight people at a correctional facility in Nome, Alaska, came from Harrison Farms of Yuma, Ariz., the Food and Drug Administration said. The remaining illnesses were caused by bagged, chopped romaine lettuce, though health officials continue to urge consumers to avoid all types of romaine from the Yuma area.\n\nThe outbreak now spans 22 states and involves a particularly aggressive strain of the bacteria, said Matthew Wise, the deputy branch chief for outbreak response at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\n\u201cThis is a serious E. coli,\u201d he told reporters on Friday. \u201cEverybody should be concerned.\u201d\n\nOfficials are investigating other parts of the lettuce supply chain and more than two dozen other fields to identify the source or sources of the 90 other E. coli infections, though they said that all are linked to the Yuma area. Because Yuma is near the end of its growing season, lettuce production will be shifting north to the Salinas Valley, in California, for the summer.", "title": "Arizona Farm Blamed for Part of Large, Nationwide E. Coli Outbreak", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Noah Karvelis, an elementary school music teacher and the founder of Arizona Educators United, said he was sympathetic to the disruption that widespread school closings would cause students and parents. But, he said, that should not forestall a walkout.\n\n\u201cIf we maintain the status quo, that is way worse than missing a couple of days of school,\u201d Mr. Karvelis said at a news conference outside the union headquarters in Phoenix. \u201cThe biggest disservice any of us could do for our students right now is to not act in this moment.\u201d\n\nAcross Arizona, tens of thousands of teachers, parents and students, clad in red, participated in protests outside schools on April 11. Gov. Doug Ducey said he was \u201cimpressed\u201d by the movement, which calls itself #RedForEd. He promised to provide teachers with a 20 percent raise by 2020, and to restore school budgets to pre-Recession levels over the next five years. He said he could do so without raising taxes, because the state\u2019s economy is improving and existing state programs could be cut.\n\nBut many teachers rejected that plan, or said they distrusted Mr. Ducey, a first-term Republican.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t rob Peter to feed Paul,\u201d said Kassandra Dominguez, who teaches kindergarten and first grade in the Pendergast school district, near Phoenix. \u201cThat\u2019s so wrong, and I wouldn\u2019t want that money.\u201d\n\nAlternate proposals for raising school budgets include increasing an education sales tax from six-tenths of a cent to one cent, or closing corporate tax loopholes.\n\nThe average teacher salary in Arizona is about $47,000 per year, according to the National Center for Education Statistics. But starting salaries are much lower, and many teachers leading the protest movement are in their 20s and 30s.\n\nMs. Dominguez, 27, earns $38,250 per year, and says that because of low education budgets, she has had to pay out of pocket, or raise money from private donors, to buy her students science supplies, chairs and snacks. She voted in favor of a walkout. Her district had lost a total of $1.6 million over the past five years because of budget cuts, according to administrators, and the school board had come out in favor of the #RedForEd movement.", "title": "Arizona Teachers Vote in Favor of Statewide Walkout", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "YEREVAN, Armenia \u2014 The Armenian police detained three opposition leaders on Sunday and dispersed protesters on the 10th day of demonstrations against the appointment of former President Serzh Sarksyan as prime minister, according to officials, opposition politicians and a witness.\n\nThe appointment by Parliament on Tuesday of Mr. Sarksyan as prime minister after a 10-year term as president has caused outrage, prompting tens of thousands of opponents to march through Yerevan, the capital, where they staged sit-ins that blocked the streets.", "title": "Armenia Detains 3 Opposition Leaders Amid Protests", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "A suspect is in custody after a freshman was fatally stabbed at Binghamton University. It was the second killing of a student there in five weeks, leaving the campus tense and grieving.\n\nThe victim, Joao Souza, 19, was attacked in his dormitory suite around 10:30 p.m. on Sunday. Timothy Faughnan, the university\u2019s police chief, said at a news conference Monday morning that emergency responders had found Mr. Souza \u201cseriously injured from what appeared to be stab wounds from a knife\u201d and taken him to the hospital, where he was pronounced dead.\n\nSurveillance footage from the dorm, Windham Hall, showed a man in dark pants and a dark hooded sweatshirt, believed to be the attacker. Late Monday, university and police officials announced that Michael M. Roque, 20, had been arrested and charged with second-degree murder.\n\nMr. Roque, a student at Binghamton, has pleaded not guilty and is being represented by a public defender.", "title": "Arrest Made After Binghamton Stabbing, the Second Student Death in 5 Weeks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "All of those eulogies are true, of course. Wenger\u2019s longevity, as Ferguson highlighted, is an achievement in itself. The loyalty between him and the club \u201cof his heart,\u201d as he has always put it, is increasingly an anachronism in soccer\u2019s age of impatience. It is the end of an era not just for Arsenal, but for the sport as a whole, too, in that sense. There will be no more who do what Wenger did, for as long as he did.\n\nHe did, as others mentioned, shape some of the finest teams England has seen: the one that won the Premier League and F.A. Cup in his first full season, built on the granite defense he had inherited; the Invincibles of Thierry Henry and Patrick Vieira in 2004; the team that came within 12 minutes of winning the Champions League in 2006.\n\nIn doing so, he transformed what Arsenal was, how it was seen, across the globe. That is Wenger\u2019s legacy, just as much as the sleek, space-age stadium the club built on the back of his success and the state-of-the-art training facility he helped design: Arsenal had not always been seen as a bastion of taste and style in England, let alone around the world.\n\nHe transformed more than just his club, though. Possibly more than any other manager in history, Wenger changed the nature of English soccer. Not just, as is always trotted out, because he accelerated great leaps forward in nutrition, in conditioning, in hydration, in sports science, in recruitment and, in later years, in analytics, too, but because of something more fundamental: He opened an entire country\u2019s eyes.\n\nPhoto\n\nWenger was only the second foreign manager to be appointed to an English club having never experienced the game on these shores. The first, the Czechoslovak Jozef Venglos, arrived at Aston Villa in 1990 championing similar methods to Wenger\u2019s, and left not long after, his players unable, or unwilling, to adapt.\n\nWenger was greeted by similar skepticism. What does he know of England, he who comes from Japan, as Ferguson \u2014 unwittingly bastardizing Kipling \u2014 almost put it. When Wenger immediately set about recruiting a battalion of French players, he was greeted by a wave of doubters and critics. A year later, he won the title, and then the cup. Wenger proved that foreign managers could cut it in an island obsessed with its own exceptionalism.\n\nIt is for all of that he should be remembered, his unyielding allies and recently converted admirers claimed on Friday, not for these last few years of drift and despair. Those long seasons punctuated by three F.A. Cup wins but dominated by the sight of Arsenal, of Wenger, being overtaken by Chelsea, by Manchester City and, worst of all, by Tottenham Hotspur; of a club first unable to compete in the Champions League and then eliminated from it entirely; of a stadium slowly emptying as fans lost patience and then hope; of a board paralyzed by its awe for an employee; of a man unable to turn away. All of that should be written out of the record, cast into shadow by the searing brightness of what went before.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt does not work like that, of course, nor should it. Wenger\u2019s second act is just as central to his legacy as his first, and the questions of why he could not halt the decline \u2014 why, for so long, he did not seem to notice it, why he kept pursuing the same solution, believing the outcome would be different, why he allowed the final years of his reign to be marked more by sadness than glory \u2014 are just as relevant as how he managed to kick-start the club\u2019s ascent all those years ago.\n\nA few years ago, in one of those many low moments that seemed to prompt a bout of soul-searching in Wenger, he contemplated how he wanted to leave Arsenal for his successor. At the annual meeting of the club\u2019s shareholders, he talked about how he wanted to bequeath a team primed for immediate, continuing success, one in ruder health than ever before.\n\nIt is hard to argue he has achieved that. No matter who replaces him \u2014 and a young, ambitious coach to re-energize a torpid club is the order of the day \u2014 that person will have to rebuild morale, reshape the squad and restore purpose. That job will be more difficult this year than it would have been had Wenger stepped down in, say, 2014.\n\nNor will it be the work of just one man. Perhaps the most eloquent testimony to Wenger\u2019s greatness came not in the words poured out in his honor over the last 24 hours, but in the work Arsenal has been doing to prepare for this day over the last 12 months. Raul Sanllehi has come in from Barcelona as director of football operations. Sven Mislintat, his reputation forged at Borussia Dortmund, is the new chief scout. The legal expert Huss Fahmy was drafted in from cycling\u2019s Team Sky to work on contracts.\n\nBilly Beane, a friend of Wenger\u2019s, has always preached the need not to find like-for-like replacements for players, but to try to replace the aggregate of what they provided. Arsenal has recognized that it will take four people, effectively, to stand in for Wenger.\n\nThat is the highest of praise, but it is also fitting recognition that Wenger was no longer a man of his time: Soccer clubs are now too vast, too complex as organizations, to be overseen by just one person. Wenger was the last of the all-powerful managers; the institution he represented, the way of thinking, is past. That, in part, is why he has been overtaken, why he lost his way.\n\nNone of that means that he should not be given a monthlong valedictory tour not just by Arsenal, but by the country he graced for 22 years, the country he changed, just a little, in his own image.\n\nNor does the fact that he was imperfect, that he stayed on too long, that he departs not with garlands but regrets, mean he does not warrant a statue. In the ancient world, even monuments to the gods contained physical imperfections, a simple metaphor. They are great, and they deserve to be remembered, and cherished, and idolized. But they have their flaws, too, just as we all do.", "title": "Ars\u00e8ne Wenger Will Leave Arsenal, Proudly but Imperfectly", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "In riveting narratives punctuated by convincing details, his guests spun eyewitness accounts of past lives, contacts with aliens, time travel, crop circles and other ostensibly inexplicable phenomena, most of which were accompanied by a knowing affirmation from the host himself.\n\nHe had reason to be credulous. One summer night, he recalled, he and his wife were driving home when a 150-foot-long triangular craft silently hovered over their car before disappearing.\n\n\u201cIt really doesn\u2019t matter that much to me if anyone believes me,\u201d Mr. Bell explained later. \u201cThousands of people seeing the same thing cannot all be wrong.\u201d\n\nJust how much Mr. Bell believed was a matter of conjecture.\n\nHe once described his program as \u201cabsolute entertainment.\u201d When he was inducted into the Radio Hall of Fame in 2008, his former business partner, Alan Corbeth, said Mr. Bell had thoroughly understood \u201chow to create theater of the mind.\u201d\n\nOn one memorable program in 1997, a man who said he had been discharged for medical reasons from Area 51 \u2014 the storied Nevada air base that has long stoked rumors of unidentified flying objects \u2014 was mysteriously cut off in mid-interview.\n\n\u201cWhat we\u2019re thinking of as aliens, Art, they\u2019re extra-dimensional beings,\u201d the man started to say, his voice choking. \u201cThey\u2019ve infiltrated a lot of aspects of, of the military establishment.\u201d\n\nOn another program, Mr. Bell introduced his guest, identified as Alex Collier, by saying he had been \u201cin contact with a human race from the constellation Andromeda, located in our galaxy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHis experience has been both telepathic and physical,\u201d Mr. Bell added. \u201cHis relationship with the Andromedans has been based on trust and friendship. Alex\u2019s free will has never been violated, and his experience must not in any way be associated with abduction.\u201d\n\nIn 1998, Mr. Bell received the ignominious Snuffed Candle Award from the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry, a group, co-founded by Carl Sagan and based in Amherst, N.Y., that promotes scientific inquiry and critical thinking. The group cited him \u201cfor encouraging credulity, presenting pseudoscience as genuine, and contributing to the public\u2019s lack of understanding of the methods of scientific inquiry.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo which Mr. Bell replied: \u201cA mind should not be so open that the brains fall out; however, it should not be so closed that whatever gray matter which does reside may not be reached. On behalf of those with the smallest remaining open aperture, I accept with honor.\u201d\n\nArthur William Bell III was born on June 17, 1945, in Jacksonville, N.C., while his parents were stationed at Camp Lejeune there. His father, a Marine Corps captain, was descended from one of the original settlers of Stamford, Conn., in the 1640s. His mother, the former Jane Lee Gumaer, was a Marine sergeant.\n\nAt 13, Art became a licensed amateur radio operator. He was an Air Force medic during the Vietnam War and later a disc jockey for an English-language station in Okinawa.\n\nThere, he was said to have set a record for continuous broadcasting \u2014 116 hours and 15 minutes \u2014 to raise money to ferry stranded Vietnamese orphans from Saigon to the United States for adoption by American families. (He also claimed a record of 57 hours of uninterrupted seesawing while broadcasting.)\n\nMr. Bell enrolled as an engineering major at the University of Maryland but dropped out to return to radio, first as a disc jockey in California and Nevada. Students of numerology were mindful that he began his political talk show in 1984 \u2014 and also that he died on a Friday the 13th.\n\nMr. Bell is survived by his fourth wife, Airyn Ruiz; their children, Asia and Alexander; and three children from his earlier marriages, Vincent Pontius, Lisa Pontius Minei and Arthur Bell IV.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis \u201cCoast to Coast\u201d show was syndicated and broadcast from 1989 to 2003, followed by episodic returns on satellite radio and online with a program called \u201cMidnight in the Desert,\u201d which he canceled in 2015 after he said shots had been fired at his home.\n\nMr. Bell said he kept a .40-caliber Glock 22 in a desk drawer of his isolated desert home.\n\n\u201cIf I had a problem out here,\u201d he told Time magazine in 2012, \u201cwell, the police would arrive just in time to draw the chalk outline on my floor.\u201d\n\nWhile some critics accused him of laying the foundation for right-wing conspiracists on talk radio, Mr. Bell\u2019s politics were not easily pigeonholed. He described himself as a libertarian, but his passion was directed less at politicians or ideology than at debunking scientific doctrine and preaching apocalyptic prophecy.\n\n\u201cHe was different, fed up with the government not because of some tax increase or a bad vote but because of what they were hiding,\u201d the journalist Jack Dickey wrote in Time magazine in 2013. \u201cWhere others had rage, he had skepticism, and lots of it.\u201d\n\nWith the horror novelist Whitley Strieber, Mr. Bell wrote \u201cThe Coming Global Superstorm\u201d (1999), in which violent climate disruptions lead to a global deep freeze. The director Roland Emmerich adapted it for the 2004 film \u201cThe Day After Tomorrow,\u201d starring Dennis Quaid.\n\n(Writing about the film in The New York Times, Andrew C. Revkin noted, \u201cMost experts on climate change say a switch from slow warming to an instant hemispheric deep freeze like the one posited in the book is impossible.\u201d)\n\nMr. Bell wrote several other books, including \u201cThe Quickening: Today\u2019s Trends, Tomorrow\u2019s World\u201d (1997) and a memoir, \u201cThe Art of Talk\u201d (1998).\n\nHis spoken words had a much wider reach, however. \u201cHis Marlboro-Lights-weathered voice blanketed the continent after dark, reliably chilling his audience,\u201d one reviewer wrote.\n\nMr. Bell acknowledged that he had a certain hold on his nocturnal audience. As he told The Washington Post in 1998, \u201cThere is a difference in what people are willing to consider, daytime versus nighttime. It\u2019s dark, and you don\u2019t know what\u2019s out there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAnd the way things are now,\u201d he added, \u201cthere may be something.\u201d", "title": "Art Bell, Radio Host Who Tuned In to the Dark Side, Dies at 72", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe send our prayers and deepest condolences to Mr. Brassner\u2019s family and loved ones,\u201d a spokeswoman for the Trump Organization said on Sunday.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Brassner\u2019s apartment in Trump Tower, built in 1983, did not have sprinklers, which were not required. In 1999, after two deadly fires in high-rise apartments, New York City enacted legislation requiring sprinkler systems in most new residential buildings and existing properties that were extensively renovated.\n\nReal estate developers, including Mr. Trump, fought the sprinklers, arguing that they were unnecessary and would add $4 per square foot to the cost of an apartment.\n\nJames Long, a spokesman for the Fire Department, said on Sunday that residents in a fireproof building, like Trump Tower, were safest inside their apartments rather than evacuating.\n\nDamage from the fire was visible from Madison Avenue and 56th Street. Fifty floors up, facing east, a pair of large horizontal windows were punched out, and the glass and metal facade above appeared scorched and sooty. A metal work platform lowered from the roof hung beside the gutted apartment.\n\nFor Mr. Brassner, the building was a prestigious address for dealing art, and his early years there echoed his successes in the nexus of the art and music worlds.\n\n\u201cHe led a very out-there life,\u201d said Jodi Stuart, who was Mr. Brassner\u2019s first girlfriend and had been in and out of his life since. \u201cOut there in sports cars, out there in rock \u2019n\u2019 roll, playing Hendrix on guitar, bigger than life.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor much of Mr. Brassner\u2019s life, she said, \u201cYou never saw him without his Jaguar.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe used to go to the Fillmore East and Max\u2019s Kansas City,\u201d Ms. Stuart said. \u201cTodd got right in with the Factory and Andy Warhol. He picked em: Jimi Hendrix, Andy Warhol, Jaguars, beautiful homes, beautiful women.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Wake Up With The Times, Anywhere in the World.
