You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Brassner was one of two sons born to an art dealer and lighting manufacturer named Jules Brassner, who introduced him to Warhol. Todd Brassner fit right into the Warhol orbit, and often went shopping with the artist, said Stuart Pivar, a collector who was very close to Warhol.\n\n\u201cThey were like two 14-year-olds, seeing the world,\u201d Mr. Pivar said. \u201cAnd he was very knowledgeable about pop art.\u201d\n\nThough Mr. Brassner enjoyed the high life, \u201che was a very family-oriented guy, and we often talked about our parents,\u201d said Howard Murray, a television director who grew up with Mr. Brassner and reconnected about a decade ago. \u201cHe always talked about his mom talking Yiddish.\u201d\n\nBut in recent years, Mr. Brassner started leaving the apartment less and less frequently, and he resisted offers from friends to visit or bring food. Blake Gopnik, who wanted to interview Mr. Brassner for a biography of Warhol, said he set up a number of meetings. \u201cBut he always made some complicated excuse,\u201d Mr. Gopnik said.\n\nMr. Brassner\u2019s struggle with drugs brought him into contact with \u201cshady characters, who snookered him out of masterpieces,\u201d Mr. Pivar said. The apartment was so cluttered Mr. Brassner could barely move, Mr. Pivar said.\n\nHe filed for bankruptcy in 2015, but soon after he inherited money from his father. \u201cHe showed up at my house the next day in a brand-new red Lamborghini,\u201d Mr. Pivar said. \u201cThat was Todd.\u201d\n\nMs. Stuart said she thought Mr. Brassner did not want his friends to see him in declining health.\n\n\u201cWe tried very hard to meet with him or have lunch or dinner with him,\u201d she said. \u201cHe wanted us to know the Todd that was before. Not the Todd who was impaired. He suffered a lot.\u201d", "title": "Art Collector and Bon Vivant Dies in Trump Tower Home He Couldn\u2019t Sell", "authors": ["John Leland", "Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "A shift in the cultural winds is palpable in New Jersey\u2019s state capital. Since the year began, a new governor, Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat, has been sworn in, and a vibrant arts scene has continued to expand downtown.\n\nOn the banks of the Delaware River, Trenton is a postindustrial city that\u2019s been buffeted by bad news for decades. Factories closed, crime escalated and restaurants moved to the suburbs, making it almost impossible to find a decent tomato pie, a local specialty.", "title": "Art, Punk Rock and a New Governor Reinvigorate Trenton", "authors": ["Julie Besonen"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Kopelman, 65, is a founder and president of the Coastal Research Education Society of Long Island and a guide for amateurs willing to spend six hours on the sea. He is also a professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology \u2014 which, with his long white beard and penchant for thermal coveralls, means that he knows something about species adapting to alien habitats. \u201cI try to be a role model for the anti-fashion group, to help people move away from caring about what you own,\u201d he said.", "title": "Arthur Kopelman Works the Other Hamptons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "But when he needed a second chance, one seemed to be waiting for him.\n\nMr. Pence\u2019s race in a safely Republican district where he has lived most of his life \u2014 stretching from the far eastern suburbs of Indianapolis to Muncie in the north and the Kentucky line to the south \u2014 shows the durable power in politics of a famous name and insider connections even in an outsider era.\n\nThe older Mr. Pence has the same white hair, genial bearing and deeply conservative politics of his brother, and his campaign is tethered to the Trump administration. He pledges to help advance Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d agenda in Congress. The vice president held a fund-raiser for him at the Trump International Hotel in Washington recently, and Donald Trump Jr. will headline another later this month in New York.\n\nThe race is Mr. Pence\u2019s first for public office, and he has largely avoided attention and scrutiny. But that strategy will be tested as the Republican primary on May 8 approaches. He faces at least one serious challenger, Jonathan Lamb, who has put more than $800,000 of his own money into the race and calls himself a serial entrepreneur. He said Mr. Pence\u2019s run smacked of nepotism.\n\n\u201cNo amount of money in the world can buy the name ID that Pence has,\u201d Mr. Lamb said. \u201cBut with name ID, you step on toes. People don\u2019t want to see this dynasty, like the Kennedys and Bushes.\u201d\n\nMr. Pence has never displayed the political ambitions of his brother, who was elected in 2000 to the House seat that he now seeks, then Indiana\u2019s governor in 2012, before joining Mr. Trump\u2019s ticket in 2016. The elder Mr. Pence\u2019s campaign says he is \u201cready to serve again,\u201d a reference to his enlistment in the Marines in 1979 after he graduated from Loyola University in Chicago.\n\nHe also highlights his business experience, which he said showcased how he cared for his employees, putting their interests ahead of his own. His most prominent position was when he served as president of Kiel Brothers Oil Company from 1998 until 2004.\n\nKiel Brothers was a growing family business in Columbus when its founder, Carl Kiel, asked Edward Pence, the father of Greg and Mike, to join the company in 1965. They sold fuel to service stations, then eventually went into the convenience store business, which grew to more than 200 outlets, primarily in Indiana and Kentucky, mostly under the name Tobacco Road.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWant a smoke, a Coke or a tank of gas? Kiel Brothers Co. is there to serve you,\u201d a company description in Hoover\u2019s said. The company prospered, building a corporate headquarters in Columbus, where it held a place of esteem.\n\nWhen Mr. Pence died in 1988, the Kiel family turned to Greg Pence to join the business. Mr. Pence steadily took on more responsibility until he became president in 1998. With that came other obligations to the company, and he and a younger member of the Kiel family, Theodore, each signed personal guarantees to the local Home Federal Bank to obtain loans to continue to expand.\n\nA year later, Mr. Pence was named to Home Federal\u2019s board of directors. As he was becoming a more prominent member of the Columbus business community, Mike was a rising power in the Republican Party.\n\nMr. Pence signed another guarantee in 2001, records show, promising to repay any outstanding debts from his personal assets if the need arose.\n\nThree years later, it did \u2014 the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, facing $100 million in claims from creditors.\n\nAt the next regular board meeting of the bank, with the officials seated around a wooden conference table, Mr. Pence told them about the bankruptcy and said he would not be able to honor his personal guarantee to repay company loans. He acknowledged the obvious conflict of interest, board members said, and resigned from the board.\n\nHe had resigned abruptly from the company as well, leaving the restructuring work to the chief financial officer, David E. Roll, who, bank officials said, worked tirelessly, sometimes until midnight, trying to keep the company afloat. Attempts to reach Mr. Roll were not successful.\n\nLast Monday, in a video on Twitter in which he discussed his views on the economy, Mr. Pence said of his business experience: \u201cYou have to put your employees and customers before yourself. I\u2019ve always done that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is not how former bank and company officials said Mr. Pence acted when it mattered most. While businesses fail all the time, said one former bank official who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal matters, such failures reveal the character of those involved, and Mr. Pence had \u201cbailed.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnother bank board member, Harold Force, who runs a construction company in Columbus, had no criticism of Mr. Pence, but acknowledged the consequences of the failure of a homegrown company that he described as a \u201cpillar\u201d in the town of 46,000 in southern Indiana.\n\n\u201cWhen a company like that comes to an end, there are probably a lot of loyal people who are let down in some ways, heartbroken in some cases,\u201d Mr. Force said, adding, \u201cI think everybody regrets that.\u201d\n\nJay Jaffe, a lawyer in Indianapolis who represented the company in the bankruptcy proceedings, defended Mr. Pence\u2019s actions. \u201cI would not say he ran away because he wanted to run from a bad situation,\u201d Mr. Jaffe said. \u201cHe stuck around for a long time to try to make the situation work.\u201d\n\nKyle Robertson, the spokesman for Mr. Pence\u2019s campaign, said in a statement that \u201cprior to his departure, Mr. Pence negotiated and secured a KERP (Key Employee Retention Plan) that would help employees going through the eventual transition. Mr. Pence voluntarily forfeited his KERP when he resigned.\u201d\n\nThe account of Mr. Pence\u2019s actions and the bankruptcy is based on interviews with a half- dozen former bank officials and others with ties to the company, along with a review of hundreds of pages of court records, including in the bankruptcy case. One of the creditors in the case was the Indiana Department of Environmental Management, which said that the company had caused $8.4 million in damage to the state.\n\nIn a separate legal action, Mr. Pence also refused several attempts from the bank to collect money based on his personal guarantee, forcing the institution to go to court.\n\nPence campaign officials defended the candidate\u2019s actions.\n\n\u201cMr. Pence chose to resign in order to pursue other opportunities,\u201d Mr. Robertson said in response to written questions. \u201cEveryone knows the oil and gas industry changed rapidly in the 1990s and early 2000s, and many small, independent companies like Kiel Brothers were not able to survive because of the national consolidation.\u201d\n\nRecords from the Superior Court in Indianapolis show that Home Federal Bank won a $3.8 million civil judgment against Mr. Pence to satisfy the personal guarantees. But former bank officials said he settled the matter for a small fraction of that amount. In contrast, Theodore Kiel lost his primary residence as part of his effort to satisfy his guarantee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Robertson declined to discuss those actions except to say that they were unrelated to bankruptcy court action against the company. Those \u201cpersonal guaranty liens\u201d were \u201creleased after being satisfied,\u201d Mr. Robertson said.\n\nThe Indiana Department of Environmental Management claim against the company was withdrawn after insurance payments and remediation efforts. Mr. Robertson said that Mr. Pence played no role in settling the action brought by the state.\n\nSix months after Mr. Pence resigned from the bankrupt company, the state\u2019s governor at the time, Mitch Daniels, seemed to offer him a lifeline, appointing him deputy commissioner of the same state environmental agency that had sued his company. But Mr. Pence stayed in the job at the agency, known as IDEM, for only two and a half months.\n\n\u201cGovernor-elect Mitch Daniels asked Mr. Pence to help with transition work at IDEM,\u201d Mr. Robertson said, later adding, \u201cThere was never a discussion how long Mr. Pence would stay.\u201d\n\nMr. Pence and his wife now own two antique malls in southern Indiana, valued at between $5 million and $25 million, according to financial disclosure statements he filed with the House in January.\n\nMr. Lamb, his opponent in the primary, said he could draw a sharp contrast between his business success and Mr. Pence\u2019s record. \u201cI\u2019m an entrepreneur and have had success,\u201d Mr. Lamb said. \u201cHe was handed a very large corporation that he ran into the ground.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Pence\u2019s business record may become one focus of the campaign, his hearty endorsement of the Trump agenda could provide another.\n\nColumbus is a rare Rust Belt town that continues to have a thriving manufacturing economy, with an unemployment rate of 2.7 percent. Its downtown is bustling with small businesses, and its modern architecture has drawn international acclaim.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Brookings Institution study last year ranked Columbus as the No. 1 metro area measured by exports as a share of local gross domestic product \u2014 50.6 percent. As such, it is heavily exposed to the kind of wild trade gyrations that Mr. Trump\u2019s policies have generated.\n\nThe district also has a large agricultural presence that could be hurt by them as well. \u201cWe can\u2019t be getting into a tariff war over soybeans,\u201d Mr. Lamb said. \u201cThat\u2019s why people are looking for someone who can be their voice.\u201d\n\nWhen asked about the Brookings study, Mr. Robertson replied, \u201cMr. Pence supports the Trump administration in its defense of American companies who have been subjected to decades of illicit trade practices and unfair policies.\u201d", "title": "As Another Pence Runs for Congress, His Business Record Raises Questions", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere will be a free and fair court for him,\u201d he said, adding that a new law on the security service and other measures would end the existence of a \u201cstate within a state without any sort of oversight.\u201d\n\nOn the first day of Mr. Abdullaev\u2019s trial in an open court on March 7, the judge asked the journalist to take off his shirt to see whether there were traces of torture \u2014 and then accepted a request by the defense team that the proceedings be suspended until doctors could carry out a full medical examination of the defendant.\n\nThe medical exam, which human rights activists said ignored crucial facts like the dates of Mr. Abdullaev\u2019s detention, did not confirm that the journalist had been tortured. But when his trial resumed last week he and other defendants, including a jailed blogger, were allowed to testify at a court session open to representatives from Human Rights Watch and news media organizations that under Mr. Karimov were barred from entering Uzbekistan.\n\nIn a country where courts for years did no more than rubber-stamp judgments decided in advance by the S.N.B., the judge\u2019s willingness to address the issue of torture and open the court to observers, human rights activists said, was a clear sign that Uzbekistan was trying to change its ways.\n\nMr. Karimov, who ruled from 1991 until his death in 2016, was unforgiving of dissent, particularly after unrest in the eastern town of Andijon in 2005, which ended with armed S.N.B. officers killing hundreds of unarmed protesters. So deep was this obsession that, according to the former British ambassador in Tashkent, his regime boiled some of its opponents to death. Mr. Karimov even had members of his own family arrested.", "title": "As Authoritarianism Spreads, Uzbekistan Goes the Other Way", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor decades, community activists in northeast Ohio have held demonstrations at the Cleveland Indians\u2019 home opener to protest the team\u2019s name and logo \u2014 a grinning, red-faced caricature named Chief Wahoo that some consider racist.\n\nAnd in what has become another tradition, Chief Wahoo\u2019s supporters have screamed back as they head toward the turnstiles at Progressive Field.\n\nThe back-and-forth on Friday at Cleveland\u2019s first home game of the season followed a pattern similar to past years\u2019 protests. But one longtime participant, Philip Yenyo, the executive director of the American Indian Movement of Ohio, said the confrontation was more crowded, more tense and more vulgar than usual. The heightened atmosphere was likely in part because of the team\u2019s decision to stop using the Chief Wahoo logo on its uniforms beginning next year \u2014 which angered some fans when it was announced in January.\n\nCleveland\u2019s baseball team is just one part of a cultural conversation that stretches across the sports landscape. Many people vigorously oppose the use of Native American names and images as mascots and insignias, saying they are demeaning or worse. Several teams use such logos, including the N.F.L.\u2019s Washington Redskins, the N.H.L.\u2019s Chicago Blackhawks and the N.C.A.A.\u2019s Florida State Seminoles. But some find the Indians\u2019 caricature, which has existed in various forms since 1947, particularly distasteful.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne video of this year\u2019s demonstration, which was organized by Mr. Yenyo\u2019s group and the Committee of 500 Years of Dignity and Resistance, has been viewed more than 110,000 times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPeople think this is just now coming up,\u201d Mr. Yenyo said. \u201cWe were never covered before. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, confirms in his new book that the bureau had already begun a criminal investigation focused on Hillary Clinton\u2019s handling of her email in 2015 when her campaign and its allies excoriated journalists for reporting that such an inquiry was being contemplated.\n\nThe New York Times reported in July 2015 that two inspectors general had made a criminal referral to the Justice Department recommending an investigation into whether Mrs. Clinton had mishandled sensitive information by using a private email server as secretary of state. Mrs. Clinton\u2019s campaign, relying on a statement from President Obama\u2019s Justice Department, complained vigorously to The Times, resulting in two corrections to the article.\n\nThe corrections said that the inspectors general had made a \u201csecurity referral\u201d rather than a \u201ccriminal referral\u201d and that the referral did not request that Mrs. Clinton specifically be investigated. Mrs. Clinton\u2019s campaign called the article an \u201cerroneous story\u201d with \u201cegregious\u201d errors that misled voters into thinking that she was at risk of being investigated by the F.B.I. for possible criminal violations when the referral was a more routine security matter not focused on her in particular. Early estimates for East Side Access predicted the tunnel would cost $2.2 billion and be finished by 2009.\n\nIn a presentation to the board, Janno Lieber, the authority\u2019s chief development officer, listed reasons for the rising price tag, including changes to contracts and insurance costs. One budget category alone known as \u201csoft costs,\u201d which includes engineering, management and real estate costs, has risen to nearly $2.2 billion, Mr. Lieber said.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t tell you that there isn\u2019t a lot of disappointment coming out of this review in terms of the budget impact,\u201d Mr. Lieber told the board.\n\nCosts have also ballooned on other M.T.A. projects, especially compared to international standards \u2014 the recently completed Second Avenue subway on Manhattan\u2019s Upper East Side cost $2.5 billion per mile, and the 2015 extension of the No. 7 line to Hudson Yards cost $1.5 billion per mile. Fitzsimmons"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "But Democrats assailed Republicans for preaching fiscal responsibility not long after voting for a tax bill that is projected to widen deficits. They warned that the proposal, if it ever became reality, would lead to deep cuts to Social Security and Medicare, programs that are driving up spending as the population ages.\n\n\u201cLike some stormy sermon from Trump on the virtues of chastity, I believe these House Republicans today really do deserve a gold medal for hypocrisy,\u201d said Representative Lloyd Doggett, Democrat of Texas.\n\nIn addition, economists critical of the idea of a balanced-budget amendment argue that it would essentially tie the hands of the government in the event of a recession, making economic conditions even worse.\n\n\u201cIt would force the government to kick the economy when it was down, because it would force the government to raise taxes and cut benefit programs, or any other type of spending, when times were bad \u2014 which is exactly the opposite of what you want to do,\u201d said Richard Kogan, a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a left-leaning research organization.\n\nIn another sign of the discomfort being felt by Republicans over the recent spending bill, the White House and congressional Republicans \u2014 including Representative Kevin McCarthy, the majority leader \u2014 have been discussing whether to try to rescind some previously approved spending.\n\nUsing procedures laid out in a 1974 budget law, such an effort could pass the Senate with only a majority, allowing Republicans to sidestep Democrats whose votes were needed to pass the spending bill last month.\n\nBut even that would be a difficult threshold to reach, given the Republicans\u2019 razor-thin majority in the Senate. It just seemed, given where Detroit was at the time, kind of a long-shot.\n\nIs Detroit ready?\n\nWe are. If you were with me in community meetings, you\u2019d see where people come and say: \u2018You need to reopen more recreation centers.\u2019 And I say, \u2018Look, this city ended up in financial crisis because its elected officials didn\u2019t have the courage to say to you that with the revenue we have, we can\u2019t afford to do that. I\u2019m not going to allow us to get to the point where anybody from the outside ever takes over again. So I\u2019m just going to tell you truth: We can\u2019t afford to do that right now.\u2019 And inevitably there\u2019s a huge round of applause from the crowd. People in this city just want to be told the truth.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs revenues grow, Detroit is bringing basic services like street sweeping back. How\u2019s that going?\n\nThe first time, we put up signs saying \u2018Please remove your cars for the street sweeper,\u2019 and people thought it was a joke. They didn\u2019t move their cars. The second and third time, people said, \u2018Oh my God, they\u2019re really sweeping streets.\u2019 It may seem like a small thing to you but for people in this city who are thinking, \u2018I\u2019m getting tired of living here, maybe I\u2019ll move out,\u2019 that street sweeper coming down the street says the quality of life is really being restored.\n\nSo, does this mean everything is great in Detroit now?\n\nEach year we have moved the needle in a positive direction and you can just see it. We have a six-month wait list now to get an apartment in Midtown. But we\u2019ve got a long way to go. Other cities have had a big advantage on us. We\u2019re up for it.\n\nIf you could magically fix one thing about the city right now, what would it be?\n\nThe violence. That\u2019s a huge part of our focus \u2014 to keep driving down the rate of violence.\n\nWhen Detroit filed for bankruptcy, lots of experts said it was a risky move that would forever tarnish the city\u2019s image and financial standing. But does Detroit\u2019s experience make an argument in favor of struggling cities going bankrupt?\n\nThe bankruptcy certainly gave us a restructured balance sheet that gave us money to deliver more services. But it was a traumatic experience for the people who lived here. I wouldn\u2019t recommend it to anybody.", "title": "As Detroit Sheds State Oversight, Its Mayor Reflects on Its Path", "authors": ["Monica Davey"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The engine failure that knocked a hole in the side of a Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 and left a woman dead on Tuesday was an extraordinarily unusual event, seemingly the result of a rare engine defect that scattered debris and knocked out one of the plane\u2019s windows at 32,000 feet.\n\nYet it was foreshadowed by a similar episode less than two years earlier.\n\n\u201cThe fact that this happened is a really, really freakish condition,\u201d said Mark Millam, a vice president at the Flight Safety Foundation. \u201cIf I was going to look at all the probabilities for a fatal accident, it would not have been this.\u201d\n\nThe initial cause of the engine failure this week, which forced the flight to make an emergency landing in Philadelphia, is believed to have been metal fatigue \u2014 the same problem that investigators think caused an engine failure on another Southwest 737 in August 2016.\n\nThat episode caused no deaths, but it prompted federal transportation regulators, the engine manufacturer and airlines to agree that more thorough engine inspections were necessary. Panmunjom, located within the DMZ and just 35 miles from the South Korean capital, Seoul, is the site of the Joint Security Area, where troops from North and South Korea are separated by only a few feet.\n\nA hotline directly connecting the two Korean leaders was installed last week. As a warm-up gesture, the line is supposed to be used by Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon before they travel to Panmunjom. Their talks will take place inside the Peace House, a conference center on the south side of the truce village.\n\nWhat would a peace treaty mean?\n\nMr. Moon has said the leaders will talk about establishing a treaty that would formally end the Korean War.\n\nIn the past, North Korea has demanded that the American soldiers stationed in the South must leave the peninsula as a condition of peace. But Mr. Kim\u2019s stance on the future of the 28,500 American troops appears to have softened in recent weeks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOver the decades, American presidents have decreased the number of troops stationed in the South. The Trump administration has made no suggestion that it would shrink the military contingent further.\n\nWhat is the likely outcome of Friday\u2019s meeting?\n\nExpect heavily scripted generalities. Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon plan to issue a joint declaration, which was largely brokered during a recent visit by South Korean officials to Pyongyang. Mr. Kim has said he is willing to discuss denuclearization in exchange for guarantees that his government would not be overthrown and his personal security would be assured.\n\nThe expected statement is likely to be short on specifics, intended to set the groundwork for more substantial negotiations between Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump. Watch for a commitment that the North and South will meet more regularly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat should we expect from talks between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim?\n\nThe two leaders spent much of last year exchanging threats and insults, but Mr. Trump has been widely positive in his approach to Mr. Kim since the North Korean leader signaled a willingness to negotiate.\n\nThe president praised Mr. Kim\u2019s announcement last week that he would suspend missile and nuclear tests and close a nuclear test site. So far, Mr. Trump has set no preconditions for talks with Mr. Kim.\n\nBut administration officials have been much firmer. They have called for a complete dismantlement of the nuclear arsenal in North Korea, a process that would need to be verified by inspections. Many experts see the latest offer from North Korea to suspend testing as an effort to wind back punishing United Nations sanctions.\n\nMr. Kim has called for the \u201cphased\u201d and \u201csynchronized\u201d implementation of any denuclearization deal, in which each stage of dismantlement would be met with incentives like the easing of sanctions.\n\nWhy is Japan wary of the rapprochement between Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump?\n\nPrime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is worried that the United States will agree to a deal in which North Korea dismantles its intercontinental missiles, but keeps shorter-range missiles that can hit Japan.\n\nSome analysts believe such an agreement would allow Mr. Trump to claim that he had saved the United States from the threat of North Korea, though doing so could come at the expense of Japan and South Korea.", "title": "As Korean Leaders Meet for Talks, Here\u2019s What You Need to Know", "authors": ["Jane Perlez"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia \u2014 In highway billboards and radio announcements, the government of Malaysia is warning of a new enemy: \u201cfake news.\u201d\n\nOn Monday, the lower house of Parliament passed a bill outlawing fake news, the first measure of its kind in the world. The proposal, which allows for up to six years in prison for publishing or circulating misleading information, is expected to pass the Senate this week and to come into effect soon after.\n\nThe legislation would punish not only those who are behind fake news but also anyone who maliciously spreads such material. Online service providers would be responsible for third-party content, and anyone could lodge a complaint. As long as Malaysia or Malaysians are affected, fake news generated outside the country is also subject to prosecution.\n\nWhat qualifies as fake news, however, is ill defined. Ultimately, the government would be given broad latitude to decide what constitutes fact in Malaysia.", "title": "As Malaysia Moves to Ban \u2018Fake News,\u2019 Worries About Who Decides the Truth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "But the group grew so big, including hundreds of children and infants, that the organizers paused the procession here last weekend, even before it had captured Mr. Trump\u2019s attention.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe migration authorities, taking advantage of the lull, began registering the migrants this week and issuing them letters of safe passage. The documents offer protection from deportation for either three weeks or a month, depending on whether the migrant intends to apply for legal immigration status in Mexico or leave the country \u2014 which for many migrants means applying for asylum in the United States or otherwise trying to cross the border.\n\nTold about Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet on Thursday declaring the end of the caravan, Irineo Mujica, Mexico director of Pueblo Sin Fronteras, shook his head in annoyance.\n\n\u201cThis man is completely wrong,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cWe\u2019re going to keep going.\u201d\n\nHe reflected a moment; his conflict with the American president had come into even sharper focus. \u201cWe\u2019re going to regroup in Puebla and send a message to Trump,\u201d he announced. \u201cNobody is going to stop us.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe size of the group camped at the sports complex here had gradually dropped over the course of the week as migrants received their safe-travel documents and left on their own. But there were still close to 1,000 on Wednesday, tired and undernourished, sleeping on sun-scorched soccer fields or in the shelter of forlorn buildings.\n\nThe first of the buses arrived before dawn on Thursday and took some 70 passengers to Puebla, where Pueblo Sin Fronteras plans to hold know-your-rights workshops. Two more buses left with every seat full around midday, one bound for Puebla and the other for Mexico City. Several more buses were expected to take only women and children to Puebla late Thursday.\n\nA contingent of about 200 men left, planning to hitchhike to a rail crossing where they hoped to get a ride on the top of one of the freight trains known collectively as La Bestia, or the Beast. The property they were leaving behind was a wasteland of food wrappers, clothes left soggy by a torrential downpour overnight and the odor of improvised latrines in the lee of trees and bushes.\n\nAlessandra L\u00f3pez, 26, said she hoped to be on board one of the overnight buses to Puebla where she intended to seek guidance on how to prepare a petition for asylum in the United States. Ms. L\u00f3pez, who is one of about a dozen transgender migrants in the caravan, said a criminal gang repeatedly tried to force her into prostitution and drug dealing.\n\n\u201cThey tried to kill me,\u201d she said. Her hope was to make it to the United States border and apply for asylum.\n\n\u201cHow is it there?\u201d she asked. \u201cHow is it crossing the bridge and asking for asylum?\u201d", "title": "As Migrant Caravan Splinters, Trump Takes Credit and Mexico Scoffs", "authors": ["Kirk Semple"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The number of new monthly prescriptions for medications that treat opioid addiction nearly doubled over the past two years, according to new data, while prescriptions for opioid painkillers continued to decline.\n\nThe changing calculus reflects a stepping up of efforts among policymakers and the medical establishment to address the nation\u2019s opioid epidemic, which is killing more than 115 people every day. But it also underscores questions about whether some pain patients are now being undertreated, and whether tightened prescribing over the last few years has contributed to the surge in overdose deaths from heroin and especially fentanyl.\n\nAlthough the number of people taking medications to combat addiction is rising, it remains a small fraction of the roughly 2.6 million people believed to suffer from \u201copioid use disorder,\u201d or addiction. The federal government has estimated that about 20 percent of them are getting some kind of treatment, but of those, only about a third are getting buprenorphine, naltrexone or methadone, the three medications approved by the Food and Drug Administration.\n\nPrescriptions for opioid painkillers have been dropping since 2011, but the trend accelerated last year with a decline of 10 percent from January through December, according to the IQVIA Institute for Human Data Science, which studies prescription drug use and spending. The highest-dose prescriptions, equivalent to 90 milligrams or more of morphine daily, dropped even more sharply, by 16 percent. Over the course of 2016, high-dose prescriptions dropped by 14.3 percent and opioid prescriptions over all dropped by 1.5 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe number of people newly prescribed opioid pain medicine declined by 7.8 percent over the course of 2017, according to the report, after rising by less than 1 percent the previous year.", "title": "As Opioid Prescriptions Fall, Prescriptions for Drugs to Treat Addiction Rise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "TEHRAN \u2014 As the veteran American director took the stage at Iran\u2019s Fajr International Film Festival, the audience stood up, clapping and cheering.\n\nYoung men wearing round sunglasses and women with purple dyed hair peeking out from under their compulsory headscarves watched as scenes from \u201cPlatoon,\u201d \u201cMidnight Express,\u201d \u201cJFK\u201d and \u201cAny Given Sunday\u201d appeared on the screen. The clip ended with the introduction of the guest of honor: \u2018\u2018American writer and director, Oliver Stone.\u2019\u2019\n\n\u201cYou make it seem as if I\u2019m dead already,\u201d Mr. Stone, 71, joked. Typically, Iranian hard-liners try to prevent prominent Americans, even harsh critics of United States policies like Mr. Stone, from obtaining visas. But in his case other forces had prevailed. Iranian politics are divided by those opposing any approach to America and those who feel there should be an outreach.\n\nNow, the American was the guest of honor at an event that, like Iranian society, has undergone major changes in recent years. His cell is about 161 square feet \u2014 compared with the usual 97 square feet \u2014 and he doesn\u2019t share it with other inmates.\n\nThe cell, which was previously used to host police officers visiting Curitiba on temporary assignments, is near offices in an area separate from the holding cells where regular prisoners are held.\n\nHe is the only prisoner on the fourth floor of the Federal Police building here; the others are on the first floor.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a clean space, with a bed, a dresser and a bathroom,\u201d Cristiano Zanin, Mr. da Silva\u2019s lawyer, said in an interview on Monday. \u201cThe room itself is not a problem. As far as the place, it\u2019s, let\u2019s say, modest.\u201d\n\nMr. Zanin said the soccer game just happened to be playing. \u201cHe didn\u2019t make any request, didn\u2019t ask to be allowed to watch the game,\u201d the lawyer said. \u201cThe television set was already there.\u201d\n\nMr. da Silva packed a handful of books to read while in custody, including \u201cA Elite do Atraso,\u201d or \u201cThe Backward Elite,\u201d a book by the Brazilian sociologist Jess\u00e9 de Souza. The author argues that Brazil\u2019s huge corruption investigation, which is known as Lava Jato, or Car Wash, is a critical part of a plot to maintain wealth and power in the hands of the elite.\n\nMr. Zanin said there were several details yet to be worked out regarding how much contact Mr. da Silva, an energetic and gregarious leftist politician, would be allowed to have outside his legal team.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPrisoners in the Curitiba police building ordinarily get two hours a day outside their cells. They can see their lawyers anytime, and relatives once per week. The cell\u2019s windows, which do not have bars, open onto an interior corridor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile Mr. da Silva\u2019s cell boasts no luxuries, it is a far cry from the conditions ordinary prisoners endure in Brazil\u2019s notoriously crowded, violent and underfunded prison system.\n\nLast year, 722,000 inmates were detained, crammed into a network of buildings designed to house one-third that number, said Juliana Melo, a professor at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte who studies the country\u2019s penal system.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a myth that this is the country of impunity,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s the country of selectivity.\u201d She noted that the vast majority of prisoners in Brazil are black or mixed-race men charged with drug crimes. More than 40 percent have yet to be tried.\n\nOther defendants convicted in the Car Wash scandal have also been spared being held with the general prison population. Several \u2014 including the former governor of Rio de Janeiro, S\u00e9rgio Cabral, and the former speaker of the lower house of Congress, Eduardo Cunha \u2014 are imprisoned at a medical correctional institution outside of Curitiba.\n\nAs Mr. da Silva has begun settling into a new routine, hundreds of his supporters have set up a camp outside the police building.\n\n\u201cLula has become a political prisoner, victim of relentless persecution by adversaries who resorted to the judiciary to silence him, destroy him, in an effort to discredit his role before history and the Brazilian people,\u201d the former President Dilma Rousseff, Mr. da Silva\u2019s handpicked successor, said in a statement Monday.\n\nThe leader of Mr. da Silva\u2019s Workers\u2019 Party, Senator Gleisi Hoffmann, has reiterated over the past couple of days that Mr. da Silva is still the party\u2019s candidate for the presidential election that will be held in October. But even if Mr. da Silva were free to campaign, under Brazilian law, his conviction makes him ineligible to run.\n\n\u201cOur vigil will not end,\u201d Ms. Hoffmann said during a rally on Sunday in Curitiba. \u201cWhile Lula is in jail, we\u2019ll stay here.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, as some 500 supporters gathered, there were sandwiches for sale, a row of portable toilets and an information center staffed by party loyalists. They offered free water and snacks for passers-by.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re socialists,\u201d a woman explained, as she handed a reporter a cup of water.", "title": "As President, \u2018Lula\u2019 of Brazil Opened the Prison. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, is confronting the political fight of his career. Amid sustained criticism by President Trump and rumors that he will be fired, Mr. Rosenstein is also maneuvering to defuse demands by Republicans in Congress that Democrats say are aimed at ousting him from his job \u2014 and from his role as protector of the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.\n\nSo far, he appears to be succeeding. Two years ago it would have been an unthinkable one. But last month an email arrived in my inbox requesting my presence in Riyadh, the capital city of Saudi Arabia. The desert kingdom, one of the most conservative societies in the world and historically known as a place with a resistance to anything new, was in the final stages of preparations for its first official fashion week. Now the organizers wanted a reporter from The New York Times to attend.\n\nI said yes immediately, and not just because I wanted to see local design talent on the runways, or experience catwalk shows at an event held at the Ritz-Carlton hotel (yes, that one), with women-only audiences and a strict social media ban. Not long ago, such access to Saudi Arabia as a journalist, especially as a young, unmarried Western female one, was virtually unheard-of. But the country is experiencing a time of great change, propelled by the ascendance of the king\u2019s son, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 32. Alongside efforts to diversify the economy away from oil, \u201cM.B.S.,\u201d as he is widely known, has been spearheading the easing of many longstanding social restrictions. In recent months Saudi Arabia has given women permission to drive, join the military, visit sports arenas and cinemas, and as of last week, attend public fashion shows.\n\nThe prince even said last month that women do not need to wear the hijab or the black abaya (a loose-fitted robe), as long as their attire is \u201cdecent and respectful.\u201d (For opening night, I opted to wear a floor-length, long-sleeved, midnight blue silk dress with hand-painted white flowers on the skirt, but kept an abaya close at hand in my bag.)\n\nBut did Saudis themselves believe real change was in the air? People under 25 represent 51 percent of the population; add Saudis up to their mid-30s and the proportion approaches 75 percent. I wanted to see what those citizens, most glued to their smartphones and plenty who have either been educated or spent time abroad, made of the lofty promises being made to them, and discover what government measures felt meaningful versus simply symbolic. I was curious to hear about their ambitions for employment in a volatile economy, and what their hopes were for what could come next. My chance came when the fashion week was unexpectedly postponed by 24 hours following my arrival into Riyadh (the event\u2019s second abrupt delay), and I ended up with more time on my hands than originally expected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n[For more coverage of women and gender issues, subscribe to Gender Letter, a new newsletter, or follow @nytgender on Instagram.]", "title": "As Saudi Arabian Society Opens, a Fashion Reporter Looks Past the Runway", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "TOKYO \u2014 Amid tensions over trade and North Korea, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan leaves Tuesday to visit President Trump at his Palm Beach estate. Spotify had closed its first day with a market valuation of $26.5 billion.\n\nIn Spotify\u2019s early days, record companies viewed the streaming service\u2019s hybrid business model of both free and paid streaming as a potential risk that could undermine the sales of CDs and downloads. Cuomo\u2019s push to tie teacher evaluations more closely to student scores. The opt-out momentum has stalled considerably, but the number of test refusers remains substantial. They earned a matchup against the Pittsburgh Penguins, their hated rival and the two-time defending Stanley Cup champions.\n\nAfter a 7-0 loss on Wednesday to the Penguins in Pittsburgh in Game 1 of the series, the Flyers rallied for a 5-1 victory in Game 2 on Friday, scraping up some mojo. Game 3 is Sunday in Philadelphia, which was called a \u201ccity of losers\u201d as recently as the beginning of February but which is now on a winning streak.\n\nThe Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl in February, their first N.F.L. championship since 1960. Villanova, whose campus is 12 miles outside Philadelphia, this month won the N.C.A.A. men\u2019s basketball tournament for the second time in three years, celebrating with a victory parade through Philadelphia\u2019s streets.\n\nWith the Eagles\u2019 championship, the Flyers took over as the city professional team whose title wait is the longest. The 76ers won their last N.B.A. title in 1983, and the Phillies won their last World Series in 2008.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m pretty sure we\u2019re all aware of it,\u201d Shayne Gostisbehere, a 24-year-old defenseman, said of the 43-year streak. \u201cThe whole city of Philadelphia is, probably.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nChampionship fever may be contagious. After the Eagles won the Super Bowl on Feb. 4, the Flyers won 10 of their next 11 games, with the only loss in a shootout. The Sixers, who made the N.B.A. playoffs this season for the first time since 2012, won seven games in a row after the Super Bowl.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen you see that parade, you want to take part in one yourself,\u201d said Jake Voracek, the forward who has played for the Flyers for seven seasons. \u201cMaybe, in that way, it helps. I\u2019ve been there.\u201d\n\nDornhoefer said he had no problem with the Flyers\u2019 past being right in the face of the current players in their dressing room, saying with a laugh: \u201cI would want it around. I think it would motivate me even more.\u201d\n\nHe said of the Eagles, who won three playoff games as underdogs, \u201cThey weren\u2019t favored to win, either, but they won it all.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow it would seem to be the Flyers\u2019 turn.", "title": "As Titles Pile Up in Philly, the Flyers Wonder When It Will Be Their Turn", "authors": ["Dave Caldwell"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Investors may believe China\u2019s move will lead to drawn-out negotiations. Here, Brexit is again illustrative. As the back and forth between the European Union and Britain has gone on, investors have gained more clarity and confidence. If talks between the U.S. and China gain steam, the uncertainty now clouding relations between the two countries may gradually clear.\n\nBut the standoff between the U.S. and China differs in important ways from the Brexit tensions. The U.S., for instance, is in a much stronger position than Britain. China exports far more to the U.S. than the U.S. does to China. Limiting access to the U.S. economy could hurt China\u2019s growth at a time when it is trying to overhaul important economic sectors. If investors believe that the U.S. can successfully exploit its advantages to make China more friendly to foreign businesses, they may even see the trade skirmish as positive for the global economy.\n\nBut Brexit also flashes a warning to those expecting a big win for Mr. Trump. One of the reasons that the European Union has presented a united front is that it sees Brexit as a threat to its values and goals. Similarly, China may believe that Mr. Trump\u2019s trade attack puts some of its most deeply held aspirations under threat \u2013 and will fight back hard.\n\n- Peter Eavis\n\nAnother bank takes steps toward gun safety.\n\nAfter Citigroup announced plans to limit firearms sales by business customers, the question was which lenders would be the next to make a move on guns. The latest: Amalgamated Bank, the union-owned bank known for its socially minded policies.\n\nThe firm said on Wednesday that it would adopt guidelines for lenders laid out by Everytown for Gun Safety, an advocacy group backed by Mike Bloomberg.\n\nAmong those recommendations:\n\n\u2022 Require gun dealers to protect merchandise from burglary and theft and refuse sales to people who appear in distress or intoxicated\n\n\u2022 Require retailers to stop selling high-capacity magazines and bump stocks\n\n\u2022 Require gun makers to \u201ccommit to developing innovations in firearms that will allow law enforcement to more easily solve gun crimes\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmalgamated said that it would not only require all business customers to adhere to those guidelines but added that it won\u2019t invest any of its own money in gun manufacturers or distributors.\n\nHere\u2019s what Amalgamated\u2019s C.E.O. Keith Mestrich, said in a news release:\n\n\u201cCollectively, banks and lenders have the power to promote responsible business practices from gun manufacturers and distributors, and ultimately contribute to a safer society for all. Amalgamated will do whatever we can to achieve that goal and we hope other banks and financial institutions will agree and act.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nCambridge Analytica harvested the data of 87 million Facebook users, not 50 million.\n\nFacebook on Wednesday said the personal information of up to 87 million people, most of them Americans, may have been improperly shared during the 2016 election with Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm connected to President Trump.\n\nThe new figure sharply increased the company\u2019s previous estimate of how many users\u2019 information was harvested by Cambridge Analytica. The number had been put at more than 50 million users.\n\nThe sharing of the user data has unleashed a torrent of criticism at Facebook, the world\u2019s largest social network. The company\u2019s stock is down sharply since The New York Times and The Observer of London reported on how Cambridge Analytica improperly acquired users\u2019 data.\n\nThe company released the revised estimate of affected users in an extended statement on Wednesday about its plans for handling personal data. The company said it will start alerting users on April 9 about whether their information may have been shared with Cambridge Analytica.\n\nIn related Facebook news\n\n\u2022 Earlier on Wednesday, lawmakers in Washington had said Facebook\u2019s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, would testify before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on April 11 about the company\u2019s handling of sensitive user data.\n\nPhoto\n\nNext steps in the tariffs tit-for-tat.\n\nBeijing moved quickly to escalate its fight with the U.S., responding to the White House\u2019s latest move with $50 billion worth of tariffs on soybeans, cars, chemicals and more. U.S. market futures predictably dropped, as did other markets.\n\nBoth sides could suffer. Chinese companies are scrambling to react, especially as the U.S. looks to be taking aim at technology (like that central to Made in China 2025). And the squeeze could extend to American companies in unexpected industries, like wine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe big question: Is a full-blown trade war coming? Nathaniel Taplin of Heard on the Street writes, \u201cIf ongoing negotiations fail and these tariffs become a reality, the long-term impact will likely be far more damaging.\u201d\n\nBoeing is down 4 percent.\n\nAnd is dragging down the Dow Jones industrial average. The blue-chip index is off nearly 350 points, or 1.4 percent. That slide is worse than the declines of the S.&P. 500 and the Nasdaq Composite, which are both down less than 1 percent.\n\nBoeing\u2019s 4 percent fall has shaved 87 points off the Dow Wednesday. Boeing is the highest priced stock in the price-weighted index, which means Boeing has an outsized impact on the index\u2019s moves.\n\nBoeing\u2019s shares have served as a proxy for investor concern about a possible trade war with China since the Trump administration announced tariffs on aluminum and steel.\n\nOver that period, the stock has fallen 12 percent.\n\nPhoto\n\nSpotify continues to slide.\n\nThe streaming-music company\u2019s shares opened at $165.90, but they steadily decline throughout their first day of trading, closing at $149.01.\n\nThe stock is down 4.1 percent to $142.91 in early trading Wednesday.\n\nBecause Spotify eschewed a typical initial public offering in favor of a direct listing, there is no I.P.O. price off which to base the performance of its shares. But the company\u2019s current shares price remains well above the $132.50 its private shares changed hands at earlier this year.\n\nSpotify\u2019s public. Now what?\n\nSpotify finished Tuesday valued at $26.5 billion. Does that count as a success? Shira Ovide of Gadfly argues no, since only a tiny fraction of Spotify\u2019s shares are available to trade.\n\nAnd will it lead to a wave of direct listings, leaving depressed, workless I.P.O. bankers in its wake? Maybe not, though the Big Board acknowledged signs of more informal interest in direct listings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne big winner from Spotify's trading debut?\n\nSony.\n\nIts subsidiary, Sony Music Entertainment, owned 5.7 percent of Spotify ahead of its listing. Sony said it sold 17.2 percent of that stake Tuesday. Sony expects to book a non-operating profit of $986 million this quarter from the increased valuation of the Spotify shares it continues holds and from the share sale.\n\nAt Tuesday\u2019s close, Sony\u2019s 5.7 percent stake was worth $1.5 billion.\n\nSony isn\u2019t only Asian tech company benefitting from Spotify\u2019s smooth debut. Tencent, the Chinese social media company, holds a 7.5 percent stake. That was worth about $2 billion as of Tuesday\u2019s close.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat we don\u2019t know about the YouTube shooter\n\nThe video site and its parent company, Alphabet, are still grappling with the shooting at YouTube\u2019s headquarters in the Bay Area yesterday. What we know: Police identified the shooter as Nasim Najafi Aghdam, who was in her late 30s and killed herself at the scene. Three people were hurt, one critically.\n\nWhat we don\u2019t know: the motive. Ms. Aghdam, who posted to YouTube and other social media, criticized the video site\u2019s policies on Facebook in February. But authorities haven\u2019t highlighted any specific grievance, and said they had yet to find evidence that specific individuals were targeted.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. YouTube, like many other big tech companies, doesn\u2019t have visible metal detectors or armed guards.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 Robert Mueller reportedly told President Trump\u2019s lawyers that he\u2019s a subject of interest, but not yet an investigation target. A former Skadden lawyer who admitted deceiving Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigators, Alex van der Zwaan, was sentenced to 30 days in prison and fined $20,000.\n\n\u2022 The Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget are fighting over how to implement the tax overhaul, as businesses go to great lengths to lower their tax bills.\n\n\u2022 Senator Elizabeth Warren\u2019s suggested method for measuring misconduct at financial institutions probably wouldn\u2019t lead to more prosecutions. (White Collar Watch)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 John Williams is the next president of the New York Fed, despite calls for diversity. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Articles about Scott Pruitt are now focusing on ethical improprieties, not regulatory rollbacks. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nWPP\u2019s C.E.O., a giant in the ad world, is under investigation\n\nAt issue in WPP\u2019s inquiry into its C.E.O., Martin Sorrell, are allegations of misuse of company assets and of personal misconduct, according to the WSJ. Mr. Sorrell has denied any wrongdoing.\n\nThe investigation comes at a tough time: WPP\u2019s revenue is down, and competition from Google and Facebook is up. One of the FT\u2019s unnamed sources couldn\u2019t see how Mr. Sorrell would survive.\n\nIn other misconduct news: Morgan Stanley fired Douglas Greenberg, a star financial adviser accused of physical abuse and stalking by multiple women, following an NYT investigation.\n\nPhoto\n\nCan venture capital become less male?\n\nForbes profiled All Raise, a group of 36 women trying to double the percentage of women in V.C. partner roles and to increase funding to female founders to 25 percent from 15 percent. It has commitments of $2 million from supporters like Silicon Valley Bank and is in talks with Melinda Gates\u2019s investment firm.\n\nDiversity, they argue, will help investors spot future successes like Stitch Fix.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat to expect from the CBS-Viacom talks\n\nIt\u2019ll be a joust, over money and management. CBS has reportedly submitted a takeover bid for its corporate sibling, Viacom \u2014 but one below Viacom\u2019s market value of $12.5 billion, and without a No. 2 slot at the combined company for the target\u2019s C.E.O., Bob Bakish.\n\nThat isn\u2019t going to sit well with either Mr. Bakish or his patron, Shari Redstone. Tara Lachapelle of Gadfly argues that ego shouldn\u2019t hold up a deal.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Procter & Gamble is reportedly talking to Pfizer about buying its consumer health business, but far from agreeing on a price. GlaxoSmithKline and Reckitt Benckiser both walked away. (CNBC)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The Justice Department is relying on a skewed study of the Time Warner deal, lawyers for AT&T argued in court. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Elliott Management has purchased a $1 billion stake in various affiliates of Hyundai Motors, another venture into Korean chaebols. (Elliott)\n\n\u2022 The high-end coffee brand La Colombe, reportedly hired Moelis & Company to explore the sale of a stake that could value the company at $1 billion. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 The Chinese digital conglomerate Meituan has bought Mobike, a bike-sharing company, for $2.7 billion. (CNBC)\n\nPhoto\n\nSoftBank finds limits to its friendship with Trump\n\nThe Japanese conglomerate has reportedly given up day-to-day control over the Fortress Investment Group to help its deal pass the powerful U.S. security watchdog known as Cfius, according to the FT. That could make the investment firm a less useful support for SoftBank\u2019s $100 billion Vision Fund.\n\nThe takeaways: The efforts by SoftBank\u2019s Masa Son to court President Trump don\u2019t always translate into favorable treatment by the White House, and national security concerns will weigh heavily on foreign investment in the U.S. post-Broadcom.\n\nPhoto\n\nWill Trump act against Amazon?\n\nThe president has pressed his claim that Amazon is \u201ccosting the United States Postal Service massive amounts of money,\u201d (It isn\u2019t.)\n\nVanity Fair reports that some specific anti-Amazon ideas have been kicked around, including rethinking Amazon\u2019s contract with the U.S.P.S., canceling its cloud services contract with the Pentagon and encouraging state investigations. (Amazon does not have a contract with the Department of Defense for cloud computing services. The contract for those services has not been awarded to any company including Amazon.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Bloomberg can find no active discussions about such actions, and Wall Street analysts say investors should ignore the noise, which puts Amazon in good company.\n\nMore on Amazon and the cloud: Mr. Trump was scheduled to dine last night with Safra Catz of Oracle. Why is that important?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Tesla\u2019s first-quarter production still fell short of an already lowered target, but shares in the embattled carmaker rose anyway. Investors might want to be wary of Elon Musk\u2019s promises.\n\n\u2022 Facebook removed over 270 accounts and pages tied to Russia\u2019s Internet Research Agency, widely regarded as a troll factory. Mark Zuckerberg won\u2019t globalize Europe\u2019s stricter privacy regulations. Tim Wu of Columbia Law School argues that Facebook needs replacing, not fixing.\n\n\u2022 India\u2019s government is eager to collect personal data, but bad at protecting it, an NYT Op-Ed contributor argues. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Apple has hired John Giannandrea from Google to run its machine learning and A.I. strategy. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Deutsche Bank formally named John Thain, Mayree Clark and Michele Trogni to its supervisory board. (Deutsche Bank)\n\n\u2022 Goldman Sachs has reportedly hired Hari Moorthy, an engineer at JPMorgan Chase, to build tools to help big companies manage cash. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe speed read\n\n\u2022 Companies\u2019 charitable spending is more self-serving than they would have us believe. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 An Indian government crackdown on fake news lasted less than a day. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Chinese conglomerate Anbang will receive $9.7 billion from an industry rescue fund. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Longfin, a fintech company that went public under small-company rules in December, lost 85 percent of value in six trading days and is now under investigation by the S.E.C. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 After one of its worst quarters ever, David Einhorn\u2019s hedge fund Greenlight Capital is sticking to its strategy. (CNBC)\n\nNote: While we congratulated Villanova yesterday, we did not congratulate Notre Dame for its win on Sunday, which we heartily do so now.\n\nKnow someone who would enjoy this newsletter?
