Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "As Trade Tensions Rise, Here Are Some Lessons From Brexit: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "For his part, Mr. Brown said Washington was \u201cbasically going to war against the state of California.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPolls suggest that the two leading contenders to succeed Mr. Brown are Gavin Newsom, the lieutenant governor and a former mayor of San Francisco, and Antonio R. Villaraigosa, the former two-term mayor of Los Angeles and Assembly speaker, both Democrats. The two are known as effective public speakers with extensive political experience that could prove important in navigating the fight against Washington.\n\nOf the two, Mr. Newsom has assumed the more aggressive stance in taking on the Trump administration, drawing strong support from liberal Democrats in the process. He has also called for the impeachment of Mr. Trump. A centerpiece of his campaign is a pledge to adopt a government-run, single-payer health care system, a direct challenge to the free-market vision embraced by Mr. Trump and congressional Republicans.\n\n\u201cThis is more than a political campaign,\u201d Mr. Newsom told cheering delegates at the state Democratic convention here this year. \u201cIt\u2019s about Democrats acting like Democrats in a battle for America\u2019s soul against a president without one.\u201d\n\n\u201cSome of the defeatist Democrats are saying we just want to defend against the status quo,\u201d he told another audience that day. \u201cHow can you just defend against the status quo? We need to do more than just push back against their agenda to wreak more havoc.\u201d\n\nMr. Villaraigosa has struck a more restrained note, saying it was too early to talk about impeachment and dismissing Mr. Newsom\u2019s promise to have California go it alone with its own health care system as a \u201cpie in the sky\u201d promise he was making to ride anti-Trump sentiment. In tone, Mr. Villaraigosa is closer to Mr. Brown in positioning himself against the president.\n\n\u201cGavin likes to talk about the resistance \u2014 I don\u2019t use that word,\u201d Mr. Villaraigosa said over green tea during a break from campaigning in downtown Los Angeles. \u201cI tell people the best way to resist is not to text and tweet, scream and yell at Donald Trump. The best way to resist is for us to chart a different path here in this state.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are going to push back,\u201d he said. \u201cBut most of our attention, most of our efforts need to be focused on improving the human condition here.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRobert Shrum, the director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California, said the divisions on health care and impeachment reflected discussions Democrats were having nationally as they debated the best way to defeat Mr. Trump. Mr. Villaraigosa\u2019s stance reflects the calculation that while California is overwhelmingly Democratic in its voting habits, many voters are independent by registration, and thus might be less receptive to an overly confrontational position against Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cNewsom is endorsing all of those things on the Democratic wish list,\u201d Mr. Shrum said. \u201cVillaraigosa is saying, \u2018I like those things, but we actually can\u2019t do them.\u2019\n\n\u201cOne position speaks to the anger in the base,\u201d he said. \u201cThe other speaks to what I think Democratic leadership in Congress prefers.\u201d\n\nUnder California\u2019s election system, 27 candidates will appear on a primary ballot on June 5, regardless of party. A runoff in November will be held between the top two finishers.\n\nWhile polls suggest the November contest will be between Mr. Villaraigosa and Mr. Newsom, the dynamics of a multicandidate field can make it difficult to predict who might finish in the top. John Chiang, a Democrat and the state treasurer, and John H. Cox, a Republican businessman, also appear to be in position to capture a spot on the November ballot, according to some polls.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd Delaine Eastin, a Democrat and the former state superintendent of public education, has drawn vocal support from the left with her own call for single-payer health care and the impeachment of Mr. Trump.\n\nIf the November election ends up being between Mr. Villaraigosa and Mr. Newsom, it will be a classic north-versus-south contest. Candidates from Northern California tend to win those, because of heavier turnout in the Bay Area; Mr. Newsom enjoys a big advantage in fund-raising and leads in most statewide polls.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Villaraigosa would be the first Latino governor elected in modern times. He is running when the ever-growing Latino community accounts for nearly 40 percent of the population and when California is battling with the administration over restrictive immigration policies.\n\nMr. Newsom, 50, has made a single-payer government-run health care system for California a central plank of his campaign as he has sought to ride the anti-Trump sentiment that is surging in Democratic circles here, including within the powerful nurses\u2019 union. \u201cIt is a litmus test for our endorsement,\u201d said Bonnie Castillo, the executive director of the California Nurses Association. \u201cGavin passes it with flying colors.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s efforts to undermine the Affordable Care Act, and his pledge to continue doing so, mean that health care will most likely be another challenge for the next governor, whether or not California carries out single-payer.\n\n\u201cIf our health care system is thrown into absolute chaos because of what happens in Washington, the voters in California are going to expect the Democrats who control California to deal with it,\u201d said Garry South, a longtime Democratic consultant who advises the nurses\u2019 union.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf Mr. Newsom won and made good on that campaign promise, he would open a up a whole new area of contention with Mr. Trump. Single-payer health care is likely to require waivers from the Trump administration in order to apply Medicare payments to financing a potentially $400 billion program, along with substantial tax increases.\n\nMr. Villaraigosa, 65, said he supported the concept of single-payer health care, but dismissed Mr. Newsom\u2019s promise as unrealistic.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s arguing with bold leadership we\u2019re going to do it \u2014 even though he knows you need Trump\u2019s waivers to do it,\u201d Mr. Villaraigosa said. \u201cThey are not going to give us the waivers for that. Think about this: You ready to double your taxes? Nobody is going to do that. Everyone is for it until they realize \u2014 whoa. The cost. \u201d\n\nMr. Chiang said he, too, supported a state health care system. \u201cI just think Gavin Newsom should be forthcoming on how they are going to pay for it,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Newsom dismissed his critics as \u201cdefeatist Democrats.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a jaw-dropping thing: to say you support something but it can\u2019t be done,\u201d Mr. Newsom said in an interview a few blocks from his office in Sacramento. \u201cWho the hell is interested in \u2018it can\u2019t be done\u2019? We wouldn\u2019t have marriage equality if I had listened to \u2018it can\u2019t be done.\u2019\u201d\n\nAsked what his plan was to pay for it, Mr. Newsom responded: \u201cThe one that works is the one I support. I\u2019m not an ideologue.\u201d\n\nStill, the biggest question may well be whether anyone will be able to replace Mr. Brown as California\u2019s counterpoint to Mr. Trump \u2014 and whether the state\u2019s stature as a national leader in this fight will diminish when Mr. Brown retires to his ranch next January.\n\n\u201cCalifornia is usually the leading edge,\u201d said Ms. Eastin, one of the Democrats seeking to replace him. \u201cIt\u2019s the sixth-largest economy in the world. I think California will get attention.\u201d", "title": "As Trump Leads a \u2018War\u2019 on California, Who Will Lead California?", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "By that time, Mr. Trump had suspended more than $200 million in funds for recovery efforts in Syria.\n\n\u201cI want to get out,\u201d he said at the White House last week. \u201cI want to bring our troops back home.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s aides quickly talked him out of an immediate withdrawal. But Mr. Trump made clear that he wanted the troops out within a few months, senior administration officials said, a decision that would alter the landscape in ways that would echo far beyond Syria\u2019s borders.\n\nFoes of the United States have cheered the prospect of an American withdrawal. But America\u2019s regional allies, including Israel, Saudi Arabia and its partners in Syria, dread it.\n\nThey argue that American forces are still needed to provide a check on Russia, which considers Syria its strategic foothold in the Middle East, and Iran, whose proxies are building a military infrastructure in Syria to counter Israel.\n\nA withdrawal could also leave the door open for the return of the Islamic State in some parts of Syria, the very reason the United States gave for intervening in the country to begin with.\n\nThe bombing that Mr. Trump was responding to was part of a battle between rebels and the Syrian government, one that the United States had withdrawn from long ago, in a part of the country where the United States has neither a military presence nor any clear allies.\n\nThere is nothing to stop Mr. Trump from ordering a missile strike on western Syria, where the chemical attack was alleged to have taken place, and still pulling the approximately 2,000 American troops out of eastern Syria, where their main task was battling the militants of the Islamic State. But the seesaw of withdrawal and deeper engagement, without the articulation of a clear strategy for the region, is sure to confuse allies and enemies alike.", "title": "As Trump Seeks Way Out of Syria, New Attack Pulls Him Back In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is a moment of his own making,\u201d Mr. Cha added.\n\nCharacteristically, Mr. Trump betrayed no anxiety in recent days as he discussed the challenges of the summit meeting, which is scheduled for late May or early June in a location still to be determined. He took much of the credit for the diplomatic thaw on the Korean Peninsula, and he said he would not commit the mistakes of his predecessors, whom he said had showered the North with money and extracted nothing in return.\n\n\u201cThe United States has been played beautifully, like a fiddle, because you had a different kind of a leader,\u201d Mr. Trump said after meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at the White House. \u201cWe\u2019re not going to be played, O.K.? We\u2019re going to hopefully make a deal; if we don\u2019t, that\u2019s fine.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump reiterated that he was prepared to cancel the meeting, or walk out in the middle of it, if his diplomatic efforts were not making any headway. But some of his aides say privately they worry that the president, with an eye on the history books and a flair for the theatrical, is determined to emerge with a victory, even if it falls short of his stated goals.\n\nCertainly, he seemed beguiled by the imagery of the Moon-Kim meeting. \u201cKOREAN WAR TO END!\u201d he tweeted before 7 a.m. on Friday, a few hours after the leaders shook hands in the Demilitarized Zone.\n\nOn Saturday, Mr. Trump said he had a \u201cvery good talk\u201d with Mr. Moon. \u201cThings are going well,\u201d he tweeted. \u201cTime and location of meeting with North Korea is being set.\u201d Later, at a rally in Michigan, Mr. Trump told supporters that he deserved virtually all the credit for the success of the meeting between the North and the South.\n\nThe price of failure would be high for Mr. Trump. The United States could face a split with its ally South Korea, which is deeply invested in ending its estrangement from the North. Tensions could flare with China, North Korea\u2019s main trading partner, which only grudgingly signed on to the sanctions and would be likely to balk at keeping them in place if Mr. Kim is talking about peace.\n\nMr. Trump is also moving on other fronts that could undercut his negotiations with Mr. Kim. He appears more likely than ever to rip up the Iran nuclear deal as he faces his next deadline of May 12 to decide whether to reimpose sanctions on Tehran.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWalking away from one nuclear disarmament deal while trying to strike another would be a trick, even for a self-proclaimed dealmaker like Mr. Trump.\n\nThere is little question, senior officials and analysts said, that the American-led sanctions, combined with Mr. Trump\u2019s bellicose vows to rain \u201cfire and fury\u201d on North Korea if it threatened the American homeland, helped bring Mr. Kim to the table.\n\nBut Mr. Trump is only one of three actors in this drama, and perhaps not the most crucial one. Mr. Moon, a progressive former human rights lawyer, ran for office on a platform of conciliation with the North and has moved aggressively to deliver on that promise. He, not Mr. Trump, has set the pace and terms of the negotiation with the North, though American officials say that Seoul is closely coordinating with Washington.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kim, for his part, made a bold bet on diplomacy. His motives for seeking a rapprochement are open to debate. Skeptical analysts said the advancements in North Korea\u2019s intercontinental ballistic missile program \u2014 as much as sanctions or threatened military strikes \u2014 made the timing right for an overture. Others say he is replaying the cycle of provocation and conciliation pioneered by his father and grandfather.\n\nWhatever his motives, the 34-year-old dictator has proved to be a remarkably adroit player on the world stage. \u201cIf anyone gets credit, it\u2019s Kim Jong-un,\u201d said Daniel R. Russel, a former assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs who is now at the Asia Society. \u201cIt\u2019s his show.\u201d\n\nSo far, Mr. Kim\u2019s bet has paid off handsomely. Since beginning his overture a month before the Winter Olympics in South Korea, he has been awarded a meeting with President Xi Jinping of China, who had earlier treated him with thinly disguised contempt. He was welcomed by Mr. Moon with a South Korean honor guard. And he is on the verge of something once inconceivable: a meeting with the American president.\n\nThough Mr. Kim made gestures of his own \u2014 a pledge not to test bombs or long-range missiles, and an end to the North\u2019s longtime insistence that American troops withdraw from the peninsula \u2014 he has not made any tangible concessions on his nuclear weapons. The language in his joint statement with Mr. Moon about denuclearization was both vague and familiar to veterans of past negotiations with North Korea.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s gotten all these meetings with world leaders without making any concessions,\u201d said Jung H. Pak, a former C.I.A. analyst who is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution\u2019s Center for East Asia Policy Studies. \u201cSo far, everything has been no-cost for Kim.\u201d\n\nGiven the warmth of the Moon-Kim meeting, few analysts are predicting that Mr. Trump\u2019s meeting with Mr. Kim will be sour. The most likely situation is an encounter that produces more riveting imagery and results in a broad agreement to negotiate disarmament in return for an easing of North Korea\u2019s economic isolation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Friday, Mr. Trump said the meeting location had been narrowed to two or three sites. Officials had hoped to have already locked down a place, but said the process was more complicated than expected. Singapore and Mongolia have emerged as prime candidates, though an official said a site in South Korea remained a possibility.\n\nThe challenge for Mr. Trump will be embarking on a protracted negotiation with Mr. Kim that, if the past is any guide, will quickly bog down in highly technical discussions about inspections of nuclear sites, the dismantling of installations and the removal of nuclear fuel.\n\nSome question whether Mr. Trump\u2019s hawkish new national security team \u2014 led by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and the national security adviser, John R. Bolton \u2014 will have the stomach for that. Others note that Mr. Trump may face pressure on the right if it looks as though North Korea is playing for time, as it did during the Bill Clinton and George W. Bush administrations.\n\nWith the North seeking to re-establish diplomatic and economic ties to the South, Mr. Trump will find it difficult to play the cards he used during his first year in office. Some analysts said Mr. Kim\u2019s outreach to Mr. Moon amounted to a kind of insurance policy against Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cIt becomes awfully hard for Trump to return to the locked-and-loaded, \u2018fire and fury\u2019 phase of the relationship,\u201d said Jeffrey A. Bader, a former Asia adviser to President Barack Obama.\n\nAdministration officials acknowledged the risk that Mr. Trump could find himself out of sync with Mr. Moon. They said their job was to remind the president of the proper sequence of negotiations with North Korea: tangible steps toward denuclearization, followed by an easing of sanctions, and then a peace treaty.\n\nAs always, though, the wild card is Mr. Trump himself.\n\n\u201cHe sees this as a Nixon-in-China moment, and he will want to move quickly, where patience is the order of the day,\u201d said Kurt M. Campbell, a former assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs.", "title": "As Two Koreas Talk Peace, Trump\u2019s Bargaining Chips Slip Away", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "For that reason, Juli\u00e1n didn\u2019t grow up thinking of artists as dead white European men, as many Americans did. \u201cWhen I began my curiosity in the arts, absorbing it in an everyday context, it was in Mexico City,\u201d he explained. \u201cThe Mexican pyramids, Aztec history, Diego Rivera \u2014 this was the context.\u201d\n\nHe became more aware of the difference when he lived as a boy in Wales (where his mother was working) and when he graduated from high school in Paris. \u201cThen I become a foreigner, and then my perspective is different,\u201d he said.\n\nThat different context helped him see that \u201cthere\u2019s no one art history, and there\u2019s no one world purview,\u201d he said. So did speaking several languages. \u201cThere\u2019s no one way of saying something. Each language conveys with a subtle difference.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think that has shaped my mind and my everyday life,\u201d he said. Sometimes in the most literal of ways. \u201cI have an Android phone and an iPhone,\u201d he confessed, \u201cand two different carriers.\u201d He also owns a Mac and a PC and makes a point of working on both.\n\nIn his 54 years, Mr. Zugazagoitia has lived in Mexico City, Kansas City, Rome, Cardiff and Paris, where he earned a doctorate from the Sorbonne. But he also came back to New York. He was an assistant to Thomas Krens, when Mr. Krens was director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, and he served as director of the Museo del Barrio from 2002 to 2010, overcoming considerable opposition because he was not Puerto Rican.\n\nThat was when Reynold Levy, then president of Lincoln Center, met him and was impressed by his leadership skills. Today he describes his friend as a \u201cone-of-a-kind force of nature.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cBeware! Exposure to Juli\u00e1n risks being caught up in a whirlwind of intellectual energy,\u201d Mr. Levy wrote in an email, \u201ca capacity to cultivate colleagues and friends born of empathy and kindness, a sense of history and of humor, gift-wrapped in appealing ambition\u201d \u2014 not necessarily for himself, but for the people and institutions he serves.\n\nAmbition mixes with pride. Just ask Mr. Zugazagoitia about the Nelson-Atkins doors. Between the main Beaux-Arts building and the modern, architecturally acclaimed Bloch building (2007), there are seven. One leads to the Isamu Noguchi sculpture court. Another reveals \u201cThe Gates of Paradise,\u201d casts of Ghiberti\u2019s 17-foot-tall, gilded, carved bronze 15th-century portals originally made for the Baptistry of San Giovanni in Florence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can literally open any door and discover something,\u201d he said.\n\nDiscover is the key word. After 18 months of research, he said, museum leaders concluded that today\u2019s public doesn\u2019t necessarily want to be taught \u2014 in a way that old-style museums saw their mission \u2014 but it does want to learn. Discover is an even better word than learn, because it doesn\u2019t suggest school or grades or tests. \u201cCome on your own terms, and we\u2019re here to let you and help you learn \u2014 or help you discover \u2014 or help you be in awe,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Zugazagoitia hopes that makes a difference for people whose reason for not going to museums is simply that they haven\u2019t gone before and aren\u2019t completely sure what to expect. \u201cI learned the codes,\u201d he said, remembering those first New York museum visits in his youth. \u201cI know how you enter the museum. There\u2019s a coat check. You buy a ticket \u2014 or maybe it\u2019s free.\u201d (Like a growing number of American museums, including the Nelson-Atkins.)\n\n\u201cFor some people, who don\u2019t go to museums, that\u2019s not natural.\u201d But now, he says, he understands exactly how they feel. \u201cI go to sports arenas,\u201d he said. \u201cI feel awkward.\u201d Since moving to Missouri with his wife and their two children, now in high school, he added, he has attended more big sports events than ever before.\n\nMr. Zugazagoitia may seem an unusual choice to direct a museum in the heart of the Midwest. Since he took the job in 2010, though, attendance is up 43 percent, he said, and local art lovers have gotten used to unconventional events, although there have been snags.\n\nThere was major excitement about the \u201cart tastings\u201d he introduced soon after his arrival. He and a guest speaker or two (often a curator or a fellow museum director) would sip wine and casually discuss a particular exhibition or subject. \u201cMr. Zugazagoitia told the crowd to imagine that the auditorium was a bar,\u201d Hilarie M. Sheets, attending a 2011 tasting, wrote in The New York Times. That turned out to be a tough sell; audience members weren\u2019t getting their drinks until the reception afterward.\n\n\u201cThe wine was only onstage,\u201d Mr. Zugazagoitia said recently, sounding amused at having overlooked the disparity. \u201cThat was the frustration.\u201d", "title": "As a Child He Found Refuge in Museums. Now He Runs One.", "authors": ["Anita Gates"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe taught me more off the ice than on the ice, the leadership role he had as captain,\u201d Morris said of Petersen. \u201cYou could see him last year; he was as cool as it was back there, never got flustered or anything. I tried to tie it into my game. We\u2019re both pretty easygoing off the ice, so it was not too difficult to learn from him.\u201d\n\nJackson sees the similarity.\n\n\u201cThe best attribute about Cale is he\u2019s in control,\u201d he said. \u201cHe\u2019s very calm, doesn\u2019t get rattled. When he gives up a goal, they have the confidence to know there isn\u2019t going to be another one right away. He\u2019s going to be able to stand in there and play the same way, even if he gives up a goal off a fluky bounce or whatever it may be.\u201d\n\nNamed the Big Ten player and goaltender of the year, Morris added the Most Outstanding Player award in the Big Ten tournament, making 41 saves against the Buckeyes in the final. In the East Regional semifinals, Michigan Tech\u2019s Jake Jackson beat Morris for the tying goal with about a minute left in regulation. But Morris allowed nothing more until Jordan Gross scored the winner late in the first overtime. In the regional final, Dylan Malmquist\u2019s goal with 27 seconds to play upended Providence, 2-1, to send the Irish to the Frozen Four.\n\nNotre Dame has won 31 N.C.A.A. team national championships, adding the last two since March 25 in fencing and women\u2019s basketball. It has never won one in men\u2019s hockey. Jackson would prefer a less stressful finish Saturday night, though his players promised nothing of the sort.\n\n\u201cHe told us again he\u2019s getting scar tissue or something on his heart,\u201d forward Andrew Oglevie said after the semifinal victory. \u201cBut no, I\u2019m not going to apologize.\u201d\n\nEvans added: \u201cWe keep winning. (The N.B.A. must have missed this memo when they made a silhouette of Jerry West \u2014 who was 1-8 in career finals appearances \u2014 the league\u2019s logo.)\n\nIt is the fascination with championships, and the rings that come with them, that has a 16-team playoff season \u2014 the first round of which begins on Saturday \u2014 boiling down for many to what it would mean for the various players involved to walk away with the diamond-encrusted validation that comes with a finals triumph.\n\nIf Stephen Curry and the Golden State Warriors win, does that cement them as a dynasty? If they don\u2019t win, does it invalidate the hyperbole about them that\u2019s been thrown around the last three years? What would a fourth ring mean for James? How would it change things for Chris Paul of the Houston Rockets if he finally won a championship in his 13th year in the league?", "title": "As the Playoffs Begin, the N.B.A.\u2019s Biggest Stars Are Going Ring Hunting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "HGTV is applying this formula vigorously; 19 of its current series are toplined by duos, with more on the way. Some of the emerging shows star siblings (\u201cRestored by the Fords\u201d) or parent-child teams (\u201cGood Bones\u201d), but most revolve around couples.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t make another Chip and Jo,\u201d said Ms. Weidhorn, who still works with HGTV, now as the head of her own unscripted-content production company, 547 Barnard. \u201cThey had their own lifestyle, their own world. But you can set out to find duos who make viewers say, \u2018Relationship goals!\u2019 or \u2018Hey, I talk to my brother like that.\u2019 Viewers like to see their own relationships reflected in the talent.\u201d\n\nMany of those viewers are enjoying the network in twos. \u201cThe fact is, our viewers are duos themselves,\u201d said Kathleen Finch, the chief lifestyle brands officer for Discovery Inc., which owns HGTV. \u201cWhat we hear is, \u2018My husband and I sit on the couch together and watch.\u2019\u201d\n\nHGTV is so focused on finding talent that reflects that audience, it sometimes lets the couch couples cross through the screen. Three years ago, Dave and Chenoa Rivera \u2014 who left their tourism and medical sales jobs to start renovating properties in Paradise, Calif. \u2014 were two of the viewers Ms. Finch describes.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe had been watching \u2018Flip or Flop,\u2019 and I was like, \u2018Hey, we do this,\u2019\u201d Ms. Rivera said by phone.\n\nShe sent HGTV\u2019s casting inbox an email that described the renovations projects she and Mr. Rivera collaborate on and included their family Christmas photo. A year later, she heard from a producer. The Riveras shot a pilot and eventually got a series greenlight. Their show, \u201cRustic Rehab,\u201d which has its premiere on April 26, paints them as savvy and down-to-earth, can-do hustlers in a woodsy corner of California.\n\nConceptually, \u201cRehab\u201d follows the blueprint of \u201cFlip or Flop,\u201d the franchise that has become HGTV\u2019s go-to format for breaking couple talent. Network executives are especially excited about two in particular: \u201cFlip or Flop Vegas,\u201d with the mixed martial arts fighter Bristol Marunde and his Realtor wife, Aubrey; and \u201cFlip or Flop Nashville,\u201d with the former N.F.L. player DeRon Jenkins and Page Turner, a real estate broker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBristol and Aubrey\u2019s projects all have this fun, blingy vibe,\u201d Ms. Finch said. \u201cDeRon and Page are exes, which adds this sweet element to the show: They\u2019ll roll their eyes at things and say, \u2018And that\u2019s why we\u2019re not together anymore.\u2019\u201d The shows\u2019 initial seasons have averaged around 1.2 million viewers per episode. (By comparison: \u201cFixer Upper\u201d has averaged 2.8 million viewers per episode in its fifth and final season.)\n\nThen there are the original \u201cFlip or Flop\u201d stars: Christina and Tarek El Moussa, who recently shot their first episodes since 2016, for a new season that starts May 31. The El Moussas drew \u201cthrough-the-roof, gangbusters\u201d numbers for HGTV, according to Ms. Finch; their return to the network will probably do even better. That\u2019s because the El Moussas have divorced \u2014 proving, in the process, how heavily invested their fans were in their personal lives. A $13.99 all-HGTV edition of \u201cPeople\u201d currently on newsstands dedicates eight pages to the former couple, calling them \u201cdevoted to their kids \u2014 and their hit show\u201d and chronicling Ms. El Moussa\u2019s post-divorce dating life.\n\nThe magazine is more evidence that the network\u2019s duos have blown past the traditional star potential of home-television talent. (\u201cIt\u2019s like the Tiger Beat of HGTV!\u201d Ms. Finch said.)\n\nBut HGTV stars need more than chemistry and interesting personal lives: They have to actually know their way around a hammer, or at least look and sound as if they do on television.\n\nWhich leads to hires like the mellow, Pittsburgh-based Leanne and Steve Ford, of \u201cRestored by the Fords.\u201d The siblings have been at their respective trades for years \u2014 hers in design, his in construction \u2014 and their signature style skews more modern and minimal than the typical HGTV aesthetic.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cRestored by the Fords\u201d debuted in January and has averaged nearly 1.7 million viewers per episode (it is HGTV\u2019s best-rated new program this year among viewers 25 to 54). So \u201cFords\u201d is off to a good start, and its stars\u2019 profiles are on the rise. \u201cOur Instagrams are booming,\u201d Ms. Ford said by phone.\n\nMr. Ford, conferenced in on the same call, went silent for a moment.\n\n\u201cSteve?\u201d Ms. Ford said, an edge of sisterly annoyance creeping into her voice.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Ford apologized. \u201cSomebody just drove by and yelled over the fence to me, \u2018Hey, we like your show!\u2019\u201d he said, sounding bewildered.\n\nBewilderment does seem to be the de facto response to becoming an HGTV power duo, even for the Gaineses. \u201cNo matter how many times someone asks me to sign their hat or asks Jo for a picture, it still feels surreal,\u201d Mr. Gaines, whose memoir \u201cCapital Gaines\u201d is a current best seller, wrote in an email during an earlier interview. \u201cWe don\u2019t think of ourselves as \u2018famous\u2019 even now.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nErin Napier, a co-host of \u201cHome Town,\u201d can empathize. On her show, she and her husband, Ben, renovate homes in Laurel, Miss., where they grew up. In its second season, \u201cHome Town\u201d was watched by an average of 1.5 million viewers per episode \u2014 the fame that has followed has made Laurel feel somehow even smaller to Ms. Napier.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI am an introvert,\u201d she said by phone. \u201cI get anxious when people who don\u2019t know me want to talk at the grocery store.\u201d\n\nMr. Napier, a woodworker, was nearby with their 3-month-old daughter, Helen. \u201cPeople are spending their spring breaks in Laurel,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you\u2019d told me that 10 years ago, I\u2019d have laughed.\u201d (He might have taken a lesson from the trajectory of the Gaineses, who have brought more tourists to Waco \u2014 the vacation rentals they own sometimes sell out up to a year in advance.) In Laurel, \u201cHome Town\u201d fans shop for goods inspired by the show at the Napiers\u2019 Front Street boutique, Laurel Mercantile Co., and cruise past the couple\u2019s 1920s Craftsman home.\n\n\u201cI was planting flowers on my front porch earlier today,\u201d Ms. Napier said. \u201cAbout 15 tourists drove by and filmed me doing it.\u201d\n\nSuch anecdotes hint at why HGTV\u2019s duos have become so popular \u2014 and crucial to the network\u2019s success. They blur the line between fame and regular life, talking on TV the way you imagine they would if you invited them to dinner.\n\nBut Ms. Napier suspects there\u2019s something more subtle drawing people to her show and her street. \u201cHome Town\u201d \u2014 like many HGTV shows \u2014 celebrates common experiences that other types of TV ignore or mock: married life, modest budgets, settling down in the place where you grew up.\n\n\u201cWhen I was a teenager, I thought I was going to go work in publishing in New York,\u201d Ms. Napier said. \u201cBut once I left Laurel, I realized how special it was. It didn\u2019t matter that it was small. I thought, if the opportunity I want isn\u2019t there \u2014 well, I\u2019ll just make it.\u201d\n\nSo she returned. She married Mr. Napier, who plays a lumberjack mascot at town events. Together they found stardom on a network that learned a lesson about construction down in Waco six years back: Put two authentic-seeming people on camera, and the audience will follow them \u2014 sometimes, all the way to their front porch.", "title": "As \u2018Fixer Upper\u2019 Ends, HGTV Builds a Roster of Power (Tool) Couples", "authors": ["Megan Angelo"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "NOLAN I\u2019ve never been terribly interested in twists for twists\u2019 sake. I\u2019ve been interested in the limitations of human \u2014 or in the case of \u201cWestworld,\u201d not-human \u2014 perception. The way that we see the world and the way that our biases and our hangups and our flaws impact the way that we see this world. So with this project, we were interested in the ways that an artificial mind would perceive the world differently. Memory, which is something Lisa and I have long been fascinated by, and the clarity of memory felt like a really interesting thing to play with, and the story followed from that. We had initially turned it down because I couldn\u2019t see past the \u201cFantasy Island\u201d version of it, like we\u2019d have different guests each week and the hosts would help through their relationship problems. [Laughs.] But Lisa saw it very clearly. She said to me one night when we were having dinner and talking about it: \u201cGod, this is everything that we think about and talk about. Everything that we\u2019re interested in right now in one show.\u201d\n\nLISA JOY We\u2019re in this really lovely creative moment right now where people aren\u2019t holding themselves back anymore and saying, \u201cWell, this is the genre or this is the world that I\u2019m working in, so I can\u2019t step outside of this box.\u201d Previously, you might have thought that this should just be a kind of horror film, or a dystopian thing where robots chase humans around. And now as tastes evolve, as TV evolves, you can do an episode that has an amazing fight scene but also a scene that poses legitimate philosophical questions and also contains character elements that speak to the most simple and enduring elements of the human condition.\n\nThere\u2019s been about 17 months or so between seasons. What were you doing over that time? Do you worry about situating people in the story after so much time away without their heads swimming?\n\nNOLAN I think a little head-swimming is not a bad thing. For \u201cWestworld,\u201d Lisa and I go through three distinct phases. We write \u2014 or rather, we pull together a writers\u2019 room and we plot it out. The original film is packed with cool ideas, but there isn\u2019t really a single shared character between the film and our series. We had to build the world out from the ground up, so that means we spend six months thinking and writing. Then we turn our attention \u2014 Lisa and I both direct on the show \u2014 to the production. Then we turn our attention to the editing phase. The short version is we definitely didn\u2019t get a vacation in between the two seasons.\n\nA common theme in reviews of the second season is that the show feels more fun now that the hosts have busted out. Do you feel that, too?\n\nJOY For us, the show needs to go and follow the tone that logically extends from where our characters are at. Season 1 ended with a bang, and Season 2 picks up where that ended, and you see the hosts finally getting to be free, to slowly start liberating themselves and fighting back. That\u2019s going to be exhilarating because we\u2019ve been rooting for them for so long, but power always comes with its own complexities, and just because you have agency doesn\u2019t yet mean that you\u2019re going to be free from trouble or that you will know exactly who you want to be. It just means you have the freedom to decide who you want to be.", "title": "As \u2018Westworld\u2019 Returns, the Creators Discuss Twists, Reddit and Rickrolls", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Judd is suing Mr. Weinstein for defamation and sexual harassment and for violating California\u2019s broadly written Unfair Competition law, which prohibits \u201cunlawful, unfair and fraudulent business acts and practices.\u201d Unfair competition has not historically been applied to the area of sexual harassment and retaliation.\n\n\u201cAshley is fighting back, but she also wants to point the way for others,\u201d Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., the lead lawyer representing Ms. Judd in the suit, said in an interview. Mr. Boutrous, who is known for his high-profile work for companies like Walmart and Apple and for pushing the courts on issues like gay marriage, added that \u201cif this isn\u2019t an example of unfair business practice then I don\u2019t know what is.\u201d\n\nJeannie Suk Gersen, a professor at Harvard Law School who specializes in gender and sexual harassment issues, said Ms. Judd\u2019s complaint is notable because it \u201cspeaks to the fact that this is not just a sexual issue \u2014 that, beyond physical and emotional harm, it also involves economic harm.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cIf successful, the legal arguments that are being marshaled here are a big deal for lots of people, not just in show business but in all sorts of hiring contexts.\u201d\n\nMs. Judd said in a statement that \u201cfinancial recuperation will be donated to the Time\u2019s Up Legal Defense Fund, so that women and men in all professions may have legal redress for sexual harassment, economic retaliation and damage to their careers.\u201d\n\nThe lawsuit maintains that Mr. Weinstein was retaliating against Ms. Judd for refusing to engage in sexual activity with him. About a year before Ms. Judd was in contention for the \u201cLord of the Rings\u201d role, Mr. Weinstein had her meet him in a hotel room in Beverly Hills \u2014 under the guise of discussing business \u2014 where he appeared in a bathrobe and, among other things, asked her to submit to a massage and watch him shower, the complaint said. Ms. Judd had previously recounted the episode in an interview with The New York Times published last October.\n\n\u201cWeinstein\u2019s wrongful and outrageous conduct has not just deprived Ms. Judd of the specific opportunity to play a prominent role in a blockbuster film trilogy; it has had a long-lasting ripple effect on her whole career,\u201d the complaint said. \u201cNo person \u2014 in whatever job, in whatever industry \u2014 should have to forfeit professional aspirations and the right to earn a living to the abusive whims of the powerful.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA spokesman for Mr. Weinstein released a statement late Monday that said in part, \u201cThe most basic investigation of the facts will reveal that Mr. Weinstein neither defamed Ms. Judd nor ever interfered with Ms. Judd\u2019s career, and instead not only championed her work but also repeatedly approved her casting for two of his movies over the next decade.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Weinstein has previously denied trying to derail Ms. Judd\u2019s career. In December, when Mr. Jackson told a publication in New Zealand that Mr. Weinstein had told him not to cast Ms. Judd or Mira Sorvino, Mr. Weinstein said in a statement that he had \u201cno input into the casting whatsoever.\u201d (Ms. Sorvino has also accused Mr. Weinstein of harassment.) Although the \u201cLord of the Rings\u201d movies were started at Miramax, a boutique studio run by Mr. Weinstein and then owned by Disney, the project moved to New Line Cinema before filming began.\n\nMr. Jackson rejected Mr. Weinstein\u2019s denial in subsequent public comments in December, saying that his creative partner on the films, Fran Walsh, \u201cremembers these negative comments about Ashley and Mira as clearly as I do.\u201d\n\nThe lawsuit filed by Ms. Judd on Monday laid out a pattern of retaliatory behavior by Mr. Weinstein against actresses who rebuffed his sexual advances \u2014 what California courts have described as \u201cme too\u201d evidence in employment cases. Ms. Sorvino is cited as one example.\n\n\u201cWeinstein made false statements of fact about Ms. Sorvino to others in the film industry to punish her and damage her career,\u201d the suit said. \u201cThese comments included, but were not limited to, statements made to Mr. Jackson and Ms. Walsh in a private business meeting that Ms. Sorvino was \u2018a nightmare to work with.\u2019\u201d Ms. Sorvino told The New Yorker in October that Mr. Weinstein tried to massage her and \u201cchased her around\u201d a hotel room at a film festival in 1995.\n\nAnother example cited by Ms. Judd involved Annabella Sciorra, who has said that Mr. Weinstein raped her in the 1990s. \u201cShe believes she did not work from 1992 to 1995 because the \u2018Harvey machine\u2019 spread a baseless rumor that she was \u2018difficult,\u2019\u201d the complaint said of Ms. Sciorra. Mr. Weinstein has repeatedly denied ever engaging in \u201cnonconsensual sex.\u201d\n\nThe case adds to already formidable legal entanglements for Mr. Weinstein, who was one of Hollywood\u2019s most powerful producers before dozens of women \u2014 led by Ms. Judd, Rose McGowan, Rosanna Arquette and others \u2014 came forward last fall with allegations of sexual misconduct against him.\n\nProsecutors in New York, Los Angeles and London are now pursuing possible criminal cases against him. Eric T. Schneiderman, New York\u2019s attorney general, is suing Mr. Weinstein and his brother and business partner, Bob Weinstein, for repeatedly violating state and city laws barring gender discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual abuse and coercion. Mr. Weinstein also faces additional civil suits, including one filed by Kadian Noble, a British actress who is suing him for sex trafficking.\n\nAmid these investigations, the Weinstein Company has toppled into bankruptcy. Bids for the movie and television studio\u2019s assets were due on Monday, with an auction scheduled for later in the week should competing offers emerge.\n\nIn a statement on Monday afternoon, Mr. Schneiderman pressed bidders to propose \u201cenhancements that set aside financial resources to compensate and provide support services for injured employees and industry talent.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe added, \u201cBid enhancements also should include nonmonetary terms that protect future employees and contractors and avoid rewarding wrongdoers.\u201d", "title": "Ashley Judd Sues Harvey Weinstein, Saying He Harmed Her Career", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Showcasing artists in a retail environment is one way to draw online shoppers back to stores, suggested Roma Cohen, who sells upscale street wear at Alchemist, his concept store in Miami Beach. Mr. Cohen, who has initiated collaborations with Damien Hirst, Marina Abramovic and their influential like, and whose own fashion/music/art installation is on view at Bergdorf this week, added, \u201cPeople like to feel they are getting an experience,\u201d one that they\u2019re inclined to photograph and share.\n\nMs. Longshore is well ahead of that game. On her social media platforms she exposes not just her art but her own perceived flaws: runaway carb cravings, a tendency to hoard and an unyielding competitive drive. She\u2019s \u201cambitcheous,\u201d Ms. Longshore acknowledged. Sorry, not sorry. \u201cI\u2019m brave enough to be who I am in a society where there\u2019s a lot of pressure to be perfect,\u201d she said.\n\nThere is no danger that she will succumb. An edge of defiance creeping into her voice, she recalled having dealt with overbearing Masters of the Universe. \u201cWhen I get these hedge-fund guys in here, I know how to talk to them,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m not sitting here batting my eyes and smiling. I\u2019m not about to be ground down.\u201d\n\nShe has encountered her share of mean girls too. \u201cBut I\u2019ve learned my lesson,\u201d Ms. Longshore said. She turned a wily glance toward her visitor. \u201cYou ain\u2019t sitting at their damn store, are you?\u201d she said.", "title": "Ashley Longshore Is Fashion\u2019s Latest Art Darling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "A group that is suing Harvard University is demanding that it publicly release admissions data on hundreds of thousands of applicants, saying the records show a pattern of discrimination against Asian-Americans going back decades.\n\nThe group was able to view the documents through its lawsuit, which was filed in 2014 and challenges Harvard\u2019s admissions policies. The plaintiffs said in a letter to the court last week that the documents were so compelling that there was no need for a trial, and that they would ask the judge to rule summarily in their favor based on the documents alone.\n\nThe plaintiffs also say that the public \u2014 which provides more than half a billion dollars a year in federal funding to Harvard \u2014 has a right to see the evidence that the judge will consider in her decision.\n\nHarvard counters that the documents are tantamount to trade secrets, and that even in the unlikely event that the judge agrees to decide the case without a trial, she is likely to use only a fraction of the evidence in her decision. Only that portion, the university says, should be released.", "title": "Asian-Americans Suing Harvard Say Admissions Files Show Discrimination", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "In the last midterm election, in 2014, the nationwide turnout for Asian-American citizens was dreadful \u2014 just 27 percent, according to the census. That\u2019s far below the rates for whites and blacks and virtually identical to the Latino rate. In Virginia, however, turnout has been significantly higher \u2014 the highest Asian-American turnout in the nation, Desai writes \u2014 thanks to a deliberate strategy that has included:\n\n\u00b7 Creating Democratic Asian Americans of Virginia (or DAAV), a group dedicated to raising turnout.\n\n\u00b7 Publishing sample ballots and voting guides in other languages and distributing them before elections.\n\n\u00b7 Recruiting volunteers who speak Asian languages to make phone calls and go door to door.\n\n\u00b7 Doing some of the basic political outreach that for too long has skipped over Asian-Americans. (Last year, for example, DAAV threw a celebration of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, for now-Gov. Ralph Northam to lead.)\n\n\u00b7 Talking about the many issues \u2014 like immigration policy, education funding and social services \u2014 in which the opinions of most Asian-Americans align with Democratic positions.\n\nFor more on this topic, you can read: my recent columns on the problem of low progressive turnout; Karthick Ramakrishnan\u2019s American Prospect piece, \u201cHow Asian Americans Became Democrats\u201d; and Pew\u2019s extensive 2013 report, which breaks down the attitudes of different groups of Asian-Americans.\n\nPew\u2019s report helps highlight the size of the opportunity for Democrats. The six biggest Asian-American groups \u2014 which, in descending order, are Chinese-, Filipino-, Indian-, Vietnamese-, Korean- and Japanese-Americans \u2014 have varying opinions on nearly every major political issue (as these charts show). Yet not one of these subgroups leans Republican.", "title": "Opinion | Asian-Americans, a Sleeping Political Giant", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "[Hong Kong was once seen as a rare blend of East and West that China might seek to emulate. Read how it\u2019s now a cautionary tale \u00bb]\n\nThe shift reflects the increasingly authoritarian efforts of President Xi Jinping, China\u2019s strongest leader since Mao, to assert his control over China, including Hong Kong. When the British returned Hong Kong to Chinese control in 1997, the \u201cone country, two systems\u201d arrangement was supposed to give the territory a \u201chigh degree of autonomy\u201d until at least 2047.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut since the 2014 protests known as the Umbrella Movement, in which thousands of Hong Kong residents filled the streets to call for greater democracy, Mr. Xi\u2019s China has grown more willing to intervene. Revelations in 2016 about Chinese agents\u2019 earlier abduction and detention of five Hong Kong-based publishers of critical and often salacious books about Chinese leaders seemed a death knell to Hong Kong\u2019s free speech.\n\nLam Wing-kee, one of the five, who said he was held in solitary confinement for five months and pressured into a public confession, is now planning to reopen his bookshop, which had been in Hong Kong until he shut it down, in Taiwan.\n\n\u201cWe Hong Kong people look to Taiwan for lessons,\u201d Mr. Lam said. \u201cAnd people in Taiwan look to see how the Chinese mainland controls Hong Kong.\u201d\n\nThe growing recognition of Taiwan as one of Asia\u2019s freest environments for expression is itself a dramatic change. Until 1987, the island was under brutal martial law, controlled by the dictator Chiang Kai-shek, who had fled the Communist takeover of mainland China in 1949, and later his son.\n\nTaiwan\u2019s freedoms were hard-won. Last Saturday, Taiwan marked Freedom of Speech Day on the 29th anniversary of the death of the free-speech advocate Deng Nan-jung, who burned himself to death as the police prepared to storm his office and arrest him for publishing a revised constitution.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Deng\u2019s death prompted large protests that helped set the island toward democratic government and greater freedoms.\n\nC\u00e9dric Alviani, the Taipei bureau director of Reporters Without Borders, said Taiwan has since become an \u201cisland of stability\u201d in a region where press freedoms were backsliding. \u201cFreedom of expression is a big part of Taiwanese culture,\u201d he said.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Saturday, Mr. Deng\u2019s widow, Yeh Chu-lan, warned that Taiwan\u2019s freedoms were not guaranteed. \u201cWe could lose our freedom of expression anytime in the face of Chinese hegemony,\u201d she said.\n\nHong Kong has seemed a cautionary tale of Beijing\u2019s interference. Some of the young leaders of the Umbrella Movement were sentenced to prison terms, raising concerns about interference by Beijing. Hong Kong\u2019s Legislature is currently moving to outlaw insults to the Chinese national anthem after Hong Kong soccer fans booed it.\n\nPhoto\n\nLi Dan, organizer of the 1905 Hong Kong Human Rights Film Festival, said that he will relocate this year\u2019s event in May to Taiwan, with a smaller satellite festival in Hong Kong. The move, Mr. Li said, came after the festival had difficulty in finding large donors to sponsor the event in Hong Kong, where the costs are high.\n\n\u201cRight now in Hong Kong there is increasing control of information and media, so, often there is a fear of the term \u2018human rights,\u2019\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cAs for the environment for free speech in Taiwan, I\u2019d say it\u2019s the best in Asia \u2014 there\u2019s nothing you can\u2019t say,\u201d he added.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOthers also say that Taiwan has proved much more welcoming to regional rights activists. The Network of Young Democratic Asians, a group with members from Hong Kong, Taiwan and Southeast Asia, decided to meet last September in Taipei because it was the only place that was certain to allow all of its members to enter.\n\n\u201cI felt really glad that Taiwan could still provide this kind of safe space for activists from different parts of Asia,\u201d Johnson Yeung, the head of the group\u2019s development team, said in a phone interview.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile Taiwan is relishing its new reputation as the center for free speech in the Chinese-speaking world, there have also been instances when Taiwan has appeared to compromise on its political values to avoid angering Beijing, which claims Taiwan as its territory.\n\nLast year, Taiwan returned a Chinese activist seeking political asylum to China. Some Chinese say it is also getting harder for mainland activists to enter Taiwan to attend workshops or conferences.\n\nPhoto\n\nZhao Sile, a Chinese journalist and author who writes about civil society in China, said Chinese activists have told her that it has become more difficult in the past two years to obtain visas from Taiwan.\n\nMs. Zhao, now in Taipei as a guest of National Chung Cheng University, said in an interview that she knew of multiple cases in which nongovernment groups or universities that invited a Chinese participant used medical visas as a workaround. The visas, which are easier to obtain than normal visas, are intended for medical tourists coming to Taiwan for plastic surgery.\n\nAccustomed to free speech at home, Taiwanese are also running afoul of the authorities in China and even Hong Kong.\n\nLast year, China made an example of one Taiwanese activist, Lee Ming-cheh, who was detained upon entering China. After being held incommunicado for months, he gave what appeared to be a forced confession before being sentenced to five years in prison for state subversion.\n\nThe case has had a chilling effect in Taiwan because the court used as evidence postings that Mr. Lee had made on social media while in Taiwan.\n\nIn November, the Taiwanese filmmaker Kevin H. J. Lee said he was denied a visa to Hong Kong. He thinks it was because of his new documentary, \u201cSelf-Censorship,\u201d which was released last month. Mr. Lee believes the authorities in Hong Kong or China acted to prevent his entry after seeing his crowdfunding page, which included a trailer that was partly filmed in Hong Kong.\n\nIn March, a group of Hong Kong university students contacted Mr. Lee to ask if he would be willing to speak with them from Taiwan after a showing of his film. Concerned that they might be monitored by school officials, they were only willing to communicate via the social media platform WhatsApp, he said, which features end-to-end encryption.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was only at the last moment that they quickly notified everyone and told them \u2018We\u2019re about to show this film,\u2019\u201d Mr. Lee said. \u201cI told them that when I look at the situation in Hong Kong it reminds me of Taiwan before the end of martial law. How could Hong Kong end up like this?\u201d", "title": "Asia\u2019s Bastion of Free Speech? Move Aside, Hong Kong, It\u2019s Taiwan Now.", "authors": ["Chris Horton", "Austin Ramzy"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "My point is, there is a lot going on in the world. There is a lot going on in my world. There is a lot going on in your world. This is the nature of life. We try to find ways to balance taking care of ourselves and our families, with caring about the world we live in and the greater good. Sometimes, we will fall short in one of these areas. Sometimes we will fall short in all of these areas. Most of the time, we do the best we can.\n\nI don\u2019t have an easy answer for you, but I do think many of us get overwhelmed because we think we have to care about everything all the time, as if that\u2019s even possible. We get mired in solipsism and delude ourselves into believing that the proverbial struggle cannot go on without us. This is rarely the case. The grand thing about collective effort is that we can generally trust that someone is out in the world, doing important social justice work when we are too tired or burned out to join in.\n\nYour friend didn\u2019t go to the women\u2019s march in New York this year, but hundreds of thousands of other people did. Every day, everywhere, people are doing the work of resisting oppression and tyranny in ways great and small.\n\nLately, I\u2019ve been doing two things to maintain my sanity without checking out completely. I\u2019ve stopped watching cable news because the 24-hour news cycle has become an incoherent mess. There are plenty of ways to stay well informed without listening to lazy punditry and an endless regurgitation of only the most salacious news. I\u2019ve also been trying to pick one issue at a time in which to invest my social-justice-oriented energy.\n\nIf I focus on just one issue and apply genuine effort and attention to it, I just might contribute something useful. I choose to invest that energy in different ways, whether it\u2019s writing about a pressing issue, amplifying the voices of others, donating money and time to nonprofit organizations, or whatever I can think of that might be useful. Sometimes, I have no idea how I can be useful, so I ask people who are well positioned to point me in the right direction because I recognize that I don\u2019t have to have all the answers.\n\nWhat you describe in your letter is not apathy. You aren\u2019t indifferent to the current state of the world. You are human, a woman trying to balance your own needs with doing good in the world, and right now, your own needs are winning out. Take the time you need. There is no shame in that so long as you remember to extend your empathy as far as you can when your emotional stores have replenished.\n\nI would worry if you didn\u2019t care about the state of the world. I would worry if you didn\u2019t ask this question.", "title": "Opinion | Ask Roxane: I\u2019m Outraged, but Failing at Activism. Why?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Nazi History Behind \u2018Asperger\u2019 \u201d\n\n(Sunday Review, April 1):\n\nI applaud Edith Sheffer for her research on Dr. Hans Asperger and the dark side of his work on autism under the Nazi regime. She suggests that we should stop calling the condition Asperger syndrome because \u201cnaming a disorder after someone is meant to credit and commend\u201d that person.\n\nBut it is precisely by not forgetting Dr. Asperger that we honor the victims of medical science at the service of an evil ideology.\n\nIt is a great moment when a young intern presents his first case of Reiter\u2019s syndrome, or reactive arthritis (another example of a Nazi-era doctor cited by Ms. Sheffer for whom a condition was named), at grand rounds, and a great opportunity to teach the audience some historical facts that should never be forgotten.\n\nAsperger syndrome is a historical medical term, not a honorary distinction. I will continue to use the term and the story that goes with it.", "title": "Opinion | Asperger: What\u2019s in a Name?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The organizers and lawyers identified the strongest asylum cases \u2014 about 200, most of them children \u2014 and encouraged those people to apply for protection, while suggesting that the remainder seek protection in Mexico or elsewhere in Latin America.\n\nTo qualify for asylum, applicants must prove that they have been persecuted or fear persecution based on their race, religion, nationality, political belief or membership in a particular group. People who request protection at an American entry point must submit to a screening by an asylum officer, called a credible-fear interview. If the officer finds the fear credible, the case is then referred to an immigration judge for a full hearing.\n\nBut until late Monday none of the asylum seekers among the caravan had been allowed by border officials to begin the process.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMigrants\u2019 advocates had accused the Trump administration of engaging in brinkmanship for political gain at the asylum seekers\u2019 expense.\n\nIn a statement late Monday announcing the resumption of asylum processing at San Ysidro, Customs and Border Protection officials explained that the number of undocumented people they can process at border crossings depended on a range of factors including the complexity of cases, translation requirements, detention space and the number of migrants.\n\n\u201cAs in the past when we\u2019ve had to limit the number of people we can bring in for processing at a given time, we expect that this will be a temporary situation,\u201d the statement said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDuring the delay, most of the migrants adopted mind-sets of hardened patience.\n\n\u201cReally, nobody\u2019s said anything,\u201d said Arnaldo Rivera, 40, who fled his native Honduras with his wife and five children after the family was threatened by a gang. They were among the migrants who were waiting outside the entrance to the border crossing on Sunday, eating donated food and using a nearby public bathroom.\n\nThe family had staked out a patch of the pedestrian plaza by spreading out a blanket and demarcating it with a few knapsacks containing their belongings.\n\n\u201cIt could be this afternoon, it could be tomorrow,\u201d he said, shrugging. \u201cGod has the last word.\u201d\n\nLate Sunday, local, state and federal authorities tried to persuade the migrants to decamp from the pedestrian plaza and spend the night in shelters. But in an act of communal defiance, the caravan\u2019s participants elected to remain where they were. As the officials walked away, the migrants applauded and cheered.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve experienced a lot, and this isn\u2019t going to stop us,\u201d said Shannel Smith, 29, who fled gang violence in Honduras and is one of about 35 transgender migrants in the caravan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Smith was part of a delegation of about 50 migrants who were selected by the lawyers and caravan organizers to approach the American border entry on Sunday afternoon and test the authorities\u2019 claim that they had no capacity to process asylum petitions.\n\nBut no members of that group, many of them children, were allowed to pass through the gate. Some decided to remain there for much of the night, corralled behind metal barricades and huddled under blankets on the cold concrete ground, maintaining pressure on the American government.\n\nMore than 24 hours after they arrived, eight members were finally invited to step through the gate.", "title": "U.S. Lets a Few Members of a Migrant Caravan Apply for Asylum", "authors": ["Kirk Semple"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Science communication is the art of making science accessible, and thanks to the internet, science is more accessible than ever. More research and original data is being posted publicly online, and a new generation of science ambassadors \u2014 in the tradition of Mythbusters or Carl Sagan and Ann Druyan \u2014 has found a large audience on social media. But they face a conundrum: the platforms that help get their message out sometimes favor a style that inflames as much as it informs.\n\nScience enthusiasts have built enormous audiences online not only because they appeal to human curiosity, but also because they have a flair for entertainment.\n\nMichael Stevens, whose YouTube channel Vsauce often explores psychology, has described how he packages his videos to reach the biggest audience and has bragged that he could even make paint drying interesting. Derek Muller is known for using man-on-the-street interviews on his popular YouTube channel Veritasium to expose misconceptions about science. And Elise Andrew, who commands an audience of 25 million through her Facebook page, \u201cIFLScience,\u201d often shares science-themed memes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA lot of the science stuff that goes viral ends up being \u201cinformation-light and punchline-heavy,\u201d said Yvette d\u2019Entremont, who runs SciBabe, a popular Facebook page.\n\nMs. d\u2019Entremont specializes in debunking myths around homeopathy, pet wellness, G.M.O.s and other trends. Her arguments are dense with citations, but she also dispenses a fair amount of snark, as in an essay for The Outline titled \u201cThe Unbearable Wrongness of Gwyneth Paltrow\u201d about the Goop wellness guru.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of really wonderful science communicators on YouTube that find a way to break down science concepts; they do these long form videos,\u201d she said. But she says the videos that really go viral are, \u201cshort punchy ones that seem to be taking a swing at things that we hate, or that we\u2019re trying to combat in sci-comm or in the skeptic universe.\u201d\n\nSome of this trend may result from algorithms that promote certain types of content over others, often to maximize the time users spend on a site.\n\n\u201cThe algorithm is trying to make people react, trying to make people engage,\u201d said Guillaume Chaslot, a former YouTube engineer who now advocates for greater accountability for tech platforms. \u201cWhen you have these very combative videos, it\u2019s very efficient at getting people to watch.\u201d\n\nHis site, AlgoTransparency, shows how videos asserting that the Earth is flat and that vaccines are harmful were among those most recommended by YouTube\u2019s algorithm in February. Another was \u201cBill Nye Destroys Noah\u2019s Ark,\u201d in which the famed scientist dismantles arguments from creationist Ken Ham.\n\nFacebook has said it will make changes to its algorithms to favor \u201ctime well spent\u201d over just time spent. (The company declined to comment.) A statement from YouTube pointed to its announced changes intended to combat misinformation.\n\nAfter Mr. Zozaya posted his video, anti-vaccination activists left hateful comments, accused him of being a shill for the pharmaceutical industry and even posted personal information about his family. At first, he gleefully debated them, cheered on by 65,000 new Facebook fans.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t just for the views, although he admits that aspect was gratifying. As a devotee of empiricism, Mr. Zozaya felt compelled to push back against the discredited autism-vaccines link. He also empathized with the autism community.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThink about it from their perspective,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s people who are like, \u2018I would rather have my child die of X deadly disease and be contagious and put everyone else in danger than have my child get this condition that you were born with.\u2019\u201d\n\nAs it happens, he later found out he is on the autism spectrum himself.\n\nMr. Zozaya realized he wasn\u2019t convincing anyone by picking fights, nor was he doing much to further human understanding. But when he shifted toward more informational videos \u2014 like an analysis of the role snakes play in the environment \u2014 his viewership plummeted.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI was really disappointed,\u201d he said. \u201cI thought I had a following mostly made up of people who loved science, because that is what I originally wanted to build on. I wish honestly that people were as much into science as they are into shutting people down.\u201d\n\nThere is a real concern in the science communication community about how best to handle the tide of pseudoscience.\n\nEmily Gorcenski is a data scientist and activist who has studied how fake science spreads on the internet. In her view, snark or cheeky videos are not the problem: If people are really committed to a piece of pseudoscience, a video from someone like Mr. Zozaya will not convince them otherwise, no matter how respectful. Rather, she\u2019s more concerned with how much science is locked up behind university doors or in paid journals.\n\n\u201cWe live in a time of deep polarization on many fronts,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re partly in this position that we\u2019re in because scientific communication, scientific writing, is deeply inaccessible. If there is something that makes it more accessible for people, then I\u2019m all for it.\u201d\n\nMr. Zozaya believes he can build the kind of audience he wants: People who love science. It might just take a little longer.\n\nIn January, he posted a video tracing the origin of the mythical \u201cel chupacabras,\u201d a monster said to suck the blood out of livestock, back to the evolutionary advantage of fear. It has about 6,400 views \u2014 not viral, but not bad either. He is working on a video about the placebo effect.\n\n\u201cI will definitely keep making videos,\u201d he said.", "title": "At 12, He Had a Viral Science Video. At 14, He Fears He Was Too Rude.", "authors": ["Adrianne Jeffries"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "A welder by trade, he picks up work where he can and helps George out on weekends. I asked him how to access the grounds of the 704,000-acre national monument, which is roughly twice the size of Los Angeles. He told me I\u2019m \u201cabout the second\u201d person to ever make this request of him in the two years since President Obama signed an order protecting the land. Mr. Obama did so at the urging of the former Senate majority leader Harry Reid, a Democrat who represented Nevada, and in spite of vocal opposition from elected officials in Lincoln and Nye counties, where Basin and Range lies.\n\nSenator Reid was reportedly smitten with \u201cCity,\u201d a huge geometric sculpture that the renowned landscape artist Michael Heizer has been constructing from materials mined on-site for the past 45 years, at an estimated cost of more than $25 million. While \u201cCity\u201d sits on private land, it is within Basin and Range\u2019s boundaries, and the federal designation was actively supported by Mr. Heizer\u2019s benefactors. (They hope that the artwork will be viewable to the public by 2020.)\n\nIn April, Basin and Range was among 27 national monuments that President Trump instructed Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke to consider shrinking to accommodate fossil-fuel speculation and other private endeavors. In early December, however, it was announced that Basin and Range \u2014 unlike similarly designated lands in Nevada and Utah \u2014 had been spared manipulation (for now, anyway).", "title": "At Basin and Range National Monument, Landscapes, Art and Aliens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "A news release accompanying the data included a written statement from Mr. de Blasio that acknowledged no fault with the city\u2019s handling of such cases during his administration.\n\n\u201cFar too long, survivors of sexual harassment had to suffer in silence,\u201d the statement said. \u201cWe\u2019ve reviewed and overhauled our policies to send a loud and clear message of support to survivors.\u201d\n\nAmong other agencies, the parks department also had a relatively high number of cases, with 130 complaints filed between July 1, 2013, and June 30, 2017. Of those, 59 were substantiated and at least 39 were found to be without substance, although the data for that category was not complete.\n\nThere were numerous gaps in the data provided by the city. For many agencies, the city provided only partial data, for instance, failing to indicate how many cases were substantiated. And it omitted some kinds of data, such as how many complainants brought their cases to federal or state investigators.\n\nThe news release said that all city employees will receive sexual harassment training over the next year. It also said that the city will release data annually and create a standardized system for reporting harassment.\n\nThe largest settlement identified by the city included a payment of $550,000 in a suit brought three women employed by the city\u2019s Human Resources Administration. In that case, a supervisor was accused of repeated assaults, including groping breasts and, in at least one instance, choking one of the women while she was at her desk. The women brought their complaints to more senior staff at the agency, which oversees much of the city\u2019s social services programs, but according to the suit their allegations were never addressed and the sexual harassment continued.\n\nThe city also reached a $500,000 settlement in 2015 with a police officer, who sued the city in federal court over harassment by her supervisor, a sergeant, accusing him of a yearslong pattern of harassment that included forcible touching, sexual insults and, at one point, taking a picture of his penis next to her face as she rested with a jacket over her head. The suit said the harassment was not limited to the sergeant and was not taken seriously by supervisors.\n\nThe sergeant told the female officer that he \u201cknows people\u201d on the job and that he was \u201cuntouchable,\u201d according to the complaint. He retired from the force, according to the complaint.", "title": "At City Agencies, Hundreds of Harassment Claims but No Consistent Response", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "While in Italy, Mr. Pruitt \u201crefused to stay at hotels recommended by the U.S. Embassy, although the recommended hotel had law enforcement and other U.S. resources on site,\u201d according to the letter, in which the lawmakers ask Mr. Pruitt to turn over documents related to the claims. Instead, Mr. Pruitt chose to stay \u201cat more expensive hotels with fewer standard security resources,\u201d while bringing along his own security team \u201cat taxpayer expense.\u201d\n\nIn addition, Mr. Perrotta played a central role in approving Mr. Pruitt\u2019s regular use of first-class flights, and has often joined him in first class, including during the trip to Italy last June, for which travel costs totaled at least $120,000, according to public records. And when Mr. Pruitt wanted a secure place to make sensitive phone calls, Mr. Perrotta pushed for the construction of a $43,000 surveillance-proof booth in Mr. Pruitt\u2019s office in Washington, over the objections of colleagues who had advocated a less expensive option. Mr. Perrotta also pressed, unsuccessfully, for a bulletproof vehicle for Mr. Pruitt and a bulletproof desk for his security detail.\n\nFrom the time Mr. Pruitt arrived at the E.P.A., the Trump transition team requested increased security for him, suggesting that safety was a concern. But as Mr. Pruitt\u2019s security measures and requests have grown over the past year, various internal reviews at the E.P.A. have questioned the need.\n\nMr. Perrotta, who joined the Secret Service in 1995 and moved to the E.P.A. in 2004, declined requests for comment left at his office at the E.P.A. and at his security consulting firm, Sequoia Security Group.
