An E.P.A. spokesman defended the heightened security measures, repeating previous E.P.A. assertions that Mr. Pruitt \u201chas faced an unprecedented amount of death threats\u201d and that \u201cmembers of the president\u2019s cabinet should be kept safe from these violent threats.\u201d\n\nA native New Yorker, Mr. Perrotta, 50, made a name for himself in the mid-1990s when he worked for the Bronx district attorney, investigating gambling and loan-sharking activities of the Gambino crime family, and then later helping efforts that led to the arrest and conviction of John Gotti, the longtime boss of the Gambino family.\n\nPhoto\n\nLongtime E.P.A. employees described Mr. Perrotta as a backslapper and a fast-talker who enjoys talking about his mob-busting days and has given the impression that he chafed under the leadership of others.\n\nSince taking over the protective detail weeks after Mr. Pruitt\u2019s confirmation in February 2017, Mr. Perrotta has cheekily referred to himself as the agency\u2019s sheriff and has whistled the distinctive tune made famous by the Western film \u201cThe Good, the Bad and the Ugly,\u201d said two E.P.A. officials who worked with Mr. Perrotta. On occasion, he has worn a black cowboy hat and boots around the E.P.A. office, a move that some colleagues considered a lighthearted allusion to Mr. Pruitt\u2019s home state, Oklahoma.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Perrotta, a polarizing figure in the agency, is viewed among some career officials as playing to Mr. Pruitt\u2019s ego and security fears to seize power over rivals. The measures he advocated in the name of security provided Mr. Pruitt with perks more commonly associated with heads of state, and often came over the objections of top agency officials. Some of them complained that Mr. Perrotta was playing fast and loose with the rules, but that he could not be challenged because he was thought to have Mr. Pruitt\u2019s blessing.\n\nErcole Gaudioso, a former New York Organized Crime Task Force investigator who worked the Gotti case with Mr. Perrotta, says he thinks his former junior partner, with whom he keeps in contact, may find the work of protecting a cabinet secretary boring by comparison.\n\n\u201cHe was the guy who wanted to be out fighting the bad guy all the time,\u201d Mr. Gaudioso said.\n\nIn a self-published 2016 book detailing his work in law enforcement, Mr. Perrotta acknowledged skirmishes during his career, particularly in its early days.\n\n\u201cIt often appeared to me that my fellow agents and supervisors did not quite get me, my motivations and authenticity often maligned and misunderstood,\u201d he wrote. \u201cI have come to accept that I contributed to this misconception and false labeling in part because of my high level of energy.\u201d\n\nMr. Perrotta became Mr. Pruitt\u2019s security chief after the administrator removed Eric Weese, a special agent who had a reputation, even before Mr. Pruitt\u2019s arrival, for closely following agency rules, even if it might mean standing up to political appointees, according to Fred Burnside, who led the E.P.A.\u2019s criminal enforcement division from 2008 to 2010.\n\n\u201cWe always encouraged anyone to speak up if they disagree with the direction of the organization,\u201d Mr. Burnside said.\n\nMr. Weese had denied Mr. Pruitt\u2019s requests to use lights and sirens when being driven in his agency-issued vehicle to restaurants and airports, and also made it clear he would be opposed to signing off on security waivers to allow Mr. Pruitt to fly in first class.\n\nMr. Perrotta not only indulged those requests, but also quickly moved to restrict access to Mr. Pruitt, making his office and the rest of that floor of the E.P.A. headquarters off-limits to anyone who was not on a list drawn up by Mr. Perrotta, said Ronald Slotkin, former director of the agency\u2019s multimedia office.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe used to be friends,\u201d Mr. Slotkin said, referring to Mr. Perrotta. Then, he said, \u201cboom, overnight this list was blocking me from getting in.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Perrotta urged Mr. Pruitt to take other steps in the name of security that struck some as excessive, including the surveillance-thwarting booth and the sweep for listening devices.\n\nSweeps are typically initiated by the agency\u2019s homeland security office and are conducted by government personnel or certified outside contractors, two agency officials said. Mr. Perrotta, instead, turned to Mr. Steinmetz, a vice president at the security firm that Mr. Perrotta founded in 2013 and continues to work for even while on the E.P.A. payroll. The agency confirmed that Mr. Perrotta had gotten a waiver to maintain outside employment.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt was an emergency, they needed it right away,\u201d said Mr. Steinmetz, who had conducted security sweeps for other government agencies, but never previously for the E.P.A. \u201cI dropped everything and took care of it.\u201d\n\nMr. Steinmetz, who received $3,000 for the work, said none of the money went to Mr. Perrotta or his company. The E.P.A. did not respond to a question about whether the sweep turned up anything. But Mr. Steinmetz suggested it had been necessary because \u201cthere are people there working behind the scenes doing anything they can to cause embarrassment for this administrator,\u201d including, he said, \u201choldovers from the previous administration.\u201d\n\nThe sweep, conducted within weeks of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s taking office in February 2017, inflamed tensions between Mr. Perrotta and the agency\u2019s homeland security office, where officials were increasingly \u2014 and openly \u2014 skeptical of the expensive security demands.\n\nThings got so heated that a scuffle broke out during a meeting last summer of the agency\u2019s top security and administrative staff, according to attendees. They said that Mr. Perrotta traded expletives with Mario Caraballo, who until recently served as the deputy associate administrator of the homeland security office, and that the two men had to be physically separated.\n\nFrictions persisted as Mr. Perrotta worked to consolidate power within the security detail, giving his team a top role in evaluating threats against Mr. Pruitt and determining the financial resources needed to combat them.\n\nOne part-time member of the security detail, John C. Martin, was removed when it was discovered that his cellphone had an application that allowed him to communicate confidentially, according to people with knowledge of the matter. The application was discovered after the E.P.A. did an audit of government-issued mobile devices, looking for secure applications such as Signal and WhatsApp, which could be used to communicate with members of the media, as well as for legitimate government work. Mr. Martin had raised questions internally about the bug-sweeping contract and the security booth, agency officials said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Perrotta later instructed Kevin Chmielewski, a Trump administration political appointee who had served as Mr. Pruitt\u2019s deputy chief of staff, to confiscate Mr. Martin\u2019s gun and badge, according to agency officials. Mr. Chmielewski later told associates that he regretted carrying out Mr. Perrotta\u2019s instructions, which he came to believe were retaliatory.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Perrotta also retained more than a dozen private security guards for Mr. Pruitt\u2019s trip to Italy, a decision that would typically be made by the agency\u2019s homeland security office and the State Department.\n\nAccording to an E.P.A. official who was involved in the trip, Mr. Perrotta and the security guards attended a five-course meal at a Rome restaurant with Mr. Pruitt and his staff, a rarity for security personnel, who usually do not dine with those they protect.\n\nOfficials from the E.P.A.\u2019s homeland security office, under Mr. Caraballo, questioned the need for all of the additional security expenses. \u201cEPA Intelligence has not identified any specific credible direct threat to the E.P.A. administrator,\u201d a memo from Mr. Caraballo\u2019s office said in February.\n\nAfter excerpts from the memo were made public by two Democrats in the Senate this week, Mr. Pruitt\u2019s staff confirmed that Mr. Caraballo had been removed from his job. He is one of several career officials who have been reassigned or removed after challenging Mr. Perrotta\u2019s implementation of enhanced security measures for Mr. Pruitt. Even political appointees have not been immune.\n\nAfter months of objecting to Mr. Pruitt\u2019s security spending, Mr. Chmielewski, who had been among the first employees of Donald J. Trump\u2019s 2016 presidential campaign, was asked to surrender his credentials, electronic security card and parking pass to one of Mr. Perrotta\u2019s agents late one night in the agency\u2019s parking lot.\n\nMr. Chmielewski refused, got in his car and began driving to his family\u2019s home in Maryland, at which point he got a call from Mr. Perrotta, according to an administration official briefed on the exchange and the letter sent Thursday by Democrats in Congress. If Mr. Chmielewski did not immediately return to the E.P.A. to surrender his credentials, security card and parking pass, Mr. Perrotta said he would drive to Mr. Chmielewski\u2019s home that night and personally retrieve them.\n\nMr. Chmielewski reported the exchange, which he characterized as a threat, to the White House and to the E.P.A.\u2019s internal affairs and criminal investigative divisions. Mr. Chmielewski, Mr. Martin and others who have crossed Mr. Perrotta have told associates that they are concerned Mr. Perrotta will not be held to account by the inspector general.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven after Mr. Perrotta\u2019s colleagues raised concerns about his oversight of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s security, Mr. Perrotta and the assistant inspector general who oversees investigation, Patrick Sullivan, have been spotted drinking beers together at Elephant and Castle, a bar across the street from the E.P.A. headquarters. The men were both with the Secret Service before coming to the E.P.A. Mr. Perrotta initially worked in the inspector general\u2019s office when he arrived at the agency, and moved to the security detail late in George W. Bush\u2019s presidency.\n\nA spokesman for the inspector general did not dispute that Mr. Perrotta and Mr. Sullivan were \u201cfriendly\u201d but disputed that they socialized outside of work and added that the office has \u201cimpairment and impartiality requirements\u201d intended to prevent bias in any investigation.\n\nMr. Steinmetz, the business associate of Mr. Perrotta, said he had been encouraged by Mr. Perrotta to be candid if contacted by the inspector general.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got nothing to hide,\u201d said Mr. Steinmetz. \u201cI know the guy. I know that he\u2019s straightforward. He\u2019s honest.\u201d", "title": "At E.P.A., Pruitt\u2019s \u2018Sheriff\u2019 Clashed With Critics of Spending", "authors": ["Kenneth P. Vogel", "Eric Lipton", "Lisa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Tensions, too, were rising a few blocks away, inside the rehearsal hall at the Jewish Community Center. Rex Harrison, the show\u2019s Henry Higgins and marquee star, was looking increasingly nervous, as the 20-year-old Julie Andrews, who was to play Eliza Doolittle, was keeping her cool. In an era before microphones could supersize voices, actors had only their own vocal cords to project to the back of the theater, and Harrison \u2014 a novice to the Broadway musical, though he had sung in London shows decades before \u2014 was feeling insecure.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe show\u2019s director, Moss Hart; its librettist and lyricist, Alan Jay Lerner; and its composer, Frederick Loewe, tried to reassure the temperamental actor, but when he faced an orchestra of 32 musicians in the 1,600-seat, two-balconied theater in a final rehearsal for that first public performance, he became overwhelmed\n\nAccording to Lerner\u2019s 1978 memoir, when Harrison got to the \u201cA Hymn to Him\u201d number, he stopped the rehearsal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMossie! Mossie!,\u201d he cried out to the director in the darkened orchestra, stepping into the footlights. \u201cWe\u2019re not going to open tonight \u2014 and I may never open.\u201d\n\nAmong the backstage witnesses to that piece of theater history: Jerry Adler, now 87, who was an assistant stage manager. \u201cHe flung his hat into the orchestra and stormed off to his dressing room, slamming the door behind him,\u201d Mr. Adler recalled recently.\n\n\u201cHe was terrified,\u201d added Mr. Adler, now best known as a late-in-life actor (\u201cThe Good Wife,\u201d \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d). \u201cWe were opening that night and we hadn\u2019t been through the second act yet.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Mr. Adler remembers it, Harrison\u2019s British valet emerged from his dressing room to make a formal announcement: \u201cMr. Harrison would like to see Mr. Hart.\u201d\n\nMr. Adler went on: \u201cThe rest of us were all standing around, like, what do we do now? So we did a little rehearsal of the next scene, which was \u2018A Little Bit of Luck\u2019 with Stanley Holloway.\n\n\u201cEverything was fine and great with that number,\u201d he added. \u201cFinally, Moss came out and told us to release the cast for the day.\u201d\n\nThe creative team scurried in and out of Harrison\u2019s dressing room to urge the star to change his mind.\n\nFinally, an emergency telephone call was placed to Maurice H. Bailey, who ran the Shubert and was playing bridge at the local country club, according to Edith Goodmaster, his executive secretary at the time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bailey rushed to the theater, remembered Ms. Goodmaster, 87, and told Harrison that if he didn\u2019t perform that night, Mr. Bailey would go onstage and tell the audience of the actor\u2019s refusal.\n\nHarrison\u2019s manager \u201cturned white,\u201d Ms. Goodmaster said, adding: \u201cMr. Bailey later told me that he would never have gone through with the threat. He was bluffing.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s not clear whether Mr. Bailey\u2019s warning \u2014 or the failure-to-perform lawsuits that were then being discussed with Harrison\u2019s lawyer and agent \u2014 had an impact, but the actor relented, appeased by the promise that Hart would advise the theatergoers of the production\u2019s tenuous state before the curtain rose.\n\n\u201cMoss told Rex that we would explain to them that there are technical problems, and that it\u2019s more like a rehearsal,\u201d Mr. Adler said. \u201cHe said, \u2018They won\u2019t mind at all, because audiences love things like that.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAround 6 o\u2019clock, Hart came out of Harrison\u2019s dressing room. \u201cI\u2019ll never forget what he said,\u201d Mr. Adler recalled. \u201cHe said, grandly: \u2018Gather the players! We\u2019re opening tonight!\u2019\u201d\n\nWord of the performance\u2019s cancellation, which had been broadcast on the radio, was rescinded, and crowds started forming at the theater: Yale students, local fans and trainloads of theater folk from Manhattan.\n\nMeanwhile, Mr. Adler and another assistant stage manager crisscrossed New Haven, rounding up the actors from Kaysey\u2019s (a theater hangout) and the nearby Taft Hotel, where most of the cast was housed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI went across the street to the Loew\u2019s Poli,\u201d said Mr. Adler, referring to the movie theater opposite the Shubert, \u201cand in the middle of the movie, I yelled out: \u2018Anyone here from \u2018My Fair Lady\u2019 cast? The show is back on tonight!\u2019 We got everyone but one \u2014 Rosemary Gaines, who had an attack of appendicitis and was in the hospital.\u201d (She was an ensemble member who played a servant.)\n\nAs promised, Hart stepped before the curtain around 8:45 p.m. \u2014 openings were later in that era \u2014 and addressed the audience with his famous elegant charm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was one of the great opening night speeches,\u201d said Mr. Adler, who watched from the wings. \u201cHe finished by quoting Blanche DuBois: \u2018We have always depended on the kindness of strangers.\u2019 The audience loved it.\u201d\n\nThe orchestra started its overture as lights on the scrim revealed a tableau at Covent Garden. The first scene began with Harrison\u2019s revealing himself from behind a pillar. He was holding a notebook. \u201cI could see that he was shaking,\u201d Mr. Adler said.\n\nThe welcoming applause helped calm him, and he got through his opening number: \u201cWhy Can\u2019t the English?\u201d\n\n\u201cThat gave him confidence,\u201d Mr. Adler said. \u201cWouldn\u2019t It Be Loverly,\u201d which showcased Ms. Andrews\u2019s soprano, was welcomed even more warmly. By the time the old music hall pro Holloway performed \u201cWith a Little Bit of Luck,\u201d it was clear that the audience was loving the show.\n\nBut the night\u2019s high point, according to those who were there, was at the end of \u201cThe Rain in Spain,\u201d when Ms. Andrews, Harrison and Robert Coote \u2014 who played Colonel Pickering \u2014 joyously collapsed on a sofa after Eliza\u2019s linguistic breakthrough.\n\n\u201cThe audience just went berserk, leapt to their feet and refused to stop applauding,\u201d Mr. Adler said.\n\nHarrison and Coote didn\u2019t know what to do.\n\n\u201cIt was little Julie \u2014 a veteran of England\u2019s music halls \u2014 who took command,\u201d Mr. Adler said. \u201cShe grabbed their hands and led them in taking a small bow, acknowledging the audience\u2019s applause so they could go on with the show. It never happened quite like that again.\u201d\n\nAt intermission, Ms. Goodmaster remembered, members of the audience were rushing to the box office to snap up remaining tickets for the run.\n\nThat\u2019s not to say the show was perfect. With technical delays and an overstuffed score, \u201cMy Fair Lady\u201d ran past midnight. Three numbers were later cut. And the problematic turntables proved problematic throughout.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey never worked perfectly,\u201d Mr. Adler said. \u201cNot even on opening night in New York.\u201d", "title": "At First Performance of \u2018My Fair Lady,\u2019 the Drama Was Offstage", "authors": ["Frank Rizzo"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Dan Davenport, an editor and writer who also attended, recalled that when Ms. Nixon was asked about legalizing marijuana, she \u201cpumped her fist and said yes.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe was very exuberant about that point,\u201d he said, noting she framed the issue around raising revenue.\n\nGov. Andrew M. Cuomo has long opposed legalizing recreational marijuana.\n\nSince Ms. Nixon declared her bid for governor in mid-March, she has provided few details about her policy plans for the state. Instead, she has focused almost exclusively on criticizing Mr. Cuomo, the two-term incumbent she is challenging in the primary, questioning both his ethics and whether he is a \u201creal Democrat.\u201d\n\nAsked about her qualifications outside a campaign launch party, Ms. Nixon quipped, \u201cMy chief of staff has not been convicted on three counts of bribery \u2014 that\u2019s a start.\u201d Joseph Percoco, one of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s former top aides and his former campaign manager, was recently convicted in a federal corruption trial.\n\nMs. Nixon has never held office or managed a large organization, although she has been an education activist in New York for more than a decade. In the early stages of her campaign, she has said schools deserve more equitable funding, and she has backed raising taxes on those earning more than $5 million. She has also vowed to focus on the beleaguered subway system in New York City, though has offered few specifics.", "title": "At Fund-Raiser, Cynthia Nixon Says She Favors Legalizing Marijuana", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "He learned to cook as part of the natural rhythm of life, in the kitchen with his parents, Taiwanese immigrants who gently bickered over ingredients. (His mother\u2019s roots are in mainland China; his father\u2019s family has lived in Taiwan for generations.)\n\nHere, he starts with collagen-heavy cow hooves and beef shin bones with tendon attached, leaving them to simmer for a day and a night, commingling with the Chinese culinary trinity of garlic, scallions and ginger. The only salt comes from two kinds of soy sauce, both dark but one aged longer, until it approaches syrup.\n\nSweetness leaches from rock sugar, goji berries, star anise, cloves, cinnamon and licorice \u2014 the scents alone stir the palate \u2014 and is held in check by heat, conjured by doubanjiang, dried red chiles and Sichuan peppercorns for a low-level buzz. (These last ingredients are a legacy of refugees from Sichuan Province who fled to Taiwan after Mao\u2019s victory on the mainland.)\n\nIn another pot, beef shank relaxes in rice wine, soy sauce and the same heady mix of aromatics. Once combined, the two stocks are given a few hours to sort out their differences and become one. The panels of beef emerge beautifully tender, the connecting stitches of fat visible to the eye but dissembling immediately on the tongue. Knottier tendon is available for those who want more of a fight.\n\nThe soup is notably holistic, as if refusing to take sides, neither frankly carnal nor purely herbaceous but somewhere more intriguingly in between. You may order it extra rich, with a last-minute spoonful of liquefied marrow added just before serving, although I didn\u2019t notice much difference beyond a gloss on the lips. Another variation is spicy, the broth turned incarnadine from hot sauce, which proves to be more accent mark than armament, contouring the mouth instead of searing it.", "title": "At Ho Foods, a Noodle Soup That Nourishes and Transports", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "One way to prove himself, he said, was to accept the condition they have for outsiders who want to learn about the area: Newcomers have to share some bit of knowledge or help with a project. On his first trip, Mr. Vallejo made photographs for a catalog of traditional plants in the community\u2019s herbarium.\n\nMembers of the community who had left to study have returned to apply their newly acquired skills and help preserve their culture and the environment. The financial settlement they reached with the government allowed them to set up a local bank, and they have also undertaken projects to provide each home with a solar panel that can power a light and radio.\n\nAnd while they may be far from the city, they are not cut off. An administration building has a satellite internet connection and a generator, which attracts people who want to charge their phones, tablets or laptops (which, apart from connecting them to supporters and allies in the environmental movement, are also good for watching movies).\n\n\u201cThis super global tool, you might think was a bad influence, but they use it for their campaigns,\u201d Mr. Vallejo said. \u201cIt\u2019s interesting how there is this influence of foreign culture, and the majority of people there, especially the young, have Facebook and Instagram accounts. They connect to the Western world and borrow some things. For example, when they have feasts, they paint their faces. Used to be they painted spirits. Now, one kid paints his face like a member of Kiss.\u201d", "title": "At Home in the Jungle, Everything Is \u2018Alive and Has a Spirit\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nBaby on floor. In a first, Senator Tammy Duckworth of Illinois brought her 10-day-old baby into the Senate chamber yesterday, so Duckworth could cast a vote. \u201cThere weren\u2019t even bathrooms for women at the U.S. Senate until 1992,\u201d Patricia Zengerle of Reuters noted. Duckworth\u2019s office tweeted: \u201cFamily-friendly workplace policies aren\u2019t just a women\u2019s issue, they are a common-sense economic issue.\u201d And many mothers, like Dr. Esther Choo, took to social media to remember people who had been supportive \u2014 and not so supportive \u2014 when they brought their babies to work.\n\nAllowing babies into the workplace is one of these steps that seemed radical for so long and now seems like an obvious, necessary and decidedly modest step toward women\u2019s equality.\n\nThe deficit debate. The Washington Post\u2019s Robert Samuelson did not like my latest column, \u201cThe Democrats Are the Party of Fiscal Responsibility.\u201d He called it \u201ca real hash\u201d that came to \u201ca partisan conclusion based on meager and selective evidence.\u201d If you\u2019re interested in the subject, I encourage you to read his piece and decide for yourself.", "title": "Opinion | At Long Last, a Baby in the Senate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Transit advocates and board members \u2014 a notoriously difficult group to impress \u2014 quickly praised the bus plan. Jaqi Cohen, the campaign coordinator for the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group, called it \u201cone of the biggest wins for our city\u2019s 2.5 million daily bus riders in more than half a century.\u201d\n\nNew York City\u2019s buses are the slowest among major cities in the world, with buses in Manhattan moving at just 5.7 miles per hour on average, according to the authority. A modernization plan for the subway, which carries about six million riders each day, will be released in May.\n\nThe region is also struggling to respond to a broader transit crisis, with frequent problems on commuter railroads and bus lines. On Monday, Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey announced that New Jersey Transit would hire 40 new bus drivers as part of his proposed state budget.\n\n\u201cFor all the discussion on rail, it\u2019s buses that make the show go in urban centers and urban communities,\u201d Mr. Murphy said at a news conference in Newark, with a shiny New Jersey Transit bus parked behind the podium.\n\nAfter the M.T.A. board meeting, Mr. Byford also stood in front of a shiny bus \u2014 this one a blue double-decker model similar to the iconic two-tiered red buses in London. The new bus was expected to run on the X17J express route between Staten Island and Manhattan as part of a pilot program. Officials could order more double-decker buses in the future.\n\nPhoto\n\nDouble-decker models work better on express lines with fewer stops, Mr. Byford said.\n\n\u201cYou can carry more people in comfort over these long-distance, limited-stop routes,\u201d Mr. Byford told reporters.\n\nAs part of the bus plan, officials promised a redesign of the entire system by 2021 and the expansion of all-door boarding by 2020 as part a new fare payment system. They plan to expand a program known as traffic signal priority, which allows a bus to hold a green light or shorten a red light, in order to keep buses moving. The proposal also called for digital signs showing when the next bus is due and urging state lawmakers to allow more cameras to enforce bus lane rules.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Byford declined to provide an estimate for how much the bus plan would cost. He argued that it would depend on how many bus lanes and cameras were ultimately installed and said that many of the costs could be included in the current budget.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany pieces of the proposal will require the city\u2019s cooperation, but the initial reaction was positive. Polly Trottenberg, the city\u2019s transportation commissioner and an M.T.A. board member, praised the bus plan.\n\n\u201cSome of these items are easy to do, and some are less easy to do. But we\u2019re really looking forward to working with you,\u201d Ms. Trottenberg said.\n\nBus ridership in New York City has declined, dropping about 14 percent since 2007, even as the city\u2019s population has grown. Fed up with slow buses, some commuters have switched to bicycles or ride-hailing apps like Uber. Despite the flagging ridership, buses provide a critical source of transportation outside Manhattan, reaching into neighborhoods that are far from subway stops. Bus riders also tend to be less well-off than subway commuters.\n\nGov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who controls the transportation authority, recently revived a push for congestion pricing, a proposal to charge some drivers entering Manhattan to reduce gridlock and to raise additional revenue for public transit. But the idea failed to garner the support of state lawmakers, who instead approved a new fee on Uber and for-hire vehicles rides.\n\nPeter Ajemian, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, said the governor supported the bus plan and urged the city to do its part to implement it.\n\n\u201cMuch of the plan relies on the city\u2019s willingness to make improvements to the network and provide aggressive enforcement \u2014 we hope they will dedicate the necessary resources,\u201d Mr. Ajemian said.\n\nOmar Vera, a transit enthusiast and frequent attendee at M.T.A. board meetings, was beaming as he examined the double-decker bus and chatted with Mr. Byford, who has promised a more friendly and transparent approach.\n\n\u201cHe is amazing,\u201d Mr. Vera said. \u201cHe\u2019s going to make the M.T.A. great again.\u201d", "title": "At Long Last, a Plan to Fix New York City\u2019s Buses", "authors": ["Emma G. Fitzsimmons"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The ship has been asea already for some time. It has pointed its sharp-nosed prow toward Eighth Avenue since 2011, when it floated in from the nearby Hudson or, for all I know, down from space. It\u2019s an odd-looking edifice \u2014 bulging on one side, flat the other, but graceful, somehow graceful. It\u2019s Marni, adjacent to the meatpacking district but not quite of it. The telegraph click of needle heels doesn\u2019t resound. Your brunch cocktails have no power here.\n\nPhoto\n\nMarni is not new. The label was founded in 1994, and its founder and original creative director, Consuelo Castiglioni, raised it up from a counterpart of the family-run fur business into something richer and stranger: an oasis of the odd in the world of high-end fashion, offering uniforms for the working woman unafraid of color or shape.\n\nBut in recent years, fade and fatigue had set in. In 2016, the company was acquired by OTB and Ms. Castiglioni stepped down. In her place came Francesco Risso, a cherub-curled Italian given to nonsense pronouncements. (About his own men\u2019s wear, and its disregard for tired conventions like fit: \u201cHis game of sizing is absent-minded!\u201d)\n\nPhoto\n\nA year and a half into his tenure, his sprightly take on Marni has made its way off the runways of Milan and into the stores. While the essential elements of Marni remain the same \u2014 color and print being two \u2014 it is now a reflection of its head and his childlike sense of wonder and play.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat makes Marni especially welcome at the present, when the reigning stance of luxury fashion is aggression, reared up on its hind legs: a mash-up of street wear \u2014 in the Virgil Abloh/Supreme sense \u2014 and finery, logo-spattered, grimly protective. You used to be able to play around with clothes \u2014 not least at Prada, where Mr. Risso spent years. But even Prada, where Miuccia Prada extolled bad taste as well as good and dabbled in fabrics she hated as well as ones she loved, seems stuck in a rut. Compared with dour neutrals and ironic casual wear, Marni is an antidepressant, the Prozac to the prosaic. Here, you still can believe that fashion might be fun.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first day I went, a friend in tow, the ship was manned by two clerks in matching orange sweaters, wrinkled shirts and green pants with their hems undone. Tweedledee and Tweedledum, as I have come to think of them, were kind, laid-back tour guides to the woozy weirdness of the Marni world. (They had dressed identically, they confessed, not entirely on purpose, but not entirely by accident, either \u2014 the kind of admission well suited to Wonderland.)", "title": "At Marni, Shopping the Good Shop Lollipop", "authors": ["Matthew Schneier", "Critical Shopper"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Others who have departed include the head of diversity and inclusion, a vice president in footwear and a senior director for Nike\u2019s basketball division.\n\nIt is a humbling setback for a company that is famous worldwide and has built its brand around the inspirational slogan \u201cJust Do It.\u201d While the #MeToo movement has led to the downfall of individual men, the kind of sweeping overhaul that is occurring at Nike is rare in the corporate world, and illustrates how internal pressure from employees is forcing even huge companies to quickly address workplace problems.\n\nAs women \u2014 and men \u2014 continue to come forward with complaints, Nike has begun a comprehensive review of its human resources operations, making management training mandatory and revising many of its internal reporting procedures.\n\nWhile the departure of top executives has been covered in news accounts, new reporting by The New York Times, including interviews with more than 50 current and former employees, provides the most thorough account yet of how disaffection among women festered and left them feeling ignored, harassed and stymied in their careers. The Times also viewed copies of three complaints to human resources.\n\n\u201cI came to the realization that I, as a female, would not grow in that company,\u201d said Francesca Krane, who worked for five years in Nike\u2019s retail brand design area before leaving in 2016. She said she grew tired of watching men get promoted into jobs ahead of women she felt were equally or better qualified.\n\nMany of those interviewed, across multiple divisions, also described a workplace environment that was demeaning to women. Three people, for instance, said they recalled times when male superiors referred to people using a vulgar term for women\u2019s genitals. Another employee said that her boss threw his car keys at her and called her a \u201cstupid bitch.\u201d She reported the incident to human resources. (She told her sister about it at the time, the sister confirmed.) He continued to be her supervisor.\n\nMost of the people who spoke to The Times insisted on anonymity, citing nondisclosure agreements or a fear of being ostracized in the industry, or in the Portland community, where Nike wields outsize influence. Some have spouses or family members still working there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn response to questions, Nike portrayed its problems as being confined to \u201can insular group of high-level managers\u201d who \u201cprotected each other and looked the other way.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat is not something we are going to tolerate,\u201d said a spokesman, KeJuan Wilkins.\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Parker said the vast majority of Nike\u2019s employees work hard to inspire and serve athletes throughout the world. \u201cIt has pained me to hear that there are pockets of our company where behaviors inconsistent with our values have prevented some employees from feeling respected and doing their best work,\u201d he said.\n\nFor Amanda Shebiel, who left Nike in September after about five years at the company, the promise to address longstanding systemic problems is welcome, but late.\n\n\u201cWhy did it take an anonymous survey to make change?\u201d she asked. \u201cMany of my peers and I reported incidences and a culture that were uncomfortable, disturbing, threatening, unfair, gender-biased and sexist \u2014 hoping that something would change that would make us believe in Nike again.\u201d\n\n\u201cNo one went just to complain,\u201d Ms. Shebiel added. \u201cWe went to make it better.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAn Inner Circle of Men\n\nWith a market value of about $112 billion and annual revenues of around $36 billion, Nike is a global behemoth in the athletic market, where its dominance went largely unchallenged for several decades.\n\nBut the company is facing significant business hurdles. Adidas, one of its biggest competitors, has gained ground in key markets like apparel and footwear. Nike is also struggling to get traction in women\u2019s categories, the fastest-growing segment of the market.\n\nSome of those interviewed by The Times said the weakness in women\u2019s products in part reflected a lack of female leadership and an environment that favored male voices. Nike\u2019s own research shows that women occupy nearly half the company\u2019s work force but just 38 percent of positions of director or higher, and 29 percent of the vice presidents, according to an April 4 internal memo obtained by The Times.\n\nAnd while Nike executives have told investors that the women\u2019s category was a crucial part of its revenue growth strategy, former employees said it was not given the budget it needed to roll out the sophisticated marketing campaigns that were the hallmark of traditional men\u2019s sports, like basketball.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Nike did put money behind campaigns targeting women, it sometimes flailed.\n\nLast year, Mr. Edwards, the former president, gave the green light for a marketing campaign for the fall launch of the VaporMax shoe for women; the female British singer FKA Twigs was given creative license for a shoot in Mexico City. The result, according to a person who saw a rough cut of the commercial and another who saw the final cut, featured few shots of the shoes and instead had a woman twirling on what looked like a stripper pole and male athletes in sports bras striking odd poses. The campaign was killed, costing Nike millions of dollars.\n\nAsked about the aborted campaign, Mr. Wilkins of Nike said the company was proud of its relationship with the singer. \u201cWe have a history of pushing the boundaries in marketing, just as we do in product development,\u201d Mr. Wilkins said. \u201cWe create a lot of material that is not deployed in the marketplace.\u2019\u2019\n\nNike forcefully disputed the notion that women were not involved in the creative and marketing operations, noting that a female executive leads its women\u2019s division. But Mr. Wilkins, the spokesman, acknowledged that, in areas like basketball, \u201cthere was more room and opportunity for the company to increase female representation in its senior positions.\u201d\n\nWhile women struggled to attain top positions at Nike, an inner circle of mostly male leaders emerged who had a direct line to Mr. Edwards. Within the company, as reported earlier in The Wall Street Journal, this group was known as F.O.T., or Friends of Trevor. They texted him in meetings or bragged about having lunch or dinner with him.\n\nA charismatic and creative marketing force, the London-born Mr. Edwards joined Nike in 1992. He oversaw marketing in Europe in the late 1990s, before moving to the United States and taking over the brand in 2002. In 2013, he became Nike brand president.\n\nPhoto\n\nPaige Azavedo recalls her first meeting in 2014 with her new boss, Daniel Tawiah, then a senior director for Nike\u2019s digital brand in North America. She expected they would discuss digital marketing plans.\n\nInstead, she was surprised when he talked mostly about himself and how Mr. Edwards had nominated him for a fast-track career program. \u201cHe basically said, I\u2019ve been nominated to be in this V.P. program and that\u2019s going to be my goal for the next six months to a year,\u201d said Ms. Azavedo, who left Nike in 2015. \u201cHe made it clear he was a friend of Trevor.\u201d\n\nMultiple women, including Ms. Azavedo, told The Times they reported Mr. Tawiah to human resources for berating them in front of their peers, sometimes to the point of tears. He was promoted to vice president last year. This month, he was among those who abruptly departed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nReached by telephone, Mr. Tawiah declined to comment. Mr. Wilkins declined to comment on the complaints against Mr. Tawiah or his departure.\n\nMr. Edwards, who resigned in March but is advising Mr. Parker until he retires in August, did not respond to an email or a message left on his LinkedIn profile. A representative for Mr. Martin declined to comment.\n\nAs men advanced more quickly into key roles in merchandising, design and marketing, a number of high-ranking women began to leave the company.\n\nAmong the first to depart, in the spring of 2017, was Patty Ross, a vice president of workplace design and connectivity who had started working at Nike when she was 16. She had also founded a women\u2019s mentoring network inside Nike.\n\nShe was followed by Kerri Hoyt-Pack, a 15-year veteran of the company who had helped launch the Nike women\u2019s brand. Then came Nikki Neuburger, a vice president in global brand marketing for running, who was a driving force behind the Nike+ app.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Ross declined to comment for this article. Ms. Hoyt-Pack and Ms. Neuburger did not respond to messages seeking comment.\n\nWhen Ms. Neuburger left, she sent a pointed letter to Mr. Parker as well as other members of her team, laying out the reasons for her departure. They covered familiar themes, said one person who said she was read the letter: harassment, and the exclusion of women from the inner circle of decision makers.\n\n\u201cNikki did write a letter,\u201d Mr. Wilkins said. \u201cIt was thoughtful and professional. Mark took the letter very seriously and did meet with Nikki.\u201d\n\nConcerned about these departures, a group of women inside Nike started the behind-the-scenes survey that eventually ended up on Mr. Parker\u2019s desk.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018I Was Looking for Help\u2019\n\nThe obstacles to advancement for women at Nike are not new and, in many ways, common in companies with male-dominated leadership. Since Nike\u2019s early days in the 1960s, many employees have been guided by a simple ethos: work hard, party hard, get up for your five-mile run in the morning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe culture that evolved could be belittling to women. On the way to a work dinner in Los Angeles, two senior men debated whether Los Angeles or Portland had better strip clubs, according to a person who attended, as the women traveling with them in the van stared out the windows.\n\nOne current employee said a supervisor pushed his way into a bathroom and tried to kiss her, according to a copy of her complaint that was viewed by The Times.\n\nOver time, many women developed a deep skepticism of Nike\u2019s human resources services. Some avoided the department altogether, fearing retribution or convinced that nothing would happen. Those who did seek help said they often came away frustrated.\n\n\u201cI was looking for help and they just totally shut it down, like \u2018You\u2019re the problem,\u2019\u201d said Marie Yates, a former retail designer, who said she went to human resources seeking help with issues she was having with a manager. She left the company in 2016.\n\nA senior manager who mentioned a female employee\u2019s breasts in an email was not terminated, but rather given a verbal warning, according to a former staff member in the human resources department.\n\nIn one complaint reviewed by The Times, a woman described her manager bragging about the condoms he always carried and the magazines he kept on his desk with scantily clad women on the covers, despite being told to remove them. She reported him to human resources, and was told she had made a mistake by not confronting him first, she said.\n\nUntil last year, human resources was run by David Ayre, who was hired in 2007 by Nike from PepsiCo and reported directly to Mr. Parker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ayre did not return phone and email messages seeking comment.\n\nComplaints were sometimes handled casually. The employee whose supervisor tried to kiss her in the bathroom set up a meeting with human resources to discuss it, and was taken aback when she was told to meet her representative in the Mia Hamm cafe \u2014 a public space on Nike\u2019s sprawling campus.\n\nAmber Amin said her manager routinely belittled her with sexist and dismissive comments but still worried about what would happen if she reported him.\n\n\u201cI think his general attitude toward women was just, subtly, that we were less capable,\u201d said Ms. Amin, a junior designer on one of the Nike apps, who added that she had received positive performance reviews since becoming an employee in 2014.\n\nShe eventually sought help from human resources, which told her that corrective action would be taken. Two days later, she was part of a round of layoffs.\n\nMr. Wilkins said Nike has a no-retribution policy that it takes seriously and noted that there was a significant reorganization of the work force last year.\n\nThe callousness that some women experienced extended at times to the work force at large, employees said. By the summer of 2016, for instance, Nike had decided to stop making golf balls, golf clubs and other equipment. Members of the division were summoned to a meeting inside the Clubhouse, the nickname for one of Nike\u2019s buildings.\n\nThere, horrified employees watched their names appear on a large screen, directing them to different rooms, where some would be laid off, according to one person who attended the meeting and two people who were told of it. The person said it left employees with the impression they were being let go via PowerPoint presentation.\n\nAsked about those layoffs, Mr. Wilkins said, \u201cThat\u2019s absolutely not normal practice for us,\u201d and suggested the situation was more nuanced than it appeared. In layoff situations, he said, \u201cwe make great efforts to treat every employee in a very thoughtful manner.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRegarding complaints to human resources, Mr. Wilkins said: \u201cWe\u2019re not going to comment on individual cases, but cases are often more complicated than simply listening to one side of the story.\u201d\n\nWhile Nike believes it has a set of human resources procedures installed, those systems \u201chave not worked consistently,\u201d Mr. Wilkins said. \u201cAs Mark has said, we are currently reviewing and improving our practices to re-establish trust where it has been lacking and to guard against this happening in the future.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPressure on Chief Executive\n\nNike\u2019s goals would have been hard to achieve even before the recent departure of high-level executives. In October 2015, Mr. Parker announced an ambitious target: By 2020, Nike would reach $50 billion in annual revenues. But last fall the company pushed the target date to 2022.\n\nAnd while Nike\u2019s stock has climbed 25 percent in the past year, its revenues for the first nine months of its current fiscal year grew by only 4 percent, with North American sales dipping in crucial areas, like footwear.\n\nIn women\u2019s products, Nike \u201cis growing in the low single digits, which means it is a long way away from where it wants to be,\u201d said Matt Powell, a sports industry analyst at the NPD Group. Companies like Lululemon and even Old Navy are finding greater success in the women\u2019s sportswear market, Mr. Powell said.\n\nFor now, Mr. Edwards\u2019s duties have been split between two other executives. Nike recently named a woman, Kellie Leonard, as chief diversity and inclusion officer, and Mr. Wilkins said Nike is focused \u201con attracting, developing and elevating both women and people of color throughout the organization.\u2019\u2019\n\nIt now falls to Mr. Parker, 62, to move Nike forward. A quiet executive who designed several of Nike\u2019s running shoes, Mr. Parker has been the company\u2019s chief executive since 2006. He appeared to solidify his control over the company\u2019s operations around 2015 when Nike\u2019s co-founder Phil Knight stepped down as company chairman.\n\nBut given the recent tumult at Nike, Mr. Parker may face tough questions himself. At least a dozen current and former employees told The Times they could not see how Mr. Parker was not aware of the problems with his top leaders. What is unclear, some said, is whether information was deliberately kept from Mr. Parker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs he did with other executives who reported directly to him, Mr. Parker met regularly with Mr. Ayre when he was the head of human resources to discuss, among other things, any active investigations of suspected employee misconduct, Mr. Wilkins said.\n\nWhen appropriate, he said, action was taken. But with 74,000 employees, Mr. Wilkins said, \u201cMark would not have been aware of all issues.\u201d\n\nThat explanation did not satisfy Ms. Shebiel, the former employee who left in September.\n\nIf Mr. Parker did not know, she said, \u201cit negates the times over the years my peers and I sought support and counsel from the people we were told we could trust to bring about change.\u201d\n\nMs. Shebiel said she and her colleagues risked or experienced retaliation \u201cfor shining a light on both significant and everyday experiences that left us feeling bullied, uncomfortable and intimidated.\u201d", "title": "At Nike, Revolt Led by Women Leads to Exodus of Male Executives", "authors": ["Julie Creswell", "Kevin Draper", "Rachel Abrams"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "From the bottom of a gentle grassy slope a hundred feet away, the rusted steel columns look like nothing remarkable. Lined up in rows under an open-air shed, they could be abandoned I-beams or castoffs from an old railroad bridge. Then, before you know it, you\u2019re among them. Hundreds of reddish-brown hulls, each maybe six feet tall, surrounding you. Each bolted to a thick metal post anchored not to the floor but to the ceiling. Each \u2014 you imagine, feeling a bit crazy \u2014 watching.\n\nYou\u2019d turn and run right out of there if you could.\n\nThen you see the names. Simon Jenkins. 7.17.1877. Frank Harrell. 02.09.1893. Unknown. 08.08.1883. Stenciled into the face of each column, the names of the men and women hanged, shot, drowned, beaten and burned because of the color of their skin. The columns \u2014 more than 800 \u2014 are the heart of the stunning new National Memorial for Peace and Justice, which opens on Thursday in Montgomery, Ala. They represent the counties throughout the South and across America where lynchings were carried out with impunity. So far researchers have documented more than 4,400 killings starting from the end of Reconstruction in 1877, a campaign of racial terror by white people against black and brown people lasting more than seven decades.\n\nIf the memorial were simply an accounting of all those names lost to history, it would be devastating enough. But as you walk among them, two things happen: The wooden path under your feet begins to descend and the columns appear to rise. They rise until they are suspended above your head, unreadable and unreachable, a forest of scarred brown figures. There are no more names, only a growing pressure on your chest as you try to absorb the scope of it all.", "title": "Opinion | At This Memorial, the Monuments Bleed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cComputer imaging tends to flatten our magnificent, multi-sensory, simultaneous and synchronic capacities of imagination by turning the design process into a passive visual manipulation, a retinal journal,\u201d Mr. Pallasmaa argued.\n\nDesigners, he said, shortchanged all the nonvisual ways we experience architecture \u2014 and through architecture, the fullness of life. In their recent book called \u201cAre We Human?\u201d the architects Beatriz Colomina and Mark Wigley even correlate this approach by modern architects to modern medicine\u2019s painkilling drugs.\n\nNumb to other senses, ocularcentric architecture cultivates alienation.\n\nWhat does designing more sensitively for nonvisual experience mean?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe huge new Bloomberg LP headquarters in London, designed by Foster + Partners, in collaboration with Sandy Brown, the acoustic consultants, may not be thrilling to look at from the outside. But inside, it exploits new technologies by Meyer Sound Laboratories, the Berkeley, Calif., firm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSound engineering turns open offices into private spaces, an auditorium into a confessional. These state-of-the-art acoustics weave a kind of invisible architecture into the fabric of the building.\n\nNeedless to say, one building can\u2019t stack up against the wider universe of drones, pixels and earbuds. In general, we have taken leave of our nonvisual senses \u2014 and need to get back in touch, literally.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cA room is not just a cube punctured with windows and doors,\u201d Andrea Lipps and Ellen Lupton, the show\u2019s co-curators, write in the exhibition catalog. \u201cA rug inhales noise; floorboards sigh with grief. Sensory design tweaks our skin, bones and muscles. It tickles, pinches and pops. It plays rough. It touches us, and we touch back.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s where \u201cSenses\u201d comes in. Ms. Lipps and Ms. Lupton stress how touch, sound, smell and taste activate the natural \u201cwisdom of the body.\u201d Ms. Lipps also describes a collective \u201creality hunger,\u201d which products like Cyrano, frivolous though they may seem, attempt to assuage.\n\nThe show brings together some 65 designers and teams. It presents commissions, videos, products and prototypes. Some address sensory disabilities like blindness and deafness. A device like Vibeat, for example, by a young Israeli designer, Liron Gino, is worn as a bracelet, brooch or necklace and translates music into vibrations that can be perceived by anyone, including the deaf.\n\nCheerfully colored tableware, devised for visually impaired customers, works for everyone else, too, including people with dementia, for whom distinguishing food from plates or liquids from containers can become a difficult and unappetizing chore.\n\nThere are art installations. \u201cSeated Catalogue of Feelings\u201d by Eric Gunther mixes chairs that vibrate with descriptive texts whispered through headphones and projected onto the floor (\u201cDriving over a dead body\u201d; \u201cSex on a washing machine\u201d).\n\nIt doesn\u2019t turn out to be as riveting as that scene from \u201cMad Men,\u201d but it did inspire me to Google the name Morton Heilig, sometimes called the father of virtual reality, who, half a century ago, concocted a contraption called Sensorama. The size of a vending machine, it involved a 3-D video headset, a chair that moved, fans and a device that pumped out aromas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike the Rocket Belt, it failed to take off, commercially. But its promise of a fully immersive, multisensory experience today doesn\u2019t seem far-fetched.\n\nUltrahaptics, a British-based company, invented that device that made the virtual champagne bubbles I mentioned earlier. Just as sounds can be felt through vibrations, those audio vibrations can simulate the feeling of objects in midair. Those objects can then be remotely manipulated.\n\nI know what you\u2019re imagining. But think beyond the pornographic angle.\n\nIn the not-too-distant future, ultrasound devices may create invisible sliders for adjusting the volume on your television or the flame on your stove. Bosch, the German electronics giant, has already introduced a concept car with haptic controls. Picture Wii without the hardware. Or \u201cMinority Report.\u201d Or that VR Lexus in \u201cBlack Panther.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s all very exciting \u2014 even if sensory technology will always have its limits.\n\nHands-free driving is one outcome. But of course nothing will ever substitute for the feeling of holding your own child\u2019s hand or the crunch of those brown-butter wafers.", "title": "At This Museum Show, You\u2019re Encouraged to Follow Your Nose", "authors": ["Michael Kimmelman"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "The procession was led by a singing choir, with people behind them hoisting banners that read \u201cLove for all hatred for none.\u201d Some of those marching wore orange shirts that said \u201cFree Hugs.\u201d\n\nThe march ended at Mel Lastman Square, where religious leaders representing Toronto\u2019s highly diverse population \u2014 Hindus, Jews, humanists, Muslims, Christians, Buddhists and more \u2014 delivered short speeches. An Aboriginal group, Red Spirit Drummers, was among those providing music.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI needed to be here,\u201d said Solange Homer, an immigrant from Trinidad. \u201cRace, religion doesn\u2019t matter. In times like this, we support one another.\u201d\n\nAmong those listening was Ken Greenberg, 73, an urban designer who has been asked often over the last week about the practicality of erecting protective barricades for the city\u2019s sidewalks. But as he looked around the packed square, where people born all around the world were offering hugs of support to one another, he said \u201cthe real armor is the connections\u201d among Toronto\u2019s residents.\n\nIndeed, while the attack has cast a pall of sadness over the city, it also has given rise to a new saying: Toronto the Good, a sentiment perhaps best encapsulated by the actions of Constable Ken Lam, the police officer who earned praise around the world for maintaining his composure while arresting the man accused of driving the van, Alek Minassian.\n\nBefore his arrest, Mr. Minassian held an object in his hand and repeatedly pointed it at the officer, as if it were a gun. He also shouted he had a gun in his pocket and demanded the officer \u201cshoot me in the head.\u201d\n\nBut Constable Lam made the arrest without incident.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m proud of my city,\u201d said Colleen Rooney, 60, a life coach. \u201cHow this has brought people together, more than separated us.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn addition to the response of the city\u2019s emergency services, the Canadian news media has highlighted the actions of ordinary citizens in the aftermath of the attack: people who held the hands of dying victims, who tore off their belts to fashion tourniquets, who performed CPR until the paramedics arrived.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt says something that we came together like this,\u201d said Annie Lee, 28, who lives in a condominium building close to where the attack ended. \u201cNo one jumped to conclusions. Politicians did not blame each other like in the United States. It\u2019s a testament to our unity,\u201d said Ms. Lee, 28, who works in marketing.\n\nThe city began a #TorontoStrong fund-raising effort, which had raised 1.8 million Canadian dollars, or about $1.3 million, by Sunday. Much of the money will go to the families of the victims, to help cover funeral costs and trauma counseling.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe attack happened in a once-sleepy inner suburb in the north of Toronto that, over recent decades, has transformed into a mini-downtown, with new condominium towers shooting up, bringing immigrants and bustle to the area. Korean restaurants, bubble tea cafes and small karaoke bars dot the wide suburban sidewalks, along with nods to gentrification \u2014 Whole Foods and Starbucks.\n\nOver the past week, pilgrims from across the city have ventured to the street, bringing flowers and candles and handwritten cards near the spots where people were struck down.\n\nThe victims ranged in age from So He Chung, a 22-year-old molecular biology student, to 84-year-old Mary Elizabeth Forsyth, who had wheeled her walker to a stop, on one of her frequent strolls, to feed the birds and squirrels.\n\nOne victim, Renuka Amarasingha, left behind a 7-year-old son. Ms. Amarasingha, a 48-year-old school cafeteria worker, was a single mother who had just finished her first day of work at a nearby school and was on her way to get her child. Her Buddhist center has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars to go toward his education and future.\n\nMr. Minassian, 25, faces 10 counts of first-degree murder and 13 counts of attempted murder.\n\nHe has been described by acquaintances as a loner, who expressed fear of women.\n\nThe police say Mr. Minassian posted a message hostile to women on his Facebook page moments before the deadly rampage began. In it, he praised \u201cincels,\u201d or involuntary celibates \u2014 a term used by an online community of misogynists who blame women for denying them what they see as their right to sexual intercourse.\n\nThis fact has given rise to another feeling in Toronto, in addition to the sadness and the civic pride: an uneasiness that misogyny might have been the primary factor behind the terrible act.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt struck in me a kind of terror,\u201d said Ms. Lee. \u201cHow many more people like that are there hidden out here?\u201d", "title": "At Toronto Vigil After Van Attack: Sadness, Civic Pride and Unease", "authors": ["Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Rates\n\nFrom $ 329\n\nBasics\n\nHotels that pretend to be dog friendly yet charge extortionate fees are my literal pet peeve. Not so Kimpton, which is perhaps the paw-friendliest chain. Downtown Denver\u2019s 200-room Kimpton Hotel Born opened in August 2017, with a Wild West-goes-modern aesthetic, and when we checked in with our papillon, Huckleberry, we were greeted with peanut butter and molasses treats. That was nearly where our pampering ended, though, as some amenities the hotel\u2019s website promised \u2014 including Tesla rides within a two- mile radius and an art tour of the hotel\u2019s collection curated by the Museum of Contemporary Art Denver \u2014 were not available, nearly three months after opening (both are there now). The hiccups may have been symptomatic of growing pains: Kimpton has launched upward of eight properties a year since International Hotels Group acquired the brand in 2015.\n\nLocation\n\nUnbeatable. The hotel sits adjacent to Denver\u2019s dazzlingly revamped 1914 Union Station, so guests are within walking distance of Tattered Cover Book Store; the Cruise Room, a 1933 Art Deco time warp of a bar modeled after the Queen Mary; and Sassafras American Eatery in the Highlands neighborhood, which serves the best Southern breakfast I\u2019ve had west of Dollywood.", "title": "At a Denver Hotel, Art, Yoga Mats and Loaner Bikes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Since it was founded in 1948, London\u2019s Institute of Contemporary Arts, known as ICA, has gained attention for exhibitions, screenings and other events focused on serious-minded high culture, not infrequently with a political point to make. Its bookshop, where aesthetics and left-wing politics also overlap, has long been a draw too. But ICA was never thought of as a place for a good meal.\n\nIn October, however, the proprietors of Rochelle Canteen in the Shoreditch neighborhood of East London set up a second outpost on the ground floor of ICA, a five-minute walk from Trafalgar Square in an area more propitious for genteel private clubs than for decent restaurants serving the general public. One of the owners, Margot Henderson, said it was \u201ctime our galleries took their food as seriously as they take their art.\u201d\n\nMs. Henderson is married to Fergus Henderson, founder of the influential London restaurant St. John, who was leading the charge on nose-to-tail eating long before it became a clich\u00e9. The kinship between the two restaurants is easy to see at the new Rochelle Canteen \u2014 in the calculated plainness of its mostly white, somewhat ramshackle d\u00e9cor, and in the language employed on the ever-changing menu, whose terseness cannot mask the food\u2019s appeal. The words \u201cGuinea Fowl & Smoked Bacon Pie,\u201d for example, could hardly be simpler, but who (other than a vegetarian) could resist them? It was a wonderful and surprisingly light dish, with a perfectly crisp and golden suet crust laid over tender breast and leg meat braised in a flavorful broth that also served as the pie\u2019s poultry-and-bacon-scented sauce.", "title": "At a London Temple to Art, Culinary Virtuosity on Display", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Atkins added that he felt little emotional connection to the Commonwealth itself.\n\n\u201cIn an identity sense, I would like to become a republic \u2014 I don\u2019t see the need for us to be part of the Commonwealth, really, anymore,\u201d he said.\n\nPeter Beattie, a former premier of the state of Queensland, and the chairman of the Gold Coast Games, said that he empathized with those who had reservations about the event.\n\n\u201cI understand that there\u2019s always a bit of cynicism: is this the remnants of the Empire? Look, it came from the Empire Games, but its relevance and relationship with the Empire Games is very tenuous,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Beattie believed that Brexit and its fallout had given the Commonwealth, and its Games, a unique opening to capitalize upon.\n\n\u201cBrexit, actually, in a converse way, has made the Commonwealth more relevant, not less,\u201d he said. \u201cBritain\u2019s now looking at free trade agreements. Part of what\u2019s happening here is a meeting of all the trade ministers.\u201d\n\nOf course, it is difficult to ignore that the Games are, in a way, a sort of Olympics-lite: an athletic coming together of many nations, to be sure, but with the notable absence of medal-winning mainstays like China, the United States and Russia.\n\nBut organizers, including Mr. Beattie, were quick to paint the Games as more nimble and progressive than the Olympics, and several times implied that the latter could do with some evolution.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Olympics are just a hard, competitive sporting event \u2014 and that\u2019s terrific,\u201d he said. \u201cThe Commonwealth is more than that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
