Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis year\u2019s Games, for the first time, will feature an equal gender split of events. Women will compete for the same number of medals as men, a feat that organizers said had not been replicated by any other major multisport international event \u2014 including the Olympics.\n\nMr. Beattie said that the Games would send a message about the advancement of women that he hoped the Olympics would emulate.\n\nOthers said the Games presented athletes with a rare chance at higher competition like the Olympics and World Championships \u2014 and some athletes with perhaps the peak competition of their careers.\n\n\u201cI just snuck into the Commonwealth Games. It was the first major team that I made, representing Australia \u2014 they have more relaxed standards,\u201d said Steve Moneghetti, a retired Australian runner who eventually competed in four Olympic marathons. \u201cIt\u2019s a good steppingstone, and certainly for some athletes it will be the only multisport competition that they go to.\u201d\n\nIt is easy to see why for certain nations these Games may be just as watchable as the Olympics \u2014 there\u2019s a far greater chance of seeing a fellow countryman win.\n\n\u201cAustralians, we\u2019re quite competitive. We\u2019ve either topped or been second in the medal tally for most Games in history. The Australian public really embrace them,\u201d Mr. Moneghetti said. \u201cI know this sounds quite na\u00efve, but Australians kind of go, Commonwealth Games, Olympic Games, if you won a medal, that\u2019s great.\u201d", "title": "At the Commonwealth Games, Competing for Medals and Relevance", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Aguiar was first noticed by Mr. Cunningham in 1998, when Mr. Aguiar was working at Bergdorf Goodman, where he was then the associate creative director for visual merchandising. Mr. Cunningham saw Mr. Aguiar working around the outside of the store and started clicking away.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t think anything of it until I got a phone call one day from a friend who told me that my photo was in The New York Times,\u201d Mr. Aguiar said.\n\nMr. Cunningham photographed the couple for other features, at work, at parties and during nights out on the town. And, of course, at the Easter Parade.\n\n\u201cWith Bill photographing us consistently for a decade, Mark and I unwittingly became integral parts of the parade,\u201d Mr. Aguiar said. \u201cEvery year people now come to see what we are wearing.\u201d\n\nNeither Mr. Aguiar nor Mr. Haldeman can remember exactly what they wore upon their first meeting, in 1991 at a gay bar on the Upper West Side. But 28 years later, they can still feel the initial vibe.\n\n\u201cI walked in and the first person I noticed was James, who was standing there talking to some friends,\u201d Mr. Haldeman recalled. \u201cEveryone in there looked kind of preppy except for James. He was dressed differently, and he was tall and handsome with a dark complexion. He really stood out from the crowd.\u201d", "title": "At the Easter Parade, a Wedding Many Outfits in the Making", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Because of all the time and effort required to fill in the details, Greller said, he lives in dread of losing his Masters book. It would be like losing a computer file that was not saved on your hard drive. \u201cIt\u2019d be less stressful to lose my passport, absolutely,\u201d he said.\n\nThe value of the books was driven home recently when Jeff Ghim, who is caddying here for his 21-year-old son, Doug, lost the yardage book he had painstakingly padded with notes over three months of research.\n\nThe book fell from a pocket of his long-sleeved overalls on Monday. His heart dropped, he said.\n\n\u201cFifteen years my son\u2019s dreamed of playing here,\u201d Jeff Ghim said, \u201cand I lose the directions.\u201d How could he replicate three months\u2019 worth of notes in two days?\n\nThankfully, he got the book back. Someone turned it into the caddie headquarters the next day, and Ghim, with book in pocket, guided his son, a Masters rookie, to low-amateur honors.\n\nPhoto\n\nYardage books have been around since at least the 1950s, when the future P.G.A. commissioner Deane Beman, then a junior golfer, sketched crude models for his own use. In the 1970s, the books proliferated as professional players and caddies, in search of a legal edge, turned to the course field guides compiled by pioneers like Mark Long, who has followed the high-tech path. He supplies his greens books to caddies for $150 apiece.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCarl Jackson is widely considered a priceless alternative. Known as the greens whisperer of Augusta National, Jackson worked 54 Masters, including 39 as the bag man for the two-time champion Ben Crenshaw. When Greller was about to caddie in his first Masters, in 2014, he sought out Jackson to try to absorb some of his knowledge about Augusta\u2019s bedeviling breaks and slopes.\n\nEvery tournament week since, Greller has checked in several times with Jackson, who first caddied at the Masters as a 14-year-old in 1961. The two do not go over notes because Jackson stores all his knowledge on the pages of his mind.\n\nSince Crenshaw regards Spieth as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of sorts, Greller is never shy about using Jackson as a resource.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cCarl probably wants to throw his phone any time he gets a phone call from Michael, he\u2019s probably talked to him so many times,\u201d said Justin Thomas, Spieth\u2019s competitor and close friend.\n\nGreller said the best advice he had received from Jackson had nothing to with a fall line or a pin placement. It was simply: \u201cThere will be multiple times you\u2019ll be confused. Then you trust your instincts.\u201d\n\nTo remind himself, Greller writes a note on some pages amid all the technical jargon: \u201cTRUST YOUR INSTINCTS.\u201d\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t seen it,\u201d said Spieth, who, like most golfers, keeps books of his own.\n\nJohn Wood, a veteran caddie who works for Matt Kuchar, spent Monday morning walking the course by himself, stopping often to take notes. By the time he was through, the pages of his yardage book resembled geometry assignments. He described the outing as a chance to \u201crecheck stuff I\u2019ve seen over the years.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJack Nicklaus, who counts six Masters titles among his 18 major victories, wonders why any touring pro would not want to be the master of his own game.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTo me, the game of golf is learning how to play the game and be responsible for everything you do,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s the fun of it. It\u2019s fun to learn how to putt greens and how to play clubs.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cNow everything is given to the guys. That said, if it were all given to me back when I started in 1962 on the tour, I probably would have done exactly the same thing.\u201d\n\nLanier was playing on golf\u2019s minor league circuits when he started a side business making yardage books for his competitors. The side business outlasted his playing career. He uses every resource at his disposal, including Google Earth, to make his hand drawings as detailed as possible. Lanier can sketch Augusta National as if it were the back of his hand because it is practically his backyard. He grew up a couple of miles away and now lives close enough to walk to the course.\n\nHis drawings, while highly respected among golfers, are often lost on outsiders. Lanier recalled a visit he once paid to a Staples store in Florida to make copies of a book. A woman was using the copier next to him. Peering at his drawings, she asked, \u201cSir, excuse me, are you a medical illustrator?\u201d\n\nLanier told her that, no, the illustrations she had mistaken for amoebas were greens and bunkers.", "title": "At the Masters, Low-Tech Data Still Rules", "authors": ["Karen Crouse"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "He has recorded the most birdies at No. 12 \u2014 24 in 163 rounds \u2014 but there was the time in 1964 that Nicklaus shanked an eight-iron off the tee with his idol, Bobby Jones, watching from a nearby cart. If not for a double bogey at No. 12 on Saturday in 1981, when Nicklaus finished tied for second behind Tom Watson, he might have had a seventh green jacket. And Nicklaus seems to have forgotten the second round in 1991, when the wind knocked two of his balls into the creek.\n\n\u201cI committed the sin I\u2019ve always tried to avoid,\u201d Nicklaus said at the time.\n\nTo gauge the wind, golfers go through a variety of moves that include checking the flag on the nearby 11th green and throwing blades of grass in the air. Predicting the effect of wind on a shot is a little like trying to forecast the stock market; every one seems to have a method. The bridge that contestants cross to reach the 12th green is named for Ben Hogan, the 1951 and 1953 champion, who said, \u201cNever hit on 12 until you feel the wind on your cheek.\u201d\n\n[READ MORE: Matt Parziale Is an Amateur at the Masters, but a Pro Fighting Fires]\n\nAdam Scott, the 2013 champion, prefers to wait until the flags on the 11th and 12th greens whip in the same direction. Mickelson ignores the flag at No. 11, and prefers to examine the trees along the 13th fairway. His long-held theory is to pick a club for a certain wind and then wait for it to blow. How does the 2017 champion, Sergio Garcia, choose his club? \u201cYou grab a coin and you flip it,\u201d he said with a smile.", "title": "At the Masters\u2019 12th Hole, Shots Are Left Twisting in the Wind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA stranger at home / Looking over my shoulder / Every two steps back / Only one step forward / Treading water waiting for the tide to rise,\u201d she sings.\n\nMs. McKeown, a singer-songwriter making her musical theater debut, first wrote those words with Ms. Hudes in 2013. Last June, Thomas D. Homan, the acting director of the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency, known as ICE, testified before Congress about how the administration was broadening its priorities beyond deporting criminals. He warned anyone living in the country illegally that they were deportable: \u201cYou should look over your shoulder,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cAs proud as I am of the song, I wish I was not so prescient as to how the phrase would get wielded in 2018,\u201d Ms. McKeown said.\n\nThe idea for the musical began in 2011, when Ms. Hudes contacted Ms. McKeown through her website, suggesting they collaborate on turning her play \u201c26 Miles,\u201d about a mother-daughter road trip, into a musical. Three days later, Ms. McKeown left on a planned trip to Nogales, Ariz., with other artist-activists to observe immigrants being detained at the border.\n\nIt took until later in 2013 for the pair to start writing. In the interim, Ms. Hudes (who wrote the book for the Tony Award-winning \u201cIn the Heights\u201d) won a Pulitzer in 2012 for her play \u201cWater by the Spoonful.\u201d Then she had a baby. Ms. McKeown released another album.\n\nOn Nov. 6, 2016, \u201cMiss You Like Hell,\u201d which was commissioned by the La Jolla Playhouse in California, opened. By the time the curtain fell on the second performance, on Nov. 8, Donald J. Trump had been elected president.\n\nIn 2017, in the context of daily immigration news, the women began rewriting to streamline the production into one act.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe bureaucratic immigration details are spot-on, as Ms. Hudes consulted an immigration lawyer based in New York. In an instance familiar to undocumented immigrants for decades, Beatriz was pulled over for a broken taillight, a violation. Because she was using someone else\u2019s license, the stop turned into a criminal arrest, with potential immigration consequences.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHalf my junior class has fake IDs, no one cuffs them,\u201d Olivia says, both indignantly and ignorantly. Olivia is a sheltered 16-year-old from Philadelphia struggling with anxiety and with resentment from having been abandoned by her mother. Her awakening gives the production its power.\n\nMs. Hudes said she established 2014 as the setting because in January 2015, California enacted a law enabling undocumented immigrants to get driver\u2019s licenses. But while the script includes the time reference, the program purposely leaves it out, so as not to confuse the audience experiencing the piece in the present, Ms. Hudes said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, Alexis Ramirez, 19, a student at New York University who is Mexican-American from California, was quizzical after seeing a preview last week. She said that Olivia\u2019s ignorance of immigration enforcement was the only thing that didn\u2019t make sense, since Olivia has an active online presence with a blog. \u201cHow did she not know what ICE was?\u201d Ms. Ramirez said.\n\n\u201cPeople are much more hip to the issues surrounding an undocumented life on a daily basis,\u201d Ms. Hudes acknowledged.\n\nAll three female creators of \u201cMiss You Like Hell\u201d have activist backgrounds. Ms. deBessonet founded Public Works for the Public, which incorporates community groups and actors in large-scale productions that try to cross social and cultural borders.\n\nMs. Hudes grew up in Philadelphia, accompanying her mother on midnight runs to the women\u2019s health center she founded, which often helped undocumented women fearful of deportation. Ms. Hudes\u2019s husband is a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society of New York, who participated in a recent walkout of lawyers at the Bronx Criminal Courthouse protesting ICE agents making immigration arrests there.\n\nIn her spare time, Ms. Hudes is also a writing mentor for the Migrant Leaders Club, in Mount Vernon, Wash., where children of Mexican agricultural workers share their fears in words. The club will be traveling to New York for the show on Friday, participating in a talkback and also visiting two schools in the Bronx to discuss their experiences.\n\n\u201cThe notion of trying to write individuals and communities out of the shadows feels particularly important at this moment,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf course, plays by and about immigrants have long been fertile sources for the stage, including two recent productions in New York.\n\nA revival of the 2007 play \u201cDe Novo\u201d \u2014 about a former member of the transnational gang MS-13, which has roots in Los Angeles and El Salvador, challenging his deportation \u2014 ran in December as part of New York Theater Workshop\u2019s Next Door series.\n\nAnother play, \u201cqueens,\u201d about immigrant women sharing basement living quarters in that borough, recently finished its run at Lincoln Center Theater and will open at the La Jolla Playhouse in July.\n\nIn \u201cqueens,\u201d written by Martyna Majok, Mr. Trump is not named. But a character in Ukraine does refer to him, in broken English, when advising another woman who wants to come to the United States: \u201cThings it\u2019s changing over there in America, past few months. With this orange guy. Things it\u2019s not really so great anymore over there.\u201d", "title": "At the Public Theater, a Mother, a Daughter and Deportation", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is a very dangerous day today for lawyer-client relations,\u201d Mr. Dershowitz said Monday night on Fox in an interview with Sean Hannity, one of Mr. Trump\u2019s favorite hosts. \u201cShoe on the other foot. If this were Hillary Clinton being investigated and they went into her lawyer\u2019s office, the A.C.L.U. would be on every television station in America, jumping up and down.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump took up the theme on Twitter on Tuesday morning, posting that \u201cattorney\u2013client privilege is dead!\u201d\n\nMr. Dershowitz, who has argued that Mr. Trump should not agree to be interviewed by Mr. Mueller, said Mr. Cohen\u2019s treatment had vindicated that point of view. \u201cThis sends a powerful message that cooperation is not going to be rewarded by Mueller,\u201d Mr. Dershowitz said on Fox. \u201cThe result may very well be far less cooperation\u201d with the special counsel.\n\nElsewhere in the White House, as the president considered options on Syria and absorbed cable news chyrons about Mr. Cohen, staff members at the National Security Council were rattled by the ouster of the homeland security adviser, Thomas P. Bossert. Two White House officials said the move came at the urging of the new national security adviser, John R. Bolton, whom one of the officials described as serving as the president\u2019s shiny new object.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s mood had begun to sour even before the raids on his lawyer. People close to the White House said that over the weekend, the president engaged in few activities other than dinner at the Trump International Hotel. He tuned into Fox News, they said, watched reports about the so-called deep state looking to sink his presidency and became unglued.\n\nMr. Trump angrily told his advisers that people were trying to undermine him and that he wanted to get rid of three top Justice Department officials \u2014 Jeff Sessions, the attorney general; Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general who appointed Mr. Mueller; and Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director \u2014 according to two people familiar with what took place.\n\nHe eventually calmed down and the anger abated. But it was stoked anew on Monday, after the F.B.I. raids on Mr. Cohen. Mr. Rosenstein in particular was a source of Mr. Trump\u2019s anger on Monday, and some aides believed the president was seriously considering firing him, to a degree he has not in the past.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s foul mood continued into Tuesday as he watched more coverage of Mr. Cohen\u2019s problems. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe president indicated to some advisers that he had been proved right that Mr. Mueller was out to get him, after nearly a year of hearing from some of his lawyers that he should cooperate with the investigation and turn over everything that the special counsel requested. His participation in an interview with Mr. Mueller, which the special counsel has sought, seemed less likely, three people close to the president said.\n\nMr. Trump has long felt as if he has been unfairly hit by the Mueller investigation, and he has wanted to hit back. But there were few people on cable TV defending the president on Tuesday.\n\nWhite House advisers were particularly alarmed by the president\u2019s tirade in front of reporters on Monday, when he called the raids on Mr. Cohen \u201can attack on our country\u201d in far angrier terms than he has ever referred to the Russian assault on the 2016 election.\n\nFew people still at the White House are able to restrain Mr. Trump from acting on his impulses after the departures of crucial staff members who were once able to join forces with other aides to do so. That included Hope Hicks, his former communications director; Rob Porter, his former staff secretary; and, in 2017, the chief of staff Reince Priebus and the chief strategist Stephen K. Bannon.\n\nJohn F. Kelly, the current chief of staff whose influence over the president has waned for months, appeared beaten down and less hands-on, according to two White House officials. Mr. Kelly has told Mr. Trump it is frustrating for staff members that the president deems most news media stories fake news but believes the ones accusing various advisers of leaking, according to people familiar with the discussions.\n\nIt is not clear whether Mr. Trump can fire Mr. Mueller himself. Many legal experts believe the president would have to direct Mr. Rosenstein to do so because Mr. Sessions has recused himself from the case and Mr. Rosenstein technically oversees Mr. Mueller.\n\nMr. Rosenstein has told Congress that he would dismiss Mr. Mueller only for cause, and people close to Mr. Rosenstein have indicated he would resign if the president ordered him to fire Mr. Mueller. Bipartisan legislation has been introduced to protect Mr. Mueller, with senators urging the president to let it go forward \u201cwithout impediment.\u201d\n\nRepublican leadership has dismissed such legislation as unnecessary. But the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, warned Mr. Trump on Tuesday to not fire Mr. Mueller, saying in an interview on Fox Business Network it would be \u201csuicide\u201d to continue to talk about firing him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Tuesday on the South Lawn, Mr. Trump appeared to leave such concerns behind during the event with the Crimson Tide, winners of the N.C.A.A. championship. Mr. Sessions, a former Alabama senator, was on hand to salute his home-state players, but the president did not acknowledge him.\n\nInstead, he praised the team\u2019s pugnacious spirit, saying that they \u201cfought back as they did all season long.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey kept fighting and fighting,\u201d the president said.", "title": "At the White House, Trump Takes Selfies and Seethes Over Mueller", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 An attack on Monday in eastern Afghanistan killed one American service member and wounded another in the second United States military combat death this year in the enduring war.\n\nThe American-led international mission in Kabul announced the casualties but did not identify the troops, pending notification of their next of kin. Several Afghan soldiers were also killed in what the American military deemed a \u201ccombat operation.\u201d\n\nRoughly 14,000 American troops are spread across Afghanistan in a war that is now in its 17th year. The forces are split between training the Afghan military to fight the Taliban and hunting terrorist organizations, such as the Islamic State\u2019s affiliate in the country, which is known as the Khorasan group.\n\nIn eastern Afghanistan, the American military has been fighting the Khorasan group since 2015 \u2014 shortly after the extremists began seizing large pieces of territory from the Afghan government and the Taliban.", "title": "Attack Kills American Service Member in Eastern Afghanistan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "On Thursday, the international body that monitors compliance with chemical weapons treaties confirmed Britain\u2019s assessment that the toxin used in Salisbury, England, against the Skripals was a powerful, military-grade agent known as novichok, which experts say was developed in the Soviet Union.\n\nThe group, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, released a report saying that its laboratory analysis of \u201cenvironmental and biomedical samples\u201d that its experts had collected \u201cconfirm the findings of the U.K. relating to the identity of the toxic chemical.\u201d\n\nThe team \u201cnotes that the toxic chemical was of high purity,\u201d it added, lending support to Britain\u2019s claim that the nerve agent was manufactured with a degree of expertise and sophistication strongly indicating that a national government was responsible. But the agency did not try to say where the chemical was made, or by whom.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRussia, which had demanded that the organization take over the investigation from Britain, was quick to dismiss the findings. Maria Zakharova, the spokesman for the Russian Foreign Ministry, told reporters that the report was part of a continuing British plot against Russia.\n\n\u201cWe are all simply drowning in a torrent of misinformation that is in one way or another supported by official London,\u201d she said. \u201cThere are no grounds to believe that all of this is not the continuation of a crude provocation against the Russian Federation on the part of the British special services.\u201d\n\nBoris Johnson, the British foreign secretary, released a statement on the organization\u2019s report, saying, \u201cThere can be no doubt what was used and there remains no alternative explanation about who was responsible \u2014 only Russia has the means, motive and record.\u201d\n\nMr. Skripal, 66, is a former Russian military intelligence officer who has lived for several years in Salisbury; his daughter, 33, lives in Russia and was visiting him at the time of the poisoning.\n\n\u201cThe attack on Sergei and Yulia Skripal in Salisbury was the first time a nerve agent had been deployed in Europe since the Second World War,\u201d Mr. Fleming said.\n\nOn Wednesday night, the Metropolitan Police released a statement attributed to Ms. Skripal, turning down a Russian offer of consular assistance, adding another irritant to worsening relations with Moscow. Russia has repeatedly requested access to Ms. Skripal, accusing Britain of improperly denying it contact with one of its citizens.\n\n\u201cI have been made aware of my specific contacts at the Russian Embassy, who have kindly offered me their assistance in any way they can,\u201d Ms. Skripal was quoted as saying in the statement. \u201cAt the moment, I do not wish to avail myself of their services, but if I change my mind, I know how to contact them.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRussian officials have ridiculed British accusations, while floating an array of theories, some of them contradictory, about what happened in Salisbury. They claim that neither the Soviet Union nor Russia ever had a novichok program, that other former Soviet bloc countries could have supplied the novichok, that the toxin involved was not novichok, and that the British might have poisoned the Skripals.\n\nThe statement attributed to Ms. Skripal, 33, met with derision from the Russian authorities, who described it as \u201can interesting read,\u201d pointedly noting that there was no way to verify it, and suggesting that the remarks contained more questions than answers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe would like to make sure that the statement really belongs to Yulia,\u201d the Russian Embassy in Britain said in a statement on Wednesday. \u201cSo far, we doubt it much. The text has been composed in a special way so as to support official statements made by British authorities, and at the same time to exclude every possibility of Yulia\u2019s contacts with the outer world \u2014 consuls, journalists and even relatives.\u201d\n\nMs. Skripal was released from a hospital in Salisbury this week after more than a month of treatment for the poisoning, but said she was still enduring the effects of the attack. She noted that her father, who lives in Salisbury, while no longer in critical condition, remained in a perilous state.\n\n\u201cI have left my father in their care, and he is still seriously ill. I, too, am still suffering with the effects of the nerve agent used against us,\u201d her statement said. \u201cI find myself in a totally different life than the ordinary one I left just over a month ago, and I am seeking to come to terms with my prospects, whilst also recovering from this attack on me.\u201d\n\nA police officer who was exposed to the chemical early in the investigation, Detective Sgt. Nick Bailey, was treated at the hospital and released last month.\n\nThe poisoning has seriously worsened ties between Britain and Moscow, setting off a chain events that led to the expulsions of hundreds of diplomats around the world, including from Britain, Russia and the United States.\n\nThe British police said last week that Ms. Skripal had been made aware of Russian offers of assistance and had turned them down, prompting Russian officials to insist on getting proof that she was acting of her own free will.\n\nThe statement released on Wednesday \u201conly strengthens suspicions that we are dealing with a forcible isolation of the Russian citizen,\u201d the Russian Embassy said. \u201cIf British authorities are interested in assuring the public that this is not the case, they must urgently provide tangible evidence that Yulia is all right and not deprived of her freedom.\u201d\n\nThe case, filled with high-level intrigue and unexpected twists and turns, was marked by another unexpected development last week when Viktoria Skripal, a 45-year-old Russian accountant and a relative of the two poisoned Russians, said the British authorities were untrustworthy and cast doubt on their accounts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an interview, Viktoria Skripal said she was \u201cscared\u201d for her relatives. Her comments came after she recorded what she said was a phone call with Yulia Skripal, a copy of which she gave to Russian state television, which broadcast it.\n\nYulia Skripal\u2019s statement distanced her from her cousin, emphasizing that \u201cno one speaks for me, or for my father, but ourselves.\u201d\n\n\u201cI thank my cousin Viktoria for her concern for us,\u201d she added, \u201cbut ask that she does not visit me or try to contact me for the time being. Her opinions and assertions are not mine and they are not my father\u2019s.\u201d", "title": "Attack on Skripals Shows Russia Is \u2018Reckless,\u2019 U.K. Says", "authors": ["Stephen Castle", "Michael Wolgelenter", "Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a", "Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan \u2014 Four attacks across Afghanistan on Saturday night and Sunday killed at least 26 government security officers, while two schools were also set ablaze, according to Afghan officials.\n\nThe four attacks struck government outposts in northern and eastern Afghanistan; at least three appeared coordinated. They occurred late at night or early in the morning, with the attackers using long-range sniper rifles and night-vision equipment, according to Afghan officials, who tallied at least 10 wounded in all, along with those killed.\n\nIn separate assaults, a girls\u2019 high school in Logar Province, near the capital, Kabul, was burned on April 11, and masked attackers struck a school in the village of Momandara, in Nangarhar Province, on Saturday night, setting archives and labs ablaze, according to education officials.\n\nNo one was reported hurt in those two attacks.\n\nThere was no immediate claim of responsibility, but government officials blamed Taliban insurgents for the attacks on the government outposts. In recent years, mainstream Taliban forces have normally refrained from attacking schools.\n\nIn the Sancharak District, in the northern Sar-i-Pul Province, which has teetered between government and Taliban control over the past year, the governor, Naqibullah Daqiq, said that two government checkpoints in the west had been attacked by Taliban fighters using night-vision equipment and sniper rifles, with one guard killed at first.\n\nWhen local pro-government militiamen tried to counter the assault, they fell into a Taliban ambush, and 10 others were killed, Mr. Daqiq said.\n\nNematullah Tofan, the police chief of the district of Dawlat Abad, in another northern province, Faryab, said that two government checkpoints in the village of Khairabad had fallen to Taliban fighters after their snipers killed four government defenders, shooting each of them in the head.\n\nAttacks by insurgents using sophisticated night-vision technology have risen in the past year, especially against police and militia units that do not have such equipment. Afghan officials have asked for the gear to be issued to their police officers, but American officials have been reluctant to do so for fear that it would fall into Taliban hands.\n\nThe third attack was in Ghazni Province, in southeastern Afghanistan, where two Afghan Local Police checkpoints in the district of Jaghatu were attacked at 2 a.m. Sunday, killing eight officers and wounding four others, according to Hamidullah Nawruz, a member of the Ghazni provincial council.\n\nAfghan Local Police officers are militiamen defending their own communities; they are generally less trained and not as well equipped as the national police.\n\nA fourth attack took place on Sunday afternoon, when three guards outside Nangarhar University in the eastern city of Jalalabad took a break for worship. Gunmen on a motorcycle opened fire on them while they were praying, killing two immediately, according to a news release from the provincial governor\u2019s office. The third guard fled but was chased by the gunmen and killed as well, according to a witness who insisted on anonymity for fear of reprisals.\n\nThe girls\u2019 high school in Logar Province, in a village in Mohammad Agha District, was attacked on April 11 by gunmen who beat up the night watchmen and locked them in a room, then set the school afire, according to Kabir Haqmal, a spokesman for the Ministry of Education. It was unclear why the attack had not been previously disclosed.\n\nThe school has 981 female students and 21 teachers, Mr. Haqmal said. It is in the home district of President Ashraf Ghani, 35 miles from Kabul.\n\nIn Nangarhar Province, the attack in Momandara was the third time a school in that district had been targeted in the past month, according to Mohammad Asif Shinwari, a spokesman for the provincial education ministry.\n\nAttacks on schools by Taliban insurgents were common 10 years ago but proved so unpopular with communities that the insurgents announced that they would not be continued, even claiming to support girls\u2019 education, although few such schools operate in areas dominated by the militants.", "title": "Attacks in Afghanistan Leave Dozens Dead and 2 Schools Burned", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe headlines in the auction world tend to involve Christie\u2019s, Sotheby\u2019s and Phillips, 18th-century businesses with English roots that routinely provide record prices, historic consignments and single-owner sales with famous names attached.\n\nBut as Kathleen M. You just have to know where to look. Here are just a few standouts and some of the areas they specialize in. Facebook has since estimated that as many as 87 million users were affected.\n\nLike its competitors, PwC closely protects the inner workings of its review process. The public versions of the reports it submits to the F.T.C. redact both the names of the employees who performed the work and the tests the firm used to assess Facebook\u2019s privacy measures. It is not clear whether Facebook informed its auditors of the leak, or whether PwC knew about it.\n\nIn a statement, Facebook\u2019s deputy chief privacy officer, Rob Sherman, said the company remained \u201cstrongly committed to protecting people\u2019s information\u201d and appreciated \u201cthe opportunity to answer questions the F.T.C. may have.\u201d\n\nA spokeswoman for PwC declined to comment.\n\nThe firm\u2019s vetting of Facebook\u2019s privacy practices revives questions about how diligently federal officials were overseeing Facebook. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cClearly, the F.T.C. needs to be more forthcoming with the contents of those reports,\u201d said Marc Rotenberg, president of the Electronic Privacy Information Center, which advocates more stringent privacy protections. \u201cThere is still too much that is not known about Facebook\u2019s business practices during that critical time period.\u201d\n\nThe 2011 decree \u2014 triggered in part by a complaint EPIC and other consumer groups filed \u2014 followed a two-year investigation that found Facebook had routinely ignored its users\u2019 privacy preferences and shared their data without their permission. Besides demanding that Facebook give users more control over their data, the decree required the company to assess potential privacy risks. Facebook has acknowledged that it did not sufficiently police how third parties with access to its data, like Mr. Kogan, used the information.\n\nF.T.C. officials hailed the consent decree as a new and powerful model for regulating tech giants like Facebook and Google, which in recent years have built immensely lucrative advertising businesses rooted in the vast quantities of data they collect from people who use their free services.\n\nBut critics of the agreement said it reflected the essential weakness of relying on an outside firm to evaluate Facebook\u2019s compliance with the order. The F.T.C. is a relatively small agency, where even major investigations are handled by teams of just a few people. Instead of retaining a large staff of technology and data experts to monitor businesses, the agency makes companies hire outside accounting and consulting firms. These are paid by companies like Facebook and periodically report back to the F.T.C.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to the assessment documents, Facebook chooses which policies and procedures PwC reviews.\n\n\u201cA conversation has to be had about how the F.T.C. handles these assessments,\u201d said Joseph Jerome, policy counsel at the Center for Democracy and Technology, which is funded in part by Facebook and other tech companies. \u201cFacebook decides how they are being assessed. She said the agency was \u201calready taking steps to correct hazardous conditions within 90 days.\u201d\n\nThe auditors found a pervasive lack of knowledge within the Housing Authority leadership about the state of the playgrounds. When they first asked Nycha officials to submit a list of all the playgrounds the agency managed, for example, Nycha submitted a list of only seven playgrounds, the report said. In fact, auditors, through site inspections, found the agency manages 788 playgrounds.\n\nAmong the most hazardous conditions were a broken crossing bridge and chain ladder at the South Jamaica Houses in Queens; a missing bridge at the Davidson Houses and broken metal slides with sharp edges at the Jackson Houses, both in the Bronx; and a broken spiral climber with sharp edges at the Jacob Riis Houses in Manhattan.\n\nVisibly hazardous conditions that were judged to pose an imminent danger to children were found in 72 of the 549 playgrounds with problems. In more than 350 playgrounds, safety surfaces were damaged, and in 149 playgrounds, benches were broken. But in 30 percent of the playgrounds, the conditions were good, suggesting that a great deal depends on the management of each housing project.\n\nNycha is the largest public housing authority in North America. More than 400,000 New Yorkers live in its developments, including 100,000 children. Policies at the club have been amended at a glacial pace; the first female members were not admitted until 2012.\n\nBut on Wednesday, Fred Ridley, in his first major appearance as the new chairman of Augusta National, unexpectedly announced that the club would create and help host the Augusta National Women\u2019s Amateur Championship next year. The 54-hole tournament will be played the week before the 2019 Masters, with the first two rounds at a local club near Augusta and the final round at Augusta National on April 6, a Saturday.\n\nThe objective is to grow the game of golf and to benefit women\u2019s golf at all levels.\n\nThe event may accomplish both goals quickly since it will most likely be the most watched women\u2019s golf tournament of 2019.", "title": "Augusta National Takes an Unexpected Turn Toward Women\u2019s Golf", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "But environmentalists said the plan from Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull\u2019s government was nowhere near enough. The reef\u2019s health and prospects are increasingly grim. Huge sections stretching hundreds of miles across have died over the past two years, killed by overheated and more acidic seawater caused by climate change.\n\nThis month, scientists declared that much of the damage was irreversible, and said the only solution was a global one: Reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the use of fossil fuels, and get climate change under control.\n\n\u201cScience is well aware of what is killing coral on the Great Barrier Reef \u2014 it\u2019s the excess heat that comes from burning fossil fuels,\u201d said Bill McKibben, an American environmentalist, author and founder of 350.org, which aims to rapidly end the use of fossil fuels. \u201cIf the Turnbull government was serious about saving the reef, they would be willing to take on the industry responsible for the damage.\u201d\n\nCritics seized on Australia\u2019s continued subsidized development of gas and coal, especially its openness to the Adani coal mine in northern Australia that would be among the world\u2019s largest, pushing coal on boats running near the reef. And Australia\u2019s prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, said Vanuatu had assured his government that no such request had been made.\n\n\u201cWe would view with great concern the establishment of any foreign military bases in those Pacific Island countries and neighbors of ours,\u201d Mr. Turnbull said on Tuesday.\n\nMassive infrastructure projects and investment activity around the world form the backbone of China\u2019s ambitious economic and geopolitical agenda, but to date China has built only one full-fledged overseas military base, in the Indian Ocean port of Djibouti on the Horn of Africa. Since a match in Perth at the end of 2013, which Smith has identified as the turning point in his career, he averages 70.71 in Test matches, scoring a century every four innings.\n\nHe has done all this with an everyman appeal endearing to Australians. He is \u201cone of the more genuinely decent people to skipper the Australian team in recent decades,\u201d the longtime cricket journalist Peter Lalor wrote in The Australian. He is so driven and obsessed with the sport that his fianc\u00e9e has said that Smith sometimes makes her throw balls into the bowling machine, to give him extra batting practice.\n\nSo the revelations about the match in South Africa have left Australia aghast.\n\nIt has been confirmed that Smith did not intervene despite full knowledge that the team\u2019s vice captain, David Warner, was instructing Cameron Bancroft, the most junior player, to rub sandpaper on the ball, altering its aerodynamics.\n\nWarner also received a yearlong suspension, and Bancroft was barred for nine months.\n\n\u201cTo see the way my old man has been, and my mum, it hurts,\u201d Smith said. \u201cI just want to say I\u2019m sorry for the pain I have brought to Australia and the fans and the public. But a newly published report, written by the same conservative government, reveals the opposite \u2014 immigration is a critical engine of the country\u2019s growth.\n\nThe report, first published on Tuesday by Fairfax Media after journalists submitted multiple Freedom of Information requests, concluded that reducing immigration would cost the national budget billions of dollars and reduce job growth.\n\nOne of every two Australians is an immigrant, or the child of an immigrant. About a quarter of Australia\u2019s population is foreign born, roughly twice the rate of the United States.\n\nBut immigration is a hotly contested issue, especially as Australia\u2019s cities have been growing rapidly without the infrastructure to match, and the far-right contingent of the Liberal Party has been pushing to reduce immigration levels by tens of thousands of immigrants per year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s a cause championed by former Prime Minister Tony Abbott and Peter Dutton, the immigration minister, who has said he hopes to become prime minister. And while Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has generally resisted, his poll numbers are weak and his government is now being accused of pandering to the anti-immigration mood of his party\u2019s fringes in a populist appeal to his conservative base.", "title": "Australian Government Acknowledges Immigrants Are Boon to Economy", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOften, Australians don\u2019t realize it,\u201d she said of the ubiquity of the machines. \u201cIt\u2019s like being a fish in water.\u201d\n\nTheir operators are often prominent community entities: Woolworths, one of Australia\u2019s largest supermarket chains, is the biggest operator of pokies in the country, controlling about 12,000 machines through its majority stake in the Australian Leisure and Hospitality Group, a large company that encompasses bars, restaurants and wagering.\n\nThough the Woolworths Group doesn\u2019t distinguish liquor sales from gambling revenues in its annual report, estimates suggest that it pulls more than 1 billion Australian dollars, or $770 million, in revenue from the machines each year.\n\nOther community mainstays also operate machines. In Victoria, the heartland of Australian Rules Football, 90 percent of Australian Football League teams operate their own pokies, generating more than 93 million Australian dollars in revenue last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Australia, delivered to your inbox. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPokies are regulated on a state-by-state basis, instead of by the federal government. Western Australia is the only state or territory that bans the operation of pokies outside casinos.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nState budgets are increasingly made up of revenues from the machines, and legalized gambling, including from pokies, accounted for 7.7 percent of total tax revenues for Australian states and territories in 2016. In some parts of Australia, gamers can deposit 7,500 Australian dollars into a machine in one transaction, and can lose more than a thousand dollars per hour.\n\nA study conducted by Dr. Rintoul comparing two regions outside Melbourne found that the less wealthy one had twice as many pokie machines, and more than three times the per capita losses.\n\n\u201cThe people who can least afford to be losing large sums of money are losing the most,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Rintoul described the casino-like methods used by venues to maximize revenue, including rewarding patrons with free food and drinks, and hiring part-time models as wait staff.\n\nOne gaming floor at a venue in Sunshine, the region Dr. Rintoul\u2019s study focused on, enjoyed a busy gaming floor one recent Wednesday night. Gamblers placed \u201cRESERVED\u201d signs under their machines of choice, which Dr. Rintoul said reflected how frequent gamblers come to relate to the machines: picking favorites, and believing that a particular one can get \u201chot\u201d or due for a win.\n\nA few hours later, in Balaclava, a suburb on the opposite side of Melbourne, patrons filled the gaming room at an Australian Leisure and Hospitality Group venue open until 6 a.m. A large Woolworths supermarket across the road keeps foot traffic in the area high.\n\n\u201cWe regularly had people tell us that they often ended up in a gambling venue even when they weren\u2019t intending to gamble when they left the house,\u201d Dr. Rintoul said.\n\nIn February, Andrew Wilkie, an independent Australian politician, published leaked documents from two whistle-blowers at Australian Leisure and Hospitality showing that the company had been secretly collecting data on frequent gamblers, including their favorite sporting teams, their relationship statuses and when they had the most money to spend.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGordon Cairns, the chairman of Woolworths, said that the company was \u201cvery concerned\u201d about the findings and that the matter was being reviewed by external auditors.\n\nIn a country that has confronted other powerful industries by mandating graphic warnings on cigarette packages and cracking down on guns, some wonder why gambling has escaped tougher regulation. Critics say politicians are increasingly afraid to confront the growing influence of the gambling lobby.\n\nThe Rev. Tim Costello, a spokesman for the Alliance for Gambling Reform, compares pro-gambling bodies to the National Rifle Association in the United States in their ability to sway politicians.\n\nPhoto\n\nAustralians, he said, \u201csay Americans have a blind spot on guns.\u201d\n\n\u201cHere, we have a blind spot on pokies,\u201d he added.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPro-gambling groups frequently refer to Mr. Costello and other gambling opponents as \u201cprohibitionists,\u201d and are quick to point to support services they have developed for frequent gamers. They also argue that tighter regulation of pokies would lead to huge job losses at the venues that operate them.\n\nThe groups have increasingly flexed their muscles in state elections. Anti-gambling candidates who ran in Tasmania and South Australia this year faced a barrage of negative advertising from pro-gambling bodies.\n\nIn the run-up to the South Australian election, the Australian Hotels Association \u2014 which counts Australian Leisure and Hospitality as a member \u2014 donated to several opponents of Nick Xenophon, an independent whose new party, S.A.-BEST, vowed to cut in half the number of pokies per venue, and institute smaller betting limits. After positive early campaign polling, Mr. Xenophon and his party ultimately failed to win a single lower-house seat. It was the first election loss of Mr. Xenophon\u2019s 20-year career.\n\n\u201cHow much influence they wield, it\u2019s unhealthy,\u201d said Frank Pangello, Mr. Xenophon\u2019s media adviser in the recent election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey bought an election in Tasmania, they bought one in South Australia,\u201d Mr. Pangello added. \u201cThey\u2019re like the N.R.A. in America: You take them on, they\u2019ll crush you.\u201d\n\nThe Australian Leisure and Hospitality Group declined to comment for this article or discuss whether it spent money on the Tasmanian and South Australian state elections.\n\nMr. Costello said that with governments so dependent on gambling revenues, it may be difficult to pass tighter regulation of pokies.\n\n\u201cThe states are Dracula in charge of the blood bank,\u201d he said.", "title": "Australians Are the World\u2019s Biggest Gambling Losers, and Some Seek Action", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Maralinga, which means \u201cthunder\u201d in the extinct Aboriginal language Garik, is an unlikely tourist destination. It is hot and arid, and at 700 miles west of Adelaide it is difficult to reach. When tours started in 2016, the village was accessible by only two flights a week from Ceduna, the closest \u201clarge\u201d city, which itself has a population of fewer than 3,000 people.\n\n[Sign up to the Australia Letter to get news, insights and recommendations in your inbox each week.]\n\nBut the Maralinga Tjarutja people hope to increase the number of visitors to the site this year. The Maralinga Tjarutja Administration, which operates the site, is increasing the number of regular flights to the village, increasing the length of the tour to three days and working with the South Australian government on a business plan to lure more visitors, said Sharon Yendall, the group\u2019s general manager.\n\nDon Richards, who served at Maralinga as a clerk in the Australian Air Force from 1963 to 1965, was one of the 1,000 tourists who have so far visited the site.\n\n\u201cI learned more in that tour than I really learned in the two years I was out there,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was a pretty interesting place to be \u2014 a fairly motley crew lived at Maralinga once.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nToday just four people live full time in Maralinga village, a veritable ghost town. Amid the old buildings are new lodgings built for tourists, complete with hot water and Wi-Fi.\n\nIn the 1950s and \u201960s, at the height of the Cold War, 35,000 military personnel lived here. There was a permanent airstrip, then the longest in the Southern Hemisphere, plus roads, a swimming pool, accommodation and railway access.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first nuclear test was conducted in September 1956, two months before the Melbourne Olympics. That blast \u2014 as powerful as the bomb that the United States dropped on Hiroshima, Japan \u2014 was the first of seven atomic bombs set off here.\n\nCoral Sea NORTHERN TERRITORY QUEENSLAND AUSTRALIA SOUTH australia Maralinga NEW SOUTH WALES Ceduna Sydney Adelaide VICTORIA Tasman Sea 500 miles\n\nBut it was the so-called minor tests that were the most harrowing. Carried out in secret, the tests examined how toxic substances, including uranium and plutonium 239, would react when burned or blown up. To ensure tourists\u2019 safety in the area, a zone was cleaned up by radiation scientists at the cost of more than 100 million Australian dollars, about $77 million.\n\nAround one area tourists can visit are 22 major pits, each at least 50 feet deep and cased in reinforced concrete to prevent dangerous radiation from seeping out.\n\nThe site looks like a recently tilled garden bed, stretching out for hundreds of yards, in a near perfect circle. Dotting the red desert earth are shards of twisted metal. Aside from a few feral camels loping nearby, it is still and silent.\n\nBut on Oct. 4 1956, a \u201cnuclear land mine\u201d was detonated here, tearing a crater 140 feet wide and 70 feet deep into the earth.\n\nThe resulting atomic reaction took only a fraction of a second, but its effects on one Indigenous family would last decades.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn early 1957, Edie Millpuddie and her family were traversing the Great Victoria Desert plains. \u201cThe Millpuddies needed shelter for the night, and they came across this enormous hole where the ground was still warm,\u201d Mr. Mathews said. \u201cThey drank rainwater from the bottom and lit a fire. All the rabbits in the area seemed disoriented; they were easy pickings for dinner before the family went to sleep in the crater.\u201d\n\nTwo weeks later, Ms. Millpuddie delivered a stillborn baby.\n\nLater, her surviving children\u2019s children would all be born with \u201cphysical and mental deformities,\u201d Mr. Matthews said. \u201cThis all happened right where we\u2019re standing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSurvivors of the blasts, their children and grandchildren suffered from cataracts, blood diseases, arthritic conditions, stomach cancers and birth defects. In the 1980s, a Royal Commission investigating the tests awarded Ms. Millpuddie 75,000 Australian dollars.\n\nThere was no overt pressure or media scrutiny over what happened at Maralinga until the 1970s, when those injured by the tests came forward and a small group of journalists and politicians cast a more critical eye on the tests and the secrecy surrounding them.", "title": "Australia\u2019s Least Likely Tourist Spot: A Test Site for Atom Bombs", "authors": ["Ben Stubbs"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia has accomplished a dubious feat: for the 30th straight time, an opinion poll placed his governing Liberal Party behind the opposition, intensifying pressure on the embattled leader as he confronts a tide of stubborn scandals.\n\nThe Newspoll, one of the country\u2019s most respected political polls, was the same survey that Mr. Turnbull used to justify forcing his predecessor, Tony Abbott, from office in 2015.\n\nMr. Turnbull\u2019s poor showing in the latest poll, released Sunday, marks what experts describe as a rare moment in the country\u2019s political history: The government hasn\u2019t won a single Newspoll since the day of its election two and a half years ago.\n\nFaced with the troublesome poll results, Mr. Turnbull said he was meeting expectations on another front: the success of his policies.", "title": "Australia\u2019s Prime Minister Just Can\u2019t Win an Opinion Poll", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities in Northern California said late Monday that they had recovered and identified the bodies of all four members of a California family who disappeared while on a road trip this month.\n\nSearchers on the Eel River in Leggett, Calif., on Sunday recovered the submerged bodies of Sandeep Thottapilly, 41, and his daughter, Saachi, 9, the Mendocino County Sheriff\u2019s Office said in a statement on Monday. It won the Pulitzer in international reporting in 2013.\n\n______\n\nA Drug War Made Visible\n\nPhoto\n\nDaniel Berehulak, a photographer born and raised in Sydney who works with The New York Times all over the world, won the Pulitzer for breaking news photography last year for his coverage of the Philippines.\n\nThe judges praised his work for \u201cshowing the callous disregard for human life in the Philippines brought about by a government assault on drug dealers and users.\u201d\n\nIt was Daniel\u2019s second Pulitzer. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n______\n\nThe Longest War\n\nPhoto\n\nC.J. Chivers is a veteran of the United States Marine Corps who has been covering conflict since 9/11. So much of his work is memorable, but his profile of an American sniper named Sam Siatta is what won him the Pulitzer for feature writing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVeterans of any war, from any country, will connect with the powerful accounting of Mr. Siatta\u2019s descent into violence after fighting in Afghanistan, reflecting neither the actions of a simple criminal nor a stereotypical case of PTSD.\n\nOur coverage of Afghanistan was also the subject of two other Pulitzers: Barry Bearak won in 2002 for \u201chis deeply affecting and illuminating coverage of daily life,\u201d and John F. Burns won in 1997 for his haunting coverage of the Taliban.\n\n______\n\nScience and Tech, Explained\n\nThe explanatory category of the Pulitzers ranges widely year to year, but we\u2019ve had several winners who won the award for coverage of science and technology.\n\nAmong my favorites: Amy Harmon won in 2008 for her series, The DNA Age, which explored the impact of new genetic technology on how we live.\n\nMichael Moss won two years later for a project about meat and food safety.\n\nAnd in 2013, a team of reporters in China and the United States won for their penetrating look into business practices by Apple and other technology companies that illustrated the darker side of a changing global economy.\n\n______\n\nCultural Criticism\n\nWesley Morris (who will be in Australia next month) won a Pulitzer for his inventive movie reviews before we managed to hire him from The Boston Globe, but whatever, we still count that one now that we\u2019ve got him!\n\nMore recently, his profile of Jordan Peele is worth a read. And of course, you should listen to the podcast he hosts with Jenna Wortham each week, \u201cStill Processing,\u201d for some of the smartest discussion of culture and identity around.\n\n______\n\n...And We Recommend\n\nI just did a lot of recommending so I\u2019ll keep this short: Go see Wesley and Jenna while they\u2019re in Australia. In it, he attacked racial integration as a \u201cludicrous misconception\u201d and \u201ca dangerous delusion,\u201d and predicted that \u201cin 15 or 20 years\u2019 time, the black man will have the whip hand over the white man.\u201d\n\nOn Saturday night, the BBC will broadcast the entire text on radio for the first time \u2014 read by the actor Ian McDiarmid, who is famous for playing the \u201cStar Wars\u201d character Emperor Palpatine \u2014 as part of a program analyzing the speech and its impact 50 years after it was delivered.\n\nThe BBC\u2019s decision has sparked widespread criticism and has been denounced as an \u201cincitement to racial hatred\u201d at a time when far-right nationalism, xenophobia and racism are on the rise in Britain and other parts of Europe.", "title": "BBC to Resurrect Full \u2018Rivers of Blood\u2019 Speech, Spurring Outrage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "But meditating is just another thing. Yoga? Another task, another item for the to-do list.\n\nThis battle between striving and serenity may be distinctly American. The struggle between toil and the dream of ease is an American birthright, the way a Frenchman expects to have decent wine at a reasonable price, and the whole month of August on vacation.\n\nMaybe it goes all the way back to the Declaration of Independence, our founding document. Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. How proud I\u2019ve always been, through the years of protesting, the radical this and progressive that of my 1960s generation, to think of those words.\n\nThat unlikely word \u2014 happiness \u2014 made me proud to be an American, not just for my own sake, but that everyone was enjoined to find a personal project of delight. Of course happiness is an illusion. Still, I\u2019ll pledge allegiance to it.\n\nBut happiness is the only word in the Declaration of Independence triad that doesn\u2019t stand alone. Happiness is not, like life and liberty, a given. Happiness in the American credo is a job. It must be pursued. It may not be clear what happiness is, but you better get hold of it. Your fault, sucker, if you can\u2019t somehow nab it for yourself.\n\nThe essential American word isn\u2019t happiness. It\u2019s pursuit.\n\nThis is where the struggle is engaged, happiness as a national enterprise. Its pursuit is the loneliness coiled within the heart of the American dream.\n\nEven a postmodern to-do list is not the answer. Go ahead \u2014 meditate, do yoga, eat probiotic foods, all that.\n\nBut how about just giving up? What about wasting time? Giving up or perhaps giving over. To what? Perhaps what an earlier age called \u201cthe life of the mind,\u201d the phrase that describes the sovereign self at ease, at home in the world. This isn\u2019t the mind of rational thought, but the lost music of wondering, the sheer value of looking out the window, letting the world float along. It\u2019s nothing, really, this wasted time, which is how it becomes, paradoxically, charged with \u201ceverything,\u201d liberated into the blessed loss of ambition.", "title": "Opinion | Baby Boomers Reach the End of Their To-Do List", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 After a long legal battle in China with no known precedent, a surrogate mother has given birth to a boy four years after his parents died in a car crash, a local newspaper has reported.\n\nShen Jie and Liu Xi, a couple in the eastern Chinese city of Yixing, tried without success to conceive in the first two years of their marriage. They decided to pursue in vitro fertilization, but on March 20, 2013, five days before the embryos were to be implanted, they were killed in a car crash, Beijing News reported on Tuesday in an article detailing the court battle that followed.\n\nThe husband and wife were both only children, and the couple\u2019s parents resolved to use surrogacy to continue the family line. Surrogacy is illegal in China, and the first obstacle for the families was obtaining the embryos.\n\n(Read about how surrogacy has been growing in China because of rising infertility, a relaxation of the one-child policy and a cultural imperative to have children.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe parents of the dead couple repeatedly visited the hospital in Nanjing where the frozen embryos were stored, but senior hospital officials repeatedly refused to meet with them.
