But it did feature the long shadow cast behind the home bench by Jaromir Jagr, Kladno\u2019s player-owner and one of the most prolific scorers in hockey history.\n\nJagr, sidelined by a lingering knee injury, watched his team lose, 2-1, hurting the club\u2019s chances of earning promotion for the first time since being relegated to Czech hockey\u2019s second division four years ago.\n\nJagr, 46, acknowledged that he did not think he would be here, with the N.H.L. season wrapping up this weekend thousands of miles away.\n\nAfter remaining unsigned through most of the off-season, he had signed with the Calgary Flames in October, a few days before the start of the season. The Flames were his ninth team in a 24-season N.H.L. career.", "title": "Back Home in Czech Republic, Jaromir Jagr Plots His Next Move", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Growing up in Merrick, Long Island, Michael Kors was surrounded by women who loved fashion: \u201cMy mother was a former Revlon model, my grandmother was obsessed with Bill Blass and beige and I had two midriff-bearing aunts who idolized Cher,\u201d says the designer, who drew dresses in the sand at the family beach club, where he first observed the leisure-class glamour that would become his eponymous label\u2019s signature. \u201cEveryone would arrive to their cabanas wearing bikinis and leave for dinner in evening gowns,\u201d Kors recalls. After high school, he attended the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, but dropped out after two semesters to work as a window dresser and \u201csales boy\u201d at Lothar\u2019s clothing boutique on Fifth Avenue (a favorite of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Diana Ross) where he also began selling pieces \u2014 crisply tailored blazers, sporty sheaths and maxi skirts \u2014 of his own design.\n\nKors officially launched his label in 1981 when, at age 21, he debuted an 18-piece collection of white crepe de Chine dresses and streamlined leather separates made for the resort season. \u201cNew York in the early \u201980s was like the wild, wild West; anything could happen, there was so much possibility,\u201d says Kors. \u201cGlamour in those days was everything. I would send my muses out at night wearing gold lam\u00e9 gowns with cashmere.\u201d Four decades later, he has over 650 stores worldwide. In 2010, he became the youngest designer in history to receive the CFDA\u2019s Lifetime Achievement Award. But the Broadway fanatic and dedicated AIDS activist has never forgotten what women actually want to wear. Indeed, his famously loyal customers, including Michelle Obama, Hillary Clinton and Oprah, seem to be his greatest source of inspiration. As Kors puts it, \u201cI have always thought that you are truly only as good as the people you dress.\u201d\n\nHere, Kors shares some of his many inspirations.", "title": "Back to the Early \u201980s With Michael Kors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The chief executive of Backpage.com, the sex advertising website recently seized by the federal government, pleaded guilty on Thursday to charges in California and Texas, and officials unsealed plea agreements made last week in federal court in Arizona.\n\nThe chief executive, Carl Ferrer, pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiracy and three counts of money laundering in California, and to money laundering in Texas, the states\u2019 attorneys general announced. Additionally, the company pleaded guilty to human trafficking in Texas.\n\nThe state-level pleas were required by the federal plea agreements Mr. Ferrer and Backpage entered on April 5 in the United States District Court for the District of Arizona. In news releases on Thursday, Attorneys General Xavier Becerra of California and Ken Paxton of Texas described them as major victories in combating human trafficking.\n\nIn his federal deal, Mr. Ferrer, 57, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy to facilitate prostitution using a facility in interstate or foreign commerce, and conspiracy to engage in money laundering, acknowledging that he had \u201clong been aware that the great majority\u201d of the advertisements on Backpage for \u201cadult\u201d and \u201cescort\u201d services were actually advertisements for prostitution.", "title": "Backpage Chief Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy and Money Laundering", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "In other words, the superstars have done superstar things. Yes, the games have been long; these teams know no other way. But the talent is undeniable. You won\u2019t find zany clubhouse characters like Johnny Damon or Kevin Millar, but the play on the field is still sublime \u2014 and feisty.\n\nThe benches actually cleared twice on Wednesday, in the third and seventh innings. Austin slid into second base in the third and spiked shortstop Brock Holt\u2019s lower calf. Holt just stood there, telling Austin what he thought about it. Austin got a little closer, and suddenly 50 players had swarmed the field. Nothing much happened, though.\n\n\u201cI thought it was over,\u201d Holt said. \u201cWe\u2019re not trying to fight those guys over there. They\u2019re big. I wasn\u2019t expecting anything to happen, something did happen, and it escalated quickly.\u201d\n\nSince we\u2019re using \u201cAnchorman\u201d terms, after Kelly drilled Austin in the seventh, the teams were throwing down in fisticuffs \u2014 a Cliff Johnson here, a Troy O\u2019Leary there (or something like that). Kelly, naturally, insisted the pitch got away from him. Give the guy credit, at least, for self-deprecating supporting evidence.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI walk a batter per inning,\u201d Kelly said, \u201cso it\u2019s not like I have Greg Maddux command.\u201d\n\nCatcher Christian Vazquez said he expected the Yankees to retaliate, either on Thursday or when the teams meet again May 8 to 10 in the Bronx.\n\n\u201cThey feel like us,\u201d Vazquez said. \u201cThe clubhouse is our home. Let\u2019s protect our home. There will be something soon. If not this series, maybe in New York.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYankees General Manager Brian Cashman, who has seen decades of this rivalry, defended Austin for charging Kelly after the obvious purpose pitch.\n\n\u201cIn the heat of the moment, it\u2019s hard to control your emotions,\u201d Cashman said. \u201cThere\u2019s two competitive teams going at it and stuff happens and sometimes stuff shouldn\u2019t happen.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAaron Boone, the Yankees\u2019 manager, mentioned the incident last April between the Red Sox and Manny Machado, the Baltimore Orioles star who injured Dustin Pedroia with a hard slide. That sparked an awkward follow-up in which Boston\u2019s Matt Barnes threw behind Machado, only to have Pedroia tell Machado, from the dugout, that he had nothing to do with it.\n\nThe Red Sox went on to win the division, of course, but the ordeal underscored at least some level of dysfunction or absence of leadership. That does not seem to be an issue anymore. In the code of the clubhouse, Kelly protected his teammate, and Holt liked what it suggested.\n\n\u201cIt shows how close-knit we are in here,\u201d Holt said, \u201cand the same goes for them, how close-knit they are.\u201d\n\nHad the Red Sox been playing another team, the incident might have played out the same way; a spike to the calf hurts just as much from a Mariner as it does from a Yankee. But when a Yankee does it at Fenway, there are layers of historical resonance.\n\n\u201cBench-clearing brawls are bench-clearing brawls,\u201d Holt said. \u201cI think Red Sox-Yankees makes it bigger for people outside of the Red Sox and Yankees \u2014 fans and media and stuff like that, I think that\u2019s a big part of it. But I don\u2019t think it\u2019s any different for us.\u201d\n\nThe Red Sox and the Yankees do not really hate each other \u2014 do they? \u2014 but scenes like Wednesday\u2019s validate the passion of the fans, in those cities and far beyond.\n\nPurists love seeing the Kansas City Royals and the Houston Astros in the World Series. Those championship teams played with athleticism and verve, and they were endearing to those who paid attention. If you really love baseball, you wouldn\u2019t mind seeing the Milwaukee Brewers knock off the Chicago Cubs, or the Arizona Diamondbacks upset the Los Angeles Dodgers.\n\nBut when the Yankees and the Red Sox are this good \u2014 and the Angels\u2019 Shohei Ohtani captivates fans with his two-way magic in greater Los Angeles \u2014 the sport thrives on a bigger scale. So while baseball will surely impose discipline for Wednesday\u2019s scuffle, it will do so with a wink.", "title": "Bad Blood Between the Yankees and the Red Sox Is Good for Baseball", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The restaurant scene in NoLIta from the time the chef Einat Admony and her husband, Stefan Nafziger, opened Balaboosta in 2010 until today has changed \u2014 enough that they will be closing the restaurant at the end of May.\n\n\u201cThe neighborhood is saturated, and there are so many Israeli restaurants now,\u201d she said, adding that \u201cbusiness has fallen off a bit.\u201d\n\nShe cited the amount of competition and rising expenses as reasons, saying they contributed to the difficulty of keeping the restaurant viable.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m tired,\u201d Ms. Admony said. \u201cI need some time off to recalculate everything.\u201d\n\nClosing Balaboosta does not mean that Ms. Admony and Mr. Nafziger are withdrawing from the business completely. They still have Bar Bolonat in the West Village and the Taim falafel shops in NoLIta, the West Village and Midtown Manhattan, with one in the financial district on the way. Next month, they will be opening Kish-Kash, specializing in Moroccan-style hand-rolled couscous, at 455 Hudson Street, near Barrow Street in the West Village.", "title": "Balaboosta to Close at End of May", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "For years, scientists have disagreed about which species of baleen whale came first, and how the toothless species were related.\n\nBody structure suggested one set of relationships; molecular data suggested another.\n\nNow, researchers in Germany and Sweden have sequenced the DNA of six of the living species, of which there are at least 10.\n\nThe relationships are so complicated, however, that the senior researcher Axel Janke said \u201cfamily tree\u201d is too simple a metaphor. Instead, the species, all part of a group called rorquals, have evolved more into a network, sharing large segments of DNA with even distant cousins. Scientists expressed surprise that there had been so much intermingling of baleen whales, given the variety of sizes and shapes.", "title": "Baleen Whales Intermingled as They Evolved, and Share DNA With Distant Cousins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "A banana might reasonably replace sports drinks for those of us who rely on carbohydrates to fuel exercise and speed recovery, according to a new study comparing the cellular effects of carbohydrates consumed during sports.\n\nIt found that a banana, with its all-natural package, provides comparable or greater anti-inflammatory and other benefits for athletes than sports drinks. But there may be a downside, and it involves bloating.\n\nFor decades, athletes and their advisers have believed, and studies have confirmed, that eating or drinking carbohydrates during prolonged exertion can enable someone to continue for longer or at higher intensities and recover more quickly afterward than if he or she does not eat during the workout.\n\nThe carbohydrates rapidly fuel muscles, lessening some of the physiological stress of working out and prompting less inflammation afterward.", "title": "Bananas vs. Sports Drinks? Bananas Win in Study", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTurbulent markets and relaxed regulations are great news for banks \u2014 and it shows.\n\nCitigroup and JPMorgan Chase, the first big United States banks to report their first-quarter results, reported on Friday that business was booming on their stock trading desks as markets gyrated wildly during the first three months of the year. And they reaped greater profits from their core lending businesses, thanks to rising interest rates.\n\nTheir results could represent the beginning of a new period of vigor for the banking industry, which in recent years has had to contend with a mix of ill winds, including an eerie quiet in markets, which depressed their usually lucrative trading businesses.\n\nImproved business conditions are good news for banks, but the prospect of regulators loosening up their oversight could be even better over the long haul.\n\nCitigroup and JPMorgan each revealed slightly thinner capital cushions in the first quarter, apparently reflecting their expectation that regulators would ease rules for banks in the coming months. With reduced capital buffers, the banks can afford to spend more on repurchasing their shares, distributing dividends to shareholders, paying their employees or lending more to clients.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe reduction in the banks\u2019 capital cushions is slight, but it is a sign that actions by the Trump administration and its appointees are having a concrete impact on the banking industry.", "title": "Bank Earnings Boom as Regulators Relax Rules", "authors": ["Emily Flitter"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Bank of America will stop lending money to gun manufacturers that make military-inspired firearms for civilian use, such as the AR-15-style rifles that have been used in multiple mass shootings, a company executive said Tuesday.\n\nThe policy is the latest example of Wall Street wading into the divisive gun control debate after Citigroup\u2019s announcement last month that it would require business customers to restrict certain types of firearms sales.\n\n\u201cWe want to contribute in any way we can to reduce these mass shootings,\u201d Anne M. Finucane, vice chairwoman at the Bank of America, said on Bloomberg TV.\n\nThe bank works with \u201cjust a handful of manufacturers,\u201d with whom it has had \u201cintense conversations over the last few months,\u201d Ms. Finucane said. Their reactions to the new policy have been \u201cmixed,\u201d she said.", "title": "Bank of America to Stop Financing Makers of Military-Style Guns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Since then, his home has been burgled by unidentified intruders and he has struggled to defend himself against what he describes as a conspiracy by crooked bankers who want him in jail because he threatened their profits from highly risky money laundering deals.\n\nAbout the only person to defend him publicly is his ex-wife, Lyga. A family, she said, even a divided one, should look out for its own.\n\nRules protecting the central bank from political meddling make it difficult to unseat Mr. Rimsevics, who denies any wrongdoing and has refused to quit. Even his underlings in the central bank, known as Latvijas Banka, seem to want him gone. They decided recently to bar him from using his office, the bank\u2019s computer system, staff cars and other facilities.\n\nHe \u201chas few to zero friends,\u201d said Morten Hansen, the head of the economics department at the Stockholm School of Economics in Riga.\n\nAfter weeks of silence, the European Central Bank, on whose governing council Mr. Rimsevics sits but whose meetings he cannot attend because he is barred from leaving Latvia, this month offered a timid gesture of support. It asked the European Union\u2019s top court to weigh in on whether the \u201csecurity measures\u201d imposed on him violated rules protecting the independence of European central banks.\n\nThe standoff is unlikely to end soon. The European court rarely makes swift decisions and Latvia\u2019s Corruption Prevention Bureau, which is leading the investigation into Mr. Rimsevics, has said that the case would not be handed over to prosecutors for months.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Rimsevics attributes his troubles to what he says was his hard line against Latvian banks that profit from taking deposits from and moving funds for nonresident clients, mostly citizens of former Soviet lands. \u201cThey are taking their revenge,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe biggest of these banks, ABLV, announced last month that it was going into \u201cself-liquidation\u201d after the United States Treasury Department issued a damning report describing the bank as a sprawling money laundering racket with a rogue\u2019s gallery of disreputable clients who, among other things, helped North Korea develop ballistic missiles capable of hitting the United States.\n\nThe American bombshell, which the bank insists was the result of \u201cfalse information,\u201d but that supported what many have long suspected, was followed quickly by an even more shocking blast \u2014 the news that Mr. Rimsevics, a man so powerful and seemingly immovable that he was known as \u201cthe king,\u201d was under investigation for taking bribes.\n\nOfficials say the two events are not connected, but Mr. Rimsevics insists they both flow from the same source \u2014 the dirty shenanigans of Latvia\u2019s \u201cnonresident\u201d banking sector.\n\nHe said it was no coincidence that anticorruption investigators first raided his central bank office and his home a few hours after he declined a request from ABLV bank for a billion euros in \u201cliquidity support\u201d to help survive a bank run caused by the Treasury Department report. \u201cThe two things are absolutely connected,\u201d he said, claiming that he is the victim of a \u201cbig plot\u201d by dodgy bankers.\n\nLatvia\u2019s finance minister, Dana Reizniece-Ozola, a chess grandmaster well versed in elaborate gambits, derided Mr. Rimsevics\u2019s conspiracy theory. \u201cI know this is his line of defense,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is a free country so he can say whatever he wants.\u201d Yet, she added, \u201cHe is not a victim. He is a suspect.\u201d\n\nAlso skeptical about Mr. Rimsevics\u2019s claims of victimhood is Ainars Latkovskis, the chairman of the Latvian Parliament\u2019s Defense, Internal Affairs and Corruption Prevention Committee. Mr. Latkovskis said his committee had long pushed for tighter controls on banks like ABLV but, speaking in the chamber where the committee has discussed ways to toughen measures against money laundering, he said, \u201cwe never saw him here in this room.\u201d\n\nJohn Christmas, a banker who worked with Latvia\u2019s now defunct Parex bank, said Mr. Rimsevics had, at times, shown concern about money laundering. He remembers meeting the central bank chief in 2004 and getting an earful about Parex. \u201cHe started cursing that Parex was a criminal organization,\u201d Mr. Christmas said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe banker later left Parex and Latvia to become a vociferous online critic of the country\u2019s banking system. But, he said, Mr. Rimsevics did not respond to a 2005 letter urging the closure of Parex, which collapsed three years later after a bank run.\n\nAll the recent tumult, accompanied by purported death threats and accusations of Russian meddling, has delivered a sharp blow to Latvia\u2019s image as a placid and predictable country firmly anchored in the West, a counter-model of post-Soviet development to that offered by Russia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe evidence against Mr. Rimsevics for bribetaking has not been revealed, and the only accuser to come forward so far is Grigory Guselnikov, the Russian owner of Norvik, another Latvian bank focused on nonresident clients. Speaking by telephone from London, where he lives, Mr. Guselnikov said he had been asked to pay 100,000 euros, around $125,000, in bribes a month by an intermediary sent by Mr. Rimsevics. He also accused the central banker of having once worked for the Soviet K.G.B.\n\nMr. Guselnikov\u2019s accusations, said Mr. Rimsevics, \u201care total, total lies.\u201d\n\nLatvia\u2019s Defense Ministry, in a statement in response to the crisis rocking the country\u2019s financial world, claimed that the tiny Baltic nation had fallen victim to a \u201cmassive information operation from outside\u201d that was \u201cidentical in structure and execution\u201d to operations linked to Russia that preceded elections in France, Germany and the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\nHardly anybody is buying that, least of all the United States Treasury Department\u2019s Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, known as FinCEN, which issued the February report cataloging how ABLV bank\u2019s \u201cexecutives, shareholders and employees have institutionalized money laundering as a pillar of the bank\u2019s business practices.\u201d\n\nMarshall Billingslea, an assistant secretary at Treasury, visited Riga last month to again press officials to curtail Latvia\u2019s shady nonresident banks and assure them that Washington has evidence that ABLV not only laundered dirty money but \u201cused bribery to influence Latvian officials when challenging enforcement actions and perceived threats to their high-risk business.\u201d\n\nThe bank has categorically denied paying bribes and has cast itself, like Mr. Rimsevics, as a victim.\n\nThe finance minister, Ms. Reizniece-Ozola, said the Defense Ministry statement portraying Latvia as a victim of a Russian-inspired hybrid war did not mean to suggest that Moscow is to blame for all the troubles that have engulfed Mr. Rimsevics and ABLV bank. It was, she said, simply a reminder of the tense geopolitical backdrop to the banking crisis at a time when Russia is working hard to undermine NATO and the European Union, both of which Latvia has belonged to since 2004.\n\nOnly 6 percent of ABLV\u2019s deposits, which totaled $3.2 billion at the end of 2017, came from Latvians. The largest share \u2014 43 percent \u2014 was from Russians.\n\nThe problem, said Ms. Reizniece-Ozola, is not that depositors are Russian but that \u201cwe don\u2019t really know who they are,\u201d as most operate through layers of opaque shell companies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver the years Latvian banks, particularly ABLV, have figured in scandals involving crime-tainted money. These include the transfer of funds stolen by corrupt Russian officials exposed by Sergei Magnitsky, a Russian lawyer who died in a Moscow prison in 2009; money from a $1 billion bank heist in Moldova in 2014; and billions of dollars transferred out of Russia in what the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project called the \u201cRussian laundromat.\u201d\n\nAfter long denying that Latvia had a serious problem and arguing that the country was merely utilizing its \u201ccompetitive advantage\u201d as Russia\u2019s neighbor but part of Europe, the authorities and even some banks have tried to end the free-for-all. They have imposed tougher anti-money laundering controls and are at least paying lip service to the idea that crime-tainted money should be shunned.\n\n\u201cIt is clear that the credibility and reputation of the financial sector has been damaged,\u201d said Sanda Liepina, the new chairman of the Association of Latvian Commercial Banks, which for years played down accusations of money laundering. Control measures introduced starting in 2015, she said, \u201cshould have been taken four or five years earlier.\u201d\n\nMr. Rimsevics, the beleaguered central bank chief, says he, too, \u201cfelt uneasy about what has been going on for years\u201d in Latvian banks catering to Russians, but when he tried to curb their shady activities, ABLV, Norvik and other banks \u201c complained about me big time.\u201d\n\nHe said he had even received text messages on his cellphone warning that he would be shot if did not ease up.\n\nWhatever the truth of that, one thing seems clear: Latvia\u2019s role as the \u201cSwitzerland of the Baltics,\u201d a business model eagerly cheered by European and American consultants and officials in the early 1990s, seems over.\n\n\u201cThis is really yesterday\u2019s business,\u201d Ms. Reizniece-Ozola said. \u201cThe sooner the banks themselves understand that, the better.\u201d", "title": "Banker Finds He Has \u2018Even More Enemies Than I Thought\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew Higgins"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "HOUSTON \u2014 At the Episcopal church that has been her spiritual home for more than 50 years, the former first lady Barbara Pierce Bush was celebrated at her funeral as one of the most beloved political matriarchs in American history.\n\nMrs. Bush, the wife of the 41st president and the mother of the 43rd, died on Tuesday in the bedroom of her home in Houston. She was 92, and took her last breaths holding the hand of her husband of 73 years, former President George Bush.\n\nAs her coffin lay beneath an ivory-colored pall in the center aisle of St. Martin\u2019s Episcopal Church, some of the most powerful and famous political figures in the United States \u2014 including four of the five living former presidents \u2014 gathered to honor a woman who carried her own power and fame lightly.\n\n\u201cWe learned to strive to be genuine and authentic by the best role model in the world,\u201d Mrs. Bush\u2019s son, Jeb Bush, the former two-term governor of Florida, told mourners in his eulogy. The family called her Bar, Mother, Ganny, the Silver Fox and, notably, the Enforcer, as she used her wit, humor and tough love to raise six children, 17 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.", "title": "Barbara Bush Is Remembered at Her Funeral for Her Wit and Tough Love", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Bush was the first and only former American president to call Houston home, and both he and his wife helped raise the city\u2019s global profile. They dined at the famously tony Tony\u2019s, or had Tex-Mex at Molina\u2019s Cantina, or Chinese at Yao. Anyone curious about just how much Houston adored the Bushes need only look at the couple\u2019s pets. Mr. Bush may have had an airport named for him and Mrs. Bush may have had a library named for her, but three of their dogs have parks honoring them: Millie Bush Bark Park (named for their late English springer spaniel) and the Bibi and Mini-Me Bush Dog Park.\n\n\u201cBarbara Pierce Bush was best known to the world as the wife of a president and the mother of another, but in Houston we also knew her as a local leading light, an achiever in her own right who spoke and acted from the heart and the gut,\u201d Mayor Sylvester Turner said in a statement.\n\nMrs. Bush was the matriarch of a Republican family in a Democratic-leaning city, yet seemed above politics, or maybe just off to the side of it.\n\nIn November 2009, Annise D. Parker won the Houston mayor\u2019s race, becoming the first openly gay mayor of a major American city. During the campaign, Ms. Parker, a Democrat, had won a key Republican endorsement \u2014 from Mrs. Bush. Years later, during her tenure as mayor, Ms. Parker saw Mrs. Bush at an event.\n\n\u201cShe looked at me and she said she thought I had done an excellent job as mayor,\u201d recalled Ms. Parker, who served as mayor from 2010 to 2016. \u201cAnd she said: \u2018I like your style. You could have been a Bush.\u2019 And that\u2019s one of the highest compliments that anyone\u2019s ever paid me. She\u2019s from the Northeast, but in a lot of ways she personifies what we expect of Texas women: tough and honest and occasionally sharp-tongued.\u201d\n\nMrs. Bush, a native of New York, met her future husband in 1941 at a dance in Connecticut. The couple eventually moved to West Texas, and then settled in Houston in the late 1950s.\n\nHouston played a role \u2014 albeit a small, scenic one \u2014 in one of Mrs. Bush\u2019s most important decisions. It was the summer of 1978, and she was jogging in Memorial Park, the Central Park of Houston. She had struggled to pick a cause that she could throw herself behind, and landed on one during her jog \u2014 literacy. \u201cFinally, after much thought, I realized everything I worried about would be better if more people could read, write and comprehend,\u201d she wrote in her 1994 autobiography, \u201cBarbara Bush: A Memoir.\u201d", "title": "Barbara Bush Mourned in Houston as a Revered Matriarch and \u2018Salty\u2019 Neighbor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Barbara Bush, the seriously ill wife and mother of presidents who has long been among the most popular members of her famous family, has decided to stop seeking medical treatment to prolong her life, a spokesman said on Sunday.\n\nMrs. Bush, who is 92 and frail, has been in and out of the hospital but has now forsworn further interventions and \u201cwill instead focus on comfort care,\u201d according to a statement issued by her husband\u2019s office in Houston.\n\n\u201cIt will not surprise those who know her that Barbara Bush has been a rock in the face of her failing health, worrying not for herself \u2014 thanks to her abiding faith \u2014 but for others,\u201d the statement said. \u201cShe is surrounded by a family she adores, and appreciates the many kind messages and especially the prayers she is receiving.\u201d\n\nMrs. Bush was resting at the family home in Houston. Her husband, former President George Bush, was with her, along with her children Neil, Marvin and Dorothy. Her two eldest sons, former President George W. Bush and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, have both been to visit in recent days and were calling frequently on Sunday, according to a person close to the family.", "title": "Barbara Bush, Gravely Ill, Opts to Halt Treatment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI got away with murder,\u201d Mrs. Bush said shortly before her husband\u2019s inauguration.\n\nOne glaring exception came in 1984. Speaking of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of New York, the Democratic nominee for vice president, Mrs. Bush characterized her as something that \u201crhymes with rich.\u201d She later apologized, but even then she parried with her critics, saying she did not mean any offense by calling Ms. Ferraro \u201ca witch.\u201d\n\nShe was born Barbara Pierce on June 8, 1925, at a maternity hospital in New York City run by the Salvation Army principally for unwed mothers. The family obstetrician practiced there one month a year, and that month happened to be June. She was the third child of the former Pauline Robinson and Marvin Pierce. Her father was in the publishing business and eventually became president of the McCall publishing company. Her mother, the daughter of an Ohio Supreme Court justice, was active in civic affairs in Rye, N.Y., the New York City suburb where the family lived.\n\nOne of Mrs. Bush\u2019s distant relatives was Franklin Pierce, the 14th president of the United States.\n\nBarbara was brought up in considerable affluence. She attended the public Milton School and the private Rye Country Day School and, along with her contemporaries, suffered through dancing classes, which she never forgot. \u201cI was 5 feet 8 inches at the age of 12, and it certainly bothered the boys,\u201d she recalled.\n\nHer final two years of high school were spent at Ashley Hall, a boarding school in Charleston, S.C. A classmate once described it as a place where \u201cbeing bad meant taking off your hat and gloves when you got out of sight of the school.\u201d\n\nLong Romance Begins\n\nShe met George Bush in 1941 at a Christmas dance at the Round Hill Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. George had grown up in Greenwich, a son of Prescott S. Bush, a Wall Street executive and a future United States senator from Connecticut, and the former Dorothy Walker. At the time, he was a senior at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. They began corresponding.\n\nAfter graduating in 1942, Mr. Bush enlisted in the Navy and trained as a pilot. The next year, he was assigned to a torpedo squadron in the Pacific and piloted a Grumman Avenger. On one combat mission, in 1944, he was shot down and rescued by a submarine. Barbara did not hear from him for a month.", "title": "Barbara Bush, Wife of 41st President and Mother of 43rd, Dies at 92", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "She knew who she was, and she saw no need to apologize for it. In the spring of 1990, the administration of Wellesley College \u2014 the alma mater, as it happened, of Hillary Rodham Clinton \u2014 invited Barbara Bush, then the first lady of the United States, to speak at commencement and receive an honorary degree. Students at the women\u2019s college protested, declaring in a petition that Mrs. Bush had \u201cgained recognition through the achievements of her husband,\u201d and adding that Wellesley \u201cteaches us that we will be rewarded on the basis of our own merit, not on that of a spouse.\u201d\n\nAnd so a generational battle was joined. As her husband, George H. W. Bush, put it in his private White House diary, Mrs. Bush was being attacked \u201cbecause she hasn\u2019t made it on her own \u2014 she\u2019s where she is because she\u2019s her husband\u2019s wife.\u201d Mr. Bush added: \u201cWhat\u2019s wrong with the fact that she\u2019s a good mother, a good wife, great volunteer, great leader for literacy and other fine causes? Nothing, but to listen to these elitist kids there is.\u201d To the young women of the last decade of the 20th century, Mrs. Bush, who had dropped out of Smith College to marry, seemed a throwback to a less enlightened time.\n\nMrs. Bush, who died on Tuesday at age 92, never flinched, appearing at Wellesley and using her commencement address to explore the complexities of life\u2019s choices. There was no single path, she told the graduates; one followed one\u2019s heart and did the best one could. \u201cMaybe we should adjust faster, maybe we should adjust slower,\u201d she said. \u201cBut whatever the era, whatever the times, one thing will never change: Fathers and mothers, if you have children \u2014 they must come first. You must read to your children, hug your children, and you must love your children. Your success as a family, our success as a society, depends not on what happens in the White House, but on what happens inside your house.\u201d\n\nThe loudest applause came when she remarked that perhaps there was someone in the audience who would, like her, one day preside over the White House as the president\u2019s spouse. \u201cAnd I wish him well,\u201d Mrs. Bush said.", "title": "Opinion | Barbara Bush, a First Lady Without Apologies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Barbara Bush was an expert at throwing shade, even before the term existed.\n\nWhen Congressman Dan Rostenkowski gave the first lady a shampoo for white hair made in his Illinois district, she tried it on her dog Millie.\n\n\u201cWhen I shampooed her with it, she became a brown and slightly yellow-haired dog,\u201d she wrote in her memoir. \u201cAt this writing, Danny is under fire, accused of financial wrongdoing. We certainly wish him well.\u201d\n\nShe took her revenge, chilled, on Nancy Reagan, who never invited the Bushes to the White House residence for dinner in the eight years H.W. was vice president and who instructed Mrs. Bush to stay away from wearing \u201cNancy red\u201d while she was the second lady. Writing about Nancy and Raisa Gorbachev competing at a wives\u2019 lunch, Mrs. Bush said she wasn\u2019t sure of Raisa\u2019s age: \u201cI don\u2019t know how old, but I think the paper said 53 or 55. That\u2019s funny, for we really don\u2019t know if Nancy Reagan is 65 or 67 and she won\u2019t tell.\u201d\n\nShe could be caustic, practicing radical candor. She told reporters at Kennebunkport once when I was there that she did not want W. to run for governor of Texas while his father was president. But when he dived into politics, she turned over one of the most valuable documents in fund-raising history: the Bush family Christmas card list.", "title": "Opinion | Barbara Bush: Fake Pearls, Real Heart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "For a first lady famously and proudly uninterested in fashion, focused rather on literacy and her family, it was a strategic choice. The pearls reflected her approach to the job \u2014 practical, with humor and an understanding of tradition \u2014 and her personality in a way that allowed women around the world to relate. They acknowledged the exigencies of the White House and the unelected, often silent, but very visible role that is first lady, with all the expectations of first hostess and first helpmate that implies, with respect but without fuss or frippery.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a patrician, dynastic family such as the Bushes, this created no small public relations counterpart and advantage.\n\nIt began at her husband\u2019s 1989 inaugural ball, when Mrs. Bush appeared in a royal blue velvet gown with an asymmetric velvet bodice and draped satin skirt by Arnold Scassi (Scaasi being something of her go-to couturier) topped by a triple strand of pearls from Kenneth Jay Lane, the New York costume jeweler. The dress was elegant, but the pearls, declared to be faux, were a global hit, so much so that Mr. Lane renamed the necklace the \u201cBarbara Bush pearls,\u201d acknowledging Mrs. Bush\u2019s role as an influencer longer before the term even existed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey signaled, in their (relative) affordability, a break with the Reagan administration, and set off a trend for pearls, real and faux, in the jewelry industry \u2014 especially as it seemed Mrs. Bush so rarely took them off. As Mark Gurdus, vice president of sales for Marvella jewelry, told United Press International not long after Mrs. Bush moved into the White House, \u201cBarbara Bush wearing them every night on the 6 p.m. news is really not hurting.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAccording to the Kenneth Jay Lane website, where the Bush pearls continue to be sold (for $150), \u201cthe former first lady wore the three-strand necklace so often she said that, if she took it off, her head would fall off.\u201d\n\nThey became her signature. She wore them with suits, with dresses, to casual events and state dinners, and she continued to do so long after her husband left office. She wore them when she met visiting dignitaries, and when she was photographed with her dog, Millie. She wore them on the cover of her official memoir, and on the cover of the coming biography, \u201cThe Matriarch,\u201d by Susan Page, Mrs. Bush is pictured wearing a bright red coat and her three strands of pearls. They are now part of the historical record: the strands she wore to the inauguration were donated to the Smithsonian Institution in 1990.\n\nEarly in the Bushes\u2019 White House tenure, Mrs. Bush\u2019s deputy press secretary, Jean Becker, told U.P.I. that the first lady wore the fake pearls because she \u201cjust liked them.\u201d But in a 2015 interview with her granddaughter, Jenna Bush Hager, Mrs. Bush joked that she used them to cover the wrinkles on her neck. Both the attitude and the actuality are now a part of her legacy. She wore them well.", "title": "Barbara Bush: Soft Power in Fake Pearls", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman", "On The Runway"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "She introduces us to a world of dystopian \u201cintrabody conflict.\u201d (Ehrenreich has a Ph.D. in cellular immunology.) Our bodies are subject to randomness and even outright \u201cconflict at the cellular level.\u201d She cites a biologist who describes pregnancy as \u201cmaternal-fetal competition\u201d: The fetus tries to siphon off the nutrients from the mother, whose body struggles to retain them for herself. Our immune system has been found to nourish cancer cells (\u201cthe fire department is indeed staffed by arsonists\u201d).\n\n\u201cNatural Causes\u201d is peevish, tender and deeply, distinctively odd \u2014 and often redeemed by its oddness. Ehrenreich is so offended by the American conflation of health with virtue and offers charming contrarian essays on the \u201cdefiant self-nurturance\u201d of cigarette smoking, for example, and the dangers of eating fruit. The pleasures of her prose are often local, in the animated language, especially where scientific descriptions are concerned. Her description of cells rushing to staunch a wound is so full of wonder and delight that it recalls Italo Calvino.\n\nThere are, however, a few swan dives into near-nonsense. In arguing that the wellness epidemic seeks to prettify our body\u2019s actual processes, she reveals a horror of menstruation \u2014 a \u201cviolent occurrence\u201d that she claims can be \u201cappalling, even terrifying, to the young girl who experiences it.\u201d She rails against \u201cpro-menstrual propaganda\u201d that dares \u201cnormalize this.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a confusing moment of squeamishness and overstatement from a woman who was politicized as a young mother by the funky feminism of the 1970s. (There\u2019s even a fond mention of a speculum in these pages.)\n\nMore surprising, Ehrenreich never really grapples with the obvious point that most Americans suffer from a lack \u2014 not excess \u2014 of access to basic health care. This is especially true for women of color, as the alarming rates of maternal mortality make clear.\n\nEhrenreich\u2019s focus on relatively rarefied issues and pet preoccupations make it clear that this is a book born out of private not public concerns \u2014 despite masquerading as such. It possesses what the critic Helen Vendler described as \u201cthe strange binocular style\u201d of late works, in which the writer is attentive to death\u2019s encroaching shadow but also vividly alive to the present moment. There is a feeling of Ehrenreich getting her affairs in order, slaying a few final foes.\n\nThe wellness movement neatly dispatched, she sits in contemplation of death itself in the book\u2019s concluding, very beautiful passages, bringing to it her characteristic curiosity and awe at the natural world. \u201cIt is one thing to die into a dead world and, metaphorically speaking, leave one\u2019s bones to bleach on a desert lit only by a dying star,\u201d she writes. \u201cIt is another thing to die into the actual world, which seethes with life, with agency other than our own, and at the very least, with endless possibility.\u201d\n\nI\u2019m reminded of a haiku by Mizuta Masahide, the 17th-century Japanese poet who commemorated the burning down of his barn, which left him homeless: \u201cMy storehouse burned down\u2014/now nothing stands between me/and the moon above.\u201d", "title": "Barbara Ehrenreich Urges Us to Accept, Accept the Dying of the Light", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The two regulators said in a brief statement that they had concluded their investigations and had issued \u201cdraft warning notices in respect to the C.E.O.,\u201d but did not provide further details.\n\nThe fine caps an awkward, yearlong chapter for Barclays. Despite its central role in the British economy, it has spent the last decade in almost constant tumult. Regulatory sanctions, a fraud investigation, and lackluster financial results have created a revolving door at the top: When Mr. Staley became chief executive in 2015, he was the bank\u2019s fifth in just seven years. That may in fact have worked in his favor, by making the British authorities wary of causing additional disruption.\n\nBarclays had appeared to cement Mr. Staley\u2019s future at the bank in February, handing him an annual bonus for 2017 of 1.07 million pounds, or about $1.5 million. Though less than the maximum he could have been awarded, the payout raised for Mr. Staley was nevertheless in addition to his annual salary of \u00a32.35 million, and amounted to a vote of confidence in the executive. The annual salary is paid in cash and in shares.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe whistle-blower investigation stemmed from Mr. Staley\u2019s attempts in 2016 to learn the identity of a person who had penned anonymous letters to Barclays officials protesting a senior hire. The letters claimed that the new employee, an investment banker, had behaved erratically in a previous job at JPMorgan, according to people who were briefed on the documents, and suggested that made him unfit to work for Barclays.\n\nBarclays stood by its hiring. But Mr. Staley, who described the letters as a malicious smear attempt, could not let the matter go.\n\nHoping to stop what he described in a note to employees as \u201charassment,\u201d Mr. Staley asked executives whether he could try to identify the letter writer, said a person who was briefed on the matter at the time. He was warned off initially, according to a statement from the bank.\n\nAfter an internal reassessment of the hiring was completed, however, Mr. Staley directed Barclays\u2019s internal security team to try to find the writer, the bank\u2019s statement said. Their efforts failed.\n\nThen, early in 2017, an employee complained to the Barclays board about its whistle-blowing procedures, pointing out Mr. Staley\u2019s reaction to the anonymous letter writer the prior summer. Barclays hired an outside law firm to investigate the episode, and the firm concluded that Mr. Staley had \u201chonestly, but mistakenly\u201d believed his unmasking attempt to be appropriate, according to the bank\u2019s statement at the time.\n\nThe authorities were notified, and, months later, the Financial Conduct Authority and the Prudential Regulation Authority began their own inquiries.", "title": "Barclays Chief Executive Staley Fined Over Whistle-Blower Scandal", "authors": ["Kate Kelly"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Is this a good thing? Yes. We should be happy that grace is still considered a goal of fair play. How exactly that plays out is what causes much of this debate.\n\nIf the Orioles (in the above instance) are still trying to win by getting a base runner on, that is a noble cause. If the Twins are still trying to preserve their lead by shifting the defense, then so be it. No one really can complain about either team playing hard through the last out. After all, many a game has been won with just a strike left and one team\u2019s back against the wall.\n\nIt just happened that the spirit of competing to the undying end \u2014 which is what we expect from big leaguers \u2014 created this unwritten moment. Bunting in the third inning while down 7-0 would not have prompted outrage. Not so in the ninth. Theoretically, a player versed in the unwritten lexicon should know when to say when.\n\nThere is some historical context. Unwritten rules fill in the blanks concrete law leaves us. Two major safety rules have come about since I retired in 2005: the \u201cPosey rule,\u201d which protects catchers at home plate from getting smashed by runners, and the \u201cUtley rule,\u201d which prohibits runners from targeting infielders. During my time, you could run the catcher over and wipe out the infielder on a double play, though you still had interference-regulating rules about going in \u201cspikes high\u201d or body-rolling or being required to reach the base when you slid.\n\nThe unwritten rules made us all accountable, not just the umpires and coaching staff, and through them players educated other players on caring about safety. Now that these rules have adapted to a world with less contact, players continue to share their nuances to underscore the importance of safety for all.\n\nWhen my children eat dinner, I often pull my hair out. All four of them are under 10, and all do something that offends my sensibility. But in the end, I am motivated by my family history, my expectations for them in the world, and I remember that what my wife and I expect is not written in law.\n\nSo my daughter insisting on sitting on top of the table or my son\u2019s habit of not being able to remain seated for more than 14 seconds could be seen as kids being kids. In steering them (or not), we draw from an unwritten understanding about table etiquette \u2014 \u201crules\u201d that are we concede are subjective, unless you live at Downton Abbey. Most families do not reference a rule book every time the table is set. (Your salad fork is one centimeter too close to the plate!)", "title": "Opinion | Baseball\u2019s Unwritten Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "In 2009, John Kerry went to Damascus and hailed the Syrian president as \u201can essential player in bringing peace and stability to the region.\u201d Mr. Assad had waited out yet another passing storm of Western hostility, which was replaced by outright friendship, without sacrificing his interests in Lebanon.\n\nWhen the civil war began in Syria in 2011, President Barack Obama called on Mr. Assad to step down. At times, it seemed that the United States might even try to make that happen. But Mr. Assad took steps to protect against an American intervention. He allowed the Islamic State to flourish, essentially creating a dilemma for the Americans: Would they rather have the jihadists take over Syria? So long as the Islamic State existed, Mr. Assad was safe \u2014 all he had to do was wait. Not only was he spared, but also the United States obliged him by fighting the Islamic State while letting him continue his war on the opposition unobstructed.\n\nAs the Islamic State weakened, life grew dangerous again for Mr. Assad. Not only did the group\u2019s defeat eliminate the \u201cAssad or the jihadists\u201d dilemma, but it also coincided with a new administration in Washington that is bent on \u201crolling back\u201d the influence of Mr. Assad\u2019s main ally, Iran. However, despite Mr. Tillerson\u2019s announcement of an indefinite American military deployment in Syria, President Trump soon signaled the United States would beat the Islamic State and get out of Syria.\n\nThis most likely won\u2019t be the United States\u2019 last word on Syria. The latest chemical attacks could force Washington\u2019s hand once more, leading Mr. Trump to try to prove that his \u201cred lines\u201d matter. If so, Mr. Assad will wait out any American response, knowing it will not aim to endanger his regime\u2019s survival. And then he will resume his conquest of Syria. (Though it\u2019s also possible that the policy machine in Washington is too dysfunctional to decide on and execute a strategy.)\n\nAmerican policymakers like to say that Mr. Assad has not won the war because much of Syria is occupied by foreign powers, its economy and cities are in ruins and its regime is an international pariah. But Mr. Assad does believe that he is winning, that he will take his country back eventually and that a wave of airstrikes or cruise missiles will not change that. Who can blame him?", "title": "Opinion | Bashar al-Assad Knows What He Can Get Away With", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I cannot even get my Canon printer on my wireless network in the first place so I can register it or print anything with a Chromebook. Where do I start?\n\nA. Canon makes a large number of different printers, and the wireless setup steps will vary based on the model you have. If you cannot reach anybody on the company\u2019s telephone support lines to walk you through the process, check the technical support area of Canon\u2019s printers site for instructional videos or browse the page devoted to wireless printing. The Canon video library has clips that guide you through the wireless setup for several printers, and you may be able to find one for your specific model. In some cases, you may need a smartphone or a computer to help get the printer on the network.", "title": "Beating Those Wireless Printer Woes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Here they examined two often dueling human instincts \u2014 to be wary of unknown forces and to cooperate in order to survive. And they warned against education that warped formative minds, whether overtly, as in Nazi Germany, or more subtly, as when an us-against-them mentality is cultivated based on nationalistic, racial or other group divisions.\n\n\u201cAs we have seen in many places over many generations, it is possible to shape youngsters in hateful ways, prepared for large-scale killing even at the expense of their own lives,\u201d they wrote. \u201cEducation for hatred is a harsh reality of history, amplified now by immensely enhanced capacities for destruction. Surely there is no attractive future for humanity in this direction \u2014 indeed, perhaps no future at all.\u201d\n\nBeatrix Ann McCleary was born on Oct. 19, 1923, in Jacksonville, Fla. Her father, Minor, was a doctor who died when she was a toddler. Her mother, the former Beatrix Ann Downs, took her to New York, where Beatrix\u2019s grandparents lived, and reared her with a strong emphasis on education.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat paid off when Vassar, playing catch-up to some other prestigious colleges, became determined to shake its all-white label (although a black student who identified as white had graduated there in 1897).\n\n\u201cI was informed by a Methodist minister that at Vassar they wanted to find a black student,\u201d Dr. Hamburg said in a 2011 video interview, \u201cand he was going to suggest me. So I was in essence recruited to go there.\u201d\n\nThe college did not assign her a roommate at first, she recalled years later, \u201cbecause they didn\u2019t know how I would work out.\u201d But she found ready acceptance at Raymond House, her residence hall on the campus, in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., although her Vassar years were not without awkwardness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI represented the Negro Problem \u2014 in capitals \u2014 and the Raymond students were interested in that problem and in seeing that Vassar solved it successfully,\u201d she told The Vassar Quarterly in 1946. \u201cThat I should be thought of, at least at first, as the representative of a problem race rather than as an individual was natural; it was also sometimes difficult.\n\n\u201cThe most amusing of these difficulties was that everyone assumed I was an authority on all things Negro,\u201d she continued. \u201cI was bombarded with questions about the Negro theater, Negro political problems and opinions, African lore, Negro music, and so on indefinitely. I answered all the questions I knew anything about and some I didn\u2019t. But it\u2019s an odd thing about my education in a predominantly white college that it made me learn more about Negroes than I knew when I came.\u201d\n\nWhile at Vassar she met Eleanor Roosevelt, who was on the college\u2019s board of directors when Dr. Hamburg was a student representative to the board.\n\n\u201cShe was a big role model for me,\u201d Dr. Hamburg said. \u201cSo that was another activist lady, in addition to my mother, who was very important in my life.\u201d\n\nIf adjusting to being black on a white campus was a theme of her Vassar years, at Yale Medical School there was a different obstacle.\n\n\u201cIt wasn\u2019t a very big deal to be an African American at Yale, but it was much more of a challenge to be a woman there,\u201d she said in another video interview. \u201cI didn\u2019t notice this at Vassar because it was all women, but in medical school, a woman, when a question was tossed out, would answer it, and it would be as if talking into the wind \u2014 hadn\u2019t happened. Later on a man would say the same thing \u2014 the same thing! \u2014 and they\u2019d say, God, John, that was so fabulous.\u201d\n\nAt Yale, she met David Hamburg, a fellow medical student. They married in 1951. He survives her, along with a son, Eric, a filmmaker; and a daughter, Margaret Hamburg, who was Food and Drug Administration commissioner under President Barack Obama.\n\nBeatrix Hamburg\u2019s research dealt with a wide range of issues, including diabetes in children and teenage pregnancy. All of her work demonstrated an appreciation for the stresses of being a child in a complex modern world. A 1972 paper written with Barbara B. Varenhorst reported the results of an experimental peer-counseling program that trained high school and junior high school students to help other students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPeer counselors were not conceived of merely as academic tutors,\u201d the authors wrote, \u201cbut viewed as assistants in solving personal problems; teaching social skills; giving information about jobs, volunteer opportunities, and mental health resources in the community; acting as models; developing friendships; acting as a bridge to the adult world for disaffected students; and finally, over a period of time, serving as agents of change where the school atmosphere is characterized by coldness and indifference.\u201d\n\nThat same understanding of the difficulties young people face was evident in \u201cViolence in American Schools,\u201d a 1998 compilation she edited with Delbert S. Elliott and Kirk R. Williams. It argued that ending shootings and other forms of school violence required a coordinated effort involving not just schools, but also families and the community at large.\n\nThe year after that book came out, the mass shooting at Columbine High School in Colorado occurred. In an interview with The Boston Globe that year, Dr. Hamburg talked about what parents could do to keep their children from turning to violence.\n\n\u201cThey should recognize they\u2019re smaller players in the lives of their kids than they ever have been, with the impact of peers, TV and the internet,\u201d she said. \u201cBut it\u2019s very important to be warm, to be attentive, to listen, to teach them respect, and to deal with them in a mode \u2014 when kids get angry and yell \u2014 that exemplifies conflict resolution at home.\u201d\n\n\u201cAvoid allowing them to become tyrants in the home,\u201d she added. \u201cHang in there. And recognize you can\u2019t do it all.\u201d", "title": "Beatrix Hamburg, Barrier-Breaking Scholar, Is Dead at 94", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The news of the raid caught them off guard, according to the person briefed on the discussions, undercutting the \u201cfundamental assumptions\u201d that had guided the negotiations. Trust with Mr. Mueller\u2019s team has been \u201cdamaged,\u201d the person said.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s advisers have considered the search warrants against Mr. Cohen as extensive overreach. That the warrants were handled by the United States attorney\u2019s office for the Southern District of New York suggested to them that Mr. Mueller and his team were using a federal prosecutor\u2019s office as a cover to go after Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s team had been told of distinct \u201cbuckets\u201d of issues that Mr. Mueller\u2019s team sought to discuss with the president, primarily related to Michael T. Flynn, the national security adviser who resigned under pressure; Russia; and the broader question of obstruction of justice, according to people familiar with the discussions.\n\nBut the issue of Mr. Cohen was never raised, they said.\n\nThe Trump advisers have not broken off discussions with the Mueller team, but they are devising a new strategy. Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers had advised the president against participating in a wide-ranging interview, putting them at odds with Mr. Trump, who has said publicly and privately that he is eager to speak with Mr. Mueller. But the president\u2019s interest in doing so has decreased.\n\nTy Cobb, a lawyer for the White House counsel\u2019s office, declined to comment, suggesting only that the two sides continued to speak. Peter Carr, a spokesman for the special counsel\u2019s office, declined to comment.", "title": "Before Learning of Raid, Trump\u2019s Legal Team Convened to Discuss Mueller Interview", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Batsh, who in 2013 co-wrote a paper on drone applications, had been sent there to research and acquire weapon systems and drones for Hamas, the intelligence officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity to discuss a classified program.\n\nMossad has been particularly interested in Hamas\u2019s advances in unmanned aerial and underwater vehicles, the officials said, which could be used to attack Israeli targets more effectively than the rockets Hamas used during its last wars with Israel.\n\nIsrael has distanced itself from allegations that it was responsible for Mr. Batsh\u2019s death. Defense Minister Avigdor Lieberman blamed the assassination on internal rivalries within the Palestinian leadership.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Malaysian Connection\n\nThe killing of Mr. Batsh, 34, in the Kuala Lumpur suburb of Gombak, known locally as Little Arabia, is bringing to light not only the increasing presence of Hamas and other groups here, but also Malaysia\u2019s emergence as an epicenter of international intrigue.\n\nThis was the second high-profile assassination in the Malaysian capital in little more than a year. In February 2017, Kim Jong-nam, the half brother of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, was killed at Kuala Lumpur International Airport by two women who prosecutors said smeared a deadly nerve agent on his face. The women, from Indonesia and Vietnam, are on trial for his death, but at least seven North Koreans suspected of being linked to the killing escaped or were allowed to leave the country, officials said.\n\nMalaysia is also known as a port for contraband, ranging from North Korean weapons to endangered animal products and illegally felled trees.\n\n\u201cIt has been a permissive environment for many rogue actors, as long as their focus was not directed within Malaysia,\u201d said Zachary Abuza, a professor at the National War College in Washington who studies Southeast Asian security issues.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMalaysia\u2019s government has for decades been sympathetic to the Palestinian cause: It has no diplomatic relations with Israel, and Prime Minister Najib Razak visited Gaza in 2013 at the invitation of Hamas, which governs the territory. The intelligence officials said that Hamas, in recent years, had begun seeing the country as an ideal place to incubate its research ambitions.\n\nIn another case, in 2010, Palestinians who had been sent to Malaysia trained in paragliding as a potential tool for attacks, according to a statement from the Israeli secret service. Malaysian officials denied any involvement in such a plot.\n\nThe United Malays National Organization, or UMNO, the dominant party in the coalition that has ruled Malaysia since independence, has maintained relations with an unusual array of political organizations around the world. Until Mr. Kim\u2019s assassination last year at the Kuala Lumpur International Airport, for instance, UMNO sustained a formal relationship with North Korea\u2019s ruling Workers\u2019 Party. Malaysia was one of the few nations in the world that North Koreans could enter without a visa.\n\nThe relationship between UMNO and Hamas is even more overt. Representatives from Hamas are invited every year to UMNO\u2019s party conference.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Kind Professor\n\nColleagues and students of Mr. Batsh in Malaysia, where he lived with his wife, Enaas al-Batsh, and their three young children, characterized him as a kind professor who was dedicated to improving life in his native Gaza. His public research focused on renewable energy, and he spoke about wanting to bring abundant electricity to a Palestinian territory always short of power.\n\nMr. Batsh won scholarships from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund, the first Arab to earn such an honor. In 2016, Mr. Najib, the Malaysian prime minister, presented Mr. Batsh with an award.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know about his politics back at home, but I know that he was a very big inspiration for all of us for making it out of Gaza and succeeding in Malaysia,\u201d said Jailani Othman al-Kathery, a Yemeni English teacher who attended a mosque in Gombak where Mr. Batsh taught Quran classes and served as an imam.\n\nMr. Batsh told friends in Malaysia that he had narrowly avoided an attempt on his life while still living in Gaza. In 2014, his uncle, Tayseer al-Batsh, the Gaza police chief, was nearly killed by Israeli airstrikes. Eighteen members of the Batsh family died in those raids.\n\nBut Mr. Batsh did not dwell on his family\u2019s tragedy, his friends in Malaysia said, though he wrote social media posts criticizing Israel over the conflict with Gaza. \u201cMost everyone in Gaza has lost a member of the family,\u201d said Hafidzi Mohammed Noor, chairman of Humanitarian Care Malaysia, a charity that provides humanitarian assistance to Gaza. \u201cFor him, for all the Palestinians here in Malaysia, this is normal.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver the weekend, a mourning tent was set up in the Jabaliya refugee camp in Gaza, where Mr. Batsh grew up. Ten masked members of the Qassam Brigades, Hamas\u2019s armed wing, were stationed in front of the tent, a positioning that usually denotes the death of a top fighter.\n\nBanners hung in the tent described Mr. Batsh as an \u201cengineer commander\u201d for the Qassam Brigades and \u201cour martyr to God.\u201d Another relative of Mr. Batsh\u2019s was said by family members to be a commander in Islamic Jihad, a separate militant group that operates in Gaza.\n\nOn the day he was killed, Mr. Batsh was supposed to travel to Istanbul to attend an academic conference. One Middle Eastern intelligence official, however, said that Hamas\u2019s efforts to cultivate its scientists living abroad were directed from Istanbul, and that Mr. Batsh was scheduled to meet with the head of the unit, Maher Salah, upon arrival in Turkey.\n\nWestern and Middle Eastern intelligence officials said that Mr. Batsh may have been involved in negotiating North Korean arms deals through Malaysia. Egypt recently seized a shipment of North Korean communications components used for guided munitions destined for Gaza, they said. One intelligence official said that Mr. Batsh had helped mediate the deal.\n\nAlthough such weapons are under international sanctions, the United Nations said in a report last year that a shell company run by North Korea\u2019s intelligence agency had been hawking military-grade communications systems from Malaysia.\n\nMalaysian officials rejected that report. And this week, officials here would not comment on the claims that Mr. Batsh had been researching or trying to buy weapons systems.\n\nPhoto\n\nHamas Abroad\n\nMr. Batsh is not the first Hamas-linked engineer to be targeted abroad.\n\nIn 2011, a Palestinian electrical engineer named Dirar Abu Sisi was abducted in Ukraine and ended up in an Israeli jail more than a week later. He was sentenced to 21 years in prison for aiding Hamas in its manufacture of missiles, among other convictions.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2016, Mohammed Zawahri, a Tunisian scientist and Hamas military commander who was said to be developing aerial and underwater drone warfare technology, was shot dead in the Tunisian city of Sfax. In January, a car bomb injured Mohammed Hamdan, a Hamas operative who was said to be building a workshop to produce missile parts and drones in Sidon, Lebanon.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Wednesday, the Malaysian police said that the motorcycle used in Mr. Batsh\u2019s murder had not been stolen. But many declined to go on the record with their criticism.\n\nDanny Lams, a former Dutch paratrooper and chairman of a veterans\u2019 organization, condemned the plans.\n\n\u201cYou do not go to a war zone with men who miss their mama,\u201d he told The Guardian. \u201cWe used to sleep on the cold ground under a leaky tarpaulin. We wanted to serve our country.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you allow the recruits to go home during the week, the military will soon ask for a mobile home if they are sent to the front,\u201d he added.\n\nBelgium would be the first country in modern Western military history to make such a move, according to experts from the European Defense Agency, which monitors defense capabilities of European Union member states.\n\n\u201cEvery army trains to go to war, and there will be no sleeping at home when you go to war,\u201d said Vir Maram, 35, a reservist corporal of the French Foreign Legion who served several tours under the command of Western armies and NATO in Afghanistan, Iraq and Mali and who is studying international security in Brussels.\n\n\u201cAn army evolves with the way that it fights,\u201d he added, \u201cbut the only thing that changes are the weapons we fight with \u2014 the nature of war itself doesn\u2019t change, and so the basic principles of the army don\u2019t change.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMilitary service was mandatory in Belgium until 1994 for men turning 18 or ending their studies for one year. Since then, the head count of the country\u2019s armed forces has gradually diminished, to about 28,500 active personnel from 40,000.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBelgium now has about 2.6 soldiers per 1,000 civilians, fewer than many of its NATO allies. And the average age has crept up.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s almost like a Dad\u2019s Army,\u201d said Roger Housen, a retired colonel in the Belgian armed forces, referring to a television comedy about the British Home Guard, a World War II volunteer force made up of men exempt from conscription, often because they were considered too old to fight.\n\n\u201cThe army is right to try to attract more youngsters, as many senior personnel will retire over the next five years,\u201d Colonel Housen said. But the requirement to live in barracks, he said, was not the main factor driving young people away.\n\nAbout 20 percent to 25 percent of recruits chose to end their contracts early, official army statistics show, but only 16 percent of those who leave say they do so because of \u201cfamily reasons.\u201d\n\nMore important, Colonel Housen said, was the effect of cuts in the Belgian defense budget over the past decades, which meant that \u201cyoung people don\u2019t have the appropriate equipment, they lack the means to train in a convenient way, they don\u2019t have the right garrisons, the right training infrastructure, they don\u2019t have the required readiness.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs a matter of fact, they can\u2019t do the things they want to do, and the things they joined the armed forces for,\u201d he added.\n\nMr. Claesen, the army spokesman, said that a growing economy and increasingly lucrative civilian jobs for young people had kept many millennials away from the military. Others, he added, deem the prospect of patrolling the streets of Antwerp and Brussels under the country\u2019s continuing counterterrorism operation, Vigilant Guardian, not adventurous enough.\n\nBelgium\u2019s military expenditure as a share of gross domestic product was 0.91 percent in 2017, down from almost 1 percent in 2010, the second-lowest proportion in NATO, after Luxembourg; NATO guidelines request 2 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout 1,000 Belgian troops are currently active abroad: Forty soldiers are stationed in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan, and 100 others are training local forces in Mali. Every six months, six Belgian F-16 fighter jets take turns with Dutch warplanes to patrol the air space above Iraq and Syria and to carry out bombing raids against Islamic State targets. Belgian ships regularly take part in missions to control the international waters off the coast of Europe.\n\n\u201cContributions to NATO operations are important,\u201d said Oana Lungescu, the senior spokeswoman for NATO. \u201cBut so are defense spending and having the right capabilities.\u201d\n\nAs for Mr. Maram, the Legionnaire, he said: \u201cIn the French Foreign Legion, we stay in the barracks for the first five years.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat do you want next, the army can go on strike? You want unions in the army?\u201d he said, bursting into laughter. \u201cHow I hate the 21st century!\u201d", "title": "Belgium May Have New Appeal for Millennials: Join the Army and Sleep at Home", "authors": ["Milan Schreuer"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "It was the schools and activities outside of school that appealed to Mandy and Ricardo Suero, now 36 and 38, who moved from an apartment in Sunnyside, Queens, when they were expecting their third child, in 2011. They bought a four-bedroom, two-bath Cape Cod for $300,000, after ruling out similarly priced homes on Long Island.\n\nMs. Suero said she was happy that her children, ages 15, 10 and 6, feel challenged in school, and that class sizes are small. Both parents coach local baseball. And Ms. Suero, an event planner, said her husband, an elevator mechanic in Manhattan, has an easier ride on an early-morning New Jersey Transit bus than he would have had on the Long Island Rail Road.\n\nThe diversity \u2014 there are sizable numbers of Hispanic, Filipino and Orthodox Jewish residents \u2014 has also been a welcoming feature. \u201cFor us, this feels like home in the sense that it\u2019s similar to Queens,\u201d Ms. Suero said. \u201cOur children continue to learn about their Hispanic culture, and others.
