Because the organization running it is a nonprofit owned by the galleries themselves, the participation fee is deliberately kept low: This year, it\u2019s 7,500 euros (about $9,200). That allows small and midsize galleries to enjoy the attention of art-world professionals (though galleries that take part are selected by the organizers).\n\n[READ MORE: In Berlin, Artists Find a Home]\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of artists and critics and curators living in Berlin who might not really be able to afford life in most other comparable cities in the world,\u201d said Philomene Magers, a founder of the Spr\u00fcth Magers Gallery, one of Berlin\u2019s most prominent. \u201cIt is really important to bring an international crowd to Berlin which interacts with them.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cObviously, the galleries profit from the same people coming,\u201d she added, and not just financially: Gallery Weekend is \u201ca magnet for international curators\u201d who could later show the work of artists they see.\n\nEncouraged in part by the event\u2019s success, Berlin\u2019s gallerists have in the last few years raised their game architecturally. The Esther Schipper Gallery and Blain/Southern Gallery have spaces in what was once the printing site and warehouse of Berlin\u2019s Der Tagesspiegel newspaper.\n\n[READ MORE: In Berlin, Looking at a Familiar Art Collection With New Eyes]\n\nThe K\u00f6nig Gallery is based out of the disused St. Agnes church, a striking 1960s work of Brutalist concrete in a formerly working-class area. \u201cNobody knew what to do with this massive space,\u201d Mr. K\u00f6nig said. \u201cAfter a long process of negotiation, we bought it, fixed it and commissioned an architect to make it usable.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Konrad Fischer Gallery (which is moving into a new warehouse space) is showing Carl Andre and Lawrence Weiner, while Spr\u00fcth Magers is putting the African-American artist Kara Walker in the spotlight. Ms. Walker is presenting a movie with shadow puppets called \u201cFall Frum Grace, Miss Pipi\u2019s Blue Tale,\u201d dealing with the oppression of African-American women in United States history.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBerlin\u2019s relative affordability has meant that it\u2019s witnessing fewer gallery shutdowns than cities like New York and London. Still, what is the future for an event that focuses exclusively on art galleries, considered something of a dying model in other capitals?\n\n\u201cIf people cannot participate in art fairs anymore, they will concentrate more and more on these kinds of events that are cheap and that happen in their own gallery,\u201d said Ms. Kruse.\n\nMr. K\u00f6nig added that the event \u201cis a model for destinations which are not financial capitals and don\u2019t host the big auctions like London or New York.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe concept fits Berlin very well,\u201d he added, \u201cbecause Berlin is a city of artists more than it is a city of collectors.\u201d", "title": "Berlin Galleries Find a Way to Lure the World", "authors": ["Farah Nayeri"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe real question is why it happened and it\u2019s no secret: Everybody underestimated the backlash that would come to the first African-American president,\u201d he said.\n\nAs Mr. Sanders seeks to gain support from black voters, the Jackson forum was also notable for what the senator did not say to the audience, which skewed young and was almost evenly divided between blacks and whites.\n\nWhile briefly noting that Dr. King had been a \u201cmajor political inspiration\u201d for him, Mr. Sanders said nothing about his history as a civil rights activist and his arrest demonstrating against segregation as a college student.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the No. 1 selling point,\u201d said Teneia Sanders Eichelberger, who plays in a husband-wife band here and supported Mr. Sanders in 2016. \u201cFor me and for my grandmother, who\u2019s 82, she loved that about him.\u201d\n\nBut unless they already knew about Mr. Sanders\u2019s connection to the movement, hundreds of would-be Democratic primary voters left the gathering none the wiser. (Mrs. Clinton won the 2016 Mississippi Democratic primary with nearly 83 percent of the vote; Mr. Sanders took 16.5 percent.)\n\nPart of Mr. Sanders\u2019s appeal is that he is not a typical, lip-biting politician, ever on the lookout to find a personal connection with any audience. But his relentless focus on the policy dimensions of social justice, which has been the animating cause of his life, can also deprive him of creating bonds that can be essential, especially in building a multiracial coalition.\n\n\u201cYes, I\u2019m a fairly private person and I don\u2019t like to talk about every aspect of my life,\u201d Mr. Sanders acknowledged in a dressing room interview after the forum. \u201cI think a lot of politicians do that in a way that is not appropriate.\u201d\n\nUpon hearing the suggestion that recounting his own youthful activism would be compelling to an audience full of younger voters becoming activists in their own right, he all but rolled his eyes.", "title": "Bernie Sanders Courts Black Voters Anew. A fixture on the women\u2019s tennis tour, Sands can usually be found at his wife\u2019s side. He attends almost all of her matches and training sessions, and he was immediately on court consoling her that day at Wimbledon when Mattek-Sands, the No. 1-ranked women\u2019s doubles player at the time, screamed out in a combination of pain and fear after her right knee buckled.\n\nSix months later, Sands followed his wife onto the operating table for the couple\u2019s second right knee operation in less than a year. And for the past few weeks, they have been doing their recovery work in tandem. They hook up to the same electric wave-therapy machine, they warm up and stretch together, and they do some of the same exercises, like the agonizing wall-sits to build strength in their quad muscles. And, of course, they have matching scars.\n\nThe family that rehabilitates together stays together.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s pretty similar how you rehab for the two injuries,\u201d Sands said.\n\nSands, who runs his own insurance business, was a defensive lineman at the University of Albany and later tried out for the Arena Football League and N.F.L. teams as a long snapper. He never made it, but he knows about training and recovery \u2014 he had previous knee injuries as a player.", "title": "Bethanie Mattek-Sands\u2019s Husband Follows Her Everywhere. Even the Operating Table.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Bette Midler will return to Broadway, playing another six weeks in the title role of \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d before the revival closes this summer.\n\nScott Rudin, the show\u2019s lead producer, said early Friday he would close the show on Aug. 25, about 17 months after performances began. The show opened to strong reviews and won four Tony Awards, including for best musical revival and for Ms. Midler\u2019s performance.\n\nMs. Midler, who played the title role until January, will return on July 17. She will succeed Bernadette Peters, who has been playing the role since Ms. Midler departed the cast; Ms. Peters\u2019s final performance will be July 15.\n\nDavid Hyde Pierce and Gavin Creel will also rejoin the cast as Horace Vandergelder and Cornelius Hackl. Mr. Creel had also won a Tony Award for his performance.", "title": "Bette Midler to Return to \u2018Hello, Dolly!\u2019 This Summer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. Julia Moskin has a beautiful treatise on beef stew (above) in The Times today, a considered and deeply reported examination of the European style of slowly cooking the dish in a Dutch oven. \u201cThe meat softens, but never collapses or becomes stringy,\u201d she writes. \u201cThe liquid and the aromatics are fused into the kind of rich, complex sauce that professional chefs used to spend decades trying to achieve.\u201d\n\nOf course there is a recipe. You ought to make it soon, in your own Dutch oven, your own cocotte. (Julia did try making the dish in an electric pressure cooker, just to see. She knew you\u2019d ask about that. Eating the Instant Pot version, she wrote, \u201cwas rather like wearing a perfect knockoff of an expensive handbag.\u201d It was pretty great, in other words. But Julia could tell the difference and so will you.)\n\nIn other new recipe news, David Tanis has a fine one for spiced lamb shanks with oranges and honey, which you may well wish to cook this weekend, a kind of celebration of spring at long last.\n\nBut for this evening, midweek and harried, perhaps Molly O\u2019Neill\u2019s great old recipe for chicken Marsala with mushrooms will answer more loudly. It\u2019s delicious. (If you have slightly more time, try this recipe for shoemaker\u2019s chicken, which we learned from the kitchen at Rao\u2019s in East Harlem.)", "title": "Better Beef Stew", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The sled tests, which use test dummies, strongly suggest that rear-facing seats perform better than front-facing seats in children through age 3. In Sweden, children use rear-facing seats all the way till age 4, then move to front-facing booster seats. (Here in the United States, we use front-facing car seats from about 2 years old until children outgrow them.)\n\nHow do Swedish parents manage this? For one thing, rear-facing car seats in Sweden and other parts of Europe are different from those here. They are often built with a bar that comes down from the car seat to rest on the floor of the car. This allows the seat to rest farther from the back of the car\u2019s rear seat, giving the child much more room. Parents in Sweden find it easier to get bigger children into them. Such seats, which are not available in the United States, were also found to be safer in the sled tests than the versions we use.\n\nBut rear-facing car seats for older children are just one of the many differences between the United States and Sweden.\n\nBecause accidents are inevitable, Swedish regulations aim to make them nonlethal. Roads rely more on roundabouts, less on intersections. Cars are not allowed to turn at all when pedestrians are crossing. There are national camera enforcement policies. Sweden also focuses on pedestrian bridges, and separates cars from bicycles and oncoming traffic.\n\nFar fewer people drive under the influence of alcohol; stricter policing has reduced impaired driving to less than 0.25 percent of tested drivers vs. about 1.5 percent of American drivers. (Sweden also has a more stringent definition of driving under the influence, 0.02 percent vs. 0.08 percent.) The speed limit in areas where cars might come into contact with pedestrians (think all of New York City) is less than 20 m.p.h. Speed bumps and other traffic-calming interventions are common. The average cost of obtaining a driver\u2019s license is the equivalent of more than $1,800.\n\nAll of this seems to work. Over the last 20 years, Sweden reduced pedestrian deaths by 31 percent and overall traffic deaths by 45 percent. In 2013, Sweden\u2019s rate of death from car accidents was about 3 per 100,000 people, about one-quarter the rate in the United States. But Swedes are not necessarily satisfied with that. They have bought into a program known as \u201cVision Zero,\u201d which is summarized in one sentence: \u201cNo loss of life is acceptable.\u201d", "title": "Better Car Seats Are Just the Start: Road Safety Lessons From Sweden", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cActually, You Can Fix Stupid,\u201d by Timothy Egan (column, March 31):\n\nYes, Americans are shockingly lacking in civic awareness.\n\nYes, our schools can and should do a better job of preparing students to be participating citizens.\n\nBut an overemphasis on STEM education is not to blame. Science, taught well, shows young people how to use valid evidence to support conclusions and how to discern when preconceived notions taint observations. These are essential features of both scientific investigation and citizenship.\n\nThere is, however, an overemphasis on consequential testing, which prioritizes short, quick-response answers over deliberation and elaboration, and prioritizes test scores over authentic learning.\n\nA better mix of science education to make sense of the natural world and social studies to makes sense of how people live in the world can go a long way toward developing more effective citizens. Automatically registering all 18-year-olds as voters would help, too.", "title": "Opinion | Better Education, to Prepare Better Citizens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "For his own use, Mr. Svenson bought a two-bedroom, one-bathroom 19th-century house in North Adams for $116,900 last winter and gut renovated it for about $67,000, exposing the original wooden posts and beams. It now serves as a second home, but he plans to move to North Adams full time in August with his wife and sons, 3 and 5, after the arrival of their third child this summer.\n\nA short stroll away is another 19th-century home he owns: a four-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bathroom house he got in a foreclosure auction for $77,700, and then spent about $40,000 renovating. Ms. Burns now lives there.\n\nMr. Svenson is at work on a number of other houses in the area, and has helped find second homes for dazzled friends. He has the growing sense that they are not the only ones interested in putting down roots in the Berkshires. \u201cYou feel it and see it everywhere now,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s something brewing here.\u201d\n\nFigures from the Berkshire County Board of Realtors back up that assertion. Last year, the total number of single-family home sales in Berkshire County rose to 1,374, the highest number since the organization began tracking sales in 1997. The average sales price of those homes jumped 8 percent over that in 2016, to $279,557. And in February, the number of active listings for single-family homes declined to 872, the lowest inventory has been in 13 years.\n\nThere are marked differences, however, between the affluent southern part of the county, which includes the manicured estates and picturesque towns of Great Barrington, Lenox and Stockbridge (literally Norman Rockwell country \u2014 the artist lived in Stockbridge from 1953 until his death in 1978, and his museum remains), where the average home price was $426,600 in 2017, and the rest of the county, where some cities are still struggling to recover from the departure of manufacturing jobs decades ago.\n\nIn the slightly scruffier central part of the county, including Pittsfield, the largest city in the Berkshires, the average sales price last year was $197,667. In the northern part of the county, anchored by North Adams, where 18.9 percent of the population is living in poverty and the median household income is $32,804, according to United States Census Bureau data, the average sales price was lower still, at $186,388.", "title": "Betting on the Berkshires", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "And in between those sets, another milestone moment: The first Pulitzer Prize for music awarded outside of classical or jazz went to Kendrick Lamar, for his album \u201cDAMN.\u201d It was both a significant shift in perspective for the prize, and also an after-the-fact arrival for hip-hop into yet another hallowed hall. (And while we\u2019re here, it was also an implicit rebuke to the Grammys, which have also consistently denied Mr. Lamar its top honor.)\n\nTo talk about Beyonc\u00e9\u2019s breakthrough performance and Mr. Lamar\u2019s Pulitzer Prize on this week\u2019s Popcast, Mr. Caramanica is joined by Doreen St. F\u00e9lix, a staff writer for The New Yorker, and Salamishah Tillet, an associate professor of English and Africana Studies at the University of Pennsylvania and a regular contributor to The New York Times. And to discuss the history of the Pulitzer Prize for music, Mr. Caramanica is joined by Zachary Woolfe, the classical music editor for The Times.", "title": "Beyonc\u00e9 and Kendrick Lamar Break Boundaries", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "She also amplified Malcolm X\u2019s famous words about black women: \u201cThe most disrespected woman in America is the black woman. The most unprotected person in America is the black woman. The most neglected person in America is the black woman.\u201d This centering of black womanhood is not what black people have been taught to do when given as much power and attention as Beyonc\u00e9 has.\n\nIt would have been reasonable to assume Beyonc\u00e9 would perform the entire show in a glamorous couture number, like the Nefertiti-inspired costume she came onstage in. Respectability is also imagery: Black people are told, when we gain power, and are under the gaze of the public, we must always wear our most formal and elegant attire.\n\nInstead, with millions of people watching in the desert and online, Beyonc\u00e9 reappeared in blue distressed denim shorts and a hoodie advertising a fake historically black college. Success does not need to have a preferred style; a black person does not have to wear a glamorous gown or a tailored suit to captivate the imagination of the public. Beyonc\u00e9 shows that talent and discipline are enough.\n\nShe follows in the tradition of black performers like Michael Jackson and Tina Turner, but she is unique in imagining blackness as something so big. To Beyonc\u00e9, attending a historically black college is more than a niche experience coveted only by students and alumni. Instead, it\u2019s something thematically paramount and worthy of an enormous stadium.\n\nYou might think that Beyonc\u00e9\u2019s promotion of historically black colleges and their intellectual traditions also might have conflicted with her sexually charged songs like \u201cPartition\u201d and \u201cDrunk in Love.\u201d We\u2019re taught that an intellectual being can never be sexual one. This is especially true for black people who have been hypersexualized in media and daily life. So it wouldn\u2019t have been odd for her to edit her sexuality to fit society\u2019s ideas of what it means to be proud, black and smart.\n\nNot at Coachella. Beyonc\u00e9 performed her sensuality proudly in those songs making political statement that a person can be both intellectually rigorous and sexually expressive.\n\nWe know Beyonc\u00e9 can sing and move, and that she treats stadiums as if they are her living room. But it wasn\u2019t clear whether, after Clive Davis called her \u201cthe first lady of music,\u201d she would adhere to respectability politics, especially on a stage like Coachella, where she may have alienated a large portion of her audience. The easier route would have been cultural ambiguity. But excellence is found in risk, and Beyonc\u00e9 has proved to be an artist most interested in excellence.", "title": "Opinion | Beyonc\u00e9 and the End of Respectability Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The first requirement to push a child to a higher level of sport is a lot of money. When asked about the cost of her sons\u2019 hockey training, Dawn-Marie Movalli laughed. \u201cAn arm and a leg,\u201d she said.\n\nHer husband said $10,000 a year would be on the low end. But that is just for the hockey program and skates. It does not include the two homes they maintain and the costs associated with traveling to games, which could require hotel stays over a weekend and hours on the road or in an airplane. The Movallis rent a home from another family that uprooted for a child: Kiley McKinnon, an Olympic snowboarder who trains in Park City, Utah.\n\nEach sport has its own expenses. Jane Hill declined to say how much her daughter\u2019s riding cost, but said the family owned and leased several horses and traveled around the Southeast for competitions. Maggie said she could ride four or five horses in a competition.\n\nBecause these athletes are still children, parents are likely to pay for private school or tutors. Maggie Hill is taking high school classes through an online program at Laurel Springs School and working with private tutors in Wellington.\n\nThere are also private schools geared toward children who want to focus on athletics. They often charge the same rate as top New York private schools: Tuition is $54,000 at Stratton Mountain School in Vermont, which focuses on winter sports, and $59,000 at Spire Academy in Geneva, Ohio, which specializes in basketball, track and field, and swimming.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn some sports, children can pay their own way. Brock Crouch, an 18-year-old based at Mammoth Mountain, Calif., several hours east of San Francisco, has been snowboarding since he was 3. His sponsors have paid his travel expenses for the past three or four years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that did not cover all the financial obligations, said Denise Crouch, his mother. She lived with her son in Mammoth Mountain while he trained, while her husband and other son were 400 miles away in Carlsbad, Calif. \u201cYou still have two houses with expenses,\u201d she said.\n\nAnd there are other indirect costs.\n\nParents need flexible jobs. The Movallis, for instance, own their own technology company, Orion Systems, which allows them to work remotely and travel back if necessary. Ms. Crouch said that when her son was starting out, she was allowed to work remotely for three months a year in Mammoth. But after Brock began to travel internationally for competitions, her husband quit his job of 20 years working for a commercial contractor so he could travel with him.\n\nMs. Hill said her husband, Thomas, the chief executive of Summit Materials, a building materials company, commuted to Denver, where the company is based.\n\nThere are often other children to consider, too. In some of these families, younger siblings followed older ones into the same sport.\n\nJustin Movalli started playing hockey a decade ago. But it was his younger brother\u2019s interest that was the impetus for the family to move to Connecticut so Connor could get started at the elite level sooner than his brother had.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut some siblings never develop the appetite. Ms. Hill said her younger daughter enjoyed riding a horse when they lived in Wyoming but did not share her sister\u2019s passion for the sport. But she said moving to Wellington, where Maggie trained, had brought everyone together.\n\n\u201cFlorida is the place where we could rebalance our family,\u201d she said.\n\nFor many of these families, relocating can save on travel costs.\n\nJustin Movalli said he had moved to Kansas City at age 17 to play hockey and live with a family there. His parents paid a fee to the host family, which receives about $500 a month for taking in a young hockey player. But then he was bused all over the Midwest to play games. His younger brother benefits from living in Connecticut, where his games are closer to home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter all of the expenses and time spent, there is no guarantee of professional success. Managing expectations can be among the costliest things to do.\n\nThe sports schools say they are, in some ways, the managers of overinflated expectations. They essentially serve as curators of talent, placing one child athlete into the mix of others who may be more gifted.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll get 200 inquiries a year, and we\u2019ll assess them,\u201d said Christopher G. Kaltsas, headmaster of the Stratton Mountain School. He stressed that the program, which accepts about 40 applicants a year, was not going to turn every student into an Olympian or a member of the United States national team. Some would simply go on to top schools with sports programs.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re turning them into incredible athletes,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we\u2019re also focused on time management. The application of those traits extends far beyond us.\u201d\n\nRon Clutter, founder and chief executive of Spire Academy, said the school and its related training facility had 16 athletes in the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. That\u2019s catnip for parents and children alike.\n\nBut he said that for many student athletes, the best they might hope for would be playing at a college where they were paying their own way.\n\n\u201cSome parents have grander visions for their kids but don\u2019t understand what the real world is like,\u201d Mr. Clutter said. \u201cThey quickly learn there are a lot of athletes around them that are as good or better than they are.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cWorking with the parent is just as hard as working with the athlete.\u201d\n\nBrock Crouch said that he had missed the Olympic team for slopestyle snowboarding by two spots, but that he planned to try again in four years. Until then, being a professional in his sport allows him to travel and enjoy himself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRight now, I\u2019m making a film for Snowboarder Magazine,\u201d he said. \u201cI envision myself being in a few more movies and having as much fun as I can, being in some contests over the next two years. Then two years before the Olympics, I\u2019ll try to buckle down.\u201d\n\nJustin Movalli said he would be a freshman in the fall at Framingham State University in Massachusetts, where he would play hockey.\n\n\u201cMy career has been so all over the map,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m happy how it turned out.\u201d", "title": "Beyond Soccer Moms: Relocating for a Child\u2019s Sport", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The inquiry these fictitious people made was simple: They asked for local restaurant recommendations. We tracked whether hotel employees responded and also analyzed the content of the emails from those who did respond.\n\nAcross the range of responses, racial discrimination was clear. Overall, hotel employees were significantly more likely to respond to inquiries from people who had typically white names than from those who had typically black and Asian names. But racial bias did not end there. Discrimination also happened in many subtle ways.\n\nHotel employees provided 20 percent more restaurant recommendations to white than to black or Asian people. Employees\u2019 politeness also varied by race. When responding to white people, employees were more likely to address them by name and to end their emails with a complimentary close (e.g., \u201cBest,\u201d \u201cSincerely\u201d) than they were when responding to black or Asian people. And employees were more likely to go \u201cabove and beyond\u201d in their service: They were three times as likely to provide extra information \u2014 even when the initial inquiry was just about restaurants \u2014 to white than to black or Asian people.\n\nThe manager at Starbucks called the police with the claim that the two men were \u201crefusing to make a purchase.\u201d The manager did not believe that they were customers.\n\nOur research suggests that this belief \u2014 that a nonwhite person cannot or will not be a legitimate customer \u2014 can indeed worsen discrimination in service delivery. In a follow-up study, we emailed nearly 2,000 hotels and made a similar inquiry about local restaurants. But this time, in addition to varying the race of the inquirers, we varied whether they made clear their intention to stay at the hotel. Indeed, making customer status explicit helped reduce discrimination against minority people. These results are in line with the recent incident at Starbucks: We see that service workers do not apply the rule that every person is a potential customer deserving the same level of service.", "title": "Opinion | Beyond Starbucks: How Racism Shapes Customer Service", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhat It Was Like to Finally Write My Will,\u201d by John Schwartz (Sunday Business, April 8):\n\nWriting a will is the first step, but only the first, if you want to make unwinding your life and managing its assets and detritus as easy as possible for your executor. This person is probably your child. Though she\u2019s likely to be an adult when she assumes this task, it will remain daunting, time-consuming and emotionally draining.\n\nYou can help by maintaining a list of what she will need to know: your bank account, safe deposit box and credit card numbers and passwords; your health, home, car and life insurance policies and agents; your computer, laptop and cellphone passwords; how to reach your dog sitter, brokers, doctors, accountant and estate lawyer; your funeral wishes; and memberships, rewards programs and charitable pledges.\n\nThink of the subscriptions, appointments and prescriptions that will be automatically renewed, and payments that will be automatically debited, if they aren\u2019t stopped.\n\nNone of this business of living is in a will, but all of it must be sorted out. So, once your will is done, go to step two: Make a list of What You Need to Know. Someone will be glad you did.", "title": "Opinion | Beyond Writing a Will", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "My colleagues on the news side of The Times had a good expos\u00e9 yesterday on another example of oligopoly: the music business. Live Nation appears to be using its power to hurt both consumers and other industry players. And it\u2019s able to do so partly because the Obama administration allowed the company to merge with TicketMaster in 2010.\n\nWashington\u2019s lenient approach to corporate power in recent decades \u2014 from both parties \u2014 has aggravated inequality, and it\u2019s time for that approach to change. Fortunately, there are some early, if still tentative, signs that this may be changing. The Democrats have put antitrust policy at the center of their economic agenda. And the Trump administration actually has a more nuanced stance on antitrust than it does in many other areas, even if that stance is sometimes for the wrong reasons.\n\nIf you want to learn more about the issue, you can start with some of the pieces that Washington Monthly \u2014 a pioneer on this subject \u2014 has published. The Obama administration\u2019s Council of Economic Advisers and the Roosevelt Institute have also done good work.\n\nPodcast recommendation. Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation has reportedly widened to include efforts to influence American policy on behalf of the Saudi and Emirati governments. If you\u2019re trying to make sense of it all, I recommend Terry Gross\u2019s recent \u201cFresh Air\u201d interview with The Times\u2019s David Kirkpatrick, who helped break several of the stories.\n\nVehicle deaths. American society is far too willing to accept avoidable driving deaths, as I\u2019ve written before. The increase will represent a pay raise of 35 percent or 84 percent, depending on the player\u2019s classification.\n\nThe N.B.A. pays all player salaries in the G League.\n\nPlayers also will remain eligible to earn affiliate player bonuses worth as much as $50,000, which are triggered when a player goes to training camp with an N.B.A. team and then plays for that team\u2019s G League affiliate.", "title": "Big Pay Raises Coming for G League Players", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 South Africa\u2019s new president, Cyril Ramaphosa, who had traveled to London this week to assure global investors of his determination to tackle corruption in his country and restore faith in its public institutions, cut short his trip on Thursday to deal with unrest at home \u2014 a vivid indication of the challenges he faces.\n\nThe protests in the North West Province, in which demonstrators seeking better jobs and housing, and improved roads and hospitals, clashed with the police, were the biggest in the two months since Mr. Ramaphosa took office.\n\nHis predecessor, Jacob Zuma, was tarnished by scandal and deeply unpopular during much of his nearly nine-year tenure, and he was eventually forced out in a struggle within the leadership of the African National Congress, the party that has governed South Africa since the end of apartheid in constructing rule of not having part of the answer in the clue, but it doesn\u2019t. \u201cOpinion pieces\u201d is a perfectly cromulent clue for OP-EDS because the OP does not stand for \u201copinion.\u201d It stands for \u201copposite the editorial page.\u201d\n\n56A: Wordplay alert! \u201cPin money\u201d was a phrase that originally had to do with the money housewives set aside to buy pins for sewing, but note that the word PIN is in all capital letters. It\u2019s not being shouted at you; it\u2019s a hint that you\u2019re supposed to be thinking about a different kind of PIN, or a number that you might punch into an ATM.\n\n11D: Hi, kids! Back in the 1960s (Google it), there was a band called the Rolling Stones, and they were deep, man. They released a song called \u201cMother\u2019s Little Helper\u201d in 1966, in which they observed the trend of parental reliance on prescription medications to defer the psychological ramifications of aging, not that we, for one minute, are saying that this is a good thing to do. But there is that lyric \u201cWhat A DRAG it is getting old.\u201d We wouldn\u2019t know.", "title": "Big School Event", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Prosecutors on Friday seemed cognizant of the defense efforts to depict Ms. Constand in an unflattering light when they asked her why she had agreed to cooperate when they brought charges, even after securing a large financial settlement. \u201cFor justice,\u201d she replied.\n\nIn more than two hours on the stand, led by Kristen Gibbons Feden, a special prosecutor, Ms. Constand described how an older man she respected, and who was a major source of career guidance, had taken advantage of her trust.\n\nShe recalled meeting Mr. Cosby, a famous alumnus of Temple University, where she worked, during a basketball game in 2002. She was an administrator for the women\u2019s team, and she said he subsequently called her office and invited her to dinners at his homes in New York and Connecticut, which she attended. On two occasions, when they were alone, she said, she had rebuffed his advances.\n\nOnly once did she pause in her testimony, and that was just before she provided a graphic, detailed accounting of what she said happened at the Cosby home near Philadelphia in January 2004. Mr. Cosby gave her three blue pills, she said.\n\nShe testified that he said: \u201c\u2018Put \u2019em down. They will help you relax.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cI began to see double vision,\u201d she continued.\n\n\u201cI was very scared,\u201d she said. \u201cI didn\u2019t know what was happening, why I was feeling that way.\u201d\n\nHer court appearance followed several days of testimony from five other women who said they, too, believed Mr. Cosby had drugged and sexually assaulted them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs part of Mr. Cosby\u2019s defense, his lawyers have said they will bring forward an academic adviser at Temple, who said she had roomed with Ms. Constand during university basketball trips and that Ms. Constand had once told her before the incident with Mr. Cosby that she could fabricate a claim of sexual assault about a celebrity to get money.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe adviser, Marguerite Jackson, was barred from testifying at the first trial after Ms. Constand told the court she did not know her. But Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers are expected to challenge that testimony when they cross-examine Ms. Constand.\n\nProsecutors seemed interested in taking some of the sting out of that effort on Friday morning when they asked Ms. Constand about the adviser.\n\n\u201cI recognize the name,\u201d she said this time. But asked if she had ever roomed with Ms. Jackson, she said, \u201cNo.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn recent days, the defense has worked to find holes in the other women\u2019s testimony, suggesting that their accounts were not credible and were probably motivated by a desire for money or media attention.\n\nMr. Cosby, now 80, is not charged with assaulting the other five women who have testified, but prosecutors hoped to show a pattern of predatory behavior that eventually targeted Ms. Constand, now 45. At the first trial, prosecutors were allowed to introduce only one other accuser to bolster Ms. Constand\u2019s account.\n\nMr. Cosby has denied any inappropriate behavior and said the sex with Ms. Constand was consensual.\n\nAfter the encounter, Ms. Constand said, she went to his house several weeks later to confront him. Mr. Cosby discussed the night a bit, suggesting he thought she had had an orgasm, but then evaded her questions, Ms. Constand testified.\n\nAs Ms. Constand spoke, Mr. Cosby sometimes sat back in his chair at the defense table, listening carefully. At times, he stared at the ceiling as she spoke.\n\nMs. Constand said she had feared retaliation from Mr. Cosby if she were to speak out, but nearly a year later she told her mother what happened. Together, they spoke to Mr. Cosby, who, she said, admitted to giving her pills, penetrating her with his fingers, and using her hand to masturbate himself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAfter a very short time on the telephone with my mom there, he eventually apologized for doing what he did, but he would not tell us what he gave me,\u201d she said. \u201cHe said \u2018I don\u2019t know. I have to go check the prescription bottle.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Cosby has said the pills were Benadryl.\n\nUnder cross-examination by Thomas A. Mesereau Jr., a lawyer for Mr. Cosby, Ms. Constand was pressed to explain some discrepancies in her account, such as why she told Pennsylvania police that the encounter had occurred in March 2004, not January, as she had told Canadian authorities and has since insisted.\n\n\u201cI was just trying to recall an enormous amount of information,\u201d she said. \u201cI was nervous.\u201d\n\nIn one deposition in the civil case, Mr. Mesereau said Ms. Constand had recounted lying on the bed in Mr. Cosby\u2019s room at the hotel of a Connecticut venue where he was performing. In court Friday she said she had not.\n\n\u201cI was mistaken,\u201d Ms. Constand said. \u201cI was just trying to piece it together.\u201d\n\nMr. Mesereau suggested that Ms. Constand was the engine driving the relationship, that she flirted with him, accepted gifts of perfume and cashmere sweaters from Mr. Cosby, never asked about his wife and had a closer relationship with him than she was admitting, even visiting and calling him after what she had described as an assault.\n\n\u201cYou went back to the house with the person who assaulted you,\u201d he asked, \u201cand after that you had your family go to the theater with him?\u201d\n\nMs. Constand has said she only went to the house to confront him. She has said she accompanied her family to the theater because her parents \u2014 whom she still had not told of the encounter \u2014 wanted to see Mr. Cosby perform.", "title": "Bill Cosby Accuser Tells Jury: \u2018I Could Not Fight Him Off\u2019", "authors": ["Graham Bowley", "Jon Hurdle"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Bill Cosby, one of the world\u2019s best-known entertainers, was found guilty on Thursday of drugging and sexually assaulting a woman 14 years ago.\n\nThe jury convicted Mr. Cosby of three counts of aggravated indecent assault against Andrea Constand, at the time a Temple University employee he had mentored.\n\nDuring the trial, Ms. Constand became something of a proxy for other women, more than 50, who have accused Mr. Cosby of similar sexual misconduct. In the last few years, he has lost television deals, honorary college degrees and his reputation as \u201cAmerica\u2019s Dad.\u201d Now with the guilty verdict, he is facing possible prison time, up to 10 years, though the sentences could be served concurrently.", "title": "Bill Cosby Criminal Case: A Timeline From Accusation to Verdict", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "[Read reactions to the verdict.]\n\n\u201cEnough of that,\u201d Judge Steven T. O\u2019Neill said. He did not view Mr. Cosby as a flight risk, he said, adding that he could be released on bail but that he would have to remain in his nearby home. The judge did not set a date to sentence Mr. Cosby on the three counts, all felonies and each punishable by up to 10 years in state prison.\n\nThe National Organization for Women called the verdict a \u201cnotice to sexual predators everywhere.\u201d Rose McGowan, one of the women who has accused Harvey Weinstein of assault, tweeted a thank you to the judge and jury and to \u201csociety for waking up.\u201d Gloria Allred, the lawyer who represented many of Mr. Cosby\u2019s accusers, hailed the decision as an important breakthrough.\n\n\u201cAfter all is said and done, women were finally believed,\u201d she said outside the courtroom.\n\nThe impression of change was evident within the trial itself when the defense attacked the credibility of five women who had testified that they, too, believed Mr. Cosby had drugged and sexually assaulted them. Kathleen Bliss, one of Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers, called one of the women a failed starlet who slept around. She branded another a publicity seeker.\n\nThe remarks inflamed Kristen Gibbons Feden, a prosecutor on the case. She called the attacks filthy and shameful and the sort of criticism that had long kept sexual assault victims from coming forward. Ms. Feden\u2019s colleague, M. Stewart Ryan, described Ms. Bliss\u2019s approach as \u201cthe last vestiges of a tactic not to get to the truth, but to damage character and reputation.\u201d\n\nTheir boss, Kevin R. Steele, the Montgomery County district attorney, referenced the broader significance of the case when he thanked Ms. Constand for taking part in not one, but two trials. \u201cShe has been a major factor in a movement that has gone in the right direction, finally,\u201d he said.", "title": "Bill Cosby Is Found Guilty of Sexual Assault", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Dennis McAndrews, a Pennsylvania lawyer who has followed the case closely, said that the most likely scenario, because of Mr. Cosby\u2019s age and the similarity of the counts, is that Judge Steven T. O\u2019Neill will merge the counts and base the sentencing on just one count. As a result, Mr. Cosby will probably face a maximum sentence of 10 years.\n\nHow long will Mr. Cosby be free on bail?\n\nPhoto\n\nNo sentencing date has been set, but that would typically occur within two to three months. Until then, Mr. Cosby remains free on $1 million bail but is essentially confined by order of the court to his Pennsylvania home until the sentencing hearing.\n\nMs. Ashcroft said Mr. Cosby had not been shown any special treatment when he was allowed to leave on bail. Bail would have been revoked if he were an especially dangerous risk to society or was a flight risk. Where he did have an advantage was the ability to meet the $1 million bail, she said.\n\nNow his lawyers will probably ask Judge O\u2019Neill to postpone Mr. Cosby\u2019s incarceration until after their appeal to the Pennsylvania Superior Court is decided. Weighed against that, however, is any flight risk, something emphasized by the district attorney, Kevin R. Steele, at the trial on Thursday.\n\nIn the interim, experts said, Mr. Cosby will be classified as a sex offender and will be required to register with the state police.\n\nWhere might Mr. Cosby serve his sentence?\n\nInmates with short sentences often serve them in a county jail, but Mr. Cosby is likely to enter the state correctional system, experts said. Susan McNaughton, communications director for the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections, said the state has 22 institutions to care for men, and it was too early to say which one he would go to. All are set up to cope with elderly inmates, and there is no facility that is especially designated for such prisoners.\n\nWhat are the grounds for an appeal?\n\nPhoto\n\nSTATUTE OF LIMITATIONS Mr. Cosby\u2019s spokesman mentioned that issue as a likely ground for appeal in a conversation he had after the verdict. Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers argued in court that there is little evidence that the sexual encounter with Ms. Constand occurred in January 2004, as she testified. Any earlier and the state\u2019s 12-year statute of limitations would have expired by the time he was charged in December 2015.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTESTIMONY FROM THE FIVE ADDITIONAL WOMEN Ordinarily, prosecutors cannot introduce evidence or accusations of prior bad behavior. It is viewed as too prejudicial for a jury as it considers the facts of the single case before it. But here five women were allowed to describe their own encounters with Mr. Cosby. The judge did not provide a legal reasoning for his decision to allow five, compared with one other accuser he permitted to testify at the first trial, and the introduction of evidence like this has been allowed in other cases, but several experts said it is a likely target of the defense team.\n\n\u201cThis is an enormous issue that is going to be argued on appeal,\u201d said Shan Wu, a former sex-crimes prosecutor in Washington.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTHE JUDGE\u2019S REFUSAL TO RECUSE HIMSELF Defense lawyers had sought to have Judge O\u2019Neill replaced before the trial because the judge\u2019s wife has been an active supporter of sexual assault victims. Judge O\u2019Neill would not recuse himself, and experts said higher courts have typically not viewed spousal affiliations as grounds for judicial recusal, but the defense could revisit the topic.\n\nTHE DEFENSE\u2019S INABILITY TO INTRODUCE EVIDENCE FROM SHERI WILLIAMS Ms. Williams, a friend of Ms. Constand, testified during Ms. Constand\u2019s civil suit against Mr. Cosby. But Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers had sought to have her testify at the trial, and when they could not find her, they asked that her deposition testimony be read to the jury. It\u2019s unclear what the defense hoped to show with Ms. Williams\u2019s testimony, but The Associated Press reported that the defense thought it would show that Ms. Constand was not as unaware of Mr. Cosby\u2019s romantic intentions as she had indicated.\n\nThe judge denied, reasoning that prosecutors had been unable to cross-examine the witness when she gave the deposition. Mr. Wu said the defense\u2019s inability to produce this witness may be something they emphasize on appeal, especially since the prosecution was allowed to bring five prior bad acts witnesses.\n\nTHE JUROR WHO WAS KEPT ON Before the retrial started, the defense lawyers had asked to bar one of the jurors who had been selected to hear the case. They said the juror had been overheard by another prospective juror saying he thought Mr. Cosby was guilty. After several hours of discussion with both sides, Judge O\u2019Neill ruled that the juror could continue on the case, but he never made his reasoning publicly known.\n\nWhat happens to the civil suits?\n\nThe review of Mr. Cosby\u2019s behavior is now likely to shift to the arena of the civil courts, where he has been sued by several women. Many of the women are suing him for defamation because, they say, he or his staff branded them as liars by dismissing their allegations as fabrications. The suits had mostly been delayed, pending the outcome of the criminal trial but are now likely to draw momentum from the guilty verdict.", "title": "Bill Cosby Is Guilty. What\u2019s Next?", "authors": ["Graham Bowley"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "NORRISTOWN, Pa. \u2014 A jury of seven men and five women will sit at the retrial of Bill Cosby on sexual assault charges, a court here decided on Wednesday.\n\nAfter almost three days of jury selection, prosecutors and lawyers for Mr. Cosby agreed on the final member of the panel, a white man, ending a drawn-out process in which the defense team used all but one of its seven strikes. The jury selection was closely watched because Mr. Cosby\u2019s previous trial on the same charges ended last summer with a hung jury unable to reach a verdict after six days of deliberation.\n\nJurors this time were asked whether they had formed opinions about Mr. Cosby\u2019s guilt or innocence in the highly publicized case, whether they were already too influenced by the #MeToo movement and allegations of sexual misconduct in the entertainment industry, and whether they or a close family member had been a victim of a sexual assault.\n\nTwo of the 12 jurors \u2014 a man and a woman \u2014 are black; the rest are white. All are residents of Montgomery County, a predominantly white suburban area north of Philadelphia.", "title": "Bill Cosby Jury Is Set After a Dispute Over the Racial Makeup", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "NORRISTOWN, Pa. \u2014 In a major victory for Bill Cosby, the judge in his sexual assault trial ruled Tuesday to admit testimony from a Temple University academic adviser who says that Mr. Cosby\u2019s central accuser, Andrea Constand, told her she could make money by falsely claiming that she had been molested by a prominent person.\n\nJudge Steven T. O\u2019Neill of the Montgomery County Court of Common Pleas had barred the testimony of the administrator, Marguerite Jackson, 56, an adviser in Temple\u2019s Boyer College of Music and Dance, during Mr. Cosby\u2019s first trial, which ended with a hung jury last summer.\n\nThat ruling came after Ms. Constand, a former staff member for the Temple women\u2019s basketball program, testified in the first trial that she did not know Ms. Jackson. But in recent weeks, Mr. Cosby\u2019s defense had brought forward two former colleagues of Ms. Constand\u2019s at Temple who said she knew Ms. Jackson.\n\nMs. Constand\u2019s credibility is expected to be a prime focus of the defense, as it was at the first trial, where she testified at length that Mr. Cosby had drugged and then assaulted her at his home outside Philadelphia in 2004.", "title": "Bill Cosby Jury to Hear Account That His Accuser Was Scheming", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The prosecution\u2019s case has also been significantly bolstered since the first trial last summer, which ended with a hung jury. Judge Steven T. O\u2019Neill is allowing prosecutors to present accounts from five women who say Mr. Cosby tried to intoxicate them as part of a plan to sexually abuse them, accusations similar to Ms. Constand\u2019s that the prosecution says demonstrate a signature pattern of assault. In the first trial only one additional accuser was allowed to add her voice.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou will have an understanding of a common plan, scheme or design of the defendant,\u201d Mr. Steele told the jurors Monday. \u201cAnd when this happened with Andrea Constand, there was no mistake.\u201d\n\nOne of the additional accusers who prosecutors plan to call is Janice Dickinson, the former supermodel, who said Mr. Cosby drugged and raped her in Lake Tahoe in 1982.\n\nThe testimony of Ms. Constand, 44, will still be central to the retrial \u2014 as it was in the first trial. The defense, which will present its opening statement Tuesday, will almost certainly question why she maintained contact with Mr. Cosby after the encounter and ask why she took a year to come forward to police, both issues raised at the first trial.\n\nIn an opening statement of more than an hour, Mr. Steele appeared determined to undercut any credibility issues, mentioning how Ms. Constand only sued Mr. Cosby after prosecutors more than a decade ago declined to bring charges. The current charges were brought after the investigation was reopened in 2015.\n\nThe prosecution had some of Mr. Cosby\u2019s prior statements projected onto a screen, including his acknowledgment that on the night of their encounter he had given Ms. Constand three pills \u2014 \u201cthree friends\u201d he called them \u2014 to help her relax without telling her what the pills were, as well as a later admission to her mother that he had digitally penetrated Ms. Constand. Mr. Cosby has said the pills were Benadryl and the sex was consensual.\n\nThe start of the proceedings had been delayed for several hours as Judge O\u2019Neill reviewed a motion by Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers to dismiss a juror who, they said, had told another prospective juror last week that he thought Mr. Cosby was guilty. Judge O\u2019Neill decided the juror could remain, though he did not disclose his reasoning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cosby\u2019s entry to the courthouse was briefly delayed in the morning by the protest of a topless woman, later identified as Nicolle Rochelle, a former actress who had appeared several times on \u201cThe Cosby Show.\u201d She jumped over a crowd barrier outside the courthouse and yelled \u201cWomen\u2019s lives matter\u201d before being wrestled to the ground by courthouse deputies about ten yards in front of Mr. Cosby as he walked toward the building\u2019s front doors.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Rochelle, 38, of Little Falls, N.J. had written on her torso the names of some of the women who have accused Mr. Cosby of assault. Mr. Cosby, wearing a dark suit and using a cane, was guided toward a side entrance instead.\n\nIn an interview after her arrest on disorderly conduct charges, Ms. Rochelle said she is a performing artist and activist who now lives in Paris.\n\n\u201cI wanted to get as close to him as possible without touching him,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was a peaceful demonstration but I wanted him to feel uncomfortable.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. She said that nothing inappropriate had happened on the set with Mr. Cosby, whom she said she liked as a young actress.\n\nBut now she said she wanted to express the anger of the other women and had chosen to do it topless so as to use her body as \u201ca political tool.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was contesting the image of a woman\u2019s body as constantly sexual,\u201d she said.\n\nAbout a dozen other protesters also demonstrated outside the courthouse, an indication of how Mr. Cosby\u2019s profile has changed since he was one of America\u2019s most beloved entertainers. His is the first high-profile sexual assault trial of the #MeToo era, and experts are watching to see what effect the eruption of accusations of harassment and assault against prominent men may have on the trial and on jurors\u2019 attitudes.\n\nThe 12-person jury is made up of five women and seven men. One woman and one man are African-American. The panel will be sequestered for the trial, which is the only criminal case to arise from the many accusations made against Mr. Cosby by women, all of which Mr. Cosby has denied.", "title": "Bill Cosby Paid His Sex Assault Accuser $3.38 Million in Settlement", "authors": ["Graham Bowley", "Jon Hurdle"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "A New Defense Team, and a New Style\n\nLast time out Mr. Cosby\u2019s main lawyer was a Philadelphia courthouse veteran, Brian J. McMonagle, who had served as a prosecutor and knew the local people and the processes well. This time out, Mr. Cosby has hired more of an outsider to lead his defense: Thomas A. Mesereau Jr., a high profile criminal defense veteran who helped Michael Jackson win acquittal in his 2005 child molesting trial.\n\nMr. Mesereau, with his white shoulder-length hair, will be a distinctive figure as the case unfolds. His team has already demonstrated his aggressiveness with its move to have Judge O\u2019Neill recuse himself because his wife has been an active supporter of sexual assault victims. Judge O\u2019Neill rejected the motion.\n\nWhat the Jury Will Not Hear\n\nOne part of the defense case during the first trial was an effort to let the jury know that in 2005, when Ms. Constand first went to the police, the district attorney decided not to bring charges. The news release by the former district attorney, Bruce L. Castor Jr., played a big role at the first trial. But his opinions about the evidence and why he decided against charges won\u2019t be heard this time around, Judge O\u2019Neill decided.\n\nWhat the Jury Will Hear\n\nAfter Mr. Castor declined to bring charges, Ms. Constand sued Mr. Cosby in 2005. The case was settled confidentially in 2006 with a financial payment made by Mr. Cosby to Ms. Constand.\n\nAt the first trial, references to the civil case were barred. This time, Mr. Cosby has lifted his objections, and jurors can hear more about the lawsuit, including the payment amount.", "title": "Bill Cosby Returns to Court. Immediately.\u201d\n\n\u2018This is all about celebrity\u2019\n\nShortly after the A.P. interview was made public, the Radar Online site published the audio of an interview Mr. Cosby did with The National Enquirer in 2005 about sexual assault allegations against him by Tamara Green, who said he drugged and groped her in 1970.\n\nMr. Cosby did not explicitly deny the allegations but said he thought the media was treating him unfairly because he was famous. But experts see them mostly as a prelude to a meeting between Mr. Kim and President Trump.\n\nFrom dessert to d\u00e9cor, we looked at the symbolism of the meeting and of Panmunjom, above, the truce village where it\u2019s taking place.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. \u201cIt\u2019s crazy \u2014 they were looking for this guy for 40 years and he was right here under our noses.\u201d\n\nThat was a shellshocked neighbor of Joseph James DeAngelo, the man the police believe is the Golden State Killer. The 72-year-old \u2014 who once worked as a police officer himself \u2014 had been living in the Sacramento suburbs. Here\u2019s what we know about him.\n\nThe attacker often wore ski masks like the ones above. The writer Michelle McNamara spent the final years of her life chasing the Golden State Killer, hoping to identify him in her book, \u201cI\u2019ll Be Gone in the Dark.\u201d It was published in February, after her death, and helped reignite public interest in the case. HBO is adapting it into a documentary series.\n\nHer husband, the comedian Patton Oswalt, said that he hoped to visit Mr. DeAngelo and confront him with questions that Ms. McNamara had planned to ask.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Federal Reserve officials are beginning to worry about a possibility that still seems remote to many Americans: the danger that the economy is close to \u201coverheating.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s when an abnormally low unemployment rate sets off spikes in inflation and destabilizes financial markets. Some officials are calling for faster increases in interest rates to prepare for such a scenario.\n\nBut others say it\u2019s way too early to try to turn down the heat on the economy \u2014 and on workers who are still waiting for big wage increases to show up.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n___\n\nPhoto\n\n8. O\u2019Neill agreed they were hopelessly deadlocked and sent them home.\n\nJudge O\u2019Neill, who is presiding at this retrial, charged the jury Wednesday morning. Deliberations began around 11 a.m. and dragged into the night as the 12-member panel considered the presentations by prosecutors and defense lawyers.\n\nThe latter argued that Ms. Constand, a former Temple University employee who viewed Mr. Cosby as a mentor, had a consensual sexual encounter with Mr. Cosby at his home near here in 2004. But they said she later concocted a story about having been assaulted to pressure him into a financial settlement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProsecutors said it was Mr. Cosby, now 80, who was the manipulator, a man who hid behind a genial image, they said, while using drugs to incapacitate and assault not just Ms. Constand, but other women as well.\n\nPhoto\n\nOver the course of the day, jury members came back with three questions for the judge. One asked for an explanation of the legal definition of \u201cconsent.\u201d Two other questions concerned the testimony of the defense\u2019s star witness, Marguerite Jackson, a veteran employee of Temple University, Mr. Cosby\u2019s alma mater, and Mr. Cosby\u2019s deposition testimony in the 2005 lawsuit brought by Ms. Constand. The judge read a portion of Mr. Cosby\u2019s words to the jurors.", "title": "Bill Cosby\u2019s Fate Rests With Jury as It Begins Deliberations", "authors": ["Graham Bowley", "Jon Hurdle"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Bill Cosby\u2019s publicist on Friday compared his sexual assault conviction to the plight of Emmett Till, the black teenager who was lynched and disfigured in Mississippi in 1955 after he was wrongfully accused of flirting with a white woman.\n\nMr. Cosby was convicted on Thursday of drugging and sexually assaulting a woman, Andrea Constand, at his home 14 years ago. More than 50 other women have accused him of sexual abuse.\n\nTill, by contrast, was 14 years old in 1955, when a white woman accused him of flirting and whistling at her. Four days later, a group of white men forced their way into the home where he was staying and abducted him. He was beaten, shot in the head and thrown into a river. His body was found three days later, mutilated so badly it could be identified only by the ring he was wearing.\n\nHis accuser, Carolyn Bryant Donham, later told a historian that Till had not been menacing or sexually crude toward her.", "title": "Bill Cosby\u2019s Publicist Invokes Emmett Till to Discredit Accusers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Bill Nack, an elegant sportswriter, best known for his work at Sports Illustrated, who found an early outlet for his love of horse racing as a teenage groom and went on to chronicle the magnificent career of the 1973 Triple Crown winner Secretariat, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 77.\n\nHis wife, Carolyne, said the cause was lung cancer.\n\nOver nearly a quarter-century at Sports Illustrated, Mr. Nack was one of its storytelling stars, along with Frank Deford, Gary Smith, Sally Jenkins, Leigh Montville and Richard Hoffer. His subjects included horses and jockeys; the boxers Joe Frazier and Rocky Marciano, the racecar driver A. J. Foyt, the baseball players Jackie Robinson and Keith Hernandez, and a football player, Bob Kalsu, the only major professional sports athlete to die in the Vietnam War.\n\nHe was hired by Sports Illustrated after a decade at Newsday, where he had covered politics and the environment in his early years there. But that changed during a Christmas party in 1971, when he stood on a tabletop and recited the names of every Kentucky Derby winner, a list that began with Aristides in 1875.\n\nThe newspaper\u2019s editor, David Laventhol, a horse-racing fan, was impressed and asked why he had such specialized knowledge.", "title": "Bill Nack, Who Covered the Horses From Up Close, Dies at 77", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement late Wednesday, Ms. Feinstein said she was worried that the amendment, which she had not seen, could \u201cundermine the investigation.\u201d She did not detail her concerns.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve discussed this with Chairman Grassley and he has agreed to not take action this week but instead place the bill on the committee\u2019s markup calendar next week,\u201d she wrote.\n\nThe aides said that Mr. Grassley is studying statutes that place some limits on the firing of certain agency inspectors general, with an eye toward echoing some of that language for a Justice Department special counsel. Some such statutes, for example, require the executive branch to give Congress 30 days\u2019 notice and an explanation before such an official is removed.\n\nWith or without Mr. Grassley\u2019s amendment, even proponents of the bill concede that its chances of becoming law remain slim. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, who would decide whether to put it up for a full Senate vote, said Tuesday that he had not seen \u201cclear indication yet\u201d that such a bill was necessary.\n\nSpeaker Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin would also have to put it up for a vote, and he has not yet commented on the new bill. If it passed Congress, Mr. Trump would most likely veto it.\n\nStill, a bipartisan committee vote would be significant.\n\nSenators from both parties introduced a pair of bills late last summer aimed at protecting Mr. Mueller, and the Judiciary Committee held a hearing to consider their constitutionality. But an effort to combine the two bills into one languished for months, as urgency among Republicans dissipated.\n\nLawmakers involved in the drafting of the new bill said the pace began to pick up again in recent weeks as Mr. Trump\u2019s increasingly aggressive posture against Mr. Mueller prompted speculation that he might try to fire him.", "title": "Bill to Protect Special Counsel Mueller Is Headed for a Committee Vote", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHeadliner\n\nBISTROT LEO After saying goodbye to Sessanta, his Italian restaurant in the hotel at 60 Thompson Street in SoHo, John McDonald has rolled out the welcome mat for this French bistro, its replacement. He hired Brian Loiacono, 30, whose experience includes many years at Daniel Boulud\u2019s restaurants, so snails, foie gras, rillettes, steak frites, petits pois, potato-crusted black sea bass and a stunning crown roast of lamb with asparagus are now on the menu. Mr. McDonald said that a profusion of Italian restaurants and a shortage of French ones downtown had influenced his decision. He has tinkered with the space, creating a cafe area that spills onto the street, shortening the bar for tables, adding floral-patterned wallpaper, and, in a daring move, using tablecloths in the main dining room: Sixty SoHo Hotel, 60 Thompson Street (Broome Street), 212-219-8119, bistrotleo.com.\n\nOpening\n\nSERRA BY BIRRERIA Eataly\u2019s rooftop restaurant and microbrewery, Birreria, which changes its theme twice a year, will represent the atmosphere and food of the Italian countryside this season. (Thursday): Eataly, 200 Fifth Avenue (23rd Street), 212-937-8910, eataly.com.\n\nLooking Ahead\n\nSUSHI INOUE This sushi palace in the heart of Harlem with a Michelin star and several omakase options will open a sprawling edition near Lincoln Center in the former Picholine space. In contrast to the tiny, intimate sushi bars throughout the city, this one will seat about 150. It is expected to open in the fall: 35 West 64th Street.\n\nHARWOOD ON HUDSON Lisa Murphy Harwood and Terry Harwood, who branched out from their popular Shelter Island spot, Vine Street Caf\u00e9, with Cove Hollow Tavern in East Hampton last year, will unveil this restaurant in Manhattan. Here, their partners are Kim Nguyen and Bill Block. It is to open in late spring with Mr. Harwood as chef and his wife handling pastry. They plan to offer a menu that includes bluefish p\u00e2t\u00e9 and pastrami-spiced pork ribs along with Vine Street Caf\u00e9\u2019s Bolognese: 430 Hudson Street (Morton Street).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCLAUDIO\u2019S The beacon, owned by the same family, on the Greenport, N.Y., waterfront since 1870, has changed hands. The new owners and former regulars, Perry Weitz, David Weitz, Ian Behar and Ryan Sasson, bought it from Kathy and Janice Claudio. To run it, they have hired Tora Matsuoka, who owns Sen restaurant in Sag Harbor, and Stephen Loffredo, a Manhattan restaurateur who owned Zoe in SoHo. Claudio\u2019s satellites, Claudio\u2019s Clam Bar and Crabby Jerry\u2019s, are also part of the deal. All the restaurants are to reopen by Memorial Day weekend: 111 Main Street, Greenport, N.Y.", "title": "Bistrot Leo, Replacing Sessanta, Opens in SoHo", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Off The Menu"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Depending on what the subjects are wearing, the closely cropped images conjure complicated representations that are not unlike his own views of modern policing. The side-by-side frames of Officer Eric King show him in uniform wearing his badge, handcuffs and firearm \u2014 all symbols of state-sanctioned power long regarded suspiciously in many black communities. The second image is a portrait of Mr. King wearing a black hoodie \u2014 an article of clothing that often results in black men and boys being seen as suspects on the streets of their communities.\n\n\u201cI approached this project from the lens of what W.E.B. Du Bois called \u2018double consciousness\u2019: the idea of having to fraction yourself in a space to survive,\u201d said Mr. Edwards, 29, of the project that is featured on his social justice oriented multimedia website, BlackVign. \u201cWhat is it like to have to navigate that as a black person in America? What is it like when you end up putting on this uniform that represents danger to a lot of people and can represent danger to you when you\u2019re out of the uniform and you\u2019re just wearing your black or brown skin?\u201d", "title": "Black Cops on Both Sides of the Badge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "After weeks of feeling as if I were going to die, I emailed a cardiologist I found through a peri-partum cardiomyopathy Facebook group. If I didn\u2019t have my Harvard email address, I often wonder if he would have emailed me so quickly. But he did. An MRI led to a diagnosis of peri-partum cardiomyopathy \u2014 a type of pregnancy-induced heart failure. I am receiving better care now, but it\u2019s been hard physically and psychologically.\n\nWhitney Polk, Salem, Mass.\n\n\u2018The Psychological Weight of Three Generations of Black Women Lives in My Womb\u2019\n\nImage Credit Photograph by Noah Fecks\n\nThe first six months of my pregnancy were smooth sailing: zero morning sickness, no diabetes and my nursery to-do list had many check marks. My husband of 11 years was supportive and grounded in his duties as a new father to be. But one week after a cherry-blossom-themed baby-shower luncheon, I got the news that my daughter no longer had a heartbeat. Flower-essence treatments, reiki sessions, acupuncture and a birth doula didn\u2019t save the life of Lulu Mika, stillborn at seven months (May 8, 2017). She was 3 pounds. I held her but couldn\u2019t stand to see her face.\n\nMy OB-GYN of 10 years was super-attentive, but at a loss for the medical language of what cut my daughter\u2019s life short. The autopsy showed nothing. My follow-up postnatal treatments included many talks with her about managing myself and the pros and cons of jumping back into work. I didn\u2019t have the luxury of taking a complete pause while working through a broken heart, nor did I have family members to help me navigate the emotional tunnel ahead.\n\nLuckily, I had a circle of friends who held me up in big and small ways, with weeklong getaways, french-fry dates, bouts of absences, phone calls (not text messages), Rancho Gordo beans deliveries, flowers, cards and showing up at my apartment with wine. Mostly, women of color who understood the definition of \u201cpush through it.\u201d In the beginning, I wanted to die, but I tucked that feeling away; I\u2019m lucky the thought faded. This nuclear group understood that being a black career woman doesn\u2019t allow much room to mourn. They knew the unspoken rule of protecting the lineage narrative or never speaking the trauma of the women closest to us. It\u2019s silence that contributes to the demise of black women and our babies. After counseling and many days of reflection, my eyes were open to the multitude of unhealthful societal structures that were riding my back while carrying a child. I realized that the psychological weight of three generations of black women lives in my womb.\n\nNicole A. Taylor, Brooklyn, New York\n\n\u2018You Would Have Thought I Was a Mute From Mars\u2019\n\nImage Credit Courtesy of Deidre Johnson\n\nI am a mother of two sons. After each of their births, I ended up in the hospital with postpartum eclampsia and HELLP syndrome \u2014 serious complications of high blood pressure. Both times it was a struggle to get doctors to even pay attention to my symptoms. When I first noticed that my blood pressure was elevated, I was told, \u201cYou people usually have higher blood pressure.\u201d The first time, but for the presence of my father who called an OB-GYN friend in California, I would be dead. The second was even more frustrating and surreal, because I was in a different hospital for high-risk pregnancies in the same system, and I still was not listened to until my family threatened litigation. I am an African-American woman with degrees from Princeton and Yale. I still remember every conscious moment of both experiences. The second time, I was even using their language to describe my vascular headache, asking why they were not checking my urine for protein, requesting a magnesium drip because that saved me the first time. You would have thought I was a mute from Mars. It was the most frustrating experience of my life.\n\nDeidre Johnson, Denver", "title": "Black Mothers Respond to Our Cover Story on Maternal Mortality", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "David Smith, the president of the Mobile County N.A.A.C.P., did not respond to a message seeking comment on Tuesday.\n\nIn an odd coincidence, the arrest of Ms. Clemons occurred at about 3 a.m. on Sunday, around the same time a man armed with a rifle opened fire in a Waffle House outside Nashville, killing four young people of color and injuring four others.\n\nMs. Clemons, who was charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest, and Ms. Adams, who was not arrested, could not be reached for comment on Tuesday. Ms. Clemons-Howard, who told the Alabama news media that she was speaking on her daughter\u2019s behalf, did not return a call seeking comment.\n\nAfter the Starbucks arrest, the Philadelphia police chief apologized, as did Starbucks's chief executive, and the company announced it would shut down 8,000 stores in the United States for a day next month for racial-bias training. The arrest in Saraland, Ala., has not drawn the same reaction from Waffle House.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. A Waffle House spokesman said \u201cpolice intervention was appropriate.\u201d\n\nOn Monday afternoon, the Police Department released a portion of a 911 call from a Waffle House employee and footage from two security cameras inside the restaurant.\n\nIn the 911 call, the worker said her manager had asked her to call because two women and a man acting \u201cdrunk and disorderly\u201d had arrived with alcohol and were refusing to throw it away. The security footage had no audio but showed Ms. Clemons, 25, and Ms. Adams, 26, pointing and yelling at employees.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt a news conference on Monday, Detective Brian Mims said the women were cursing and threatening them.\n\n\u201c\u2018You ain\u2019t going to be here tomorrow,\u2019\u201d Detective Mims said the women told employees. \u201c\u2018I may have a gun.
