I can come back up here and shoot this place up if I need to.\u2019\u201d\n\nWhen the officers arrived, Detective Mims said, Ms. Clemons refused to comply with their orders and resisted placing her hands behind her back. He said her race played no role in what happened.\n\n\u201cBased on the interviews conducted,\u201d he said, \u201cit was based solely on that they were asked to take their beverages out and not to consume them on premises.\u201d\n\nThe Police Department did not release the names of the officers but said that none of them would be disciplined.\n\nMs. Clemons\u2019s mother told AL.com that the encounter on Sunday morning had started over plastic utensils. The women asked for plastic ware with their meal, her mother said, but a waitress told them that the utensils cost 50 cents extra. When Ms. Clemons and Ms. Adams objected and said they had not been charged for them in the past, the waitress canceled their order, Ms. Clemons-Howard said.\n\nThe police arrived when the women were trying to get the name of a Waffle House supervisor to file a complaint, Ms. Clemons-Howard said. \u201cThe footage shows the story completely,\u201d she told AL.com, referring to the cellphone video.\n\nDetective Mims said Monday that the waitress was following Waffle House policy to charge customers for plastic ware if they plan to dine at the restaurant. A company spokesman did not immediately answer an email seeking comment about its plastic ware policy.", "title": "Black Woman\u2019s Violent Arrest at Alabama Waffle House Was Justified, Police Say", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "A fraternity at California Polytechnic State University was sanctioned by its national organization on Tuesday after students dressed as gang members, including one in blackface, during the college\u2019s annual multicultural event over the weekend.\n\nPhotos first surfaced online on Sunday showing white students from Lambda Chi Alpha outside their fraternity house wearing baggy jeans, gold necklaces and bandannas as they flashed fake gang signs.\n\nBut it was another photo \u2014 of a fraternity brother in blackface \u2014 that drew swift outrage from both students and officials at the university in San Luis Obispo, Calif., leading to an almost immediate suspension of the chapter, protests on campus and a standing room only meeting with students to address racism at the college.\n\nOn Monday, the college placed Lambda Chi Alpha on interim suspension while it investigated. On Tuesday, the national fraternity office said it had placed the chapter on \u201climited operations,\u201d sanctions that restrict it from participating in formal activities.", "title": "Blackface Leads to Fraternity Suspension at Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "The Fair Housing Act of 1968, which outlawed housing discrimination on paper, might have made amends for some of this history had the federal government actually enforced it. But studies continue to show pervasive discrimination in housing, and lower-income whites still have greater access than middle-class African-Americans to healthy mixed-income communities.\n\nA study by the National Fair Housing Alliance of a dozen metropolitan areas \u2014 including Atlanta; Austin, Tex., Birmingham, Ala.; Chicago; Dayton, Ohio; Detroit; New York; Philadelphia; Pittsburgh; San Antonio; and the District of Columbia \u2014 showed that real estate discrimination was pervasive.\n\nThe alliance filed a federal fair housing complaint against a real estate group in Jackson, Miss., charging that real estate agents were denying African-Americans the right to buy homes in high-value areas that would provide greater returns on their investments after testers posing as home buyers established that black and white clients were treated very differently. The real estate group settled the case by agreeing to specific steps to expand equal housing opportunities.\n\nA HOME MORTGAGE \u2018BLACK TAX\u2019\n\nAfrican-Americans who had amassed equity in their homes and who should have been offered safe, reasonably priced loans were set up for default in the run-up to the recession, when they were targeted for predatory loans that were often deceptively marketed. A study of the problem in Baltimore found that black residents were charged higher rates and discriminated against at every stage of the transactions compared with comparably qualified white customers.\n\nThe authors determined that the loan default rate would have been considerably lower for black customers had they been treated in the same fashion as whites. Most tellingly of all, the study took into account factors like credit scores, income and down payments that would have been known to brokers and lenders when these abusive loans were made.\n\nIt comes as no surprise that such tactics took a heavy toll on black homeowners, who already lagged far behind whites in terms of wealth and homeownership levels. An analysis by the nonprofit Urban Institute shows that between 2001 and 2016 the homeownership rate for African-Americans declined about five percentage points, to 41 percent, as opposed to just one percentage point for whites, whose rate fell to just over 71 percent. The nine percentage point decline for middle-aged black homeowners is particularly ominous, given that these people are closer to retirement with fewer resources to rely on.\n\nThe Urban Institute\u2019s analysis of the black-white homeownership gap in 100 cities across the country shows that none have actually closed the ownership gap. The gap was widest in Northeastern and Midwestern cities \u2014 with the widest gaps, listed in order of severity, found in Minneapolis; Albany; Buffalo; New York; Salisbury, Md.; and Bridgeport, Conn. The cities with the smallest gaps were Killeen, Tex.; Fayetteville, N.C.; Charleston, S.C.; Austin; and Augusta, Ga.", "title": "Opinion | Blacks Still Face a Red Line on Housing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nMy family and I returned home to Park Slope from Buffalo late one night to find that a couple of days\u2019 worth of mail had accumulated.\n\nIn the pile was a December 1974 issue of Guitar Player magazine, addressed to a subscriber who had presumably lived at our address several decades ago.\n\nI sent a note to my block\u2019s listserv asking whether anybody remembered the family who had lived in our apartment in the mid-1970s. I attached a picture of the magazine cover with the subscriber\u2019s name.\n\nOne of our neighbors recognized the name as belonging to the husband of a relative of hers who had lived at our address when she was a girl. She also remembered how, when she was growing up, she had played with her cousins in the house where we now live.\n\nSo the subscriber was real. The address was correct. The bulk mail postage code was authentic. It seems that the magazine had gotten lost in the mail for 43 years.", "title": "Blast From the Past", "authors": ["Kedin Kilgore", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Last year, representatives of 25 countries met in Tokyo to work on setting international standards for the blockchain, the technology that was introduced by the virtual currency Bitcoin and has ignited intense interest in corporate and government circles.\n\nSome of the technologists at the meeting of the International Standards Organization were surprised when they learned that the head of the Russian delegation, Grigory Marshalko, worked for the F.S.B., the intelligence agency that is the successor to the K.G.B.\n\nThey were even more surprised when they asked the F.S.B. agent why the Russians were devoting such resources to the blockchain standards.\n\n\u201cLook, the internet belongs to the Americans \u2014 but blockchain will belong to us,\u201d he said, according to one delegate who was there. He was 85.\n\nHis son, Zeno, confirmed the death but did not specify a cause. Mr. Beattie (pronounced be-AT-tee) lived for 40 years in Woody Creek, Colo.\n\nAs a sportscaster Mr. Beattie was renowned for his call, with Frank Gifford, of the Austrian Franz Klammer\u2019s gold medal-winning downhill race at the 1976 Winter Games in Innsbruck, Austria, as Klammer beat the time of Bernhard Russi of Switzerland.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s right on the edge!\u201d Mr. Beattie said as the daredevil-like Klammer nearly fell.\n\n\u201cYou certainly cannot accuse him of doing anything but attacking!\u201d he said, observing Klammer\u2019s aggressive style.", "title": "Bob Beattie, 85, Olympic Ski Coach and ABC Sports Analyst, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNot to unduly shame the American education system,\u201d People magazine began an article in 2016, \u201cbut chances are Bob Dorough has had more of an impact on grammar fluency than any other individual in the 20th century.\u201d\n\nMr. Dorough (rhymes with \u201cthorough\u201d; his wife said Thorough Dorough was a nickname) was music director for the initial series and also wrote and sang some of the most fondly remembered \u201cSchoolhouse Rock!\u201d songs. They apparently stuck in young heads, or parental ones, or both. For the rest of Mr. Dorough\u2019s career, it was not uncommon for him to be playing a jazz set and have someone call for a \u201cSchoolhouse Rock!\u201d tune.\n\n\u201cJust about every concert we did we would do some \u2018Schoolhouse Rock!\u2019 because people enjoyed it,\u201d Steve Berger, Mr. Dorough\u2019s longtime guitarist, said in a telephone interview. The songs, he noted, were deceptively intricate.\n\n\u201cWhat you\u2019ll notice is, each one of them is musically brilliant, is lyrically brilliant,\u201d Mr. Berger said. The key, he said, was Mr. Dorough\u2019s respect for the audience.\n\n\u201cHe never wrote down to the kids,\u201d he said. \u201cHe always brought them up.\u201d\n\nRobert Lrod Dorough was born on Dec. 12, 1923, in Cherry Hill, Ark. His father, Robert, was a salesman, and his mother, Alma Lewis Dorough, worked for a time for the Singer sewing machine company.", "title": "Bob Dorough, Jazzman With a Hit Kid-Music Series, Dies at 94", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "To secure the right to perform the songs with altered lyrics, permission was required from the songs\u2019 publishers. \u201cThe response was completely positive,\u201d said Rob Kaplan, the project\u2019s executive producer.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kaplan started his search for artists with Ben Gibbard, the frontman for Death Cab for Cutie, an alternative rock band from Washington State. Mr. Gibbard had expressed his support of marriage equality in a 2012 essay for The Daily Beast, inspired by his sister, a lesbian. \u201cThis was a cause at our family dinner table,\u201d Mr. Gibbard said.\n\nFor the project, Mr. Gibbard elected to recast the Beatles classic \u201cAnd I Love Her\u201d to \u201cAnd I Love Him.\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s a song my dad often played to my mom after dinner,\u201d he said. \u201cAlso, it\u2019s a song everyone knows.\u201d\n\nKesha chose Janis Joplin\u2019s \u201cI Need a Man to Love\u201d (\u201csuch a gritty, soulful song,\u201d Kesha said), and changed it to \u201cI Need a Woman to Love.\u201d \u201cFor years I said that I\u2019m not getting married until any two people can legally marry in this country,\u201d Kesha said. She has since become ordained and has performed weddings for two gay couples.\n\nValerie June, a country and blues singer who attended her first gay marriage last year for her cousin, recorded a big-band version of \u201cMad About the Boy,\u201d changing \u201cboy\u201d to \u201cgirl.\u201d Ms. June believes it adds an extra layer of meaning that the song\u2019s writer, No\u00ebl Coward, was gay and that the version he recorded in 1932 wasn\u2019t released in its day because of prevailing homophobia.\n\n\u201cIt brings the song full circle to know that it was written by a gay man who meant every single word of \u2018Mad About the Boy,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Dylan, who does not appear to have spoken out in favor of gay rights in the past, declined to be interviewed. But his choice of song, \u201cShe\u2019s Funny That Way,\u201d which has been recorded by Frank Sinatra and Nat King Cole, gains a wink in its current guise; \u201cHe\u2019s Funny That Way\u201d can also be read as an antiquated code for a gay person.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Dylan\u2019s warm and wry performance captures the mix of wit and sincerity favored by songs from the American standards era.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kaplan said that when he contacted Mr. Dylan, he got a very quick yes. \u201cAnd it wasn\u2019t just \u2018yes, I\u2019ll do this,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cIt was \u2018hey, I have an idea for a song.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cUniversal Love\u201d arrives at an evolving time for same-sex pronouns in pop. Though major music stars started to come out in significant numbers in the 1990s, with artists including K. D. Lang, Melissa Etheridge and Elton John, rarely, if ever, did they use same-sex pronouns in their recordings.\n\nOnly in the last six years have younger stars slowly begun to do so, including Frank Ocean, Olly Alexander and Mary Lambert, who crooned the chorus of Macklemore and Ryan Lewis\u2019s Grammy-nominated \u201cSame Love\u201d in 2012.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFor a long time, queer people had to use the awkward \u2018you\u2019 in their songs to avoid outing themselves,\u201d said Stephan Pennington, a professor of music at Tufts University who teaches a course in \u201cqueer pop.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere has also always been pressure from the record companies to not be exclusionary by using a same-sex pronoun,\u201d Mr. Pennington said. \u201cBut heterosexual expressions are never thought of as exclusionary.\u201d\n\nIndeed, Sam Smith, arguably the most prominent gay pop star today, refrains from using same-sex pronouns.\n\nAllison Zatarain, a producer of a new album titled \u201cInstant Love,\u201d which mirrors the mission of \u201cUniversal Love\u201d by featuring female artists singing love songs to other women, believes the use of same-sex pronouns in pop songs \u201cfills a massive hole in the world\u2019s musical library.\u201d\n\n\u201cTo hear a woman sing to another woman, or a man to a man, lends the song a specificity that is so much more impactful than addressing \u2018you,\u2019\u201d she said.", "title": "Bob Dylan Sings About Gay Love", "authors": ["Jim Farber"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "In late 2015, an unexpected name popped up in the liquor industry press: Bob Dylan.\n\nA trademark application for the term \u201cbootleg whiskey\u201d had been filed under Mr. Dylan\u2019s name. Among those who noticed the news was Marc Bushala, 52, a lifelong fan and a liquor entrepreneur whose bourbon brand, Angel\u2019s Envy, had just been sold for $150 million. Mr. Bushala said he immediately spent weeks \u201cobsessing over this concept of what a Dylan whiskey could be.\u201d\n\nSo he reached out, and after being vetted by Mr. Dylan\u2019s representatives, Mr. Bushala \u2014 who speaks branding jargon like \u201cflavor profile\u201d and \u201cname exploration\u201d in an earnest Midwestern accent \u2014 talked to Mr. Dylan by phone, and proposed working together on a portfolio of small-batch whiskeys. As he saw it, there was just one problem: The name \u201cbootleg,\u201d while an apt Dylanological pun, wasn\u2019t quite right for a top-shelf liquor. Might Mr. Dylan, Nobel laureate, be open to some name exploration?\n\n\u201cIt was a little bit daunting,\u201d Mr. Bushala said of his pitch.\n\nBut it worked. Next month, he and Mr. Dylan will introduce Heaven\u2019s Door, a collection of three whiskeys \u2014 a straight rye, a straight bourbon and a \u201cdouble-barreled\u201d whiskey. They are Mr. Dylan\u2019s entry into the booming celebrity-branded spirits market, the latest career twist for an artist who has spent five decades confounding expectations.\n\nMr. Dylan is not simply licensing his name. He is a full partner in the business, Heaven\u2019s Door Spirits, which Mr. Bushala said had raised $35 million from investors.", "title": "Bob Dylan\u2019s Latest Gig: Making Whiskey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMusicians and booze have long gone together, and in the last few years acts from the Pogues to Drake have put their names on whiskey bottles. This year, Bob Dylan joins them with his own brand, Heaven\u2019s Door, beginning with a seven-year-old bourbon, a \u201cdouble-barreled\u201d American whiskey and a rye finished in French Vosges oak barrels.\n\nMr. Dylan and his team don\u2019t make the whiskey; they buy it from undisclosed producers and add their own twists before bottling. When I recently sampled the three variations of Heaven\u2019s Door, I was curious about what, if anything, set it apart from other notable whiskeys. Here\u2019s what I found.\n\nStraight Tennessee Bourbon\n\n$49.99\n\n750 milliliters\n\n90 proof\n\nOn the nose, this is a classic, no-fuss bourbon, though with more oak-derived notes \u2014 think caramel, vanilla and wood char \u2014 than you\u2019d expect from a seven-year-old. I also smelled sandalwood, leather and linseed oil. And there\u2019s a creamy cola note that suggests a good bit of rye in the mash bill. (Mr. Dylan and his team say they use just 70 percent corn, leaving a lot of room for other grains to show their influence.) The palate opens with a soft cocoa and buttercream note, then sharpens toward black pepper and cigar tobacco. The finish is slightly bitter, with the sweet spiciness of an Atomic Fireball. My favorite of the bunch.\n\nDouble Barrel Whiskey\n\n$49.99\n\n750 milliliters\n\n100 proof\n\nMore restrained than its stable mates, the Double Barrel \u2014 in which different whiskeys have been blended and further aged together in another cask \u2014 smells of cake batter, fresh berries and children\u2019s cough syrup; as it develops in the glass, its nose turns darker and woodier, with a hint of sweet fortified wine lurking in the background. It tastes surprisingly astringent and medicinal, given the nose, with a thin mouthfeel and notes of tobacco, allspice and wood smoke, resolving in ground pepper. The wood influence on this one is strong, perhaps too much, but it would make a nice substitute for a rye in a manhattan.\n\nStraight Rye Whiskey\n\n$79.99\n\n750 milliliters\n\n92 proof\n\nMost rye whiskey on the market these days is made at a distillery in southern Indiana called Midwest Grain Products, then sold to brands like George Dickel and Bulleit. Some brands then \u201cfinish\u201d the whiskey by placing it in a used or new barrel to give it a twist \u2014 in this case, the rye goes into toasted Vosges oak barrels, which are often used to age pinot noir. Heaven\u2019s Door doesn\u2019t reveal where its rye comes from, but its nose is rich with MGP\u2019s trademark dill and herbal notes. There\u2019s also a sweet grassiness, cocoa powder, tobacco and a slap of leather. It opens deceptively smooth on the palate, but builds to a sweet spiciness before finishing with a burst of spicy, bittersweet chocolate.", "title": "Bob Dylan\u2019s Whiskey: A Taste Test", "authors": ["Clay Risen"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe were so fascinated that they could stay underwater much longer than us local islanders,\u201d Dr. Jubilado said. \u201cI could see them literally walking under the sea.\u201d\n\nEven as anthropologists study Bajau culture, biologists have grown curious about them, too. Bajau divers been observed plunging more than 200 feet underwater, their only protection a pair of wooden goggles \u2014 a physiological marvel.\n\nIn 2015, Melissa Ilardo, then a graduate student in genetics at the University of Copenhagen, heard about the Bajau. She wondered if centuries of diving could have led to the evolution of traits that made the task easier for them.\n\n\u201cIt seemed like the perfect opportunity for natural selection to act on a population,\u201d said Dr. Ilardo.\n\nHer first step was to travel to Sulawesi, Indonesia, and then to a coral reef island where she reached a Bajau village. After she proposed her study, they agreed to the plan. She returned a few months later, this time with a portable ultrasound machine to measure the size of the Bajau people\u2019s spleens.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen people plunge into water, they respond with the so-called diving reflex: the heart rate slows and blood vessels constrict as a way to shunt blood to vital organs. The spleen also contracts, squirting a supply of oxygen-rich red blood cells into the circulation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll mammals have a diving reflex, but marine mammals like seals have a particularly strong one. Scientists suspect that the reflex helps them dive deeper \u2014 as it turns out, seals with bigger spleens can dive deepest. An enlarged spleen seems to function like a bigger scuba tank.\n\nDr. Ilardo scanned the abdomens of the Bajau villagers and then traveled about 15 miles inland to a village occupied by farmers known as the Saluan. She scanned them, too.\n\nWhen Dr. Ilardo compared scans from the two villages, she found a stark difference. The Bajau had spleens about 50 percent bigger on average than those of the Saluan.\n\nYet even such a remarkable difference might not be the result of evolution. Diving itself might somehow enlarge the spleen. There are plenty of examples of experience changing the body, from calloused feet to bulging biceps.\n\nOnly some Bajau are full-time divers. Others, such as teachers and shopkeepers, have never dived. But they, too, had large spleens, Dr. Ilardo found. It was likely the Bajau are born that way, thanks to their genes.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn her visit to Sulawesi, Dr. Ilardo also took mouth swabs from the Bajau and Saluan from which she extracted DNA. She looked at the genetic variations in each village and compared them to people from neighboring countries, such as New Guinea and China.\n\nA number of genetic variants have become unusually common in the Bajau, she found. The only plausible way for this to happen is natural selection: the Bajau with those variants had more descendants than those who lacked them.\n\nOne variant of a gene called PDE10A influenced the size of spleens in the Bajau. People with one copy of the mutant gene had bigger spleens than those with none. People with two copies had even bigger spleens.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nScientists had never found a special role for PDE10A in the spleen. \u201cThis connection was a bit bizarre,\u201d Dr. Ilardo said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut there\u2019s one possible link. PDE10A has been shown to control the level of thyroid hormone in the body. And scientists have found that injecting thyroid into mice with stunted spleens can make the organs grow larger.\n\nStill, that wouldn\u2019t pin down exactly how PDE10A became so common in the Bajau. \u201cIt\u2019s the question that\u2019s harder than others,\u201d said Rasmus Nielsen, a geneticist at the University of California, Berkeley, who collaborated with Dr. Ilardo.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor her own part, Dr. Ilardo suspects that natural selection favored the Bajau variant of PDE10A because deep diving is so risky. \u201cI would think, as morbid as it is, that if they didn\u2019t have this, it would kill them,\u201d she said.\n\nFran\u00e7ois-Xavier Ricaut, an anthropologist at the University of Toulouse who was not involved in the study, said that it wasn\u2019t clear yet how quickly this evolutionary change happened.\n\nSome researchers suspect the Bajau only began diving to great depths when a market for sea cucumbers opened up in China in the 1600s. Or perhaps the adaptation began thousands of years earlier, at the end of the Ice Age, when rising sea levels turned the region around Indonesia into islands.\n\n\u201cThis study acts as a cornerstone for exciting questions to follow,\u201d said Dr. Ricaut.\n\nDr. Ilardo said there were likely a number of other genes that help the Bajau dive. She and her colleagues also found evidence for natural selection on a gene called BDKRB2.\n\nIn a study published last year, Russian scientists discovered that it plays a role in the diving reflex. In people with variants of BDKRB2, blood vessels are more tightly constricted when they plunge their faces into cold water.\n\nTo see if that\u2019s the case with the Bajau, Dr. Ilardo will need to take another trip to beautiful Sulawesi. \u201cI would be happy doing this as long as I can,\u201d she said.", "title": "Bodies Remodeled for a Life at Sea", "authors": ["Carl Zimmer"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA body found floating near the California coast on Friday may belong to one of the children missing after a family\u2019s sport utility vehicle plummeted from a cliff late last month, according to the Mendocino County Sheriff\u2019s Office.\n\nThe authorities, who said last week that the crash may have been intentional, had already recovered the bodies of Jennifer and Sarah Hart and three of their six adopted children, but the whereabouts of the remaining three teenagers were unknown.\n\nThe body recovered on Friday, identified as African-American and female, was found near the crash site and may belong to one of two missing girls \u2014 Hannah, 16, or Sierra, 15 \u2014 the sheriff\u2019s office said. An autopsy was scheduled for Tuesday.\n\n\u201cThe Sheriff\u2019s Office is investigating the possibility that the body may be one of the two missing Hart girls but identification will most likely be done through DNA analysis, a process that can take several weeks,\u201d the office said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe floating body was discovered by a couple who had been vacationing on the coast, according to the statement. It was pulled to shore by a third bystander.", "title": "Body Found Off California Coast May Be Teenager From S.U.V. Plunge", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The body of a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention employee who went missing two months ago was found in a river in Atlanta on Tuesday, the authorities said on Thursday.\n\nIn February, the authorities announced a $10,000 reward for information leading to an arrest and indictment in the disappearance of Timothy J. Cunningham, 35. But on Thursday the authorities said there did not appear to be any signs of foul play in his death.\n\n\u201cRight now the preliminary cause of death is drowning, but the investigation is still open,\u201d Dr. Jan Gorniak, the chief medical examiner of Fulton County, said at a news conference. \u201cWe do not have a manner of death or whether it is an accident or suicide or anything other than that.\u201d\n\nMr. Cunningham was last seen leaving work on Feb. 12 after telling colleagues he did not feel well.\n\nHis body was spotted on Tuesday in a remote area of the Chattahoochee River by a group of fishermen who called 911, Michael O\u2019Connor, an Atlanta Police Department commander, told reporters. He was still wearing his favorite running shoes, raising the possibility that he had been jogging before his death.", "title": "Body of Missing C.D.C. Employee Found in Atlanta River", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Legalization has barely made a dent in those disparities. As of 2014 in Colorado, the marijuana arrest rate for black people was almost three times that of whites. In New York City, the marijuana arrest rate for black people in New York City was over four times that of whites; the Bronx has one of the country\u2019s highest rates of marijuana arrests. Meanwhile, black people make up an estimated 1 percent of marijuana dispensary owners, owning less than three dozen of the 3,000 or so retail shops nationwide.\n\nToo many people have been deported, made homeless, lost financial aid, levied fines and fees or had their children taken away from them because of marijuana arrests.\n\nWhite entrepreneurs who are cashing in on legal marijuana must work to reverse these trends. People in the marijuana industry, and the lawmakers who help it flourish, should highlight the racist history of marijuana prohibition and acknowledge its continuing impact.\n\nThe cannabis industry must also press for policies to decriminalize marijuana. It should call for the release of people like Mr. Winslow who sit in jails and prisons for the mere use, possession or sale of marijuana. And it must push legislators, prosecutors and law enforcement officers to throw out convictions derived from marijuana offenses.\n\nCannabis profiteers and customers should also push their lawmakers to emulate Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Florida and the city of Oakland, Calif., each of which has enacted policies, in some cases described as \u201cmarijuana reparations,\u201d that encourage and give priority on retail licenses to people of color and those who have been disproportionately harmed by marijuana prohibition and enforcement.\n\nMore white people should do what Mr. Boehner did and publicly announce their support of sensible marijuana policy. They should draw on their own experiences to undermine the racialized stigma the drug was long tagged with. The reality is that when a problem has a white face, the government and law enforcement agencies are more likely to react sensibly to that problem.\n\nAs white people make money from marijuana, black people languish in jail for smoking it.", "title": "Opinion | Boehner Benefits From Weed. Blacks Are in Prison for Using It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "However, if America attacked because President Trump was worried that continued North Korean missile and nuclear weapons development would ultimately increase Pyongyang\u2019s ability to hold American cities at risk, the strike would no longer be \u201canticipatory\u201d or \u201cpre-emptive.\u201d It would clearly be preventive \u2014 in legal terms, no different from a North Korean first strike against America motivated by Kim Jong-un\u2019s fear that America might one day attack North Korea.\n\nPreventive strikes are not legal under international law or the United Nations Charter. Indeed, the charter has a name for such an operation. It is \u201caggression.\u201d\n\nA disingenuous lawyer might argue that an attack on North Korea would not be a first strike but merely another strike in a continuing conflict, because combat in the Korean War halted in 1953 with an armistice, not a peace treaty. But that is specious. Given the armistice\u2019s indefinite duration \u2014 during which the parties committed to \u201ca complete cessation of hostilities\u201d \u2014 the right to resume hostilities would require a new legal justification.\n\nA domestic legal issue also arises because President Trump lacks constitutional authority to launch a preventive strike against North Korea. The power to declare war lies with Congress. Without its approval, the commander in chief\u2019s powers allow him to introduce American forces into areas of hostilities only in emergencies or military situations \u201cshort of war.\u201d Mr. Bolton\u2019s insistence on not waiting until \u201cthe very last minute\u201d to attack inadvertently acknowledges that such a strike wouldn\u2019t be an emergency response that would provide an arguable constitutional basis for a president to act without congressional approval.\n\nMr. Bolton did, however, raise a useful analogy that evokes the need to assess laws in the context of strategic imperatives: the Israeli air attacks on the Osirak nuclear reactor in Iraq in 1981 and on a Syrian nuclear reactor in 2007. Both strikes were arguably illegal, since there was no imminent threat to Israel. But we would argue that Israel\u2019s strikes were nevertheless wise, given the longstanding threats against it from dictatorships in Baghdad and Damascus, and the low risk that the attacks would escalate into a war. The attacks could be called, in legal terms, \u201cillegal but legitimate.\u201d Israel could argue that its formal violation of the law should be excused because it saved the world from new nuclear threats from Iraq and Syria.", "title": "Opinion | Bolton\u2019s Illegal War Plan for North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cShe\u2019s Got Surprises, Onscreen and Off\u201d (Sunday Styles, April 22):\n\nThe actress Rachel Weisz remarked, \u201cI would say, the thing about James Bond is, he doesn\u2019t get married, right?\u201d\n\nWrong. And as the wife of Daniel Craig, the current cinematic 007, Ms. Weisz should know better.\n\nThe British Secret Service agent James Bond was married, memorably, in both Ian Fleming\u2019s 1963 novel, \u201cOn Her Majesty\u2019s Secret Service,\u201d and its 1969 big-screen adaptation, to Teresa \u201cTracy\u201d Draco, a k a the Contessa Teresa di Vicenzo, daughter of Marc-Ange Draco, the head of the Union Corse crime syndicate.\n\nIn both versions as well, she was murdered shortly after the wedding by the supervillain Ernst Stavro Blofeld, the mastermind of SPECTRE, and his consort, Irma Bunt.\n\nBond\u2019s marriage is also specifically referred to in the authorized Eon Productions films \u201cThe Spy Who Loved Me,\u201d \u201cFor Your Eyes Only\u201d and \u201cLicense to Kill.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Bond. James Bond. Husband.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTAMPA, Fla. \u2014 Rick Nash and the Boston Bruins\u2019 high-scoring line of Patrice Bergeron, David Pastrnak and Brad Marchand are off to a flying start in the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.\n\nNash had two goals and Bergeron, Pastrnak and Marchand combined for 10 points on Saturday, helping the Bruins pull away for a 6-2 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning in Game 1 of the best-of-seven series.\n\nBergeron also scored twice, Marchand had a goal and two assists, and Pastrnak finished with four assists in a dominating performance.\n\nTuukka Rask stopped 34 shots for the Bruins, who finished one point behind Tampa Bay for the Atlantic Division title, as well as the No. 1 seed in the Eastern Conference.\n\nPhoto\n\nDan Girardi and Mikhail Sergachev scored for the Lightning, who trailed, 3-2, entering the third period.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMarchand and Bergeron hiked Boston\u2019s advantage to three goals before Jake DeBrusk added an empty-netter with 6 minutes 19 seconds remaining.", "title": "Boston Bruins Beat Tampa Bay Lightning in Game 1", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "BOSTON \u2014 An exhibition of works by Nicholas Nixon, the renowned photographer who has been accused of inappropriate sexual behavior, is being shut down Thursday at the photographer\u2019s request.\n\nMr. Nixon asked the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston, to close his exhibition to the public, saying that the allegations swirling around him made it impossible for viewers to regard his work on its merits. The show, \u201cPersistence of Vision,\u201d which opened in December, features his most notable work \u2014 \u201cThe Brown Sisters,\u201d photographs taken every year since 1975 of his wife, Bebe, and her three sisters.\n\nIn an investigation published last week, The Boston Globe reported that former students said that an atmosphere of intense sexuality had pervaded Mr. Nixon\u2019s classes at the Massachusetts College of Art and Design, where he was a professor.\n\nThe former students told the newspaper that Mr. Nixon, 70, had showed them pictures of his penis, and asked students to photograph genitalia. He also asked students to photograph seven people they wanted to sleep with, The Globe said.", "title": "Boston Museum Closes Nicholas Nixon Photography Show Early", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "One term that comes up often in discussion of gender and, especially, what it means to be a man, is \u201ctoxic masculinity.\u201d But as Colleen Clemens writes in Teaching Tolerance, \u201c\u2018Toxic masculinity\u2019 is tricky. It\u2019s a phrase that \u2014 misunderstood \u2014 can seem wildly insulting, even bigoted.\u201d\n\nThe Good Men Project defines it this way:\n\nToxic masculinity is a narrow and repressive description of manhood, designating manhood as defined by violence, sex, status and aggression. It\u2019s the cultural ideal of manliness, where strength is everything while emotions are a weakness; where sex and brutality are yardsticks by which men are measured, while supposedly \u201cfeminine\u201d traits \u2014 which can range from emotional vulnerability to simply not being hypersexual \u2014 are the means by which your status as \u201cman\u201d can be taken away.\n\nIt is crucial, however, that students understand some key ideas:\n\n\u2022 Talking about toxic masculinity is not about vilifying boys, men or any of the particular qualities society has deemed \u201cmasculine.\u201d Rather, it is an opportunity to begin to reconstruct a more positive model of masculinity that makes room for the many different ways to be a boy or man and allows all individuals to feel secure in their masculine identity.\n\nMichael Ian Black sums up this sentiment in a response to a reader comment on his Op-Ed, \u201cThe Boys Are Not All Right\u201d:\n\nMr. Florentino: I cried as I read this. My son \u2014 a high school and college wrestler who achieved much success on the mat \u2014 is one of the most sensitive souls I know. But far too often, I cheered his masculinity, his fierceness, and his muscles. I should have been cheering his kindness, his empathy, and his innate ability to be gentle. Those emotional qualities are what REALLY make him strong. MIB: I am very interested in a fuller expression of male strength. Physical strength is great (I wish I had more of it, because I would like, for once in my life, to look good shirtless on a beach). But a man\u2019s strength can be expressed in innumerable ways, including the strength to be vulnerable, the strength to ask for help, to seek forgiveness, to display empathy. By all means, root for your son, but root for his entire being. It sounds like you\u2019re doing that.\n\n\u2022 Toxic masculinity is not just a men\u2019s issue \u2014 its consequences are pervasive and affect everyone, including girls and women. Also, girls, boys, women and men all make choices about their behavior that can either perpetuate a culture of toxic masculinity or disrupt it. (And, of course, \u201ctoxic femininity\u201d is its corollary.)\n\nTo further explore this phrase, students might complete a Frayer model, including the definition, characteristics, examples and nonexamples of toxic masculinity. You can also see how it has been used in New York Times articles.\n\nAfter defining the term, show students this three-minute trailer of the documentary \u201cThe Mask You Live In\u201d by the Representation Project. As they watch, they might continue to add to their Frayer models. (Note to teachers: This clip includes some profanity and graphic language. Please preview it to make sure it is appropriate for your students.)\n\nThen, have students read Mr. Black\u2019s Op-Ed, \u201cThe Boys Are Not All Right,\u201d highlighting the characteristics and examples of toxic masculinity he gives. You might also assign students to read some of the 2,000-plus comments from readers that the article inspired. Do they agree with Mr. Black\u2019s assertions? Why or why not? What arguments made by readers are also compelling?\n\nAsk students if they can think of any other characteristics, examples or nonexamples of what it means to be a man according to this model of masculinity \u2014 such as those they came up with during the warm-up \u2014 and add them to the Frayer model.", "title": "Boys to Men: Teaching and Learning About Masculinity in an Age of Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAfter he got to Paris, he found life outside the studio much more fascinating than the challenge of painting,\u201d said Peter Galassi, the Museum of Modern Art\u2019s former chief curator of photography, who wrote the book\u2019s first essay. \u201cAnd then he was lucky that he had the talent to turn that fascination into great photographs.\u201d\n\nThough Henry Miller named Brassa\u00ef \u201cthe Eye of Paris,\u201d his ear was a foreign one, as the writer Antonio Mun\u0303oz Molina notes in the book. But, as with Sylvia Plachy or Inge Morath, photography became his main language, or a supplement to learning French through Proust\u2019s writing. The difference between Plachy and Morath \u2014 born in 1943 and 1923 \u2014 and Brassa\u00ef was timing. After World War I, there were no cultural outlets for photography.\n\n\u201cThere were no museums, collectors, or dealers,\u201d Mr. Galassi said. \u201cThat generation of photographers born around 1900 created the modern tradition of photography because there hadn\u2019t been one before. Inevitably, that had to include people planning to do something else with their lives.\u201d\n\nAs with Morath, though, photography for Brassa\u00ef began with the written word. After dodging combat duty in the Austro-Hungarian Army because of a sprained knee, and a brief period in Berlin, he arrived in Paris and began writing for various European publications. He didn\u2019t want his name associated with work he considered dull compared with the more serious arts he wanted to take up later \u2014 like painting, or sculpture, another one of his pursuits \u2014 so he adopted the byline Gyula Brassa\u00ef and finally, in the 1930s, Brassa\u00ef, which means, \u201cof Brasso.\u201d To supplement his articles, Brassa\u00ef commissioned photographers and collected old photographs, operating what he would describe as a small photo agency.", "title": "Brassai: The \u2018Eye of Paris\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDo you think breakdancing should be an Olympic event? What about other kinds of dance? Why do you think so?\n\nBreakdancing, skateboarding, cross-country running, rugby sevens, sport climbing, indoor soccer, beach handball and a basketball dunk contest are among some of the Olympic and Youth Olympic events that have begun to bend the definition of sports.\n\nWhat other \u201csporting\u201d events would you like to see featured in the Olympics and why?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to see the possibilities one writer came up with.", "title": "Breakdancing", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe spend so much time in solitary screen-based worlds, so it is magical when people from a wide range of ages come together and solve a challenge,\u201d said Scott Nicholson, a professor at Wilfrid Laurier University in Ontario who teaches a course in creating escape rooms.\n\nThe vast majority of escape rooms in the United States are mom-and-pop operations with one or two sites, Ms. Spira said. From chains to smaller outfits, the format is similar. A group of about four to eight people play an hourlong game that could include escaping a prison, evading a serial killer or finding a cure to a deadly disease. Once one puzzle in the escape room is solved, a clue unlocks the next challenge. Hidden doors often reveal new spaces such as secret passageways as the game proceeds.\n\nThe outcome is not guaranteed. If players get stuck, escape room staff, often in character, provide hints. The success rate varies, but only about 30 percent to 50 percent of participants escape a given room in the time allotted, Ms. Spira said.\n\nAdmission usually ranges from $20 to $45 per person, with escape rooms in bigger cities usually charging more. Some business owners earn close to a half-million dollars a year, Mr. Spira said, although getting accurate data is difficult because the companies are private and do not release financial figures.\n\nWell-designed games draw on many types of knowledge, so all players have a chance for a \u201chero moment,\u201d said Summer Herrick, a co-founder of Locurio, an escape room in Seattle.", "title": "Breaking Into the Boom in Escape Rooms: What Entrepreneurs Need to Know", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "It was an English monarch who purportedly said, \u201cNo news is better than evil news,\u201d and thereby launched an enduring (though now somewhat less wordy) maxim. Unless, King James I should have added, it\u2019s news about his successors.\n\nFrom the time Catherine, the Duchess of Cambridge, entered the maternity hospital until she and her husband, Prince William, emerged with their newborn boy 12 hours later, the minutiae of the royal birth on Monday dominated the news in Britain \u2014 and not only there. The arrival of the French president, Emmanuel Macron, in Washington was no competition for the suspense in London, broken shortly after 11 a.m. not by the traditional notice in a wooden frame posted by the gates of Buckingham Palace (that came later, carried out by two women in morning coats, black ties and bright red waistcoats) but by a tweet from Kensington Palace that the duchess \u201cwas safely delivered of a son.\u201d\n\nBefore and after that there was little the inquiring public would not learn. It was \u201cbreaking news\u201d when Prince William brought his other children, little Prince George, still in his school uniform, and Princess Charlotte, who gave an oh-so-precious wave to the crowd, to visit their new brother. The royal obstetrician and royal gynecologist \u2014 \u201croyal\u201d was the word of the day \u2014 were richly profiled. The fact that Lady Gabriella Windsor, the daughter of Prince and Princess Michael of Kent, had been born in the same hospital on the same day, only 37 years earlier, was presented as a remarkable coincidence. Westminster Abbey announced it would ring a full peal of \u201cCambridge Surprise Royal\u201d on Tuesday; tabloids noted with disapproval that the Labour Party leader, Jeremy Corbyn, took more than three hours to send his greetings to \u201cKate and William.\u201d\n\nAnd so it went. That which did remain unknown by day\u2019s end \u2014 the baby\u2019s name and the godparents \u2014 was endlessly discussed. Bookmakers were putting odds on Arthur, Albert, Frederick, James and Philip; as for sponsors, the speculation was that a third child with few chances of ever ascending the throne would not need a roster of prominent godparents like his siblings.", "title": "Opinion | Breaking News! A Prince Is Born!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nReading \u201cMom Is Running for Office,\u201d by Susan Chira (news analysis, Sunday Review, April 15), I wondered: Why are we still arguing about women nursing on the legislative floor?\n\nIn 1977, four days postpartum, I voted on the New Hampshire state budget. It was a tight vote; every vote counted. I had been elected to serve my constituents, and chose not to abandon my responsibility.\n\nAnd of course I would not abandon my newborn daughter. Like so many women all over the world, I put her in a sling to nurse and went about my day. A male legislator lobbied me and never noticed the nursing baby.\n\nWhy, 40 years later, when breasts are exposed in bus ads, in movies and on tops of buildings, is modesty required of lactating mothers? Perhaps legislators need a sex education course that teaches them that breasts do not exist merely for their sexual pleasure, but to perpetuate the human race.", "title": "Opinion | Breast-Feeding and Legislating", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cU.K. Universities Face Uncertainty as Brexit Looms\u201d (Learning section, nytimes.com, April 5):\n\nBrexit is creating uncertainty for British universities that is acutely felt by our European students and staff members. But our global vision remains clear.\n\nImperial College London and other British universities are assertively campaigning in Westminster and Brussels for policies that support talent mobility and access to European research programs.\n\nOver the last decade, Imperial scholars collaborated on more than 60,000 research papers with European peers. We want that figure to grow. That is why we started a seed fund after the Brexit vote, independent of government. It is supporting scores of Imperial academics\u2019 European collaborations in fields like data privacy, particle physics and cancer prevention.\n\nWe have started similar seed funds with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and with Tsinghua University in Beijing as our global ambitions grow. Imperial recently opened an international mathematics laboratory in London with CNRS, France\u2019s research agency. It cements the status of our two countries as global leaders in mathematics, artificial intelligence and aligned disciplines.", "title": "Opinion | Brexit and the Universities: \u2018Our Global Vision Remains Clear\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "In a series of tweets, the president inaccurately stated that Mr. Kim had \u201cagreed to denuclearization.\u201d In fact, North Korea said it would consider relinquishing its nuclear weapons and was ending testing. The suspects are believed to be in Russia.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 When Facebook expands into developing countries, it is often welcomed as a force for good. First in the series is \u201cThe Middle,\u201d a song written by a shy Australian that took producers more than a year to mold into an international hit.\n\n\u2022 \u201cPollution Pods\u201d at an art installation in London are five geodesic domes that simulate the air quality in five cities, from cleanest (Tautra, Norway) through varying levels of pollution (London, New Delhi, Beijing and S\u00e3o Paulo).\n\n\u2022 \u201cCannabis mania.\u201d In Italy, hemp flowers were recently legalized (it\u2019s still forbidden to eat or smoke them), creating a booming industry. Is it a bubble waiting to be burst?\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHere we are in front of the elephants.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a phrase that you probably don\u2019t recognize, but it helped launch a platform that you probably do: YouTube.\n\nThirteen years ago today, one of the video-sharing site\u2019s co-founders, Jawed Karim, above, published its first clip: a brief video of himself at the San Diego Zoo.\n\nYouTube now has over a billion users who consume a billion hours of video each day. With five billion views, the music video for \u201cDespacito\u201d is the most-watched video on YouTube. (Here\u2019s a full list.)\n\nPeople can watch Tom Cruise jump off Oprah Winfrey\u2019s couch on repeat; laugh at a baby biting his brother\u2019s finger; and relive the world\u2019s introduction to the singer Susan Boyle.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYouTube, now owned by Google, was dreamed up by Mr. Karim and two other former PayPal employees. They were initially depressed by YouTube\u2019s content: \u201cThere\u2019s not that many videos I\u2019d want to watch,\u201d one lamented.\n\nThe trip to the zoo was one of those videos.\n\n\u201cThe cool thing about these guys is they have really, really, really long trunks and that\u2019s cool,\u201d Mr. Karim says in the 19-second video, which has more than 48 million views. \u201cAnd that\u2019s pretty much all there is to say.\u201d\n\nRemy Tumin wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Brexit, Emmanuel Macron, Hemp: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Dan Levin"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "When James Garish married his kindergarten crush Liz Stipkovits on Feb. 17 near their hometown, McKeesport, Pa., it wasn\u2019t with the expectations many couples entertain, about raising a family and growing old together.\n\nMr. Garish, 34, and Ms. Stipkovits, 34, had been dating since 2010, when he was serving in the Army in Iraq and looked her up on Facebook. They hadn\u2019t been in touch since they were 5 and Mr. Garish was the kindergarten class rabble-rouser. But \u201cI wanted to see how life had turned out for her,\u201d he said.\n\nIt had turned out O.K. Ms. Stipkovits was then working as a medical receptionist and raising a daughter, Maleena, as a single parent in McKeesport. Four years later, though, she would get her first breast cancer diagnosis. By the time they decided to marry, in 2017, the cancer was advancing toward her brain.\n\n\u201cLittle Bad Jimmy,\u201d as Ms. Stipkovits remembered Mr. Garish from their school days, never left her side.", "title": "Bride Dies Two Months After Her Dream Wedding", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "TOKYO \u2014 Kaori Masukodera remembers, barely, riding as a child with her mother, her hair teased and her lips bright red, in the family\u2019s convertible to the beach. It was the last gasp of the 1980s, a time of Champagne, garish colors and bubbly disco dance-floor anthems, and the last time many people in Japan felt rich and ascendant.\n\nA so-called Lost Decade and many economically stagnant years later, the family\u2019s convertible and beach vacations are long gone \u2014 but Ms. Masukodera is helping to bring the rest of Japan\u2019s bubble era back. She performs in a pop-music duo called Bed In that borrows heavily from the keyboard lines, electric drums and power chords of the \u201980s. They dress \u201980s, too: The shoulder pads are big, the skirts are mini and the hues are Day-Glo when they aren\u2019t just plain shiny.\n\n\u201cUntil a few years ago, most people saw the bubble period as a negative legacy, and it was considered quite tacky,\u201d said Ms. Masukodera, 32, wearing a tight blazer with jutting shoulder pads emblazoned with images of the Tokyo nightscape, paired with a miniskirt and gold jewelry.\n\n\u201cThat completely changed in the last few years,\u201d she added. \u201cNow people recognize it as kind of a cool period.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJapan is in the midst of its most prosperous period in decades, as the economy cranks up and companies scramble for increasingly scarce workers. Still, for many people in Japan, that only underlines how far the country has fallen from the heights of the \u201980s \u2014 wages are barely rising, the population is aging and shrinking, and many feel that Japan\u2019s best days are over.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat feeling has helped fuel nostalgia for the last time Japan was unquestionably on top of the world, joining a global reappreciation for the \u201980s in general.", "title": "Bright Lights, Big Shoulder Pads: A Timid Japan Recalls Its Bubble Era", "authors": ["Mari Saito"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "One of the more ravishing spaces is in the basement, where Juan Montoya built an entire living room \u2014 from the paneling to the ceiling \u2014 from scratch. The designer said he was inspired by \u201ccosmic forces.\u201d In his living room, one floor up, David Netto recalled the Manhattan of his youth. Now 48, Mr. Netto was a teenager during the heyday of Kips Bay, when Mario Buatta, the so-called Prince of Chintz, and Mark Hampton , the scholarly traditionalist, squared off like gladiators in show house after show house, alongside Albert Hadley or Joe D\u2019Urso or John Saladino, designers whose flourishes were more modern. Manhattan in those days was a tale of two cities, both of which were radical in their own fashion.\n\n\"There was the downtown, music-driven club world,\" Mr. Netto said, \"and the uptown, neo-Gilded Age, neo-Rothschild fantasy\" that was erupting along Park Avenue, where Mr. Buatta and Mr. Hampton were creating blood red habitats with acres of damask and armies of old masters for their robber baron clients. Park Avenue wives would shop at Kips Bay, swooping in to buy entire rooms \u2014 from pelmet to pilaster \u2014 and you might find yourself, as Mr. Netto once did, meeting exiles from earlier eras, like Slim Keith, one of Truman Capote\u2019s swans. \u201cLady Keith, Mario called her,\u201d Mr. Netto said, meaning Mr. Buatta.", "title": "Bright Lights, Big Sofas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "at 20 seconds\n\nRunners-up\n\nMuch of the attention after the Pulitzer Prize in Music was announced this week was focused on the winner. Understandably: Kendrick Lamar, a popular and critical darling, became the first hip-hop performer \u2014 indeed, the first artist outside classical and jazz \u2014 to get the prize, for his album \u201cDAMN.\u201d\n\nBut there is sensitivity and sincerity in a string quartet by Michael Gilbertson, one of the two finalists. The other, Ted Hearne, was recognized for \u201cSound from the Bench,\u201d a cantata for choir (the extraordinary Crossing, out of Philadelphia), electric guitars and drums. Melting voices, driving rhythms, wailing guitar: Mr. Hearne conjures a kind of medieval-psychedelic landscape to reflect on fragments of texts from Supreme Court proceedings about the ambiguous nature of speech and identity. The piece commands attention from the beginning, as a moment of stillness and purity is shattered by a guitar\u2019s growl. ZACHARY WOOLFE\n\nRead a conversation about the implications of Mr. Lamar\u2019s Pulitzer win.\n\nRead a remarkable, inspiring interview with Mr. Hearne and Mr. Gilbertson.", "title": "Bristling Energy: The Best Classical Music Moments of the Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is a game-changer,\u201d said Andrew Bazeley, a policy manager at the Fawcett Society, a British organization that campaigns for women\u2019s rights and equality. \u201cIt will force businesses to think about the gender pay gap in ways they might not have before.\u201d\n\nUnder the new reporting requirements, companies with 250 or more employees must publish salary differences between men and women every year. They are also required to provide details on gaps in average bonuses paid, and the proportion of men and women who received those bonuses.\n\nImage Johan Lundgren, easyJet\u2019s chief executive, is taking a 4.6 percent pay cut to match the salary of his female predecessor. Credit Georges Gobet/Agence France-Presse \u2014 Getty Images\n\nThe submissions have made for uncomfortable reading for company executives. At Goldman Sachs\u2019s sprawling moneymaking machine in Britain, women are paid an average of 56 percent less than men. Men outearn women by around 52 percent at easyJet, the country\u2019s busiest discount airline. And at WPP, the British advertising giant, women take home, on average, around one-quarter less than their male counterparts.\n\nStill, at least in some cases, the requirement to publish the data has made an impact as big companies have scrambled to counter the fallout from embarrassing reports. EasyJet has said its male chief executive would take a 4.6 percent pay cut to match the salary of his female predecessor, and pledged to more than triple the proportion of its female pilots.\n\nIn other cases, a change in the pay culture has been pushed from the outside. At Mills & Reeve, a British law firm whose audit determined it was paying women an average of 32 percent less than men, a major impetus has come from big clients that have started to request more female representation among the firm\u2019s attorneys.", "title": "Britain Aims to Close Gender Pay Gap With Transparency and Shame", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "As lunchtime approached, he grew increasingly emphatic. \u201cThe sheer amount that was taken on Arthur has forced us to cut it to 2 to 1,\u201d he said. \u201cSo, yeah, I have no idea why so many people are confident in Arthur.\u201d\n\nThe participation of bookmakers at a royal birth has become a ritual.\n\nBy comparison to sports-betting pools, interest in names is not huge \u2014 amounting to roughly 100,000 individual bets, and about a quarter million pounds, or $350,000, said Jessica Bridge, the head of public relations for sports and news at Ladbrokes. The pool stands out because it is about 70 percent female and because the bets tend to be small ones, made by once-a-year betters who \u201cenjoy a wee flutter on events that take over the entire nation,\u201d Ms. Bridge said.\n\n\u201cAnd, of course, we love a good, happy news story, so it\u2019s nice to feel a part of it somehow,\u201d she added.\n\nLately, the news stories around betting in Britain have not been happy.\n\nOn Tuesday, The Times of London reported that the British treasury would reduce the maximum bet on fixed odds betting terminals from about $140 every 20 seconds to around $3, sending share prices in betting companies plummeting. The betting industry had lobbied vigorously to stave off a crackdown on the machines, which generated a profit of $2.5 billion in 2016.\n\nLast year, sports and betting companies were the top donors to members of Parliament, according to official declarations published in August. The Ladbrokes Coral group appeared more than 15 times on the register, more than any other donor. But the efforts did not save the terminals, dubbed \u201cthe crack cocaine of gambling\u201d by one lawmaker.", "title": "Britain Greets New Prince in Old Style: By Placing a Bet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Our reporters note that the U.S. military is generally barred by law from carrying out domestic law enforcement functions like apprehending people at the border. Rubin, our former Baghdad bureau chief, made a return trip to northern Iraq \u2014 and found herself navigating checkpoints as endless as the rival armed fighters manning them.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nEach week, The Times\u2019s crossword column, Wordplay, highlights the answer to one of the most difficult clues from the previous week\u2019s puzzles.\n\nThis week\u2019s word: Niobe.\n\nThe Greek mythological character Niobe was the subject of a tough clue from last Wednesday\u2019s crossword puzzle: \u201c \u2018Like ___, all tears\u2019: Hamlet.\u201d The word has appeared in Times crosswords 139 times.\n\nNiobe is most closely associated with tears, as noted in William Shakespeare\u2019s \u201cHamlet\u201d:\n\n\u201cA little month, or ere those shoes were old With which she followed my poor father\u2019s body, Like Niobe, all tears. Why she, even she \u2014 O God, a beast that wants discourse of reason Would have mourned longer! \u2014 married with my uncle \u2026\u201d\n\nIt was arrogance that was Niobe\u2019s undoing, and the cause of her tears.\n\nThe story of Niobe\u2019s tears began at a ceremony held to honor the Titan Leto, mother of the twin gods Apollo and Artemis. In a fit of arrogance, Niobe bragged that she was superior to Leto because she had more children (either 12 or 14, depending on the version of the myth).\n\nWhen the twins heard this, they came to earth and killed all of Niobe\u2019s children. In deep anguish, she ran to Mount Sipylus to beg the gods to end her pain. Zeus felt sorry for her and turned her into a rock, so she would not feel anymore.\n\nHowever, even as a rock, Niobe\u2019s tears continued to flow, and the stream that pours from the real Weeping Rock in Manisa, Turkey, symbolizes a mother\u2019s eternal mourning.\n\nDeb Amlen contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\n\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. The French photographer Willy Ronis captured France\u2019s capital and its people with warmth, humanity and compassion. The first major retrospective of his work since his death opened this week at the Pavillon Carr\u00e9 de Baudouin in Paris, and it\u2019s keeping his generosity alive: Entrance is free.\n\n\u2022 One of our most-discussed recent stories was about \u201cI Feel Pretty,\u201d the Amy Schumer movie that attests that it\u2019s what\u2019s inside us that matters. It\u2019s not that simple, our critic at large writes. Beauty standards are stricter than ever \u2014 it\u2019s just become taboo to admit that.\n\n\u2022 How the Golden State Killer left a trail: A serial rapist and murderer in California flaunted his power as well as his belief that he could elude accountability forever. The breakthrough that finally snared a suspect came via a public genealogy website.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nNatural wonder, honeymoon site and tourist attraction in two countries.\n\nBy the time Niagara Falls was established as a New York State park on this day in 1885, it was already popular.\n\nA French priest is credited with telling the world about the waterfalls at the border of the United States and Canada in the late 1600s.\n\nThe region later became a place of escape for slaves fleeing the American South. (The Niagara Falls Underground Railroad Heritage Center opens this weekend.)\n\nIn the 1800s, tourists and honeymooners began to come in large numbers, with an 1851 report of up to 100,000 seasonal visitors.\n\nDaredevils helped make it popular. People walked on tightropes across it and went over the edge in barrels \u2014 including Anna Edson Taylor, the first recorded person to go over the falls and live. Eventually such stunts were banned as too dangerous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJust how dangerous Niagara can be is evident in this 1954 video showing the collapse of a section of American Falls.\n\nBut despite an increase in kitschy attractions, perhaps not much has changed since an 1889 travel guide: \u201cOne might, I imagine, spend two months here and not grow tired of the ever-varying beauty; but he would get tired of the ever-monotonous crowd.\u201d\n\nSarah Anderson wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. (In addition to our European edition, we have Australian, Asian and U.S. editions.)\n\nSign up here to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, and here\u2019s our full range of free newsletters.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Britain, Pamplona, Killer Caterpillars: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Dan Levin"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The United States on Tuesday ratcheted up its efforts to block Kremlin-linked industrialists from doing business in the West, warning that British banks will have to sever their relationships with the tycoons if they want continued access to American financial institutions.\n\nSigal P. Mandelker, a top American Treasury official in London to meet with her counterparts, said British banks could face \u201cconsequences\u201d if they continued to carry out significant transactions on behalf of the 24 influential Russians sanctioned by Washington on Friday. The list includes the industrialists Oleg Deripaska and Viktor Vekselberg, along with Kirill Shamalov, who American officials have identified as President Vladimir V. Putin\u2019s son-in-law.\n\n\u201cThese are blocking sanctions,\u201d Ms. Mandelker, under secretary of the Treasury for terrorism and financial intelligence, said at a briefing with reporters. \u201cThere of course would be consequences for U.K. financial institutions\u201d that continued to do business with the Russians.\n\nThe warning has resonated in London, which for decades has served as a haven for Russia\u2019s wealthiest families. Russian investors own iconic British assets like the Chelsea Football Club and swaths of high-end London real estate, and they support thriving networks of lawyers, financial advisers and estate agents.", "title": "British Banks Will Have to Cut Ties to Sanctioned Oligarchs, U.S. Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "United States publishers have long coveted the European market, and with Britain scheduled to formally part ways with the union by March 2019, some are gearing up for an invasion. A warning flare of sorts was fired last fall at the Frankfurt Book Festival, when Simon & Schuster\u2019s chief executive, Carolyn Reidy, told an audience that, after Brexit, \u201cthe argument the British have used to grab Europe as an exclusive market will then be over.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s about as close to a public declaration of hostilities as you can expect. The battle for Europe\u2019s book market is already being fought quietly wherever author contracts are drafted. These contracts always include a list of territories where publishers want exclusive rights of distribution. More and more often, the list now drafted by American publishers includes the European continent.\n\nPatrick Walsh, a literary agent based in London, has seen Europe included in early drafts of two deals with United States publishers. In both cases, the publishers argued that by the time the book was in stores, Britain and the European Union will have parted company. In both cases, Mr. Walsh pushed back, suggesting that it was too early to know how Brexit would play out, and the codicil was removed.\n\n\u201cIt was a relatively friendly opening gambit,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I\u2019m absolutely certain we\u2019re going to see more of this.\u201d\n\nMuch of the talk here about the terms of Britain\u2019s divorce from Europe has centered on banks, real estate and blue-collar industries like fishing and mining. But the creative sector is also bracing for change and fretting about life after Brexit. Few are as worried as the roughly 30,000 people employed by the British book business.\n\nPart of it is a concern that Britain will cease to serve as one of the world\u2019s great cultural hubs. London in particular has been a huge attraction for foreign artists in fields like contemporary dance and theater.\n\n\u201cThose people are based here because they can come and go,\u201d said Andrew Franklin, co-founder of Profile Books, a London publishing house. \u201cThe same is true of literary culture. It\u2019s hugely dependent on new voices coming in from other places, and I worry that as this place puts up walls, the literary culture will become more isolated, with a consequent effect on publishing.\u201d", "title": "British Book Publishers Fear Brexit Will Bring a U.S. Invasion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Some have been detained. At least one man was denied cancer treatment because he could not prove to his doctors that he was in the country legally.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPrime Minister May at first tried to place the blame on the Labour Party, but she was forced to back down in the face of evidence that the groundwork for the scandal was laid during the years that she was the home secretary, the cabinet minister responsible for overseeing immigration.\n\nThe Labour Party, in the person most prominently of David Lammy, a black member of Parliament whose parents were Windrush-era migrants, has accused Mrs. May of presiding over racist policies and has demanded that her home secretary, Amber Rudd, resign.\n\nBeyond pledging to grant citizenship to all those caught up in the migration crackdown and to waive the fees and tests usually involved in that process, the Home Office has established a special team to expedite applications.\n\nBut the scandal has had a particularly distasteful resonance for black Britons, who say it is a symptom of lingering racism within government institutions.\n\nUnder the rules imposed when Mrs. May was home secretary, people were required to prove their identity and legal status in the country in order to get a job, rent an apartment, receive free medical care, open a bank account or enroll in school, among other things.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat created an immediate problem for Windrush-era migrants like Mr. McIntyre, who struggled to prove their status. They had been unaware that they had to apply for the necessary documentation; theoretically, they have indefinite permission to remain under a 1971 law.\n\nTheir plight surfaced now and then in the news, but came to prominence after a series of reports in The Guardian. The Home Office, the newspaper reported, had not kept a record of those granted permission to remain or issued any paperwork confirming it. Then, in 2010, it even destroyed the landing cards recording migrants\u2019 arrivals from the Caribbean.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. McIntyre questioned the motive behind the destruction of landing cards. \u201cWhy did they do that?\u201d he asked. \u201cTo me, it seems like they want to get rid of us.\u201d\n\nIt has seemed that way to many in a generation of workers who accepted an invitation to come to Britain. They pitched in as construction and railway workers, nurses, bus and truck drivers, among other, mostly blue-collar pursuits, never suspecting that their status as British citizens or legal residents would be challenged.\n\nMany black Britons say institutionalized racism of the kind endured by the Windrush migrants remains deeply ingrained and rarely publicized.\n\nDanesha Forte, 37, whose parents were Windrush migrants from Barbados, could not hide her exasperation.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s atrocious,\u201d Ms. Forte said, as she stood in Windrush Square in Brixton, the heart of London\u2019s West Indian community. \u201cWhy are they targeting us? Are they trying to create a riot?\u201d The neighborhood was the scene of major riots in 1981 and again in 1985, as young black men clashed with a police force they believed was persecuting their community.\n\n\u201cBlack people are always targeted for something,\u201d Ms. Forte said, adding that the police still disproportionately stopped and searched black people, particularly the young. \u201cIt\u2019s one thing after the other. We just can\u2019t catch a break.\u201d\n\nBritain, Ms. Baptiste said, remains enamored with romantic visions of its imperial past, a sentiment that in part drove its decision to leave the European Union. \u201cWe are an empire,\u201d she said, \u201cbut for some people here, there are still too many dark faces.\u201d\n\nMost Britons are not taught about the prominent roles blacks played at royal courts in 15th-century Tudor Britain. Nor is it widely known that millions of ordinary Britons, even humble shopkeepers, owned shares in the slave trade. And across Britain, heritage plaques on Georgian townhouses euphemistically describe former slave traders and slave owners as West Indies merchants or planters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA rose-tinted narrative of the British Empire was also peddled to its colonial subjects. Barbadians, for example, had been taught to revere the \u201cmother country,\u201d a mythical land populated by gentlemen, said Peter Fryer, author of \u201cStaying Power: The History of Black People in Britain.\u201d\n\nBefore moving to Britain for work, \u201cThey took their British citizenship seriously, and many regarded themselves not as strangers but as kinds of gentlemen,\u201d he wrote. \u201cEverything taught in school encouraged this belief. What they found here dismayed and shocked them.\u201d", "title": "British Citizen One Day, Illegal Immigrant the Next", "authors": ["Kimiko De Freytas-Tamura"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Britain\u2019s military laboratory has not established whether the nerve agent that poisoned a Russian former double agent and his daughter came from Russia, the laboratory\u2019s chief executive said on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cWe have not verified the precise source,\u201d the executive, Gary Aitkenhead, told Sky News. Mr. Aitkenhead said his laboratory, the Defense Science and Technology Laboratory, had confirmed that the poison was Novichok, or from its family of nerve agents, and that it was of military grade.\n\n\u201cWe provided the scientific information to the government, who have then used a number of other sources to piece together the conclusions they have come to,\u201d Mr. Aitkenhead said. He said it was \u201cnot our job to say where it actually was manufactured.\u201d\n\nThe British authorities have blamed Russia for the March 4 poisoning, with Foreign Minister Boris Johnson suggesting it was \u201coverwhelmingly likely\u201d that President Vladimir V. A spokesman, Douglas Cohen, said the department was also seeking to remove Mr. Braddy from its payroll.\n\nAt his arraignment on Thursday, Mr. Braddy\u2019s lawyer, Andrew Stoll, asked the presiding judge, Adam Perlmutter, to consider releasing Mr. Braddy on his own recognizance.\n\n\u201cI know the allegations are disturbing,\u201d Mr. Stoll said, but he contended that the charges were nonviolent felonies that do not require jail time.\n\nThe judge instead set Mr. Braddy\u2019s bail at $25,000 cash or $75,000 bond. But when the duo performed its hit \u201cStay a Little Longer,\u201d the singer T.J. Osborne reached the end of the final chorus and tilted his head toward his older brother John, who promptly went into a rhapsodic acoustic guitar solo.\n\nBesides showcasing some of the best-known entries in their catalogs, the participants in this songwriters round, a charity event called The First and the Worst, were asked to share some of their greenest, most embarrassing output for the audience\u2019s amusement. So the Osbornes offered \u201cDon\u2019t Bring the Redneck Out in Me,\u201d a song that reeled off rowdy, boastful good ol\u2019 boy stereotypes.
