Midway through a line about having three children and a wife, T.J., 33 and lanky with a long face and combed-back hair, paused to wryly point out that at 16, this was what he\u2019d thought country songs were supposed to be like.\n\nThe day before, at a taco shop the brothers frequent up to twice a day when they\u2019re not on the road, John, 35 and sporting a bushy, red beard with a ball cap over his shaggy mane, joked that \u201cDon\u2019t Bring the Redneck Out in Me\u201d was \u201cthe first official song we wrote that we thought, yeah, we\u2019ve got it all figured out.\u201d\n\nBack then, the Osbornes na\u00efvely assumed that copying country\u2019s familiar templates might get them somewhere. Later, they concluded it was far more important, and satisfying, to commit to a musical identity they could inhabit convincingly. The one they chose \u2014 a groove-driven, occasionally jammy singing-and-shredding duo \u2014 has made for a rather exotic presence in contemporary country over the last half-decade. Guitar heroes have receded from the spotlight, and even in Nashville, once nicknamed Guitar Town, studio production is frequently powered by drum machines, programming and synthesizers these days.", "title": "Brothers Osborne Want to Bring Guitar Heroes Back to Nashville", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "But the Browns, who have two of the first three picks in the second round Friday night (thanks to a trade that helped the Eagles net their starting quarterback, Carson Wentz, in 2016), were unquestionably the central players of the draft. Recently and historically, they have been the N.F.L.\u2019s most hapless franchise. They have sustained more than one front-office overhaul in the past few years, and their record over the past two seasons is 1-31.\n\nAt this point, though, there is method to the Browns\u2019 madness. In the N.B.A. and Major League Baseball, some franchises have adopted \u201ctanking\u201d \u2014 intentionally fielding a less-competitive team in order to stockpile and develop younger players \u2014 as a rebuilding strategy. After years of what the N.B.A.\u2019s Philadelphia 76ers have labeled \u201cThe Process,\u201d anchored by a few young stars, that team is a series away from its first Eastern Conference finals since 2001. Baseball\u2019s most successful recent tankers were the Houston Astros, the reigning World Series champion.\n\nAfter a few years of counterproductive mediocrity, the Browns got the losing thing right, going 1-15 in 2016 and a perfect 0-16 last season. That made them the first team to receive the top overall pick in consecutive years since 1999 and 2000. Of course, the Browns held the top spot those years, too.\n\nCleveland secured the fourth pick this year after trading the 12th pick last year to the Houston Texans, who used it to select a franchise quarterback in Deshaun Watson.\n\nThe Browns came away from this year\u2019s draft with what they hope will be their own franchise quarterback along with an immediate contributor on defense to go along with last year\u2019s top pick, Myles Garrett, an electric defensive end at Texas A&M who managed to lead the Browns in sacks last year while playing barely half their games because of injury trouble.\n\nGarrett was a no-brainer. Mayfield will prove much more controversial. His character is bold or brash, depending on one\u2019s perspective, as illustrated by his infamously planting an Oklahoma flag at Ohio Stadium\u2019s midfield last year after beating Ohio State. He also pleaded guilty to public intoxication last year.\n\nHe is shorter than a typical top quarterback prospect, and smaller than the other three selected high this year. But he is a two-time Heisman Trophy finalist \u2014 and the reigning winner \u2014 who led Oklahoma to the national semifinals with a sure and accurate arm.", "title": "Browns Take Baker Mayfield at No. 1 Amid a Quarterback Frenzy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "BOSTON \u2014 Jake DeBrusk scored his second goal of the game to break a third-period tie, and the Boston Bruins came from behind to beat the Toronto Maple Leafs in Game 7 \u2014 again \u2014 winning, 7-4, on Wednesday night to advance to the Eastern Conference semifinals.\n\nKasperi Kapanen put Toronto ahead, 4-3, with a short-handed goal in the second, but Boston scored four times in the third period to pull away. Torey Krug tied the score, DeBrusk gave Boston the lead with 14 minutes 35 seconds to play, David Pastrnak added a goal with 8:21 left to help clinch the outcome, and Brad Marchand lofted one into the empty net with 51 seconds left to set off a celebration in the stands.\n\nTuukka Rask stopped just 20 of 24 shots for Boston, which will play the Tampa Bay Lightning in the second round. Game 1 is Saturday in Tampa.\n\nFrederik Andersen had 29 saves for the Maple Leafs, who have not won a playoff series since 2004. They came close in the first round in 2013, when they rallied from a three-games-to-one deficit against Boston and took a 4-1 lead in Game 7, but the Bruins rallied to win in overtime.", "title": "Bruins\u2019 Late Run Knocks Out Maple Leafs in Game 7", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Bruno Sammartino, an Italian immigrant who was heavyweight champion of the World Wide Wrestling Federation for a record 11 years in the 1960s and \u203270s, long before the federation admitted that its matches were scripted and largely choreographed entertainment shows, died on Wednesday at 82.\n\nHis death was announced on the website of WWE, the organization also known as World Wrestling Entertainment, a successor of the World Wide Wrestling Federation. No other details were provided, but a family friend and former wrestling announcer, Christopher Cruise, told The Associated Press that Sammartino had been hospitalized for two months. Sammartino lived in Pittsburgh.\n\nIn an era when the sports world, except for some die-hard wrestling fans, knew that professional matches were staged dramatizations, with heroes and villains, story lines and beefcake actors shamming the violence, Sammartino was one of the most popular performers in the business. He wrestled in Australia, Spain, Mexico, Canada and Japan, and often drew gates of 20,000 at Madison Square Garden, where he had more than 200 matches.\n\nUnlike many heavies on the pro wrestling circuits, he was a soft-spoken, gentlemanly connoisseur of grand opera, especially Verdi. And for one who had bench-pressed 565 pounds as an amateur, he was relatively small: under 6 feet tall and a trim 260 or 270 pounds, with bulging pectorals and biceps and a big head. He looked tiny beside giant rivals like Haystacks Calhoun, who topped 600 pounds.", "title": "Bruno Sammartino, Durable Champ in WWE Hall of Fame, Dies at 82", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Early in the morning, Natasha Pickowicz ducked into the walk-in refrigerator, the one all the way at the end of the dishwashing station in Caf\u00e9 Altro Paradiso\u2019s kitchen, and studied the family shelf. As usual, the tidy nook was stacked with plastic containers of odds and ends, leftover prep from the night before, set aside for staff meal. A pint of blanched broccolini stems here, a lump of blue-cheese butter there. But where anyone else might have seen a random muddle of junk, Natasha Pickowicz saw tarts \u2014 big, beautiful tarts that would feed the whole kitchen before noon.\n\nShe gathered a few pint containers: ham and red-onion scraps, spare confit leeks and yesterday\u2019s mashed potatoes, tatters of provolone and raw cauliflower debris. She reached for fluttery maitakes, a sticky paste of caramelized onions and a handful of cold, slightly sad-looking boiled potatoes with their skins still on. Pickowicz set everything on the counter, just across from a cook smashing raw beef for carpaccio. \u201cIt\u2019s really satisfying to find a purpose for all these things,\u201d she said, already seeing how the bits and pieces would come together on cold discs of pie dough.\n\nPickowicz is a pastry chef, known for desserts like her glamorous fruit crostatas and the pastries she makes at both Altro Paradiso and Flora Bar in New York. She started baking savory tarts at an old job when there was an excess of squash one summer, and now she builds a few out of whatever\u2019s on hand each morning, working quickly among the tasks on her to-do list so that she can set out a late breakfast for herself and the cooks. Her approach is spontaneous but deliberate, which is to say, the scraps are random, but there\u2019s nothing random about the way that Pickowicz composes them. \u201cI\u2019m always thinking critically about how they\u2019ll cook,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m thinking about creating layers, so when you bite into it, you\u2019re transitioning from tender dough through body and structure.\u201d I wasn\u2019t sure exactly what she meant, until I watched her make four tarts.\n\nFor one, she layered mashed potatoes and cauliflower over dabs of caramelized onion. After it came out of the oven and cooled, she covered it in parsley leaves and lemon zest and draped over those thin, soft pieces of ham. She arranged the leeks over smudged mascarpone and lemon zest, keeping it simple. For the third, she broke the potatoes apart with her hands, creating rough, jagged edges that would go golden as they roasted on the pastry \u2014 which she coated first with smears of ricotta and an oily condiment of preserved lemon. The maitakes, after they were roasted with red-onion pieces and caramelized onion for the very last tart, would be covered with crisp, dressed leaves of pink radicchio del Veneto.\n\nPhoto\n\nRepurposing leftovers, making something entirely whole and new from fragments, isn\u2019t only about economy and efficiency in the kitchen. There\u2019s joy in limiting yourself to what you already have, in finding a use for every scrap and stretching a little into a lot. At home, I made Pickowicz\u2019s pastry dough, with its giant flecks of butter, using as little ice water as possible to bring the crumbs together, and tucking some extra dough into the freezer for another day\u2019s tart. It was only technically spring in New York, so I didn\u2019t have much to work with. Some ricotta, some small boiled potatoes and a single shallot. I asked myself, what would Natasha do?\n\nI smeared ricotta all over the cold dough, grated lemon zest over the top and cracked a little bit of black pepper. Then I broke the potatoes up into big pieces with my hands, mixed in the sliced shallot and dressed it all with olive oil and salt. That went on top of the ricotta. I filled a few gaps with torn up provolone, using the last few slices in the fridge. And when the tart came out of the oven, when it had cooled down to room temperature, I seasoned it again and covered it in dressed radicchio leaves, which wouldn\u2019t have been quite enough to make a meal on their own. It was a delicious and inexact emulation, a spontaneous salad tart, and somehow it was big enough to feed six.\n\nRecipe: Potato-and-Radicchio Tart | Tart Crust", "title": "Build a Beautiful Savory Tart Out of Your Leftovers", "authors": ["Tejal Rao"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "What differentiates the Mayfield Innovation Center from traditional classrooms is evident not just in the virtual reality technology, the 3-D printers or the open architecture that make the two-floor, 30,000-square-foot building seem less of a secondary school than a Google satellite office.\n\nIt is also in the words emblazoned on the crimson-colored wall of the Computer-Aided Drafting and Design lab, a quote attributed to Curt Richardson, the founder of OtterBox, which makes consumer electronics accessories:\n\nFailure is a part of innovation. Perhaps the most important part.\n\nWait a minute. Failure, being extolled, even celebrated? In a high school?\n\nYes, in part because this is not a typical school. The center at suburban Mayfield City Schools, a district of 4,300 K-12 students 15 miles east of Cleveland, is a striking example of an approach to education that could eventually make traditional methods as outdated as chalk and blackboards.", "title": "Building Skills Outside the Classroom With New Ways of Learning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "General Electric will use Union Point as a laboratory for testing new products and as a showroom for working systems. Eric Gebhardt, the strategic technology officer at GE Power, said the community\u2019s energy plan will include micro grid technology, renewable generation and power storage. The company will also install \u201cintelligent\u201d lighting \u2014 streetlights with sensors that can track sound, light and other conditions. The data can be used to monitor traffic, help drivers find parking spaces and alert law enforcement if a gun is fired.\n\nG.E. has piloted some of its smart products in existing cities, but Union Point is an unusual opportunity because most of the infrastructure does not exist yet and the developer is open to experimentation, Mr. Gebhardt said.\n\nLStar plans to open an innovation center in the air station\u2019s old power plant. The center has expressed an interest in featuring an interactive planning tool developed by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology City Science Group called CityScope, which could aid in Union Point\u2019s evolution by allowing users to visualize and explore trade-offs around factors like density, transportation and walkability, said David Rose, a researcher and lecturer at MIT\u2019s Media Lab.\n\nPhoto\n\nLStar wants \u201cthe center to be a showcase for what the city could be, a place to monitor what it is becoming, and a place to ask existential questions like, \u2018Could it be more inclusive, say, or energy efficient?\u2019\u201d Mr. Rose said.\n\nLStar also has an agreement with Optimus Ride, an autonomous vehicle start-up in Boston, to set up a self-driving vehicle service at Union Point. The company is already testing its electric vehicles at the property.\n\nUnion Point\u2019s first commercial tenant is expected this spring, when Prodrive Technologies, a Dutch company that develops and manufactures products for the automotive, medical and other industries, will break ground on its 60,000-square-foot United States headquarters. The site\u2019s proximity to Boston, access to commuter rail service and ample room for expansion were crucial to the firm\u2019s location decision, said Roy Willems, the company\u2019s general manager of United States operations. He said Prodrive expected to build a second 200,000-square-foot building within three years, and increase its work force to roughly 300 people.\n\nLStar had to persuade the three host communities to approve critical zoning changes before it could move forward with the project. They also granted the developer considerable latitude over the design and layout of the community, which will take shape over 15 to 20 years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe three towns recognized an opportunity to do something quite extraordinary\u201d on a site where previous development plans stalled, said David P. Manfredi, a founding principal at Elkus Manfredi Architects, which helped create the master plan for Union Point. \u201cThis is an alternative to what could have been suburban sprawl.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nUnion Point promises to bring badly needed tax revenue to Weymouth, said the town\u2019s mayor, Robert L. Hedlund. \u201cIt\u2019s the commercial build-out that we\u2019re lusting after,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, similarly ambitious smart city projects have proved perilous. Mr. Rose cited Songdo, a smart city nearing completion in South Korea, as a prime example. The city boasts advanced connectivity, but it has so far failed to meet expectations in attracting international businesses and residents.\n\n\u201cWhat they got wrong was any sort of sense of streetscape,\u201d said Mr. Rose, who has visited Songdo. \u201cThere\u2019s no sense of patina, no authentic street life. It\u2019s super sterile. It was built as this fantasy of the future, but it\u2019s a place that humans don\u2019t want to occupy.\u201d\n\nThe integration of technology into urban planning has prompted questions about how the data being collected will be used. In Toronto, for example, Sidewalk Labs, a subsidiary of Alphabet, the parent company of Google, attracted considerable publicity when it was selected last year to help create a smart neighborhood of sorts in a waterfront district called Quayside. Some local officials and critics are questioning whether the deal gives too much authority to Sidewalk Labs without putting limitations on Google\u2019s collection and use of data.\n\nThe need for greater regulation of driverless vehicles has also come up for debate after the death last month of a woman who was struck by one of Uber\u2019s self-driving cars in Tempe, Ariz.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cVery few local governments have thought through the long list of public- and private-sector values and concerns that should be deployed to constrain\u201d the use of autonomous cars, as well as the technologies being used to monitor city streets, said Susan Crawford, a Harvard Law School professor. \u201cOnce you\u2019ve given a developer license to deploy total surveillance, with no public limitations, you\u2019re done.\u201d\n\nLStar has considerable leeway to test technologies at Union Point. The developer is purposely holding on to its roads, rather than asking for them to be made public ways, to maintain flexibility in testing autonomous vehicles, lighting and other technologies, said Robert Luongo, Weymouth\u2019s director of planning and community development.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf these were public ways, we might not be able to give them that flexibility,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Corkum said retaining ownership of the roads would enable them to play with designs for amenities like drop-off areas for driverless shuttles and heated sidewalks. \u201cIt\u2019s better for us to stay in this testing phase until we have good workable solutions,\u201d he said.\n\nState oversight of autonomous vehicles applies only once there is public use, he said. Even then, the rules are vague. Ryan Chin, the chief executive of Optimus Ride, said his company would adhere to the same high-level safety standards and testing protocols at Union Point that it followed for testing driverless cars in Boston\u2019s Seaport neighborhood.\n\nAs for privacy concerns, Mr. Corkum said that he believed in setting boundaries on data collection and use. There is value in using technology to improve quality of life by, for instance, alleviating traffic jams, but he said he was wary of falling prey to a \u201cpreoccupation with optimization.\u201d\n\nThe company is working with law firms and consultants on operating guidelines for gathering and anonymizing data and ensuring it cannot be hacked or used to invade privacy, he said.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like the Big Brother notion that we know everything about you,\u201d he said. \u201cWe will use data for the benefit of the group, not in a way to leverage the group.\u201d", "title": "Building a Connected City From the Ground Up", "authors": ["Lisa Prevost", "Square Feet"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Bridge\u201d meticulously depicts the enormity of the project, from meeting room intrigues to the sometimes perilous construction site. A scene in which the trustees consider naming the younger Roebling chief engineer (Their question: \u201cYou\u2019ve never supervised anything of this scale and magnitude, Mr. Roebling, is that right?\u201d His response: \u201cNo one has.\u201d) is followed a few pages later by a presentation on caissons \u2014 hollow, waterproof boxes made of wood and iron and filled with compressed air that allow workers to dig the riverbed. Roebling notes, \u201cThese will be the largest caissons ever built.\u201d\n\nThe book is Ms. DuVall\u2019s debut as a graphic novelist. She was approached during her final year at the School of Visual Arts. \u201c\u2018How do you feel about drawing bridges?\u2019\u201d she recalled being asked. \u201cI had never, never actually drawn many bridges before, but I didn\u2019t want to turn it down,\u201d she said. One of her favorite scenes is when Roebling and the workers get to the bedrock for the first time, for which Mr. Tomasi supplied reference images. \u201cIt looked so eerie,\u201d she said. \u201cI can\u2019t believe people worked down there.\u201d\n\nReviews of \u201cThe Bridge\u201d have been favorable. \u201cRather than being a story of a singular genius overcoming adversity, the book is a paean to collaboration,\u201d noted Publishers Weekly. \u201cIconic structures often have fascinating stories behind them, but rarely do the tellings emphasize the human as this one does.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt makes sense that this presentation of events, as conveyed by Mr. Tomasi, sounds like the makings of a Hollywood biopic. It was conceived as a screenplay. \u201cI wanted to write this story so I could see it visualized by a filmmaker,\u201d he said.\n\nThe inspiration for the project was the George Washington Bridge, which Mr. Tomasi could see from his childhood bedroom. He turned his attention to the Brooklyn Bridge in the mid-1990s, but found excuses not to pursue it. \u201cOnce 9/11 happened, it really set my focus,\u201d he said. \u201cI wanted to write something uplifting and hopeful.\u201d\n\nA reader can imagine a tense action scene when an excavation water chamber is clogged and Roebling dives in to clear it. Upon reading the news, his wife asks, \u201cDo you have a death wish?\u201d He tells her: \u201cI need to lead by example, Em. You know the dangers ahead better than anyone. They need to be fearless for $2 a day.\u201d It proves to be a harbinger of doom: Many of the laborers \u2014 and Roebling himself \u2014 would be stricken with decompression sickness or \u201ccaisson disease.\u201d \u201cThe slightest noise and intense lights would set him on edge. His nerves would go crazy,\u201d Mr. Tomasi said. Roebling \u201chad intense pain that he would have to deal with from his mid-30s until he died.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen Roebling gets the disease (which causes him intermittent paralysis and blindness), at about the book\u2019s halfway point, his wife becomes his eyes and ears. He communicates details involving the bridge\u2019s towers, the suspensions cables, the anchorages, the roadways and the electrics for her to administer. The reaction to her role by trustees and workers evolves from shock to bemusement to acceptance.\n\nMr. Tomasi and Ms. DuVall capture many historic moments: Frank Farrington crossing the span by cable and tipping his hat to the crowd below; Emily Roebling riding a horse-drawn carriage (with a rooster, an apparent symbol of good luck) on completion of the project; and a two-page spread of the Brooklyn Bridge in the glow of fireworks on the night it opened.\n\nBut the book ends on a quiet moment of artistic license. Weeks after the official opening, Roebling walks across the bridge with his wife. \u201cYou did it, Wash,\u201d she says. He responds: \u201cWe did it, Em. Together.\u201d", "title": "Building the Brooklyn Bridge, in Graphic Detail", "authors": ["George Gene Gustines"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Perhaps the most striking example was center William Karlsson, 25, who had 18 goals in 183 games with Columbus and Anaheim before this season, but scored 43 goals in 82 games for the Golden Knights.\n\nThe door opened for Karlsson when Vadim Shipachyov, the Knights\u2019 first marquee signing, did not make the team out of training camp and returned to Russia\u2019s Kontinental Hockey League.\n\n\u201cNot having that player make the team may have been our best move all year because it sent the message to everyone that nothing matters other than the way you compete and perform,\u201d McPhee said.\n\nKarlsson, formerly a checking center who last scored 20 goals in junior hockey, said he made no drastic changes to his routine or his body. He also said that he was not exactly a film buff when it comes to video scouting.\n\n\u201cHockey is a game of instincts, and that\u2019s how I play my best,\u201d Karlsson said.\n\nHe has embraced his newfound role, which has attracted other teams\u2019 top defensive pairings.\n\n\u201cI want to be that guy that leads the team; I put that pressure on myself,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Florida Panthers furnished the Knights with Karlsson\u2019s linemates, Jonathan Marchessault and Reilly Smith, receiving only a fourth-round draft pick in return. Marchessault and Smith combined for 135 points in 144 games playing for their former Florida coach, Gerard Gallant, who was fired by the Panthers early last season.\n\nLeft wing Erik Haula, 27, netted 55 points, and the veteran forward David Perron, 29, had 66; both were career bests.", "title": "Built to Win, the Golden Knights Did So Sooner Than Expected", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "The hundreds of pages of documents include Ms. Kristeva\u2019s supposed registration card as an agent of Bulgaria\u2019s former Committee for State Security and extensive reports of alleged conversations with her handlers in Parisian cafes and restaurants between 1971 and 1973. But there is not a single intelligence-related document written or signed by her.\n\nIn an interview on Thursday, Ms. Kristeva vigorously dismissed the accusation as \u201cfake news\u201d and a \u201cbarefaced lie\u201d \u2014 \u201cmud being slung at me,\u201d she said, by unspecified people who wished her harm.\n\nAfter the release of the dossier, she reiterated her denials in an interview on Friday. She had never been approached by anyone claiming to be a State Security agent, she said emphatically, and certainly never agreed to collaborate.\n\n\u201cThese allegations are completely false,\u201d she said, speaking in French. \u201cI find it quite extraordinary that the commission, which read these allegations, never thought that the secret services could have been lying.\u201d\n\nTo Ms. Kristeva\u2019s defenders, the case recalls something out of Franz Kafka \u2014 or perhaps one of her own murder mystery novels, which mix racy conspiracy plots with heady metaphysical speculation.\n\n\u201cEveryone is trying to keep an open mind, but nobody who knows anything about her or her work believes this,\u201d said Alice Jardine, a French literature professor at Harvard who is writing an intellectual biography of Ms. Kristeva.\n\nInstead of showing that Ms. Kristeva was a spy, she added, the dossier \u2014 which also includes intercepted letters and other surveillance of Ms. Kristeva \u2014 shows \u201chow she was targeted and spied upon.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Bulgaria, where opinion is divided, the case has stirred debate about what counts as collaboration and the reliability of the state security archives.\n\nSome have argued that Ms. Kristeva might have spoken to agents without realizing it. Others have called the evidence insufficient and have expressed doubt about the fairness of the procedure for branding someone a collaborator. (On Friday, after the release of the dossier, the commission announced that its website had been attacked by hackers.)\n\nMartin Dimitrov, a Bulgarian political scientist at Tulane University who has written about State Security, said the documents do seem to show that Ms. Kristeva knowingly, if not enthusiastically, shared information on French intellectual and political life with the agency.\n\nBut her handlers, he noted, frequently complained about her lack of commitment, and in 1973 dropped her as an associate after deeming most of the information she provided \u201cof little interest.\u201d\n\n\u201cWas she a spy? State Security thought so; she says otherwise,\u201d Mr. Dimitrov said. \u201cThis raises a question that is more moral than legal: Namely, who is a spy?\u201d\n\nMs. Kristeva was born in Sliven, Bulgaria, in 1941, to Christian Orthodox parents. In the recent documentary \u201cWho\u2019s Afraid of Julia Kristeva?\u201d she describes arriving in Paris in late 1965 to study literature on a French government scholarship, with the equivalent of $5 in her pocket.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy 1971, the year of her alleged recruitment, she was established and well-connected enough to be deemed a useful source of information by State Security. She was writing prolifically and was part of a group of politically engaged intellectuals around the avant-garde journal Tel Quel, including the critic Roland Barthes, the novelist Philippe Sollers (whom Ms. Kristeva married in 1967) and the philosopher Jacques Derrida.\n\nThe radical politics and intellectual glamour of that generation of French intellectuals were sent up in Laurent Binet\u2019s recent novel \u201cThe Seventh Function of Language,\u201d which imagined them as theory-addled James Bond wannabes embroiled in a conspiracy around the death of Mr. Barthes (who, in real life, died in 1980 after being hit by a laundry van).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn one scene Ms. Kristeva coolly confesses to murdering Mr. Barthes. There are also numerous deaths by poison-tipped umbrellas, a riff on the famous case of the Bulgarian dissident Georgi Markov, who was assassinated in London in 1978.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe spycraft described in Ms. Kristeva\u2019s dossier is far less dramatic. In January 1971, she reportedly asked to give testimony only orally, rather than in writing, and her handlers, who are identified by code names, agree.\n\nIn multiple reported meetings between that year and 1973, Ms. Kristeva allegedly offered information on French political and intellectual figures, Arab progressive movements, Bulgarian \u00e9migr\u00e9s and other subjects, most of which is deemed \u201cof little interest.\u201d (Among other things, she reports back on a Bulgarian national who had a stomachache.)\n\nThe operatives expressed dismay when Ms. Kristeva and Mr. Sollers signed a petition in Le Monde in 1972 protesting repression in Czechoslovakia. By that time, the Tel Quel group, like others on the French left, had broken with the pro-Soviet French Communist Party in the wake of the crushing of the Prague Spring, and turned toward Maoism.\n\nAccording to the dossier, the agency formally released Ms. Kristeva from the ranks in 1973 after handlers cited frustration with her \u201ccompletely pro-Maoist\u201d politics and her general lack of commitment. But operatives continued to communicate with her as late as 1978 with the hope of reactivating her.\n\nAt various points in the dossier, she is described as requesting travel permission for her parents, who were still in Bulgaria, and sister, who was in France on a limited visa.\n\nIn 1976, after she wrote a letter to a government office complaining that her parents were not allowed to visit their new grandson in Paris, a document reads: \u201cSabina is employing the same tactics once again \u2014 trying to get something from us without giving anything in return.\u201d\n\nIn the interview on Friday, Ms. Kristeva acknowledged that she had known Vladimir Kostov, a former Bulgarian spy who is described in one document as having met with her in France in the 1960s to \u201cpsychologically prepare\u201d her for possible work as an agent, and who some have suggested might also be behind one of the code names in the dossier. (After defecting, Mr. Kostov survived an apparent poison umbrella attack in the Paris Metro in 1978.)\n\nBut she said she was unaware that Mr. Kostov \u2014 whom she had worked with at a newspaper in Bulgaria, and recalled encountering again in Paris around 1974 or 1975 \u2014 had worked with State Security.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for the commission, she said it had put too much trust in the story the dossier told. \u201cThey saw it as a document, and not as a manipulation,\u201d she said.\n\nSince 2007, when the state security files were opened, there have been questions about material that may have been redacted, destroyed or manipulated. Hristo Hristov, a Bulgarian journalist who has written extensively about the state security files, said that parts of Ms. Kristeva\u2019s dossier appear to have been removed, but that the documentation that remained was persuasive.\n\n\u201cShe was clearly aware who she was meeting with and what kind of information she\u2019s providing,\u201d Mr. Hristov said.\n\nThat the file contains only accounts of Ms. Kristeva\u2019s alleged oral reports, and nothing written or signed by her, was not unheard-of, said Ekaterina Boncheva, a former journalist who has been a member of the commission for more than 10 years.\n\n\u201cThe important fact is that she has a registration card\u201d as an agent, she said.\n\nSince the fall of Communism in 1989, Ms. Kristeva has been vocal about her harsh judgment of the former Bulgarian regime.\n\nOn Thursday, she reiterated her belief that her father had been \u201cinvoluntarily assassinated\u201d in 1989 in a Bulgarian hospital where, she said, \u201cexperiments were carried out on the elderly.\u201d\n\nShe mentioned her 1991 novel \u201cThe Old Man and the Wolves,\u201d a postmodern parable about a professor who is the only person to speak out about sinister animals that begin arriving in a sleepy Eastern European town, and who then dies in a hospital after his artificial lung is disconnected.\n\nWith the release of the dossier, Ms. Kristeva said, she felt like the old man\u2019s daughter, who uncovers evidence of conspiracies she cannot untangle.\n\n\u201cBut fortunately, freedoms exist and we can talk,\u201d she said. \u201cI am going to keep siding with freedom of speech.\u201d", "title": "Bulgaria Says French Thinker Was a Secret Agent. She Calls It a \u2018Barefaced Lie.\u2019", "authors": ["Jennifer Schuessler", "Boryana Dzhambazova"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wildstein said the retail industry was \u201cbifurcated.\u201d \u201cThe department store model is being disrupted by Amazon,\u201d he said, and many department stores are suffering. On the other hand, he said, the home improvement giants are seemingly unaffected: \u201cHome Depot and Lowe\u2019s continue to do well.\u201d\n\nBrian Ruffner, manager of the Federated Bond fund, said auto parts stores should also flourish in a positive economic environment\n\nPhoto\n\nDebt loads aren\u2019t merely a concern for fixed-income investors. Equity investors need to be aware of debt loads at troubled companies because, in a severe case, bankruptcy would wipe out the value of any stock holdings.\n\nFor equity investors who are bullish about online retail outlets and skeptical about more traditional stores, the ProShares Long Online/Short Stores exchange-traded fund may be a useful vehicle: It invests in online purveyors while betting against challenged brick and mortar retailers.\n\nEnergy is another industry where debt is worrisome. Oil and gas companies carry large loads of lower-rated debt that is due to mature in the next five years, according to S.&P. New fracking technology has helped to expand domestic oil and gas output and loosened the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries\u2019 grip on prices. But as the new supply depresses prices, it also pinches cash flow.\n\nIndeed, 14 of 16 midsize and larger drillers tracked by Gordon Douthat, a director of equity research at Wells Fargo Securities, had higher capital spending costs than cash flow last year: Anadarko Petroleum, Noble Energy and Pioneer Natural Resources are among them.\n\nCarl Kaufman, who manages the Osterweis Strategic Income fund, said of domestic drillers: \u201cThose companies don\u2019t throw off any cash.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne central problem is the modest level of oil prices which, despite a recent rebound, remain well below highs of over $100 a barrel. Mr. Wildstein said he expects them to remain \u201caround $60\u201d \u201cWe don\u2019t believe they\u2019ll go back to the $70s or $80s,\u201d he said.\n\nFor investors who are bearish on the price of oil, there is the ProShares UltraShort Bloomberg Crude Oil E.T.F. For equity investors who expect domestic drillers to rebound eventually, there are E.T.F.s like iShares U.S. Oil and Gas Exploration & Production.\n\nTelecom debt also is worth watching. Citing increased price competition, Moody\u2019s has a negative outlook on the entire sector. Bill Wolfe, Moody\u2019s senior vice president, said the industry was rife with \u201clarge companies with a lot of debt,\u201d including Frontier Communications, CenturyLink and Sprint.\n\nPhoto\n\nVerizon Communications also carries a large debt load, but it may be something of a special case. \u201cThey\u2019re an extremely large issuer,\u201d Mr. Wildstein said.\n\nOne important positive for Verizon, Mr. Wolfe said, is that it has \u201cthe premier wireless network.\u201d But the cost of upgrading that network may also be a Verizon vulnerability. The company is moving aggressively to put in place 5G technology, which uses higher frequencies to speed wireless transmission. But 5G is expensive to install, and it faces widespread opposition in many municipalities and from some scientists, who say it entails health risks.\n\nMr. Wildstein\u2019s fund holds Verizon debt, and he says the company may be overly dependent on its wireless network. It needs to diversify by acquiring a cable provider or media company, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRobert Persons, a manager of the MFS Corporate Bond fund, is also concerned about Verizon\u2019s 5G expenditures. \u201cWe are monitoring that closely,\u201d he said. With uncertainty and controversy overhanging the 5G rollout, he wonders: \u201cWill it be worth the capital investment?\u201d\n\nVerizon lists its total debt as $117.1 billion. \u201cWe want to strengthen the balance sheet,\u201d Matthew D. Ellis, the company\u2019s chief financial officer, said on a Jan. 23 earnings call. \u201cYou should expect us to deleverage from where we are today,\u201d he added.\n\nOutside these industries, debt is high for much of corporate America but probably manageable, several analysts said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe leverage is elevated \u2014 companies are borrowing more,\u201d said Mr. Wolfe of Moody\u2019s. But since they are borrowing at historically low rates, their repayment abilities have not been measurably affected, he noted.\n\nAmong investment-grade companies, the ratio of earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, to interest expense has inched up to 9.9 in the 12 months through Sept. 30, 2017, from 9.7 in 2010. Companies with speculative-grade \u2014 also known as high-yield \u2014 debt have also seen their Ebitda-to-interest expense ratios improve a bit, Moody\u2019s reports.\n\nThe broad outlook for corporate bonds isn\u2019t entirely rosy. Interest rates have been rising, and S.&P. estimates that more than $4 trillion in corporate debt will have to be refinanced \u2014 presumably at even higher interest rates \u2014 by the end of 2022. But S.& P. doesn\u2019t expect this refinancing to cause undue problems.", "title": "Bulging Debt May Spell Trouble for Energy, Telecom and Retail", "authors": ["Norm Alster"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "In 2014, about 50 colleges had either announced or started CBE programs. In 2017, the education research firm Eduventures issued a report about 175 institutions with some level of CBE, even if just a course or two. Hundreds more say they are considering such programs.\n\nBut competency-based education is hard to put into effect because it is so different from traditional higher education \u2014 in the way courses are designed, the way faculty members are expected to teach, how long courses take and how students should be charged.\n\n\u201cThe demand side is there,\u201d said Howard Lurie, principal analyst at Eduventures. \u201cThe actual execution is limited.\u201d\n\nAt least so far. \u2014 Tara Garc\u00eda Mathewson\n\nShould Teachers Carry Guns?\n\nWe asked students to tell us what they think about arming teachers.\n\nImage\n\nKayin Jordan, 15, Maryland\n\n\u201cTeachers have it hard enough already. You\u2019re giving them more stress, worrying about this.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nJace Laquerre, 19, Vermont\n\n\u201cI would think everyone would want armed guards and police officers in school. I think it would do nothing but good.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nLucy James-Olson, 18, Delaware\n\n\u201cI understand the rationale behind having a resource officer. But it\u2019s not my personal preference. School should be a resource, not something you have to survive.\u201d\ufeff\n\nImage\n\nLisa Lawrence, 17, Delaware\n\n\u201cThe teacher\u2019s job is to teach us, to be ready for the real world. We need to focus on that.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nMichael Wigginton, 23, Virginia\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to stop these school shootings if we don\u2019t have reactionary measures in place to stop the school shooters.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nBenjamin Beard, 16, New Jersey\n\n\u201cArming teachers is a completely half-baked and stupid idea. It\u2019s a way for our politicians to dance around gun control.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Interviews by Emily Cochrane. Illustrations by Kyle Hilton.\n\nEducational Terms 101\n\nBLENDED LEARNING Any instruction that blends the use of computers with human teachers.\n\nPERSONALIZED LEARNING An instructional model in which each student studies at his or her own pace, often aided by technology. The student may also have some choice in what to study, the order in which topics are studied or the learning method.", "title": "Bulletin Board", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe kind of burlesque that we do has never been celebrated in mainstream shows,\u201d Una Osato said while applying eyeliner before an impromptu performance in Union Square Park in Manhattan a week before her Brooklyn show. \u201cPeople have limited views about who can perform burlesque and it\u2019s really important that we have created a space for women of color, transgender and queer folks .\u201d\n\nIn a city often heralded for its diverse art and performance world, spaces for \u201cnontraditional\u201d art \u2014 a term several members used to describe the way that performers of color are often spoken of \u2014 are limited. In addition to brASS, troupes like \u201cBrown Girls Burlesque\u201d in New York City (also co-founded by Ms. Crandell) and \u201cChocolate City Burlesque\u201d in Washington D.C. have been established as a response to the lack of opportunities.\n\nSweet Lorraine, a native of Jacksonville, Fla., moved to New York City to pursue a career in theater. She was introduced to burlesque when an internet search for black pinup models like Miss Topsy and Joyce Bryant in publications like Ebony and Jet magazines led her to vintage burlesque footage . Days after watching the footage, she enrolled in The New York School of Burlesque and began to perform in shows.", "title": "Burlesque, Redefined", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNearly five years after the government of President Bashar al-Assad agreed to purge Syria\u2019s chemical weapons stockpile, the chemical warfare shows no sign of ending as Syria\u2019s bloody civil war stretches into its seventh year.\n\nThe suspected chemical attack on a Syrian rebel stronghold near Damascus on Saturday was the latest in a string of similar deadly assaults, including one in 2013 that killed more than 1,400 and shocked the world\u2019s conscience.\n\nJohn Kerry, then secretary of state, called it a \u201cmoral obscenity.\u201d\n\nAnalysts have said that the use of poison gas, a war crime under international law, is integral to Mr. Assad\u2019s scorched-earth drive to regain control of the rebel-held areas near Damascus.\n\nHere is a look at some of the major episodes of suspected chemical attacks.\n\nPhoto\n\nAugust 2013: Sarin\n\nThe attacks in Syria began with blasts in the night. Some residents who heard the explosions and lived to tell about them described the sound like \u201ca water tank bursting.\u201d\n\n\u201cThen came the smell, which burned eyes and throats, like onions or chlorine,\u201d The New York Times wrote at the time.\n\nOpposition groups said rockets carrying chemical weapons hit the towns of Ain Tarma, Zamalka, Jobar and Muadamiya. Videos and photos posted online showed hundreds of bodies without visible wounds. Many victims exhibited symptoms like vomiting, intense salivating, suffocation and tremors. The chemicals were believed to be a \u201ccocktail\u201d of the toxic nerve agent sarin and other components.\n\nOpposition activists also posted photos of rockets they said were used in the attack. The deadliest toll fell on the heart of Eastern Ghouta.\n\nWhen the enormity of the attacks became clearer to the administration of President Barack Obama, Mr. Kerry accused the Syrian government of the \u201cindiscriminate slaughter of civilians\u201d and of cynical efforts to cover up its responsibility for a \u201ccowardly crime.\u201d\n\nThe attack spurred Mr. Obama to ask Congress for permission to launch a military counterattack. It also emerged as a test of Mr. Obama\u2019s willingness to hold to his stance that a chemical attack would cross a \u201cred line.\u201d\n\nIn 2012, he stated at an impromptu news conference at the White House:\n\n\u201cWe cannot have a situation where chemical or biological weapons are falling into the hands of the wrong people. We have been very clear to the Assad regime but also to other players on the ground that a red line for us is we start seeing a whole bunch of weapons moving around or being utilized.\u201d\n\nBut in 2013, as he drew criticism for not taking more decisive action on Syria after the suspected chemical attacks, Mr. Obama said while on a trip to Stockholm: \u201cI didn\u2019t set a red line. The world set a red line.\u201d\n\nIn September, the United States and Russia reached an agreement that called for Syria\u2019s arsenal of chemical weapons to be removed or destroyed by the middle of 2014.\n\nPhoto\n\nApril 2014: Poison Gas\n\nAn attack in the village of Kfar Zeita sent streams of choking patients to hospital, and Syrian state television and antigovernment activists said that poison gas had been used in the rebel-held village in the central province of Hama.\n\nAccording to opposition activists, government helicopters dropped improvised bombs on the village, covering it with a thick smoke that smelled of chlorine. Syrian state television blamed the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda\u2019s affiliate in Syria, for the attack.\n\nThe Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, said in a statement in September 2014 that it had collected evidence that chlorine had been used as a weapon, \u201csystematically and repeatedly,\u201d in three villages in northern Syria in April. A United Nations report also said chlorine attacks had taken place in April and May.\n\nMay 2015: Chlorine\n\nIn spring of 2015, two years after Mr. Assad agreed to dismantle Syria\u2019s chemical weapons stockpile, the smell of bleach hit the Syrian town of Sarmeen, making it difficult for residents to breathe.\n\nThat May, rescue workers began raising the alarm: There was growing evidence that the government was flouting international law to drop jerry-built chlorine bombs on insurgent-held areas.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe chemical is typically dropped in barrel bombs that explode on impact, distributing clouds of gas. The gas injures the respiratory tract, and, in some cases, can cause victims to choke to death as the lungs fill with fluid.\n\nHatem Abu Marwan, then 29, a rescue worker with the White Helmets civil defense organization, told The Times in 2015: \u201cWe know the sound of a helicopter that goes to a low height and drops a barrel. Nobody has aircraft except the regime.\u201d\n\nThe United Nations Security Council discussed a draft resolution that would create a panel, reporting to the secretary general, to determine which of the warring parties was responsible for using chlorine as a weapon. But Syrian state media dismissed it all as propaganda.\n\nPhoto\n\nAugust 2015: Mustard Gas\n\nLater that year, in August, the Syrian American Medical Society, a humanitarian group, said it had received more than 50 patients, 23 of whom showed symptoms of chemical exposure.\n\nSome had blisters associated with mustard gas after an attack in the city of Marea. A United Nations report blamed the Islamic State.\n\nSeptember 2016: Chlorine\n\nAnother attack in 2016 killed at least two people when barrels containing chlorine gas were dropped over a rebel-held section of Aleppo.\n\nUsing chlorine as a weapon is forbidden, but it was not included in the eradication of Syria\u2019s chemical weapons because it also has many civilian uses.\n\nPhoto\n\nApril 2017: Sarin\n\nAlmost exactly one year ago, dozens of people, including children, died on April 4, 2017, in Khan Sheikhoun, in northern Syria, and hundreds more were injured in what was described as the worst chemical attack in years.\n\nThis time, the doctors and rescue workers suspected something beyond chlorine gas. Soon after, the Turkish health minister confirmed a preliminary report that the nerve agent sarin had been found in the blood and urine of victims who were evacuated to Turkey.\n\nIn response, President Trump ordered a military strike that fired 59 Tomahawk missiles at the Al Shayrat airfield, where the chemical weapons attack had originated.\n\nPresident Vladimir V. Putin of Russia expressed doubt that the attack had happened and said it wasn\u2019t the Syrian government that possessed the chemical weapons \u2014 it was the insurgents fighting Mr. Assad\u2019s forces. The White House accused Russia of engaging in a cover-up.\n\nPhoto\n\nApril 2018: \u2018Chemical Agent\u2019\n\nIn the latest episode of violence, dozens of Syrians were killed in a suspected chemical attack in the rebel-held suburb of Douma, aid groups said on Sunday.\n\nThe Syrian Civil Defense and the Syrian American Medical Society said in a joint report that more than 500 people had gone to medical centers after the assault \u201cwith symptoms indicative of exposure to a chemical agent.\u201d Symptoms included including trouble breathing, foaming at the mouth, burning eyes and the \u201cemission of a chlorine-like odor.\u201d\n\nThe attack could not be independently verified, but rescue workers reported that at least 49 people had died. Video footage circulated by antigovernment activists showed the bodies of men, women and children sprawled on floors.", "title": "Burning Eyes, Foaming Mouths: Years of Suspected Chemical Attacks in Syria", "authors": ["Yonette Joseph", "Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cUnfortunately, we take these accidents as part of life,\u201d said Sudheendra Kulkarni, a political strategist who served on an advisory committee for railroads.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe said that most of those who use India\u2019s railways, especially in rural areas, are poor people who lack political power. As a result, he said, railway safety has never been \u201ca pressing priority\u201d for any of India\u2019s governments.\n\nThe causes of the accidents are as varied as human error to animal hazards. At least twice this year trains have plowed into elephant herds, killing endangered wildlife.\n\nIn this case, railway authorities say the bus driver, a 22-year-old man, was at fault. Around 6:50 a.m., he had just finished collecting 17 children from their homes in a rural area about 30 miles outside the midsize city of Gorakhpur.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRailway officials said parents in poorer parts of India took great pride in their school-going children, dressing them in clean white shirts and neckties, but that the drivers entrusted with taking the children to school were often poorly trained and paid, sometimes making the equivalent of $60 a month.\n\nThe crossing where the accident occurred was one of thousands across rural India that don\u2019t have any gates, though it did have a crossing guard, railway officials said. The guard saw a train approaching, and waved and shouted for the bus driver to stop. He did not slow down, and did not seem to hear the screams of the children packed in behind him because, railway officials said, he was listening to music.\n\nAt the moment he drove over the tracks, a passenger train from Siwan, a town south of Gorakhpur, was bearing down on them. It slammed into the bus, a small passenger van that railway officials said was meant to carry six or seven passengers, not 17. The bus was crushed.\n\nEleven children were killed on the spot. Two more died on the way to the hospital. Four others are in intensive care, fighting for their lives.\n\nThe driver was also badly hurt. The authorities said they were eager to talk to him, if he survives.", "title": "Bus Driver in India Is Distracted by Music, and 13 Children Die", "authors": ["Jeffrey Gettleman", "Suhasini Raj"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBushes were to win, but not brag; succeed, but not preen,\u201d Jon Meacham writes in his recent biography of the 41st president. Trump brags and preens through successes and failures alike. Bush had a capacity to laugh at himself. Trump does not. Bush had some money, and a lot of class. Trump has lots of money and no class.\n\nBush is profoundly decent. Trump is profoundly not.\n\n[Receive the day\u2019s most urgent debates right in your inbox by subscribing to the Opinion Today newsletter.]\n\nThese contrasts don\u2019t mean that Bush was without blemish: As Meacham notes, there were political misjudgments and calculated concessions to ambition on the long path to power. Nor does it mean that Trump doesn\u2019t have his own kind of strengths, not the least of which is his loudly declared indifference to elite opinion.\n\nYet the fact that personal virtue does not always guarantee political success \u2014 or that private vice may often facilitate public achievement \u2014 does not mean countries can afford to remain indifferent to questions of virtue and vice. That\u2019s what some of Bill Clinton\u2019s liberal defenders argued during the impeachment debates in the 1990s, and what Trump\u2019s defenders believe today.\n\nThey\u2019re wrong. In an age of radical transparency, who the president is inevitably spills over into how he\u2019s seen. Jack Kennedy might have been all class in public and a complete cad in private, but he lived in an era when he could get away with it.\n\nNot anymore. Today\u2019s presidents will be judged on their behavior, which is why the Trump brand is proving so damaging to the G.O.P.\u2019s midterm prospects, despite the strength of the economy. Today\u2019s presidents also model behavior, and tell every presidential aspirant what will or won\u2019t work for them politically.\n\nThe Bush model was about proving one\u2019s worth and paying one\u2019s dues. The Trump model is about the vain boast and the savage put-down. It\u2019s either Hadrian or Caligula: Whose regime would you rather live under?\n\nThe intense interest in Barbara Bush\u2019s funeral, as well as the concern for President Bush\u2019s health, no doubt reflects the ordinary human sympathy for a couple that has been such an enduring part of our common political landscape. But it reflects something else, too: They \u2014 that \u2014 was what we once were, too, at least at our striving best. In the age of Trump it\u2019s a reason for mourning and nostalgia, along with a prayer for resurrection.", "title": "Opinion | Bush 41, Trump, and American Decline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Age 32\n\nHometown: Pflugerville, Tex.\n\nNow Lives: In a 1950s two-bedroom apartment in West Hollywood, Calif.\n\nClaim to Fame: Mr. Yang is an online personality and film director who is best known for his role on BuzzFeed\u2019s \u201cThe Try Guys.\u201d The show blends whimsical humor with earnest social commentary through outlandish scenarios, like simulating labor pains and checking for prostate cancer in a doctor\u2019s office. As the series has taken off over multiple seasons, he has become a prolific comedic performer and a role model for other Asian-American social media stars.\n\nBig Break: After graduating from film school at the University of Southern California, Mr. Yang found his way to the video branch of BuzzFeed in 2014, where he was given free rein to experiment with writing and directing novel story formats. His early work explored pervasive stereotypes about Asian-Americans and body issues, including the popular, \u201cWomen\u2019s Ideal Body Types Throughout History,\u201d which, with more than 44 million views on YouTube, remains one of BuzzFeed\u2019s most watched. The positive reaction to the candor and reliability of some of these early works encouraged sketches examining even more provocative topics, leading to the conception of the Try Guys.\n\nLatest Project: Mr. Yang plans to leave BuzzFeed this year and start his own production company with the rest of the Try Guys cast. There he hopes to create innovative unscripted comedy that digs into the psyche of millennials and sensationalized internet culture.", "title": "BuzzFeed\u2019s Eugene Lee Yang Mixes Humor With Social Commentary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Earlier this year, Rose McGowan\u2019s shaven pate was displayed in high definition on the cover of \u201cBrave,\u201d her account in part of her experience with sexual harassment. Last month, Asia Kate Dillon and the shaved head returned to small screens (and promotional billboards) everywhere in \u201cBillions,\u201d and the first nonbinary gender character on American series television.\n\nPhoto\n\nSince the release of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d in February, the bald heads of the Dora Milaje soldiers, led by Okoye (Danai Gurira), have become clarion calls of black female strength and beauty. And Adwoa Aboah, the Model of the Year at the British Fashion Awards in December, is known for not only her stubbled head but also her Gurls Talk platform and her advocacy on the part of young women\u2019s mental health.\n\nIn all cases, it is almost impossible to separate the image from the activism.\n\nEspecially because those images exist in stark contrast to those of certain other women in the public eye, in particular the women associated with the Trump family, including the first lady, Melania Trump, and the former communications director Hope Hicks, whose long, lush locks represent what Mr. McCracken call \u201cvoluptuous hair\u201d \u2014 hair in the Rita Hayworth-Cindy Crawford mode. It could be a coincidence, though it is also notable that some of the things the women who have shaved their heads stand for represent a group of values and cultural beliefs that the administration does not share: gun control, L.G.B.T.Q. rights.\n\nPhoto\n\nHair is not solely a female issue, of course; men\u2019s hair is also fraught (hello, Samson; hello, skinheads). Though as Dr. Vearncombe said, \u201cbecause we focus so much attention on the head, especially on the female head, and because this attention is gendered, and because, more than anything, this attention is visible, absent hair on a woman\u2019s head can be read as disruptive to the politics of the male gaze. Looking at a woman\u2019s face, at her hair, has conventionally been an exercise of desire, and of an assertion of male power. Disrupting this convention, disrupting this gaze, allows us to see a different set of possibilities for the female head. The shaved head \u2018speaks\u2019 in a different way.\u201d\n\nAnd what is says is multitudes. It can sometimes speak of punishment: After World War II, women in France who were accused of being collaborators had their heads shaved in public; Natalie Portman\u2019s character in \u201cV for Vendetta\u201d had her head shaved during a torture scene. It can reflect discipline and toughness: See Demi Moore in \u201cG.I. Jane\u201d and Charlize Theron in \u201cMad Max: Fury Road.\u201d It can represent instability: When Britney Spears had her breakdown in 2007, she shaved her head in an act that has practically become a synonym in the pop lexicon for unstable. And it can be a direct riposte to a certain set of social and cultural values and expectations.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn an excerpt from her book published in i-D, Ms. McGowan wrote of shaving her head: \u201cI broke up with you. The collective you, the societal you. I broke up with the Hollywood ideal, the one that I had a part in playing.\u201d It was a way of rejecting, she wrote. \u201cThe ideal version of a woman that is sold to you by every actress in every hair commercial telling you, \u2018this the secret to being beguiling, the secret to getting a man to want you.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis is hair as seen through the Freudian lens, wherein the whole head becomes a stand-in for sexuality. Ms. McGowan later went on to say that her hair made her feel like a blowup sex doll. And yet, by rejecting it, by shaving it, she did not escape it (none of us do); she simply transformed its messaging.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Geraldine Biddle-Perry, an Associate Lecturer at Central Saint Martins and the co-editor of \u201cHair: Styling, Culture and Fashion,\u201d wrote in an email exchange, \u201cFor women who voluntarily cut/shave their hair, volition alters the symbolic grammar and so the act functions in terms of female agency and empowerment.\u201d\n\nWhich in turn raises the question of whether we are in for more head shaving, and whether that may ultimately lead to a time when, Dr. Vearncombe said, \u201cwe will not care about what a woman puts on or removes from her head.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s possible. Though given the history, gun control may have a better chance.", "title": "Buzzed: The Politics of Hair", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "To shut off the sea route to Greece, the European Union is paying billions of euros to a Turkish government that is dismantling its democracy. In Libya, Italy is accused of bribing some of the same militiamen who have long profited from the European smuggling trade \u2014 many of whom are also accused of war crimes.\n\nIn Sudan, crossed by migrants trying to reach Libya, the relationship is more opaque but rooted in mutual need: The Europeans want closed borders and the Sudanese want to end years of isolation from the West. Europe continues to enforce an arms embargo against Sudan, and many Sudanese leaders are international pariahs, accused of committing war crimes during a civil war in Darfur, a region in western Sudan.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the relationship is unmistakably deepening. A recent dialogue, named the Khartoum Process (in honor of Sudan\u2019s capital) has become a platform for at least 20 international migration conferences between European Union officials and their counterparts from several African countries, including Sudan. The European Union has also agreed that Khartoum will act as a nerve center for countersmuggling collaboration.\n\nWhile no European money has been given directly to any Sudanese government body, the bloc has funneled 106 million euros \u2014 or about $131 million \u2014 into the country through independent charities and aid agencies, mainly for food, health and sanitation programs for migrants, and for training programs for local officials.\n\n\u201cWhile we engage on some areas for the sake of the Sudanese people, we still have a sanction regime in place,\u201d said Catherine Ray, a spokeswoman for the European Union, referring to an embargo on arms and related material.\n\n\u201cWe are not encouraging Sudan to curb migration, but to manage migration in a safe and dignified way,\u201d Ms. Ray added.\n\nAhmed Salim, the director of one of the nongovernmental groups that receives European funding, said the bloc was motivated by both self-interest and a desire to improve the situation in Sudan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t want migrants to cross the Mediterranean to Europe,\u201d said Mr. Salim, who heads the European and African Center for Research, Training and Development.\n\nBut, he said, the money his organization receives means better services for asylum seekers in Sudan. \u201cYou have to admit that the European countries want to do something to protect migrants here,\u201d he said.\n\nCritics argue the evolving relationship means that European leaders are implicitly reliant on \u2014 and complicit in the reputational rehabilitation of \u2014 a Sudanese security apparatus whose leaders have been accused by the United Nations of committing war crimes in Darfur.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere is no direct money exchanging hands,\u201d said Suliman Baldo, the author of a research paper about Europe\u2019s migration partnership with Sudan. \u201cBut the E.U. basically legitimizes an abusive force.\u201d\n\nOn the border near Abu Jamal, Lieutenant Omar and several members of his patrol are from the wing of the Sudanese security forces headed by Salah Abdallah Gosh, one of several Sudanese officials accused of orchestrating attacks on civilians in Darfur.\n\nElsewhere, the border is protected by the Rapid Support Forces, a division of the Sudanese military that was formed from the janjaweed militias who led attacks on civilians in the Darfur conflict. The focus of the group, known as R.S.F., is not counter-smuggling \u2014 but roughly a quarter of the people-smugglers caught in January and February this year on the Eritrean border were apprehended by the R.S.F., Lieutenant Omar said.\n\nEuropean officials have direct contact only with the Sudanese immigration police, and not with the R.S.F., or the security forces that Lieutenant Omar works for, known as N.I.S.S. But their operations are not that far removed.\n\nThe planned countertrafficking coordination center in Khartoum \u2014 staffed jointly by police officers from Sudan and several European countries, including Britain, France and Italy \u2014 will partly rely on information sourced by N.I.S.S., according to the head of the immigration police department, Gen. Awad Elneil Dhia. The regular police also get occasional support from the R.S.F. on countertrafficking operations in border areas, General Dhia said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey have their presence there and they can help,\u201d General Dhia said. \u201cThe police is not everywhere, and we cannot cover everywhere.\u201d\n\nYet the Sudanese police are operating in one unexpected place: Europe.\n\nIn a bid to deter future migrants, at least three European countries \u2014 Belgium, France and Italy \u2014 have allowed in Sudanese police officers to hasten the deportation of Sudanese asylum seekers, General Dhia said.\n\nNominally, their official role is simply to identify their citizens. But the officers have been allowed to interrogate some deportation candidates without being monitored by European officials with the language skills to understand what was being said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMore than 50 Sudanese seeking asylum in Europe have been deported in the past 18 months from Belgium, France and Italy; The New York Times interviewed seven of them on a recent visit to Sudan.\n\nFour said they had been tortured on their return to Sudan \u2014 allegations denied by General Dhia. One man was a Darfuri political dissident deported in late 2017 from France to Khartoum, where he said he was detained on arrival by N.I.S.S. agents.\n\nOver the next 10 days, he said he was given electric shocks, punched and beaten with metal pipes. At one point the dissident, who asked that his name be withheld for his safety, lost consciousness and had to be taken to the hospital. He was later released on a form of parole.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe dissident said that, before his deportation from France, Sudanese police officers had threatened him as French officers stood nearby. \u201cI said to the French police: \u2018They are going to kill us,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cBut they didn\u2019t understand.\u201d\n\nEuropean officials argue that establishing Khartoum as a base for collaboration on fighting human smuggling can only improve the Sudanese security forces. The Regional Operational Center in Khartoum, set to open this year, will enable delegates from several European and African countries to share intelligence and coordinate operations against smugglers across North Africa.\n\nBut potential pitfalls are evident from past collaborations. In 2016, the British and Italian police, crediting a joint operation with their Sudanese counterparts, announced the arrest of \u201cone of the world\u2019s most wanted people smugglers.\u201d They said he was an Eritrean called Medhanie Yehdego Mered, who had been captured in Sudan and extradited to Italy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe case is now privately acknowledged by Western diplomats to have been one of mistaken identity. The prisoner turned out to be Medhanie Tesfamariam Berhe, an Eritrean refugee with the same first name as the actual smuggler. Mr. Mered remains at large.\n\nEven General Dhia now admits that Sudan extradited the wrong man \u2014 albeit one who, he says, admitted while in Sudanese custody to involvement in smuggling.\n\nBlack Sea ITALY TURKEY GREECE Mediterranean Sea Sabha SAUDI ARABIA LIBYA EGYPT Kufra Red Sea SUDAN NIGER Abu Jamal CHAD Khartoum Darfur ERITREA 500 miles S. SUDAN\n\n\u201cThere were two people, actually \u2014 two people with the same name,\u201d General Dhia said.\n\nMr. Berhe nevertheless remains on trial in Italy, accused of being Mr. Mered \u2014 and of being a smuggler.\n\nBeyond that, the Sudanese security services have long been accused of profiting from the smuggling trade. Following European pressure, the Sudanese Parliament adopted a raft of anti-smuggling legislation in 2014, and the rules have since led to the prosecution of some officials over alleged involvement in the smuggling business.\n\nBut according to four smugglers whom I interviewed clandestinely during my trip to Sudan, the security services remain closely involved in the trade, with both N.I.S.S and R.S.F. officials receiving part of the smuggling profits on most trips to southern Libya.\n\nThe head of the R.S.F., Brig. Mohammed Hamdan Daglo, has claimed in the past that his forces play a major role in impeding the route to Libya. But each smuggler \u2014 interviewed separately \u2014 said that the R.S.F. was often the main organizer of the trips, often supplying camouflaged vehicles to ferry migrants through the desert.\n\nAfter being handed over to Libyan militias in Kufra and Sabha, in southern Libya, many migrants are then systematically tortured and held for ransom \u2014 money that is later shared with the R.S.F., each smuggler said.\n\nRights activists have previously accused Sudanese officials of complicity in trafficking. In a 2014 report, Human Rights Watch said that senior Sudanese police officials had colluded in the smuggling of Eritreans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA British journalist captured by the R.S.F. in Darfur in 2016 said that he had been told by his captors that they were involved in smuggling people to Libya. \u201cI asked specifically about how it works,\u201d said the journalist, Phil Cox, a freelance filmmaker for Channel 4. \u201cAnd they said we make sure the routes are open, and we talk with whoever\u2019s commanding the next area.\u201d\n\nGeneral Dhia said that the problem did not extend beyond a few bad apples. Sudan, he said, remains an effective partner for Europe in the battle against irregular migration.\n\n\u201cWe are not,\u201d he said, \u201cvery far from your standards.\u201d", "title": "By Stifling Migration, Sudan\u2019s Feared Secret Police Aid Europe", "authors": ["Patrick Kingsley"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The government will lower the $375,000 salary of the new director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Robert R. Redfield, after reports that he was being paid considerably more than previous directors, the Department of Health and Human Services confirmed on Monday, though it declined to say what his new pay will be.\n\nDr. Redfield, who became the C.D.C. director in March, had been given the higher salary under a provision called Title 42. It was created by Congress to allow federal agencies to offer compensation that is competitive with the private sector in order to attract top-notch scientists with expertise that the departments would not otherwise have. News reports of his earnings sparked complaints from Senate Democrats and watchdog groups.\n\n\u201cDr. Redfield has expressed to Secretary Azar that he does not wish to have his compensation become a distraction for the important work of the C.D.C.,\u201d an H.H.S. spokeswoman, who declined to be named, wrote in an emailed response to questions from The New York Times. \u201cTherefore, consistent with Dr. Redfield\u2019s request to the Secretary, Dr. Redfield\u2019s compensation will be adjusted accordingly.\u201d\n\nTitle 42 was not used for Dr. Redfield\u2019s predecessor, Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, an obstetrician-gynecologist, who was paid $197,300 a year until she resigned in January, or for her predecessor, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, an infectious disease specialist and the former health commissioner of New York City, whose salary was $219,700.", "title": "C.D.C. Director\u2019s $375,000 Salary Will Be Cut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "President Clinton would later agree to the deal, but Congress often delayed the oil shipments and refused to immediately lift sanctions, and the light-water reactors were never built.\n\n2000\n\nNorth and South Korea Hold Talks\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Il-sung\u2019s son and successor, Kim Jong-il, and the then president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, met in Pyongyang in 2000, the first such summit meeting between the leaders of the two Koreas since a war divided the peninsula 50 years earlier.\n\nThe talks ushered in an unprecedented rapprochement and various joint projects including a factory park in the North Korean town of Kaesong. But the credibility of Kim Dae-jung\u2019s so-called Sunshine Policy was damaged after an investigation revealed that the South Korean government had funneled $450 million to the North shortly before the talks.\n\nMadeleine Albright Visits the North\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Jong-il invited President Clinton to North Korea in 2000. Madeleine K. Albright, the secretary of state, went instead. She traveled to Pyongyang in an effort to expand the Agreed Framework to include ballistic missiles, which North Korea was developing and selling abroad.\n\nClinton administration officials said a deal was close, but nothing was concluded by the time President George W. Bush took office in 2001.\n\n2002 - 2006\n\nA Nuclear Bomb Test\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Agreed Framework collapsed in 2002 after the United States confronted North Korea over its secret program to enrich uranium using equipment from Pakistan. The United States stopped oil shipments to North Korea and Pyongyang restarted its nuclear weapons program.\n\nThe so-called Six-Party Talks continued fitfully between representatives of North and South Korea, China, Russia, Japan and the United States. The North said in 2005 that it would give up nuclear weapons and its existing nuclear programs in return for security guarantees. North Korea carried out its first nuclear test in 2006.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n2007 - 2011\n\nSix-Party Talks Collapse\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2007, Kim Jong-il and South Korea\u2019s president at the time, Roh Moo-hyun, held the second summit meeting between the two sides. The meeting produced an agreement aimed at expanding inter-Korean ties and easing military tensions along the disputed maritime border on the west coast of the Korean Peninsula.
