And it\u2019s always a thought in parents\u2019 and families\u2019 minds, what can happen and unfortunately has happened,\u201d said Humboldt Mayor Rob Muench, wearing a team jersey Saturday. \u201cI grew up watching the Broncos in the old rink as a kid.\u201d\n\nMr. Moe called on fellow Canadians to support the families of the victims. \u201cIn these boys, we see teammates, we see classmates, we see friends, we see brothers, sons and grandsons,\u201d he said. \u201cThese boys are our boys, their team is our team, their school is our school, their community is our community and their families are now our families.\u201d", "title": "Canadian Town Reels After Bus Crash Kills Beloved Hockey Players", "authors": ["Ian Austen", "Catherine Porter", "Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Candida Rebecca Moss and Conrad Justin Foa were married April 4. The two middleweights are among the most accomplished active fighters, and their first bout last September ended in a hard-fought draw. Golovkin is 37-0-1, and Alvarez is 49-1-2. The Ring Magazine currently ranks Golovkin as the best pound-for-pound fighter in the world, with Alvarez at No. 4.\n\nAlvarez had tested positive for clenbuterol on Feb. 17 and 21. The aromatic hemp flowers must not be smoked or eaten. Seeds, should there be any, must not be cultivated. As the jars\u2019 labels sternly specify, the products are for \u201ctechnical use\u201d only and \u201cnot for human consumption.\u201d Instead, they are sold \u2014 as countless salesclerks will explain with a nudge-nudge, wink-wink smile \u2014 as \u201ccollectors\u2019 items.\u201d\n\nSuch is the current, perplexing status of legal cannabis in Italy.\n\nItaly\u2019s cannabis mania, as it has been called, exploded after a December 2016 law regulating hemp production went into effect, a series of norms meant to help revive a crop that was once widely cultivated in the country. In the 1940s, Italy was said to be the world\u2019s second-biggest producer of industrial cannabis, after the Soviet Union. (Statistics for China, also a major producer, do not exist.)", "title": "Cannabis Flowers Are Legal in Italy. They eschew European designer labels manufactured for consumerism in favor of local designers, many of whom have caught the spirit of the moment.\n\nThat Cape Town, known as the \u201cMother City,\u201d has become a front in the war on Western gender roles is somewhat fitting. The sold-out crowd gave Shaw an ovation.", "title": "Capitals Hold On to Early Lead, Tying Series With the Penguins", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "ARLINGTON, Va. \u2014 Washington Capitals forward Tom Wilson wore the label like a tattoo during his first four N.H.L. seasons: a fourth-line enforcer who often committed bad penalties with devastating hits.\n\n\n\nSince selecting him with the 16th overall pick in the 2012 draft, the Capitals had tried on and off to make Wilson, 24, fit on one of their top lines, but the experiment always seemed to fizzle \u2014 until this season.\n\nNow, the 6-foot-4, 218-pound Wilson is skating on the Capitals\u2019 top line with Alex Ovechkin and Evgeny Kuznetsov, bringing energy, controlling the physical side of his game, scoring and playing a crucial defensive role.\n\n\u201cHe is such a dynamic player,\u201d Washington center Jay Beagle said. \u201cThere is no slow start for him. He goes all-out. He is scoring and making plays. The defensive side of his game, the way he kills penalties and the way he hits and puts fear into other team\u2019s eyes \u2014 especially the defensive core. There are maybe two or three other guys that play a similar style like him in the league.\u201d", "title": "Capitals\u2019 Tom Wilson Tries to Shed Tough Guy Label for a New One: Go-To Guy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "By now, the dispatchers and officers \u2014 even the chief of police \u2014 know him simply as Floyd. By his own tally, he has found and helped return about 75 vehicles so far this year. The authorities in Anchorage say they have not tracked the number of people, like Floyd, who have taken on roles as self-appointed spotters, watchers, trackers or all-around crime fighters, but that they are numerous. Frustration has fueled their energy, and social media has given them tools to coordinate efforts.\n\nAlaska often zigs while the rest of the nation zags; its economy boomed through the nation\u2019s recession a decade ago. Now property crimes have spiked in the Anchorage area, where a majority of Alaskans live, even as such offenses have been declining for the nation as a whole, federal figures show.\n\nThat is making way for people like John Staser, another civilian crime fighter in Anchorage. Mr. Staser, 60, is a fit-looking retired lieutenant colonel in the United States Army Corps of Engineers and the co-owner of two sporting goods stores that have been hit lately by increased shoplifting.\n\nPhoto\n\nNot long ago, when Mr. Staser suspected someone had been stealing, he held the culprit with a Taser at a store\u2019s front door until the police arrived. He said he once followed another man on foot for about 45 minutes, trying to talk to him about issues of \u201caccountability for his actions,\u201d even though the stolen goods, valued at about $1,500, had been dropped at the store\u2019s door. Mr. Staser only ended his pursuit after the man desperately waved a $20 bill at a passing motorist, climbed into the car and raced off.\n\nMr. Staser said he knows that he might one day cross a line and put himself at risk. The culprits are almost all much younger than he is, for one thing.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve got to stop chasing these guys,\u201d he said, shaking his head.\n\nAnchorage, a city with nearly 300,000 residents, has long had its share of rough edges, including patterns of homelessness and transience, with people here for a while, then gone. In interviews around the city, people said they still felt safe walking around, day or night, but the need to lock doors \u2014 a new imperative here \u2014 has left them unsettled.\n\nAnchorage set a record for homicides last year, with 35, though violent crimes overall were up only slightly, according to the F.B.I. Some other American cities have far higher per capita rates of killings, but Alaskans say the uptick in property crime is still palpable.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Anchorage Police Department says auto thefts jumped by 52 percent in 2017 over the previous year. In the first two months of 2018, the numbers were up again \u2014 27 percent over the same period last year. The city went from having the nation\u2019s 47th highest rate of auto theft per capita in 2015 to the sixth highest in 2016, according to the National Insurance Crime Bureau, an insurance industry-funded group.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome people here attribute the rising crime to an increase in opioid addiction and an economic downturn. The state\u2019s unemployment rate, 7.3 percent in February, was the highest in the nation, as the state\u2019s oil industry has sputtered. The State Legislature also overhauled the criminal justice system in 2016, reducing penalties for some property crimes.\n\n\u201cThere isn\u2019t just one thing,\u201d Justin Doll, the Anchorage police chief, said. Chief Doll said that new hires have brought the department to its highest staffing ever, with 435 officers, giving him hope that the crime trend can change. Arrests for car theft have also increased, he said, adding: \u201cTo me that suggests we\u2019re starting to have an impact.\u201d\n\nBut car theft in Alaska is unique. Thieves swiping a car in the lower 48 have options: Drive it to another state for resale or sell the parts for scrap. There are few getaways here. A 20-hour trip to the capital, Juneau, still leaves you inside state borders. And most communities \u2014 more than 85 percent \u2014 aren\u2019t reachable by road at all.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo vehicles are stolen to commit other crimes, the police said, or to live in for a while, or simply as a quick lift. It also means that most stolen cars are eventually recovered and returned \u2014 if worse for wear.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve seen cars stolen, abandoned, then stolen again by somebody else,\u201d Mr. Hall, the stolen car chaser, said.\n\nCar thefts have surged in winter, when people start their cars and leave them warming, keys in plain view. That prompted Tracy Lohman and her husband, Tom, to buy a car with a remote that starts their vehicle from inside the house.\n\nKaren Stephens, an architect, said everybody knows somebody who has been a victim.\n\n\u201cI used to leave my house, my car, everything, open all the time \u2014 all the time,\u201d she said.\n\nSome residents said they believed that an assumption that most Alaskans are armed \u2014 an idea borne out by studies \u2014 may be keeping crime from getting worse.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEveryone\u2019s got a gun inside their house, you know, so not too many people are concerned about home invasion,\u201d said Blake Quackenbush, a lawyer.\n\nChief Doll said he supports citizen activism like neighborhood watches, but said he worries that more aggressive tactics could drift toward vigilante justice.\n\n\u201cNobody is doing this with anything other than good intentions in trying to help keep the community safe, but it\u2019s really dangerous,\u201d Chief Doll said.\n\n\u201cWhat I would encourage Floyd or anybody to do is to continue to be active, be a voice for public safety,\u201d he said. \u201cBut when crime actually happens, let us deal with it.\u201d", "title": "Car Stolen in Alaska? It Could Be Your Neighbor Chasing the Thief", "authors": ["Kirk Johnson"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "The theft is one of the largest known breaches of a retailer and shows just how difficult it is to secure credit-card transaction systems despite the lessons learned from other large data breaches, including the theft of 40 million card numbers from Target in 2013 and 56 million card numbers from Home Depot in 2014. Last year, Equifax, a credit reporting firm, disclosed that sensitive financial information on 145.5 million Americans had been exposed in a breach of the company\u2019s systems.\n\nThe research firm that identified the Saks breach, Gemini Advisory, said on Sunday that a group of Russian-speaking hackers known as Fin7 or JokerStash posted online on Wednesday that it had obtained a cache of five million stolen card numbers, which the thieves called BIGBADABOOM-2. The hackers, who have also hit other retail chains, offered 125,000 of the records for immediate sale.\n\nFin7 did not disclose where the numbers had been obtained. But the researchers, working in conjunction with banks, analyzed a sample of the records and determined that the card numbers all seemed to have been used at Saks and Lord & Taylor stores, mostly in New York and New Jersey, from May 2017 to March 2018.\n\nAlthough it\u2019s unclear exactly how the malware was installed in the stores\u2019 checkout systems, Gemini said it was most likely through phishing emails sent to Hudson\u2019s Bay employees. In a phishing attack, hackers send seemingly legitimate emails to a company\u2019s employees that encourage them to click on a link or attached file that secretly installs software on their computers, giving the attackers a back door into the systems.\n\nThe breach comes at a difficult time for Saks and Lord & Taylor, and retailers more generally.\n\nOnline shopping has cut deeply into the traditional brick-and-mortar retail industry, and department stores have been particularly slow to adapt to the new ways that people shop.", "title": "Card Data Stolen From 5 Million Saks and Lord & Taylor Customers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Last summer, with her ubiquitous hit \u201cBodak Yellow,\u201d Cardi B became the first female rapper since Lauryn Hill in 1998 to reach No. 1 on the Billboard singles chart with a fully solo release \u2014 that is, with no \u201cfeature\u201d appearance by another artist (say, a male rapper).\n\nNow, Cardi B has pulled off a similar feat on the album chart, as her \u201cInvasion of Privacy\u201d (KSR/Atlantic) opens at No. 1 with the equivalent of 255,000 album sales in the United States, according to Nielsen. As Billboard noted, she is only the fifth female rapper in history to top the chart, after Nicki Minaj, Eve, Foxy Brown and Ms. Hill.\n\n\u201cInvasion of Privacy\u201d also had the highest streaming week ever for a female artist, with 202.6 million streams of tracks from the album, beating Beyonc\u00e9, who logged 115 million for \u201cLemonade\u201d two years ago. In addition to the streams, \u201cInvasion of Privacy\u201d had 103,000 sales as a complete album, on formats like CD and download.\n\nAlso this week, Thirty Seconds to Mars, the rock band featuring the actor Jared Leto, opened at No. 2 with \u201cAmerica,\u201d and the Weeknd\u2019s new EP \u201cMy Dear Melancholy,\u201d which started at No. 1 last week, fell to No. 3. The soundtrack to \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d is in fourth place, and XXXTentacion\u2019s \u201c?\u201d is No. 5.", "title": "Cardi B Becomes the Fifth Female Rapper With a No. 1 Album", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Here alone are three possible Cardis: switchblade Cardi, empowerment-seminar Cardi, pan-Latin-unifier Cardi. And those aren\u2019t even all of them. On \u201cShe Bad\u201d and \u201cI Do,\u201d she raps about sex with the assertiveness and raw detail of Lil\u2019 Kim or Too Short. And on \u201cThru Your Phone,\u201d she\u2019s convincingly broken by an untrustworthy partner: \u201cI might just cut all the tongues out your sneakers/Smash your TV from Best Buy/You gon\u2019 turn me into Left Eye.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cInvasion of Privacy\u201d is also, notably, a hip-hop album that doesn\u2019t sound like any of its temporal peers: It is not a samey post-trap longread designed for zoned-out maximal streaming, nor does it flirt with the sonic and thematic excesses of the SoundCloud generation. In fact, it\u2019s more reminiscent of the late 1990s and early 2000s, when New York rap was beginning to test its pop edges.\n\nAnd though it\u2019s a debut album, it\u2019s by no means a debut: Cardi B has been famous for years already, first as a libertine social-media slice-of-life comic, and later as an effervescently campy reality-television standout. Both of those sorts of fame are relatively young, though. Succeeding in music has generally been thought to require something more than the natural vim and charm that she\u2019s deployed to this point.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd yet, that is partly a hip-hop myth deployed by gatekeepers. Cardi proves it\u2019s a lie: The skills she has been deploying to hilarious effect in her other careers are exactly the ones that make her music so invigorating. Few artists of any kind are so visibly and infectiously enthused.\n\nAs a result, the appetite for her is insatiable, and the career milestones are coming fast and furious: co-hosting \u201cThe Tonight Show\u201d alongside Jimmy Fallon, appearing on the covers of various magazines, announcing her pregnancy during a performance on \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe has also been the most reliable hip-hop guest star of the last 12 months, with appearances on G-Eazy\u2019s \u201cNo Limit,\u201d Migos\u2019s \u201cMotorSport,\u201d Ozuna\u2019s \u201cLa Modelo\u201d and the remix of Bruno Mars\u2019s \u201cFinesse\u201d \u2014 she has yet to release a dud. For someone who only started rapping a few years ago, that stylistic versatility is striking \u2014 it shows Cardi to be a quick study. And indeed, in a recent interview with Ebro Darden for Apple\u2019s Beats 1, she spoke openly about wanting to improve as a rapper and working with a more experienced rapper and songwriter, Pardison Fontaine, to improve her technical skills. \u201cI needed a little bit of help from breaking out of my box,\u201d she said. \u201cI need to learn how to flow a little bit easier and cleaner.\u201d (There was some consternation online after an old video of Mr. Fontaine performing part of \u201cBe Careful\u201d recently resurfaced online. Atlantic Records did not make songwriting credits for \u201cInvasion of Privacy\u201d available.)\n\nThe hard work shows, especially in terms of her cadences, and her ease in adapting to various production styles. Her quick-jab rhymes aren\u2019t particularly complex, but occasionally she gets off a delicious turn of phrase, like this one, from \u201cMoney Bag\u201d: \u201cThese bitches salty, they sodium, they jelly, petroleum/Always talking in the background, don\u2019t never come to the podium.\u201d\n\nThe work of becoming a great rapper is something that\u2019s rarely spoken about, but Cardi has been open about her education process, an implicit acknowledgment that her path to success has been unusual. It is one way rap stars are made today, and may be for the foreseeable future \u2014 not by triumphing over other rhymeslingers in Darwinian fashion, but by arriving to the genre as a fully formed personality, and then learning how to shrink-wrap that personality around beats.\n\nThis is a new paradigm, one that puts charm before bona fides. It is what happens when a genre is exposed to sunlight and expands beyond the internal logic that once drove it. But it\u2019s not enough for Cardi to win on those terms \u2014 she wants to succeed on the old ones, too.", "title": "Cardi B Is a New Rap Celebrity Loyal to Rap\u2019s Old Rules on \u2018Invasion of Privacy\u2019", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "When they zig, he zags.\n\nCardi B will co-host \u201cThe Tonight Show\u201d with Jimmy Fallon next Monday night, the first time the show has ever had two people sharing hosting duties, NBC said on Tuesday.\n\nNext Monday\u2019s show will, as usual, stand out compared to his competitors: Mr. Fallon has kept his show joke-and-celebrity heavy while CBS\u2019s Stephen Colbert and ABC\u2019s Jimmy Kimmel have gotten increasingly political. In that time, Mr. Fallon\u2019s ratings have declined while Mr. Colbert and Mr. Kimmel have seen their total viewerships go up.\n\nEnter Cardi B.\n\nThe Bronx-born rapper appeared on Mr. Fallon\u2019s show in December, and her segment on the couch became a viral hit. To date, the five-minute interview has collected more than 16 million views. She also appeared on the show in September when she performed \u201cNo Limit\u201d with G-Eazy.\n\nNBC said on Tuesday that Cardi B would join Mr. Fallon on \u201cThe Tonight Show\u201d stage throughout the program, and would help interview that evening\u2019s scheduled guests. The contestants were Leslie Jones as Shanice, Chris Redd as Rashad \u2014 and Boseman as his \u201cBlack Panther\u201d character, T\u2019Challa, the king of a fictional, quasi-utopian, all-black African nation called Wakanda.\n\nAs you might imagine, T\u2019Challa experienced a bit of culture shock. He bungled questions about credit card debt and parenting, before buzzing in on a clue about law enforcement: \u201cThe policeman says there\u2019s been some robberies in your neighborhood and asks if you have any information.\u201d\n\nBoseman responded, \u201cWhat is, not only do I tell this man what I know, but I also assist him in tracking down the offender. After all, our ministers of law enforcement are only here to protect us.\u201d\n\nThompson twisted his features into an expression reminiscent of the nauseated face emoji.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m thinking you haven\u2019t spent much time in America,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2018Weekend Update\u2019 Riff of the Week\n\nThe \u201cWeekend Update\u201d co-anchor Colin Jost also addressed President Trump\u2019s decision to send National Guard troops to the border with Mexico, even though, he pointed out, \u201creports show that illegal border crossings are at their lowest level since 1971.\u201d\n\nHe continued, \u201cIt\u2019s all part of Trump\u2019s philosophy: \u2018If it ain\u2019t broke, I\u2019ll break it.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u2018Weekend Update\u2019 Deskside Gag of the Week\n\nA robotic Mark Zuckerberg, played by Moffat, stopped by \u201cWeekend Update\u201d to address the criticism he has received since the Cambridge Analytica data leak.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHi there, Colin,\u201d he greeted Jost, before instructing himself to \u201cbegin eye contact.\u201d\n\n\u201cUnlike my facial expression, Facebook is going to change,\u201d Moffat promised, in an interview punctuated by high-pitched giggles and stiff attempts at dabbing.\n\nHe concluded with a disingenuous mea culpa:\n\n\u201cMy point is, sure, maybe Facebook sold out our democracy to Russian troll farms. My bad? But, on the other hand: Farmville. To be honest, I feel great about Facebook\u2019s future. I sleep easy at night, upside down in my pressurized sleep egg. And sure, I still have all your photos, your memories, your unspoken thoughts and fears. But, America, look at me in my shark eyes when I say this \u2014 that, on behalf of everyone on Facebook, I\u2019m sorry. On opposite day!\u201d\n\nProbably Uncalled For Sketch of the Week\n\nWhat started out as a sketch about three girlfriends at Disneyland found its punch line in the R&B singer R. Kelly, who has been the subject for many years of disturbing accusations.\n\nStaring into a \u201cmagic\u201d mirror that had shown her friends their \u201cpersonal Disney princesses,\u201d Jones was surprised to find the leather-clad musician staring back at her, then gyrating with a bag of popcorn held over his crotch.\n\n\u201cWhat are you up to R. Kelly? Why is R. Kelly in there?\u201d she demanded. \u201cThe last place he needs to be is Disneyland!\u201d\n\nShocking Reveal of the Week\n\nThe rapper Cardi B, who released her debut album, \u201cInvasion of Privacy,\u201d on Friday, played a medley of her biggest hits to date, \u201cBodak Yellow\u201d and \u201cBartier Cardi,\u201d in her first performance of the night.\n\nClad in white and black fur, sporting close-cropped green hair, and flanked by four backup dancers, she delivered a typically energetic (and heavily bleeped) performance.\n\nShe showed off her softer side in a performance of a quieter \u201cInvasion of Privacy\u201d track, \u201cBe Careful,\u201d appearing in a long, high-necked dress with a retro beehive hairdo. When the camera pulled back from a close-up to show her torso, the form-fitting dress seemed to reveal that Cardi B was pregnant.\n\nShortly after the performance, her fianc\u00e9, the rapper and Migos member Offset, appeared to confirm that impression on Instagram.", "title": "Cardi B, Donald Trump and T\u2019Challa Walk Into an \u2018S.N.L.\u2019 Episode", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "BALLARAT, Australia \u2014 Rob Walsh was outside Melbourne Magistrates\u2019 Court recently awaiting a pretrial hearing for Cardinal George Pell, the Vatican\u2019s third-highest-ranking official, when, he said, he unexpectedly walked into the cardinal himself.\n\nThe encounter wasn\u2019t their first. They both were raised in the same old mining town, which could be why the cardinal extended his hand, inviting Mr. Walsh to shake it. Mr. Walsh declined \u2014 a gesture that signified the lasting impact of a decades-long sexual abuse scandal that has rocked this town, Ballarat, and sent shock waves around the world.\n\n\u201cThe ripple is still on the lake and it\u2019s still occurring,\u201d Mr. Walsh said from his home in Ballarat, referring to the lingering effects from that scandal, in which priests preyed on children, including Mr. Walsh, during the 1960s and 1970s.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s gone through families and generations.\u201d\n\nThis town, officially a city of about 100,000 people, was once the center of Australia\u2019s gold rush, but is now better known as the epicenter of that pedophile ring, in which Catholic clergy preyed on those who depended on them the most \u2014 children from Ballarat\u2019s poor, blue-collar neighborhoods.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe scale of the abuse in Ballarat was staggering. Gerald Ridsdale, the former chaplain of St. Alipius Primary School in Ballarat, was imprisoned for sexually abusing 65 children from the early 1960s to late 1980s. He was only one of several priests convicted of abusing children.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout 45 victims were estimated to have committed suicide, prompting an outpouring of grief from once devout Catholic parents who said the church robbed them of their sons.", "title": "Cardinal George Pell\u2019s Hometown Breaks Its Silence About Grim Past of Sexual Abuse", "authors": ["Jacqueline Williams"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Carl Kasell, an NPR newscaster who, late in his career, cast off his anchorman gravitas once a week and for years became an absurdist comedian on the popular satirical quiz show \u201cWait Wait \u2026 Don\u2019t Tell Me!,\u201d died on Tuesday in Potomac, Md. He was 84.\n\nHis wife, Mary Ann Foster, said the cause was complications of Alzheimer\u2019s disease.\n\nTo anyone who ever wondered what a radio personality was really like behind the disembodied baritone dignity, Mr. Kasell (pronounced KASS-uhl), gave it away in 1998 when he suddenly dropped the rock-steady mid-Atlantic voice of authority that millions had come to know over his decades as an \u00e9minence grise on public radio\u2019s \u201cAll Things Considered\u201d and \u201cMorning Edition.\u201d\n\nIn its place was a whimsical, charming North Carolina comic doing goofy impressions of Henry A. Kissinger, Britney Spears, Lindsay Lohan and others in the news. A voice that had been likened to that of America\u2019s most trusted broadcaster, Walter Cronkite, was now concocting puns, singing falsetto jingles and joking about his comedown \u2014 from a radio kingpin to a comic making up voice-mail greetings as game-show prizes.\n\nMr. Kasell\u2019s improbable second career, as \u201cofficial judge and scorekeeper\u201d of the news-related, call-in comedy hour \u201cWait Wait,\u201d began when he was 64 and still working as an NPR newscaster. In what he regarded as his weekend gig, he played a sly, deadpan straight man to the show\u2019s host, Peter Sagal, who quizzed contestants on the week\u2019s dumbest events and most misguided newsmakers.", "title": "Carl Kasell, NPR Newsman Who Discovered Laughs, Dies at 84", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Scheib dropped out of school for good in the spring of 1943 and became a batting-practice pitcher for the A\u2019s.\n\n\u201cI hate to say it, but being born and raised in Gratz, where you worked on farms, we didn\u2019t know about big league baseball,\u201d Scheib once told The Patriot-News of Harrisburg. \u201cI thought they were crazy to pay you to play ball.\u201d\n\nHe made his major league debut on Sept. 6, 1943, relieving against the Yankees in the ninth inning of an 11-4 loss. He was 16 years, 8 months and 5 days old. In all, he got into six games that year, all in relief.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe pitched for the A\u2019s in all or parts of 11 seasons, but when he died on March 24 in San Antonio at 91, Scheib was most remembered for having been the youngest player in American League history.\n\nIn fact, he was the youngest in all of modern Major League Baseball history when he pitched his first game for the A\u2019s. But that distinction was erased when Joe Nuxhall pitched one-third of an inning for the National League\u2019s Cincinnati Reds in his major league debut on June 10, 1944, at the age of 15 years, 316 days. (Nuxhall went on to a long major league career, mostly with the Reds.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nScheib, a right-hander, 6 feet 1 inches tall and 190 pounds, became a mainstay of the A\u2019s pitching staff as a starter and reliever and won 45 games for teams that were usually mediocre or worse.\n\nHis best season came in 1948, when he went 14-8 with a 3.94 earned run average and 15 complete games for an A\u2019s team that finished fourth in the American League with an 84-70 record, the franchise\u2019s best mark in his years with them. He also batted .298 that year, hit a pair of home runs along with eight doubles and three triples, and drove in 21 runs in 104 at-bats.\n\nCarl Alvin Scheib was born in Gratz, a small town about 25 miles north of Harrisburg, on Jan. 1, 1927. He was one of four children of Oliver Scheib, a coal miner as well as a farmer, and the former Pauline Wolfgang.\n\nCarl starred as a pitcher and outfielder for Gratz High School before making that barely imaginable leap to the major leagues.\n\nHe recalled that when he joined the Athletics, neither his teammates nor his coaches supplied advice.\n\n\u201cI was a shy, bashful kid,\u201d he told Jim Sargent in an interview for the Society for American Baseball Research more than 60 years later. \u201cMy parents drove me down and dropped me off in the big city of Philadelphia, and, hey, it was rough. I had to find a restaurant to eat. I didn\u2019t even know how to read a menu. I had never been 50 miles from home. The Great Depression was just getting over, and our family never had the money to go anywhere or do anything.\u201d\n\nScheib pitched in 15 games for the Athletics in 1944 and in four games for them in 1945, all in relief, before being drafted into the Army that May. He pitched for an Army ball club that won the G.I. \u201cWorld Series\u201d of occupied Germany in September 1946, then returned to the A\u2019s in 1947.\n\nScheib was part of a rotation that included combat veterans like Phil Marchildon, who had been a gunner on a Canadian bomber and taken prisoner by the Germans when his plane was shot down; Lou Brissie, who wore a brace to protect a leg that had been shattered by a German shell during the Italian campaign; and Bob Savage, whose division had taken part in the liberation of a concentration camp.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nScheib saved 11 games in 1951 and posted an 11-7 record in 1952. After experiencing arm problems, he was sent to the St. Louis Cardinals early in May 1954. He pitched in three games for them before his major league career ended at age 27.\n\nHe had an overall record of 45-65 and a career batting average of .250.\n\nAfter leaving baseball, Scheib retired to San Antonio and owned a service station and carwash.\n\nScheib\u2019s death, at a hospital, was confirmed by his family on Thursday. He is survived by his sons Kenneth and Carl Jr., his daughters Barbara McCauley and Sandy Pratt, six grandchildren, five great-grandchildren and two great-great-grandchildren.\n\nScheib\u2019s first wife, the former Georgene Umholtz, died in 1998, and his second wife, the former Sandra Lindinger, died in 2012.\n\nScheib returned to Gratz in 2005, the bicentennial of its founding, for a ceremony in which the community ballpark where he once pitched was renamed for him and a bronze plaque with his likeness was dedicated.\n\nThe small-town boy who had gone so far was awed by the tribute.\n\n\u201cNobody knows what a man feels like when they put a monument up for him,\u201d Scheib said. \u201cI love this town, and I love the people in it.\u201d", "title": "Carl Scheib, Youngest Player in American League History, Dies at 91", "authors": ["Richard Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Carmen Patricia Isabel Collyns and Matthew Ross Heiman were married April 27 at the Superior Court of Washington.\n\nThe bride, 30, is the manager of business operations at Honeybook, a technology start-up in San Francisco. She graduated from Harvard, from which she also received an M.B.A.\n\nShe is a daughter of Myriam J. Collyns and Charles V. Collyns of Bethesda, Md. Her mother retired as a translator in the linguistics department of the International Monetary Fund in Washington; the bride\u2019s father is a director of the fund. He previously served as the chief economist of the Institute of International Finance, and as the assistant secretary for international finance at the Department of the Treasury, both in Washington.\n\nMr. Heiman, also 30, is an investor for Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif. He graduated summa cum laude from Columbia and received an M.B.A. from Stanford.", "title": "Carmen Collyns, Matthew Heiman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Presented in the Stanford White-designed mansion, Herrera\u2019s first show was a mingling of different worlds and societies \u2014 a heady mix that would come to define Manhattan\u2019s creative culture in the \u201980s. \u201cThe Metropolitan Club didn\u2019t allow men without ties,\u201d recalls Herrera. \u201cEverybody arrived, including Steve Rubell, who was the owner of 54, and they didn\u2019t allow him to go in. So he went to Bergdorf Goodman and bought a tie. And he put on his jacket and said, \u2018Here I am.\u2019 And then they let him in.\u201d It was, she acknowledges, a different kind of place to show. And the crowd \u2014 buyers, press, artists and the likes of Vreeland, Rubell, Bianca Jagger and a roster of heavyweight New York socialites \u2014 felt different, exciting.\n\nLooking at Herrera\u2019s 1981 collection today, the clothes seem the apotheosis of \u201980s extravagance. Opulent is the word she uses. \u201cEverything was over the top,\u201d she says. A dress from that show, now part of the collection at Manhattan\u2019s Fashion Institute of Technology, is ecru silk, with puffed sleeves that fluff the upper body to roughly twice its natural width \u2014 The New York Times critic John Duka dubbed Herrera\u2019s ruffles \u201cthunderous.\u201d\n\nImage Downtown woman shot by Amy Arbus, circa 1983. Credit Amy Arbus\n\nIt was a fashion moment that, unexpectedly, has found itself newly resonant today: Herrera ironically takes her last bow in a season where the hard-edged, wide-shouldered opulence and glamour of the \u201980s is re-emerging as a key trend. Even as some of the most talented American designers are opting to present their collections in Paris, not New York, we are harking back to a moment when American fashion came into its own. Echoing the \u201980s reminds us of why we got excited about New York fashion in the first place.\n\nHerrera\u2019s final show this year \u2014 she is the first designer to hold a runway show at the Museum of Modern Art \u2014 links with her debut: the old generation making way for the new; in Herrera\u2019s case, the 31-year-old American designer Wes Gordon. But it also echoes her fundamental ambitions: to celebrate glamour and beauty, even in unglamorous times. \u201cI think to survive in this business you have to believe in something. Make it your own and stay with it,\u201d she says. \u201cIf you want to be a designer, you have to be really sure that what you\u2019re doing is what you really believe in. I believe in glamour. I believe in beautiful, elegant women. And I believe women become beautiful when they wear Herrera.\u201d", "title": "Carolina Herrera\u2019s Very First Show \u2014 and What It Meant for Fashion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Steve Greenberg, who is running the auction for the current Panthers owner, Jerry Richardson, had no comment.\n\nThe sale of the Panthers is being widely watched in the league because the final price will become a benchmark for other team sales. Sports bankers said the Denver Broncos, New Orleans Saints and Tennessee Titans could change hands in the next few years. The patriarchs of each of those teams has died in recent years or are in failing health.\n\nRichardson, the Panthers\u2019s founder and owner, said he would sell the team in December, shortly after an article in Sports Illustrated linked him to allegations of sexual harassment. The N.F.L. is investigating those allegations. Richardson was initially seeking at least $3 billion for his team, but trimmed his expectations when no potential buyers emerged at that price.\n\nEven at $2.5 billion, the Panthers would set a record for the highest-priced sale for any team, and nearly a billion dollars more than the Buffalo Bills, who sold for a record $1.4 billion in 2014. That price was too much for Tepper and Rubin, who bid between $2 billion and $2.2 billion for the team, according to several people with knowledge of their offers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The team must play there through June, 2019, or pay a penalty to break the agreement.\n\nIf the Panthers leave after that date, the city could buy the stadium for $1 or the team could pay the remaining debt on the city\u2019s investment.", "title": "Carolina Panthers Sweepstakes Enters Its Home Stretch", "authors": ["Ken Belson"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Carolyn Jacobson, who roused organized labor to confront sexism in its ranks and helped place women\u2019s health care on its bargaining agenda, died on March 23 at her home in Washington. She was 67.\n\nThe cause was cancer of the uterus, her niece, Clarice Jacobson, said.\n\nDuring her 40-year career in the union movement, Ms. Jacobson galvanized support for her agenda from several platforms, beginning as communications director for the Bakery, Confectionary and Tobacco Workers & Grain Millers.\n\nShe was also a founder of the Berger-Marks Foundation, which trained women union organizers; a founding member of the Coalition of Labor Union Women; and a member of the International Labor Press Association (now the International Labor Communications Association).\n\n\u201cI am one of many women labor leaders that stand on her shoulders and have benefited from her legacy,\u201d Elizabeth H. Shuler, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said in an email.", "title": "Carolyn Jacobson, Champion of Women\u2019s Union Rights, Dies at 67", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "The good news is that more and more cities are deciding to wrest control of their streets back from the tyranny of the automobile \u2014 and to put people, and other modes of transportation, on a par with the auto.\n\nLondon now has 15 years of experience with a stiff \u201ccongestion charge\u201d that discourages many drivers from entering the city center. In a virtuous cycle, the money goes to better public transit and more bike lanes. Early legislative discussions are underway about trying the same thing in Seattle and in some of California\u2019s more congested cities. New York has just turned down such a plan for the second time in a decade, but the idea is not going to die \u2014 the city needs it too badly.\n\nIn the crowded cities of Asia, people are not allowed to get a car just because they want one. Shanghai residents must buy license plates that have gone for up to $13,000 at auction, and Beijing residents have to enter a lottery for a plate. Such measures might seem extreme, but they are sensible in a country that endured a 60-mile traffic jam in 2010 requiring 11 days to unsnarl.\n\nAs we write these words, we can sense the bile rising in some drivers. Americans have such a sense of entitlement about cars that any attempt to limit them can provoke a fight, as New York has discovered.\n\nYet the truth is that people who drive into a crowded city are imposing costs on others. They include not just reduced mobility for everyone and degraded public space, but serious health costs. Asthma attacks are set off by the tiny, invisible soot particles that cars emit. Recent research shows that a congestion charge in Stockholm reduced pollution and sharply cut asthma attacks in children.\n\nThe bottom line is that the decision to turn our public streets so completely over to the automobile, as sensible as it might have seemed decades ago, nearly wrecked the quality of life in our cities.\n\nWe are revealing no big secrets here. Urban planners have known all these things for decades. They have known that removing lanes to add bike paths and widen sidewalks can calm traffic, make a neighborhood more congenial \u2014 and, by the way, increase sales at businesses along that more pleasant street. They have known that imposing tolls with variable pricing can result in highway lanes that are rarely jammed.", "title": "Opinion | Cars Are Ruining Our Cities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The only thing more tearful than the goodbyes of dropping a freshman off at college are the four years of tuition, rent, food and books that follow. The College Board pegs the average annual cost, over all, at in-state institutions at $25,290. If your student is turning the tassel this spring, congratulations. Your checkbook deserves a well-earned breather.\n\nIt might have to endure one last flogging, though.\n\nShould that sheepskin result in a job (and let\u2019s hope so!) a vehicle may be needed. Or maybe you have a high school graduate who will be commuting to college, or one diving straight into the working world. Sending them off with a solid automobile is a terrific \u2014 albeit extravagant \u2014 graduation gift. Even if it\u2019s simply a hefty down payment to get them started, think of it as a final investment. One that means that maybe they\u2019ll come back only to visit, not to move back in.\n\nFirst, determine whether they\u2019re getting a new, used or leased vehicle. Buying new provides the security of knowing that the car wasn\u2019t abused, plus a warranty and the possibility of no-cost maintenance. That\u2019s reassuring if they live thousands of miles away. Going with a low-mileage two- or three-year-old car can be a great value, one that eliminates the sting of instant depreciation. If that\u2019s your route, buying a certified pre-owned car adds peace of mind. Leasing typically offers more car for a lower monthly payment, but an early-career job switch out of state can complicate matters.\n\nNext, get educated on brands and reliability. Ten years ago, the sage advice was to stick with Japanese cars, especially used models. These days, not so much. If you check the popular top-10 lists from Consumer Reports, J.D. Power and U.S. News and World Report, you\u2019ll find a mix of manufacturers from America, Europe, Japan and South Korea. Like students switching majors, you have options.", "title": "Cars That Will Get Your Grad Down the Road of Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Other supporters of the law, including President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto and federal government officials, have argued that the legislation will guide and regulate military operations, offering legal certainty to both the armed forces and the population by clarifying soldiers\u2019 tasks, limits and obligations. Such a framework, they said, had long been absent.\n\nAccording to government estimates, 32,000 people have been reported missing in Mexico since 2006, disappearances that have caused an indelible wound on families across the country. Members of the security forces are suspected in some of the disappearances, but many more are presumed to be the work of drug gangs.\n\nMexico\u2019s failure to investigate these cases has left families such as the Alvarados desperate for answers but with nowhere to turn.\n\nThe court\u2019s ruling in the Alvarado case, expected later this year, could influence another case being considered by Mexico\u2019s Supreme Court. That case is evaluating challenges to a law that critics say strengthens the military\u2019s role in policing the country\u2019s streets.\n\nUnder the past two Mexican administrations, the army\u2019s role has been expanded to include operations against drug gangs as well as policing duties. At the same time, formal complaints filed by civilians with different government agencies about allegations of torture, extrajudicial killings and forced disappearances have surged.\n\nAnd yet as allegations of serious crimes by soldiers and police officers piled up, the military remained largely untouched, protected by governments keen on enforcing the rule of law through the only force seen as able to stand up to the drug gangs.\n\nThe three members of the Alvarado family were snatched from Ejido Benito Ju\u00e1rez, a small town south of El Paso. What\u2019s the scope of operations in the region you handle?\n\nIn North America, we have about 40 customer service centers located in or near airports, where our teams do all the cooking and prepping from scratch. Then we transfer plated dishes to planes via trolleys.\n\nWhat is your role?\n\nI manage 13 chefs in Irving, Tex., part of our more than 500 employees throughout North America. I oversee the design and development of recipes and liaison between our airline customers and these chefs. My goal is to ensure each airline customer gets quality food service with individual touches that mirror its own brand identity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow do you design recipes and menus?\n\nA lead chef works out the recipes according to the airline\u2019s needs in conjunction with our international chef colleagues. After four days of prepping, we invite the customer\u2019s team to a presentation in our Irving kitchens. We do a walk-through explaining every dish; then they taste. Some airlines even bring flight attendants, who will be the ones to handle the food on board. If the customer wants to adjust the flavor profile, we immediately make the adjustment in our test kitchen and represent the revised menu item right after.", "title": "Catering to Fliers\u2019 Tastes at 30,000 Feet", "authors": ["Perry Garfinkel", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "27A: I have knitted and crocheted with a lot of different types of yarn, but only a few of them really stretch. That\u2019s why the answer is SAGA, another type of \u201cyarn\u201d that becomes bigger and stretchier the more it is told.\n\n5D: Hand up if you confidently dropped the word \u201clye\u201d in \u201cNeed for making soap from sap?\u201d Yes, I fell for it, too. You don\u2019t need lye to make soap from sap. You need AN O.\n\n9D/15D: Sometimes I need things explained to me, and that\u2019s O.K. That\u2019s how you learn. I thought these two clues were reversed, so I spoke to the puzzle editors, who reassured me that I was completely and utterly wrong. The clue for 9D, \u201cSingle,\u201d is ONE because it refers to a one-dollar bill. The clue for 15D, \u201cNumber for 9-Down,\u201d is SOLO because it refers to a song or \u201cnumber\u201d an artist can sing solo.\n\n10D: \u201cMet demands?\u201d can be something you do for, say, a kidnapper, but that\u2019s not what we\u2019re going for today. If you think of \u201cMet\u201d as short for Metropolitan Opera House, which is what it\u2019s called around these parts, the demands would be ARIAS.\n\n39D: Zero degrees is very, very cold no matter where you are, but in today\u2019s puzzle, we\u2019re not thinking about temperature, we are thinking about placement on a compass. \u201c0 degrees\u201d would be NORTH.\n\n63D: \u201cThe French way?\u201d sounds as if it would be hinting at the French way of doing things, but it\u2019s not. The clue is looking for the French word for \u201cway,\u201d which is RUE.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nI\u2019ve written two books of baseball-themed puzzles and love the idea of cluing baseball jargon in a nonbaseball way. This puzzle actually relates five answers to a situation you might hear described by a baseball announcer, with the appropriate payoff at the end. The puzzle needed to be a little wider to accommodate the longest answers and I tried to make the answers sound unforced. Looking forward to the 2018 season!\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Causing a Walk-off", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Duckworth was supposed to have a 12-week maternity leave, but she promised to return if her vote was really needed. And on Thursday, when her daughter Maile Pearl was only 10 days old, there was a super-close vote on the nomination of Jim Bridenstine to be NASA administrator. Bridenstine, a Republican member of the House, does not have much of a background in aeronautical science, unless you count time spent running the Tulsa Air and Space Museum. Plus, the fact that he\u2019s a climate-change hedger made some people wonder about the science part.\n\nNevertheless, he squeaked through by one vote. It seemed like an inauspicious way to introduce Maile Pearl to the democratic process, but fortunately the baby slept through everything. When she\u2019s 10 and gets to see pictures of her public debut, maybe they can tell her it was all about animal rights or better schools.\n\nIt\u2019s always a good thing when our elected officials experience the same daily-life stresses as their constituents. Until fairly recently, historically speaking, congressional-work-parenting tensions mainly involved making it to school recitals, while everything else was left to the stay-at-home wives. It wasn\u2019t until the 1980s that then-Representative Chuck Schumer became the first member of Congress with small children and a full-time working spouse.\n\nNow it\u2019s getting normal. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, whose husband spends part of each week working in New York, has vivid memories of the critical 5-to-6 p.m. crisis time in which her kids had to be scooped up from child care and tended to until the babysitter arrived. \u201cThey started calling votes a lot at that time, for some reason,\u201d she recalled. Gillibrand decided the safest place to leave her toddlers \u201cwas in [Majority Leader] Harry Reid\u2019s reception area.\u201d\n\nThe baby-vote rule is a welcome sign that members of the House and Senate are becoming more aware of how difficult it is for working couples to balance jobs and child care. And people like Duckworth have also sponsored legislation to make life easier for them.\n\nDo not take this as a signal to sigh in satisfaction. The current congressional majority has hardly translated that new sensitivity into a big investment in early childhood education or after-school programs.\n\nStill, in the interest of mental health, feel free to take whatever victories we get. The Senate is now ready to let babies on the floor for a few minutes, and soon may even manage to end the practice of settling members\u2019 sexual harassment suits with public cash.\n\nSomeday, maybe we\u2019ll be able to say that the infants are sleeping but the place is totally woke.", "title": "Opinion | Caution, Babies Voting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "At the center of his art was that dazzling physicality and the percussiveness of his playing \u2014 his deep, serene, Ellingtonian chords and hummingbird attacks above middle C \u2014 which held true well into his 80s.\n\nBut in concert he also recited his own poems, whose enjambed lines might describe Aztec architecture, paleoanthropology, crocodile reproduction or a woman\u2019s posture. His motions around the instrument and the bandstand were a part of his performance too.\n\nIn his system of writing music, working with bands and performing, he was concerned with what he called, in a 1971 interview with the writer Robert Levin, \u201cblack methodology\u201d: oral traditions, music as embodied celebration and spiritual homage.\n\nClassically trained, he valued European music for what he called its qualities of \u201cconstruction\u201d \u2014 form, timbre, tone color \u2014 and incorporated them into his own aesthetic.\n\n\u201cI am not afraid of European influences,\u201d he told the critic Nat Hentoff. \u201cThe point is to use them, as Ellington did, as part of my life as an American Negro.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a long assessment of Mr. Taylor\u2019s work \u2014 one of the first \u2014 from \u201cFour Lives in the Bebop Business,\u201d a collection of essays on jazz musicians published in 1966, the poet and critic A. B. Spellman wrote:\n\n\u201cThere is only one musician who has, by general agreement even among those who have disliked his music, been able to incorporate all that he wants to take from classical and modern Western composition into his own distinctly individual kind of blues without in the least compromising those blues, and that is Cecil Taylor, a kind of Bartok in reverse.\u201d\n\nBecause his fully formed work was not folkish or pop-oriented, did not swing consistently (often it did not swing at all) and never entered the consensual jazz repertoire, Mr. Taylor could be understood to occupy an isolated place. Even after he was rewarded and lionized \u2014 he was given a Guggenheim fellowship in 1973, a National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters award in 1990, a MacArthur fellowship in 1991 and the Kyoto Prize in 2014 \u2014 his music was not easy to quantify.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf improvisation means using intuition and risk in the present moment, there have been few musicians who took that challenge more seriously than Mr. Taylor. If one of his phrases seemed of paramount importance, another such phrase generally arrived right behind it. The range of expression in his keyboard touch encompassed caresses, rumbles and crashes.\n\nHe was capable of performances full of stillness and awe, suggesting a kind of physical movement through musical phrases, as on the unaccompanied \u201cPemmican\u201d (from the 1981 live recording \u201cGarden\u201d). Or he could go on full attack, as on \u201cTaht\u201d from the 1984 album \u201cWinged Serpent (Sliding Quadrants)\u201d \u2014 his fingers hammering and flying across the keys and breaking through the sound of a polytonal, polyrhythmic 11-piece band.\n\nSome of his greatest musical relationships were with drummers, among them Max Roach, Elvin Jones, Sunny Murray and Ronald Shannon Jackson.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Mother\u2019s Influence\n\nCecil Percival Taylor was born in Long Island City, Queens, on March 25, 1929, and grew up about four miles away, in Corona. His father, Percy, originally from North Carolina, was a chef for Dr. John Kindred, president of the River Crest Sanitarium in Corona. Growing up, Cecil revered his mother, the former Almeida Ragland, for her learning and her high standards. She spoke French and German, took him to see Bill Bojangles Robinson and Ella Fitzgerald, and suggested that he read Schopenhauer.\n\nAcknowledging his desire to become a musician, rather than pursuing one of the careers she preferred for him \u2014 doctor, lawyer or dentist \u2014 his mother insisted that he practice the piano six days a week, then do what he wanted on Sunday. \u201cThat\u2019s when the organization of my music began, when she wasn\u2019t looking,\u201d Mr. Taylor said in an interview in the literary journal Hambone.\n\nShe died of cancer when he was 14.\n\nMr. Taylor studied piano at the New York College of Music in Manhattan and, in the early 1950s, moved to Boston, where he had relatives, to attend the New England Conservatory.\n\nWhile studying piano, arranging, harmony and solf\u00e8ge notation there, he started going to jazz clubs, which he said helped him develop ideas about his music more than anything he learned in school. He prized Ellington for his orchestral approach to the piano and Horace Silver for his rough, vernacular energy; he saw Charlie Parker, Bud Powell, Sarah Vaughan and the relatively little-known pianist Dick Twardzik, all of whom would contribute to his conception of music, as did Stravinsky.\n\n(The answer to the question of what music gave rise to Mr. Taylor, and what he liked to listen to, would encompass all those names as well as Marvin Gaye, Gyorgy Ligeti, Betty Carter, Judy Garland and Thelonious Monk. The Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava and the flamenco dancer Carmen Amaya had also influenced him to think about structure, movement and time, he said.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBack in New York, Mr. Taylor formed groups with the vibraphonist Earl Griffith and the soprano saxophonist Steve Lacy. In 1956, with a quartet rounded out by Mr. Lacy, the bassist Buell Neidlinger (who died on March 16) and the drummer Denis Charles, he made his first album, \u201cJazz Advance.\u201d Featuring standards as well as his own compositions, it was produced by Tom Wilson, who later worked with Bob Dylan, the Mothers of Invention and the Velvet Underground.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe quartet played at the Newport Jazz Festival the next year, a performance released by Verve Records as one side of an album. (The other side featured a group led by the alto saxophonist Gigi Gryce and the trumpeter Donald Byrd.)\n\nMr. Taylor\u2019s music at that time was steadily swinging and fit recognizably within the modern jazz idiom \u2014 its spiky phrases had a clear connection to Monk\u2019s \u2014 but it was also already moving beyond it. \u201cTune 2,\u201d for example, from the Newport record, had an 88-bar form, a long way from the 32-bar song structure more commonly used in jazz.\n\nHe went further in that direction on the 1958 record \u201cLooking Ahead!,\u201d then recorded a session, originally issued as \u201cHard Driving Jazz,\u201d with an ad hoc group, put together by Mr. Wilson, that included John Coltrane.\n\nPhoto\n\nListeners \u2018Fidgeted\u2019\n\nWith renown came a particular kind of scrutiny. In 1959, Gunther Schuller devoted a long essay in The Jazz Review to the question of whether Mr. Taylor\u2019s music was atonal.\n\n\u201cListening carefully to his playing leaves no doubt of the fact that Taylor indeed does think tonally, but the result of his thinking most of the time cannot be analyzed on tonal terms,\u201d he wrote.\n\nWhitney Balliett of The New Yorker described a crowd reacting to Mr. Taylor\u2019s performance at the Great South Bay Jazz Festival on Long Island in 1958: A few were mesmerized, he wrote, while others \u201cfidgeted, whispered and wandered nervously in and out of the tent, as if the ground beneath had suddenly become unbearably hot.\u201d\n\nBy 1961, given the chance to contribute half the music on an album under the arranger Gil Evans\u2019s name (the other half showcased the composer Johnny Carisi), Mr. Taylor played only original music: striking pieces with shifting tempos and splintering melodic lines.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe next year he formed a bond with the alto saxophonist Jimmy Lyons, who would work with him for more than 20 years; the two were the core of the Cecil Taylor Unit, a group with an otherwise shifting membership. (Mr. Lyons died in 1986.)\n\nBy 1966, when he recorded the album \u201cUnit Structures\u201d for Blue Note, Mr. Taylor was forming a syntax where none had existed. He was using blues tonality and dissonance in his improvisations and original structures in his written music, organized in ways that were not traditional for jazz, even for the relatively new avant-garde sort with which he was generally associated.\n\nIn one piece on \u201cUnit Structures,\u201d titled \u201cEnter Evening,\u201d piano, oboe, alto saxophone and bass play staggered and unresolved melodic lines that refer to one another only in a distant sense, coming together loosely only in places. There is percussion, but no steady rhythm.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t the technique and feeling of jazz that Mr. Taylor was rejecting, only its form: the 32-bar song, the theme-solos-theme progression.\n\nInstead, his structures often proceeded sequentially, shifting among motifs and tonal centers. When he used written scores for his musicians, melodies were indicated by note letters, but there were no staves or bar lines; this gave musicians more freedom within his music, and, he decided, more investment in it.\n\n\u201cWhen you think about musicians who are reading music,\u201d he said in \u201cAll the Notes,\u201d a 1993 documentary directed by Chris Felver, \u201cmy contention has always been: The energy that you\u2019re using deciphering what the symbol is is taking away from the maximum creative energy that you might have had if you understood that it\u2019s but a symbol.\u201d\n\nThere was no academy for what Mr. Taylor did, and partly for that reason he became one himself, teaching for stretches in the 1970s at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, and at Antioch College in Ohio. (He was given an honorary doctorate by the New England Conservatory in 1977.) Not until the mid-1970s, Mr. Lyons told the writer John Litweiler, did the Cecil Taylor Unit have enough work that the musicians could make a living from it \u2014 mostly in Europe.\n\nSolos and Duos\n\nDuring this time Mr. Taylor was giving a lot of solo-piano performances, a practice he started around 1967 and refined through albums like \u201cIndent\u201d (1973), \u201cFly! Fly! Fly! Fly! Fly!\u201d (1980) and \u201cFor Olim\u201d (1986).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe would occasionally perform in a duo with another improviser: pared-down and sometimes jarring situations if the other performer pushed too hard against Mr. Taylor. Those pairings led to a clashing concert with the swing-era pianist Mary Lou Williams in 1977; memorable performances with Max Roach in 1979, 1989 and 2000; and collaborations with the Japanese butoh dancer Min Tanaka. In 1979, he collaborated with the dancers Mikhail Baryshnikov and Heather Watts on a short ballet.\n\nIn the summer of 1988, Mr. Taylor played a series of concerts in East and West Berlin \u2014 solo, in duos and with groups of various sizes \u2014 which were released on the FMP label as an 11-CD set, \u201cCecil Taylor in Berlin \u201988.\u201d\n\nSince 1983, Mr. Taylor had lived alone in a three-story home in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. During that time he would perform occasionally in nightclubs, but more often in theaters or even museums around the world.\n\nIn 2014, a contractor working on his house, Noel Muir, bilked him out of nearly all of the $500,000 that Mr. Taylor had received for the Kyoto Prize; Mr. Muir was sentenced to one to three years in prison.\n\nNo immediate family members survive.\n\nAs uncompromising as Mr. Taylor could be, many musicians bear his influence, directly or by general example; a list of pianists alone would include Marilyn Crispell, Vijay Iyer, Craig Taborn, Chucho Vald\u00e9s and Jason Moran.\n\nIn 2016, the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York organized a two-week exhibition and residency dedicated to Mr. Taylor; it featured panel discussions, a play, films, dance performances, displays of his written scores and live music. He performed at the beginning and end of the event, playing piano and reading poetry, with Mr. Tanaka and with various ensembles. It was an ambitious attempt to take the full measure of Mr. Taylor as an artist who would not be held to the conventions of any one discipline.\n\n\u201cWhat I am doing,\u201d he said in 1994, \u201cis creating a language. A different American language.\u201d\n\nPhoto", "title": "Cecil Taylor, Pianist Who Defied Jazz Orthodoxy, Is Dead at 89", "authors": ["Ben Ratliff"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "She rolled out the first moufleta with the help of an assistant, dropped it into the pan, flipped it once and then put the next on top. The heat from the first moufleta began cooking the side of the second that touched it, and then she flipped both at once, so the second moufleta got a browning on one side. She repeated this, over and over, until she had a stack of dozens, flipping the growing stack with her fingers.\n\n\u201cWhen you work in a kitchen, you don\u2019t really feel the heat anymore,\u201d she said.\n\nAs the pile became nearly unmanageable, the guests began hovering. The hosts laid out softened sticks of butter and squeeze bottles of honey, near an enormous tea set with a kaleidoscopic array of colored glasses.\n\nWhen the guests dug in, one thing became immediately clear: Mimouna has to be in the running for the stickiest culinary ritual known to humanity. Honey gets under your fingernails, on your lapel, in the crevices of your cellphone and on the bottom of your shoes as children mill about and dribble it on the floor. So you rinse, and repeat.\n\nIn Moroccan communities in Israel, there are generally no formal invitations to Mimouna, but everyone comes. Hosts maintain an open-door policy, and families wander from house to house, sipping tea, eating a moufleta, sampling another sweet or two and then walking down the street for more.", "title": "Celebrating Mimouna and Its Dose of Post-Passover Carbs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The Boston Celtics, whose season began with a devastating injury, will enter the N.B.A. playoffs with news of another: Kyrie Irving, their All-Star point guard, needs another operation on his left knee and will miss the postseason.\n\nThe team, which had been hopeful that Irving would return to the lineup at some point in the playoffs after undergoing knee surgery last month, announced Thursday that he was scheduled for a second procedure to remove two screws from the knee and that he would need four to five months to recover.\n\nWith just over a week remaining in the regular season, the Celtics (53-25) have the second-best record in the Eastern Conference, but Irving\u2019s absence is a blow to their hopes of contending for a title.\n\nIrving, in his first season with the Celtics after forcing an off-season trade from the Cleveland Cavaliers, averaged 24.4 points and 5.1 assists a game this season while shooting a career-best 49.1 percent from the field. Six former Census Bureau directors have warned that the move would depress responses among minorities who fear that the government would use that information against them.\n\nBut that is just one of the challenges ahead.\n\nThe Providence census was supposed to be one of four that would test a wealth of new digital equipment and counting methodologies under starkly different conditions \u2014 in urban Rhode Island, rural West Virginia, Spanish-speaking Puerto Rico and tribal lands in Washington State. But budget problems, largely rooted in Congress\u2019s refusal to fully fund the bureau, forced the cancellation of three tests. That has left Providence County as a make-or-break trial of the reimagined head count \u2014 the statistical equivalent of staging a Broadway musical after a single rehearsal in New Haven.", "title": "Census Officials Say Rhode Island Rehearsal Is Going Well. Not Everyone Agrees.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Groups such as the Central Park Conservancy and the New York Road Runners celebrated the decision for the benefit it will have for runners and bicyclists in the park as well as for the environment. Last year, 42 million people visited Central Park.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat we are saying is that the street doesn\u2019t belong only to drivers, it belongs to all of us,\u201d said Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez of Manhattan.\n\nThe evolution of Central Park\u2019s drives has been decades in the making. In 1966, Mayor John V. Lindsay first announced that Central Park would be closed to cars on Sundays. The next year, Saturdays were added. In 2015, Mr. de Blasio banned cars on Central Park drives north of 72nd Street, which had been open during certain hours of the morning and afternoon rush. In January, Mr. de Blasio also permanently banned cars from Prospect Park in Brooklyn.\n\nChristopher Nolan, chief operating officer for the Central Park Conservancy, said there has been a steady shift in the notion of the car\u2019s role in urban life.\n\n\u201cPeople have a focus on urban life that\u2019s not dependent on the car,\u201d Mr. Nolan said. \u201cYou come to the park to escape the city. By letting the cars in, you perforate the edge of the park and let the city in.\u201d\n\nAs the city has closed more and more of Central Park to cars, drivers have adjusted, said Polly Trottenberg, the city\u2019s transportation commissioner.\n\nWest Drive, for example, located between 72nd Street and the Seventh Avenue exit and open from 8 a.m. to 10 a.m. on weekdays, is used by 1,050 vehicles per day, according to the Department of Transportation. East Drive, between Sixth Avenue and 72 Street, is open from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. on weekdays and is used by 3,400 vehicles per day.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe impact on surrounding streets is expected to be minimal, Ms. Trottenberg said. New York Police Department traffic agents will be at intersections to help ease the transition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt takes a few weeks, but people find new routes and blend into the grid,\u201d Ms. Trottenberg said. \u201cParticularly here in Manhattan, there are a lot of different routes people can take.\u201d\n\nPedicabs and horse-drawn carriages will also be allowed to continue in the park. Mr. de Blasio pledged to ban the horse-drawn carriage industry on the first day of his administration. Three months into his second term, he has been unable to do so.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address.
