Officers had confronted Mr. Garner, who was unarmed, over accusations of selling untaxed cigarettes. His final gasps of \u201cI can\u2019t breathe,\u201d captured on a cellphone video, became a rallying cry for protesters around the country.\n\nIn recent weeks, career prosecutors recommended civil rights charges against Officer Pantaleo and sought approval from the deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, to seek an indictment, according to the officials. Mr. Rosenstein has convened several meetings that revealed divisions within the Justice Department over whether to move forward. No decision has been made, but one law enforcement official said that, based on the discussions so far, it appeared unlikely that Mr. Rosenstein would approve charges.\n\nAttorney General Jeff Sessions has also been briefed on the case and could weigh in after Mr. Rosenstein makes his own recommendation, officials said.", "title": "Charges Sought in Eric Garner\u2019s Death, but Justice Officials Have Doubts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Think of it like this: One way a company could please Senator Chuck Grassley, the Iowa Republican who leads the Judiciary Committee and is a member of the committees on finance, agriculture, the budget and taxation, would be to have a corporate political action committee donate directly to his campaign.\n\nBut there is another way, one that often slips below the radar of campaign-finance watchdogs. Why not donate to the Partnership for a Drug-Free Iowa, where the senator has been an honorary advisory board member?\n\nA corporation could also give to the University of Northern Iowa Foundation, on whose board Mr. Grassley sat as a trustee. Over the period covered by the study, the foundations of AT&T, ConAgra Foods, General Electric, Goldman Sachs, Medtronic, Merck, Monsanto, Nationwide Insurance, Principal Financial Group and Rockwell Collins all contributed to one or the other.\n\nMr. Grassley\u2019s office, when asked about the corporate contributions to causes linked to the senator, said: \u201cSenator Grassley receives many requests to support various nonprofit organizations. He lends his name to some, but declines most.\u201d\n\nThat companies might butter up legislators by donating to their pet charities is not new. In 2010, my colleague Eric Lipton documented the contributions to the Joe Baca Foundation and the James E. Clyburn Research and Scholarship Foundation, each affiliated with a Democratic member of Congress.\n\nThe researchers who conducted the new study don\u2019t claim that any specific charitable contribution was meant to manipulate the political process. But their work lays bare the extent to which corporate donations may respond to political, rather than charitable, motivations.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt is possible that when the Exelon Corporation donated $25,000 to Representative Joe Barton\u2019s effort to build a Boys and Girls Club in Texas in 2008, it did so because it believed in boys and girls, not because Mr. Barton was the top Republican member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Microsoft\u2019s donation to the Seattle Art Museum may have reflected the company\u2019s support for the arts, not its desire to please Representative Jim McDermott, who was on the museum\u2019s honorary committee. (Mr. McDermott, a Democrat, has since retired.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe new research uncovers patterns in the aggregate data that suggest corporate donations are often dictated by recipients\u2019 political clout. For instance, a company foundation will donate more to charities in districts where the representatives have gained seats on a committee that is important to the company. And when the member of Congress leaves office, corporate donations to charities in his or her district will dip.\n\nCorporations\u2019 philanthropy often flows to the same areas as their political action committee contributions: Charities in districts where companies favor a particular candidate tend to get more corporate donations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA charity need not have been founded by a member of Congress to get corporate money. But it helps. A nonprofit is more than four times more likely to receive grants from a corporate foundation if a politician sits on its board. And corporate foundation grants are even more likely if the politician happens to sit on a committee being lobbied by the firm.\n\nThe authors of the study examined only a subset of corporate philanthropy, money flowing through corporate foundations that must disclose the recipients of their largess. But the research suggests that the impact of corporate contributions could be much bigger than even critics of campaign-finance practices realize.\n\nThe researchers estimate that over 7 percent of charitable donations by corporate foundations are intended to buy political leverage. Applied to $18 billion worth of corporate philanthropy in 2014, that would amount to $1.3 billion, almost four times as much as total political action committee contributions that year and 40 percent more than the corporations\u2019 lobbying expenditures.\n\nThere are a couple of lessons here. For those who favor campaign-finance reform, perhaps the most urgent message is that there are many doors that corporate America can use to buy influence. But the research also highlights the way that companies interact with society.\n\nCorporations are likely to tally their foundations\u2019 charity as a decided plus on the dashboard of corporate social responsibility. But politically motivated charitable giving meant to undercut regulations, promote a tax cut or otherwise gain a break could actually reduce total welfare.\n\nAs the researchers write, \u201cIf corporations\u2019 good deeds (in the form of charitable contributions) cater to politicians\u2019 interests, who as a result put the interests of business ahead of those of voters, the overall welfare effects are ambiguous \u2014 society benefits via increased charity, at the potentially high cost of distorting laws and regulation.\u201d\n\nNone of this would happen, of course, if politicians weren\u2019t so hungry for corporate money. \u201cCompanies wouldn\u2019t do this if it didn\u2019t pay off,\u201d Professor Bombardini told me. \u201cPoliticians get good publicity by channeling funds that are valuable to the community. Whatever makes you look good, you want to take credit for it.\u201d\n\nBut with a new wave of scandals engulfing some of the nation\u2019s corporate titans, it would behoove them to honestly assess the ultimate purpose of their charity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFacebook doesn\u2019t have a corporate foundation. But its chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has pledged 99 percent of his Facebook shares to advance human potential and promote equality. Perhaps the pledge could include never deploying his company\u2019s financial might to steer the nation\u2019s political process for corporate gain.", "title": "Charitable Giving by Corporations Is Also About Getting, a New Study Finds", "authors": ["Eduardo Porter", "Economic Scene"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Charles Frederick McDew was born in Massillon, about 55 miles south of Cleveland, on June 23, 1938. His father, James, had taught chemistry in South Carolina but as a black was unable to get a job in the Ohio schools; he went to work in the steel mills. His mother, the former Eva Stephens, was a nurse.\n\nHis parents persuaded Charles to attend South Carolina State College, his father\u2019s alma mater, instead of attending the University of Michigan, where he had hoped to play football.\n\nHis first semester in Orangeburg went well, until he was driving back to campus with a classmate after Thanksgiving.\n\nStopped by a police officer, Mr. McDew failed to show proper deference (he neglected to say \u201csir,\u201d he said) and was struck by the officer. Mr. McDew hit him back, and a fight ensued. (\u201cMind you, this is before the nonviolent civil rights struggle,\u201d he said.) He wound up in jail with a broken arm and jaw.\n\nTaking a train back to college, he was arrested again after refusing to sit in a baggage car designated for blacks.\n\n\u201cIt seems that on every car, on every train in the South \u2014 this is in 1959 \u2014 there was one car on the train for black people, the car right behind the engines, where the soot and dust would come through,\u201d Mr. McDew told a Smithsonian Institution oral history project in 2011. \u201cAnd when that was filled, you\u2019d sit in the baggage car. I said: \u2018No, no, no, sport. Not for my little 10 dollars and 50 cents do I ride with suitcases and mangy dogs. I don\u2019t do baggage cars. And there are plenty of seats right here, and I\u2019m having one of them,\u2019 and sat down.\u201d\n\nWhen he arrived in Orangeburg, he was arrested yet again after taking a shortcut though a whites-only public park.", "title": "Charles McDew, 79, Tactician for Student Civil Rights Group, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Upon his release he moved to New York City. He became involved in modern jazz and toured with soul singers like Johnnie Taylor, Clarence Carter and O. V. Wright.\n\nHe returned to New Orleans in 1976 for a recording project: \u201cThe Wild Tchoupitoulas,\u201d which brought the Mardi Gras Indian tribe led by his uncle George Landry (a. k. a. Big Chief Jolly) into the studio with a band featuring his nephews, the four Neville brothers. The album\u2019s fusion of traditional street chants and funk made it a cornerstone of modern New Orleans music.\n\nThe brothers decided to keep working together. In New Orleans, the Neville Brothers were a supergroup. Art Neville had sung the 1954 hit \u201cMardi Gras Mambo\u201d and in 1969 formed the influential New Orleans funk band the Meters, which Cyril Neville later joined. Aaron Neville had a Top 10 pop hit in 1966 with \u201cTell It Like It Is.\u201d\n\nThe brothers brought their old repertoires and a growing new one to their concerts, gaining nationwide and worldwide followings on tour. They were the perennial finale on the main stage at the annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival and played New Year\u2019s Eve shows at the Fillmore Auditorium in San Francisco.\n\nThe Neville Brothers recorded more than a dozen studio and live albums, although the only one to sell as many as a half-million copies was \u201cYellow Moon\u201d (1989).\n\nMr. Neville also recorded with Diversity, a group mixing jazz and classical musicians, and with Native American musicians in the group Songcatchers. He released an album as a leader, \u201cSafe in Buddha\u2019s Palm\u201d \u2014 the title reflected his longtime interest in Eastern philosophies \u2014 in 2008.\n\nIn the 1990s he moved to rural Massachusetts, and he performed with his sons, Khalif and Talyn, as the New England Nevilles. But he returned often to New Orleans, and after the Neville Brothers disbanded in 2012 he joined Aaron Neville\u2019s touring band; he also performed in New Orleans with a daughter, the singer Charmaine Neville. Failing health prevented him from joining a Neville family reunion concert in 2017.\n\nIn addition to his three brothers, he is survived by his wife, Kristin Neville; his sister, Althelgra Neville Gabriel; and his children \u2014 Charmaine, Khalif, Talyn, Charlotte, Carlos and Charles Neville; Charlene White, Rowena Alix and Charlestine Jones \u2014 as well as numerous grandchildren.", "title": "Charles Neville of the Neville Brothers Is Dead at 79", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Fueled by a booming economy, the surcharge resulted in a $3.2 billion surplus for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1969, by which time Richard M. Nixon was in the White House. It was the only surplus generated by the federal budget from 1960, the last full year of the Eisenhower administration, to 1998, under President Bill Clinton.\n\n\u201cIt was not cutting expenditures,\u201d Mr. Zwick recalled in 2000 in an oral history interview with the University of Florida history department. \u201cIt was growing revenues that really balanced the budget.\u201d\n\nMr. Zwick\u2019s assistant budget director, Peter A. Lewis, also gave credit for the surplus to what he described as Johnson\u2019s uncomplicated formula for bankrolling federal disbursements.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cRather than closing this or that loophole,\u201d Mr. Lewis said in a telephone interview, \u201cat the end of your tax form you just added 10 percent.\u201d\n\nMr. Zwick was director of the Bureau of the Budget (now the White House Office of Management and Budget) for a year, until Johnson left office in January 1969. He was then chairman and chief executive of Southeast Banking Corporation in Florida until 1991, when he resigned after the company recorded losses in real estate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2010, Mr. Zwick gave $1 million to the University of Connecticut to finance the expansion of the renamed Charles J. Zwick Center for Food and Resource Policy, which seeks market solutions to problems involving food and energy.\n\nIn 2011, he donated $1 million to the RAND Corporation to establish the Zwick Impact Fund, which has studied autonomous vehicle safety, the benefits of educating prison inmates, the prevention of hazing in the military and the cost of caring for patients with dementia.\n\nCharles John Zwick was born on July 17, 1926, in the Plantsville section of Southington, Conn., to the former Mabel Rich and Louis Zwick, a farmer who raised vegetables and flowers.\n\n\u201cThen we grew what is known as the last crop of every farm in Connecticut, a housing development,\u201d he said in 2000. \u201cThat was the end of the Zwick farm.\u201d\n\nHis mother sent him off to the University of Connecticut, where the only A grade he received as a freshman was in economics.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Gee, that is pretty good. Maybe that is what I ought to be, an economist,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Zwick recalled.\n\nWhen his father was seriously injured in a tractor accident, he returned home to run the farm for several years.\n\n\u201cThat was enough for me to decide I did not want to be a farmer full time,\u201d Mr. Zwick said.\n\nHe enlisted in the Army and served in Japan after World War II, then completed his bachelor\u2019s and master\u2019s degrees in agricultural economics in 1950 and 1951 at the University of Connecticut. He later earned a doctorate in economics from Harvard.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis first wife, the former Joan Cameron, died in 2005. He is survived by their two children, Bob and Janet E. Zwick, and his wife, the former Barbara Collingwood.\n\nMr. Zwick was a researcher at the RAND Corporation from 1956 to 1965, heading its logistics department and studying urban transportation and Air Force efficiency. He came to the attention of the Johnson administration during the Vietnam War as leader of an on-site RAND study of the so-called pacification program to win popular support for the South Vietnamese government. The study concluded that the program was failing because the government\u2019s leadership was not indigenous.\n\nHe was named assistant to the budget director, Charles L. Schultze, in 1966 and succeeded him in 1968.\n\n\u201cOne of the first things you must do, Mr. Zwick, is to learn the basic vocabulary of the budget director,\u201d Johnson advised him at his swearing-in. \u201cYour predecessors were masters at it. As they can tell you, the first word you have to learn to speak is, like a child says \u2018da da,\u2019 a budget director has to say, \u2018no, no.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Charles Zwick, Who Balanced Budget Under Johnson, Dies at 91", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Success in show business has begotten success in the hospitality business. A year and a half ago, Mr. Palminteri partnered with a New York liquor company to introduce his own line of Sicilian vodka, BiVi. By the strangest coincidence, it is available at Chazz Palminteri Italian Restaurant, which recently moved from the east side of Manhattan to the theater district.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat Mr. Palminteri\u2019s boyhood dream became a reality \u2014 an expansive residence with a fountain out front, a pool out back, a gym and wine cellar in the basement and a Jackson Pollock on the wall leading to the second floor \u2014 should come as a surprise to no one.\n\nActually, the Pollock is a remarkably good copy, a cherished housewarming gift to Mr. Palminteri and his wife, Gianna, from their friend Peter Brant, an executive producer of the movie \u201cPollock,\u201d who educated them about modern art.\n\nEighteen years ago, after the Palminteris settled on the right parcel of land in Bedford (one near an easy route to New York City), \u201cwe walked through the lot to decide which trees were going to go,\u201d recalled Ms. Palminteri, an actor and producer. \u201cBut I did not like cutting trees down. I saw all the birds and squirrels and I said, \u2018We are destroying nature to build a house.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe added: \u201cAnd Chazz was like, \u2018This is good. We need the land. The squirrels can move to the next tree.\u2019\u201d Spoken like a true son of Belmont Avenue.\n\nThe house that displaced the resident fauna is Georgian on the outside, thanks to Mr. Palminteri, who, for the record, was very particular about the quantity of stones (more, more) and the masonry. It looks like a Tuscan villa inside, thanks to Ms. Palminteri.\n\n\u201cI have a very Mediterranean sense of style,\u201d she said, nodding at the arched doorways, the walls that were faux-finished to resemble aged plaster, and the limestone and rough-hewn marble floor in the double-height foyer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. They sit on the Directoire chairs that ring the walnut dining table and that bear the scratches of abundant use. And they gather in the living room, whose look \u2014 animal prints on the ottoman, the wing chairs and throw pillows \u2014 speaks to Ms. Palminteri\u2019s fondness for African design.\n\nRalph Lauren was the taming influence in the lair Mr. Palminteri calls his own. The paneled walls are a dignified hunter green, the carpet burgundy, the ceiling beams mahogany, the desk perfect for a lawyer or banker. \u201cI think it\u2019s so classy to have my office look like this,\u201d he said.\n\nThe zero-gravity chair (where Mr. Palminteri does some of his best writing and takes some of his best naps) and the mini-trampoline, known as a rebounder (where he does five minutes of bouncing every hour or so), may not quite fit with the genteel d\u00e9cor, but so what.\n\nHere, Mr. Palminteri is surrounded by framed posters of his movies (\u201cThe Usual Suspects,\u201d \u201cMulholland Falls,\u201d \u201cAnalyze This,\u201d \u201cA Bronx Tale\u201d), photos of buddies like Al Pacino and Mr. De Niro, a duplicate of the Chazz Palminteri caricature that hangs in Sardi\u2019s and a framed document certifying that a card with Mr. Palminteri\u2019s signature observation about wasted talent is floating in space. For that, he thanks the former astronaut Mike Massimino, who, it so happens, is a big fan of \u201cA Bronx Tale.\u201d\n\nIn a corner sits an angel sculpture, one of several in the house.\n\n\u201cI have a thing for them,\u201d Mr. Palminteri said. \u201cI\u2019m very spiritual, and they give me a feeling of being watched over.\u201d The feeling seems justified.", "title": "Chazz Palminteri\u2019s Bedford Tale", "authors": ["Joanne Kaufman", "What I Love"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Visiting this page also prompts the program to check for any new updates to itself. Chrome is typically set to keep itself updated automatically and downloads new versions of itself in the background as you use it. The updates \u2014 which can include security patches, new features and bug fixes \u2014 are installed when you quit the program and reopen it.\n\nTo see what version of Mozilla Firefox is running on a Windows PC, open the program, click the Help menu and choose About Firefox. On the Mac edition, click the Firefox menu in the upper-left corner of the screen and choose About Firefox; the steps for checking Apple\u2019s Safari browser are similar, except you click on Safari in the menu bar and choose About Safari.\n\nFor Microsoft\u2019s Internet Explorer and Edge browsers, check the Options or the Settings menu. In Internet Explorer, click the gear-shaped icon in the upper-right side of the tool bar and select About Internet Explorer. For the Edge browser, select the three-dot more menu in the top-right corner of the browser window and scroll to the bottom of the menu that opens \u2014 where the Edge version is listed.", "title": "Checking Your Browser Version", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "This might have made the clues too long, but I felt that a puzzle like this cried out for punnier clues. For example, at 28A\u2019s FETA ATTRACTION, a pun on the film \u201cFatal Attraction,\u201d I think a clue like \u201cThriller about an obsession with Greek cheese?\u201d would have been fun.\n\nIn nontheme news, I liked some of the fill that seemed like a nod to Mr. Yankovic, like Tom LEHRER and John CLEESE, in addition to the shout-outs to memories from his and Mr. Berlin\u2019s childhoods, like Wile E. Coyote (TNT) and Star Trek (\u201cHE\u2019S dead, Jim\u201d).\n\nTricky Clues\n\n7A: The entry space for \u201cShouts made with the waving of white hankies\u201d was too short for WE SURRENDER, so it had to be OL\u00c9S, as in the cheering people do in a corrida during a bullfight, right before they give up.\n\n42A: Tricky one! In its molten form, LAVA is a \u201crock that rolls.\u201d\n\n32D: I like these \u201cdouble meaning\u201d clues because they really stretch your brain. \u201cCoach \u2026 or what a coach is part of\u201d is TRAIN, because to coach someone is to train them, and the coach is part of a railroad train.\n\n35A: What a coincidence. The singer SARA Bareilles is in the puzzle just days after her performance as Mary Magdalene in the electrifying televised concert, \u201cJesus Christ Superstar Live.\u201d If you missed it, you can watch it in its entirety on NBC.com.\n\n48D: Were you tricked by the subtlety of the clue, \u201cAcre\u2019s land\u201d? In today\u2019s puzzle, Acre isn\u2019t a measurement, it\u2019s a city in ISRAEL. You\u2019ve just been fooled by a veiled capital clue, which is when a proper name is stashed at the beginning of a clue so you don\u2019t notice that there is an alternative reason for using a capital letter.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nEric Berlin: I\u2019m a child of the earliest days of MTV, and I\u2019m also a big old nerd, so naturally I\u2019ve been a fan of Weird Al practically from the moment he first emerged on the scene. His lyrics were clearly the product of somebody with a puzzler\u2019s mind \u2014 just glance at the all-palindrome lyrics of \u201cBob,\u201d or his innumerable pun-filled parodies. When a documentary about the man briefly showed a picture of him holding an issue of Games magazine, I was simultaneously a) completely unsurprised and b) transported with delight at this further proof that Al and I would get along famously should we ever meet. Back in early December I got it into my head that Al would make an ideal addition to the celebrity/constructor pairings that The New York Times has been featuring on its crossword page. I pitched this to Will Shortz. He turned around and pitched it to Al. (And thanks to my old friend and occasional Times contributor, Gavin Edwards, who has a knack for knowing how to get in touch with famous people.) Al, to my delight, leapt at the idea, and all of a sudden I found myself in a weeklong many-e-mails-a-day correspondence with one of my childhood \u2014 and heck, adult \u2014 idols. We batted around a few theme ideas, some of which seemed worth developing but none of which made it to the finish line. I suggested \u201cThe ____ Film Festival,\u201d with that blank to be filled in with whatever struck Al\u2019s fancy. He replied with a long list of cheese/movie puns, and I had no doubt that we had a winner. My very first attempt at the grid included one of my favorites from his list, QUESOBLANCA. I was under the misapprehension that queso is not just the Spanish word for cheese but also a specific kind of cheese. Whoops, not quite. (This was entirely on me, I should note \u2014 Al, not knowing during his brainstorming that the end result would be restricted to specific cheeses, had several cheese-adjacent puns in his list, including FONDUE THE RIGHT THING and CHEESY RIDER.) Back at the start of all this, Al suggested a puzzle that would salute his peers and predecessors in comedy. That didn\u2019t quite work out, but I was pleased to have worked Tom LEHRER into the grid, and John CLEESE. [Fun fact: Mr. Cleese\u2019s father\u2019s last name was Cheese until he changed it during World War I to avoid being picked on. \u2014 D.A.] Thanks very much to Al for diving so enthusiastically into the world of crosswords! Co-constructing with him was an absolute pleasure.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Cheesy Stuff", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Here are some other takeaways. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his subordinates have called the accusations of Russian complicity a lie that has maligned the Kremlin, fed Western \u201cRussophobia\u201d and contributed to the worst East-West tensions since the Cold War.\n\nEven as the war in Syria exacts a fearful toll on the ground, discussion of the Douma attack, like so much of the international posturing about the war, has been wrapped in a fog of contradiction and confusion. Nations made charges and countercharges, claiming to have damning but secret evidence about each other\u2019s conduct, with Russia in particular spinning an array of theories of varying degrees of plausibility.\n\nSyrian and Russian officials have told the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons team \u201cthat there were still pending security issues to be worked out before any deployment could take place,\u201d Ahmet Uzumcu, the organization\u2019s director general, told its executive council on Monday. The meeting was held in private, but the organization released the prepared statements of Mr. Uzumcu and some other officials.\n\nMr. Uzumcu also said the Russians and Syrians had offered the inspectors an opportunity to interview 22 witnesses to the Douma attack. He did not say whether the organization had accepted the proposal.\n\nThe British delegation to the organization wrote on Twitter: \u201cRussia & Syria have not yet allowed access to Douma. Called Poulet Sans T\u00eate, or chicken without a head, it stars juicy, heritage-breed chicken from a specially built rotisserie, either whole, half or quartered. Rich chicken soup, a salad with chicken, and a chopped \u201chealth\u201d salad with cabbage and cucumbers are also on the menu. Delivery for now is limited to a one-mile radius; pickup is in the restaurant: Whole chicken, $21, Left Bank, 117 Perry Street (Greenwich Street), 212-727-1170, pouletsanstete.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. But his aides also point out that Mr. Trump relishes doing things his own way and bristles against being told he must adhere to certain conventions, even when failing to do so may mean enduring political fallout.\n\nIn interviews in recent days with conservative news outlets, including Fox News and The Washington Examiner, Mr. Pruitt pushed back hard against accusations that his actions were unethical. In an interview with Fox News, he described his living arrangement as an \u201cAirbnb situation,\u201d and said the E.P.A.\u2019s ethics office had signed off on it.\n\nThe ethics office ruled that Mr. Pruitt\u2019s condo rental did not violate the agency\u2019s rules. A later memo released this week said the office did not have all the facts about the rental when it made its initial ruling, including reports that Mr. Pruitt\u2019s daughter, McKenna Pruitt, lived at the apartment when she was a White House intern.\n\nAsked by Fox whether renting a room from a Washington lobbyist violated Mr. Trump\u2019s credo of draining the swamp, Mr. Pruitt replied, \u201cI don\u2019t even think that\u2019s even remotely fair to ask that question.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump, an avid Fox viewer who puts great stock in TV performances, did not appear to think much of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s appearance. Asked Thursday on Air Force One what he thought about it, he paused, smiled wryly and said, \u201cIt\u2019s an interesting interview.\u201d\n\nOn Friday, a coalition of 64 House Democrats called for Mr. Pruitt\u2019s resignation. Chief", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The closing of that loophole follows new government religious regulations that have effectively tightened rules on Christianity and Islam, while promoting Buddhism, Taoism and folk religion as part of President Xi Jinping\u2019s efforts to promote traditional values.\n\nThe moves also come as China is engaged in negotiations with the Vatican to end the split between the underground and government-run Catholic church. This would end a nearly 70-year split between the Chinese government and the global church, which Beijing traces to the Vatican\u2019s historically strong anti-Communist stance.\n\nObservers said the new measures could be a sign of a broader crackdown. At a news conference on Tuesday outlining Beijing\u2019s approach, a government spokesman said the Vatican would never be allowed control over the clergy in China. That came after a recent government reorganization in which a hard-line Communist Party department took over management of religious policy.\n\n\u201cIt sounds like the opposition force within the Chinese authorities who oppose the Vatican-China relations have their voice,\u201d said Yang Fenggang, head of the Center on Religion and Chinese Society at Purdue University. \u201cIt clearly shows that they worry or are concerned about Catholics as well as Protestants.\u201d\n\nTexts for other major religions are available online in China: The Taoist classic the Daodejing is for sale on JD, Taobao, and Amazon, and Buddhist sutras are available commercially.\n\nThe Quran was also sold online, perhaps reflecting Islam\u2019s status as a faith practiced by minorities who sometimes enjoy more privileges than the majority ethnic Chinese population. The Quran is also available commercially in bookstores and, unlike the Bible, has the Chinese equivalent of an ISBN, a numeric book identifier.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBoth Christianity and Islam, however, have come under heavy government pressure.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2016, more than 1,500 crosses were removed from churches in one Chinese province with close ties to Mr. Xi. At the same time, the government has stepped up measures against what it sees as excessive public displays of the Islamic faith, such as men wearing long beards or women wearing headscarves, as well as shops and restaurants that do not sell pork products, tobacco or alcohol.\n\nAt the same time, government policy has encouraged faiths that it sees as more indigenized, for example by subsidizing Taoist music or folk religious pilgrimages. Mr. Xi has also spoken favorably about Buddhism, calling it integral to Chinese people\u2019s cultural and spiritual life.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis overall approach to faith was reflected in a report issued Tuesday that shows the extent of the country\u2019s religious revival. The previous report, in 1997, showed that China had 100 million followers of all of its officially sanctioned religions. The new report doubles the number.\n\nAlthough other surveys show higher overall numbers, the new report is significant because it represents official recognition of China\u2019s religious boom.\n\nThe report shows that most religions in China have been quickly increasing their reach. The number of Buddhist or Taoist believers was not counted because those faiths lack membership rolls, but their growth can be seen in the increasing number of temples \u2014 to 33,500 and 9,000 today from 13,000 and 1,500 in 1997.\n\nChristianity presented a more bifurcated picture. Catholicism grew during the same period to six million worshipers from four million, while Protestantism increased to 38 million adherents, from 10 million. Most surveys and experts, however, believe that these figures represent only about half the total number of believers, because each has a strong underground church that roughly matches the number of believers in government-run churches.\n\nIn China, Islam is defined as being practiced by most members of 10 non-Chinese ethnic groups, especially the Hui and Uighurs. Their populations totaled 20 million in 2018 versus 18 million in 1997, according to the report.\n\nBoth Christianity and Islam were singled out for contributing to problems in China. According to the report, government-appointed Muslim figures condemned violence, especially in the heavily Muslim region of Xinjiang, which is the site of longstanding unrest against control by Beijing.\n\nChristianity was linked to historic troubles, especially China\u2019s decline in the 19th century \u2014 the \u201ccentury of humiliation\u201d that Mr. Xi has vowed to reverse. The report says that Catholicism and Protestantism were \u201ccontrolled and utilized by colonialists and imperialists.\u201d\n\nThe new report stated that Chinese publishers have printed 160 million copies of the Bible, exporting it to more than 100 countries. About half were published in Chinese, according to the report. Assuming none of those were exported, that would roughly mean one Bible for each of the faith\u2019s adherents.", "title": "China Bans Online Bible Sales as It Tightens Religious Controls", "authors": ["Ian Johnson"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 China carried out live-fire military drills in the Taiwan Strait on Wednesday, its state news media reported, an exercise intended to show the growing strength of its navy and deliver a message to self-governed Taiwan, which China claims as its territory.\n\nThe war games were the first in the Taiwan Strait since 2016, Chinese state television reported. They were held in a two-square-mile area that includes two islets off the city of Quanzhou in Fujian Province. That area is about 125 miles west of the city of Hsinchu on Taiwan\u2019s west coast.\n\nChina has been increasing pressure on Taiwan in recent months, while the United States has taken steps to show support for the island, a longtime ally. While the drills Wednesday were most likely planned long in advance, they come at a time when the United States and China are increasingly at odds over a number of issues besides Taiwan, particularly trade.\n\nLiu Jieyi, the director of China\u2019s Taiwan Affairs Office, said this week that the exercises were being planned with Taiwan in mind. \u201cOur military exercises are carried out to protect the sovereignty of our motherland and territorial integrity,\u201d he told reporters Monday on the sidelines of a cross-strait business conference in the central Chinese city of Zhengzhou.", "title": "China Conducts War Games, and Taiwan Is the Target", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "But China, unlike those agencies, isn\u2019t putting short-term conditions on those loans or pushing for austerity measures. Instead, its interest in Latin America is part of a long strategic game, an effort to assert its influence around the world, quench its need for raw materials and control the flow of global trade through Chinese-funded transportation hubs.\n\nWhile the United States has been retreating from its southern neighbors for years, Mr. Trump has added outright hostility to neglect. Five months after taking office, he reversed Barack Obama\u2019s historic overtures to Cuba and stifled United States business ties with the country, a move perceived as potentially devastating for the island\u2019s private sector. Threats to blow up Nafta, cut aid to Honduras and Colombia, and militarize the United States border with Mexico have underscored Mr. Trump\u2019s contempt.\n\nThe message is not lost on Latin America, and it is much louder than anything Mr. Pence may say in Lima, where he is expected to argue that the United States, not China, is Latin America\u2019s preferred trading partner. He may also announce some progress on a renegotiated Nafta.\n\nUnited States influence in the region lingers, of course. The United States remains Latin America\u2019s largest trading partner. Despite the pivot to China, certain countries have resisted its dominion, wary of China\u2019s thirst for raw materials and its lax environmental standards. President Mauricio Macri of Argentina, breaking from his predecessor, has sought warmer ties with the West. And however strong Mr. Trump\u2019s xenophobic rhetoric may be, Latin America is intimately tied to the United States by immigration. Remittances from the states to the region amounted to $74 billion in 2016, a 7.4 percent increase from the previous year.\n\nIt\u2019s not too late for Mr. Pence to quietly strengthen those ties. He could listen to the concerns of pro-business leaders, such as Mr. Macri and President Sebasti\u00e1n Pi\u00f1era of Chile, who may ask for a return to more open trade policies. He can put something concrete behind Mr. Trump\u2019s apparent willingness to re-enter the Trans-Pacific Partnership, an agreement that includes three Latin American countries and serves as a countermeasure to China. He could signal the administration\u2019s openness to ending the ban on American business transactions with the government-led group that oversees the Cuban economy. That policy, criticized even by Republicans, is likely to harm average Cubans more than the inner circle of Cuban leadership.", "title": "Opinion | China Fills Trump\u2019s Empty Seat at Latin America Summit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere are people who want to spend the most, but there are also aspirational buyers,\u201d Mr. Honig said. \u201cYou may want to buy the Rolls-Royce, but you can afford the Mercedes.\u201d And that\u2019s his sweet spot.\n\nHis most popular cabernet goes for around $25 a bottle wholesale, and he sends more than 500 cases of it every year to a plucky Shanghai importing business started by two brothers with dual citizenship. With existing tariffs and value-added taxes mixed in, the total charge tacked on to California wine was already close to 50 percent. After the importer factors in shipping, takes its cut and passes the bottles to a hotel or retail store, which takes its cut, the Napa red ends up selling for the equivalent of around $100.\n\nAn extra 15 percent charge would be brutal. \u201cNo one wants to overpay,\u201d Mr. Honig said. \u201cIf all they\u2019re looking at is two different bottles side by side, and we are competing with Australia and Chile, that\u2019s a big competitive disadvantage.\u201d\n\nChilean and New Zealand wines face no Chinese levies, thanks to free-trade agreements. Australian bottles will enter the country tariff-free next year.\n\nLarry Yang, an importer in Shanghai, said his customers liked California wines, but not enough to ignore an even higher price tag. The wine isn\u2019t cheap as it is, he said, and if it gets pricier, he will look elsewhere.", "title": "China Finds California Wine Pairs Well With a Trade War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBEIJING \u2014 China will not allow any foreign interference in religious affairs in the country, a senior official said on Tuesday, dousing expectations of an imminent deal with the Vatican over control of the Roman Catholic Church here.\n\n\u201cI think there is no religion in human society that is above the state,\u201d the official, Chen Zongrong, said during a briefing on religious affairs in China, underscoring the government\u2019s intention to maintain strict control over all religious organizations and their believers.\n\nMr. Chen\u2019s remarks came amid reports that the Vatican was prepared to make concessions to Beijing in the appointment of the church\u2019s bishops \u2014 including by asking two \u201cunderground\u201d bishops to step aside \u2014 in exchange for retaining some influence over those who are chosen in the future.\n\nThe prospect of a breakthrough after decades of dispute between China\u2019s Communist leaders and a succession of popes has raised hopes but also stirred unusual public criticism of the Vatican. Some Catholic leaders have warned that concessions to Beijing could betray those who have faced pressure and even persecution by worshiping in the so-called underground church here.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPope Francis has sent officials to Beijing to negotiate an agreement, but a Vatican spokesman last week disputed reports that one was imminent.", "title": "China Insists on Control of Religion, Dimming Hope of Imminent Vatican Deal", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Xi\u2019s plan to further open up China\u2019s auto market was seen as a potential olive branch. It calls for phasing out by 2022 the Beijing government\u2019s requirement that any foreign automaker that wants to make cars in China do so through a 50-50 joint venture with a Chinese car company. For makers of electric cars, the requirement would end this year. He also said that China would reduce its 25 percent tariff on imported cars, without offering details.\n\nThe plan could help companies setting up new factories, especially upstarts like the electric vehicle company Tesla Motors, which has big ambitions in the world\u2019s largest market for new cars.\n\nBut established carmakers like Daimler, Volkswagen and Ford said at the auto show on Wednesday that they planned to keep their joint ventures the way they were. The companies have already moved their production and auto parts supply chains to China. And foreign auto companies have found making cars in China for local drivers quite profitable.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe will maintain the structure as we have today,\u201d said Rupert Stadler, the chairman of Audi, the luxury arm of Volkswagen of Germany. Referring to Audi\u2019s two joint ventures in China, he added, \u201cFor us it is very clear: We will, in the long run, have two feet on the ground in China.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, executives said that some of their biggest trade concerns have not been addressed. These include China\u2019s insistence that electric cars have batteries that are made in China, not imported. Local subsidies for electric vehicles, which total as much as $9,000 per car, are available only for cars with batteries that were manufactured in China. The subsidies have helped make China the world\u2019s largest market by far for electric cars, so carmakers have rushed to shift their supplier networks to China.\n\n\u201cWe hope things may change,\u201d said Jochem Heizmann, the president and chief executive of Volkswagen Group China. \u201cAt the end, this limits competition, this limits innovation.\u201d\n\nThey also cited China\u2019s ambitious program to use state support to build up world-beating competitors in electric and self-driving cars, among other emerging technologies, a program called Made in China 2025.\n\nChina also requires that electric cars be manufactured under brand names that are partly owned by Chinese partners.\n\nPeter Fleet, the president of Ford Motor\u2019s Asia and Pacific operations, said the company already planned to sell electric cars in China through a joint venture under an inexpensive local brand that would not carry its famous blue oval logo. Still, he said, he thought the rule might be erased once China eliminates the requirement that electric cars also be produced by joint ventures in China.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s some of the detail we\u2019ve yet to see,\u201d he said.", "title": "China Is Opening Its Car Market. But Not Enough, Say Auto Companies.", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 Staking an assertive negotiating stance, China says it will refuse to discuss President Trump\u2019s two toughest trade demands when American officials arrive in Beijing this week, potentially derailing the high-level talks.\n\nThe Chinese government is publicly calling for flexibility on both sides. But senior Beijing officials do not plan to discuss the two biggest requests that the Trump administration has made over the past several months, according to people involved in Chinese policymaking. Those include a mandatory $100 billion cut in America\u2019s $375 billion annual trade deficit with China and curbs on Beijing\u2019s $300 billion plan to bankroll the country\u2019s industrial upgrade into advanced technologies like artificial intelligence, semiconductors, electric cars and commercial aircraft.\n\nThe reason: Beijing feels its economy has become big enough and resilient enough to stand up to the United States.\n\nA half-dozen senior Chinese officials and two dozen influential advisers laid out the Chinese government\u2019s position in detail during a three-day seminar that ended here late Monday morning. The officials and most of the advisers at the seminar gave an overview of China\u2019s economic policies, including an in-depth review of the country\u2019s trade policy, to make sure China\u2019s stance would be known overseas. All of the officials and most of the advisers at the seminar insisted on anonymity because of diplomatic sensitivities.\n\nIt is not clear what will happen when the two sides sit down this week or whether either will find a reason to waver. Still, the Chinese and American positions are so far apart that China\u2019s leaders are skeptical the two sides can find common ground by the end of this week. They are already raising the possibility that Chinese officials may fly to Washington a month from now for further talks.", "title": "China Is Set to Take a Hard Line on Trump\u2019s Trade Demands", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The company behind the other app, Huoshan, wrote: \u201cThanks to CCTV\u2019s supervision, Huoshan feels a deep sense of responsibility.\u201d The creators of both apps said that they would strengthen their systems for screening videos.\n\nIt was not clear whether or when the apps would be returned to stores. Spokeswomen for Kuaishou\u2019s and Huoshan\u2019s parent companies declined further comment.\n\nOnline video has become a fierce battleground for Chinese technology firms. Kuaishou (pronounced KWAI-show) says its app is used by 100 million people every day. The parent of Huoshan (hwaw-SHAN) is Beijing Bytedance Technology, which says its flagship news app, Jinri Toutiao, has 120 million daily users. The attention of big-name Silicon Valley investors such as Sequoia Capital has helped Bytedance become one of the most highly valued tech start-ups in the world, with a recent valuation of $30 billion.\n\nKuaishou has a huge following outside China\u2019s megacities. The platform, which shares features in common with Instagram, Snapchat and Periscope, has become a way to exchange glimpses \u2014 often bawdy and free spirited \u2014 of ordinary lives in China. It has made celebrities out of people as varied as train conductors, ice fishermen, female welders in shipyards and would-be guitar heroes in ramshackle hamlets.\n\nThe democratizing possibilities of such services have not gone unnoticed by China\u2019s censors.\n\nAs they have taken a harder line on online discourse, media regulators have made targets of celebrity gossip blogs, ranting rappers and more. Updates to several sections on Toutiao, Bytedance\u2019s news app, were halted for 24 hours recently after regulators accused it of spreading \u201cvulgar information.\u201d Sina Weibo, a Twitter-like forum, had to take several features offline for a week after it was scolded for similar transgressions.", "title": "China Isn\u2019t Happy About Its Newest Internet Stars: Teenage Moms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Beijing\u2019s offer on Tuesday to make it easier for foreign aircraft manufacturers to set up wholly owned factories in China might even increase worries in the national security community in Washington about further transfers of the technology needed to retain America\u2019s military edge.\n\nEasing electric car limits may not be enough to bring the Trump administration to the negotiating table, much less reach a deal. The White House has expressed more interest in creating jobs in the United States than in making it easier for American companies to build factories overseas.\n\nIt also isn\u2019t clear whether the measures \u2014 part of a series of moves to relax trade rules for carmakers \u2014 will win over the auto industry.\n\nChina has previously said it will also reduce tariffs on imported cars, but it has not specified when or by how much. Much of the global auto parts industry has already moved to China to avoid those tariffs.\n\nG.M., Volkswagen and others have learned to profit handsomely with their local partners, which have developed fairly few homegrown models attractive enough to win over Chinese customers. And foreign automakers may want local partners anyway to smooth potential political problems and to win access to Chinese subsidies.\n\nThe latest move, announced on Tuesday by China\u2019s top economic planning agency, follows through on a long-promised effort by Beijing to further open its markets to foreign companies.\n\nThe planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, said in a statement that rules requiring a Chinese partner would be lifted this year for the electric-car industry, in 2020 for the production of trucks and other commercial vehicles, and in 2022 for all cars made in China.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChina also said on Tuesday that it would eliminate foreign ownership restrictions this year on its shipbuilding industry. But that industry is in disarray, saddled with overcapacity and heavy debts after more than a decade of large loans from the state-controlled banking industry.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe move on Tuesday by Beijing nevertheless came with a warning. As expected, China also took steps to impose steep duties on imports of sorghum from the United States, an action that could hurt farmers in states where Mr. Trump enjoys political support. The White House has threatened to levy tariffs on $150 billion in Chinese-made goods, and Beijing has threatened to retaliate, dollar for dollar.\n\nThe immediate big winner from the decision on car manufacturing would be Tesla. Going into the Chinese market without a joint venture partner would mean that Tesla could keep better control of its technology and retain all the profits. That also means Tesla would have to foot the entire investment cost.\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t need to negotiate with any party, but the bad news is they have to invest 100 percent of their own money,\u201d said Yale Zhang, the managing director of Automotive Foresight, a Shanghai consulting firm, referring to Tesla.\n\nGeneral Motors quickly issued a statement on Tuesday indicating that it was not eager to buy out its partners, notably the powerful and state-controlled Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation. \u201cG.M.\u2019s growth in China is a result of working with our trusted joint venture partners,\u201d the statement said. \u201cWe will continue to work with our partners to provide high-quality products and services to consumers.\u201d\n\nVolkswagen also said in a statement that it was committed to continuing its joint ventures, but that it would explore whether new opportunities were possible. The German company has been making ambitious plans to build electric cars in China, and only has a loose and deliberately temporary joint venture with Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Group to do so.\n\nCui Dongshu, the secretary general of the China Passenger Car Association, which represents the country\u2019s domestic industry, said that Chinese automakers had developed a lot of expertise recently in electric cars. \u201cFor the short term, they still face huge pressures,\u201d he said on Tuesday. \u201cFor the long term, automakers will adapt to the new environment and make our auto industry more competitive.\u201d\n\nChina has been the only carmaking nation of any significance that requires joint ventures with local companies. Even countries like Brazil and India, which have some of the world\u2019s highest barriers to imports, do not have similar joint venture requirements.\n\nBeijing insisted on the special rule when it joined the World Trade Organization in 2001. Chinese trade negotiators wanted to make sure that the country\u2019s automakers, which were tiny by international standards then, would not be crushed by foreign competition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Chinese Commerce Ministry official suggested at a conference in 2013 that the joint venture rule might be lifted, noting that China wanted to see its automakers start exporting to the West. The Chinese industry responded furiously, contending that it was not yet ready to compete on the world stage and was more worried about retaining its alliances at home with foreign automakers. The idea was dropped.\n\nBut the top executive at a Chinese automaker with no foreign partners argued at the time that the rule should be scrapped. Li Shufu, the founder of Geely, a large carmaker in Zhejiang Province in eastern China, said in an email interview in early 2014 that the rule should be abandoned. \u201cThe cap has hindered fair, open and transparent competition, which undermines the interests of consumers and the overall competitiveness of the Chinese auto industry,\u201d he wrote.\n\nIn any case, Chinese automakers may have less to fear now from international competition in electric cars, a rapidly growing market for which they are already among the world\u2019s dominant producers.", "title": "China Loosens Foreign Auto Rules, in Potential Peace Offering to Trump", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 The Chinese government hit back Monday at President Trump\u2019s tariffs on steel and aluminum by acting on a threat to put tariffs as high as 25 percent on imports of 128 American-made products, including pork and seamless steel pipes.\n\nThe Chinese Ministry of Commerce indicated that the tariffs, which it first publicly suggested almost two weeks ago, were intended to pressure the Trump administration to back down from a simmering trade war. In addition to imposing additional tariffs on steel and aluminum from China and other countries, President Trump has threatened to put protective duties on other Chinese-made products worth $60 billion.\n\n\u201cWe hope that the United States will rescind its measures that violate World Trade Organization rules as quickly as possible,\u201d the ministry said in an online statement about China\u2019s retaliatory tariffs. \u201cChina and the United States are the world\u2019s two biggest economies, and cooperation is the only correct choice. Both sides should use dialogue and consultation to resolve their mutual concerns.\u201d\n\nThe Chinese retaliation was no surprise. But Beijing appeared to go a step beyond its initial threat last month to counter the United States\u2019 tariffs on steel and aluminum.", "title": "China Slaps Tariffs on 128 U.S. Products, Including Wine, Pork and Pipes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "China\u2019s proposed new tariffs cover a significant chunk of what it buys from the United States. The protections on the $50 billion of goods announced on Wednesday, together with those on the $3 billion worth of products that Beijing unveiled earlier this week in retaliation for American tariffs on global steel imports, account for about a third of China\u2019s American imports.\n\nBy contrast, because the United States imports significantly more from China, tariffs on the same amount of products make up roughly one-ninth of its Chinese imports. That gives the United States more room to find other Chinese products to target.\n\nEven as Chinese officials struck a defiant tone on Wednesday, they still said they wanted to avoid escalating the conflict.\n\n\u201cChina\u2019s attitude is clear,\u201d Mr. Zhu, the vice minister of finance, said. \u201cWe don\u2019t want a trade war because a trade war would hurt the interests of both countries.\u201d\n\nChina could still fight back in other ways. Its control over its domestic economy and news media, and its homegrown internet, give it a strong hand in controlling public opinion and minimizing the potential impact on its consumers. In the past, China has mobilized its vast ranks of consumers to turn up their noses at products from Japan, the Philippines and South Korea during political disputes, though getting Chinese consumers to stop buying iPhones and Chevrolets could be trickier.\n\nThe two sides are clashing with the future in mind. President Trump instituted his latest round of tariffs against China while citing Beijing\u2019s government-driven efforts to retool the country\u2019s economy to focus on the technologies of the future. Known as the Made in China 2025 program, the plan specifies efforts to build up cutting-edge industries like robotics, aerospace and electric cars.\n\nMany companies in Europe and the United States say they fear the program will create state-supported competitors, an argument that has won backing in the Trump administration. Washington has declared that the coming negotiations are about getting rid of the arsenal.\n\nStill, Mr. Trump apparently wants to claim a place in history as the American leader who formally ended the Korean War \u2014 even though he tweeted on Sunday morning that he was not rushing into a deal. And Mr. Moon is eager to edge toward the reunification of the two Koreas. So China fears the outcome could be either a North Korea or a unified Korean Peninsula leaning toward the United States.\n\nSince the 1950-53 Korean War, when China fought on the side of the North against the United States and its ally in the South, the alliances have been immovable. The North has provided a convenient buffer for China against having American troops on its border; the South serves as a base in the region for the American military.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn negotiations over the denuclearization of the North, Beijing has to worry whether all that could suddenly be in play, Chinese analysts said.\n\n\u201cIf a grand deal can be struck between Kim and Trump, in the form of denuclearization in exchange for normalization of bilateral relations, then Northeast Asia may see a major realignment,\u201d Mr. Zhang said. \u201cChina does not run Kim\u2019s foreign policy and they know that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe possible new alignment on the Korean Peninsula that most concerns Beijing is a loose unification between North and South Korea with American troops remaining in the South.\n\nAs part of its conciliatory moves before the meetings, the North has dropped its demand for the departure of the 28,000 United States troops stationed in the South as a condition for denuclearization.\n\n\u201cA unified, democratic Korea aligned with the U.S. will be dangerous to the Communist regime in China, though not necessarily the Chinese nation,\u201d said Xia Yafeng, a North Korea expert at Long Island University.\n\nFrom China\u2019s point of view, a favorable outcome from the meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim may simply be a less dangerous version of the status quo, Mr. Xia said.\n\nThere could be a \u201cnice photo\u201d of the two men, with vague promises from the North Korean leader to get rid of his nuclear weapons, and then long negotiations in which China would have a big say, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat is curious is that China has for decades spoken in favor of a peace treaty to end the Korean War. Premier Zhou Enlai of China mentioned ending the Korean War in a 1971 interview with The New York Times columnist James Reston, Mr. Xia said.\n\nChina, however, has a very specific view of what such a treaty would entail: the withdrawal of American troops from South Korea, which would leave both Koreas leaning toward China.\n\n\u201cA peace treaty is good for China in that it will presumably denuclearize North Korea, and more important, it will end the legality of the U.S. military alliance and troop presence on the peninsula,\u201d said Yun Sun, a North Korea expert at the Stimson Center in Washington.\n\nSince North Korea is looking for security guarantees from the United States in return for denuclearization, that guarantee \u201cwill hopefully include the withdrawal of U.S. troops,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut, like his grandfather and father, who ruled North Korea before him, Mr. Kim has shown signs of wanting to reduce China\u2019s influence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen the young leader made a surprise visit to Beijing three weeks ago to meet Mr. Xi for the first time, the two men seemed to repair somewhat the traditionally close relationship between the two countries that had been in the freezer since Mr. Kim came to power in 2011.\n\nIn fact, the visit was probably not so much a gesture of rapprochement as a deft move by Mr. Kim to play China against the United States, just as his grandfather had maneuvered between China and the Soviet Union, Chinese analysts said.\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s purpose was to give the impression to the Americans that he was entering the meetings with China at his back, they said. Mr. Xi accepted an invitation from Mr. Kim to make a return visit to Pyongyang, but there were no signs that would happen before Mr. Trump meets with Mr. Kim, a Chinese government spokesman said.\n\nAnalysts say that since coming to power, the young Mr. Kim has resented his country\u2019s almost total economic dependence on Beijing, which has only increased under the tough United Nations economic sanctions that China voted for last year.\n\nAbout 90 percent of the North\u2019s foreign trade in essential items \u2014 coal, minerals, seafood, textiles \u2014 passes through China, and China is its biggest supplier of fuel.\n\nAt the urging of the Trump administration, China approved the sanctions that have severely cut the North\u2019s access to fuel and hard currency. North Korean ties with China seemed to hit a low, with Mr. Kim refusing to even meet a Chinese envoy in November, and conducting a ballistic missile test instead.\n\nPerhaps wary of alienating the North, and unhappy with Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to impose tariffs on Chinese imports, Beijing was no longer so willing to punish the North, Chinese analysts said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are already signs that trade is picking up along China\u2019s border with North Korea, Chinese traders say, which could mean a relaxing after six months of near total trade embargo.\n\nHours after the North\u2019s announcement on Saturday of its suspension of nuclear tests, one outspoken Chinese state-run newspaper, The Global Times, said the United Nations should \u201cimmediately discuss the cancellation of part of the sanctions against North Korea.\u201d\n\nFurther, the United States, South Korea and Japan should lift their unilateral sanctions against the North, the paper said.", "title": "China, Feeling Left Out, Has Plenty to Worry About in North Korea-U.S. Talks", "authors": ["Jane Perlez"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "1. the social media world is also the real world.\u201d [B/R Football, via Twitter]\n\n\u2014 Max Fisher, The Interpreter columnist\n\nOver the Weekend\n\n\u2022 On Easter Sunday, Pope Francis urged reconciliation in the Middle East and pressed for \u201cthe fruits of dialogue\u201d in Asia.\n\n\u2022 A public relations battle has erupted after violence along Israel\u2019s border with Gaza left 15 Palestinians dead.\n\n\u2022 President Trump blamed Democrats and Mexico for a \u201cdangerous\u201d flow of immigrants, and vowed \u201cNO MORE DACA DEAL.\u201d\n\n\u2022 A Chinese space station the size of a school bus re-entered Earth\u2019s atmosphere, scattering over the southern Pacific Ocean.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, greeted South Korea\u2019s most popular girl band, Red Velvet, at a concert in Pyongyang.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Steven Spielberg successfully returned to his crowd-pleasing roots, as \u201cReady Player One\u201d earned $53.2 million and the top spot at the North American box office.\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 Redemption of a lost prodigy\n\nAs a child, Saul Chandler was a promising violinist, playing at Carnegie Hall before the age of 11. But at 16, he had a nervous breakdown and left the world of classical music.\n\nFifty years later, he has found refuge at a boatyard in the Bronx. His story was one of our most popular this weekend.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In memoriam\n\nWinnie Madikizela-Mandela was among the pantheon of South Africa\u2019s liberators, but her legacy was tarnished by scandals involving corruption, kidnapping, murder and the implosion of her marriage to Nelson Mandela. She was 81.\n\nJohan van Hulst helped save as many as 600 children from a Nazi concentration camp. He died at 107.\n\nSteven Bochco, a celebrated TV writer and producer, created boundary-pushing dramas like \u201cHill Street Blues,\u201d \u201cL.A. Law\u201d and \u201cNYPD Blue.\u201d He was 74.\n\n\u2022 Notre Dame 2, Buzzer 0\n\nTwo days after Arike Ogunbowale hit a last-second shot to beat Connecticut, she did it again on Sunday, giving Notre Dame its second N.C.A.A. women\u2019s basketball title. The Fighting Irish beat Mississippi State, 61-58.\n\nThe men\u2019s championship game, between Michigan and Villanova, is tonight. Here\u2019s how the teams match up.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. Hayes was president, though some accounts suggest that informal egg-rolling parties began under Abraham Lincoln.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first lady, Melania Trump, will host guests who won a public lottery in February. In the signature event, children guide the eggs across the lawn with a wooden spoon. There will be live music and other activities, including a reading nook staffed by White House figures like Kellyanne Conway, the president\u2019s counselor, and Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the press secretary. New this year: bowling.\n\nThe elaborate and labor-intensive Egg Roll is among the most daunting social events a presidential staff has to plan, The Times noted last year.\n\nGuests receive souvenir wooden eggs as they leave, a tradition that began when Nancy Reagan was first lady. This year, the commemorative eggs were made from birch by a company in Maine, and they\u2019re also available online.\n\nThe White House says that more than 21,000 guests attended last year. That was down from about 37,000 in recent years. They expect 30,000 today.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKaren Zraick contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "China, Steven Bochco, Notre Dame: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Shen has denied the accusations.\n\nMany people have held up the case as an example of the abuse and discrimination women in China experience.\n\n\u201cThe hidden victims are inspired by the promise of justice and have become brave enough to speak up,\u201d said Zoe Chen, 24, a student activist in Dalian, a northeastern city.\n\nThe widespread anger over the case has brought unusually swift action. Several universities in recent days condemned Mr. Shen, who currently teaches at Nanjing University in eastern China.\n\nPeking University, where Mr. Shen taught until 2011, vowed over the weekend to do more to prevent sexual harassment, saying it had \u201czero tolerance\u201d for violations of students\u2019 rights. The university also revealed that it had given a warning to Mr. Shen over suspicion of inappropriate behavior after the police investigated the case in 1998.\n\nStudent activists said they were pleased that the case had resonated so widely. But they said universities needed to give students more of a say in determining how sexual harassment and assault are reported on campus, and to better train professors in appropriate conduct with students.\n\n\u201cMerely resolving one or two specific cases is meant to gag the public,\u201d said Zheng Xi, 30, an activist in the eastern city of Hangzhou.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
