The Justice Department will sum up its position that the deal should be blocked by the Federal District Court of the District of Columbia because it believes the merger will harm consumers and competition. AT&T and Time Warner will defend the $85.4 billion agreement and say it would not harm consumers but create a stronger competitor to new entertainment rivals from Silicon Valley. The federal judge hearing the case is expected to take at least a month to reach a decision. Cecilia Kang\n\nTRADE\n\nA tariff deadline looms for six United States allies.\n\nA crucial deadline will pass on Tuesday for six American allies who were temporarily exempted from President Trump\u2019s steel and aluminum tariffs. The European Union, Canada, Mexico, Brazil, Argentina and Australia have been negotiating furiously to extend their reprieve from the tariffs, but it remains unclear whether the Trump administration will grant the countries further exemptions from tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum. If the tariffs do go into effect, the European Union and other allies will most likely respond with tariffs of their own and challenges at the World Trade Organization. Ana Swanson\n\nTECHNOLOGY\n\nApple will report its earnings.\n\nApple is scheduled to report its quarterly earnings on Tuesday. While all indications suggest its huge business continues to hum along, investors will be watching for the answers to two major questions. How much, if any, growth is left in iPhone sales? And now that Apple has repatriated most of the $252 billion it held abroad to comply with the new tax law, how much will it return to shareholders? Some analysts predict the company could send as much as $180 billion to investors through stock buybacks and dividend increases over the next two and a half years, on top of the $300 billion it has already authorized. Jack Nicas\n\nECONOMY\n\nEstimate of eurozone economic growth expected.\n\nThe uncertain state of the eurozone economy may become clearer on Wednesday when the European Union statistics office releases an estimate of its economic growth in the first quarter. Recent indicators suggest that the economy, which had been exceptionally strong, is slowing. But most analysts expect growth from January through March to have remained solid, just not quite as vibrant as before. Jack Ewing\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Fed is expected to leave interest rates unchanged.\n\nThe Federal Reserve will conclude a two-day meeting on Wednesday, probably by leaving interest rates unchanged. But analysts will watch the official statement after the meeting for signs of rising concern about inflation, and hints that the Fed might accelerate its pace of rate increases later this year. Jim Tankersley", "title": "Closing Arguments in AT&T Trial, and Jobs Numbers Will Be Released", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I often get interrupted by little pop-up windows showing comments from friends when I\u2019m using Facebook on my computer. I looked in the notification settings for a place to turn off the pop-ups, but didn\u2019t see anything. Am I stuck with these annoyances?\n\nA. Unlike the simple notification alerts that appear quickly and disappear, those windows that rise up from the lower part of the window when you are browsing Facebook are intended to keep you in the loop when your friends comment and start a conversation on a post you have made. (Facebook does not pop up windows for every conversation connected to your posts, but concentrates on the conversations it has determined you might care about the most.) The pop-up windows are more immediate than email notifications about comments on your posts. If you dislike the alerts, you can turn them off \u2014 but not in the main Facebook settings.", "title": "Closing Facebook Comment Windows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cHow to Level the College Playing Field,\u201d by Harold O. Levy with Peg Tyre (Sunday Review, April 8), about increasing access for students with limited financial resources, is an essential discussion. But the focus should not be on the colleges that traditionally dominate national rankings.\n\nThe primary drivers of increased social mobility are the many lesser known colleges that dot our country\u2019s landscape, institutions that were founded to serve as agents of social transformation. The real question to address is how, in a decade of reduced governmental support across many states (New York being an exception), can these colleges continue to prosper and assist students?\n\nPerhaps the greatest gap between traditional have and have-nots is the inequity of alumni giving, and the article rightly encourages donors to focus on whom a college serves \u2014 on helping the many students who need every possible dollar to enable them to complete their education and change their future forever.\n\nDREW BOGNER\n\nROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y.\n\nThe writer is president of Molloy College.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe essay brilliantly describes the challenge and some innovative approaches to American education and the future of the American dream. Clearly, the challenge will have to be addressed across the educational spectrum.", "title": "Opinion | Closing That College Affluence Gap", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe have done our best to look for ways to soften the impact of this looming six-month closure, especially for our workers who look upon us for support in this time of confusion and uncertainty,\u201d said Ms. Graf, who runs the Boracay Beach Resort.\n\nUnder the guidelines coming into force Thursday, the government is barring local and foreign tourists on the island, while workers on Boracay must have government identification cards.\n\nAll island residents must also be able to show their credentials, and resort or hotel owners must show \u201cproof of ownership.\u201d Foreigners who are long-term residents of Boracay need to have been properly vetted by immigration officials.\n\nFernando Hicap, leader of the fishermen\u2019s rights group Pamalakaya, criticized what he called a \u201cmilitarization\u201d of Boracay.\n\nThe 630-man Joint Task Force Boracay \u2014 which includes the police, the military and the coast guard \u2014 has been patrolling shores since the start of the week. Photos of the group conducting the patrols and anti-riot drills have made the rounds on social media, alarming some island residents.\n\n\u201cPresident Duterte never disclosed to the public that his supposed rehabilitation plan includes deployment of police forces in a full battle gear,\u201d said Mr. Hicap, a former congressman. \u201cWe can\u2019t see the point of militarizing the tourist island but to sow intimidation and curtail civil rights of the residents who stand affected by the six-month closure.\u201d\n\nHis group \u2014 along with a civic organization, the Kalikasan People\u2019s Network for the Environment \u2014 is alarmed by reports that during the closing the state casino company is to begin construction of a casino by the Macau-based Galaxy Entertainment Group on the island.", "title": "Closing of Philippine Tourist Hub Stirs Fears of Military Takeover", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Researchers already knew that when corals and anemones bleach, clown fish and other animals living among them produce hormones that may help them cope with a changing environment. But scientists hadn\u2019t found a way to show that the fish\u2019s whole body could be stressed out.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo do this, the researchers collected 16 fish from a healthy coral reef near French Polynesia in the Pacific Ocean and took them back to the lab. They put half in tanks with healthy anemones, and half in tanks with anemones that had been bleached with hot water. The anemones were still living and had not yet shrunk, but their algal companions were gone.\n\nAfter two weeks, the researchers moved the clown fish into tanks pumping out oxygen every few minutes and measured how much oxygen the fish consumed during their most sedentary times.\n\nThis gave them an idea of the fish\u2019s basal metabolic rate \u2014 that is, how much energy the animals needed to sit around and do nothing. (That\u2019s akin to a human \u201clying motionless on the couch doing nothing but still being awake,\u201d Dr. Norin said.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe researchers found that the clown fish living with the bleached anemones had a higher basal metabolic rate than the fish living around healthy anemones. That is, the fish needed more energy to just stay alive around bleached anemones.\n\nYou can think about basal metabolic rate as a kind of cost-of-living measure, like the minimum salary you need to get by in New York City. And just as you need to budget for emergencies, social or entertainment expenses, the fish need additional energy for behaviors like risk-taking and foraging that may lead to reproducing and surviving longer.\n\nResearchers have found that in some places with warming water, fish with increased basal metabolic rates can\u2019t get enough energy to adapt and also to conduct important survival tasks, like swimming. And Dr. Norin warns that as oceans continue to warm, clown fish could face a double whammy from bleached anemones and rising temperatures that increase the energy needed to survive.\n\nMore research is needed to determine whether the metabolic stress is just temporary. With more time, the anemones might recover or the clown fish could acclimate to conditions.\n\nThe tale of the stressed out clown fish is a reminder of the myriad ways in which humans are damaging the ocean, Dr. Norin said: \u201cAt some point, we will open our eyes and see that we really need to do something.\u201d", "title": "Clown Fish Need More Energy to Live in a Bleached Home", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Headliner\n\nEXISTING CONDITIONS Here\u2019s a bar like no other in town. Start with the name, which alludes to the notion of taking a former bar space, in this case Whiskey Social, and giving it new life. \u201cWe\u2019ve kept as much of the stuff that was here as possible,\u201d said Dave Arnold, the avant-garde cocktail master who is in partnership with Don Lee, another drinks innovator, and Greg Boehm, who founded Cocktail Kingdom, which makes and sells barware and books. They will serve some beers and wines, and can stir a proper martini, but that\u2019s beside the point. Their drinks are listed as nonalcoholic (sophisticated, at times sparkling, and priced at $15, the same as the alcoholic selections), carbonated, shaken, stirred straight up or on a big rock. Those in a hurry can buy bottled cocktails from vending machines with a $15 token. The ingredients they use are often extracted in a centrifuge or chilled with liquid nitrogen. But aside from such techniques, the cocktails are simple and focused, not assembled with a pantryload of components like many concoctions these days. \u201cThese drinks are all flavor-driven,\u201d Mr. Arnold said. Mr. Lee added that they intended to show off ingredients in drinks like the delicious nonalcoholic Doyenne with clarified Comice pear juice, the fresh-tasting OG Celery with gin and a blast of celery, and the satisfying Professor Plum, which is like an old-fashioned with prune-infused bourbon. Bar food, from a simple plate of fries to a steak, are the work of the executive chef Josh Eden, formerly at August. (Scheduled to open by May 18): 35 West Eighth Street, 212-203-8935.\n\nOpening\n\nBOQUERIA This latest addition to Yann de Rochefort\u2019s collection of Spanish restaurants, the fifth in New York (there\u2019s also a Washington, D.C., branch), is the largest. Distinguished by a handsome curved wood ceiling that soars near the entrance, it seats nearly 100 at a generous island bar surrounded by booths with more tables beyond, heading to the big open kitchen. There\u2019s also a chef\u2019s table, an intimate private dining room with shelves of Spanish grocery products, and outdoor seating for 20. The menu, by the executive chef Marc Vidal, includes the tapas for which the restaurants are known, along with sandwiches, salads, paella and, for the first time, chicken and suckling pig from a rotisserie: 260 West 40th Street, 646-233-4078, boquerianyc.com.\n\nBAR SALUMI What began as A&E Supply Co. last year is now this Mediterranean restaurant with an Italian accent that specializes in cured meats. The partners, Ennio Di Nino and Adam Harvey, have started making their own charcuterie, but are still buying most of it. (The original restaurant\u2019s retail butcher counter has been discontinued in favor of in-house curing.) The restaurant menu includes clams casino, lobster carbonara and porchetta: 548 Fourth Avenue (15th Street), Gowanus, Brooklyn, 718-635-3388, bar-salumi.com.\n\nUNA PIZZA NAPOLETANA This is one peripatetic pizza. Anthony Mangieri began his professional pizza career in Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., over 20 years ago. He moved his operation to the East Village in 2004, to much acclaim; a 2009 article in The New York Times called it \u201cperhaps the most meticulous pizzeria in New York.\u201d He let his dough rise overnight and sold his pizzas until it ran out. He then pulled up stakes in 2009 and, lured by the weather, headed West, opening a site in San Francisco in 2010. Now he\u2019s back in New York, with the partners Jeremiah Stone and Fabian von Hauske Valtierra, who own Contra and Wildair down the street. There are seven pizzas; the small plates on the menu are devised by his partners. (Monday): 175 Orchard Street (Stanton Street), 646-692-3475, unapizza.com.", "title": "Cocktails, Alcoholic and Nonalcoholic Alike, in Greenwich Village", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\nHannity and Cohen\n\nThe legal team for Michael Cohen, President Trump\u2019s personal lawyer, said on Monday that the Fox News host Sean Hannity was a former client of his \u2014 setting off a denial from Hannity and a gleeful reaction from Stephen Colbert. The \u201cLate Show\u201d host slumped blissfully into a chair after telling his audience the news, cradling a glass of celebratory red wine in his hand.\n\nThen he dug into Fox News.\n\n\u201cHow did Fox News let him on the air with this massive conflict of interest? Did he not tell them? Or did he tell them and they just ignored it? I\u2019m going to go with the first one, because I know Sean Hannity, and delivering factual information is not his strong suit.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nColbert played a clip in which Hannity scolds other members of the media for \u201cspinning out of control\u201d with their coverage of Cohen\u2019s work for Trump.\n\n\u201cI gotta agree with Sean on this one: The media is spinning out of control. Did you hear about this guy on Fox News who\u2019s defending Cohen without revealing that it\u2019s his lawyer, too? That\u2019s crazy!\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\n\u2018An Impartial Lawman\u2019?\n\nIn promoting his new book, James Comey, the former F.B.I. director, has begun to state publicly that he believes Trump is not suited to be president. In an interview with ABC News over the weekend, he also went into detail with a critique of Trump\u2019s tan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrevor Noah wondered aloud whether Comey could be undermining his own credibility.\n\n\u201cYou see, now that\u2019s funny, but that doesn\u2019t sound like an impartial lawman. That sounds like a guy who got fired from White Castle talking trash about his old boss \u2014 that\u2019s what it sounds like. It\u2019s like, \u2018Man, that dude smelled like onions before he got to work!\u2019\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH\n\nColbert said he was skeptical when Comey pointed out the similarities between Trump\u2019s leadership style and that of a typical mob boss.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sorry, Trump just doesn\u2019t seem tough enough to be a mob boss. \u2018Luca Brasi sleeps with the fishes, but I sleep with the Filet-O-Fishes.\u2019\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nThe Punchiest Punchlines (Markle Sparkle Edition)\n\n\u201cMeghan Markle\u2019s nephew is creating a strain of marijuana called the Markle Sparkle. Yeah, the marijuana is so strong it renders you as useless as a member of the royal family.\u201d \u2014 CONAN O\u2019BRIEN \u201cTrump\u2019s approval ratings are the lowest in the history of polls, which go all the way back to Harry Truman, but his legal bills, on the other hand, are skyrocketing. More than one out of every $5 donated by supporters to his re-election campaign this year went to attorney\u2019s fees. Twenty percent of the money, spent on lawyers! How does it relate to and comment on society? Can you connect to it personally? If so, how? What is your opinion of its message?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out what it means.", "title": "College", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Many high school seniors have completed the often harrowing process of applying to college and have heard where they were accepted \u2014 or not. What worked and what didn\u2019t? How could the process be made less stressful, fairer and easier?\n\nWe invite students and parents to tell us in no more than 200 words.\n\nEmail: letters@nytimes.com\n\nThe deadline is Thursday, April 19, at 10 a.m., Eastern time.\n\nPlease include your name, city/state and contact information, and put \u201ccollege\u201d in the subject line.", "title": "Opinion | College Admissions Angst: Tell Us About Your Experience", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Finally, even if your kid is going to her or his dream school, there will be bumps. High school to college is a huge transition. Getting into the best or right school does not change the reality of finding yourself living with a group of strangers with less structure than ever before in your life.\n\nAPRIL STEMPIEN-OTERO\n\nSEATTLE\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nOf all the stressful aspects of the college application process, the one causing the most anxiety for me as a parent was exposure to college consultants. I participated in free introductory seminars that left me with a niggling fear that I would be doing my son a disservice if I didn\u2019t hire an expert to review his essay, devise a strategy and manage all aspects of his application.\n\nLuckily, my son had the good sense not to succumb to the hype. He was determined to do it himself, with support from Khan Academy test prep, his school counselor, and friends and family who expressed faith in his ability. Now that he has been accepted to all of his top-choice schools, he can enjoy a sense of accomplishment and attend his dream school, an accomplishment that is all his own.\n\nBETH BRODSKY, BRONX\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAlas, I am unable to say what works and what does not in the college admissions process because my fate is to wait. I applied to one school early decision (Stanford). I got deferred, so I had to wait for the final (negative) decision. Additionally, I was wait-listed from my next top three schools (U.C. Berkeley, Dartmouth, Cornell). The wait list (or a deferment) is rather like purgatory. You\u2019re qualified enough to not be rejected, but not good enough to be accepted. So you wait, even though you\u2019ve already been waiting for three-plus months.\n\nAnd while you do so, you wonder what you could have done better to be admitted. Would higher grades or scores have helped? Should I have pushed my athletics and extracurriculars more? Was my essay too flat? I will never know. Nor can we do anything now, except send our spring grades and write an update letter to the admissions committee. So we wait.\n\nCONNIE BERDAN\n\nGLASTONBURY, CONN.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIt is ugly out there. Despite our best efforts to start the message of \u201cwhere you go is not who you\u2019ll be\u201d very early (ninth grade), a motivated, high-achieving student will body-block you if you suggest restraint.\n\nMy daughter heard about a Postal Service subscription that allows you to view a photo online of each piece of mail that is going to be delivered to your house on that day. I am not making this up. She knew exactly how much the piece of mail from her top-choice school would weigh if a rejection and how much if an acceptance (thanks, College Confidential).", "title": "Opinion | College Admissions: Let\u2019s Cut the Stress!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Growing College Graduation Gap\u201d (column, March 25):\n\nI was saddened, but not surprised, by David Leonhardt\u2019s observation that college graduation rates for students from modest backgrounds are abysmal compared with rates for the wealthy.\n\nThose of us who teach in urban schools and community colleges know that we teach some of the most inspiring and deserving of students: Their diversity, honesty and richness of experience make them so. But we know, too, that obstacles get in the way. They have jobs to pay tuition bills; some have children or even parents they help support; some are unprepared for the discipline required of college courses.\n\nMr. Leonhardt is right; we need to shift the focus from getting into college to efforts ensuring that all students, once they have paid that first tuition bill, have a fair shot at completing the course. But this will cost schools money, and too many colleges today are profit-driven, not student-centered.\n\nCATHY BERNARD, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is an associate professor of English at the New York Institute of Technology.", "title": "Opinion | College for the Disadvantaged", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "California\u2019s public university teams have felt compelled to devise legal workarounds. The men\u2019s basketball committee, which selected the 36 teams that received at-large bids to the N.C.A.A. tournament and seeded all 68 in the field, disregarded state travel bans, said its chairman, Bruce Rasmussen, the Creighton athletic director.\n\n\u201cWe, unfortunately, do not control where we play in the tournament, and we will not deny our student-athletes the opportunity for postseason play,\u201d Shana Wilson, a senior associate athletic director for U.C.L.A., wrote in an email. She confirmed that last year, U.C.L.A. used revenue generated by the athletic department \u2014 sources like ticket sales, donations and sponsorships, but not direct state funding \u2014 to pay for the Bruins\u2019 trip to Memphis.\n\nSan Diego State, which is in the California State University system, used revenue from donations to finance the basketball team\u2019s trip to Kansas in March, as well as its football team\u2019s trip to Fort Worth to play Army in the Armed Forces Bowl last December, said Chuck Lang, a senior associate athletic director.\n\n\u201cWe avoid going to them as much as possible,\u201d said Lang, referring to the eight banned states.\n\nSan Diego State does not schedule nonconference road competitions against teams in those states, though Lang said other Aztecs squads had traveled to them \u201cbecause we had to\u201d for other N.C.A.A. championship events.\n\nSome opponents of the laws that the travel bans were meant to challenge remain uneasy about such accommodations, saying they circumvent the bans\u2019 spirit, if not their letter.\n\n\u201cWe would prefer that in states that have active travel bans, that organizations and agencies in those states honor those bans,\u201d said Thomas Witt, the executive director of Equality Kansas, an L.G.B.T. advocacy group.\n\nKansas showed up on California\u2019s list after its state government passed a law in 2016 that permitted groups on Kansas campuses to turn away prospective members who did not share their religious beliefs. Supporters of that law say it protects religious freedom; detractors like Witt say it inappropriately allows state-financed groups to discriminate.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is debatable whether California\u2019s travel ban applies to sports teams\u2019 travel to N.C.A.A. championship events like the men\u2019s basketball tournament. The law lists several exceptions under which state funds can be used to travel to those states, including for litigation or to comply with a federal request to appear before a committee. One of the exceptions is \u201cto meet contractual obligations incurred before January 1, 2017.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSan Diego State had been a member of both the N.C.A.A. and the Mountain West Conference (which has a contract with the Armed Forces Bowl) before that date, Lang said, so the university concluded that its teams\u2019 participation fell under that exception. Yet it used non-taxpayer funds to pay for the trip anyway, Lang said, \u201cout of an abundance of caution.\u201d\n\nThe California attorney general\u2019s office has been considering whether the ban applies to \u201cUniversity of California and California State University athletic team staffs\u201d for nearly a year. But the question remains unanswered. The attorney general\u2019s office declined to comment for this article.\n\nIn the past, the N.C.A.A. has taken a stand in reaction to some state laws. It opposed the 2014 \u201creligious freedom\u201d law in Indiana, where the association is headquartered. And before last year\u2019s tournament, it responded to North Carolina\u2019s passage of a notorious bill that put restrictions on bathroom access for transgender citizens by pulling some events from the state and threatening not to schedule more there. In both cases, the N.C.A.A.\u2019s public opposition played a significant role in the laws\u2019 subsequent modification or repeal, with the N.C.A.A. going on to keep events in those states and schedule others.\n\nThe N.C.A.A. sends a questionnaire to prospective host sites asking how they plan to accommodate all participants or spectators, including those who are gay or transgender. Although the association moved a basketball subregional out of North Carolina last year, it seems to recognize the extreme difficulty in making plans, often years in advance, around the shifting political priorities of all 50 states where it has members.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t control what states\u2019 laws are, nor should we,\u201d Mark Emmert, the N.C.A.A. president, said last year.\n\n\u201cIf any state says they\u2019re not going to travel to any other place for some other reason,\u201d he added, \u201cWe can\u2019t then say, \u2018Well, we\u2019ve decided we\u2019re not going to go there because another state has decided it.\u2019\u201d\n\nSeveral future N.C.A.A. championship sites could test this question. The Division I men\u2019s and women\u2019s basketball tournaments alone have scheduled several regionals and subregionals in states on California\u2019s list. Several Division II baseball tournaments, including this year\u2019s, are planned for North Carolina.\n\nAs with many boycotts, the travel bans stir complex feelings even among their supporters. Witt, who supports travel bans, acknowledged that he is based in a state that takes college basketball extremely seriously, and watched its flagship university make the Final Four this year.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of fans in the L.G.B.T. Kansas community who are big-time basketball, and K.U. basketball, fans,\u201d Witt said.", "title": "Colleges Dance Around Travel Bans, With the Help of Their Lawyers", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Diane Cheng, associate research director at the nonprofit group The Institute for College Access and Success, or TICAS, said her organization recently analyzed 200 financial aid letters from public and private four-year colleges. It found that many fell short of communicating critical information.\n\n\u201cMost were not clear, comprehensive or consumer friendly,\u201d said Ms. Cheng, noting that a \u201cdisproportionate share\u201d didn\u2019t show the full cost of attending the school.\n\nFewer than a fourth of the schools used the federal government\u2019s suggested financial aid \u201cshopping sheet\u201d format, which clearly outlines all the costs of attending school before subtracting financial aid, to show a net cost of attending.\n\nSome letters blurred the lines between aid like grants and scholarships, which don\u2019t have to be repaid, and loans, TICAS found.\n\nThat means the onus is on students and families to carefully evaluate offers, before making a final decision about a school.\n\nCalculate Net Cost\n\nMake sure you calculate the net cost of attending each school you are considering, so you can compare apples to apples, Ms. Cheng said. The net cost is the full cost of attendance \u2014 not just tuition, but also room and board, meals, books and supplies, lab fees and other expenses \u2014 minus grants and scholarships, which don\u2019t need to be repaid. The bottom line is the amount you\u2019ll have to pay, whether from savings, or by working or borrowing the money.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s important to determine, as closely as possible, the school\u2019s true cost, said Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert. \u201cToo often,\u201d he said, \u201cfamilies try to wing it.\u201d\n\nMany colleges include net-price calculators on their websites, or you can start online at the College Board\u2019s website.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKnow the Terms of Your Offer\n\nStudents should also ask whether the grants and scholarships will continue at the same level for four years, since some schools \u201cfront load\u201d aid, to entice students to accept. About half of colleges do this, awarding more grants to freshmen than upperclassmen, said Jackie Bright, executive director of the National Scholarship Providers Association. Also, keep in mind that even if the aid level stays the same, it won\u2019t go as far if the cost of attending the school increases.\n\nPell Grant Increase\n\nThis year some of the neediest students can look forward to a little bit of extra financial aid from the federal government.\n\nThe maximum amount for Pell grants \u2014 need-based grants that help low-income students cover the cost of college \u2014 was just increased for the 2018-19 academic year. The maximum award for the coming school year rose by $175, to $6,095.\n\nThe unexpected increase was included in the fiscal 2018 budget finalized in March.\n\nBefore the passage of the spending bill, the Department of Education had instructed colleges to use the prior maximum, $5,920, in initial financial aid packages sent out this year. So, students who are eligible for Pell grants should be on the lookout for revised financial aid letters reflecting an increase, said Megan Coval, vice president of policy and federal relations with the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators.\n\nWhile the increase of about 3 percent isn\u2019t huge, every bit helps for students who are scrimping for college, Ms. Coval said.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a nice bump,\u201d she said. \u201cWe were very pleased.\u201d\n\nNot all students will get the maximum grant, but all who are eligible for Pell grants should see some increase, Ms. Cheng said.\n\nLast-Minute Aid\n\nIf financial aid is a bit short for your preferred school, students could try to make up the difference by finding more scholarships. Most deadlines had passed by March, but some local scholarships may still be available. One place to search is the scholarship providers association website.\n\nAvoid services that charge a fee to search for scholarships, Ms. Bright said; they\u2019re likely to be scams.", "title": "College\u2019s First Test: How to Pay for It", "authors": ["Ann Carrns"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Because of what Colombia\u2019s United Nations verification mission calls \u201cgrowing frustration with the lack of opportunities,\u201d most ex-guerrillas have left the 26 demobilization zones. Eight thousand were there last May, but by November, there were perhaps 3,600. There are fewer today, and it\u2019s nobody\u2019s job to know where the rest are.\n\nBetween 1,000 and 1,500 (including some new recruits) have returned to the jungle as \u201cdissident\u201d groups. They are once again enriching themselves from cocaine, illegal mining and extortion, intimidating the population and attacking the security forces.\n\nFARC shares some of the blame. It wanted \u201ccollective reintegration\u201d to keep its cadres together in rural areas. But its leaders weren\u2019t clear about how they wanted this collective model to work, and the government didn\u2019t want it at all. Sixty percent of ex-FARC guerrillas say they want to be farmers. Now the FARC is asking for 67 plots of land around the country, covering just 5,000 hectares (12,400 acres).\n\nThe cost of reintegration shouldn\u2019t be a roadblock. Whether for land, training or busywork, funding an ex-combatant at four times Colombia\u2019s gross domestic product per capita would cost $25,000 per year. Multiplied by 13,000 guerrillas, that would be $325 million per year. That\u2019s less than 0.4 percent of Colombia\u2019s national government budget for 2018.\n\nForeign donors can help. But as it\u2019s interpreting current law, the United States government can\u2019t buy even a cup of coffee for a former FARC member, because the Common Alternative Revolutionary Force, the political party that sprang from FARC, is on the State Department\u2019s list of foreign terrorist organizations. Any aid \u2014 even for reintegration \u2014 is interpreted as \u201cmaterial support for terrorists\u201d under United States law.\n\nTaking a group off the terrorist list is a slow process, and FARC will remain on it for a while. The question is whether the \u201cmaterial support\u201d provision should continue to apply to all individual ex-combatants. If someone with skills for making war wants to leave them behind and is resisting the lure of crime, it\u2019s in the United States\u2019 interest to help him or her to do that. The United States should be able to help ex-guerrillas who are not top leaders, not wanted by American justice, not awaiting trial for war crimes and reasonably believed to have abandoned violence. At least 7,000 people fit these criteria and need attention. But the number shrinks every day, as ex-guerrillas abandon the process and melt into the countryside.\n\nPeace processes are fragile, but they can and do work. Negotiated agreements save years of bloodshed and are an honorable endeavor. Past experience offers rich lessons for reintegrating ex-combatants. Colombia and its friends must heed these lessons and prove the skeptics wrong.", "title": "Opinion | Colombia\u2019s Imperiled Transition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The Post, which covers a metropolitan area of roughly three million residents in a state of nearly six million, has a weekday circulation of about 170,000 and about 8.6 million unique monthly visitors to its website.\n\nIn a statement on Thursday, Mr. Sanders and his business partner, John Goede, said they were \u201ccommitted to helping facilitate the purchase of The Denver Post to ensure open-minded, journalist-driven print and digital news for decades to come.\u201d\n\nRepresentatives for Alden Global Capital and a subsidiary that runs The Post, Digital First Media, did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nThe effort in Colorado comes amid a broader reckoning over the ownership of local newspapers, whose financial problems \u2014 many have struggled to offset steep declines in print advertising and circulation revenue \u2014 have prompted questions about whether they might be better off operating under local control than as part of large media companies.\n\nA recent newsroom rebellion at The Los Angeles Times, for instance, helped induce its owner, Tronc, which is based in Chicago, to sell the paper to Patrick Soon-Shiong, a local doctor and billionaire.\n\nThe other papers Alden Global Capital runs through Digital First Media include The Boston Herald; The Pioneer Press of St. Paul; The Mercury News of San Jose, Calif.; The East Bay Times; and The Orange County Register.\n\nThe Post garnered widespread attention and support with its public denunciation of Alden executives as \u201cvulture capitalists,\u201d and an editorial saying that \u201cif Alden isn\u2019t willing to do good journalism here, it should sell The Post to owners who will.\u201d But journalists at other newspapers under the hedge fund\u2019s control \u2014 frustrated by what they view as similarly relentless cost cuts \u2014 have also been hoping to be sold to local buyers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe editor of The Mercury News and The East Bay Times, Neil Chase, has for months been holding discussions with people and groups in the community who might be interested in purchasing the newspapers. On Tuesday, he wrote a column that called for support of local journalism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDemocracy cannot succeed without a healthy, free press,\u201d Mr. Chase wrote. \u201cSo the owners of the press must be committed to its vital role, even if it reduces their profit.\u201d\n\nThe Bay Area News Group, which, in addition to The Mercury News and The East Bay Times, includes The Marin Independent Journal, now has 160 newsroom employees, down from 380 in 2011. Over that time, the group\u2019s operating profit has increased, Mr. Chase said.\n\nIn the Philadelphia suburbs, the union that represents journalists at four Digital First Media papers \u2014 The Mercury of Pottstown; The Times Herald of Norristown; The Trentonian in Trenton, N.J.; and The Daily Times of Delaware County, Pa. \u2014 has been seeking new owners. The union, the NewsGuild of Greater Philadelphia, has also asked Alden Global Capital whether it would consider offers, Bill Ross, the union\u2019s executive director, said in an interview.\n\n\u201cI think they would entertain an offer if we were to put one together,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Ross said the union had contacted local philanthropists, foundations and other hedge funds about the possibility of submitting bids.\n\nSince Digital First Media took over the papers, the union\u2019s membership, which includes reporters, photographers and other employees, has declined by about 70 percent, Mr. Ross said. The Daily Times, which once had 125 union members, now has just 25. The Trentonian has 20.\n\nOf those who remain, many work under demoralizing conditions, he added. The Trentonian\u2019s building, Mr. Ross said, had no hot water for so long that the union filed a complaint with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Rats scamper about. Employees at the Norristown paper no longer have a building of their own and must work either from Pottstown\u2019s offices or out of their homes.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019ve put no money into any of the properties,\u201d Mr. Ross said. \u201cIt\u2019s a bizarre situation of neglect.\u201d\n\nAll four of the papers the union represents are profitable, he said.\n\nDespite Mr. Ross\u2019s belief that Alden Global Capital would consider an offer, it is not clear how willing the company is to sell any of its papers.\n\nThe hedge fund generally buys publications at a low price \u2014 it recently bought The Boston Herald for roughly $12 million \u2014 with the goal of extracting as much profit as it can, for as long as it can. A sale might provide a quick infusion of cash, but it would deprive Alden Global Capital of future returns.", "title": "Colorado Group Pushes to Buy Embattled Denver Post From New York Hedge Fund", "authors": ["Sydney Ember"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe respect the rights of students to express their views and the rights of all students and faculty to continue their teaching, learning and progress toward degrees,\u201d said Caroline Adelman, a Columbia spokeswoman. But, she added, \u201cwe do not understand why the G.W.C.-U.A.W. prefers the pressure tactics and disruption of a strike to a definitive, nonpartisan resolution of that legal question in the federal courts.\u201d\n\nThe question of whether graduate students at private universities can unionize has seesawed for years, depending, in part, on the political leanings of the members of the National Labor Relations Board. During the Clinton administration, the N.L.R.B. established the right to unionize in a case that involved graduate students from New York University. A few years later, though, that decision was reversed during George W. Bush\u2019s presidency with a case out of Brown University. Then, during the Obama years, in 2016, the N.L.R.B. ruled again, this time in favor of the Columbia graduate students.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Columbia has declined to bargain, and with a Trump administration that is less friendly to unions now in charge, the case is expected to eventually find its way before a federal appeals court.\n\nIf the court rules in Columbia\u2019s favor, the decision could have repercussions for graduate students at other private universities. The U.A.W. represents graduate students at the New School and N.Y.U., both private schools that voluntarily recognized their unions, as well as at Boston College and several public universities. Other unions, like the American Federation of Teachers, are also active in the movement to organize graduate students.\n\nStates can choose whether to allow public university graduate students to unionize.\n\nAt Columbia, both sides had been bracing for a strike ever since graduate students last week voted overwhelmingly to set a deadline of April 24 if the university did not come to the bargaining table. Dueling websites were launched by both the U.A.W. and the university.\n\nThe university\u2019s site promised, \u201cWe are taking all necessary steps to minimize the disruption of instruction, to ensure your course objectives are met, and to ensure timely grading.\u201d It also had an F.A.Q. section, with questions like, \u201cShould I be doing the assignments I have due next week?\u201d (Yes.)\n\nOn Tuesday, at least, the vast majority of undergraduates who were interviewed said that they were sympathetic to the graduate students, and that their academic lives had not yet been disrupted much, other than a few classes and discussion groups being canceled.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m supportive, and I think they\u2019re bringing up some really legitimate issues,\u201d said Emma Kolchin-Miller, 22, a junior from Amherst, Mass., majoring in history. \u201cAnd the grad students have been as helpful as possible to prepare us for the strike.\u201d", "title": "Columbia Graduate Students Walk Out Over Union Fight", "authors": ["David W. Chen"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "It had been almost a decade since the shooting, and the memorial was a circular expanse cut into a hillside next to the school. An outer wall formed the \u201cRing of Healing,\u201d and an inner wall formed the \u201cRing of Remembrance.\u201d Parents, classmates and teachers had submitted messages for the walls.\n\n\u201cThe hardest part to understand,\u201d wrote one student, \u201cis kids killing kids.\u201d\n\nThe memorial followed years of challenges.\n\nIn the days after the shooting, an Illinois man erected an initial tribute, placing 15 crosses atop a hill to recall the 13 victims and two student killers. A father of one of the dead students soon ripped out two of the crosses, and for months a debate raged about the appropriate way to recall the assailants.\n\nA committee that had formed to create a permanent memorial eventually decided to avoid mention of the gunmen. It also agreed that the memorial should be separate from the scene of the attack.\n\n\u201cWe did not want the memorial on school grounds,\u201d said Frank DeAngelis, who was Columbine\u2019s principal the year of the attack. \u201cIf you do that at school it disrupts the educational process.\u201d\n\nToday, the memorial is a \u201cplace of hope,\u201d Mr. DeAngelis said. But paying for it was and continues to be a challenge. Fund-raisers found it difficult to meet their $1.5 million goal to build it. Even now, the Columbine Memorial Foundation struggles to find the $15,000 or so that it costs to maintain the park each year.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhich is why Rick Townsend, the foundation\u2019s president, is hoping to establish an endowment for the space. His daughter Lauren, 18, was killed in the shooting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want it to be forgotten,\u201d he said.\n\nVirginia Tech\n\nPhoto\n\nStudents began to gather on a field at Virginia Tech on April 16, 2007, just hours after a gunman killed 32 people on campus. By morning, stones had been laid there in an arc, one for each of the dead.\n\nThey were made of Hokie Stone, limestone typical to the region that had been pilfered from a nearby construction site.\n\nIt took only a short time for the university to recreate the arc in a permanent memorial on campus. New stones, each weighing 300 pounds, were laid, polished and etched with the names of the victims.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe school unveiled the memorial on Aug. 19, 2007, along with a plaque: \u201cWe will prevail.\u201d\n\nSandy Hook Elementary School\n\nTwenty children and six adults died in the Dec. 14, 2012, attack at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Conn.\n\nNow the community plans to build a memorial on an expanse of open meadow, ponds and sparsely wooded land.\n\nUnlike the privately funded Columbine memorial, this one will be paid for by the local government. A group called the Sandy Hook Permanent Memorial Commission is leading the effort to build it.\n\nThe commission has sought out expertise from others who have experienced attacks, including Mr. DeAngelis.\n\nMany disparate memorials popped up in the weeks after the shooting, but the commission decided early on that the town needed a central place to heal, \u201crather than reminders all over the community,\u201d said Dan Rosenthal, Newtown\u2019s first selectman.\n\nA call for design submissions led to 188 ideas from around the world, including one with a plant selection that ensures vibrant colors in each season to \u201chonor the warmth and joy the victims lived.\u201d\n\nThe commission has narrowed the field to 13 of those ideas. Eventually it will make a recommendation to Newtown\u2019s government, which will consider local feedback before it signs off on the final design.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt the core of our design,\u201d reads one submission, \u201cis the notion that the earth has the inexplicable ability to hold us and cradle our sorrows.\u201d", "title": "Columbine. Virginia Tech. Sandy Hook. How 3 Communities Honor Their Dead.", "authors": ["Julie Turkewitz"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor\n\nRe \u201cWhen Pads Can\u2019t Fix Prejudice\u201d (Sunday Review, April 1)\n\nChris Bobel suggests that menstrual activism focuses disproportionately on providing hygiene products, instead of combating menstrual stigma. While I agree with 99 percent of her argument, she underestimates the role products can play in reducing stigmas.\n\nAs a program manager for water and sanitation projects at Plan International, I have seen firsthand how the provision of products, or the construction of sanitation facilities, opens the door to dialogue in places where it was firmly shut.\n\nMenstrual stigma is often so strong that local authorities balk when related programming is proposed. But they like infrastructure and technological fixes. So by offering new toilets and access to products, we gain permission to talk to girls, boys, parents, teachers and the community about menstruation, stigma and taboos.\n\nI share Ms. Bobel\u2019s frustrations. But sometimes a pad is more than just a pad.\n\nCAITLIN GRUER, WASHINGTON", "title": "Opinion | Combating Menstrual Stigma", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 Rupert Murdoch sold most of 21st Century Fox to Disney in December for $52.4 billion, spurning a proposal from Comcast that was 16 percent higher on a per-share basis, in part because Comcast refused to offer protections in the event of regulatory rejection.\n\nAlthough Comcast\u2019s interest in 21st Century Fox was previously known, details of Comcast\u2019s proposal \u2014 and Fox\u2019s reasoning for rebuffing it \u2014 were disclosed for the first time on Wednesday as part of a 456-page filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The paperwork, required under securities law, also disclosed that senior Fox executives, including Mr. Murdoch and his two sons, James and Lachlan, are eligible for tens of millions of dollars in \u201cgolden parachute\u201d payments.\n\nDisney\u2019s all-stock deal with 21st Century Fox, announced on Dec. 14, valued Mr. Murdoch\u2019s company at $29.54 a share. Among other assets, Disney bought the 20th Century Fox studio, Hulu, the FX cable network, and stakes in two overseas television-service providers, Sky of Britain and Star of India. Disney did not buy Fox News or the Fox broadcast network.\n\nComcast, identified in the filing as Party B, made an all-stock proposal worth $34.41 per share in November. The filing portrays Mr. Murdoch and the Fox board as taking Comcast\u2019s interest seriously \u2014 until Comcast repeatedly refused to agree to a breakup fee in case Department of Justice regulators rejected the deal. Disney, perhaps showing more confidence in its chances with regulators, had offered a $2.5 billion fee.", "title": "Comcast Bid 16% More Than Disney for 21st Century Fox, Filing Shows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "For Mr. Murdoch, buying the 61 percent of Sky that Fox does not currently own would give his company full control of a strongly performing business to which the media mogul has a special attachment. He founded the broadcaster in the early 1990s and had previously tried to buy the entire company, only to be forced to withdraw his bid in the wake of a British phone-hacking scandal involving one of his tabloids.\n\nComcast\u2019s move, telegraphed two months ago, seizes upon Fox\u2019s troubles in getting government approval for its bid. British regulators have questioned whether buying Sky, which operates the 24-hour news channel Sky News, would give Mr. Murdoch too much control over the country\u2019s news media, given his ownership of newspapers like The Times of London and The Sun.\n\nIt also changes the calculus for Fox and Disney. Both have already offered concessions to allay regulators\u2019 concerns, including an offer to sell Sky News to Disney.\n\nBut now they may be forced to pay up to win Sky.\n\nUnder the terms of its offer, Comcast would pay 12.50 pounds, or $17.45, a share in cash for each Sky share. Fox has offered \u00a310.75 a share.\n\nHoping to press on Fox\u2019s weak spot, Comcast said that it was committed to Sky News\u2019s editorial independence, offering to set up a board for the news unit and maintain its funding. Comcast also repeated pledges to increase investment in Britain\u2019s film and television industries.", "title": "Comcast Starts Bidding War With 21st Century Fox for Sky", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "I chalked that up to a fleeting passage overplayed by the media, and I was heartened by other advance material from the book. Comey, for example, mentions his experience in two administrations before Trump\u2019s and has judicious complaints about members of each. He thus makes clear his broad frame of reference and ability to find flaw on both sides of the aisle.\n\nBut he revisited Trump\u2019s physical peculiarities with Stephanopoulos on Sunday night. Didn\u2019t Comey always tell us that he was better than this?\n\nHe could have set the record straight and settled any scores that need settling without a tour this extended or details this catty. His choice of a different tack suggests some unflattering motives in the mix. It gives Trump\u2019s allies plenty to attack him with, and it has goaded Trump \u2014 predictably \u2014 into his most infantile epithets.\n\nThere\u2019s obviously no contest of character or credibility between Comey and Trump. I believe most and maybe all of what Comey has to say, and much of it needs saying, as an answer to the president\u2019s lies and an exposure \u2014 affirmation might be the better word \u2014 of who and what Trump is.\n\nBut in succumbing to this showboating and spite, hasn\u2019t Comey joined Trump almost as much as he\u2019s defying him? Comey says that he means to shine a spotlight on what leadership should and shouldn\u2019t be, and I hope that\u2019s the long-term takeaway of the \u201cHigher Loyalty\u201d rollout and all the hours and miles being devoted to it.\n\nBut right now I\u2019m cringing at a food fight. In fact, \u201cGood Morning America\u201d displayed a snazzy graphic of Trump\u2019s various Twitter tirades against Comey \u2014 \u201cSlippery,\u201d \u201cSlimeball,\u201d \u201cLeaker & Liar\u201d \u2014 as Comey was asked to respond.\n\nTrump personalizes everything. Ideas don\u2019t joust. People do. And it\u2019s vanity, not verities, at stake. With the way that Comey has written his book, which charts every last tremor of his conscience, and the staging of his appearances in promotion of it, he has abetted his own transformation from a crucial witness to a character in the serial melodrama of Trump\u2019s life.", "title": "Opinion | Comey Is Trump\u2019s Ultimate Victory", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "That exchange and other broad outlines of the memos, which were first published by The Associated Press, have already been reported by The Times, and were relayed by Mr. Comey in testimony before the Senate and in his recent memoir, \u201cA Higher Loyalty.\u201d\n\nBut they are believed to be evidence in a possible obstruction of justice case against Mr. Trump being pursued by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.\n\nThe memos are exacting in their specificity, including details about who was sitting where, the precise times that conversations began and their durations. In some cases, Mr. Comey shared his accounts with others immediately afterward.\n\nThese details add credibility to Mr. Comey\u2019s account of events. Mr. Trump has disputed some parts, including asking Mr. Comey to shut down an investigation into Mr. Flynn.\n\n\u201cWhat follows are notes I typed in the vehicle immediately upon exiting Trump Tower on 1/6/17,\u201d Mr. Comey writes at the beginning of his first memo, sent the next day to his deputy director, chief of staff and the F.B.I.\u2019s chief counsel.\n\nSelect lawmakers have been allowed to view redacted versions of the memos at the Justice Department. But three House Republican committee chairmen requested last Friday that they be sent to Congress, and made clear this week that they were willing to issue a subpoena if the deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, did not comply.\n\nThe Justice Department relented on Thursday and is expected to deliver unredacted versions of the memos via a secure transfer on Friday.", "title": "Comey Memos Provide Intimate Look Into Trump Presidency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "DORIS FENIG, FLORAL PARK, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Calls Comey \u2018Untruthful Slime Ball\u2019 as Book Details Released\u201d (news article, nytimes.com, April 13):\n\nWhen President Trump calls James Comey an \u201cuntruthful slime ball,\u201d he could just as easily be talking about himself.\n\nAttacking Mr. Comey so vociferously may make political sense, especially when you cannot rebut his charges with the truth, but does this president really believe that the American people will side with him over a man who by all accounts has lived up to his sworn oath to support and defend the Constitution against all enemies foreign and domestic?\n\nMICHAEL SCOTT, SAN FRANCISCO\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Law Is Coming, Mr. Trump\u201d (editorial, April 11):\n\nTo this I can only add, \u201cPlease hurry.\u201d No one should be surprised if within the coming days President Trump embroils us in some sort of international or domestic crisis in order to take the focus off his legal troubles. Either that, or he will simply fire Robert Mueller and prepare to ride out the storm.\n\nThe bottom line is, Mr. Trump has a real gift for self-survival and will stop at absolutely nothing, whatever the cost to the country or the Constitution, to ensure that survival. Having thwarted both the law and justice, he will then tweet his satisfaction at seeing the \u201cwitch hunt\u201d brought to an end.\n\nJOE ELLIOTT, ASHEVILLE, N.C.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI am no fan of President Trump, but I believe he should be commended when he does the right thing. Your April 13 front-page article \u201cTrump Weighs Rejoining Accord With Pacific Rim in About-Face\u201d is good news. We should be stressing the potential positive outcomes from this decision (especially for American farmers) rather than the fact that it is an \u201cabout-face.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Comey vs. Trump: Fighting Words", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "1. President Trump has ordered strikes against Syria as punishment for a suspected chemical attack near Damascus. Britain and France joined in the strikes, he said. Check back for updates on this developing story.\n\nEarlier Friday, U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley accused the Syrian government of having used chemical weapons at least 50 times during the civil war. That was higher than previous U.S. estimates. We mapped 34 of those confirmed chemical attacks.\n\n____", "title": "Comey, Syria, Cohen: Your Friday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "The interview with Mr. Comey and the publicity tour for his book, which is scheduled to hit bookstores on Tuesday, amount to a remarkable public assault on a sitting president by someone who served at the highest levels in the government.\n\nThe stakes for both men could hardly be higher. Mr. Comey seems likely to be the star witness in any obstruction of justice case that might be brought against the president by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel in the sprawling Russia investigation. Mr. Trump\u2019s legal fate, as well as his political fortunes in Washington, may depend on whether he succeeds in undermining the credibility of Mr. Comey and the law enforcement institutions he views as arrayed against him.\n\nWhile many of Mr. Trump\u2019s critics believe that the proper remedy for his perceived transgressions is impeachment, Mr. Comey insisted that would just \u201clet the American people off the hook.\u201d He said the public was \u201cduty bound\u201d to vote Mr. Trump out of office in the next election.\n\n\u201cYou cannot have, as president of the United States, someone who does not reflect the values that I believe Republicans treasure and Democrats treasure and independents treasure,\u201d Mr. Comey said. \u201cThat is the core of this country. That\u2019s our foundation. And so impeachment, in a way, would short-circuit that.\u201d\n\nEpic Battle of Wills\n\nMr. Comey\u2019s intensely personal attacks \u2014 a reflection of his self-righteousness, his detractors say \u2014 are all the more combustible because they are aimed directly at a president who has said with pride on Twitter that \u201cwhen someone attacks me, I always attack back...except 100x more.\u201d\n\nAs if on cue, hours before the interview aired, Mr. Trump called Mr. Comey a \u201cslimeball\u201d for the second time in three days, saying in a pair of early-morning Twitter posts that he belonged in jail for what the president said were lies to Congress and leaks of classified information. In another post, Mr. Trump said Mr. Comey would go down in history as \u201cthe WORST FBI Director in history, by far!\u201d He added that \u201che is not smart!\u201d\n\nIn the ABC interview, Mr. Comey had kinder things to say about Mr. Trump\u2019s brainpower, saying he did not think the president suffered from mental incompetence or was in the early stages of dementia. He said Mr. Trump struck him as a person of \u201cabove average intelligence.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Comey responded to the president\u2019s Twitter posts with a more subtle dig of his own.\n\n\u201cMy book is about ethical leadership & draws on stories from my life & lessons I learned from others,\u201d he wrote on Twitter. \u201c3 presidents are in my book: 2 help illustrate the values at the heart of ethical leadership; 1 serves as a counterpoint.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear where this epic battle of wills will lead, other than a sustained escalation of insults between two men who have each admitted to having outsize egos. But it is certain to be a test of powerful forces in the modern media landscape: the presidential megaphone, amplified by 50 million Twitter followers, and the global reach of an adversary who is on a seemingly endless, 24-hour, cable-news-driven book tour.\n\nThe president took a break from his attacks on Mr. Comey as he left the White House on a rainy Sunday afternoon to spend time at Trump National Golf Club in Sterling, Va. But it seemed likely that he and his allies would not back down in the face of Mr. Comey\u2019s barrage of public accusations, which are expected to continue for weeks.\n\nOn ABC\u2019s \u201cThis Week\u201d on Sunday morning, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the press secretary, unloaded on Mr. Comey, calling him a \u201cself-admitted leaker\u201d and a liar. At the White House on Friday, she had called him a \u201cdisgraced partisan hack\u201d and a fired employee trying desperately to \u201crehabilitate his tattered reputation and enrich his own bank account.\u201d\n\nMr. Comey was similarly unrestrained in his ABC interview, speaking with the abandon of a man who finally feels unleashed. He repeated for the cameras some of the assertions from his book that he must know will get under the president\u2019s skin: that Mr. Trump\u2019s hands are \u201caverage-sized,\u201d that his skin is \u201corange\u201d and that he seemed shorter than Mr. Comey had imagined he would be.\n\n\u201cHis tie was too long, as it always is,\u201d Mr. Comey said. \u201cHe looked slightly orange up close with small white half-moons under his eyes, which I assume are from tanning goggles.\u201d\n\nMr. Comey described in vivid detail the interactions he had with Mr. Trump, including meetings and phone calls about which he said he meticulously wrote down notes afterward for posterity. (In another Twitter post Sunday morning, Mr. Trump said that Mr. Comey\u2019s \u201c\u2018memos\u2019 are self serving and FAKE!\u201d)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStartling New Details\n\nSome of the most startling assertions by Mr. Comey revolved around his first meeting with the president-elect at Trump Tower just days before the inauguration. That day, intelligence officials, including Mr. Comey, briefed the incoming president on Russia\u2019s attempt to meddle with the election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Comey said Mr. Trump and his aides seemed interested only in what the former F.B.I. director called the \u201cP.R. and spin\u201d about the issue.\n\n\u201cThe conversation, to my surprise, moved into a P.R. conversation about how the Trump team would position this and what they could say about this,\u201d Mr. Comey said. \u201cI don\u2019t remember any questions about, \u2018So what are they going to do next; how might we stop it? What\u2019s the future look like? Because we\u2019ll be custodians of the security of this country.\u2019 There was none of that.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt was all, \u2018What can we say about what they did and how it affects the election that we just had?\u2019\u201d Mr. Comey said.\n\nIt was at the end of the meeting that Mr. Comey said he asked to speak to Mr. Trump alone to brief him on the salacious \u201cSteele dossier,\u201d which contains unverified allegations about Mr. Trump, including a claim that the Russian government has video recordings of him watching prostitutes urinate on one another in a Moscow hotel room in 2013.\n\nMr. Comey said Mr. Trump denied the allegations that day, saying, \u201cDo I look like a guy who needs hookers?\u201d Weeks later, in a telephone call after the dossier was published by BuzzFeed, Mr. Trump again denied the account in graphic terms, Mr. Comey said.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no way I\u2019d let people pee on each other around me,\u201d Mr. Trump said, according to Mr. Comey\u2019s account. Mr. Comey said the president also raised the idea that the F.B.I. should investigate the claim as a way of proving that it never happened. Mr. Comey said he warned Mr. Trump that doing so would add to \u201cthe narrative\u201d that the president was under investigation.\n\nMr. Comey said in the interview that he did not know whether the episode had taken place, or whether the Russians had material they could use to blackmail Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s possible. I don\u2019t know,\u201d Mr. Comey told Mr. Stephanopolous. \u201cThese are more words I never thought I\u2019d utter about a president of the United States, but it\u2019s possible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHallmarks of a Mob Boss\n\nMr. Comey also offered additional details about the one-on-one dinner at which he says Mr. Trump demanded his loyalty.\n\n\u201cAnd I said, \u2018You will always get honesty from me,\u2019\u201d Mr. Comey recalled. \u201cAnd he paused and then he said, \u2018Honest loyalty,\u2019 as if he was proposing some compromise or a deal. And I paused and said, \u2018You\u2019ll get that from me.\u2019\u201d\n\nThat dinner felt like a mob initiation of sorts, Mr. Comey said in the interview, similar to the ones he often came across as a young prosecutor working to break up the mafia.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not trying to, by the way, suggest that President Trump is out breaking legs and, you know, shaking down shopkeepers,\u201d Mr. Comey said. Instead, it was reminiscent of \u201cthe loyalty oaths, the boss as the dominant center of everything. It\u2019s all about how do you serve the boss, what\u2019s in the boss\u2019s interests. It\u2019s the family, the family, the family, the family.\u201d\n\nIn one of his Sunday Twitter posts, Mr. Trump insisted that \u201cI never asked Comey for Personal Loyalty. I hardly even knew this guy.\u201d\n\nAs he does in his book, Mr. Comey largely kept a distance in the interview from the Russia investigation. But he said Mr. Trump must have known that it was improper to ask his other top aides to leave the Oval Office so he could privately ask Mr. Comey to drop the investigation into Michael T. Flynn, his just-fired national security adviser.\n\n\u201cIf he didn\u2019t know he was doing something improper, why did he kick out the attorney general and the vice president of the United States and the leaders of the intelligence community?\u201d Mr. Comey said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s certainly some evidence of obstruction of justice,\u201d he said, though he added that a prosecutor would need to evaluate \u201cother things that reflected on his intent.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe president has repeatedly criticized Mr. Comey for his handling of the Hillary Clinton email case. On Sunday, he did so again in a Twitter post, claiming that Mr. Comey had admitted in his book that he went easy on her because he thought she would win the election.\n\nIn fact, Mr. Comey said the opposite in his book, acknowledging that he may have unconsciously assumed she would win when he reopened the email investigation just days before the election, something that many Democrats believe was devastating to her campaign.\n\nIn the ABC interview, Mr. Comey said he believed at the time that it would be extremely damaging to the credibility of the F.B.I. if the reopened investigation did not come to light until after Mrs. Clinton had won the White House.\n\n\u201cIf I ever start considering whose political fortunes will be affected by a decision, we\u2019re done,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re no longer that group in America that is apart from the partisans, and that can be trusted.\u201d", "title": "Comey, in Interview, Calls Trump \u2018Morally Unfit\u2019 and \u2018Stain\u2019 on All Around Him", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Four months later, Mr. Trump abruptly fired Mr. Comey, setting in motion a cascade of political and legal consequences that led directly to the appointment of Robert S. Mueller III as special counsel overseeing the federal investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Mr. Comey and Mr. Trump have been engaged in a verbal war with each other, often on Twitter, since then.\n\nThe 304-page memoir by Mr. Comey is the only firsthand, insider account to emerge so far by a former Trump official describing what it was like to work in the chaotic early days of the administration. In it, Mr. Comey, a veteran law enforcement agent, writes unsparingly about Mr. Trump, calling him a tempestuous president whose connection to honesty was tenuous at best.\n\n\u201cThis president is unethical, and untethered to truth and institutional values,\u201d Mr. Comey writes in the book, saying his service to Mr. Trump recalled for him the days when he investigated the mob in New York. \u201cThe silent circle of assent. The boss in complete control. The loyalty oaths. The us-versus-them worldview. The lying about all things, large and small, in service to some code of loyalty that put the organization above morality and above the truth.\u201d\n\nWith the book\u2019s release set for next week, Mr. Comey is planning a media blitz, beginning with an intensely hyped interview with ABC News that is set to air Sunday night. Republican allies of Mr. Trump\u2019s have already set in motion a counteroffensive, creating a \u201cLyin\u2019 Comey\u201d website aimed at discrediting the former F.B.I. chief.\n\nMr. Comey\u2019s book does not include dramatic new revelations about the Russia investigation itself, which is continuing. But Mr. Comey does not pull punches as he provides rigorous detail \u2014 pulled from his contemporaneous notes \u2014 about his charged interactions with Mr. Trump during the transition and in the White House.", "title": "Comey\u2019s Memoir Offers Visceral Details on a President \u2018Untethered to Truth\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "YOON HAEUNDAE GALBI Bobby Yoon, among the third generation of the family that opened Haeundae Galbi, a barbecue restaurant in Busan, South Korea, in 1964, has brought the business to New York. The menu offers short ribs, sirloin, bibimbap, a pancake for the table and braised pork ribs. It\u2019s sleekly decorated in wood and stone, with state-of-the-art burners on the tables: 8 West 36th Street, yoon-nyc.com.\n\nMOMOFUKU KO About two months ago, David Chang\u2019s flagship in the East Village closed for renovation. It has reopened, having expanded into a storefront next door, which is now the restaurant\u2019s entrance and bar. There are 23 seats, eight facing an open kitchen, a design recalling the original Ko on First Avenue at 10th Street. An \u00e0 la carte bar menu will change daily and offer dishes being developed for the main restaurant\u2019s tasting dinners. Sean Gray is the executive chef. Spot prawn crudo, lobster cake, duck pie and mandarin tarte Tatin were on the menu last week: 8 Extra Place (First Street), 212-203-8095, ko.momofuku.com.\n\nBLANK SLATE TEA This teahouse specializing in tea drinks and food like a matcha yogurt bowl, as well as items like avocado toast, will open a few doors from Blank Slate Coffee & Kitchen.
