It will occupy 11,000 square feet on the ground floor, where there will be 16 dining choices, plus two bars. On the fifth floor, there will be four more restaurants and a bar. Jo\u00e3o Cepeda, the president, and Didier Souillat, the chief executive of Time Out Market, have not selected the tenants, but they emphasized that street food would not be featured. They are looking for significant chefs; there will be burgers and a New York-style deli. Seating will be at counters and communal tables, and food will be served on china, glass and metal, not disposable plates and cutlery. Soon after this is up and running, they will open a Time Out Market in Miami Beach, with Boston and Chicago on the horizon: 55 Water Street (Main Street), Dumbo, Brooklyn.\n\nChefs on the Move\n\nDENISSE LINA CHAVEZ, the talented Mexican chef with whom Noah Arenstein opened El Atoradero in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, has left once again. Last year, she went on leave because of health concerns, which evidently have recurred.\n\nRESY PRESENTS THE FRANKS\u2019 BACKYARD CHEF SERIES II After a successful run last year, Resy.com will again be a partner in this series, in which Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, the owners of Frankies Spuntino, invite chefs to cook dinners held in the garden of their location at 457 Court Street (Luquer Street) in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. The monthly dinners, held rain or shine at communal tables, start at 7 p.m. with cocktails; first up, on April 18, are David Chang, and Pedro Miguel Schiaffino from Lima, Peru. The other chefs include Inaki Aizpitarte from Paris, Sean Brock from Charleston, S.C., and Roy Choi from Los Angeles. Tickets, $150 including beverages, tax and tip, will go on sale at 9 a.m. Eastern time on Friday at Resy.com/Frankies. This year, a package of 10 dinners will be sold for $1,500. The organizers say that last year the dinners sold out in a matter of minutes.\n\nClosed\n\nWILMA JEAN Rob Newton\u2019s fried chicken restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, has closed. Mr. Newton still owns Nightingale Nine nearby and remains involved with Yellow Magnolia Caf\u00e9, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.", "title": "Comfort Food With Middle Eastern Spices at Bleecker Street Luncheonette", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Off The Menu"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cCargo,\u201d a Netflix Original movie that will have its premiere on May 18, has an exemplary slow-burn opening. On a quiet river in the middle of a beautiful Australian landscape, Andy, played by Martin Freeman, steers a houseboat. In its kitchen area, his wife, Kay, feeds their infant daughter. Things look idyllic. The boat eases toward the shoreline; some balloons in trees hint of a celebration. Andy looks across the water at a patriarchal figure, who stares back, deadeyed. The man raises his shirt to show a revolver tucked into his jeans.\n\nAndy and his family, we learn, are running out of food. Something catastrophic is afoot. The movie, directed by Ben Howling and Yolanda Ramke from a screenplay by Ms. Ramke, keeps the exact nature of the calamity hidden for a good long time. Long enough that I was rather disappointed to find out \u2026 yup, flesh-eating zombie pandemic. (It was only two weeks ago that I wondered how long it would take for every region in the world to deliver its own zombie movie. We now have southern Australia covered.)\n\nBut \u201cCargo\u201d has more than a few terrifying, and provocative, tricks. In this movie\u2019s zombie pandemic, people who are bitten don\u2019t turn into flesh eaters immediately. When Andy is infected, he has 48 hours to find a nonzombie guardian for his daughter. As it happens, the indigenous people of this region seem to have a higher survival rate than others. They have gone back to the \u201cold ways,\u201d says Thoomi (Simone Landers, a newcomer who does excellent work), an indigenous teenage girl who befriends Andy. These ways include body and face paint to ward off the undead.\n\nOne of these survivors is played by David Gulpilil, who made his screen debut in the 1971 film \u201cWalkabout\u201d and whose presence in Australian and Australia-set cinema (his CV includes classics like \u201cThe Last Wave, \u201d from 1979, and the 1986 hit \u201cCrocodile Dundee\u201d) has rendered him a genuine icon. Mr. Freeman, the adept comic actor, is always good playing an ordinary joe, and here he portrays one in an extraordinary jam. The movie depicts his character\u2019s heroism without creating a \u201cwhite savior\u201d tale; instead, it advocates community and communal action.", "title": "Comic Performers Play It Dark in Netflix Movies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "She shifts in this way from the didactic to the fabulist \u2014 and at her best moments melds the two.\n\nDavis eventually has us follow the fortunes of a cast of nine fictional artists, including Dolores, a performance artist (think of a slightly gentler Marina Abramovic); Ju-Long, a sculptor; Twicetwo, who works in \u201cmassive multimedia\u201d; and Richard, whose practice involves humble papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9. Eventually, devastation strikes during an art opening for the group in the form of a catastrophic storm. \u201cWhy Art?\u201d recalls significant comics about disaster, whether Josh Neufeld\u2019s nonfiction \u201cA.D.: New Orleans After the Deluge\u201d or Richard McGuire\u2019s quietly ominous graphic novel \u201cHere.\u201d There is both whimsy and sharpness in the storytelling.\n\nPhoto\n\nWater and winds rapidly destroy the group\u2019s building and entire city; they escape into a small hand-held shadowbox, pulled in by its miniature residents. Recovering inside the shadowbox, they make \u2014 because they\u2019re artists \u2014 tiny versions of themselves who make tiny artworks. \u201cWe rebuild our entire world,\u201d the nameless narrator explains \u2014 but they rebuild their small selves aspirationally, slightly better than they are. Eventually Dolores crushes the built world, making the story recursive, repeating the disaster the artists themselves had experienced and survived. \u201cShow us how to be brave,\u201d she demands of her miniature self. \u201cShow us how to save ourselves.\u201d\n\nEccentric and visually inventive, answering all the many questions it raises, \u201cWhy Art?\u201d is about the power that comes from creating. The art that we mold with our own hands shows us how to be strong; it shows us how to live. The book, at 5.6 by 6.7 inches, is about the size of a person\u2019s spread palm; the cover swarms with hands drawn at size.\n\nPhoto\n\nDavis earned a degree in sequential art from the Savannah College of Art and Design \u2014 one of the few rigorous comics-making programs in the country. But she started creating her own mini-comics \u2014 a term for self-produced work \u2014 in high school, inspired by cartoonists like John Porcellino.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPorcellino, Davis\u2019s elder by nearly 15 years, is now out with FROM LONE MOUNTAIN (Drawn & Quarterly, $22.95), a collection of his autobiographical zine King-Cat Comics and Stories, which he has self-published since 1989. The Chicago-born Porcellino has a clean, stripped-down style, his black line art a minimalist take on bodies and scenery (see the notes in the back about his obsessive-compulsive \u201cdespecking\u201d of his drawings). His comics unfold in neat, regular panels, small boxes containing wonderment in the everyday.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis collection revolves around the power of place, as Porcellino bounces from various Midwestern locales to Denver and San Francisco and back; wherever he is, he finds tranquillity in open space, in the silence and grandeur of nature. \u201cFrom Lone Mountain,\u201d earnest and sweet, is not as wacky and weird an art object as the hybrid \u201cWhy Art?,\u201d but it does put on display, zine-style, a mix of modes, from long comics stories, such as the moving \u201cLas Hojas\u201d (about playing football with a group of kids in Elgin, Ill., in November 2001), to written ones, such as Porcellino\u2019s memories of his father, to meditative four-panel comic vignettes and Porcellino\u2019s signature \u201cTop 40\u201d lists of things he loves in his life, which are my favorite element (they routinely combine \u201cthinking about Thoreau\u201d and specific Led Zeppelin songs).\n\nPhoto\n\nPorcellino and Davis are two of the most important cartoonists still dedicated to the punk-inspired world of self-publishing. But even before Porcellino launched King-Cat from his parents\u2019 home in the Chicago suburbs, Jennifer Camper was publishing her queer and feminist comics in underground comic books and independent newspapers.\n\nThere\u2019s a great example of her work in the April/May issue of The Believer in the form of a 16-page comics story called \u201cBoys Will Be Boys.\u201d The fictional yet true-to-life story was inspired by Bill Cosby \u2014 who was just found guilty of sexual assault \u2014 and spotlights the sordid life of Bobby Otis, a celebrity baseball player, on trial for rape.\n\nCamper uses to brilliant effect the ability of comics to easily switch perspective: She presents readers with Otis\u2019s interactions with eight different women over the decades, starting from the late 1960s, but at the same time spotlights, throughout, how the women themselves experienced the abuse. While Otis doesn\u2019t seem to distinguish between them, the reader can \u2014 we see their names and witness the aftermath \u2014 thus restoring a sense of their humanity. Camper\u2019s piece is devastatingly timeless and current at once. It includes hard-to-look-at scenes of assault, rendered in a black and white much less airy than either Porcellino\u2019s or Davis\u2019s. The discomfort it produces is its strength \u2014 another potent answer to the question \u201cwhy art?\u201d", "title": "Comics in Black and White That Are Anything but Simple", "authors": ["Hillary Chute"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe see more private collectors engaged with museum boards and loaning works to museums,\u201d said John Mathews, head of private wealth management at UBS America. \u201cCompetition for the best works has increased among institutions with the globalization of the art world and the rise of income-generating blockbuster exhibitions.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Mathews added: \u201cThe collecting habits of our clients are directly tied to their passion habits. Billionaires want to give back to communities.\u201d\n\nBillionaires on museum boards can create tensions, as well as present solutions, particularly as exhibition programs become more diverse.\n\nLast month, the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles (MOCA), announced that it had \u201cdecided to part ways\u201d with its chief curator, Helen Molesworth, \u201cdue to creative differences.\u201d\n\nMs. Molesworth had organized critically acclaimed exhibitions devoted to the African-American painter Kerry James Marshall and the Brazilian artist Anna Maria Maiolino. Artnews reported that Ms. Molesworth had criticized the overwhelming whiteness of the MOCA board during a January talk at the University of California, Los Angeles.\n\nShe made a similar point two months earlier at a talk in San Francisco. \u201cMuseum boards are increasingly comprised of exceedingly affluent people who don\u2019t come from a philanthropic or cultural background,\u201d Ms. Molesworth said. \u201cThey often come from a financial background or a being-rich background,\u201d Artnews quoted her as saying.\n\nThe MOCA board has the Los Angeles collector Maurice Marciano as a co-chair, and it includes other wealthy collectors such as Steven A. Cohen, Laurence Graff and Victor Pinchuk.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Los Angeles painter Mark Grotjahn is also on the board. MOCA had planned to hold a fund-raising gala in his honor in May, but with controversy in the air, Mr. Grotjahn pulled out of the event in February.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Molesworth did not reply to a request from The New York Times for comment.\n\n\u201cSome curators are working hard to change the canon to include different genders and minorities,\u201d said Lisa Schiff, a New York art adviser with an office in Los Angeles, who has clients who sit on museum boards. \u201cBut oftentimes, not always, that collides with the collections of the board members,\u201d she added, noting that some concentrated on works by white male artists.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe have art historical issues entangled with the market,\u201d she added. \u201cIt\u2019s a very complicated time.\u201d\n\nOn the other hand, cultivating wealthy board members, trustees and patrons is crucial for museums seeking to make a major acquisition through a gift or loan. Major acquisitions bring in more visitors, which in turn drives income.\n\nIn the first 12 days that the Seattle Museum of Art displayed the 1982 Jean-Michel Basquiat painting \u201cUntitled,\u201d the museum attracted more than 13,000 visitors, or 56 percent more than had been projected before the loan was secured. The suggested admission price of $19.95 for adults lets patrons see this monumental image of a skull that drew headlines around the world in May when it sold for $110.5 million at Sotheby\u2019s.\n\nSeattle is the latest stop in a world tour that the painting\u2019s new owner, the Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa, planned for the painting. It had previously been on display at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, and will travel to an as yet unspecified venue in Europe in August.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDistance should neither restrain nor limit us,\u201d Mr. Maezawa said in a Seattle Museum of Art news release, underlining how the painting, certainly in his mind, had become a \u201cdestination\u201d artwork.\n\nThe same can be said with even more certainty of Leonardo da Vinci\u2019s \u201cSalvator Mundi,\u201d which shattered auction highs when it sold for $450.3 million in November. The details of how it came to be acquired by the Louvre Abu Dhabi have yet to be clarified, but whenever it goes on show \u2014 no dates have been announced \u2014 it should bolster visitor numbers at the Jean Nouvel-designed museum, which opened to the public on Nov. 11. The Louvre brand will then have the distinction of displaying the world\u2019s most valuable painting (the \u201cMona Lisa\u201d) in France, and the most expensive in the United Arab Emirates.\n\nAs leading museums compete for crowd-drawing exhibits, and try to balance commercial interests and cultural diversity, visitors are bearing a rising proportion of the cost.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough admission to the permanent collections of Britain\u2019s public museums is free, adults are paying 22 pounds, or about $31, to view the must-see Tate Modern exhibition \u201cPicasso 1932 \u2014 Love, Fame, Tragedy.\u201d British museums had long been careful to keep exhibition ticket prices below \u00a320.\n\nSince March 1, people who do not live in New York State have to pay a mandatory admission fee of $25 to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The museum, already facing a budget deficit, is planning a new wing, at a cost of at least $450 million, to house acquisitions and gifts of modern and contemporary art.\n\n\u201cI foresee that the expansionist ethos of museums, which apes the world of business, is unsustainable and potentially corrupting, or at the very least distracting from the museums\u2019 main mission,\u201d Anna Somers Cocks, the founding editor and chairman of The Art Newspaper, wrote in its 300th anniversary issue.\n\nBut what, exactly, is the main mission of a museum?\n\nIf it is to show the greatest art to the largest number of people in a scholarly and affordable manner, then that mission might have been accomplished last year in Japan. In just three months, the exhibition \u201cUnkei: The Great Master of Buddhist Sculpture\u201d at the Tokyo National Museum attracted an average of 11,268 visitors a day, 2,342 more than the average for the Shchukin Collection show in Paris. Adult admission to the Tokyo show cost 1600 yen, or about $15.\n\nSo, measured by daily footfall, an exhibition of religious sculptures more than 800 years old was the most popular show in the world in 2017. Even Ruskin might have approved.", "title": "Commerce vs. Curation: Lessons From Today\u2019s Museum World", "authors": ["Scott Reyburn"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOver-the-counter pain pills are safer and more effective than prescription opioids for controlling the pain following dental procedures, a review of the evidence has found.\n\nResearchers analyzed five reviews of studies of medication and medication combinations for pain relief. They included only reviews of high or moderate methodological quality.\n\nThe data included many randomized trials on the use of oral medication for the most severe kinds of postoperative dental pain \u2014 for example, the pain following the extraction of a molar. More than three dozen drugs and drug combinations were tested in various dosages. The study is in The Journal of the American Dental Association.\n\nThe researchers conclude that the most effective pain relief with the fewest side effects comes from a combination of 400 milligrams of ibuprofen (Advil and other brands) with 1,000 milligrams of acetaminophen (Tylenol). No opioid or opioid-containing medicine or any other combination of drugs was more effective.\n\nA co-author, Anita Aminoshariae, an associate professor at Case Western Reserve University, said there may be some people who can get relief only with opioids. But for most patients, she said, opioids are not only less effective, they also have unpleasant side effects, including nausea, constipation and dizziness. They also carry a high risk of addiction.\n\n\u201cYou have to start with an NSAID,\u201d she said, meaning a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug. \u201cIf that doesn\u2019t work, add Tylenol. No one should go home in pain, but opioids should not be the first choice.\u201d", "title": "Common Pain Relievers Beat Opioids for Dental Pain Relief", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhere is the authority for payment to be made to a member of the Senate in the special capacity of \u2018vice chair\u2019 of a committee?\u201d wrote Christopher M. Gorka, the deputy comptroller, on March 23, adding, \u201cUntil this question is answered, we are unable to pay.\u201d\n\nThe state Comptroller\u2019s office had already paid 25 percent of the yearly stipend to the five senators, but declined the remaining 75 percent \u2014 totaling $54,750 \u2014 that was due to be paid this week.\n\nState legislative law 5-a expressly says what senators are to be paid for various leadership positions. Vice chairs are not listed as receiving any payments.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe use of false titles in requests for stipends, known as \u201clulus\u201d in Albany, was uncovered last year by The New York Times, prompting an investigation by federal authorities in Brooklyn. The authorities declined to comment on the investigation.\n\nThe five senators who were assigned false titles are Diane J. Savino and Jose R. Peralta, both members of the Independent Democratic Conference, a eight-member faction that has helped the G.O.P. rule the Senate; and Senators Thomas F. O\u2019Mara, Patrick M. Gallivan and Patty Ritchie, all Republicans from upstate.\n\nIn each case, the senators served as vice chairs, while the actual chairpeople \u2014 all of whom are Republicans \u2014 received larger stipends for other leadership roles. By law, no Senator is allowed more than one stipend, however, so the stipends for those committees would have gone unpaid had the vice chairs not attempted to claim them.\n\nThe news of the rejected payments came the same day as word of a reconciliation in Democratic ranks in the Senate, where the I.D.C.\u2019 s seven-year collaboration with the G.O.P. has been a point of intense unhappiness among many mainstream Democrats and progressive groups.\n\nThe deal for the I.D.C. to dissolve could impact committee chairs as well since those positions are granted by Republicans led by State Senator John J. Flanagan of Long Island.\n\nTwo other members of the I.D.C. \u2014 Jeffrey D. Klein, who leads the group, and David Valesky, his deputy \u2014 were allowed to receive their stipends, totaling $61,500 for the year, after the comptroller determined that their assigned titles \u201cvice president pro tempore\u201d and \u201csenior assistant majority leader of the Senate\u201d were supported by other documents. Neither man, however, had used such titles on their websites or professional biographies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a separate letter dated Friday, Ms. Savino and Mr. Peralta told the comptroller that they would decline their stipend payments \u2014 which had already been rejected \u2014 until their legality is determined.", "title": "Comptroller Rejects Stipends for State Senators Citing False Titles", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "As Concacaf\u2019s president, Montagliani is responsible for overseeing a 41-nation organization based in Miami with members scattered from his native Canada to Suriname, which borders Brazil on the northeastern coast of South America.\n\nAfter the indictments, the crisis at Concacaf, was worse than that suffered by any of soccer\u2019s six regional confederations, with the possible exception of South America. Concacaf\u2019s members include the United States and Mexico, and Montagliani\u2019s three predecessors all were charged with graft. About 40 percent of the administration has since been replaced. Moggio, a former N.B.A. executive, became general secretary in May 2016. His annual salary is $1 million.\n\nSince the scandal, soccer has renewed its focus on how much its leaders make from the game. FIFA and UEFA have decided to release executive compensation information. Infantino did not receive a bonus in 2017, though he is eligible for one in 2018, the year the men\u2019s World Cup is played. That event accounts for the vast amount of FIFA\u2019s revenue.\n\nThe president of South America\u2019s 10-member confederation, Alejandro Dominguez of Paraguay, earns $44,000 per month, according to news media reports. It is not clear what the leaders of confederations for Africa, Asia and Oceania earn.\n\nConcacaf hired external experts to help set Montagliani\u2019s pay. A separate compensation committee negotiated the deal, which the organization\u2019s top board members ratified. The committee agreed to a base of $1.25 million and the provision of a nonguaranteed 100 percent bonus. The figure was based on the assumption that Montagliani, an insurance executive, would spend 2,000 hours working on Concacaf business. Some of Montagliani\u2019s bonus includes work done in 2016, before the terms of his bonus were fixed. He pays taxes in both the United States and Canada.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLike most soccer organizations, annual income at Concacaf surges when the top regional competition is played. In good years, when the biennial Concacaf Gold Cup is played, revenue is about $100 million. When the Gold cup is not played, revenue drops to about $25 million. FIFA has budgeted $5.7 billion in earnings for the four-year cycle through the 2018 World Cup, and UEFA \u2014 through its own championship and also the lucrative Champions League \u2014 has projected collecting about $15.5 billion through its current four-year cycle.\n\nConcacaf is battling to restore its nonprofit status in the United States, a designation that remains uncertain after the criminal indictments against several former officials, including Jeffrey Webb, the last permanent Concacaf president. Webb pleaded guilty to a raft of charges after he was arrested in Switzerland in 2015. An internal audit found he supplemented a $2 million salary with at least an additional $1 million in expense claims. Webb\u2019s deputy at the time, who was later banned from soccer, approved those expenses.\n\nConcacaf\u2019s new regulations don\u2019t allow for similar excesses. Private jet flights that once were common are now prohibited, as are stays at some of the world\u2019s most exclusive hotels and limousines for top officials. Still, officials on the group\u2019s executive committee are paid on average $125,000 a year. Efforts by some of the members to supplement that with bonuses were rejected. Montagliani gets an additional $300,000 for his role as one of eight vice presidents on FIFA\u2019s governing council. The group meets three or four times each year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConcacaf\u2019s three-person compensation committee includes two independent members. They received a report from external experts who looked at the pay of top executives of similar sports organizations based in North America, including the United States Olympic Committee, top college sports organizations and Major League Soccer, whose commissioner, Don Garber, earns a base salary of $5 million.\n\nMoggio said the compensation experts based Montagliani\u2019s salary on the pay of his peer group.\n\n\u201cI can assure you he spends way more than 2,000 hours per year,\u201d Moggio said. \u201cHe\u2019s involved in every part of the business.\u201d\n\nAt the height of the corruption crisis, outside consultants ran Concacaf as it teetered on the brink of collapse. Montagliani joined as the organization\u2019s members approved a series of governance reforms. UEFA, by contrast, has largely been able to operate as it did before the scandal, although its former president Michel Platini was barred for receiving an illicit payment from FIFA. That has allowed Ceferin to enjoy a relatively stable tenure, with competitions like the Champions League continuing to swell the organization\u2019s coffers.\n\nUnder Montagliani, Concacaf has retained key sponsors, signed new broadcast agreements, revamped some of its competitions and created a new national team league. The organization also is in talks with South America\u2019s confederation, Conmebol, which may cooperate to create a regular tournament for the Americas.\n\nConcacaf renewed its principal partner Scotia Bank on better terms, and signed richer contracts with Fox Sports in the United States and Latin America. A recent deal with Verizon, Moggio said, was a sign of increased confidence in the organization\u2019s new corporate governance structures. He said the operating income target for 2017 was double the projected amount.\n\nConcacaf will present its latest financial results to its member nations at an annual meeting in Moscow shortly before the start of the World Cup there in June. It remains unclear if details of the top executives\u2019 pay will be disclosed at that meeting because of continuing negotiations over restoring nonprofit status.", "title": "Concacaf\u2019s Leader Earned $2 Million Last Year, More Than FIFA and UEFA Presidents", "authors": ["Tariq Panja"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThomas Neuwirth, who won the 2014 Eurovision Song Contest performing in drag as Conchita Wurst, has announced that he is H.I.V. positive, saying a threat of blackmail prompted him to make the news public.\n\nIn a statement posted on the official Conchita Wurst Instagram account on Sunday, Mr. Neuwirth said he has been H.I.V. positive for \u201cmany years\u201d and had not intended to discuss the diagnosis publicly.\n\n\u201cAn ex-boyfriend is threatening me to go public with this private information,\u201d Mr. Neuwirth wrote on Instagram, \u201cand I will not give anyone the right to frighten me and affect my life in the future.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for the performer said in an email that Mr. Neuwirth was not available for further comment. He also clarified that Mr. Neuwirth\u2019s preferred pronouns are \u201cshe\u201d for references to the stage persona of Conchita Wurst and \u201che\u201d for Mr. Neuwirth, the private individual.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConchita Wurst gained international attention in 2014 when she won the Eurovision Song Contest, representing Austria. Status", "authors": ["Anna Codrea-Rado"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "A traumatic brain injury, even a mild concussion, increases the risk for Parkinson\u2019s disease, a new study reports.\n\nResearchers identified all patients diagnosed with T.B.I. in a Veterans Health Administration database \u2014 162,935 men and women \u2014 and matched them with the same number of people with similar health and behavioral characteristics but who had not had a brain injury. The study is in Neurology.\n\nOf the T.B.I. cases, half were mild, involving a blow to the head with some subsequent symptoms but with little or no unconsciousness. The rest were moderate to severe, involving extended unconsciousness or long-term symptoms.\n\nAfter controlling for age, race, income and many medical and psychiatric diseases, they found that compared with those who had had no T.B.I., those with a mild T.B.I. had a 56 percent increased risk for Parkinson\u2019s disease; those with moderate to severe T.B.I. had an 83 percent increased risk.", "title": "Concussions May Increase the Risk for Parkinson\u2019s Disease", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Yes, it\u2019s very strange to me. They\u2019ll never forgive me. This revealed something of my character that I don\u2019t want to look at.\u201d", "title": "Confirm or Deny: David Duchovny", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "In fact, Assembly members from New York City were divided. While the congestion zone was backed by some members from Manhattan and Brooklyn, others saw it as fundamentally unfair to drivers, especially in neighborhoods with few public transit options.\n\n\u201cFamilies cannot afford paying additional hundreds of dollars a month on top of the rising costs of living,\u201d said Assemblyman William Colton, of Brooklyn. \u201cIt is unfair to subject working-class people to these costs without guaranteeing an equal value of increased benefits.\u201d\n\nIn the end, the congestion zone became a losing battle, the latest in a long line of failed congestion pricing efforts since at least the 1970s. A decade ago, a similar congestion zone proposed by then-Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had passed the City Council after much arm-twisting, only to die in Albany after Assembly leaders refused to bring it to a vote.\n\nThis time around, the meltdown of the city\u2019s subway system, which was not an issue the last time, seemed to provide a stronger argument for congestion pricing. A state task force assembled by Mr. Cuomo, called Fix NYC, laid out a plan with the congestion zone as the centerpiece and included $2 to $5 surcharges on for-hire vehicles, including Ubers, Lyfts and yellow taxis.\n\nDozens of influential business, transportation and community groups signed on to the Fix NYC plan, expanding upon a grass-roots effort by Move NY, an early proponent of congestion pricing. The coalition spent $500,000 on a campaign, which included hiring lobbyists to press their case with legislators who were on the fence, and running targeted online ads in their districts. \u201cIt was a full-throated, well-coordinated, all-out campaign,\u201d said Alex Matthiessen, the founder and director of Move NY.\n\nBut congestion pricing remained a hard sell, and not just to lawmakers. A Quinnipiac University poll of city voters released the day before the budget agreement found that 52 percent of respondents opposed it.\n\n\u201cIt was an intractable issue,\u201d said Douglas Muzzio, a public affairs professor at Baruch College, adding that congestion pricing came with too much baggage to ever really gain steam in Albany. \u201cIt was a massive effort that didn\u2019t work \u2014 and couldn\u2019t work \u2014 because of the unalterable opposition of legislators in the outer boroughs and suburban areas.\u201d", "title": "Congestion Pricing Plan for Manhattan Ran Into Politics. Politics Won.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nConnie Lawn, a radio and broadcast reporter who covered the White House in the waning days of Lyndon B. Johnson\u2019s administration, when women were a rarity there, to the first year of Donald J. Trump\u2019s, died on Monday at her home in Falls Church, Va. She was 73.\n\nThe cause was a rare form of Parkinson\u2019s disease, said her husband, Dr. Charles Sneiderman.\n\nUnlike many White House correspondents, Ms. Lawn built her nearly 50-year career without the consistent support of an established media company. She created an independent news service called Audio Video News (she was the only employee) and reported for different clients, like the BBC, Radio New Zealand, USA Radio Network and Salem Radio Network.\n\nMs. Lawn said she had created her own company in order to maintain her independence and pursue stories that interested her.\n\nAnd like many women in politics and the media, she endured sexual harassment on the job, she said. In 2016, for example, she told The Washington Post that when she was a young reporter a senator groped her in his office after inviting her there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut she was not discouraged by such experiences, colleagues said, and did what she could to make the White House press corps more welcoming. The groom was a widower.\n\nThe couple, who had been social friends in Washington since 1999, began dating there in December 2012.", "title": "Constance Carter, Gordon Dale", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMaking complaints public gives companies a stronger incentive to treat people right,\u201d said Lauren Saunders, associate director of the National Consumer Law Center. \u201cIt also helps people stay away from companies with bad track records. It lets the free market help steer us in the direction of consumer protection.\u201d\n\nThe Consumer Financial Protection Bureau asks the subjects of complaints to respond within 15 days. Complaints are later posted online, regardless of a company\u2019s response. The bureau has used the complaints to spot patterns of bad behavior. A wave of complaints about Wells Fargo helped spur the agency\u2019s investigation and exposure of the bank\u2019s sham accounts. Complaints have also prompted actions against student loan servicers, debt collectors, mortgage lenders and credit card companies.\n\nMore than 185,000 complaints to the bureau have been resolved with some form of compensation or relief, often with financial institutions changing their practices or making customers whole.\n\nDavid M. Perry was one of the beneficiaries.\n\nLast year, he filed a complaint against Midland Credit Management, a collection firm, over an inaccurate entry on his credit reports. Years earlier, a thief had fraudulently opened credit card accounts in his and his wife\u2019s names, Mr. Perry said. Most of the accounts were shut down, but one slipped through and was referred to Midland. Mr. Perry learned of it only last June when he applied for a mortgage and discovered that his credit score was hundreds of points lower than he expected.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen he contacted Midland, a representative suggested that he simply pay off the balance owed, Mr. Perry said. So he filed a complaint with the consumer bureau.\n\nThirteen days later, Midland sent Mr. Perry a letter: \u201cMidland Credit apologizes for the inconvenience caused to you.\u201d The collection firm agreed to close the disputed account, end collection efforts on it and instruct the credit bureaus to delete the record from their files.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t spend a lot of time feeling grateful to the federal government, but I was really grateful to the C.F.P.B. at that moment,\u201d Mr. Perry said. \u201cWe need more accountability and transparency from our financial institutions, not less.\u201d\n\nFinancial institutions, however, say the database can be misleading because the agency publishes a record of all the complaints that it receives, without vetting them. The companies also argue that they already have channels for resolving customer disputes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPublishing unverified complaints \u2014 or, worse, using those complaints to paint a picture of guilt in the public domain \u2014 is irresponsible,\u201d said Richard Hunt, the chief executive of the Consumer Bankers Association.\n\nMr. Mulvaney\u2019s disdain for the complaints database has already lessened its use. The New Economy Project, a community organization, has shifted its focus to reporting disputes to other regulators, including New York\u2019s attorney general and the state\u2019s Department of Financial Services.\n\n\u201cWhen Mulvaney stepped in, we saw the writing the wall and stopped advising our clients to file C.F.P.B. complaints, which anyone paying attention to what\u2019s going on at the agency can see would be an exercise in futility,\u201d said Sarah Ludwig, the New Economy Project\u2019s founder and co-director.\n\nA bureau spokesman declined to comment further about the agency\u2019s plans for the complaints database. Last week, the agency put out a public call for feedback on its complaint process \u2014 a standard precursor to making changes.", "title": "Consumer Bureau Looks to End Public View of Complaints Database", "authors": ["Stacy Cowley"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mick Mulvaney, the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, has complained that the regulator engages in \u201cwasteful spending\u201d and needs to be slimmed down. To underscore the point, he submitted a quarterly budget request recently that was a nice round number: $0.\n\nThat attitude, though, apparently didn\u2019t apply to two of his recent hires.\n\nMr. Mulvaney appointed two senior staff members who are paid salaries of more than $230,000, amounts that are far above what they had been earning in their previous government jobs in Washington, according to agency documents obtained by The New York Times through a public records request.\n\nThe consumer bureau, as well as fellow financial regulators like the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, is allowed under federal law to pay employees significantly more than other government agencies can pay. The rationale is that the higher salaries are necessary to recruit skilled employees who otherwise might land jobs on Wall Street.\n\nAs a result, the C.F.P.B. is stocked with employees who earn more than the average Washington bureaucrat. Of the agency\u2019s 1,600 employees, 219 make more than $200,000, according to the records reviewed by The Times.", "title": "Consumer Bureau\u2019s Chief Gives Big Raises, Even as He Criticizes Spending", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Want the Australia Letter by email? Sign up and forward my weekly dispatches to your friends so they can join our discussion about Australia and the world.\n\n______\n\nOne of the first things you learn as a foreign correspondent is that history matters. Everywhere. So as I toured Port Arthur this week on a brisk Tasmanian morning, I wondered what the restored convict camp might have to teach.\n\nOur guides gave us clues more than conclusions. They pointed to the garden for guards\u2019 families, set up to resemble an English country estate. They told us about punishment. They shared tales of individual prisoners and the British commandants who ran the place.\n\nBut it was the cemetery just off the coast that lingered in my mind.\n\nPort Arthur\u2019s upper-class overseers called it Isle of the Dead or Isle de Mort, and they were buried with headstones on the island\u2019s highest point.", "title": "Convict History Matters in Australia. But What Else?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. I got it into my head to make a fancy grilled cheese sandwich. I didn\u2019t have a recipe because you don\u2019t really need a recipe to make grilled cheese sandwiches, especially in the middle of the week. You just need desire, and a triangle in your head: salt; crunch; melting ooze.\n\nSo at lunchtime I went to the store and bought duck legs, and when I got home I seared them in a pan under a dusting of five-spice powder and salt and put them in an electric pressure cooker with a splash of chicken stock and some star anise and zapped them for around 35 minutes. That was pretty magic, on the legs. I got a lot of fat out of them, to boot.\n\nI broiled the skin and shredded it with the meat. Made a bowl of mayonnaise cut through with hoisin sauce. Sliced some mild Cheddar. Got some decent bread.\n\nThen: Sizzle-sizzle-flip-flip in some unsalted butter, a big pile of smashed cucumbers on the side, and this made for a fantastic dinner, unexpected by all involved save maybe me, and an excellent challenge for anyone in the middle of the week. Greenwood, instead pleaded guilty to a noncriminal violation and will complete 75 hours of community service.\n\nMr. Greenwood, 20, of Toronto, pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct, a violation, and admitted using the slur in the September altercation that left a black student with a bloody nose. But Mr. Greenwood denied taking part in the assault.\n\nCiting a \u201clevel of doubt\u201d in the case and the victim\u2019s desire to put the episode behind him, Matthew Van Houten, the Tompkins County district attorney, said on Tuesday that he had decided to drop three misdemeanor charges against Mr. Greenwood, including the charge of attempted assault as a hate crime.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe victim is a young man who simply wants to focus on his education at Cornell and to avoid the continued stress of this litigation,\u201d Mr. Van Houten said in a statement. She is Terri Goldman, not Terry Goldman.\n\nTRAVEL\n\nAn article about Cuba on March 18 misstated the year in which President Barack Obama visited that country. It was 2016, not 2015.\n\n\u2022\n\nThe 52 Places Traveler column last Sunday, about San Juan, P.R., misstated the number of people in Puerto Rico without electricity. As of February, the number was more than 900,000, not 400,000.\n\nTHE MAGAZINE\n\nAn article on March 25 about Aleksander Doba, who kayaked across the Atlantic Ocean three times, misstated the date of a National Geographic Society award ceremony and described incorrectly the clothing Doba wore to it. He is Dean Brockman, not Bookman. It also misstated the given name of a resident who has hosted the team\u2019s players in the past. He is Devin Cannon, not David. The article, relying on incorrect information from the chief coroner of Saskatchewan, also misidentified one of the victims killed in the crash. He was Parker Tobin, not Xavier Labelle.\n\nINTERNATIONAL\n\nAn article on Thursday about gains made in solar power capacity worldwide overstated the amount by which solar energy has increased. Solar accounted for more than a third of all net new power capacity added worldwide in 2017, not more than a third of all electricity generated.\n\n\u2022\n\nBecause of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Central American migrants traveling through Mexico incorrectly rendered the name of the group that organized the caravan. All renewable energy sources together, with the exception of large hydropower projects, represent 12 percent of worldwide energy consumption. This is not the share of solar power alone.\n\nWEEKEND ARTS\n\nA review on Friday about the HBO documentary \u201cElvis Presley: The Searcher\u201d misstated the year of a film Elvis starred in. The movie, \u201cKing Creole,\u201d was released in 1958, not 1956.\n\n\u2022\n\nA review on Friday about the 1983 film \u201cLiquid Sky\u201d misstated the status of a club that was part of the club scene in Lower Manhattan in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The Pyramid Club is still open; it has not closed.\n\n\u2022\n\nA review on Friday about the documentary \u201c\u2018Grace Jones: Bloodlight and Bami\u201d misstated the title of one of Ms. Jones\u2019 hit singles. It is \u201cPull Up to the Bumper,\u201d not \u201cPull Up to My Bumper.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOPINION\n\nAn Op-Ed essay on Thursday about online privacy described Illinois\u2019s face recognition privacy law incorrectly. It is Guastavino tile, not Gustavino tile.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article about the musical culture at American Legion Post 398 in Harlem misspells the surname of one of the organists in the Harlem Groove Band. She is Mariana Romero, not Marcela. It also misstated the given name of a sociologist. She is Dora Barrancos, not Nora.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Sunday about a village in the Netherlands that added musical rumble strips to a newly paved section of highway misstated the length of the section. It is about 16 miles long, not 124 miles.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Sunday about Russia\u2019s reaction to limited American-led airstrikes in Syria misstated part of the name of a Russian current affairs magazine. The increase was noted among Russian hashtags, not bots. Additionally, the information should not have been attributed to the department\u2019s spokesman, Tyler Q. Houlton.\n\nBUSINESS DAY\n\nAn article on Tuesday about the 2018 Pulitzer Prizes misspelled the surname of the editor of pictures for Reuters. He is Ahmad Masood, not Maood.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Tuesday about a Senate bill that would have exempted businesses on tribal lands from federal labor standards misstated how many more votes were needed to end a filibuster blocking a package of bills that included the Tribal Labor Sovereignty Act. Lavrov, Russia\u2019s foreign minister. It was broadcast Tuesday, not Thursday.\n\nNATIONAL\n\nAn article on Wednesday about an announced one-day shutdown of 8,000 Starbucks locations misstated the annual revenue of all of Starbucks\u2019s stores in the United States, Canada and Latin America. Those stores generated $14 billion in revenue in the company\u2019s most recent fiscal year, not $1.3 billion.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Tuesday about public school classrooms referred incorrectly to the base salary of teachers in North Las Vegas, Nev. Wood, who presided over a hearing related to President Trump\u2019s attorney Michael D. Cohen, described incorrectly Judge Wood\u2019s marital history. Michael Kramer was her second husband, not her first. The article also misstated the connection between her current husband, Frank E. Richardson, and George Soros\u2019s Quantum Industrial Holdings. Mr. Richardson once served as an unpaid member of an investment advisory committee for the group; he did not sit on its board.\n\nTHE ARTS\n\nA review on Saturday about works by the Martha Graham Dance Company misstated the name of an award the company grants. It is more than $70 billion, not more than $70 million.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Friday about memos made by the former F.B.I. director James Comey documenting his interactions with the president rendered a date incorrectly in quoting one of Mr. Comey\u2019s notes. He wrote that he typed the notes \u201cupon exiting Trump Tower on 1/6/17,\u201d not 1/5/17.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Thursday about a settlement between American Media Inc. and Karen McDougal, a former playboy model, described incorrectly one provision of the agreement. Under the deal\u2019s terms, A.M.I. has the right to up to $75,000 of the profits from any deal Ms. McDougal makes in the next year for her story about an affair she claims to have had with Donald J. Trump before he became president. The provision does not apply to any deal made after that.\n\nBUSINESS DAY\n\nAn article on Friday about damaged engines on multiple Southwest Airlines planes misstated the type and frequency of inspections of the engine of an American Airlines Boeing 767 that failed in 2016. According to a National Transportation Safety Board report, the inspections used eddy current and fluorescent penetrant techniques; they were not visual inspections. The article also misstated the last time an inspection of the engine was conducted. According to the report, the last inspection was conducted in 2011, not between flights.", "title": "Corrections: April 21, 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "SUNDAY BUSINESS\n\nA picture caption with an article on April 8 about a national identification system being developed by India misstated what was being scanned during a security check. It was a man\u2019s irises, not his retinas.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article last Sunday about investing in bonds misquoted Peter Chiappinelli, a member of the asset allocation team at the investment management firm GMO. He said that investing in a portfolio of bonds that is increasing its duration when interest rates are \u201cat historic lows is the exact opposite of prudence.\u201d He did not say that adding more duration when \u201crates are rising is the exact opposite of prudence.\u201d\n\nARTS & LEISURE\n\nAn article on Page 14 about different renditions of the tale of Orpheus misstates the name of a chorus presenting \u201cOrfeo ed Euridice.\u201d It is MasterVoices, not Masterworks Chorale.\n\nTRAVEL\n\nAn article last Sunday on street food in Bangkok misstated the name of the organization that announced it would ban street food vendors. In fact, Palestinian officials have acknowledged providing payments to the families of Palestinians killed while carrying out attacks on Israelis or convicted of terrorist acts and imprisoned in Israel; that is not a conspiracy theory.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Saturday about President Trump\u2019s criticism of OPEC and rising oil prices misstated, in one reference, a recent increase in gasoline prices. They have risen 33 cents in the last year, not the last month.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Wednesday about budget airlines reinvigorating smaller airports on the outskirts of major cities misstated the distance between Seattle Tacoma International Airport and Paine Field. They are about 37 miles apart, not 12.\n\nSPORTS\n\nAn article on Friday about the hesitance of the International Association of Athletics Federations to allow Russian athletes to compete in major track and field events misstated Sebastian Coe\u2019s title within the organization during an extortion scheme. He is Jeremy Davis, not Jeremy Ford.\n\n\u2022\n\nAn review on Monday about \u201cThe Metromaniacs\u201d by David Ives, using information from a publicist, misstated the number of French plays from the 17th and 18th centuries that David Ives has translated. It is four, not three. The review also misstated the number of plays that were collected for \u201cAll in the Timing.\u201d It is six, not three.\n\nOPINION\n\nAn editorial on Monday about what the special counsel\u2019s investigation has revealed about business misconduct referred imprecisely to the reason prosecutors were able to persuade a judge to allow them to seize documents from the president\u2019s lawyer Michael Cohen. The prosecutors had to show the judge that Mr. Cohen\u2019s files probably contained evidence of criminal activity, not that he himself had committed a crime, although he is under criminal investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOBITUARIES\n\nAn obituary on Friday about the record producer and songwriter Ronald Dunbar omitted the name of one of his survivors. The survey found that 11 percent of seniors had vaped nicotine in the previous 30 days and that 24 percent of those students reported vaping daily. The survey did not find that 24 percent of high school seniors overall reported vaping daily.\n\nINSIDE THE TIMES\n\nAn article on Monday about how a Times photographer captured the cover picture of Defense Secretary Jim Mattis for Sunday\u2019s Magazine misstated the official with whom Mr. Mattis was meeting when the photograph was taken. Mr. Bhatia is playing with both the drummer Ian Chang and the bassist Jackson Hill, not only with Mr. Chang.", "title": "Corrections: April 7, 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "OPINION\n\nCharles Blow\u2019s column last week misidentified the source of a report on the disparate use of force by the police. It is the Center for Policing Equity, not the Center for Policing Equality.\n\nErrors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.\n\nTo contact the newsroom regarding correction requests, complaints or other comments about our coverage, please email nytnews@nytimes.com or call 1-844-NYT-NEWS (1-844-698-6397).\n\nComments on editorials may be emailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.\n\nFor newspaper delivery questions: 1-800-NYTIMES (1-800-698-4637) or email customercare@nytimes.com.", "title": "Corrections: April 9, 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Schneider played in only five games in the last five weeks of the season and compiled a save percentage of .850. Not surprisingly, Devils Coach John Hynes made Kinkaid the starter for the first-round series against the top-seeded Lightning. But then Kinkaid gave up nine goals on 46 shots.\n\nHynes replaced Kinkaid with Schneider midway through a 5-3 loss in Game 2 on Saturday in Tampa that put the Devils in an 0-2 hole in the best-of-seven series. Schneider stopped all 10 shots he faced, and Hynes played a hunch Monday for Game 3.\n\nSchneider was acquired from the Vancouver Canucks in June 2013 to eventually replace Martin Brodeur, who now has a statue in the plaza outside Prudential Center. The Devils got Schneider just for enormous games like Monday\u2019s.\n\n\u201cI was looking forward to it,\u201d he said after the game. \u201cThese are fun games. This is the exciting time of year. There\u2019s no real time to overthink it or to be nervous. We\u2019ve had a fun year all year, and everything\u2019s kind of reset for the playoffs. For me, it\u2019s starting over, starting fresh and just having a lot of fun playing the game.\u201d\n\nSchneider stopped 34 of 36 shots Monday. He had no chance on Alex Killorn\u2019s second-period power-play goal, set up by a magnificent pass from Nikita Kucherov. But Schneider did get his glove on Steven Stamkos\u2019s power-play goal early in the third period that put the Lightning up, 2-1.\n\nSchneider shut out Tampa Bay from that point, and the Devils beat Lightning goaltender Alexei Vasilevskiy twice and flipped in two empty-net goals to ice the victory.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe looked steady, where it\u2019s a nice, calming effect,\u201d Devils forward Blake Coleman said of Schneider.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHynes said: \u201cHe looked like the Cory Schneider we know. He was poised in the net. He controlled rebounds. I thought he read plays well. He was quiet. He came up with some big saves when we needed them. Those are the attributes that make Cory such a good goalie \u2014 how under control he is, his hockey sense, his ability to read plays and how quiet he plays in the net.\u201d\n\nBy \u201cquiet\u201d Hynes meant that the 6-foot-3, 200-pound Schneider did not fling himself around the crease, like Brodeur sometimes did, often in the playoffs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe doesn\u2019t make all of these miraculous saves,\u201d Hynes said, \u201cbecause he\u2019s in position, and his ability to read the play makes the saves look a little bit easier sometimes than they are.\u201d\n\nMidway through the third period, with the score tied, 2-2, Lightning defenseman Ryan McDonagh, a former Ranger, barreled into Schneider while attempting a backhand shot. Schneider stopped the shot but stayed down during a chaotic scramble.\n\nFinally, Devils rookie center Nico Hischier drew a tripping penalty on Tampa Bay forward J.T. Miller while clearing the puck. As a sellout crowd chanted, \u201cCory!,\u201d a trainer came out to attend to Schneider. He skated slowly to the bench. The crowd stopped chanting.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t want to leave,\u201d Schneider said. \u201cI was able to push through a bit and finish the game. I should be fine.\u201d\n\nHis groin had cramped. Hynes said: \u201cYou always want to make sure when you have competitive players that they\u2019re not trying to push through something. For him, it was more cramping than anything. For me, that was comforting as a coach.\u201d\n\nTampa Bay still leads the series, two games to one, with Game 4 on Wednesday at Prudential Center. Monday\u2019s game ended with a melee that resulted in five 10-minute misconduct penalties for each team.\n\nIf Hynes will have Schneider back in goal, Schneider said he will be delighted to be there. He was asked if ending his long losing streak was as important as ending the team\u2019s long streak without a playoff victory, and Schneider had an answer quicker than a pad save.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m happy for the fans,\u201d Schneider said. \u201cThey\u2019ve supported us all year, and hopefully, we\u2019ve been a fun team to watch. It\u2019s never about me. It\u2019s not about one individual player. Every person is trying to contribute to the greater good.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor me, this is what I expect from myself, and it\u2019s never changed the entire year. One time, in February 2004, she said Ms. Constand told her she had been assaulted by a celebrity, after seeing a clip on television about another, unnamed star who had been so accused.", "title": "Cosby Accuser Talked of Framing a Celebrity, Witness Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "NORRISTOWN, Pa. \u2014 Bill Cosby\u2019s defense team rested its case on Monday after presenting additional witnesses whose testimony was intended to suggest that Mr. Cosby could not have sexually assaulted Andrea Constand at his home near here in January 2004, as she has said.\n\nThe two final witnesses, a woman who worked for Mr. Cosby\u2019s agent at what is now called the William Morris Endeavor, and a pilot with expertise about flight records, were introduced to bolster defense arguments that Mr. Cosby was traveling and away from his home near Philadelphia during the month in which Ms. Constand says she was molested.\n\nThe witnesses pored over itineraries and flight documents and testified to the accuracy of the records typically kept in such circumstances. The records indicated that on many dates during that month Mr. Cosby had traveled to performances in different states and then returned to his house in New York, not to the home outside Philadelphia where Ms. Constand says she was drugged and sexually assaulted.\n\nBut prosecutors said the records contained errors, were often vague about the destination and hardly comprehensive in detailing Mr. Cosby\u2019s whereabouts for the entire month.", "title": "Cosby Defense Rests as Sexual Assault Trial Nears Its End", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was his deposition, really,\u201d Mr. Snyder, 22, the youngest of the 12 jurors, said in an interview that aired on Monday on ABC\u2019s \u201cGood Morning America.\u201d \u201cMr. Cosby admitted to giving these quaaludes to women, young women, in order to have sex with them.\u201d\n\nIn the deposition, Mr. Cosby acknowledged that he had drugged another accuser, Therese Serignese, after they met at a Las Vegas hotel in 1976. \u201cI give her quaaludes. We then have sex,\u201d he said in the deposition.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe conviction on Thursday of Mr. Cosby, who was found guilty on three counts of aggravated indecent assault, was immediately viewed by many as a turning point in the #MeToo movement, which would tilt the balance of power and influence in courtrooms for female accusers.\n\nBut Mr. Snyder said, as the broader panel said in its statement, that #MeToo did not weigh on his mind during the two days of deliberations last week at the Montgomery County Courthouse outside Philadelphia. In fact, he said he had not heard of the movement until after he left the courthouse on Thursday and read up on the news coverage of the trial.\n\n\u201cI really only found out about it after I got home,\u201d Mr. Snyder, who also said he had only a vague understanding of Mr. Cosby\u2019s career before the trial, told ABC News. \u201cThen I looked online to see what everything was.\u201d\n\nMr. Snyder said he believed the account of Ms. Constand, who testified on April 13 about the night in 2004 she said she was assaulted at Mr. Cosby\u2019s house. He said he also believed the testimony of five other women who said that Mr. Cosby had drugged and sexually assaulted them.\n\nProsecutors in the case had successfully pushed Judge Steven T. O\u2019Neill to allow the women to speak during the trial, allowing them to add their stories to the account of Ms. Constand. Mr. Cosby had faced only one other accuser in his first trial, which ended last summer in a hung jury. That trial had also presented Mr. Cosby\u2019s deposition.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Snyder said he still would have found Mr. Cosby guilty even if the five women had been barred from testifying in the retrial.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn the deposition, he stated that he gave these drugs to other women,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t think it really necessarily mattered that these other five women were here, because he said it himself, that he used these drugs on other women.\u201d\n\nThe anonymous jury was sequestered at a local hotel during the trial. Judge O\u2019Neill, who has yet to release the names of the men and women who sat on the jury, scheduled a hearing for Tuesday to discuss a request by several news organizations for the identities of the jurors.\n\nAfter the first trial, Judge O\u2019Neill only reluctantly released the names of jurors to the news media after a similar hearing. He ruled that he had had little choice, under a 2007 State Supreme Court ruling.\n\nEven then he sharply limited what jurors were allowed to discuss about the protracted deliberations, leaving them free only to reveal their own views and actions.\n\nMr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers have said the entertainer, 80, will appeal the conviction.\n\nOn Monday, the jurors in their statement were direct in asserting that they had taken great care in their deliberations, and recognized during the discussions the magnitude of what they had been asked to decide.\n\n\u201cEach of us spoke of the weight of our responsibility,\u201d the statement said. \u201cWe understood the consequences to human lives, to an American icon, and to all who are victims and we knew we needed to be comfortable with our decisions in order to be able to sleep at night with clear consciences. Each of us is walking away with that sense of peace, knowing we performed our duty in the manner it deserved.\u201d", "title": "Cosby Jury Says Accuser\u2019s Credibility, Not #MeToo, Led to Guilty Verdict", "authors": ["Graham Bowley", "Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "She later said, in redirect testimony, that there were other numbers she was able to call to reach Mr. Cosby, whom she has accused of drugging and molesting her at his home near here.\n\nThe defense, though, continued to point to the phone records as evidence that Ms. Constand had kept in touch with Mr. Cosby in the following weeks at a level at odds with her account of having been assaulted. They said Ms. Constand had called Mr. Cosby more than 70 times in the weeks following the encounter, including two calls she made to Mr. Cosby on Valentine\u2019s Day that year.\n\nMs. Constand, who was director of operations for the Temple University women\u2019s basketball team at the time, said she was only calling Mr. Cosby on matters of business at the university, where he was a powerful trustee and its best known alumnus. In many cases, she said that she was only returning his calls, perhaps to alert him to a basketball game, and that her contacts were not evidence of any romance.\n\n\u201cI called many people on Valentine\u2019s Day, sir,\u201d she said at one point.\n\n\u201cI called him when he called me,\u201d she added. \u201cI didn\u2019t have a reason to call Mr. Cosby.\u201d\n\nIn the afternoon, Ms. Constand\u2019s mother, Gianna Constand, testified that she did call to confront Mr. Cosby after her daughter told her about being assaulted. Even before that conversation, Ms. Constand said she had noticed her daughter\u2019s distressed state, including twitching and screaming at night, and thought she was both depressed and withdrawn.", "title": "Cosby Team Cites Phone Records as It Tries to Discredit Accuser", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The guilty verdict against Bill Cosby was hailed by some as long overdue.\n\nNot just because his victim, Andrea Constand, first reported that he had sexually assaulted her 13 years ago, but also because, as a lawyer for other Cosby accusers put it, \u201cwomen were finally believed.\u201d\n\nGetting there required surmounting significant obstacles: a victim who waited a year to report the crime and gave two different dates for the attack, a prosecutor who declined to bring the case, a new district attorney who raced against the statute of limitations and, finally, a first trial in which the jury could not agree.\n\nThat was before a series of revelations that caused a seismic shift in public awareness of sexual assault by powerful men. And this is after. But those who know the legal system best say the verdict is not the bellwether that many would like. Criminal convictions in sexual misconduct cases where the victims and the accused knew each other will remain exceedingly hard to get.\n\nNeither Harvey Weinstein, the former Hollywood mogul, nor Russell Simmons, the music producer, has faced criminal charges, despite investigations into allegations against each of them. James Toback, a film director who has been accused by scores of women of sexual misconduct over decades, will likely never face arrest because the statute of limitations has expired.", "title": "Cosby Verdict Is Hailed a Breakthrough. Here\u2019s Why It Was an Anomaly.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI can finally lay down my shield and sword for a while,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m a little weary and feel battered, but right now I\u2019m thrilled.\u201d\n\nThe jury convicted Mr. Cosby of aggravated indecent assault against Ms. Constand, at the time a Temple University employee he had mentored. But during the trial, Ms. Constand became something of a proxy for the many other women who have accused Mr. Cosby of similar sexual misconduct. His first trial ended in a hung jury last June.\n\nPhoto\n\nLili Bernard, who said she was drugged and raped while guest starring on \u201cThe Cosby Show\u201d in the early \u201990s, was ebullient: \u201cI feel like my faith in humanity is restored.\u201d\n\nShe said the verdict was \u201ca victory for all sexual assault survivors, female and male. It\u2019s a victory for womanhood.\u201d\n\nDonna Motsinger, who said Mr. Cosby drugged and assaulted her in 1972, said the verdict felt less a victory for her personally than for Ms. Constand, who has become a close friend.\n\n\u201cIt took one woman, one courageous, tenacious woman, to bring a criminal to justice,\u201d Ms. Motsinger said. \u201cSometimes the justice system doesn\u2019t work. But it worked because of her.\u201d\n\nShe continued: \u201cIt\u2019s not really about me. I didn\u2019t process it for me. I\u2019m still processing that it can still happen. One person can make a difference.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther reaction\n\nPhoto\n\nBounce TV, an Atlanta-based network programmed primarily for African-American audiences and one of the few networks that still showed reruns of \u201cThe Cosby Show,\u201d said on Thursday it would immediately pull the show from its schedule.\n\nIt was the second time Bounce TV agreed to take Mr. Cosby off the air. In July 2015, the network stopped airing reruns after he admitted to drugging women, but started running them again in December 2016.\n\nA spokesman for the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, where Mr. Cosby is featured in a gallery called \u201cTaking the Stage,\u201d declined to comment on whether it would make any changes in light of the verdict. Before the museum\u2019s opening in September 2016, several women who accused Mr. Cosby of sexual assault complained that the museum did not plan to mention their accusations, which the museum later added.\n\nOn Twitter, the National Organization for Women said that \u201cjustice was served today.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is a notice to sexual predators everywhere,\u201d the organization said.\n\nRose McGowan, an actress who has accused Harvey Weinstein of assaulting her and who has been a vocal advocate in the #MeToo movement, celebrated the result on Twitter.\n\nLisa Bloom, a lawyer who "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 A former labor minister and novelist from the governing party was decisively elected president of Costa Rica in a runoff on Sunday, holding off an evangelical Christian singer who had built an upstart campaign in part on his opposition to same-sex marriage.\n\nWith ballots from most polling stations counted, the former minister, Carlos Alvarado Quesada, won three-fifths of the vote, while his opponent, Fabricio Alvarado Mu\u00f1oz, received the rest, according to the federal election authorities.\n\nThe overwhelming victory defied polls in recent weeks that showed the candidates locked in a statistical dead heat or Mr. Alvarado Mu\u00f1oz with a lead.\n\n\u201cCosta Rica once again delivered a beautiful democratic message,\u201d Mr. Alvarado Quesada, 38, told supporters late Sunday night. \u201cWell done, Costa Rica.\u201d He added: \u201cWhat unites us is much greater than what divides us!\u201d", "title": "Costa Rica Election Hands Presidency to Governing Party Stalwart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "San Francisco passed a similar ban in 2014 on the sale of plastic water bottles 21 ounces or smaller in public spaces, including municipal buildings, streets and parks. David Chiu, a Democratic state legislator who championed the ban as president of the city\u2019s board of supervisors, said it has helped change the culture. People now carry around their favorite refillable water bottle. Concerts and festivals set up refillable water stations instead of selling plastic bottles by the caseload. \u201cWhile it was controversial when it was proposed, in hindsight today, it has been a no-brainer,\u201d he said. \u201cI think everyone has adjusted to it.\u201d\n\nThe residents of Concord had gone even further in 2012, when they voted to ban the sale of one-liter or smaller plastic water bottles anywhere within town limits. As an alternative, public drinking fountains and water filling stations have been expanded and upgraded. Though plastic bottles still show up in recycling bins, \u201cIt\u2019s definitely a lot less than you would see in other towns,\u201d said Erin Stevens, Concord\u2019s public information officer.\n\nBottled water sales were also eliminated in some national parks, including the Grand Canyon and Zion, under a 2011 National Park Service policy. But in August, the Trump administration ended that ban following years of opposition by the bottled water industry, which argued that it removed water from the shelves while leaving unhealthy sweetened drinks.\n\nCouncilman Kallos said the Trump decision spurred him to action. He said he has wanted to ban disposable plastic water bottles since trying to buy one himself while visiting San Francisco several years ago and being told he could not. So he bought a reusable bottle to tote around \u2014 something he now does in New York.\n\n\u201cYou see plastic bottles everywhere,\u201d he said. \u201cIt makes New York look like a dump and we can do better.\u201d\n\nThis is not the first time that New York has taken a stand against plastic bottles. In 2008, the office of the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, stopped buying bottled water for Council offices. A 2009 state executive order barred state agencies from buying bottled water, to save taxpayer dollars and improve the environment.\n\nThe city has also targeted other plastic waste. In 2016, the Council sought to encourage shoppers to give up plastic store bags by charging 5 cents for most plastic and shopping bags. But that law was blocked last year by state legislators, some of whom argued that it imposed a regressive tax on the poor, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.", "title": "Could New York City Parks Be Going Plastic Bottle-Free?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Let\u2019s say you volunteer to serve on the board of your New York co-op apartment, and conflicts arise. Legal threats follow.\n\nJust how much personal risk have you taken on?\n\nWhile most boards carry liability insurance for the directors and officers, would it protect you in the event of legal action? Or could you be forced to pay legal fees and suffer damages?\n\nNo one seems to be keeping track of the total number of lawsuits filed against the boards and individual directors of the roughly 6,000 cooperative apartment buildings in New York City. But lawyers say it is extremely common for angry co-op members to file lawsuits and name individual directors \u2014 often as a bullying tactic.\n\nAt the same time, court awards against individual directors are so rare that many co-op lawyers cannot name a single recent example.", "title": "Could You Be Sued as a Co-op Board Member?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Far from helping those left behind by globalization, he argued, the true agenda of leading Brexit supporters is to shrink the state and extend the laissez-faire policies of Margaret Thatcher. He sees the Brexit vote as a protest from areas with legitimate grievances, and says he thinks that concerns about immigration must be addressed.\n\nThere are compelling practical arguments for another referendum, because the 2016 vote was silent on what should replace European Union membership, and those options vary enormously. Since none have a specific democratic mandate, any outcome is likely to be contested for years.\n\nBut it is hard to detect a burning public desire for another vote. Outside a shopping mall here in Salford, the main complaint is not about Europe, but about municipal cost-cutting and reduced garbage collection. (\u201cIf we can get weekly bin collections, we can stay in the European Union,\u201d jokes Mr. Adonis.)\n\nIf it happens, a \u201cpeople\u2019s vote\u201d will result less from popular demand than from a political impasse. Mrs. May has been embarrassed by defeats on amendments to legislation to quit the bloc in the House of Lords, the unelected second chamber of Parliament, and faces crunch votes to overturn them in the House of Commons soon.\n\nThen, when lawmakers vote on any Brexit deal in the fall, the Labour Party will be crucial. Though its left-wing leader, Jeremy Corbyn, is a lifelong Euroskeptic, most of his lawmakers and party members are not, and analysts say they believe he will oppose any deal that Mrs. May strikes, on the pretext that Labour could do better.\n\nSo one strand of the pro-European campaign aims to galvanize Labour Party members \u2014 including young people \u2014 to pressure Mr. Corbyn to resist Brexit. But another is to start engaging with supporters of Brexit in case there is another campaign.\n\nAt an open meeting in Oldham, one of Britain\u2019s most deprived towns, about two dozen people answered a recent invitation from Mr. Adonis to debate Brexit.", "title": "Could the U.K. Vote Again on Brexit? Months later, she married a Muslim man, Shafin Jahan, adding to her father\u2019s resolve to have his daughter placed in his custody, at the family home.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
