Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHadiya, who was born Akhila Asokan and changed her name after converting, said she had converted of her own free will and did not even have a passport that would have enabled her to leave the country to join the Islamic State.\n\nThe high court of Kerala State, where the family lives, annulled the marriage last May, ruling that \u201ca girl aged 24 years is weak and vulnerable, capable of being exploited.\u201d\n\nHadiya, who then returned to her family home, has told activists and the courts that her father beat her and committed her to a yoga center, where she says she was tortured and forced to convert back to Hinduism. Hadiya\u2019s father declined to comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer lawyer, Haris Beeran, said on Tuesday that she was keeping a low profile. Worried about threats from right-wing Hindu nationalists, she filed an affidavit in the courts in February saying that she fears for her life.\n\nHer husband, with whom she has been reunited, is being investigated by India\u2019s National Investigation Agency, a government counterterrorism body, for possible links to radical Islamist groups. His supporters call it a trumped-up charge to derail the couple\u2019s marriage in the courts by making it seem that her conversion was part of a larger jihadist plot.\n\n\u201cThey have been married and forced to live away from each other for the past year, facing harassment from her family and the N.I.A.,\u201d Mr. Beeran said in a telephone interview.\n\n\u201cThey are relieved\u201d after the court\u2019s verdict, he said.\n\nSecular activists hope the ruling will help protect future interfaith relationships and religious conversions, though some worry that India\u2019s rule of law is too weak to prevent future such cases from arising.\n\nHindu nationalists vowed to continue trying to prevent interfaith relationships.\n\n\u201cLove jihad is a reality,\u201d said Rakesh Sinha, who is referred to as an \u201cideologue\u201d of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, a right-wing group widely seen as the parent organization of the B.J.P. \u201cA lot of organizations lure Hindu girls in the name of marriage.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cintention is to destabilize the Indian society by initiating conversions,\u201d he added.", "title": "Couple Can Reunite in \u2018Love Jihad\u2019 Case, India\u2019s Supreme Court Rules", "authors": ["Maria Abi-Habib", "Suhasini Raj"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Courtney Anne Walker and Dr. Bobby Allen Garcia were married April 14 in San Juan Capistrano, Calif. Her mother is a clinical consultant pharmacist working with PharmScript.\n\nThe groom, 33, is a fellow in female pelvic medicine and reconstructive surgery at Louisiana State University in New Orleans. He graduated from Yale and received a medical degree from the University of Texas Southwestern.", "title": "Courtney Walker, Bobby Garcia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Agreement did not give Ms. Lee approval rights over the script of the Play, much less did it give her a right to purport to edit individual lines of dialogue,\u201d he argued in the lawsuit. \u201cIt certainly did not give such rights to Ms. Carter, who is not an author, editor, literary agent or critic, and has no known expertise whatsoever in theater or writing.\u201d\n\nMs. Carter emerged as a polarizing figure in the final years of Ms. Lee\u2019s life, as a debate raged over whether or not Ms. Lee had authorized the publication of her second novel, \u201cGo Set a Watchman,\u201d which she had written in the 1950s and had abandoned. Ms. Carter initially said she stumbled upon the manuscript in a safe deposit box in 2014, but a conflicting account suggested the novel had been discovered years earlier.\n\nIn a statement Monday, Ms. Carter said, \u201cAs the personal representative of the Estate of Nelle Harper Lee, I must protect the integrity of her beloved American classic, and therefore had no choice but to file a lawsuit against Rudinplay for failing to honor its contract with Ms. Lee. It is my duty and privilege to defend the terms of Ms. Lee\u2019s agreement with Rudinplay, and I am determined to do so.\u201d\n\nBut, in his lawsuit, Mr. Rudin questioned Ms. Carter\u2019s status as a representative of Ms. Lee\u2019s will and for the first time accused Ms. Carter of having an ulterior motive in challenging the play: a desire to force the cancellation of the Broadway production because of a separate dispute between Ms. Lee\u2019s estate and the heirs of Gregory Peck, who played Atticus Finch in the movie adaptation, over stage rights.\n\nWhile a local theater group in Ms. Lee\u2019s hometown Monroeville, Ala., has staged a production based on the novel annually for nearly three decades, there has never been a Broadway adaptation of \u201cMockingbird,\u201d one of the most beloved novels in American literature. In the lawsuit, Mr. Rudin suggests he already intends to postpone the new production, writing that the legal dispute \u201chas rendered it impossible for the play to premiere as scheduled in December, 2018, and unless this dispute is resolved in the immediate future, the play will be canceled.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Rudin said he was willing to take the unusual step of performing the play in a courtroom so a jury could determine whether or not the production is true to the spirit of the novel. \u201cA play and a book are two different things. A book is meant to be read; a play is meant to be performed,\u201d he said.", "title": "Courtroom Drama: Producer Offers to Stage Disputed \u2018Mockingbird\u2019 for Judge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts to restrict immigration and increase deportations of undocumented immigrants began days after he took office when he signed the first temporary ban on travel from several mostly Muslim countries.\n\nThat ban was imposed with no notice and little discussion among federal agencies. A flurry of court rulings blocking the ban led Mr. Trump to abandon it in favor of a second version, which was also blocked by courts.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t until the president\u2019s third attempt that he found some legal success. While lower-court judges again sought to block the restrictions, the Supreme Court let the ban go into effect while it considered the case. And on Wednesday, the justices appeared inclined to uphold the president\u2019s action, given his powers over immigration and national security, and to discount his campaign promises to impose a \u201cMuslim ban.\u201d\n\nThe president has also been fighting a legal battle over his decision to end the DACA program, which President Barack Obama put in place in 2012. The program allows young immigrants who were brought illegally to the United States as children to live and work without the fear of deportation.\n\nAbout 700,000 immigrants signed up for the program, which requires them to renew every two years.\n\nAs a candidate and as president, Mr. Trump said DACA was an unconstitutional abuse of presidential power and vowed to end it. In September, he followed through, saying he would end the program by March and was acting on behalf of \u201cthe millions of Americans victimized by this unfair system.\u201d\n\nCourts intervened to save the program much the same way judges had blocked Mr. Trump\u2019s actions on the travel ban. Within weeks of the March deadline, judges ordered the president to continue renewing participation in the program for those who had already enrolled.\n\nOn Tuesday, Judge John D. Bates of Federal District Court for the District of Columbia went one step further, saying that government officials must also allow new applicants to sign up for protections offered by DACA.", "title": "Courts Give Trump a Possible Path Through a Legal Minefield on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Nonetheless, Mr. Pruitt still has champions, particularly among a far-right cadre who deny the established science of human-caused climate change and see Mr. Pruitt as the best hope of undoing the government\u2019s policies to curb fossil fuel pollution.\n\nSo when he was summoned to testify before two House committees on Thursday, it was viewed as a make-or-break moment. If, in the course of the expected four to six hours of questioning, he stumbled badly, creating an \u201coops moment\u201d that would be broadcast on the Fox News programs that his boss watches, it could signal the end of his tenure.\n\nIn the days leading up to the hearings, I spent a lot of time in the Capitol, stopping Republicans in the halls to ask about their views of Mr. Pruitt. It seemed that Mr. Pruitt\u2019s stock among the G.O.P. was dropping fast. While lawmakers typically close ranks around one of their own, rank-and-file Republicans told me that there were \u201clegitimate concerns\u201d about him, and that his ethical lapses are \u201ctroublesome.\u201d The Republican strategist John Feehery put it more bluntly: \u201cPruitt has made a lot of people very angry.\u201d Perhaps most remarkable was the exchange I had with Senator James Inhofe of Oklahoma, Mr. Pruitt\u2019s longtime political patron, who said he, too, now believed that there should be an investigation into the ethics of his prot\u00e9g\u00e9.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Mr. Pruitt walked briskly into the hearing room wearing a red tie and a smile. As the questioning began, I was most interested in what Republicans would do: Would they come after one of their own with pointed lines of inquiry that put Mr. Pruitt on the spot? Such a break in party unity would be remarkable, but Representative Greg Walden, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, had assured me just days before, \u201cHe\u2019s got some tough questions to answer.\u201d\n\nHowever, I\u2019ve now covered Mr. Pruitt\u2019s congressional testimony several times, so I\u2019m familiar with his style. For all the controversy and criticism swirling around him, he always manages to deliver a calculatedly calm, low-wattage performance. He deflects, defuses and never loses his temper. At the center of the red-hot controversy is a beige career lawyer, who is a master of the bland non-answer. It\u2019s a tactic that enrages his Democratic opponents, but also ensured that he emerged from previous congressional grillings battered but unbroken.", "title": "Covering Scott Pruitt, Beige Career Lawyer and Master of the Non-Answer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "In a strange way, that is kind of comforting for us Danes. We are not very likely to get killed at all, and in particular not by a random stranger. (Murderers and victims are usually related through either family or gangs.) Danish society is one of the world\u2019s safest, most tranquil \u2014 some would say boring \u2014 societies, and when we are warned about dangerous city districts or about shoot-first-ask-questions-later-police officers, it\u2019s always abroad.\n\nIn the days after Ms. Wall\u2019s death, I asked female colleagues for their thoughts because I sensed many of them saw this as more than just another news story. Generally, there is no gender difference in how stories are perceived here. There are roughly as many women who are reporters, journalists, editors and international correspondents in Danish media as there are men, and they are at least as prominent. In asking them I found that Ms. Wall\u2019s killing struck at the core of the sense of trust that is the fabric of our society.\n\n\u201cShe was doing \u2014 brilliantly \u2014 exactly what we as women in our society have been taught that we can do. Which is anything a man can do, and better, if you\u2019re smarter,\u201d said Lotte Folke Kaarsholm, a TV anchor. Classic Scandinavian feminism, she explained, involves \u201ca thinking that says that we\u2019re actually all the same, we\u2019re all equal, and the fact that you\u2019re a woman should never stop you from becoming anything you want to become \u2014 such as, for instance, a fearless reporter.\u201d\n\nAs the case unfolded I realized that the fearless female reporters around me took a hit from Ms. Wall\u2019s death. They were used to keeping their guards up on assignments in more volatile, less egalitarian societies. But at home, in Scandinavia, they knew that they were safe and could enjoy high levels of trust even between strangers.\n\nPeter Madsen\u2019s world of snuff porn and premeditation revealed a new kind of danger. In the court\u2019s verdict on Wednesday, the judges noted that Ms. Wall had walked into a trap set up for any random woman with the right amount of curiosity and trust. In the days before the murder, Mr. Madsen had searched online for images of mutilated women \u2014 and had also invited three other women to join him on his submarine. Among them were women who had randomly walked by the vessel and taken an interest in him and his projects. All three declined.\n\nThe fourth he asked, Ms. Wall, said yes in spite of being busy hosting a going-away party. She was moving to China a few days later, but she wanted the interview for a story. As the prosecutor said, in one of the most chilling remarks of the case: Her death could have been anyone\u2019s.", "title": "Covering the Murder Case That Shook Denmark", "authors": ["Martin Selsoe Sorensen"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Dez Bryant, the Dallas Cowboys\u2019 fiery star receiver, was released on Friday.\n\n\u201cThis was not an easy decision,\u201d the team\u2019s owner, Jerry Jones, said in a statement with few specifics. \u201cIt was made based upon doing what we believe is in the best interest of the Dallas Cowboys.\n\n\u201cUltimately, we determined it was time to go in a new direction.\u201d\n\nBryant, 29, is a passionate player known for highlight-reel catches. Forever Dallas in my heart.\u201d", "title": "Cowboys Release Receiver Dez Bryant", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cRoster of Stars Lets Live Nation Flex Ticket Muscles, Rivals Say\u201d (front page, April 2):\n\nThe Obama administration was warned repeatedly that allowing the nation\u2019s largest concert promoter to merge with its largest ticket provider would midwife an octopus that would strangle competition and squeeze consumers. Bipartisan coalitions of which I was a part practically begged regulators to halt the merger, to no avail.\n\nLive Nation and Ticketmaster\u2019s abuse of their monopoly power should be taken as a warning in the halls of the Justice Department. For too long, administrations of both parties have been lax in their approaches to antitrust enforcement. Americans are paying the price, as monopolies now sit atop industries across the nation.\n\nAfter decades of indifference to the impact of monopolies, the government must begin to act against concentrated power.\n\nBILL PASCRELL JR., PATERSON, N.J.\n\nThe writer is a Democratic congressman from New Jersey.", "title": "Opinion | Crack Down on Monopolies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "But the tax cut is having its biggest impact with small craft distillers, most of which turn out less than 100,000 gallons a year and struggle to compete with larger companies. And it is evidence of their growing political clout as distilling becomes a significant source of jobs and tax revenue in every state.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe backing for the move attested to that geographical and political reach. By the time the amendment \u2014 introduced by a bipartisan group of lawmakers from Minnesota, Missouri, Oregon and Wisconsin \u2014 was adopted in a final version by Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, it had collected 304 co-sponsors in the House and 56 in the Senate.\n\n\u201cThis is a tremendous change from where we were in the past, fighting tax increases,\u201d said Frank Coleman, a senior vice president of the Distilled Spirits Council, a trade association representing American producers and marketers. \u201cUp until recently, the efforts on taxes at the federal level were entirely defensive.\u201d\n\nThe victory was not achieved without a great deal of legwork. Dozens of distillers joined in a multiyear effort to win over Congress members to the idea. The Distilled Spirits Council estimated it organized thousands of visits to the Hill.\n\n\u201cWe encouraged our members small and large to invite their local officials at all levels of government to take a tour,\u201d Mr. Coleman said. \u201cMany have done so, in the process learning about how spirits are made, how they fit into the agricultural economy.\u201d\n\nIn two visits to Washington, Christian Krogstad, the founder of House Spirits, spoke with several lawmakers during appointments and what he called \u201cdrop-ins.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was surprised by how accessible senators and congressmen are,\u201d he said.\n\nThe bill brings federal taxes on spirits into line with those for the wine and beer businesses, which won similar reductions. To achieve that, the three industries \u2014 normally rivals \u2014 combined their lobbying forces.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis was an unprecedented collaboration by spirits, wine and beer producers,\u201d said Mark Gorman, a senior vice president of the Distilled Spirits Council.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn response, New York Distilling Company, in Brooklyn, has done something just as unusual: lowering prices.\n\nAllen Katz, a founder, wanted to get Perry\u2019s Tot, its \u201cNavy strength\u201d gin, into more bars and consumers\u2019 homes. The tax cut allowed him to reduce the wholesale price, per bottle, to $18 from $29. With by-the-case discounts, the wholesale price drops further, to $14, and some merchants have cut retail prices to as low as $23.\n\n\u201cI would say the reaction from our industry peers has been jaw-dropping,\u201d Mr. Katz said. \u201c \u2018You\u2019re offering it at what price?\u2019 \u201d In March, sales of Perry\u2019s Tot doubled. (The company has also hired its first full-time salesman.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. We dutifully pack our tote bags with high hopes for rhubarb and strawberries, asparagus and tender field greens, only to find piles of last year\u2019s cellared roots and apples \u2014 the same ones that were there months ago and will continue to be there for a few more weeks.\n\nIt\u2019s in these weeks that citrus is a saving grace. A bright note under a cover of clouds \u2014 a big bowl full of grapefruit, Cara Cara oranges, lemons and limes \u2014 is enough to tide over even the most seasonally affected souls.\n\nThis lemon olive oil ice cream is a taste of sunshine, even as a chill often hangs in the air. It\u2019s sweet and creamy from the dairy and eggs, tart from lemon zest and juice, and a little savory, from a glug of olive oil and a bit more salt than you might be used to in your ice cream.\n\nServe it with even more olive oil, flaky salt and a shower of finely grated lemon zest while you wait for the weather to turn. If you are somewhere a little sunnier, where the spring bounty has arrived, a few sliced strawberries wouldn\u2019t be out of place on top.\n\nRecipe: Lemon Olive Oil Ice Cream\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Try This.", "authors": ["Yossy Arefi"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "MONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Happy Monday! This puzzle has a feature that teaches a good lesson in puzzle solving. You may, in your cruciverbal travels, rely on familiar paths when you slowly fill in a completely bonkers entry. A lot of letters just don\u2019t go together, and their dissonance is a clue that you\u2019ve made a misstep. A word beginning with FZG? Ending in GCU? That\u2019s part of the process of elimination that helps you solve.\n\nBut as you progress, you\u2019ll find that constructors love a red herring \u2014 an unusual pairing or a triple combination that can make solvers scratch their heads or go astray. That\u2019s because constructors are usually sadists, but I digress.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nToday\u2019s theme pertains to a skinny little vowel that we all need to stand on our own, but isn\u2019t in team, and hardly ever spends time in its own company, unless you\u2019re talking about a Shinto religious gate or going on a lake vacation.\n\nTo what could I be referring?\n\nThere are four theme clues, at 17A, 24A, 37A and 52A, that have something in common. It\u2019s hinted to at 62A, \u201cAsset for a public speaker,\u201d which, true enough, is EYE CONTACT.", "title": "Creative Start", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "For nearly a decade, Doug Taylor, a sales manager who travels often for work, has signed credit card receipts with a doodle of a dog wagging its tail.\n\nNo cashier has ever rejected his \u201csignature\u201d as invalid.\n\n\u201cIt gets a laugh, most of the time,\u201d said Mr. Taylor, 44, who lives in Mobile, Ala. \u201cOr they just glance at it and don\u2019t really notice.\u201d\n\nCredit card networks are finally ready to concede what has been obvious to shoppers and merchants for years: Signatures are not a useful way to prove someone\u2019s identity. Later this month, four of the largest networks \u2014 American Express, Discover, Mastercard and Visa \u2014 will stop requiring them to complete card transactions.\n\nThe signature, a centuries-old way of verifying identity, is rapidly going extinct. Personal checks are anachronisms. Pen-and-ink letters are scarce. When credit card signatures disappear, handwritten authentications will be relegated to a few special circumstances: sealing a giant transaction like a house purchase, or getting a celebrity to autograph a piece of memorabilia \u2014 and even that is being supplanted by the cellphone selfie.", "title": "Credit Card Signatures Are About to Become Extinct in the U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Are you creeped out by the idea of a company checking a job candidate\u2019s credit history before deciding whether to hire her or him? Your answer could be tied to your political views.\n\nA new poll on surveillance from the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania found that Americans are deeply divided over tracking, both online and in real life. And political affiliation is a main predictor of Americans\u2019 emotional reactions to surveillance, the researchers found.\n\nAmong people who identified themselves as Democrats, for instance, 62 percent said they felt \u201ccreeped out\u201d by the idea of companies checking job applicants\u2019 credit history before hiring them. By contrast, half of independents and just 29 percent of Republicans felt creeped out.\n\n\u201cThe Republicans are most likely to be positive about surveillance,\u201d said Joseph Turow, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania and the lead author of the study. \u201cThe Democrats are most likely to be negative, and independents are always in the middle.\u201d", "title": "Creepy or Not? We are not responsible for the well-being of the people of Gaza.\n\nIn the years after our disengagement, billions of dollars in aid poured into the Gaza Strip. Instead of improving the lives of Palestinians, Hamas, internationally recognized as a terrorist group, misappropriated these funds, using them to build rockets and to dig terror tunnels with the intent of harming Israeli civilians.\n\nSecond, the restrictions that exist on Gaza are not the cause of the situation there but rather a result of Hamas\u2019s refusal to renounce violence. We took comfort in the unshakable belief that our highest office was bigger than any one person, that its underlying principles were greater than the mistakes of omission or commission of any temporary holder, our structure stronger than any errors committed on one person\u2019s watch.\n\nBut that understanding has been shaken to the core. President Trump has made us question the fundamental belief of the greatness of the office of the presidency. And beyond all else, this we can never forgive.\n\nROBERT S. NUSSBAUM, FORT LEE, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFirms Shudder as Trump\u2019s Tweets Mean Business\u201d (front page, April 4):\n\nShouldn\u2019t our president be promoting American business in general, not denigrating specific companies? Just one more example of insensitivity at the White House.", "title": "Opinion | Critiques of Trump, on Many Fronts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cOver 700 Children Taken From Parents at Border\u201d (front page, April 21):\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security\u2019s practice of removing children from their parents upon crossing our borders is nothing short of horrifying. It is hard to imagine the mind-set that would sanction and pursue such a cruel and psychologically misguided policy.\n\nChildren are dependent on their parents to help them manage and make sense of their world and deal with childhood anxieties. It would be terrifying for both the child and the parent to be abruptly separated from each other. Many prominent psychologists have written about the critical importance of this early dependent relationship and how disrupting it can seriously impair the child\u2019s ability to develop into a healthy, well-functioning person.\n\nFailures in this area speak to a failure in our humanity. And they will inevitably give rise to a generation of individuals with severe psychological damage, which they will bring to the societies in which they live.\n\nJUDITH FELTON, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is a psychoanalyst and president of the Contemporary Freudian Society.", "title": "Opinion | Cruelty at the Border: Separating Children From Parents", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Those economic reforms? Some have failed to materialize, while the most successful \u2014 the issuing of licenses to start small businesses \u2014 has all but stalled as the state deliberates how to move forward. The rapprochement with the United States? President Trump all but torpedoed it, at least in tone. Even the island\u2019s historic escape valves \u2014 visas and undocumented migration to the United States \u2014 have been turned off.\n\nIn the most recent blow, the United States Embassy in Havana vastly reduced its staff and stopped issuing visas to Cubans after dozens of its personnel were mysteriously sickened in what the State Department has described as attacks of unknown origin.\n\nThat happened after the immigration pipeline of Cubans trying to reach the United States had already been abruptly squeezed by the Obama administration. Before leaving office, President Barack Obama put an end to the longstanding policy known as wet-foot-dry-foot, which allowed Cubans who made it to American soil or border crossings without a visa to stay in the United States.\n\nNow the Trump administration\u2019s decision to shut down many of the functions of the Havana embassy is making it even harder for Cubans to head north.\n\nWithout an operating consular office, Cubans had to travel to Colombia earlier this year to even apply for their visas, a costly endeavor considering that their average salaries amount to about $1 a day. Today, that pipeline has been blocked, too. Visa issuance for Cubans hoping to visit their families in the United States is now being done from Guyana.\n\n\u201cThere are thousands of parents who have children in the U.S. and who are not going to be able to visit them,\u201d said one Cuban doctor, who spoke on condition of anonymity because she and her partner are trying to leave the country without permission. \u201cWith Obama, there was a big step forward because relations were reestablished. And now just because of Trump\u2019s whim, things have become worse than ever.\u201d\n\nIt is still unclear exactly how Mr. Trump\u2019s promised reversal of Obama administration policies will play out over the long haul. Some American visitors to Cuba say they did not take any measures to come to the island that were not already in place following the opening of relations between the two nations.", "title": "Cubans Doubt a Change at the Top Will Bring Change at the Bottom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "They know that not having a Castro atop the Cuban government is a significant occasion. But, with Mr. Castro still heading the island\u2019s all-powerful Communist Party, they fear that the ascension of Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel will merely result in more of the same.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a moment in history,\u201d said Tom\u00e1s Regalado, 70, a former Miami mayor who hosts a daily Spanish-language radio show. \u201cBut it\u2019s not a historical change.\u201d\n\nJournalists from Argentina, Colombia and Spain have called to interview him on the handoff of power, he said. \u201cAnd I\u2019ve answered: \u2018What handoff?\u2019\u201d\n\nFor years, exiles clung to hopes that they might someday be able to return to Cuba. Once Fidel is gone, they thought. But the elder Mr. Castro relinquished power to his younger brother 12 years ago. When he died in 2016, Miami erupted in joyous street celebrations. By then, however, it had long become clear that the revolution would continue to outlive both its leader and its fiercest critics.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m 80 years old, and this has hit me pretty hard,\u201d said Esteban Bovo Caras, a Bay of Pigs veteran who said he was too depressed to attend Tuesday\u2019s ceremony and reunite with his friends. \u201cIt\u2019s sad. I thought there would be a revolution against the Castros. But nothing has happened. They\u2019re so entrenched. And Cubans are going to have to keep suffering.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think the fight has been lost, because there will always be someone who will do something,\u201d he added. \u201cBut I feel sad, upset, to see how the situation continues, and there\u2019s no way out, and the free world turns its back on it. They could not care less.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nWhile his children also worry about Cuba, he said, they have built their lives here. \u201cIt\u2019s a generational shift,\u201d he said. \u201cMy grandchildren are more into baseball, soccer and all the nonsense in this country. The battle horses are hanging up their sabers.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAndy Gomez, the former interim director of the Institute for Cuban and Cuban-American Studies at the University of Miami, blamed \u201cCuba fatigue\u201d for the relative apathy among Cubans in the United States surrounding Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel\u2019s ascension. When Fidel Castro died, he was inundated with media inquiries for days. This time around, he has fielded maybe 15 calls, and no one asks if a major change is underway.\n\n\u201cThe Cuban community has moved from a politics of passion to a politics of realism,\u201d Dr. Gomez said. \u201cHow many of us are going to go back?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJorge L. Piedra, president of the Cuban American Bar Association, which helps independent lawyers on the island, said Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel\u2019s ascension had been met with \u201ca sense of helplessness\u201d by many Cuban-Americans who otherwise care deeply about Cuba policy.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know whether it\u2019s the state of politics and everything that\u2019s going on at home and in Washington that has kind of distracted everyone, but I certainly don\u2019t feel that it\u2019s getting the attention that I would have expected for such a major event,\u201d Mr. Piedra, 48, said.\n\nPatrick Hidalgo, 39, an entrepreneur who was director of the White House Business Council under President Barack Obama, suggested that some Cuban-Americans born in the United States are more concerned with what\u2019s happening here than with Cuba\u2019s future under a new president who is unlikely to veer from Ra\u00fal Castro\u2019s hard line.\n\n\u201cThe problems in the U.S. are so significant that that\u2019s what we\u2019re more focused on. It affects our daily lives \u2014 health care, education, lack of jobs, lack of rising wages, authoritarian tendencies under our own leadership,\u201d he said.\n\nAt the Bay of Pigs ceremony, Victoria Armengol Gempton, 34, helped her two children, Emma, 6, and Charles, 3, lay flowers on the monument to the fallen. Four generations of her family \u2014 starting with Ms. Gempton\u2019s grandmother, Myrna Mill\u00e1n, whose husband, Pepe, died in the invasion \u2014 continued the tradition of attending, as they did when Ms. Gempton was a child.\n\n\u201cI want my kids to know what it\u2019s like to fight for freedom,\u201d she said.\n\nBrigade 2506 veterans greeted friends they had not seen in months or years, sometimes commenting on each other\u2019s appearance and health. The priest who used to lead their Mass has developed Alzheimer\u2019s and cannot deliver it anymore, said Felix Rodriguez, 77, cane in hand as he sat in a plastic white chair to protect his frail back.\n\nMr. Rodriguez dismissed questions about the importance of Mr. Castro\u2019s succession, calling Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel\u2019s selection political window-dressing.\n\n\u201cWe know that absolutely nothing is going to change. It\u2019s going to be exactly the same,\u201d said Mr. Rodriguez, a former C.I.A. agent who helped capture the Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara in Bolivia in 1967.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Communist Party controls Cuba. Ra\u00fal Castro has put up a figurehead. The only time when there might possibly be a change is the day Ra\u00fal dies.\u201d", "title": "Cubans in Florida Have Waited to See Castros Go, but No One Is Celebrating", "authors": ["Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "If the bill were to pass, New York would join California, which approved a statewide ban of plastic bags in 2016. Hawaii has a de facto ban on plastic bags; all of its counties have instituted bans.\n\nBut the measure faces an uncertain path in the Legislature, where leaders of the Assembly and the Senate had opposed the city\u2019s bill. A spokesman for Carl E. Heastie, the Assembly speaker, said the Assembly had been generally supportive of a ban but not a fee.\n\n\u201cThe speaker supports banning unnecessary plastic waste, and we will review this proposal,\u201d said the spokesman, Michael Whyland.\n\nThe measure would very likely face a stiffer challenge in the Senate, which is run by Republicans. A Senate spokesman had no immediate comment.\n\nState Senator Simcha Felder, a Brooklyn Democrat who says he holds no party loyalty and who sits with the G.O.P., was one of the staunchest opponents of the 5-cent city fee, saying it would unfairly burden low-income consumers, like many of those who shop at bodegas and grocery stores in his district. On Monday, Mr. Felder said that he had not had time to review the Cuomo bill but that his opposition had to do with fees and taxes, not a ban per se.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cuomo\u2019s opposition to the city measure was similarly centered on the fee structure; he said at the time that the bill was \u201cdeeply flawed\u201d because it allowed merchants to keep the 5-cent fee as profit, a giveaway that he said would total $100 million a year.\n\nBrad Lander, Democrat of Brooklyn, the councilman who led the city\u2019s effort to impose a 5-cent fee, called Mr. Cuomo\u2019s proposal a transparent political maneuver.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI wish I believed the governor was serious about reducing the billions of single-use plastic bags New Yorkers are sending to landfills every year, but this looks like election-year, Earth Day politics,\u201d Mr. Lander said.\n\nSusan Brockmann, one of hundreds of demonstrators who filled the State Capitol on Monday to rally for stronger environmental protections, said that New York should emulate California.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s time,\u201d said Ms. Brockmann, 55, a midwife from Long Island who was dressed in a suit made of 500 plastic bags. \u201cWe should follow the lead of other progressive communities.\u201d\n\nMonday\u2019s proposal came as a result of a report in January by a task force that Mr. Cuomo convened last year after blocking the city bill. A ban was one of eight options entertained by that report, though it also outlined a number of drawbacks, including the fact that paper bags, an alternative to plastic, cost retailers \u201cthree to five times as much as single-use plastic bags.\u201d\n\nUnder Mr. Cuomo\u2019s proposal, a variety of bags would be exempted from the ban, including those that contains raw meat, fish or poultry; bags sold in bulk; those used in bulk packages of fruit and dried goods; those used for deli products; newspaper bags; trash, food storage and garment bags; and takeout food bags. The state\u2019s Department of Environmental Conservation would also be allowed to exempt certain bags through regulations.\n\nAt an environmental rally held hours before the governor\u2019s announcement, Ms. Nixon called Mr. Cuomo\u2019s environmental record \u201clacking\u201d and wore a T-shirt with the words \u201cStop CPV,\u201d a reference to Competitive Power Ventures, a Maryland-based power company at the heart of the recent corruption trial of one of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s former top aides, Joseph Percoco.\n\nMs. Nixon told reporters that her candidacy seemed to have inspired the governor to veer left on a number of issues on which he had previously equivocated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere certainly seems to be, in the last month, a number of issues on which Governor Cuomo has reversed himself rather startlingly,\u201d she said.\n\nRichard Azzopardi, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, said that the unveiling of the bill was related to the completion of work of the commission and its experts, not Ms. Nixon\u2019s candidacy.\n\n\u201cThe timing is governed by the facts and the process,\u201d he said.", "title": "Cuomo Announces Bill to Ban Plastic Bags in New York State", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley", "Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. de Blasio was conspicuously absent Monday as Mr. Cuomo signed the order on a crowded indoor basketball court in the Johnson Houses in East Harlem, flanked by other city officials who have criticized the mayor\u2019s management of Nycha.\n\n\u201cDelivering money to Nycha is like throwing it out the window,\u201d Mr. Cuomo told reporters after the signing. \u201cI\u2019m not going to hand over money to an entity that can\u2019t spend the money \u2014 that was the entire point.\u201d\n\nThe declaration appoints an independent monitor that will oversee how Nycha spends the $250 million the state appropriated to the agency in the budget signed this weekend. The monitor will also oversee $350 million the state has pledged in previous years but has not released to the agency, as well as any unspent money appropriated by the city.\n\n\u201cIt is very important that that money not get caught up in any bureaucracy,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said.\n\nMayor de Blasio, during his weekly interview on NY1 Monday evening, said he feared the order would create \u201ca whole lot of bureaucracy.\u201d Now, he added, the governor is responsible for giving Nycha half a billion dollars.\n\nThe independent monitor would have broad powers over Nycha and could make changes to its management, a state official said. But the monitor\u2019s primary task would be to expedite repairs to problems like broken boilers, mold and lead paint, which pose a threat to public health.\n\nAccording to the order, the independent monitor must be appointed within the next 60 days and will be chosen by the mayor, the City Council speaker and the president of the Citywide Council of Presidents, a group of tenant leaders chosen by Nycha residents, which sued the agency in February.\n\nThe monitor would then have 30 days to select a private contractor for repairs, and certain procurement rules would be waived to speed along projects. Nycha would have no say in the selection of contractors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Cuomo\u2019s order was unsparing in its critique, asserting \u201cthe conditions of habitability at Nycha-managed residential properties constitute a public nuisance affecting the security of life and health in the City of New York\u201d and that a \u201cdisaster is imminent for which the affected local government is unable to respond adequately.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe governor\u2019s visit to the Johnson Houses was his fourth visit to a public housing complex since March 12. He made the announcement on the same spot where, three years ago, Mr. de Blasio and Shola Olatoye, the agency\u2019s embattled chairwoman, unveiled NextGen Nycha, the administration\u2019s ambitious plan to reverse the agency\u2019s shortfalls.\n\nSeveral city officials who have been reliable antagonists of the mayor joined Mr. Cuomo and praised his decision, including Scott M. Stringer, the city comptroller, and Councilman Ritchie Torres, as well as those seeking to assert independence from him, like Corey Johnson, the council speaker, and Letitia James, the public advocate.\n\nAfter the governor\u2019s announcement, the mayor and the governor spoke, by phone, for the first time in more than two weeks, according to City Hall. City Hall was not given a copy of the emergency order before the governor signed it.\n\nCity officials had told the state Nycha intended to use the $250 million in new aid to replace \u201c63 poorly rated boilers\u201d in 14 housing developments, but it was unclear if the monitor would take those priorities into consideration.\n\nMr. Cuomo\u2019s announcement comes roughly two weeks after the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development told the city\u2019s housing authority that it would no longer be able to draw federal funds without approval, placing the authority on a so-called \u201czero threshold.\u201d\n\nThat development came after months of back-and-forth between agencies, stemming from the revelation that Nycha had been filing false paperwork to the federal government related to lead-paint inspections. The failures were part of what the housing department called a \u201cfraud investigation\u201d into Nycha by the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.\n\nThose allegations led to a public outcry and calls for Ms. Olatoye\u2019s resignation, but Mr. de Blasio has stood by the chairwoman\u2019s side.\n\nThe city has been negotiating with federal prosecutors for months but has yet to reach a settlement. Mayor de Blasio has said the negotiations could result in a federal monitor for the Housing Authority. Last year, the federal housing department warned of penalties if Nycha did not reach a settlement with the United States attorney, or come up with a health and safety plan to address concerns over lead paint and other issues with the physical state its apartments and buildings. Those deadlines passed last month.\n\n\u201cAs a consequence of its failure to produce this corrective plan, H.U.D. will now review and approve all expenditures from Nycha\u2019s Capital Fund,\u201d the department said in a statement.", "title": "Cuomo Creates Monitor to Oversee Repairs to City\u2019s Public Housing", "authors": ["Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed", "J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "But when they took their places alongside the governor for the signing, most of the city elected officials had not been given a copy of the emergency order. Now, they are scrambling to decipher how the executive order might affect the city\u2019s finances and how the city will fund repairs to the largest public housing system in the country.\n\nThe order by Mr. Cuomo was an unprecedented intervention in the agency\u2019s 84-year history, one the governor had been hinting at for days before, as he escalated his criticism of the agency\u2019s performance under Mr. de Blasio \u2014 the latest clash in the fractured relationship between governor and mayor.\n\nAt a news conference two days later, Mr. de Blasio voiced his frustration. \u201cI don\u2019t see how you write an executive order like this without having a consultative process with the city,\u201d he said. Last week Mr. de Blasio said he \u201cdid not expect the hits from Albany to be as bad as they ended up being\u201d and that Nycha would \u201chave a serious price tag attached\u201d in this year\u2019s budget.\n\nBefore the governor\u2019s mandate, the city had no legal obligation to fund Nycha, according to experts and city officials. The housing authority, like other public authorities in New York, is a state-chartered entity, though the mayor appoints its seven-member board. Its budget is not part of the city\u2019s budget, and it relies primarily on dwindling federal subsidies and on rental payments from the system\u2019s 176,000 units.\n\nIn recent years, the city has nonetheless chosen to voluntarily fund Nycha in response to the authority\u2019s growing deficit, investing $3.7 billion in the agency since Mr. de Blasio took office, city officials said.", "title": "Cuomo Order on Public Housing May Carry Big Costs for City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The pardon would not expunge a felon\u2019s record nor would it restore other rights stripped from them, such as the right to serve on a jury. Mr. Azzopardi called the executive order a \u201cnarrow use of power.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo\u2019s plan would bring New York in line with 18 other states, as well as Washington, D.C., that allow parolees to vote, according to the governor\u2019s office. Fourteen states automatically restore felons\u2019 rights when they are paroled; two never remove them in the first place; and two \u2014 Iowa and Virginia \u2014 also use executive orders to issue pardons.\n\nCivil-rights advocates hailed Mr. Cuomo\u2019s decision as a long overdue step toward helping former inmates re-enter society.\n\n\u201cIf we want to give people the opportunity to successfully live in our communities, we want to give them the opportunity to vote and be stakeholders,\u201d Myrna P\u00e9rez, director of the Voting Rights and Elections Project at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University, said.\n\nBut Donna Lieberman, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, cautioned that the state still had \u201ca lot of work to do before we can call ourselves a paragon of democracy,\u201d noting ongoing political gerrymandering and other stalled efforts to enact electoral reform.\n\nSome of the signature accomplishments of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s two terms in office have centered around criminal justice reform. In 2015, he issued an executive order appointing a special prosecutor to investigate police-related civilian deaths, and last year he signed \u201cRaise the Age\u201d legislation that ended the practice of treating 16- and 17-year-old defendants as adults in criminal court. New York had been one of two states that still tried juveniles as adults.\n\nThis year, Mr. Cuomo proposed ending cash bail for low-level offenses, a measure that was not included in the final state budget. The governor has also pushed for voting reform, including the introduction of early voting and same-day registration, neither of which was taken up by the Legislature, and neither of which he has the power to enact via executive order.", "title": "Cuomo Plans to Restore Voting Rights to Paroled Felons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cuomo was asked twice on Thursday at a news conference about that specific \u201close my number\u201d phrase. Who the unions should support or not support, that\u2019s up to the unions. Nobody is going to tell them what to do.\u201d\n\nCouncil members mostly described the pressure from Mr. Cuomo\u2019s team as respectful. Most received calls on Wednesday, a day before the rally.\n\n\u201cThis was a campaign person who said, \u2018We want to make sure you know what\u2019s going on,\u2019 \u201d one Council member said. \u201cIt was all obviously \u2018don\u2019t go,\u2019 but they did not say to me, \u2018Do not show up.\u2019 \u201d\n\n\u201cImplicit in that was an ask not to go,\u201d the member said.\n\nAnother member said an aide to Mr. Cuomo offered \u201cvarious levels of 'you shouldn\u2019t go' and 'this will be noted.\u2019 \u201d\n\nCarlos Menchaca, a Brooklyn councilman who attended the rally, said the governor\u2019s office reached out to him to see if he would be going, and Mr. Menchaca viewed it as an attempt to exert pressure.\n\n\u201cI got a text message.
