David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ahead of the party\u2019s vote, Ms. Nixon and Mr. Cuomo \u2014 either personally or through their emissaries \u2014 have been trying to seal up support.\n\nMs. Nixon appealed to state committee members in a roughly hourlong conference call on Wednesday evening, including taking questions ahead of the weekend gathering, according to committee members who were on the call. She has made outreach to the party, which has its own ballot line in New York elections, an early priority.\n\n\u201cCertainly anybody running in the Democratic Party should seek the support of the Working Families Party,\u201d Ms. Nixon said in a brief phone interview earlier this month.\n\nPowerful labor allies of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s are pushing to fill vacant slots on the party\u2019s central committee to tilt the governing body in the governor\u2019s favor \u2014 and threatening to withdraw from the party entirely if they fail and Ms. Nixon wins the endorsement.\n\n\u201cThere is a number of vacancies in the party and we want to run people in those vacancies so we can have the full participation of labor,\u201d said Hector Figueroa, the president of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, a key labor union in the party that supports Mr. Cuomo.\n\nMr. Figueroa said he hoped Working Families would at least remain neutral. \u201cMaybe stay out of it,\u201d he said.\n\nAsked if that stance suggested he was worried that the party was edging toward Ms. Nixon, Mr. Figueroa said yes. \u201cIt\u2019s a fair characterization that I am concerned the party will go in that direction,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis week, Ms. Nixon has rolled out endorsements of progressive groups with close ties to the Working Families Party, including Citizen Action of New York and New York Communities for Change. The respective leaders of both those groups, Karen Scharff and Jonathan Westin, hold leadership posts on the executive board of the W.F.P. and are seen as holding sway over a bloc of committee member votes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a sign of the overlap, both are also on the board of the Alliance for Quality Education (Ms. Scharff serves as chairwoman), an education group. Ms. Nixon was once a spokeswoman for the group, and it organized her first event in Albany. Its executive director, Billy Easton, is a key early backer of her campaign and is also a W.F.P. committee member.\n\nIn the brief phone interview, Ms. Nixon would not commit to staying on the Working Families ballot line through November, if she does not win the Democratic Party\u2019s nomination. \u201cI appreciate you asking that question,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m not going to answer that question.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat would be a risk for the Working Families Party, too. If its nominee does not win at least 50,000 votes in the general election, it would lose its guaranteed spot on the ballot in races across the state.\n\nHer campaign declined to comment for this story.\n\nFour years ago, the fight for the Working Families nomination was among the most contentious moments in the contest between Mr. Cuomo and his primary challenger, Zephyr Teachout. Mr. Cuomo ended up winning the party\u2019s backing, with the help of Mayor Bill de Blasio. The governor recorded a tape \u2014 now known widely as the \u201chostage video\u201d \u2014 making a series of promises that included helping Democrats win back the State Senate, a vow many activists felt he quickly reneged upon.\n\nBruised egos and raw feelings still remain from that episode.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s going to be much harder for the Cuomo faction to seduce us this year,\u201d said Sandy Oxford, a Working Families committee member. In 2014, she said she arrived as a supporter of Ms. Teachout but flipped to Mr. Cuomo after his concessions.\n\nThere was other fallout. Some labor unions allied with Mr. Cuomo withdrew from Working Families because of the process.\n\n\u201cThe other unions left because they felt the way the party asserted itself in selecting the governor as a candidate was not giving good consideration to the unions,\u201d Mr. Figueroa said. As for the possibility of his own union quitting this year if Ms. Nixon wins the endorsement, he said, \u201cThat\u2019s a decision that we have to make internally, whether we are going to decide to leave the party or not.\u201d\n\nEven before Ms. Nixon had emerged as a possible challenger, top aides to Mr. Cuomo, including his executive secretary, Melissa DeRosa, had begun reaching out to W.F.P. state committee members in February for a series of listening sessions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was pretty clear what we were all doing in the room and why,\u201d said Blair Goodman, a state committee member who attended one such meeting in Kingston. \u201cI suspect it\u2019s sunk in to someone, perhaps Ms. DeRosa or some other senior staff, that we have a state committee and we do as our conscience guides us.\u201d\n\nAttendees of the sessions said one of the top priorities expressed was to unite Democrats in the State Senate, where a breakaway group of eight lawmakers formed the Independent Democratic Conference and worked more closely with the Republican majority for the last seven years.\n\nAfter Mr. Cuomo did help broker such a deal, resulting in the reunification of the Democrats and the dissolution of the I.D.C. earlier this month, he called Bill Lipton, the state director of the W.F.P., to describe its details, according to people familiar with the call.\n\n\u201cAfter years of discord the New York State Democratic Party is completely unified, and with Donald Trump in the White House, the stakes have never been higher,\u201d Sarah Paden, a senior adviser to Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign, said in an email. \u201cThe governor is 100 percent focused on maintaining that unity and taking back the House and the State Senate this year.\u201d\n\nMs. Paden added: \u201cThe W.F.P. situation could now replicate a new \u2018I.D.C.\u2019 dynamic, dividing Democrats to the benefit of Republicans. A fight between labor unions representing the interests of working people and a third-party ballot line is not something we are interested in engaging.\u201d", "title": "Cuomo and Nixon Confront First Test: Wooing Working Families Party", "authors": ["Shane Goldmacher"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "A Marist College poll last week had better news for the governor, showing him with a 47-point lead over Ms. Nixon, though the margin narrowed when pollsters asked those who were \u201chighly enthusiastic\u201d to participate in a Democratic primary, which typically draws the most ardent and energized voters.\n\nThe governor could take reassurance in other details of the Siena poll, including a 3-to-1 lead in New York City \u2014 where the largest batch of Democratic primary voters reside \u2014 and a 30-point lead in New York City\u2019s suburbs. He does better with female voters than male, and best among self-described moderates.\n\nBut the race is much closer upstate \u2014 with the governor leading by 48-37 \u2014 despite the governor\u2019s repeated assertions that he has done more than any other governor to revive the economy. Ms. Nixon also does well against Mr. Cuomo with younger voters, aged 18 to 34, trailing the incumbent by 14 points in that demographic.\n\nThe poll also showed that Mr. Cuomo would easily defeat two Republican candidates \u2014 Senator John DeFrancisco and Marc Molinaro, the Dutchess County executive \u2014 by margins similar to what he currently holds over Ms. Nixon. The two Republicans, neither of whom are well known, are in a dead heat among voters, with each receiving 18 percent.\n\nThe poll, conducted from April 8 to 12, surveyed 692 registered voters in New York State, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4.3 percentage points.", "title": "Cuomo\u2019s Lead Over Nixon Slightly Narrows in 2018 Election Poll", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "I have some help with travel arrangements from The Times (and data scientists from Kayak, the travel aggregation site, who crafted an initial itinerary for me), so that\u2019s taken a burden off. I try to make sure I have three days of activities in a place, and a full day of writing, plus two mornings for editing and fact-checking. That isn\u2019t always possible so I\u2019m often squeezing writing and social media into whatever spare moment I have.\n\nI have two sacred times for myself: a weekly therapy call (this job is stressful!) and dinner. I\u2019m willing to pull an all-nighter as long as I can have an hour of eating good food and sipping wine very slowly.\n\nMost important, if I\u2019m somewhere incredibly beautiful, I pause to take a mental image and be grateful. Who knows when I\u2019ll be back to any of these places. That\u2019s precious time, too, and I don\u2019t want to waste it.\n\nPacking for the journey\n\nQ. How has your fast traveling pace streamlined your packing or the perception of what you \u201cneed\u201d? - Shelley Steingraeber\n\nGlad you asked, because I think about packing constantly! I\u2019ll go over more of this in a separate packing article to come, but I\u2019ve sent back maybe four shipments of stuff and the majority has been clothes. Cute dresses, cute shoes, cute jacket \u2014 all of it is gone.\n\nWhat I\u2019ve needed are items (mostly black) that can act as a uniform, layers to keep me warm, fast-drying underwear and a bra that won\u2019t dig into me on the plane. Toiletries, I\u2019m still carting around too many. I also joke that half the weight of my bag is tampons, but those aren\u2019t going anywhere.\n\nFavorite meals\n\nQ. What country or place has your favorite typical breakfast, and what did you eat for breakfast there? - Elise Evans\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nQ. What\u2019s the best thing you\u2019ve eaten? \u2014 Juliana Baldo Walker via Facebook\n\nI\u2019m combining these two because all roads in food satisfaction lead to Bogot\u00e1, Colombia. I would eat every meal I had there a million times over.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Click Clack Hotel, where I stayed for a few nights, had hands down the best breakfast of the trip. Nothing crazy, just omelets done well, strong coffee and platters of exotic fruits.\n\nI also went to the Plaza 7 de Agosto market and got this insane fruit cocktail called a salpic\u00f3n, which is mango, papaya, banana and watermelon bathed in a pur\u00e9e of papaya and watermelon. Also, arepas de choclo at brunch (sweet corn cakes with cheese) \u2014 yum. The best of the bunch was the lulada, a drink made out of lulo, a tart fruit that grows in Colombia and Ecuador. Eat it with a spoon, die of happiness.\n\n(For future breakfasts, I\u2019m looking forward to France and Italy, always, and China. Love egg and tomato and any breakfast foods with a kick of soy sauce.)\n\nSurprises along the way\n\nQ. What has been a surprising discovery for you at any of your locations so far? An unexpected turn of events, a detour, a random act of kindness? - Shelley Steingraeber\n\nWhen I think of surprises, San Juan, Puerto Rico, is the first that comes to mind. I was eager to go there to see the Hurricane Maria damage for myself, and also to see if there was a way that, in writing about it, I could help out somehow. The hotel stock was so depleted that I was still scrambling to find a room when my plane took off. (I ended up booking an Airbnb, but just barely.)\n\nSo I was pretty stressed out when I got there. But the first thing I encountered was a bunch of women dancing around and singing by baggage claim. And through that encounter, I met everyone I hung out with on that trip. People were dealing with so much trauma and loss and yet I was welcomed into homes, onto farms, at parties.\n\nI hope everyone gets a chance to experience the warmth of Puerto Rico as I did.\n\nHealth and sanity\n\nQ. How are you keeping yourself healthy and sane during the many hours of alone time? - Sara Brenneis\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe healthy part, I\u2019m not sure I\u2019m succeeding at. So. Many. Carbs! So. Little. Exercise.\n\nMy mind, I have a better handle on. I\u2019ve cried a few times, and felt quite overwhelmed, but that\u2019s what phone calls to my therapist in New York City are for.\n\nI\u2019d like to tell you I\u2019m finally watching \u201cBreaking Bad,\u201d but mostly I unwind with TV shows that don\u2019t require much thinking (\u201cThe Bachelor,\u201d \u201cQueer Eye,\u201d the entire first season of \u201cThe Good Doctor\u201d). Phone-a-friend is always a good option. I have a few folks on Instagram \u2014 and folks I\u2019ve met while traveling \u2014 who have become pen pals.\n\nAnd a friend encouraged me to talk into voice memos as a feelings diary, which I did a ton while driving hours by myself on dirt roads in Chile. Essentially, my iPhone is my Wilson.\n\nTraveling alone, as a woman\n\nQ. I realize that solo female travel is becoming a much more common thing. Have you encountered any discrimination, uncomfortable sexualized situations, or barriers due to being a solo woman on the road? - Elise Evans\n\nI definitely encountered tons of uncomfortable sexualized situations when I was in my late teens and 20s and traveling solo. Either I\u2019m getting too old to get hit on or sadly, I\u2019ve gotten used to it. So far, nothing overt has happened, other than some construction workers in Chile relentlessly asking about my marital status. I let it slide because it just didn\u2019t seem worth the energy expenditure.\n\nQ. What would you recommend to young women solo travelers who love off-the-beaten-path destinations and enjoying night life, but still want to remain cautious and safe? - Livia Halltari\n\nWhen you say \u201cyoung,\u201d I\u2019m assuming you mean young enough to handle slightly rugged lodging. I\u2019d stay in hostels. They have a community around them, and you can form a buddy system with other solo female travelers. Hotels make it harder to have those kinds of interactions.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen you\u2019re out, keep yourself on a two-drink regimen, for your sake and your buddy\u2019s, be mindful of being slipped drugs, and always have the club or restaurant call you a taxi home, unless you\u2019re ride-sharing and feel O.K. with that.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout off-the-path destinations, I think the safest thing you can do is always make sure someone knows where you are: the innkeeper, plus a parent or a close friend who will know to sound the alarm if you go off the grid for too long.\n\nSafety is a huge concern for women (and often people of color and other minority groups), and I\u2019m not sure everyone gets that. Trust your gut and be as cautious as you feel like you need to be, even if people make fun of you.\n\nThe worst trouble I\u2019ve gotten into while traveling has been when I\u2019ve tried to act like a local. Hang out with locals, but remember you\u2019re always a potential target.\n\nAnd try to have fun. It\u2019s possible, I promise!\n\nQ. What has been the easiest and hardest thing, specifically about solo travel, as a woman? - Ashley Zari\n\nHardest: Definitely safety concerns. There\u2019s a patina of anxiety that coats me every time I go out in an urban environment \u2014 especially since I\u2019m doing so much work with a phone and a camera that are ripe for getting snatched. It\u2019s infinitely better to walk around with someone else, not just for the warmth of companionship, but also to have the chance to relax into my environment a bit.\n\nEasiest: Not having to compromise and be on anyone else\u2019s schedule (except for my editor\u2019s). That probably says something about why I\u2019m still single!\n\nAdvice for older women\n\nQ. What advice do you give for an older woman (healthy, but 70), traveling alone? - Alyn Caulk\n\nHi Alyn, if you are the older woman in question, I say mazel! Happy to have a fellow adventuress on the road.\n\nTour groups and activities like cooking classes are great ways to make friends while maintaining the independence of traveling alone. Europe by bicycle is my favorite way to see the countryside, and all the trips I\u2019ve taken have included active seniors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis time around, I\u2019ve hired private guides for wilderness hikes, both for the company and a fail-safe should anything go wrong.\n\nAlso, say hi to the 30- and 40-somethings you meet. Chances are we think you\u2019re very cool.\n\nTraveling as a woman of color\n\nQ. Can you write about what it\u2019s like to travel alone as a woman, and even more so, what it\u2019s like for a person of color perhaps? Many articles and blogs I find of solo female travel are white women, and I think their privilege plays into a lot of their experiences, especially positive ones on the road.\n\nAs an Asian woman who blends in easily in many eastern and Southeast Asian countries and has traveled to many of them, I always worry about how I\u2019m perceived and treated by locals. - Emily L\n\nHi Emily! I\u2019m half Chinese, but I don\u2019t read as \u201cAsian\u201d in China, so I can\u2019t speak to your experience of being able to blend. Chinese people can spot the pale, not-so-skinny American in me right away. I have, however, seen my dad encounter confusion and surprise that he doesn\u2019t speak the language. He\u2019s a scientist and is antisocial (sorry, Dad, it\u2019s true!), so he mostly runs off, which seems like a fine enough policy to me.\n\nThe phenomenon of young white women writing about travel being easy doesn\u2019t seem as noticeable to me as young white men doing it. As you\u2019ve seen, a good deal of the questions here are women asking about safety while traveling solo. It\u2019s a pervasive concern and every time I don\u2019t see it mentioned in another writer\u2019s article, I feel a bit of a disconnect \u2014 as I\u2019m sure some people from other backgrounds feel while reading my work.\n\nPhoto\n\nI, for one, would love to experience what it\u2019s like to pass as an Asian local, to not be immediately marked as a tourist, to fly under the radar and observe subcultures unnoticed. Think of it as a blessing. Maybe you\u2019ll get some weird looks when people figure things out, but by that time, you\u2019ll be at an underground karaoke party.\n\nThe bigger issue here seems to be that you aren\u2019t finding writing out there that jibes with your experience. It sounds like you want to change that. I\u2019d definitely be a reader.\n\nFriendly spots for singles\n\nQ. As a single person who would love to make these stops someday, I would be curious to learn which places are single traveler friendly. Not just in terms of safety, but places where you can walk into a bar or hotel, or roam a beach or village, and random people would want to be your friend, chat with you, and even invite you to dine with them. - ND\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWell, I\u2019m glad you\u2019re not asking about the dating scene, because I\u2019ve sadly had no time for that!\n\nAny kind of resort destination, for me, has been the hardest as a single person. I felt pretty out of place at Disney Springs, which is made for families, couples, and gaggles of friends drinking around the world at Epcot. Peninsula Papagayo in Costa Rica, San Jos\u00e9 del Cabo in Mexico, and even where I\u2019m staying now in Rogue River, Ore., all seem geared toward couples vacations.\n\nThe easiest time I\u2019ve had making friends was on the adventure travel circuit of Chile, or any time I\u2019ve taken a tour. Activities are bonding; you\u2019ll likely find other single folks with similar interests. And the line, \u201cHey, so I\u2019m traveling the world by myself, where are you from?\u201d seems to work wonders at starting conversations.\n\nLanguage barriers\n\nQ. How have you been able to overcome language barriers? \u2014 Lorene Lynn, writing from Utqiagvik, Alaska, via Instagram\n\nSo far I\u2019ve been lucky in that the only language I\u2019ve been required to speak, other than English, has been Spanish. I\u2019m pretty rusty, but it\u2019s a language I started studying in first grade, as a requirement of New Mexico public schools \u2014 and I improved a lot over the course of my travels in Latin America. I\u2019ll be O.K. in places with French and Italian, too.\n\nMost places, I\u2019ve befriended native speakers who know English and have been happy to volunteer as interpreters.\n\nIn my first instance of trying to talk to someone who spoke zero English, we spoke into Google Translate on my phone.\n\nDangerous locations\n\nQ. Is this trip going to bring you into any overt danger? \u2014 Michael Erard via Twitter\n\nNot that I know of, but political situations around the world change all the time, and quickly. I was vacationing in Delhi when the 2008 Mumbai attacks happened, and I was visiting a friend during several bombings in Kabul over Thanksgiving in 2012. Danger is real, but I\u2019ve got a pretty great support network at The Times to help me keep an eye on it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018The essence of a place\u2019\n\nQ. Do you think you really can glean the essence of a place by spending at most just a week there? - Ben\n\nDefinitely not. But the word \u201cessence\u201d is interesting here. If we think of it as the diffuse aroma of a perfume, perhaps a scent you remember deep in your brain, then it may be possible.\n\nI\u2019ve been thinking a lot about the job of a travel writer and I agree with my colleague Lucas Peterson, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, that it may be to simply encourage the idea of travel as a good thing in the world.\n\nSo if I can give you, the reader, a detail to hang onto or tell a story that compels you travel to that place, or travel anywhere, then I\u2019ve done my job.", "title": "Cute Shoes Are Useless, and Other Lessons From Three Months Traveling the World", "authors": ["Jada Yuan"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Once upon a time the Gagosian Gallery produced museum-quality shows at an unmatched rate \u2014 at least once a year. Then it seemed to cede this role to the well-oiled machine that is David Zwirner\u2019s gallery.\n\nBut now Gagosian is back, with \u201cCy Twombly: In Beauty It Is Finished: Drawings 1951-2008,\u201d a ravishing, revelatory and compressed overview of this great postwar career that more than makes up for lost time. Comprising over 90 drawings, collages and the occasional painting on paper at the West 21st Street gallery, this concentrated presentation spans over five decades and gives Twombly\u2019s art a new pace and immediacy. No matter how well we may think we understand his achievement, it introduces an artist we haven\u2019t quite seen before.\n\nThe show has been selected and organized by Mark Francis of Gagosian, with the help of Nicola Del Roscio from the Cy Twombly Foundation; its title is from a Navajo night chant that Twombly used in the title of a voluptuous unbound book of 36 paintings on paper (1983-2002) in the final gallery here. The exhibition, celebrating the publication of the eighth and final volume of the catalogue raisonn\u00e9 of his drawings, coincides with a presentation of his \u201cCoronation of Sesostris,\u201d a 10-part painting from 2000 at Gagosian\u2019s Madison Avenue gallery, in commemoration of what would have been his 90 birthday on April 25.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nThe gathering of works in Chelsea reconfigures the general sense of Twombly (1928-2011) as a lanky, slow-moving, ever-relaxed Southerner who worked in fits and starts and soaked up the good life on Italy\u2019s Amalfi Coast or in Lexington, Va. \u2014 his birthplace, to which he returned in his later years. In its stead is a man driven by an almost demonic energy, who never stopped pushing and testing his aesthetic engine, drawing, making it ever bigger and more encompassing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nParaphrasing Shakespeare, this show could be said to ask, \u201cWhat\u2019s in a line?\u201d Everything: drawing, painting, language from vulgate to Olympian, mathematics, pictographs, architecture, writing in tongues, the body, the war between the sexes, myth and history, and nature, especially the sea.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nThe show is densely installed and has an immersive feeling that becomes oceanic as the rhythms of Twombly\u2019s hand expand. It begins with a startling vitrine of 39 drawings, which are being exhibited for the first time: tiny scraps mounted on index cards made in 1951. They show a range of quasi-abstract motifs resembling trees, fences, rows of flowers and \u2014 strangely \u2014 little sketches for Wiener Werkstatte broaches. They are about as precise as Twombly gets; the motif turns shambling in four larger oil paint drawings nearby.", "title": "Cy Twombly, Redefined by His Drawings", "authors": ["Roberta Smith"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "The attack\u2019s target appears to have been Latitude Technologies, a Texas-based provider of electronic data-sharing between pipeline companies and their gas producer and utility customers. The company handles the critical computer communications of gas storage facilities, as well as sales contracts and shipment scheduling.\n\nChris Bronk, a cybersecurity expert at the University of Houston, said such attacks on the gas marketing communications hub is a way to gather intelligence on the entire gas industry.\n\n\u201cIf I compromise their operations, I can see all the buyers and sellers,\u201d he said. \u201cIf I can persistently be in their network I can issue fake transactions.\u201d In that way, Mr. Bronk added, hackers could potentially jumble gas shipments, and even cause electricity production outages.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLatitude Technologies, a unit of Energy Services Group, declined to discuss the disruption in detail. In a statement, it said, \u201cWe do not believe any customer data was compromised.\u201d\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was investigating the attack, and no suspect has been publicly identified. But the attack came shortly after the department and the F.B.I. issued a report alleging that Russia was taking aim at the electric grid and other critical infrastructure with cyber probes.\n\nThe House Committee on Science, Space and Technology released a staff report this month that described Russian efforts to influence American energy markets and energy policy through inflammatory posts on social media. The motivation for such efforts appeared to be the increase in exports of liquefied natural gas from the United States, a challenge to Russian dominance in European markets.\n\nCybercriminals, frequently suspected of working for foreign governments, have been increasingly active in the energy sector in recent years. Last fall, hackers penetrated safety systems of a petrochemical plant in Saudi Arabia, the latest in a spate of increasingly sophisticated attacks on the kingdom\u2019s energy infrastructure. An attack on Ukraine\u2019s grid in 2015 led to extensive blackouts.\n\nAmerican gas pipeline companies were targeted in 2012, although the damage was believed to have been limited. Employees of several pipeline companies have been targets of spear-phishing attacks \u2014 efforts to lure them to click on email attachments containing malicious code.\n\nThe Trump administration has announced that it is establishing an office within the Department of Energy to shore up cybersecurity for critical infrastructure like nuclear plants, refineries and pipelines.", "title": "Cyberattack Shows Vulnerability of Gas Pipeline Network", "authors": ["Clifford Krauss"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "One of the people pushing him has been Cynthia Nixon. She has worked for years with the Alliance for Quality Education, a progressive public school advocacy group backed by the teacher\u2019s union. She first got involved with the organization when Mayor Michael Bloomberg proposed cutting public school budgets in the early 2000s. She enjoyed her first political arrest outside City Hall in 2002 and has been an unflagging advocate of public education since, with a focus on combating segregation.\n\nShe\u2019s taking a similar approach to her campaign. Ms. Nixon declared her candidacy in Brownsville, one of Brooklyn\u2019s poorest neighborhoods. She has called for legalizing marijuana, single-payer health care and, citing Mr. Sanders, raising taxes on the rich.\n\nMs. Nixon has also built on the areas where the Sanders campaign fell short: She has made a point to address racism directly, especially when it comes to housing and educational disparities. She has talked about Mr. Cuomo\u2019s sexism \u2014 he invented the bogus Women\u2019s Equality Party during the last election but has refused to push for legislation that would guarantee New Yorkers the right to an abortion if Roe v. Wade is overturned.\n\nMs. Nixon\u2019s critics say that her appeal will be only in New York City, but there\u2019s good reason to think she will find support elsewhere. In Brownsville, she cited \u201cthe tyranny of landlords.\u201d That\u2019s not just an issue in Brooklyn: Places like Syracuse face severe housing crises, and homelessness statewide has grown around 40 percent under Mr. Cuomo as of 2016. Similarly, while much of Ms. Nixon\u2019s public education activism has been based in the city, the issue is a hot one across the state.\n\nThis week, the Working Families Party endorsed Ms. Nixon, refusing to once again be bullied by the governor. That\u2019s a great start. Every other progressive organization in the state should get behind her, too, from criminal justice advocates to labor unions. She faces an uphill battle against Mr. Cuomo\u2019s $30 million in campaign funding, but she\u2019s gaining in the polls.\n\nAnd Ms. Nixon\u2019s is only one name on a slate of reformers, including the candidate for lieutenant governor, Jumaane Williams, a City Council member from Brooklyn with grass-roots support, who has government experience that Ms. Nixon lacks. Across the state, new left-wing candidates are standing up to save New York from Cuomo-style centrism. This is the kind of coalition that working people need to win more power, and it\u2019s the kind of slate commentators always declare impossible \u2014 rural and urban, multiracial, feminist, unified against the influence of the 1 percent. Not only could it move the Statehouse to the left. It can show the rest of the country how to win.", "title": "Opinion | Cynthia Nixon Can Save the Democrats (From Themselves)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "So far, running for a third term as governor of New York has been a little harder than Andrew Cuomo expected.\n\nGovernor Cuomo has a huge lead in the polls, a $30 million war chest and a political operation that can put the fear of God into the toughest foes. But in recent weeks, when he might have hoped to begin striding toward the White House, the governor has instead had to endure the indignity of a primary challenge, and that from a woman who had the audacity to seek the Democratic nomination without any political experience. Even worse, she was familiar to millions of New Yorkers for playing a lawyer on the TV show \u201cSex and the City\u201d who slew scores of professional adversaries without wrinkling her pantsuit. Now, his challenger is taking on the role of liberal hero, at Mr. Cuomo\u2019s expense.\n\nThe governor has real progressive accomplishments to point to. He successfully pushed to legalize same-sex marriage, extending basic rights to millions. He secured one of the toughest gun safety laws in the country, astonishing even his supporters by expanding the state\u2019s assault weapons ban in a matter of weeks after a gunman killed 20 children and six adults at a school in Newtown, Conn. He helped thousands of families in New York City and elsewhere in the state secure free prekindergarten, a triumph.\n\nIs everyone showing gratitude? No, they\u2019re talking about that celebrity challenger, Cynthia Nixon.\n\nJust weeks into the race, Ms. Nixon has already stolen the endorsement of the state leadership of the Working Families Party, a coveted seal of liberal approval. Worse, she\u2019s been attracting all the Democratic attention, basking in the glow of glossy magazine spreads, promising to legalize marijuana and blaming him for the city\u2019s crumbling public housing. (Hello, it\u2019s Mayor Bill de Blasio\u2019s fault! O.K., maybe along with the federal government.)", "title": "Opinion | Cynthia Nixon Gets Cuomo to Play to Type", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement to The New York Times, Ms. Nixon also suggested that she would seek to mitigate the effects of past criminalization.\n\n\u201cEnding the injustice of putting New Yorkers in prison for marijuana is a start,\u201d she said. \u201cBut we also have to correct past injustices, by expunging prior convictions \u2014 particularly for nonviolent offenders whose only convictions are for marijuana use.\u201d\n\nWhile her candidacy has attracted attention across New York and the country \u2014 Ms. Nixon, an actress, is best known for starring in the television show \u201cSex and the City\u201d \u2014 polls suggest that she faces a steep climb in her challenge to Mr. Cuomo, a second-term incumbent with $30 million in campaign funds. In a Siena College poll last month, 66 percent of Democratic voters said they would support Mr. Cuomo in a primary, compared to 19 percent who chose Ms. Nixon; among African-American voters, 77 percent backed Mr. Cuomo.\n\nBruce Gyory, a Democratic political consultant who is not working on either campaign, said Ms. Nixon\u2019s selection of legalization as her first policy issue and her emphasis on racial inequities in marijuana arrests reflected her recognition of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s bulwark of support among African-American voters.\n\n\u201cBy pushing for this, it not only helps her connect to younger minority voters but younger progressive voters. But the question is, will it be a motivator to vote?\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a very interesting issue choice \u2014 I\u2019m not saying it\u2019s crazy \u2014 but I don\u2019t know that it will on its own do the trick.\u201d\n\nIn 2014, when Zephyr Teachout, a little-known Fordham Law professor, challenged Mr. Cuomo for the Democratic nomination, she captured one-third of ballots in the primary \u2014 but failed to win a foothold among minority voters.\n\nMr. Gyory said Ms. Nixon, who, like Ms. Teachout, has positioned herself as a strong progressive alternative to Mr. Cuomo\u2019s centrism, would face a similarly uphill battle.\n\n\u201cThe holy grail of New York politics has been the notion that white progressives can win a majority of minority voters,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd there have been very few who have been successful in that.\u201d", "title": "Cynthia Nixon Puts Legalizing Marijuana Front and Center of Campaign", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "What would you say is harder: appearing in two concurrent Broadway shows when you were a full-time college student, or running for governor of New York State when most people know you only from \u201cSex and the City\u201d? I think that running for office has pieces of stuff that I\u2019ve done before, like interacting with and collaborating with people, trying to get the word out about the thing that you\u2019re doing and trying to get people interested in it. But in politics, when people come after you, they really come after you.\n\nChristine Quinn, former speaker of the New York City Council, called you an \u201cunqualified lesbian,\u201d though she later apologized. Christine was speaking for herself, but she was also speaking on behalf of Andrew Cuomo. No matter who\u2019s saying it, it all comes from him.\n\nAt a time when people are increasingly dissatisfied with a certain famous person holding office, why do you think you\u2019re qualified? I\u2019ve been a political activist since I was a teenager. Donald Trump may be the epitome of the problem, but not because of his celebrity \u2014 because of his desire to reward the wealthy and corporations.\n\nIs it your belief that no career politician could fix Albany? I think they could go in and start. But no one stops to say: \u201cWe\u2019re one of the most progressive states in the country. We\u2019re two-to-one Democratic. Why haven\u2019t we enacted campaign-finance reform or criminal-justice reform? Why do we have the second-most-unequal schools in the country? Why haven\u2019t we legalized marijuana?\u201d", "title": "Cynthia Nixon Wants to Legalize It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis has been a rough week for the W.F.P.,\u201d Mr. Lipton told the crowd on Saturday afternoon at the Albany Hilton.\n\nAnother leader, Karen Scharff, the party\u2019s co-chairwoman, expressed \u201cthe greatest respect\u201d for the two unions that had dropped out on Friday \u2014 Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union and Communications Workers of America District 1.\n\n\u201cIt saddens me to see them step away at this moment,\u201d Ms. Scharff said, adding, \u201cI\u2019m confident that we will work together in the future.\u201d\n\nBut it was also apparent that the tactics of Mr. Cuomo \u2014 who had a fraught relationship with the party, dating to his ultimately successful struggle in 2014 to get its nomination \u2014 and his allies had seemingly only hardened the consensus around Ms. Nixon.\n\n\u201cTo endorse Cynthia Nixon is a very, very brave thing to do,\u201d said Zephyr Teachout, who herself ran a spirited primary challenge to Mr. Cuomo in 2014, and is now working with Ms. Nixon\u2019s campaign, adding that the governor\u2019s actions to undermine the Working Families Party in recent days had been \u201chorrifying.\u201d\n\n\u201cBehind every bully,\u201d she said, \u201cthere\u2019s a coward.\u201d\n\nOn Friday evening, after the union pullout, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign had said he would not seek the endorsement or the formal nomination of the Working Families Party, which will be finalized at its convention next month.\n\nAnd after the party\u2019s vote, Abbey Fashouer, a spokeswoman for Mr. Cuomo, defended the governor\u2019s record \u2014 citing an increase in the minimum wage, a paid family leave program and billions in funding for education.", "title": "Cynthia Nixon, Battling Cuomo, Wins Endorsement of Progressive Die-Hards", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Drug Enforcement Administration is investigating a former agent who was previously stationed in Colombia for misconduct, an American law enforcement official said on Friday.\n\nThe former agent, Jose Irizarry, abruptly quit his position at the D.E.A. and is suspected of passing information to Colombian drug traffickers, according to BuzzFeed News, which first reported the investigation.\n\n\u201cThe matter remains ongoing within the D.E.A. disciplinary system, and we cannot comment at this time,\u201d said Melvin Patterson, an agency spokesman.\n\nThe allegations against Mr. Irizarry could make it more difficult for United States law enforcement officials to earn the trust of confidential informants in the shadowy world of drug trafficking. In some Latin American countries like Colombia, where cartels rule with force, cooperating with law enforcement almost certainly spells a death sentence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInformants are a critical tool for United States law enforcement officials working to untangle transnational drug trafficking. But their ability to protect those informants has come under scrutiny in recent years.", "title": "D.E.A. Is Investigating a Former Agent on Misconduct Allegations", "authors": ["Ali Watkins"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "It was a two-alarm blaze that left Mr. Fass, who uses a wheelchair, inhaling smoke for several minutes until the movers rushed in and carried him out.\n\n\u201cI could have been roast D.J.,\u201d said Mr. Fass. \u201cHave you ever heard the Warren Zevon song \u2018I was in the House When the House Burned Down?\u2019\u201d\n\nAnd so the \u201cUnnameable\u201d radio host now faces an unknowable future.\n\nEven in adversity, though, Mr. Fass, whose show airs Thursday nights at midnight, can be counted on for a pithy take on things. His improvisational monologues and his mix of guests and music helped pioneer free-form radio, and his show was a vital forum for activists, musicians, and everyday people to come together around issues including the Vietnam War, drugs and social justice.\n\nAfter the fire, with nowhere else to stay, the Fasses returned to their empty house on Lake Avenue on Staten Island, near the Bayonne Bridge, where they live with their 10 or so adopted feral cats.\n\nA single couch now serves as their shared bed as they sort out their future. Most of their belongings either remain in storage or were damaged by the fire.\n\nThe bulk of Mr. Fass\u2019s radio archive was recently acquired by Columbia University, with payment for the acquisition going toward the new house, he said.\n\nBut numerous boxes of radio recordings that Columbia had not acquired were damaged in the fire, Mr. Fass said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of history in there,\u201d said Mr. Fass, who is no stranger to dealing with tumultuous events: His show became both a communications and coverage hub for Yippie events, the 1963 March on Washington, the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago and the 1988 Tompkins Square Park riot.\n\nHis callers have ranged from Black Panthers to John Lennon to ordinary New Yorkers. One of Mr. Dylan\u2019s first broadcast appearances was on Radio Unnameable. The Yippie movement leader Abbie Hoffman was a regular guest, as were Hunter S. Thompson, Allen Ginsberg and Timothy Leary.\n\nThe Danbury house fire occurred just before the Fasses were set to close on both the sale of the Staten Island house and the purchase of the Danbury home. So the fate and details of both transactions are in limbo, he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Fasses said they signed an agreement with the developer buying their house stipulating that they vacate by the original move-out date last month or face daily monetary penalties.\n\nA lawyer for the buyer did not respond to messages.\n\nEven if they had the money to rent a place, it might be hard to find a landlord who would welcome a colony of cats, said Mr. Fass, who had already taken two of the cats to the Danbury house. During the fire, one of them, Plutarch, escaped and remained missing for several weeks, until Ms. Fass found him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Fass recently completed a three-month hospital stay and is recovering from heart problems. The smoke inhalation from the fire has added a chronic cough to his health concerns.\n\nMr. Fass, a native of Brooklyn who lived for decades in Manhattan, moved to Staten Island 25 years ago, but said he had grown weary of the increasing truck traffic at a warehouse across the street.\n\nThe Danbury house was an affordable option that allowed Ms. Fass to continue to commute to her paralegal job in Brooklyn. Mr. Fass had been broadcasting his show remotely in recent years from a studio in his house, and planned on doing so from Danbury.\n\nIn interviews, the Fasses\u2019 broker and the lawyer handling the purchase of the Danbury house both insisted that the Fasses will be able to move into the house after a renovation covered by the seller\u2019s homeowners insurance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the Fasses said they have no guarantee of this, and with much of the purchase price for the Danbury house in escrow, they are being pressured to close on the property.\n\n\u201cThis type of thing is really not my area, and I have no money for a lawyer to figure it out,\u201d said Mr. Fass, whose radio career was depicted in a 2012 documentary, \u201cRadio Unnameable.\u201d\n\nThe seller of the Danbury home did not respond to an email, and her lawyer, Lawrence M. Riefberg, said he could not comment without her permission.\n\nIn a poetic reversal, Mr. Fass recently called in to his own show \u2014 which is being temporarily handled by a colleague, Bill Propp \u2014 and described the fire story on WBAI (where this reporter is an unpaid co-host of a weekly talk show).\n\nMr. Fass said he stopped receiving a salary from WBAI in 1977 and relies on Social Security benefits. Over the years, some of his listeners have donated to a retirement fund for him.\n\nAfter the fire, some of his longtime listeners \u2014 the Fass \u201ccabal,\u201d as he has always called them \u2014 organized pages, which have raised roughly $2,000.\n\nOn the radio, Mr. Fass often helped raise funds for demonstrations and for legal defenses for such figures as the boxer Rubin \u201cHurricane\u201d Carter, the activist Wavy Gravy and Mr. Hoffman, not to mention institutions like the East Village Other newspaper.\n\n\u201cBob\u2019s been a voice for the people for so long, and so many listeners have called in to his show in their time of need,\u201d said Jessica Wolfson, who with Paul Lovelace, produced and directed the \u201cRadio Unnameable\u201d documentary. \u201cAnd now he has a chance to move to a comfortable living situation and the whole thing literally goes up in flames.\u201d\n\nResting on his couch in the living room, next to his walker and his oxygen tanks, Mr. Fass disposed of a telemarketer by feigning a heart attack while on the phone. Then he sighed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just overwhelmed by everything that\u2019s happening,\u201d he said. \u201cIt might sound amusing, but not when it\u2019s happening in your own life.\u201d", "title": "D.J. of the Counterculture Narrates Another Mishap: His Own", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Daedra Charles, a Hall of Fame basketball player who helped the University of Tennessee win two national championships under its indomitable coach, Pat Summitt, died on Saturday in Detroit. She was 49.\n\nHer death was confirmed by the University of Tennessee, which did not specify the cause.\n\nCharles, who went by the surname Charles-Furlow after her marriage to Anthony Furlow, was a powerful center with a soft touch who became a critical part of the Lady Vols, a team characterized by relentlessness and an unflagging work ethic under Summitt, who by the time she retired had won more games (1,098) than any other Division I college coach, male or female. (She died in 2016 at 64.)\n\nCharles was twice an All-American pick and in 1991 was named the Southeastern Conference\u2019s Female Athlete of the Year. (The male honoree was Shaquille O\u2019Neal, of Louisiana State University.) That same year, she won the Wade Trophy, an annual award given by the Women\u2019s Basketball Coaches Association to the best women\u2019s college player in the country.", "title": "Daedra Charles, 49, Hall of Fame Center for Tennessee, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 An underwater heat wave that damaged huge sections of Australia\u2019s Great Barrier Reef two years ago spurred a die-off of coral so severe that scientists say the natural wonder will never look the same again.\n\nScientists said nearly one-third of the reef\u2019s coral were killed when ocean temperatures spiked in 2016, a result of global warming, according to a study published Wednesday in the journal Nature.\n\nThe damage to the reef, one of the world\u2019s largest living structures, has also radically altered the mix of its coral species, scientists said.\n\n\u201cThe reef is changing faster than anyone thought it would,\u201d said Terry P. Hughes, the lead author of the study and the director of a government-funded center for coral reef studies at James Cook University in Queensland.", "title": "Damage to Great Barrier Reef From Global Warming Is Irreversible, Scientists Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "I do find Jonathan Haidt\u2019s book \u201cThe Righteous Mind: Why Good People Are Divided by Politics and Religion\u201d captivating. I am intrigued by the fact that a self-described liberal (at least he was in 2009) has the temerity to investigate why people (in particular working-class Americans) vote Republican. His answer? Human nature. In particular he argues that people are fundamentally emotional, not rational. This argument flies in the face of all the economics I have been taught, which rests on the foundation that people (economic agents) are rational. For anyone who wants to understand why liberal thinking can be unappealing at the polls (and what to do about it), read this.\n\nWhat\u2019s the last book you\u2019ve recommended to somebody in your family?\n\n\u201cLiving with a SEAL.\u201d This is Jesse Itzler\u2019s insane story of living with David Goggins, a former Navy SEAL and workout fiend who has completed around 50 ultra-endurance races (including the 135-mile race in Death Valley, and an Ultraman: 6.2-mile ocean swim, 261-mile bike ride and then a 52.4-mile run), and has had Top 5 finishes in at least 20 of them. He also set the Guinness World Record with 4,030 pull-ups completed in 17 hours.\n\nI would train with Goggins (aptly nicknamed \u201cthe toughest athlete on the planet\u201d) if I had the guts. Sadly, I don\u2019t. But I loved the fact that Itzler moved Goggins into his home with his wife and kid for a month. I could not put the book down (I read it in one sitting with my mouth open in astonishment), and now follow Itzler and Goggins on Instagram.\n\nWhich books do you think capture the current social and political moment in America?\n\nWith the manifold cultures, religions, races and political beliefs that define America, I do not think such a book has been written, nor do I necessarily think it could be written \u2014 certainly not by a singular author.\n\nThat said, I am intrigued by two books that, if true, foretell a challenging road ahead for the United States. One is \u201cThe Fourth Turning: An American Prophecy \u2014 What the Cycles of History Tell Us About America\u2019s Next Rendezvous with Destiny,\u201d by Neil Howe and William Strauss.\n\nThe other is Philip Roth\u2019s \u201cThe Plot Against America,\u201d which offers an alternative history where Franklin D. Roosevelt loses the 1940 presidential election to Charles Lindbergh. Although both books are somewhat dated (published in 1997 and 2004, respectively) they offer compelling narratives that could explain the social and political shifts that appear to characterize the path the United States is on today.\n\nFor what it\u2019s worth, I hope both books are wrong.\n\nWhich historians and biographers do you most admire?", "title": "Dambisa Moyo: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The actress and playwright Danai Gurira was born in Iowa but grew up in Zimbabwe. That may be an explanation for why, when it comes to beauty, Ms. Gurira, who plays the kick-butt General Okoye in \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d finds fun in variety. Now living in New York, Los Angeles and Atlanta, Ms. Gurira, 40, will be reprising Okoye for \u201cAvengers: Infinity War,\u201d out later this month. Find out what beauty staples she\u2019s leaning into lately.\n\nPhoto\n\nSkin Care\n\nI really feel like I\u2019ve been on a constant journey on how to enjoy beauty, and it\u2019s about the things you pick up along the way. I started experimenting with makeup in my teens. Sometimes I do a little less; sometimes I do a little more. Often I just use CeraVe. It\u2019s a gentle cleanser and good for combination skin. I also like having a hyaluronic acid component in my routine.\n\nThen I use a lot of Sisley. My makeup artist introduced me to Sisley when I was battling dehydration in the dead of winter in New York. She used the Black Rose Cream Mask on me, which is really less of a mask and more of a cream. It was really great for my skin, and now I always have it for long flights. I also use the mattifying moisturizer, which is oil free. And I have their lip stuff. It\u2019s just a lip balm, but it\u2019s pretty fantastic.\n\nI\u2019ve been on set a lot lately, and that\u2019s when I really stick with what works for me. The worst thing would be to disrupt my skin care. If I\u2019m going to be in the sun, I might add the Sisley All Day All Year, which has sun protection. I\u2019ll also use Clarins Beauty Flash Balm before I put on makeup. It\u2019s hydrating and glow-y. I use it religiously.\n\nPhoto\n\nMakeup\n\nI definitely take what I learn from the pros and apply it to what I do at home. Lately I\u2019ve really grown to love a good lip. Sometimes I\u2019ll do something subtle, and sometimes I\u2019ll go for it \u2014 it depends on what I\u2019m wearing. My makeup artist ends up giving me a lot of lip products because I\u2019m a germophobe and don\u2019t want to share. I have a great collection. I use a lot of Chanel lipstick for the bold colors. They have a really great variety of reds that work on my skin tone. For my character on \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d I brought out my own Chanel lipstick in Etienne, which is like a burgundy red. A sustained, targeted attack on these economic engines could send us into a recession, or worse.\n\nSome forward-thinking companies are already investing millions to protect their assets. But New York and other global cities need to support cyber companies developing the latest technology that can keep all our institutions, both public and private, safe.\n\nNew York recently announced that it will create a dedicated cyber hub to accelerate research and development, an important first step in bringing more cybersecurity options to the marketplace.", "title": "Opinion | Danger of a Cyberattack on New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "During his Senate years Mr. Akaka had stints as chairman of its Committee on Veterans Affairs and of its Committee on Indian Affairs.\n\nMr. Akaka was an outspoken critic of the war in Iraq. On March 17, 2003, three days before the United States attacked that country, he warned the Senate:\n\n\u201cIf we pursue our current path, we will have a war lacking in many things essential to achieving complete success. It will be a war without broad international support, without sufficient planning for post-conflict reconstruction and stability, without a definite exit time and strategy, and without a firm price tag.\n\n\u201cMoreover,\u201d he continued, \u201cit will be a war with serious ramifications for our long-term readiness capabilities for homeland security and for managing other crises.\u201d\n\nA steadfast liberal on most issues, he was known as a champion of federal workers, complaining that his Senate colleagues too often denigrated them and cheerfully froze their pay.\n\nHe chaired a Senate subcommittee on the federal work force and was the chief sponsor of the 2012 Whistleblower Protection Act, which provided safeguards against retaliation to federal workers who report waste, fraud and abuse.\n\nDaniel Kahikina Akaka was born in Honolulu on Sept. 11, 1924, the youngest of eight children. His father was of Chinese and Hawaiian descent; his mother was Hawaiian. He attended public schools.\n\nAfter service with the Army Corps of Engineers, he graduated from the University of Hawaii in 1952 with a degree in education and taught music, social studies and math in elementary, middle and high schools. He later became a school principal and earned a master\u2019s degree.", "title": "Daniel Akaka, Former Democratic Senator From Hawaii, Dies at 93", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Daniela M. Adams Suarez and Sam Schatz were married April 7 at the Marigny Opera House in New Orleans. John Adams, a Universal Life minister, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 30, is an event coordinator at Rolex in New York. She graduated from the Universidad Tecmilenio Villahermosa, Mexico.\n\nShe is a daughter of Elvira Suarez of Sunnyside, Queens. He graduated from Columbia and received a master\u2019s degree in management from the London School of Economics.", "title": "Daniela Suarez, Sam Schatz", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNursery rhymes danced off our bedroom walls and hand-painted sunshine birds of Kenya adorned silk lampshades,\u201d Ms. Sheldrick wrote in her autobiography, \u201cLove, Life, and Elephants: An African Love Story\u201d (2012).\n\nMs. Sheldrick\u2019s father, she wrote, had a great affection for the natural world, and so he was distressed when, at the outbreak of World War II, he was sent to a game reserve in an area called Selengai and ordered to kill wildebeest and zebra to provide food for British and Kenyan troops.\n\n\u201cBy the end of the war he had shot thousands of wildebeest and zebra, and I know just how devastating this was for him,\u201d she wrote. \u201cAt least, if there is any comfort to be had, there was no one better than my father to carry out such work. He was a sensitive naturalist, a man who cared deeply about wildlife, and he ensured that no wounded animal was ever left to suffer.\u201d\n\nHis assignment provided a revelation for her when, in 1940, her mother took her to visit him at his camp.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAs soon as I saw the location of the camp I thought, \u2018This is how I would like to live, out here among the animals under the sky,\u2019 \u201d she wrote.\n\nIn 1953 she married Bill Woodley, who worked on Kenya\u2019s game reserves and whose duties included battling poaching. It was a fraught time in Kenya, with the Mau Mau rebellion making life dangerous for European colonists, and Ms. Sheldrick had some harrowing tales to tell of brushes with violence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer marriage to Mr. Woodley ended in divorce, in part because she and his boss, Mr. Sheldrick, were drawn to each other. They married in 1960.\n\nMr. Sheldrick became warden of Tsavo East National Park in Kenya. He and Ms. Sheldrick lived there and began taking in orphaned animals of all sorts, with an emphasis on finding ways to reintroduce them to the wild. Because of poaching and a prolonged drought, many were young elephants, which are quite vulnerable in their first years. Ms. Sheldrick developed a milk formula that young elephants that had lost their mothers could tolerate, and took to hand-feeding them.\n\nAfter Mr. Sheldrick\u2019s death, she established the Sheldrick Trust in Nairobi National Park, focusing on elephants and rhinoceroses.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1994 Ms. Sheldrick was seriously injured when a wild female elephant, with a flick of her trunk, knocked her into a pile of boulders, shattering her leg; she had made the mistake of standing between the animal and its calves. As she lay immobile, the elephant came over to her, but not, as it turned out, with hostile intent.\n\n\u201cI could feel her tusks underneath me, trying to lift me,\u201d Ms. Sheldrick told The Daily Telegraph of London in 2012. \u201cSo I knew she wasn\u2019t going to kill me. When an elephant wants to kill you it kneels down and crushes you with its head.\u201d\n\nIn 2006 she was given the title of dame commander by Queen Elizabeth II. She is survived by a daughter from her first marriage, Gillian Woodley; a daughter from her second marriage, Angela Sheldrick; two sisters, Sheila Wren and Betty Bales; and four grandchildren.\n\nIn addition to her autobiography, Ms. Sheldrick wrote several other books, including \u201cThe Orphans of Tsavo\u201d (1966) and \u201cAn Elephant Called Eleanor\u201d (1981). The work of the trust was the focus of \u201cElephant Diaries,\u201d a British series, in 2005; \u201cBorn to Be Wild,\u201d a documentary narrated by Morgan Freeman and released theatrically in 2011; and numerous other films and newsmagazine segments.\n\nIn an interview with \u201c60 Minutes\u201d in 2009, Ms. Sheldrick was asked what she admired most about elephants after years spent with them.\n\n\u201cTheir tremendous capacity for caring is, I think, perhaps the most amazing thing about them,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cThey have all of the best attributes of us humans and not very many of the bad.\u201d", "title": "Daphne Sheldrick, 83, Who Saved Orphaned Elephants, Is Dead", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Darius Bazley is a long, skilled, athletic forward with a soft touch who, until a month ago, was expected to be one of the best freshmen in college basketball next season. A senior at Princeton High School in Cincinnati, Bazley signed a letter of intent last summer to play for Coach Jim Boeheim at Syracuse University.\n\nBut by the time the McDonald\u2019s All-American Game rolled around on March 28, Bazley, 17, was reconsidering his options. And the day after the game, Bazley stunned many observers by announcing he would forgo college and head directly to the N.B.A.\u2019s development league.\n\nSeveral top high school players have opted to skip college and play professionally overseas since the N.B.A. implemented its so-called one-and-done rule in 2006, which requires prospects to be 19 years old and a year removed from high school to enter the draft. However, Bazley will be the first since Latavious Williams in 2009 to head straight to the development league, which announced last week that it would raise salaries to $35,000 next season, from $26,000. Bazley had foreshadowed his plan before the all-star game, saying that since coaches had told him he\u2019d be ready for the N.B.A. after one year of college, he felt tempted to skip another year of school altogether.\n\n\u201cMy ultimate goal is to play professional basketball, so going that route, that would be great for me,\u201d he said.", "title": "Darius Bazley Charts Yet Another Path to the N.B.A.: The Development League", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "BERLIN \u2014 In the final years of the Weimar Republic, Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht pushed musical theater in a radically new direction, with collaborations like \u201cThe Threepenny Opera\u201d that remain a high-water mark for musical sophistication, dramatic daring and unsparingly dark vision.\n\nIn the early 1990s, Tom Waits and Robert Wilson teamed up in Hamburg for two productions at the Thalia Theater that brought the promise of Weill and Brecht\u2019s savage, sardonic approach into the modern era. This spring, new productions of the Waits-Wilson collaborations are among several glitteringly dark musicals to be found in sunny southern Germany.\n\n\u201cAlice,\u201d a very adult riff on \u201cAlice in Wonderland\u201d that premiered in 1992, is the hit of the season at Munich\u2019s Metropoltheater, an independent theater in the residential neighborhood of Freimann. The show plumbs the mind of Charles Dodgson \u2014 the logician, photographer and church deacon better known by his pen name, Lewis Carroll \u2014 and his obsession with the 11-year-old Alice Liddell. Paul Schmidt\u2019s free-associative book interprets \u201cWonderland\u201d as a surreal fantasy concocted by the writer to protect Alice from his sexually aggressive desire. It features some of Mr. Waits\u2019s finest songs (co-written with his wife and frequent collaborator, Kathleen Brennan), but aside from a performance in Brooklyn in 1995, \u201cAlice\u201d has gone pretty much unseen in the United States over the past two decades.\n\nThe young German director Philipp Moschitz\u2019s intimate and intricate staging, coupled with the company\u2019s high production values, makes a strong argument for increased public support for this small, innovative theater. Dominating the stage is a rust-colored wheel that churns like a windmill and has adjustable shelves for the actors to support themselves (sets are by Thomas Flach).", "title": "Dark Musicals Shimmer on the German Stage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou want me to imagine what it\u2019s like to be a woman, to put myself in a black man\u2019s shoes or a black woman\u2019s shoes,\u201d he says. \u201cThat\u2019s actually what we all should be trying to do, whether or not we come up with a nice work of fiction from it or it\u2019s horrible and you got it all wrong. I really feel like the wrong way to go about it is to try to imagine that there are some movies that should be told by women as opposed to by men. And so a woman can direct any movie and a man can direct any movie and you hope you can get it to a meritocracy at some point. If you say, \u2018No, you can\u2019t do that,\u2019 then you\u2019re shutting down exactly the impulse that you want to come out of this bomb that went off in our culture.\u201d\n\nAfter the Harvey Weinstein revelations, he said, he had to \u201cre-educate\u201d himself. He said his belief in equality between men and women and blacks and whites skewed his perception of the fundamental nature of the problem.\n\n\u201cSo my education has been to acknowledge that even if I didn\u2019t perpetuate it, it has to be dealt with \u2014 if I\u2019m not being part of the solution I\u2019m being part of the problem,\u201d he says, adding that witnessing all the hatred and division that has cascaded since the advent of Trump has \u201creopened\u201d his eyes to misogyny and racism.\n\nGillian Anderson has complained that after struggling for years to get equal pay for playing Scully \u2014 initially, as a newcomer, the actress was even told to stand several feet behind Mr. Duchovny in scenes \u2014 she was at first offered half of Mr. Duchovny\u2019s salary for \u201cThe X-Files\u201d revival.\n\nWhen I mention that only 4 percent of women directed the top 100 grossing films, he shakes his head, murmuring, \u201cThat\u2019s mind-blowing.\u201d\n\nFor a long time, Mr. Duchovny was touted as the next George Clooney. \u201cI envisioned a career more in movies, but we all did at that point,\u201d he says. \u201cNow the business has changed, where everybody\u2019s doing television. I could have been more social.", "title": "David Duchovny\u2019s Truth Is Out There, Between Covers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "David R. Edgerton, who helped start what became the world\u2019s second-largest hamburger chain, Burger King, but then agreed to sell the company for what proved to be a bargain price just as the industry was about to take off, died on April 3 in Miami. He was 90.\n\nThe cause was complications of surgery after a fall, his friend and accountant Betty Amos Righetti said. His death was announced in a paid notice in The Miami Herald, but it was otherwise not widely reported.\n\nA business contemporary of Raymond A. Kroc, who built the McDonald\u2019s chain into the industry leader, Mr. Edgerton started Burger King with $12,000 after managing Howard Johnson\u2019s restaurants in Miami and Orlando, Fla.\n\nAt the time, he had been preparing to open a Dairy Queen with a hamburger section in Jacksonville, Fla. But he changed his mind and sold the business to acquire Insta Burger King, a 15-cent hamburger business in Miami. He took it over in March 1954.", "title": "David Edgerton, a Founder of Burger King, Is Dead at 90", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Celine Dion is the person every singer should study, whether you like her singing or hate it. How she\u2019s raised her children. How she\u2019s been in her marriage. How she\u2019s been in her shows. How she takes care of her voice. How she treats people. And yes, when she opens her mouth that voice just comes out.\n\nYou\u2019ve also been quoted saying that you love her because she does what she\u2019s told.\n\nFor a guy like me who wants to get his licks in, it\u2019s great. She can interpret exactly what I want at all times. She\u2019s so amenable. I think that\u2019s to her credit. When I asked Whitney for something, she would give me something different. Sometimes it was better, sometimes it was not as good. But it was never what I imagined.\n\nDid you feel you knew Whitney Houston?\n\nI felt I did not. We never had an argument. We never had a problem. I was a junior at Sarah Lawrence College and had come to the Fulton Fish Market, accompanied by my intrepid roommate, Turid, for an assignment given by my creative writing professor, Harvey Swados.\n\nThe idea was to visit the fish market as the boats come in, and to write about it. \u201cUse concrete details, please,\u201d Professor Swados had instructed.\n\nWe watched fishermen hoist bins of dripping, shiny fish and shellfish to the dock, and then haggle and argue with the buyers. I took notes as we breathed in the briny smells.\n\nThe sun crept above the horizon, and we followed some of the fishermen into a restaurant to feast on fresh fried flounder and scrambled eggs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn a whim, Turid insisted that we buy lobsters to cook in our dormitory kitchen. A lobsterman shoved two live lobsters into a paper bag for us, and we headed off for the subway.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Johnson was at three under par. Tied with Johnson, the 2016 United States Open winner, was Justin Thomas, last year\u2019s P.G.A. champion.\n\nPhoto\n\nJustin Rose and Louis Oosthuizen, also major winners, were another stroke back, as was Bubba Watson, the two-time Masters champ.\n\nBut the spotlight shone brightest on Reed, and with good reason. He has one-putted on 22 of his 36 holes, and he is the only player who has birdied the course\u2019s four par 5s in each round.\n\nHe is also a galvanizing figure in the game, renowned for a cocky demeanor and a showy Ryder Cup record. But Reed, the world\u2019s 24th-ranked golfer, has been forced to wait impatiently for his first major victory. His best finish in a major has been second place at the P.G.A. Championship last year, when he finished two strokes behind Thomas.\n\nAnd Reed\u2019s Masters record is far from glittering. In four appearances, he has twice missed the cut. He also tied for 22nd and tied for 49th. Not surprisingly, past failures do not weigh on the self-assured Reed.\n\n\u201cThe more you play someplace, especially Augusta National, the more you pick up the little subtleties,\u201d he said late Friday evening. \u201cI\u2019m in a better frame of mind with my golf game and mentally.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nReed, 27, insisted he would sleep well as the midpoint leader of the Masters.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve just got to stick to my game plan,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s a long way to go.\u201d\n\nWith rain forecast throughout Saturday afternoon in the Augusta area, the third round could be a test of not only golf skill but also the ability to battle uncomfortable conditions.\n\nReed, true to form, had one response: Bring it on.\n\n\u201cI am from Texas,\u201d he said, smiling as he noted that wind and rain are common elements faced by golfers in the Lone Star State.\n\nPhoto\n\nWith a glint in his eye, he added, \u201cI would say I like it when it gets challenging.\u201d\n\nHours before Reed soared to the top of the leader board, Spieth\u2019s implosion was the most startling turn of events, especially since he had streaked through Thursday\u2019s first round with five consecutive birdies in his final nine holes. You can make up a lot of ground.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter.
