The move came just four days after the investigations commissioner, Mark G. Peters, fired a former prosecutor he had recently hired to head the office.\n\nWhile the office has reported to the head of the Department of Investigation since its inception in 1990, it has always operated with a great deal of independence. The former prosecutor, Anastasia Coleman, had objected to efforts by Mr. Peters to restructure the office and eliminate its independence, according to letters, emails and other documents. Ms. Coleman has said his changes violated the law, a position Mr. Peters and his staff have strongly disputed.\n\nIn a statement responding to the mayor\u2019s executive order, a spokeswoman for Mr. Peters suggested that Mr. de Blasio\u2019s action interfered with the agency\u2019s ability to independently police corruption in the city school system.", "title": "De Blasio Steps Into Power Struggle Over School Investigations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "So far, the provision has resulted in the dismissal of more than 500 disability rights complaints.\n\nCatherine E. Lhamon, who led the Office for Civil Rights under the Obama administration, said the new provision undermined the mission of the office. Unlike the Justice Department, the Education Department cannot pick and choose the cases it pursues. If the office has evidence that the law has been violated, it must open a case.\n\n\u201cThe thing that scares me is when they get to say \u2018we won\u2019t open some cases because it\u2019s too much for us,\u2019 or \u2018we don\u2019t like the complainant,\u2019 or \u2018it\u2019s not our week to work on that,\u2019 you start to change the character of the office,\u201d Ms. Lhamon said.\n\nBut Debora L. Osgood, a lawyer who worked for 25 years at the Office for Civil Rights and now consults with and represents schools on civil rights matters, praised the change.\n\nShe said the provision showed that the agency was \u201cessentially taking the reins back for control of its complaint docket.\u201d\n\nMs. Osgood said that in her experience, one person could clog the pipeline in each of the agency\u2019s 12 regional offices, limiting investigators\u2019 ability to respond to other complaints. It often frustrated investigators who prided themselves on being able to resolve complaints promptly, she said.\n\n\u201cIn effect, it turned over the decision-making about how the agency would use many of its resources to a single individual, rather than to agency officials and staff charged with the responsibility for implementing the agency\u2019s stated mission,\u201d she said.\n\nAccording to the Education Department, 41 percent of the 16,720 complaints filed in the 2016 fiscal year came from three people. The next year, of the 12,837 total cases, 23 percent of them did.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe department calls the complainants \u201cfrequent fliers.\u201d\n\nMarcie Lipsitt is proud to be one of them.\n\nIn the last two years, Ms. Lipsitt, a disability rights advocate in Michigan, has filed more than 2,400 complaints with the office against schools, departments of education, colleges and universities, libraries and other educational institutions across the country that have websites that people who are deaf or blind or who struggle with fine motor skills cannot navigate.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cNo one even knew about this issue until I started filing,\u201d Ms. Lipsitt said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to get anybody in trouble. I just wanted to raise awareness.\u201d\n\nShe has secured more than 1,000 agreements with institutions that committed to bringing their websites into compliance with the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities and requires that electronic and information technologies be accessible to them.\n\nIn recent weeks, Ms. Lipsitt said, she has received notice that more than 500 cases, including active and open investigations, were dismissed. Each letter cited the new provision as the reason. The department will instead work with colleges on complying with web accessibility laws.\n\n\u201cBut I won\u2019t stop,\u201d Ms. Lipsitt vowed, \u201cbecause if I do, the story goes away.\u201d\n\nThe new manual also eliminates an appeals process for Office for Civil Rights decisions \u2014 department officials said it usually resulted in the same outcome \u2014 and says complaints can no longer be filed on the basis of journal articles and news media reports.\n\nThe manual also drops all mention of investigators\u2019 looking into \u201csystemic issues.\u201d However, the department said that the new provision would not apply to class-action-like complaints filed by groups.\n\nThe changes worry civil rights groups, which point out that Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has already rescinded guidances meant to protect students against sexual assaults on campuses and black and transgender students against bias.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNeena Chaudhry, associate general counsel and senior adviser of education at the National Women\u2019s Law Center, said that by filing dozens of complaints in recent decades, the group has been able to secure equal scholarship money and increased sports opportunities for female athletes. Now, as the organization shifts its focus to sexual assault, the department may prove less responsive.\n\nRachel M. Kleinman, senior counsel at the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, said that the new manual was \u201cyet another avenue for O.C.R. to not seriously investigate systemic race discrimination.\u201d\n\nThe group has filed complaints on behalf of large groups of black students it believes were being disproportionately affected by law enforcement policies. Already, one case has been closed by the DeVos administration, and the department declined to conduct a broader analysis.\n\n\u201cThey seem to be closing all of the pathways for students to have their rights enforced by the federal government,\u201d Ms. Kleinman said.\n\nMs. DeVos\u2019s Office for Civil Rights has maintained that it wants to be more efficient and effective than it was under the Obama administration, which was known for its aggressive enforcement and broad investigations but was also accused of being overzealous and leaving cases languishing for years.\n\nMs. Osgood said such changes would be welcomed by the colleges and universities that she assists with federal civil rights investigations.\n\nShe said the changes showed that the department was willing to work with schools in a \u201cmore reasonable, more nimble and more expeditious manner.\u201d\n\nThe department did not say how its investigators would determine that a case would place an \u201cunreasonable burden\u201d on its resources. However, just weeks after the new manual took effect, Congress allocated $8.5 million more in funding to the Office for Civil Rights, which Ms. DeVos had sought to cut, in order for the office to manage its caseload.\n\nMs. Lhamon said that, in her time in the office, she sought out ways to manage large volumes of cases that stemmed from one complainant, and she acknowledged that her office struggled with timely responses. But she said she could not come up with any measure that would not shortchange an investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s not a limitation on justice, and there\u2019s not a limitation on how we perceive injustice,\u201d Ms. Lhamon said. \u201cTo say you\u2019ve reached your quota is to say that there\u2019s somehow a cap on the number of children who might be harmed.\u201d", "title": "DeVos Education Dept. Begins Dismissing Civil Rights Cases in Name of Efficiency", "authors": ["Erica L. Green"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "SHOPIAN, Kashmir \u2014 An Indian Army operation against militants fighting Indian rule in the Muslim-majority Kashmir Valley killed at least 12 militants on Sunday, the largest one-day death toll of insurgents in recent years, officials in Kashmir said.\n\nAt least three soldiers and four civilians also died, and about 70 other people were wounded in the army crackdown in the district of Shopian, according to the Kashmir authorities.\n\nArmy officials called the operation a major success. \u201cIt is a special day for our forces,\u201d Lt. Firefighters and other emergency personnel, along with villagers, were still trying to contain the blaze on Wednesday evening.\n\nIndonesia\u2019s Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources and the state-owned oil company Pertamina sent teams to Aceh, which has industrial oil and gas operations, to investigate the episode, said Agung Pribadi, a ministry spokesman.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis is a case of illegal drilling, and the ones responsible for it must be dealt with by the law,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Agung said the well was being operated by local residents, adding that he was not sure if there were other illegal wells in the area.\n\nLt. Col. Wahyu Kuncoro, chief of the East Aceh District police, told reporters at the scene that firefighters were trying to \u201cbreak the chain of oxygen\u201d in the well to stop the fire. He confirmed the well operation was illegal, but he said many villagers depended on it for their livelihood.\n\nIllegal well operations are common in Indonesian regions where oil is present, including on the islands of Sumatra and Java. In some cases, the wells were abandoned by the Dutch colonial administration that once ruled Indonesia, and are now run by villagers working around the clock.\n\n\u201cOil doesn\u2019t come up to the surface easily in these old wells, so they try to pump it up manually, then try to separate the oil by distillation in barrels, and that\u2019s where they probably had the fire,\u201d said Mangantar Marpaung, former chief of the Indonesian Mining Fire and Rescue Agency.\n\n\u201cThen they sell it as kerosene to the local market, or for motorcycles and fishing boats,\u201d he said. \u201cThose are their customers. The local governments know, but because they can\u2019t provide any other jobs, they look the other way.\u201d", "title": "Deadly Fire Erupts at Illegal Oil Well in Indonesia", "authors": ["Joe Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Within days after the news broke about Harvey Weinstein, almost every post in my Facebook feed ended with the hashtag #MeToo. The stories shared sometimes concerned workplace harassment, but they also involved lecherous doctors, relatives or boyfriends. There was a feverishness to the way women were telling them \u2014 as if it had just occurred to them how lonely they\u2019d felt.\n\nThe most concrete goal of the \u201cMe Too\u201d movement has been to reform workplace culture. But the movement has also accomplished something broader, and more nebulous: It has given women the ability to talk about some of the hardest moments of their lives with less shame, stigma or fear of repercussions.\n\nIt has, in other words, created room for the sort of discussions that once were restricted to, essentially, just one type of public space: advice columns. For decades, the columns were where women with creepy bosses or abusive husbands went to air their grievances.", "title": "Opinion | Dear Abby, #MeToo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Match Book,\n\n\u201cThe Rosie Project,\u201d by Graeme Simsion, was a real hit with my book group. Ever since we read it I have been searching for something similar \u2014 for books that will leave us giggling on the sofa (unfortunately, I found the sequel disappointing). Sure, there\u2019s the dry wit of P. G. Wodehouse\u2019s Jeeves stories, and Nancy Mitford\u2019s quirky family novels \u201cThe Pursuit of Love\u201d and \u201cLove in a Cold Climate.\u201d Gerald Durrell\u2019s autobiographical \u201cMy Family and Other Animals\u201d is also hilarious, but are there any funny novels that will appeal to a broader audience?\n\nJANE ROSSI\n\nSALINE, MICH.\n\nDear Jane,\n\nAlthough I understand the type of warmly comic novel you\u2019re looking for, don\u2019t mistake P. G. Wodehouse as fringe: The master humorist edges out \u201cThe Goldfinch,\u201d by Donna Tartt, \u201cAll the Light We Cannot See,\u201d by Anthony Doerr, and \u201cStoner,\u201d by John Williams, to claim the top spot on the list of favorites sent to the Match Book inbox.\n\nNote Books\n\nBy my informal tabulation, another fan favorite, Maria Semple\u2019s \u201cWhere\u2019d You Go, Bernadette,\u201d ranks as the book most frequently introduced into conversations I\u2019ve had at parties and at school pickups since the farcical, (mostly) epistolary novel was published in 2012. It could be Semple\u2019s sharp takedown of precious parenting in a Seattle middle school that inspires the same kind of devotion readers have for \u201cThe Rosie Project.\u201d But it is the wisdom and resolve displayed by the precocious 15-year-old Bee Branch throughout her search for her mysteriously missing mother \u2014 a brilliant, agoraphobic architect \u2014 that drives the book\u2019s suspense.\n\nAdd another deliciously absurd novel-in-correspondence, \u201cDear Committee Members,\u201d by Julie Schumacher (the book\u2019s sequel, \u201cThe Shakespeare Requirement,\u201d is due out this summer), to your list. The zestful, bitter voice of the book\u2019s protagonist, Jason T. Fitger, a professor of creative writing at Payne University and frustrated novelist, begs to be read aloud. The narrative is told entirely through Fitger\u2019s letters of recommendation, in which he overshares his grievances over academic politics and offers cautious praise for his students (he likens the intellectual style of one talented young woman to a \u201chighly articulate snake\u201d), while also revealing his fundamental decency.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Funny Pages", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Antoinette,\n\nIn a 2013 interview on the FanBros podcast, Junot D\u00edaz spoke about diversity fiction: \u201cThere\u2019s no person of color, there\u2019s no person from a marginalized community, that doesn\u2019t read the genres \u2014 comic books, science fiction \u2014 and not see how more honest these texts are about the way we\u2019re living. About the way we\u2019re oppressed; the way that power is used.\u201d Take it from D\u00edaz, a MacArthur Grant and Pulitzer Prize winner; your voice is essential to these genres\u2019 evolutions.\n\nAcross the Universes\n\nStart your list with three black writers who conjure an array of speculative worlds. In N. K. Jemisin\u2019s stately and brutal debut, \u201cThe Hundred Thousand Kingdoms,\u201d even the flora and fauna \u2014 an \u201caltarskirt rose\u201d that blooms at both the top and near the bottom of the stem; \u201cbeasts that do not exist\u201d \u2014 are imagined from scratch. Their creation is just a sliver of the meticulously imagined landscape in Jemisin\u2019s epic in which a young woman is thrust into a battle over the inheritance of her grandfather\u2019s throne.\n\nAnother supernatural setup shimmers on the fated journey undertaken by Onyesonwu, the sorceress who holds a diamond under her tongue in Nnedi Okorafor\u2019s dark fantasy \u201cWho Fears Death,\u201d set in a postapocalyptic Sudan. And a dystopian vision similarly vivifies the quest for a human heart in Nalo Hopkinson\u2019s debut, \u201cBrown Girl in the Ring,\u201d an eerie mash-up of old Caribbean obeah and science fiction set in a futuristic Toronto riven by \u201cchaos in the city core.\u201d\n\nYour affection for the layered literary style and atmospheric pleasures of \u201cDracula\u201d and \u201cFrankenstein\u201d led me to Jeffery Renard Allen\u2019s \u201cSong of the Shank.\u201d The sprawling, fictionalized Civil War-era account of the life of Thomas Greene Wiggins, a blind savant pianist born into slavery and exploited by a string of characters, doesn\u2019t fit neatly into any one speculative genre. But fantastic ripples \u2014 an enigmatic, utopian island and mythical \u201cornate sea creatures\u201d \u2014 break the narrative surface so that the prose\u2019s lyrical pulse builds to one long, unbroken spell.\n\nSomething Wicked\n\nLike \u201cSong of the Shank,\u201d \u201cThe Changeling,\u201d Victor LaValle\u2019s thorny, disquieting contemporary folk tale about race and parenthood (among other hot-button topics), features an alternatively imagined New York City that includes an enchanted version of Forest Park in Queens. A lost child, witchy characters and bloody scenes edge LaValle\u2019s tale closer to horror than allegory, for the kind of frights you love.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Genre Fiction by Black Writers, About Black Characters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Match Book,\n\nEver since the election I\u2019ve had a hard time reading books that are emotionally and psychically challenging. After Trump leaves office I\u2019ll be able to go back to something like \u201cBastard Out of Carolina,\u201d by Dorothy Allison, or \u201cMan\u2019s Search for Meaning,\u201d by Viktor E. Frankl, but for now I want to read books in which people like each other and everything turns out O.K. If it\u2019s funny, all the better. I enjoyed Ivan Doig\u2019s \u201cThe Whistling Season,\u201d which a librarian friend recommended, as well as Pete Hamill\u2019s \u201cSnow in August.\u201d Next I may just reread an old childhood favorite like \u201cThe Little Prince,\u201d by Antoine de Saint-Exup\u00e9ry.\n\nI am looking for comfort books, in the way that others turn to comfort food in tough times. Do you have any more ideas?\n\nAMY STODOLA\n\nHARRISVILLE, N.H.\n\nDear Amy,\n\nThe books you\u2019ve turned to for solace do still feature some dramatic downbeats: There\u2019s that scene in \u201cThe Whistling Season\u201d in which wolves are skinned alive, and the wrenching, violent anti-Semitism that erupts more than once in \u201cSnow in August.\u201d \u201cThe Little Prince,\u201d too, strikes a deeply melancholy tone, with lines like this: \u201cAnd when he watered the flower one last time, and put her under glass, he felt like crying.\u201d\n\nState of the Unions\n\nBut your favorites also share a sense of nostalgia: for early 20th-century Montana; for midcentury Brooklyn; for childhood. In Wallace Stegner\u2019s grand novel of the American West \u201cThe Angle of Repose,\u201d a historian\u2019s romanticized vision of 19th-century America clouds when, in the course of researching the life of his grandmother \u2014 a writer and artist who \u201ccame West not to join a new society but to endure it\u201d \u2014 he uncovers a breach and a tragedy in her marriage, the effects of which reverberate in the book\u2019s present.", "title": "Dear Match Book: In Search of Comfort Reading", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.\n\nThis past week, the City of New York removed the statue of a famous 19th century gynecologist, J. Marion Sims, from its perch at the edge of Central Park on Fifth Avenue. Because Sims had performed experimental surgeries on female slaves, an arts commission empowered with determining whether public sculptures were still deserving of display had determined that he should no longer be glorified, despite the advancements he furthered in medicine.\n\nI wrote a column arguing that this was an exercise in easy virtue because the statue wasn\u2019t being destroyed or even removed from view; instead it was getting sent to Green-Wood cemetery in Brooklyn, a gorgeously landscaped urban green space and national historic landmark that receives more than a quarter million visitors per year.\n\nOthers had pointed out that the statue should not have a home simply in some other part of town. As the actress Annabella Sciorra, a Brooklyn native, put it before I wrote my column:\n\nThe column drew impassioned responses from readers, several of whom argued that Sims has been needlessly vilified by modern observers.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cReading about Dr. Sims\u2019 practices, the medical condition faced by these women, and the state of medicine in the 1840s, creates a far more nuanced story than that told by opponents of honoring Dr. Sims,\u2019\u2019 as JEG from New York put it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn this vein, other readers pointed to the research of L. Lewis Wall, a doctor and medical anthropologist at Washington University in St. Louis, who has argued that the condition Sims was trying to repair, vesicovaginal fistula, a complication of childbirth for many 19th century women, was so painful and horrific that women were desperate for relief and that the female slaves on which he initially operated wanted to try something, anything, rather than live with the misery.", "title": "Debate Over the Statue of a 19th-Century Gynecologist Continues", "authors": ["Ginia Bellafante"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Republican officials described their efforts as precautionary, a nod toward the party\u2019s humiliating special election losses in Alabama and Pennsylvania and an acknowledgment that they must fortify their defenses in even the reddest of districts.\n\nThe Phoenix-area seat for the Eighth Congressional District, a haven for sunshine-seeking retirees from the Midwest, is so reliably Republican that Democrats did not even field a candidate in the last two elections.\n\nBut after the previous representative, Trent Franks, resigned following revelations he had offered $5 million to an aide in exchange for carrying his child, Arizona Democrats rallied to Ms. Tipirneni. She outraised Ms. Lesko in what was the first high-profile congressional election since 2016 between two women.\n\nNational Democrats, however, stayed away from the race, deducing that a district that has sent only Republicans to Congress for four decades was out of reach. And any hopes Ms. Tipirneni had to win outside support may have faded this month when a local TV station reported that she had not practiced medicine since 2007 and had settled a malpractice lawsuit with a woman who blamed her for contracting tetanus.\n\nIn contrast, the Republican National Committee, the National Republican Congressional Committee and the Congressional Leadership Fund, the primary House Republican super PAC, each poured hundreds of thousands of dollars into the race. The investment proved critical in what became an unexpectedly close race.", "title": "Debbie Lesko Wins Arizona Special Election for Congress, Rallying G.O.P.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I saw the recent instructions for disabling autocorrect on an iPhone, but what about those of us who use Android? How do I turn off the automatic-correction feature?\n\nA. The exact steps vary based on your device and the particular version of Android you use, but for the typical system, start by opening the Settings app. On the main Settings screen, choose Languages & Input. In later versions of Android, select Virtual Keyboard. When you get to the list of keyboards and input methods, tap Android (or Google) Keyboard. On the next screen, select Text Correction.\n\nImage Many versions of the Android operating system allow you to disable automatic corrections and other keyboard features in the Language & Input settings. Credit The New York Times\n\nThe Text Correction screen lists several controls, including a button to turn off autocorrect. You can also choose to enable or disable Android\u2019s help when you type, including prompts for contact names and personalized suggestions based on your use of other Google apps, and you can decline suggestions for potentially offensive words.\n\nOn some Samsung Galaxy phones, you can get to the keyboard software by opening the Apps icon on the home screen, tapping Settings and then General Management. From there, select Language and Input and then On-screen Keyboard. Tap the name of the keyboard you are using \u2014 usually Samsung Keyboard or a third-party keyboard app. The Smart Typing section of the Samsung Keyboard settings has all the controls for predictive text, auto replace (automatic correction) and other tools.", "title": "Declining Android\u2019s Automatic Correction Help", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is simply indicating, according to the records from his own company, that he was on a plane on several occasions between Jan. 2 and Feb. 8, correct?\u201d he asked Ms. Meister.\n\n\u201cCorrect,\u201d she replied.\n\nThere is no question as to whether there was a sexual encounter between Mr. Cosby and Ms. Constand, a former Temple University employee who said she viewed him as a mentor. But Mr. Cosby has said it was consensual, not criminal, behavior.\n\nThe retrial ended its 10th day on Friday with a prediction by the judge that it may well be concluded long before the month first forecast. Jury deliberations will begin next week, Judge Steven T. O\u2019Neill of the Montgomery County Court of Common Pleas told the panel of seven men and five women. Two more defense witnesses are scheduled to testify on Monday, and then both sides will deliver closing statements.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The suit was settled for $3.38 million, jurors heard during the retrial.\n\nMr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers said in a motion that they had tried repeatedly but failed to get Ms. Williams to testify at the retrial, and so were asking for portions of the deposition to be read instead. My column yesterday on the Democrats\u2019 strong record of reducing the deficit led to some criticism that\u2019s worth sharing. The main point of the criticism: The Democrats don\u2019t deserve praise, because reducing the deficit is bad policy.\n\nDavid Kusnet, a former Clinton administration official, tweeted: \u201cWhy should Democrats borrow the austerity policies preached by the Republicans whom Trump beat?\u201d Joe Weisenthal, of Bloomberg, chided me for \u201cfurthering the unfounded notion that lower deficits are, per se, more \u2018responsible.\u2019 \u201d A reader named Russell Sharp wrote, of the Democrats: \u201cThey treat the deficit as a bigger deal than it should be. What\u2019s accurate is that one party has done a good job of managing fiscal policy the way centrist pundits think it should be managed, whereas the other has not.\u201d\n\nAll of this is part of a broader reconsideration, happening among both conservative and liberal writers, of how much policymakers should care about the deficit.\n\nI\u2019m of two minds about this reconsideration. On the one hand, there is some unavoidable arithmetic at work here. The deficit can\u2019t simply get larger and larger over time, without some serious economic consequences. If every president ran up the deficit as much as George W. Bush did, financial markets would at some point begin to punish the United States government, out of a legitimate fear that it wouldn\u2019t be able to repay its debts. Borrowing would become more expensive for this country, and our economy would suffer.\n\n\u201cRising deficits forever\u201d just isn\u2019t a serious economic position. And we should be grateful that one of our two political parties understands as much and has acted responsibly to reduce the deficit.", "title": "Opinion | Deficits Don\u2019t Matter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. da Silva spent the day holed up at the metalworkers union headquarters in S\u00e3o Bernardo do Campo, a municipality just outside of S\u00e3o Paulo, surrounded by supporters. Though Mr. da Silva did not speak publicly on Friday, a series of posts on his Twitter account conveyed a message of defiance.\n\n\u201cThey want to arrest me to silence my voice, but I will speak through you,\u201d one said. Another read: \u201cThey want to leave me jailed in a cell so I can\u2019t carry on, but I will move forward through your legs.\u201d\n\nThe setting provided a powerfully symbolic backdrop for a pivotal moment of his political career. The headquarters is where Mr. da Silva gained prominence as a union leader in the 1970s by railing against the military dictatorship, and where he and fellow leftist leaders formed a political movement that decades later carried him to the pinnacle of power.\n\n\u201cHe is staying positive, he is talking and listening,\u201d said Eduardo Suplicy, a founder of Mr. da Silva\u2019s Workers\u2019 Party who visited with him during the afternoon. \u201cThere has been such an outpouring of solidarity from the people. He has received all these men and women crying, but he always managed to say something positive.\u201d\n\nMr. Suplicy said Mr. da Silva planned to attend a Mass at the union hall on Saturday morning for his wife, who died last year. Yet, representatives of the former president said he would surrender to the federal police if they came to take him into custody.\n\nFederal police officials were deeply reluctant to wade through crowds of supporters to apprehend Mr. da Silva, according to local press reports, because doing so could lead to a violent confrontation.\n\nAllies of the president were negotiating with federal police officials on Friday night, but it was unclear how soon \u2014 or even whether \u2014 a compromise might be reached.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. da Silva on Thursday afternoon was ordered to surrender to federal police officials in the southern city of Curitiba, where his trial was held, no later than 5 p.m. Friday. He ruled out traveling there, a spokesman, Jos\u00e9 Chrispiniano, said, in part because his assets had been frozen as part of the criminal investigation, leaving him unable to afford the trip.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSupporters who gathered outside the union building waited hours for Mr. da Silva to deliver one of his trademark fiery speeches. But as night fell, onlookers got only fleeting glimpses of the former leader through the windows.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to watch this happen,\u201d said Jose Cano Herdeia, 30, a black Brazilian who attributed his education at a private university to a racial quota system put in place by Mr. da Silva\u2019s government. \u201cAnd even then we had to fight our way in the door. We know what it\u2019s like to fight and Lula will live to keep on fighting.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut for law enforcement officials, the imminent arrest of Mr. da Silva answered their yearslong effort to upend the kickback schemes that have long been at the intersection of business and politics in Brazil.\n\n\u201cJustice exists to protect everyone, and to demand that the law be applied indistinctly to those who are poor and those who are powerful,\u201d said Jos\u00e9 Robalinho Cavalcanti, the president of Brazil\u2019s National Association of Prosecutors. \u201cThat may seem obvious in the democratic world. But for Brazil, it is not.\u201d\n\nMr. da Silva was convicted last July of corruption and money laundering after a federal judge, S\u00e9rgio Moro, determined that he had accepted a seaside apartment as a bribe for contracts issued to the construction company O.A.S.\n\nIn January, an appeals court unanimously upheld the conviction and increased his sentence to 12 years. Despite those setbacks to Mr. da Silva, he has campaigned vigorously for a third presidential term, and has carved out a comfortable lead in the polls.\n\nThis week, Mr. da Silva\u2019s bid to remain a viable candidate appeared to fizzle as the country\u2019s top court rejected his petition to remain free pending further appeals.\n\nHours after the ruling was handed down on Thursday morning, Judge Moro signed a warrant ordering Mr. da Silva to surrender to the authorities in Curitiba.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Curitiba, a crowd of about 50 people chanted against Mr. da Silva as they ignited fireworks and honked horns.\n\n\u201cLula, you drunk, give me my money back!,\u201d some chanted.\n\nRegina Santos, a 53-year-old resident of Curitiba, watched the demonstration with mixed feelings. She voted for Mr. da Silva in 2002, the first time he was elected.\n\n\u201cLike every Brazilian, I had hope he would be different because he was from the people, like us,\u201d she said. But as allegations of corruption against Mr. da Silva and several allies mounted, her loyalty waned.\n\n\u201cUnfortunately in Brazil, we have a culture of corruption,\u201d she said. \u201cPerhaps watching this, Brazilians will understand corruption doesn\u2019t pay off.\u201d", "title": "Defying Arrest Deadline, Brazil\u2019s Ex-President Dares Police to Come Get Him", "authors": ["Shasta Darlington", "Ernesto Londo\u00f1o", "Manuela Andreoni"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Delaney Simon and Graeme Smith were married April 6 in an outdoor ceremony on the beach in Malibu, Calif. Leo Sidran, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 28, is the special assistant to the United Nations special coordinator for Lebanon in Beirut. She graduated cum laude from Barnard College and received a master's degree in international security, conflict resolution and gender policy from Columbia. From 2013-15 she worked for Afghanistan\u2019s permanent mission to the United Nations in New York, which included assisting negotiations on Security Council reform and small arms and light weapons agreements.\n\nShe is a daughter of Emily Simon and Ralph Simon of London. The bride\u2019s father is the founder of Mobilium Global Limited, a mobile technology consultant based in London that provides insight and strategy to companies worldwide in mobile and connected device strategies. From 1993-95, he served as the executive vice president of Capitol Records and Blue Note Records in Hollywood. He also was a founder of Jive Records in London. The bride\u2019s mother, a former entertainment lawyer in London, founded the Women\u2019s Foundation there.\n\nThe groom, 38, was until March 1 a political affairs officer for the United Nations Assistance Mission in Kabul, Afghanistan. From 2012-15, he was the Afghanistan country director for the International Crisis Group, a global think tank also based in Kabul. He is now a freelance writer and political analyst based in Beirut. He is also the author of \u201cThe Dogs Are Eating Them Now: Our War in Afghanistan\u201d (Knopf and Counterpoint). He graduated from Ryerson University in Toronto.", "title": "Delaney Simon, Graeme Smith", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement forwarded by Mr. Stone, Rob Buschel, Mr. Stone\u2019s lawyer, said he had not yet been served with the D.N.C. suit and described it as a \u201cregurgitation\u201d of a complaint filed last year by Democrats alleging their privacy was invaded during the campaign. That litigation is still in progress.\n\nThe Democrats\u2019 legal maneuver comes amid a swirl of intensifying scrutiny of Mr. Trump, his associates and their interactions with Russia. The president, who has long denied allegations of collusion, has repeatedly attacked the special counsel investigation this week and has vented angrily about renewed claims by James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, that Mr. Trump sought to influence the bureau\u2019s review of the election.\n\nMr. Trump added Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor, and two other lawyers to his legal team this week. And on Thursday night, Mr. Trump thundered on social media that there was \u201cNO COLLUSION and NO OBSTRUCTION,\u201d and again branded the whole Russia investigation as a \u201cwitch hunt.\u201d\n\nThe D.N.C. complaint is broad in its claims and stark in its language, naming a long list of defendants that includes Mr. Trump; his son, Donald Jr., and son-in-law, Jared Kushner; the Russian government and its intelligence service; and a group of former campaign aides including Mr. Stone, Paul Manafort, Rick Gates and George Papadopoulos.\n\nThere is substantial overlap between the targets of the D.N.C. lawsuit and the group of people known to be under investigation by Mr. Mueller. Mr. Manafort has been indicted by the special counsel, while Mr. Gates and Mr. Papadopoulos have both pleaded guilty to different charges.\n\nThe Democrats accused Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign of being \u201ca racketeering enterprise\u201d that worked with the Russians and WikiLeaks in a conspiracy that included hacking email servers at the D.N.C. and leaking damaging information to the public. The Trump campaign had extensive warnings of the Russians\u2019 activities and intentions, the Democrats allege, embraced the meddling of a foreign power.\n\nThe lawsuit demands monetary damages and a declaration that the defendants conspired to alter the course of the election.", "title": "Democratic Party Alleges Trump-Russia Conspiracy in New Lawsuit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cToday what unites us is more important than what divides us,\u201d he declared.\n\nSkepticism abounds, and many details, including the division of staffing and budget for a unified conference, remain unresolved. The longtime chief deputy under Ms. Stewart-Cousins, Senator Michael N. Gianaris of Queens, who has clashed with Mr. Klein, is expected to remain in the leadership. In the past, Mr. Klein and Mr. Gianaris have also run rival Democratic political operations.\n\nStill, the accord represents a watershed for fractious Democratic politics in the state and a political coup for Mr. Cuomo as he faces his most serious primary challenge. For years, Mr. Cuomo had said it was not in his power to arrange a \u201cshotgun marriage\u201d between Mr. Klein and Ms. Stewart-Cousins, but as a deal came together the governor was very much in the middle of it.\n\nIn a brief phone interview, Ms. Nixon said \u201cAndrew Cuomo can\u2019t have it both ways\u201d \u2014 claiming he was powerless to corral the I.D.C. for years and then taking credit for it disbanding on Wednesday. She accused Mr. Cuomo of working from the \u201cold playbook\u201d of centrist politics.\n\n\u201cHe is trying hard to evolve,\u201d she said, \u201cbut I think it\u2019s a little too late.\u201d\n\nMs. Nixon noted the accord came less than a week after lawmakers struck a deal on a $168 billion budget, when the state\u2019s priorities were set. Ms. Stewart-Cousins had been excluded from those discussions.\n\n\u201cI would have the leader of the Senate Democrats in the room negotiating,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Cuomo\u2019s team touts his progressive record, which includes approving a minimum-wage increase, paid family leave and some of the tightest gun-control measures in the nation, despite a Republican State Senate.\n\nMr. Cuomo has burnished those credentials since Ms. Nixon emerged on the scene, and on Wednesday he personally called Bill Lipton, the state director of the liberal Working Families Party, to describe the Senate unity agreement, according to three people familiar with the call.\n\nMr. Cuomo is actively seeking the endorsement of the Working Families Party, which has its own ballot line in New York. He has also been calling other leaders across the state on the phone to sell the unity package as key to helping the Democrats win a Senate majority.", "title": "Democrats in New York State Senate Reconcile After Years of Infighting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "The lead editorial pulled no punches, describing executives at Alden Global Capital, the paper\u2019s hedge-fund owner, as \u201cvulture capitalists.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe call for action,\u201d the editorial continued. It went on to make the case that \u201cDenver deserves a newspaper owner who supports its newsroom. If Alden isn\u2019t willing to do good journalism here, it should sell The Post to owners who will.\u201d\n\nThe Post, which serves a city of some 700,000 residents, has a weekday circulation of an estimated 170,000 and 8.6 million unique monthly visitors to its website. It has won nine Pulitzer Prizes, including in 2013 for its coverage of the mass shooting at a movie theater in Aurora, Colo. Alden Global Capital took control of the paper in 2010 after acquiring its bankrupt parent company, MediaNews Group, and runs it through a subsidiary, Digital First Media.\n\nPhoto\n\nChuck Plunkett, The Post\u2019s editorial page editor, masterminded the package of articles that, in part, rebuked the ownership of the publication where he has worked since 2003. Before posting it, Mr. Plunkett said, he did not warn executives at Digital First Media. The Post\u2019s news and opinion sections are separate fiefs, and he also did not inform the paper\u2019s chief editor, Lee Ann Colacioppo, of his plans.\n\nShortly after the articles were posted online, Guy Gilmore, the chief operating officer of Digital First Media, called Ms. Colacioppo. He said he wanted to discuss the editorial and the \u201cappropriate response\u201d from the company, Ms. Colacioppo said. The two ultimately decided, she said, that the stories would remain online and that the Sunday print section would proceed as planned. In addition, Mr. Plunkett would stay on as editorial page editor, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDigital First Media did not immediately reply to requests for comment.\n\nReaders inside and outside the newsroom met the articles with an outpouring of support.\n\n\u201cThe @denverpost is being murdered by its owners,\u201d one Post reporter, John Wenzel, wrote on Twitter. He continued, \u201cWe need a new owner, or we are going to get shut down (and soon).\u201d\n\n\u201cI am so proud to work for this brave newspaper staff,\u201d Elizabeth Hernandez, another Post reporter, said on Twitter. \u201cI\u2019ve been asked if I\u2019m afraid of losing my job for speaking out against our owners. I am afraid of losing my job due to our owners completely killing Colorado\u2019s largest newspaper.\u201d\n\nThe package also had a fan in City Hall.\n\n\u201cDenver is so proud of our flagship newspaper for speaking out,\u201d Mayor Michael B. Hancock said in a statement. \u201cThe Denver Post said it best \u2014 they are necessary to this \u2018grand democratic experiment,\u2019 especially at a time when the press and facts are under constant attack by the White House. For a New York hedge fund to treat our paper like any old business and not a critical member of our community is offensive. We urge the owners to rethink their business strategy or get out of the news business. Denver stands with our paper and stands ready to be part of the solution that supports local journalism and saves the 125-year-old Voice of the Rocky Mountain Empire.\u201d\n\nMr. Plunkett said he was aware that he was putting his livelihood at risk by taking on the paper\u2019s owner.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI had to do it because it was the right thing to do,\u201d he said. \u201cIf that means that I lose my job trying to stand up for my readers, then that means I\u2019m not working for the right people anyway.\u201d\n\nSunday\u2019s print opinion section will hit newsstands and land in driveways one day before more than two dozen employees at The Post say farewell to the newsroom.\n\nAlready devastated by staff reductions made since Alden Global Capital took over in 2010, The Post was ordered last month to slash another 30 jobs from a newsroom whose count was already below 100.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThese job losses are painful, and we know meaningful work will not get done because talented journalists have left the organization,\u201d Ms. Colacioppo told the staff after a meeting during which she delivered news of the layoffs. \u201cI\u2019m sure some commenters will cheer what they believe is the eventual demise of the mainstream media, but there is nothing to celebrate when a city has fewer journalists working in it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBefore she was ordered to carry out the latest reduction in staff \u2014 a process that is scheduled to be completed by July \u2014 the editor said she believed that things were looking up for The Post.\n\n\u201cAside from the last three weeks or so, I would have described the last year as a turning point for us,\u201d Ms. Colacioppo said in an interview on Saturday. \u201cThen this came.\u201d\n\nEarlier this year, in another cost-cutting effort, the newspaper left its longtime headquarters in the heart of downtown Denver, steps from the Capitol and City Hall, to an office in Adams County located in the same building as its printing press.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe moves have left the remaining Post staffers demoralized. \u201cEvery single staffing reduction has been really difficult,\u201d Jesse Paul, a politics reporter who joined the paper in 2014, said on Saturday. \u201cThis last one in particular I described it as cutting off a leg. This was literally like taking off a limb of the newspaper.\u201d\n\nThe announcement of the latest layoffs pitted Post employees against an ownership team that seems to have little regard for quality journalism. But as newspapers across the country continue to suffer \u2014 and as more of them come under the ownership of public companies like Gannett or investment firms looking to wring profits from a troubled business \u2014 The Post has also become a flash point in the newspaper industry\u2019s battle for survival.\n\nDigital First Media is among the biggest newspaper chains in the country, with more than 90 newspapers including The Pioneer Press of St. Paul, Minn.; The Mercury News of San Jose, Calif.; The Orange County Register; and The Boston Herald. The company has aggressively cut resources in its quest for profit, with recent staff reductions at several of its papers, including The Mercury News and The Herald.\n\nAlden\u2019s strategy follows a pattern: It typically buys newspapers at a bargain \u2014 it purchased The Herald for roughly $12 million \u2014 before cutting costs.\n\n\u201cThis is the problem with people who bought newspapers on the cheap, thinking they were buying at the bottom,\u201d said Alan D. Mutter, who teaches media economics at the University of California, Berkeley. \u201cThe revenue cataclysm continues and probably can\u2019t be reversed.\u201d\n\nUntil 2009, Denver was a two-newspaper town, with The Rocky Mountain News in competition with The Post. By taking its case to its readers, The Post is hoping to avoid its rival\u2019s fate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe were a pretty good newspaper for a real long time,\u201d Gregory L. Moore, who resigned as the Post\u2019s editor two years ago after a 14-year run, wrote in one of the pieces that went online Friday. \u201cI will miss it if it is gone.\u201d", "title": "Denver Post Rebels Against Its Hedge-Fund Ownership", "authors": ["Sydney Ember"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "For instance, a Yemeni man resettled in Serbia in 2016 has struggled to learn the local language while complaining that a Guant\u00e1namo stigma was wrecking his job and social-life prospects. He was resettled alongside a former detainee from Tajikistan, who has more readily adapted. But both lack legal status, and a Serbian official told one of their lawyers that the government is reviewing whether to deport them this summer, after the two-year travel ban ends. A government spokesman said no decision has been made.\n\nBeth Jacob, the Yemeni\u2019s lawyer, said her client fears repatriation but she could \u201cnot even find someone in the U.S. government to discuss our concerns with.\u201d And Matthew O\u2019Hara, a lawyer for the other former detainee, said his client would likely be persecuted or tortured in Tajikistan, which revoked his citizenship. \u201cMy level of concern went through the roof when I saw what happened in Senegal,\u201d he said.\n\nSenegal took in the two former detainees from Libya in April 2016 as a favor to Mr. Obama by its president, Macky Sall. The two men, Salem Abdul Salem Ghereby and Awad Khalifa, were given apartments in Dakar, with a minder living nearby.\n\nWhen a Times reporter visited the men on April 3, Mr. Ghereby complained that Senegal would not permit his wife and children from Libya to come stay with him. Both wanted larger grocery rations. But there were also signs the resettlement was working. Mr. Khalifa, for example, was warmly greeted by his neighbors and said he was engaged.\n\nSenegalese officials have refused to discuss what prompted them to consider deporting the men. Relations between African countries and the United States have generally deteriorated under Mr. Trump, especially since reports surfaced in January that he insulted African nations using a crude term.\n\nRamzi Kassem, a law professor at the City University of New York who is represents Mr. Khalifa, said his client was first told in January he might not be allowed to stay in Senegal. Mr. Kassem emailed the United States Embassy but received no reply. On March 26, the men were told in writing they would be deported.\n\nWhile Mr. Ghereby apparently did not object because at least in Libya he could be reunited with his family, Mr. Khalifa was terrified, telling a Times reporter that he feared he would be killed. Mount the flower from the fascinator onto a wide-brimmed hat, dyed to match the outfit. Ms. Sulla pulled out a color chart to determine the dress\u2019s precise shade of blue.\n\nThe showroom, on the 10th floor of a West 34th Street building, offers everything from practical straw hats to fantastical creations topped off with teapots or lobsters. Fascinators (decorative headpieces) start at $120, while more elaborate hats can go upward of $1,000.\n\nEvery Moore creation, whether a custom order or part of a line slated for boutiques or the shop\u2019s website, is made in the West 34th Street studio. Each hat is blocked over wooden forms, and smaller touches like cutting and stitching ribbon for the trim and hand-painting silk flowers, are also done on the premises.\n\nMs. Moore, 52, has worked closely with racetracks for over a decade. The Kentucky Derby Museum displays one of her hats. Mary J. Blige wore a Moore when she sang the national anthem at the 2012 Derby. But the conditions did not stop Linden and Yuki Kawauchi, 31, who came from behind to win the men\u2019s race. He is the first Japanese man to win the race since 1987, the year Kawauchi was born.\n\nLinden had to chase down Mamitu Daska of Ethiopia, also 34, who had bravely separated from the lead women\u2019s pack before the halfway mark and led by as much as 30 seconds, running alone in the rain and wind.\n\nEarly in the race, though, Linden was doubting whether she would even finish. When her fellow American Shalane Flanagan made a quick stop at a portable toilet about 45 minutes in, Linden slowed. She had told Flanagan she might drop out and that if her countrywoman needed anything \u2014 someone to block the wind, for example \u2014 to let Linden know before she quit.\n\n\u201cShe nudged me and was like, \u2018I\u2019m going to hit the bathroom,\u2019\u201d Linden recalled. \u201cI was like, if it slows up, great. If not, I will try to tuck in and bring you back to the group.\u201d\n\nLinden helped Flanagan rejoin the lead pack when she returned. Flanagan soon tired and wound up seventh, and Linden surged ahead.\n\n\u201cI was in third or fourth, and I thought, \u2018I probably shouldn\u2019t drop out,\u2019 so I kept going,\u201d Linden said. \u201cI mean honestly, I felt miserable, and sometimes when you pick it up and just forget about how you\u2019re feeling and just engage for a little bit, it can kind of turn everything around.\u201d\n\nKawauchi, who won in 2:15:58, defies the typical standard of elite runners entering just two or three marathons a year. Many of Japan\u2019s top marathoners compete for corporate teams that dictate very different schedules.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Kawauchi is not a full-time marathon runner. He has a job working as an administrator at a high school in Saitama Prefecture. His victory on Monday was his fourth in four marathons in 2018.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe welcomed the cold and rainy weather, even calling it \u201cinstrumental\u201d to his win. \u201cIf they had been regular conditions, it might have been a little bit tougher to beat some of the competition,\u201d he said through a translator.\n\nData suggests that marathoners run their fastest races when the temperature is in the 40s \u2014 but the study did not take wind into consideration. Others did not share Kawauchi\u2019s opinion on the conditions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe cold, the wet and the rain \u2014 that\u2019s the three worst things you can have, and you have that in one race,\u201d Abdi Abdirahman, a four-time United States Olympian who finished 15th on Monday, said on Sunday night. \u201cA lot of guys have been talking about it, trying to be the tough guy and say, \u2018Oh, I\u2019m not worried about it, I will just have to deal with it.\u2019 But you know, we will find out how many people are still intact after 30K.\u201d\n\nThe temperatures and winds led to slower race times. Runners were mostly reluctant to move in front of the pack early on. Geoffrey Kirui of Kenya finished second in 2:18:23, and Shadrack Biwott of the United States was third in 2:18:35.\n\nTim Don, the world-record holder in the Ironman triathlon, who broke his neck six months ago, finished in 2:49:42.\n\nThe rain was so bad that the traditional Patriots\u2019 Day Red Sox game was postponed for the first time since 1984.\n\nAnd there were certainly fewer fans than usual cheering along the course. Some who braved the weather taped plastic bags to their sneakers and wore trash bags in lieu of waterproof jackets.\n\nAt the starting line, runners crossed their arms over their chests, rubbing their forearms and jumping up and down in an attempt to stay warm. The athletes were all given two bib numbers so they could put one over each layer of clothing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe wheelchair races went at a significantly slower pace than usual, as athletes were cautious on wet roads. Marcel Hug of Switzerland won the men\u2019s push-rim race for the fourth straight year in a time of 1:46:26, the slowest since 1987. Tatyana McFadden won her fifth women\u2019s push-rim title, in 2:04:39, the slowest since 1988.\n\nErnst Van Dyk, the men\u2019s push-rim second place finisher from South Africa, put sandpaper on his gloves to gain traction between his hands and the wheel of his chair.\n\n\u201cI feel I really had to be Boston strong today,\u201d McFadden said after the race. \u201cIt just got so slippery.\u201d\n\nIt was not the first time runners endured harsh weather for the race. In 2015, there was also a strong headwind.\n\n\u201cIf it hadn\u2019t been difficult,\u201d Linden said, \u201cit probably wouldn\u2019t mean as much.\u201d", "title": "Desiree Linden and Yuki Kawauchi Pull Off Upsets in Rainy Boston Marathon", "authors": ["Malika Andrews"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Before the environmental activist and gay rights lawyer David Buckel set himself afire in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on April 14, he wrote a letter explaining that he had chosen his \u201cearly death by fossil fuel\u201d as an act of protest against the environmental catastrophe that we are bringing upon ourselves and the planet. It was a horrifying end, not least because in life Mr. Buckel had successfully taken on issues as seemingly intractable as the legalization of same-sex marriage. If someone so capable had given up on the environment, one woman remarked to a Times reporter, \u201cWhat does that mean for the rest of us?\u201d\n\nI was thinking about Mr. Buckel and about despair a few nights later, over a drink with Joe Walston of the Wildlife Conservation Society. As director of that organization\u2019s worldwide field conservation work, Mr. Walston routinely comes face-to-face with the dark forces of human overpopulation, mass extinction of species, climate change and pollution. But he is also the co-author of a paper being published this week in the journal BioScience that begins with the uplifting words of Winston Churchill to the British nation in June 1940, under the shadow of the Nazi conquest of France: \u201cIn casting up this dread balance sheet and contemplating our dangers with a disillusioned eye,\u201d Churchill declared, \u201cI see great reason for intense vigilance and exertion, but none whatever for panic or despair.\u201d\n\nMr. Walston and his co-authors go on to argue against the increasingly common view that these are the end times for life as we know it. Instead, they suggest that what the natural world is experiencing is a bottleneck \u2014 long, painful, undoubtedly frightening and likely to get worse in the short term \u2014 but with the forces of an eventual breakthrough and environmental recovery already gathering strength around us.\n\nMr. Walston sipped his beer and listed what he called \u201cthe four pillars\u201d of conservation in the modern era \u2014 a stabilized human population, increasingly concentrated in urban areas, able to escape extreme poverty, and with a shared understanding of nature and the environment \u2014 \u201cand all four are happening right now.\u201d He singled out the trend toward urbanization as the biggest driver of environmental progress, bigger perhaps than all the conservation efforts undertaken by governments and environmental groups alike.", "title": "Opinion | Despairing on Earth Day?
