Aid Effort", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Travel operators bill Canc\u00fan and the adjoining Riviera Maya on Mexico\u2019s Caribbean coast as carefree beach escapes with something for everyone from spring break partyers to families. But a wave of violence, linked to rival drug gangs, threatens travel in the region like a storm hovering on the horizon.\n\nThe local news site Noticaribe reported 14 murders in Canc\u00fan over a 36-hour period in early April, continuing a pattern of violence reported last summer. Gun deaths have also occurred in Playa del Carmen, the biggest town on the Riviera Maya, about 40 miles south of Canc\u00fan.\n\nTravelers have not been targeted in these crimes, but a bomb that detonated in February on a ferry linking Playa del Carmen with the island of Cozumel, a popular cruise port, injured more than two dozen passengers, including tourists. It prompted the Department of State to issue a travel ban on the ferry route for government employees. Reuters later reported the bomb was a homemade device believed to be unrelated to terrorists or organized crime.\n\nSince then, Mexican authorities have strengthened security around the ferry as well as the ferries that run between Canc\u00fan and Isla Mujeres, including adding metal detectors and bomb-sniffing dogs. The American government subsequently dropped its ban on ferry travel.", "title": "Despite Violence, Tourism Is Strong in Mexican Resort Areas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Arguing against jail time, Mr. Arlia said that Mr. Desormeau\u2019s \u201cfall from grace\u201d was already accomplished. He had lost the \u201ccareer he cherished\u201d as a police officer and had been reduced to working as an Uber driver, the lawyer said.\n\nMr. Desormeau, who still faces a separate criminal case in Manhattan, did not speak during the sentencing. Mr. Arlia assured the judge Mr. Desormeau felt \u201cremorse and contrition.\u201d\n\nMr. Arlia, the defense lawyer, also argued that jail was unnecessary from the perspective of deterrence. The prosecution and conviction of Mr. Desormeau alone was enough to deter other officers who might be willing to lie in order to justify an arrest or make a case stick, Mr. Arlia said.\n\n\u201cThis case screams to every member of service: \u2018Don\u2019t even think of embellishing or making up facts to support an arrest,\u2019\u201d Mr. Arlia said.\n\nA jury concluded Mr. Desormeau had done just that in 2014, when he claimed to have witnessed a man sell drugs to two women on a street corner in Jamaica, Queens.\n\nAccording to Mr. Desormeau, after observing those two transactions, he and his partner got out of their unmarked car and stopped the man, Roosevelt McCoy, in front of a nearby Jamaican restaurant. Mr. Desormeau testified that he quickly recovered crack cocaine from behind Mr. McCoy\u2019s waistband.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut surveillance videotape from the Jamaican restaurant showed Mr. McCoy shooting pool inside the restaurant when the detective said he was outside dealing drugs. The two detectives can be seen approaching Mr. McCoy inside the restaurant, bringing him outside and then searching him. On the video, they do not appear to find any contraband.\n\nThe case raised troubling questions about the prevalence of police perjury, particularly because a gun arrest which Mr. Desormeau and his partner made in Manhattan less than three months later became the subject of additional charges, including perjury. That case is pending.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Times examined Mr. Desormeau\u2019s career in an article in October. More recently The Times investigated the phenomenon of \u201ctestilying\u201d within the New York Police Department in a series of articles.\n\nOn Wednesday, Justice Aloise criticized Mr. Desormeau for undermining his fellow officers, but did not address the broader issue of police perjury, other than to suggest that Mr. Desormeau\u2019s actions could encourage a tendency to regard police testimony with undue skepticism. \u201cIt helps feed the false narrative that police officers are not to be trusted and their testimony is not to be believed,\u201d Judge Aloise said.\n\nThen Judge Aloise accused the prosecution of allowing Mr. McCoy, who was the main witness against Mr. Desormeau, to lie on the witness stand. Mr. Desormeau had said he found a rock of crack cocaine on Mr. McCoy, and testing indicated that the twist bag in which the crack was found contained DNA that matched Mr. McCoy\u2019s sample.\n\nYet Mr. McCoy testified during Mr. Desormeau\u2019s trial that the police had never recovered drugs from him, not during a search on the sidewalk, nor during a strip search at the precinct. That claim, according to Justice Aloise, cast a shadow over the entire prosecution. Calling Mr. McCoy \u201ca bum,\u201d the judge accused the district attorney\u2019s office of relying on a lying witness in order to convict the detective of another lie.\n\n\u201cThis was the most transparently disingenuous testimony this court has ever witnessed,\u201d Justice Aloise said.\n\nThe Queens district attorney\u2019s office said in a statement it stood by the prosecution and pointed out both the defense and the jury were made aware of questions about Mr. McCoy\u2019s credibility.\n\n\u201cWe will not be deterred from pursuing bad cops by the court\u2019s ill-advised comments,\u201d the statement read. \u201cKevin Desormeau was a New York City police detective. He should be and was held to a higher standard. He violated his oath and framed the complainant.\u201d\n\nMr. McCoy had spent much of his adult life in prison for killing two men. After Mr. Desormeau arrested him on the cocaine charges, he spent 51 days in jail. He later received a legal settlement that cost the city $547,501.", "title": "Detective Convicted of Perjury Receives No Jail Time", "authors": ["Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "But he said that the bank would aim to become less dependent on revenue from investment banking, which is often erratic, and instead look for growth in markets closer to home like Italy and Spain.\n\nMr. Sewing spoke after Deutsche Bank said Thursday morning that net profit had fallen nearly 80 percent in the first quarter of 2018 to 120 million euros, or $146 million, on revenue of \u20ac7 billion.\n\nThe meager return \u201cunderscores the need for immediate action,\u201d said Mr. Sewing, a risk management specialist who replaced John Cryan as chief executive at the beginning of April. \u201cOur shareholder returns are not satisfactory.\u201d\n\nThe plan will also include job cuts, but Deutsche Bank did not give specifics.\n\nDeutsche Bank became a major presence on Wall Street in 1998 when it acquired Bankers Trust. But the deal was troubled from the start. The $10.1 billion purchase price was widely viewed as inflated, and the risk-happy traders of Bankers Trust clashed with Deutsche Bank\u2019s conservative German leadership.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe hidden risks of Deutsche Bank\u2019s investment banking operations became clear after the onset of the financial crisis in 2008. The bank had a hand in virtually all of the major scandals of the era. It paid billions of dollars in fines and settlements related to the fraudulent sale of mortgage bank securities, and over its role in a conspiracy to rig the benchmarks used to set the interest rates on trillions of dollars in loans and other financial products.\n\nStill, Deutsche Bank was more reluctant than its European rivals to reduce its Wall Street presence. Others like Credit Suisse moved more quickly, and have since been rewarded with better profits.\n\nDeutsche Bank\u2019s position in investment banking has become increasingly untenable. The bank\u2019s share price has fallen 30 percent since December, and it has not reported an annual profit since 2014. The stock market values the bank at less than half of the nominal value of its assets, an indication that investors believe there are hidden risks.\n\nTraders seemed Thursday to be waiting to see if Deutsche Bank\u2019s latest strategic plan by would be more successful than others. The bank\u2019s stock price was little changed at \u20ac12 per share.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDeutsche Bank has also been under intense pressure from regulators. The European Central Bank, which has ultimate authority for bank regulation in the eurozone, has asked the lender to calculate the cost of winding down its derivative holdings.\n\nThough the analysis is hypothetical, it underscores regulators\u2019 concern about risks that may be lurking in Deutsche Bank\u2019s balance sheet.\n\nMr. Cryan, who served less than three years as chief executive, had already started trimming the investment bank. But he was criticized as not moving fast enough. Mr. Sewing\u2019s plan appears to go much further by explicitly shifting the focus from the United States to Europe.\n\n\u201cWe will change the path of our bank now,\u201d Mr. Sewing said. \u201cThere is no time to waste.\u201d", "title": "Deutsche Bank Abandons Wall Street Ambitions, and Focuses on Europe", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "One of Mr. Sewing\u2019s main tasks will be to resolve Deutsche Bank\u2019s ambivalence toward its investment banking unit, which has produced huge profits in some years and huge losses in others. The bank, based in Frankfurt, is one of the last European banks with a prominent outpost on Wall Street, but has struggled to keep up with its American rivals even as they have come back stronger than ever.\n\nMarcus Schenck, the co-head of the investment bank, will also leave as part of the shake-up announced Sunday. Garth Ritchie, who shared leadership of the investment bank with Mr. Schenck, will assume sole responsibility.\n\nMr. Sewing (his name is pronounced \u201csaving\u201d) is not expected to radically change the bank\u2019s direction, but he will face pressure to move more aggressively than Mr. Cryan, whose dismissal had been widely rumored in recent weeks.\n\nDuring his three-year tenure, Mr. Cryan, a bookish Briton who speaks German fluently, helped Deutsche Bank begin to crawl out from under the legal problems that had weighed on the bank\u2019s reputation and cost it billions of euros in fines and settlements. Late in 2016, for instance, Deutsche Bank reached a settlement with the United States government to pay $7.2 billion related to the sale of toxic mortgage securities before the 2008 financial crisis.\n\nBut new scandals have continued to appear. Last year, Deutsche Bank agreed to pay more than $600 million to authorities in New York and Britain to settle charges that it had helped Russian investors launder as much as $10 billion through branches in Moscow, London and New York. Regulators said the conduct took place from 2011 to 2015.\n\nMr. Cryan was also unable to return Deutsche Bank to profitability. The bank reported a loss of \u20ac735 million, or about $900 million, for 2017, its third consecutive annual loss.\n\n\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInvestors have punished the bank\u2019s shares, which have lost more than half their value since Mr. Cryan became co-chief executive in July 2015. Mr. Cryan initially shared the top job with J\u00fcrgen Fitschen and became the sole chief executive in 2016.\n\nUnlike almost all of his recent predecessors, Mr. Sewing is not primarily an investment banker. He has worked at Deutsche Bank since 1989, spending time at bank offices in London, Singapore, Tokyo and Toronto. He held top positions in risk management at the bank and was its chief auditor until being named to the management board in 2015.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a German and a Deutsche Bank lifer with a background in risk management, Mr. Sewing will reassure German regulators concerned that the bank has taken too long to pare down the risky assets accumulated by its London-based investment banking unit. With its zeal to remain in the Wall Street big leagues, Deutsche Bank was slower than its European rivals like Credit Suisse to scale back its investment banking operations after the financial crisis.\n\nMr. Sewing\u2019s management portfolio has included Postbank, which offers banking services from German post offices. That background will most likely raise expectations that he will shift Deutsche Bank\u2019s emphasis from investment banking back to its roots in the German domestic market.\n\nThose expectations may be misplaced. The German banking market is overcrowded and profit margins are slim. Deutsche Bank has little prospect for growth without investment banking and international expansion. In a sign that the bank continues to have ambitions in investment banking, the supervisory board has nominated John Thain \u2014 former chief executive of Merrill Lynch and the New York Stock Exchange and a former co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs \u2014 as a new member. The nomination must be approved by shareholders at their annual meeting in May.\n\nMr. Cryan\u2019s departure followed several weeks of media speculation that created the impression of intense infighting between him and Mr. Achleitner, a former partner at Goldman Sachs who has been chairman of the Deutsche Bank supervisory board since 2012.\n\nOn March 28, Mr. Cryan wrote a memo to Deutsche Bank employees in which he acknowledged the rumors but said, \u201cI am absolutely committed to serving our bank and to continuing down the path on which we started some three years ago.\u201d\n\nLate Saturday, Deutsche Bank issued a one-sentence statement saying that the supervisory board would discuss the chief executive job, tacitly confirming that Mr. Cryan was on his way out. On Sunday evening, the 20 members of the supervisory board held a conference call, issuing a statement well after 11 p.m.\n\nThe public power struggle was reminiscent of previous management changes, and could also put pressure on Mr. Achleitner, who bears ultimate responsibility for the bank\u2019s strategy.", "title": "Deutsche Bank Replaces C.E.O. Amid Losses and Lack of Direction", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The New Jersey Devils are back in the playoffs for the first time since 2012.\n\nPatrick Maroon set up second-period goals by Pavel Zacha and Miles Wood, and the Devils ended a five-year postseason drought with a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs on Thursday night.\n\nKeith Kinkaid, the mainstay in goal since the end of January, made 31 saves as the Devils won their fourth straight and extended their points streak to eight games (7-0-1). He preserved the lead with a stop in close on Auston Matthews with just over seven minutes to play.\n\nNew Jersey is 10-2-1 in its past 13 in going from the worst team in the Eastern Conference a year ago to one that will get a chance to start playing for the Stanley Cup next week.\n\nAfter it was over, the players went to center ice and saluted the fans, who were standing for much of the final minute.", "title": "Devils Head to Playoffs for First Time Since 2012", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "NEWARK \u2014 Taylor Hall had a goal and two assists as the Devils rallied for a 5-2 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning on Monday in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference quarterfinals in Newark.\n\nHall\u2019s big night ensured the Devils will get a chance to even the series in Game 4 at home on Wednesday.\n\nHall scored his second goal of the series and then made nifty passes to set up goals by Will Butcher and Stefan Noesen in the third period. Hall\u2019s pass to Butcher during a five-on-three tied the game at just over 4 minutes into the third, and his feed to Noesen gave the Devils a one-goal lead with 7 minutes and 5 seconds remaining.\n\nHall became the first Devil to have a three-point postseason game since Zach Parise in 2012 against the Rangers in the Eastern Conference finals.", "title": "Devils Rally to Climb Back Into Series Against Lightning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "But the classes, targeting a disease that affects 30 million Americans, have also become a revenue generator for hospitals and an opportunity for marketing and branding.\n\n\u201cIf you can get 25 in the class and charge $500 each, you can make a lot of money,\u201d said Gerard Anderson, a professor of health policy and management at Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg School of Public Health. An additional incentive is that the classes bring \u201cpeople into the hospital that they expect will need the hospital in the future.\u201d\n\nMr. Phillips\u2019s class had about a dozen students and included lunch, parking and a sample of Glucerna, a nutrition drink formulated for diabetics. The instructor noted that St. Mary\u2019s operates a gym that participants could join for a fee.\n\nDiabetes is among the costliest of medical conditions. The American Diabetes Association estimates that average medical expenditures for those with diabetes diagnoses are 2.3 times higher than those without.\n\nThe classes, say experts, are a chance to rein in some of that spending. When Harvard Law School researchers ran the numbers in 2015, they found an estimated savings of $1,309 over three years for every Medicare Advantage patient who completed an education program.\n\nBut for many patients, the cost of the classes can either become a barrier to actually attending, or leave them with unanticipated bills.\n\nAfter St. Mary\u2019s billed Mr. Phillips\u2019s insurer $1,044 for the two half-day classes he attended, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Georgia, in turn, lowered that to $626, or the \u201callowed amount\u201d it had negotiated with St. Mary\u2019s. Because he had not yet met his $3,500 annual deductible, Mr. Phillips is responsible for the entire $626.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Phillips, who took early retirement from his job in 2005 to care for his elderly parents, said he probably would not have attended had he known the price. He\u2019d expected the instruction to cost about $50, noting that he\u2019d already paid $120 for a one-on-one session with one of the hospital\u2019s certified diabetes educators, or C.D.E.s.\n\nMedicare sets an average reimbursement of $356 for an entire nine-hour group course, with the beneficiary\u2019s share of that amount estimated at $71.\n\nSt. Mary\u2019s said it is proud of its fully accredited program, which helps diabetes patients manage their condition.\n\n\u201cOur charges are in line with other similarly recognized programs in the state,\u201d according to a written statement from Mark Ralston, public relations director for the St. Mary\u2019s Health Care System.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cPrior to enrollment, we send patients a letter that includes information that there will be a charge,\u201d the statement said, noting that the amount \u201cthe patient will pay depends on the patient\u2019s insurance coverage.\u201d\n\nMr. Ralston also noted that, because St. Mary\u2019s is a Catholic health care system, \u201cwe are always happy to work with patients who have financial difficulties, up to and including applications for charity care.\u201d\n\nMr. Phillips\u2019s charges seem high even though they were for a program that might actually save the insurer money over the long term, said William Custer, who studies health care markets as the director of the Center for Health Services Research at Georgia State University.\n\nHe questioned why the insurer, one of the state and the region\u2019s largest, didn\u2019t drive a harder bargain.\n\n\u201cIf the course has a benefit in terms of increasing health and reducing utilization, Blue Cross has an incentive to cover it and an incentive to negotiate,\u201d said Mr. Custer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nColin Manning, a spokesman for the insurer, said, \u201cWe do have questions about the amount charged for this class and we are reaching out to St. Mary\u2019s Hospital to discuss reimbursement for this service.\u201d\n\nDiabetes management courses vary considerably in length and format, and even more so in price.\n\nInternet searches and phone calls uncovered some cost examples, including a $396, nine-hour course in Ohio to one in Wisconsin that lasted six hours and had a $420 price.\n\nOne of the most expensive \u2014 a 7\u00bd-hour diabetes self-management group course that included two-hour individual sessions with a dietitian and a diabetes educator \u2014 cost $1,700 in Washington state.\n\nHoward County General Hospital in Maryland has decided to bypass insurance and charge patients $50 upfront for a six-hour course taught by a certified diabetes educator. That price was selected because in many cases it was less than what people with insurance would pay in co-payments or deductibles under the former price, which was billed to insurers at a rate of about $1,000.\n\nBefore they made the switch about a year and a half ago, patients would often cancel after learning how much they would owe, said Mike Taylor, a clinical manager and diabetes educator who runs the hospital\u2019s program. \u201cWe would literally lose half the appointments we would schedule.\u201d\n\nThe Maryland hospital also offers free classes by a lay instructor.\n\nMeanwhile, thinking his original bill was in error, Mr. Phillips in late January appealed St. Mary\u2019s $1,044 charge to his insurer. It was denied a month later as the insurer noted the bill was \u201ccoded correctly.\u201d Hospitals can charge what they like for their services.\n\nAnd after being contacted by the hospital billing office in early April to confirm he was aware of his bill\u2019s \u201cdelinquent status,\u201d he wrote a second appeal letter.\n\nMr. Phillips said the class was well taught, though he noted that he was already dieting before he took the class. He \u201cfollowed what they said\u201d and he has lost 31 pounds, he said, and his blood sugar is back in the normal range.\n\n\u201cAt least now I\u2019m well-informed about what to eat and not eat if I ever do have diabetes,\u201d he said wryly.", "title": "Diabetes Self-Care Courses Can Come With Sticker Shock", "authors": ["Julie Appleby", "Kaiser Health News"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Two months later, after going home to Georgia to evaluate her position, DeShields informed Tennessee that she was leaving and signed with Cukurova in Turkey.\n\n\u201cAs a collegiate athlete, there\u2019s a kind of uniformity to it and a second level depending where you go,\u201d DeShields said. \u201cBeing at Tennessee, there\u2019s a Lady Vol way \u2014 \u2018This is how Lady Vols do things, this is how Lady Vols behave, this is how Lady Vols talk, this is how we walk.\u2019 I\u2019m blessed to have gone to Tennessee and been a part of that, but there always is the personal side of everybody that is maybe different from what the university has sculpted as their idea. That\u2019s why I say I\u2019m a unicorn.\u201d\n\nOverseas, DeShields said she learned to be more aggressive playing with and against tougher competition. She also spent more time watching film and scouting opponents.\n\n\u201cI used to kind of take more breaks because I could,\u201d DeShields said. \u201cBefore I was able to maneuver on the court better than most people because of my natural ability. Now I want to dominate.\u201d\n\nAccording to the Eurobasket website, DeShields averaged 16.5 points for Cukurova. Her detours raised questions about her fit as a franchise centerpiece, but the Chicago Sky felt confident enough to take her with their first pick (they also held the No. 4 pick in the draft, which they used on Gabby Williams of Connecticut).\n\nDeShields\u2019s career arc has certainly been different from that of A\u2019ja Wilson, who was selected first by the Las Vegas Aces and has been a model of stability throughout her career. Wilson was born in South Carolina and stayed in-state through college, where she led the Gamecocks to the national title in 2017.\n\nBut DeShields\u2019s choices are not unprecedented. Epiphanny Prince notably left Rutgers early in 2009 to play in Turkey and Russia before entering the W.N.B.A. Transfers are increasingly becoming the norm in the women\u2019s college game. Azura Stevens, who was selected sixth over all by the Dallas Wings on Thursday, transferred to Connecticut after two seasons at Duke and then decided to forgo her final year of eligibility with the Huskies.", "title": "Diamond DeShields\u2019s Path to the W.N.B.A. Took Her From Tennessee to Turkey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019m attracted to diamonds because they are part of my family: My father is descended from a long line of jewelers, and my brothers now work in jewelry as well. For this film, I wanted to use my father\u2019s voice to tell an animated story using diamonds as a metaphor for mankind through the ages. To me, the place of diamonds in society is as multifaceted as the gemstones themselves, full of paradoxes and intrigue.\n\nSince we discovered them thousands of years ago, mankind has turned diamonds into symbols of authority, power, passion or wealth. But the stone\u2019s commercial exploitation has led to its ever-stricter standardization. We devalue imperfect diamonds, so to stay marketable, the diamond had to become more and more standardized in its appearance. But impurities are what give diamonds their individuality and character.", "title": "Opinion | Diamonds and Lies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Diana Catherine Banks and Emile Christopher Thompson were married April 14 at St. Augustine Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. Robert Boxie, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.\n\nMs. Banks, 36, is a senior counsel at the American Bankers Association in Washington. She graduated from Stanford University and received a law degree from Harvard. She was previously a deputy assistant secretary of defense during the Obama administration.\n\nShe is the daughter of Yon N. Banks and William C. Banks of Columbus, Ga. The bride\u2019s father retired from the Army, having achieved the rank of sergeant first class at Fort Benning, Ga. Her mother, who is retired, worked as a custodian at the Swift Denim factory, which manufactured denim shirts and jeans in Columbus.\n\nMr. Thompson, 34, works in Washington as an assistant United States attorney for the District of Columbia. He graduated from Morehouse College in Atlanta and received a law degree from Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C.", "title": "Diana Banks, Emile Thompson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "June 10, 2017: It is so hot. I have ordered two of the biggest stainless steel fans I can find from Restoration Hardware, and my daughter is assembling them. The little window unit is not strong enough to cool the entire apartment.\n\nBoard discussions remain heated. \u201cAre you calling me selfish?\u201d asks one director along the way. I make the mistake of saying, \u201cYes! Yes, I am!\u201d Apologize later in a phone call. Presidents are not supposed to lose it. This has gone downhill so quickly.\n\nNov. 25, 2017: Frantic pounding on the door late at night by fellow board member. Heart racing, I leap out of tub to learn our overflow drain has leaked, flooding the apartment downstairs. It is our third strike on the same ceiling, once with gravel, once with sewage and now with bath water. My husband mops their floor.\n\nImage Credit Kevin Whipple\n\nDec. 4, 2017: Finally! The board passes a spending plan for installing central air-conditioning, dividing estimated costs between the co-op as a building project and the individuals who want air-conditioning now. But we are not united. Oh no. A majority of the board \u2014 five \u2014 were in favor, but two were very, very opposed. (Those in favor of the plan believe it is in the best interest of the building, would increase the building\u2019s value and be accessible to all apartments in the future.)\n\nDec. 20, 2017: Heading into the holidays. The new buyers upstairs are upset that the board has not yet approved their remodeling plans. Their plans include A/C lines running up to the roof through the shaft. It feels like an end run by a new player. They issue a litigation hold letter to the board \u2014 five days before Christmas. (I have not done any shopping yet.)\n\nWhat is a litigation hold letter? Board members are not allowed to delete emails or use a shredder because our new neighbors may be planning to sue, and they might need the material. The letter from their lawyer says, \u201cWe have reason to believe that you have documents and materials in your possession, custody or control that are relevant to claims that may be asserted against you and others.\u201d\n\nReally? For the record, I have complied. Naturally, I am thinking of Hillary. Lesson learned on deleting emails. I no longer want to be president of this co-op board. I no longer care if anyone likes me. And they are welcome to my emails. I have saved every last one.", "title": "Diary of a New York Co-op Board President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods plans to destroy the assault-style rifles and accessories it agreed to take off its shelves in February instead of returning them to manufacturers.\n\nIt is the latest action taken by the Pennsylvania retailer that agreed to ban the sale of assault-style rifles at its 35 Field & Stream stores, and to stop selling firearms and ammunition to anyone younger than 21.\n\nSince the massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., in February that left 17 students and staff members dead, corporations have quickly responded to the public\u2019s growing demand for responsible gun control measures. Several retailers agreed to stop selling firearms to consumers younger than 21. Among them are Walmart, the nation\u2019s largest gun seller; L.L. Bean; and Kroger, which said it would restrict gun sales at its Fred Meyer stores.\n\nWalmart also agreed to stop selling toys online that look like assault-style rifles. And Kroger announced in March that it would stop selling \u201cassault-rifle themed periodicals.\u201d", "title": "Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods Will Destroy the Assault-Style Weapons It Didn\u2019t Sell", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "She asked me whether I thought I\u2019d be where I am now if I\u2019d made a different decision.\n\nI honestly don\u2019t know. Where I am now is the Midwest, a newly tenured professor at a Big Ten school. My best friend from high school, who graduated second in our class and was supposed to be my Gator roommate, went to the University of Florida and loved it. She has a fulfilling career, rewarding friendships and a gorgeous house in a South Florida neighborhood we\u2019d both always dreamed of living in: There is no \u201cbut\u201d to alter these facts.\n\nAt Cornell, I had a hallmate from Iowa whose family worked in pig ranching; the school she\u2019d almost attended instead was the University of Iowa. She eventually chose to transfer back home. The way she put it, she realized she just didn\u2019t need to be in upstate New York spending so much money for what she wanted to do with her future, though I\u2019m sure there was more to it than that. The girls in my hall \u2014 myself included, all of us from the East Coast \u2014 teased her about her pig-ranching background, a fact of which I\u2019m now very much ashamed.\n\nI don\u2019t know why the University of Florida didn\u2019t feel like the right place for me, but that feeling was strong enough to make me sign on for some major financial commitments at a school far from home at the ripe old age of 18 and head to a school that may not have been right for me either.\n\nI want to be clear here: I\u2019m not trying to encourage people to take on debt. It would probably be even harder for me today to make the same decision I made in 1999, with the debt feeling even more insurmountable and new fears about what the job market would look like when I finished.\n\nBut was it worth it? Did I need to go to the more expensive school?\n\nHere is my answer: When I started high school, my mother took me to an orthodontist. I had inherited my parents\u2019 jacked-up teeth, and at the time when most of my friends were getting their braces removed, we were there potentially to start the whole ordeal, having waited until we were in a good enough financial position to do so. After poking around in my mouth and taking impressions of my teeth, the orthodontist declared that I did not need braces \u2014 my bite was mostly fine, so braces weren\u2019t necessary and would be primarily for cosmetic reasons. Because we\u2019d already identified ourselves as the kind of people who would need help affording orthodontics, the doctor thought this news would come as a relief to my mother. It did not: She started crying.\n\n\u201cIf she needed them, in my head that would make it easier to pay for it,\u201d she said. \u201cEveryone is getting braces. Someday they\u2019ll all be people with straight teeth. I don\u2019t want her to not have that.\u201d\n\nShe wanted to give me an advantage she never had, and this itself counted as a need \u2014 it had to. She knew that people might make assumptions about me based on something superficial.\n\nMy braces came off my junior year of high school. I still sometimes wear my top retainer: I grind my teeth in my sleep, unconsciously undoing the work that made them straight. The bottom retainer no longer fits, thanks to a wisdom tooth I foolishly chose to leave in my head. It has all but pushed my bottom teeth back to where they started.", "title": "Opinion | Did I Choose the Wrong College?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "As the power elite of Washington filed out of the White House Correspondents\u2019 Association dinner on Saturday, chattering about the rough-and-tumble set by the comedian Michelle Wolf, the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, was invited to pose for a portrait with her fellow honorees on the dais.\n\nMs. Wolf smiled for the camera. But Ms. Sanders declined, not wanting to appear in a photo alongside the comedian, according to two people who described the exchange.\n\nIt was an early ripple of the tsunami to come. Ms. Wolf\u2019s punch lines about Ms. Sanders and Kellyanne Conway, another prominent woman in the Trump administration, set off a high-dudgeon debate that raised the possibility that Saturday\u2019s edition of the nearly 100-year-old dinner could be the last of its kind.\n\n\u201cIt will not surprise you to hear that my email inbox is overflowing with advice on how to improve the dinner,\u201d Olivier Knox, the incoming president of the White House Correspondents\u2019 Association, said in an interview on Monday. He reeled off the possibilities now on the table: \u201cNo entertainer. No comic. A serious speaker. Maybe a musician. Maybe don\u2019t televise it.\u201d", "title": "Did Michelle Wolf Kill the White House Correspondents\u2019 Dinner?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "JAMES ADLER, CAMBRIDGE, MASS.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMichelle Wolf\u2019s comments did what the fictional Mr. Dooley famously urged the press to do, \u201cafflict the comfortable.\u201d Ms. Wolf did that well, evidenced by the stony silence from many of the dinner\u2019s participants. Watching journalists and politicians squirm in their fine tuxes and gowns as their deeds are called out is the perfect visualization of Mr. Dooley\u2019s quote.\n\nPresident Trump and Sarah Huckabee Sanders lash out almost daily, and now they have seen how this feels when it happens to them. If Mr. Trump had attended the dinner, he would have had an opportunity to have his day in court with humor aimed at his critics.\n\nThe White House Correspondents\u2019 Association dinner is the only time a comedian can say what much of America is really thinking to the press and the White House occupants in attendance. Please do not make it go away.\n\nJACQUELINE HICKS GRAZETTE\n\nUPPER MARLBORO, MD.\n\nThe writer is a former journalism teacher.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs a father, I have recently found myself emphasizing more often than I should have to the importance of being kind. Initially, I faulted memes. Too often, my kids laughed at their phones and attributed it to a funny meme they read online. I soon learned that some memes contain horribly inappropriate \u201chumor\u201d directed at others.\n\nIt was easy to initially blame social media. The White House Correspondents\u2019 Association dinner proves that the problem is more systemic. How did we get to the point where it is appropriate to personally attack other Americans based on the way they look, think, speak or dress?", "title": "Opinion | Did Michelle Wolf\u2019s Roast Go Too Far?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The news agency Reuters published an in-depth report on the Inn Din slaughter in February. U Wa Lone and U Kyaw Soe Oo, local reporters for the agency who had investigated the killings, were detained late last year. They are now on trial, accused of violating Myanmar\u2019s Official Secrets Act. The prisoner amnesty on Tuesday, which covered only those convicted of crimes, did not include their names.\n\nU Min Tun Soe, the deputy director of Myanmar\u2019s Prisons Department, confirmed that those convicted of crimes in Inn Din remained behind bars. \u201cI don\u2019t remember all their names,\u201d he said, \u201cbut I can say these seven soldiers are still in Sittwe prison.\u201d The seven men filmed exiting Sittwe prison, he added, had not been members of the military.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe amnesty on Tuesday was the first major one since Daw Aung San Suu Kyi\u2019s National League for Democracy took over Myanmar\u2019s civilian administration two years ago. More than 8,000 prisoners were freed, many of them drug offenders or soldiers who had deserted.\n\nPresident Win Myint \u2014 who holds the position because Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi is constitutionally precluded from taking the post \u2014 issued the pardons to coincide with Myanmar\u2019s new year. The presidential pardon also included 36 political prisoners.\n\nDuring her long years in political opposition, most of which she spent under house arrest, Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi campaigned against the military government\u2019s penchant for locking up dissidents. When she was released in 2010, she said her first priority would be to clear the country\u2019s jails of political prisoners.\n\nBut since the National League for Democracy began sharing power with Myanmar\u2019s military in 2016, the number of people charged with violating a harsh online defamation law has skyrocketed. Others have been jailed for unlawful association or under vague legislation criminalizing the circulation of information that could cause public disharmony.\n\nMore than 200 people engaged in political activity remain in jail or are awaiting trial, according to rights groups that monitor Myanmar, formerly known as Burma.\n\n\u201cWith the use and scope of repressive laws being increased rather than repealed, it seems that under the N.L.D. government, there is no end in sight to the scourge of political prisoners in Burma\u2019s jails,\u201d said Mark Farmaner, director of Burma Campaign U.K., a rights advocacy group.", "title": "Did Soldiers Jailed for Killings Go Free? Myanmar TV Says Yes (Briefly)", "authors": ["Hannah Beech"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "The trial of Bill Cosby provides what social scientists might call a natural experiment. In the spring of 2017, a jury could not agree on whether Mr. Cosby had drugged and sexually assaulted Andrea Constand, setting the stage for a retrial.\n\nBut between that trial and this one came the revelations over Harvey Weinstein and a cascade of other powerful men that invigorated the #MeToo movement. The big question: would it make any difference?\n\nIt well may have. The jury deliberated not even two days \u2014 compared with six days the first time around \u2014 before finding Mr. Cosby guilty on all counts.\n\nThere were other key differences: Jurors saw a new defense witness, who testified that Ms. Constand had said it would be easy to use fabricated abuse claims to extort a celebrity.", "title": "Did the #MeToo Movement Sway the Cosby Jury?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI don\u2019t know if I expect that every time he comes up,\u201d Manager Aaron Boone said of Gregorius. \u201cBut I know I feel good when he walks to the plate with runners on base. His patience has continued to grow and when you make a mistake to him it\u2019s usually an extra-base hit. He\u2019s obviously in a pretty good place right now.\u201d\n\nSo are the Yankees, who won their fourth straight game and, with the Boston Red Sox losing for the third straight time, moved within four games of first place in the American League East.\n\nBut perhaps the biggest story of the first 22 games of the 2018 Yankees season has been the rise of Gregorius.\n\nHe has steadily improved at the plate ever since a difficult first month as a Yankee in 2015, in which he batted .206 and made a number of mental mistakes on the basepaths. He hit a career-high 25 home runs last season, and seems to have the Yankees\u2019 shortstop job locked up for as long as he wants it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re just continuing to see the evolution of a really good player,\u201d Boone said of Gregorius\u2019s performance this year.\n\nThat evolution is most readily apparent when Gregorius, a left-hander, faces left-handed pitching. When he was with the Arizona Diamondbacks in 2014, he batted just .137 against lefties, but that has steadily improved; this season, he is batting .333 against them.\n\nAnd he is showing signs of becoming a more selective hitter; after having walked just 19 times in 2016 and 25 times last year, Gregorius has already drawn 15 walks in 22 games this season.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s continued to make adjustments,\u201d Boone said. \u201cHe\u2019s coming off a great year last year but to really control the strike zone has been the next step in continuing along as being a really, really good player.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite the legitimate sluggers in the Yankees\u2019 lineup, Gregorius has batted cleanup 12 times, more than any of his teammates \u2014 although Boone last week moved him up to third while moving Stanton down to fourth, an effort both to jump-start the struggling Stanton and to insert a left-handed hitter between Stanton and Judge, both right-handers.\n\nThe lineup shake-up has shown some promising, if minor, results. Stanton, despite a three-strikeout performance on Tuesday, showed signs of life on Monday with a four-hit game that included a homer, and on Tuesday Judge hit a long home run in the Yankees\u2019 three-run seventh inning. And in a development that could portend even more devastating results in the near future, Sanchez, who came into Tuesday\u2019s game batting just .192, went 2 for 4 with a pair of home runs, including one that traveled an estimated 436 feet.\n\nInside Pitch\n\nIn his second start since a brief stint on the disabled list with a hip injury, C.C. Betances was booed as he left the mound. \u2026 Third baseman Brandon Drury, on the disabled list since April 7 with migraines and blurred vision, took batting practice on the field before the game and will begin a rehab assignment with Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Wednesday. They are sound.\n\nHis departure is a great loss. He worked as hard as he could for the common good and for the Republican Party, in dispiriting circumstances. He appears to be a truly good man. I wouldn\u2019t believe every politician who said he was leaving office to spend more time with his children, but I believe Mr. Ryan.\n\nMaybe he will return to the public sector when his children are off to college. Egan also writes that the biggest threat to the Great Lakes at present \u201cis our own ignorance,\u201d and that it\u2019s a \u201cmirage\u201d that humans and lakes have learned to get along. What surprises you about how humans have messed with the lakes, even after the passage of the major Clean Water Act of 1972?\n\n4. Why is it not actually a good thing that the Great Lakes are as clear as they are?\n\n5. A recurring theme in the book is the invasive species that have been brought to the lakes from ships arriving from ports all over the world. Today, the Great Lakes are home to 186 nonnative species \u2014 the worst being the zebra and quagga mussels. How and why are these species a problem?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n6. Egan tells us that one of the most recognizable images of the perils facing the Great Lakes is \u201cthe grotesque mug of an Asian carp,\u201d which was imported in the 1960s for government research on sewage treatment. This invasive species can grow up to 70 pounds and eat up to 20 percent of its weight in plankton a day, and is now making its way closer to Lake Michigan. What could happen if the Asian Carp do enter the Great Lakes?\n\n7. Does this book introduce us to heroes and villains in the Great Lakes story? If so, who are they?\n\n8. As the news is filled with stories of water shortages in California and water crises like the one still facing Flint, Mich., how do the Great Lakes fit in?\n\n9.
