Here are three books that can help.\n\nImage\n\nYOU ARE A BADASS AT MAKING MONEY\n\nMaster the Mindset of Wealth\n\nBy Jen Sincero\n\n269 pp. Viking. (2017)\n\nAccording to this book, if you want to make more money, it starts with changing how you think about your finances. This book is aimed at changing readers\u2019 mentality. In Sincero\u2019s view, pursuing wealth gets a bad rap \u2014 that it is greedy, gross or will prevent you from spending time with your family \u2014 and those negative associations hold people back from achieving their desired or deserved income level. She argues that money can be a conduit to living a richer life and guides readers through thought exercises and mantras to change how readers talk to themselves about money and unleash their ability to attain it.\n\nImage\n\nTHIS IS THE YEAR I PUT MY FINANCIAL LIFE IN ORDER\n\nBy John Schwartz\n\n320 pp. Avery. (2018)\n\nBorn from an article that Schwartz, a science reporter for The Times, wrote in 2015 about realizing he was ill-equipped for retirement, this book uses his personal story to walk readers through the financial steps they should take to improve their finances. With self-deprecating humor, Schwartz highlights some of his and his wife, Jeanne\u2019s, money mistakes as young professionals and, later, as midlife adults. Through the writer\u2019s follies and his analyses of current financial attitudes, as well as \u201cpunch lists\u201d in each chapter that offer action items, readers learn about managing debt, buying a house, writing a will and otherwise preparing for a comfortable retirement.\n\nImage\n\nINVESTED\n\nHow Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger Taught Me to Master My Mind, My Emotions, and My Money (With a Little Help from My Dad)\n\nBy Danielle Town and Phil Town\n\n319 pp. William Morrow. (2018)", "title": "Do Your Taxes. Then, Read These Books", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "This is a strange tale of a staid institution whose rules for members are lax enough that even an official investigation that found blatant plagiarism did not qualify as cause for expulsion of an elusive doctor.\n\nThe core of the complaint, filed by Dr. Kellermann of the F. Edward H\u00e9bert School of Medicine at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences in Bethesda, Md., concerns a research paper in which Dr. Noji described some daring emergency medicine work he performed during the 2003 Iraq invasion. But an investigation in 2016 by the Uniformed Services University (a military medical school), where Dr. Noji was an adjunct professor, found that the mission was actually handled by Dr. Frederick \u201cSkip\u201d Burkle Jr., records show. The investigation also concluded that Dr. Noji plagiarized other research papers and misrepresented his credentials, according to the university\u2019s complaint.\n\nDr. Noji did not respond to multiple requests for an interview, but in a letter in 2016 to the university, he denied wrongdoing.\n\n\u201cI must say that engineering the appearance of blatant plagiarism on my part was absolutely brilliant,\u201d Dr. Noji wrote.\n\nPhoto\n\nCorrecting the record has become something of a personal mission for Dr. Arthur Kellermann, dean of the military medical school, and a group of high-profile colleagues that includes a former surgeon general, an astronaut and a former White House doctor. They argue that the reputation of their mentor, Dr. Burkle, has been severely damaged and that the good name of both the university and the academy is at stake.\n\nThe case has pitted the military medical school, which prides itself on honor and service, against the academy, which considers its members above reproach.\n\n\u201cIf you want to try and have an independent effort to investigate, it can be a very significant undertaking, with due process, so that you are confident in the outcome,\u201d said R. Alta Charo, a professor of law and bioethics at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, who is also a member of the academy. \u201cA lot of it will be confidential because they are personnel actions.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn this case, it wasn\u2019t until Dr. Burkle heard about the plagiarism, years after it occurred, that he notified the military medical school. An investigation by the medical school found that before Dr. Noji was named to the academy, he had plagiarized five research papers, fabricated an account of his personal exploits in Iraq, and claimed unearned degrees and awards, according to the school\u2019s documents. The school dismissed him in May 2016.\n\nBut when Dr. Arthur Kellermann asked the academy to dismiss Dr. Noji as well, he hit a roadblock. Nothing in the academy bylaws allowed for ousting a member who had committed scientific misconduct. So Dr. Kellermann, who was on the academy\u2019s governing board, and colleagues, lobbied for the change. Dr. Victor Dzau, president of the academy, supported it.\n\nFormerly known as the Institute of Medicine, the organization is a division of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine and has over 2,000 members in the United States. It accepts about 70 new members from the U.S. a year. It is not a government agency, but it is often relied on as a source of independent, objective analysis for policymakers on subjects ranging from gun violence to regulation of medical devices. There is a long list of researchers who would like the cachet that comes from election to the academy and the high profile that can come from serving on one of its advisory panels.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a compromise reached in December 2016, in the wake of the Noji complaint, the academy decided that membership could be rescinded if an individual provided false information before becoming a member.\n\nFalsification, plagiarism or fabrication after a doctor becomes a member of the elite organization isn\u2019t grounds for removal, said a spokesman for the organization. They are still considering Dr. Noji\u2019s case.\n\nBrian Martinson, an associate professor of medicine at the University of Minnesota, and a specialist in research ethics, believes that\u2019s an unfortunate loophole.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s crazy,\u201d Mr. Martinson said. \u201cI serve on a district council in my neighborhood and our bylaws are such that if you behave badly while you are on the board of directors we can kick you out.\u2019\u2019\n\nAttempts to reach Dr. Noji at King Saud University in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, where he is a professor, according to the school\u2019s website, were unsuccessful. A native of Hawaii, Dr. Noji spent roughly 20 years as a medical officer at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, leaving in 2008.\n\nIn \u201cNotes from the Field: Crisis in Iraq,\u201d published in the International Journal of Mass Emergencies and Disasters in March 2003, Dr. Noji wrote that he played a major role in the disaster assistance response after the invasion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMuch of my work has been in hospitals, directly with patients and trying to identify the most critical needs of the health system, which has been under strain before, during and after the war,\u201d Dr. Noji wrote.\n\nDr. Burkle, who was his supervisor on the mission, contradicts the account and say Dr. Noji never visited hospitals or treated patients, and spent just a few hours in Iraq. The university\u2019s investigation confirmed Dr. Burkle\u2019s account, their records show.\n\nDr. Burkle said he was pleased by the university\u2019s investigation.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m honored because one feels quite alone when this kind of plagiarism or fabrication happens, and not aware that it is happening to others,\u201d Dr. Burkle said. \u201cEverybody wants to avoid the subject. This is the first major step forward.\u201d\n\nPaul Auerbach, a Stanford medical school professor and editor of a popular medical textbook, said he was stunned to receive a call last year from Dr. Kellermann, telling him that a chapter written by Dr. Noji was actually heavily copied from the work of Dr. Burkle and Mark Keim, now retired from the C.D.C. and working as chief executive of DisasterDoc, an emergency services consulting firm. Dr. Auerbach compared the two copies.\n\n\u201cI was shocked, I went \u2018oh my goodness!\u2019\u2019\u2019 Dr. Auerbach said. \u201cThat was my worst nightmare. Once I saw it, it was a no-brainer. I won\u2019t ever write a paper or publish a book again without putting it through plagiarism checks.\u201d\n\nWith Dr. Burkle\u2019s health fragile, Dr. Kellermann and others want Dr. Noji expelled from the academy while Dr. Burkle is still alive.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a mentor to the entire field,\u201d Dr. Keim said, referring to Dr. Burkle as the father of disaster medicine. \u201cThat\u2019s why it hurts us so much.\u201d", "title": "Doctors Urge Elite Academy to Expel a Member Over Charges of Plagiarism", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "MONASAO, Central African Republic \u2014 Each morning, Marie Noella Kango walks over to the local clinic here and takes her spot behind the main desk by 8 a.m. Often, mothers and their children are already waiting in a line outside. One by one, the mothers meet with Ms. Kango and describe their children\u2019s symptoms: fever, diarrhea, vomiting and stomach pains. These are all symptoms Ms. Kango can easily diagnose as malaria or parasites, the two most common ailments in this village. Then she prescribes a treatment plan.\n\nMs. Kango, a BaAka Pygmy woman who grew up in the village, has no formal medical training, but under the guidance of Emilia Bylicka, a Polish doctor who oversees the small clinic, she has emerged as a critical part of the operation.\n\nWith young children dying all too frequently from treatable diseases, Ms. Kango and Dr. Bylicka\u2019s partnership provides a burst of optimism and inspiration. Along with three other local workers, they are transforming the medical services available to the local population and making serious strides in building local capacity.\n\nAccording to the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, easily treatable health problems like malaria, respiratory infections, malnutrition and diarrheal diseases are among the top causes of death in the Central African Republic. But there are only 0.05 physicians per 1,000 people in the nation, so even these simple diseases often go ignored. There\u2019s a solution: training locals to take on the responsibilities traditionally reserved for highly trained doctors to fill the gap in resources.", "title": "Opinion | Doctors-in-Training at a Rural Clinic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Do scammers send unsolicited text messages about credit card fraud? How do I know what is real?\n\nA. Scammers will try just about anything to steal your money or your identity, so bogus credit card fraud alerts are certainly possible.\n\nMany credit card companies have a warning system in place to automatically notify you of suspicious activity on your account, and will contact you by the method specified in your account settings \u2014 usually by text message, telephone call or email.\n\nIf you get a text message or email alert about fraud out of the blue and want to confirm its authenticity, call the customer-service number on the back of your card and ask to speak to a representative. If you prefer an online approach, log into your account on the company\u2019s website (or mobile app) over a secure network connection and check for notifications about suspicious account activity. To be on the safe side, do not call the number or open any links that may have been included with the message, even though some can be legitimate.\n\nImage Many credit-card companies issue legitimate alerts when they detect suspicious activity on your account. If you're not sure a text message is real, call the number on the back of the credit card or visit your account online to check. Credit The New York Times\n\nMany financial institutions have sophisticated and automated fraud-detection algorithms that can quickly detect signs of unusual activity on your account \u2014 often before you are aware of it. Your purchasing history, geographic location of the charge, merchant choice and spending amounts are some factors typically used in fraud-detection systems.", "title": "Dodging Fake Fraud Alerts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Does studying mathematics enhance your overall mental prowess?\n\nAbraham Lincoln certainly believed so, embarking on the arduous task of mastering Euclid\u2019s treatises on geometry to increase his cognitive capacities, in particular his linguistic and logical abilities. This idea \u2014 that mathematics strengthens your mind much as physical exercise strengthens your body, helping you negotiate a variety of mental challenges \u2014 goes all the way back to Plato. Alive and well in today\u2019s world, it is one reason popularly given for why everyone should study mathematics.\n\nSo it can come as a surprise to learn that cognitive psychologists have a different take on the issue. Various studies point to the conclusion that subjecting the mind to formal discipline \u2014 as when studying geometry or Latin \u2014 does not, in general, engender a broad transfer of learning. There is no sweeping increase of a general capacity for tasks like writing a speech or balancing a checkbook.\n\nBut surely a narrower claim is true: that mathematics, so systematically built as it is on inference, must develop logical thinking. Right?\n\nBy \u201clogical,\u201d I mean the kind of thinking needed to solve the following problem:\n\nFour cards are laid in front of you, each of which, it is explained, has a letter on one side and a number on the other. The sides that you see read E, 2, 5 and F. Your task is to turn over only those cards that could decisively prove the truth or falsity of the following rule: \u201cIf there is an E on one side, the number on the other side must be a 5.\u201d Which ones do you turn over?", "title": "Opinion | Does Math Make You Smarter?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Take a moment to scan the photographs in the article linked below. How do these schools compare with yours? Does your school building feel safe, clean and welcoming? Do you have the resources you need to learn?\n\nIn \u201c25-Year-Old Textbooks and Holes in the Ceiling: Inside America\u2019s Public Schools,\u201d Josephine Sedgwick writes:\n\nBroken laptops, books held together with duct tape, an art teacher who makes watercolors by soaking old markers.\n\nTeacher protests have spread rapidly from West Virginia to Oklahoma, Kentucky and Arizona in recent months. We invited America\u2019s public school educators to show us the conditions that a decade of budget cuts has wrought in their schools.\n\nWe heard from 4,200 teachers. Here is a selection of the submissions, condensed and edited for clarity.\n\nRio Rico, Ariz.\n\nMichelle Gibbar, teacher at Rio Rico High School\n\nSalary: $43,000 for 20 years of experience\n\nAnnual out-of-pocket expenses: $500+\n\nI have 148 students this year. The district skipped textbook adoption for the high school English department, leaving us with 10-year-old class sets, and we do not have enough for students to take them home. Our students deserve better. Our nation deserves better.\n\nAs I near retirement age, I realize I will retire at the poverty level. The antiquated myth of the noble, yet poor, teacher must go. I am passionate about my subject and my students. I am not passionate about living paycheck to paycheck.\n\nTempe, Ariz.\n\nJose Coca, teacher at Kyrene Middle School\n\nSalary: $46,000 with 12 years of experience\n\nAnnual out-of-pocket expenses: $1,000\n\nThe building smells old and dank. There are holes in the ceiling, skylights don\u2019t work, the walls need to be painted, I still use a chalk board, but \u2014 more important \u2014 my students need new desks and computers.\n\nI can\u2019t speak for other school districts, but mine \u2014 in Tempe \u2014 can\u2019t get new social studies books for students. Young teachers spend more out of their own pockets because they don\u2019t have supplies stockpiled.\n\nMy pay is not keeping up with inflation. I have co-workers leaving midyear, or not renewing their contracts, and I work with a lot of older teachers that have maybe five more years in them. I also work with some who retire and return as workers for a private staffing company.", "title": "Does Your School Need More Money?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe following piece discusses details from the ending of \u201cAvengers: Infinity War.\u201d\n\nI\u2019m not good enough at math to calculate whether the percentage of the world\u2019s population who saw \u201cAvengers: Infinity War\u201d over the weekend corresponds to the proportion of Marvel superheroes \u2014 spoiler alert! \u2014 killed at the end of the movie. I suspect, though, that many people who haven\u2019t seen it yet are already aware of what happens. A lot of superheroes die, perhaps including some of your favorites. T\u2019Challa, we hardly knew you!\n\nIt\u2019s remarkable how quickly that lethal denouement went from top secret to common knowledge. Those of us who were invited to last Monday\u2019s press screenings received a finger-wagging email asking us to \u201cplease let everyone else discover the surprises, the jokes, and the twists for themselves\u201d and not say too much about what happened. We were accordingly circumspect in the reviews published in the following days, though not enough for some readers. Michael Phillips of the Chicago Tribune was scolded on social media because of a headline referring to the ending as \u201cbleak.\u201d He responded with a characteristically reasonable and scholarly essay on the history of movie spoilers, going back to \u201cThe Crying Game\u201d and \u201cTerms of Endearment.\u201d\n\nBy which time the point was moot. Before \u201cAvengers: Infinity War\u201d had been in theaters even a full day, a barrage of post-review think pieces appeared discussing and dissecting the bleakness, most of them dutifully adorned with warnings not to read any further if you wanted to preserve your innocence. And no wonder. The last moments of the film are by far the most interesting. They bring intimations of darkness and grief that feel like something new in the Marvel Universe. The bad guy (his name is Thanos and his chin is remarkable) not only wins, but triumphs in a way that brings despair rather than sequel-setting rage or defiance. His victims don\u2019t go down fighting; they turn to dust and drift away in the breeze, watching as their friends and their own limbs decompose. It\u2019s a reverse rapture, with a somber emotional payoff.\n\n[ Looking for other pieces to read about the ending of \u201cAvengers: Infinity War?\u201d We have you covered. ]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow seriously are we supposed to take it? There is another \u201cAvengers\u201d movie coming next year, which along with this one is meant to represent a finale of sorts. But of course it\u2019s not really the end. The Marvel Cinematic Universe will keep expanding: release dates are already in place into the next decade, and if Disney\u2019s acquisition of Fox goes through there will be fresh crossover opportunities.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThanos, when he kills Loki early in \u201cInfinity War,\u201d promises \u201cno resurrections\u201d this time. The intricate logic of the plot, however \u2014 there are these magic stones that give their possessor the ability, among other things, to reorder time \u2014 suggests a route back to life for Black Panther, Spider-Man and the other dead heroes. Dr. Strange, who can see into the future, might have offered a cryptic prediction to that effect. And here in the real world, plenty of fans and critics have assumed that the next Avengers movie will cook up an escape clause. Kevin Feige, the head of Marvel Studios, has insisted otherwise. Why would he lie?", "title": "Does the Ending of \u2018Avengers: Infinity War\u2019 Spoil Itself?", "authors": ["A.O. Scott"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nOn a cold winter morning, I went to Crown Heights to meet Blue, a dog that my friend was watching for a couple of days.\n\nBlue was an older Dachshund, squat and stately, with back problems and an affinity for frozen green beans.\n\nAs my friend prepared to go out for the day, I rubbed Blue\u2019s back and told him a secret: I think I\u2019m in love with my friend, I said, \u201cbut I don\u2019t think I can tell him yet.\u201d\n\nBlue rolled over onto his stomach and looked at me with big brown eyes.\n\nWith Blue on a leash, my friend and I walked past bodegas and restaurants toward the Franklin Avenue subway station, and then looped around to walk through Prospect Park.\n\nBlue kept moving in front of me so that my friend and I were side by side.\n\n\u201cWhy does Blue want you to be in the middle?\u201d my friend asked.\n\nI shrugged, but I knew.", "title": "Dog With a Secret", "authors": ["Abigail Bereola", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "He is one of three leading Republican contenders heading into the primary, even though he is lugging around enough political baggage to disqualify a candidate most anywhere else.\n\nThat Mr. Blankenship retains a political hope is a consequence of West Virginia\u2019s sharp shift to the right, driven by seething hostility to the Obama presidency, both its social changes and its perceived \u201cwar\u201d on coal. The emergence of a former coal boss with a criminal record as a potential Senate nominee seems partly an expression of many West Virginia voters\u2019 desire to poke a thumb in the eye of the Washington establishment, Republicans very much included.\n\nMr. Blankenship offers no apology for his many contradictions and personal and business decisions, some of them previously undisclosed. Though he lives a baronial lifestyle thanks to a fortune built on coal scratched from West Virginia\u2019s mountains, he says the size and origins of his wealth are no one\u2019s business. He is the only candidate in either party in the Senate race who has not disclosed his personal finances as required by law to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics. There isn\u2019t \u201cmuch of a penalty\u201d for flouting the law, he explained in an interview, justifying his refusal.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t personally think anybody should have to disclose private information,\u201d he said while awaiting the start of a \u201cmeet the candidates\u201d event last week in Cabin Creek, W.Va.\n\nNational Republican leaders are alarmed that Mr. Blankenship could emerge as the winner of the primary, which they fear would cost them a winnable seat in November against Senator Joe Manchin, a vulnerable Democrat.\n\nIn a highly unusual move, a super PAC linked to Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky senator and Republican leader, began saturating the West Virginia airwaves last week with an ad attacking Mr. Blankenship for poisoning local drinking water from his former coal mines. The nearly $745,000 campaign of TV and digital ads is meant to boost the chances of two conventional Republicans in the race, Attorney General Patrick Morrisey and Representative Evan Jenkins. A Fox News poll conducted last week found a fluid race, with Mr. Blankenship trailing his rivals but about one in four voters undecided.\n\nOn Monday, responding to the attack ads, Mr. Blankenship brought up Mr. McConnell\u2019s marriage to Elaine Chao, the secretary of transportation, and questioned whether the majority leader faced a conflict of interest in foreign relations. Ms. Chao\u2019s father is \u201ca wealthy Chinaperson,\u201d Mr. Blankenship said, speaking on a West Virginia radio show, adding, \u201cAnd there\u2019s a lot of connections to some of the brass, if you will, in China.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI read in books that people think he\u2019s soft on China,\u201d he said of Mr. McConnell.\n\nChina, as it happens, is a topic of personal interest to Mr. Blankenship. His fianc\u00e9e, Farrah Meiling Hobbs, was born there. The two met on a flight from Atlanta to Las Vegas about eight years ago, Mr. Blankenship said. According to the website of an international trading company Ms. Hobbs founded, she is \u201ca former Chinese professional basketball player and part-time model\u201d who moved to the United States in 1996.\n\nIn 2016 Ms. Hobbs and Mr. Blankenship paid $2.4 million in cash to buy the palatial home near Las Vegas that Mr. Blankenship claims in court papers is his principal residence. It is a six-bedroom, eight-bath Spanish-style mansion with marble floors and a dolphin sculpture beside the pool, according to an online real estate site. (He also owns a residence in West Virginia.)\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was purchased just before Mr. Blankenship began a one-year prison sentence following his conviction on a misdemeanor count related to the 2010 explosion at Upper Big Branch mine, the deadliest mine accident in the United States in 40 years.\n\nThough Mr. Blankenship stepped down that year as chief executive of the Massey Energy Company, he exited with his sumptuous earnings intact. Massey paid him $17.8 million in his last year. He gained an additional $86.2 million when the company was later sold, by one estimate.\n\nPart of Mr. Blankenship\u2019s assets are now paying for some $2 million of TV and digital ads \u2014 far more than his rivals \u2014 that seek to muddy the picture of his 2015 conviction by painting him as a victim of a politically driven \u201cObama judge\u201d and \u201cObama prosecutors.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFamily members of the 29 Upper Big Branch victims said it was crushing to watch those ads, in which Mr. Blankenship portrays himself as a champion of safety and refuses responsibility for the loss of life.\n\n\u201cI want Mr. Blankenship to say he\u2019s sorry, I want him to feel contrition, I want him to feel compassion,\u201d said Dr. Judy Jones Petersen, whose brother Dean Jones died in the explosion. \u201cPeople have to understand that Mr. Blankenship is a bad man. Your character doesn\u2019t change.\u201d\n\nIn his campaign, Mr. Blankenship positions himself as a West Virginia populist, an \u201cAmerican competitionist\u201d who stands for unfettered capitalism. The heart of the government\u2019s case against him at trial was that he rapaciously sought profit while ignoring mine safety.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYet he identifies the new frontier of uninhibited capitalism as China. In a telephone conversation he recorded in 2009, introduced at his trial, Mr. Blankenship said he might move to Asia where governments enforce fewer regulations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m actually considering moving to China or somewhere and being more like George Washington if I can get citizenship,\u201d he said. \u201cI can probably get citizenship in India. I\u2019d rather be in China.\u201d\n\nIn the interview, he repeated this sentiment and freely discussed his financial history in China, though he said foreign citizenship was no longer a priority for him \u2014 perhaps dual citizenship would be useful, he mused.\n\nHe expressed admiration for how Beijing exercises central control over its economy.\n\n\u201cAmericans confuse the words communism and dictatorship,\u201d he said. \u201cThe Chinese are running a dictatorial capitalism and it\u2019s very effective. That\u2019s the way corporations are run. Corporations are not a democracy.\u201d\n\nBefore his foreign travel was restricted after his arrest in 2014, Mr. Blankenship was a frequent enough visitor to China that he opened a bank account there. \u201cWhen I go over there I don\u2019t have to carry a lot of money with me,\u201d he said in the interview. \u201cIf you go over there and you spend some time, you can easily spend a good bit of money.\u201d\n\nMs. Hobbs and Mr. Blankenship formed a business together in 2012, Generator World, to import home generators made in China. According to records from Panjiva, which tracks global trade, a shipment of 386 items was sent from Fuzhou, China, the next year to Ms. Hobbs\u2019s company, Amerasia International.\n\n\u201cThey arrived and we did sell them, but we didn\u2019t grow the business or continue it,\u201d Mr. Blankenship said. \u201cI wasn\u2019t in a position to do that.\u201d It was a dry reference to his trial, sentence and one-year parole, which will end the day after the May 8 primary.\n\nIn the absence of much public polling, the clearest sign that Mr. Blankenship is a threat in the race is the hefty advertising budget of national Republicans who seek to disqualify him with voters.\n\nOtherwise, signs of his support can be elusive. He draws sparse crowds to his events, and when he appears at multicandidate gatherings, he shows little knack for political skills. Rather than working a room, he keeps to himself, as he did at the Mineral County Lincoln Day dinner on Friday in Keyser.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think someone who\u2019s on parole at this moment in time should be running for office,\u201d Jessica Imes, a voter at the dinner, said.\n\nMr. Morrisey, the attorney general, moved easily among the party activists dining on stuffed chicken breast and mashed potatoes beneath a giant stuffed moose head at the local Order of Moose hall. His campaign has spent little time attacking Mr. Blankenship, in the belief that primary voters recognize that Republicans should not run a convicted criminal in the general election.\n\n\u201cI think he would get crushed in the fall, crushed,\u201d Mr. Morrisey said.\n\n\u201cThe hypocrisy runs deep in this race,\u201d he added. \u201cHe\u2019s a Nevada resident. He abandoned West Virginia when we really needed people to stand up to Barack Obama.\u201d\n\nAlthough Mr. Blankenship maintained in numerous court proceedings that his principal residence was Nevada, he still owns a home in West Virginia, in Mingo County not far from where he was raised. He said he paid property taxes in West Virginia but not income taxes.\n\nThere is nothing legally barring him from seeking a Senate seat from the state if he declares a primary residence elsewhere.\n\nHe scoffed at the notion that voters might regard him as an outsider, even a carpetbagger, because he lives mostly in Nevada.\n\n\u201cMany people have two homes,\u201d he said. \u201cMost coal miners now have one in Tennessee and one in West Virginia.\u201d", "title": "Don Blankenship, West Virginia Candidate, Lives Near Las Vegas and Mulled Chinese Citizenship", "authors": ["Trip Gabriel", "Stephanie Saul"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Those hospital visits in Vietnam must have been intense.\n\nIt was very, very difficult. Oh my goodness, it was a life-changing experience. You\u2019d walk into the wards, these guys from the front lines, some had just woken up with no legs, no arms. It was the hardest thing I\u2019ve done. It almost made an alcoholic out of me. You\u2019d visit those hospitals all day and go out and drink all night.\n\nWhat\u2019s your daily life here like?\n\nI\u2019ve been buying real estate for 20 years here, and building houses and renting them out. So that\u2019s our business now. A lot of Warrior fans stay with us. I built this place next to me. It\u2019s not a wedding chapel, but they have weddings there. My daughter Lee runs that. She\u2019s an interesting story. I had that daughter out of wedlock. I knew nothing about her for 29 years.\n\nHow did you find out about her?\n\nI was in Dallas, coaching, and my secretary brought in this letter. It said, \u201cDear Mr. Nelson. In 1968, you met a young girl in Washington, D.C., by the name of Debby Dial. Nine months later, I was born.\u201d I had been on the road with the Celtics, playing the Bullets. We were doing some of that stuff when I was playing, which wasn\u2019t the best thing to do. But I did remember that lady\u2019s name. I thought, \u201cWow, this could be true.\u201d\n\nSo we brought her into Dallas, and there was this 6-foot blond lady who looks like all my other kids, and I\u2019m going, \u201cShe\u2019s mine.\u201d I helped her finish college, met the parents who raised her, because she was adopted. My wife and I have six other kids, but she\u2019s the only one who\u2019s moved to Maui. Isn\u2019t that funny?\n\nAnd you\u2019ve got an agrarian venture over here in Maui, too?\n\nI\u2019ve got a farm, yeah, I do. We grow some pot and flowers and coffee, and I\u2019ve got a fish farm up there.\n\nPot?\n\nI\u2019ve got a medical card. I\u2019m legal here. When any athlete gets old, every injury you have sustained seems to resurrect. It helps me deal with the pain without pain pills, and helps with that stress.", "title": "Retired N.B.A. Coach Don Nelson Talks Playoffs, Poker and, Uh, Weed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Donald McKayle, one of the first choreographers to weave the African-American experience into the fabric of modern dance and the first black man to direct and choreograph a Broadway musical (\u201cRaisin\u201d), died on Friday at a hospital near his home in Irvine, Calif. He was 87.\n\nHis wife, Lea Vivante McKayle, confirmed the death. He was a professor of dance at the University of California, Irvine, for almost 30 years.\n\nMr. McKayle had been working on Broadway for more than two decades when he achieved his triumph with \u201cRaisin,\u201d a musical based on \u201cA Raisin in the Sun,\u201d Lorraine Hansberry\u2019s classic drama about a black family struggling with loss, change and identity in midcentury Chicago.\n\nClive Barnes, in his New York Times review of the production, suggested that the musical was even more evocative than the play, and compared Mr. McKayle to the star choreographer Jerome Robbins.", "title": "Donald McKayle, 87, Broadway and Modern Dance Choreographer, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. View more of his work, visit his website or follow him on Twitter.\n\nFollow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump and Kim Jong-un Prepare to Meet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "But what speaks most succinctly about how Villanova won two titles in three seasons is precisely that DiVincenzo was able to go from imitating an opposing superstar in one Final Four to being the superstar in the next one. It is a trajectory distinctive to the program, which could reasonably be expected to lead to another title a year or two from now.\n\nHield never had a game as spectacular as DiVincenzo had on Monday, particularly on a Final Four court.\n\nThe statistics \u2014 31 points on 15 shots, five rebounds and three assists \u2014 still undersell the extent to which DiVincenzo was his team\u2019s fulcrum Monday night. The team\u2019s sixth man, he was the one who stopped the bleeding after the underdog Michigan surprised the 67,831 spectators in the Alamodome and millions more watching on television who had expected a fairly easy victory by Villanova, the top seed.\n\nPhoto\n\nBefore DiVincenzo scored his first basket, Michigan led 14-8. Villanova\u2019s next 8 points were DiVincenzo\u2019s: a 3-pointer, a 3-point play, a jump shot. DiVincenzo responded to ball screens by hitting long 3s from where he was standing or, once, finding Omari Spellman down low on a brilliant bounce pass.\n\nOn defense, during one stretch he forced a driving Zavier Simpson into a miss and then, on the next possession, the 6-foot-5 DiVincenzo straight-up blocked an attempted dunk by Charles Matthews.\n\nAt one point, after back-to-back 3-pointers, DiVincenzo winked at the crowd. He later said he was aiming for Hart.\n\nHad DiVincenzo been in a video game, flames would have been coming off his ball.\n\nIt would be easy to characterize him as an overachieving diamond in the rough, another scrappy kid from Villanova\u2019s backyard (he is from Delaware) who thrived in Coach Jay Wright\u2019s system. The story sounds great, but it doesn\u2019t check out. DiVincenzo was a four-star recruit who had offers from Florida, Notre Dame, Syracuse and elsewhere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Villanova innovation, rather, is to have a talent like DiVincenzo, as a redshirt sophomore, come off the bench.\n\n\u201cAll he wants to do is play,\u201d said DiVincenzo\u2019s mother, Kathy, elated in a straw cowboy hat with a Villanova \u201cV\u201d as she watched him being named the Final Four\u2019s most outstanding player. \u201cHe doesn\u2019t care if he starts.\u201d\n\nWhat makes Villanova the class of college basketball \u2014 the first team to win two titles in three seasons since Florida repeated more than a decade ago, the second since Kentucky did it in 1996 and \u201998 \u2014 is this model of sustainable success, with players who could be the center of attention at other big programs sacrificing to play for the Wildcats.\n\n\u201cDonte could do more,\u201d Assistant Coach George Halcovage said on Sunday, the day before the title game. \u201cHe\u2019s a great player. He\u2019s the sixth man. He could be starting on any team in the country.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHalcovage added, \u201cUnderstanding being part of something bigger than himself allows him to give us a guy who is a starter off the bench.\u201d\n\nVillanova\u2019s way should challenge our own preconceptions. We think of one-and-done factories (and, let\u2019s face it, we are thinking of Duke and Kentucky) as facing a test that is not only difficult but unique: the need to reload rosters annually as they lose players to the N.B.A. draft.\n\nBut Villanova\u2019s experience shows the difference is one of degree, not kind. (It also shows that the popular dichotomy between one-and-done programs and others is an oversimplification.) Players graduate. Players transfer \u2014 though fewer than the norm do from Villanova. Players come out early, but not as freshmen. Everyone must reload.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nVillanova lost two starters from its title team two seasons ago, and then two more from the team that last season was the N.C.A.A. tournament\u2019s No. 1 overall seed. Just three players \u2014 Brunson, Bridges and the redshirt junior Phil Booth \u2014 contributed major minutes to both championship teams. Brunson is the only player who started for both.\n\nWhere was DiVincenzo during the 2016 championship game? \u201cI was on the bench in a suit,\u201d he said Monday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike DiVincenzo, Booth was the sixth man on the 2015-16 team. Like DiVincenzo, he was Villanova\u2019s leading scorer in the championship game. There is a pattern here.\n\nPart of the way Villanova makes this work is careful attention to what Wright called \u201croster structuring.\u201d Wright and his staff carry a chart around that projects every player\u2019s next three seasons. Players are considered in their final seasons not based on whether their eligibility is about to run out, but based on when they are likely to leave (like Brunson and Bridges, juniors who are both projected as first-round draft picks). The coaches then recruit to the spots they anticipate having holes in.\n\nThey \u201ctalk about it every day,\u201d Wright said.\n\nBut there is still the matter of persuading top players to head for Philadelphia\u2019s suburbs with the knowledge that they may enter this complex chart and be stashed away while a veteran gives Villanova his best basketball. The key here might be a popular motto of Wright\u2019s, which he echoed in a tweet early Tuesday morning: \u201cWe play for those who came before us.\u201d", "title": "Donte DiVincenzo Is Villanova\u2019s Newest Star. Next Year It\u2019ll Be Someone Else.", "authors": ["Marc Tracy", "On College Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "A native Montrealer, I recently returned to Quebec, 28 years after leaving Canada, and embarked on a road trip aimed at understanding Quebec identity. And so it was that I found myself on a recent day in a village many Quebecers would rather forget. I was curious to observe whether attitudes had shifted.\n\nMy initial reception was as cold as the chilly March weather.\n\n\u201cNothing ever happens here \u2014 we have a church and a few chalets. Oh, that\u2019s about it,\u201d said the first woman who crossed my path. \u201cWhy are you here?\u201d\n\nThe code, which polarized Quebec, helped spur a loud national debate and even a provincewide commission on what constituted \u201creasonable accommodation\u201d when it came to respecting the cultures and traditions of immigrants. Should veils, for example, be worn by Muslim students at school? Should a Montreal Y.M.C.A. have installed frosted windows at the request of ultra-Orthodox Jews who didn\u2019t want to see scantily clad women exercise?\n\nQuestions of identity and cultural preservation run deep in Quebec, a majority French-speaking province of eight million people, which fears that its native tongue could be subsumed by the large English-speaking majority in much of the rest of North America. To help preserve the French language, there are laws in place, including a requirement that immigrants send their children to French schools.\n\nPhoto\n\nH\u00e9rouxville became such a target of derision that it was recast in a comedy show as \u201cH\u00e9rouxtyville,\u201d in a now famous skit in which a Muslim couple accidentally end up in the village. They are brought before a stern village councilor because, among other things, the veiled woman has ordered baklava at the local bakery and they are driving a Hyundai, a foreign car. Pointing to the car, the red-faced councilor barks at them to drive their \u201cmoving bomb\u201d out of town.\n\nTo take today\u2019s political temperature in the village, I contacted H\u00e9rouxville\u2019s mayor, Bernard Thompson, an early supporter of the code of conduct. He declined to meet me, citing an urgent meeting with other local leaders. (He later told residents his mother had been ill when I was in town.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNor were some Quebecers pleased about my H\u00e9rouxville visit. On radio shows and social media, commentators tut-tutted me, suggesting that there were more interesting places. \u201cYou are completely out of touch with Quebec society,\u201d Johanne Vallin, a history teacher, wrote on Twitter.\n\nIn H\u00e9rouxville, many residents declined to disclose their full names, citing fears of retribution. At the local convenience store, a truck driver, a beer in each pocket, complained that the code of conduct was the first subject visitors brought up.\n\nA woman buying groceries said locals were fed up with all of the attention. Suzanne Lamothe, a retiree whose house is next to the main H\u00e9rouxville sign, said visitors came to the village to take selfies in front of the sign, some putting mock head scarves on their heads. She defended the code of conduct. \u201cIf immigrants come, they should respect local customs,\u201d she said. \u201cI wouldn\u2019t go to a Muslim country and walk around scantily clad.\u201d Another resident asked whether I was Muslim.\n\n50 MILES quebec canada Quebec City H\u00e9rouxville Montreal me. Vt. N.Y. N.H.\n\nYet for all of the annoyance at the apparent impertinence of my visit, I was struck by the way the identity politics raised by H\u00e9rouxville still resonate.\n\nLate last year Quebec introduced Bill 62, a law requiring people to show their faces when using public services like buses and libraries. Some human rights advocates have pilloried the law for stigmatizing Muslims who wear head scarves. But others have defended it as a necessary measure to ensure Quebec\u2019s vaunted secularism and way of life.\n\nMarie Louise H\u00e9roux, whose great-uncle, the abbot Joseph-Euchariste H\u00e9roux, founded H\u00e9rouxville in 1897, said she had wanted to walk with a \u201cbag over my head\u201d after the village that bears her name became synonymous with xenophobia. She said the guidelines had been a particular source of angst for her, as she had been in love with a Muslim doctor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt does not represent me as a H\u00e9roux,\u201d she said, adding: \u201cIn Quebec, we like to think that immigrants should come and adapt to our way of doing things. In H\u00e9rouxville it was pushed to ridiculous proportions, but it tapped into something that had to be taken into account.\u201d\n\nOthers said the visceral reaction to safeguard Quebec against immigration, and conservative Islam in particular, was a reflection of the province\u2019s history, its staunch feminism and its strong reflex against outward signs of religiosity.\n\nG\u00e9rard Bouchard, an eminent historian and sociologist who helped lead the commission on cultural accommodation spurred by H\u00e9rouxville, lamented that the code of conduct had attracted outsize notoriety. Nevertheless, he said the backlash against accommodating ethnic minorities partly reflected the extent to which Quebec was still under the sway of the so-called Quiet Revolution of the 1960s, when Quebecers revolted against a Roman Catholic Church that had once ruled daily life, including pressuring women to reproduce.\n\nAlluding to the situation of majority-French Quebec surrounded by English-speaking Canada, he added, \u201cWhen a majority feels like a minority, it\u2019s not a very good neighbor for other minorities.\u201d", "title": "Don\u2019t Burn Women: Warning to Immigrants Looms Over a Quebec Village", "authors": ["Dan Bilefsky"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "This makes me think \u2014 have people who used this term ever actually met any Vietnamese people? Been to a Vietnamese restaurant, much less a Vietnamese household or Vietnam itself? We\u2019re really, really loud.\n\nThe situation, now and in the past, is that the minority and marginalized communities of this or any other country are often not voiceless. They\u2019re simply not heard.\n\nThat\u2019s the problem with being called a voice for the voiceless, whose exceptional status is related to what we call genius. We would rather deal with a solo voice than a chorus, or a cacophony, of voices. And in praising today\u2019s voice for the voiceless, we would just as soon forget, or not even know about, all the other voices for the voiceless that came before.\n\nI think back to Edith Maude Eaton, half-Chinese and half-white, who adopted a Chinese pen name and wrote as Sui Sin Far. She advocated for Chinese immigrants and chose to be Chinese in the early years of the 20th century, at a time when to be Chinese was to be despised in North America. She published one book of short stories, \u201cMrs. Spring Fragrance,\u201d and died in poverty and obscurity at an early age in 1914.\n\nI think back to Carlos Bulosan, who migrated from the Philippines in the 1930s as a colonial ward of the United States. He worked as a journalist and a labor organizer and became a nationally celebrated writer. His fame peaked with his book \u201cAmerica Is in the Heart\u201d in 1946. By 1954, however, suspected of having Communist sympathies, he was a target of McCarthyism. He died poor and alone, of pneumonia.\n\nI think back to John Okada, who fought in World War II even though his Japanese-American family was in an internment camp. Okada came back from the war and published \u201cNo No Boy\u201d in 1957, the first novel dealing with the little-known story of Japanese-American draft resisters. America did not want to think about the internment, and the Japanese-American community, intent on being patriotic, did not want to acknowledge draft resisters. \u201cNo No Boy\u201d immediately disappeared. Okada died relatively young and his widow, in despair at his rejection, burned his second manuscript.\n\nThose are three of the most iconic Asian-American writers, and I wish genius grants were retroactive. It took genius to decide to write about Asian-Americans at a time when there was no market for Asian-American literature, no recognition for Asian-American writers, and when there weren\u2019t even any Asian-Americans. (Until the 1960s, we were collectively Orientals.)\n\nThinking back to writers like Sui Sin Far, Carlos Bulosan and John Okada, it is clear that genius is too often unrecognized in its day. I know my good luck is at least partly due to the sacrifice of writers who came before me.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Call Me a Genius", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDude, are you watching Kanye right now?\u201d\n\nI was trying to get some work done and so had logged off of Twitter, that black hole of permanent distraction. But I couldn\u2019t escape the nonstop emails and texts from my friends suggesting that I drop everything and watch the rapper\u2019s feed. So, like the rest of America, I did.\n\nThere, @kanyewest, I was treated to a torrent of pro-Trump statements, including a photograph of West\u2019s red \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d baseball cap, autographed by the president himself. \u201cYou don\u2019t have to agree with Trump,\u201d Kanye tweeted on, \u201cbut the mob can\u2019t make me not love him. We are both dragon energy.\u201d Not one to miss out on an endorsement, Trump tweeted right back, thanking Kanye and adding a \u201cvery cool!\u201d for emphasis.\n\nKnowing that I dislike Trump almost as much as I like Kanye, my friends were curious: Did I admire the artist less now that he\u2019s referred to the president as his brother?\n\nIt\u2019s an easy question, one that we Israelis have had a lifetime to ponder.\n\nGrowing up in Tel Aviv, I would often grow enamored of a band, a writer or a filmmaker only to discover that my new celebrity crush was, to put it mildly, not a big fan of my country. At first, I resolved to disavow anyone whose politics I found reprehensible. I tossed aside those Brian Eno CDs, convincing myself that I had no business enjoying the music, no matter how entrancing, of someone who was calling for a boycott of Israel. I bored roommates at the time with endless rants against a musician for speaking his mind.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Delete Kanye", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "What the journalist Walter Lippmann said in 1959 of \u201cfree\u201d TV is also true of \u201cfree\u201d social media: It is ultimately \u201cthe creature, the servant and indeed the prostitute of merchandizing.\u201d But social media itself isn\u2019t going away. It has worked its way into our lives and has come to help satistify the basic human need to connect and catch up. Facebook, in fact, claims lofty goals, saying it seeks to \u201cbring us closer together\u201d and \u201cbuild a global community.\u201d Those are indeed noble purposes that social media can serve. But if they were Facebook\u2019s true goals, we would not be here.\n\nThe ideal competitor and successor to Facebook would be a platform that actually puts such goals first. To do so, however, it cannot be just another data-hoarder, like Google Plus. If we have learned anything over the last decade, it is that advertising and data-collection models are incompatible with a trustworthy social media network. The conflicts are too formidable, the pressure to amass data and promise everything to advertisers is too strong for even the well-intentioned to resist.\n\nSo what stands in the way of building a genuine alternative? It isn\u2019t the technology. A good Facebook competitor needs merely to build a platform that links you with friends and allows posting of thoughts, pictures and comments. No, the real challenge is gaining a critical mass of users. Facebook, with its 2.2 billion users, will not disappear, and it has a track record of buying or diminishing its rivals (see Instagram and Foursquare). But as Lyft is proving by stealing market share from Uber, and as Snapchat proved by taking taking younger audiences from Facebook, \u201cnetwork effects\u201d are not destiny. Now is the time for a new generation of Facebook competitors that challenge the mother ship.\n\nOne set of Facebook alternatives might be provided by firms that are credibly privacy-protective, for which users would pay a small fee (perhaps 99 cents a month). In an age of \u201cfree\u201d social media, paying might sound implausible \u2014 but keep in mind that payment better aligns the incentives of the platform with those of its users. The payment and social network might be bundled with other products such as the iPhone or the Mozilla or Brave browser.\n\nAnother \u201calt-Facebook\u201d could be a nonprofit that uses that status to signal its dedication to better practices, much as nonprofit hospitals and universities do. Wikipedia is a nonprofit, and it manages nearly as much traffic as Facebook, on a much smaller budget. An \u201calt-Facebook\u201d could be started by Wikimedia, or by former Facebook employees, many of whom have congregated at the Center for Humane Technology, a nonprofit for those looking to change Silicon Valley\u2019s culture. It could even be funded by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which was created in reaction to the failures of commercial television and whose mission includes ensuring access to \u201ctelecommunications services that are commercial free and free of charge.\u201d\n\nWhen a company fails, as Facebook has, it is natural for the government to demand that it fix itself or face regulation. But competition can also create pressure to do better. If today\u2019s privacy scandals lead us merely to install Facebook as a regulated monopolist, insulated from competition, we will have failed completely. The world does not need an established church of social media.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Fix Facebook. Replace It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The Republican attack on these repayment plans is based in part on the claim that the benefits are too generous and too expensive. For example, Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, the chairman of the Senate committee considering reforms to the program, says it is now \u201cstandard\u201d for students to expect their debt to be forgiven. This view is backed even by some left-leaning organizations concerned about costs. A New America Foundation report called the program a \u201cwindfall.\u201d One from the Brookings Institution said that the program was \u201csinking under its own weight.\u201d Yet another from the Urban Institute said that \u201cthe current IDR system is likely to impose high costs on taxpayers.\u201d\n\nEmboldened, Representative Virginia Foxx, Republican of North Carolina, sponsored the Prosper Act, which has passed out of committee in the House. Under the bill, new borrowers would pay 50 percent more per month and would no longer have their loans forgiven after 20 to 25 years of repayment. The bill would also drastically cut the amount that can be borrowed for graduate school.\n\nIncome-driven repayment does have a price tag, of course. Estimates vary, but the Department of Education puts the cost for all loans outstanding at about $36 billion. Even though this may sound like a lot of money, $36 billion is pretty low in context. For one thing, it\u2019s a tiny piece of the $1.3 trillion in loans outstanding. For another, the cost of the program is nearly the same as one year of Pell Grants, the other major federal program for low-income students, but it covers 25 years\u2019 worth of loans. And most of this cost is just lost interest \u2014 the government anticipates that it will still get back more than it lends to these borrowers.\n\nEven with this cost, the student loan program could still net as much as $50 billion for taxpayers. It has long been a profit center. The profit used to be sucked up by banks, but today it belongs to the federal government, and it is appropriate to reinvest some of this money in higher education rather than kick it all back to the Treasury. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the Prosper Act\u2019s changes to student loans would pad the government\u2019s profit by another $40 billion over the next 10 years. That\u2019s money coming directly out of borrowers\u2019 pockets \u2014 to what end?\n\nEven if income-driven repayment did erase the loan program\u2019s profit margin, would that be such a bad thing? Taxpayers have always subsidized higher education, recognizing that it produces enormous gains for the economy and for society as a whole. The prospect of high debt is a financial (and psychological) barrier for many students, and some insurance for those who may end up with lower incomes is a worthy goal. To call that insurance a \u201closs\u201d is to imply that taxpayers are entitled to profit off the backs of struggling borrowers.\n\nIncome-driven repayment is not without flaws. The various plans are too cumbersome and confusing, and the system of loan servicing does not work well and has led to some predatory practices. But these problems are bureaucratic, not financial. Cutting back on student loan relief because of hysteria about nonexistent losses is pound-foolish. The Department of Education is a lender, but it is not a bank; its purpose \u2014 and the purpose of the student loan program \u2014 is to further education and support students, not to turn a profit.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Let the G.O.P. Dismantle Obama\u2019s Student Loan Reforms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine a black man who lived in the Bronx around 2011, the height of the stop-and-frisk era. New York police officers threw him up against walls; they turned his pockets inside out. Some days they accused him of trespassing in his own apartment building. Every time, the police let him go without a summons and without arresting him \u2014 because he was doing nothing wrong. He was only walking to the corner store or home. Now he\u2019s a father. And while the police department says that stops have dropped, his son is also getting stopped, tossed and humiliated,even if less often.\n\nBut the words of lawyers or federal court appointees cannot serve as a substitute for that black father\u2019s voice and experiences. He knows better than we do what lasting change looks like.\n\nThousands of people like this man \u2014 people who were repeatedly stopped, or whose children or friends were repeatedly stopped \u2014 gave their input into the design of reforms through 64 focus groups and 24 community forums across the city. At the very least, the New York Police Department must adopt these three reforms to fix the problems that took it to court in the first place.\n\nFirst, the department must establish progressive and serious penalties for unconstitutional behavior by officers. One unlawful stop might lead to retraining, for example, while two could mean a loss of vacation days. The police commissioner could diverge from the guidelines whenever he deemed it appropriate. But establishing minimum discipline standards that set strict penalties would encourage lawful behavior while communicating that the department is committed to addressing misconduct.\n\nSecond, the police must use department-issued smartphones to instantly collect information about investigative activities, and to briefly explain these activities in their notes. We heard many community members describe stops that we know police officers did not report. This reform would ensure that more encounters do get reported, which would give the department a better view of whether officers understand the limits on their authority.\n\nThird, the department must create a citywide community oversight board consisting of those who have been most invested in advancing stop-and-frisk reforms. The board would monitor the department\u2019s fulfillment of changes and provide assistance. For example, it would help to identify penalties to use in the discipline standards. Such sustained and structured community oversight promises more complete and abiding reform. And it\u2019s not unprecedented: Just last month, Chicago agreed to a similar measure.\n\nThe New York Police Department says it wants to improve community relations and build trust. But it\u2019s easier to go on a listening tour than to give the community power over policies. And it\u2019s easier to talk about accountability than to earn trust through action. We can\u2019t let the department choose the easy way out.\n\nOn April 30, a court appointee is to issue a report on the community-input process. Without discipline standards, improved documentation of police activity and a community oversight board, we believe the routine violation of the rights of people of color during police encounters in New York City will go on. And if these reforms do not happen through the community-input process, then they will not happen.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Let the Police Wreck Stop-and-Frisk Reforms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cStrange Pension Math Leaves States in Pinch of Own Making\u201d (front page, April 15):\n\nHighlighting statistical outliers \u2014 like the $76,000 monthly pension for a state university president \u2014 makes for lively storytelling, but it is far from a thorough or fair way of looking at public pensions.\n\nIn Oregon and across the United States, career public servants \u2014 teachers, firefighters, police officers \u2014 regularly forgo higher private-sector wages for the promise of a dignified future retirement. Oregon\u2019s retired public employees receive a modest median benefit of $24,062 a year. Two-thirds of the state\u2019s retirees receive $36,000 or less a year.\n\nPublic pension shortfalls do occur, chiefly as a result of two factors: the lingering effects of recession and decisions by many states to skip making required contributions into their pension funds, even as workers faithfully paid their fair share.\n\nPolicymakers would do well to look at other measures \u2014 such as rethinking corporate tax breaks and regressive tax systems \u2014 rather than penalizing workers. Slashing pensions is a shortsighted fix that would backfire by making more Americans financially vulnerable in their golden years, with devastating consequences for their communities.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Slash Public Pensions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cHow to Disobey Your Tiger Parents,\u201d by Michelle Kuo (Sunday Review, April 15):\n\nLike Ms. Kuo, I am a Taiwanese-American. Unlike her, I enjoyed the unconditional support and encouragement of my immigrant parents from the time I was pre-med to my seven years as a freelance classical musician. I continue to enjoy that support now as a student of political science.\n\nHer essay perpetuates a stereotype about Asian-Americans that may bear a hint of truth for some families but that buries the diversity of immigrant stories and perspectives. It paints my parents and the parents of my Asian-American peers as unassimilated foreigners whose children need an instruction manual to navigate a basic human relationship with them.\n\nParents with specific and demanding expectations exist in every demographic. These instructions reek of \u201cmodel minority\u201d nonsense.\n\nJENNIFER WU, NEW YORK", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Stereotype Asian-Americans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Last week, the court published its first full reasoning for one such decision, in which the cross-country skier Alexander Legkov had his punishment overturned because, the court said, it could not be certain the athlete himself had been personally involved in the cheating scheme, in spite of suggestive evidence that his urine sample had been manipulated.\n\nRussian officials have seized on victories like Mr. Legkov\u2019s, calling them a vindication of the nation\u2019s athletes and a repudiation of Dr. Rodchenkov. In recent days, Russian officials have claimed that Dr. Rodchenkov has walked back or retracted his statements about Russia\u2019s cheating.\n\n\u201cWe see now as a fact that this person is confused with his testimonies, that he is actually confirming his lies and his slander,\u201d Dmitry Peskov, President Putin\u2019s spokesman, told Russian state media last week.\n\nBut Dr. Rodchenkov\u2019s lawyers \u2014 Mr. Walden, of Walden Macht & Haran, and Gregory L. Diskant of Patterson Belknap in New York \u2014 said their client \u201chad not wavered,\u201d calling him \u201cvery clear and very highly corroborated.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf the Russians seriously believe there is no state-sponsored doping system, why didn\u2019t they produce the emails, the lab data, the stored samples at the Moscow lab?\u201d Mr. Walden said, referencing certain specific evidence that regulators and investigators have long requested of Russia, which remains decertified by the global antidoping regulator and barred from track and field competitions.\n\nIn the filings on Monday, Dr. Rodchenkov responded to the libel claim with a simple defense: He argued he had told the truth, pointing to scientific and forensic evidence that later confirmed much of what he had told The New York Times in 2016.\n\nDr. Rodchenkov\u2019s countersuit is likely to seek in depositions the names of the others who are financing the lawsuit against him, as well as information on the assets of Mr. Prokhorov, who this spring sold 49 percent of his stake in the Nets but remains the team\u2019s controlling owner.\n\n\u201cProkhorov has assets here,\u201d Mr. Walden said. \u201cWe need to go about expeditiously securing them, so he doesn\u2019t go about taking them out of the country.
