She was 103.\n\nHer death was announced by Heinz Endowments, a foundation established by members of the family behind the H. J. Heinz foods empire. Ms. Heinz\u2019s third husband, Henry John Heinz II, known as Jack, was a chairman of the company.\n\nThe British-born Ms. Heinz gave generously to the arts and had an affinity for literature. In the fall of 1970, intrigued by the literary quarterly Antaeus, she sent a letter on Heinz stationery \u2014 with its famous pickle logo \u2014 looking to purchase a subscription.\n\nAfter contacting Daniel Halpern, the editor who founded Antaeus in Tangier, Morocco, with the writer Paul Bowles, she agreed to do substantially more: help fund the publication.", "title": "Drue Heinz, Patron of Literature and Host of Authors, Dies at 103", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Federal officials said they were focusing on the anticompetitive practices of brand-name drug makers under the impetus of a vow by President Trump to hold down prices set by drug companies, which he has said are \u201cgetting away with murder.\u201d\n\nLegislation to ensure access to drug samples for generic drug manufacturers has broad support in Congress, from Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, on the left to Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, on the right. A similar bill in the House also has diverse backers, including Representatives Peter Welch, Democrat of Vermont, and Mark Meadows, Republican of North Carolina, who is the chairman of the conservative House Freedom Caucus.\n\nUnder the bill, a generic drug developer could file a lawsuit, and a federal court could require a brand-name drug maker to provide samples of its product to a generic company \u201con commercially reasonable, market-based terms.\u201d The court could also award damages if it found that a drug maker had refused to sell samples \u201cwithout a legitimate business justification.\u201d\n\nBrand-name drug companies make several arguments against the legislation. First, they say, it is not needed. The F.D.A. approved 1,027 generic drugs last year, a record number, and nearly 90 percent of prescriptions are filled with generic medicines, suggesting that generic manufacturers have generally been able to obtain the samples they need, the brand-name companies say.\n\nSecond, they say, the bill would be a boon to trial lawyers, giving them an incentive to sue brand-name pharmaceutical companies for damages, which could be worth more than sales of the proposed generic drug.", "title": "Drug Company \u2018Shenanigans\u2019 to Block Generics Come Under Federal Scrutiny", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The coastal province of Friesland, while part of the Netherlands, has its own language. \u201cWe don\u2019t speak Dutch; we speak Frisian,\u201d Ms. Poepjes said. \u201cSo that\u2019s why we gained the title of cultural capital in 2018, and we wanted to highlight that.\u201d\n\nWorking overnight last Friday, road crews painted about 490 feet of a newly paved, 16-mile stretch of the road with the strips.\n\nMs. Poepjes said music from \u201ca popular part\u201d of the regional anthem, \u201cDe Alde Friezen,\u201d or \u201cThe Old Frisians,\u201d from the 19th century, had been painted on. The project cost 80,000 euros, or about $99,000.\n\nSigns told drivers, \u201cYou are approaching a singing road.\u201d When drivers hit 60 kilometers per hour, about 38 m.p.h., the regional anthem rang loud and clear. And if drivers wandered onto the shoulder at a lower speed?\n\n\u201cIf you go too slow, it\u2019s the same thing like if you play a normal record: brr-brr-brr,\u201d Ms. Poepjes said, imitating a slowed-down record.\n\nAnd if a driver drove on the shoulder backward?\n\n\u201cYou\u2019d get the same thing if you play a Madonna record backward,\u201d she said, laughing.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s basically vinyl on the road,\u201d Ms. Poepjes explained. \u201cIt\u2019s like grooves on the record, but with literally grooves on the road. It\u2019s a very basic concept.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut soon, villagers began complaining that they could not sleep.\n\n\u201cThe Frisian national anthem is fine, but not 24 hours a day,\u201d Sijtze Jansma, who lives about 600 feet from the road, told the news website RTL. \u201cI\u2019m going nuts. You can\u2019t sit outside and you can\u2019t sleep at night.\u201d\n\nResidents are accustomed to noise because the village is home to an air base where fighter jets regularly take off and land. But another resident, Alie Tiemersma, told a local daily, The Leeuwarder Courant: \u201cI would rather the planes than this. At least they stop at 5 p.m.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYet another, Margriet de Ruiter, told the newspaper that the noise from the road was \u201cpsychological torture.\u201d\n\nMs. Poepjes said she had visited the village to hear complaints because officials wanted to be in sync with villagers on the project. What she heard, she said, was that \u201cit\u2019s working \u2014 but, please, not here.\u201d\n\nBasically, she said, \u201cThey hated it.\u201d\n\nMs. Poepjes said residents had complained that a lot of drivers were deliberately veering onto the shoulder to start the anthem. \u201cEnthusiastic young people were driving way too fast,\u201d she said.\n\nShe added of the complaints: \u201cI can completely relate. They could hear the anthem over and over when they were sitting in their garden; it has been wonderful weather.\u201d\n\nSo, less than two days after the strips were laid down, province officials had them scraped off overnight Wednesday.\n\nThe Jelsum experiment is not the first of its type in the Netherlands. In 2014, the city of OSS installed glow-in-the-dark, \u201csmart\u201d highway lanes.\n\nAnd the Netherlands isn\u2019t the first country to make roads \u201csing\u201d in an effort to improve safety. Denmark, Japan, South Korea and the United States also have musical roads.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDenmark claims credit for the first known musical road, known as the \u201cAsphaltophone.\u201d In Albuquerque, N.M., a section of Route 66 rumbles \u201cAmerica the Beautiful.\u201d In Japan, rumble strips near Mount Fuji can be brought to life. In South Korea, musical grooves were installed in dangerous stretches to get drivers to pay attention, including one road that plays an off-key version of \u201cMary Had a Little Lamb.\u201d\n\nIn Lancaster, Calif., however, a stretch of desert highway is woefully out of tune. It is supposed to play the \u201cWilliam Tell Overture\u201d from Rossini\u2019s opera when drivers hit 55 m.p.h.\n\nThe grooves in the road, however, were not installed at the right distance from each other, distorting the sound.\n\nAs for the Dutch experiment, Ms. Poepjes said officials had not totally given up.\n\n\u201cIt has been fun, but now we\u2019re in a cool-down period,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re not going to drop the idea completely. If we do it again, we will do it with a complete understanding of the neighborhood and make sure nobody is bothered by it.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cIt just wasn\u2019t a good idea in the end.\u201d", "title": "Dutch \u2018Singing Road\u2019 Silenced After Villagers Complain: \u2018I\u2019m Going Nuts\u2019", "authors": ["Palko Karasz", "Yonette Joseph"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNearly three dozen people have been infected in an E. coli outbreak linked to chopped romaine lettuce from the Yuma, Ariz., region, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday.\n\nThe agency said that it had not yet identified a grower, supplier, distributor or brand common to the 35 cases of infection across 11 states, so it urged consumers to avoid any chopped romaine lettuce from the Yuma area.\n\n\u201cIf you cannot confirm the source of the lettuce, do not buy or eat it,\u201d the C.D.C. said in a statement. The agency also recommended that restaurants and retailers not serve chopped romaine lettuce from the region.\n\nThe people infected so far range in age from 12 to 84 years old. Of the 22 people hospitalized in the outbreak, three had developed a type of kidney failure, according to the C.D.C. No deaths have been reported. Because of an average reporting delay of two to three weeks, illnesses that may have occurred after March 27 have not yet been counted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe C.D.C. said that 26 of 28 infected individuals surveyed reported eating a salad at a restaurant, with romaine lettuce being the only common ingredient. The restaurants reported using bagged, chopped romaine lettuce.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe agency said it is still working to pinpoint the source of the outbreak.\n\nThe infections are somewhat spread out, geographically. Nine people were infected in Pennsylvania, more than any other state. Eight people were infected in Idaho and seven in New Jersey. Connecticut, New York and Ohio each had two people infected. Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, Virginia and Washington State each had one.", "title": "E. Coli Linked to Chopped Romaine Lettuce Infects People in 11 States", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you do not know if the lettuce is romaine, do not eat it and throw it away,\u201d the C.D.C. said in a statement.\n\nThe Wednesday report shows that the outbreak has expanded in recent days. On Friday, the C.D.C. had reported only 35 illnesses in 11 states.\n\nThe people infected in the outbreak range in age from 10 to 85. Seventy percent of them are female. At least 31 people were hospitalized and five had developed kidney failure, according to the agency. No one has died yet.\n\nThe first illness linked to the outbreak began on March 13 and the last was recorded as starting on April 6, but there may be more to come. Any infections that began after March 29 may have yet to be counted because it typically takes two to three weeks for an illness to be reported.\n\nThe agency was first alerted to the outbreak by health officials in New Jersey, who had noticed an increase in E. coli cases in the state, said Dr. Laura Gieraltowski, an epidemiologist at the C.D.C. After some discussion, it became clear that many of those infected had eaten chopped romaine lettuce at restaurants before getting sick.", "title": "E. Coli Outbreak Tied to Romaine Lettuce Expands to 16 States", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Environmental Protection Agency has been examining posts on Twitter and other social media about Scott Pruitt, the agency\u2019s administrator, to justify his extraordinary and costly security measures, which have included first-class travel and full-time protection even on personal trips to Disneyland, the Rose Bowl and college basketball games, according to interviews and agency and congressional documents.\n\nThe social media efforts have come under scrutiny by some Democratic lawmakers, as well as senior officials at the E.P.A., who said the review had uncovered individuals sounding off against Mr. Pruitt but had found no actionable threats against him. One top E.P.A. official said in an interview that he had objected to the efforts when they were first discussed last year, to no avail.\n\nSuspicious posts are referred to the E.P.A. inspector general\u2019s office, which is charged with investigating threats. Spokesmen for both the inspector general and the E.P.A. declined to comment on the nature of specific threats, citing security concerns. The E.P.A. spokesman, Jahan Wilcox, said in a statement, \u201cScott Pruitt has faced an unprecedented amount of death threats against him.\u201d\n\nBut two Democratic senators said on Tuesday that an agency whistle-blower had provided them with an internal E.P.A. memo concluding that a threat assessment prepared by Mr. Pruitt\u2019s security detail did not appear to justify the increased protection. The internal memo was prepared in February by the intelligence unit of the agency\u2019s homeland security office, according to the senators, Tom Carper of Delaware and Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island.", "title": "E.P.A. Assesses Threats on Twitter to Justify Pruitt\u2019s Spending", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Auditors wrote that the E.P.A.\u2019s \u201cfailure to comply with a governmentwide statutory requirement that an agency notify the appropriations committees before it spends more than $5,000 for the office of a presidential appointee\u201d was a violation of the law and should be reported to Congress and the president.\n\nIn an eight-page letter to lawmakers, Thomas H. Armstrong, the G.A.O.\u2019s general counsel, said the agency did not send advance notice to Congress when it paid $43,238.68 from its Environmental Programs and Management budget to pay for the installation of the soundproof booth.\n\nThe G.A.O. reports its findings to Congress but has little enforcement power of its own.\n\nSenator Tom Udall, the New Mexico Democrat who requested the investigation along with three other members of Congress, said Mr. Pruitt was \u201cblatantly breaking laws and ethics rules that protect taxpayers from government waste, fraud and abuse in order to help himself to perks and special favors.\u201d\n\nSenator John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming and chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, which has jurisdiction over the E.P.A., also criticized the agency, while not identifying Mr. Pruitt by name.\n\n\u201cIt is critical that E.P.A. and all federal agencies comply with notification requirements to Congress before spending taxpayer dollars,\u201d Senator Barrasso said in a statement. \u201cE.P.A. must give a full public accounting of this expenditure and explain why the agency thinks it was complying with the law.\u201d\n\nLiz Bowman, a spokeswoman for the E.P.A., said in a statement, \u201cE.P.A. is addressing G.A.O.\u2019s concern, with regard to Congressional notification about this expense, and will be sending Congress the necessary information this week.\u201d\n\nThe G.A.O. report noted that federal laws would not have blocked E.P.A. from purchasing the phone booth, and Ms. Bowman said that the accountability office had recognized the need for employees to have access to secure telephone lines to handle sensitive information.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe other report Monday, from the E.P.A.\u2019s own inspector general, an independent office within agency, did not draw any conclusions as to whether Mr. Pruitt or his chief of staff, Ryan Jackson, violated laws in using the Safe Drinking Water Act of 1974 to hire officials and award raises.\n\nRather, it provided more than 80 pages of \u201crequests for personnel action\u201d showing that Mr. Jackson, often with the signed authorization of Mr. Pruitt, handled most of the paperwork associated with the employees.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nArthur A. Elkins Jr., the E.P.A. Inspector General, indicated that more may be coming from his office regarding agency hiring practices, and said the report Monday was merely to alert officials to \u201ccertain factual information while our audit continues.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for the E.P.A., Jahan Wilcox, said in a statement that Mr. Pruitt did not determine his appointee\u2019s salaries or raises. That, he said, is done by the E.P.A. chief of staff, White House liaison, and career human resource officials.\n\n\u201cSalaries are based on work history, and any increases are due to either new and additional responsibilities or promotions,\u201d Mr. Wilcox said. \u201cSalary determinations are made to avoid disparities among positions of equivalent or similar responsibilities, to the extent possible.\u201d\n\nHe said that the agency would continue to provide information to the inspector general for any further inquiries.\n\nThe use of the Safe Drinking Water Act of 1974 to hire political appointees and grant raises to two Oklahoma aides has, in particular, drawn the ire of Democrats. According to documents provided under the Freedom of Information Act to American Oversight, a liberal watchdog group, Mr. Pruitt used the law to bring on board at least 20 political appointees, known as \u201cadministratively determined\u201d hires.\n\nAmong those hires were Sarah Greenwalt, who served as general counsel for Mr. Pruitt when he served as attorney general of Oklahoma, and Millan Hupp, who was a financial and political consultant for Mr. Pruitt\u2019s political action committees in Oklahoma.\n\nThe E.P.A. has acknowledged that it asked for Ms. Greenwalt\u2019s salary to be raised from $107,435 to $164,200, and for Ms. Hupp\u2019s to be raised from $86,460 to $114,590, under the Safe Drinking Water Act.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an interview on April 4 with Fox News, Mr. Pruitt denied responsibility for the raises. \u201cI found out this yesterday and I corrected the action, and we are in the process of finding out how it took place and correcting it,\u201d he said.\n\nThe next day, Mr. Pruitt\u2019s chief of staff, Ryan Jackson, issued a statement taking responsibility for the raises and saying that Mr. Pruitt \u201chad zero knowledge of the amount of the raises, nor the process by which they transpired.\u201d\n\nMr. Pruitt is not the first E.P.A. administrator to hire under the drinking water law. Agencies are allowed to fill up to 30 administratively determined positions and that authority has been used by both President Barack Obama and the elder President George Bush. Critics, however, said it was unusual to use the authority to hire deputy assistant administrators as Mr. Pruitt has.\n\nAlso on Monday, the inspector general for the Department of Interior reviewed costs associated with charter flights that Secretary Ryan Zinke took and found no violation of laws.\n\nBut investigators concluded that a $12,377 charter flight the secretary took in June to his home state of Montana from Las Vegas, where he was speaking to a hockey team, might have been avoided if agency employees had worked with the hockey team to better accommodate the secretary\u2019s schedule.\n\nNonetheless, Mr. Zinke \u201cgenerally followed relevant law, policy, rules and regulations\u201d when he chartered the flight, auditors said.", "title": "E.P.A. Chief\u2019s $43,000 Phone Booth Broke the Law, Congressional Auditors Say", "authors": ["Lisa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The disclosures, he has suggested, were the handiwork of critics who were resorting to personal attacks to derail the deregulatory agenda being pursued by his agency and the Trump administration. Since taking the administrator\u2019s job in February 2017, Mr. Pruitt has advanced one of the administration\u2019s most aggressive regulatory rollbacks, including regulations intended to tighten rules related to coal-burning power plants, oil and gas drilling, auto and truck air emissions, and pesticides.\n\nYet the revelations about his staff turnover, which have not been previously reported, demonstrate that concerns about his spending and leadership resonated within his own team well before they became the subject of media reports and investigations by the E.P.A. inspector general and the White House.\n\nAgency records obtained through open-records requests show the critical role that Mr. Allen, Mr. Chmielewski and Mr. Reeder played in reviewing Mr. Pruitt\u2019s travel plans. In some instances, several agency officials said, pushback by the officials prevailed.\n\nFor instance, in a conversation with one of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s closest aides, Mr. Chmielewski sharply objected to a proposal to buy a $100,000-a-month charter aircraft membership that would have allowed Mr. Pruitt to take unlimited private jet trips for official business, according to two administration officials. The membership was not purchased.\n\nMr. Chmielewski also objected to a proposal to spend about $70,000 to replace two desks in Mr. Pruitt\u2019s office suite, including his personal desk and one at a security station outside his office. Asked about the proposed desk purchases, Mr. Wilcox, the E.P.A. spokesman, said that \u201cthe administrator never considered the proposal.\u201d Pasquale Perrotta, who became head of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s security detail after Mr. Weese was removed, insisted that the security desk be upgraded to a bulletproof model, according to current and former E.P.A. employees with direct knowledge of the discussions.\n\nThe bulletproof security desk was not purchased, but two new desks were ordered for Mr. Pruitt\u2019s personal office: a brown maple wood stand-up desk, with brass locks, that was purchased from a craftsman and an oversize desk with ornate woodworking that had been in a federal government warehouse in Virginia and was refurbished for Mr. Pruitt at a cost of $2,075. E.P.A. employees gawked at the size and grandeur of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s refurbished desk, with some comparing it to the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office, officials said in interviews.\n\nStill, Mr. Pruitt and his team obtained many of the perks he wanted. Staff members questioned, but nonetheless approved, frequent trips that routed Mr. Pruitt through hub airports that allowed him to spend weekends at his home in Oklahoma. The administrator also had charter flights approved after they were already taken, the public records show.", "title": "E.P.A. Officials Sidelined After Questioning Scott Pruitt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "In the draft, the agencies lay out eight different options for revising the Obama-era standards. The preferred course of action would freeze fuel-economy standards at 2020 levels for both cars and light trucks, greatly slowing progress in reducing auto emissions.\n\nThe proposal also challenges California\u2019s authority to impose its own vehicle standards.\n\nCurrently, California has a waiver under the Clean Air Act to impose its own, stricter, air pollution regulations on cars and trucks to deal with problems like smog. But the administration\u2019s draft proposal argues that California cannot use this waiver to set standards on greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles because that would be tantamount to regulating fuel economy, which states are forbidden from doing under a 1975 law.\n\nThe auto industry has previously tried to challenge California\u2019s greenhouse gas standards for vehicles on these grounds, but federal courts have so far rejected their arguments. Legal experts have said that, as long as California is regulating the pollutants that come out of tailpipes and not directly determining fuel economy standards, the state is on solid legal ground.\n\nThe Trump administration has also signaled that it would consider rescinding California\u2019s waiver altogether, although the draft proposal does not mention this. On Thursday, Mr. Pruitt told Congress that the agency was still in \u201cactive discussions\u201d with California and had no plans at the present to revoke the waiver.\n\nIn recent months, automakers have become increasingly nervous about the Trump administration\u2019s collision course with California. A group of automakers has requested a direct meeting with President Trump to urge the administration to avert a legal clash with California, which could plunge the auto industry into regulatory chaos, according to two people with knowledge of the automakers\u2019 plans. A spokeswoman for the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers was not immediately available for comment.", "title": "E.P.A. Readies Plan to Weaken Rules That Require Cars to Be Cleaner", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "BRUSSELS \u2014 Virtually no one in Europe wants President Trump to plunge headlong into a trade war with China. But nearly everyone thinks that it is time to stand up to China\u2019s closed markets and trade manipulation.\n\nThe European Union may not like Mr. Trump or the way he is doing things \u2014 but that does not mean it dislikes his aims when it comes to trading with China.\n\nBut Europe would also like the conflict to go away, fearing the bloc will be caught between the United States, its primary market and second-largest supplier, and China, its primary supplier and second-largest market.\n\nThe way to make that happen, it believes, is challenging China through negotiations within the existing trading system, avoiding a degenerative tit-for-tat battle that could harm Europe\u2019s relatively vibrant economy.", "title": "E.U. Likes Trump\u2019s Stance on China, but Hates His Methods", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Doug Creutz, a media analyst at Cowen, said it was not important for ESPN+ to generate revenue in the near term. Rather, it should serve as a safety net in case the traditional cable bundle continues to collapse. \u201cThe economic pressure that all these guys are finding on this model, it is kind of a slow drip,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is not catastrophic collapse. It is death by a thousand cuts.\u201d\n\nHe added that ESPN did not have a long history of new product launches, besides new channels, because it hasn\u2019t had to. \u201cIt has been a really simple business to run for a long time,\u201d he said. \u201cIt has gotten complicated recently, so they are trying some new things.\u201d\n\nThe current ESPN app prioritizes scores, news and highlights, and also has a tab for cable television subscribers to watch ESPN.\n\nThe new app will essentially contain three better integrated parts: news and scores, live events and shows that are on ESPN\u2019s television channels, and ESPN+. \u201cThis is essentially a three-in-one service,\u201d Pitaro said.\n\nThe ESPN app has been downloaded 70 million times and has two million daily active users, according to Apptopia, an app analytics company. It regularly ranks as the most downloaded sports app.\n\nESPN wants to use the integrated app to drive ESPN+ subscriptions. If you are browsing Yankees scores in the app and a Yankees game is live on an ESPN channel or ESPN+, a banner will alert you that the game is available to watch. If you have entered your cable subscription information or subscribed to ESPN+, you will go straight to the game. If not, you will be prompted to enter your information or to subscribe to ESPN+.\n\nThe app was built by both BamTech, the Major League Baseball Advanced Media spinoff that Disney, ESPN\u2019s parent company, bought a 75 percent stake in for $2.58 billion in 2017, and ESPN\u2019s core technology team in Bristol.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt $4.99, ESPN+ is cheaper than other streaming services, but has one enormous drawback: It won\u2019t show anything available on ESPN\u2019s television channels. That means no \u201cMonday Night Football,\u201d no N.B.A. games, no \u201cSunday Night Baseball\u201d and few Power 5 conference football and basketball games. For those options you will still need to have a cable subscription.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFewer than 87 million people currently subscribe to a television package with ESPN, compared with more than 100 million in 2011, according to Nielsen. The company knows that its television audience is declining and that streaming video is the future, but television remains a cash cow that generates billions of dollars in revenue annually. ESPN collects about $8 per month for each subscriber from pay television companies that carry the network, according to Kagan, the media research firm.\n\nExecutives say ESPN+ is designed not to cannibalize the television business.\n\n\u201cThis application, this service, this will all be complementary,\u201d Pitaro said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nESPN believes there are three types of customers who will subscribe to ESPN+. There is the sports fanatic who wants access to everything; the fan of many niche sports that ESPN+ will have rights to, like rugby and cricket; and alumni and fans of non-Power 5 colleges.\n\nESPN will show more than 10,000 games on ESPN+. The network has the rights to thousands of college events, as well as tennis, golf and lower-level soccer matches that never appear on television. Those events will now find a home on ESPN+. Agreements with the N.H.L. and Major League Baseball call for ESPN to stream a daily game, and the company has streaming deals with the Sun Belt Conference and the Ivy League, as well Major League Soccer and the United Soccer League, among many others.\n\nESPN also hopes that exclusive, original programming will be a draw. The entire library of \u201c30 for 30\u201d sports documentaries will be available to stream at any time, and \u201cThe Last Days of Knight,\u201d about the former ESPN commentator Bob Knight\u2019s dismissal as Indiana\u2019s basketball coach, will be available only on ESPN+. It will also stream new programs like \u201cDraft Academy,\u201d a look at N.F.L. prospects in advance of the draft, and \u201cDetails,\u201d a basketball analysis program hosted by Kobe Bryant.\n\nExecutives declined to state their goals or expectations for ESPN+ other than to say they wanted to expand the network\u2019s reach and continue \u201cdelighting\u201d fans. There are no current plans to introduce price tiers to ESPN+ or to allow customers to buy television channels through it.\n\nDisney is in the process of buying 22 regional sports networks from 21st Century Fox. If that deal goes through, some content owned by those channels may also become available through ESPN+.\n\nFor Pitaro, who took over ESPN in March after John Skipper resigned in December to address what he has described as a cocaine problem, ESPN+ may become a litmus test for his first months on the job. Pitaro\u2019s other big debut, the morning show \u201cGet Up,\u201d is struggling to gain traction.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt ESPN\u2019s upfronts last May, the company announced \u201cGet Up,\u201d which finally made its debut last week. Hosted by Mike Greenberg, Michelle Beadle and Jalen Rose, it is a lighthearted sports version of a traditional morning show, with some segments remaining from the \u201cSportsCenter\u201d programs that are traditionally shown from 7 to 10 a.m.\n\nESPN has made significant investments in \u201cGet Up.\u201d It broke up the popular and profitable radio show \u201cMike & Mike\u201d to free Greenberg; built a studio in Lower Manhattan; and relocated Beadle, Rose, other staffers and its \u201cNBA Countdown\u201d pregame show to New York from Los Angeles.\n\n\u201cGet Up\u201d averaged 256,000 viewers last week. That is down 15 percent from the audience for \u201cSportsCenter\u201d the previous week, and down 19 percent from the same time period last year.\n\nBefore the show\u2019s debut, Bill Wolff, its executive producer, said of the show: \u201cWe need to try to increase the number of viewers that come to us. That\u2019s measurable. That\u2019s tangible.\u201d", "title": "ESPN Tries to Get With a Mobile, App-Driven World", "authors": ["Kevin Draper"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) \u2014 Earle Bruce, who embraced the unenviable task of following his mentor, the revered Woody Hayes, as Ohio State\u2019s head football coach and then compiled an impressive record of his own beginning in 1979, has died in Columbus. He was 87.\n\nHis death was announced by his four daughters on Friday in a statement released by Ohio State. He had Alzheimer\u2019s disease.\n\nBruce had a record of 81-26-1 as head coach in Ohio from 1979-87. He took over under unusual and challenging circumstances, hired after Hayes was fired for punching a Clemson player in the 1978 Gator Bowl. Hayes coached Ohio State for 28 seasons.", "title": "Earle Bruce, Winning Football Coach at Ohio State, Dies at 87", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "1. On April 22, 1970, millions of people throughout the country demonstrated on the inaugural Earth Day, calling for clean air, water and land. They were spurred by severe pollution and environmental disasters. And that year, in a bipartisan effort, the Environmental Protection Agency was created.\n\nBut now environmental rules are under threat as the Trump administration looks to roll back federal regulations. And the head of the E.P.A., Scott Pruitt, above, is under scrutiny for allegations of unchecked spending and ethics lapses, including his interactions with lobbyists.\n\nOur investigative reporters found that many of the pitfalls he has encountered in Washington have echoes in his past.\n\nDid you keep up with the headlines this week?
