Here\u2019s the front page of our Sunday paper, and our crossword puzzles.", "title": "Earth Day, North Korea, Michael Cohen: Your Weekend Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Has spring come to the place where you live? What signs are you seeing?\n\nFive photographs set out to document what the arrival of the season looked like in New York City this year. See what they found in It\u2019s Spring! (No, It Isn\u2019t.) Yes, It Is!, then create your own photo essay about your neighborhood.\n\nOr, do something similar to what Marielle Anzelone did in her 2012 Spring Time series for the Metro section, in which she photographed and offered weekly dispatches from a bit of Staten Island woodland as it changed with the season. Here is what she wrote on March 20, 2012:\n\nThe frame of the photograph above will not change between now and the summer solstice on June 20. But everything within it will. We will watch leaves burst from their buds, wildflowers come into bloom, butterflies emerge from hibernation, and birds build nests and fledge their young. Our window into the woodland world will reveal shift and change, growth and decay as it seemingly comes to life. \u2026 I hope this series will inspire you to seek out nature in New York City and observe spring in the native places where you live.\n\nWhere can you find a patch of nature to observe? How might you document the season as it unfolds?\n\nIf you would like to observe animal behavior this season, you might read \u201cWaking From Hibernation, the Hard Work of Spring Begins\u201d to learn about bears, bats, bees and squirrels, or \u201cOn Long Migrations, Birds Chase an Eternal Spring\u201d to understand why \u201cbird migrations have stumped the greatest minds for thousands of years.\u201d\n\nBut many also find a \u201cdark warning\u201d in how climate change is affecting our seasons. One Times Op-Ed writer summed it up on March 11:\n\n\n\nOn Presidents\u2019 Day, the high in Nashville was 76 degrees; the next day it hit 80. This, we all assured one another, was nothing more than our annual false spring, an idyll of sunny skies and temperate breezes that briefly gives us all heart before winter crashes back and turns the saucer magnolia\u2019s pink blossoms into a brown smudge against the cold blue sky. ... But this, it turns out, was not a false spring. This was actual spring arriving very early. The symptoms of climate change are well known, and its risks to some of our favorite creatures \u2014 tigers, sea turtles, elephants, giant pandas, mountain gorillas, monarch butterflies \u2014 are equally clear, though it\u2019s easy to forget that in the comings and goings of our own daily lives. In December a National Geographic video of a starving polar bear went viral as people faced at a gut level the undeniable consequences of a phenomenon that can sometimes seem mainly theoretical. A storm system that moved through the country last week temporarily brought colder temperatures to Nashville and a blizzard across the Northeast, but that won\u2019t change anything. There will be consequences to this absurdly early spring.\n\nWhat are these \u201cconsequences,\u201d and what can we do about them? Ahead of Earth Day on April 22, check out some of the campaigns around environmental and climate literacy the Earth Day Network has created, or visit the Times Topics page on climate change, or our own Learning Network resources for teaching and learning about the topic, including this lesson plan for young citizen scientists.\n\n_________\n\nCelebrate the Season in Sports, Style, Food and Travel", "title": "Earth Day, Poetry Month, Baseball Season and More: Teaching and Learning About Spring With The New York Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "True, there are issues of intermittency remaining \u2014 the wind doesn\u2019t always blow, the sun doesn\u2019t always shine \u2014 although batteries and other energy storage technologies are also making rapid progress. There are also some energy uses, especially transportation, where fossil fuels retain a significant advantage in cost and convenience. And exactly how we\u2019re going to have carbon-neutral air travel is still, well, up in the air.\n\nBut there is no longer any reason to believe that it would be hard to drastically \u201cdecarbonize\u201d the economy. Indeed, there is no reason to believe that doing so would impose any significant economic cost. The realistic debate is about how hard it will be to get from 80 to 100 percent decarbonization.\n\nFor now, however, the problem isn\u2019t technology \u2014 it\u2019s politics.\n\nThe fossil fuel sector may represent a technological dead end, but it still has a lot of money and power. Lately it has been putting almost all of that money and power behind Republicans. For example, in the 2016 election cycle the coal mining industry gave 97 percent (!) of its contributions to G.O.P. candidates.\n\nWhat the industry got in return for that money wasn\u2019t just a president who talks nonsense about bringing back coal jobs and an administration that rejects the science of climate change. It got an Environmental Protection Agency head who\u2019s trying to suppress evidence on the damage pollution causes, and a secretary of energy who tried, unsuccessfully so far, to force natural gas and renewables to subsidize coal and nuclear plants.\n\nIn the long run, these tactics probably won\u2019t stop the transition to renewable energy, and even the villains of this story probably realize that. Their goal is, instead, to slow things down, so they can extract as much profit as possible from their existing investments.\n\nUnfortunately, this really is a case of \u201cin the long run we are all dead.\u201d Every year that we delay the clean-energy transition will sicken or kill thousands while increasing the risk of climate catastrophe.\n\nThe point is that Trump and company aren\u2019t just trying to move us backward on social issues; they\u2019re also trying to block technological progress. And the price of their obstructionism will be high.", "title": "Opinion | Earth, Wind and Liars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The rate of maternal mortality in the United States, already higher than in other wealthy countries, has risen by more than half since 1990. The grim increase is largely because of alarmingly high rates among black women, who nationally are three times as likely to die in pregnancy or childbirth as white women.\n\nIn New York City, the numbers are even more staggering. Black women here are 12 times as likely to die from childbirth-related causes as white women. They experience severe, life-threatening complications from pregnancy and childbirth in about 387 out of every 10,000 births, according to city data. That is triple the rate of white New Yorkers, and roughly comparable to complication rates in Sierra Leone.\n\nThe disturbing phenomenon has been closely examined by The New York Times Magazine and ProPublica, which in recent months have laid out the shameful details of how we have failed to protect the lives of black women in pregnancy and childbirth. One stunning find: Wealthier, more educated black women in New York City are also dying or almost dying in childbirth at a far higher rate than their white neighbors. One city study found that black college-educated women were more than twice as likely to experience severe complications from childbirth as white women without a high school diploma.\n\nLatinas and Asian women also experience higher rates of severe and potentially life-threatening complications. But some researchers and city officials believe that the higher rates of death and complications among black women are caused only partly by longstanding disparities in poverty, obesity and lack of access to top-rate health care. The dangers black women face in pregnancy and childbirth, they say, are compounded by racism, unconscious biases in health care and the long-term anxieties, regardless of economic status, that come with being an African-American woman.", "title": "Opinion | Easing the Dangers of Childbirth for Black Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump has long railed against Chinese trade practices, and he has long criticized previous presidents for their approach to the issue. This year, he has pushed aggressively on the issue. He levied tariffs on imported steel and aluminum that were largely viewed as a shot at Chinese oversupply of those metals. Then he proposed as much as $150 billion in tariffs on other imports from China.\n\nHis advisers have stressed that economists largely agree with Mr. Trump that the Chinese are stealing American intellectual property and restricting access to their market in ways that put American companies at a disadvantage.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cNo free-market guy, no free-trade guy disagrees on this subject,\u201d Larry Kudlow, the new director of the National Economic Council, said on CNN\u2019s \u201cState of the Union\u201d on Sunday. \u201cThe guild, if you will, the brethren of the economic profession have all agreed that something has to be done.\u201d\n\nPeter Navarro, the director of Mr. Trump\u2019s Office of Trade and Manufacturing Policy, told NBC\u2019s \u201cMeet the Press\u201d on Sunday that \u201cwhat we have here is a situation where every American understands that China is stealing our intellectual property, they\u2019re forcing the transfer of our technology when companies go to China, and by doing that, they steal jobs from America, they steal factories from America, and we run an unprecedented $370-billion-a-year trade deficit in goods. This is an unsustainable situation.\u201d\n\nMany economists agree that China needs to be confronted on several trade issues, though very few share Mr. Trump\u2019s fixation on the United States\u2019 trade deficit with China. Most say bilateral trade deficits are not a good measure of market access or the fairness of trade agreements.\n\n\u201cI think the basic issue that the Trump administration is pointing to \u2014 the lack of intellectual-property protection \u2014 is a serious one, particularly for the United States,\u201d said N. Gregory Mankiw, a Harvard economist who headed President George W. Bush\u2019s Council of Economic Advisers. \u201cIt\u2019s a completely serious and appropriate issue for the administration to be concerned with.\u201d\n\nWhat worries Mr. Mankiw and others is Mr. Trump\u2019s threat of tariffs, which administration officials have portrayed both as a bargaining chip and as a policy Mr. Trump would certainly carry through on.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEconomic forecasters are just beginning to predict how tariffs would affect growth. Goldman Sachs analysts wrote this week that the currently proposed tariffs would cut less than 0.1 percentage points off American growth this year, but also said that \u201cit is harder to rule out continued escalation to a level that does ultimately have a first-order impact on the economy\u201d if the United States and China could not find compromise.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBecause tariffs would raise prices for American businesses and consumers that buy imported goods, \u201cyou\u2019re hurting yourself if you follow through with it,\u201d Mr. Mankiw said. \u201cIt just seems to me to be a not very smart threat to be making, given that it would not be rational to follow through with it.\u201d\n\nEconomists who don\u2019t like tariffs but favor action against China largely say the United States should be forming a multinational coalition to confront the Chinese.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAny good strategy has to include getting other countries on your side,\u201d said Jason Furman, an economist at Harvard\u2019s Kennedy School of Government who headed the Council of Economic Advisers under President Barack Obama. \u201cIf it\u2019s the United States versus China, we\u2019re similar-sized economies. If it\u2019s the United States and the world versus China, that\u2019s not something China can win.\u201d\n\nMr. Furman, Mr. Mankiw and others said the United States should continue to press its case against China before the World Trade Organization \u2014 a strategy that Mr. Navarro and other advisers to Mr. Trump say has not produced favorable results in the past. The economists who disagree with the administration\u2019s approach also stress, frequently, that joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership would have given the United States leverage in this dispute.\n\nSince Mr. Trump quit the pact, 11 other countries have forged ahead on it. He said this year that he would reconsider joining the agreement if it was renegotiated to benefit the United States more substantially.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s obviously a terrible mistake\u201d to have quit the agreement, said Austan Goolsbee, an economist at the University of Chicago\u2019s Booth School of Business and another past chairman of Mr. Obama\u2019s Council of Economic Advisers. \u201cThis was a coalition of the vast majority of the economies of Asia outside of China, agreeing to principles exactly of the form that we\u2019re now saying that we want. We would be in a lot better situation if we had all of those people on our side.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s unilateral approach, including his tariff threats, has drawn qualified support from at least one unlikely high-profile economist: Martin Feldstein, of Harvard, a chairman of President Ronald Reagan\u2019s Council of Economic Advisers.\n\nMr. Feldstein began a syndicated op-ed column last month, on the subject of Mr. Trump\u2019s steel and aluminum tariffs, by declaring, \u201cLike almost all economists and most policy analysts, I prefer low trade tariffs or no tariffs at all.\u201d But he went on to criticize China\u2019s intellectual-property policies and predict that the United States \u201ccannot use traditional remedies for trade disputes or World Trade Organization procedures to stop China\u2019s behavior.\u201d\n\nAmerican negotiators, Mr. Feldstein wrote, would use tariff threats \u201cas a way to persuade China\u2019s government to abandon the policy of \u2018voluntary\u2019 technology transfers.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf that happens, and U.S. firms can do business in China without being compelled to pay such a steep competitive price,\u201d he continued, \u201cthe threat of tariffs will have been a very successful tool of trade policy.\u201d", "title": "Economists Say U.S. Tariffs Are Wrong Move on a Valid Issue", "authors": ["Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe country is irrelevant to me,\u201d he said over a bowl of shrimp soup with pasta and peppers at an Atlanta branch of his restaurant, Taqueria del Sol. \u201cIt\u2019s what\u2019s available and what you can do with it.\u201d\n\nToo much emphasis is placed these days on culinary authenticity, he continued. \u201cIn Mexico, we eat what we like and don\u2019t worry about what is authentic to this cuisine or that,\u201d he said. \u201cYou make do, and you make it taste good.\u201d\n\nMr. Hernandez, who learned to cook from his grandmother, first came to America when he was a teenager with his rock band Fascinaci\u00f3n. They tried to land a recording contract in Houston. It didn\u2019t go so well.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter a decade of working in factories and Tex-Mex restaurants while trying to break into the music business, he moved to Atlanta. He said that despite his chunky gold jewelry, pierced ear and long rocker hair, he got a job at a restaurant owned by Mike Klank, a low-key son of the South.\n\nHe and Mr. Klank, to whom the book is dedicated, are now partners in the seven-restaurant Taqueria del Sol chain. Mr. Hernandez sells plenty of carnitas folded into flour tortillas, and bowls of green pork chili. But the menu also has his own Southern-Mexican mash-ups like tacos stuffed with fried chicken and lime jalape\u00f1o mayonnaise, or Memphis-style smoked pork with spicy cabbage slaw.\n\nMr. Klank has helped Mr. Hernandez understand the Southern palate. They toured Atlanta\u2019s meat-and-three restaurants, and sampled the dry-rub barbecue from Memphis, Mr. Klank\u2019s hometown.\n\nSome of Mr. Hernandez\u2019s education was simple experimentation. Early on, a customer gave him a bag of turnip greens. He didn\u2019t know what to do with them. Mr. Klank explained that Southerners simmer them for a long time with a ham hock to make a smoky, almost murky broth called potlikker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead, Mr. Hernandez approached them the way his family used to cook lamb\u2019s quarters, the greens called quelites in Spanish. He put them in a pot with chicken stock, tomatoes and garlic, and added a hit of chile de arbol. The dish is a mainstay at the restaurants, and the recipe is in his book.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo is his take on pork roast, a Southern Sunday supper staple. A pork loin with a little cap of fat is rubbed with onion and garlic, both in granulated form, then roasted fast in a very hot oven whose residual heat is used to roast a couple of jalape\u00f1os. The chopped peppers are then folded into gravy made from a classic French roux and homemade stock.\n\nThe result is a decidedly Southern dish, punched up with the flavors he grew up eating in his hometown, Monterrey. Like most of his recipes, it\u2019s thrifty, practical and delicious.\n\n\u201cMy food doesn\u2019t require an arm and a leg, and you don\u2019t have to spend six hours in the kitchen,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat\u2019s not to say they aren\u2019t specific. Mr. Hernandez is, if nothing else, very specific. He prefers lemon juice to lime juice in his guacamole because lime is too acidic and \u201ccooks\u201d the avocado. And he blisters jalape\u00f1o in oil for the dip because it takes away the green taste of the pepper, which he thinks interferes with the flavor of the avocado \u2014 which, by the way, has to be Hass.\n\n\u201cThis is the way I cook,\u201d he said. \u201cEither you like it or not. I don\u2019t care.\u201d\n\nThe point is to not fuss too much. \u201cIf you have something good and you want to make it better,\u201d he advised, \u201cbe careful. You can ruin the good you\u2019ve got already.\u201d\n\nRecipes: Pork Roast With Roasted Jalape\u00f1o Gravy | Green Peach Salad With Simple Lime Dressing\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Eddie Hernandez Doesn\u2019t Care if His Food Isn\u2019t \u2018Authentic\u2019", "authors": ["Kim Severson"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "His one-man, stream-of-consciousness shows \u2014 often performed in full makeup and a dress \u2014 bounce rapidly among topics as diverse as his use of cosmetics, religion and the former British Empire.\n\n\u201cHis brand of seduction aims directly at the head, not below the belt,\u201d a critic for The Times wrote of Mr. Izzard\u2019s \u201cSexie\u201d show, when he performed it in New York in 2003.\n\nMr. Izzard has long delivered shows in French, which he speaks fluently, as well as English. And in recent years he has performed in German and Spanish, as well.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve got this weird thing which is, for one thing, making the stuff universal,\u201d he once told The Independent in Britain.\n\nThough he is most famous for his comedy, Mr. Izzard also has significant acting credits to his name.\n\nHe has appeared in the Hollywood blockbusters \u201cOcean\u2019s Twelve\u201d and \u201cOcean\u2019s Thirteen,\u201d and in television series such as \u201cThe Good Wife\u201d and \u201cHannibal.\u201d He recently acted opposite Judi Dench in \u201cVictoria and Abdul,\u201d a British period drama.\n\nA Marathon Runner and Political Activist\n\nMr. Izzard embraces challenges \u2014 like performing in other languages \u2014 with a certain fervor.\n\nIn 2009, he ran 43 marathons in 51 days to raise money for charity, and in 2015, he ran 27 marathons in 27 days in South Africa, as a tribute to Nelson Mandela\u2019s 27 years in prison.\n\nHe has been a vocal Labour Party member for years, and was a prominent campaigner for Britain to remain in the European Union, though he ended up on the losing side of that issue.\n\nIn 2016, he toured 31 cities in 31 days to \u201cpersuade people, particularly young people, to vote\u201d ahead of Britain's referendum on its European Union membership, calling his campaign \u201cStand Up For Europe.\u201d He clashed with Nigel Farage, a prominent campaigner for a \u201cLeave\u201d vote, over housing and immigration during a BBC debate in the weeks before the referendum.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot one to shy away from extravagance, Mr. Izzard added the Union Jack and the European Union flag to a perfect set of blood-red nails while he was campaigning.\n\n\u2018I\u2019m Not Wearing Women\u2019s Clothes\u2019\n\nMr. Izzard, who has described himself as \u201ca transvestite,\u201d \u201ca transgender guy\u201d and \u201ca wannabe lesbian,\u201d has been open about his identity since the age of 23.\n\nBeing trans, he has said, has informed his politics: In his campaign for the Labour Party position, he spoke about coming out in 1985, and declared that he had \u201calways fought for the campaigns that I believe in, even when they are unpopular or I\u2019ve been advised against it.\u201d\n\nMr. Izzard has maintained that he has \u201cboy genetics and girl genetics,\u201d and that he does not believe in calling dresses \u201cwomen\u2019s clothes.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not wearing women\u2019s clothes \u2014 I\u2019m wearing clothes,\u201d he has said in many interviews.\n\nHe has said that coming out prepared him for the ruthless world of politics.\n\n\u201cWell, how much hate did I get for being a transvestite? It\u2019s very, very high,\u201d he said in an interview in 2013. He then added that people had referred to him as \u201cthat.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou know, if I can deal with that, then politics is easy,\u201d he said.", "title": "Eddie Izzard: Comedian, Transgender Activist, Labour Party Official", "authors": ["Iliana Magra", "Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Can I edit RAW image files from my D.S.L.R. on an iPad Pro? If so, is it possible to save the edited images back to the computer later so I don\u2019t have to take a laptop with me on my trip?\n\nA. If your camera uses a RAW format supported by Apple\u2019s iOS system on the iPad and you have a photo-editing app that works with RAW files, you should be able to import, edit and save your photos as you go. When you are done, you can transfer the edited images to the computer back home in a few different ways. (For those unfamiliar with the file type, RAW photos are uncompressed image files that retain much more visual data in the picture than do files saved in the compressed JPG format. RAW files give photographers more to edit.)\n\nWhen you are ready to edit photos, you first need to get the picture files from the camera to the tablet. You can do this in a few ways, including using one of Apple\u2019s camera-card adapters plugged into the iPad to download the original RAW files, or beaming the photos wirelessly from camera to tablet with a camera memory card enabled for Wi-Fi.\n\nOnce you have imported the images to the iPad\u2019s camera roll, you can pull them into an app that supports RAW editing and make your adjustments. The $20 Affinity for iPad, the freemium RAW Power and the older (but free) Snapseed are among the apps that can edit RAW files on the tablet. The free Adobe Lightroom CC for iOS added RAW editing in 2016 and can sync edited files back to the companion Adobe Lightroom CC app on a Mac or Windows PC \u2014 with a paid subscription.", "title": "Editing RAW Images on an iPad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMark Twain had Quarry Farm. Pablo Neruda had his Valparaiso home on the hill. And Edna St. Vincent Millay had Steepletop, her farmhouse home in Austerlitz, N.Y., where she wrote poetry about its sprawling, lush grounds. But the house, now a museum and a National Historic Landmark, is in danger of being shuttered. The Millay Society has started a fund-raising campaign, and said that the site will close in November unless $1 million is raised.\n\n\u201cThe cost of operating the site, even with a small staff and an extremely tight budget, exceeds the money brought in each year from donations and visitor fees,\u201d Vincent Elizabeth Barnett, the president of the organization\u2019s board of trustees, wrote in a statement.\n\nMillay and her husband, Eugen Jan Boissevain, bought the property in 1925, when it was still a blueberry farm, as a respite from New York City. In the poem \u201cSteepletop,\u201d published posthumously in 1954, she wrote about tending to the plants there: \u201cNothing could stand / All this rain. / The lilacs were drowned, browned / before I had even / smelled them / Cool against my cheek.\u201d\n\nShe lived there until her death in 1950, and is buried there alongside her husband. The site was named a National Historic Landmark in 1971 and became home to the Millay Colony of the Arts, which offers residencies and workshops. And the Millay Society opened the house and gardens to visitors in 2010; many of her possessions are on display, including her portable typewriter, her library collection and gowns she wore on reading tours.\n\nThough the house runs on a meager staff, with one full-time and two part-time employees as well as volunteers, it will close unless funds are raised. The Millay Society said that $1 million would allow the house to remain open for three to five years. They hope either to start an endowment or conjoin operations with another organization to stay open beyond then. More information can be found at millay.org.", "title": "Edna St. Vincent Millay\u2019s Farmhouse Faces Closure", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Gen. Efra\u00edn R\u00edos Montt, who as dictator of Guatemala in the 1980s ordered fierce tactics to suppress a guerrilla insurgency and was later convicted of genocide and crimes against humanity, died on Sunday in Guatemala City. He was 91.\n\nThe cause was a heart attack, according to his lawyers, Jaime Hern\u00e1ndez and Luis Rosales. The general had dementia and had suffered lung and heart problems in recent years.\n\nIn the panoply of commanders who turned much of Central America into a killing field in the 1980s, General R\u00edos Montt was one of the most murderous. He was convicted in 2013 of trying to exterminate the Ixil ethnic group, a Mayan Indian community whose villages were wiped out by his forces.\n\nA Guatemalan judge found that the general had known about the systematic massacres, in the hillside hamlets of the El Quich\u00e9 department, and had done nothing to stop them or the aerial bombardment of refugees who had fled to the mountains.", "title": "Efra\u00edn R\u00edos Montt, Guatemalan Dictator Convicted of Genocide, Dies at 91", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement, Amnesty International denounced Mr. Geneina\u2019s trial and sentencing as \u201canother example of the shameless silencing of anyone who is critical of the Egyptian authorities.\u201d\n\nNathan Brown, an Egypt scholar at George Washington University, said in an email that the issue might not be \u201ccriticism per se, but the threat to provide information that would be highly embarrassing to the military as an institution and to el-Sisi personally.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe is not merely being discredited; he is being muzzled and punished,\u201d Mr. Brown said of Mr. Geneina.\n\nDuring the election campaign, Mr. Sisi\u2019s supporters made a concerted effort to mobilize voters \u2014 using incentives like free groceries and small cash payments \u2014 widely taken as a sign of the president\u2019s desire for a strong mandate to usher in constitutional changes that could extend his term in office.\n\nThere has been little talk of such changes since then, but Egyptian officials have signaled they intend to continue with an uncompromising approach that brooks little dissent.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAbdel Moneim Aboul Fotouh, a moderate Islamist who ran in the 2012 presidential contest, continues to be detained, a sign of how little space exists for opposition voices.\n\nOn Monday, the Foreign Ministry denounced the decision by Unesco, the United Nations cultural organization, to award its annual press freedom prize to Mahmoud Abou Zeid, a photojournalist also known as Shawkan who has been detained without charge for four and a half years.\n\nA spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Ahmed Abu Zeid, accused Unesco of \u201cdisregard for the rule of law\u201d in bestowing the award on a prisoner. Human rights groups say the journalist is typical of thousands of Egyptians held for months, often years, without trial in brimming prisons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore recent investigations targeting journalists have further chilled free speech.\n\nLast week, the former editor in chief of Al Masry Al Youm, one of Egypt\u2019s most widely read newspapers, was released on bail. He is being investigated with eight journalists at the paper for a headline in their election coverage.\n\nThe case was instigated by Samir Sabry, a private lawyer who has brought numerous cases against Mr. Sisi\u2019s critics in the news media. Separately, the editor in chief of a website that translated a New York Times article on the election remains in custody.\n\nMr. Geneina, a former judge, headed Egypt\u2019s Central Auditing Organization until he was fired by Mr. Sisi in 2016 after he estimated that official graft had cost Egypt $76 billion over a three-year period.\n\nAfter signing up for Mr. Anan\u2019s short-lived election campaign in January, Mr. Geneina was badly beaten outside his home by men he described as government thugs. The police said the men had gotten into a fight with Mr. Geneina over a traffic accident.\n\nMr. Geneina\u2019s lawyers say they will appeal the five-year sentence. \u201cThis is what happens to all those who choose the path of justice and struggle,\u201d one said in a Facebook post.", "title": "Egyptian Military Court Sentences Sisi Critic to 5 Years in Prison", "authors": ["Declan Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "If it seems as though each time you log into Netflix there are a dozen new original series on offer, it might be because that\u2019s essentially what\u2019s happening. According to Variety, the company\u2019s chief financial officer, David Wells, announced in February that Netflix was aiming to host around 700 original shows worldwide by the end of 2018. In the United States, some of these are shows produced by Netflix, and some are foreign shows for which Netflix has purchased the rights. Either way, it\u2019s more television than any one person can consume.\n\nIn order to help you prioritize your queue, we\u2019ll periodically sift through the latest original programming on Netflix and let you know which shows we think are worth watching. This inaugural roundup features crime thrillers, teen comedies, food shows and one of the craziest documentary series in recent memory.\n\nLiv Lisa Fries in \u201cBabylon Berlin.\u201d Beta Film TV Show Babylon Berlin Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d has everything: Communists, fascists and flappers! Pornographers, cops and gangsters! Set during the Weimar Republic and created with the filmmaker Tom Tykwer (\u201cRun Lola Run\u201d), this hit German crime drama combines the decadence of \u201cCabaret\u201d with the grit of a contemporary police procedural. At the center of its sprawling story are Gereon Rath (Volker Bruch), a vice-squad detective scarred by his experiences in World War I, and Charlotte Ritter (Liv Lisa Fries), a typist and sometime prostitute who wants desperately to join the all-male police force. For those who hate reading subtitles, there is a dubbed version available on Netflix. But it\u2019s distractingly awkward, so consider giving the show a shot in its original language first.\n\nBhagwan Rajneesh in \u201cWild Wild Country.\u201d Netflix TV Show Wild Wild Country Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like In the early 1980s, followers of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh built a community for themselves on a 63,000-acre swathe of Oregon ranchland. Tensions quickly flared between the commune, called Rajneeshpuram, and its new neighbor, the tiny city of Antelope. From one angle, the conflict appeared to pit xenophobic yokels against a vulnerable religious minority; from another, it appeared that a sex cult was terrorizing a quiet community of working-class retirees. And that was before things in Rajneeshpuram got really weird. The documentary series \u201cWild Wild Country\u201d uses archival footage and startlingly frank interviews with the former leaders of the community and their adversaries in Antelope to raise big questions about spirituality, democracy and the ethics of self-defense.\n\n0\n\nCarey Mulligan and Nathaniel Martello-White in \u201cCollateral.\u201d Liam Daniel/Netflix TV Show Collateral Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like After appearing in one of last year\u2019s best Netflix original films, \u201cMudbound,\u201d Carey Mulligan returns to the streaming service with another stirring performance. \u201cCollateral\u201d casts her as Kip Glaspie, an ambitious detective inspector whose investigation into the murder of a pizza delivery man leads her to a far more complicated mystery. With lots of incisive commentary on immigration in post-Brexit Britain and a top-notch supporting cast that includes Jeany Spark, John Simm, Billie Piper and Nicola Walker, this mini-series isn\u2019t just for thriller addicts. Bonus: You can \u2014 and will probably want to \u2014 watch the entire four-episode season in an afternoon.\n\nA scene from \u201cUgly Delicious.\u201d Netflix TV Show Ugly Delicious Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like If you\u2019re a fan of Anthony Bourdain\u2019s globe-trotting food-adventure shows, add this series to your queue. With episodes organized around dishes rather than destinations, \u201cUgly Delicious\u201d sends David Chang, the chef and Momofuku restaurateur, to culinary capitals from Los Angeles to Copenhagen to Tokyo in order for him to sample the best incarnations of everyday meals like pizza and barbecue. Accompanying Chang is a boisterous, rotating cast of pals including Jimmy Kimmel and the \u201cWalking Dead\u201d actor Steven Yeun. In the sweetest episode, \u201cHomecooking,\u201d the host and his longtime collaborator, the food writer Peter Meehan, join Chang\u2019s mother in her kitchen to prepare a Korean-American Thanksgiving feast.\n\nNicole Byer and Jacques Torres in \u201cNailed It!\u201d Netflix TV Show Nailed It! Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Television can never get enough baking competitions, most of which follow the same basic recipe: Talented pastry chefs + high-concept creations + expert judges = sculptural desserts that are a feast for the eyes. \u201cNailed It!\u201d swaps out the professional contestants in favor of hapless novices who try their damnedest to replicate elaborate wedding cakes and other decorative sweets. The result is Food Network meets Cake Wrecks, with a lot of heart. As host, the comedian Nicole Byer strikes the perfect balance between encouragement and ridicule, and the competitors\u2019 self-aware humor ensures that the show never feels as if it\u2019s taking cheap shots.\n\n[Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.]\n\nRegina King in \u201cSeven Seconds.\u201d JoJo Whilden/Netflix TV Show Seven Seconds Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like In this crime drama from Veena Sud, the creator of \u201cThe Killing,\u201d a black teenager is struck by a car while riding his bike and is left for dead. But \u201cSeven Seconds\u201d isn\u2019t a whodunit. We know from the beginning that the hit-and-run collision is an accident, that a white police officer named Peter Jablonski (Beau Knapp) is the culprit and that his colleagues help him cover it up. The question is: Will the burned-out prosecutor assigned to the case (Clare-Hope Ashitey) and her detective partner (Michael Mosley) figure out what happened? And if they do, will a jury punish four cops for what they did to a black teen? \u201cAmerican Crime\u201d fans, take note: That show\u2019s standout actress, Regina King, gives a similarly moving performance in this series as the victim\u2019s mother.\n\nA scene from \u201cThe End of the ____ing World.\u201d Netflix TV Show The End of the ____ing World Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like British TV may be best known for Monty Python and costume dramas, but it is also home to some of the most daring teen programming in the English-speaking world. (See: \u201cSkins,\u201d \u201cMy Mad Fat Diary,\u201d \u201cMisfits.\u201d) \u201cThe End of the ____ing World,\u201d which comes to Netflix by way of Britain\u2019s Channel 4, is an exceptionally dark, suspenseful comedy about two disturbed teens who run away together. But one of these road-trippers, James (Alex Lawther), is only feigning interest in his companion, Alyssa (Jessica Barden). What he really wants is to kick off his psycho-killer career by murdering her \u2014 or so he thinks.\n\nElijah Stevenson and Sydney Sweeney in \u201cEverything Sucks!\u201d Scott Patrick Green/Netflix TV Show Everything Sucks! Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like For a lighter teen comedy, try this charming show about outcasts living in the aptly named town of Boring, Ore., in the mid-1990s. Our heroes are the nerdy A.V. clique and their slightly older, slightly cooler peers in the drama club \u2014 two warring factions that unite to make an absolutely ridiculous movie. Odd-couple romances, betrayals, family conflicts, journeys of self-discovery and montages set to period-appropriate songs ensue, so it\u2019s no wonder that \u201cEverything Sucks!\u201d has earned comparisons to \u201cFreaks and Geeks.\u201d While it doesn\u2019t quite live up to that hype, the show is funny, sweet and sure to hit all the right nostalgia buttons for viewers in their 30s.\n\n0\n\nRead more: The 100 Best Movies on Netflix\n\n10 Great Movies Under 90 Minutes Long on Netflix", "title": "Eight Recent Netflix Original Series That Are Worth Your Time", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTORONTO \u2014 Women accounted for eight of the 10 people killed when a van plowed through pedestrians along Toronto\u2019s main street this week, officials said on Friday, a toll that included two young university students and a 94-year-old woman who had stopped to feed the birds.\n\nThe police would not say whether they believed that Alek Minassian, the man identified as the van\u2019s driver, had singled out women in Monday\u2019s deadly rampage. But Bryan Bott, a Toronto homicide inspector, said investigators were examining a Facebook message hostile to women they said Mr. Minassian had posted minutes before the attack, along with testimony from 170 witnesses and evidence gathered from the suspect\u2019s home.\n\nIn the Facebook post, Mr. Minassian had praised \u201cincels,\u201d or involuntary celibates, a term used in a Reddit group where men vented frustrations that tipped into misogyny. Mr. Minassian\u2019s Facebook account has been suspended, but the company confirmed in an email the authenticity of the posting.\n\nInspector Bott reiterated that the police did not believe that the crime constituted terrorism, nor did they think more than one person was involved.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Minassian, 25, was taken into custody by a Toronto traffic officer who has been lauded for his composure while the suspect pointed an object at him and yelled that he had a gun. He has been charged with 10 counts of first-degree murder and 13 counts of attempted murder for other people injured in the rampage. The police said they intended to lodge additional charges of attempted murder against Mr. Minassian based on interviews they have conducted.", "title": "Eight of 10 Victims in Toronto Van Rampage Were Women", "authors": ["Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "El Salvador\u2019s draconian abortion law \u2014 the procedure is banned there under all circumstances \u2014 has led to horrific outcomes. Children as young as 9 have had to bear their rapists\u2019 children. Women who\u2019ve experienced obstetric complications have been imprisoned under suspicion that they sought abortions. And other women have died of conditions that doctors were hesitant to treat because doing so could endanger their pregnancies.\n\nNow the country\u2019s lawmakers have the chance to do right by at least some Salvadoran women and girls by softening that law \u2014 though they must act quickly to have a good chance of success.\n\nEl Salvador\u2019s Legislative Assembly is considering two amendments to its penal code relating to the abortion ban, neither of which is by any means comprehensive. The one that\u2019s much more likely to pass \u2014 it was proposed by a right-wing lawmaker and has bipartisan support \u2014 would make abortion legal only in cases when the life of the pregnant woman is in danger and when a minor becomes pregnant by rape or incest.\n\nBut even that modest change would save Salvadoran lives by allowing medical professionals to provide women and girls with the health care they need. Doctors in El Salvador have become vocal supporters of reforming the existing law, as it leaves them unable to treat high-risk pregnancies without running the risk of a criminal abortion charge, punishable by up to eight years in prison.", "title": "Opinion | El Salvador\u2019s Chance to Save Women\u2019s Lives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "A memory play, \u201cThe Waverly Gallery\u201d revolves around Gladys, a leftist activist struggling with Alzheimer\u2019s disease in her old age. Though she fights to remain independent, her decline affects her family, particularly her grandson. The play was nominated for a Pulitzer Prize in 2000.\n\nMr. Lonergan\u2019s first Broadway production, \u201cThis Is Our Youth,\u201d opened in 2014, almost eight years after his first full-length play premiered. \u201cLobby Hero\u201d followed this year, opening in March.\n\n\u201cThe Waverly Gallery\u201d premiered in 1999 at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts and was first produced in New York Off Broadway at the Promenade Theater in 2000.\n\nMr. Cera will have appeared in all three of Mr. Lonergan\u2019s Broadway plays; he starred in \u201cThis Is Our Youth\u201d alongside Kieran Culkin and Tavi Gevinson.\n\nMr. Lonergan is also a screenwriter and film director. His credits include \u201cMargaret\u201d (2011) and \u201cManchester by the Sea\u201d (2016), both of which he wrote and directed. In 2017 he won the Oscar for best original screenplay for \u201cManchester by the Sea.\u201d", "title": "Elaine May Returning to Broadway in Kenneth Lonergan Play", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Eleanor Joan Geise and Benjamin David Wasserman were married April 21 at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Rabbi Annie Bornstein officiated.\n\nThe couple met in 2011 at the University of Pennsylvania, from which they graduated magna cum laude. They also received law degrees from Duke, he cum laude and she magna cum laude.\n\nThe bride, 28, is a law clerk for Judge Robin L. Rosenberg of the Southern District of Florida. She also received a master\u2019s degree in adolescent special education from Hunter College.\n\nShe is the daughter of Elizabeth R. Geise and John V. Geise of Kensington, Md. Her mother is a partner in the Washington office of Schiff Hardin, a Chicago law firm. Her father retired as the chief of the professional misconduct review unit at the office of the deputy attorney general in Washington.\n\nThe groom, 27, is a law clerk for Judge Donald M. Middlebrooks, also of the Southern District of Florida. He is a son of Amy F. Wasserman of Manhasset, N.Y., and Jacob B. Wasserman of Queens, N.Y. His mother is a special-education teacher at Lakeville Elementary School in Great Neck, N.Y. Lyft sued him for breaching a confidentiality agreement and fiduciary duty. The litigation was eventually settled.\n\nOf his time at Uber, which has since been exposed as having had a growth-at-all-costs environment, Mr. VanderZanden said: \u201cI learned some good things, and I learned some bad things.\u201d\n\nHe left Uber in 2016 and moved to Southern California. Last year, he founded Bird to bring electric scooters, already popular in cities across China, to America. To date, Bird has raised $115 million from investors, including Craft Ventures and Index Ventures. Mr. VanderZanden now has a team of more than 100 people.\n\nHe likes wordplay. The scooters are called Birds. He calls a group of people riding on the scooters a flock. The areas where scooters are supposed to be generally kept are called nests. His mom\u2019s name is Robin.\n\n\u201cWe might have taken the birds too far,\u201d Mr. VanderZanden said.\n\nBird initially rolled out its scooter-rental service in Santa Monica and now operates in seven cities. The company will not disclose how many scooters are in operation but said it has sent out 22,500 helmets to riders, as part of a compliance effort for cities that require riders to use helmets. That includes Casey Mittelstadt, the eighth pick in the 2017 draft, who signed with the Buffalo Sabres last week after finishing his freshman season at Minnesota.\n\nAfter losing to Ohio State in the Midwest Regional final on March 25, Denver lost its entire top line when Henrik Borgstrom, Dylan Gambrell and Troy Terry signed pro contracts. Terry, who like Greenway was on the United States team at the Olympics in February, played for the Anaheim Ducks on March 27 in Vancouver.\n\nDenver Coach Jim Montgomery, who played parts of six seasons in the N.H.L., called their signings \u201ca foregone conclusion.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe have an open dialogue with our players, so we knew all were going to sign after this season,\u201d he said.\n\nNorth Dakota Coach Brad Berry has seen 10 players leave early in the past three seasons, more than any other program.\n\nLast year the sophomore forward Brock Boeser, Vancouver\u2019s first-round draft pick in 2015, played for the Canucks in Minnesota two days after the Fighting Hawks were eliminated in double overtime by Boston University in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament. This year Boeser was the leading rookie goal scorer with 29 goals until a back injury ended his season on March 5.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s college hockey now,\u201d Berry said. \u201cYou try to get high-end players and develop them.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first college player to join the N.H.L. this year was Harvard\u2019s Ryan Donato, who, entering Tuesday, already had four goals in eight games for the first-place Boston Bruins. He said Greenway had the opportunity to sign with the Wild after last season.\n\nTypically, he said, he advises the player to think about his best interests before signing. \u201c\u2018What do you want? Are you ready to start your pro career? Are you ready for a year in the A.H.L.?\u2019\u201d Quinn said. \u201cThey think one thing happens, and then the other thing happens.\u201d\n\nBerry, a former N.H.L. defenseman, said players need a self-awareness of when the time is right to move on. \u201cThe bar is usually two years\u201d in college, he said. \u201cBut players have different time lines.\u201d\n\nHe noted that forward Drake Caggiula, now in his second year with Edmonton, did not blossom as a player until his senior year, in 2015-16, when he led North Dakota to the national title and was named most outstanding player of the N.C.A.A. tournament.\n\n\u201cHe needed all four years to get to where he wanted to go,\u201d Berry said.\n\nCraig Button, a former general manager of the Calgary Flames and currently TSN\u2019s director of scouting, said college players were more advanced in their games and better prepared for pro hockey than ever before.\n\nStill, he cautioned: \u201cIf you\u2019re not ready, the league will chew you up and spit you out like you were nothing, no matter where you were drafted. The N.H.L. is all about being ready. I believe players need more time, not less, in college.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMadigan, the Northeastern coach, said going from the structure of a college environment to the N.H.L. can be daunting.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s almost like being a pro golfer,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019re on your own.\u201d\n\nBefore leaving for Vancouver, Gaudette, the top scorer in college hockey this season, wore his Northeastern gear for one last session on Matthews Arena ice, firing pucks into the net. He arrived in Vancouver with a Northeastern equipment bag.\n\n\u201cIt still feels like it hasn\u2019t set in yet,\u201d he said to Canucks TV as he was being driven from the airport. \u201cI\u2019m not sure it will until I step on the ice for the first time. It\u2019s just crazy how quick it all happened.\u201d", "title": "Eliminated from the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Then Off to the N.H.L.", "authors": ["Gary Santaniello"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI knew from the very first poem that she started at the top; she just had it,\u201d Mr. Black told American Cowboy magazine. \u201cIt\u2019s like you\u2019re having a parade, and everyone is driving a Honda, and she comes in a Cadillac, sitting on the top.\u201d\n\nA somewhat esoteric genre today, cowboy poetry originated in the cattle drive era following the Civil War, as cow punchers strained to keep themselves entertained during the long and often tedious journeys north from Texas. Typically narrative-based and following traditional ballad rhyme schemes, the genre mostly retreated from popular view until the founding of the National Cowboy Poetry Gathering in Elko, Nev., in 1985.\n\nThough cowboy poetry remains an outsider art, the national gathering helped launch several poets into a larger orbit, among them Mr. Black and Waddie Mitchell, both of whom performed multiple times on \u201cThe Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.\u201d\n\nElizabeth Ebert Reads \u201cAn Ordinary Morning\u201d Audio\n\nAfter her first performance at the Elko gathering, in 1991, Ms. Ebert attracted an almost immediate following with her authentic portrayals not only of the cowboy but also of what she called \u201cthe cowman\u2019s wife.\u201d Her woman\u2019s perspective helped open a male-dominated genre to female voices.\n\nIn one poem, titled \u201cCowboy Courtin\u2019 Time,\u201d she described a ranch romance, in which the woman invariably ends up between the cowboy and his dog.\n\nThe cowboy\u2019ll put his arm around\n\nAnd hug you \u2019til you hurt\n\nAnd then he starts to pawin\u2019\n\n(The dog, that is) your shirt.\n\nThey\u2019ve got you snuggled there between\n\nJust a pawn within their game.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t matter where you turn\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018Cause they kiss about the same.\n\nLong years have passed since courtin\u2019 time\n\nChanged me from Miss to Mrs.\n\nAnd I\u2019ll admit, I\u2019ve grown to like\n\nThose cowboy-cowdog kisses.\n\nMs. Ebert later performed at gatherings all over the country, rising to the status of what her friend and fellow poet Yvonne Hollenbeck called \u201cthe Grand Dame of Cowboy Poetry,\u201d a title quickly ratified by their peers.\n\n\u201cElizabeth walks up to the podium, and every time you think, \u2018What\u2019s this old gray-haired lady doing here?\u2019 \u201d Ms. Hollenbeck told American Cowboy. \u201cAnd then she starts in her little high voice, and she just kills her audience.\u201d\n\nBesides \u201cPrairie Wife,\u201d Ms. Ebert wrote another full-length book of poetry, \u201cCrazy Quilt,\u201d a chapbook of Christmas poems and a spoken-word album titled \u201cLive From Thunder Hawk.\u201d\n\nIn perhaps her most popular poem, titled \u201cHe Talked About Montana,\u201d she eulogized one of her husband\u2019s hired hands.\n\nAnd he\u2019d talk about Montana.\n\nAnd you\u2019d get a glimmer then,\n\nOf the cowboy that he used to be,\n\nAnd the man he might have been\n\nBefore the war and wife and whiskey\n\nHad bent him out of shape.\n\nNow the war and wife were history\n\nAnd the whiskey was escape.\n\nElizabeth Ebert Reads \u201cHe Talked About Montana\u201d Audio\n\nAmong her awards, Ms. Ebert was the inaugural recipient in 2012 of The Badger: Excellence in Cowboy Poetry Award, presented by the Heritage of the American West Performance Series. In 2005, Mike Rounds, then governor of South Dakota, proclaimed Feb. 24 of that year \u201cElizabeth Ebert Day.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s doubtful that Ms. Ebert \u2014 who insisted that \u201cif it isn\u2019t meter and rhyme, it\u2019s prose\u201d \u2014 would have found similar success within the wider world of contemporary literature, which often considers the genre a folk art at best, if not mere doggerel. She didn\u2019t seem to mind.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like their poetry, either,\u201d Ms. Ebert said, \u201cso it\u2019s fair enough.\u201d\n\nElizabeth Summers was born on Feb. 24, 1925, outside tiny Thunder Hawk, S.D., just south of the North Dakota border, one of four children. She spent her early years watching Dust Bowl storms scour the prairie.\n\nWhen she was 4, Elizabeth\u2019s impoverished family, chasing work, spent one summer in a three-sided tent attached to their car. Though her parents, John and Alma, worked odd jobs over the years, they were primarily small farmers, raising wheat and cattle.\n\nMs. Ebert attended Thunder Hawk High School, receiving her diploma as the valedictorian of a class of four. At 16, she enrolled at the Black Hills Secretarial School in Rapid City, S.D. She worked briefly as a bookkeeper for a bank in Lemmon, about 10 miles west of Thunder Hawk, before following a friend to Washington, where she spent a summer waiting tables.\n\nMiserable in the city, she returned to South Dakota. At 18, yearning to be a novelist, she moved to Minneapolis and spent a year at the University of Minnesota studying journalism and English and imagining a writer\u2019s life, like that of Dorothy Parker.\n\n\u201cAt the time, I admired Parker\u2019s long cigarette holder and wished to go to New York and hobnob with the literati,\u201d she said. \u201cOne summer in secretary school, one year at the University of Minnesota, and a summer in Washington, D.C., cured me of that notion, and all I wanted was a piece of prairie that I could call my own and lot fewer people around.\u201d\n\nShe met S.J. \u2014 a \u201ccute\u201d and \u201ccapable\u201d World War II veteran, in her words \u2014 at a dance hall in Morristown, S.D., in November 1945. They married four months later, put money down on some farmland and spent their first 15 years together in a fixed-up homestead shack, upgrading to a newer farmhouse up the road in 1962. They raised three children on the farm.\n\nMs. Ebert said the best years of her life were spent with S.J. after their retirement, when they took the scenic routes to her poetry gatherings around the country. It was a time, she said, \u201cwhen we got to do what we wanted to do and didn\u2019t have to worry about things.\u201d Mr. Ebert died at 94 in 2008.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSaddled with a small oxygen tank during her last years, Ms. Ebert often cursed her immobility and the burden her frailties had placed on others.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t worry about dying \u2014 that\u2019s the least of my problems,\u201d she told American Cowboy. \u201cSome days I wish I would, \u2019cause I\u2019m tired of dragging this damn thing around.\u201d\n\nThough physically spent, her daughter Jayne says, \u201cshe was Mother, bright and sharp, to the end.\u201d\n\nAnd though she was surprised by the attention she received, she appreciated it. \u201cIt\u2019s nice that somebody recognizes you. It really is,\u201d she said in October 2016. \u201cThey even know me in Lemmon now sometimes.\u201d", "title": "Elizabeth Ebert, \u2018Grand Dame of Cowboy Poetry,\u2019 Dies at 93", "authors": ["Carson Vaughan"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Representative Elizabeth Esty, a Connecticut Democrat, said on Monday that she would not seek re-election this year after days of controversy over what she called her failure to protect women on her staff from sexual harassment and threats of violence from her former chief of staff.\n\nRepresentative Esty, a vocal supporter of the #MeToo movement, has faced a storm of criticism since it was reported last week that she waited three months to fire her former chief of staff, Tony Baker, after Anna Kain, another former staff member who once dated him, said he had sexually harassed and threatened to kill her.\n\n\u201cI have determined that it is in the best interest of my constituents and my family to end my time in Congress at the end of this year and not seek re-election,\u201d Representative Esty said in a statement on Monday afternoon.\n\n\u201cToo many women have been harmed by harassment in the workplace,\u201d she said. \u201cIn the terrible situation in my office, I could have and should have done better.
