He graduated from the University of North Carolina and received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago.", "title": "Elizabeth MacLean, Nicholas Anderson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "And soon you\u2019re making your directorial debut. Why now?\n\nWell, it certainly can\u2019t be much later. [Laughs] I was thinking a few years ago, I never directed a movie and I always meant to. What a dope I am! How did I let that get away from me? And then this script arrived, \u201cBathing Flo,\u201d for me to act in, and they said, \u201cWho would you like to direct it?\u201d And I went, \u201cMe.\u201d And they said, \u201cO.K.\u201d\n\nYou were on \u201cLouie\u201d with Louis C.K. and \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d with Kevin Spacey. Did it shock you to learn of the sexual misconduct allegations against these men?\n\nKevin Spacey didn\u2019t shock me because I have heard rumors of that. Louis just broke my heart because I love him. When I worked with him, I had such admiration for his talent and his person, his being. I know he\u2019s a good person, but even good people have sexual hang-ups that hurt other people. I just wish he had gone to therapy or whatever so it didn\u2019t have to ruin his life.\n\nDo you have a #MeToo story of your own?\n\nI had forgotten about this; I just remembered it the other day. First I was a model in New York, and at the point when I was transitioning from model to actress I was taken home from a gathering by a man who was second in command at one of the biggest agencies. And when we got to my home, he tried to make a move on me, and I said no and he persisted. And I kept saying no, and finally he said, \u201cO.K., it comes down to this: If you want to be an actress, you\u2019ll have to be represented by my agency because we control the talent in this business, and the only way that can happen is if you go to bed with me.\u201d I looked at him and kind of shrugged my shoulders and said, \u201cWell, there goes my career.\u201d\n\nAnd did it?\n\nNot at all. That\u2019s the thing. We don\u2019t have to fall for these stories. Now, Harvey Weinstein really did stop actresses from being hired, so I\u2019m not saying that doesn\u2019t happen because he obviously was doing some heavy revenge. But for the most part, those stories are rather pitiful. If a guy has to pull a line like that to get sex, he\u2019s pretty pathetic. But the culture tolerated it. We\u2019ve been living under a patriarchy since the fall of Crete, and that culture is coming to an end. And that\u2019s very good news.", "title": "Ellen Burstyn Honors a Friendship With a Futurist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDr. Ellen Stofan, the former chief scientist at NASA, will become the first woman to lead the National Air and Space Museum, the Smithsonian Institution announced on Thursday.\n\nAt NASA, Dr. Stofan, who has a background in geology, was a top adviser to Charles F. Bolden Jr., then the administrator for the department, where she helped lead in the development of a long-term plan to get humans to Mars.\n\n\u201cEllen\u2019s scientific background, leadership skills, communication acumen and strategic thinking have positioned her superbly to lead the National Air and Space Museum,\u201d David Skorton, the director of the Smithsonian Institution, said in a statement. \u201cHer passion for science coupled with her love of education will ensure that the museum will continue to be a global treasure and world leader through its extensive programming, exhibitions and scholarship.\u201d\n\nSpace has been a part of Dr. Stofan\u2019s life for almost its entirety. Her father was a NASA rocket scientist and at the age of 4 she attended her first rocket launch at Cape Canaveral, an event that spurred her own career.\n\n\u201cIt is an incredible honor to join the National Air and Space Museum family at this important point in the museum\u2019s history,\u201d Dr. Stofan said. \u201cSpace and aviation inspire our next generation of explorers, and there is no better place to experience this than at our museums on the Mall and at the Udvar-Hazy Center.\u201d\n\nDr. Stofan joins the museum at a time when interest in space interest might be climbing. In the new budget recently passed by Congress and signed by President Donald J. Trump, NASA was a big winner, to the tune of a $1 billion increase. She will be overseeing an institution with more than 300 full time employees and a budget of $48 million, 70 percent of which comes from federal appropriations.", "title": "Ellen Stofan, Former NASA Chief Scientist, to Head National Air and Space Museum", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s Pittsburgh, shifting from a dying steel town to a \u201ccity of renewal.\u201d It\u2019s Chattanooga, the old Tennessee railroad town, becoming \u201cone of America\u2019s most start-up-friendly cities.\u201d It\u2019s even Dresden, the German city flattened during World War II that\u2019s now the heart of \u201cSilicon Saxony.\u201d\n\nIn Adelaide\u2019s case, Elon Musk has already helped: He introduced a new rocket at a space conference here last September, following up in November by building the world\u2019s biggest battery, which has already driven down local electricity prices.\n\nBut this city of 1.3 million \u2014 with its aging population and unemployment rates that are often among the highest in the country \u2014 needs an even bigger jolt. Frustrations have been building for years as Adelaide\u2019s factories shuttered, with Holden closing its plant last year, bringing an end to Australia\u2019s auto industry.\n\nThe response is what\u2019s interesting: Quiet Adelaide, a former industrial center now seen as a laid-back community of churches and retirees, is banging the table for change.", "title": "Elon Musk Likes It Here. Will Other Tech Innovators Follow?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "For the past week, as the electric-car maker Tesla has been buffeted by a barrage of negative news, Elon Musk, its chief executive, has offered no public comments on the company\u2019s shaky finances, its slumping stock price or the increasing questions about the safety of its self-driving technology.\n\nHe finally responded on Sunday \u2014 with an April Fool\u2019s joke that the company was going bankrupt.\n\n\u201cDespite intense efforts to raise money, including a last-ditch mass sale of Easter Eggs, we are sad to report that Tesla has gone completely and totally bankrupt,\u201d Mr. Musk wrote on Twitter. \u201cSo bankrupt, you can\u2019t believe it.\u201d", "title": "Elon Musk Makes Light of Tesla\u2019s Troubles in April Fool\u2019s Tweets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think the resignation of Shola was an inevitability rather than a choice,\u201d said Councilman Ritchie Torres, who held a contentious oversight hearing with Ms. Olatoye earlier this year. \u201cI think that we\u2019re entering a period of uncertainty.\u201d\n\nSince the council hearing, Ms. Olatoye has been largely kept out of the public eye. She did not appear at a public housing announcement last week at which Mr. de Blasio promoted the city\u2019s investment in repairing public housing roofs.\n\nThe mayor used the occasion to push back on criticism of conditions in public housing by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who has in recent weeks made a series of appearances with tenants, touring apartments and underscoring the need for changes at the agency. The authority manages more than 175,000 apartments in over 2,400 buildings across the five boroughs.\n\nMr. Cuomo recently signed an emergency order requiring city officials to name an independent monitor to oversee a new infusion of state money in the city agency to make repairs.\n\nBut pressure had been mounting on Ms. Olatoye, whom many considered to be a capable leader of the underfunded city authority, since it emerged last year that she had signed off on federal paperwork indicating that mandated lead paint inspections had been done when they had not. The agency receives the bulk of its funding from the federal government and has a backlog of needed repairs that could cost more than $20 billion to address.\n\nThe agency learned of the failure to conduct inspections, lapses that began during the Bloomberg administration, but Ms. Olatoye and top officials did not alert the public \u2014 or tenants \u2014 until much later, after they had done remediation in apartments. The false filings became public in a report from the city\u2019s Investigation Department \u2014 long after Ms. Olatoye first knew of the problem.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLast month, the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development told the agency that it would no longer be able to draw federal funds without approval, a move that stemmed from the issue over the filings.\n\n\u201cWhile her intentions were never in question, we are long overdue for a fresh start at Nycha,\u201d said the city\u2019s public advocate, Letitia James, who had called for Ms. Olatoye\u2019s resignation after revelations of false filings over lead paint inspections.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer departure recalled other instances in which Mr. de Blasio had defended an embattled senior official before ultimately pushing the person out or seeing them abruptly leave his administration. His jails commissioner quit last year after it was revealed he had misused his city car for trips to his home in Maine. His commissioner for homeless services, Gilbert Taylor, left in 2015 as the city scrambled to cope with rising numbers of homeless people flooding into shelters.\n\nAnd now Ms. Olatoye.\n\nIn his statement, the mayor said that Stanley Brezenoff would act as an interim chairman of the housing authority during the search for a permanent leader. Mr. Brezenoff recently served a similar interim role at NYC Health & Hospitals, the city\u2019s financially ailing public hospital system.\n\nMs. Olatoye\u2019s last day is April 30.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m incredibly proud of the leadership team we\u2019ve assembled and the strides we\u2019ve made over the last 4 years to speed up repair times, reduce crime, launch a major development program and bring Nycha into the 21st century,\u201d Ms. Olatoye said in a statement.\n\nCity Hall officials would not say when she informed the mayor of her intention to resign. She is expected to appear with Mr. de Blasio at a news conference in Queens on Tuesday.\n\nDanny Barber, the president of the Citywide Council of Presidents, a group of tenant leaders chosen by Nycha residents, said Ms. Olatoye\u2019s resignation was a step in the right direction.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been fighting for a long time,\u201d said Mr. Barber, whose group sued the agency in February. \u201cThis is a testament to what the tenants can pull together by taking things into their own hands.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere could have been a lot more done, a lot more transparency and accountability,\u201d Mr. Barber said of Ms. Olatoye\u2019s tenure.\n\nMr. Barber said Nycha residents should have a say in the process to replace Ms. Olatoye.", "title": "Embattled Housing Authority Chief in New York City Is Resigning", "authors": ["J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEmily Louise Cashman and Harrell Raso Kirstein were married March 29 at the Manchester City Hall in Manchester N.H. Joanne Doukeris, a member of the city clerk\u2019s office, officiated. On March 31, Senator Jeanne Shaheen, Democrat of New Hampshire and a friend of the couple, led an exchange of vows at the Bedford Village Inn, a hotel in Bedford, N.H.\n\nThe bride, 32, works in Washington as the senior manager of government affairs at Thorn, a nonprofit organization based in San Francisco that builds technology to defend children from sexual abuse. From 2010 to 2016, the bride worked in various positions for Senator Shaheen. She also worked as the trip director for Hillary Clinton\u2019s general election campaign in New Hampshire in 2016. She graduated from the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass., and received a master\u2019s degree in international relations from the Universidad Aut\u00f3noma de Madrid in Spain.\n\nShe is the daughter of Madeline Q. Cashman and Brian A. Cashman of Litchfield, N.H. The bride\u2019s father retired as a special agent in the Andover, Mass., field office of the Defense Security Service, a federal security agency of the Defense Department based in Quantico, Va. Her mother is a teacher at the Matthew Thornton Elementary School in Londonderry, N.H.\n\nThe groom, 31, is the communications director for the Trump War Room for American Bridge 21st Century, a democratic opposition research group in Washington. He served as the communications director for Ms. Shaheen\u2019s re-election campaign in 2014 as well as in communication positions in Mrs. Clinton\u2019s 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nHe is a son of Melinda R. Kirstein and Philip L. Kirstein of Princeton, N.J. The groom\u2019s mother retired as a fixed-income portfolio manager in the Plainsboro, N.J., office of Merrill Lynch. She currently works as an independent trustee of the WisdomTree Trust board in New York. His father retired as the senior officer and independent compliance officer of the AllianceBernstein mutual funds in New York.\n\nThe couple met in 2010 while both were working for the New Hampshire Democratic Party.", "title": "Emily Cashman, Harrell Kirstein", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. View more of his work, visit his website or follow him on Twitter.\n\nFollow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | Emmanuel Macron Goes to Washington", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI suspect that this will be a very difficult conversation,\u201d said Wendy R. Sherman, the former top State Department official who negotiated the Iran deal for Mr. Obama. \u201cI\u2019m sure that Macron will say how important staying in the deal is to a strong trans-Atlantic relationship in all things, particularly security. I think Merkel will deliver the same message on Friday.\u201d\n\nEven so, the White House signaled Monday that Mr. Trump enters the talks with one set impression. \u201cHe thinks it\u2019s a bad deal \u2014 that certainly has not changed,\u201d said Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary.\n\nThe fate of the Iran agreement could influence the president\u2019s forthcoming meeting with Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader who already has a small nuclear arsenal. Whatever its flaws, American officials understand that canceling the Iran deal days or weeks before that meeting might complicate Mr. Trump\u2019s chances of making an agreement with Mr. Kim.\n\nMohammad Javad Zarif, Iran\u2019s foreign minister, implicitly made that point Monday by noting that the negotiations that led to the nuclear agreement between his country and six world powers involved give and take by all sides.\n\n\u201cAnd now the United States is saying, \u2018What\u2019s mine is mine and what\u2019s yours is negotiable. But whatever I gave you, now I want it back,\u2019\u201d Mr. Zarif said in an interview with The National Interest, a Washington policy magazine. \u201cWho would, in their right mind, deal with the U.S. anymore?\u201d\n\nMr. Trump faces conflicting positions among his own advisers as he reconstitutes his national security team. John R. Bolton, his new national security adviser, has long advocated simply ending the Iran deal, while Mike Pompeo, set to become secretary of state, is open to keeping it if strong new provisions can be negotiated.\n\nMr. Macron arrived in Washington to a festive welcome. American and French flags flew on Pennsylvania Avenue as he and his wife, Brigitte Macron, were greeted at the White House by Mr. Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Macron reached in for a hug and kissed Mr. Trump on both cheeks, French-style, a sign of their warm ties. The two couples headed inside for a few minutes and then out to the South Lawn, smiling and chatting casually as cameras recorded the moment.\n\nPhoto\n\nWielding shovels, the two presidents moved some dirt around where a tree was to be planted, a gift from the Macrons. The tree, a European sessile oak, came from Belleau Wood, where, during World War I, nearly 10,000 American Marines were killed or injured in battle in June 1918. From there, the two couples flew by helicopter to George Washington\u2019s Mount Vernon estate for dinner.\n\nThe Macrons will return to the White House on Tuesday morning for a pomp-filled arrival ceremony on the South Lawn, complete with members of all five branches of the military in formal uniforms. The two presidents will hold meetings and conduct a joint news conference. In the evening, the Trumps will host their first state dinner, featuring rack of spring lamb and Carolina gold rice jambalaya cooked New Orleans style.\n\nMr. Trump, 71, and Mr. Macron, 40, have forged an unlikely friendship, despite their political differences over the Iran deal, international trade, climate change and other issues. But while Europeans consider Mr. Macron their envoy to Mr. Trump, he has had mixed success influencing the president. The two leaders teamed up to launch airstrikes against Syria this month in retaliation for a suspected chemical attack, but when Mr. Macron publicly said he had persuaded Mr. Trump to keep American troops in the country \u201cfor the long term,\u201d the White House quickly disputed him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Macron telegraphed his message on Iran by appearing on the president\u2019s favorite network, Fox News, over the weekend.\n\nIs the pact \u201ca perfect thing for our relationship with Iran? No,\u201d he said on \u201cFox News Sunday.\u201d \u201cBut for nuclear, what do you have as a better option? I don\u2019t see it. What is the what-if scenario or your Plan B? I don\u2019t have any Plan B for nuclear against Iran.\u201d\n\nMr. Macron added that he supported modifications to the deal, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, or J.C.P.O.A. \u201cMy point is to say, don\u2019t leave now to J.C.P.O.A. as long as you don\u2019t have a better option for nuclear, and let\u2019s complete it with ballistic missile and a regional containment,\u201d Mr. Macron said.\n\nMr. Zarif picked up on that on Monday. \u201cPresident Macron is correct in saying there\u2019s no \u2018Plan B\u2019 on JCPOA,\u201d Mr. Zarif wrote on Twitter. \u201cIt\u2019s either all or nothing. European leaders should encourage President Trump not just to stay in the nuclear deal, but more importantly to begin implementing his part of the bargain in good faith.\u201d\n\nThe negotiations with European officials, led by Brian Hook, the State Department\u2019s director of policy planning, have found some common ground, according to people briefed on the talks. Negotiators are developing two annexes, or side agreements, to the original deal, one intended to constrain Iran\u2019s missile program and the other to confront its aggressions in the Middle East.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNegotiators have agreed on strong measures to impose sanctions on Iran if it tests long-range missiles and are debating a framework document to respond to testing of short- and medium-range missiles. They have agreed that Iran would be sanctioned if it blocks international nuclear inspectors from any site, including military sites. And they have made progress in defining a trigger for reimposing sanctions lifted as part of the 2015 deal \u2014 if Iran were found to have expanded its nuclear program enough to allow it to develop a weapon in less than a year.\n\nBut negotiators are divided over what would happen then. The Trump administration insists that sanctions be reimposed automatically if Iran trips that one-year wire, while the Europeans want the trigger to be a determination that Iran\u2019s expansion is inconsistent with its civilian nuclear program. If the Americans and Europeans ultimately agree, that would effectively end the expiration provisions known as \u201csunsets\u201d by making the one-year limit permanent.\n\n\u201cThe Europeans have moved very far in a few months, and I think this should be bridgeable, but of course it really depends on Macron and Trump,\u201d said Mark Dubowitz, chief executive of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies. \u201cIt sounds narrow, but it\u2019s actually pretty fundamental. It\u2019s entirely possible that the thing breaks down on that basis.\u201d\n\nThe Germans are the most resistant among the Europeans, arguing that renegotiating without Iran or the other parties to the deal, Russia and China, amounts to bad faith and ultimately will cause the original agreement to collapse. If no side agreements are reached, the Trump administration is also preparing contingency plans for Mr. Trump to withdraw from the Iran deal altogether and what the United States would then do to counter Iran.\n\nRussia and China have resisted any changes. \u201cWe will obstruct attempts to sabotage these agreements, which were enshrined in a U.N. Security Council resolution,\u201d Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, said Monday after meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, in Beijing.\n\nBut critics of the deal pressed Mr. Trump to remain strong. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday again condemned the agreement. The deal \u201cgives Iran a clear path to a nuclear arsenal\u201d and \u201cdoes not deal with the ballistic missiles that can deliver this weapon to many, many countries,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is why this deal has to be either fully fixed or fully nixed.\u201d", "title": "Emmanuel Macron to Press Trump to Keep Iran Nuclear Deal", "authors": ["Peter Baker", "Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Levi Strauss & Company introduced a novel benefit for employees at its San Francisco headquarters last fall: free genetic screening to assess their hereditary risks for certain cancers and high cholesterol.\n\nChip Bergh, Levi\u2019s chief executive, said he had hoped that the tests would spur employees to take preventive health steps and in that way reduce the company\u2019s health care costs. But even Mr. Bergh was surprised by the turnout. Of the 1,100 eligible Levi\u2019s employees, more than half took the genetic tests. Now, he wants to extend the benefit to employees in other cities.\n\n\u201cIt really is a differentiator,\u201d Mr. Bergh said.\n\nWest Coast companies vying for talent offer an unusual array of benefits like college loan repayment, egg freezing, surrogacy assistance and, for new mothers away on business trips, overnight breast milk shipping. Some companies have added genetic screening as well, and employees are lining up for the tests.\n\nInstacart, Nvidia, OpenTable, Salesforce, SAP, Slack, Stripe and Snap have offered the screenings as an employee benefit. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "Empowerment, Martha Graham-Style", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "He said that in the past, engines were designed with an abundance of precaution. \u201cThey don\u2019t do that anymore. They\u2019re trying to whittle down every last bit of material, every bit of weight. Thrust is king.\u201d\n\nBut, Mr. Giannotti said, \u201cthere is such a thing as pushing things. We try to get right to the edge, with as little edge as possible, without stepping over.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the case of the Southwest engine failure this week, investigators say they are not only considering why a fan blade broke but why the engine housing failed to contain it. The shrapnel punctured a window in the plane, and a woman seated by it was partially sucked out. She was later pronounced dead.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration had already been close to ordering airlines using that particular engine, the CFM-56B, to conduct ultrasonic inspections. The agency appears to have been prompted to act after another Southwest 737 engine came apart in 2016, sending debris into the plane\u2019s fuselage, wing and tail. The investigation into that incident is ongoing.\n\nLate Wednesday, the F.A.A. said it was ordering those ultrasonic inspections. The engines on both Southwest planes, were manufactured by CFM International, a joint venture of General Electric and Safran of France.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board concluded that the inspections were insufficient to detect flaws in the disk of a CF-6 engine on an American Airlines Boeing 767 in late 2016. The plane was gaining speed on the runway in Chicago when the engine broke apart, sending metal fragments into the fuel tank and igniting a fire. The engine was manufactured by General Electric.\n\nThe chairman of the transportation safety board, Robert L. Sumwalt, said on Wednesday that the problems with the Southwest engine were worrisome because the agency had already discovered in the Chicago incident that some engine flaws were undetectable. \u201cWe are concerned about it,\u201d Mr. Sumwalt said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInspections have also been ordered for the Rolls-Royce Trent 1000 engines that power a quarter of Boeing\u2019s newest wide-body, the 787 Dreamliner, after cracks were found on rotor blades. But the F.A.A. went further and rescinded the operators\u2019 approval to fly the airplanes any farther than 2 hours and 20 minutes from an emergency airport.\n\nInternational long-haul carriers like United Airlines, Qantas Airways, Japan Airlines, Air New Zealand and British Airways purchased the Dreamliner over the past decade specifically for the plane\u2019s ability to carry fewer people on longer routes more fuel efficiently. On extended flights over water, an airline could schedule flights on routes of up to five hours flying time from an emergency airport.\n\nPhoto\n\nAmerican and European regulators now say that cannot be safely accomplished. Should one Rolls-Royce engine fail, the higher power demand on the remaining engine could cause the second engine to fail.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s pretty frightening,\u201d said Mr. Giannotti, the aerospace engineer. \u201cWhat is very clear is, there is a design flaw in the engine.\u201d\n\nLATAM Airlines, British Airways and Norwegian Air are three airlines that must now lease substitute airplanes or reassign other model aircraft to certain destinations, an expensive disruption.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe are carrying out detailed precautionary inspections on Rolls-Royce Trent 1000 engines on our Boeing 787s to ensure we meet all the relevant regulatory requirements,\u201d said Michele Kropf, a spokeswoman for British Airways. She declined to provide details of how the carrier was handling transoceanic routes on which it flies its 787s.\n\nAlthough engine failure is not common, the bigger risk is when pieces of the motor fly out. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of mass behind them,\u201d said Robert Benzon, a former investigator with the transportation safety board. \u201cBecause of the centrifugal forces involved, if they shoot out in the wrong direction, they can do anything.\u201d\n\nFor more than a half-century, jet engines have taken the lead in advancing the capabilities of airliners, with each engine more powerful than the newest plane. They do more than just propel the plane through the sky; they provide power to the airplane\u2019s demanding and complex systems.\n\nThe recent engine failures have certainly been disruptive and attention-getting, but do not necessarily indicate a trend, though Mr. Benzon said it might.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s up to the industry and the entities, the investigators, the certification people, the F.A.A. in our case, to see if there is a trend and rectify it,\u201d he said.", "title": "Engine on Southwest Jet Not the Only One to Develop Cracks", "authors": ["Christine Negroni"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Parents in England will no longer be charged burial and cremation fees for children after Prime Minister Theresa May announced that the government would set up a fund to cover the charges.\n\nThe announcement on Saturday came after a campaign by an opposition Labour lawmaker, Carolyn Harris, who went into debt to bury her 8-year-old son, Martin, who died in a road accident in 1989.\n\nThe charges were waived for parents in Wales last year.\n\nMrs. May said in a statement, \u201cIn the raw pain of immediate loss, it cannot be right that grieving parents should have to worry about how to meet the funeral costs for a child they hoped to see grow into adulthood.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn the darkest moment of any parent\u2019s life there is little light, but there can be support,\u201d she added.", "title": "England to Abolish Burial and Cremation Fees for Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Travelers can reserve an Insidr phone online and pick it up at Paris Orly Airport or Charles de Gaulle Airport, or have it mailed to them anywhere in the city. The company was founded by Ben and Nina Forlani, a brother and sister team and Parisian natives. \u201cWe didn\u2019t want tourists to Paris to feel like they weren\u2019t getting an authentic perspective of the city because they didn\u2019t know French,\u201d Mr. Forlani said. Rental prices start at five euros a day, and Insidr concierges speak English, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Thai, Spanish, Russian and Portuguese.\n\nA Local Fixer, in Your Pocket\n\nThe City Helpline, a mobile app for Apple iPhones and devices running Google\u2019s Android operating system, gives travelers access to a concierge, either via live messaging or by phone, who can help them with a variety of requests. The concierge, for example, can help them find the right bus and bus stop that will take them to the Louvre, recommend a guide who can give them a street art tour, connect them with a an English speaking babysitter and even share a list of restaurants that serve dishes suited to their gluten-free diet. Plus, they can also assist in emergencies such as if a traveler gets sick and needs to see a doctor.\n\nRight now, the concierge service is available Monday through Saturday from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. local time, but the company has plans to have 24-hour service before the end of the year. A subscription to use the app costs five euros a day. Concierges speak English, Mandarin, Spanish, Portuguese and Italian.\n\nA Translator at the Theater\n\nTheatre in Paris translates French theater performances into English in 10 playhouses in Paris, including Theatre Mogador, currently showing French productions of \u201cThe Adventures of Tom Sawyer\u201d and the musical \u201cGrease,\u201d and Theatre de Ranelagh, currently showing the play \u201cRuy Blas\u201d by Victor Hugo, \u201cCyrano de Bergerac\u201d and more. The company placed a projection screen above the stages in these theaters that displays an English translation of the words being spoken on the stage.\n\nThose who buy a ticket through Theatre in Paris are assigned seats that will give them the best vantage point of both the stage and the screen; they\u2019re also met at the theater by a company employee who gives them a program in English. Tickets start at about 25 euros. Carl de Poncins, the app\u2019s founder, said that he came up with the idea for the projection screens because he had an Australian roommate who loved theater but knew little French. \u201cHe never used to go to performances because he couldn\u2019t understand what was going on,\u201d he said. \u201cWhy should language get in the way of seeing the incredible theater Paris has?\u201d", "title": "Enjoy Paris Without Letting Language Get in the Way", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "A 2004 Red Sox Champion Runs Boston\n\nMike Myers made 883 appearances over 13 years as a major league pitcher. It sounds like a lot, but Myers threw sidearm and averaged just 2.7 hitters per outing. Before he could exert much energy on the mound, his workday was usually over.\n\n\u201cI could pitch seven, 10, 14 days in a row,\u201d Myers said. \u201cI never got sore, pitching-wise.\u201d\n\nHis latest athletic pursuit required just a bit more stamina. Myers ran the Boston Marathon on Monday, slogging through the 26.2 miles in 40-degree weather with driving rain and 35 mile-an-hour headwinds. It was the first marathon for Myers, who helped the Red Sox win the 2004 World Series. He finished in 5 hours 7 minutes.\n\n\u201cI had two goals entering the race, one of which was to run the entire thing,\u201d said Myers, who now works for the Players Association. \u201cI fell about a mile and a quarter short of that because I walked various points knowing that if I tried to push it, I was going to hurt myself real bad and possibly not make it to the end. And the other goal was to get on the plane the next day without needing the assistance of a wheelchair \u2014 and I was able to do that with no problem.\u201d\n\nMyers, 48, raised more than $12,000 for the Angel Fund for A.L.S. Research, in honor of Sharon Timlin, the mother of his former Red Sox teammate Mike Timlin, who is now Myers\u2019s next-door neighbor in Colorado. Sharon Timlin died of A.L.S. in 2003.\n\nMike Timlin\u2019s wife, Dawn, is one of at least three wives of the 2004 Red Sox who have run the Boston Marathon, including Curt Schilling\u2019s wife, Shonda, and Trot Nixon\u2019s wife, Kathryn. It is possible that another former player besides Myers has run the race, but T.K. Skenderian, the communications director for the Boston Athletic Association, said there were none in his records.\n\nMyers started training late last summer and changed his diet in January, cutting out alcohol and almost all carbohydrates. He said he had lost 28 pounds this year, which helped during the race. So did months of running in Colorado.\n\n\u201cWhere I live, I can\u2019t go more than a mile without hitting some type of major hill, whether it\u2019s a steep incline or a steep decline,\u201d Myers said. \u201cSo that helped out on some of the hills. It helped out on Heartbreak Hill, and there\u2019s a few other ones where I was like: \u2018Oh, this is just like a normal bump in the road for Colorado. This shouldn\u2019t even be considered a hill.\u2019 But when you\u2019re out there in Mile 16 or 18 and you see a little hill, it\u2019s not like they\u2019re small anymore.\u201d", "title": "Enter Josh Hader, the Middle-Innings \u2018Closer\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think it\u2019s a really important development for this sector,\u201d said Daniel Rutherford, who directs the aviation and marine programs at the International Council on Clean Transportation, a watchdog group. \u201cUntil this past week, it didn\u2019t have a climate target.\u201d\n\nBut he and others noted that the next few years would be critical. The I.M.O. gave itself until 2023 to develop and implement specific measures to reach the target. These will probably include stricter design and operation standards for ships to increase efficiency, as well as programs to introduce low-carbon fuels or carbon-free propulsion.\n\n\u201cIf you don\u2019t make early investments and policies, then it becomes very challenging to meet the I.M.O. goals,\u201d Dr. Rutherford said.\n\nThe I.M.O. may also take steps to introduce so-called market-based measures that would set a price on carbon. This would create economic incentives for shippers to adopt new fuels and technologies, which are likely to be costly.\n\nAn analysis by researchers at the University College London Energy Institute described the agreement as a signal to the industry and investors \u201cthat a clear switch away from fossil fuels is now on the cards.\u201d\n\nThe researchers also noted that while the agreement puts shipping on a path to do its part to keep global warming at 2 degrees Celsius (about 4 degrees Fahrenheit), \u201cit\u2019s important to remember Paris targets \u2018well below\u2019 2 C and aims for 1.5 C, so this is no time for complacency.\u201d", "title": "Environmentalists and Nuclear Power? It\u2019s Complicated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Those changes were all approved in a referendum last year that Mr. Erdogan had campaigned for strenuously, with the obvious intention that he would be the first president to hold the enhanced office.\n\nMr. Erdogan has since been urging members of his Justice and Development Party to work to build enough support for him to secure the election in the first round.\n\n\u201cAlthough its seems there are no serious issues arising as the president and the government are working in harmony, the diseases of the old system can confront us at every step,\u201d Mr. Erdogan said in a speech broadcast live on television. \u201cFor our country to make decisions about the future more strongly and apply them, passing to the new governmental system becomes urgent.\u201d\n\nMinutes later, the Turkish Parliament approved a request from Prime Minister Binali Yildirim to extend the state of emergency \u2014 which has been in force since the failed coup \u2014 for another three months, the Turkish news agency Anadolu reported.\n\nWhile the coup attempt was violent \u2014 nearly 250 people died, including Mr. Erdogan\u2019s election campaign manager and close friend \u2014 critics have since accused him of using the extended powers under emergency rule to crack down on political opponents and dissent.\n\nTens of thousands have been jailed, accused of links to Fethullah Gulen, the Islamist cleric accused of masterminding the coup, or to other designated terrorist organizations. And over 100,000 people have been suspended from public-sector jobs. Mr. Gulen has denied involvement in the coup.\n\nDefense Minister Nurettin Canikli said Wednesday that the government had identified three thousand top-level officers belonging to the Gulen movement inside the military, and was preparing to purge them soon with a government decree, the Anadolu news agency reported.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Erdogan said that events in Syria and Iraq, both countries in which Turkey has deployed troops, had made a transition to the presidential system more urgent. He also said the economic situation demanded certainty.\n\n\u201cWith the cross-border operations we maintain in Syria, and also historical events happening in the area centered around Syria and Iraq, it became a must for Turkey to climb over the uncertainty as soon as possible,\u201d the president said.\n\n\u201cIn a period where developments about Syria accelerate, and we have to make very important decisions on issues from macroeconomic equilibrium to big investments, it is a must to drop the election issue from the agenda as soon as possible,\u201d he added.\n\nYet political opponents and commentators have been predicting for months that Mr. Erdogan would call early elections as soon as he could be sure of winning. He is known to closely watch opinion polls and has enjoyed a bounce in his personal rating since ordering military operations against Kurdish militias in the northern Syrian enclave of Afrin in January.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe country also enjoyed over 7 percent growth in the last quarter of 2017. Yet there are signs that the economy is faltering. Inflation remains persistently high, which hurts many of Mr. Erdogan\u2019s own supporters.\n\nThe snap election was also seen as a move to undercut political opponents.\n\nMr. Erdogan\u2019s announcement came after discussions with Devlet Bahceli, the leader of Turkey\u2019s main nationalist party, the Nationalist Movement Party, which has entered a formal alliance with Mr. Erdogan\u2019s Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., for the elections.\n\nMr. Bahceli said that he supported early elections for the stability of the country and the economy. But he also seems to be concerned with fending off a rival for the nationalist vote, Meral Aksener, who split from his party and formed her own party, the Good Party, last year, according to Turkish media reports.\n\nThe early timing of the election now could prevent Ms. Aksener from running, since her new party may not be considered to have passed the required six months from its first party congress.\n\nMs. Aksener, a former interior minister, has nevertheless declared her intention to challenge Mr. Erdogan for president and field candidates for Parliament.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTurkey\u2019s largest opposition party, the Republican People\u2019s Party, or C.H.P., was caught flat-footed by the announcement, and has not yet selected a candidate for president. Its leader, Kemal Kilicdaroglu, ruled out running for the presidency last year.\n\nEngin Altay, the deputy head of C.H.P.\u2019s parliamentary group, told a Turkish television station that a candidate would be chosen within 15 days.\n\nThe pro-Kurdish party, the People\u2019s Democratic Party, or H.D.P., has particularly suffered under the state of emergency, with nine members of Parliament in jail, including their popular former leader Selahattin Demirtas and many mayors removed from their posts. The party nevertheless has appointed new leaders and declared itself ready for elections.\n\nSezai Temelli, the co-chairman of the party, said in a tweet: \u201cJune 24 is not early, but a panic election. The government is impotent.\u201d\n\nTo win outright in the first round of the election, Mr. Erdogan will need to secure 51 percent of the vote. His personal ratings have been closer to 40 percent in recent opinion polls.\n\nThe constitutional changes to create a new presidential system were agreed in a controversial referendum in April last year, which Mr. Erdogan only barely won with a 51 percent yes vote, versus 49 percent who voted no.\n\nMs. Aksener was a prominent leader of the no campaign and has vowed to assemble similar broad support for the coming elections.\n\nThe referendum was criticized as unfair by opposition parties and independent election monitors. Since then, Mr. Erdogan has moved to exercise greater control over the High Election Board and the electoral law, the parties warned.\n\n\u201cThe alliance cannot secure 50 percent,\u201d Yalcin Dogan wrote in the online news outlet T24. \u201cSo they are changing the structure of the High Election Board and the electoral law in a manner that is against the universal democratic rules. However, the Good Party remains a complete nightmare.\u201d", "title": "Erdogan Calls Early Turkish Elections in Bid to Solidify Power", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Eric Bristow, a British laborer\u2019s son who began mastering the pub game of darts as a teenager and became a dominant world champion in the 1980s, died on Thursday in Liverpool. He was 60.\n\nThe cause was a heart attack he suffered outside the Echo Arena after a tournament, where he was working as a hospitality host, the Professional Darts Corporation said.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just a great darts player,\u201d Mr. Bristow said in \u201cArrows,\u201d a 1979 documentary filmed after he started winning tournaments.\n\nHe became nearly unstoppable in the 1980s. Nicknamed the Crafty Cockney, he won five British Darts Organization world titles from 1980 to 1986 using an unusual technique: Before letting a dart fly, he would raise his right pinkie, as if he were daintily lifting a cup of tea.", "title": "Eric Bristow, the First Superstar of Darts, Is Dead at 60", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDr. Eric James Chow and Christopher Ryan Chambers were married April 7 at the Four Seasons Resort Hualalai in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii. Dr. Su N. Aung, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.\n\nDr. Chow (left), 33, is a chief resident at Hasbro Children\u2019s Hospital, a teaching affiliate of Brown University in Providence, R.I., where he was trained in internal medicine and pediatrics. He graduated with two bachelor\u2019s degrees, one in biological sciences and the other in international relations, with honors, and a master\u2019s degree in biological sciences from Stanford. He also has both a medical degree and a master\u2019s in public health from Eastern Virginia Medical School in Norfolk, Va. In July, he is to join the Epidemic Intelligence Service at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is based in Atlanta.\n\nHe is a son of Julia L. They emerged in the 1980s, when the number of inmates was quickly outstripping capacity, and they have an outsize influence in certain states, including Arizona, Florida, Hawaii, Mississippi and New Mexico.\n\nDespite hundreds of lawsuits, findings that private prisons save taxpayers little to no money, and evidence of repeated constitutional violations, the number of privately housed inmates has risen faster since 2000 than the overall number of prisoners. In 2016, the number rose by about 1.5 percent, according to Justice Department figures.\n\nLast week, Frank Shaw, a warden for Management & Training, or MTC, at the East Mississippi Correctional Facility, was called to testify in a federal trial claiming that the prison routinely failed to shield inmates from beatings and left them so desperate for medical attention that they lit fires in their cells. Mr. Shaw had also been the warden in Arizona during the riot.\n\nThe trial concluded on Monday; the judge has yet to issue a decision.\n\nEven states that have sworn off private prisons, or tried to cut back on their use, have found it difficult to extricate themselves. After the prisoners escaped in Arizona, the state tried to reduce the number of inmates held in that prison. But MTC claimed the state was violating its contract, which guaranteed a certain number of beds would be filled. Arizona had to pay the company $3 million. MTC still operates a facility in the state.", "title": "Escapes, Riots and Beatings. But States Can\u2019t Seem to Ditch Private Prisons.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Call it a case of FOMO \u2014 Fear of Missing Out. I\u2019m usually resistant to pangs of envy inspired by social media photos of friends and families on perfect getaways around the world. And seeing that multiple acquaintances had all visited the same destination would, if anything, make me decidedly less likely to visit a place. But this was different. Everyone I knew, it seemed, was going to Mexico City, and having the times of their lives. And I wanted to go, too.\n\nBut I was determined not to retread \u2014 not entirely, at least \u2014 the same attractive parks and tree-lined avenues dotted with Instagrammable restaurants and coffee shops as my peers. I would stay away from popular neighborhoods like La Condesa and Roma Norte during this trip, preferring instead to hone my focus about six miles south, on the quieter neighborhood of Coyoac\u00e1n. Best known as the location of Frida Kahlo\u2019s Blue House, this \u201cplace of coyotes\u201d proved to be equal parts serene and invigorating \u2014 the understated cultural soul of a city and, in many ways, a getaway within Mexico City itself. And my budget, modest as it was, didn\u2019t limit my enjoyment during a four-day, three-night trip.\n\nJos\u00e9 Antonio Alban\u00e9s, my spry middle-aged tour guide whom I\u2019d found through an Airbnb Experience ($50, which included a mountain of food), was born and raised in Coyoac\u00e1n (which refers to both the neighborhood and the larger borough of the same name, one of 16 that make up the city) and had a laundry list of reasons it was the best area in the city. \u201cEverything,\u201d he said, \u201cis better. The water, the climate, the culture.\u201d The climate? He was adamant. \u201cIt is better,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s cooler.\u201d", "title": "Escaping Mexico City\u2019s Hustle Within City Limits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "BANGKOK \u2014 A Belarusian escort jailed in Thailand who claims to have evidence of Russian meddling in United States elections faces new criminal charges of solicitation and conspiracy, the police said on Friday.\n\nThe escort, Anastasia Vashukevich, who says she had a brief affair with the powerful Russian aluminum tycoon Oleg V.
