Parmi eux, de plus en plus de jeunes femmes et d\u2019enfants. La mixit\u00e9, mal vue partout dans le pays, r\u00e8gne sur les chaloupes de l\u2019immigration clandestine apparemment.\n\nEn Alg\u00e9rie, on donne \u00e0 ces aventuriers un nom \u00e9trange: harragas, grilleurs des fronti\u00e8res \u2014 audacieux, fous. Le terme n\u2019implique plus de profil type depuis longtemps sauf \u00eatre jeune, de pr\u00e9f\u00e9rence mineur, car la loi en Espagne, par exemple, interdit d\u2019expulser les moins de 18 ans. Aujourd\u2019hui l\u2019appel de la mer touche surtout les Alg\u00e9riens \u2014 \u00e9tudiant ou pas, femme ou homme; les subsahariens qui transitent par l\u2019Alg\u00e9rie sembler plut\u00f4t regagner l\u2019Europe par les voies terrestres, via le Maroc.\n\nCette migration, la harga, est un probl\u00e8me parce que des gens en meurent, bien s\u00fbr, mais aussi pour le gouvernement alg\u00e9rien parce que le d\u00e9part volontaire et dangereux des siens est la preuve manifeste de ses multiples \u00e9checs, politiques et \u00e9conomiques \u2014 entre autres: r\u00e9pression, ch\u00f4mage, augmentation du co\u00fbt de la vie.\n\nLes couloirs de fuite sont connus de tous. A l\u2019extr\u00eame-est, \u00e0 quelques 500 kilom\u00e8tres d\u2019Alger, la capitale, on part vers l\u2019Italie. Depuis l\u2019Oranie, une r\u00e9gion \u00e0 l\u2019ouest, c\u2019est plut\u00f4t vers l\u2019Espagne. Les d\u00e9parts ont maintenant leurs professionnels, leurs saisons, leurs tarifs \u2014 et leurs r\u00e9cits de r\u00e9ussite: notamment celui de l\u2019harraga qui \u00e0 la fin \u00e9pouse une am\u00e9ricaine et la convertit \u00e0 l\u2019Islam.", "title": "Opinion | Est-ce ill\u00e9gal de quitter son pays?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Couch was 16 in June 2013 when he and a group of friends stole beer from a store and had a party at his parents\u2019 house before going for a drive. He struck and killed four people on the side of a road near Burleson, Tex., a Fort Worth suburb, and a passenger in his car was paralyzed and suffered brain damage.\n\nHe had a blood alcohol level of 0.24, three times the legal limit in Texas, hours after the crash.\n\nHe pleaded guilty in 2013 to four counts of manslaughter and a juvenile court judge sentenced him to 10 years of probation, defying prosecutors who sought a 20-year prison sentence. The victims\u2019 families were outraged, and critics felt he got special treatment because of his wealth.\n\nIn December 2015, a six-second video that appeared to show Mr. Couch at a party where alcohol was served \u2014 a possible parole violation \u2014 was posted on Twitter. Two weeks later, he and his mother went missing.\n\nThey were arrested about two weeks later, about 1,200 miles away in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, where they had changed their appearances and ditched their identifications. Mr. Couch was brought back to Texas and placed in juvenile detention, while his case was moved to adult court.\n\nIn April 2016, Dee Anderson, Tarrant County\u2019s sheriff, said Mr. Couch had created \u201czero issues\u201d since beginning his jail stint that January.", "title": "Ethan Couch, \u2018Affluenza Teen\u2019 Who Killed 4 While Driving Drunk, Is Freed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "With funding from the National Institutes of Health, the investigators plan to inoculate participants with potential vaccines and then to inject them with small doses of the Zika virus to test the vaccines\u2019 effectiveness. The N.I.H. has not yet decided whether the research will proceed.\n\nThe scientists leading the trial say it is necessary to prevent a future epidemic. But Ms. Shah and other bioethicists convened by the N.I.H. concluded in 2017 that the research had \u201cinsufficient value\u201d to justify the risks.\n\nPeople outside the study, such as sexual partners, might also be infected, the panel said. And Zika infection might have unspecified consequences for participants in the long term.\n\nBut scientists in charge of the study said the panel\u2019s concerns were hypothetical and did not take into account the proposed protocol. They plan to use minimal doses of Zika virus and to quarantine patients in a hospital inpatient unit.\n\nThe study also would start by enrolling only women \u2014 who are less likely to transmit Zika sexually \u2014 and would require them to use long-term birth control.", "title": "Ethicists Call for More Scrutiny of \u2018Human-Challenge\u2019 Trials", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Besides representing the state in the Love Canal settlement under Attorney General Robert Abrams, Mr. Leff headed its environmental bureau. He pursued litigation to remove polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, and other contaminants from the Hudson River and to remediate a decades-long oil leak into Newtown Creek, between Brooklyn and Queens.\n\nBeginning in 2011, as deputy state environmental conservation commissioner, Mr. Leff drafted legislation to safeguard against future toxic chemical catastrophes.\n\n\u201cGene was indefatigable in pursuing the cleanup of the most notorious toxic waste site in the world,\u201d Mr. Abrams said on Monday in an email. \u201cWhile soft-spoken, he was tough as nails in standing up to the might of a reckless corporate giant.\u201d\n\nIn the Love Canal case, Judge John T. Curtin, of Federal District Court in Buffalo, had held in 1988 that Occidental Chemical was liable for environmental damage and cleanup costs.\n\nHowever, the judge later ruled that the state\u2019s demand for punitive damages was not warranted because dumping on the site by Hooker Chemical and Plastics, which was acquired by Occidental in 1968, was not illegal when it occurred, between 1942 and 1952.\n\nThe only remaining question was how much Occidental had to pay for the damage and cleanup.\n\nThe state sued for $150 million, but later said it was satisfied with the $98 million out-of-court settlement because that amount exceeded its legal and cleanup costs.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor its part, Occidental dropped a countersuit, in which it claimed that a sewer line installed by the state had been partly responsible for spreading contaminants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe state settlement did not affect a federal suit against Occidental, which was settled in 1995 for $129 million, or claims by hundreds of homeowners, many of which remain pending.\n\nAs early as 1945, Hooker employees had warned that the site could become a legal quagmire.\n\nHooker nevertheless entombed 21,800 tons of hazardous chemicals there over time. Sparsely populated originally, the area was developed, and the abandoned canal \u2014 an aborted 19th-century project conceived by an entrepreneur named James Love to bypass Niagara Falls \u2014 became a neighborhood swimming hole.\n\nIn 1953, the company, after warning about the landfill, sold a portion of the site for an elementary school.\n\nBeginning in 1978, when the environmental danger became obvious, state and federal officials evacuated hundreds of families within a 10-square-block area around the landfill. Congress passed the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act, popularly known as the Superfund, in 1980.\n\nAfter years of remediation, Love Canal was finally removed from the priority list of Superfund cleanup sites in 2004.\n\nIn 2008, a state report found higher rates of birth defects among families who had lived in the neighborhood but concluded that overall cancer rates appeared to be no different from those of the surrounding population.\n\nEugene Joel Leff was born on Aug. 10, 1944, in Manhattan to Dr. Abraham Leff, a psychiatrist, and the former Rose Levy, a pharmacist. He grew up first on Long Island, in Huntington, and then in Wood-Ridge, N.J.\n\nAfter graduating from Union High School in Union, N.J., he earned a bachelor\u2019s degree in political science from Columbia College and a law degree from Yale Law School. He also received a master\u2019s in Russian and East European studies from Yale and sang with the Yale Russian Chorus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis marriage to Ann Martin ended in divorce. (For a while he went by the name Eugene Martin-Leff.) In addition to his sister, he is survived by a daughter, Melanie Martin-Leff; his companion, Michele Richman; her daughter, Isabelle Rostain; and her son, Julian Rostain.\n\nAfter receiving his law degree, Mr. Leff clerked for a federal judge and then joined a Wall Street law firm whose clients included Johns Manville, the building-products manufacturer. He defended the company against lawsuits claiming medical damage over its use of asbestos.\n\nHailing from a family of health care workers, Mr. Leff switched sides, joining the National Employment Law Project, which enforces workplace standards, and then the attorney general.\n\nHe retired from the state in 2016.", "title": "Eugene Leff Dies at 73; Fought for New York in Love Canal Case", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "European leaders were largely silent after President Trump threatened to impose another $100 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods. But watching from a safe distance as China and the United States argue is not an option for Europe. Its economy is too deeply entwined with both.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat can they do in terms of staying out of the crossfire?\u201d said Adam Slater, lead economist at Oxford Economics in Britain. \u201cNot a lot.\u201d\n\nAlthough Mr. Trump\u2019s threats are aimed at China, Europe is certain to suffer collateral damage if the president follows through. A spiraling war of tariffs and counter-tariffs would interfere with the global flow of raw materials and components for manufactured goods, disrupting the European economy. And some European companies, like the German carmaker BMW, manufacture in the United States and export to China. Such companies would see their sales suffer if China were to slap tariffs on American goods.\n\nThe mere threat of a trade war has already unsettled financial markets and made it more difficult for companies to raise money, Beno\u00eet Coeur\u00e9, a member of the executive board of the European Central Bank, said Friday. \u201cNone of this supports growth and employment,\u201d Mr. Coeur\u00e9 said at a conference in Cernobbio, Italy.\n\nThe disruption to world trade comes at an unfortunate time for Europe. Recent economic indicators suggest that the Continent\u2019s recovery, after a decade of crisis, is losing momentum. Industrial production in Germany shrank 1.6 percent in February, according to official data published last week.\n\nBut European leaders\u2019 biggest fear may be that Mr. Trump\u2019s belligerent approach to trade will destroy the postwar system for resolving conflicts, which involved getting all the parties together in one room. Mr. Trump has already succeeded in forcing countries to beg for individual exemptions to steel and aluminum tariffs, bypassing the World Trade Organization, the usual forum for trade disputes.\n\n\u201cHe has created an environment to divide countries,\u201d said Andr\u00e9 Sapir, a senior fellow at Bruegel, a research organization in Brussels. \u201cMaybe we will remember that 2017 was the last year of the functioning of the multilateral system.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s possible Europe might enjoy a few short-term benefits as China and the United States duke it out. If, for example, China were to raise tariffs on Boeing airliners, Boeing\u2019s European rival, Airbus, could take advantage. But positive effects of that sort are not likely to outweigh the risks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEuropean companies have invested far more in the United States over the years than they have in China. But increasingly, China is where the action is. Germany\u2019s total trade with China, exports and imports together, is already bigger than it is with the United States. And China is the biggest single market for companies like Volkswagen, Europe\u2019s largest carmaker.\n\nChina is also where more German companies are putting their money.\n\nIn a poll published Thursday, 39 percent of German companies questioned said they planned to invest in China this year, up from 37 percent in 2017. The number that said they planned to invest in North America dropped to 35 percent, from 37 percent, according to a survey, by the Association of German Chambers of Commerce and Industry.\n\nEven so, Europe remains wary of China\u2019s intentions. Though European leaders use tamer language, they share some of Mr. Trump\u2019s concerns about unfair competition from Chinese companies that receive government subsidies. They worry that Chinese companies are stealing European technology, and accumulating too much economic power.\n\nIn recent years, Chinese investors have snapped up European assets including Greek ports, German machinery companies and a 10 percent stake in the automaker Daimler. The Chinese government\u2019s \u201cMade in China 2025\u201d campaign, a plan to dominate cutting-edge industry, is a threat to German companies that supply precision machinery that the Chinese companies are not yet able to manufacture themselves.\n\nLeaders in Brussels, Berlin and Paris have called for tighter scrutiny of Chinese acquisitions in Europe, though it is unclear how tough they will be.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Wake Up With The Times, Anywhere in the World. Get the Morning Briefing in your inbox. What you need to know to start your day, each weekday morning. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the same time, Europe and the United States have been through a lot together, most notably the Cold War. Both are multiparty democracies with free market economies, unlike China\u2019s one-party autocracy. And European and American historical and cultural ties go back centuries.\n\nStill, a trade war could push Europe closer to China.\n\nEurope\u2019s most immediate preoccupation is to resolve its own trade disputes with Mr. Trump. Cecilia Malmstrom, the European commissioner for trade, is negotiating with Wilbur Ross, the United States commerce secretary, about winning a permanent exemption from tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. A temporary exemption to the tariffs expires May 1.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Malmstrom and other European leaders have also made plain their unhappiness with what they see as Mr. Trump\u2019s crusade to undermine the World Trade Organization as the arbiter of trade conflicts. They may see China as a potential ally in efforts to preserve the W.T.O., of which China is also a member.\n\n\u201cThe E.U. believes that measures should always be taken within the World Trade Organization framework which provides numerous tools to effectively deal with trade differences,\u201d a representative for the European Commission said in a statement.\n\nFor the moment, there is little Europe can do but hope that Mr. Trump\u2019s bluster is just a tactic to win concessions from China, and that no trade war will break out. There are few other good options.\n\nMr. Sapir of Bruegel argues that, longer term, Europe should push for reforms of the trade body to respond to American criticism that the organization is too slow moving, and has failed to curb unfair competition by China. Mr. Trump is unlikely to take much interest in fixing the global trade regime rather than ignoring it, Mr. Sapir said, but it\u2019s still worth a try.\n\n\u201cThat is the only structural solution,\u201d Mr. Sapir said. \u201cOtherwise, we will always be caught in between.\u201d", "title": "Europe Caught in the Middle as Trump Threatens China", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "European authorities raided the London offices of a unit of 21st Century Fox on Tuesday as part of an antitrust investigation into the distribution of sports programming.\n\nThe search at Fox Networks Group was one of several the European Commission said it had conducted across Europe as part of an investigation into potential violations of rules prohibiting price-fixing cartels. The investigation adds to the regulatory challenges that 21st Century Fox, Rupert Murdoch\u2019s media giant, is facing in Europe, where officials have held up its bid to take full control of the British satellite broadcaster Sky.\n\nIn a statement, Fox Networks Group said it was \u201ccooperating fully with the E.C. inspection.\u201d The raid was first reported by The Daily Telegraph in London, which said the authorities had seized documents and computer files. The European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union, declined to comment on what companies were involved in the searches.\n\nSports programming has played a key role in Mr. Murdoch\u2019s ability to gain a foothold in the European pay-TV market. Through 21st Century Fox, he owns a 39 percent stake in Sky, which has 23 million customers and owns rights to show the English Premier League and other professional soccer leagues.", "title": "European Authorities Raid Offices of 21st Century Fox Unit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Data. It is the gasoline that fuels advertiser-supported internet giants like Facebook and the gold that companies mine for their algorithms.\n\nNow regulators in Europe are asking whether Facebook is excessively collecting details about the online activities of internet users \u2014 in effect, forcibly extracting a valuable commodity from consumers.\n\nThe authorities in a number of European countries contend that Facebook has unfairly used its leverage to collect details about the activities of both Facebook users and nonusers on millions of third-party sites that use tools like Facebook\u2019s \u201clike\u201d button and analytics service. Some of those regulators have developed a novel argument: data coercion.\n\nThis month, the Competition Authority in Italy said Facebook was using \u201cundue influence\u201d to get consumers to \u201cconsent to the collection and use of all the information concerning them.\u201d In February, a court in Belgium found that Facebook had collected details about Belgium-based internet users without their unequivocal consent and ordered it to stop collecting data on non-Facebook sites \u201cin a manner that is excessive.\u201d", "title": "European Regulators Ask if Facebook Is Taking Too Much Data", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Of course, we are not blind to the discord and disarray resulting from Iran\u2019s actions and attitude in the region. We strongly condemn its contribution to the war in Syria and its backing of the murderous government of President Bashar al-Assad, as well as Iran\u2019s support, by varying degrees, of nonstate actors like Hezbollah in Lebanon and the Houthis in Yemen. However, by taking the threat that Iran would develop a nuclear weapon off the table, the pact has effectively limited that country\u2019s means to carry out its destabilizing activities.\n\nThose are the reasons that France, Germany and Britain, which form the E3 group, continue to support the agreement and are calling on President Trump to make good on the commitment we took, together with the United States, on July 14, 2015, in Vienna. Now we, members of parliaments in the E3, have decided to raise our voices to tell the United States Congress that we stand by our trans-Atlantic commitments and to warn of the disastrous consequences of an American withdrawal from the Vienna agreement.\n\nTo that end, we have written a letter being published Thursday and Friday by leading newspapers in France, Germany and Britain calling on the members of Congress to bring their full backing to the nuclear deal and prevent their government from pulling out of this major diplomatic achievement. The letter has been signed by more than 500 members of France\u2019s National Assembly, Germany\u2019s Bundestag and Britain\u2019s House of Commons. The signatories as of Thursday afternoon \u2014 362 French, 70 British and 75 German \u2014 represent the entire political spectrum of our home countries. They may disagree on internal policies and on other international issues, but they agree on one thing: The compact is a major achievement of our collective security, in the Middle East and beyond.\n\nAs elected representatives, we have taken this extraordinary step of rallying hundreds of our fellow members of parliament across our political aisles, and of reaching out to our American colleagues, because we firmly believe that the diplomatic strength of a strong and unified trans-Atlantic partnership is needed today more than ever. As Europeans, we are undertaking this cross-European, cross-parliamentary initiative to show the international community that Europe\u2019s democracies will rise in solidarity on critical international problems.\n\nWe are pleading to the men and women of Congress to play their part in keeping the nuclear deal alive. We know that the citizens we represent are the people who make the formulas of our shared values come alive every day. With equal fervor on both sides of the Atlantic, they strive for liberty and believe in human rights and the rule of law. These are principles upon which we can build a more just world order.", "title": "Opinion | Europe\u2019s Plea to Congress: Keep the Iran Pact", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Twenty-four hours later, Ms. Wood was in Los Angeles, about to perform at a touring Bowie tribute. She has a lightning bolt tattoo, from Bowie\u2019s \u201cAladdin Sane\u201d album cover, and songs like \u201cRock \u2019n\u2019 Roll Suicide\u201d were her beacon. \u201cI used to just put that on when I was at my lowest points and just wait for him to scream, \u2018You\u2019re not alone!\u2019 And that would get me through another night,\u201d she said.\n\nWhen she opened the lyric page for that song, onstage at the Wiltern in Los Angeles, her hand trembled. The words looked like symbols \u2014 \u201clike I couldn\u2019t even read,\u201d she said. \u201cEverything went white. And I thought, \u2018Oh boy. Breathe, girl, breathe.\u2019\u201d In videos from the show, you can see her hesitate and back off, then regain her momentum. She finished the number with shattering intensity.\n\n\u201cEvan is a powerhouse,\u201d said her friend Linda Perry (4 Non Blondes, Pink\u2019s \u201cGet the Party Started\u201d), the vocalist, songwriter and producer, who recommended her for the Bowie gig. \u201cWhat I like about her is, she\u2019s not afraid to be vulnerable, and that to me is an extremely powerful position to be in. She stands right there with her feet on the ground and her arms open, saying, This is who I am, this is how I\u2019m going to be, and this is how I\u2019m going to walk through life. Take it or leave it.\u201d\n\nIn Ms. Wood\u2019s telling, that position is hard won. The daughter of two actors from Raleigh, N.C., where her father runs a community theater, she began performing early, and moved to Los Angeles with her mother, an acting coach, after her parents split when she was 9. A steady career followed, but looking back, she said: \u201cI didn\u2019t feel like I had proper training for the world. I lived my whole life asking, \u2018What do you want me to do and who do you want me to be?\u2019 I was so insecure and didn\u2019t feel worthy of much.\u201d As a teenager, she began a much-ogled relationship with Marilyn Manson, the older goth rocker, to whom she was briefly engaged.\n\nOnly later in her 20s, she said, and especially after she became a mother, did she find her voice. The 2016 election also impelled her to act, to set an example for her son.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn between Seasons 1 and 2 of \u201cWestworld,\u201d Ms. Wood filmed an indie drama, \u201cAllure,\u201d out now, in which she plays the gaslighting abuser of a teenage girl. It was not fun to play, she said, but a painful story she felt needed to be told. \u201cIf you\u2019re going to be famous, for me it has to mean something, or be used for something, because otherwise it just freaks me out,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe playlist we\u2019d been listening to all day \u2014 her soundtrack for the revolution \u2014 is called \u201cInvincible,\u201d she said. In a flannel shirt, dark jeans and cowboy boots embossed with stars, she was unguarded and casual, peppering the conversation with \u201cDude!\u201d and the click, every now and then, of a fidget cube, to channel her energy. Her house is cozy but feels half-lived in \u2014 she\u2019s still in Los Angeles often. \u201cWestworld\u201d shoots in the Utah desert; to lighten the mood on set, she and her co-star James Marsden, as a \u201chost\u201d gunfighter, run their lines as Veronica Corningstone and Ron Burgundy, from \u201cAnchorman.\u201d (She puts on her coaching voice; he\u2019s dense. It works.)\n\nBut Dolores\u2019s transformation, in Season 2, left Ms. Wood unnerved.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve worked for a very long time to not be angry and vengeful,\u201d she said, \u201cso it was hard to take pleasure in that, even though I knew that the character had definitely earned it.\u201d\n\nMs. Wood\u2019s mission is always to turn her trauma into some other force. Before she went to Congress, she had her aura read at a Nashville shop. It told her some of her energy was blocked, that she needed to get something out. Now, a week afterward, we went back, to see if anything had changed.\n\nShe was still glowing lavender \u2014 \u201cwonderful storytellers, writers and artists,\u201d the description said. \u201cThey have the talent to visualize and describe magical, mystical worlds.\u201d But where before her emotional chart looked like a jagged mountain range, now it was flat, calm. \u201cSpeaking your truth!\u201d she said.\n\nHer hope was that \u2014 especially post #MeToo \u2014 \u201cWestworld\u201d would do for others what Dolores did for her: help them to feel powerful, and be heard.\n\n\u201cEverything you want is on the other side of fear,\u201d she said.", "title": "Evan Rachel Wood Turns Her Trauma Into Good. On \u2018Westworld\u2019 and in Life.", "authors": ["Melena Ryzik"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "For F train riders, the signal problems have made an increasingly miserable commute worse. The F line has the worst on-time performance of any line \u2014 just 32 percent of weekday trains were on time in January, the most recent month for which statistics were available. Only a year earlier, in January 2017, the F line\u2019s on-time rate was nearly 50 percent.\n\nGov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who controls the M.T.A., has said that subway service is starting to improve. Mr. Cuomo declared that the subway was in a state of emergency last summer and announced a short-term action plan to fix it. But painful delays continue to wreak havoc on the city, and riders still complain about unreliable service and crowded trains.\n\nOn a recent morning, Zoe Belden spent 45 minutes stuck on an F train near Bergen Street because of signal problems. She was late to work. After being delayed again the next night, Ms. Belden was so frustrated that she walked more than three miles home, from Chinatown in Manhattan.\n\n\u201cI wanted to not be mad at the city anymore,\u201d Ms. Belden said, noting that the weather was nice for her jaunt across the Manhattan Bridge. \u201cI want to enjoy it, and the M.T.A. makes that difficult.\u201d\n\nSubway officials have pledged to be more transparent \u2014 and sympathetic \u2014 when informing riders about delays.\n\n\u201cFor those impacted, we know your commute was incredibly frustrating and apologize for letting you down,\u201d the main subway Twitter account said after signal problems at Bergen Street on March 15. \u201cPlease know that we will be launching a full internal investigation of the signal malfunction, so that we identify the root cause to prevent it from happening again.\u201d\n\nAfter the meltdown on April 6, the Twitter account said officials would share the findings of that investigation \u201cin the coming days.\u201d A week later, they still have not been released.", "title": "Even Newer Subway Signals Cause Headaches on F Train", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "For now, the chances of the president\u2019s impeachment remain remote, even though Democrats may be outspoken on the subject. \u201cI will sleep with my cellphone next to my ear, and if the word comes down that Donald Trump is taking out Sessions, taking out Mueller, taking other actions to undermine the rule of law and obstruct justice, I will be on the first plane to Washington,\u201d said Representative Luis V. Guti\u00e9rrez, Democrat of Illinois and a member of the House Judiciary Committee, where impeachment proceedings would begin.\n\n\u201cIt would leave this committee no choice to go ahead with impeachment hearings,\u201d he added.\n\nBut Speaker Paul D. Ryan and Representative Robert W. Goodlatte of Virginia, the Judiciary Committee\u2019s chairman, have given no indication of how they would proceed, and aides say privately that Republican leaders view the possibility of Mr. Mueller\u2019s firing as too improbable to warrant hypothetical discussions.\n\nShort of that, there are other options. Congress could pass a law reinstating an independent investigator in the executive or legislative branch, though Mr. Trump would have to sign it. Lawmakers could demand that Mr. Mueller\u2019s evidence be turned over to Congress. They could press to censure the president. Or they could make his fate a political issue and let the voters decide in November.\n\nRepublicans and Democrats do agree on one thing: Should the special counsel be ousted, the business of Congress \u2014 hearings, nominations and legislation \u2014 would screech to a stop, replaced by a painful, consequential debate over the most serious constitutional challenge in a generation.\n\n\u201cThe rule of law is very dear to many of us,\u201d said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina. \u201cI don\u2019t think you have to be too creative to understand how damaging that would be.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has made no secret of his contempt for Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation into potential ties between his campaign and Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, and into possible obstruction of justice by the president himself. He ordered the firing of Mr. Mueller over the summer before backing down.\n\nBut more recently the president has shifted to a more aggressive, direct attack on the special counsel and the legitimacy of his inquiry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnder current law, Mr. Trump cannot directly fire the special counsel. Even if he ordered the Justice Department official overseeing the case \u2014 right now, the deputy attorney general \u2014 to dismiss Mr. Mueller, he would have to cite good cause. But Mr. Trump has proved willing to fire or push out other top F.B.I. officials tied to the investigation, as well as his secretary of state and his national security adviser, and could choose to remove those who objected to the order.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn unleashed president has members of both parties nervous.\n\nIf Mr. Mueller were fired and the investigation disbanded, of primary importance would be preserving the evidence gathered by the special counsel\u2019s investigation, aides in both parties say. Congress could leverage its control of the Justice Department\u2019s nominees and purse strings to ensure its safekeeping while other matters were sorted out. Relevant committees could then call for Mr. Mueller to testify, as they weighed a path forward legislatively.\n\nBut Mr. Mueller would have to be willing to share his knowledge. If he were inclined to disclose details of his investigation to Congress, many of which are not protected by grand jury secrecy, it would be very difficult, if not impossible, for Mr. Trump to stop him, legal experts said.\n\n\u201cIf Mueller or members of his team are subpoenaed by Congress, and they\u2019re willing to tell their story, then I think there\u2019s a strong likelihood that the story gets told,\u201d said Ross H. Garber, an expert in impeachment law who has represented several politicians in high-profile investigations.\n\nThe spectacle of a fired special counsel \u2014 and former F.B.I. director \u2014 publicly divulging the results of his investigation would raise parallels to the Watergate hearings and raise pressure on Republicans to break rank. On top of that, a potential subpoena fight over Mr. Mueller\u2019s records would add a nasty sideshow that would sap Mr. Trump\u2019s political agenda.\n\n\u201cWe have to expect that all the information that Mueller and his team have discovered will ultimately be made public one way or another,\u201d Mr. Garber said.\n\nDemocrats say they also fear a less dramatic outcome: In lieu of demanding the firing of Mr. Mueller, the president could replace Mr. Sessions and Mr. Rosenstein as part of what has become regular turnover in a tumultuous administration. A new attorney general could then declare that further investigation was unnecessary and dismiss Mr. Mueller on his or her own. The end result would be the same, but it could give the White House the argument that the Justice Department made the decision independently of the president, making it harder to build support for Congress to act.\n\nWithout support for impeachment, Democrats say the most realistic path toward Republican cooperation would be an effort to get Mr. Mueller, or another investigator, reinstated. Options under discussion include hiring Mr. Mueller as a special congressional investigator, passing a new independent counsel law that would restore him or another trusted law enforcement figure as an executive branch employee with explicit protections from Mr. Trump, or enacting legislation that would allow Mr. Mueller to appeal his firing to a panel of judges.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNone of those options are a sure thing.\n\n\u201cIt would be a mess,\u201d said Senator Chris Coons, a moderate Democrat from Delaware who has all but pleaded with colleagues to support a measure he has drafted with Senator Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, giving Mr. Mueller the right to appeal his dismissal.\n\n\u201cMy concern is that they would want to do the least effective thing, which is send the president a resolution of reprimand or censure, urge him to reconsider and then just sort of go sideways for a week or two,\u201d Mr. Coons added.\n\nEven if Congress passed legislation reinstating a special counsel in some fashion, it is unclear whether such a law would have teeth, and many legal experts said the legislation could almost certainly prompt a legal challenge from the White House.\n\n\u201cThe more likely outcome is that the executive branch would ignore Congress,\u201d said Mr. Garber, the lawyer. And hiring Mr. Mueller as a congressional investigator would not be the same as maintaining him as a special counsel, with the F.B.I. and a grand jury at his disposal.\n\n\u201cIf he has no resources, and no ability to get resources, then it doesn\u2019t seem like he can do very much,\u201d Mr. Garber said.\n\nThe voters, however, would eventually have a say. Democrats have signaled that they would take a much more aggressive posture if they take the majority. Liberals say they already feel that their political base favors removing the president.\n\nRepresentative Jerrold Nadler of New York, the top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, who stands to inherit the chairmanship under Democratic control, has resisted telegraphing what steps he would take if his party were to retake the House. But he has made clear he would not stand by idly.\n\n\u201cShould a red line be crossed, and firing the special counsel or throttling his investigation are red lines, then there would be a total sea change in the political landscape of the country,\u201d he said at a recent news conference. \u201cAnd at that point, all options would be on the table.\u201d", "title": "Even Republicans Have Used the \u2018I\u2019 Word, but Would Firing Mueller Get Trump Impeached?", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "But when he became dean of student life at Haverford College last summer and started seeing\n\nlow-income students going through the same challenges he had, he decided to do something about it.\n\nHe helped spearhead the Low-Income and First-In-Their-Family Assistance and Resources program, which offers low-income students financial assistance to cover unexpected expenses. They could include academic-related costs, such as art supplies, laptop repair fees and dance class shoes. ,It also includes nonacademic costs, like winter coats, emergency medical and dental treatment, and help with plane tickets for unexpected trips home because of a family emergency or even to get home over winter break.\n\nSince the program began in September 2017, it has handled 115 requests from 78 students at a cost of about $25,000, Mr. Martinez said. (The school has 1,250 students).\n\nHaverford is among a growing number of colleges that have set up programs to help low-income students with unexpected financial expenses. Among them are Brown University, the University of Chicago, Washington University, Swarthmore College, Syracuse University and Williams College.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve known students who contemplated dropping out \u2014 not because they couldn\u2019t do the work, but because they felt they didn\u2019t have enough money to buy new clothes or commute to school or a family member was sick and they couldn\u2019t travel to see that family member,\u201d said Ohiro Oni-Eseleh, a psychotherapist for 25 years and now director of the School of Social Work at Adelphi University\u2019s Hudson Valley Center in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Then Mr. Georgiou dug into the hotel\u2019s history, reading and talking with people whose memories reached back decades. He was looking to assemble a room-by-room history of who had done what and where, arranged according to the room numbers on the doors. Then he called Guernsey\u2019s, an auction house that has found buyers for everything from Rembrandts and Renoirs to a $3 million baseball to one of Les Paul\u2019s guitars.\n\n\u201cThe doors are anything but beautiful,\u201d said Arlan Ettinger, the president of Guernsey\u2019s. \u201cSome of them have big spray-can X\u2019s to indicate the throw-it-out kind of thing. At Claro in Brooklyn, T. J. Steele, the chef and an owner of the restaurant, also has a brand of mezcal, El Buho. He has worked with Il Laboratorio del Gelato in Manhattan to create four gelatos flavored with El Buho. Most are named for the type of agave used to make the spirit, like Espadin, the mildest, and Tepeztate, with the smokiest flavor. Tobala and A\u00f1ejo are the others, all subtly different: $4.50 for two scoops at Il Laboratorio del Gelato stores; a flight of all four varieties, with oranges, $10, at Claro, 284 Third Avenue (President Street), Gowanus, Brooklyn, 347-721-3146, clarobk.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. But to do it consistently throughout the grid takes some work, and Mr. Schultz has clearly put in that work. You have to stare at your grid until eye strain sets in, making sure that no TSK TSK or TJMAXX sneaks in. You have to resist the urge to add those lovely, Scrabbly entries in yourself, and that\u2019s not easy for a constructor. So kudos to Mr. Schultz for his restraint.\n\nIt\u2019s not a challenging theme to figure out \u2014 unless having it escape you completely counts as challenging \u2014 but there\u2019s a place for puzzles like this one, I think. Noticing the oddities of our language within the boundaries of a square grid is what making crossword puzzles is all about.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nNo real trickiness here, unless you are not a fan of DEVO (11D).\n\n52D: Wordplay alert! \u201cWhat makes a ewe turn?\u201d is a play on the word U-turn, but in today\u2019s puzzle, the ewe is eyeing a RAM.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nWhen I originally submitted this puzzle, I sent in two versions: one with the reveal in the SE and one with the reveal at 1-Across. I could see the fun in both having the vowel hint to help fill out the grid (as would be the case if it was the first clue) and as having it as a more traditional reveal. Will liked the traditional way, which suited me just fine. Another interesting twist was how to treat \u201cY\u201d: when is it a vowel and when is it not? I ended up removing all Ys in the rewrite to avoid the confusion (though was really sorry to lose the crossing of \u201cODE TO JOY\u201d and \u201cYO MAMA JOKE\u201d). This is my second Times puzzle, and while the excitement of the accomplishment is less the second go around, it is only ever so slightly less. I\u2019ve got a frame picked out and a place on my wall already chosen. Here\u2019s to running out of wall space before either my brain gives out or our robot overlords make crossword constructors expendable.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. Mr. Puigdemont can still be extradited on the less serious charge of misuse of funds to hold Catalonia\u2019s banned independence referendum last year.\n\nAfter Catalonia declared independence last fall, Spain\u2019s central government dissolved the regional Parliament and charged its leaders with sedition, a move which prompted Mr. Puigdemont to flee into exile in Brussels. Pecker, is a friend of President Trump\u2019s, misled her into signing the contract. It also claimed that Mr. Cohen had inappropriately intervened in the deal. A.M.I. had denied misleading her.\n\nThe deal and the extent of Mr. Cohen\u2019s role in it are the subjects of a wide-ranging federal corruption investigation that is, in part, looking into his efforts to protect Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential prospects in 2016.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA.M.I. indicated earlier this month that it would fight Ms. McDougal, asking the Los Angeles Superior Court to dismiss her lawsuit.\n\nBut that was roughly a week before federal investigators obtained email communications, audio recordings and other documentation from Mr. Cohen during their raid of his office, home and hotel room. Those materials included information about A.M.I. and the McDougal suit, people involved in the case said.\n\nThe suit also claimed that Mr. Cohen had been secretly involved in the talks between A.M.I. and Ms. McDougal\u2019s lawyer at the time, Keith M. Davidson \u2014 who emailed Mr. Cohen at the end of the negotiations. A spokesman for Mr. Davidson has said the lawyer \u201cfulfilled his obligations and zealously advocated for Ms. McDougal.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA.M.I. also spoke with Mr. Cohen about Ms. McDougal, though it says it did so only as part of its reporting process.\n\nMr. Stris said that before reaching the settlement, he was prepared to answer A.M.I.\u2019s motion to dismiss Ms. McDougal\u2019s case with a request for a limited version of pretrial discovery. The move, compelling both sides to share emails and other records, could have provided information that would not be available through the material the F.B.I. seized from Mr. Cohen. An A.M.I. lawyer, Cameron Stracher, said that he doubted the request would have succeeded, and that avoiding discovery was not a motivating factor in the settlement.\n\nThe agreement precludes any of that from happening, at least in Ms. McDougal\u2019s civil case against A.M.I., though Mr. Stris said he expected federal investigators to eventually secure everything they needed to fully vet the process behind the deal. \u201cI have tremendous confidence in the men and women of the Southern District of New York,\u201d he said, referring to the federal prosecutors investigating Mr. Cohen.\n\nMr. Stris said he did not rule out taking legal action if more came to light about potentially inappropriate contact between Mr. Cohen and Mr. Davidson during the course of negotiating her deal. The settlement does not bar Ms. McDougal from claims against either of the men in the future. For now, Ms. McDougal said, \u201cI need to relax and get my life back and de-stress.\u201d\n\nThe initial deal prohibited Ms. McDougal from speaking about her alleged affair, but A.M.I. amended the contract after the election to allow her to answer \u201clegitimate press inquiries,\u201d in response to her complaints that the agreement was overly restrictive. In recent months, she has spoken to The New Yorker and Anderson Cooper of CNN.\n\nSeparate from the federal investigation into Mr. Cohen, A.M.I. is facing a complaint at the Federal Election Commission that its $150,000 payment to Ms. McDougal was an illegal campaign expenditure. The publisher has denied this and says it acts solely as a news organization with a First Amendment right to run stories \u2014 or not run them \u2014 as it chooses.", "title": "Ex-Playboy Model, Freed From Contract, Can Discuss Alleged Trump Affair", "authors": ["Jim Rutenberg"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. da Silva is the first former Brazilian president to be remanded into custody since democracy was restored in the mid-1980s and the first former president to have been convicted of corruption.\n\nHis imprisonment represents perhaps the biggest triumph in the yearslong effort by a team of crusading judges and prosecutors to upend the endemic graft that has long been a staple of politics and deal making in Brazil.\n\nBefore surrendering to federal police authorities, Mr. da Silva, 72, accused prosecutors and judges of knowingly pursuing a baseless case against him.\n\n\u201cI do not forgive them for creating the impression that I am a thief,\u201d an indignant Mr. da Silva, sounding hoarse, told a throng of gathered outside a metalworkers union headquarters outside of S\u00e3o Paulo. For hours on Saturday, in a tense standoff, his ardent supporters had physically blocked his surrender, before finally allowing him to leave.\n\nThe prosecution, Mr. da Silva charged, was an effort to thwart his vision of a country in which ever more poor people could enroll in universities, go on vacation and buy cars and homes.\n\n\u201cIf that was the crime I committed, I want to say that I will continue being a criminal because we\u2019re going to accomplish much more,\u201d Mr. da Silva shouted to a crowd that had spent much of the morning chanting that he should not surrender.\n\nDuring his last hours of freedom, Mr. da Silva appeared to acknowledge that his political career is over \u2014 at least for now.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou will have to transform yourselves,\u201d he told supporters. \u201cThey must know that the death of a combatant doesn\u2019t end a revolution.\u201d\n\nMonths away from Election Day, Brazil\u2019s political left now finds itself without an obvious standard-bearer.\n\nMr. da Silva did not anoint a successor to take his place on the ballot, suggesting that Workers\u2019 Party leaders have yet to decide who stands the best chance of filling the void.\n\nBut, notably, he did single out for compliments two leftist presidential hopefuls from other parties who were with him on stage, Manuela d\u2019\u00c1vila and Guilherme Boulos.\n\nOther candidates who remain in the race include Jair Bolsonaro, a far-right lawmaker who has campaigned on a promise of resorting to harsh tactics to restore security in areas plagued by violence; and a former environmental minister, Marina Silva, who supports the judiciary\u2019s crackdown on corruption and an overhaul of the political system.\n\nBut by ending the presidential candidacy of a leader who remains beloved across much of the country, the move by judicial authorities may have called into question the fairness of the October election.\n\nPhoto\n\nDaniel Aar\u00e3o Reis, a professor of contemporary history at Federal Fluminense University, said that while Mr. da Silva\u2019s prosecution was procedurally sound, it is likely to further shake Brazilians\u2019 faith in democracy, particularly if political rivals who also stand accused of wrongdoing, manage to escape accountability.\n\n\u201cIt worries me because, whether or not the people who provoked this situation meant it, it\u2019s a blow to democracy,\u201d he said. \u201cDemocracy is living a moment of very little prestige.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNo citizen is above the law, and no one, regardless of how important a leader he may have been, or what position he once held, is entitled to make a mockery of justice,\u201d Brazil\u2019s National Association of Prosecutors said in a statement issued Saturday night. \u201cInstitutions are the pillars of democracy.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
