Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Bolsonaro\u2019s reaction to the arrest was minimalist: He tweeted an image of the Brazilian flag.\n\nMr. da Silva left power in 2011 with extraordinarily high approval ratings at home and a reputation as an effective diplomatic mediator abroad.\n\nWashington initially viewed his rise with apprehension, but his rock star status appeared at its peak when President Obama, during a meeting of heads of state in London in 2009, called Mr. da Silva \u201cthe most popular politician on Earth.\u201d\n\nBrazil appeared to be on a breathtaking rise when Mr. da Silva left office in 2011, poised to cash in on new, enormous oil reserves, and revel in the spotlight that the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro would cast on the country of almost 210 million people.\n\nBut his party\u2019s legacy was marred in 2014, when prosecutors began unraveling a giant, convoluted kickback scheme as part of an investigation that became known as Lava Jato, or Car Wash, that has so far resulted in the conviction of 120 people and billions of dollars in restitution payments.\n\nThe investigation crippled the state-run oil company, Petrobras, and the giant construction firm, Odebrecht, and contributed to a devastating recession that paved the way for Ms. Rousseff\u2019s impeachment, which deeply polarized Brazilians.\n\nThe charges Mr. da Silva were convicted of were a small chapter in the annals of Lava Jato. He was found guilty last July of accepting a seaside apartment in return for contracts awarded to the construction company O.A.S.\n\nAfter a three-judge panel upheld the conviction in January, Mr. da Silva asked the country\u2019s two top courts to allow him to remain free while other appeals were considered, but his petitions were rejected.\n\nMr. da Silva is slated to start serving the sentence in a specially configured cell at the federal police headquarters in the southern city of Curitiba, a building he was on hand to inaugurate as president in 2007.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. da Silva\u2019s legal team said Saturday night that he would continue to appeal his conviction before Brazil\u2019s top courts. He is a defendant in at least seven other cases.\n\nMr. da Silva will be detained in a small bedroom with a simple, wooden bed, a small table and two windows on the fourth floor of the building.\n\nAs news of his arrest broke shortly before 7 p.m., some Brazilians who opposed his re-election celebrated across the country by setting off fireworks and honking horns.\n\n\u201cDecent Brazilians are celebrating this historic moment. Justice has been served,\u201d Jo\u00e3o Doria, a former mayor of S\u00e3o Paulo, who is believed to have presidential aspirations, said in a statement.\n\nSupporters saw his imprisonment as a tragic end of an era that had brought enormous hope and pride to Brazil.\n\n\u201cBrazil went from having the pop star of international politics to having a supporting actor for a vampire film,\u201d the former foreign minister Celso Amorim said, referring to a parody of Mr. Temer by a samba school during the recent Carnival parade in Rio de Janeiro. \u201cWe get really sad.\u201d\n\nOpposing groups of protesters awaited Mr. da Silva\u2019s arrival outside the building where he will be held in Curitiba.\n\nA few hundred supporters wearing the Workers\u2019 Party trademark red chanted to the beat of drums \u201cFree Lula,\u201d and sang a jingle from his first presidential campaign in 1989.\n\nA smaller group of critics of the former president, meanwhile, beat pots and pans as they chanted: \u201cLula, you thief, your place is in prison.\u201d", "title": "Ex-President \u2018Lula\u2019 of Brazil Surrenders to Serve 12-Year Jail Term", "authors": ["Manuela Andreoni", "Ernesto Londo\u00f1o", "Shasta Darlington"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "She also noted that the prosecutors who interviewed Mr. van der Zwaan were in the midst of an investigation \u201cof great national and international interest\u201d involving possible \u201cforeign interference in our country\u2019s democratic process.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou knew better,\u201d she told Mr. van der Zwaan, a 33-year-old Dutch citizen who lives in London. \u201cI can\u2019t just say, \u2018Pay a fine and go.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. van der Zwaan\u2019s relationship with the other men dates to at least 2012. His law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, assigned him to work with Mr. Gates and Mr. Manafort on a report used to defend their client Viktor F. Yanukovych, the pro-Russia former president of Ukraine, from international criticism over the prosecution and imprisonment of a political rival.\n\nMr. Manafort and Mr. Gates have been charged with money laundering and other financial crimes related to their work as consultants in Ukraine. Some of the accusations stem from more than $5 million in payments from the Ukrainian government for the law firm\u2019s report, which were funneled through a bank account in Cyprus controlled by Mr. Manafort and Mr. Gates, court records show.\n\nMr. Gates has pleaded guilty to financial fraud and lying to federal investigators and is cooperating with Mr. Mueller\u2019s inquiry. Mr. Manafort, who has pleaded not guilty, is arguing that the special counsel overstepped his authority by delving into his payments from Ukraine.\n\nBut a newly released memo written by Deputy Attorney General Rod J. Rosenstein last summer shows that he specifically authorized the special counsel to investigate any crimes related to payments to Mr. Manafort from the Ukrainian government as well as allegations that he conspired with the Russian government to interfere in the election. A heavily redacted version of the Aug. 2 memo was released Monday night as part of a court filing in Mr. Manafort\u2019s case.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJust days after Mr. Manafort and Mr. Gates were first indicted, federal prosecutors questioned Mr. van der Zwaan about his contacts with Mr. Gates and Mr. Kilimnik. Mr. van der Zwaan acknowledged that Mr. Gates had told him that Mr. Kilimnik was a former Russian intelligence officer. But he claimed that he had had no substantive conversations with either man in 2016.\n\nIn fact, he has now admitted, he had had a series of phone calls with both men about potential criminal charges related to payments from the Ukrainian government.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat information indicated that Mr. Gates and Mr. Kilimnik were in direct touch with each other as the presidential campaign drew to a close in September and October of 2016, a fact Mr. Weissman argued in court papers \u201cwas pertinent to the investigation.\u201d\n\nProsecutors said Mr. van der Zwaan not only deceived federal agents, but also concealed information from his own law firm, which has since fired him.\n\nWhile the lead prosecutor on the case, Andrew Weissmann, did not explicitly ask for a prison sentence, he insisted that Mr. van der Zwaan told the truth only after he \u201cwas caught red-handed\u201d in various falsehoods and had been handed a grand jury subpoena.\n\nDuring his second meeting with Mr. Mueller\u2019s team, Mr. van der Zwaan voluntarily turned over the very evidence that resulted in his felony charge, including notes, recordings, laptops and cellphones, his defense lawyer, William J. Schwartz, argued. But Mr. Weissman denied that any of that was crucial, telling the judge that \u201cthe case was already made.\u201d\n\nJudge Jackson said Mr. van der Zwaan was guilty of not simply a single lapse in judgment, but a broader pattern of concealment because of \u201ca mix of motives\u201d that she did not clearly understand.\n\nShe was unmoved, she said, by his argument that he had been stranded alone in a hotel in the United States since December. She dismissed his brief statement of contrition as \u201clip service.\u201d While others had written letters to her asking her to be merciful to Mr. van der Zwaan, she said, \u201cthe accomplished lawyer did not write one himself.\u201d\n\nThe crime of false statements to federal authorities carries up to a five-year prison term. But sentencing guidelines suggested that Mr. van der Zwaan, who has no prior criminal record, receive at most six months.\n\nHe agreed to turn himself in voluntarily. It is unclear where he will serve his 30-day term; the judge said he might wind up in the District of Columbia jail. Although she imposed a short probation term, she said that once he is released, Mr. van der Zwaan can collect his passport and return home to London to his wife, who is pregnant.", "title": "Ex-Skadden Lawyer Is Sentenced to 30 Days in Russia Inquiry", "authors": ["Sharon Lafraniere"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Last spring my dad sent my siblings and me a one-line email titled \u201cHelp, Please\u201d that read, \u201cNeed you to get whatever you want from home by early May or give us go ahead to toss or give away.\u201d A month later my sisters and I flew home to Cincinnati for the weekend to purge our childhood belongings, in anticipation of my parents\u2019 downsizing. A rented dumpster greeted us in the driveway.\n\nIn 1984, my parents moved our family into the house where my three siblings and I grew up. When I was 10, I got my own room. I spent the next eight years in a room with a chartreuse rug that came with the house. All through high school I sat on the floor to do my homework and make collages from Seventeen and Us Weekly. I cut out listings from TV Guide and wrote in my diary about how much I loved \u201cMy So-Called Life.\u201d I wrote notes to my friends and folded them in intricate ways. Twenty years ago, I graduated from high school and have not lived in Cincinnati since.", "title": "Excavating My \u201990s-Era Childhood Bedroom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Netflix\u2019s new big-budget series \u201cLost in Space,\u201d which debuts on Friday, looks like a vision of the future. But for many longtime television watchers it\u2019s a blast from the past.\n\nThe original version of \u201cLost in Space,\u201d which aired on CBS from 1965 to 1968, is one of the foundational texts of a certain kind of disposable television. Created by Irwin Allen at the apogee of the space race, what began as a \u201cSwiss Family Robinson\u201d for the rocket age soon evolved into an intergalactic \u201cGilligan\u2019s Island.\u201d It was predictable, it was repetitive, and let\u2019s face it, it was often incredibly stupid. But if you watched its original run (or if you\u2019ve seen it in reruns), you know it to be one of the more delightful, candy-coated morsels of classic American TV.\n\nMoreover, for viewers who first experienced the show as kids, there was nothing funnier than hearing Dr. Smith call a Michelin Man crossed with a gumball machine a \u201cbubble-headed boobie!\u201d If you want to reminisce or prime yourself for the reboot, all 84 episodes are streaming on Hulu. But to borrow from the Robot: \u201cWarning! An end-to-end binge does not compute!\u201d Here\u2019s what you need to know.\n\nFrom left, Angela Cartwright, Bill Mumy and Marta Kristen in \u201cLost in Space.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\nWho\u2019s Who on the Jupiter 2?\n\nThe lasting influence of \u201cLost in Space\u201d is partially due to its production design \u2014 alien costumes, ray guns and a remarkable number of earthquakes \u2014 but also its endearing characters.\n\nProfessor John Robinson (the \u201cZorro\u201d star, Guy Williams) and Maureen Robinson (June Lockhart from \u201cLassie\u201d) were strong Great Society stand-ins. With them was their eldest daughter, Judy (the Norwegian actress Marta Kristen, best known for playing a mermaid in \u201cBeach Blanket Bingo\u201d); their middle child, Penny (Angela Cartwright, recognizable from \u201cThe Danny Thomas Show\u201d and \u201cThe Sound of Music\u201d); and the kid genius, Will (Billy Mumy, whose later endeavors include forming the band Barnes & Barnes and recording the novelty hit \u201cFish Heads\u201d).\n\nThe Robinsons left earth aboard their circular ship, The Jupiter 2, in a fictional 1997, in hopes of becoming the first family to colonize another planet. (They were headed to Alpha Centauri, which is a star and not a planet, but let\u2019s not get into that now.) The Jupiter 2 featured light speed capability but also the galaxy\u2019s slowest elevator. It was piloted by Major Don West (Mark Goddard), an underdeveloped love interest for Judy. He wore a white T-shirt a lot for someone in outer space.\n\n0\n\nJonathan Harris in \u201cLost in Space.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\nNever Fear, Smith Is Here!\n\nAccording to cast interviews, the mincing, bullheaded, cowardly Dr. Smith was meant to be written out after the initial episodes. But as Jonathan Harris, the actor who played him, has said, he soon began reworking the character, adding more zest to his already flamboyant line readings. Allen, the show\u2019s creator, apparently liked the changes. By the middle of Season 1, \u201cLost in Space\u201d aired opposite the campy Adam West-led \u201cBatman\u201d on Wednesdays at 7:30. Our interstellar explorers found their groove once the lovably annoying Dr. Smith started screeching at his mechanized, stentorian straight man, the Model B-9 Environmental Robot \u2014 usually referred to as simply the Robot.\n\nIn the first episode (\u201cThe Reluctant Stowaway\u201d) Dr. Smith is an evil foreign saboteur. We never do discover whom he is working for, but we do learn that he is a bit of a klutz. His bumbling gets him (forgive me) lost in space with the Robinsons and Major West, alongside the Robot. Even though the beginning episodes show Smith trying actively to murder everyone else, he still somehow became the heart of the show. (Hulu lists \u201cThe Reluctant Stowaway\u201d as Episode 2 because of the series pilot, which did not originally air. Season 1 episode numbers will be identified here according to Hulu\u2019s practice.)\n\nFrom left, June Lockhart, Jonathan Harris, Angela Cartwright and Marta Kristen in \u201cLost in Space.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\nNickel-Plated Nincompoop!\n\nThe early dialogue with the Robot has a call-and-response rhythm that isn\u2019t far removed from telling Alexa to dim the lights. But Harris rewrote his own scenes, and his alliterative barbs against the deadpan, baritone Robot (voiced by Dick Tufeld) harmonized beautifully with the optimism of the Robinson kids.\n\nDr. Smith\u2019s insults ranged from \u201caddlepated armorer\u201d to \u201cwobbling weakling,\u201d and at first the Robot merely blurted, \u201cDanger!\u201d or \u201cWarning!\u201d in response. His comeback zings started subtly \u2014 \u201cWhat do you want from me, blood?\u201d is a breakthrough moment from \u201cA Change of Space\u201d in Season 1 \u2014 and by Season 2, it is an all-out volley of invective. \u201cAsk me no questions, and I\u2019ll tell you no lies, Earth creature!\u201d the Robot sasses in \u201cThe Ghost Planet\u201d (Season 2), inasmuch as an affectless \u201ctintinnabulating tin can\u201d can sass.\n\nThe most famous catchphrase of the series, \u201cDanger, Will Robinson,\u201d is something of a misremembered phenomenon, like Rick Blaine\u2019s \u201cPlay it again, Sam\u201d from \u201cCasablanca\u201d (he never said it) or Captain Kirk\u2019s \u201cBeam me up, Scotty\u201d from \u201cStar Trek\u201d (he came close). The robot often shouted \u201cDanger!\u201d and addressed the youngest Robinson rather formally, but the actual phrase is heard only in the episode \u201cDeadliest of the Species\u201d (Season 3), and the robot is comparatively mellow when he says it: He is merely suggesting they use caution as they investigate a fallen meteorite.\n\nAngela Cartwright and John Carradine in \u201cLost in Space.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\nThis Week\u2019s Guest\n\nNotable faces included a young Kurt Russell as an alien boy whose behavior mirrors thinly understood Native American customs (\u201cThe Challenge,\u201d Season 1); Warren Oates as space cowboy (\u201cWelcome Stranger,\u201d Season 1); and John Carradine as a bald, purple shape-shifter, pursued by a band of villainous creatures (\u201cThe Galaxy Gift,\u201d Season 2).\n\nMost of the weekly guests were character actors or old vaudevillians, among them Fritz Feld as the proprietor of a pan-dimensional department store (\u201cThe Android Machine\u201d), whose trademark schtick of popping his lips is generously exploited. Such grace notes seem unlikely in Netflix\u2019s reboot. (They were certainly missing from the joyless 1998 film starring William Hurt and Gary Oldman.)\n\nJonathan Harris in \u201cLost in Space.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\nHow to Watch: Top 10 Episodes\n\nTo repeat: This is not one to binge. The show gets more repetitive than a low Earth orbit, and there is rarely a true narrative thread connecting each episode. But it\u2019s good fun to skip around.\n\nSeason 1\n\nThe first season of \u201cLost in Space\u201d begins rich in nutritious Space Race-era exceptionalism and with some genuine \u201cTwilight Zone\u201d-style spooks before it goes full goofy. \u201cThe Reluctant Stowaway\u201d (Episode 2 on Hulu) gives the series escape velocity, so it is worth checking out. \u201cThe Magic Mirror\u201d (Episode 22) is a Penny-focused episode (both Cartwright and Mumy were gifted child actors), in which she is trapped in a pocket universe with a creepy a lonely, stalker-ish boy played by Michael J. Pollard (\u201cBonnie and Clyde\u201d). This episode also features her pet, Debbie the bloop, which was bascially a chimpanzee with giant, fuzzy ears.\n\n0\n\nThe Season 1 finale, \u201cFollow the Leader\u201d (Episode 30) is a bit of an anomaly because of its seriousness. Professor Robinson becomes possessed by an ancient spirit and only Will\u2019s love can conquer it.\n\nSeason 2\n\nThe second season brought color and velour costumes. \u201cThe Ghost Planet\u201d (Episode 3) visits a robot-run world and shows that Dr. Smith is still willing to sell out his comrades for wealth. Although the Robinsons always forgive Dr. Smith, Major West once again volunteers to drop the stowaway off on the nearest rock. \u201cThe Android Machine\u201d (Episode 7) introduces a female android who imprints herself on Dr. Smith and ruffles the Robot\u2019s circuits. (Even robots can have their feelings hurt.) \u201cThe Dream Monster\u201d (Episode 14) features an alien who, with the aid of Dr. Smith and a weird Polaroid-type device, steals emotions from the Robinsons, leaving them drained of personality.\n\n\u201cThe Golden Man\u201d (Episode 15) is possibly a Vietnam parable, as the Robinsons decide whether to get involved in a fight between a frog-headed alien and a charming man who offers Dr. Smith caviar.\n\nSeason 3\n\nThe third and final season zooms at faster-than-light speed to some of television\u2019s silliest hours. \u201cVisit to a Hostile Planet\u201d (Episode 2) gets the Jupiter 2 back to Earth, but through a time warp. (Yes, \u201cStar Trek\u201d did the same thing.) Our gang is stuck in the American Midwest in 1947, and the mix of nostalgia and futurism is extraordinary. \u201cThe Promised Planet\u201d (Episode 19) shows what happens when the Jupiter 2 runs afoul of space hippies. (It means Dr. Smith starts groovin\u2019 out and shouting \u201cIt\u2019s, like, freaky, man, real freaky.\u201d)\n\nLastly \u201cThe Great Vegetable Rebellion\u201d (Episode 23) one of the most notoriously awful episodes in the entire run, is essential viewing if you want to watch Dr. Smith transformed into an enormous stalk of celery.\n\nDon\u2019t worry about watching the final episode. They never get home.\n\nInterested in more movies and TV shows with explosions in space? Try these titles.", "title": "Excited for Netflix\u2019s New \u2018Lost in Space\u2019? Here\u2019s What to Know About the Original", "authors": ["Jordan Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhite House Withdraws Jackson Nomination for V.A. Chief Amid Criticism\u201d (nytimes.com, April 26):\n\nThe fact that Dr. Ronny L. Jackson withdrew his nomination as secretary of veterans affairs reinforces the failure of Donald Trump as an effective administrator. Additionally, it reveals that President Trump\u2019s vetting process (if there is one) is not working.\n\nTaken together with the wide turnover of other people from the Trump administration, it is truly a reflection of who Mr. Trump is: a reactive and emotional manager, not thoughtful, knowledgeable, detailed or a rational leader.\n\nSo much for his campaign proclamations that he will select only \u201ctop-of-the-line professionals\u201d and only the \u201cbest and most serious people\u201d to fill his administration. Sure thing, Mr. Trump!\n\nMICHAEL HADJIARGYROU\n\nCENTERPORT, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\n\u201cWhat do you need this for?\u201d President Trump said he asked Dr. Ronny L. Jackson, his then foundering nominee to head the Department of Veterans Affairs.", "title": "Opinion | Exit Dr. Jackson: Trump\u2019s Vetting Process (if Any) Isn\u2019t Working", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Federal officials will investigate the circumstances around the rental of a condominium last year by Scott Pruitt, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, from the wife of an energy lobbyist for $50-a-night, members of Congress announced Friday.\n\nA letter from the E.P.A.\u2019s inspector general notifying Representatives Don Beyer of Virginia and Ted Lieu of California that inspectors intended to take up the inquiry was dated Wednesday but released to lawmakers on Friday.\n\nMr. Pruitt, who testified at back-to-back congressional hearings on Thursday, did not mention that a new investigation had been taken up.\n\nThe developments came on the heels of recent information that Mr. Pruitt met personally with the lobbyist whose wife rented him the $50-a-night condo, despite earlier statements that no lobbying had occurred. Mr. Pruitt\u2019s living arrangement is the subject of multiple inquiries.", "title": "Expenses, Emails and a Phone Booth: The Investigations Faced by Scott Pruitt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Tricky Clues\n\n15A: It\u2019s not that difficult to see why \u201cdolphin-safe\u201d is an ECOLABEL, after the fact. It seemed like a bit of crosswordese to me but there is a governing body that examines a company\u2019s production process to give the labels some credibility. I see these icons and labels and generally accept them, but had never really thought about how a product proved it\u2019s ecological merit. This is a debut, naturally.\n\n25A: This might not have stumped people while solving but it took me a while to make sense of the answer \u2014 am I the only one who didn\u2019t think of D and C STREETS running east to west in Washington, D.C.?\n\n32A: Yet another thing swimmers and rappers have in common \u2014 laps in this case meaning trips across the pool, not shelves formed from sitting. You can FREESTYLE both skills.\n\n55A: Alexandre Dumas has inspired a whole subset of crossword clues with his complicated plotting. The \u201cOttoman ruler\u201d he references is ALI PASHA, or \u201cthe Lion,\u201d who controlled a wide swath of the Ottoman Empire in Europe at the turn of the 19th century.\n\n3D: Another example of international organization, there are abbreviations now for URLs for most countries that differentiate them from the simple \u201cdot com\u201d of a company name. In this case, a \u201cLondon web address\u201d probably ends in DOT CO DOT UK. Assuming that you NETSURF, you\u2019ve probably come upon this and many other country codes, but they often escape my notice.\n\n31D: This is one of a crossing pair of Mr. Ezersky\u2019s \u201cDeparture announcements\u201d: ALL ABOARD, which I stumbled on but is truly ubiquitous in train travel (and probably boats, although I\u2019m not on the water that often). The admonishment here goes back to 1829 and is a phrase that works when spoken in French too, \u201cAllez bord,\u201d so the etymology may stem from l\u2019autre side of the pond. (The twin at 52A is SO LONG, the origins of which I\u2019ve never really thought of much but turns out to have a fascinating array of possible cousins in the world.)\n\n41D: I read \u201cOpposite of free\u201d as a description so I entered \u201ccaptive\u201d and got stuck on it for a good while; ENSLAVE came at the end when I figured out O HENRY at 44A.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nSecond puzzle in a fortnight! If you weren\u2019t sick of me after my April Fool\u2019s offering, then perhaps you\u2019ll be sick of me now \u2026 my seeds for this were indeed the ridiculous-looking MICRO-USB and the even-more-ridiculous-looking DOT CO DOT UK. For those of you that like your Saturdays on the crazy side, I hope I\u2019ve hit the sweet spot with that crossing from hell. For everyone else that found themselves muttering certain four-letter words at myself or the puzzle, perhaps there was at least a bit to enjoy in the remaining 66 answers. If you don\u2019t see my byline in the next two weeks (you shouldn\u2019t), it\u2019s because I\u2019ve gone into hiding. I have no need for RIOT GEAR. P.S.: The word \u201cweb\u201d was originally omitted from the clue for 3-Down. Consider yourselves lucky.\n\nThe Friendly Sherpa\n\nNot sure what to say in every situation? You can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Expressions of Affection", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump\u2019s re-election campaign has ramped up its fund-raising this year, bringing in $20.2 million, while investing heavily in cultivating a wide base of small donors, according to reports filed Sunday afternoon with the Federal Election Commission.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s campaign apparatus spent nearly $8.2 million through the end of last month, with more than 60 percent of that going toward low-dollar fund-raising tools such as solicitations delivered via social media, email, direct mail and telemarketing, the reports show.\n\nThe reports were filed by Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign and two joint committees it formed with the Republican National Committee: Trump Victory Committee and Trump Make America Great Again Committee.\n\nThe committees also spent $863,000 on legal fees as Mr. Trump, his campaign and associates continue to deal with a handful of legal fights, as well as the special counsel investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 campaign.", "title": "Eyeing 2020, Trump Fund-Raisers Return to Familiar Well: Small Donors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "The violation carries a fine of up to $250, and Trooper Lewis accompanied every ticket he issued on Friday with a stern roadside lecture on the risks. \u201cI hope that I\u2019m teaching them,\u201d he said. \u201cDistracted driving will either kill yourself, or you\u2019re going to kill others.\u201d\n\nSasha Acosta, 26, said she knew the risks, and feared for the safety of her 2-year-old child from distracted drivers. That\u2019s why she activated a feature on her phone that turns off rings and pings when it senses she is driving. But on Friday, as she turned into the medical clinic where she works in Kiryas Joel, it didn\u2019t stop her from fiddling with a music video on YouTube. She was listening to it when Trooper Lewis caught her. \u201cI\u2019m a mom, I know better,\u201d she said, shaking her head.\n\nSome people pleaded innocence; one woman told the eagle-eyed trooper he was mistaken, until he told her the color, make and model of the phone he had seen her using as she drove by. Others said they unwittingly succumbed to the siren song of their phone. Robert Rivera, a retired New York police officer, scrolled through his phone as he turned across several lanes onto Dunning Road in Wallkill. \u201cYou don\u2019t realize you\u2019re doing it,\u201d he said, explaining that he had been trying to make a doctor\u2019s appointment as he drove his Chevy Suburban, barely looking up from his phone.\n\nIn the youth Bible class she teaches at church, Shelli Joyner, 50, a nurse, warns her students about the risks of distracted driving. Over 30 percent of fatalities ascribed to distracted driving in 2015 were drivers under 29, according to the federal safety administration. And as a registered nurse, she said she has tended to victims of such crashes. But on Friday morning she was conversing with her sister on speakerphone while holding the phone up to her mouth, as she drove her Cadillac S.U.V. down Academy Avenue in Middletown.\n\n\u201cI am a nurse, I know how very dangerous this is, I instill this in my children, and of course I fall victim to it,\u201d Ms. Joyner said. \u201cWe all know it\u2019s wrong.\u201d\n\nShe would be taking the lesson, and the citation, to her youth group that evening, she said. \u201cI want them to know they\u2019re serious about this,\u201d she said. \u201cThank God I didn\u2019t get into an accident.\u201d\n\nTrooper Lewis wrote out the citation. As he got back in his car, Ms. Joyner said the lesson hit home. \u201cFive points on my license!\u201d she screamed.", "title": "Eyes on the Road: New York State Police Are Cracking Down on Distracted Drivers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration on Friday issued an emergency order instructing airlines with the same type of engine as the one that failed catastrophically on Tuesday on a Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 to more thoroughly inspect the engines\u2019 fan blades.\n\nThe agency told airlines to perform ultrasonic inspections \u2014 which can detect flaws or cracks not visible to the unaided human eye \u2014 within the next 20 days on fan blades of engines with more than 30,000 cycles. A cycle includes an engine start, takeoff, landing and shutdown.\n\nThe F.A.A.\u2019s order came shortly after the manufacturer of the engines, CFM International, issued guidelines for the ultrasonic inspections. CFM, a joint venture of General Electric and the French company Safran Aircraft Engines, went further than the F.A.A., recommending that fan blades with 20,000 cycles be inspected by the end of August. It also recommended inspections of all other fan blades when they reach 20,000 cycles, and repeating the inspections every 3,000 cycles, which, it said, \u201crepresents about two years in service.\u201d\n\nThe F.A.A. said it was acting because it determined that fan blade cracking \u201cis likely to exist or develop in other products of the same type design.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe agency\u2019s order does not address those lesser-used engines, but said it was \u201cconsidering further rule making to address these differences.\u201d Airlines are not legally bound to follow a company\u2019s guidelines. They are bound by the F.A.A. directive.", "title": "F.A.A. Orders Closer Engine Inspections After Southwest Airlines Failure", "authors": ["Zach Wichter"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Porter\u2019s former wives have said the F.B.I. interviewed them about their abuse claims in January 2017. Mr. Porter himself also alerted Mr. McGahn that an aggrieved ex-wife was making potentially damaging accusations about him, according to a person familiar with the discussion. Mr. Roberts\u2019s letter says that in August, the bureau received a request from the White House personnel security office for additional information on Mr. Porter, \u201cincluding, but not limited to, re-interviews of Mr. Porter, his ex-wives and his girlfriend at the time.\u201d\n\nIn November, the F.B.I. gave the White House another report, Mr. Roberts wrote, \u201cwhich contained additional derogatory information.\u201d\n\nThe F.B.I.\u2019s timeline is at odds with the one given by top officials including John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, who acknowledged in March that he had stumbled in his response to the allegations against Mr. Porter but insisted that he had not known of the damaging accusations until the week Mr. Porter left.\n\nBackground investigations often uncover derogatory information, and one person familiar with Mr. Porter\u2019s said the allegations of abuse and the circumstances surrounding them were not as clear-cut as they were portrayed to be when they surfaced in the press, making it difficult to discern whether they warranted action. Even though the White House now appears to have known for months about the claims against Mr. Porter, his temporary clearance was never revoked.\n\nThe White House\u2019s contention that Mr. McGahn never saw the original F.B.I. report comes as it is facing fresh questions about its process for vetting personnel for top posts in Mr. Trump\u2019s administration, after Dr. Ronny L. Jackson, the White House physician who was his pick to be the secretary of veterans affairs, withdrew on Thursday amid damaging allegations that he drank on the job, overprescribed medication and presided over a hostile work environment.\n\nLike Dr. Jackson, Mr. Porter was among a small circle of senior officials who spent their days in proximity to Mr. Trump. As staff secretary, Mr. Porter handled the reams of sensitive documents that flow through the president\u2019s office daily. The allegations against him were one reason he could not obtain a permanent security clearance, and the scandal surrounding his departure highlighted a pattern at the White House of allowing senior officials who had not been given permanent clearance to see classified information to serve in the highest echelons of the White House.\n\nMr. Kelly has since revised clearance procedures at the White House, stripping interim clearances from some senior officials who had been working with temporary ones for months, most prominently Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser.", "title": "F.B.I. Agents raided space Mr. Cohen uses in the Rockefeller Center office of the law firm Squire Patton Boggs, as well as a room Mr. Cohen is staying in at the Loews Regency Hotel on Park Avenue while his apartment is under renovation, the person said.\n\n[Read our February 2018 profile of Michael D. Cohen]\n\nTo obtain a search warrant, prosecutors must convince a federal judge that agents are likely to discover evidence of criminal activity.\n\nThe searches are a significant intrusion by prosecutors into the dealings of one of Mr. Trump\u2019s closest confidants, and they pose a dilemma for Mr. Trump. He has dismissed Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation as a \u201cwitch hunt,\u201d but these warrants were obtained by an unrelated group of prosecutors. The searches required prior consultation with senior members of Mr. Trump\u2019s own Justice Department.\n\nMr. Trump and Mr. Cohen, however, regarded the searches as an effort by Mr. Mueller to use New York\u2019s prosecutors as his proxy, according to two people close to the men.\n\nThe searches open a new front for the Justice Department in its scrutiny of Mr. Trump and his associates: His longtime lawyer is being investigated in Manhattan; his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, is facing scrutiny by prosecutors in Brooklyn; his former campaign chairman is under indictment; his former national security adviser has pleaded guilty to lying; and a pair of former campaign aides are cooperating with Mr. Mueller. Mr. Mueller, meanwhile, wants to interview Mr. Trump about possible obstruction of justice.\n\nIt is not clear what Mr. Mueller saw that made him refer the matter to other prosecutors. It\u2019s part of a broader examination of streams of foreign money to Mr. Trump and his associates in the years before the election.", "title": "F.B.I., Mark Zuckerberg, \u2018The Simpsons\u2019: Your Monday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "In an emailed statement, Juul Labs said it agreed with the F.D.A. \u201cthat illegal sales of our product to minors is unacceptable.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe already have in place programs to identify and act upon these violations at retail and online marketplaces, and we will have more aggressive plans to announce in the coming days,\u201d the company\u2019s statement said. \u201cWe are working with the F.D.A., lawmakers, parents and community leaders to combat underage use, and we will continue working with all interested parties to keep our product away from youth.\u201d\n\nThe vaping industry has long challenged the argument that the devices are addictive and that flavorings appeal to youth, saying the evidence does not support this.\n\nBut on Tuesday, the F.D.A. came down firmly about the risks. \u201cThe nicotine in these products can rewire an adolescent\u2019s brain, leading to years of addiction,\u201d Dr. Gottlieb said in his statement. He acknowledged that e-cigarettes \u201cmay offer a potentially lower risk alternative for individual adult smokers,\u201d he added. \u201cBut the viability of these products is severely undermined if those products entice youth to start using tobacco and nicotine.\u201d\n\nDr. Gottlieb said Tuesday\u2019s announcement was the first of several steps the agency would be taking as part of a new Youth Tobacco Prevention Plan to get manufacturers to stop marketing e-cigarettes to young people. It has already convinced eBay to stop listing the products. It also asked Juul to turn over documents related to promotional games and contests, as well as anything related to product design and the appeal or addictive potential for youth.\n\nBut while the moves pleased some public health advocates and school administrators concerned about the popularity of \u201cJuuling\u201d among adolescents, other groups say they do not make up for the tremendous break Dr. Gottlieb cut the e-cigarette industry last July, when he allowed manufacturers a five-year extension on a rule that would have required them to prove that their products are a safe alternative to traditional cigarettes.\n\nThe vaping industry had lobbied hard against the rule, arguing that the cost of complying with such regulations would have deterred manufacturers from introducing new products that help adults to quit smoking.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSchools and public health advocates contend that the vaping industry is the latest incarnation of Big Tobacco, developing and promoting its products to create new markets for a younger generation. Juul comes in kid-friendly flavors like mango and cr\u00e8me br\u00fbl\u00e9e. The labels on other e-cigarette flavorings resemble popular candy brands like Jolly Rancher and Blow Pops.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe e-cigarette industry\u2019s political clout has grown as the tobacco giants have taken over the business, which was once limited to small shops and manufacturers. Altria, British American Tobacco, Imperial Tobacco, Philip Morris International and Reynolds American all produce e-cigarettes now. In 2017, according to The Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks federal disclosure reports, the tobacco industry spent nearly $22 million on lobbying.\n\nJuul, which was started by Pax Labs in 2015 and spun off into an independent company last year, is one of the biggest players, increasing its revenue by nearly 700 percent in 2017 to $224.6 million, according to a November report from Nielsen/Wells Fargo. The total e-cigarette market grew by 40 percent last year, to $1.16 billion.\n\nJuul Labs told CNBC in October that while it was producing 20 million devices and flavored pods, it could not keep up with demand. Late last year, it raised more than $110 million in private funding, and hired a new chief executive officer from Chobani, manufacturer of the popular Greek yogurt.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAccording to Monitoring the Future, an annual survey done for the National Institute on Drug Abuse, part of the National Institutes of Health, in 2017, 19 percent of 12th graders, 16 percent of 10th-graders and 8 percent of 8th graders reported vaping nicotine in the past year.\n\nJuul has come under increasing pressure over the last several weeks as parents and schools have become alarmed over how prevalent the devices are.\n\nA coalition of medical and public health advocacy groups led by the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids sued to reverse the F.D.A.\u2019s July extension of the regulations for e-cigarette companies. A group of United States senators led by Dick Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, sent a letter to Juul last week asking questions about marketing and ingredients for the devices and asking the company to do more to prevent minors from buying the devices.\n\nOn Tuesday, the health advocacy groups and lawmakers commended the F.D.A.\u2019s moves, but said the agency must go further and require e-cigarette companies to eliminate flavorings that clearly appeal to youth. They also pushed the F.D.A. again to reverse its July decision.\n\nAccording to the Juul website, the devices create an aerosol rather than using a flame to activate the ingredients. The company says the product produces a level of nicotine similar to a traditional cigarette in order to satisfy cigarette smokers who switch to vaping.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMedical researchers say this makes the Juul more addictive for youth.\n\n\u201cThis is the definition of a double-edged sword,\u201d said Michael Siegel of Boston University, who studies tobacco use.\n\nBecause Juul delivers nicotine in a more effective manner, it is appealing for adult smokers who are trying to give up tobacco cigarettes, he said. \u201cThe first time they use it, they feel the nicotine, they\u2019re more likely to stick with it.\u201d But for teenagers, \u201cit\u2019s a bad thing because it really does create the addiction potential that you don\u2019t have with normal electronic cigarettes.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat we used to see is kids would vape together in social settings, it was showing off who could blow the biggest rings,\u201d he said. \u201cNow we\u2019re starting to see kids who literally are showing signs of addiction: They\u2019re using it alone, we\u2019re seeing kids who have to sneak off to the bathroom during the day.\u201d\n\nSchool health officials say students do not realize how much they are smoking because they \u201cmicrodose\u201d all day. And many do not realize the chemicals in the devices.\n\n\u201cThey think of it as being just not that big a deal,\u201d said Timothy Hayes, the assistant superintendent for student services at New Trier, the large public high school in the Chicago suburbs. \u201cIt\u2019s not smoke, I\u2019m not inhaling, it\u2019s just water vapor, that\u2019s their thinking.\u201d\n\nThe F.D.A. crackdown, he said, could help make the risks clearer. \u201cIt makes public, and makes Juul be public, about the health consequences.\u201d", "title": "F.D.A. Cracks Down on \u2018Juuling\u2019 Among Teenagers", "authors": ["Kate Zernike"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Advocates for development of marijuana-based treatments, and those pushing for better treatments of epilepsy, were pleased with the panel\u2019s recommendation.\n\n\u201cThis is a very good development, and it basically underscores that there are medicinal properties to some of the cannabinoids,\u201d said Dr. Igor Grant, director of the Center for Medicinal Cannabis Research at the University of California San Diego. \u201cI think there could well be other cannabinoids that are of therapeutic use, but there is just not enough research on them to say.\u201d\n\nThe panel recommended approval of the drug to treat two rare forms of epilepsy \u2014 Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and Dravet syndrome. They are among the most difficult types of epilepsy to treat, with nearly all patients continuing to have seizures despite currently available medications, according to the F.D.A. The large number of seizures \u2014 experts say a person can have multiple episodes a day \u2014 puts children at high risk for intellectual and developmental disabilities, as well as death. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome usually appears between ages 3 and 5, and Dravet syndrome earlier.\n\nThere are an estimated 30,000 children and adults with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and fewer than that with Dravet syndrome. Because the conditions are so rare, GW Pharmaceuticals has received an orphan drug designation for Epidiolex.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Panel Recommends Approval of Cannabis-Based Drug for Epilepsy", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Food and Drug Administration on Monday said it would require Bayer to restrict sales of its Essure birth control implant to medical practices like doctors\u2019 offices that agree to fully inform women about the device\u2019s risks.\n\nSince the implant became available 16 years ago, thousands of women have sued Bayer, Essure\u2019s manufacturer, with many claiming they suffered severe injuries, including perforation of the uterus and the fallopian tubes from the metal implant.\n\nTwo years ago, the F.D.A. declined to pull the device off the market, and instead ordered placement of a \u201cblack box warning\u201d on the product package that said it could cause those types of injuries. The warning also noted that the implant can travel into the abdomen and pelvic cavity, causing pain and possibly requiring surgical removal.\n\nConsisting of two small coils, made of a nickel alloy and a polyester-like fiber, the device is placed in the fallopian tubes through the vagina, and is designed to create an inflammatory response that causes scar tissue to form and block the tubes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe F.D.A. said on Monday that from Nov. 4, 2002, when Essure was approved, through December of last year, the agency had received 26,773 reports of adverse events related to the device, although some might be duplicates.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe most frequently reported problems, the F.D.A. said, were pain, menstrual irregularities and headache. Most reports listed multiple conditions suffered by individual patients. There were also reports of deaths, pregnancy loss, ectopic pregnancies and other serious problems.", "title": "F.D.A. Restricts Sales of Bayer\u2019s Essure Contraceptive Implant", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The ousters of his peers left the Malaysian-born Chung as the most senior of FIFA\u2019s vice presidents, a designation that carried with it a $300,000 annual salary and the position of first replacement for FIFA\u2019s president, Gianni Infantino.\n\nChung also was an enthusiastic early supporter of the joint North American bid to stage the World Cup in 2026, pledging his confederation\u2019s collective support as far back as April 2017.\n\nThe audit of the O.F.C. started a year after Infantino\u2019s election in 2016, after FIFA found discrepancies with the headquarters project for which FIFA, then headed by Sepp Blatter, had provided a $10 million loan. O.F.C.\u2019s longtime secretary general, Tai Nicholas, suddenly quit in December, also citing personal reasons.\n\nThe audit found that Chung and Nicholas, without issuing a tender, had hired a company with no experience of the work required for the design of the project, which involved building offices, two soccer fields and other facilities in Auckland, New Zealand.\n\nInvestigators then found a series of close relationships between companies advising the O.F.C. on the project and picked to complete the project. All the companies were set up shortly before being awarded contracts, \u201cwith no track record of experience, and subcontracted their works to other companies,\u201d an executive summary of the PwC report stated. It found that a separate company set up by Chung might have had links to one hired to work on the project.\n\nThe accountants suggested FIFA go to court to find out more. \u201cDue the limitations in assessing the financial records of the external parties it is recommended to commence civil proceedings in New Zealand in order to get access to these records, substantiate or refute the concerns with regards to bribery and corruption this review has raised, and ultimately attempt to recover any potential losses from the third parties,\u201d the report, code-named Project Gunemba, concluded.\n\nDetails of the investigation\u2019s findings were sent to members of the O.F.C. executive board, leading the president of Tahiti\u2019s soccer federation, Thierry Ariiotima, to email Chung last week to explain that he expected FIFA would \u201csuspend you very shortly.\u201d", "title": "FIFA Vice President Quits After Audit Raises Questions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "During his campaign for the presidency of FIFA, Infantino promised fourfold increases in financing for soccer development to member nations. The $25 billion would provide Infantino with enough money to follow through on that commitment ahead of his bid for re-election next year.\n\nOpposition from powerful European soccer officials and some of the continent\u2019s biggest clubs remains strong. Creating the event without the agreement of the world\u2019s best clubs, employers of the top players required to make the events a success, is likely to lead to a protracted conflict in a sport that has been a battleground for primacy between national teams, which are governed by FIFA, and club soccer, which is overseen by the six regional confederations and their members.\n\nTo win support, Infantino recently met with a handful of executives from the biggest clubs, including Germany\u2019s Bayern Munich and Chinese-owned Inter Milan, according to people familiar with the situation. The discussion took place without the knowledge of the European Club Association, an umbrella group for about 200 teams from across a continent, which includes the vast majority of the world\u2019s richest clubs. A spokesman for the E.C.A. said it had not been informed about the extraordinary FIFA Council meeting.\n\nIn a briefing document sent to FIFA Council members before the Bogot\u00e1 meeting, and seen by The New York Times, FIFA said it favored a 24-team global club championship, with half the participants drawn from Europe. That group would include the finalists from the four prior editions of the Champions League, soccer\u2019s richest club event.\n\nFIFA estimated each edition of its proposed club competition could generate a maximum of $1 billion; the investment group is offering $3 billion for each tournament, with the remainder offered for a proposed nations league.\n\nEuropean soccer\u2019s governing body UEFA is largely opposed to the proposal. Both competitions proposed by FIFA would cause upheaval to its events, including the creation of a significant competitor to the Champions League, which generates billions of dollars in advertising and broadcast revenue. The global nations league also would usurp UEFA\u2019s own version of a similar competition, which begins its first edition later this year.\n\nConfederations in Asia and the Americas appear to be largely supportive of the idea, which would guarantee more games against top European sides for their best clubs. But a German member of the FIFA Council, Reinhard Grindel, a critic of Infantino\u2019s management style, told Infantino the organization should focus on national team soccer and not meddle in club affairs.\n\nIn its most recent letter to members, FIFA explained that the money from the proposed deal would directly benefit its 211 member federations, the group that will vote in next year\u2019s presidential election.", "title": "FIFA\u2019s Infantino Calls for Rare Emergency Meeting Amid $25 Billion Offer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "The viewing experience for the Mets-Phillies game was certainly different. Instead of the traditional commercial breaks in between half-innings, there were short segments about players and teams, and interviews with Mets pitcher Matt Harvey and the comedian Jim Breuer, a Mets fan. At times during game action, a viewer\u2019s comment would be highlighted on a banner across the top of the screen.\n\n\u201cI know they\u2019re trying to bring in a new audience, but I don\u2019t think that\u2019s the best way to bring them in,\u201d Schulman said.\n\nAfter receiving many complaints, producers of the stream told viewers how to hide the comments bar via the comment section, as well as on the broadcast itself. They also reduced the size of the onscreen graphics, which were originally designed for cellphone screens.\n\nOf the big four professionals sports leagues in the United States, M.L.B. has the audience that skews the oldest. A study by Magna Global, a marketing research company, found that the average age of television viewers of M.L.B. in 2016 was 57.\n\nSchulman considers himself to be part of the target audience for M.L.B.; he is 30 years old and a die-hard fan of the Mets. His television wasn\u2019t compatible with the Facebook app, but he figured out how to use a different streaming device.\n\nAlthough he and his 60-year-old father are Facebook users, Schulman said his father struggled to load the game, so he had to walk him through directions on the phone during the game. \u201cFor me it was fine, but for an older man or woman who is not as tech savvy, might be more difficult,\u201d Schulman said.\n\nNearly 69,000 comments streamed across the bar on the side of the viewing screen. They ranged from harsh criticism to compliments for the teams and players, as well as complaints about the broadcast and even about privacy concerns facing Facebook. Viewers said they were watching from as far away as Sweden.", "title": "Facebook Broadcast of Mets Game Runs Into Glitches and Complaints", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "The revelation widens the scope of data that was harvested from people on Facebook and how it went beyond what was publicly available. The development may provide grist to lawmakers on a day when Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive, is set to be grilled on Capitol Hill over data privacy and other matters, such as Russian misuse of the social network to influence the 2016 election.\n\nHow Mr. Zuckerberg publicly addresses these problems in congressional hearings on Tuesday and Wednesday will be closely scrutinized. Facebook faces possible regulation and other changes amid a backlash over the lack of data privacy.\n\nThe Cambridge Analytica outcry was triggered after The New York Times and others reported last month that a quiz app made by Mr. Kogan had collected information on Facebook users. That information was then used by Cambridge Analytica to build psychological profiles of voters in the United States and others.\n\nIt is not clear whether the direct messages were among the data eventually provided to Cambridge Analytica. In an interview on Tuesday, Mr. Kogan told The Times that the private messages were harvested from a limited number of people, likely \u201ca couple thousand,\u201d as part of a separate academic research project and never provided to Cambridge Analytica.\n\nHe said the messages were collected as part of research that he conducted at Cambridge University in 2013 and the first half of 2014, before he began working with Cambridge Analytica. The messages were collected for research into how people use emojis to convey emotions.", "title": "Facebook Data Collected by Quiz App Included Private Messages", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "In a separate interview this week, Mr. Collins talked about his education on the social platform. \u201cI\u2019ve been genuinely surprised by how much data Facebook gathers,\u201d he said, pulling out books he had been reading, including \u201cThe People Vs. Tech,\u201d a critical examination of how social media is influencing society, and \u201cChaos Monkeys,\u201d a memoir by a former Facebook executive.\n\nMr. Collins\u2019 profile has grown along with the Cambridge Analytica scandal. His committee questioned the company\u2019s chief executive, Alexander Nix, weeks before news broke about its practices. The panel has published audio records in which an executive tied to Cambridge Analytica discusses how the Trump campaign used techniques used by the Nazis to target voters. A webcast of the committee\u2019s hearing with the former Cambridge Analytica researcher Christopher Wylie was so popular it nearly took down Parliament\u2019s website, Mr. Collins said.\n\nBetween television interviews this week, Mr. Collins sat with staff watching a small set as a Canadian parliamentary committee questioned an executive from an online advertising company, Aggregate IQ, that had been involved in the Brexit referendum. When Mr. Collins heard a discrepancy in the testimony, he messaged a member of the Canadian panel. \u201cHe read out my text during the hearing,\u201d Mr. Collins laughed.\n\nAware that he doesn\u2019t have the same financial resources as Facebook and other global tech firms, or even as much as his counterparts across the Atlantic, Mr. Collins has been coordinating his investigation with others around the world. He has been in touch with regulators in France, Germany and Ireland, and even as far afield as Singapore.\n\nHis efforts come alongside those of other British regulators. The country\u2019s Electoral Commission is looking into whether laws were broken during the Brexit referendum, while Britain\u2019s data privacy watchdog is investigating Cambridge Analytica, Facebook and how social networks are used for political campaigns.\n\nMr. Collins plans to publish a report with policy recommendations by this summer.\n\n\u201cMany people would look at what\u2019s happened over the past couple of months and say the case for greater regulatory scrutiny of the way the tech companies work would be appropriate,\u201d Mr. Collins said in the interview. \u201cI don\u2019t think you can put that genie back in the bottle now.\u201d", "title": "Facebook Faces Tough Questions in Britain That It Avoided in the U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey\u2019re selling magic in a bottle,\u201d said Matt Braynard, who worked alongside Cambridge on the Trump campaign, for which he served as the director of data and strategy, and now runs Look Ahead America, a group seeking to turn out disaffected rural and blue-collar voters. \u201cAnd they\u2019re becoming toxic.\u201d\n\nThe Mercers have made no public statements about Cambridge Analytica\u2019s troubles. Through a spokeswoman, Ms. Mercer declined to answer questions about her role in Mr. Trump\u2019s circle or the Facebook meeting about Cambridge Analytica.\n\nBut the effort by Ms. Mercer\u2019s friend to help mend fences with Facebook hints at both Cambridge\u2019s importance to her family\u2019s political ambitions and the perils posed by Facebook\u2019s ban.\n\nAlthough a Cambridge spokesman last month downplayed Ms. Mercer\u2019s role at the company \u2014 saying she had a \u201cbroad business oversight\u201d role and no involvement in its daily operations \u2014 she serves on the company\u2019s board and in the past has worked to drum up campaign business for Cambridge, according to Republicans who have worked with or competed against the firm. Former Cambridge employees said she was close to Alexander Nix, the company\u2019s chief executive, who was suspended last month after reports on Cambridge\u2019s harvesting of Facebook data.\n\nMs. Mercer\u2019s intermediary with Facebook was Matthew Michelsen, a tech entrepreneur and investor based in San Diego, who lists his employer as GothamAlpha, a consulting firm. According to his LinkedIn profile, he has also advised major Silicon Valley companies, including Facebook and Palantir, a data-mining firm and intelligence contractor.\n\nMr. Michelsen\u2019s meeting came on March 20, the day after Facebook announced that Cambridge had agreed to let it audit the firm\u2019s computer servers. Mr. Michelsen met informally with a Facebook acquaintance who was accompanied by a Facebook lawyer, according to a person briefed on the meeting, and both Cambridge Analytica and the Mercers were discussed. The person discussed the meeting on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak about it publicly. No immediate actions were taken as a result of Mr. Michelsen\u2019s outreach.\n\nMr. Michelsen acknowledged in an interview on Thursday that he visited the company but he would not discuss the purpose of the trip, citing nondisclosure agreements Facebook required him to sign. Ms. Mercer declined to say whether she and Mr. Michelsen had discussed the purpose of the meeting or whether he had briefed her on it afterward.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCambridge also mounted a more formal effort to assuage Facebook, the person said, sending its own lawyers to meet with Facebook on the same day Mr. Michelsen was there. The Cambridge lawyers asked Facebook officials whether the firm could be reinstated on the platform. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive, acknowledged that meeting in an interview with The Times last month, saying that his company had not decided whether to lift the ban.\n\nA Cambridge spokesman did not respond to requests for comment. In a lengthy public statement on Monday, the company stated that \u201cthe vast majority of our business is commercial rather than political, contrary to the way some of the media has portrayed us.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn recent years, the Mercers have become among the most prominent and highly scrutinized political donors in the United States. In the early years of the Obama administration, they began doling out tens of millions of dollars to an eclectic array of conservative groups \u2014 many of them outside Washington\u2019s mainline Republican establishment. Mr. Mercer invested $10 million in Breitbart News, the nationalist website, bringing on Mr. Bannon as chairman, while Ms. Mercer joined the boards of leading conservative think tanks.\n\nThe Mercers were critical of the Republican Party\u2019s existing data apparatus, which was controlled by the party officials and consultants they hoped to disempower. Mr. Mercer bankrolled Cambridge Analytica in 2014, and Ms. Mercer encouraged candidates and PACs that took the family\u2019s money to also hire the family\u2019s data firm. Early in the 2016 presidential campaign, the Mercers backed Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, putting millions of dollars \u2014 and Cambridge Analytica \u2014 behind him.\n\nBut after Mr. Trump prevailed in the primaries, the Mercers switched candidates. In summer 2016, Ms. Mercer helped orchestrate a shake-up that put Mr. Bannon at the head of the Trump campaign. After Mr. Trump won the presidential election, he attended a costume ball at the Mercer estate on Long Island.\n\nMs. Mercer secured a slot on his transition team and prime seats at his inauguration. As Mr. Trump took office, she sought to take a leading role in America First Policies, a nonprofit formed to back the president\u2019s agenda. Last spring, Ms. Mercer and her father attended the Time 100 black-tie gala, where she was feted as one of the country\u2019s most influential people.\n\nBut her insistence on using Cambridge to provide the Trump group with voter data, and other clashes over strategy, alienated other donors and Trump allies, according to other Republicans. Ms. Mercer formed her own group, Making America Great, and hired Emily Cornell, a Cambridge executive, to run it.\n\nYet after an initial splash of spending in 2017 to promote Mr. Trump\u2019s policies on environmental deregulation and other issues, Making America Great appears to have gone quiet. Ms. Cornell said she was no longer affiliated with Making America Great and could not comment on the group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn November, Mr. Mercer stepped down from the helm of Renaissance Technologies, one of the world\u2019s most successful hedge funds, as some investors began expressing dismay over his alliance with Mr. Trump.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe family is likely to retain significant influence in broader conservative circles thanks to its vast fortune, which finances donations that many political organizations and candidates are eager to accept. The family foundation handed out about $20 million to more than two dozen conservative think tanks, charter school groups, watchdog outfits and other nonprofit organizations in 2016, according to its most recent tax return.\n\nMs. Mercer remains a trustee of the Heritage Foundation, a prominent Washington think tank that has provided the Trump administration with grist for a range of initiatives. The foreign policy hawk John R. Bolton, whose super PAC the Mercers lavished with cash and whom Ms. Mercer once lobbied the White House to make secretary of state, was recently tapped to become Mr. Trump\u2019s national security adviser.\n\nThe family has also donated $4.5 million to Republican candidates and super PACs during the 2018 election cycle, putting the Mercers among the top 20 donors in the country. And the father-daughter duo still inspire fear: Virtually no Republicans were willing to speak on the record about the family\u2019s troubles.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
