He is convinced that Amazon will find a way to deliver fresh food locally, eating into the market for local goods.\n\n\u201cWe see this coming,\u201d Mr. McNeal says. \u201cWe have to figure out how to give customers what they want or we are going to be another story about a business that didn\u2019t adapt.\u201d\n\nAfter lunch, the Nowacoskis return to their farm to pick up heads of lettuce and then drive to a bakery, minutes before it closes at 4:30 p.m. The couple have been on the road for more than six hours.\n\nThey will visit more farms the next day.", "title": "Farmers Hit the Road to Reach Shoppers Before Amazon Does", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Trump administration officials argue that the tariffs on Chinese goods, while not intended to help certain American industries, are necessary to prevent China from continuing to violate international trade rules. They say that less aggressive measures by past administrations failed, and that China has stolen American jobs and technology that are the key to future prosperity.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not possible to have true gain without the pain,\u201d said Dan DiMicco, a trade adviser to Mr. Trump during the presidential campaign. \u201cThe battle is worth the victory, and we will win.\u201d\n\nBut farm-state Republicans like Mr. Cramer believe that their constituents could be a casualty, and they are begging the Department of Agriculture to intervene.\n\nMr. Trump has directed the department to implement a plan to help farmers cope with the damage from tariffs. But few details have been forthcoming about how such a program would work or how much it might cost. And it is not clear how much the Agriculture Department could do to remedy the damage done to key trading relations in a global economy.\n\nThe secretary of agriculture has some authority to help farmers by creating new programs that could draw on funds from the Treasury. For instance, the secretary could direct the Commodity Credit Corporation, a government-owned entity, to purchase soybeans to buoy farmers\u2019 revenues, said Kent Conrad, a former Democratic senator from North Dakota.\n\nIn the past, these powers have been used to provide relief from wildfires and other natural disasters, farm groups said. But such a program could be time-consuming and costly.\n\n\u201cAll of that has serious consequences,\u201d Mr. Conrad said. \u201cIt has costs to the government at a time when the deficits and debt have already soared, and we are going to have a trillion-dollar deficit.\u201d The federal budget deficit, despite the strong economy, reached $598 billion for the first half of the current fiscal year, the Congressional Budget Office said on Friday, $71 billion more than was recorded during the same period last year.", "title": "Farmers\u2019 Anger at Trump Tariffs Puts Republican Candidates in a Bind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "But the most recent results from two surveys \u2014 one nationwide in France, the other limited to one region \u2014 caused scientists to sound an alarm, because the results suggest that agricultural methods are hurting birds, according to Benoit Fontaine, a conservation biologist at the National Museum of Natural History in Paris and a leader of the national survey, conducted twice a year by volunteers.\n\n\u201cIn the agricultural land,\u201d he said, \u201cthere is something really bad going on.\u201d\n\nOver the past 17 years, the numbers of birds in farming areas have dropped by a third. Some of the species have declined even more: Meadow pipit populations, for example, fell by 68 percent. Dr. Fontaine described the situation as \u201ccatastrophic.\u201d\n\nHe suspects that pesticides used in agriculture and intensification of land use are linked to the decline, although neither survey comes to conclusions about causes or makes any policy recommendations. But he pointed to the loss of insects, the major food source for many birds, as a likely result of pesticide use.\n\nVincent Bretagnolle, an ecologist at the Centre for Biological Studies Chiz\u00e9, led the other survey, which has been conducted by scientists in the Deux-Sevres region in the western part of the country for 24 years. \u201cOur results are completely in agreement with national and European surveys,\u201d he said.\n\nThe trend is long-term, he said, except that recently, particularly at the national level, the dip has been steeper, and the more generalist bird species have been affected as they weren\u2019t in the past.", "title": "Farmland Birds in France Are in Steep Decline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "What fashion trends from the past would you like to see revived? Which do you think would be better off staying in the past? Why?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out the styles that are making a comeback this spring.", "title": "Fashion Comebacks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "He capped weeks of diplomacy with Saturday\u2019s announcement of an end to nuclear and long-range missile tests and the shutting down of a nuclear test site, saying he would now focus on rebuilding the economy. And he earlier told American and South Korean envoys that his country was willing to give up nuclear arms if it received the right incentives.\n\nPhoto\n\nChoi Hae-jong, 55, who runs a gas station in the provincial city of Ulsan, said he believed that Kim Jong-un would indeed bargain away his nuclear weapons if given the aid and security guarantees that he needed to rebuild the economy.\n\n\u201cHe knows he can\u2019t feed his people with nuclear weapons and tanks,\u201d Mr. Choi said.\n\nWith Friday\u2019s meeting, Mr. Kim will become the first North Korean leader to cross the inter-Korean border, sitting down with Mr. Moon on the South Korean side of Panmunjom, a \u201ctruce village\u201d straddling the border. President Trump plans to meet Mr. Moon weeks later at a time and place still to be determined.\n\nThe flurry of diplomacy has left South Koreans guessing at Mr. Kim\u2019s intentions and debating the wisdom of negotiating with him \u2014 and wondering what lies in store for the future of the Korean Peninsula.\n\nFor generations, it has been an article of faith among South Koreans that they should eventually reconcile and reunify with the North. But after seven decades of division, the capitalist South and the totalitarian North have drifted so far apart that the yearning for reunification is not what it used to be, especially among young South Koreans.\n\n\u201cUnlike those in their 60s and older, who still shared a sense of national identity with the North Koreans, many in their 20s merely perceived North Korea as an \u2018enemy\u2019 or a \u2018stranger,\u2019\u201d said a study published last week by Kim Ji-yoon, Kim Kil-dong and Kang Chung-ku for the Asan Institute for Policy Studies, based in Seoul. \u201cMany in their 20s were indifferent to unification and did not view it as an urgent matter.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s recent behavior has led to some paradoxical findings in public opinion surveys. One poll last month showed that more than 81 percent of South Koreans supported holding a summit meeting with Mr. Kim. But another survey this month showed that more than 70 percent doubted that Mr. Kim would give up his most dangerous weapons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n[Read our profile of Kim Jong-un, a moody young man with a nuclear arsenal.]\n\n\u201cWhen dealing with North Korea, there is always this nagging feeling that they may stab us in the back again,\u201d said Choi Hae-pyeong, 55, a businessman from south of Seoul.\n\nVideo\n\nIn 1991, the two Koreas signed a nonaggression agreement. In 1992, they jointly vowed not to seek nuclear weapons. After an inter-Korean summit meeting in 2000, South Korea shipped billions of dollars\u2019 worth of aid and investment, but the North still went on to develop a nuclear arsenal, inviting a conservative backlash in the South.\n\nIndeed, many older conservatives fear that North Korea has developed its nuclear weapons to drive American troops from the South and reunify the peninsula under its rule. But others see the North\u2019s nuclear program as rooted in the Kim dynasty\u2019s insecurity following the collapse of the Soviet bloc, which left North Korea more vulnerable and isolated in its standoff against the United States. And a peace deal could be one way out of that predicament.\n\n\u201cThe North Korean nuclear and missile problem is a byproduct of hostile relations between the United States and North Korea,\u201d said Lim Dong-won, a former unification minister and intelligence chief of South Korea. \u201cIt can be resolved only in the context of ending the Cold War enmity and establishing peace on the peninsula, through a comprehensive deal of formally ending the Korean War and normalizing ties.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nProgressive South Koreans like Mr. Moon argue that the only realistic and peaceful way of removing the North\u2019s nuclear weapons is to persuade the government that it can survive without them. While conservatives prioritize the alliance with Washington, the progressives like to see their country as finally \u201cin the driver\u2019s seat\u201d in managing the precarious situation on the peninsula.\n\n\u201cWe are at the crossroads where it will be decided whether denuclearization and permanent peace is possible by peaceful \u2014 not by military \u2014 means,\u201d Mr. Moon said on Monday.\n\nBut Mr. Moon acknowledged that the nuclear crisis could ultimately only be resolved between North Korea and the United States. The best he can do, he says, is to serve as a \u201cguide\u201d to help Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump reach a \u201ccomprehensive\u201d deal to trade the North\u2019s nuclear weapons for security guarantees from Washington, such as a peace treaty to formally end the 1950-53 Korean War.\n\n[Read what it might mean for the Koreas to finally reach an official peace.]\n\nSome conservatives, having been burned before, remain deeply skeptical of that approach.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe current government turned the table, claiming to be \u2018a driver\u2019 just when the North began feeling the pain of sanctions,\u201d Lee Bong-bok, a well-known right-wing expert on North Korea, told the conservative daily Chosun Ilbo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has threatened to walk out of his planned meeting with Mr. Kim if he refused to denuclearize. Should that happen, South Koreans fear, calls for military action in Washington, and the risk of war in Korea, could grow greater than ever.\n\nLast year, South Koreans fretted as they watched Mr. Trump threaten to \u201ctotally destroy\u201d North Korea; Mr. Kim, in turn, called him a senile \u201cdotard.\u201d But many now hope that Mr. Kim\u2019s daring style and Mr. Trump\u2019s unpredictability combine to offer the chance to break the decades-old nuclear stalemate in Korea.\n\nMr. Trump is the first American leader to agree to sit down with a North Korean leader.\n\n\u201cWhen I said I supported President Trump\u2019s election because it would be a great opportunity for us, people called me crazy,\u201d said Mr. Lim, who leads a panel of senior nongovernmental advisers to Mr. Moon. \u201cNo matter what people say about him, here is an American leader who wants to overturn the status quo.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim himself has been overturning some of the conventional wisdom about North Korea.\n\nHis pledge to stop conducting nuclear and missile tests is the kind of concession that would have taken Washington years of haggling to extract from the North in the past \u2014 and only with promises of aid. Mr. Kim announced it Saturday without any conditions attached.\n\nPark Sang-min, 39, a marketing official in Seoul, said he sees in the North Korean leader \u201ca confidence and eagerness to negotiate.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe has completed his nuclear weapons and long-range missiles so that the Americans would have no option but to take him seriously and pay the prices he wanted,\u201d he said.", "title": "Fear and Hope in South Korea on Eve of Summit With Kim Jong-un", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "National Democrats may also intervene in the Southern California districts held by Representatives Dana Rohrabacher and Jeff Denham, where multiple Republicans and Democrats are running, and in the seat held by Representative Darrell Issa, a Republican who is retiring. Voters receive mail-in ballots starting in early May, making the next few weeks exceptionally important.\n\nHouse Majority PAC, a heavily financed Democratic group that spends millions in congressional elections, recently polled all four races and has been conducting digital surveys that simulate the complicated California ballot, according to people briefed on the group\u2019s strategy. The super PAC has run ads in California in the past when Democrats have faced disaster in primary season.\n\nRepresentative Judy Chu, a Los Angeles-area Democrat, said the open primaries had led Democrats to take unusual steps to prevent Republicans from dominating the first round of voting.\n\n\u201cThat would stop our goal of taking the House back,\u201d Ms. Chu said. \u201cWe have to have a viable candidate, and I think that if it does turn out to be a Democrat versus a Republican, the Democrat will win.\u201d\n\nMs. Chu said the campaign committee\u2019s endorsement of Mr. Cisneros was a signal to donors and volunteers that it was time to close ranks.\n\nBut picking favorites is not easy for Democrats: Until mid-March, Southern California lawmakers were divided in the 39th District race between Mr. Cisneros, who is backed by Representative Linda T. S\u00e1nchez, an influential member of the Democratic leadership team, and Jay Chen, another Democrat who was endorsed by Ms. Chu. It was only after Mr. Chen opted against running, with a call for party unity, that Ms. Chu and other Democrats swung behind Mr. Cisneros.\n\nMs. S\u00e1nchez said the glut of Democratic candidates remained concerning across California, and acknowledged having lobbied the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee to back Mr. Cisneros. National leaders, Ms. S\u00e1nchez said, had \u201ca role to play in terms of trying to talk to nonviable candidates and urging them to be team players.\u201d", "title": "Fearing Chaos, National Democrats Plunge Into Midterm Primary Fights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The question of what awaits after death has obsessed humanity for millennia.\n\nThe Korean photographer Chanho Park\u2019s fixation took root when he was 11 and his mother, who suffered from pancreatic cancer, was hospitalized. Much of his time was spent at her side, where he heard the anguished screams of the dying and their mourning families and saw the beds of gaunt patients become empty from one day to the next.\n\n\u201cI began to feel more afraid of the pain and screams that they were experiencing than the death itself,\u201d Mr. Park said.\n\nAfter his mother died, he was adrift and bereft. Discord with his father led him to run away from home when he was 14. By his late 30s, he fell into depression, which he sought to ease by taking pictures. Without meaning to, he found himself drawn to burial plots, ritual sites, and places of prayer \u2014 synonymous with marking the end of life or remembering those who died. While sorting through his photos, he was struck by a commonality: the image of mothers praying.", "title": "Fearing Death, and Photographing the Rituals That Surround It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "However, the minutes reflect officials\u2019 uncertainty about how big that boost might be, and when it might come, because there is little historical precedent for such fiscal stimulus when unemployment is so low. The minutes also show that policymakers \u201csuggested that uncertainty about whether all elements of the tax cuts would be made permanent, or about the implications of higher budget deficits for fiscal sustainability and real interest rates, represented sources of downside risk to the economic outlook.\u201d\n\nThe meeting was the first under the Fed\u2019s new chairman, Jerome H. Powell. At the session\u2019s conclusion, officials announced that they would raise interest rates for the sixth time since the end of the Great Recession, in the range of 1.5 to 1.75 percent. Officials released economic projections indicating that they expected to raise rates three times next year, more than the two increases in 2019 that they had forecast in December. The Fed said at the time the economy was continuing to get stronger and that the central bank remained on track to keep raising rates gradually. Mr. Powell echoed those sentiments at a news conference after the meeting.\n\nThe minutes suggest that decision on interest rates generated little controversy: \u201cAll participants agreed that the outlook for the economy beyond the current quarter had strengthened in recent months,\u201d and that they expected the annual inflation rate to rise in the months to come.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the minutes say that a \u201ccouple of participants\u201d suggested the Fed would benefit from holding off until a future meeting to raise rates, in order to wait for more data to confirm evidence that the rate of inflation was approaching the Fed\u2019s target of 2 percent annual growth.\n\nOfficials also debated the benefits of the economy\u2019s running hot \u2014 with unemployment very low and growth above forecast trends \u2014 for a prolonged period of time, weighing the potential for drawing more workers back to the labor force against the risk of financial instability and \u201csignificant\u201d inflation growth.\n\nOfficials seemed to shrug off the increase in stock market volatility in February, attributing it in part to Labor Department reports that the suggested growth in wages \u2014 and, with it, inflation \u2014 was gaining steam, which could force the Fed to raise rates faster than expected. \u201cMany participants reported that their contacts had taken the previous month\u2019s turbulence in stride,\u201d the minutes read.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe official statement released immediately after the March meeting did not mention trade policy concerns, which roiled financial markets after the Trump administration announced its plans to impose tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, as well as on some other Chinese goods. Mr. Powell acknowledged those concerns at his news conference, saying that trade policy had begun to worry business leaders who speak with Fed officials. Still, he played down any immediate threat to growth.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no thought that changes in trade policy should have an effect on the current outlook,\u201d Mr. Powell said at the news conference, adding that could change if a global trade dispute escalated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a speech in Chicago last week, Mr. Powell elaborated on the Federal Open Market Committee\u2019s concerns during a question-and-answer session.\n\n\u201cThe discussion about tariffs is at a relatively early stage, and we talked about this at the F.O.M.C. meeting a couple of weeks ago now,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd people really don\u2019t see yet any implications in the near term for the outlook, because we don\u2019t know the extent to which the tariffs will actually come into effect and, if so, how big will that effect be and what will the timing of it be.\u201d\n\nAny negative effects from tariffs could put the Fed in a bind, forcing policymakers to break what Mr. Powell and his predecessors have repeatedly characterized as a delicate balance between supporting economic growth and job creation, and holding inflation to the target growth rate. Economists generally view tariff fallout as stagflationary, meaning it hurts growth and also feeds inflation. Taxes on imported goods raise prices for businesses and consumers, pushing up the inflation rate, while also dampening consumption and economic growth.\n\nThe minutes suggest that Fed officials are worrying more about that possibility than they have acknowledged publicly: \u201cMost participants also cited trade policy as a source of either uncertainty or downside risk,\u201d the minutes say.", "title": "Fed Officials Have Concerns About Trade, March Meeting Minutes Show", "authors": ["Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOur view is that most of our policies are going to create growth for the economy on the supply side, and that when the supply-side growth comes, then that\u2019s actually good for inflation, because if you increase supply, it puts downward pressure on prices,\u201d Kevin Hassett, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, told reporters in February. \u201cAnd so we think that we can get the 3 percent economic growth that we forecast without a big pickup in inflation.\u201d\n\nThe group of Fed officials worried about overheating point to several economic data points. The unemployment rate is 4.1 percent, near the lowest level recorded in a half-century, and it is below what Fed officials judge to be the sustainable long-term unemployment rate. Forecasters expect the recent injection of fiscal stimulus, from tax cuts and increased federal spending, to drive that rate down even further.\n\nInflation expectations are rising in financial markets, as measured, in part, by how much the government must pay investors to borrow money. Stock values remain high by historical standards, even with the recent dips in the market.\n\nIn similar periods in American economic history, \u201cthere have been heightened risks either of inflation, in earlier decades, or of financial imbalances more recently,\u201d Lael Brainard, a Fed governor, said in a speech last week.\n\nMany Fed officials worry that by raising rates too slowly, they risk having to move quickly in the event of an inflation spike or financial turmoil. Such abrupt action, they fear, could snuff growth and plunge the economy into a recession. Other officials, such as James Bullard of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis and Neel Kashkari of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, say officials should keep to the current course of rate increases, particularly because inflation remains below the Fed\u2019s target of 2 percent annual growth.\n\nPolling and interviews suggest that American workers are worried about rising prices but far more concerned about job and wage growth. In polling in March for The New York Times by the research firm SurveyMonkey, 62 percent of respondents said consumer prices had risen faster than wages over the preceding year. Only 4 percent said inflation was the largest economic problem facing the country. Twenty-five percent named the cost of health care as the largest economic problem, 21 percent said the gap between the rich and everyone else, and 10 percent named stagnant wages and benefits.\n\nConstance Bevitt, who does freelance work in Montgomery County, Md., said Fed officials were wrong to be worried about overheating.", "title": "Fed Officials Worry the Economy Is Too Good. Workers Still Feel Left Behind.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "The new details come as Congress is examining safeguards put in place by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Homeland Security to make sure children who show up alone at the border are turned over to relatives, and not human traffickers.\n\nSenator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio and the chairman of the subcommittee, said he was shocked that government officials did not know the whereabouts of hundreds of migrant children released from their care.\n\n\u201cH.H.S. has a responsibility to better track these children so they aren\u2019t trafficked or abused, and so they show up to their court hearings,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo years ago the subcommittee released a report detailing how health and human services officials placed eight children with human traffickers who forced the minors to work on an egg farm in Marion, Ohio. The report found that department officials had failed to establish procedures to protect the unaccompanied minors, such as conducting sufficient background checks on potential sponsors and following up with sponsors. As a result, the children were turned over to the people who contracted them out to the egg farm.\n\nTo prevent similar episodes, the Homeland Security and Health and Human Services Departments signed a memorandum of understanding in 2016, and agreed to establish joint procedures within one year for dealing with unaccompanied migrant children.\n\nMore than a year after the new guidelines were due, the two agencies have not completed them, Mr. Portman said.\n\nChildren who show up at the border by themselves are usually apprehended by Border Patrol agents or turn themselves in to customs officers at the Department of Homeland Security. Once they are processed, they are turned over to the custody of the Department of Health and Human Services\u2019 refugee office. The office runs more than 100 shelters around the country where it houses children and provides care until they can be turned over to a sponsor while awaiting their immigration hearings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe sponsors are usually parents or family members already residing in the United States. The sponsors are supposed to undergo a detailed background check.\n\nAfter the children have been placed with sponsors, workers at the department follow up with calls to ensure that the minors continue to live with the sponsors, are enrolled in school and are aware of their court dates.\n\nBut several immigration advocates who work with unaccompanied children said the department did little follow-up. Allison E. Herre, a lawyer with Catholic Charities of Southwestern Ohio, said she had seen sponsors who forced the children to work instead of attending school and who failed to ensure that the children attended their court proceedings.\n\nSince 2016, health and human services officials said they have started calling sponsors to check on children 30 days after placement. But the agency said it was not legally responsible for children after they had been released from its refugee office.\n\nMr. Wagner said the agency was re-examining its interpretation of existing laws to make sure that migrant children were not turned over to smugglers or human traffickers.", "title": "Federal Agencies Lost Track of Nearly 1,500 Migrant Children Placed With Sponsors", "authors": ["Ron Nixon"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The federal government\u2019s annual budget deficit is set to widen significantly in the next few years, and is expected to top $1 trillion in 2020 despite healthy economic growth, according to new projections from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office released Monday.\n\nThe national debt, which has exceeded $21 trillion, will soar to more than $33 trillion in 2028, according to the budget office. By then, debt held by the public will almost match the size of the nation\u2019s economy, reaching 96 percent of gross domestic product, a higher level than any point since just after World War II and well past the level that economists say could court a crisis.\n\nThe fear among some economists is that rising deficits will drive up interest rates, raise borrowing costs for the private sector, tank stock prices and slow the economy, which would only drive the deficit higher.\n\n\u201cSuch high and rising debt would have serious negative consequences for the budget and the nation,\u201d said Keith Hall, the director of the budget office. \u201cIn particular, the likelihood of a fiscal crisis in the United States would increase.\u201d", "title": "Federal Budget Deficit Projected to Soar to Over $1 Trillion in 2020", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The new C.B.O. projection is the first since President Trump signed a tax cut that is expected to cost the government nearly $1.9 trillion over 11 years, then signed legislation to significantly boost military and domestic spending over the next two years. The figures are sobering, even in a political climate where deficit concerns appear to be receding.\n\nThis fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, the budget deficit is expected to total $804 billion, up from $665 billion last fiscal year, according to the C.B.O. projections. In a decade, the red ink is expected to reach $1.5 trillion.\n\n\u2014 Thomas Kaplan\n\nPhoto\n\nZuckerberg to Congress: Facebook made a \u2018big mistake\u2019\n\nWhen he goes before Congress this week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive, will issue a broad apology for letting the website be used as a conduit for fake news, election meddling by foreign entities, hate speech and privacy abuses, according to a copy of his testimony released on Monday.\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t take a broad enough view of our responsibility, and that was a big mistake,\u201d Mr. Zuckerberg said in comments published by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. \u201cIt was my mistake, and I\u2019m sorry. I started Facebook, I run it, and I\u2019m responsible for what happens here.\u201d\n\nFacebook is entering a week of intense scrutiny in Washington, with Mr. Zuckerberg scheduled to testify before congressional committeeson Tuesday and Wednesday. The company is confronting a surge in criticism over how it handled the private data of as many as 87 million users that was harvested by Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm tied to President Trump\u2019s 2016 campaign.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg, in his prepared remarks, addresses the scandal, saying that Facebook must do more to protect its users\u2019 personal information. The company, he says, will block app developers from gaining access to the data of users who have been inactive for three months; restrict the ability of users to inadvertently share information about others in their networks; and adopt stricter permissions guidelines and search features.\n\nIn a separate post on Facebook on Monday, he also said that Facebook would form an independent commission of academic researchers to study social media\u2019s impact on elections.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis appearances on Capitol Hill starting Tuesday will be one of the Facebook mogul\u2019s most public challenges to date. Here\u2019s what to expect, according to Kevin Roose, Cecilia Kang and Sheera Frenkel of the NYT:\n\nDemocrats are expected to grill Mr. Zuckerberg about the privacy scandals, and how the social network is guarding against possible interference in this fall\u2019s midterm elections. Republicans are expected to be more reticent about privacy regulations, and may use the hearings to raise suspicions of political bias on the social network.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg has prepared for his testimony with a crash course in charm and humility. The goal is to look humble and forthright \u2014 and definitely not like the \u201cS.N.L.\u201d parody of him. (\u201cS.N.L.\u201d-Zuckerberg on user data: \u201cIt\u2019s mine \u2014 you gave it to me, no backsies.\u201d)\n\n\u2022 Facebook has suspended another data analytics company for misleading users. It will start notifying users today about what data was shared with Cambridge Analytica. (Some affected users contacted by the NYT were angry.) The company will require political ad buyers to verify their identities and locations. What Facebook\u2019s tightening of its privacy controls to a new European standard means for you. And Facebook\u2019s viral stars want a bigger cut of ad revenue.\n\n\u2022 Tim Cook of Apple took a shot at Facebook\u2019s business model in an MSNBC/Recode interview: \u201cWe\u2019re not going to traffic in your personal life. I think it\u2019s an invasion of privacy.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Jack Ma, the chief executive of Alibaba, also weighed in: \u201cIt is the time to fix it. It is the time for the CEO to really take it seriously. I think the problems will be solved.\u201d\n\nElsewhere in data privacy: Consumer advocacy groups are expected to complain to federal regulators that YouTube is violating a children\u2019s privacy law. And India\u2019s plans to connect residents\u2019 fingerprints, eyes and faces to everything from welfare benefits to mobile phones has horrified civil libertarians.\n\nDealBook readers, Andrew wants to know if you\u2019ve deleted or cut back on Facebook because of the Cambridge Analytica news. Tweet your responses at him, @andrewrsorkin.\n\nWho\u2019s doing the best, and worst, at diversity in Silicon Valley?\n\nThe Information and Social Capital just released their third survey of diversity at the big investment firms in the tech world. Here are some of their findings:\n\n\u2022 Canvas Ventures and Kirsten Green\u2019s Forerunner Ventures tied for first place on The Information\u2019s V.C. Diversity Index, while Tiger Global Management and Slow Ventures tied for last place.\n\n\u2022 The number of women in senior positions at U.S. venture firms rose to 14.2 percent last year, from 10.7 percent. The percentage of Hispanic decision makers rose to 2.3 percent from 1.9 percent, while that of black senior leaders stayed roughly flat at just over 1 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from The Information:\n\n\u201cOverall, there has never been a time where we have seen so much focus on diversity. Those who believe in it and verbally commit to it will do it.\u201d \u2014 Beth Haggerty, co-founder and C.E.O. of Parity Partners, said in an interview.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat lies ahead for Deutsche Bank\u2019s new C.E.O.?\n\nMeet Christian Sewing, a Deutsche Bank lifer who most recently oversaw the firm\u2019s retail operations. Mr. Sewing\u2019s biggest priorities include:\n\n\u2022 Deciding how to scale back international banking and trading ambitions (though focusing on the overcrowded German retail market has issues, too)\n\n\u2022 Convincing investors and regulators that the firm would shed risk\n\n\u2022 Calming the waters at a firm troubled by internal squabbles, while also making deep cuts\n\nMore on Mr. Sewing: He apprenticed with the bank and gradually added responsibilities like overseeing an internal money-laundering inquiry into the Russia unit. But Gadfly warns that it isn\u2019t clear how much institutional support Mr. Sewing will have.\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: A resolute plan to shrink Deutsche Bank\u2019s huge but unexceptional Wall Street businesses makes sense. But downsizing could mean lost revenue, executive departures and even surprise losses. If the next C.E.O. plays down the pain of such an adjustment, be skeptical.\n\nPhoto\n\nUber to buy Jump\n\nUber started a pilot program in San Francisco to allow its customers to reserve \u201cpedal-assist\u201d electric bicycles within its ride-hailing app in January. Now, Uber says it plans to buy the company behind the bike-sharing service and bring that capability to other cities around the world.\n\nIn a blog post Monday morning, Uber said it reached an agreement with Jump Bikes, a provider of battery-powered bicycles, for an undisclosed sum. It would be the first acquisition for Uber since Dara Khosrowshahi took over as the company\u2019s chief executive in August.\n\nUber did not say how much it paid for the bike start-up, but TechCrunch reported earlier that Jump was considering an acquisition from Uber for more than $100 million.\n\nEven as Uber is backing away from some international markets, the Jump acquisition shows the company is still willing to invest in new ways to reach customers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Daisuke Wakabayashi\n\nCan you say frothy?\n\nHow fast are homes in San Jose appreciating? At nearly $100 per hour, according to data from Zillow. To put that in perspective, San Jose\u2019s minimum wage is $13.50.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFrom Zillow:\n\n\u201cIn San Jose, the heart of Silicon Valley where the median home value has soared above $1 million over the past year, owners of the typical local home earned more than $200,000 in equity last year \u2013 almost $100 for every hour spent at the office last year. Even considering the legendary perks of Silicon Valley\u2019s office culture, that kind of \u201cincome\u201d is probably more than enough to make some local homeowners consider a new twist on \u201cworking from home\u201d \u2013 ie, giving it up and letting their home do the work instead.\u201d\n\nIn fact, homes are appreciating at a faster per hour than minimum wage in half of America\u2019s largest cities. They include San Francisco ($60.13), Seattle ($54.24), New York City ($42.17), Oakland ($38.57), San Diego ($30.86), Los Angeles ($26.35), Long Beach ($18.64), Honolulu ($17.44), Boston ($16.91), Las Vegas ($16.87), Denver ($15.91), and Sacramento ($15.62).\n\nMore context from Zillow: \u201cThe median U.S. household earned roughly $60,000 in 2017 ($58,978 to be exact) or a little more than $28 per hour.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBDT, the firm of Warren Buffett\u2019s favorite banker, gets into tequila\n\nThe investment firm of Byron D. Trott, BDT Capital Partners, announced this morning that it would buy a majority stake in Casa Dragones, the high-end tequila producer. (A bottle of the Joven would set you back almost $300.) It\u2019s the latest sign of growing interest in the Mexican spirit.\n\nFounded in 2008, Casa Dragones\u2019 sales have grown 50 percent by volume over the last three years.\n\nThe back story: The Casa Dragones co-founder Bertha Gonz\u00e1lez Nieves (the other is Bob Pittman, the media veteran), got to know BDT over the past year, and began negotiating a deal last fall. \u201cTo have a partner that believes in entrepreneurship and is a long-term investor enables us to continue to write our growth chapter,\u201d she said. Mr. Trott told Michael, \u201cBertha is just one of these great, passionate visionary entrepreneurs.\u201d\n\nThe context: Casamigos sold to Diageo for as much as $1 billion, but both Ms. Gonzalez and Mr. Trott said that wasn\u2019t a factor in striking this deal.\n\nWhat comes next: Ms. Gonzalez said that the new money will help Casa Dragones expand internationally, especially helpful as countries outside Mexico and the U.S. become more interested in tequila. And Mr. Trott said that while today\u2019s deal was BDT\u2019s first foray into the spirits industry, his firm had been looking at investing into the business for some time \u2014 and could end up doing more deals.\n\nPhoto\n\nWho was responsible for the messy tariff rollout?\n\nTrump administration officials sought on Sunday to play down the prospect of a trade war with China, with President Trump tweeting that he and President Xi Jinping \u201cwill always be friends.\u201d But behind the scenes, White House officials are reportedly fighting over who is to blame for the situation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Jonathan Swan of Axios:\n\nSeveral senior officials blame [Steven] Mnuchin for the messy rollout. One source ripped him for \u201chiding the ball\u201d by not looping enough people in after getting such a significant request from Trump. Another senior administration official defended Mnuchin, noting that after getting the order from Trump, he told the Staff Secretary and had multiple conversations with trade representative Bob Lighthizer, who worked in lock step with him on this.\n\nMeanwhile, Europe is caught in the middle of the U.S.-China fight, as its own steel producers worry about the pending imported metals tariffs.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 President Trump wants to rescind parts of the spending bill that he signed into law last month. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Federal Deficit to Surpass $1 Trillion in 2020: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cKushner Spars With Sessions, in Whiplash on Prisons Policy\u201d (front page, March 31):\n\nPrison Fellowship has long championed federal sentencing reform, but the push for federal prison reform is also a matter of justice, not to mention human dignity.\n\nA \u201cfront-end sentencing reform or bust\u201d mentality fails to acknowledge that the federal system offers drastically less opportunity for prisoners to transition to community corrections before the end of their sentence compared with almost all states.\n\nOf more than 35 jurisdictions with codified \u201cearned time\u201d and \u201cgood time\u201d policies, we found that the federal system ranked second lowest in the country in terms of the maximum amount of time possible to earn off one\u2019s prison sentence. This is for multiple reasons, including having only one federal prison program that qualifies for credit.\n\nThe Prison Reform and Redemption Act would expand earned-time credit opportunities to include any program proved to reduce recidivism. By allowing lower-risk individuals to serve the final terms of their sentences under community corrections supervision or in-home confinement, we can allow incarcerated men and women to reunite with their families sooner and create a smoother and safer re-entry transition.", "title": "Opinion | Federal Prison Reform", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "ALBANY \u2014 State Senator Simcha Felder, a Democrat from Brooklyn, announced on Tuesday that he will continue to caucus with the Republicans, short-circuiting hopes of a new Democratic majority in Albany\u2019s upper chamber.\n\nMr. Felder, who has repeatedly said he actually has no loyalty to any party, said in a statement that he would continue to sit with the Republican majority regardless of the outcome of two special elections being held in the Bronx and Westchester County.\n\nIf Democrats win both seats, the party would gain a numerical edge in the Senate, theoretically giving them control \u2014 but only if Mr. Felder returns to the fold. Instead, Mr. Felder said that he believed the issue would be \u201cbest resolved outside of the legislative session,\u201d which ends in June.\n\n\u201cI believe it is my obligation to prevent an unprecedented and uncertain late-session political battle that will only hurt my constituents and New Yorkers,\u201d Mr. Felder said. \u201cPolitical gamesmanship must not be allowed to jeopardize the leadership, committee structure and staff of the New York State Senate and push this institution into turmoil.\u201d", "title": "Felder, a Democrat, Says He Will Remain With Republicans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 It has been 86 years since Hattie Wyatt Caraway of Arkansas became the first woman elected to the United States Senate, and women remain woefully underrepresented in the chamber. Women make up nearly 51 percent of the United States population but just 23 percent of the Senate, an all-time high, nonetheless, after Cindy Hyde-Smith was sworn in as the new senator from Mississippi this month .\n\nThey form something of a tight-knit club.\n\nThey have bipartisan dinners that make their male colleagues jealous. They have banded together to solve seemingly intractable problems; in 2013, when Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, led a move to shut down the government, the women of the Senate cut a bipartisan deal to reopen it. And they have pushed their colleagues to tackle issues like sexual harassment, domestic violence and sexual assault in the military.\n\nOn Sunday, four female senators \u2014 Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, Heidi Heitkamp, Democrat of North Dakota, Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, and Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa \u2014 discussed women in politics, public policy, and the special bond among women in the Senate at a TimesTalks forum in New York. (Ms. Ernst, waylaid by an Iowa snowstorm, arrived toward the end.)\n\nHere are some of the session\u2019s lighter moments, offering a peek behind the scenes of life as a woman in the Senate:\n\nWho me? Run for public office?\n\nMs. Collins says she is often called upon to recruit women (and men) who are thinking of running for office. Many women tell her that they do not feel quite ready. \u201cI have never, ever had a man say that to me, that he wasn\u2019t quite ready,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cI think there\u2019s a self-doubt and a hesitancy to take risks that we need to overcome.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWomen have also historically had a tougher time raising money, said Ms. Klobuchar, who in 2006 became the first woman elected to the Senate from her state. On that score, she said she believes she set a record during her first run for Senate: \u201cI raised $17,000 from ex-boyfriends.\u201d", "title": "Female Senators, Their Ranks Increasing, Reflect on Breaking Into the Boys\u2019 Club", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cCuomo vs. de Blasio: One of the Country\u2019s Ugliest Political Feuds\u201d (front page, April 23):\n\nNo need for New Yorkers to look to the White House to find a selfish, megalomaniacal, petty, childish leader who is concerned only about himself, his image and his political viability. We have two such men much closer to home.\n\nIs there any wonder that our streets are dirtier, our subways are falling apart, our infrastructure is crumbling, the number of homeless on the streets is climbing and our children are not being well educated? All of these concerns apparently are not as important as the fragile egos of the men elected to address them.\n\nI have only two words for Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio: Grow up!\n\nCAROL NADELL, NEW YORK\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe bitterness of feuds between governors and mayors over the years points to an institutional source for these conflicts. That source is the state\u2019s control over many city functions and undue influence over others. The framework is dysfunctional: Governors can interfere when it is convenient for their personal political agendas and neglect legitimate city needs when it suits them.", "title": "Opinion | Feuding Politicians: Cuomo and de Blasio", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "But even Mr. Castro, with his revolutionary credentials and fraternal connections, could not pull off all of the changes he had set out to make. Too many old-guard associates put up obstacles when they saw the widening inequalities that accompanied economic reforms. So although Mr. Castro is widely believed to be planning a move from Havana to Santiago de Cuba \u2014 on Cuba\u2019s southeastern coast, the other side of the country \u2014 he is not expected to leave Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel entirely to his own devices.\n\nMr. Castro was credited with strengthening institutional control and formalizing the concept of consensus governing. He believes in delegated authority. He has made sure that there are enough internal checks and balances to keep an eye on any successor with big ideas, while still watching this one\u2019s back. Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel was a handpicked successor, and it is not in Ra\u00fal Castro\u2019s interest to see him fail.\n\n\u201cRa\u00fal will be watching,\u201d said Andy S. G\u00f3mez, a Cuba expert, now retired, who worked at the University of Miami. \u201cRa\u00fal, as first party secretary, will be not only watching him, but, more importantly, being there for him, symbolically, so he can move forward.\u201d\n\nAlcib\u00edades Hidalgo, who was Ra\u00fal Castro\u2019s chief of staff for a dozen years, believes that his former boss will hold on to power \u201cuntil the day he dies.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlejandro Castro Esp\u00edn, 52, is Ra\u00fal Castro\u2019s son. Mr. Castro Esp\u00edn runs the intelligence services for both the armed forces and the Interior Ministry. That is a big task in a country that works hard to stifle dissent and sniff out spies.\n\nMr. Castro Esp\u00edn was part of the team that negotiated with President Barack Obama\u2019s administration over restoring diplomatic ties with the United States, a sign that he is part of the most trusted inner circle.\n\nBut he also has serious anti-imperialist credentials: The title of a book he wrote in 2009, \u201cEmpire of Terror,\u201d offers a not-very-subtle clue of his opinion of Cuba\u2019s big neighbor to the north.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe most important of the younger generation is Castro Esp\u00edn,\u201d said Brian Latell, a former C.I.A. analyst who has closely watched the Castro family. \u201cI think he has a lot of influence with his father.\u201d\n\nJuan Juan Almeida, the son of a Cuban revolutionary war hero, grew up with Mr. Castro Esp\u00edn and lived in his house when they were children. He said he was not convinced that his former best friend had the skills to succeed after his father dies.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s powerful, but his power was given to him by his father,\u201d Mr. Almeida said. \u201cHe will last as long as his father\u2019s power lasts.\u201d\n\nSome experts believe that Ra\u00fal Castro would have liked to have made his son president, but that it would have looked bad internationally to have another Castro take over.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Sign up to receive an email from The New York Times as soon as important news breaks around the world. The military runs all of the hotels and state-run restaurants, convenience stores and gas stations, making General Rodr\u00edguez one of the country\u2019s most powerful men.\n\n\u201cHe must have 1,200 companies under him,\u201d said Guillermo Fari\u00f1as, an outspoken critic of the government who lives in Villa Clara Province. \u201cI think the one who manages the country economically is him.\u201d\n\nRa\u00fal Rodr\u00edguez Castro, General Rodr\u00edguez\u2019s son, is Ra\u00fal Castro\u2019s bodyguard, the kind of position that lends itself to knowing all kinds of secrets, Mr. Fari\u00f1as said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMariela Castro is Ra\u00fal Castro\u2019s daughter. A member of Parliament, she enjoys an international and domestic following, largely because of her support for gay and transgender rights.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMariela is part of the scenery,\u201d Mr. Hidalgo said. \u201cShe\u2019s a decorative figure with a nice cause. For the international community, they need to offer a nice friendly face of Cuba, which means not putting forth a Castro.\u201d\n\nMr. Hidalgo, a former ambassador to the United Nations who later defected and now lives in Miami, does not think it will work.\n\n\u201cThey are trying to give an appearance of change to what is fundamentally the same,\u201d he said. \u201cThey are trying to continue Castroism without Castros in the near future, which is practically impossible.\u201d", "title": "Fidel Died and Ra\u00fal Resigned, but Castros Still Hold Sway in Cuba", "authors": ["Frances Robles"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Alfie Evans does not know it, but he is the subject of a national debate in Britain, international diplomacy and a bitter legal dispute. He is held up as a tragedy, a beacon of hope and an object lesson. And he might not live to turn 2 years old.\n\nThe hospital and doctors treating him in Liverpool say that Alfie suffers from a degenerative neurological condition that is certainly fatal, that he is in a semi-vegetative state and that the only humane course of action is to let him die. His parents, supported by the Italian and Polish governments and the pope, are not convinced that he is beyond hope, or even that the doctors understand his condition, and they want to continue his care.\n\nOn Wednesday, the British Court of Appeal upheld a ruling that not only approved the withdrawal of care and sustenance, but also prohibited his parents from seeking treatment elsewhere, despite an invitation to take him to a hospital in Rome. The decision is wrenching to the parents, the courts have said, but prolonging Alfie\u2019s life would prolong his suffering, and so it would be contrary to his interests.\n\nThe staff of Alder Hey Children\u2019s Hospital took Alfie off a ventilator on Monday, but defying expectations, he kept breathing on his own. The parents\u2019 lawyers from the Christian Legal Centre have said they will continue their appeals.", "title": "Fight Over Alfie Evans, a Brain-Damaged Baby, Divides U.K.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe need a sovereignty stronger than our own,\u201d he said.\n\nThe French president also sought to remind those like himself, just 40 years old, who had no memories of World War II and few of the Cold War, that the European Union was intended to play a vital role in encouraging peace and stability.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI am part of a generation that is suffering the luxury of forgetting the experiences of our ancestors,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t want to belong to a generation of sleepwalkers that has forgotten its own past,\u201d referring to a famous German trilogy of novels by Hermann Broch set before World War I. \u201cI want to belong to a generation that has decided forcefully to defend its democracy.\u201d\n\nIn a clear reference to Hungary and to Poland, Mr. Macron said: \u201cIn the face of authoritarianism, the response is not authoritarian democracy but the authority of democracy.\u201d\n\nBoth countries have moved to consolidate party authority by tightening control over state media and the courts, and both countries have vowed to protect one another from substantive efforts to punish these efforts by the European Union.\n\n\u201cMacron is the candidate of those who still believe in Europe,\u201d said Christian Lequesne, a professor of European politics at the Paris Institute of Political Studies, or Sciences Po. \u201cBut his whole strategy is based on a new image at home, of a president able to reform this unreformable country, which will give him more leverage on the European level.\u201d\n\nFor now, the jury is out, but Mr. Macron is trying to influence a conversation on Europe\u2019s future that seems especially necessary as Britain prepares to leave the bloc and the United States appears to be disengaging. He is calling on his fellow leaders to engage in a public debate on these issues a year before elections for a new European Parliament.\n\nIt is vital, he said, \u201cto have a democratic, critical debate on what Europe is about.\u201d He has suggested deeper European integration, especially for those countries that use the euro, including an enhanced European budget.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut there is considerable resistance from other member states toward creating either a more tightly integrated Europe or a multitiered one that treats certain countries differently. And nationalism in Europe is on the rise, and not just in Central Europe, under pressure from migration, terrorism and globalization.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Mr. Macron spoke, the European Commission, the European Union\u2019s executive arm, was working with Poland to soften its planned overhaul of the judiciary and so avoid being punished with a reduction in the funds the country receives from the future European budget, which is being debated now.\n\nPoland\u2019s government has been sharply criticized for trying to exercise too much political control over the judiciary and limit its independence.\n\nAs Europe contemplates what to do after Brexit, the commission had good news on Tuesday for Albania and Macedonia, urging the beginning of formal accession talks to join the European Union.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCurrently only Serbia and Montenegro are in such talks, with membership not likely until at least 2025 or beyond. Talks on the matter have been proceeding slowly but are said to be making new progress.", "title": "Fight Over Values Risks a \u2018European Civil War,\u2019 Macron Says", "authors": ["Steven Erlanger"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "The results held even after controlling for income, so it doesn\u2019t seem as if buying time is merely an indicator of being wealthier, which may also increase satisfaction. In fact, the researchers found a stronger relationship between satisfaction and buying time among lower-income groups.\n\nBut just to be sure that buying time tends to cause greater life satisfaction, the researchers conducted a randomized experiment. Participants in the trial were given $40 on each of two consecutive weekends. On one of those weekends, they were randomly assigned to spend the money on something that would save them time (like going out to eat instead of cooking). On the other weekend, they could make only a material purchase that would not save time (like buying a new shirt).\n\n\u201cWhen people spent the $40 to save time, they reported being in a more positive mood and feeling less stressed,\u201d said Ashley Whillans, lead author of both the National Academy of Sciences study and the working paper about couples, and an assistant professor at Harvard Business School. \u201cBut it is important to note that even if spending a little to buy time increases well-being, spending a lot may not.\u201d\n\nIn other words, you can also overdo it. Ms. Whillans and colleagues found that spending $100 to $200 per month on timesaving services maximized satisfaction, but spending more started to reduce it.\n\nThis could be because outsourcing may cause you to feel as if you can\u2019t do anything yourself. Or perhaps it\u2019s because of the challenges of managing others. Or maybe when you buy so many services, you\u2019re bound to feel some aren\u2019t done well and regret having not saved the money.\n\nIn a finding from other work by Ms. Whillans, outsourcing unpleasant tasks may also cause some people to feel guilty, because they\u2019re transferring the unpleasantness to someone else.\n\nResearch on this topic may also be useful to companies. During the 2013-2014 academic year, Stanford University School of Medicine offered timesaving vouchers to doctors as rewards for certain types of work.", "title": "Fighting Over Chores? Spend Some Money, Save the Marriage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf the numbers are too low today, we may have to abandon the project,\u201d Pete Pattavina, a bat biologist for the federal government, told me as we drove to the site. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to justify the continued expense if we only have a few survivors.\u201d\n\nNot everyone thinks the efforts are worthwhile. The National Speleological Society, dismayed by the closing of caves on federal land in what it sees as a misguided effort to prevent the spread of white-nose syndrome, thinks the war has been lost, that the government efforts are putting bats at greater risk and that, in any event, the disease is going to run its course. This may be what happened in Europe, where bats appear have developed resistance to it.\n\nI don\u2019t agree. While targeted cures like the one being tested in Black Diamond would likely be impractical for most wild caves, they could potentially slow the leading edges of the disease. Kelly Lutsch, a first-year graduate student of Dr. Cornelison, has been surveying concrete culverts along Interstates 75 and 95 through Georgia\u2019s coastal plains. She believes that infected bats using the culverts could be carrying the pathogen south into cave-rich zones near the Florida panhandle. If so, spraying the culverts with B23 might be warranted. One Georgia cave near the Florida border hosts a robust colony of 90,000 southeastern myotis bats.\n\nAt the Black Diamond Tunnel, the results of the spraying were encouraging. After an hour, the team slowly paddled back to share its results: 178 bats, up by 26 from the last count.\n\nDr. Cornelison cautioned against interpreting this as a success for B23, since other factors could affect the count. Still, he declared himself \u201cecstatic\u201d that the number was higher, not lower, and plans to test B23 again in the tunnel.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think we will ever know the full ecological effect\u201d of white-nose syndrome, Mr. Pattavina said. \u201cWe only realize the value of biodiversity when catastrophe happens.\u201d\n\nBut for the moment, for one tiny group of survivors in a Georgia tunnel, there is a glimmer of hope amid the catastrophe.", "title": "Opinion | Fighting to Save America\u2019s Bats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "MARAWI, Philippines \u2014 As she approached her house for the first time since militants took over the neighborhood, evidence of a disaster unfolded around Haydee Dimalawang: \u201cISIS\u201d spray-painted on the door of the family\u2019s completely stripped car, walls gouged by bullets, a kitchen ripped in half by a mortar shell.\n\nShe felt lucky \u2014 relatively.\n\nAt least her house, in a central neighborhood of Marawi, was still standing. Her neighbor across the street, Alpata Utto, was left with an empty plot. His house had burned down early in the fighting, and weeds had sprouted from the ashes.\n\nIslamic State loyalists seized Marawi, a predominantly Muslim city of more than 200,000 people on the Philippine island of Mindanao, more than 10 months ago, leading to months of military siege and devastating American-assisted airstrikes.\n\nThe residents are finally being allowed to return, but only for a day or two per family to salvage what they can and then leave again.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat happens next will depend on how and when the city is rebuilt. And in a central example of how the political wind is shifting in the Philippines, the destruction enabled in part by American military assistance will be repaired by a Chinese-led consortium, officials say.", "title": "Filipinos Get a Glimpse of Their Ruined City. The Chinese Get the Contract.", "authors": ["Ben C. Solomon", "Felipe Villamor"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "BODA, Central African Republic \u2014 Nina Beina, a widowed mother of 11, couldn\u2019t wait to give me a tour of the land she had just bought. She beamed as she showed me the site where her children will build their homes.\n\nMs. Beina isn\u2019t a real estate mogul, and like most people here she has no access to banks or formal loans. But she was able to buy the property through a program arising from one of the hot ideas in the global fight against poverty \u2014 microsavings. With the help of Catholic Relief Services, an international humanitarian organization, Ms. Beina and her neighbors recently started their own savings group.\n\nThe idea is that villagers gather regularly and deposit tiny sums \u2014 often less than a dollar \u2014 into a pool, which is then lent to a member of the group. The loan is paid back over time, and it is often used to help people start small businesses. For Ms. Beina, the new land for her children will give her more space in her already overcrowded home.\n\nFor vulnerable populations, especially women, \u201cit empowers them to save,\u201d said Laura Dills, who oversees a range of Catholic Relief Services\u2019 programming, including the organization\u2019s microfinance efforts. \u201cWe\u2019re actually building that capacity to go after loans in a very safe setting that\u2019s not going to risk any of their assets.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Finance Isn\u2019t Just for Fat Cats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Nuveen, sponsor of the Nushares E.S.G. Emerging Markets Equity E.T.F., constructs its index differently, but it, too, aims to cut the number of air polluters in the portfolio by favoring companies with lower carbon-dioxide emissions. \u201cE.S.G. investors expect low carbon, and standard E.S.G. screens won\u2019t necessarily give you that,\u201d said Martin Y. G. Kremenstein, head exchange-traded funds for Nuveen.\n\nOver the last five years, emerging markets have chugged upward, with MSCI\u2019s conventional index gaining an annualized average of 4.99 percent. In the first quarter, the index gained 1.42 percent. MSCI\u2019s Emerging Markets E.S.G. Leaders Index has outpaced its peer \u2014 rising an annualized average of 8.6 percent over the last five years, though only 1.01 percent in the first quarter.\n\nWhen Mr. Varco, of Cambridge Associates, did his study, he didn\u2019t dig into precisely why companies in the E.S.G. index might excel or, conversely, why ones in the conventional index might lag. But he said one reason might be that state-owned enterprises, like Brazil\u2019s Petrobras, where a prominent bribery scandal has implicated dozens of government officials, loom large in the standard index. These outfits are often not run as well as their nonstate kin, he said.\n\nManagers of actively managed funds echoed his assessment.\n\n\u201cThe MSCI index includes a lot of energy\u201d state-owned enterprises, said Elena Tedesco, a portfolio manager of the Calvert Emerging Markets Equity Fund. \u201cThose companies tend to have very poor governance \u2014 they allocate capital to fulfill political goals. The Russian gas companies, for example, don\u2019t have a strong reputation for creating value for shareholders. They\u2019d rather build a pipeline to fulfill a political need.\u201d Gazprom, the giant Russian natural-gas producer, is majority state-owned and a part of the standard index.\n\nLeon Eidelman, the lead manager of the JPMorgan Emerging Markets Equity Fund, is even more broadly skeptical of state-owned companies and their aims.\n\n\u201cThe Chinese state doesn\u2019t work for you,\u201d he said. \u201cIt works for itself. Its goals and incentives aren\u2019t aligned with those of minority shareholders.\u201d Two Chinese state-owned enterprises \u2014 China Mobile and China Construction Bank \u2014 are among the top 10 constituents of the standard index.\n\nPut differently, the problem with state-run companies, besides potential political agendas, is governance. They don\u2019t have procedures in place, as developed-world public companies typically do, to ensure that minority investors are treated fairly and have access to all the information they need about company operations, investments and finances.", "title": "Finding Emerging Markets Stocks With Social Consciences", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Among the professionals she recommends is her husband, who happens to be a general contractor. Mr. Lavertue and Ms. Simms hired him to do renovation work and a lawn care company to plow their driveway.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was through word of mouth that Justin Brent got his start. Mr. Brent is based in Pound Ridge, in Westchester County, and has worked in the town\u2019s maintenance department for more than two decades. He is also chief of the local fire department. And he is the proprietor of Pound Ridge Home Management LLC, which he runs with his wife, overseeing more than a dozen second homes in the area.\n\n\u201cI started out doing some landscaping, and word spread from there,\u201d said Mr. Brent, who checks on his customers\u2019 homes once a week, conducting a 21-point inspection, from the mailbox to the basement, for a fee of $55 an hour. The company also provides ancillary services, or will find third parties to do so, from power-washing furniture to changing light bulbs and fixing HVAC and plumbing systems.\n\n\u201cThese are weekenders, so if they come up on a Friday night and the heat is broken,\u201d he said, \u201cit is an emergency and they have to call the heating company to come.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Brent said he addresses any problems that arise during the week, \u201cso that when they come up, they only have to turn the key in the door and turn on the lights and enjoy themselves.\u201d\n\nMary Trier has a similar company on the North Fork of Long Island. Her job, particularly during the fall and winter months, centers on coastal erosion and protecting homes from storm damage. \u201cI thrive on the bad weather,\u201d she said. \u201cI am fixated with the weather report.\u201d\n\nMs. Trier provides a range of services, from securing beachside steps to critter control, and charges a monthly retainer of $120 to $125, which includes weekly property checks. For anything more, she charges an hourly fee of $25 to $30.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI started out with just a few houses and that stayed constant for a while,\u201d she said. \u201cBut recently business has exploded.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor a long time, the North Fork was somewhat sleepy,\u201d said Sheri Winter Clarry, an associate broker at Corcoran in the North Fork, who often refers clients to Ms. Trier. \u201cThere was always a summer market, but more people are now coming for the weekends year round, and demand for services like Mary\u2019s has grown.\u201d\n\nFor those who want to supplement services like Mr. Brent\u2019s or Ms. Trier\u2019s with smart home systems, there are a number of options, from traditional firms like ADT to relative newcomers like Nest.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNest, which is owned by Google, makes products that feature modern, sleek designs but are relatively costly. The Nest Secure system starts at about $500, with the option to buy additional products like Nest Hello, a $229 video doorbell, or Nest x Yale lock, a $279 key-free deadbolt operated with a passcode.\n\n\u201cThe system provides peace of mind,\u201d said Maxime Veron, director of product strategy at Nest, adding that the majority of the company\u2019s customers install the systems themselves.\n\nWhile Nest is largely a la carte, many companies offer comprehensive options, including services like ADT Pulse or SimpliSafe. These systems have a lower upfront cost and offer 24/7 monitoring, although they can also come with lengthy, multiyear contracts and expensive termination fees.\n\nWirecutter, a product review and recommendation site owned by The New York Times, gave SimpliSafe its top score, citing the round-the-clock monitoring and the fact it does not require long-term contracts. PCMag.com also recommended SimpliSafe, giving it four out of five stars, as well as vivint.SmartHome, which it gave four and a half stars. PCMag.com awarded Nest Secure just three stars, citing the high cost and limited voice commands.\n\nOf course, some homeowners can\u2019t be bothered to deal with installing smart home security systems, or face having to work with management companies. They prefer to have someone on site at all times. That was one reason Joanne Intrieri recently decided to buy a home at the Four Seasons Private Residences Fort Lauderdale.\n\nMs. Intrieri and her husband, who are based in New York City, already own property in Arizona and Pennsylvania. \u201cWe know what it\u2019s like to have sandstorms and snowstorms, and have to find people to fix things when you aren\u2019t there,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the Four Seasons project, owners will have all the conveniences of a hotel, as well as on-site managers to cater to most needs. \u201cHaving been there and done that,\u201d she said, \u201cI don\u2019t want to have to lift a finger.\u201d", "title": "Finding Peace of Mind for Your Home Away From Home", "authors": ["Julie Satow"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "One evening last fall, Ms. Park took her to see two relatively spacious top-floor one-bedrooms in the East 70s, each for $2,150. One faced Third Avenue.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI could hear the traffic come and go,\u201d Ms. Yang said. \u201cEven at 6 or 7 p.m., the avenue is very busy.\u201d\n\nAnd the kitchen was a collection of appliances against a wall. The apartment felt outdated \u2014 but not as outdated as the second unit they saw, which faced away from the avenue.\n\nThe next day was tightly scheduled. A one-bedroom for $2,000, also in the East 70s, was nicely renovated. But while the pictures made it look spacious, the bedroom was tiny and the hallway narrow.\n\nMs. Yang and Ms. Park moved on to the East 80s, where the saw a building with two one-bedrooms available, on the top floor and the ground floor; the rents were $2,150 and $2,300, respectively.\n\nMs. Yang fell for the sunny top-floor apartment, with its open kitchen. But the listing agent, en route, informed them by text that it had been rented earlier that morning.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe ground-floor unit wasn\u2019t ideal. \u201cThe layout was like a train, long and skinny,\u201d Ms. Yang said. I didn\u2019t want to live on the ground floor in an apartment close to the door.\u201d In her previous doorman buildings, the door was always open and attended.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut she was encouraged.
