Still, even if a place was otherwise fine, there was often one dealbreaker: a noisy street, a dingy bathroom, a tiny bedroom.\n\nPhoto\n\nNearby, another top-floor apartment was available for $2,100. Up they climbed.\n\nThis one was still occupied. It had two windows looking out onto the street, a separate eat-in kitchen and a quiet bedroom facing the back. And Ms. Yang was excited to learn that the outgoing tenant was eager to sell some furniture.\n\n\u201cUsually, a $2,100 apartment doesn\u2019t look this finished,\u201d Ms. Park said. \u201cWe took action right away.\u201d Ms. Yang left a deposit on the spot.\n\nTwo more places were still on the schedule, but one was on busy East 72nd Street and the other, on Second Avenue near her old neighborhood, was dimly lit.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt was obvious what was the best out of all of them,\u201d Ms. Park said. \u201cThe space was right, the location was right, and the furniture really helped.\u201d\n\nMs. Yang paid a broker\u2019s fee of 15 percent of a year\u2019s rent, or almost $3,800, and arrived last winter.\n\nFor $550, she bought from the departing tenant the sofa \u2014 just a year old and originally from Ikea \u2014 as well as a large wardrobe against a living-room wall.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMost people want a no-fee apartment, but she was willing to see all the options to find the best one for her, because she is planning to live there for a long time,\u201d Ms. Park said.\n\nMs. Yang ordered some additional furniture and \u201ca lot of cooking utilities, because I cook almost every day,\u201d she said.\n\nHer only disappointment is the uneven floor, which slopes so much her kitchen table tilts. \u201cWhen you walk, you can feel the floor is not even,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen I am eating dinner, I feel my food is falling.\u201d\n\nEverything else, however, is to her liking. \u201cI am very happy for this small place,\u201d she said.", "title": "Finding a Place (and a Decent Kitchen) to Call Her Own", "authors": ["Joyce Cohen", "The Hunt"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The demise of the project in Finland does not signal an end of interest in the idea. Other trials are underway or being explored in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Canadian province of Ontario, the Netherlands and Kenya.\n\nIn much of the world, the concept of basic income retains appeal as a potential way to more justly spread the bounty of global capitalism while cushioning workers against the threat of robots and artificial intelligence taking their jobs.\n\nBut the Finnish government\u2019s decision to halt the experiment at the end of 2018 highlights a challenge to basic income\u2019s very conception. Many people in Finland \u2014 and in other lands \u2014 chafe at the idea of handing out cash without requiring that people work.\n\n\u201cThere is a problem with young people lacking secondary education, and reports of those guys not seeking work,\u201d said Heikki Hiilamo, a professor of social policy at the University of Helsinki. \u201cThere is a fear that with basic income they would just stay at home and play computer games.\u201d\n\nFor centuries, thinkers across the ideological spectrum have embraced the notion of basic income. It has gained favor with the social philosopher Thomas More, the laissez faire economist Milton Friedman and the civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., an unusual diversity of support that has enhanced the appeal of the idea as a modern-day solution to economic anxiety in much of the world.\n\nSilicon Valley technologists have suggested that basic income could enable humanity to exploit the labor-saving promise of robots absent the fear of mass joblessness.\n\nPhoto\n\nLabor advocates have focused on basic income as a means of increasing bargaining power among workers, limiting the pressure for people to accept poverty wages at dead-end jobs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther people have advanced basic income as a way of enabling parents to spend more time with their children.\n\nFinland\u2019s goals have been modest and pragmatic. The government hoped that basic income would send more people into the job market to revive a weak economy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnder Finland\u2019s traditional unemployment program, those lacking jobs are effectively discouraged from accepting temporary positions or starting businesses, because extra income risks the loss of their benefits.\n\nThe basic income trial, which started at the beginning of 2017 and will continue until the end of this year, has given monthly stipends of 560 euros ($685) to a random sample of 2,000 unemployed people aged 25 to 58. Recipients have been free to do as they wished \u2014 create start-ups, pursue alternate jobs, take classes \u2014 secure in the knowledge that the stipends would continue regardless.\n\nThe Finnish government was keen to see what people would do under such circumstances. The data is expected to be released next year, giving academics a chance to analyze what has come of the experiment.\n\nIn the meantime, Finland has already moved on to consider a broader revamping of its social service programs. It is studying a new form of social welfare policy now in effect in Britain: so-called universal credit, which rolls existing government aid programs into one monthly lump sum payment.\n\n\u201cThe social security system is fragmented and has a lot of bureaucracy,\u201d said Liisa Heinamaki,who is overseeing a project exploring ways to reorganize that system. \u201cDiscussion about basic income is not over, but it is a part of the larger discussion now.\u201d\n\nIn Britain, the shift to universal credit has poor people reeling, depriving many of them of government support while their cases shift from the old system. Benefits have increased for some people, but many recipients have wound up with less.\n\nIn Finland, where the social safety net is famously generous, a structure like Britain\u2019s could yield the very thing basic income is supposed to deliver: a guarantee that every member of society can be assured of sustenance and shelter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis may be the main reason that basic income has lost momentum in Finland: It is effectively redundant.\n\nHealth care is furnished by the state. University education is free. Jobless people draw generous unemployment benefits and have access to some of the most effective training programs on earth.\n\n\u201cIn a sense,\u201d said Mr. Hiilamo, the social policy professor, \u201cFinland already has basic income.\u201d", "title": "Finland Has Second Thoughts About Giving Free Money to Jobless People", "authors": ["Peter S. Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "She said she went outside after her grandson ran into her room and alerted her to the fire.\n\nShe screamed, fearful that the neighbors she knew so well were in peril, and that the blaze might spread to her own home. She said she held the wife of Ranjit Kainth, the owner of the house, who cried in her arms before being taken to the hospital for difficulty breathing. \u201cShe kept saying, \u2018Paaji\u2019 and \u2018Biji\u2019 are gone,\u201d Ms. Ramnauth said.\n\nMr. Kainth\u2019s parents, who perished in the fire, were known by the Punjabi nicknames, meaning \u201cfather\u201d and \u201cmother,\u201d Ms. Ramnauth said. Neighbors said they were familiar faces who waved hello to everyone they passed on their daily morning walks.\n\nShe said Mr. Kainth\u2019s son jumped from the attic window to escape the flames, and was in significant pain when firefighters brought him out on a stretcher. Ms. Kaur was his sister, she said.\n\nOnlookers described the tree-lined residential block as a tight-knit community, where neighbors help raise each other\u2019s children, and first-name basis is standard. The block\u2019s older women were all \u201caunties\u201d and older men were \u201cuncle.\u201d\n\nBabzy Sukhdeo, 77, held Ms. Ramnauth as the two cried together later Sunday.\n\nMs. Sukhdeo, a neighbor of 30 years who lived around the corner, said the Kainth family had a house full of relatives during the weekend, like they usually did.\n\nTheir other daughter, who lives in North Carolina, was planning a summer wedding at a Hindu temple in Queens, Ms. Sukhdeo said. During the festivities, she said she had offered to house two or three of the Kainth\u2019s relatives. \u201cWe always helped each other out like that,\u201d she said, recalling how she would leave her keys with the Kainths when she visited her son in Florida, so they could feed her cat.\n\nAnother longtime resident, Phillip Dhanpaul, 56, said his neighbors watch over his house when he travels to Guyana. \u201cWe all look out for each other here,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re all good neighbors.\u201d\n\nMs. Ramnauth, who has lived on the block for 32 years, waved her hand at the surrounding homes, and shook her head. \u201cIt\u2019s so sad to lose someone in this neighborhood,\u201d she said. \u201cThis block will never be the same.\u201d", "title": "Fire Kills 3 in Close-Knit Queens Village Community", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 A fire that tore through a karaoke bar in southern China in the early hours of Tuesday killed 18 people, the police said, and a man was arrested on suspicion of arson hours later.\n\nA brief initial police account of the blaze in Qingyuan, a city in Guangdong Province, said firefighters received an emergency call about 30 minutes past midnight.\n\nBy the time they extinguished the fire about 25 minutes later, the karaoke bar was gutted. Miguel \u00c1ngel Yunes of Veracruz said a seventh person had died, but it was unclear whether that person was an inmate or a prison guard.\n\nMr. Yunes said four \u201chighly dangerous\u201d inmates had been helping run criminal networks in the area around La Toma prison in the town of Amatl\u00e1n de los Reyes, so officials had decided to transfer them to a maximum-security federal prison.\n\nThe governor did not name the criminal gang involved, but the area was long dominated by the Zetas cartel.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen local police officers, in support of the state police, entered the prison to get the four inmates for transfer, they were apparently ambushed by prisoners, who blocked their escape and lit a fire that suffocated six officers, the governor said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe six police officers were attacked and were enclosed in an area with no exit,\u201d Mr. Yunes said. \u201cThe inmates started a fire, and with the smoke, they caused the asphyxiation and death of the six police officers.\u201d", "title": "Fire in Mexican Prison Kills at Least 6 Police Officers", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Speaker Paul D. Ryan\u2019s abrupt decision to dismiss the House chaplain triggered an uproar on Friday over religion, pitting Republican against Republican and offering Democrats a political opportunity in a year already moving their way.\n\nMr. Ryan moved quietly two weeks ago to remove the chaplain, the Rev. Patrick J. Conroy \u2014 so quietly that some lawmakers assumed the Catholic priest was retiring. But in an interview on Thursday with The New York Times, Father Conroy said he was blindsided when Mr. Ryan asked him to resign, and suggested politics \u2014 specifically a prayer he gave in November when Congress was debating a tax overhaul \u2014 may have been a factor in the speaker\u2019s decision.\n\nFather Conroy prayed then for lawmakers to \u201cguarantee that there are not winners and losers under new tax laws, but benefits balanced and shared by all Americans.\u201d Shortly after, he said, he was admonished by Mr. Ryan of Wisconsin, who is also a Roman Catholic.\n\n\u201cPadre, you just got to stay out of politics,\u201d he recalled the speaker saying.\n\nAs reports of the dismissal circulated in the Capitol, some Republicans, in a closed-door meeting on Friday morning, demanded an explanation from Mr. Ryan, while Democrats commandeered the House floor in a boisterous, if unsuccessful, attempt to force the House to investigate Mr. Ryan\u2019s decision.", "title": "Firing of House Chaplain Causes Uproar on Capitol Hill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "With family, teammates and friends in attendance, Donato played his first game with the Bruins, at home against the Columbus Blue Jackets, on March 19, having signed a two-year, entry-level contract the night before. He scored on a blistering one-timer in the second period and finished with 3 points in Boston\u2019s 5-4 overtime loss.\n\nHis father, Ted, the hockey coach at Harvard since 2004, described the night as \u201ckind of surreal.\u201d\n\nThe next day, while his new teammates were practicing in St. Louis, Donato attended classes in Cambridge and met with his professors to work out the logistics for him to complete the semester. He later flew to meet up with the Bruins for the start of a four-game trip.\n\nSince then, Donato, 22, has been living in two worlds, with two residences: a hotel near TD Garden arranged by the Bruins and a four-person room at Winthrop House, his Harvard home for the last two years.\n\n\u201cI just want to be ready for the games, so if it\u2019s close to a game, I\u2019m staying at the hotel so I\u2019ll stay focused,\u201d he said, \u201cand maybe if we get back from a road trip at 3 a.m., I get a ride from one of the guys and get dropped off at the dorm.\u201d\n\nBrian Gionta, Donato\u2019s teammate on the Bruins and on the United States team at the Pyeongchang Olympics in February, played for four years at Boston College, winning a national title in 2001, before embarking on a long N.H.L. career.", "title": "First, Final Exams. Then, Perhaps, the Stanley Cup Finals.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Cultural trends seem to pop up early on the social media site. It\u2019s where I first noticed the popularity of Los Angeles\u2019s Zoe Church, which I recently wrote about, and where Sam Barsky, better known online as \u201cthe sweater guy,\u201d gained Internet fame. (I wrote about him, too.)\n\nSo I decided to explore.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome photographers shared secret fishing holes. Others tagged anglers with whom they seemed to have struck up friendships. The rest, well, bragged about their latest catch.\n\nThe genre had all the hallmarks of a mature social media phenomenon. A lot of people were promoting brands. So much so, one Twitter commenter asked if the fishing industry now had \u201cinfluencers.\u201d Noelle Coley of Colorado said she worked with a number of companies, receiving free fishing equipment or apparel in exchange for social media mentions. (Some outlets, like Orvis, a maker of fly fishing equipment, are seeking to increase the number of women in the sport. That\u2019s no surprise, given that recreational fishing is on the rise in the United States and women are an untapped market.)\n\nWhat was most striking, though, were the photographs themselves, which were colorful, immediate and engaging. I reached out to a number of the featured men and women from across the country and asked them to tell me their back stories.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile much of America is divided between red and blue states, these anglers recounted experiences that transcend geography and politics. They said they had friends on both coasts, as well as in the middle of the country.\n\nCould fishing be the great uniter? That would be no small feat these days, when everything seems politicized.\n\nThey even wanted to take me fishing. But that\u2019s another story. (A brother once chided me for catching a trout smaller than the purse I owned.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost of all, though, these fishing enthusiasts were eager to describe how social media helped them document their pastime so they could share it with others.\n\nOf course the smartphone itself has revolutionized the way they capture their adventures. Long gone are the days of posing afterward on the dock with a colossal prize, like Ernest Hemingway did when he lived in Key West in the 1930s. As Daniel Giunta, the owner of the sports fishing charter company Double D Charters in Montauk, N.Y., told me, customers want photographs with their catch fresh out of the water \u2014 especially since many people choose to release the fish.\n\n\u201cBeing a captain these days is all about being a good photographer,\u201d he said. \u201cI know where the light is. I know where they need to stand.\u201d\n\nSmartphones have also revolutionized how journalists interact with their sources and build an audience for their work. I posted a screenshot of the article I wrote, \u201cLots of Fish on the Screen,\u201d on my own Instagram account, with some of the more popular hashtags the fishing crowd uses. Right away a number of fishing accounts liked it or posted comments. I got an email from the wife of a fisherman I know in Santa Cruz, Calif. More emails like that followed. One of the men I interviewed posted an excerpt from the story on his Instagram account. Another one told his followers to read it.\n\nI even heard from Fishbrain, an app maker based in Stockholm, Sweden, which bills itself as the Facebook of fishing. People can log in to the app and see where fish are biting. Since 2016, the company said, more than 1,000 people have fished in the ponds in New York City\u2019s Central Park, including Harlem Meer. Followers on Instagram already knew that; centralparkfishing has its own hashtag.", "title": "Fishing for Stories via Instagram", "authors": ["Laura M. Holson"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "For decades, Gary Fritz lived in his family\u2019s house in what is now known as Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, though to him it will forever be Flatbush.\n\nWhen Mr. Fritz\u2019s mother died last fall, the developer who had bought and flipped the vacant house next door expressed interest in the Fritz house, and made the family an offer. Mr. Fritz and his sister agreed to sell the house for around $600,000.\n\nWith his portion of the proceeds, Mr. Fritz, a percussionist and D.J., hoped to rent a new home with enough space for his music gear and decades of family furniture, heirlooms and antiques.\n\nThe prospect was overwhelming to Mr. Fritz, 61, who also does music production and is known as Wicked Gary Fritz. Three years ago, his daughter died in a bus accident in Panama while she was on vacation. \u201cBetween my daughter passing and my mom passing, I was accumulating all the family stuff,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen it came time to move, I was like, \u2018What am I going to do with all this?\u2019\u201d", "title": "Fitting the Contents of a Family Home Into a Rental", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 The Getty Bronze, a Greek statue of a beautiful male athlete with enviable hair that is easily the most celebrated artwork at the Getty Villa, has not been knocked off his pedestal. But he does get a remarkably different treatment \u2014 less fanboy, more scholarly \u2014 after the extensive, yearlong renovation and reinstallation of the Getty Villa near Malibu, the branch of the Getty Museum dedicated to antiquities that is the former estate of the billionaire oilman J. Paul Getty.\n\nBefore the renovation, which was done in stages and marks its completion on April 18, this victorious athlete with a dramatic deep-sea discovery story that has inspired legal claims from the Italian government, was something of a diva looming over a small room of his own. Now he\u2019s part of a new large gallery devoted to the Hellenistic world, dating from the death of Alexander the Great in 323 B.C. to the rise of the Roman Empire in 31 B.C. (And the new pedestal is noticeably slimmer.)\n\n\u201cWhen you walk into this space, you realize what a wonderful collection of Hellenistic art we have \u2014 before, this work was spread out over 10 galleries,\u201d said Timothy Potts, the Getty Museum\u2019s director, who arrived in 2012 with an expertise in antiquities and with strong ideas for improving the Villa\u2019s academic credentials.\n\nOne driving force behind the renovation was to put artworks into proper historical context. Mr. Potts and his team have rearranged works in the permanent collection galleries to tell a more chronological story, from 3000 B.C. to 400 A.D., largely presenting Greek works on the first floor and Roman on the second. Gone are the entertaining themes like \u201cgods and goddesses\u201d that mixed figures from different periods in a pantheon of superheroes.", "title": "Five Must-See Artworks at the Renovated Getty Villa", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "If Bangkok\u2019s Ari neighborhood could write its own autobiography, it might be called \u201cFrom Bureaucrats to Baristas.\u201d For decades, the low-lying leafy district was known mainly for its federal ministries, municipal administration offices and gated quasi-suburban homes. Increasingly, however, Ari is a thicket of sleek high-rise buildings and indie cool-kid hangouts with international flavors: German beer gardens, Latin American restaurants, Korean canteens, Japanese izakayas, American-style food trucks and numerous freshly minted cafes stocked with Italian espresso makers. All that\u2019s missing is the crowds. Even on weekends, Ari\u2019s hot spots have free seats and ample breathing room \u2014 a rarity in bustling Bangkok.\n\nPaper Butter and the Burger\n\nWith its outdoor seating, picnic tables, rock \u2019n\u2019 roll music and constant smoke from grilling meats, this beer-and-burgers haven feels more like a backyard barbecue than a restaurant. Created by the Thai-British cook Patrick Stall \u2014 who studied hospitality management in Perth, Australia \u2014 and his Thai girlfriend, Parichart Payungwong, the laid-back hangout serves everything from Japanese-style chicken wings in ginger-garlic sauce to the signature Chiang Mai Spicy burger, a patty of shredded pork with Cheddar cheese and Thai herbs. If such combinations sound like a recipe for indigestion, request the house-made black hamburger buns. The color comes from activated charcoal \u2014 a digestive aid.\n\n51 Phahonyothin Soi 5, facebook.com/PaperButter.", "title": "Five Places to Go in Bangkok", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "A new spirit infuses a once-neglected Louisville neighborhood about five miles from Churchill Downs, home to the annual Kentucky Derby, this year on May 5 . The New Louisville district (NuLu for short) is a five-block stretch of East Market Street, just past the Interstate 65 Overpass. Lined with eclectic Victorian-era buildings, the upbeat district is buzzing lately with cool eateries, shops and thriving local businesses. Two new additions are bolstering NuLu\u2019s renaissance, just in time for Derby season. With its launch on May 5, Rabbit Hole Distilling, the latest in Louisville\u2019s urban distillery revival, joins dozens of establishments along the city\u2019s Urban Bourbon Trail bar and restaurant circuit, and the 152-room AC Hotel by Marriott is set to open May 2. ZeroBuses \u2014 free, all-electric public transit buses \u2014 and LouVelo shareable bikes connect the lively zone to Louisville\u2019s downtown core less than two miles away.\n\nFeast BBQ\n\nOn weekdays, this former truck repair shop serves as a meeting place for local entrepreneurs and construction workers who gather around picnic tables to nosh on hearty Southern comfort food elevated by locally sourced ingredients. Offerings at the three-year-old hot spot include juicy pulled pork cakes, creamy hand-cut slaw, tater tots and spicy collard greens drizzled with sweet Kentucky sorghum. On weekends, the quick service joint draws a long line of fans from across the city, thirsty for a Country Boy Brewing Cougar Bait ale, one of many local brews on tap, or a bourbon slushy.\n\n909 East Market Street; feastbbq.com", "title": "Five Places to Go in Louisville", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Culture lovers don\u2019t always think of cruising when planning a vacation, according to Doug Prothero, the managing director of The Ritz-Carlton Yacht Collection. \u201cCruises are stereotyped as getaways with lots of eating and drinking and little culture in sight,\u201d he said. While that may be true for some cruises, Mr. Prothero said it\u2019s not the case all-around, and shared some tips to enjoy an enlightening cultural experience by boat.\n\nPick Itineraries with Longer Stays at Ports\n\nMost cruise ships stop at a port in the morning and depart by late afternoon, but several cruise lines have itineraries where boats spend multiple days at a port, offering cruise-goers the opportunity to spend more time in port and to plan day-trips and other longer activities. They give travelers extra time to explore the destination and seek out its culture, whether it\u2019s the local museums, bars and restaurants or other public spaces.\n\nCruise on a Smaller Ship\n\nSmaller boats and river cruises can often access ports that bigger cruise ships cannot, which allows them to visit more unusual and off-the-beaten path landmarks, Mr. Prothero said. These intimately sized ships also give guests the opportunity to create bespoke, culture-focused itineraries, and many don\u2019t skimp on sleeping quarters or other onboard luxuries just because they\u2019re smaller. \u201cGenerally, the bigger the boat, the less flexibility you have in making your trip all about culture because big ships have to manage the needs of many more passengers,\u201d Mr. Prothero said.\n\nLook to Local Educational and Cultural Institutions\n\nAcademic and cultural centers often host their own cruises that offer itineraries brimming with cultural activities. Many include onboard lectures and seminars from professors and historians about the destinations you\u2019ll visit, and walking tours at ports when you arrive.", "title": "Five Ways to Get Some Culture on Your Next Cruise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "But an anti-immigration outfit called Save Jobs USA sued the Obama administration, claiming that work authorization for H-1B spouses meant that the United States would end up \u201cimporting\u201d two foreign workers for every one. Instead of defending the regulation in court, the Trump administration has decided, come June, to scrap it to advance its \u201cBuy American, Hire American\u201d agenda. Although there is nothing official yet, once the regulatory process is completed, the government may stop handing out new authorizations or renewing existing ones when they expire.\n\nRestrictionists assume a zero-sum math for workers: A job gain for a foreigner is a job loss for an American. By that logic every college graduate who enters the job market would be cause for mourning. But that\u2019s backward, given that skilled individuals create, not take away, jobs, and no economy succeeds by shackling qualified people.\n\nThese women are qualified because educated people tend to marry other educated people. The majority of H-4 women have college degrees, according to a 2014 survey by the blogger Rashi Bhatnagar, herself an H-4 visa holder. They also happen to be between the ages of 26 and 35 \u2014 peak productive years. It would be far better for the economy to accommodate their ambitions and turn them into productive, taxpaying individuals.\n\nNot letting them do so is a personal tragedy for them. But it also turns the restrictionist worry that immigrants today prefer to live transnational lives rather than assimilate into a self-fulfilling prophecy. A job is not just income. It is also an assimilation program because it offers an entry into a new culture and a chance to form new friendships.\n\nBecause getting a green card took only a few years when I came, I, like many other spouses in my situation, used that time to obtain a graduate degree and build skills in preparation for entering the job market. However, what would be the point of investing that kind of time and effort in an advanced degree if there is so little certainty that it would actually offer a return one day? Many H-4 wives I know end up staying at home, Skyping with friends and family back home to escape the boredom and isolation of being confined to a \u201cgilded cage\u201d \u2014 their description of their life in America.\n\nI remember feeling an exhilarating world of opportunities open up before me when I got my green card. It is sad \u2014 and senseless \u2014 that President Trump is so determined to prevent others like me from experiencing the full promise of America and participating fully in American life.", "title": "Opinion | Fixing the \u2018Involuntary Housewife Visa\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "The trip was led by Bnei Zion, a Tel Aviv-based leadership academy for high school graduates waiting to be called for military service. But Channel 12 in Israel reported that many in the group, including some who were killed, were prospective participants in the program who were still in their final year of high school.\n\nAll together, about 25 young people had been hiking in the riverbed in a canyon with \u201cvery deep slopes,\u201d said Nadav Eylon, chief security officer for the Central Arava Regional Council, which oversees an area south of the Dead Sea.\n\nEran Doron, head of the nearby Ramat Negev Regional Council, described the site as \u201ca canyon where the moment a flash flood comes, there is no way out.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere are walls of rock between four to 20 meters high on the sides of the canyon,\u201d Mr. Doron added.\n\nOfficials said survivors reported that they heard the sound of rushing water only about a minute before being hit by the flash flood.\n\nA police spokeswoman, Merav Lapidot, suggested that the youth group had disregarded police warnings, telling the Mako news site that, \u201cto our regret, these incidents take place when orders are not followed.\u201d She said the police had posted roadblocks in many areas warning of danger but could not be expected to close off every river in the country.\n\nMr. Eylon, speaking to the Ynet news site later, described the search and rescue effort. \u201cWe began combing the area and slowly found members of the group,\u201d he said. \u201cSome were wounded, some healthy and some in more serious condition. We found them in little groups, pairs and on their own. This is a complicated, grooved riverbed.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, in a statement, called the calamity a \u201cgrave disaster,\u201d adding, \u201cWe all pray for better news.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe hike was meant to be a three-day bonding experience for the participants, officials said.\n\nAn Israeli lawmaker, Yehudah Glick, said he had visited Bnei Zion\u2019s offices and found its staff members, and other teenage participants who had not been on the trip to Wadi Tzafit, in tears and in shock.\n\n\u201cEverybody\u2019s trying to collect crumbs of information that are coming in from all over, and mostly they\u2019re trying to collect themselves and put themselves together, and really try to keep themselves in one piece, because they\u2019re broken \u2014 they\u2019re very, very much broken,\u201d Mr. Glick said. \u201cThese are students that spent the last eight months together, almost 24 hours a day, and they\u2019re close friends.\u201d\n\nMr. Glick said the academy existed to let Israeli teenagers postpone their military service by a year and spend that time studying Israeli history, Zionism and other topics to make their army service more meaningful.\n\n\u201cMost are nonreligious, but they\u2019re very much active in social issues, trying to help people who are suffering, and really involved on the most emotional level with Israeli society,\u201d he said.\n\nThe police promised a full investigation, but early indications suggested that the academy and its outings fell into a regulatory vacuum, with neither the Education Ministry nor the Defense Ministry providing much supervision.\n\nFlash floods in the Israeli desert can come with staggering force. After a heavy rainstorm in May 2001, flooding in Nahal Arugot, near Ein Gedi on the edge of the Dead Sea, destroyed a modern highway bridge that had been designed to withstand such weather and filled a canyon with stone and alluvium in quantities officials said had not been seen in 40 years.\n\nThursday was the second day of a storm that, in the usually arid south, flooded riverbeds with sudden, lethal effect. On Wednesday, two people were killed: An 18-year-old Palestinian shepherd was found near Ma\u2019ale Amos, an Israeli settlement on the West Bank, a few miles from where he had disappeared, and a 17-year-old Bedouin was swept away in Wadi Mamshit, near Dimona.\n\nIn some places, Kan TV reported, the rainfall on Wednesday and Thursday alone totaled about a third of what is normal in a year.\n\nAcross the country, the weather seemed to keep trying to outdo itself, with hail the size of grapes and golf balls falling from Jerusalem to Mitzpe Ramon in the south, streets flooding and dozens of stranded motorists needing rescue. In Rishon Lezion, south of Tel Aviv, an acoustic ceiling collapsed, flooding a shopping mall. And the airport in Israel\u2019s southernmost city, Eilat, had to be closed after torrential rain and hail left the runway covered with erosion.", "title": "Flash Flood Kills at Least 9 Israeli Teenagers on \u2018Bonding\u2019 Hike", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "The fight between Mr. Cuomo and Ms. Nixon has emerged as an early flash point in the battle to define the future of the Democratic Party in the age of President Trump: a contest between an accomplished and pragmatic governor who controls the classic machinery of Democratic politics, and an upstart challenger with little track record but white-hot rhetoric of unfiltered liberalism to rally the base.\n\nMs. Nixon counts legalizing marijuana, increasing taxes on multimillionaires, giving driver\u2019s licenses to those here illegally, and making New York a \u201csanctuary state\u201d among her early proposals.\n\nThe political maneuvers around the Working Families Party echoed a strategy used in 2014, when Mr. Cuomo was first seeking re-election, but encountered a primary challenge from Zephyr Teachout. The Working Families Party strongly considered Ms. Teachout before reluctantly backing Mr. Cuomo.\n\nThis time around, with Working Families leaders hinting of a Nixon endorsement, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s emissaries struck first. Some of the party\u2019s top members were summoned to a meeting with labor leaders on Friday at the Manhattan headquarters of the United Federation of Teachers.\n\nMichael Mulgrew, president of the teachers\u2019 union, said he urged the advocacy groups on Friday to have the Working Families Party remain neutral until after the Democratic primary.\n\nIf the group endorses Ms. Nixon and she loses the Democratic primary to Mr. Cuomo, she could remain on the ballot through November competing for votes, potentially to the benefit of the Republican nominee.\n\n\u201cMy only concern is some reckless behavior that will have an unintended consequence of us ending up with a Republican governor,\u201d Mr. Mulgrew said. \u201cWhen these elections are over, we will judge any decision we have to make off your behavior if you caused bad things to happen \u2014 even though it was not your intent you are responsible for them.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe declined to comment on whether Mr. Cuomo had asked him to defund community groups backing Ms. Nixon, saying he has \u201crequests on all sides.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not going to divulge personal conversations,\u201d he said.\n\nBut Bill Lipton, the state director of the Working Families Party, said that he had attended a meeting earlier this week in which the governor had said, \u201cIf unions or anyone give money to any of these groups, they can lose my number.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Lipton added that the groups in question \u2014 Citizen Action, New York Communities for Change and Make the Road Action \u2014 had been critical to efforts to raise minimum wage and criminal justice reform, among others.\n\n\u201cW.F.P. has always fought for the rights of unions and for all working families, and that will never change,\u201d he said. \u201cOur friends in labor are in a tight spot and we respect their decision.\u201d\n\nSome labor leaders disputed Mr. Lipton\u2019s account of the governor\u2019s comment, while Mr. Mulgrew called Mr. Lipton \u201cmisguided and delusional,\u201d likening him to a temperamental child.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe governor, a second-term Democrat facing re-election in the fall, has been aggressive in fending off Ms. Nixon\u2019s unexpectedly vigorous primary challenge, which was announced in mid-March, and has since garnered endorsements from a handful of liberal groups.\n\nThe most recent nod came early Friday, when Make the Road Action \u2014 a grass-roots immigrant rights group that receives ample funding from labor \u2014 said it would back Ms. Nixon because of \u201cher strong progressive platform and her commitment to passing and implementing the full protections and supports that our communities need and deserve.\u201d\n\nThe governor\u2019s campaign said that no member of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s administration was at the meeting on Friday, and characterized it as an internal dispute \u201cbetween its founding labor unions and their organizing groups.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe governor stands with organized labor and will follow their lead,\u201d said Abbey Fashouer, a campaign spokeswoman.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to two people in the meeting, the governor\u2019s funding threats went unspoken but still loomed large.\n\n\u201cYou have the largest labor unions in the room who also have been our biggest funders arguing Cynthia should not get the W.F.P. line, which is a pretty forceful argument coming from your biggest funders,\u201d said one participant, who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss the private meeting and for fear of angering Mr. Cuomo.\n\nAmong the labor leaders in attendance were leaders or representatives from Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union; the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union; Communications Workers of America District 1; and the United Federation of Teachers, which collectively provide hundreds of thousands of dollars to the community groups.\n\nH\u00e9ctor Figueroa, president of Local 32BJ, and Dennis Trainor, vice president of C.W.A. District 1, confirmed their unions\u2019 withdrawal from the Working Families Party, saying in a joint statement that they \u201cfundamentally believe that endorsing Governor Cuomo is the most effective way to put the interest of working families first.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe latest developments show that the current leadership of the W.F.P. disagrees with that approach, and we have been unable to convince them otherwise,\u201d they said, adding, \u201cWe are not attending tomorrow\u2019s state committee meeting and will be pulling out of the New York State Working Families Party.\u201d\n\nThe pressure in labor ranks comes as the W.F.P. is expected to meet in Albany on Saturday to consider endorsing Ms. Nixon, an educational advocate and actress who is making her first run for public office.\n\n\u201cThis shows Cuomo will do absolutely anything to win except become a progressive,\u201d said Rebecca Katz, a top adviser to Ms. Nixon.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, Mr. Cuomo had appeared at a rally with a variety of labor leaders to present himself as their champion, and they as his ardent supporters.\n\n\u201cIt is the union family,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said. \u201cWhen one of us is in trouble, we\u2019re all in trouble. It\u2019s solidarity. We stand together.\u201d", "title": "Flexing Their Support for Cuomo, Key Unions Leave Working Families Party", "authors": ["Shane Goldmacher", "Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nArmed with two rifles, a handgun and \u201cample ammunition,\u201d John Hubert Highnote left his home in northern Florida on April 19 \u201cwith the ability and apparent intent to kill people,\u201d Sheriff Bobby Schultz of Gilchrist County said on Friday.\n\nBut the sheriff said that no clear motive had been established as to why Mr. Highnote \u2014 a bearded, balding 59-year-old described by the few who knew him as a loner and a recluse \u2014 walked into a Chinese restaurant in nearby Trenton, Fla., that day, fatally shot two deputies who were having lunch, and then went out to his car and killed himself.\n\n\u201cTo date, no clear motive has been established,\u201d Sheriff Schultz said at an emotional news conference on Friday morning in which he praised the two deputies \u2014 Sgt. Noel Ramirez, 29, and Deputy Taylor Lindsey, 25 \u2014 and called Mr. Highnote a coward. The violence, the sheriff added, will \u201cnever be explained.\u201d\n\n\u201cI am only going to speak about this person one last time, then send him back into obscurity where he came from and, frankly, belongs,\u201d Sheriff Schultz said.\n\nPhoto\n\nNo member of Mr. Highnote\u2019s family has stepped forward yet, Brett Rhodenizer, a spokesman, said later in the news conference, adding, \u201cI think that speaks to who he was.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBefore driving to Trenton \u2014 where he ambushed and murdered the deputies in Ace China \u2014 Mr. Highnote had visited a former employer in Newberry, Fla., about 13 miles away, the sheriff said.", "title": "Florida Deputies\u2019 Killer: Armed to the Teeth, but Motive Remains a Mystery", "authors": ["Maya Salam"]}
